title: Another Actor Is Flying Solo
description: Everyone knows that actors -- moody and deep -- like to be left alone. But this is getting ridiculous.

title: U.S. Indicts 5 Miami Officers As Brutality Inquiry Grows
description: Four current and former officers of the Miami Police Department were indicted today on charges of beating a suspect, while a fifth was charged with lying to cover up his actions in a fatal shooting.

title: Bush Renews Push to Partly Privatize Social Security
description: Wading into what is expected to be a major battle of the 2002 midterm elections, President Bush today promoted his plan to let workers invest part of their Social Security money in the stock market.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony To Buy Aiwa
description: Sony will buy the shares of Aiwa that it does not already own and make the company a wholly owned subsidiary. Sony currently owns 61 percent of Aiwa, which makes low-end stereos and audiovisual equipment. With most of its production outside Japan, Aiwa's business boomed in the early 1990's, when the yen rose to record highs. In the years since, the company has fallen behind competitors who moved to China, where costs are cheaper.

title: 2 Clothing Retailers Post Gains
description: Limited Inc., the second-largest United States clothing retailer, and its majority-owned Intimate Brands Inc. said their fiscal fourth-quarter profits rose as the companies controlled inventories and expenses.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Case Is Dogged by Identity Of Other Officer at Scene
description: After nearly five years, thousands of hours in courtrooms and millions of dollars spent on investigation, a single figure has confounded the prosecution of the Abner Louima torture case: the second police officer in the bathroom of the 70th Precinct station house.

title: Hearings on Digital Movies and Piracy
description: Michael D. Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, told a sympathetic Senate Commerce Committee today that only the threat of government intervention would spur the technology industry to take the necessary steps to prevent illicit copying of digital movies.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Agreement Could Let Talks Resume
description: Talks on the country's political future could resume soon after the government and the two main rebel groups agreed yesterday to let political parties decide on their own representatives. The parties, which will influence the choice of the next president, are expected to draw up a new list of delegates over the weekend. The talks, scheduled to last 45 days, were suspended less than 24 hours after the opening ceremony on Monday because the rebel groups said the government had inserted stooges in the parties' delegations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAINOR, ELLEN VERONICA, NEE O'DONNELL
description: TRAINOR-Ellen Veronica, nee O'Donnell. On February 28, died peacefully in her sleep. Of Pompano Beach, FL. Born in Manhattan and resided in New York City and Hampton Bays, NY. Beloved wife of the late John J. Trainor, a Battalion Chief in the FDNY. Devoted mother of daughters Jane Ellen Gomes of Boynton Beach, FL., and Susan Mills of Delray Beach, FL. and son, John J. Trainor, Jr. of Glen Ridge, NJ. Adored grandmother of Matthew (Kim) and Alex Gomes; Brian Trainor; Leah and Samantha Mills. Much loved mother-in-law of Michael Gomes and Patricia Erhard Trainor. Dear sister of Anna Moloney. Her wit, style, sense of humor, determination, drive, compassion and unconditional love will be etched forever in the hearts of her family and friends. Wake and funeral services in Pompano Beach, FL. Reposing at Forest Lawn, 200 West Copans Road, Pompano Beach, FL. 33064, (954-784-4000). Mass on Monday, March 4 at 11:00AM at St. Gabriel's RC Church in Pompano Beach.

title: Amy Cutler
description: Leslie Tonkonow

title: Longtime Hospital Union Leader Is Losing After Early Vote Count
description: A preliminary vote count yesterday showed that James Butler, the president of the union representing 7,500 workers at New York City's public hospitals, appeared headed to defeat after 29 years in office.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: CenterSpan In Sony Licensing Deal
description: The CenterSpan Communications Corporation, which has developed an online music distribution network, said it had signed a licensing deal to include artists from the Sony Music Corporation. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed, nor was the extent to which it granted CenterSpan access to the Sony catalog. CenterSpan, based in Hillsboro, Ore., said the music would be made available through its affiliate Web sites -- like online retailers or Internet service providers -- but the company has not yet announced the identities of those affiliates. CenterSpan made a name in late 2000 with its purchase of Scour.com, a Web site backed by Michael Ovitz that at one time permitted the free exchange of music and movie files. CenterSpan said the free exchange was no longer available. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, ALICE
description: FINE-Alice. Retired therapist at Arthur Lehman Council Service and in private practice. Died on February 27, 2002. Services on Sunday 11:30AM at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91st Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: As theater, Suba is hard to beat. It's the kind of restaurant that non-New Yorkers, at least young ones, hope that New York has lots of: deliciously strange and out of the way. Suba starts normally enough with a little bar on street level. To eat, diners descend an industrial metal staircase and alight in a small brick room with beamed and vaulted ceilings. The light flickers fitfully, refracted through water that flows in a moatlike stream all around the room. I was told by a manager that a purse or napkin occasionally floats by, although I saw nothing but pure running water when I ate there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAY, ADELA
description: BAY-Adela. Musician, teacher, survivor of the Vilna Ghetto, died peacefully at the age of 97 on February 26th, 2002. Service Sunday, March 3, 2002, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Gearing Up For Presidential Bid?
description: The daughter of the former dictator Park Chung Hee, who has said she wants to run for president, resigned from the opposition Grand National Party, saying the party had ''made a wrong choice by ignoring a popular demand that its leadership must not be monopolized by one man.'' Park Geun Hye was unlikely to get the party's nomination to run in the December election because the party chief, Lee Hoi Chang, is the leading contender to succeed President Kim Dae Jung. If she campaigns as an independent or as a candidate of another party, Miss Park, a member of the National Assembly, would be the first woman to run for president of South Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IRELAND, ROBERT L., III.
description: IRELAND-Robert L., III. A memorial service will be held, Tuesday, March 5 at St. Thomas Church, New York City, (53rd and 5th Ave.) at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that contributions in Mr. Ireland's memory be sent to The Boys' Club of New York, 287 E. 10th St., NY, NY 10009, or Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Ave., NY, NY 10022.

title: W.T.O. Pact Would Set Global Accounting Rules
description: As Congress and regulatory officials consider ways to tighten auditing and accounting rules to prevent a repeat of the Enron debacle, a little-known global agreement that places untested new requirements on the domestic regulation of professional services like accounting is quietly advancing -- with the help of firms like Arthur Andersen, Enron's much-criticized auditor.

title: Reflections On All 200 Films
description: Don't try to stump Christopher Lee. The towering, aristocratic British actor, best known for his epicurean interpretation of Count Dracula in the Hammer horror films of the 1960's, has appeared in well over 200 feature films. Mr. Lee is unsure of the exact figure, though he says he remembers something about each of them.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Clearing An I.M.F. Hurdle
description: After weeks of tense negotiations, governors of the country's 23 provinces have signed an accord with President Eduardo Duhalde that requires them to cut their budget deficits by 60 percent this year. The agreement, which also removes a monthly federal tax transfer to the provinces of hundreds of millions of dollars, paves the way for passage of an austerity budget by Congress and satisfies a condition of the International Monetary Fund for new aid to help end the country's worst economic crisis ever.

title: 'Behind the Surrealist Curtain' -- 'Sex, Sensuality And Silence'
description: Ubu Gallery

title: May I Borrow the Car? New Service Says Yes
description: THEY are still a novelty. One could sit all day at a busy intersection and not see one pass. But cars bearing a certain round Z logo may become as familiar to New Yorkers as the pushcart hot dog vendor, if Zipcar.com lives up to its ambitions.

title: Report on City Services Describes Decline After Terror Attack
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's final collection of facts about the performance of city services, exhaustive yet carefully edited, was released yesterday by the Bloomberg administration, illuminating in many ways how those services suffered after the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Trial Deadline Is Set for 2003
description: A federal judge overseeing all of the civil lawsuits against Enron, its former executives and directors and its auditor, Arthur Andersen, ordered today that the cases be brought to trial by December 2003.

title: U.S. Studying Medicare Reports at Cigna Unit
description: The Cigna Corporation, one of the largest health insurers, said yesterday that the Justice Department and the Department of Health and Human Services were investigating the Medicare cost reports at a Cigna unit in New Mexico.

title: Bush Offers New Drug Plan Similar to One Court Barred
description: Stymied once by a federal judge, President Bush offered a proposal today to require pharmacies to give discounts to Medicare beneficiaries, but drugstores contended that the president was still exceeding his legal authority.

title: One World, Many Films
description: For a while, it looked as if the New York International Children's Film Festival might be one of the artistic casualties of Sept. 11. With offices only a block from the disaster, the festival was left without space, telephone service or mail delivery. But in the midst of what Eric Beckman, a co-director of the festival, called ''this whole nightmare,'' supporters kept urging him to continue.

title: Salary Cap Forces the Giants to Make Deep Cuts
description: The Giants are going through what a number of N.F.L. teams have endured this week -- cutting many players and restructuring multiple contracts to get under the $71.1 million salary cap.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates To Shut Unit
description: Network Associates plans to close its PGP software encryption division after failing to find a suitable buyer, the company's chief executive, George Samenuk, says. Network Associates said last fall that it would try to sell the PGP unit in an effort to cut costs. Network Associates officials said PGP encryption technology will continue to be used in the company's products. In a speech at the Robertson Stephens investors conference in San Francisco, Mr. Samenuk also said that Network Associates was seeking acquisitions that would complement its remaining divisions: McAfee, which develops antivirus and security products; Sniffer, which develops system security products; and Magic, which makes service management products. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Television; Facing Death, And Other Family Issues
description: ''Six Feet Under,'' the darkly comic, deeply moving series about the funeral-running Fisher family, returns for its second season more exhilarating than ever (Sunday at 9 on HBO). Nate, the oldest son, now has a brain that could literally explode because of a rare problem with an artery. Peter Krause's performance is even more eloquent than before, with a subtle naturalism that is easily underrated. As Nate grapples with death, the ghost of his father (Richard Jenkins) appears with some surprising pals from the other side.

title: Shock, Then Giddy Disbelief For Former Officers' Families
description: The Champagne was chilling in the conference room, and the yellow roses needed a vase. Andra Schwarz, however, did not care. She was talking on the telephone to her husband, Charles, long-distance. It was the first time they had spoken since he had heard the news.

title: Buy Enron, They Said
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Prowl for a Statuesque Owl That's a Friend to Wizards
description: The snowy owl was resting quietly in the tundralike expanse of grass and marsh around the runways at Logan International Airport in Boston. Norman Smith was watching it. The owl was half asleep, as owls are when they rest, eyes almost closed, head swiveling around occasionally in a smooth, almost liquid fashion as if it were completely unhinged.

title: Past Offers Little Guidance for Drought in Winter
description: Before long, a drought emergency will be declared for New Jersey. There is a good chance one will be declared later this year for parts of southern New York. What happens then, however, is still very much up in the air.

title: Arnold Worldwide Is Laying Off 40
description: Arnold Worldwide is laying off 40 employees, or 5.3 percent of the staff at its Boston headquarters.

title: Sports of The Times; Nobody Is Rooting For the Cap
description: THE names were falling off pro football rosters like so many ornaments from an abandoned Christmas tree. Not obscure names, but future Hall of Fame names, Pro Bowl names, established names.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Airline Merger Talks Break Down
description: Merger talks by the Virgin Express airline of Richard Branson and SN Brussels, formerly Belgium's flag carrier Sabena, broke down after the two sides failed to overcome financial and cultural hurdles, Virgin Express said. The recently formed SN Brussels is focused on European business travelers, while Virgin aims at bargain hunters. Virgin Express said the decision to end two months of merger talks was mutual. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Excerpts From the Court Decision on Three Officers in the Louima Case
description: Following are excerpts from the United States Court of Appeals decision in the appeals of Charles Schwarz, Thomas Bruder and Thomas Wiese:

title: The Metal Of the Masses, Valued Now
description: Aluminum may look like a jet age material, but it was first formulated out of alumina clay in 1825. ''The two materials that have had the greatest impact on industry and everyday life over the last hundred years, aluminum and plastic, originated in the 19th century,'' Sarah Nichols writes in the catalog for ''Aluminum by Design: Jewelry to Jets,'' a traveling exhibition that she organized for the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh. (It is at the Wolfsonian-Florida International University in Miami Beach through April 7.)

title: U.S. Growth Rate, at 1.4%, Is Far Better Than Expected
description: With consumer spending holding up much better than anyone had expected, the American economy grew at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, the Commerce Department reported yesterday in a sharp upward revision of its original estimate. The new growth rate was surprisingly vigorous for a nation in recession.

title: Top E.P.A. Official Quits, Criticizing Bush's Policies
description: A top enforcement official at the Environmental Protection Agency resigned on Wednesday, venting frustration with the Bush administration for policies that he said undermined the agency's efforts to crack down on industrial polluters.

title: Mastering the Domain of Abstinence
description: The mildly amusing but wholly unnecessary comedy ''40 Days and 40 Nights'' will probably cause San Francisco to experience an uptick in desperate male tourists. That's because this mindless sex farce makes Tony Bennett's second home appear to be the site of a supermodel convention.

title: Kathy Butterly
description: Tibor de Nagy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVERA, SYLVIA
description: RIVERA-Sylvia. The board and staff of the Empire State Pride Agenda commemorate the life of Sylvia Rivera, 50, who died on February 19 after a long struggle against liver cancer. Sylvia, we admire your determination to always speak out against injustice and your resolve to never give up. We will continue the struggle you helped start at Stonewall and will not stop until everyone in America recognizes that difference is a strength that should be celebrated and not suppressed. The Empire State Pride Agenda is New York's statewide, non-partisan lesbian and gay civil rights and political advocacy organization.

title: I.R.S. Audits of Working Poor Increase
description: The Internal Revenue Service sharply increased audits of the working poor last year, while reducing to record low levels those of the highest-income Americans and big companies, new data showed today.

title: The Trouble With Death
description: To the Editor:

title: How Cowboys And Cowgirls Get Into Step
description: SUSAN STROMAN could not have known how much New York would need ''Oklahoma!''

title: S.& P. and Nasdaq Dropped for Month, but Dow Gained
description: Stocks fell yesterday, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to its biggest monthly drop since September, on concern corporate profits would rebound more slowly than expected.

title: 'Now Is the Time'
description: Dorsky Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, EMANUEL
description: KAYE-Emanuel, 91. On February 28. He is survived by his loving children Bill & Bob Kaye, Barbara Frankel & Cheryl Jackman; caring daughter-in-law Linda Kaye and son-in-law Ronald Frankel; his beloved grandchildren Merri Yacenda, Elliot Kaye, Mitchell Kaye, Marcy Sinel, Jessica Milan; and cherished great grandchildren Tilly Yacenda and Ernest Kaye. Donations to Alzheimer's Association, New York City Chapter, 360 Lex, 5th Floor, NY, NY 10017. Services Friday 11 AM ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Timeless Images That Capture the Serenity of Rural England
description: In 1830 John Constable began publishing his ''English Landscape,'' a set of etchings copied from his paintings. The idea of the prints, he said, was twofold: to capture rural life and nature's moods with more veracity than painting could and ''to give 'one brief moment caught from fleeting time' a lasting and sober existence.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: More Fallout From 1945
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder canceled a visit to Prague scheduled for this month, apparently reluctant to get embroiled in a fight between the Czechs and Hungarians stemming from the end of World War II. In 1945, Czechoslovakia stripped ethnic Germans and Hungarians of their Czechoslovak citizenship and land in retaliation for their support for Nazi Germany. Prime Minister Victor Orban of Hungary said last week that the Czech Republic and Slovakia should not be admitted to the European Union unless the decrees are revoked, angering Czech and Slovak leaders. Mr. Schrder objected when the Czech prime minister, Milos Zeman, recently called the ethnic Germans ''Hitler's fifth column.'' Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: JUDGE RULES IN G.M.'S FAVOR IN TRADEMARK DISPUTE
description: The grille of the Hummer H2, made by General Motors, does not violate the trademark design of DaimlerChrysler's Jeep vehicles, a federal judge has ruled. DaimlerChrysler sued G.M. last year, saying the grille of the Hummer H2 sport utility vehicle was too much like the Jeep grille. But Judge Robert Miller Jr. of Federal District Court in South Bend, Ind., said in a ruling posted on the court's Web site, ''Nothing in the record indicates any intent on General Motors' part to palm off the H2 as a Jeep, or to exploit consumers' association with Jeep.'' G.M. has said that changing the grille design would cost $100 million. The H2 is set to go on sale in July.

title: Montana Sheriff Contends Right-Wing Militia Plotted Killings
description: State and federal officials are investigating the case of a man in the northwest section of Montana who is described as part of a right-wing conspiracy to assassinate local police officers, prosecutors and judges.

title: Pride, Not Victimhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Troops Raid Arab Camps, Killing 11 in West Bank Fighting
description: Israeli troops for the first time battled their way into this congested camp and into another camp, in Jenin, today, killing at least 11 Palestinians and losing one soldier in some of the fiercest fighting of the 17-month conflict.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Forecast Puts Gateway Under A Cloud
description: Shares of the computer seller Gateway fell 9.8 percent yesterday, to $4.60, after it said that falling prices would mean that losses for the quarter and the year would be wider than analysts had forecast. Excluding some costs, the first-quarter loss will be 18 cents to 24 cents a share, Gateway's chief financial officer said. Analysts forecast a loss of 7 cents. The company had losses for four quarters before reporting a profit of 2 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Its chief executive, Ted Waitt, predicted that Gateway would return to profitability in 2003. ''It's as low as the stock value can get,'' Mr. Waitt, above, said. ''We're trading at book value.''

title: World Briefing Asia: Cambodia: Government Foes Sentenced
description: Twenty people including a Cambodian-American were sentenced to terms ranging from five years to life in prison for links with an antigovernment group accused of terrorism. The group, with headquarters in Long Beach, Calif., attacked government buildings in November 2000.

title: Many Mountains To Climb
description: When it got the rights to ric Valli's ''Himalaya,'' Kino International decided to give the film some breathing room away from the New York crush. ''We felt New York critics wouldn't respond favorably because it's such an audience film,'' said Hyoe Yamamoto, Kino's office manager. In this case, ''audience film'' means one that does not appeal to ordinary tastes, the kind of movie that could use some nurturing in a less pressured setting.

title: Jets Re-Sign Mickens But Cut Green
description: Ending a salary-cap purge that decimated the defense, the Jets renegotiated the contract of cornerback Ray Mickens yesterday. But the team also continued to jettison other veterans, releasing strong safety Victor Green. And, as expected, they were unable to sign linebacker James Farrior or left guard Kerry Jenkins to new contracts, which means both are free agents.

title: One Texas Candidate Cools on a Debate in Spanish
description: For many Hispanics in Texas, some of whom were punished as children for speaking Spanish at school, the Democratic gubernatorial debates set for Friday signaled a new era. The two leading candidates, both Mexican-Americans, had planned to hold one debate in English and then another in Spanish, believed to be a first in modern American politics.

title: Lawmaker Criticizes Ashcroft on Priorities
description: Representative David R. Obey, the senior Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, accused the Bush administration today of shortchanging the F.B.I.'s counterterrorism programs both before and after the suicide attacks of Sept. 11.

title: Historians Under Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: In Yonkers, Council Votes To Remove Commissioner
description: The City Council voted 4 to 3 Wednesday night to oust an embattled politician, Jay B. Hashmall, who has been serving as the city's acting commissioner of human resources since being forced to resign last fall from a high-level county post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, HELEN KLEMIS
description: ALEXANDER-Helen Klemis. In her 79th year on February 23, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Alfred Stone and the late Mae Klemis Stone. Retired auditor for The Bank of New York. Memorial service at the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 E 88 St, NYC, Saturday, 9:30 AM. For further information please contact the Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 212-535-1500

title: Two Thousand Acres
description: According to my calculations, my work space occupies only a few square inches of office floor. You may find this implausible, but I'm using a well-accepted methodology. Well accepted, that is, among supporters of oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

title: Bruised and Battered Devils Given Encouraging News on Niedermayer
description: The Devils' defenseman Scott Nie dermayer who was shaken up Wednesday after his head hit the knee of the Flyers' left wing Ruslan Fedotenko -- does not have a concussion, General Manager Lou Lamoriello said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Economy Stalls
description: The Brazilian economy performed worse than expected in the fourth quarter of 2001, contracting 0.7 percent, as high interest rates and power rationing caused a decline in industrial production. Gross domestic product rose 1.5 percent for the year. Last week, the Central Bank reduced interest rates a quarter-percent, to 18.75 percent, in a sign that the government was beginning to take steps to revive the economy ahead of presidential elections in October. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Some Profit Being Made On a Unit Of Enron
description: Some investors specializing in troubled companies have made money investing in the Enron Corporation in the last few weeks, even as creditors continue to fight in bankruptcy court over the energy company's remaining assets.

title: The Saudi Prince's Plan: Glimmer or Mirage?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Streak of Futility Climbs to 98
description: The horse who cannot lose and the trainer who cannot win came together yesterday at Aqueduct, odd bedfellows with one simple but, as it turned out, unfulfilled goal in mind: win the seventh race.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: One Year In Kashmir -- 3,465 Killed
description: The conflict in Kashmir, largely between Islamic militants and India, claimed 3,465 lives last year, according to officials in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. More than 2.000 of those killed were militants fighting either for majority Muslim Kashmir to join Pakistan, an Islamic nation, or for Kashmir's independence from India. Also killed were 909 civilians, 408 people from the army and the paramilitary forces and 128 from the police.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and a news analysis on Wednesday about Rudolph W. Giuliani's pledge to promptly distribute $100 million from the Twin Towers Fund referred imprecisely to the clients of a lawyer who threatened to sue over the transfer of the fund to Mr. Giuliani's control. They were relatives of some of the 23 New York Police Department officers who were killed; they did not include relatives of any of the 37 officers killed who were from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: All Alone? Maybe Not
description: The Earth, at right, as seen from space and projected onto the Hayden Planetarium's dome, has long been seen as a lonely outpost of life, but a new Hayden show asks whether we are really alone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, RAY BINDER
description: GORDON-Ray Binder. Of New York City, died February 28, 2002, age 88. Born on September 17, 1913 to Ella and Max Binder. She married to Leon Gordon in 1935. Leon passed away in 1954. Ray's three brothers Samuel, Israel and Nathan Binder also predeceased her. Ray graduated Hunter College 1936 where she was Sing Pianist. She continued to give pleasure as a pianist throughout her life. After retirement from City College, Ray worked at the Bookshop of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, exuding cheerfulness and sharing her intellect and good will. Ray maintained lifelong friendship during years as a New Yorker and from numerous trips to Israel and Europe. She will be loved and remembered for her generosity and vital spirit, and her keen appreciation of culture and learning. She is survived by her 2 daughters Risha Fried and Cora Gordon & by seven grandchildren Paul, Steven & Dennis Fried, Elana, Jonathan, Tamara and David Silberman, as well as by eleven great grandchildren. Funeral services at 12 noon on March 1 at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, New York City.

title: A German Orchestra Links Works With Quotations
description: The West German Radio Symphony Orchestra has a distinguished history of concert and broadcasting work in Cologne, its home city, but the concert it gave at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, under its principal conductor, Semyon Bychkov, was unremarkable.

title: Backups Overwhelm The Knicks In Late Run
description: Suddenly, they could not complete a simple chest pass, move their feet on defense, hold on to the ball or make a basket. In what may have been their most remarkable letdown in a season full of them, the Knicks morphed into the sloppiest team imaginable tonight against the Miami Heat.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telefnica Profits Down
description: The Spanish telecommunications company, Telefnica, said its profit fell 16 percent last year, hurt by Argentina's economic crisis. Net attributable profit fell to 2.1 billion euros ($1.89 billion) from 2.5 billion the year before, with fourth-quarter net profit almost halved, to 515.8 million euros. The company said it expected to take further charges in its first-quarter results because of the peso's fall against the dollar. Revenue increased 9 percent, to 31 billion euros. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Separatists in Georgia Seek 'Association' With Russia
description: The leaders of a breakaway region in Georgia said today that they were stepping up their efforts to secede and seek an ''associated'' relationship with Russia after the announcement that the United States plans to help train Georgia's armed forces.

title: Looking for Life in Cosmic Corners
description: A new space show, another of those wraparound experiences with the universe brought indoors, is opening tomorrow at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARGROVE, KATHARINE TERESA
description: HARGROVE-Katharine Teresa, RSCJ, 92. At Kenwood, Convent of the Sacred Heart, Albany, NY on Friday, February 22, 2002. Born in NY, NY on October 26, 1909, she entered the Society of the Sacred Heart of Jesus in June, 1931, making her final profession in July, 1939. Educated at Manhattanville College, Providence College and Catholic University, she held degrees in Classics, Philosophy, and Theology. She served in leadership positions of the National Conference of Christians and Jews for 40 years and was active in the International Council of Christians and Jews from its inception. She was professor of Theology at Manhattanville College for 36 years and editor of four books on Jewish-Christian dialogue. A Memorial Liturgy will be celebrated Saturday, March 2nd at 11:00 AM in the Kenwood Convent Chapel, Albany, New York.

title: New Rule on Tire Safety Is Near, Government Says
description: The government is close to issuing a regulation that will require automakers to install tire-pressure warning systems in new cars and trucks starting with 2004 models, the Bush administration told a House subcommittee today.

description: Tanya Bonakdar

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTENSEN, EDNA C. (DILLON)
description: CHRISTENSEN-Edna C. (Dillon). Of Medford, February 14, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Carl H. Christensen. Loving daughter of the late Vincent and Sarah (MacArdle) Dillon. Cherished sister of Walter Dillon & his wife Catherine of Valley Stream, Long Island, N.Y., Robert Dillon and his wife Rose of East Branch, N.Y. and the late Vincent and Harold Dillon. Dear sister-in-law of Mae Dillon of Nyack, N.Y. Loving stepmother of Carl Christensen and his wife Geraldine of Forest, VA. Edna was very much beloved by her dear friends, Saro and Elizabeth Minassian of Winchester, MA., and her friend and travel companion Gertrude Forest of Lowell, MA. She was the aunt of one niece and five nephews and 18 great nieces and nephews. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to attend her Memorial Mass on Saturday, March 2, 2002 at 9:00 am in St. Raphael's Church, 512 High Street, West Medford. A Memorial Garden is planned for Edna and Carl Christensen at her stepgrandson's church in Weare, New Hampshire. For those who wish, Edna may be remembered through donations to Reverend Robert Christensen, P.O. Box 391, Weare, N.H., 03281 or to the Visiting Nurse Association of Eastern, MA, 259 Lowell Street, Somerville, MA. 02144.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATH, JACK H.
description: NATH-Jack H. On February 28, 2002. Survived by his beloved wife Janice Puner-Nath, and his beloved children Barbara Nath Gold, Ronald Nath and Robert Nath, and seven grandchildren. Services on Sunday, March 3rd, 1 P.M., at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: CD Technology Stops Copies, But It Starts A Controversy
description: The recording industry has begun selling music CD's designed to make it impossible for people to copy music to their computers, trade songs over the Internet or transfer them to portable MP3 players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASKIR, PHILIP
description: BASKIR-Philip. On February 27, 2002. A retired fund-raiser for North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. Beloved husband of Sylvia Warren. title: Bernard Green Dies at 91; Founded Newsstand Chain
description: Bernard Green, who began hawking newspapers on the streets and subways at 11 and never quite got over being a newsboy -- even when he became the owner of one of New York City's biggest chains of newsstands -- died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Jaspers Begin Playoffs With Some Pressure Off
description: Rider has the conference's most valuable player in Mario Porter, and Iona has the confidence built from two straight trips to the N.C.A.A. tournament. But Manhattan may have the most unusual reason to believe it might emerge as champion from the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament in Albany this weekend: a few more losses.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on Tuesday with a picture of the president of UTC Fuel Cells outside the White House with President Bush misstated his given name. He is William Miller, not Jim.

title: Discovering Her Real Self By Portraying a False One
description: To say that Esther Kahn is the black sheep or the ugly duckling of her noisy family would create a false impression of cuteness. Her harried, good-humored mother (Frances Barber) remarks that Esther (played as a young girl by Philadelphia Deda and then by Summer Phoenix) is not a human child at all, but a monkey or a pig. But even those creatures have their adorable aspect, and there is nothing especially cuddly or lovable about Esther. Sullen, incommunicative and shut off from all emotions other than rage and frustration, she seems less like a daughter or a sister than a feral mascot, a wolf child taken in and raised in the busy domestic warmth of late-19th-century Jewish working-class London.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Employment Outlook Survey
description: Companies in the New York City metropolitan region are reluctant to hire workers, according to a new study. Three quarters of the purchasing managers surveyed said the hiring outlook was bad and almost 10 percent called it ugly. But the executives also said that business conditions stabilized in February after bottoming out in the wake of Sept. 11. Still, signs of an economic recovery are scarce, said Marc N. Goloven, the senior regional economist at J. P. Morgan. Mr. Goloven directs the monthly survey for the New York branch of the National Association of Purchasing Management. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: National Meet Draws Two Emerging Stars
description: At 6 feet 9 inches, Charles Clinger was an all-state high school basketball center in Wyoming until a coach suggested he take up track to help his basketball. Before he left high school, Clinger had high-jumped 7-1. End of basketball career, start of a world-class high-jumping career.

description: To the Editor:

title: Accent on Tension: Afghan School Shelled
description: A mortar attack on a boys' school 40 miles from Kabul killed one child today and wounded at least 30, heightening concerns that local power struggles could plunge Afghanistan again into violent strife.

title: If Found, Please Call
description: Secret Service agents shopping for souvenirs in Salt Lake City left behind instructions for protecting Vice President Dick Cheney and his family at the Winter Olympics, officials said today. The document outlined the positioning of agents in about 17 posts providing security for Mr. Cheney, his wife and daughter at Rice-Eccles Stadium during the closing ceremony of the Games.

title: Women and War
description: In ''Necessary Targets,'' Shirley Knight, right, plays a Manhattan therapist who travels to Bosnia to study the effects of war on the country's women. This new play, by Eve Ensler, opened last night at the Variety Arts Theater.

title: Grim Guesswork Led to the Body of San Diego Girl
description: The volunteers who found Danielle van Dam were acting on a hunch.

title: 'Works on Paper'
description: Seventh Regiment Armory Park Avenue at 67th Street

title: Senators Hear From Experts, Then Support Mammography
description: Clearly piqued that the controversy over mammography has confused women, members of the Senate heard testimony today from experts on both sides of the debate and then pointedly threw their political support behind breast cancer screening.

title: N.F.L. Ponders Midweek Start
description: The National Football League will almost certainly start its season with a midweek game, on Thursday night, Sept. 5, with the Giants playing the San Francisco 49ers at Giants Stadium, two television industry officials said yesterday.

title: Legroom in Taxis
description: To the Editor:

title: New Turn in the Louima Case
description: The unanimous decision by a federal appeals court yesterday to reverse the convictions of three officers in the Abner Louima torture trial will force prosecutors to revisit a case that has, over the last five years, appalled and torn the city. The attack on Mr. Louima, a Haitian immigrant, in a Brooklyn police station in the summer of 1997 was unusually vicious. A police officer sodomized Mr. Louima with a broken broomstick, causing grave internal injuries. No less troubling, it appeared that other police officers had conspired to prevent the attacker or attackers from being brought to justice.

title: Vote for Voting Reforms
description: All week, partisan wrangling over the question of preventing electoral fraud threatened to kill the Senate's sensible election reform bill, though a compromise seemed within reach late yesterday. Differences over the fraud issue do not justify scuttling the overall bill, the product of year-long, painstaking negotiations. The resulting bipartisan legislation goes a long way toward curing the deficiencies in the nation's balloting process that became manifest in the 2000 presidential election. Senate leaders must ensure that the vote on electoral reform proceeds, and should encourage members to support it overwhelmingly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOTT, REVEREND ROBERT V
description: LOTT - Reverend Robert V. 1939-2002. Father Lott was a visionary who saw outside of normal boundaries. He dedicated his life to teaching others to help themselves and their communities. Driven by the social gospel to serve those in need, he was a vigorous advocate for programs benefiting the elderly, and a prolific developer of low-income housing. Father Lott asked others to reach for goals that would intimidate most, and his sermons and liturgies inspired those around him to put God's words into action. Born in the Bronx on November 23, 1939, Father Lott was raised in St. Frances of Rome Parish in Wakefield. He studied at All Hallows High School, and graduated from Iona College. Shortly after, he entered St. Joseph's Seminary in Dunwoodie and was ordained on May 29, 1965. After ordination, he pursued advanced studies in Liturgy and earned a Master's Degree in Sacred Scripture. His first assignment was at St. John the Evangelist in White Plains, where he worked with the New York Apostolate for the Deaf. Father Lott served as Assistant Pastor of St. Peter's in Yonkers and St. Joseph's of Greenwich Village. While at St. Joseph's, he co-founded and served as Chairman of the Caring Community, and he led that organization in the purchase of Village Nursing Home. Father Lott was a former member of Planning Board II, and the co-founder and former Chairman of The Council of Senior Centers and Services. He was appointed Pastor of St. Francis de Sales Parish on East 96th Street in July of 1987, and Administrator of St. Lucy's Parish in 1998. At the former, he operated a soup kitchen and a shelter for the homeless. During the past fifteen years, he founded and served as Chairman of the Board and President of the SFDS Development Corporation. Through that not-forprofit organization, he developed over 700 low-income housing units in East Harlem ranging from housing for the homeless to a model assisted living facility for the elderly on Fifth Avenue. The Caring Community, Presbyterian Homes, and Village Care of New York have all honored him as Man of the Year. Last year he was presented with the Maggie Kuhn Award. Donations may be made to the The Reverend Robert V. Lott Memorial Fund, c/o SFDS Development Corporation, 1261 Fifth Ave., New York, NY, 10029.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, DANIEL F.
description: McCARTHY-Daniel F. On February 25, 2002 of Whitestone, NY. Beloved husband and best friend of Jean. Loving father of Daniel, Jr., Eileen, Kevin and Timothy. Beloved father-in-law of Kathy, Barbara and Amy and three grandsons. Devoted brother of Monica Smolenski. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th St., Whitestone. Mass of Christian Burial is on Saturday at 10:30 A.M. at St. Luke's Church. Interment at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting Thursday 7-10 PM and Friday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to Family Circle of Ozanam Hall, 4241 201st St., Bayside, NY 11361, would be greatly appreciated.

title: A Drumroll for a Season Of Jazz at Lincoln Center
description: Drums -- American, African, Afro-Cuban, Caribbean, Japanese -- will be the prevailing theme of the next season of Jazz at Lincoln Center.

title: The Top Grammys: Alicia Keys, U2 and 'O Brother'
description: The winners of the 44th Annual Grammy Awards, presented on Wednesday night in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISELBERG, MARVIN
description: WEISELBERG-Marvin. The faculty and staff of Schneider Children's Hospital's Division of Adolescent Medicine in the Department of Pediatrics mourn the loss of Marvin Weiselberg, father of our colleague and friend, Eric C. Weiselberg, MD. We offer our condolences to his entire family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, ROSALIND
description: ZUCKERMAN - Rosalind. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of Rosalind Zuckerman, a steadfast, devoted, and very beloved member of the law school administration. She served as the Law School Bursar for more than three decades, and a succession of Brooklyn Law School trustees, deans, faculty members, and students benefited from her wisdom, compassion, and energy. Her presence will be sorely missed; her imprint will long endure. We extend our deepest sympathy to her children, Arthur, Lawrence, and Barbara, her daughter-in-law Beth, her grandchildren, and the entire family. Paul Windels, Jr., Chairman Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

title: New Chief Says It's Go on Lincoln Center
description: Reynold Levy, the new president of Lincoln Center, said yesterday that he planned to proceed on schedule with the organization's contentious $1.2 billion redevelopment plan and that he hoped the project would help make the center more inviting to audiences it doesn't usually attract.

title: Executive Rejoining Foote, Cone Agency
description: Charles Taney, a former top executive at Foote, Cone & Belding in New York, is rejoining the agency, in the new post of vice chairman.

title: 'Shooting Resistance' -- South African Photography, 1976-94
description: Axis Gallery

title: ANTITRUST REGULATORS IN EUROPE TO LOOK INTO G.E. DEAL
description: General Electric's planned purchase of Unison Industries, a maker of aircraft engine parts, will be investigated by European antitrust regulators after four countries ruled that it might affect competition, the British Department of Trade and Industry said. Regulators in Britain, France, Germany and Spain have asked the European Commission to look into the takeover, the department said. ''We have only done this once before,'' a spokeswoman for the department said. ''The main thing of interest is the vertical relationship between Unison as a manufacturer of engine parts and G.E. as a manufacturer of engines.''

title: Father of Drowned Children Says He Never Feared for Their Safety
description: Testifying for a second day at the capital murder trial of Andrea Pia Yates, her husband said today that despite her history of mental illness and two suicide attempts, he had had no reason to believe that it was unsafe to leave her alone with their five children, whom she drowned last June.

title: Mr. Mugabe's Destructive Course
description: An honest election in Zimbabwe next week could well end President Robert Mugabe's 22-year grip on power there. To prevent that, Mr. Mugabe has been doing all he can to deny a fair chance to the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. Voters have been arbitrarily disqualified, European and African election observers harassed and the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, implausibly charged with treason. Should the opposition win anyway, army officers have pledged to keep Mr. Mugabe in power. Repressive new laws permit the banning of public rallies and silencing of critical reporting. A fraudulent election could seriously harm not only Zimbabwe, but also many of its neighbors. These countries, especially South Africa, need to take a stronger stand against Mr. Mugabe's attempts to suffocate democracy.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and a news analysis on Wednesday about Rudolph W. Giuliani's pledge to promptly distribute $100 million from the Twin Towers Fund referred imprecisely to the clients of a lawyer who threatened to sue over the transfer of the fund to Mr. Giuliani's control. They were relatives of some of the 23 New York Police Department officers who were killed; they did not include relatives of any of the 37 officers killed who were from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: J. Desmond Clark, 85, Expert On the Archaeology of Africa
description: Dr. J. Desmond Clark, an authority on ancient Africa and a leader of archaeological expeditions that helped outline the history of the continent as well as the history of humans, died on Feb. 14 in Oakland, Calif. He was 85 and retired from a professorship at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Omnicom Group, New York, named its new Chicago agency, handling PepsiCo assignments, Element 79 Partners, after gold's place on the periodic table of elements.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Elite College Graduates Sought
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he hoped to improve the quality of the department by recruiting at Harvard and other elite colleges. He said he was also eliminating a program that allowed some city employees, like traffic agents, to become officers without the required two years of college. ''We have been selling this job short,'' he said. Police officials in recent years have struggled to find enough recruits. But Mr. Kelly said his primary concern was quality, not quantity. Policing will appeal to college students despite the $31,305 starting pay, he said. ''You're going to be rich -- rich in experience,'' he said. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about legal proceedings against a suspect in a plot to blow up the United States Embassy in Singapore misstated the status of the case in some copies. The suspect, Fathur Rohman al-Ghozi, who is being held in the Philippines, appeared before investigators as part of a hearing in Manila. His trial has not begun, nor has he been formally charged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DU VAL, CLIVE LIVINGSTON II
description: Du VAL-Clive Livingston II, 89. Died at his home in McLean, Virginia. Senator Du Val served in the Virginia House of Delegates and in the Virginia Senate for a total of 26 years. He served as a lieutenant commander in the Navy during WWII, serving on the USS Lexington in the Pacific. After the war, he served as Assistant General Counsel for international affairs in the Department of Defense from 1953 to 1955 and as General Counsel of the US Information Agency from 1955 to 1959. He received numerous awards in recognition of his services to Virginia and to his community. He is to be honored on March 15th for several awards in McLean. He was born in New York June 20, 1912. He graduated from Groton School and received his undergraduate and law degree from Yale University. He married Susan Bontecou of Milbrook, NY and he and his family moved to Virginia in 1951. Senator Du Val is survived by three of his children, Susan Phipps, Clive Du Val III, and Daniel Du Val, all of whom lived in McLean, VA, three grandchildren and his brother Philip Du Val of New Canaan, CT. His son David Du Val died in 1988 and his wife died in 1997. Memorial contributions may be made to the Hospice of Northern Virginia.

title: Beardstown Ladies Case Ends in Offer to Trade
description: The Beardstown Ladies never recommended Enron stock.

title: Iverson Is Not Convinced Nets Are Best in the East
description: While the Nets have made their way around the N.B.A. compiling the best record in the Eastern Conference, the Philadelphia 76ers, the defending conference champions, have struggled through injuries and dissension and sit 10 games behind the Nets.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Before 'Casablanca,' There Was 'Pp'
description: Julien Duvivier's lithe and rakish 1937 French gangster drama ''Pp le Moko'' -- which begins a run today at Film Forum -- is far less well known than ''Algiers,'' the slick American remake starring Charles Boyer and Hedy Lamarr. ''Pp,'' one of the most purely enjoyable films ever made, is a doomed modernist romance. It stars the matchless Jean Gabin, whose expressive and sorrowful pudding of a face immediately gave a picture a soul. (Kenneth Branagh resembles him slightly -- physically and spiritually.) Gabin was the tropical opposite to waxy screen idols whose sleek good looks often suggested the hood ornament of a Hispano-Suiza.

title: The Assessment Scandal
description: Albert Schussler was, according to prosecutors, an unusual sort of tax consultant. Much of his ''consulting,'' they say, consisted of handing out thousands of dollars in cash bribes and fancy meals to New York City tax assessors, in exchange for favorable property-tax assessments for his clients. Mr. Schussler has emerged as a key figure in what may be one of the biggest scandals to hit New York City government in years.

title: Gucci Bags, Satin Blouses and Joy; Century 21, a Downtown Fixture, Reopens to Cheers
description: After five long months of being deprived, loyal customers streamed back into Century 21 in Lower Manhattan yesterday morning, cheering and applauding while executives of the discount department store stood on the sidelines and clapped right back.

title: Enron Paid Huge Bonuses in '01; Experts See a Motive for Cheating
description: The Enron Corporation paid its executives huge one-time bonuses last year as a reward for hitting a series of stock-price targets ending in 2000 -- the very time, investigators now say, when corporate officials were improperly inflating the company's profits by as much as a billion dollars.

title: Colombia Says It Cut Coca Crop
description: The government of Colombia said today that it had significantly reduced the amount of coca under cultivation through an aggressive, American-backed eradication campaign. But Washington is delaying the release of its own estimates, which have fueled disagreement between administration policy makers and C.I.A. analysts.

title: Conjurer of Ethereal Mysteries
description: ONE century, five decades and one year after the death of the English painter J. M. W. Turner, we are in many ways still grappling with his immense, unmanageable achievement. Nearly all the art of the Impressionists and Post-Impressionists -- for which he laid some of the most basic foundations -- has long since been swept up in popular adulation. But with Turner, there are still pockets of resistance lurking, I would wager, within many viewers.

title: Anthrax Expert Faces Fine for Burning Infected Carcasses
description: The veterinarian who discovered the Ames strain of anthrax is being fined by the State of Texas for burning carcasses infected with anthrax and other diseases -- the only safe method, he says, to get rid of the health danger.

description: In percent

Funeral services on Sunday, March 3, 1:30 P.M., Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, 5808 W. Atlantic Avenue, Delray Beach, Florida.

title: National Briefing | Washington: G.O.P. Strategy On Debt Ceiling
description: Republican leaders in the House told the Bush administration that they did not have enough votes to increase the legal limit on the national debt and urged the White House to attach the measure to another piece of popular legislation, possibly a supplemental military appropriations bill. The administration has asked Congress to raise the debt limit by $750 billion, to $6.7 trillion, by the end of March, when the government is likely to breach the limit. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: Approval of Advanced Blood Screen Will Lift Cost
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a highly sensitive test yesterday to screen blood donations for the viruses that cause AIDS and hepatitis C, offering new safety for the blood supply.

title: Milosevic Roughly Questions Albanian Documentor of War Crimes
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the former leader of Yugoslavia, worked for four hours today to discredit an Albanian activist who had documented scores of murders and deportations, saying, ''I object to everything this witness is saying.''

title: FOUNDER IS STEPPING DOWN AS CHIEF AT LILLIAN VERNON
description: The Lillian Vernon Corporation, which sells household items and toys, said yesterday that its chief executive, Lillian Vernon, was stepping down. Ms. Vernon, who founded the company in 1951, asked its board to begin a search for a new chief executive, said the chief financial officer, Wayne Palladino. Ms. Vernon will remain chairman and focus on licensing the company's name and expanding its business, the retailer said. Lillian Vernon publishes eight catalogs under titles like Lilly's Kids and Sales and Bargains, and sells goods over the Internet. Sales have fallen amid the recession, and the company, based in Rye, N.Y., said it would eliminate regular quarterly dividends after it paid a dividend of 4 cents a share today.

title: America on thin ice in South Korea
description: SEOUL:  He was disqualified at what seemed to be his moment of triumph in the Winter Olympics but received a hero's welcome anyway when he returned home Wednesday to pick up a substitute gold medal to replace the one he thought he had won in Salt Lake City.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sales Of Chip Gear Off 41% In 2001
description: Worldwide sales of semiconductor equipment tumbled 41 percent last year, to $28 billion from nearly $48 billion in 2000, according to Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, an association of companies that supply technology and materials to chip makers. The industry held up better in Japan than elsewhere, the trade group reported, with billings declining 17 percent in 2001, to $7.6 billion; sales in North America, the largest market for semiconductor equipment, dropped 37 percent, to $8.2 billion. Stanley T. Myers, chief executive of the group, said that while the industry suffered its worst annual decline last year, sales stabilized in the fourth quarter. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBIN, LEONORE D.
description: CORBIN-Leonore D. On February 28, 2002. Beloved mother of Betsy Schwebel. Cherished grandmother of Rob, Jim and his wife Karen, and Kathy and her husband Ron; . great grandmother of Nikki, Justin and Juliette. Dear sister of Billie Crocker and Harry Lee Danziger. Funeral private.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Harvard Agrees To Pay Janitors More
description: Harvard University has agreed to increase pay for janitors to as much as $14 per hour by 2005 and convert many part-time positions to full-time ones. The contract agreement came a day after a rally in which nine protesters, both students and workers, were arrested for blocking rush-hour traffic in Harvard Square. Merry Touborg, a university spokeswoman, said a campaign by students drew attention to the wage issue but did not influence contract negotiations.

title: Health and Ideology
description: To the Editor:

title: Painting Exuberant Forms With a Palette of Light
description: And Richard Koshalek said, ''Let there be light'' at the Hudson River Museum, and there was light. That happened in 1979 with the help of the National Endowment for the Arts. Mr. Koshalek, then director of this small but versatile institution, was clever enough to commission an artist instead of an electrician to light up the front entrance to the museum's modern wing.

title: PG&E SAYS IT WILL RECLASSIFY $1 BILLION IN LEASES AS DEBT
description: The PG&E Corporation, the owner of California's biggest electric utility, plans to reclassify as debt $1 billion in ''synthetic'' leases on three power plants and will revise financial results dating back to 1999. A review of the leases showed that the company must add them to its balance sheet, PG&E said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. PG&E said a week ago that it discovered that the leases might not qualify for off-balance-sheet accounting. PG&E delayed reporting 2001 results to check the leases, joining a score of companies that are examining their accounting to revive confidence in financial reports after the collapse of Enron.

title: Madden Gives Up Sundays to Team Up With Michaels on 'Monday Night'
description: The maneuvering on Wednesday that resulted in John Madden's joining ''Monday Night Football'' yesterday occurred so fast that it left him numb. In less than seven hours, Fox Sports released Madden from the final year of his contract, his agent negotiated with ABC, and he signed for four years to replace Dan Fouts and Dennis Miller.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: U.S. Agency Backs Farmers
description: The federal Bureau of Reclamation said it intended to provide Klamath Basin farmers with ample water in the coming irrigation season, angering environmentalists and fishery groups. The bureau's assessment follows a National Academy of Sciences review questioning last year's decision to limit irrigation flows to protect endangered fish in Upper Klamath Lake and the Klamath River. Before being enacted, this season's policy must be reviewed by other federal agencies.

title: Bush Aide Attacks Clinton on Mideast, Then Retracts Remark
description: The White House press secretary this morning blamed former President Bill Clinton for the continuing violence in the Middle East, causing denunciations from former Clinton aides, but he quickly reversed himself and by midafternoon issued a retraction.

description: LEAVING KATYA

title: A Ruling on Legal Basics
description: The federal appeals court did not outright decide guilt or innocence yesterday as it overturned the obstruction of justice convictions of three officers in the Abner Louima case and granted a new trial to Officer Charles Schwarz.

description: Jan Krugier

title: Brendan Behan, a Gifted Boy Reform School Failed to Reform
description: Brendan Behan, the loquacious Irish novelist and playwright who died in 1964 of diabetes complicated by alcoholism (he was only 41), once jokingly described himself as ''a drinker with a writing problem.'' Peter Sheridan's gentle, misty-eyed screen adaptation of Behan's coming-of-age novel, ''Borstal Boy,'' barely hints at the marathon toper to come in a scene in which the teenage Brendan gets pleasantly tipsy on cider.

title: DANIELSON AGREES TO BUY BARGE COMPANY FOR $34 MILLION
description: Danielson Holding, a workers' compensation and specialty insurer, said yesterday that it planned to acquire American Commercial Lines, the largest North American barge company, for about $34 million in cash and stock. Danielson will also assume $58.5 million of the company's existing senior notes, it said. Danielson expects to finance the purchase through a rights offering to its existing security holders. Shares of Danielson rose $1.16, to $6. American Commercial is closely held.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economy Rebounds
description: Canada's economy rebounded to an annualized growth rate of 2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2001 after contracting 0.6 percent in the previous three months, Statistics Canada said. The advance, the strongest in five quarters, was led by consumer spending, which more than offset a marked drop in business investment. The gross domestic product expanded 1.5 percent in 2001 as a whole, the weakest annual growth since 1992. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: After High School, Where? Let's Hit the Road and Sing!
description: Crossroads

title: Five Umpires Are Rehired
description: With a succinct announcement that belied the battle over their status, Major League Baseball put five umpires back to work yesterday. The 94-word release said that Gary Darling, Bill Hohn, Larry Poncino, Larry Vanover and Joe West will begin working exhibition games next Monday after they complete a three-day training program in New Orleans.

title: Democrats Starting To Fault President On the War's Future
description: In the first strong Democratic criticism of the Bush administration's war on terrorism, the Senate majority leader and two powerful committee chairman are questioning whether the White House is expanding its military efforts without a clear explanation of its aims.

title: Mayor Names Commissioners for Buildings and Environment
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a spate of appointments yesterday, including commissioners to run the corruption-scarred Department of Buildings as well as the Department of Environmental Protection, which has come under fire lately over concerns about air quality near ground zero.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Anti-Execution Group Ends Efforts
description: A group hoping to repeal the death penalty in the state has disbanded, citing a lack of public interest. The group, Life for a Life, spent well over $100,000 collecting signatures for an initiative to replace capital punishment with a mandatory life sentence. Geoff Sugerman, the group's spokesman, said as many as a dozen of the state's 25 inmates on death row could be executed in the next decade.

title: Two agencies are in a review dispute over the Pennsylvania state lottery's lucrative account.
description: A DISPUTE has erupted between agencies over the lucrative account of the Pennsylvania state lottery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, BENJAMIN N.
description: KATZ-Benjamin N. The Partners & Employees of Kofler, Levenstein, Romanotto & Co., CPA's, P.C., mourn the death of their retired & Founding Partner, Benjamin N. Katz. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Charlotte, his daughters Betty and Bunny & their families, and the family of his deceased daughter, Joan.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't think it would do anybody any good to second-guess what has been done to date. I think it has been successful. I've said that on many, many occasions. But I think the jury's still out about future success.''

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Grants For Baltimore Schools
description: A group of 10 national and local foundations announced that they would give $20 million to improve Baltimore's public high schools. The money, $12 million of which comes from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, is to be used to convert nine neighborhood high schools into smaller learning communities, and create six to eight small and innovative new high schools. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIRSHBA, ADA
description: WIRSHBA-Ada. On February 27, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of the late Carl and Harvey. Dear sister of Faye Bressick and the late Kate Mazza and Arthur Young. Also survived by five adoring grandsons and their families. Funeral services are today at 12:30 from Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76th Road), Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Senate Leader Puts Off Trying to Force Campaign Bill to Floor
description: With the two leading Senate adversaries in the long struggle over the overhaul of the campaign finance law locked in negotiations, the Senate majority leader put off plans today to try to force the bill to the Senate floor.

title: House Panel Voices Doubts On Skilling
description: The Congressional gantlet may not be over for Jeffrey K. Skilling.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Medicaid Runs Out Of Money
description: State legislators failed to approve an emergency bailout for the state's deficit-riddled Medicaid program by a Thursday deadline, prompting state officials to warn they no longer have the money to pay hospitals, doctors and others. Mississippi has a $158 million shortfall in the current year's Medicaid program, but the State Senate rejected a proposal that would have covered the deficit with tobacco settlement money, a tax on some health providers and lower fees for others.

title: NATO Raid Fails to Catch Former Bosnian Serb Leader
description: NATO troops mounting their first major operation to arrest Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader indicted for war crimes, failed today to find him in a remote Bosnian village that they raided around dawn.

title: Polluters Should Have to Pay
description: In 1980, after Love Canal entered the public's consciousness, Congress made an important commitment to Americans who found themselves living on toxic dump sites, exposed to deadly carcinogens and chemicals that threatened their health and lives. As a nation we said we would clean up toxic sites -- and the polluters, not the American people, would pay.

title: Mazda's U.S. Unit Selects Agencies
description: Mazda North American Operations in Irvine, Calif., part of Mazda Motor of Japan, has named agencies to handle research, strategy and other services centered on marketing aimed at minority consumers. Billings have not been determined.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hitachi Lowers Earnings Forecasts
description: The Japanese electronics company, Hitachi, said it expected to lose 480 billion yen ($3.6 billion) in the fiscal year ending March 31, more than twice as much as previously forecast. The company also lowered its sales target by 1.3 percent, to $58.2 billion. Hitachi expects to cut $1.5 billion in fixed costs in the next fiscal year, partly by cutting nearly 21,000 jobs, a third more than announced last year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Biometrics Company Goes Public
description: IQ Biometrics, which makes facial recognition software, became a publicly traded company yesterday by acquiring JV Web. an Internet marketing concern based in Houston that trades on the Nasdaq bulletin board under the symbol JVWW. The deal was valued at $23.1 million, based on Wednesday's closing price of $1.42 for JV Web, which traded at less than 25 cents a share last month when plans for the deal were announced. IQ, based in Cupertino, Calif., said Eric McAfee, the Silicon Valley venture capitalist who brought the companies together, would become vice chairman and, with a 15 percent stake, IQ's largest shareholder. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Star Power for Heroes

title: Estes Makes His First Impression a Good One With Mets
description: Shawn Estes had just completed the first inning of the Mets' exhibition season. After the 1-2-3 outing -- following a perfect inning in an intrasquad game earlier this week -- the only obstacle Estes encountered was Manager Bobby Valentine standing on the top step of the dugout. As Estes passed, Valentine stopped him and offered a quick appraisal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JOHN J.
description: KELLY-John J. Of Woodmere, N.Y., and Holderness, NH, on February 28, 2002. Beloved husband of Anna G. Loving father of Paul and Jane. Devoted grandfather of Meghan and Maureen. Cherished brother of Anne. Funeral Mass on Saturday, 9:45 AM, St. Joseph RC Church, Hewlett, NY. Burial Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, HYMAN LAWRENCE
description: AARON-Hyman Lawrence. Of Cleveland, Ohio at age 89. Beloved husband of Phyllis, devoted father of Roger Aaron and Carolyn Ross, much loved father-in-law of Ginny Aaron and Elliot Ross; adored grandfather of Peter and Todd Aaron and Katie and Douglas Ross. Funeral services in Clevland. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the H.L. Aaron Research Fund, Alzheimers Association of New York, Attn: Lynne Raymond, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

description: A.I.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Yasir Arafat's reaction to a Saudi peace proposal referred incorrectly in some copies to a Palestinian who blew herself up on Wednesday. She was the second female suicide bomber in the 17-month Palestinian uprising, not the third (another Palestinian used a knife, not a bomb, in her suicidal attack on Israeli soldiers on Monday).

title: An Old Case Is Returning to Haunt Auditors
description: THERE is a rhythm in the law, in which principles and precedents from one era can lie fallow for decades only to be rediscovered as conditions become similar to those that prompted a judge's decision in the first place.

title: Surgery Scheduled For Messier
description: Mark Messier, the Rangers' 41-year-old captain, is expected to miss the rest of the regular season after undergoing arthroscopic surgery on his left shoulder today to remove bone spurs and alleviate chronic rotator cuff pain.

title: Playing Without Any Punch, the Rangers Continue to Drift
description: Two months ago, the Rangers' season had such fresh promise. Now, it has dissolved into ''the Knicks on ice,'' according to a fan at Madison Square Garden, where the Rangers were smothered, 3-0, by the Ottawa Senators last night.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Peru Spy Chief Has Funds Frozen
description: Swiss prosecutors say they have blocked more money connected with Peru's former intelligence chief, Vladimiro L. Montesinos, who awaits trial in Peru on charges of gun running, money laundering, drug dealing and directing death squads. After $70 million was frozen earlier, the Zurich prosecutor, Cornelia Cova, gave the new total as $115 million. Jimena Cayo, a Peruvian judge investigating Mr. Montesinos, gave Ms. Cova documents that link the former head of Peru's army, Gen. Nicols de Bari Hermoza, a Montesinos associate, with $21 million in Swiss accounts. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: 2 Jet Passengers Questioned and Released
description: An Air-India plane from London was escorted into Kennedy International Airport yesterday by fighter jets, even though law enforcement officials said they had already discounted a tip that one of its 378 passengers resembled a terrorist.
