description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Endorses Microsoft Plea Modifications
description: In expectation of a new round of court hearings, Microsoft and the Bush administration announced some modest changes today in the proposed settlement of the government's antitrust case.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Nesting section on Feb. 15 about magazines that deal with interior design and home furnishings misstated the surname of the editor of The World of Interiors, based in London. He is Rupert Thomas, not Thompson.

title: Barkley Takes Jab at Knicks
description: Before calling tonight's Knicks-Heat game on TNT with Kenny Smith and Ernie Johnson, Charles Barkley gave a state of the Knicks address.

title: VERDICT AGAINST 2ND OFFICER IN LOUIMA ATTACK IS VOIDED; COURT CITES LEGAL CONFLICT
description: A federal appeals court in New York yesterday threw out the conviction of a white former police officer for taking part in the 1997 station-house torture of the Haitian immigrant Abner Louima, and overturned verdicts that the officer and two others had conspired to obstruct justice.

title: Putting Us to the Test
description: Sami Al-Arian leans back on a carved-wood Egyptian couch and squirms as he tries to explain why in 1991 he declared ''Death to Israel.''

title: CBS Is Asked To Postpone Showing Tape From Sept. 11
description: A New Jersey prosecutor has asked CBS to consider postponing a March 10 documentary special that is to feature vivid videotape shot at the World Trade Center complex on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBACCINI, MARIO M.
description: GAMBACCINI-Mario M. Of Westport, CT and North Palm Beach, FL. Husband of Dorothy Gambaccini. Father of Paul, Peter and Philip. Brother of Marie Cecarelli. Grandfather of three. Retired President of Master Eagle Family of Companies, NYC. Services today, 10AM, St. Luke Church, Westport, CT. Interment in Assumption Cemetery. Memorial contributions to either the American Red Cross or Fordham University.

title: U.S. More Wary on Bailouts Abroad
description: In the vast lecture hall where he taught introductory economics to hundreds of students at Stanford University, John B. Taylor would sing, dance and even dress up as a California raisin to show how government intervention can distort markets.

title: Bank of Japan, in Shift, Agrees to Loosen Credit
description: Under intense political pressure, the Bank of Japan moved to further loosen its monetary policy today, agreeing to buy more government bonds and ease restrictions on borrowing.

title: Europe Opens Convention To Set Future of Its Union
description: A European Union that has become increasingly distant from its citizens began an extraordinary effort today to create a more representative government as the 15-nation bloc expands across the Continent and absorbs as many as nine new members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, LEE
description: JACKSON-Lee. ''Direct Descendent of the Eight'' of the Ashcan School, died on February 19, in Southhampton, NY at the age of 93. He loved the human figure, male and female, especially in motion. He delighted in everyday things like the ''Noble Horse'' whether pulling a wagon or running the race of his life. He loved words, their derivatives and meanings. His romantic attitude was embracing of beauty and truth throughout his life, and he was a constant joy to me and all who knew him. Adele, his wife who loved him for 52 years.

title: A Swiss Vote on Joining U.N. Has a Good Chance This Time
description: Encompassing the majestic Matterhorn, the Great St. Bernard Pass and the upscale Zermatt ski resort, this ancient valley, known by the Romans as Vallis Poenina and now as Valais, is expected to vote on March 3 in favor of joining the United Nations -- but just barely.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Gibraltar: Colonists Are Restless
description: Saying that it seeks a relationship with Britain that is noncolonial, Gibraltar's parliament approved constitutional changes to enhance its powers and limit those of the British governor. The proposals, which are to be presented to London before being put to a referendum in the colony, seek the maximum level of self-government in accordance with United Nations criteria on decolonization, Peter Caruana, the chief minister, said. Britain, which has owned Gibraltar for nearly 300 years, has said that any changes in the relationship should be discussed with Spain, which wants to reclaim the colony.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Jobless Rate Rises
description: As French business reacted with layoffs to an economy that contracted in the fourth quarter of last year, the number of French unemployed rose by 5,000 in January, to 2.41 million people, or 9 percent of the work force, its highest level in more than a year. The French economy contracted 0.1 percent in the fourth quarter, its first decline in five years, slowed by the economic sluggishness of France's two biggest trade partners, Germany and the United States. Jobs are a major issue in the French presidential race, which ends with a first round of voting in April. The government expects the economy to grow only 1.5 percent this year, after a 2 percent rise in 2001. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: AMR EXPECTING LOSSES FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, expects losses for the first quarter and the full year because of the decline in travel after Sept. 11, the company said in an annual filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call estimate that AMR will have losses of $3.03 a share this quarter and $4 for the year. AMR, based in Fort Worth, had a loss last year of $1.76 billion, or $11.43 a share, compared with net income of $813 million, or $5.03, in 2000. The company's shares declined 96 cents, to $26.10.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the use of DNA technology in genealogical research misstated the name of the employer of an expert on African languages who helped a New York writer research her ancestry. It is the Smithsonian Institution, not Institute.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Chinese Leader Visits
description: Received warmly by the Vietnamese leadership, President Jiang Zemin of China called for good neighborly relations between the Communist nations, who are former enemies. He made the remarks in a live televised speech at Hanoi University, a tradition started two years ago by President Clinton and continued last year by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Media's Will to Merge
description: To the Editor:

title: Migrants From Afar See Mexico as Steppingstone to U.S.
description: For the price of a first-class plane ticket, 31-year-old Pablo Juela got a bum ride.

title: A Friendship Blossoms on Death Row
description: Sitting on death row, staring through the glass separating her from her visitor, Jennifer Jason Leigh is believably terrifying as Karla Faye Tucker. Her dark eyes are menacing, her manner belligerent even as she says she doesn't want to be interviewed about ''how I hacked up'' two people with a pickax, that their families had suffered enough.

title: Budget for Port Agency Projects Stays High, With More Security
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved a $4.5 billion expense and capital budget for 2002 today that was about $100 million less than last year's spending plan, and reflected the loss of the agency's World Trade Center complex in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

title: Early Vietnam, Mission Murky
description: It is a truism that nobody hates war more than soldiers. ''We Were Soldiers,'' which chronicles a bloody three-day battle between the North Vietnamese Army and the United States Seventh Cavalry in November 1965, offers ample evidence of why this should be so. Following the example set by Steven Spielberg in ''Saving Private Ryan,'' Randall Wallace, who wrote and directed this square, effective combat epic, plunges us into the horrific chaos of close-range fighting. Bullets smash faces and rip through bellies inches from the camera, whose lens is occasionally smeared with blood. When the snap of gunfire and the thump of artillery momentarily fall silent, the air is filled with the moans of the wounded.

title: Brooklyn Woman Is Charged In Daughter's Fatal Scalding
description: The police charged a Brooklyn woman yesterday with killing her 4-year-old daughter, who the medical examiner's office said suffered burns over 80 percent of her body when she was immersed in a tub of scalding water.

title: Portrait of an Angry Young Arab Woman
description: Darin Abu Eisheh, a devout Muslim college student from this village near Nablus, believed that women should take their place beside men in the fight against Israeli occupation, her relatives said today.

title: Bus Drivers End Walkout After City Officials Intervene
description: Drivers for three private bus companies in Queens will return to work this morning, after several city officials agreed to take up their cause with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a union official said.

title: Sports of The Times; More Curious Material Found in Skiing's Closet
description: WE always get these wonderful explanations from Olympic athletes about the various drugs found coursing around in their bodies. I can hardly wait for the explanation of the blood supplies left behind by the Austrian Nordic skiing team in a house in Utah.

title: Almost All in U.S. Have Been Exposed to Fallout, Study Finds
description: In a preliminary study that takes into account not only nuclear tests in Nevada but also nearly all American and Soviet nuclear tests conducted overseas until they were banned in 1963, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has found that virtually every person who has lived in the United States since 1951 has been exposed to radioactive fallout.

title: Too Slow on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Hitchcock Effective Despite Shaky Start
description: A year ago, Sterling Hitchcock was at spring training in Peoria, Ariz., still too weak to face major league hitters. Kevin Elster was relaxing by his pool in Las Vegas. Drew Henson was the starting quarterback at the University of Michigan. None of them were Yankees, and the only one who was even playing baseball was barely getting by.

title: Residents Say a Ruling Feeds Into Their Mistrust
description: The news of the overturned police convictions in the Louima case took a while to filter through the Haitian neighborhoods of central Brooklyn yesterday, and the ruling was technical enough that the legal reasoning behind it was not immediately clear.

title: Russian Goes on the Air To Deny Al Qaeda Ties
description: A onetime Soviet army officer accused of illegally ferrying arms to the Taliban and Al Qaeda terrorist network and to combatants in African civil wars appeared abruptly in a Moscow radio studio today, insisting on the air that he was innocent.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Nortel Ends Chief Executive Office
description: Nortel Networks, which makes telecommunications equipment, said its former chief executive, John Roth, would leave the company's board next month. Mr. Roth, who has been vice chairman since ceding the chief executive post to Frank Dunn in November, will leave the company's board, Nortel said. It said it had dissolved the three-person office of the chief executive, which was composed of Mr. Dunn, Mr. Roth and Lynton Wilson, the Nortel chairman.

title: The Vietnam War Through the Other Side's Eyes
description: It is one of the most arresting images ever made by a war photographer. A soldier is carried on a stretcher toward medical personnel who are calmly preparing to attend to his injuries. But the operating table, the gowned and masked nurses and surgeon, the stretcher carrier are all standing in water, and the operating room is enclosed in a mosquito-netting tent in the middle of a mangrove swamp. A nurse draws aside the flap of the tent, whose fluttery lines complement the delicate hanging tendrils and other vegetation. Natural light illuminates the table and hits the swirls of water around the approaching medic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALINSKY, LOUIS J.
description: WALINSKY-Louis J. Economist and playwright, died peacefully in Washington, DC, on December 24, 2001, at the age of 93. Walinsky was born in London, the son of the labor leader Ossip J. Walinsky and the sculptress and author Rosa Newman Walinsky. Coming to America in 1915, he attended Cornell University where he received honors in economics. After graduate study at the University of Berlin, he wrote the play ''Heil Hitler!'' His dramatization of Aldous Huxley's ''Brave New World'' was banned in London, but performed in Paris by the English Players. He taught economics in New York City high schools from 1930 until 1943, when he joined the War Production Board in Washington, remaining there with the Civilian Production Administration until 1947. He then led the efforts of the World ORT Union to rehabilitate and train Displaced Persons in the refugee camps of Europe. In 1950 he joined Robert R. Nathan Associates in Washington, DC, working mostly on the problems of developing nations. He served from 1953 to 1958 as Chief Economic Adviser to the Government of Burma (now Myanmar). After 1963 he worked as a consultant for the World Bank, undertaking missions to Korea, Afghanistan, El Salvador, Brazil, East Africa, Israel, Iran, India, Bolivia, Venezuela, Newfoundland, Papua New Guinea and Puerto Rico. He authored several books on economic development. He was an original member of the national board of Americans for Democratic Action, and the Executive Director of the International Commission of the World Jewish Congress in 1979-80. From 1991 to 1995 he was vice chairman of the American Friends of Democracy in Burma, which opposed the military dictatorship there. His wife Dorothy died in 1987. An earlier marriage ended in divorce. He is survived by his daughters, Marian Harrison of Bethesda, MD, and Louisa Parker of Vancouver, BC, by his son, Adam of Scarsdale, NY, and sister, Emily Rubin of New York City, and by three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will take place at Joseph Gawler and Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Avenue NW, in Washington, D.C. on April 26 at 11 AM.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Head Of New York F.B.I.
description: The head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Newark office, Kevin P. Donovan, has been named assistant director in charge of the New York office, officials said yesterday. Mr. Donovan, 52, has been a special agent with the F.B.I. for nearly 24 years. He will oversee about 1,100 agents and 800 support employees in the New York office, which also covers Long Island and Westchester, Rockland, Dutchess, Orange, Putnam and Sullivan Counties. Before Newark, Agent Donovan oversaw the Special Operations Division in the New York office and was the associate special agent in charge of the Criminal Division there. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Exploring the Pain of Bosnian Women
description: The pistol-sized tape-recorder looks, in fact, only slightly more friendly than a gun to the war-weary Bosnians who have been asked to speak into it. It is brandished, none too discreetly, by a self-described ''trauma counselor'' from the United States in ''Necessary Targets,'' the fumbling, striving new drama from Eve Ensler.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Renault To Raise Stake In Nissan
description: The French automaker Renault will bolster its stake in the Nissan Motor Company to 44.4 percent, from 36.8 percent, one year earlier than it had planned under an agreement reached in 1999. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Dancing Up a Cheerful Celtic Storm
description: For sheer good cheer, there's nothing quite like the Trinity Irish Dance Company. The program this Chicago-based troupe brought to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night offered one choreographic smile after another.

title: Detainees Stage Protest at Base Over a Turban
description: Scores of Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners being held at the United States Naval Base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, began a protest on Wednesday after guards removed a makeshift turban from the head of a praying prisoner, military officials said today.

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Koppel Is the Odd Man Out As ABC Woos Letterman
description: ABC, trying to challenge NBC and CBS for the sizable revenue of late-night entertainment, made a strong bid this week to lure David Letterman, the CBS star, in a move that would displace Ted Koppel and ''Nightline.''

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Aftermath Of Molestations By Priests
description: After settling with 16 plaintiffs who accused four Roman Catholic priests of sexual molestations over several decades, the Diocese of Tucson has announced that it will appoint a six-member committee of experts to review policies and procedures for handling child sex abuse cases. The committee will also review the diocese's hiring practices. The diocese will publicly release the committee's recommendations this spring. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Unopposed, China's Man in Hong Kong Wins a 2nd Term
description: With the Chinese government and local tycoons standing foursquare behind him, Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, won a second term today in an election in which nobody dared to challenge him.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: J. P. MORGAN CHASE, New York, the big United States bank, said it would sell eight branches in the United States Virgin Islands and British Virgin Islands to First BanCorp, Santurce, P.R. Terms were not disclosed.

title: INSIDE
description: Copy-Protected CD's Thwart Pirates and Fans

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Computer Surveillance Case
description: The son of an organized-crime figure pleaded guilty yesterday to a federal gambling charge. Prosecutors said the case would be helpful in pursuing terrorists because evidence from special surveillance software was allowed to be used. Nicadermo S. Scarfo Jr., son of the jailed mob boss Little Nicky Scarfo, was monitored by what is known as a ''key logger system'' when he kept computer records of a sports betting ring that yielded about $2,000 a week, prosecutors said. Mr. Scarfo, in an action followed by search-and-seizure legal experts, filed a motion to suppress the evidence. A judge rejected the motion in December. Mr. Scarfo faces at least 33 months in prison when sentenced on June 10. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Louis Faurer
description: Gallery 292

title: Erotic Horror With Enough Gore to Distress Dracula
description: To describe the sex scenes in Claire Denis's erotic horror film ''Trouble Every Day'' as indelible isn't to say they are the least bit inviting or easy to watch. This daring, intermittently beautiful failure of a movie, by the director who emerged with ''Beau Travail'' as one of France's greatest filmmakers, explores with gruesome explicitness the metaphor of sex as cannibalism. The squeamish are strongly advised to avoid the film, which created a minor scandal when it was shown last spring at the Cannes Film Festival. It opens today at the Quad.

description: Enron Paid Huge Bonuses As Its Profits Were Inflated

title: Toyota Names New Line of Cars 'Scion'
description: Toyota has found a name for its planned third vehicle line for young buyers: Scion, as in descendant, offspring or heir.

title: Clients Reel At Indictments In Tax Scheme
description: Albert Schussler, the wealthy executive at the center of a widening bribery scandal over tax assessments in New York City, apparently did not discriminate among luxury hotels, battered garment center buildings, McDonald's franchises and skyscrapers, as long as he got his fee, according to investigators.

title: Amex Coming Back to Lower Manhattan
description: American Express is abandoning Jersey City and moving its employees back to its building in Lower Manhattan to consolidate operations that were scattered across the New York region after the World Trade Center attack.

title: Industry Group Suggests Ways To Help Auditors Find Fraud
description: New standards to help accountants detect financial fraud at the companies they audit were proposed yesterday by the industry organization responsible for developing rules on audit practices.

description: Eyebeam

title: An Early Fighting Stance In McCall and Cuomo Race
description: Sounding the central theme of his campaign for governor, H. Carl McCall called yesterday for an $8-billion-a-year increase in school spending, while his Democratic opponent for the nomination, Andrew M. Cuomo, traveled upstate to promise aid for small businesses.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Feb. 20, about a program choreographed by Brendan McCall and Keith Thompson at St. Mark's Church in the East Village on Feb. 17, misidentified the choreographer of one of the pieces performed, ''Dean Suite.'' He was Mr. Thompson; there was no ''Mr. Richardson'' associated with the program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURG, ROBERT
description: BURG-Robert, 72, videographer. Born July 13, 1929; died February 8, 2002. Survived by Barbara, Mark, Samantha, Heather, Jordan, Cigi and Joan. Wonderful son, father, grandfather, friend and lover. He never stopped living. He will be missed.

title: Groups Banned by Musharraf Join Forces for Attacks, Officials Say
description: At least four radical Islamic groups, including one believed responsible for the killing of an American journalist, appear to have formed an alliance to mount attacks and resist a government ban against them, Pakistani officials said today.

title: In Connecticut, Governor Signs 61-Cent Cigarette Tax Increase
description: Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, signed into law a 61-cent tax increase on cigarettes today, one day after Democratic lawmakers tried and failed to pass a 65-cent increase that would have dedicated the extra four cents a pack to new antismoking programs.

title: Chronology of the Case
A Getaway From Ground Zero
description: I first came to this Hudson Valley hamlet 10 years ago for the food. And the laughs. My girlfriend at the time had heard about a four-star restaurant in the middle of the woods, as she put it, where the owner and a handpicked staff of whiz kids from the Culinary Institute of America, a short hop across the Hudson at Hyde Park, were working wonders with nouvelle cuisine.

title: U.N. Report Shows Rapid Aging Of Populations Around Globe
description: While many countries worry about a bulge in the number of restless young people with no jobs and too much time on their hands, the United Nations said today that the world's population is in fact steadily getting older everywhere.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Circuits yesterday with an article about the 40th anniversary of the first video game misstated the name of the game. As the article noted, it is Spacewar, not Spacewars.

title: Bermuda Havens To Be Reviewed
description: The Treasury Department said today that it was reviewing laws that allow multinational companies based in the United States, like Tyco International, to reduce taxes by incorporating in Bermuda.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: European Inflation Rises:
description: Annual inflation in the 12 countries that comprise the euro zone rose to 2.7 percent in January from 2 percent in December, the European statistics office Eurostat said. Initial estimates suggested the introduction of the euro on Jan. 1 had contributed up to 0.16 percentage point to the price rises, Eurostat said. Annual inflation in the 15 members of the European Union rose to 2.5 percent in January from 1.9 percent in December. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELLI, CHARLES R., JR.
description: MELLI-Charles R., Jr. Age 59. Of Ridgewood and Sea Girt, N.J. Died February 26, 2002. Loving husband of Sheila O'Shea Melli. Cherished father and hero of Kathleen Mary Melli and the late Andrew Shea Melli (June 2001). Big brother and best friend of Mark A. and Jan Melli. Dear son of the late Mary (Corcoran) and Charles R. Melli, Sr. Dedicated son-in-law of Julia O'Shea. Devoted brother of Patrick J. Melli (1997), Francis E. Melli (1972), Regina Woods and Ellen Powley. Beloved uncle of sixteen nieces and nephews. Charles graduated from Seton Hall and received his LL.B. from Saint John's University Law School, and he was a Thomas Moore Fellow. His law career began in New York City with the firm of Reilly and Reilly. He was the Founder and Senior Partner of the law firm of Melli, Guerin and Melli of Paramus, N.J. He was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. After being Trustee and Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees at Holy Name Hospital, he continued his association as General Counsel to the Hospital. He was a strong supporter of Bergen Catholic High School in Oradell, N.J., having served as a member of the Board of Trustees and President of the Alumni Association. For many, many years, he chaired the Annual Golf Outing and major fund raiser for Immaculate Conception Seminary. He was a member of the New York Athletic Club, the Hackensack and Spring Lake Golf Clubs, and the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club. Family and friends will meet Saturday, March 2nd at the Church of the Assumption, Emerson, N.J., for the celebration of the Mass of Christian Burial at 10AM. Interment to follow at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Friends may call Friday, 3-9PM at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave, Ridgewood, N.J. The family has asked that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Sister Patricia Lynch Regional Cancer Center at Holy Name Hospital, 718 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, New Jersey 07666.

title: CONCERNS ON COMPETITION HURT KINDER MORGAN SHARES
description: Shares of Kinder Morgan Inc., which controls the nation's largest network of fuel pipelines, fell to a 15-month low yesterday on concern that the company faces competition for assets and on investor wariness about its partnership arrangements. Kinder Morgan, based in Houston, fell $5.20, or 11 percent, to $41. Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, a pipeline operator controlled by Kinder Morgan Inc., fell $3.30, or 10 percent, to $28.60. A Prudential Securities analyst, Carol Coale, downgraded Energy Partners, saying it may be unable to acquire assets needed for growth. The chief executive, Richard D. Kinder, on a conference call with analysts, denied speculation that the company faced a cash squeeze or a regulatory inquiry on its finances.

title: Thirlspot Journal; Where Foot-and-Mouth Raged, Hikers Now Roam
description: There had been gales in the night and blizzards that crusted the high ground with deep and drifting snow. The police urged motorists to avoid the region for all but essential journeys. But who defines essential?

title: TOP G.O.P. DONORS IN ENERGY INDUSTRY MET CHENEY PANEL
description: Eighteen of the energy industry's top 25 financial contributors to the Republican Party advised Vice President Dick Cheney's national energy task force last year, according to interviews and election records.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCH, ROSE (NEE TOBIAS)
description: FISCH-Rose (nee Tobias). On February 27th, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Isadore Fisch. Loving mother of Geraldine Brody, Deanne Lebowitz & Ruth Einstein. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. She will be missed by all as she was an integral part of our lives.

title: Bush Officials Meet to Seek A Compromise On Steel Tariffs
description: President Bush's top political and economic advisers, deeply divided on one of the most excruciating decisions of Mr. Bush's 14-month-old presidency, met today to begin drafting a compromise that would place high tariffs on some imported steel, but force the American steel industry to shoulder the costs of the retirement benefits of its workers.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Parkway Traffic Crackdown
description: The State Police is stepping up traffic enforcement on the Garden State Parkway after data released this week showed summonses for January were down by a third, to 3,887 in 2002 from 5,989 in 2001. Known as Operation Saturation, the stricter enforcement involves about 35 extra troopers patrolling the parkway's busiest sections, a spokesman for the New Jersey Highway Authority said yesterday, adding that all moving violations would be targeted, with an emphasis on drunken and aggressive driving. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Racial Passion Stays Muted At a Reversal
description: TWICE now in this young year federal judges have summoned the ghosts of racial ordeals that tormented New York City's soul.

title: New Owners of Red Sox Quickly Fire Duquette
description: The new owners of the Red Sox said it was a difficult decision, but they did not take long to fire General Manager Dan Duquette. About 16 hours after they closed their $660 million purchase, the new guys on the Red Sox block made the first move yesterday in their plan to change the team's arrogant and aloof image.

title: ROYAL BANK OF SCOTLAND CONSIDERING PURCHASE IN U.S.
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland, Britain's second-largest Main Street bank, signaled yesterday that it was considering further American acquisitions after posting a surge in 2001 net profit, to 2.64 billion ($3.75 billion) from 2.1 billion a year earlier. Fred Goodwin, the chief executive, said Royal Bank might buy a bank in Maryland but declined to confirm speculation that it wanted to acquire Allfirst Financial from Allied Irish Banks. Royal Bank also said its provisions for bad debts in the second half of 2001 rose 94 percent, to 617 million. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: The Saudi Prince's Plan: Glimmer or Mirage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cubans Set On Asylum Crash a Bus Into Embassy
description: A bus carrying Cubans seeking to leave the island nation crashed through the gates of the Mexican Embassy in Havana late Wednesday. At least 21 Cubans remained inside the embassy today, Mexican officials said, adding that they did not qualify for political asylum.

title: Residential Real Estate; Signs of Recovery in Luxury Manhattan Market
description: After taking a drubbing during the wait-and-see skittishness of late last year, the ultraluxury niche of the Manhattan residential market has been showing signs of recovery in recent months, according to a study of co-op apartments and town houses selling for at least $4 million.

title: YUKOS OIL OF RUSSIA IS BUYING BIG STAKE IN ARCTIC GAS
description: Russia's No. 2 oil producer, Yukos Oil, said yesterday that it would pay $190 million to Benton Oil and Gas of Houston to buy a 68 percent stake in Arctic Gas, a Russian natural gas company with about 1.2 billion cubic meters of reserves. Yukos will buy an additional 20 percent from minority shareholders. The purchase will increase its oil and gas production by 20 percent in 2005, according to United Financial Group, a brokerage firm in Moscow. A few Russian oil companies are buying into gas fields ahead of the government's promised breakup of the monopoly in Russia's gas market. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBE, SIDNEY, HAZZAN
description: RUBE-Sidney, Hazzan. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of a revered colleague of over four decades. A wonderful cantor who quietly and gently served the spiritual needs of his Congregation Shaare Zedek, of Southfield, Michigan for over thirty years with dignity, warmth and care. His kindness, his humanity and his caring inspired us all. We extend our sympathy to his family and loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Sheldon Levin, President Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Executive Vice President Hassan Abraham B. Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: Hindu Rioters Kill 60 Muslims in India
description: Hindu mobs rampaged through this city in western India on Thursday, killing more than 60 people as they burned Muslims alive in their homes and set fire to Muslim-owned restaurants, shops, cars and apartments.

title: Back to the Battlefield, Heeding Her Old Union's Call
description: AT age 74, Lillian Roberts has the air of a fairy godmother. Her long, silky hair is woven into fine braids and then spun delicately into a bun. Her voice is soft and reassuring, her skin smooth and preternaturally lustrous.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Clears Morgan Library Plan
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission has unanimously approved the Pierpont Morgan Library's $75 million plan to construct three steel-and-glass pavilions among its three landmark buildings. The project is to begin next year and will require the library, at Madison Avenue and 36th Street, to close for two years. The architects are the Renzo Piano Building Workshop and Beyer Blinder Belle. The project will create a gallery, reading room, auditorium, storage vault, courtyard and offices. The commission, which met on Tuesday, found the plan to be a ''brilliant design,'' said the chairwoman, Sherida E. Paulsen. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOORNWEG, RITA
description: HOORNWEG-Rita. In loving memory. Pre-deceased by her husband Henry Hoornweg. Survived by her son Henry Hoornweg and daughter Judith Evans, granddaughters Nanette Ostrowski, Denise Evans, Maryanne Evans and seven great grandchildren. Donations may be made to the Public Library, Large Print Department.

title: Experts Cast Doubt on Report Finding High Magnetic Fields in Volvos
description: ALTHOUGH a Swedish car magazine found higher than normal levels of electromagnetism in some Volvos, its study, which alarmed many Volvo owners, may have overstated the hazard.

title: Kerik Is Fined For Using Aides As Researchers
description: Former Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik has agreed to pay a $2,500 fine to the city's Conflicts of Interest Board for using a police sergeant and two detectives to research his mother's death for his autobiography, which was published last year, the board said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, EMIL
description: GREEN-Emil. On February 23, 2002, of Boca Raton, FL, at 84. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Jay Green (Renate) and Deborah Green. Private services were held.

title: Mexican Executive Found Guilty in U.S. In Insider Stock Case
description: The scion of a prominent Mexican family has been convicted on charges that he engaged in illegal stock trades based on inside information that helped him and other relatives make at least $3.3 million.

title: Red, White, and Blue Notes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Leader of the Pack
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Asahi Bank Cuts Rating
description: The ratings agency Standard & Poor's cut the long-term credit rating of the Asahi Bank to one notch below investment grade, noting the bank's weak capital relative to other Japanese lenders. Asahi Bank's debt was lowered one level to BB+, the same as another major lender, Daiwa Bank. Daiwa Bank Holdings absorbed Asahi yesterday, creating Japan's fifth-largest banking group, with more than 50 trillion yen ($373 billion) in assets. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHITE, IRWIN
description: WHITE-Irwin. April 4, 1929March 2, 1992. ''How do I love thee? Let me count the ways...'' Carol

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Accusations In Plagiarism Case
description: The Wyandotte County district attorney's office filed a civil petition accusing the Piper school board of violating the state's open meetings law by discussing behind closed doors the case of 28 students accused of plagiarizing part of a botany project. Their teacher had planned to fail the students, but the board ordered her to raise their grades after parents complained. Each of the five counts that the seven members face carries a fine of up to $500. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Spacecraft Sends Its First Images of Mars
description: Eleven months after its departure from Earth and four months after its arrival at Mars, the Mars Odyssey spacecraft has finally settled into its working orbit and started sending back pictures and other scientific observations of the planet.

title: Switch to Eisley Gives Knicks a Big Payoff
description: When he was shipped to New York last August in the trade for Glen Rice, Howard Eisley thought he would be a key player on a playoff team. Instead, he has experienced what has probably been the worst season of his eight-year career. While the Knicks have lost games in almost every conceivable way, Eisley, a proven player in the N.B.A., has had to sit and watch, cheer and wait, fume but zip his lip. ''It's been very frustrating,'' Eisley admitted.

title: Head of Miss America Pageant Resigns, Citing Board Disagreements
description: The head of the Miss America Pageant resigned yesterday after a two-year tenure in which he threatened to move the money-losing event out of Atlantic City and cut budgets. He also solicited new sponsors and licensed Miss America slot machines and other merchandise to resurrect the 81-year-old dowager's finances.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column yesterday about the author Anne Rice's plan to sell her New Orleans house misstated the name of a novel of hers that is the basis for a new film, identically titled. It is ''The Queen of the Damned''; ''The Vampire Chronicles'' is the overall name of the series of novels.

title: Primedia to Shut Down Teen Magazine
description: Primedia Inc., the publisher of magazines including Seventeen and New York, said yesterday that it would shut down the monthly Teen magazine, which has been unprofitable and has struggled to capture a bigger share of teenage readers.

title: Penn Rallies to Keep Ivy Title Hopes Alive
description: All three teams at the top of the Ivy League held serve last night, keeping alive the possibility of a three-way tie for the conference championship, but no team had a harder time than Pennsylvania.

title: Reinventing grunge, Naples-style
description: NAPLES  Noodles and pizza have spread from Naples throughout the world. Could Neapolitan neo-grunge also be exported?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CIRCUIT CITY GROUP, Richmond, Va., a leading electronics retailer, said it had bought the customer base of the closely held 800.com Inc., Portland, Ore., an Internet retailer of brand-name electronics items. 800.com had 1.93 million visitors in January but stopped taking customers' orders on Thursday. Terms were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Broadens Terror Fight, Readying Troops for Yemen
description: President Bush has approved plans to send as many as 100 troops to Yemen to help train that nation's military to fight terrorists, senior administration officials said today.

title: Space Shuttle Launched, but Cooling System Is a Worry
description: A cooling system problem that emerged just after a flawless liftoff this morning could cut short the space shuttle Columbia's 11-day mission to rejuvenate the Hubble Space Telescope, NASA said tonight.

title: Experts Dispute Bush Aide's Criticism of War Crimes Panels
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan and international law experts rose to a strong defense of United Nations war crimes tribunals for the Balkans and Rwanda today in response to a broadside attack on them on Thursday by the Bush administration's ambassador for war crimes.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Tuesday about the roots of modern human behavior misstated the origin of three small beads that were examples of early artifact diversity from Africa. They were created in what is now Tanzania 55,000 years ago, not in Congo 90,000 years ago.

title: Notes from Washington; The Mayor Picks a Fight
description: Boxing historians will point out there hasn't been a consequential bout held in the District of Columbia since Joe Louis beat Buddy Baer at Griffith Stadium in 1941. Political squabbles have always quenched the local bloodthirst. Now the District's Boxing and Wrestling Commission hopes to regain some boxing notoriety by hosting Mike Tyson in his comeback.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATH, JACK H.
description: NATH-Jack H. Of Purchase, NY on February 28, 2002 in Boston, MA. Beloved husband of Janice Puner-Nath of New York, NY to whom he was married in 1997, and former husband of the late Claire Solomon Nath. Beloved father of Dr. Barbara J. Nath-Gold of Brookline, MA, Dr. Ronald L. Nath of Winchester, MA and Attorney Robert G. Nath of Potomic, MD. Beloved grandfather of Lisa and Jonathan Gold, Thomas and David Nath, and Jennifer, Cheryl and Daniel Nath.Mr. Nath was born in Vienna Austria on May 13, 1910 and came to America in 1931. He founded Crown Stationers, Inc of Mt. Vernon, NY and proudly continued to administer it actively until only a few months before his death at age 91. His care was greatly facilitated by his devoted nurse Sheila McGahon and Medford Visiting Nurse Association to whom the family is most grateful. Services 1pm Sunday March 3 at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Mr. Nath's name to Medford Visiting Nurse Association, 278 Mystic Ave, Ste 204, Medford, MA 02155 or to Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65 St, NY, NY 10021

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Capital of Europe? Brussels Is Primping
description: ''The crazier the idea, the better.'' That was the directive that Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, the European Union's executive arm, gave to a group of designers and thinkers who were asked for suggestions on how to create a single European capital.

title: New Meanings for Old Bids: Jumps to 3 Over 1 No-Trump
description: Most of the early authorities on contract bridge began with auction and then converted to the new game. One was Sidney Lenz, who had many talents, including magic. He was not, however, a magician in bidding theory, for, with one exception, he did not believe in forcing bids. This confused his partners, particularly in the Culbertson-Lenz match.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Pentagon Drops Rule On Women In Cars
description: The Pentagon has rescinded policies requiring women in the military to sit in the back seats of cars and be escorted by men when outside their bases in Saudi Arabia. The move came in response to a lawsuit by an Air Force fighter pilot, Lt. Col. Martha McSally, who called the rules unconstitutional. Colonel McSally had also objected to regulations, now rescinded, requiring women to wear full-length robes while off base. The Pentagon has asked a federal judge in Washington to dismiss the suit, but a lawyer for Colonel McSally said the military was still pressuring women to wear robes. James Dao (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAINOR, ELLEN VERONICA, NEE O'DONNELL
description: TRAINOR-Ellen Veronica, nee O'Donnell. On February 28, died peacefully in her sleep. Of Pompano Beach, FL. Born in Manhattan and resided in New York City and Hampton Bays, NY. Beloved wife of the late John J. Trainor, a Battalion Chief in the FDNY. Devoted mother of daughters Jane Ellen Gomes of Boynton Beach, FL., and Susan Mills of Delray Beach, FL. and son, John J. Trainor, Jr. of Glen Ridge, NJ. Adored grandmother of Matthew (Kim) and Alex Gomes; Brian Trainor; Leah and Samantha Mills. Much loved mother-in-law of Michael Gomes and Patricia Erhard Trainor. Dear sister of Anna Moloney. Her wit, style, sense of humor, determination, drive, compassion and unconditional love will be etched forever in the hearts of her family and friends. Wake and funeral services in Pompano Beach, FL. Reposing at Forest Lawn, 200 West Copans Road, Pompano Beach, FL. 33064, (954-784-4000). Mass on Monday, March 4 at 11:00AM at St. Gabriel's RC Church in Pompano Beach.

title: U.S. Says Ex-Prudential Worker Stole Colleagues' ID's and Sold Them Online
description: A former employee of the Prudential Insurance Company was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing the identities of colleagues from a database containing 60,000 names and selling some of them over the Internet as part of a credit card scam, federal prosecutors in Brooklyn announced.

title: Wind-Up Dolls Creakily Evoke A Puritan Soul
description: ''Antique Valentine,'' Paul Taylor's new dance piece, is delightful and deep. Its world is inhabited by turn-of-the-century music-box figurines, surrogates for ourselves. When a doll-like dancer stiffly offers a posy to his sweetheart, she proves allergic: the human condition summed up in one big sneeze.

title: SCHERING SCALES BACK PLANS FOR SKIN-CARE ACQUISITION
description: Schering A.G. is seeking to buy a skin-care business for less than $250 million after scrapping a larger acquisition because the undisclosed seller decided not to sell. Schering, which is based in Berlin, had intended to spend more than 500 million euros ($434.5 million) on a purchase, which some analysts speculated was the dermatology unit of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company. Schering said it was now planning to buy a dermatology business in the United States.

title: Cuba Arrests Asylum Seekers in Mexican Embassy
description: A Cuban special police unit arrested 21 young asylum seekers holed up inside the Mexican Embassy in Havana today after Mexican officials failed to persuade the group to leave.

title: Vaughn Gets Help on Defense From a Timely Gust of Wind
description: The pop fly was sailing down the first-base line, sure to fall out of reach of first baseman Mo Vaughn's large hands. Suddenly, a gust of wind blew the ball back into his glove, and Vaughn then turned and threw to pitcher Satoru Komiyama covering first base to double off a runner.

title: For glamorous dressing, the city's nightclubs steal the show : In London, forget the catwalks
description: LONDON  London has come to a pretty pass when the parties upstage the catwalk shows. So frantic was the social whirl surrounding London Fashion Week that many a fashion editor bypassed the catwalk shows altogether.

title: Hard to Handicap in California
description: A very Californian thing has happened in the election campaign for governor of California. Former Mayor Richard Riordan of Los Angeles, the early favorite to win the Republican nomination, looks as if he might be upset in the primary election on Tuesday by an inexperienced conservative who is believed to have little chance of winning in November. Some describe the election as a test of whether Republican moderates can succeed in California politics, as well as a test of whether President Bush made the right choice in deciding to promote Mr. Riordan's candidacy. Actually it is a test of whether predictions are possible in California politics.

title: Supplies vanish as well as dealers with the competence to track them down : Is the objet d'art culture dying out?
description: LONDON  Slowly, a major chapter of Western culture is coming to a close. Those who think of art as painting and sculpture and have never been involved in collecting, may react with skepticism on hearing that objects, to use a simple word, played a central part in the traditional Western approach, European and North American, to artas they did, too, in the East, but that is another story.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; BOY SAID TO CAUSE KABUL BLAST
description: Children injured in a school explosion that killed one boy and wounded 30 others outside Kabul on Thursday were quoted by Reuters today as saying that the blast had been caused by a schoolboy who brought a grenade into the classroom. An Interior Ministry spokesman and hospital officials in the capital said after the explosion that it had been caused by a mortar shell fired at the school, and the Interior Ministry spokesman attributed it to Taliban and Al Qaeda ''renegades.'' But Akmar, an 8-year-old student at the school, told Reuters yesterday: ''We were in the classroom with other children at about 8 a.m. when another child came into the classroom. He had a grenade in his hand, and he dropped it inside the class so we got injured.'' John F. Burns (NYT)

title: Letterman Offer Was News to Chief of ABC News
description: David Westin, the president of ABC News, told his top executives yesterday morning that his bosses had blindsided him and failed to tell him that ABC wanted to remove his most prestigious program, ''Nightline,'' to make room for David Letterman.

title: 3 Senators Seek Data on Plan To Help Safety In Workplace
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, chairman of the Senate labor committee, and two other Senate Democrats have asked the Labor Department for details on which officials are helping develop a plan to reduce workplace injuries, as well as copies of all the administration's correspondence on the issue.

title: Scholars Are Quietly Offering New Theories of the Koran
description: To Muslims the Koran is the very word of God, who spoke through the Angel Gabriel to Muhammad: ''This book is not to be doubted,'' the Koran declares unequivocally at its beginning. Scholars and writers in Islamic countries who have ignored that warning have sometimes found themselves the target of death threats and violence, sending a chill through universities around the world.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Prince Philip Does It Again
description: Prince Philip, the husband of Queen Elizabeth, added another embarrassing remark to his large collection, asking an Aborigine businessman and tribal leader in Australia, ''Do you still throw spears at each other?'' Philip, who is on a royal tour with the Queen, has a well-known penchant for making unfortunate off-the-cuff comments during the course of his official sightseeing duties. Speaking to British students in China in 1986, for instance, he said, ''If you stay here much longer, you'll be slitty-eyed.'' Aborigine leaders denounced his remark. Buckingham Palace said the conversation, related by the man's son, was ''a private matter.'' Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Drug Charge Flung Back At U.S.
description: The government rejected an American statement listing the country as one of the world's chief sources of illegal drugs. It said the real culprit is the United States, which is by far the largest consumer of drugs, creating a huge demand. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: A Concession On Turbans Calms Protest In Cuba Camp
description: A protest by scores of Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners held at the United States Naval Base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, lost steam today after the American military commander reversed a ban against wearing turbans, which had provoked an outcry.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 20 about Urs Boegli of the International Committee of the Red Cross, the first human rights official to inspect the conditions under which prisoners from Afghanistan are being held at the United States Naval Base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, referred incorrectly to the precedents for the United States' holding of war captives. The prisoners in Cuba are not the first the United States has detained since World War II. In the Korean War, the United States and South Korea briefly maintained separate prisoner camps before they were consolidated under the United Nations. The Americans did not hand the captured soldiers over to the South Koreans.

title: Despite Suit, Dancers Will Dance
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company will perform for the first time in two years of heated legal battles, presenting a program of Graham dances on May 9 at City Center. The program, called ''Indisputably Martha,'' will be presented by the Martha Graham Dance Center, the umbrella organization for the company and its school.

title: Auditor to Pay $217 Million To Settle Suits
description: Arthur Andersen announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $217 million to settle investor lawsuits arising from its role as auditor of the Baptist Foundation of Arizona, a nonprofit company that plaintiffs' lawyers say was a Ponzi scheme that cost investors hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Protects Name
description: Switzerland's failed national airline, Swissair, has moved to bar its former regional carrier, Crossair, from changing its brand name and corporate design to ''Swiss.'' The two companies have been trying to iron out the deal privately, but Swissair, known legally as SAirGroup, said it had to take legal action to protect its creditors' interests. It said the Swissair brand's value was estimated at $390 million at the end of November 2001. Under a government-industry bailout, the remnants of Swissair are to be merged into Crossair at the end of March to form a new national airline.

title: Sports of The Times; Some Stars Don't Know How to Quit
description: MICHAEL JORDAN, arguably the greatest player in N.B.A. history, underwent the first operation of his career on Wednesday, an arthroscopic procedure on his right knee.

title: Meditation and Dancing To the Brazilian Pulse
description: Jazzanova excels at the fine art of organizing. In a series of remixes released over the past five years, the Berlin-based collective has united a wide range of musical genres by finding an unusual common denominator: the Brazilian rhythm of the samba. The group consists of three producers and three D.J.'s, and on Tuesday night one of the D.J.'s, Alexander Barck, performed at Baktun in the West Village. The music he played was meticulously composed -- many of Jazzanova's beats are painstakingly spliced together from hundreds of samples -- but he took a casual approach to the turntables, sometimes pausing between songs so the audience could applaud and anticipate the next beat.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Bulletin Board column of the Education page on Wednesday about a proposal to replace the city's 32 elected school boards with advisory panels misidentified the board that includes Anne MacKinnon, an author of the proposal. It is Community School Board 22 in Brooklyn, not Board 2, which received the proposal.

title: Russia's Latest Export: Bad Jokes About U.S. Chickens
description: Weary, perhaps, of tolerating American diktats on everything from steel exports to NATO expansion, Russian officials are poised to strike a retaliatory blow at one of the United States' soft spots: its thighs. Chicken thighs.

title: Louima Ruling Forces Police to Revisit a Brutal Episode
description: Like a recurring illness, the torture of Abner Louima has come back to afflict a Police Department that had come to view it as a closed, if inglorious, episode from the past.

title: Strategizing By Lawyers Brings Risk Of Reversal
description: When a federal appeals court overturned the obstruction of justice convictions of three officers involved in the Abner Louima case on Thursday, it essentially said the prosecutors had failed only because they charged the men with the wrong crime.

title: Jewish Museum to Add Warning Label on Its Show
description: Faced with a storm of criticism of a coming exhibition with Nazi themes, the Jewish Museum said yesterday that it had a plan intended to satisfy Holocaust survivors who have objected to some of the works without alienating ardent supporters of provocative new art.

title: Toward a Shrine at a Solemn Place
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewery Collusion Accusation
description: The European Commission accused the Dutch brewer Heineken and its Danish counterpart Carlsberg of colluding to avoid head-to-head competition in each company's home beer market. The two brewers agreed not to compete in the other's home territory from 1993 to 1996, the commission contended. Carlsberg admits contacts with Heineken during the period, but said the links were ordinary business discussions. The commission has been investigating the case since spring 2000. A final ruling could be up to two years away.

title: Rangers Look to Old Line For Answers to Their Slump
description: With the Rangers' playoff hopes slipping away, Eric Lindros's line is expected to be reunited this afternoon at Madison Square Garden against the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURFREE, GWENDOLYN
description: MURFREE - Gwendolyn. On March 1, 2002. Director of St. Martha's Episcopal Church Nursery School and Senior Warden of St. Martha's Church Vestry. Devoted mother of Dr. Walter and Judy Handy and Nola Murfree. The family will receive friends Sunday 7-9PM and Monday 2-5 & 7-9PM at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 726 Morris Park Ave Bronx. Religious services tentatively scheduled at St. Martha's Episcopal Church for Tuesday morning.

title: RULING FAVORS GENERIC ANTIDEPRESSANT FROM ANDRX
description: The Andrx Group said a judge ruled that its generic version of GlaxoSmithKline's Wellbutrin antidepressant did not infringe a Glaxo patent, which may clear the way for Andrx to sell a copy of the blockbuster drug as early as midyear, a year earlier than some analysts had projected. Wellbutrin tops $1 billion in annual sales, more than Andrx's total revenue last year. Andrx said the ruling cleared the way for approval of its generic copies of Wellbutrin SR and another version of the same drug, sold as Zyban for quitting smoking. Glaxo said it would appeal the ruling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEER, ALEXANDER W.
description: KEER-Alexander W., 90. Of Highstown, N.J., February 27, 2002 after a brief illness. Husband of Mary Atwater Keer, step-father of Carrington B. and Frederick T. Day and of Anne H. and Edward S. Atwater IV. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions appreciated to Princeton University, Box 46, Princeton, N.J. 08544, or charity of your choice.

title: Skilling's Lawyer Aims at Accuser
description: The lawyer for Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, suggested in a televised interview tonight that an Enron executive who has drawn widespread publicity for asserting that Mr. Skilling was at fault for Enron's collapse was motivated by a lucrative book deal.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about government plans to require tire-pressure warning systems in new cars and trucks gave an erroneous name in some copies for the House subcommittee to which the plans were outlined. It is the House Commerce Subcommittee on Commerce, Trade and Consumer Protection, not on Telecommunications, Trade and Consumer Protection.

title: Brooklyn Orchestra and Union in Impasse
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians have declared an impasse in contract negotiations.

title: Boy Genius? Mother Says She Faked Tests
description: Justin Chapman was the smartest little boy in the world.

title: War and Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Snapshots
description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial In Light Moves Closer To Reality
description: The temporary installation of ''Tribute in Light,'' two luminous nighttime columns that are meant to recall the World Trade Center's place in the Lower Manhattan skyline and to honor those who died and served at ground zero, was approved yesterday by the Battery Park City Authority.

title: Bill Easing Immigration Passes First Test in German Parliament
description: After a bitter debate imbued with election-year politicking, the lower house of Parliament passed a major immigration bill today intended to ease entry for skilled foreign workers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I wouldn't say voters are stupid. But the same voter who wants unlimited services also does not want to pay for it. There's a disconnect.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOBELL, ELIZABETH RODGERS
description: DOBELL-Elizabeth Rodgers. July 13, 1936-March 2, 1992. Remembered and loved every day

title: Ruling Limits Size of Jets at Teterboro Airport
description: The Federal Aviation Administration upheld a rule today that bars a new generation of corporate jets weighing more than 100,000 pounds from using Teterboro Airport.

title: Redskins Sign Armstead As Player Market Opens
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards found himself nearly trapped at a table in an Indianapolis restaurant yesterday morning, besieged for four hours by agents who wanted to pitch their players. So began the N.F.L.'s free-agency period, which, in a scheduling quirk, overlapped with the scouting combine for college players. Such a confluence created a bazaar of agents and team executives, and Edwards called it a buyer's market.

title: State Farm Insurance Loses $5 Billion
description: The State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, the biggest auto and home insurer in the nation, lost $5 billion last year as claims rose more than expected and stock investments declined.

title: Marriott-Cendant Venture

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARIS, KRONBERG, NINA
description: PARIS-KRONBERG-Nina. On February 24, 2002. 1924-2002. The family of Nina Paris-Kronberg mourns the passing of a unique and remarkable woman. Mrs. Paris-Kronberg lived a life of great passion and adventure. She was born in Istanbul, Turkey and was raised in Athens, Greece. She was a professional ballerina and popular dancer in the 1940's in Europe. She and her husband Henri, a restaurateur, lived in Paris with their two sons until they moved to the United States in the mid 1950's. Widowed in her 40's, Mrs. ParisKronberg began an haute couture dress business in the 1960's, under the name of Nina Dimos, maintaining an atelier in Paris and a showroom on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Her clients included many high profile doyennes of the time. Her dresses have been sold recently at auction at Sotheby's. She married her long-time companion Louis Kronberg, the founder of Club ABC Tours. They both traveled extensively throughout the world. Upon the death of her husband she took the position of CEO of Club ABC Tours. Though Mrs. Paris-Kronberg valued tradition and manners greatly, she had an unconventional way of seeing the world and appreciated others who did as well. She moved with grace and lit her ever-present pipe with panache and elegance. Her philosophy of life had elements of the romantic, the practical and the poetic. Her sense of humor was unparalleled to the last days of her life. She battled her illness with great courage and fortitude. She was not one to give in to life's challenges. She met and conquered them. Eventually this final obstacle could not be overcome. She died bravely and with a conviction that life was to be lived to the fullest. Mrs. Paris-Kronberg is survived by her two sons Tom and Robert, their wives, and seven grandchildren. She also leaves one sister, Ellia McInnis, and her niece, Nina Ingold and family. All of them will miss her wisdom, her cooking and her zest for life the rest of their days. Donations in her memory may be made to the NYU Cancer Institute, C/O Dr. Howard Hochster, 160 East 32nd Street, New York, New York 10016.

description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it would remodel its chain of North American retail stores to focus some on toys and others on clothing, furniture and other products that appeal to parents.

description: In promoting the benefits of his proposal to overhaul Social Security, President Bush adopted an example this week that few financial planners would be likely to embrace, and one that more than doubles the potential of the recommendations of his own commission on Social Security.

description: NATO troops returned empty-handed again today after conducting a second high-profile raid to arrest Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader indicted on war crimes charges.

description: Qwest Communications International continues to market itself to Wall Street as the model phone company of the future, but all that investors seem interested in is how the voice and data communications giant plans to survive the present.

description: The European Union will restart the process of approving genetically modified organisms for sale in its 15 member countries, a potential boon for the Monsanto Company, Syngenta and other companies that have had applications held up for years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, PERCY NORWOOD
description: STONE-Percy Norwood, 71. Of New Hartford, CT died unexpectedly in his home on Wednesday, February 27th. Percy (known by all as ''Possum'') was born on January 8, 1931 in New York City. He was the son of the late Percy and Margaret Stone of Westport, CT. Possum grew up in Westport and lived there most of his life until recently buying a beautiful house on a hill in New Hartford. He was a graduate of Staples High School (Class of 1948), received his bachelor's degree at Wesleyan University (1952) and his MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1957. He proudly served his country as an Army Medic during the Korean War from 1953-54. He was a loving family man, successful businessman, avid gardener, historian, storyteller, jogger and an avid sportsfan (Go UCONN Women). Possum was loved by many and touched the hearts of all who had the good fortune of meeting him. He is survived by two sons, Andy Stone and daughter-in-law, Rae Ann, of Burlington, CT, Percy Stone, Jr. of Boonville, CA; a daughter, Elizabeth Stone of Pleasant Hill, CA; four grandchildren, Max, Andrah Dell, Jack of Burlington, CT and Saidie of Pleasant Hill, CA and many close friends. Funeral services will be Monday, March 4th at 10:00 a.m at St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 37 Prospect Rd., New Hartford. Calling hours will be Sunday, March 3rd from 5-7 p.m. at The Shea Funeral Home, 5 Steele Rd., New Hartford, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Nature Conservancy, Connecticut Chapter, 55 High Street, Middletown, CT. 06457.

title: Freedom From the Press
description: The night before the world got the news of Daniel Pearl's death, you could hear another reporter describing the perils of his profession in a talk carried on C-Span. The journalist was Bernard Goldberg, formerly of CBS News and author of the best-selling ''Bias,'' and his story was tragic.

title: New Raids Bring Palestinian Peace Supporter Full Circle
description: On the second day of an extensive Israeli military operation in two Palestinian refugee camps, Hussam Khader, a Palestinian legislator chased out of his apartment by Israeli forces, went from hospital to hospital today, visiting the many wounded here.

title: From France, a Soccer Shogun Stirs Up Japan
description: WITH his tousle of chestnut hair, arms akimbo and streams of invective shouted in French, Philippe Troussier cuts an odd figure on a Japanese soccer field.

title: At Least Ventura Was Able to Keep His Home
description: Robin Ventura left Shea Stadium at the end of a dreary season last October and figured he would not return. Ventura had been one of the prime reasons the Mets finished last in the major leagues in runs, and it was obvious that they would try to unload him for making too many millions and producing too little offense. Ventura took three years of memories with him, guessing there would be little chance to add more.

title: The Book of Esther, According to Handel
description: The Jewish festival of Purim, which was celebrated this year from sundown Monday to sundown Tuesday, commemorates salvation from a plot by Haman, a genocidal maniac who tried to annihilate the Jews of ancient Persia. The episode is related in the biblical book of Esther, which is read complete in synagogues during Purim, and on Tuesday evening, the 92nd Street Y extended the holiday by presenting a Hebrew translation of Handel's musical setting of the story, the oratorio ''Esther.'' The translation was made in 1759, and probably first performed about a month before Handel's death that year, but he had no hand in it, and may not even have known it was being done.

title: The Worsening Drought
description: As the Northeastern drought intensifies -- warm dry days followed by cold dry days -- jurisdictions around the region have begun to make plans for an official drought emergency, with mandatory restrictions in water use, even as they fervently hope for wet weather. Except for the cold and the leafless trees, the region's streams and reservoirs have the look of a hot, dry summer about them, and it is still only the beginning of March.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Strike Over Privatization
description: More than 5,000 workers at the government-owned Korea Electric Power Corporation remained on strike for a fifth day to protest the government's plans to privatize the company. Lee Ho Dong, leader of the union, ignored threats by government officials to arrest the leaders of the strike, warning that privatization would result in mass layoffs. Shin Kook Hwan, minister of commerce, industry and energy, said that the government would guarantee job security but that privatization was nonnegotiable. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: Patti LuPone's Carnegie Hall concert on Thursday evening culminated in a nervy conceptual coup that risked being embarrassing but ended up being the kind of triumph that should be fondly remembered by the audience for years to come.

title: Cigarette Tax Would Cost State Millions, Critic Says
description: Topping the list of things Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is asking for from Albany this year is permission to raise the cigarette tax to $1.50 a pack, a budget-balancing measure that the city is touting as pain-free for the state. But one budget critic, citing the city's own estimates, says the measure could cost the state more than $200 million in lost revenue.

title: Kidnapping Suspect Bears Sign of Militancy Elsewhere
description: When a suspect in the kidnapping and murder of the American journalist Daniel Pearl appeared in a Karachi court today, he was suffering from a bullet wound received in either Afghanistan or Kashmir, the police said, an indication of the breadth of the threat the authorities say they now face.

title: New York's Taxi Drivers Need Disaster Relief
description: In New York City, more than a half-million people depend on yellow cabs every day. But since the economic downturn and the attack on the World Trade Center, the taxi business has been facing hard times.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Survival Of The Unfittest
description: Scientists at Oxford University announced that they had extracted some DNA fragments from their dodo specimen, which has been part of the university's collection for more than 300 years. The DNA is not in good enough condition for a ''Jurassic Park''-style resurrection but can provide clues to the dodo's family tree and its living relatives, Malgosia Nowak-Kemp, the zoologist in charge of the specimen, told Reuters. The last living dodo -- a flightless bird native to the Indian Ocean island of Mauritius rendered extinct after the Dutch settled there -- was seen in 1683. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Comcast Says Its Transition To Internet Network Is Done
description: The Comcast Corporation said yesterday that it had completed its transition of thousand of clients to its own high-speed Internet network and e-mail system -- a months-long process that had been fraught with technical problems and that presented newfound e-mail delays in the last several days.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: The First Saint
description: The Vatican announced that Pope John Paul II would canonize Amabile Lucia Visintainer, giving Brazil, the world's most populous Roman Catholic country, its first saint. Known as Mother Paulina, the Italian-born nun arrived in southern Brazil in 1875 at the age of 10, moving later to So Paulo, where she devoted her life to helping orphans and slaves. The canonization ceremony is to be held on May 19 in Rome. Mery Galanternick (NYT)

For taxpayers seeking the earned-income credit, which benefits the working poor, the odds of an audit last year were about 1 in 47, based on the number who sought the credit in 2000, not 1 in 315. For taxpayers not seeking the credit, the odds were about 1 in 366, not 1 in 431.

description: Plans to use military force to free an American missionary couple kidnapped by Muslim extremists in the southern Philippines have been complicated by the captors' tight control of the hostages and the inexperience of the Philippine military in conducting night raids, senior military officials of both countries say.

description: The Lehman Brothers Holdings investment bank may be moving uptown, but the annual pay of its chief executive and other senior officers has headed south.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Troops Seeking Rebels Enter Sudan
description: Uganda has sent troops across the border into Sudan in search of rebels with the Lord's Resistance Army who have renewed attacks along Uganda's northern border. Uganda has accused Sudan of supporting the rebel group, led by Joseph Kony, which has fought the government since 1988. The rebels want to set up a government based on the 10 Commandments. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: From Brahms's Passion to Contemporary Melancholy
description: The Tokyo String Quartet is offering a series with an interestingly split focus at the 92nd Street Y this season. Its major business is an exploration of the Brahms chamber music repertory, with other musicians joining the ensemble to suit the needs of the music at hand. Each of the four programs also includes a newly commissioned work. In the third installment, the new piece was Joan Tower's ''In Memory,'' her second string quartet. Surrounding it were the two Brahms String Sextets, for which the Tokyo players were joined by Phillip Ying, violist, and David Ying, cellist, from the Ying Quartet.

description: Complexity need not be intimidating. That is the lesson taught by ''Episodes,'' which the New York City Ballet offered on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

description: One of the most fundamental responsibilities of any city government is picking up the trash. Unfortunately, New York City's system of disposing of the 11,000 tons of garbage its residents generate every day is in a state of disarray.

title: Chevrolet Sales Surpass Ford's For First Time In 10 Years
description: Chevrolet outsold the Ford brand in February for the first month in more than a decade, industry figures showed today, further highlighting the resurgence of the General Motors Corporation and the struggles of the Ford Motor Company.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fund Manager Posts Loss
description: Europe's third-largest pension fund manager, Schroders, reported its first annual loss, as stock markets slumped and clients withdrew a net 6 billion in funds. For all of 2001, Schroders lost 8.1 million, compared with a profit of 230 million a year earlier. Funds under management declined to 110 billion, compared with 129.4 billion in 2000. Last year's figure was restated to exclude private equity funds. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Stanislav Libensky, 80; Redefined Glass Art
description: Stanislav Libensky, the Czech artist who with his wife, Jaroslava Brychtova, transformed glass from tabletop decoration to a serious art form in architecture and sculpture, died on Feb. 24 in Zelezny Brod, Czech Republic. He was 80.

title: Witnesses in Corruption Trial Contradict Ex-Police Officer
description: Two police officers testifying in the corruption trial of a former commander gave accounts yesterday that appeared to conflict with that of the key prosecution witness in the case.

title: Dip in Jobless Rate Stirs Some Optimism in Japan
description: Japan's battered economy received a small dose of positive news today, as the jobless rate unexpectedly fell for the first time in a year.

title: Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr. Is Dead at 82; Fought to Improve Health Care for the Poor
description: John L. S. Holloman Jr., a doctor who in his private practice, in leadership roles with medical associations and as head of New York City's hospitals battled for health care for the poor, died on Wednesday in Queens. He was 82 and lived in East Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Rating Cut for Computer Associates
description: The credit rating of Computer Associates International, which is under federal investigation into how it accounted for sales, was cut by the Moody's Investors Service. Moody's said the company's cash flow in the next year would probably not be enough to pay its debt.

title: MORE THAN 200 DIE IN 3 DAYS OF RIOTS IN  WESTERN  INDIA
description: Three days of the worst Hindu-Muslim violence in nearly a decade has left more than 200 people dead in western India, 28 of them today, as enraged mobs burned people alive and left the country fearful that the rioting would spread.
