description: To the Editor:

title: FLEETBOSTON LOST $521 MILLION IN ARGENTINA LAST YEAR
description: The FleetBoston Financial Corporation lost $521 million doing business in Argentina last year, in contrast to earning $120 million there in 2000, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. FleetBoston said it might ''adjust its strategy'' in the country, which defaulted on debt and devalued its currency. FleetBoston set aside $750 million pretax last year to cover unpaid loans in Argentina and will not predict how future political and economic instability will influence operations there, the filing said. FleetBoston's chief financial officer, Gene McQuade, said Jan. 29 that the company had not ruled out leaving Argentina, but had no plans to do so. FleetBoston is Argentina's sixth-biggest bank, with 133 branches.

title: Religion Journal; Yes, God Is Everywhere, Even at the Local Mall
description: To be pastor of a church in a shopping mall, it helps to think like the Rev. Paul Knight of Grand Forks, N.D. He loves ministering to mall customers who, shopping bags or carts in tow, drop by his house of worship in the Grand Cities Mall.

title: Centers for Troubled Foster Children Need More Money, Administrator Says
description: Testifying in a state lawmaker's investigation into institutions for troubled foster children, administrators and advocates called on the state government today to increase funding so that more and better qualified staff could be hired.

title: Still Living a Charmed Life
description: A Hollywood screenwriter could not have scripted a better story than what happened to Simon Ammann of Switzerland during the last three weeks. Ammann, a boyish 20-year-old ski jumper, not only looks like Harry Potter, but he also revealed the magical talents of the flying wizard as he won two Olympic gold medals in Salt Lake City.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Cable Concern
description: Britain's second-largest cable company, Telewest Communications, reported a wider loss for 2001, as it wrote down the value of some assets. The company lost 1.9 billion ($2.7 billion) in 2001, compared with 706 million in 2000. The loss included a 1.13 billion write-off on the value of Flextech, a business Telewest acquired in April 2000. Sales for 2001 rose 17 percent, to 1.3 billion, compared with 1.1 billion the year earlier, as the company added subscribers and persuaded existing customers to pay more for services. Shares of Telewest fell 1.25 percent, to 16.5 pence. Some investors expect Telewest to follow in the footsteps of NTL, Britain's largest cable company, which is reorganizing to help reduce debt.

title: Energy Firms Were Heard On Air Rules, A Critic Says
description: In considering new rules for enforcing the Clean Air Act, a senior official at the Energy Department consulted 64 energy corporations and industry trade groups and only one environmental group, a Democratic congressman charged today.

title: AT&T WIRELESS REDUCES ITS SALES FORECAST
description: AT&T Wireless Services reduced sales and cash-flow forecasts for this year after the company trimmed prices and increased free minutes to win customers. The company said that wireless sales would rise by a ''low double digits'' percentage, and a spokesman, David Caouette, said growth would be in the low teens.'' The company also is paying $285 million to buy the rest of a wireless venture in Philadelphia. The company agreed to buy the 49 percent of AT&T Wireless PCS of Philadelphia that it did not already own from the Exelon Corporation. Exelon, which is based in Chicago, said it expected a gain of about $120 million, or 37 cents a share, for the sale. The venture was started in 1996.

title: Fired by C.I.A., He Says Agency Practiced Bias
description: As a young case officer at the Central Intelligence Agency, Jeffrey Sterling says, he was eager to begin his first overseas posting, in Bonn, and he relished his secret assignment to recruit Iranians as spies.

title: Damning (Yet Desiring) Mickey and the Big Mac
description: ''Why do they hate us?'' One answer to that now familiar question may be its opposite: ''Why do they love us?''

title: Monthly Killings Are Down To a 40-Year Low in the City
description: The New York Police Department recorded 32 murders last month, the lowest number of killings in a one-month period since the city began tracking crime statistics on a monthly basis in 1962, officials said yesterday.

title: Steel's 40 Percent Solution
description: President George W. Bush faces an important choice on steel. He can act to level the playing field for American steel producers and workers. Or he can allow years of unfair foreign trade to destroy a critical domestic industry.

title: They Give, but They Also Take: Voters Muddle States' Finances
description: The voters of Arizona have spoken. They want lower taxes. They also want higher taxes -- but only if they go to the state's beleaguered public schools, consistently ranked among the worst in the nation.

title: Hyundai, in Reverse, Says It Does Not Intend to Work With Union
description: The Hyundai Motor Company, which is planning to build its first plant in the United States, has retracted a statement made earlier this week in which a spokesman said the company would have a cordial approach to the United Automobile Workers.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Awaiting Evidence In Sex-Abuse Case
description: The United Nations refugee agency said it did ''not have enough evidence to discipline, let alone fire'' the half-dozen West African aid workers who have been accused of forcing child refugees to provide sex in exchange for food or aid. Kris Janowski, a spokesman, said the agency ''has its hands tied'' until an inquiry is finished. The agency is adding women to its local staff in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone to try to prevent any recurrence, he said. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Woman Charged With Arson in December Fire
description: A 21-year-old woman has been arrested in connection with a December fire here, one of three that displaced nearly 100 people. The woman remains a suspect in the other two, officials said today.

title: Pianist Cancels Concert
description: The pianist Roger Woodward has canceled his concert at the Miller Theater tonight because of an injury. The concert will not be rescheduled, and refunds are available from the Miller's box office: (212) 854-7799.

title: Bush, in Iowa, Urges Patience in War Effort and Reform of Pension Plans
description: President Bush brushed off criticism today from Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic majority leader, who has said that the United States will have failed in its war on terror if Osama bin Laden is not found.

title: Rowland Tries To Ease Pain And Costs Of Enron Deal
description: Seeking to minimize the election-year fallout from a costly failed deal between the Connecticut state trash authority and the Enron Corporation, Gov. John G. Rowland announced today that he had appointed a panel to find a way to avoid a rate increase for trash collection that would cost many Connecticut households an extra $50 a year.

description: The only hint of what really goes on inside the Flushing offices of David Scheinfeld, attorney at law, is a giant red ceramic heart perched on a balcony of the three-story building.

title: Bunker System of Cold War Is Back in Use After Sept. 11
description: The Bush administration has dispatched dozens of career government employees to underground bunkers outside Washington since Sept. 11 to try to ensure that the government would continue to function in case of a catastrophic nuclear attack on the capital, senior administration officials said today.

title: Senate Democrats Drop Voter Sign-In at Polls
description: Senate Democrats said today that they were dropping their demand that certain new voters be allowed to establish their identities at the polls by merely signing a form. The concession removes a major obstacle to the passage of a bipartisan bill to clean up the nation's election procedures.

title: As great paintings disappear, lesser works are upgraded : The Old Masters' domino game
description: NEW YORK  Think of the domino game and you get the idea of the huge readjustment that is now going on in the market for Old Master paintings.

title: Italy's small jewelry designers shine
description: MILAN  When it comes to producing sensational jewelry, Italy wins hands down. As the foremost manufacturer and exporter of mass-produced and crafted gold jewelry, the country is also the largest single consumer market in Europe and a leading trendsetter in jewelry design.

title: Nassau Planning to Revamp Realty-Tax Refund System
description: Nassau County has many fiscal problems, but by far the biggest stems from its antiquated property assessments, based partly on construction costs in 1938, long before modern materials like plasterboard, vinyl siding and thermal windows.

title: Iverson, Sixth Man for a Night, Crushes the Nets
description: Another woeful start led to another loss for the Nets tonight.

title: On a Fast Runway, Pate Really Takes Off
description: Many runners have talked about how fast the track is in the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Hardly anyone said how fast the long-jump runway was. Miguel Pate was so fast on it last night that he became the third-longest long jumper in indoor track and field history.

title: Judge Facing Pornography Charges Is Unopposed on Ballot
description: Judge Ronald C. Kline, charged with child molestation and under house arrest on federal charges of possessing child pornography, might seem to have an unlikely shot at re-election. Not so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOTT, ROBERT REVEREND
description: LOTT-Robert Reverend. We at Herrick, Feinstein LLP wish to pay tribute to Reverend Robert V. Lott, an extraordinary person and treasured client. Father Lott cared deeply about those in need, including particularly the elderly and the poor, and just as important, developed practical ways of helping. As Chair and President of SFDS Development Corp, Father Lott built hundreds of units of low-income housing. He was a pioneer in creating New York's first affordable assisted living facility and we were honored to work with him on this wonderful project. A handsome facility on 5th Ave & 108 St stands as a living testament to his vision. We will miss his unique sense of mission and on a personal level, his graciousness and kindness. He accomplished much and inspired many. His memory will live on.

title: Burning Diesel Is Cited in Fall Of 3rd Tower
description: Massive structural beams that functioned as a sort of bridge to hold up the 47-story skyscraper known as 7 World Trade Center were compromised in a disastrous blaze fed by diesel fuel, leading to the building's collapse on Sept. 11, investigators have concluded in a preliminary report.

title: Russia's Leader Says He Supports American Military Aid for Georgia
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said today that he supported the American military initiative in the post-Soviet state of Georgia because it would help rid the region of terrorists operating on Russia's frontier and in Chechnya, where Russia has been fighting rebels allied with Islamic extremists.

title: Near Angolan Rebel's Battleground, Suffering Survives Him
description: Long before the aging guerrilla fighter Jonas Savimbi was finally cornered and killed last week, this town was paying a punishing price for the Angolan government's unrelenting pursuit of its archenemy. But even with his death that toll only shows signs of mounting.

title: Archdiocese to Yield List of Sex Accusers
description: A month after the Archdiocese of Boston began giving prosecutors the names of almost 90 active or retired Roman Catholic priests accused of sexually molesting children, the church today agreed to turn over the names of the people they are accused of abusing.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Corrections
description: A subheading yesterday with an article about a new study of health effects of radioactive fallout from nuclear weapons tests from 1951 to 1963 misstated a finding of the study, by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. As the article noted, the study suggested that global fallout might eventually be linked to more than 11,000 cancer deaths in the United States, not ''up to'' 11,000 deaths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREUHAFT, PEARL
description: TREUHAFT-Pearl. Of Weehawken, New Jersey, died peacefully on Thursday, Feb. 28, at the age of ninety. Dear sister-inlaw of Elaine Treuhaft, beloved aunt of Laurie and Robert, and wonderful great-aunt to Layla, May, Melanie & Miles. Cherished by all of her family and her many friends. Funeral services at 11:30 A.M. at ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey. Memorial donations may be made to Deborah Hospital Foundation, 212 Trenton Road, Browns Mills, New Jersey 08015.

description: With his team beginning a seven-game stretch against struggling teams, Coach Peter Laviolette implored the Islanders tonight to treat each remaining game this season as the seventh game of a playoff series.

title: Both Sides Express Confidence About New Schwarz Trial
description: There appears to be one act left in the long-running drama of the Abner Louima case: the retrial of Charles Schwarz.

title: Hernndez Impresses Both Yanks and Scouts
description: The scouts sat shoulder to shoulder in the sixth row of Dunedin Stadium today, raising their radar guns as if they were on a firing line. Scouts are a presence at every spring training game, so it was not unusual to see 15 or more watching this one. But teams needing a starting pitcher now have a fresh report about one who may be available: Orlando Hernndez.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERBER, JOAN H.
description: MERBER-Joan H. Died in Manhattan's NYU Medical Center on February 28, 2002 after a long battle with cancer. Born November 27, 1939 to Grete and Norman Heger in the Inwood section of Manhattan. Joan went to PS 52, G.W. High School, CCNY for her Bachelor's in Education and LIU for her Master's. Joan lived in Rockland County for 27 years, working for various county agencies. She also lived in Park Ridge, NJ, Flushing and Jackson Heights. She is survived by her husband Charles, of 42 years as well as her loving children Laurie (Michael) Zeilberger of Suffern, NY and Kenneth (Sherry) Merber of Livingston, New Jersey. She is also survived by her beloved grandchildren Jonathan and Alex as well as her sister, Ruth (Dr. Larry) Schuster and their children David, Ilana, and Rachel also of Livingston, NJ. Funeral Sunday, 1 PM at Temple Beth Torah, Upper Nyack, NY. Shiva will be observed at the Merber residence in New City through Monday evening and then in Livingston, NJ through Tuesday evening. For more information call Hellman Memorial Chapels: 845-356-8600.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Klamath River Panel
description: President Bush created a panel charged with resolving disputes over water use in the Klamath River Basin of Oregon and California. Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton will direct the efforts to satisfy farmers, environmentalists and Indian tribes who were at odds over water distribution during a drought last year. To save rare fish, the government stopped sending water for irrigation from Upper Klamath Lake last year, pleasing environmentalists but angering farmers. A recent study said the ban on irrigation had been unwarranted. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit At Paribas
description: Despite the global slowdown, the big French bank BNP Paribas reported a 19 percent rise in fourth-quarter net income, to 866 million euros ($752 million), as a result of cost- cutting and investment gains. Net income for all of 2001 dropped 2.6 percent, to 4.02 billion euros, despite a rise of almost 15 percent in the cost of covering risk, particularly in the United States, to 1.3 billion euros. Michel Pebereau, the chief executive, above, said economic uncertainty made it difficult to forecast the bank's performance this year. BNP Paribas paid $2.4 billion in December to acquire the United California Bank, which it plans to merge with BancWest. It bought BancWest for $2.4 billion last year. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: By Barring Religious Garb, Singapore School Dress Code Alienates Muslims
description: One month ago, on the first day of school, four 7-year-old girls carried out the most potent act of civil disobedience this tightly controlled nation has seen in years.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: In California, a Turf Fight Over Smog
description: Squinting into what looks like beige cotton candy in a vain search for the nearby Sierra Nevada, it is easy to understand the anger of pollution control officials here in California's agricultural heartland, the Central Valley.

title: Bloomberg Pushes Plan For Control Over Schools
description: Sounding confident that he could overcome resistance by the teachers' union and some members of the State Assembly, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pressed forward yesterday with his campaign to win sole authority to appoint the chancellor of New York City schools and run the school system directly.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Industry Seeks Spotted-Owl Review
description: A timber industry group said it would sue the federal government unless it reviewed the protected status of the marbled murrelet and spotted owl. Chris West, spokesman for the American Forest Resource Council, in Portland, said the government had not conducted mandated periodic reviews of the species listing under the Endangered Species Act. The Department of Interior has 60 days to respond. Approval of protection for the spotted owl in the early 1990's stopped logging in millions of acres in the Northwest. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Fred Decr -- Restaurateur, 82
description: Fred Decr, former co-owner of the Manhattan restaurant La Caravelle, died on Feb. 20 in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 82.

title: World Briefing | World: Mine Treaty Seen As Success
description: On the third anniversary of the implementation of a global treaty banning land mines, the International Committee of the Red Cross said there had been a sharp decline in land mine casualties. So far 122 countries have signed the pact, which bars the use, production, stockpiling and transfer of antipersonnel mines. Some 31 countries have said they have destroyed all land mine stocks and 22 more are doing so. But the Red Cross warned that mines continue to be a deadly hazard in many parts of the world, including Afghanistan. The United States has not signed the treaty. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Stocks Flex Some Muscle, Ending Week With Big Gains
description: The stock markets surged yesterday, ending higher for the week, as technology shares posted sharp gains and better-than-expected data provided evidence that the economy appeared to be recovering.

description: To the Editor:

title: Chuck's Place
description: RECENTLY, Charles E. Schumer, the senior senator from New York, had a problem on his hands. Alison, his 12-year-old daughter, had been asked out on a date.

title: Previous U.S. Deaths
description: The number of American service members killed by hostile fire while engaged in the war on terrorism reached two today, with the Pentagon's announcement of the death of an American soldier in Afghanistan. The soldier's name was not released.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASKIEWICZ, LEON J.
description: WASKIEWICZ-Leon J. Of Eastchester, NY on March 4, 2002, age 46. Beloved husband of Peggy Grubert Waskiewicz. Dear father of Meg and Michael. Beloved son of Betty. Brother of Ann Marie Grimaldi and the late Robert. Devoted nephew of The Uncle Joe and Aunt Millie. Also surviving are many loved nieces and nephews. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, 2-4 and 7-9 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe, on Thursday, March 7 at 9:45 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Tuckahoe Scholarship Fund.

title: DataBank; A Market Lifted by Economic Data
description: A barrage of positive economic reports propelled stocks higher last week, as investors bet that the data signaled the end of the recession.

title: 9 Hijackers Scrutinized
description: Nine of the 19 men who hijacked four airplanes on Sept. 11 were singled out for special scrutiny at airports that morning under aviation-security guidelines. But because their baggage contained no explosives and their document irregularities were not glaring, the hijackers were allowed to board the planes, which crashed into the World Trade Center, the Pentagon and a field in Pennsylvania. Government officials said things might be different if hijackers tried a similar plan today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTEL, MAYME DORFMAN
description: GERSTEL-Mayme Dorfman. 92 years of age. Died on March 4th. Beloved wife and partner for 71 years of Julius. Devoted mother of Joel & Deanne, Joanne and Joel. Grandmother of Sharon, Jeffrey and Karen Gerstel, Harry and Kate Merker. Great-grandmother of Dylan and Alexandra. Loving sister of Sophie and Sam. Graveside services Tuesday 12:45 P.M. Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACHSCHEFES, HERBERT
description: MACHSCHEFES-Herbert. Joined his beloved wife Hilda in heaven on December 22, 2001. He is survived by his sister Gisela Nollstadt, his two children Karl Machschefes and Nora Soares, both of West Sacramento, and five grandchildren. Herbert was born in Berlin, Germany, on August 15, 1913. He lived, worked and married in New York City from 1949 to 1964. He worked as an International Financial Officer for Sumitomo Bank and retired in 1982. He was a member of the Green Mountain Club in Vermont. Memorial Services were held on Thursday, January 24, in San Francisco.

title: Israelis Say Arms Are Found In Search of 2 Refugee Camps
description: The Israeli army said its soldiers found six makeshift rockets and stores of bomb-making chemicals today as they continued ransacking this camp, punching holes through walls as they hunted house-to-house for Palestinian militants and munitions.

title: To Wait or to Flee
description: Your article about the Hazara tribespeople trapped in their ancient mountain homes kept me reading, oblivious to everything until I finished it. The story could hardly have been more effective -- or more dreadful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ALEN, CANDACE A.
description: VAN ALEN-Candace A. The International Debutante Ball Committees and Margaret Joyce Hedberg cherish the memory of Candace A. Van Alen, our beloved Honorary Chairman for 32 years.

title: Keeping It Confidential
description: AS a girl in Queens in the 1970's Harriet P. Pearson, ''Star Trek'' fan and nature lover, thought she might become an environmentalist. Instead, she has wound up, at 38, as the chief privacy officer for I.B.M.

description: NINA SIMONE'S 69th birthday was the perfect excuse:

title: Some Decide to Skip League's Workouts
description: Before this weekend's N.F.L. scouting combine in Indianapolis, the executive director of the players' union, Gene Upshaw, wrote an open letter to the agents who represent about 325 draft-eligible players. Many of these athletes went on to the event, which began Thursday and ends tomorrow. There, they are weighed, tested and timed as they try to improve their prospects for the draft in April.

title: Hard Work, Little Glory, but Still Game
description: COACH JIM CALHOUN leaned against the basket at the southwest end of an empty Gampel Pavilion during an afternoon practice last month in Storrs and, in an unmistakable Boston accent, issued uninterrupted instructions to the starting players of his University of Connecticut men's basketball team as they ran a half-court offense.

title: Postings: Sellers Must Provide Information; Disclosure Law Takes Effect
description: A state law that requires sellers of many one- to four-family residences in New York State to provide buyers with detailed information about the property went into effect last Friday. The Property Condition Disclosure Act requires sellers to provide a disclosure statement to a prospective buyer before contracts are signed. Sales involving co-ops, condominiums, raw land and new construction -- as well as transactions involving spouses, co-owners, government entities and estates -- are not covered.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Roman Tsukerman, Mineola, N.Y., Feb. 9, 2002

description: MEREDITH M. STEWART is trying to wrestle some good and perhaps some laughs -- out of the Enron debacle.

description: GALCHUS-Robert P., The Rev., C.M., died at St. Catherine's Infirmary, Philadelphia, PA on March 3, 2002. He is survived by his sisters, Helen Galchus and Antonina ''Tess'' Reseska. Viewing will be held at the Community Chapel, Vincentian Residence of St. John's University, 8000 Utopia Parkway, Jamaica, NY, Wednesday, March 6, 2002, 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM, and Thursday, March 7, 2002 prior to A Celebrated Mass of Christian Burial at 10:30 AM. Interment, St. Joseph's Seminary, Princeton, NJ.

title: It's Corseting, It's Cosseting
description: Corsets, the fashion-victim -- requisite of last fall, have now evolved into a more wearable construct: corset-lacing detail on leather accessories. For the waist-conscious, Anna Sui has a metal-studded brown leather belt (below; $124 at Anna Sui New York), while Palmyra Swanley's multistrip cinchers have contrasting top-stitching and come in a two-inch width ($248) or four-inch width ($298, both at Henri Bendel). Feet can be similarly bound at will in woven pointy-toed shoes by Miu Miu ($330), Versace's camel eel pumps (right; $645) and Gianni Barbato's cone-heeled linen-and-kid sandals ($270 at Barneys New York). But it is the season's new batch of Balenciaga-inspired handbags that truly carry the look. Hogan's zip-up Gaucho pocketbook ($790) and Ferragamo's camel denim tote ($890 at Saks Fifth Avenue) both sport lanyard whipstitching on seams and handles.

title: Back to Basics on Security
description: Many crime-prevention gadgets are available to businesses, but a study suggests that simple precautions are more effective.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Page 57 of The Times Magazine today with an article about N.B.A. players from foreign countries misspells one player's given name. He is Predrag Drobnjak, not Pedrag.

title: Loans From Parents Hide Assorted Strings
description: SHAREHOLDERS and rubber-neckers may gawk at the multilayerd financial shenanigans at Enron, but many people have firsthand experience with an even more nebulous transaction: a loan from parents. Sometimes it's a loan, sometimes a gift. Sometimes there are no strings attached. Sometimes the strings are long enough to spin you like a top.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCINO, DAN M.
description: MANCINO-Dan M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Dan M. Mancino, associated with The Times from February 1960 until retiring in June 2001.

title: Irvington Bans V-Word in Play's Ads
description: THEY'RE tacked onto the utility poles that line Main Street here, and posted in the windows of businesses. There are several larger versions along Route 9 near town. You can read all the words but one. It starts with a ''V'' but the rest is obscured by neon-colored cardboard.

title: Jacqueline Donovan: She Kept the Party Going
description: At the bar that night, everyone else at the Keefe, Bruyette & Woods table was young, male and in investment banking. The interloper, merry and unintimidated, was 34, female and a temporary secretary at the firm. But with her party sparkle and give-and-take humor, Jacqueline Donovan swiftly became an honorary member of the club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTHEIMER, GLORIA
description: HARTHEIMER-Gloria. Of Hackensack, formerly of Dumont, N.J. on March 4, 2002. Beloved wife of Louis. Devoted mother of Richard, Fred, Walter, David, Peter and Debra Ellison Gass. Loving grandmother of Julia and Joline. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park St, Hackensack, on Wednesday at 12 noon. Should friends desire, contributions to Englewood Hospital Hospice Program would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAWITT, KURT C., M.D.
description: RAWITT-Kurt C., M.D. Devoted husband of Regina, loving father of Ronald (Jean), Tamara, Peggy (Philip) and proud grandfather of Jonathan and Benjamin.

title: Private Sector; Prospecting, After the Gold Rush
description: ONE day last April, after the venture capital wellspring had nearly run dry, a few software engineers were inspecting a modest office in Silicon Valley to house their dream for striking it rich. Their real estate agent mentioned that he had just read ''The New New Thing,'' a biography of the Internet start-up wizard Jim Clark that already stood as a eulogy to an era.

title: Personal Business; Schools Extend a Hand to Middle-Class Parents
description: WHEN Rick Velleu and Joy Jacobson attended a fund-raiser last fall for the Nursery School at the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, they didn't expect to receive any money. They had already put their son Jesse, now 5, through the private school for two years, paying $3,550 in annual tuition, and were about to enroll Leo, who is 3. But they learned that night that financial aid might be available for people like them.

title: Rambling Round a World That's Gone Biennialistic
description: AS the number of international biennials, triennials and other similar art spectacles continues to rise, anyone trying to attend them all would embark on an endless art junket.

title: Introduction
description: Readers were appalled by the situation of an Afghan community caught in the cross-fire of war. Others defended pilots who, many said, got a bad rap in the United Airlines article. And our Gary Condit mail yielded no support for the controversial congressman.

title: Peachtree Street
description: In his exploration of dreams, Freud compared the mind to an ancient city, its many layers, one buried beneath the next, revealed only by the archaeological investigations of a psychotherapist. Now, however, it's not our dreaming mind that resembles a city; rather, our cities have to come to resemble our dreaming minds -- jumbled, chaotic, built upon an obscure system of nonlogical associations.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Evening Hours column last Sunday about a Feb. 21 preview for the Armory Show 2002, an art fair, misidentified the subject of the nude painting shown with David McDermott. It was Cary Grant, not Rock Hudson.

title: A Spirited Way to Take On The Ever-Dangerous Lopez
description: Five grandmasters tied for first place in the Aeroflot Open International Tournament in Moscow, Feb. 4 to 11. They were two American citizens formerly of the Soviet Union, Gregory Kaidanov of Lexington, Ky., and Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh; one Russian, Aleksandr Gritschuk; one Belarusian, Aleksandr Aleksandrov; and one longtime Swiss citizen, Vadim Milov. Each was awarded a prize of $10,000 out of a total prize fund of $150,000.

title: Law Firms' Marquees Bring No Advantage
description: Suggesting that the marquee value of a law firm helps to advance a client's cause [''New Flag Atop L.I. Legal Hill,'' Feb. 24] does a disservice to both the legal system and the public. Judges decide cases based upon the facts and law adduced at trial. Government agencies decide applications based upon the merit of their content. A lawyer's competency, not celebrity or connection, best serves the client. To think otherwise ignores the real and fundamental role of lawyers in our society.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDBERG, HARRY
description: GOLDBERG-Harry. January 6, 1906-March 5, 1952 Remembered. His son, Stuart

title: The Return of a Popular Italian Place
description: NORTHPORT diners who love stylish Northern Italian food have reason to rejoice. La Capannina is back. The sign outside the white house by the side of Route 25A reads ''since 1974.'' That's not the whole story. In 1998 the nearly quarter-of-a-century-old spot closed and was replaced by Traviata. After just three years it, too, shut its doors. The original owner of La Capannina, the landlord of the building, has decided to give it another try.

title: Building Crosswalk Confidence: Maestro! The Street Is Yours!
description: AS a police recruit last year, Marty Garcia's first time out in public in uniform was directing traffic at the corner of Broad Street and Liberty in Meriden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEARD, JOSEPHUS SIMMONS II.
description: BEARD-Josephus Simmons II. Former President of IBM World Trade Corporation Asia and United States Navy Lieutenant Commander, WW II and Korea. Died March 4th, 2002 in Jacksonville, FL. Former resident of Rye, NY, Atlanta, GA, and Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. Beloved husband of 59 years to Jean Otey Beard, loving father of James Beard of Little Rock, Ark, Blaine Trump of NYC, Josephus Beard of Stamford, CT, adored grandfather of Christopher Trump Retchin, Scott and Lelia Barden, Lauren and Ansley Beard, father-in-law to Robert Trump, Lannette Beard, Judy Hefner Beard and Robert Barden. Loved dearly by his family and friends he will be greatly missed by all. Memorial services will be held 2:00 PM Friday at Christ Episcopal Church, 400 San Juan Drive, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL.

title: Pushing 30 And Still Homebound
description: COOING over her infant son, a mother tells him, ''You're such a cutie, you can live here forever!'' So why would darling Tanguy, when we next see him 28 years later, be in a hurry to flee the happy nest, with its wraparound view of the Paris skyline? Why move out when you have a thesis to finish, your girlfriends are welcome at the breakfast table and maman still does the laundry?

title: China Punishes a Christian Home for the Aged
description: Alarmed by unauthorized church services, officials in a northern suburb of Beijing have cut off the electricity for a small Christian-run home for the aged and are threatening to shut off the water supply unless the home is disbanded.

title: Confounding Expectations, Political Neophyte Closes Gap in California Governor's Race
description: The Republican primary for governor is not until Tuesday, but Bruce Cain, a political scientist at the University of California at Berkeley, speaks for many here by saying he has already placed this remarkable campaign in his political hall of fame.

title: Emergency Response Plans Died With Shoreham
description: Senators Chuck Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton are seeking federal financing to protect the Plum Island laboratory from a terrorist assault that could unleash potentially deadly biotoxins across Long Island. Congressman Steve Israel has proposed federal aid to implement mass evacuation plans for the Island, and Matthew Crosson, the Long Island Association president, recently argued [''The Island's Economic Issues,'' opinion, Jan. 27] that the state should appropriate millions to expand and update the region's emergency response plans.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit with the Cuttings column last Sunday, about the Philadelphia flower show, misstated the name of the company that provided the photographs. It is Beds & Borders Inc., not Bed & Borders.

title: A Restaurant Says Ciao, but a Mural Is Forever
description: First, a calming note to those who grew to love it over the years: It's still there. And the landlord says it's there to stay.

title: Mary Stuart, 76, a Star In 2 Soap Operas, Is Dead
description: Mary Stuart, a veteran actress and pioneer of soap operas who spent 35 years as the star of one daytime series built around her, died on Thursday at her home in New York. She was 76.

title: Seattle Signs Dilfer To 4-Year Deal
description: The Seattle Seahawks signed Trent Dilfer to a four-year contract and will make him their No. 1 quarterback heading into training camp.

title: Court Upholds Law On Pine Barrens
description: Judge Thomas C. Platt of Federal District Court in Central Islip last week upheld the 1993 state law that created the 100,000-acre Long Island Pine Barrens state preserve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRORBAUGH, WELLS JR.
description: DRORBAUGH-Wells Jr., 81. Died Sunday, February 17, 2002. He is survived by a daughter and son-inlaw, Hilary and Michael Propst; a son and daughter-in-law, Daniel and Marilyn Drorbaugh and their children Thomas and Katharine, two brothers, Dr. James Drorbaugh and Leonard Drorbaugh, and many devoted nieces and nephews. Memorial contributions may be made to the YWCA Tumblebus Fund, c/o YMCA/YWCA of Princeton, Paul Robeson Place, Princeton, NJ 08540; Friends of the Princeton Library, 1 Washington Rd, Princeton, NJ 08544; The Princeton University Rowing Assoc., C/O Alfred G. Piranian, 41 Callowhill Road, Chalfont, PA. 18914-2101.

title: Buy! Buy! But the World Won't End if You Don't
description: ONCE upon a time, all you had to do was build a better mousetrap. Today, what supposedly counts is how well you market that mousetrap.

description: 'James Biederman: Paintings and Drawings'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, CHAYA RIFKA
description: BERGER-Chaya Rifka. The Officers and members of the New Synagogue of Fort Lee mourn the loss of our beloved rabbi's mother. Born in 1911 in Jerusalem, she will be interred there alongside her beloved husband, Rabbi Baruch Berger. She was from two of the oldest and most prestigious families in Jerusalem, the Eisenbachs and the Hamburgers. Survived by her children, Miriam and Louis Fruchter, Rabbi Meir and Miriam, Samuel and Ronnee, Isaac, Cantor Leon and Francine, Rabbi Moshe and Karen, eight grandchldren and six great grandchildren. Donations may be made to the New Synagogue of Fort Lee, 1585 Center Ave., Fort Lee, NJ 07024, or JOY, Jewish Outreach and Intervention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNINGS, RUTH BAKER
description: JENNINGS-Ruth Baker. On March 1, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Milton S. Jennings. Loving mother of Ellen and Paolo, John and Rosemary and Richard and Nancy. Cherished grandmother of Peter and Joni, Nicholas, Annie, Sally, Tory, Aubrey, Tiane and Gillian. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral service will be held on Monday, March 4, at 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROSCH, MARJORIE MACMILLAN
description: FROSCH-Marjorie MacMillan. Died on February 26, 2002, in Charlottesville, VA. She was 75 years old. Mrs. Frosch moved to Charlottesville in 1997 from New York, where she resided in Manhattan and Quogue, LI. She is survived by her daughters: Juliana Frosch, & husband Jim Arrington of Nellysford, VA; Phoebe Frosch of Charlottesville, VA; Suzanna Frosch and husband Blake Tovin of Palisades, NY. Seven grandchildren, sister Betty Thompson of Guilford, CT. Her husband Aaron R. Frosch died in 1989. A graveside service will take place at the Quogue, LI Cemetery, March 16 at noon. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that memorial contributions be made to The Southampton Town Wildfowl Association, Marjorie Frosch Memorial, PO Box 492, Quogue, New York 11959.

title: Bar Mitzvahs and Their Meanings
description: The excess described in ''Putting Together a Big Bar Mitvah'' [Feb. 24] is a natural consequence in a community that thinks it's normal for 3-year-olds to go to 25 birthday parties (of 30 children each) per year. Though these parents are doing their children an injustice, the social pressure to conform makes it difficult for the few parents who wish to buck the tide.

title: Feb. 25-March 2: NATIONAL; ENRON EARNINGS, AFTER ALL
description: The bankrupt Enron Corporation found a way to cash in on its bad reputation: the Houston Astros will pay it $2.1 million to be able to stop calling their ballpark Enron Field. But executives can still watch the games; Enron paid $90,000 last month for 35 season tickets. Among the people unlikely to use them are Ben F. Glisan Jr., a former treasurer reportedly cooperating with prosecutors, and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former president, who told a Senate panel that while there were ''perpetrators'' responsible for Enron's downfall, he was not one of them. Floyd Norris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNOFF, STANLEY
description: CHARNOFF-Stanley. The Maimonides Medical Center family extends our deepest sympathy on the passing of Dr. Stanley Charnoff, a longtime member of our medical staff, having served Maimonides for nearly four decades. To his son Judah, also a member of our medical staff, and the entire Charnoff family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Martin D. Payson, Chairman Stanley Brezenoff, President

title: Crawling Out of Recession
description: The major economies of the world are at present like trains side by side at a station. One or the other may be moving forward a bit, but it's hard for passengers looking out the window to tell whether it's their train or the one on the next track that is actually moving. Things are that slow, and may remain so for a time.

title: More Dispatches From the Parking Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Beasts of Burden: 15 Pounds of Books to Go
description: IN 25 years as a middle school principal in Cromwell, H. B. Dumeer has watched as textbooks have grown larger and backpacks heavier, with no corresponding size gains in the children carrying them.

title: She's Out Of the Closet. Now What?
description: ROSIE O'DONNELL, the talk-show host known as the Queen of Nice, performed at Caroline's Comedy Club in New York last Monday night. During her act, part of a benefit for cancer research, Ms. O'Donnell engaged an audience member in conversation outside the prepared comic routine.

title: Saving at Wal-Mart, But Paying a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Into Thin Air
description: Let me get this straight: United Airlines overexpanded to the tune of $22 billion to get younger and cheaper pilots, overplayed yield management, not to mention the hub-and-spoke system, paid a consultant $7 million ''to rename United's parent the Allegis Corporation,'' hired too many pilots, then wasted money training them because too many were fired (Roger Lowenstein, Feb. 17). Who exactly is minding the store? Blaming the pilots for United's demise is like blaming Enron's rank and file for not taking pay cuts to save Enron. I'm tired of hearing about employees losing their jobs or being expected to take pay cuts to make up for losses caused by bad decisions made by grossly overpaid execs. I imagine pilots are too.

description: CLAIRE MARVEL

title: Former County Official Denied Yonkers Personnel Post
description: The Yonkers City Council voted last week against hiring Jay B. Hashmall, the former deputy county executive, as the city's commissioner of personnel.

title: Bar Mitzvahs and Their Meanings
description: I am outraged that The New York Times would so blatantly distort the Jewish ritual of bar mitzvah by prominently featuring ''Putting Together a Big Bar Mitzvah'' in the Feb. 24 Long Island section. The author is not reporting in the journalistic sense, but retelling anecdotal stories with no effort at substantiation. Perhaps the height of absurdity is the quote about the average cost of a bar mitzvah on the Island being $35,000. Who is the authority quoted here? None other than a caterer and owner of one of these extravaganza production companies! How objective he must be!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFUNKEL, EDITH FRIEDMAN
description: GARFUNKEL-Edith Friedman. March 2 at age 86, twelve weeks after the death of Julian, her treasured husband and life partner for 65 years; proud and involved mother of George and Sandy, Ronald and Sande; loving and supportive grandmother of Jon and Betsy, Jill, Stacey and Rob; boastful and adoring great-grandmother of Emily and Maddie. Devoted sister of Helen Levy and the late K. Bertram Friedman. Dear sisterin-law of Prof. Florence G. Roswell and Edward Levy and beloved Aunt Edith to three generations of nieces and nephews. Special friend to many and constant telephone communicator to all. Services at 11:30 AM, Tuesday, March 5, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle, NY. Contributions may be made to the ''Edith Fund,'' Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation, 271 Main St., Great Barrington, MA 01230-1606.

title: Personal Business; You May Be Downsized, but You Can Stay in the Loop
description: AGILENT TECHNOLOGIES may have lost some of its finest employees when it cut its work force by 8,000 last year because of weak sales and profits. But it made sure that it didn't lose contact with all of them.

title: Tying Saltwater Flies Is a Labor of Artistry
description: Virginia Woolf reported that she often received her inspirations for writing while in the bath. Bob Popovics, 6 feet 3 inches and built like a fullback, often finds inspiration for his revolutionary saltwater flies during long car drives. Such was the case with his Bucktail Deceiver, a huge wisp of a fly that, were it tied any more sparsely, would simply be the visualized thought of a fly.

title: Guilford Antiques Show
description: When the parlor curtains at the 300-year-old Hyland House in Guilford needed replacement, the people at the Guilford Historical Society which owns the house did not waver in their dedication to authenticity.

title: Assembling Works Meant To Move and Heal
description: WHEN he was 8 years old, Sean Curran snipped images from Life magazine and pasted them into outrageous collages. One that he assembled for his parochial school class featured luridly colorful photographs of Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin from an article about rock stars who had died of drug overdoses. The nun in charge was so distressed that she sent him home with a reprimand. ''I didn't mean to cause trouble,'' Mr. Curran said. ''I was just making art.''

title: Gary Condit Is Still Running
description: Gary Condit's attempt at political resurrection would be funny if it didn't reveal such a profound contempt for, and underestimation of, the intelligence of the American people (Frank Bruni, Feb. 17). His narcissism leads him to believe that just because he is no longer front-page news, the public has forgotten or will somehow be more favorably disposed toward his egregious behavior. Contrary to what he might think, our memory isn't that short.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMEO, ANDREW A.
description: ROMEO-Andrew A. Passed on Mar. 2 in his 70th year. A man of great gusto, lover of life, successful in business, loyal friend, avid handball player and golfer. Loving husband and best friend of Lynne Romeo. Devoted father of Andrew Romeo, his wife Sandra, & Marco Romeo. Cherished grandfather of Adriana. Beloved brother of Barbara Polito. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Graduated from Fordham in 1955 which he attended on a football scholarship. Remained active in the university's Gridiron Club. Longtime member of the New York Athletic Club where he served as restaurant chairman and on its Board of Governors for 14 years. Soon after graudating from Fordham he joined the Horn & Hardart Company where he rose to EVP of Operations in a 14 year tenure. In 1970 he became divisional president of ARA, known as Aramark. In 1979 he became Chairman and CEO of B/G Foods, which doubled in size under his leadership and which he subsequently took private. Made numerous acquisitions and operated such restaurants as the Broadway Diner and the Landmark Oscar's Salt of the Sea. Co-founder and Chairman of the Board of ADF Companies, a franchisee of 200 restaurants and the second largest Pizza Hut franchise. Andy's larger than life personality and unforgettable sense of humor will be greatly missed by the many who loved him. Family will receive friends on Thursday 2-4 and 6-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral services Friday, 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to be made to the Fordham University Football Recruiting Fund, C/O Michael Fazio, Office of Development, 113 W. 60 St., NY NY 10023 and the New York Athletic Club, The Athlete Fund, C/ O The New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South, New York, NY 10019.

After the 1999 season, when a beat-up Piazza looked numb after the Mets lost to the Braves in the National League Championship Series, he drove through the South, clearing his mind and relaxing his body. After the 2000 World Series, the drive went from his parents' home near Philadelphia to his house in Boynton Beach, Fla.

And then there's all that drinking. ''Drunk as a monkey, which he often was -- after an entire bottle of Scotch,'' Higgs writes. An entire bottle? Higgs should know, or should learn, what Alcoholics Anonymous has to say about all that. No, I'm afraid his friend's legacy was, unfortunately, extremely well planned.

title: Pataki's Chance for Reform
description: Every 10 years, state legislatures around the country are required to create new voting districts based on the latest federal census. Their new maps for Congress often get the most national attention. But the real power plays often occur closer to home because state legislators have the authority to draw their very own districts. Some enlightened states have come up with nonpartisan commissions to draft lines based more on population than self-interest. New York is not one of them. Instead, the latest maps drawn by New York's Legislature are set up to keep the leaders and their parties in power. One man could change all that in New York State: Gov. George Pataki.

title: Eat Drink Man Woman
description: I went to bed thinking of Dover sole and woke up pondering beets. This is normal, trust me. But lately it's reached a feverish pitch. I have wanted to cook like never before.

title: The Golden Age Of Ravenna
description: The best way to see any city worth seeing is on foot and at leisure. Its history is written on its streets. But this must be particularly true for Ravenna, which has a very long history indeed and has seen more ups and downs than most.

title: Chicago
description: When Chicago rose from the ashes of its devastating 1871 fire, architects flocked there to help rebuild and, ultimately, gave birth to the skyscraper. Although it's no longer America's second city (in 1984, Los Angeles surpassed it in population), Chicago is still one of the nation's most vibrant urban centers. But what else would you expect from the city that nurtured the invention of the zipper and the Hostess Twinkie?

title: BackTalk; Dodgeball, In Adult Hands
description: As we are constantly being reminded, this is a dodgeball world. People are always trying to knock you out of the game, because they hate you or because they want to win or because they are so filled with rage that they write ''To whom it may concern'' on the ball before they throw it. You can look at the front pages or the sports pages and find your own examples.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, JULIA MACY
description: THOMPSON-Julia Macy. Died peacefully at her Moss Cottage near Middleburg, VA, February 20, 2002. Beloved mother of Cary Nicholas (deceased) and Dick Macy Potter (deceased), Charles Henschel, Julia Dick, and Francis Thornton Thieriot, grandmother of Cary Nicholas, Jr., Christopher Kingsland, and Jennifer Potter, great-grandmother of Macy Lockheart, Nina Webb, and Nicholas Alonzo Potter. Born January 15, 1914 to Julia Dick and William Kingsland Macy, Republican Representative to the 80th and the 81st Congress. A direct descendant of Thomas Macy, one of the eight men to buy and the first to settle Nantucket Island, Massachusetts in 1635. Mrs. Thompson was a graduate of the Chapin School, 1932. A former member of the Colony Club, New York City, the Victoria Golf Club, British Columbia, the Tuscon National Golf Club, Arizona, and the Middleburg Tennis Club, Virginia. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice Support of Fauquier County Inc, 42 North 5th Street, Warrenton, VA, 20186. Services private.

title: At 11th Hour, He Bought Enron. But Why?
description: THREE months into the Enron scandal, many mysteries remain unsolved. Outside of those slowly unraveling in Houston, one of the biggest concerns the Florida state pension fund, which lost $328 million -- among the largest losses suffered by any Enron shareholder. All fall, as Enron's stock plunged, Alliance Capital and its star money manager, Alfred Harrison, bought more and more Enron shares for the Florida fund.

Mr. Ciardullo, the principal architect of John Ciardullo Associates in New York, designed it.

description: In a banner headline on Friday, The Washington Post blared: ''Shadow Government Is at Work in Secret.'' The article said President Bush had assembled a cadre of officials to operate under the radar, out of the sunlight.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: AIDING AND ABETTING, by Muriel Spark. (Anchor, $11.) In her 21st volume of fiction, Dame Muriel, now in her 80's, gleefully pulls her characters' strings in a farce in which two men who claim to be Lord Lucan (the real-life aristocrat who disappeared in 1974 after killing his children's nanny during a botched attempt to kill his wife) try to blackmail a German psychoanalyst who has a bogus identity and criminal past of her own. The result is a typically witty romp filled with ''eye-and-mind-catching gesticulations,'' Richard Eder said here last year.

title: Feb. 25-March 2: NATIONAL; SUPERFUND SWITCH
description: President Bush's budget scales back the Superfund program, created in 1980 to make corporate polluters pay to clean up their own toxic messes. Mr. Bush is pushing the program's cost, which could amount to billions over the next decade, onto taxpayers. Democrats are furious, saying that would undercut the program's intent. They plan to push to reinstitute the corporate taxes that, until 1995, financed the program. Katharine Q. Seelye

title: Feb. 25-March 2: ENTERTAINMENT; GRAMMYS HONOR RISK
description: Musicians who took chances were rewarded at the 44th Annual Grammy Awards. A collection of Southern roots-music from the film ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'' earned five Grammys, including album of the year. The neo-soul singer Alicia Keys spent six years struggling for the artistic freedom to make ''Songs in A Minor,'' which earned five Grammys, including song of the year. And the London Symphony Orchestra started its own label and recorded Berlioz's ''Les Troyens,'' which won best classical album and best opera recording. U2 was also a big winner, with four Grammys. title: PROPERTY TAX BILLS UP
description: The average property tax bill in New Jersey, already among the highest in the nation, increased by slightly more than 5 percent for 2001, up by $222 to $4,651, according to figures released by the state Department of Community Affairs last week. But for many homeowners, the increase was more than offset by the NJ Saver rebate, a property tax relief program; the average rebate more than doubled from $240 to $500, according to the treasury department. The tax-relief checks are scheduled to increase this year to an average $600. However, the rebate program is under scrutiny as state officials work to close a budget gap that could reach $6 billion for the next fiscal year. That same budget gap is forcing a freeze in most municipal and school aid, which could trigger more property tax increases, said William Dressel, executive director of the League of Municipalities. Karen DeMasters

description: The sense of mortality can seem overwhelming along the depressed Ohio River Valley as Big Steel heads into the Big Sleep and hundreds of dish and pottery factories -- the valley's old artisan glory -- dwindle to a precious few.

title: Your Photo, Neon-BrightIn Acrylic
description: The fashion world -- has finally deemed acrylic chic -- but not as a fabric. Stephen Caliguiri's Plexi art portraiture has been popping up all over town, in exhibits and in window displays at Versace, Dolce & Gabbana, Barneys New York, Jonathan Adler and Saks Fifth Avenue. Such high-profile exposure is sparking interest among private customers -- fashion editors, models and music industry executives among them -- who crave something hipper than the same old family Christmas-card photo. Working from photographs and sketches, Mr. Caliguiri uses a Matisse-cutout-style technique to create surrealistic three-dimensional portraits out of neon-bright pieces of acrylic sheeting. An average picture measures 12 by 12 inches and requires about 80 hours to complete; prices range from $800 to $10,000 (to order 212-591-2088). Although faces are Mr. Caliguiri's specialty, his subjects run the gamut, from Madonna and Elvis to pet parrots.

title: A Jack-in-the-Book
description: Like Mary Janes -- and pigs in blankets, pop-up books are increasingly crossing over to adult territory, in sophisticated superdesigned form. This month, Thunder Bay Press will release ''Frank Lloyd Wright in Pop-Up,'' featuring three-dimensional images of Wright's most famous buildings, including Falling Water and the Guggenheim Museum. In December, St. Martin's Press released ''The Pop-Up Book of Nightmares,'' a collection of darkly funny scenarios such as ''Infestation'' (rats eating their way through a refrigerator) and ''Giving Birth'' (doctors delivering a middle-aged man-baby, viewed through big stirrups in the foreground). Universe Books released ''The California Pop-Up Book,'' which features original works by Frank Gehry and David Hockney and essays by Dennis Hopper and Amy Tan. The physical construction of the book has returned as a point of interest to customers, said Charles Miers, the publisher of Universe Books. Pop-ups, he said, ''are interactive and alive.'' ''People appreciate the effort that goes into a handmade book,'' he added. They also enjoy pulling those tabs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNER, EDWARD H.
description: KERNER-Edward H. Died at home in Newark, Delaware, on Feb. 11, 2002, of myelofibrosis. Dr. Kerner was Emeritus Professor of Physics at the University of Delaware, having retired in 1999 after 37 years of service as a Professor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. Dr. Kerner was born in New York City on April 22, 1924. He earned a Bachelor's Degree from Columbia College in 1943, and a Ph.D in Physics from Cornell University in 1950. Dr. Kerner was interested in theoretical physics very broadly. He studied and contributed significant research results in biophysics, relativity, gravity, and the foundations of quantum mechanics. Recently, he had published an article and was working on others in the area of uniform field theory, i.e., how particles and waves interact at a subatomic level. He was preceded in death by son Jeffrey C. Kerner. He is survived by his wife Barbara B. Kerner; brother George H. Kerner; son Benjamin Kerner; and daughter Winifred Kerner. Contributions may be made to the Scholarship Fund, Dept. of Physics, The University of Delaware, Newark, DE. 19716.

title: Opera Into Dance? Not as Simple as It Sounds

title: An Accidental Truce
description: James McBride's affecting historical novel, MIRACLE AT ST. ANNA (Riverhead, $24.95), follows a brief period in the life of four ''Buffalo Soldiers'' from the Army's all-black 92nd Division. These soldiers are stranded for several days in late 1944 in the Italian town of Bornacchi. In this interval from fighting, as the four Americans become acquainted with the villagers and partisan Italian fighters battling the Germans, the personalities of the men emerge. The gentle and artless draftee Sam Train, who convinces himself that in battle he is invisible, has hands like ''meat cleavers'' and a large head that swivels ''back and forth, moving like the head of a dinosaur.'' Train has taken into his care an Italian boy who survived a German massacre at the village of St. Anna, and he harbors unreasonable ambitions of taking the boy home with him to North Carolina. Other tensions arise within the group. Aubrey Stamps, an educated, chestnut-skinned lieutenant, resents Train's attachment and struggles to make peace with his own black heritage. A bitter enmity grows violent between Stamps and the soldier Bishop Cummings -- a swindling preacher who Stamps believes represents all those ''who acted just like whitey wanted them to act.'' The book's final catastrophe is set in motion by the Army's Jim Crow-style racism and its ''unwritten law that no colored should ever be able to tell a white man what to do.'' McBride, whose memoir, ''The Color of Water,'' movingly described his Jewish mother's marriages to two black men and the rearing of 12 children, creates an intricate mosaic of narratives that ultimately becomes about betrayal and the complex moral landscape of war. Charles Wilson

title: Abbey Lincoln, Maker of Her Own Genre

So does her sense of pitch, heavily colored by blues intonation. Like Holiday, Ms. Lincoln does not scat sing. Improvisational flights, widely considered a defining feature of jazz vocals, play no role in her art. Instead, she elevates the written word, taking pains to make songs expressions of self.

title: Only Gossip

Hunsecker, watch a drunk get tossed out of a strip club and say, with satanic gusto, ''I love this dirty town.'' It was funny and horrible, riveting. For certain people, the 1957 movie ''Sweet Smell of Success'' has an almost ''Rocky Horror Picture Show'' cult appeal: we could, if called upon, recite whole chunks of its dialogue. As when Hunsecker puts a cigarette to his lips and casually orders the press agent Sidney Falco (Tony Curtis), ''Match me, Sidney.'' Or chuckles about the plausible deniability his web of favors and threats provides him: ''My right hand hasn't seen my left hand for 30 years.'' Or complains about his toadies: ''I often wish . . . I could shut out the greedy murmur of little men.'' The prospect of hearing John Lithgow, as Hunsecker, deliver those lines live on stage is enough by itself to get me to the Martin Beck Theater, where a new Broadway musical -- book by John Guare and music by Marvin Hamlisch -- is scheduled to open on March 14.

title: The Uses of American Power
description: If Congress cranks up the Pentagon's budget as much as President Bush would like, the United States will soon be spending more on defense than all the other countries of the world combined. That is just one measure of America's armed might -- and a global imbalance of power the likes of which has probably not been seen since the height of the Roman empire. While the United States is used to regarding itself as a global power, and its status as the sole superpower has steadily grown since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the overwhelming disparity is still a big change. So is the country's willingness to exercise its power in the wake of Sept. 11. Before President Bush decides where next to take the war against terrorism, he and the American people ought to pause for a moment to think about how we intend to behave in this new and awesome role.

title: Traveling Light
description: In architecture, as in life, it's better to make the most of what you have than to try to be something you're not. Just ask Kimberly Ackert, the architect who turned a 2,500-square-foot apartment on Fifth Avenue -- with plain-Jane architecture but a great view of Central Park -- into a shimmering hall of mirrors. Ackert and her associate, Felice Grodin, were asked to transform a jumble of small spaces (that had once been two apartments) in a mundane, 1960's glazed-brick building into a pared-down, light-filled home for a couple and their young son. (The apartment's spare but glamorous furnishings were the work of the design firm Healing Barsanti.) The result combines the openness of a downtown loft with the elegant sparkle of uptown's tonier precincts without trying to tart up the apartment's boxy structure.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: Yes, that's Jim Carrey as the dentist who brings cocaine to the class reunion in PEGGY SUE GOT MARRIED (1986). That's Joan Allen behind those frightful eyeglasses as the heroine's high school friend, Helen Hunt (age 23) as the heroin's daughter and Sofia Coppola (15) as the little sister. But Kathleen Turner is the film's center as Peggy Sue, a fortyish woman who accidentally time-travels back to 1960 and high school. With the influence of Charlie (Nicolas Cage), the boyfriend she later marries, she learns that is if he had it to do over again, she would. Francis Ford Coppola's expert mix of nostalgia and humor, John Barry's haunting score and Peggy's renewed sense of wonder and up to more than the sum of their parts. Peggy thinks she must be dreaming or dead but tries to look on the bright side, announcing to her parents, ''I'm going to go to Liverpool and discover the Beatles'' -- Sunday at 12:30 p.m. on AMC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SYLVIA JOSEPHS
description: BERGER-Sylvia Josephs. In her 100th year. Died on March 2, 2002. A woman of extraordinary intelligence and taste; character and grace. Fiercely independent in mind and action. Her midwestern roots were evident in her sense of fairness and ethics. Born and raised in Duluth, MN she graduated from Smith College in 1924 (was the only one to return and participate in her 75th reunion). Attended the Sorbonne, received a law degree from New York University in the late 1920's. She was a pro bono lawyer for 20 years at the Juvenile Court in the Bronx. A seasoned traveller before World War II. She could read Greek, Latin and French; studied Russian language and Russian literature at Hunter College until she was 96. Attended art classes at the Metropolitan Museum and went to the Philharmonic until late last fall. Married to Arthur M. Berger for over 53 years. He predeceased her, as did a brother Irving and son-in-law Daniel Cowin. Survived by daughter Joyce Cowin, three grandchildren Kenneth (Jasmin), Andrew (Allyson), Dana (Barclay Palmer), three great-grandchildren Reagan and Alexandra Cowin, Sylvie Palmer. As well as a sister Muriel Cowan and brother Arthur Josephs (Adrianne) from Duluth, MN. Interment private. A celebration of her life will be held at her daughter's, April 3rd, 4-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Russian Department at Hunter College or the Jewish Studies Program at Smith College.

title: Feb. 25-March 2; A Final Message?
description: A MESSAGE? Friends of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter executed in Pakistan, suspect the last photos of him show him making a defiant gesture. Two, sent by e-mail to news outlets, show his middle fingers extended and slightly raised. Other U.S. prisoners have sent such messages: when the U.S.S. Pueblo was captured by North Korea in 1968, a photo of its crew showed some making the same gesture. Mr. Pearl's gesture is ambiguous, but a friend, Daniel Gill, said, ''I have no problem believing that he's telling them what he thinks of them.'' He added, ''I don't want to speak for Danny, but I can believe that.'' FELICITY BARRINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, MARVIN E.
description: FRANKEL-Marvin E. The Board of Trustees and the staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services acknowledge with great sorrow the passing of Judge Marvin E. Frankel, beloved husband of Dr. Alice Kross Frankel, Director Emerita and Chief Psychiatrist of our Child Development Center. A former U.S. District Court Judge, Southern District of New York and Professor of Law at Columbia University, Judge Frankel was one of the world's leading advocates for human rights and had a powerful influence in the fight for social justice. Dr. Frankel was and will continue to be a true partner in this work. Judge Frankel also cared deeply for the well being of children, his wife's life work, and shared on a pro bono basis the vast expertise of his firm, Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel to help CDC when needed. He was a wonderful husband, loving father and devoted grandfather. Our deepest condolences to Dr. Frankel, their four children and their spouses and six grandchildren. The world is a stronger and freer place thanks to the extraordinary work of Judge Marvin E. Frankel. Joseph S. Kaplan, Chairman of the Board, JBFCS Jean L. Troubh, President, JBFCS Alan B. title: Beijing
description: Whatever wonders lure other visitors back to China, my favorite memories were of the delectable street foods I enjoyed throughout the country in 1986. On my return last June, I was both surprised and delighted to see that Beijing had become a gleaming metropolis with broad, tree-lined avenues, excellent new hotels and an immaculate, quick and quiet subway. But I feared this might mean that the markets and back alleys where I had sampled so many savory snacks had been modernized out of existence. Fortunately, I worried in vain, for while a few have disappeared, many remain, dispensing specialties with great flair and showmanship and giving visitors a chance to sample the world's most succulent and inexpensive fast food.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREGORI, LEON
description: GREGORI-Leon. On March 6, 2001. Dearest Dad, this has been the longest year in our lives. Even though you are in our thoughts and hearts 24/7 and every second each day, our sadness is overwhelming. We are so proud of the lessons you have taught us, the knowledge we soaked up from you in many subjects, your adoption of my friends as their ''surrogate father''. Everyone in this town of NYC misses you, respected you, admired you, was thankful for your kindness, gentleness and ability to make us all laugh, a gentleman's gentleman. Dad, your life's work, art and illustrations are all masterpieces and are recognized as such. You truly had ''golden hands''. Mom sends her love, Eva sends her love, you know how much they miss you. As for me, your son Michael, I also send my love and ask for forgiveness that I was not with you hand-in-hand as you started your journey one year ago. I shall never forgive myself. Dad, I love you so very much. Thanks for everything. Your Michael.

He was the former President and CEO of Canal Randolph Corporation and a former Director of Lincoln National Life Insurance Co., Downstate Medical, Dollar Drydock Bank, American States Insurance Co's., Blue Ridge Real Estate Co., C.W. Post College and Hofstra University. He is survived by his wife, Joan Foy French and three daughters, Wendy Nolan of Manhattan, Christina Porter of Locust Valley, New York, and Pamela French of Chatam, New York. A memorial service will be held on Long Island in May. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Saint John of Lattingtown, Long Island.

title: Feb. 25-March 2: INTERNATIONAL; HINDUS KILLED
description: After years of calm between Hindus and Muslims in India, a Muslim mob torched a train carrying Hindu fundamentalists determined to build a temple to Ram, incarnation of the Hindu god Vishnu, on the site of a mosque torn down by Hindu fanatics in 1992. Fifty-eight people, mostly women and children, were immolated. Violence spread across western Gujarat state; by Saturday, with no end to the violence in sight, the death toll reached into the hundreds. The World Hindu Council has vowed to begin building the temple by March 15. Celia W. Dugger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORRESTER, DONAL F., CSP.
description: FORRESTER-Donal F., CSP. On March 4, 2002 at age 95. He was born and raised in New York City. Fr. Donal made first promises to the Paulist Fathers on June 16, 1930 and was ordained in St. Patrick's Cathedral by then Cardinal Hayes on May 25, 1934. A proud veteran, his assignments included two tours of duty as Army chaplain, one during W.W. II and then in Korea. He served at both Good Shepherd Parish in Inwood Park and St. Paul the Apostle Church in Midtown. His Paulist priesthood took him to the Paulist Chinese Mission in San Francisco, Old St. Mary's in Chicago's Loop and Santa Susanna the American Parish in Rome, Italy. Two brothers were also priests, one for the Archdiocese of New York, Msgr. Henry Forrester & Fr. Berthold Forrester a Carmelite. Fr. Don Forrester was a member of Division Three of AOH. Viewing will be at the Paulist Rectory, 405 W. 59 St on Wednesday, March 6 from 7:00 to 9:00 PM and on Thursday, March 7 from 4:00 to 7:00 PM followed by a Mass of Christian burial at 7:30 PM in the Church of St. Paul the Apostle (60th & Columbus Ave). Burial will follow on Friday, March 8 at the Paulist Retreat House in Oak Ridge, N.J. at 10:30 AM.

title: On the Other Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: The City's Soul Lies Beyond The Tunnel
description: Rio de Janeiro was the first city I visited outside the United States, almost 30 years ago, and from the start it has seemed to me to be not one city but two. First, there are the beaches and the landmarks known from postcards, movies and songs: Copacabana, Ipanema and Sugar Loaf -- the official, acclaimed Rio visible from the foot of the giant statue of Christ atop Corcovado Mountain.

title: A Wizard of Form Who Found a Career In Color Woodcuts
description: SOME artistic breakthroughs are bigger than others. On the immense radar screen of art history, B. J. O. Norfeldt's development of the white-line color woodcut -- in Provincetown, Mass., in 1915 -- may be only a tiny blip compared to, say, one-point perspective or lost-wax casting. But it had one immediate benefit: it made possible the best work of Blanche Lazzell, a perennially overlooked American modernist.

title: Corrections
description: My Feb. 22 column mentioned ''line 47'' in this year's 1040. What I said was correct, but has been subject to misinterpretation, most of it innocent, some of it deliberate. Let me say it another way: Most people think that they received both a rebate and a tax cut. But the rebate was only an advance on the tax cut; it must be counted against the refund you would otherwise receive. Hundreds of thousands of early filers have already gotten this wrong. The effect is to give many people a rude shock, which is not what this economy needs.

description: THE WIZARD OF ODDS

title: Foreign Guys Can Shoot
description: Five foreign-born players appeared in the National Basketball Association All-Star Game last month, and another five played in the Rookie Challenge game. Of the 348 active players in the N.B.A., 49 are from abroad; there is at least one player from every continent, and 26 of the 29 teams have at least one non-American on their rosters. Seven international players were selected in the first round of the 2000 N.B.A. draft; last year, another six were chosen, including the No. 3 pick, Pau Gasol of Spain, now a star with the Memphis Grizzlies. Lenny Wilkens, coach of the Toronto Raptors, has said, ''I wouldn't be surprised if there are double the number of players now in the next five or so years.''

title: And the Kids Say Nothing Happens Here
description: IT is close to midnight on a Thursday, and a small crowd gathered inside a Great Neck community center is going wild. Sarah Hughes, a bright-eyed, perfection-seeking Great Neck North High School junior, has just won the Olympic gold medal in women's figure skating.

title: Vatican Weighs Reaction to Accusations of Molesting by Clergy
description: Many Vatican officials, conservative and liberal alike, say it will take a sweeping reform of the priesthood to stop the pedophile scandals.

title: Feb. 25-March 2: INTERNATIONAL; COLOMBIAN ATTACKS
description: After President Andrs Pastrana, in the face of rebel abuses, broke off negotiations and revoked rebel control of a vast demilitarized zone, the rebels decided to settle some old scores before leaving the area. They killed nine villagers in three towns. And there are fears that paramilitary gunmen will be coming to the zone to exact revenge on those they view as rebel collaborators. Juan Forero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, HAROLD
description: GOULD-Harold. Age 94, on March 2, 2002. Loving husband of the late Mildred. Father of Thomas and Barbara Gould. Grandfather to Mitchell & Julie and Gregory & Juli.
