title: Rambo Takes a Hit
description: It's not easy facing the twilight years in an Enron economy. First, Ken Lay had to sell the house in Aspen. Now, another aging pensioner is shocked -- shocked! -- by the financial shenanigans going on under his very own nose. In a lawsuit filed on Feb. 14 in California Superior Court in Los Angeles, Sylvester (Sly) Stallone alleges that he was led financially astray by one Kenneth Starr -- not the Clinton nemesis but Stallone's business manager and investment adviser. Stallone, a litigious fellow who has sued not only his father-in-law for mishandling his money but also his former nannies, landscapers, car dealers, real-estate agents, art dealers, producers and wives, accuses Starr of duping him into holding onto shares of Planet Hollywood stock until it was virtually worthless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CHARLES BUCHANAN
description: SMITH-Charles Buchanan. Our elder partner, Charlie Smith, died suddenly in Delray Beach, Florida on February 24, 2002 at the age of 77. We mourn his passing. Charlie was born in New York, December 3, 1924, served his country in the Pacific Theater in W.W. II, completed his education after his return from that duty, and than served his clients and this law firm as a feisty, wise counselor and friend from 1951 to 1995. He is survived by his wife Beverly Cox Smith, son Christopher B. Smith, granddaughter Jessica, and grandson Shawn, to all of whom we extend our deepest sympathy. Fish & Neave

title: What's Doing In Marrakesh
description: Morocco, known as a peaceful, moderate Muslim country, was hurt by the Sept. 11 attacks, but not as badly as expected. There was a nearly 20 percent decline in tourists for 2001, with a particularly disastrous year-end. Even in the increasingly chic Marrakesh, some businesses that deal mainly with American and British travelers say they are threatened with bankruptcy.

title: Gary Condit Is Still Running
description: Chad Condit's assertion that ''we've gone to the mattresses'' aptly describes his father's problem and his plight. As Frank Bruni points out, Condit squandered his good will, respect and possible survival by not simply coming clean and asking forgiveness for the Chandra Levy affair. The article paints a stark portrait of a self-absorbed politician headed down for the count who, sadly, is bringing his family down with him.

title: The Medium Is the Real Message
description: These are the nearly invisible pitchmen, mute, grim, shunning eye contact. They are the anti-Madison Avenue, and their target audience is broad: anyone who can read. Primal advertising: no hard sell, no video jump cuts serving up hard-body models. And the signs have advanced from the days of plugging meals; they now tout haircuts, suits and cash for your diamonds. This being New York, the men could be performance artists -- but they're not. They're just men clinging to the bottom rung of the economy, armored in atavistic sandwich boards. All they can offer capitalism is their strong backs and stoicism. So, they stand on the cold streets, ears numb, hands prickling, feet aching, bearing their scarlet marks of the market economy. DANA JENNINGS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOXEN, WILLIAM A.
description: FOXEN-William A. Of Laurel Hollow, NY, died March 4, 2002 at the age of 85. Mr. Foxen was born to William and Mary Foxen of Brooklyn, NY, on July 19, 1916. He was a graduate of the Brooklyn Technological High School, and attended New York University and Columbia University. In 1940 Mr. Foxen volunteered for service in the United States Army, graduating from the infantry school at Ft. Benning, GA, and Command and General Staff School at Ft. Leavenworth, KS. He served in a number of command and staff positions during four years in the Pacific Theater, including command of an infantry battalion combat team as a twenty-eight-year-old major. Mr. Foxen was a veteran of forty-six years in the advertising business, including serving as a vice president of the Benton & Bowles Agency, and a senior vice president of Ketchum, McLeod & Grove. In 1976 he founded the Foxen & Fredman Agency of Long Island, which he successfully managed until his retirement at age 76. Mr. Foxen was an early proponent of the application of advertising agency talents on a pro bono basis to the problems of not-for-profit organizations. He gave of his time extensively to a number of volunteer organizations, including serving on the Hoover Commission, the Advertising Council, the National Council of the American Cancer Society, and as a trustee of the Village of Laurel Hollow. His wife of 55 years, Eleanor Amy Foxen; seven children, William, Jr., Kathleen, Nancy, Elizabeth, Ellen, Peter and Anne; two brothers, Robert and Richard; and seventeen grandchildren survive Mr. Foxen. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc. of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd. Visiting Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, 11:30 AM at St. Dominic's Chapel, Oyster Bay, N.Y. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Book Fund of the Cold Spring Harbor Library, 75 Goose Hill Road, Cold Spring Harbor, New York 11724.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, THEODORE J.
description: VOGEL-Theodore J. Died on November 20, 2001 at age ninty-six at Gardens Court, Palm Beach, FL. Husband of the late Nancy Vogel. Dear uncle of John Corcoran of Shrewsbury, NJ and Robert Corcoran of New Windsor, NY. Mr. Vogel was a partner in Marcus and Vogel Construction Company, the builder of thousands of homes and apartments in New Jersey. During a career that spanned sixty years, Mr Vogel also built airforce bases and military facilities in North Africa for the United States government during World War II. The burial was at the Gold Coast Crematory, Ft. Lauderdale, FL.

title: UPDATE ON SCHOOL AID
description: New Jersey's school districts should not expect any increase in state aid for the 2002-03 school year, according to a letter released last week by Richard Rosenberg, assistant commissioner for the Education Department. The letter said that districts should start planning their budgets based on the Governor's goal of not reducing school aid and that the goal was to have actual aid numbers available by March 4. The new assistant commissioner in charge of the state's poorest districts or Abbott schools, Gordon MacInnes, said he anticipated that early childhood education aid for Abbott districts would probably increase, but that in general the schools would face ''a reduction in the rate of increase,'' compared with other years. The schools would have adequate funding, he said, ''but not the increase they requested.'' Debra Nussbaum

title: Corrections

title: CRIME
description: George P. Pelecanos writes about the kind of people you swerve to avoid on the street -- and those are the good guys. In HELL TO PAY (Little, Brown, $24.95), this down-and-dirty writer from the urban badlands of Washington breaks out two of his scary best, Derek Strange and Terry Quinn, ex-cop detectives so hard-boiled their shells have cracked. As a black man with plenty of miles behind him, Strange has access to neighborhoods where his Irish partner would be handed his head; but both of them take big chances when they cross Worldwide Wilson, a menacing pimp who breaks in teenage runaways, and then go after the wild street kids who shot the 9-year-old quarterback of the Petworth Panthers, the Pee-Wee team Strange coaches.

title: On the Road to Weedless Gardening
description: WHO'S to blame for much of our weed problems? Possibly Jethro Tull, the 18th-century farmer and writer who advocated, and developed, implements for the thorough pulverization of the soil. As we gardeners go out every spring to turn over our soil we have also been churning our ground and exposing the myriad weed seeds lurking in every soil to light and air, which is just what they need to sprout.

title: The Trouble With Self-Esteem
description: I was dismayed by the analysis of self-esteem in Thomas Szasz's letter (Feb. 17), commenting on Lauren Slater's article (Feb. 3). He wrote: ''As children mature, they may learn to do certain things better than their siblings, parents, teachers or other adults. That will give them self-esteem.'' Ouch! He suggests that self-esteem comes from besting the world. Climb up there, stay there or it's goodbye self-esteem. I may not do things better than most people, but I have plenty of self-esteem.

title: Feb. 25-March 2: ENTERTAINMENT; KOPPEL V. LETTERMAN
description: ABC is trying to lure David Letterman from CBS, and to make room for his popular late-night show, is ready to remove the prestigious program ''Nightline,'' with Ted Koppel. The move blindsided top ABC News executives, and offered a signal of just how intent the network's parent, the Walt Disney Company, is on improving its troubled balance sheet.

title: The Telephone Lady Ad-Libs
description: LAST week's reports of the death of Gordon Matthews, the man who invented voice mail, sounded a note of melancholy in the world of impersonal electronic communications. The genius who ensured that corporations would never again have to speak with their customers had quietly altered the pace of the modern world, then left it with only slight acknowledgment.

title: Travel Advisory; The Michelin Star Shuffle for 2002
description: Changes for the 2002 French Michelin red guide include the addition of three restaurants to the three-star category. Guy Savoy, long considered a three-star chef despite his ongoing two-star status, finally received the top award. The Paris restaurant that bears his name, two blocks north of the Etoile in the 17th Arrondissement, is known for modern, inventive, ever-changing cuisine. The others crowned with three stars are Ledoyen, a historic butter-yellow mansion at the east end of the Champs lyses that houses a bright, elegant and modern restaurant where the Breton chef Christian Le Squer has been at the helm since 1998; and L'Arnsbourg, in the village of Untermuhlthal in the heart of the Vosges forest.

In its early years, it was used for family weddings and baptisms, and sometimes regular Masses, and until the 1970's it was a regular stop on neighborhood religious processions.

title: Nothing Personal
description: Bruce Headlam (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 17) raises good questions about the value of selection versus treatment in the development of institutions, but he makes a common mistake in putting up the New York Yankees as the ''all-selection team.'' The celebrated 1998-2001 Yanks, who barely missed a fourth consecutive championship last fall, could in fact be cited on either side of the argument. On last year's roster, Roger Clemens, Mike Mussina, Scott Brosius, Paul O'Neill, Tino Martinez and Chuck Knoblauch were indeed established players ''skimmed off'' (in Headlam's phrase) from other teams before going on to notable achievements in pinstripes. But their contributions to the Bombers' record are matched, in my view, by those of Mariano Rivera, Andy Pettitte, Ramiro Mendoza, Jorge Posada, Derek Jeter, Bernie Williams and Alfonso Soriano, who are all home-grown Yankees. Whether you're looking at Harvard or the Yankees, selection and treatment appear to offer the clear path to repeated success.

title: Feb. 25-March 2: NATIONAL; UPSET IN LOUIMA CASE
description: A federal appeals court overturned the convictions of three New York police officers in the 1997 stationhouse torture of the Haitian immigrant Abner Louima, a case that became a national symbol of police brutality. Leaving the main assailant, Justin A. Volpe, convicted, the court allowed a new trial for Charles Schwarz, who was convicted of participating in the torture, because his lawyer, under a contract with the police union, had a conflict of interest. The court reversed two other officers' convictions of conspiring with Mr. Schwartz to obtruct justice. They will not be retried. Robert F. Worth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, HON. MARVIN E.
description: FRANKEL-Hon. Marvin E. Yeshiva University and its Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law mourn the passing of the Hon. Marvin E. Frankel, who served as chairman of the Board of Directors of Cardozo from 1979 to 1981 and played a significant role in the strengthening of the law school. A former member of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, he was a strong advocate for human rights, including before the Supreme Court. A distinguished attorney and partner at Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel, a Manhattan law firm where he was litigation director for many years, he taught law at Columbia University from 1962-1965 and was the author of five books and more than 40 major articles. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Alice, children Eleanor Perlman, Mara Wallace, Ellen Schorr and David Schorr, sister Marjorie Frankel, and his six grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Earle I. title: Feb. 25-March 2: NATIONAL; A BIG MISTAKE

Summonses for speeding, not paying tolls, not wearing seat belts and other violations dropped to 3,887 last month, a decrease of 2,102 from January 2001, according to State Police records released last week. title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; M'm! M'm! Familiar!
description: When the Daily Soup down the street from the office closed, I was as desperate as only the soup-starved can be. Nothing, I believed, nothing could compare to the luscious pleasures of its complex mulligatawny, its hot, hot, hot Senegalese peanut soup and its creamy chicken noodle, soothing as a mother's touch, capable of relieving colds as well as impending deadline pressure. So I am quite sure you can imagine my exhilaration when a Daily Soup turned up the other week in my very own town. Naturally, I slammed on my brakes, made a beeline for the door and begged entry, even though I was a good 25 minutes early for its 11:30 a.m. start. It was well worth the sharp yank across the neck by my shoulder belt just to be around that soup. And it was heaven. In the interests of full disclosure, I must note that between spoonfuls I realized that the new president of the Daily Soup Company was Rich O'Donnell, my son Paul's former soccer coach (and a good one at that). But even if the company were led by a team of rampaging Huns, it would be impossible not to feel as I do, and I have a lot of company there. The soup is exactly comparable to what I enjoyed -- oh, all right, was slavishly devoted to -- in the city.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Kimberly Ackert's modernist design sensibilities are obvious (she worked in Richard Meier's office before going out on her own), but her real interest is environmental. During a three-year stint in Australia, Ackert and her partner at the time won a competition to design an environmentally friendly, energy-efficient house (a), which was completed near Perth in 1991. The house, whose materials include rammed earth made from the reddish, iron-rich soil, has a split roof that allows daylight to enter what is usually the darkest part of the interior (b) while doubling as a natural vent for hot air. An energy tower for the house includes a wind turbine to power the lights, solar panels for hot water and water tanks for the fire-suppression system, a must in Western Australia's hot, dry climate.

title: Writer On The Road: The Mission Trail

Each one kindles my imagination, but I'm aware that the stories they conjure up are tinged with romanticism. Blame it on the natural beauty of California that unfolded before me while gliding along its highways, and the sense of peace I felt sitting under the wide sloping eaves of a mission arcade.

But there was a shift in ownership, and Kochumathen Babu (addressed as Babu), once a partner, is now the sole owner. And the place is bright once more. title: Butlers Behind Counters
description: If having to face -- a snooty sales clerk in an overpriced store seems like insult heaped on injury, the new Dunhill shop at 711 Fifth Avenue, at 55th Street, in Manhattan, the company's North American flagship store, could be a tonic. (A small Dunhill store on Park Avenue has closed.) The sales staff at the new Dunhill's -- which specializes in men's clothes and accessories, bespoke tailoring, cigars and pipes -- has taken a rigorous course in proper manners at the store's butler school, run by Phillip DeAngelis, the former head butler at the St. Regis Hotel. In the program, Mr. DeAngelis, who trained at the Ivor Spencer School for Butlers in London, which supplies the royals with household help, taught service traditions and values. Those include the right way to give directions (never point but gesture with an open hand); correct forms of address (a princess is first ''your royal highness'' and then ''ma'am''); how to stand at attention when not helping a customer; how to greet clients and escort them to the door; how to tie a perfect bow tie; and, a syllabus says, how to ''problem solve'' without being pompous. description: FOR years, developers and state officials have sold Florida as a great place to retire -- often without any regard for the long-term consequences of a ballooning older population. Now those consequences are piling up, and the state is becoming a test case of how well society will deal with the health care needs of growing numbers of old people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEST, EVELYN M.
description: WEST-Evelyn M. Died at home on February 28, 2002. A long time member of MENSA and INTERTEL, she graduated with a B.A. and a Phi Beta Kappa from Mount Holyoke and an M.A. in experimental psychology from Columbia University. Her career was long and varied, including teaching, mediation and social work as well as administrative assignments in several City agencies. She headed a foundation for the promotion of badminton and organized consciousness-raising groups for NOW. She was a poet and a ballroom dancer. She is survived by a wide circle of friends who loved her. Funeral services will be held on Monday, March 4 at 12:00 noon at the Fairhaven Funeral Home, 1045 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

title: The World; Exit Savimbi, and the Cold War in Africa
description: TO judge by his effect on the lives and fortunes of an entire region, Jonas Savimbi, the guerrilla leader who was killed in a shootout with Angolan government troops on Feb. 22, had only one real rival in southern Africa over the last half-century: Nelson Mandela.

title: Anna Kay Brokaw,James Rice
description: Anna Kay Brokaw and James Michael Rice were married yesterday at the Renaissance Vinoy Resort in St. Petersburg, Fla. The Rev. Siegfried Jaeger, a Lutheran minister, performed a nondenominational Christian ceremony.

title: Ominous Clouds
description: The day the Weather Channel went on the air, nearly 20 years ago, it was balmy out, clouds scudding in a high sky, no possibility of rain. Today, looking out my window, I see that is still the case. The weather's still nice. At least there's a breeze. The Weather Channel anchor is right now warning me the weather may change. A front is somewhere not too far away. They say there are five stories in Hollywood. With the weather, there has always been only one. It will get cold, and then it will get warm. Warm, cold, warm, cold.

title: Feb. 25-March 2; FRONT LINES
description: ISRAEL: The week began hopefully, with Israel moving the tanks that had held the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat inside his Ramallah compound for months. But, angering Palestinians, the Israelis said he would not be able to leave the city without Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's permission.

title: Sarah Carnevale and Brandon del Pozo
description: LIKE many people do on their birthdays, Brandon del Pozo spent his, Sept. 10, reflecting on his life. Having turned 27, he noted in his journal how happy he was with his family, his work as a New York City police officer, and with his fiance, Sarah Elizabeth Carnevale.

title: Bar Mitzvahs and Their Meanings
description: It is the parents who control the purse strings and the ones who instill values. During their time of coming into adulthood we need to remind our children where the emphasis should be without turning this whole, beautiful and memorable event into a three-ring circus.

title: Arthur Lyman, 70, of Hawaii, King of the Jungle Vibraphone
description: Arthur Lyman, a Hawaiian vibraphonist who squawked, rattled, thumped, hooted and cawed his way to the top of the world of Polynesian mood music in the 1950's and early 1960's, died on Feb. 24 in Honolulu. He was 70 and had been regularly performing his old hits -- including his signature tune, ''Yellow Bird'' -- for tourists in Waikiki until last year.

It was 9 p.m. at the Sony post-Grammy party on Wednesday, and the group, 3rd Faze, rolled up in a stretch limousine in Versace dresses and a new record contract just like all the other fresh-faced hopefuls.

title: Beware the Schemes Of the Tax Season
description: There are plenty of ways to save on taxes. Unfortunately, there appear to be plenty of ways to be cheated by con artists while you think you're saving on taxes. The Internal Revenue Service is again warning about old schemes that surface around this time each year -- and about some new ones.

description: HALPER-Beatrice T. Beloved wife of the late Oscar for 45 years. Cherished mother of Harlan. Loving mother-in-law of Marlina. Adored grandmother of Rachel and Jennifer. Reveered sister of the late Sam, Mina, Lea, Harry and Moe. Passed away on March 1, in Yonkers, NY, at the age of 81. She loved her family, her friends (whom she considered as close as family), the arts, and all that NYC had to offer. A strong supporter of Judaism, she was a proud member of Temple Israel of The City of New York since 1967. She loved life and she lived it with class, grace, and style. For all who knew her she will be dearly missed, always loved and never forgotten. title: A Story the Movies Can't Get Right
description: IT is apparently difficult to make good movies about foreign correspondents, especially war correspondents. The latest entry, ''Harrison's Flowers,'' which stars David Strathairn as a combat photographer and Andie MacDowell as his admiring wife, has many of the successes and failures of the genre. Like ''The Year of Living Dangerously,'' it combines an unremarkable love-driven plot with a riveting background. Scenes of an infamous atrocity that was perpetrated in Croatia a decade ago are graphically re-enacted.

title: Ethical Quandaries, Pivotal Boundaries
description: AS Italians say at election time, piazza pulita! -- let's clean up the square! The clearing of ground zero has proceeded much faster than expected, and it is not too soon to think about cleaning up the politics of redeveloping the site. Indeed, the 16-acre property is now a zone of convergence for our top two national crises: 9/11 and Enron. Architecture is a cultural medium in which this convergence will be conspicuously manifested.

title: Ways to Control Those Bothersome Weeds
description: WHO'S to blame for much of our weed problems? Possibly Jethro Tull, the 18th-century farmer and writer who advocated, and developed, implements for the thorough pulverization of the soil. As we gardeners go out every spring to turn over our soil we have also been churning our ground and exposing the myriad weed seeds lurking in every soil to light and air, which is just what they need to sprout.

Now executive vice president for original programming at Home Box Office, she has been running the cable network's documentary unit since 1979. And in that time she has emerged as the high priestess of a certain kind of cinematic nonfiction, which is -- like Nevins herself -- emotional, demanding, unflinching and provocative.

title: Private Sector; A Dinner Honoring a Statue
description: After nearly six months of raising money for the victims of the World Trade Center attack, many of New York's rich and famous have turned their attention to the neighborhood. Tomorrow night, the new Ritz-Carlton New York, which overlooks ground zero, is playing host to a black-tie dinner and auction organized by a committee that includes Alec Baldwin, Tina Brown, Barry Diller, Diane Von Furstenberg and J. W. Marriott Jr., whose company owns the hotel. Among the expected guests are Interior Secretary Gale Norton; Gov. George E. Pataki of New York; Richard A. Grasso, the New York Stock Exchange chairman; and Peter Max, the Pop artist. Proceeds will go to a fund to increase maintenance and security for New York Harbor and the Statue of Liberty, which has remained closed since the attack but may reopen later this year.

description: HUTNER-Margarita Silva. The faculty of the Department of Dermatology of Columbia University acknowledges with deep sympathy the passing of Dr. Margarita Silva-Hutner, a distinguished scholar and a beloved teacher and mentor of so many. She made pioneering contributions to the development of medical mycology and dermatology and was a distinguished member of our faculty for over fifty years. Her scientific contributions were matched by her humanism and her personal charm and she set standards of excellence that will endure. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, March 20 at 12 noon in the Department of Dermatology at Columbia University. David R. Bickers, M.D., Chairman Department of Dermatology College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALVERT, SEYMOUR, PH.D
description: CALVERT-Seymour, Ph.D Chemical Engineering. Pioneer in air pollution control and education. Died February 25, 2002 in San Diego, CA. Born January 9, 1924 in Detroit, MI. Internationally recognized as the foremost expert on air pollution control scrubbers. He has lectured throughout the world. His research led to the publication of books, numerous technical papers and patents. He served in the U.S. Army from 1943-46, in the Spec. Eng. Detach. at Los Alamos, NM, working on the atomic bomb initiator, which ultimately led to his demise from Berylliosis (respiratory failure). He set up & directed an Air Pollution Interdisciplinary Research Center at Penn State which became the largest air pollution program in the US. In 1967 Dr. Calvert joined the University of California Riverside as Dean of Engineering and Director of the Air Pollution Research Center. Dr. Calvert's ability and years of service were recognized by his invitation to attend the signing of the first Clean Air Act in 1967 at the White House by President Lyndon Johnson. In 1969 Dr. Calvert set up his own engineering company, A.P.T. Inc. in San Diego, CA. A.P.T. became the major contractor for EPA-sponsored Scrubber Research and Development. Dr. Calvert is survived by his wife of 54 years, Phyllis; his daughters Barbara Kuwent and Susan Sherman; and two grandchildren, Michael and Stephen Sherman.

title: On the Track Of Black History
description: IT may not be part of his official job description, but Giles R. Wright, the state's official black historian, has been spending a lot of time lately debunking the myths that surround the Underground Railroad.

title: Practical Traveler; Room Bargains Await in Dorms
description: FOR vacationers who don't want to spend a fortune on hotels, one solution is to go back to school. Each summer, many colleges and universities worldwide open their residence halls to tourists. Campus lodgings are more private than hostels or bed-and-breakfasts and are often in the center of town, where hotels charge premium prices. Savings can be huge: a room in central London or in Berkeley with a view of the San Francisco Bay can cost $50 a night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIEFFELIN, JOHN W. ''JACK''
description: SCHIEFFELIN-John W. ''Jack'' of Lafayette, California peacefully passed away at home on February 22, 2002. His beloved wife of 38 years, Marion, was at his side. He is survived by his wife, Marion, son John and his wife Cathy, daughter Cynthia and her husband Barry and grandchildren Anna and Reade. Born in 1932, in New York, NY, Jack spent his childhood in White House Station, NJ. He was passionate about wildlife and had a large snake collection which he eventually took to Harvard University ('54). A graduate of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons ('59), Jack completed his internship at Roosevelt Hospital in New York City and residencies in Internal Medicine and Pediatrics at both Roosevelt Hospital and New York Hospital. In 1965, Jack and his wife Marion settled in California where he served the community as a pediatrician at Kaiser Foundation Hospital in Walnut Creek from 1965 to 1992. During these years and into retirement, Jack worked tirelessly as an advocate of children's safety. He served as Chairman of the Accident Prevention Committee, Chapter 1 District IX, Director of the Drowning Prevention Network, Director of the National Prevention Foundation and was a member of the National Accident Prevention Committee of the American Academy of Pediatrics, and a member of the Board of Directors of the Danny Foundation. In addition to Jack's numerous medical affiliations, he also served on the Board of Directors of Charles Scribner's Sons. Upon retirement from Kaiser, Jack devoted his time to native plant gardening and world travel with his wife. He will be remembered for vivid stories of ancestors, his rousing rendition of ''On Top of Old Smokey'', and his love of butterflies and Christmas. But, most of all, he will be remembered as a devoted husband and father and as a kind and generous friend. Family and friends are invited to attend a memorial service at St. Anselm's Church, 682 Michael Lane, Lafayette, CA on March 6, 2002 at 5PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be made in his name to Kaiser Foundation Hospice Program, 1425 South Main Street, Walnut Creek, CA. 94596.

I have seen parties where frivolous centerpieces were replaced with food baskets for the needy or stuffed animals that were donated to children's hospital wards. I have received invitations that asked guests to bring to the party canned food for a food pantry, small toiletries to be contributed to a women's shelter or old cellphones that can be reprogrammed to dial 911 and given to battered women.

The map had suddenly made Melville and my life more relevant.

title: Tread Carefully in the Caucasus
description: Washington's plans for fighting terrorism with military aid and training programs continue to expand, now to a troubled border region of the former Soviet republic of Georgia, next door to Russia's war in Chechnya. It's a treacherous place for American military advisers to go, not only because of Georgia's chronic turbulence but also because of Russian sensitivities regarding this region. Washington should proceed with a limited mission, making clear that its only purpose is to help Georgia hunt down terrorists, not to compete with Moscow for military influence in the Caucasus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SYLVIA JOSEPHS
description: BERGER-Sylvia Josephs. In her 100th year. Died on March 2, 2002. A woman of extraordinary intelligence and taste; character and grace. Fiercely independent in mind and action. Her midwestern roots were evident in her sense of fairness and ethics. Born and raised in Duluth, MN she graduated from Smith College in 1924 (was the only one to return and participate in her 75th reunion). Attended the Sorbonne, received a law degree from New York University in the late 1920's. She was a pro bono lawyer for 20 years at the Juvenile Court in the Bronx. A seasoned traveller before World War II. She could read Greek, Latin and French; studied Russian language and Russian literature at Hunter College until she was 96. Attended art classes at the Metropolitan Museum and went to the Philharmonic until late last fall. Married to Arthur M. Berger for over 53 years. He predeceased her, as did a brother Irving and son-in-law Daniel Cowin. Survived by daughter Joyce Cowin, three grandchildren Kenneth (Jasmin), Andrew (Allyson), Dana (Barclay Palmer), three great-grandchildren Reagan and Alexandra Cowin, Sylvie Palmer. As well as a sister Muriel Cowan and brother Arthur Josephs (Adrianne) from Duluth, MN. Interment private. A celebration of her life will be held at her daughter's, April 3rd, 4-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Russian Department at Hunter College or the Jewish Studies Program at Smith College.

title: A Voice Out of the Silence: Imagining the Other Cassatt

A sister of the painter Mary Cassatt, Lydia, when she died of Bright's disease, a kidney ailment, in 1882 at 45, left behind no known letters, no tangible creations. Her only legacy was her image, of a fresh-faced woman with a strong jaw and reddish-blond hair, in Cassatt's paintings, like ''Woman Reading'' and ''The Cup of Tea.''

The woman, identified as Hazel Ehmke, 92, was pronounced dead at 8 p.m. Saturday after firefighters extinguished the blaze at her apartment in Jamaica Estates, Queens, the authorities said. Investigators said they believed it was ignited by an electrical problem. The second fire broke out at 5:44 a.m. yesterday in the Soundview section of the Bronx, fire officials said. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hudson: Lyme Disease Incidence
description: Columbia County, which borders Massachusetts, reported the most Lyme disease cases per capita in the United States in 2000, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. The county also had the highest incidence in New York State three years running. It had 593 cases in 2000, up from 398 in 1999, the latest years for which C.D.C. data are available. County health officials report that the number of cases in 2001 was 646. Marcia Fabiano, a Columbia County epidemiologist, said that the county's many forests were an ideal environment for deer ticks, which transmit the disease. Hope Reeves (NYT)

Said coolly, the statement seemed a put-down of anything but the most banal way of looking at clothes. You know how it is. Referring to his fall prototype, he added, ''This is a very strong woman.''

Vaughn of Riverside, CT; 11 grandchildren and 22 great-grandchildren. Service will be held, 11 AM, March 5, at St. Andrew's Church, Richmondtown, Staten Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to St. Andrew's Church.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Billions of dollars are being controlled by two companies, and nobody knows who they are.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 25 in the Writers on Writing series, about newcomers who receive aid from established authors, misidentified the poet on whose property the young Robert Lowell pitched a tent. He was Allen Tate, not John Crowe Ransom.

description: GROSS-Joan. We keep on loving you. All of us

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERMAN, JEAN P.
description: OBERMAN-Jean P. On March 2, 2002. Loving wife of the late Leonard S. Oberman. Beloved mother of Karen O. Minsky and son-in-law Aaron G. Minsky. Services Monday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Success Now a Given, No Longer a Surprise
description: Q is the stiff-legged and drooling bulldog who is the school's mascot and who roams the athletic department offices as if he were just another administrator. Mark Few is the 39-year-old basketball coach who copes with high expectations and job offers for better money at bigger universities by casting a fly-fishing line on the Spokane River. Jack & Dan's is a tavern across from campus where talk about Gonzaga University basketball history keeps pace with the beer taps.

title: A Primedia Founder Is Going to a Smaller Magazine Venture
description: When last seen in the magazine industry, William F. Reilly, the co-founder and chief executive of Primedia -- publisher of New York, Seventeen and scores of specialized magazines -- had been forced out by his majority investors, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: This Week
description: Martyr's Memorial

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAGOWAN, STEPHEN
description: MAGOWAN-Stephen. In grateful memory of Stephen Magowan, one of our earliest and most generous supporters. American Friends of the Royal Court Theatre

title: Widows Seek Wider Inquiry Into Trade Center Collapse
description: Several dozen widows and parents of World Trade Center victims, as well as New York City firefighters, intend to travel to Washington on Wednesday to urge Congress to expand the federal investigation into the structural failure of the twin towers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Killed By Subway Train
description: A homeless man died yesterday after he apparently slipped from a subway platform in Mount Eden and was struck by a No. 4 train, the authorities said. The man's name was not released, but the police said he was 55 and lived in a shelter. The man was standing on the northbound platform of the 170th Street station around 10:30 p.m. Saturday when he lost his balance, the police said. He fell to the tracks and was hit by a train pulling into the station, they said. The man was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he died at 5 a.m. yesterday. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Court Clerk Arrested On Drug Charges
description: A Supreme Court clerk has been charged with selling marijuana out of the courthouse in downtown Brooklyn, the authorities said. The clerk, Dennis Bram, 54, who has worked at the court since 1982, was charged with criminal sale of marijuana, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney's office said on Thursday. On Jan. 23, an undercover informant bought about $60 worth of marijuana from Mr. Bram and later bought marijuana worth $2,500, the spokesman said. Mr. Bram, who made $73,138 a year as a senior clerk, has been suspended without pay. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Saudi Idea for Peace Prompts An Outburst from Qaddafi
description: As Arab diplomacy gathered momentum today behind a Saudi peace plan for the Mideast, Libya's quixotic leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, sought to upstage the initiative, first threatening to quit the Arab League in protest then consenting dramatically to hold off and attend a key summit meeting later this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLOMAN, DR. JOHN L. S. JR.
description: HOLLOMAN-Dr. John L. S. Jr. Columbia University's Health Sciences Division and the Columbia University Affiliation at Harlem Hospital Center salute the life and mourn the loss of Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., physician, servant of the Harlem community and Harlem Hospital Center, and leader in the quest for social justice and proper health care for all. Dr. Holloman exemplified the unswerving physician advocate as a devoted practitioner in the personal care of his patients in the Harlem community, a determined participant in civil rights demonstrations againt racial discrimination, an effective critic of organized medicine's failure to adequately address racial discrimination in health care, the distinguished President of the National Medical Association, the noble President of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, and as the Medical Director of the William F. Ryan Community Health Center. We cherish the life and work of Dr. Holloman, a tireless champion of human rights and justice in medical care. Gerald E. Thomson, M.D. Columbia University Harlem Hospital Center Affiliation

title: If You Can't Join 'Em, You Can Always Tweak 'Em
description: It would seem that nearly everyone interested in art has an opinion about the Whitney Museum of American Art's biennial survey of contemporary work. Since the Whitney's selections for the 2002 Biennial were announced in November, artists, curators and gallery owners have been chewing over the choices, a discussion that will only intensify once the exhibition opens on Thursday.

title: Big City Ideas Fight Small Town Crime
description: It all started when Bill London, a state game warden, stopped a man for fishing illegally in a pond in this rural, mountainous area north of Boise and found he had a ball of methamphetamine, the size and color of a Ping-Pong ball.

title: Is The Observer for Sale? Always, At a Dollar Apiece, Its Owner Says
description: One can be forgiven for speculating about Arthur L. Carter and his plans for The New York Observer. After all, who doesn't speculate? The salmon-pink bundle of news and attitude preys on the imagination and fears of powerful New Yorkers in a way that few other publications of its size -- it says it has a circulation of about 50,000 -- can match.

title: Congressional Inquiry Cites Flaws in Antimissile Sensor
description: A Congressional inquiry into reports of corporate fraud has found widespread technical failures in a prototype antimissile sensor meant to track enemy warheads. It leaves open the question of whether the government contractors withheld information about those failures from military officials.

title: Bush Weighs Raising Steel Tariffs But Exempting Most Poor Nations
description: President Bush's top economic advisers have presented him with proposals to rescue the American steel industry that would most heavily penalize China, Japan, Germany, Taiwan and South Korea, but exempt most poor nations -- and Mexico and Canada -- from punishing tariffs.

title: Argentine Estates Decay With Economy
description: As a child growing up in the 1940's, Carlos Emilio Lamas always thought that his grandfather's 12,000-acre estate here on the pampas was a magical place. There were hundreds of horses and thousands of cattle, and on weekends a steady stream of visiting relatives and friends.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about plans for a retrial of former Police Officer Charles Schwarz in the torture of Abner Louima misstated the acknowledgment by another former officer, Thomas Wiese, about his presence in the bathroom where the assault took place. Mr. Wiese has said that he entered the room only after the assault, not before, and that he was outside the door while it went on.

title: Stepping Back From Isolation, Switzerland Votes to Join U.N.
description: By a slender margin, neutral Switzerland decided in a countrywide vote today to leave behind decades of isolationism and become a member of the United Nations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Muslim Discrimination Suit
description: A company that formerly ran a health food store in SoHo has agreed to pay $715,000 to settle a religious discrimination lawsuit filed on behalf of 11 Muslim workers who said they were not allowed to wear religious headgear or use other religious paraphernalia, the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said. In a civil complaint filed in September 2000, the commission charged the health food store, Rekrem, with pressuring Muslim workers not to wear their headscarves and with removing the workers' prayer mats. The commission also accused Rekrem of improperly firing several Muslims when they refused to sign false affidavits saying there was no discrimination.

title: In Siberia, Serious TV News Fights to Survive
description: Aleksandr Karpov has come a long way since 1993, when his television station broadcast the news from a bomb shelter underneath the city's post office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARMON, LOUIS
description: KARMON-Louis. 91, a prominent Manhattan restaurateur, owner of Chateau Henry IV and La Cave, died Friday in Florida. He is survived by his loving daughter Linda, son Robert, grandchildren Elysa and Jennifer, and his second wife Lois.

title: James McKenzie, 75, Executive Producer of Westport Playhouse
description: James B. McKenzie, the longtime executive producer of the Westport Country Playhouse in Westport, Conn., where he lived, and a force in regional and summer theater throughout the country, died on Feb. 20 at a hospital in Norwalk, Conn. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GADSDEN, CHARLES C.
description: GADSDEN-Charles C. 78, of Pelham, NY, and Little Compton, RI, died Saturday, March 2, 2002. Husband of Marie Dittmann Gadsden for 55 years. He is survived by his loving wife, his six children, Charles, James, Lavinia, Victoria, Philip, Pamela and his eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church in Pelham on Wednesday, March 6, at 2 PM.

title: Looking for Another 'Miracle'; With a New Album, Barry Manilow Finds Himself Back on the Charts
description: Barry Manilow is ready for his comeback now.

title: A Different City
description: The idea that police officers involved in the attack on Abner Louima may escape justice is profoundly upsetting to many people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNINGS, RUTH BAKER
description: JENNINGS-Ruth Baker. On March 1, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Milton S. Jennings. Loving mother of Ellen and Paolo, John and Rosemary and Richard and Nancy. Cherished grandmother of Peter and Joni, Nicholas, Annie, Sally, Tory, Aubrey, Tiane and Gillian. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral service will be held on Monday, March 4, at 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind.

title: New Economy; Corporations are now spending more on computer services than on computers themselves.
description: THE new new thing, to borrow a phrase, is the old old thing: corporate computing.

title: Rangers Embrace Physical Approach
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have brought out the best in the Rangers this season. The question is, how will the Rangers respond tonight, when the atmosphere in Madison Square Garden figures to be much less electric with Calgary in town?

title: Preparing for a Drought
description: Up and down the East Coast, scientific evidence is revealing the extent and severity of what could be the deepest drought of the past 100 years. Forest fires in Maine, usually snuffed by snow, burn to the ground. The Potomac River has dipped to historic lows. New England is experiencing one of its driest winters since records started being kept. The United States Drought Monitor, a joint project of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and various academic partners, has classified the entire coast from Georgia to Maine as in ''severe'' or ''extreme'' drought conditions. A good spring rain will not solve this problem.

title: Northrop's Bid for TRW Turns Hostile
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation made a hostile $5.9 billion takeover bid for its rival, TRW Inc., late last night after TRW's board rejected its original unsolicited offer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENHOUSE, BETH
description: GREENHOUSE-Beth. On March 3. Devoted mother of Burt and Barbara Rosen. Devoted sister of Martha Greenhouse Sasmor. Cherished grandmother of Deborah, Robert and Jacqueline. Loving great-grandmother of Paisley, Spencer Jake, Alexandra and Nicole. Loving aunt of Kenneth, Sheila and Daniel. Services private at Old Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Latest Attacks Stun Israelis And Dampen Hopes for Peace
description: Worn and frightened by a worsening conflict that their leaders were already calling a war, Israelis went to bed Saturday night with images on television of black plastic body bags lined up along a Jerusalem street.

title: A Russian Trademark Dispute Sends a Vodka Brand Fleeing
description: Sitting on a lonely dock in the Russian port city of Kaliningrad, a load of Stolichnaya and Moskovskaya vodka awaits shipment to bars and liquor stores in the United States and other foreign watering holes because of a trademark dispute between a Russian company and the Ministry of Agriculture.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Thursday, about plagiarism by historians, misstated the title of a book from which passages were borrowed without credit. It is ''Wings of Morning,'' not ''Wings of the Morning.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column on Wednesday about a Carnegie Hall appearance this past Saturday by the Boston Philharmonic Orchestra misidentified the composer of the Ninth Symphony on the program. It was Mahler, not Beethoven.

title: Novelist and an Actress Sharing a Leaky Boat
description: Ambition writhes to a gospel beat in ''The Last Five Years,'' Jason Robert Brown's slim, elegiac new musical at the Minetta Lane Theater. For Jamie, a novelist on the threshold of fame, a first taste of success has him singing like a revivalist preacher. The words may express doubts, but the tempo is as affirmative as the ''Hallelujah Chorus.'' Jamie has boarded an express train to his own custom-made heaven.

title: Compressed Data; In France, Scents Waft Over the Web
description: In this post-boom era, sending aromas over the Internet sounds like one of those what-were-they-thinking ideas. DigiScents, a company that generated a ton of media coverage with its plans to add smells to Web sites, ran out of money and expired last April.

title: Koppel's 'Nightline' Caught in Cross-Fire
description: David Letterman or no David Letterman, Ted Koppel is in a fix.

Beloved mother of Dr. Beth Orringer Hodge and her husband, Dr. Malcolm H. Hodge of Chicago, IL; Dr. Robert D. Orringer and his wife, Terri of Livingston, NJ; cherished grandmother of: Debra, Lindsay and Samantha Orringer; beloved sister of Alma Kaplan and Grace Denenholz both of New York, NY. She was predeceased by her brothers: Marshall, Daniel, Richard, Reginald and Victor Denenholz and two sisters: Jessica Levin and Devorah Schwebel. Funeral March 5, 2002, 10:30 AM, Tree of Life Memorial Park, Franklin Park Borough, PA.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Plan: Join the Fray
description: In devising its offensive against a pocket of Al Qaeda fighters in Afghanistan the American military seems to have learned the bitter lessons of Tora Bora.

title: Metro Matters; In the Schools, 'Control' Isn't the Word
description: IF the daffodils can bloom in February and the forsythia before the Ides of March, the mayor of New York City can run the public school system -- probably less directly than he would like, but more directly than mayors have in more than 30 years.

title: Nijinsky Returns, With a Scarf And a Triple Kiss
description: Parents did not have to worry about sex on television in 1913; they might have worried a bit about sex in ballet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, SYLVIA WIENER
description: GROSS-Sylvia Wiener. January 27, 1910-March 2, 2002. Born in Brooklyn, a high school English teacher in the New York City system for 40 years, graduate of Erasmus High, Adelphi University, Brooklyn College, 1993 Recipient of New York Newsday's Award for Community Service as a volunteer at the Queensborough Library and knitter of Hats for the Homeless and several Native American communities. As a teenager, she had danced on toe at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Devoted wife for 49 years of the late Howard A. Gross. She is survived by brother Myron Wiener, daughter and son-in-law Cynthia and Jerry Dantzic, son and daughterin-law Tony and Connie Gross, grandchildren Laurie and Harry Gray, Susan Gross and Grayson Dantzic, also the late Michael Gross, and great-grandsons Charlie and Maxi Gray. Services Tuesday, March 5, at noon, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd at 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

title: U.S. PLANES POUND ENEMY AS TROOPS FACE TOUGH FIGHT
description: American bombers flying round-the-clock sorties struck positions believed to be held by fighters of the Taliban and Al Qaeda in the folds of 11,500-foot-high mountains near this provincial town for the second successive day today, as allied ground forces met some of the fiercest resistance since American military operations began across Afghanistan five months ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Suffolk: Judge Upholds Pine Barrens Law
description: A federal judge has upheld a 1993 state law that limits the development of 100,000 acres of the Pine Barrens in eastern Suffolk County to protect the drinking supply. In a decision dated Feb. 21 but released last week, the judge rejected a suit from 168 landowners claiming their rights were violated. The landowners are considering an appeal. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, DAVID A.
description: MANN-David A. At 85, on March 1, 2002. He is survived by his beloved wife Penny, his sons Jeffrey and Samuel, daughter-in-law Amy and future daughter-in-law Laura Pastor, his cherished grandchildren Jessica Gutteridge and Rachel Rosan and his great-grandson Raphael Leo Gutteridge. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBSTEIN, ALAN A.
description: ALBSTEIN-Alan A. Died on March 3, 2002. Beloved husband of Janet, devoted and loved father of Arthur and Joan, and father-in-law of Natalie. Adoring grandfather of Justin and Sharona, respected and loved brother, uncle and greatuncle. Services at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, Tuesday, 10 AM.

title: Peanut Proposals Put a New Wrinkle on Farm Subsidies
description: Buried in the proposed farm bill is an entirely new $3 billion subsidy for peanut farmers, a 10-year entitlement of direct cash payments meant to help American peanut farmers adjust to competition unleashed by the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Knicks Show Some Flair, but Six Seconds of It Is Not Enough
description: Latrell Sprewell shot from the left side of the key yesterday and hit the backboard and nothing else. It was Sprewell's signature moment in what was essentially 42 minutes of lethargy against the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: 2 Charged In Arson Ring Case
description: Two men have been indicted on charges that they took part in an arson ring that the authorities say was operated by a former Mercer County police detective, the state district attorney announced Thursday. The authorities say they believe the men, Otis Boone, 34, and Jerome Adderly, 37, started seven fires in and around Trenton in 1999 at the behest of the detective, Marc Rossi, whose insurance-adjustment business benefited by more than $50,000 from the fires, the authorities said. Mr. Boone is charged with starting six of the fires and would face up to 20 years in prison if convicted. Mr. Adderly, charged with igniting the seventh, could be sentenced to up to five years. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: A Personal Musical Compass That Always Points Inward
description: Cecil Taylor doesn't play other people's music or lean on a marketing concept. The idea is that he is a once-and-forever new concept, and you go to his concerts to meditate on him, not to see him dealing with an idea imposed from without. His music is an eruption, honed to perfection since the late 1950's. It's his own, and it comes from as broad a consciousness and as deep a commitment to beauty as we have in American culture.

title: A Secured Kandahar Is Now Safe Enough For Some Night Life
description: A group of men, neither police officers nor soldiers, walk through a shadowy bazaar, oblivious of the time. That is a remarkable state for them to be in, given that this is Afghanistan and it is 10:52 p.m.

title: St. John's Fumbles Its Shot At a Bid
description: It is only a two-hour drive to this Main Line suburb of Philadelphia, but in recent years it has been a miserable trip for St. John's players. Villanova's home floor haunts them as balls bounce mysteriously off toes, shots suddenly fall leaden before reaching the basket and the scoreboard at the Pavilion usually reflects the Red Storm's frustration.

title: Fans Pass Loyalty Test As Knicks' Season Fails
description: Charlie Tebele watched from his $250-a-game courtside seat yesterday as Allan Houston missed a 15-foot jump shot. Houston may have a good 10 inches on Tebele, a clothing manufacturer from Brooklyn, but Tebele swore he could have made that shot.

title: In Shift, Israel Bars Building of a Mosque Near a Church
description: Under stiff pressure from the Vatican and a united front of Christian factions in the Holy Land, the Israeli government reversed earlier decisions and declared today that a mosque being built by Muslim militants near a Roman Catholic basilica would not go ahead.

title: Cloning Your Dog: A Sweet Illusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions Raised of Conflicts At 2 Hospital Buying Groups
description: Amid a tangle of wires and worried faces, the brief life of Joshua Diaz was slipping away, and Dr. Mitchell R. Goldstein knew he must soon make an agonizing decision.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 19 about a dispute between the United Nations and the Cambodian government over a proposed tribunal to try former Khmer Rouge leaders misspelled the surname of the American ambassador in Phnom Penh, who supported the Cambodian argument. He is Kent Wiedemann, not Weideman.

title: Pocketing Soft Money Till Pocket Is Sewn Up
description: With the Senate likely to approve landmark restrictions on political fund-raising and with Congress up for grabs, Republicans and Democrats are mounting an aggressive, last-ditch drive to collect unrestricted checks from wealthy donors before such donations are banned.

title: Daschle Wants President to Tell Congress More About His Plans for War
description: With Republicans accusing him of being unpatriotic, Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, renewed his questions today about the administration's expansion of the war on terrorism and called on President Bush to keep Congress better informed.

title: Nostalgia and Cries of Anguish From the Sinking Mahler
description: The Boston Philharmonic, founded by Benjamin Zander in 1979, has a peculiar makeup, with professional musicians, music students and amateurs mingling behind the stands. But Mr. Zander, a British conductor who has been on the faculty of the New England Conservatory for 35 years, seems able to inspire his players to give performances in which the amateurs work at a fully professional level.

title: The Ruses to Block Reform
description: Senators like to put on a show of elaborate respect for decorum. In that spirit, Senator John McCain and others have been patiently waiting for the foes of campaign finance reform to come forward with supposedly technical ''corrections'' to the Shays-Meehan bill that passed in the House last month. The bill has the votes to pass. Patience with opponents is therefore looking harder and harder to justify. The moment has come for a vote. A patently insincere search for technical perfection is becoming an increasingly obvious ruse for those trying to delay and kill reform.

title: Apprehension Grows as Colombia Rebels Step Up Pace and Intensity of Their Attacks
description: Peace talks between the government and Marxist rebels collapsed just 11 days ago, and it took no time at all for Colombia to plunge into a new, ominous phase of the long-running conflict. Almost immediately after the talks ended, the rebels launched a coordinated series of attacks aimed at spreading misery across this vast country while demonstrating the government's inability to stop them.

description: GOULD-Harold, DDS. Age 94, on March 2, 2002. Loving husband of the late Mildred. Father of Thomas and Barbara Gould. Grandfather to Mitchell & Julie and Gregory & Juli. description: BAKER-Richard Brown. A gathering in remembrance of art collector and philanthropist Richard Brown Baker will be held at The Grolier Club at 47 E. 60 St, NYC, on Tuesday, March 12, at 6 PM.

description: Three groups have submitted bids for Wessex Water, a British utility that is being sold by the Enron Corporation after its collapse, people close to the discussions said today.

description: The police released a photograph yesterday to try to identify a man arrested Saturday night in the Bronx carrying two homemade grenades and a loaded machine gun.

description: The coffins of three Albanian-American brothers who went together to Kosovo to fight, and who insisted, in battle and out, that they remain together, lay side by side yesterday in a funeral home in the Bronx.

Devoted sister of Helen Levy and the late K. Bertram Friedman. Dear sisterin-law of Prof. Florence G. Roswell and Edward Levy and beloved Aunt Edith to three generations of nieces and nephews. title: Rev. Donald G. Lothrop, 96, Boat-Rocking Minister, Dies
description: The Rev. Donald G. Lothrop, the radical minister of what was once one of Boston's most prominent Protestant churches, who defied politicians who called him a Communist -- mistakenly, he emphasized -- by warmly welcoming Communists to his congregation, died on Feb. 20 in Belfast, Me. He was 96.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Investors Puzzled By FTD.Com Changes
description: Shares of FTD.com plunged more than 32 percent yesterday after its owner said it would combine the Internet florist with its parent company, FTD, a telephone florist, to make a single, publicly traded company housing all FTD businesses. The move left FTD.com investors scratching their heads over what they would receive in the merger. FTD is a unit of the privately held IOS Brands Corporation. FTD.com, based in Downers Grove, Ill., was spun off from FTD in September 1999 for $8 a share, but FTD has always controlled about 98 percent of the voting power of outstanding FTD.com shares. According to a statement issued before the major markets opened yesterday, each share of FTD.com is to be converted into 0.26 share of common stock in IOS Brands. Just what 0.26 of an IOS Brands share equals is uncertain. An FTD spokeswoman declined to comment on the transaction beyond what was in the statement. Shares of FTD.com dropped $2.93, to $6.07.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREIDLER, IRENE S.
description: KREIDLER-Irene S. Of Oyster Bay Cove, on March 2nd, 2002. Beloved wife of James P. Loving sister of Verona Stark. Cherished cousin of Pam Fuss. Dear sister-inlaw of Gail Kreidler. Irene was the past president of the National Women's Bowling Association. Visitation Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 & 7-9 PM at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 1380 New York Ave. Huntington Station, NY. Prayer Friday 10:00 AM at the funeral home. Burial in Locust Valley Cemetery.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M.-Xilinx Deal Valued At $100 Million
description: I.B.M. said its previously announced agreement to manufacture a high-performance semiconductor for Xilinx, a chip designer, was valued at $100 million over two years. The companies said in July 2000 that I.B.M. would produce the Virtex-II chip for Xilinx, without giving an estimated value. Production of the chip, designed for switching equipment for computer networks, began in the fourth quarter, an I.B.M. spokesman, Michael Loughran, said. The Virtex-II will be built at I.B.M. plants in East Fishkill, N.Y., and Essex Junction, Vt., I.B.M. said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Fred Decr, a restaurateur, misspelled the name of a restaurant in Banksville, N.Y., of which he was a co-owner. It is La Crmaillre, not Crmaillire.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: New Prime Minister
description: President Jean-Bertrand Aristide has chosen Senator Yvon Neptune, left, as prime minister, officials said. Mr. Neptune, an architect who has been a spokesman for Mr. Aristide's Lavalas Family party and is currently president of the Senate, will replace Jean-Marie Chrestal, who resigned six weeks ago after complaints about corruption and his inability to improve social and economic conditions. International donors have withheld $500 million in aid because of an unresolved dispute over the May 2000 elections, which gave Lavalas an overwhelming legislative majority.

title: Stocks Gain on Signs Of Quicker Recovery
description: Stocks rallied powerfully amid signs that the economy is recovering more quickly and strongly than investors had expected.

title: Dolphins Make Offer For Saints' Williams
description: The Miami Dolphins, who ranked 23rd in rushing in the N.F.L. last season, made a trade offer yesterday for Ricky Williams, the former Heisman Trophy running back from Texas for whom the New Orleans Saints gave up their entire 1999 draft.

title: Mildly Elementary, But Not in the Acting
description: Sightlessness is a quality that actors are often called upon to play, but rarely to play with, so even beyond the question of its theatrical art, the Theater by the Blind is of inherent interest for its theatrical problem solving. And watching the company, which was founded in 1979 and includes sighted performers as well as those with varying degrees of visual impairment, is a particularly valuable enterprise for what it reveals about acting and the eyes.

title: Credit Agency Drops Rating On the Debt Of New Jersey
description: Warning that the stock market's sluggish performance was likely to suppress New Jersey's tax revenues for years to come, a major credit rating agency lowered the rating today on more than $14 billion in state bonds.

title: Listening for the Call of a Vanished Bird
description: It was early afternoon in the swamp. We had spent the morning hiking through Louisiana bottomland forest and the early afternoon slogging through bayous in search of the ivory-billed woodpecker.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Under Pressure, Magazine Apologizes
description: The Far Eastern Economic Review offered an apology for any negative interpretation of a recent article about the government and the monarchy, and the police said they were considering whether to withdraw expulsion orders for two of the magazine's reporters. At the same time, the government blocked distribution of the latest issue of The Economist because of an article that discussed the royal family in terms that are not acceptable in the country. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Voluntary Water Restrictions In Declaration of Emergency
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey today issued his long-expected declaration of a drought emergency, intensifying the state's exhortations that the public save water and opening the door to mandatory water restrictions for a state that has been sliding into drought since 1998.

title: 7 AMERICANS DIE DURING RAID ON AFGHANISTAN MOUNTAINS
description: Seven American soldiers were killed today in some of the fiercest fighting of the five-month war in Afghanistan as American ground forces took the lead in a large-scale combat operation for the first time, American officials said.

title: One Way to Lower the Risk of Exercise
description: The American Heart Association is urging all gyms and fitness clubs, especially large centers and those with many elderly members, to install automated external defibrillators, the portable devices that can sometimes shock a stalled heart back to life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SYLVIA JOSEPHS
description: BERGER-Sylvia Josephs. In her 100th year. Died on March 2, 2002. A woman of extraordinary intelligence and taste; character and grace. Fiercely independent in mind and action. Her midwestern roots were evident in her sense of fairness and ethics. Born and raised in Duluth, MN she graduated from Smith College in 1924 (was the only one to return and participate in her 75th reunion). Attended the Sorbonne, received a law degree from New York University in the late 1920's. She was a pro bono lawyer for 20 years at the Juvenile Court in the Bronx. A seasoned traveller before World War II. She could read Greek, Latin and French; studied Russian language and Russian literature at Hunter College until she was 96. Attended art classes at the Metropolitan Museum and went to the Philharmonic until late last fall. Married to Arthur M. Berger for over 53 years. He predeceased her, as did a brother Irving and son-in-law Daniel Cowin. Survived by daughter Joyce Cowin, three grandchildren Kenneth (Jasmin), Andrew (Allyson), Dana (Barclay Palmer), three great-grandchildren Reagan and Alexandra Cowin, Sylvie Palmer. As well as a sister Muriel Cowan and brother Arthur Josephs (Adrianne) from Duluth, MN. Interment private. A celebration of her life will be held at her daughter's, April 3rd, 4-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Russian Department at Hunter College or the Jewish Studies Program at Smith College.

title: N.F.L. to Open on a Thursday
description: The National Football League made it official yesterday, confirming that the 2002 season would start on Thursday night, Sept. 5, with the game almost certain to be played in Giants Stadium. The Giants are expected to play host to the San Francisco 49ers in a game televised by ESPN. The Giants-49ers matchup will not become official until the full schedule is completed about a month from now.

title: Corrections

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Oahu Smoking Ban
description: The Honolulu City Council has banned smoking in restaurants and most restaurant bars on the island of Oahu starting July 1. The ban will apply to the remaining restaurant bars starting July 1, 2003. Stand-alone bars and nightclubs are exempt. Nearly 400 other American communities have smoke-free restaurant ordinances, said Cynthia Hallett, executive director of Americans for Nonsmokers Rights. Patrick McCain, president of the Hawaii Restaurant Association, says his 430 members fear the law will hurt business but do not plan to seek a repeal. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: U.S. Moves to Close Canadian Drug Route for Illegal Stimulant
description: The illegal production in the United States of popular stimulants like methamphetamine reflects lax regulations in Canada for the chemical ingredients, American and Canadian law enforcement officials have said.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Sentence In Anthrax Threat
description: A man pleaded guilty yesterday to mailing letters falsely threatening to infect their recipients with anthrax. The defendant, Amir Omerovic, a 28-year-old naturalized citizen from Bosnia now living in Derby, admitted in Federal District Court that in late October he sent such letters to the offices of Gov. John G. Rowland, the United States Coast Guard and Marines in Connecticut, and the Judicial Review Council in Hartford. John A. Danaher III, the United States attorney, said that Mr. Omerovic, who faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine, is to be sentenced on May 17. Prosecutors said the letters contained a note that read: ''09.11.01. Anthrax is deadly. You breathe and die. This is only the beginning. Americans will die. Death to America and Israel.''

title: An Old Childhood Disease Reappears
description: As chickenpox begins to disappear in the United States, another potentially dangerous disease for children, pertussis, has been bouncing back, according to two recent studies from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Yankees' Injury List Grows As Jeter Strains His Neck
description: Derek Jeter had a pain-relieving gel spread across the back of his neck and kept his head as rigid as Frankenstein's monster's after spending most of this morning in the trainer's room. Jeter could twist his neck to the right, but he could barely turn to the left because of a muscle strain.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Trouble At Foreign Ministry
description: The scandal-plagued Foreign Ministry acknowledged that a senior governing party politician had exerted improper influence over ministry policies and bidding for government contracts. The accusations against Muneo Suzuki, a member of Parliament, have been blamed for a sharp loss in popularity for Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi. Mr. Koizumi's support began to plummet last month, when he removed the popular foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, who had called for a major shake-up of the ministry. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Environment Officials Approve Kyoto Pact
description: The European Union's 15 environment ministers agreed that their countries would be bound by the Kyoto Protocol, the treaty that seeks to cut the pollution blamed for global warming. Formal ratification of the pact -- which commits the union to reduce emissions of ''greenhouse gases'' by 8 percent of 1990 levels during the five-year period from 2008 through 2012 -- now goes to the European Council of heads of state and government, which could act as early as this month at the union summit in Barcelona. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Enron's Last Charity Ball
description: Throughout Houston, leaders of cultural and charitable organizations are facing a new problem: Enron-created budget shortfalls. In a city that prides itself on the ideals of self-reliance and low taxes, private patrons have long been expected to sponsor libraries, support public schools and finance the arts. But Enron stood out as munificent, a sort of corporate Medici. And in Houston, as in Renaissance Florence, displays of civic patronage go hand-in-hand with political influence and, of course, social stature.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Money For Housing
description: The Los Angeles City Council has approved a $100 million trust fund for affordable housing. Officials said the fund would help build at least 2,000 additional housing units a year. ''We are moving from housing crisis to housing revival,'' said Mayor James K. Hahn. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Mubarak, on Visit to U.S., Urges Meeting of Mideast Rivals

title: Rescued H.I.V. Babies Face New Problems as Teenagers

These infants were the offspring of H.I.V.-positive women, many of them addicted to drugs. Often extremely sick, the babies were frequently either given away or taken away; most were not expected to reach their fifth birthdays.

title: Despite Complaining About Pay, Justices Won't Review a Ruling That Blocks Raises

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Falls
description: One of Europe's largest banks, HSBC, reported a 14 percent decline in pretax profit, to $8.8 billion, compared with $10.3 billion last year, as it wrote down $1.12 billion in Argentine investments after that country's currency was devalued. The bank also set aside $575 million to cover the costs of settling a lawsuit brought by Japanese investors against the Republic New York Corporation, which HSBC bought from Edmond Safra in 1999. Provisions for bad loans rose to $2 billion in 2001. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Petroleum Merger

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Barclays To Stay Downtown
description: In a boost for Lower Manhattan, Barclays Bank renewed its lease last week for three floors -- 104,000 square feet -- at 222 Broadway, near Park Row. The lease renewal is one of the largest downtown since the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center and follows the decision by American Express to abandon Jersey City and move more than 500 employees back to Lower Manhattan. Barclays had moved some employees last summer to 200 Park Avenue. ''This is a major confidence-builder for the downtown market,'' said Peter G. Riguardi, vice chairman of Colliers ABR, which represents Merrill Lynch, the 222 Broadway landlord. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Aether To Cut 25% Of Work Force
description: Aether Systems, which develops software and wireless data products and services, said it would cut about 225 jobs, or about 25 percent of its work force, because of the economic downturn and a slower adoption of wireless data technologies than the company expected. Aether said it would cut expenses, consolidate sites and streamline its European venture, Sila Communications, in an effort to cut operating costs and become profitable. The company, in Owings Mills, Md., said it would take a charge of about $11 million in the first quarter for the revamping. Aether said operating expenses would decrease throughout the year, from about $40 million in the first quarter to roughly $20 million for the fourth quarter.

title: Bush Says He Is Saddened by Deaths but Undeterred
description: President Bush said today that he was saddened by the deaths of American soldiers in Afghanistan but that he was more focused than ever in hunting down Al Qaeda fighters in the expanding American war on terrorism.

title: STOP AND SHOP AND PATHMARK BID FOR 26 SHOPRITE STORES
description: The Stop and Shop Supermarket Company, a unit of the food distributor Royal Ahold N.V., said it teamed with Pathmark Stores Inc. to bid for 26 ShopRite stores from creditors of the Big V Holding Corporation's Big V Supermarkets. Pathmark would pay $71 million plus an unspecified amount for inventory to acquire nine of the outlets in New York state, it said. Stop and Shop, in a separate statement, did not say how much it would pay. Big V, which operates 31 ShopRite stores in New York, filed for protection from creditors in November 2000. The purchase will require permission from the court handling Big V's Chapter 11 protection in addition to that of antitrust regulators and Big V creditors, Stop and Shop said.

title: Hard-Pressed Argentina to Tax All Exports
description: With its revenues plummeting, social unrest continuing and inflation beginning to rise, the Argentine government announced tonight that it was imposing a tax on all exports and that it intended to use the money to keep popular social programs going.

title: After Questioning, New Jersey Panel Approves State Police Nominee
description: Joseph J. Santiago, Gov. James E. McGreevey's nominee to lead the New Jersey State Police, was approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee tonight after a daylong show of fierce support and fierce opposition.

title: U.S. Report Criticizes Allies in Antiterror Campaign for Human Rights Abuses
description: Many of the Bush administration's strategic allies in the war on terror abused human rights in their own countries last year, from Pakistan to the Central Asian states and Saudi Arabia, the State Department's annual report on the subject said today.

title: Martin Won't Play Against The Lakers
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott was guilty of overstating the obvious in a recent meeting with Kenyon Martin, telling his tempestuous forward, ''We need you in uniform, not in street clothes.''

title: Enron Pensions Still Under Old Management
description: Despite an agreement three weeks ago to replace the executives who oversee Enron's pension plans with an independent official, the retirement plans are still being supervised by the executives who did little when Enron stock plummeted last year, a senior Democratic lawmaker said today.

title: Russians Make No Promises To OPEC Officials on Oil Cuts
description: Russia made no promises one way or the other today to the leaders of OPEC, who had traveled here in hopes of persuading this country's oil industry to continue to hold back exports of crude.

title: Deadline for Bomb Screening Will Not Be Met
description: The Transportation Department said today that it would not meet the Dec. 31 deadline Congress had set for screening all baggage checked at the nation's airports with costly explosive detection systems.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a consortium that is being set up to bid for six cable networks of Deutsche Telekom mistranslated the amount that Compere Associates, a British investment group, might be willing to offer. The possible bid of 5.5 billion euros, cited by people close to the companies, would translate to $4.8 billion, not million.

description: Plastic, heal thyself.
