description: If you get kicks from watching old films of the Bears beating the Redskins by 73-0 or Secretariat winning the Belmont Stakes by 31 lengths, you would have loved the Connecticut-Villanova semifinal tonight in the Big East tournament.

title: Visiting Joffrey Is Right at Home In Washington
description: A home away from home is what the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts should offer the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago. The company looked just right here in the center's opera house when it presented a signature bill of diverse 20th-century ballets.

description: Dr. Callum Roberts, 39, a soft-spoken senior lecturer of marine environmental management at the University of York in England and one of the world's leading conservation biologists, was sipping a cup of tea and waxing passionate about his favorite creature: the fish.

description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about a campaign created for the Hartford Financial Services Group, misstated the scope. It covers the company as a whole, not just its life insurance unit.

description: BILT-Helen Francis Rubin. Formerly of Deal, N.J. and New York City. It is with heartfelt sorrow that her family announces their tragic loss. Daughter Cynthia and husband Jack N. description: YOUNG-Dr. Victor J. Of Green port, L.I. (formerly of Port Washington) on March 1, 2002 at the age of 88. Graduate of Albion College and the University of Iowa. Professor Emeritus at CUNY and Queensboro Community College. Former Vice-president of Hazeltine and Research Engineer with Sperry-Rand. Beloved husband of the late, Margaret Brandt Young. title: Full and Not at All: The Difference Between 2 New Jersey Reservoirs
description: The Wanaque Reservoir is a sorry sight these parched days. Parts of the reservoir, the largest in northeastern New Jersey, resemble a desert pocked with ponds. But only about an hour's drive south, the state's biggest reservoir, the Round Valley, is almost brimming with water, a strange oasis in the worsening East Coast drought.

title: Costas Is on Wish List At ABC and ESPN
description: Bob Costas will be a free agent in midsummer when his contract ends, raising the legitimate possibility that he and NBC Sports will part.

title: He Has the Third-Generation Genes for His Genres
description: THE door to the Greenwich Village cubbyhole that houses Nick Davis Productions swings open to reveal the young company's namesake, Mr. Davis, outnumbered by flickering computer screens as he yaps into his phone in the hyper shorthand that passes for conversation with television types. He seems thrilled to be harried. Nothing like a production deadline to make a start-up producer's heart go pitter-patter.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If the Palestinians are not being beaten, there will be no negotiations. The aim is to increase the number of losses on the other side. Only after they've been battered, will we be able to conduct talks.''

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Heart Surgeons Stage Protest
description: Heart surgeons carried out a one-day national work stoppage to protest what they described as a dangerous shortage of medical supplies brought on by the country's economic crisis. In a separate action, public school teachers in seven provinces did not report for classes on the first day of the new school year, complaining that the government was months in arrears on their salaries because of the economic collapse. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, ELAINE
description: UNGER - Elaine. Congregation Talmud Torah Adereth El wishes to express our heartfelt condolences to our dear member, Mrs. Ginger Wexler, on the loss of her mother Elaine Unger. May she be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Butler Tops Big East Stars
description: Connecticut's Caron Butler was the only unanimous selection to the all-Big East men's basketball team yesterday. Voting by the conference coaches was so close that seven players made the first team.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Party Leader Takes Over
description: Roberto Madrazo, a former governor, was sworn in as president of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which governed the country for most of the last century until it fell from power in 2000. After a vote marred by allegations of fraud, Mr. Madrazo was formally declared the winner of the party's first attempt at a democratic contest for president. Recovering the people's confidence in a party with a long history of corruption and fraud will be his chief priority, Mr. Madrazo said, adding, ''There is no doubt that if the PRI does not change, it will disappear from the national political scene.''

title: Mathis And U.S. Sparkle
description: CLINT MATHIS is back, swagger, goals and all.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Gun Owners Sue To Lower Fees
description: Seven Nassau County residents are suing to overturn the county's increase in the permit fee for licensed pistols to $200 a year from $25. The suit, filed last month and announced yesterday, said that fees ought to reflect actual costs, which the police have estimated at $75, the gun owners say. The suit claims that the County Legislature increased the fees in 2000 to raise $5 million a year to help close the county's budget deficit.

description: To the Editor:

title: Creditors Resist Asian Bid for Global Crossing
description: Creditors of Global Crossing are strongly resisting an offer by two Asian companies to acquire the bankrupt company's assets after reports of a competing bid emerged over the weekend, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: That Lovable Sitcom Dad Who Likes to Nibble Bats
description: As the cameras follow a family moving into its new California house, we see the boxes all neatly labeled: ''Pots & Pans,'' ''Linens,'' ''Devil Heads.'' Then we meet the characters in this newest reality series. There's Sharon, the practical mom; Jack, the bored teenage son; Kelly, the pink-haired teenage daughter; and Dad, a heavy-metal icon who screams ''rock 'n' roll!'' at the camera.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon To Trim Equivalent Of 10,000 Jobs
description: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, plans to eliminate the equivalent of about 10,000 jobs this year, mainly through the reduction of overtime and contract positions. Ivan Seidenberg, Verizon's chief executive, told investors at a conference in Orlando, Fla., that the company was trying to cut costs because of slower sales growth caused by a sluggish economy. Verizon had about 247,000 employees at the end of 2001, compared with about 263,000 a year earlier. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: CITIGROUP PLANS $4 BILLION TRAVELERS OFFERING
description: Travelers Property Casualty Corporation, a subsidiary of Citigroup Inc., will offer investors 210 million shares in an initial public offering worth as much as $4 billion, the largest ever for an insurance company. Travelers will offer investors a 20 percent stake with shares at $16 to $19 each, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Travelers plans to sell $850 million in senior notes at the same time as the stock sale, according to the filing.

title: Leo Ornstein, 108, Pianist And Avant-Garde Composer
description: Leo Ornstein, a Russian-born composer and pianist who in the early 20th century was a leading figure of the American avant-garde, died on Feb. 24 in Green Bay, Wis. He was either 108 or 109.

description: VOGEL-Theodore J. Died on November 20, 2001 at age ninty-six at Gardens Court, Palm Beach, FL. Husband of the late Nancy Vogel. Dear uncle of John Corcoran of Shrewsbury, NJ and Robert Corcoran of New Windsor, NY. Mr. Vogel was a partner in Marcus and Vogel Construction Company, the builder of thousands of homes and apartments in New Jersey. During a career that spanned sixty years, Mr Vogel also built airforce bases and military facilities in North Africa for the United States government during World War II. The burial was at the Gold Coast Crematory, Ft. Lauderdale, FL.

description: In a scathing opinion released yesterday, a federal judge excoriated city officials for what he said was a routine practice of removing children from battered mothers by claiming that the mothers were ''engaging in domestic violence.''

description: Three cars of a No. 7 train bound from Queens to Manhattan derailed yesterday, transit officials said, causing no injuries but creating long delays for thousands of city commuters.

title: Early Warnings When the Volcano Starts to Slip
description: Every 300,000 years or so, a piece of earth about the size of Rhode Island slides off the side of a Hawaiian volcano and falls into the ocean. The splash -- a disastrous ocean-size version of tossing a pebble in a pond -- sends rings of waves 100 feet and higher radiating outward until they crash, catastrophically, against shorelines around the Pacific Rim, from California to South America to Australia.

title: Four Die in a Brooklyn Fire As a 6-Year-Old Seeks Help
description: At 2 a.m. yesterday, there was a knock on the door of Keith Campbell's Brooklyn apartment. He opened it to see a familiar face -- the 6-year-old boy who lived upstairs -- horribly transfigured: he was so badly burned that the white-charred skin hung off his face and arms.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kirch May Sell Assets
description: A top executive at the Kirch Group, Germany's troubled media conglomerate, said the company would be willing to give up control of its pay television network and possibly its broadcasting rights to Formula One races. Dieter Hahn, Kirch's deputy chief executive, made the remarks at a media conference in London. Kirch is struggling to avoid bankruptcy, but talks about a possible bailout have been bogged down in disagreements among Germany's biggest creditor banks. The pay television business, Premiere, is believed to be losing more than $700 million a year and industry executives say it needs an infusion of money quickly to stay alive. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Playing Politics With Trade
description: Many corporate chieftains around the country must be scratching their heads in amazement, wondering why they worked so hard to elect a market-loving, free-trading Republican administration. Democrats are supposed to be the ones who pander to labor unions. Yet it is President Bush who is considering the ill-advised move of slapping tariffs on steel imports, one that his Democratic predecessor responsibly resisted.

title: Where to Go in Louisiana When the Music Dies
description: The gravedigger pointed down a row of homemade headstones.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Tax Amnesty Advances
description: The State Senate overwhelmingly approved a tax amnesty measure yesterday intended to coax millions of dollars from delinquent taxpayers. The measure, estimated to raise about $150 million, was proposed by Gov. James E. McGreevey to help close the state's $2.9 billion budget deficit. The full Senate passed the measure 36 to 1, just before the Assembly Appropriations Committee approved the bill, clearing it for a vote by the full Assembly. The measure forgives penalties and interest on overdue taxes. The amnesty period would last 60 days, until no later than June 10, 2002, and apply to taxes owed between Jan. 1, 1996, and Jan. 1, 2002. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Reviewing Death Row Cases
description: Gov. George Ryan will review the cases of all 163 inmates on death row before he leaves office next year and has not ruled out commuting all the sentences, his spokesman said. The review comes two years after Governor Ryan issued a moratorium on the death penalty after 13 death row inmates were freed after new evidence was submitted. No action is expected by the governor until a commission makes recommendations this spring. Daniel I. Dorfman (NYT)

description: When Mrs. S. and I first discussed whether she should have a spiral C.T. scan to look for lung cancer, it seemed like the right thing to do.

description: As the six-month mark approaches after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, executives at the charities supported by the 9/11 Neediest Fund reflected on the wave of need that found its way to their doorsteps and on the flood of donations that met it.

title: Greenwich Extends a Beach Fee for Outsiders to All Its Parks
description: This town's Board of Selectmen was criticized last month when it voted to charge out-of-towners $308 a head to use the town's beaches. But the reaction apparently did not faze the board, which has decided to extend those fees to all of the town's parks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKERMAN, SYLVIA
description: BECKERMAN - Sylvia. Beloved mother of Daniel and the late Laurence and Ann. Loving mother-inlaw to Gwenn Williams. We were all touched by your gracious heart, your gentle words and your fiercely loyal love. Know that you shall live on in each and every act of kindness that graces our days. Even as we are diminished by your passing, so we are blessed and strengthened by the gift of your life. We shall love you now and forever with reverence and gratitude. So suffer no more, sweet Mother, you are free to let your spirit soar.

He was beloved by his wife of 57 years, Lila; his children, Sydele, Lawrence and Nina, and Harvey (deceased); and his grandchildren, Maggie Golston, John and Robin Golston, Isabel and Rishon Blumberg, Amy and Will Gadsden, and Brian Epstein. description: JOSEPH-Esther Griffing. Age 74, on February 11, 2002. Memorial service will be held March 6 at 3 PM, Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street, NYC.

title: An All-American Boy, From Australia
description: If it sometimes seems that Australian movie stars are more quintessentially American on the screen than many home-grown actors, the same might be said of the Australian singer David Campbell's approach to American popular song. In ''Back From Oz,'' his new show at the Cafe Carlyle, this 28-year-old singer from Adelaide pays tribute to Bobby Darin (with a medley of his hits) and Sammy Davis Jr. (''Mr. Bojangles''). He rounds out his performance with a happy-go-lucky ''Alexander's Ragtime Band.''

title: Mount Sinai Budget Squeeze Is Forcing 450 Jobs to Be Cut
description: Mount Sinai Medical Center said yesterday that it would cut 450 jobs as it attempts to deal with a tight financial squeeze that has grown worse since Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank To Sell Stake
description: Bank Sarasin & Cie, buffeted by losses, has agreed to sell a 28 percent stake to Rabobank, a Dutch company. Profit at the bank, which is privately held and based in Basel, fell 47 percent last year. The unusual deal involved no cash, but the Dutch company has the option to buy control from Sarasin's 10 partners over a seven-year period. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Language Law Aimed At Immigrants
description: The government proposed a law that would make German language classes mandatory for all immigrants from countries outside the European Union and make them pay half the cost. Under the Integration Contract long sought by the far-right Freedom Party, which shares power in the coalition government, all immigrants would be fingerprinted, and those who refused to take the language courses would have social and unemployment benefits suspended. The plan is to be presented to Parliament this spring. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Ex-Nets Star Accused of Manslaughter Offers Condolences to Victim's Family
description: In his first public statement since he was charged with manslaughter last week, the former New Jersey Nets star Jayson Williams offered ''heartfelt condolences'' today to the family of a limousine driver whom he is accused of killing during a party at his estate last month.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Partial Budget Approval
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber said he would allow most of a Republican budget, which he called ''stunningly irresponsible,'' to become law without his signature. The budget was approved in a special session called to deal with the state's projected $846 million fiscal gap. Mr. Kitzhaber, a Democrat, indicated he would veto parts of the budget and make up the difference in administrative cuts. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Relief Found for Children's Dual Ailments
description: Muscle tics and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, commonly called A.D.H.D., often go together, a fact that has complicated treatment. Doctors have worried that the stimulants prescribed for the hyperactivity will worsen the twitching that comes with conditions like Tourette's syndrome.

title: Device Aims to Cut Injuries From Handlebars
description: Bicycle accidents that seem minor can cause serious abdominal injuries in children, say researchers in Philadelphia who have designed a handlebar that they hope will make biking safer.

description: AS anyone who bought Reese's Pieces after watching ''ET'' knows, product placement can be an effective marketing tool. Fast forward 20 years as the concept has moved to video games.

title: Bush Promotes His Education Agenda and a Senate Candidate
description: President Bush came to Minnesota today to raise political donations and to promote the benefits of the education bill that he signed into law in January, speaking to students flanked by huge chalkboards displaying the White House-created motto ''A Quality Teacher in Every Classroom.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUART, MARY
description: STUART-Mary. On February 28, 2002. ''The Queen of Soaps'', she starred as Joanne Tate for the entire 35-year run of ''Search for Tomorrow'', then as Meta Bauer on ''The Guiding Light''; awarded a Lifetime Achievement Emmy Award in 1983, and was the first daytime actress nominated for an Emmy. Adored wife of Wolfgang Neumann, loving mother to Cynthia and Jeffrey, devoted gradmother to John and William. A truly remarkable woman who excelled in every endeavordaughter, mother, grandmother, wife, actress, author, singer, composer, advocate, mentor, friend. Donations may be made to the Mary Stuart Fund for Book PALS, Screen Actors Guild Foundation, 5757 Wilshire Blvd, Los Angeles, CA. 90036. A memorial service will be held April 5th at 10:30AM at the Explorers Club in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, MARVIN E.
description: FRANKEL-Marvin E. The Board of Trustees and the staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services acknowledge with great sorrow the passing of Judge Marvin E. Frankel, beloved husband of Dr. Alice Kross Frankel, Director Emerita and Chief Psychiatrist of our Child Development Center. A former U.S. District Court Judge, Southern District of New York and Professor of Law at Columbia University, Judge Frankel was one of the world's leading advocates for human rights and had a powerful influence in the fight for social justice. Dr. Frankel was and will continue to be a true partner in this work. Judge Frankel also cared deeply for the well being of children, his wife's life work, and shared on a pro bono basis the vast expertise of his firm, Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel to help CDC when needed. He was a wonderful husband, loving father and devoted grandfather. Our deepest condolences to Dr. Frankel, their four children and their spouses and six grandchildren. The world is a stronger and freer place thanks to the extraordinary work of Judge Marvin E. Frankel. Joseph S. Kaplan, Chairman of the Board, JBFCS Jean L. Troubh, President, JBFCS Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., EVP and CEO, JBFCS Renee J. Ward, Chair, CDC Divisional Committee Marian Davidson-Amodeo, Director, CDC

title: Maine Parish Agonizes Over a Priest's Confession
description: The Catholic roots of this far-northern valley are about as deep as they get. More than two centuries after Catholics marked the land with a large cross, people in and around this town named for a martyred saint are still steeped in the faith.

title: Israeli Raids Kill 17 Palestinians; In Tel Aviv, 3 Die in a Shooting
description: Still burying its dead from the weekend's bloodshed, Israel unleashed its anger at Palestinians throughout their territories on Monday. Helicopters fired shells that landed near Yasir Arafat's headquarters in Ramallah, and an Israeli tank shell ripped into a pickup truck there, killing a woman and her children before the eyes of passing schoolchildren.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen advanced, fueled by a rally in Japan's benchmark stock average. In New York, the dollar settled at 132.27 yen, down from 133.26 on Friday.

title: 2 Ex-Officers in Louima Case Delay Plans for Reinstatement
description: Two former police officers whose convictions were overturned in the Abner Louima torture case have decided not to seek reinstatement to the department in the immediate future, their lawyers said yesterday.

title: U.S. MAY APPROVE MORE AID FOR KIN OF SEPT. 11 DEAD
description: After months of criticism from the families of those killed on Sept. 11, the Bush administration is close to a decision on several changes in the Victims Compensation Fund that could result in scores of families' receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars more than the fund's original rules would have allowed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARCADI, ANTONY
description: ARCADI-Antony. Of Brooklyn on March 3, 2002. Beloved husband of Linda (nee Squiciarino). Loving father of Antony Philip and Jackie. Cherished son of Carmela Arcadipane. Fond brother of Mariann. Adored grandfather of Gabrielle. Antony was a C.P.A. and professor at Brooklyn College, where he was a department chairperson. He donated his time as an auditor for New York City under former Mayor Giuliani. At the request of the deceased, funeral services will be private. The family will receive visitors at their home on Tuesday and Wednesday, 4-9PM.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Robbery Is Likely Motive In Murder
description: Investigators say robbery is the most likely motive in the fatal shooting of a doctor from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., in a hotel parking lot. Dr. Jeffrey S. Perchick, 55, died after being shot in the head Friday night as he walked toward the Wyndham Newark Airport Hotel. Thomas V. Manahan, the Union County prosecutor, said that Dr. Perchick's black leather wallet, with credit cards and more than $500 cash, was missing. ''Dr. Perchick happened to be in the wrong spot at the wrong time,'' Mr. Manahan said. Witnesses heard at least one shot, then saw a stocky black male with a goatee, wearing a plaid shirt or jacket, crouching over Dr. Perchick's body.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Union Vote Averts Newspaper Closing
description: The management of The Jersey Journal, the last remaining daily in Jersey City, announced yesterday an agreement with union officials that would save the 135-year-old newspaper. Steven Newhouse, the editor in chief, said that the drivers' union had voted to accept job cuts to reduce its 18 members by half. The other two unions, representing reporters, photographers and clerical employees, had already agreed to make similar cuts. The Journal, with a circulation of 40,000, has been battered by shrinking readership and advertising revenues. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Hospital Says a Faulty Recall May Have Put 400 in Danger
description: A defective medical device used at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore by doctors who say they did not know that it had been recalled may have exposed more than 400 patients to bacteria that can cause a dangerous lung infection.

title: For a New Obstruction Trial
description: Thomas Bruder, Thomas Wiese and Charles Schwarz were acquitted last week of conspiring to obstruct justice in the Abner Louima case, but they were hardly exonerated. The Second Circuit Court of Appeals held that prosecutors had failed to present sufficient evidence that the three men had violated a federal law against conspiring to obstruct a grand jury inquiry. But in reversing their convictions, the court said that if the three men had been charged under a broader law against conspiring to lie to federal agents, there would have been enough evidence to uphold the convictions.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Credit Outlook Improving
description: Malaysia's credit rating may be raised for the first time in more than two years, Standard & Poor's said, citing the resilience of the nation's currency peg and government progress in returning ailing companies to health. S.& P. raised its outlook on Malaysia's BBB rating to positive from stable, the first step toward an upgrade. The rating, two notches above noninvestment grade, was last raised in November 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, PAUL E., SR.
description: CARR-Paul E., Sr. Former Executive Vice President Goodall Fabrics. Died March 4, 2002 in Danbury, CT at the age of 98. Husband of the late Mildred Brenner Carr. Beloved father of Paul Jr., Nancy Carr, Joan Eggert and Virginia Kops. Devoted grandfather of Ambrose Carr III, Paul Carr III, Christopher, Carol, Charlotte and Celeste Eggert, George, Gregory and Alexandra Kops, Paula Cummings, Margot Carr and Marette Winchester. Also five great grandchildren. Memorial services will be announced. Contributions to Favorite Charity in his memory would be appreciated. Cornell Memorial Home, Danbury, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETTINATO, LAWRENCE G. JR.
description: PETTINATO-Lawrence G. Jr. Passed away peacefully Sunday, March 3rd at home with his loving wife and children at his bedside. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth N. (nee Brown) whom he cherished, his sons Lawrence III and Michael whom he adored, his loving parents Edith and Lawrence, Sr. and his devoted brothers John and Thomas. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (at 20th St,) NYC, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10 A.M. at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Morristown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Pettinato Boys Education Fund will be appreciated.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sierra Leone: Rebel Leader Charged
description: Foday Sankoh, the rebel leader who has been held in prison for nearly two years, was taken to court and charged with murder, a charge that could lead to the death penalty, according to Justice Minister Solomon Berewa. The government could no longer hold Mr. Sankoh and 71 other members of the Revolutionary United Front without filing charges because a state of emergency was lifted last week, Mr. Berewa said. The rebels killed and mutilated thousands of civilians in the civil war, which they and the government have declared over. Elections are set for May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOXEN, WILLIAM A.
description: FOXEN-William A. Of Laurel Hollow, NY, died March 4, 2002 at the age of 85. Mr. Foxen was born to William and Mary Foxen of Brooklyn, NY, on July 19, 1916. He was a graduate of the Brooklyn Technological High School, and attended New York University and Columbia University. In 1940 Mr. Foxen volunteered for service in the United States Army, graduating from the infantry school at Ft. Benning, GA, and Command and General Staff School at Ft. Leavenworth, KS. He served in a number of command and staff positions during four years in the Pacific Theater, including command of an infantry battalion combat team as a twenty-eight-year-old major. Mr. Foxen was a veteran of forty-six years in the advertising business, including serving as a vice president of the Benton & Bowles Agency, and a senior vice president of Ketchum, McLeod & Grove. In 1976 he founded the Foxen & Fredman Agency of Long Island, which he successfully managed until his retirement at age 76. Mr. Foxen was an early proponent of the application of advertising agency talents on a pro bono basis to the problems of not-for-profit organizations. He gave of his time extensively to a number of volunteer organizations, including serving on the Hoover Commission, the Advertising Council, the National Council of the American Cancer Society, and as a trustee of the Village of Laurel Hollow. His wife of 55 years, Eleanor Amy Foxen; seven children, William, Jr., Kathleen, Nancy, Elizabeth, Ellen, Peter and Anne; two brothers, Robert and Richard; and seventeen grandchildren survive Mr. Foxen. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc. of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd. Visiting Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, 11:30 AM at St. Dominic's Chapel, Oyster Bay, N.Y. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Book Fund of the Cold Spring Harbor Library, 75 Goose Hill Road, Cold Spring Harbor, New York 11724.

title: Unfinished War in Afghanistan
description: More American soldiers -- at least seven -- were killed in combat yesterday in Afghanistan than during the entire period since the war began last October, a telling sign that this conflict is far from over and that more fatalities on all sides can be expected. The job of defeating and capturing leaders and fighters of Al Qaeda's terrorism network has not been completed.

title: Bush Edging Toward Decision on Steel Imports
description: The White House edged toward a final decision today to impose tariffs on imported steel, as President Bush weighed recommendations from his advisers and last-minute pleas from an array of competing interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, CAROL
description: GOLDBERG-Carol. Loving partner of seven years of Rhoda London. Loving daughter of David (Paulette) and the late Lorraine Goldberg. Cherished sister of Mark (Sharon) Goldberg. Debbie Goldberg, and Susan (Rich) Tuckman. The most fun aunt of Liza, Julia, Daniel and Eric. Services 12:30 Wednesday at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapel'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Donations to be made to: Katies Find A Cure, P.O. Box 142, Bourbonnais, IL, 60914.

title: Network News Is Still Serious Business
description: I have to confess to a slightly perverse satisfaction at the outpouring of warm and generous support that my ''Nightline'' colleagues and I have received since news reports that our employers at ABC are negotiating with David Letterman to take over the time slot we currently occupy.

title: Thrills Onstage and Off As Youngsters Step Out
description: Tap is alive and well. That was the message of ''21 Below,'' a program on Friday night at Town Hall by 11 dancers and groups of performers under 21 years old, put together by the New York Committee to Celebrate National Tap Day. Part of the fun was the large and vociferous audience, which shouted out encouragement to the young dancers and to Jennifer Holliday, the evening's gracious host. The indispensable Frank Owens Trio was also on hand to accompany the dancers and perform on its own with typically easygoing, crisp grace.

title: Claim of Small-Scale Fusion Produces Early Skepticism
description: In an echo of claims that limitless, cheap energy could be generated through ''cold fusion'' 13 years ago, a team of scientists will report in Friday's issue of the journal Science that it has achieved nuclear fusion in a small, tabletop experiment. But even before the findings reach print, many scientists are already expressing skepticism and are wondering why Science accepted the article over the doubts.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT SAYS IT WILL CUT 2,000 JOBS
description: Waste Management, the biggest United States trash hauler, said yesterday that it would cut 2,000 jobs, or 3.5 percent of its work force. The company will record about $50 million in pretax costs in the first quarter because of the restructuring, which it hopes will result in saving about $100 million a year, Waste Management said. Shares of Waste Management, which is based in Houston, rose 60 cents, to $27.63. The news was released after the close of regular trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAWITT, KURT C., M.D.
description: RAWITT-Kurt C., M.D. Devoted husband of Regina, loving father of Ronald (Jean), Tamara, Peggy (Philip) and proud grandfather of Jonathan and Benjamin.

In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87 St, NY, NY 10128 or to the Irvington Institute for Immunologic Research, 245 5th Avenue, Room 2101, New York, New York 10016.

title: Garnes Changes Locker Rooms but Not ZIP Codes in Move to the Jets
description: In a continuum reaching back to Don Maynard in 1960, Sam Garnes, a Bronx native, will become the 41st player to play for the Giants and the Jets.

title: Gap Revises Its Spring Campaign
description: The troubled Gap division of Gap Inc. is changing its spring advertising plans.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Manugistics Predicts Higher Earnings
description: The Manugistics Group,a software company in Rockville, Md., said its fourth-quarter earnings would exceed company and Wall Street estimates. ''We are continuing to see improved business spending and positive market momentum,'' said Greg Owens, the chief executive of Manugistics. ''We are confident in our ability to continue to take market share and increase revenue as we begin our new fiscal year.'' Manugistics, which makes software that helps companies share inventory, pricing and planning information with customers and suppliers over the Internet, said it would end a mandatory unpaid leave program on March 17. In October, the company said it would require employees in the United States to take off three days each month without pay -- effectively a 15 percent pay cut for its work force of more than 1,000.

title: Beeston, Owners' Negotiator, Leaves
description: Negotiators for baseball's club owners confirmed tonight that Paul Beeston, soon to depart as Major League Baseball's No. 2 executive, was no longer the chief negotiator in the talks with the union for a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Publisher's Profit Declines
description: Pearson, the owner of The Financial Times and Penguin Books, reported a 12 percent decline in pretax earnings, as it wrote down the value of some assets and advertising sales continued to slump. Pretax profit in 2001 was 294 million ($417 million), compared with 333 million a year earlier. The company took a 153 million write-down, mainly related to its acquisition of the book publisher Dorling Kindersley and the value of equity investments. Sales rose 15 percent, to 4.2 billion, compared with 3.7 billion last year, mainly driven by Pearson's educational publishing division in the United States. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Contractor In Japan Is Seeking Bankruptcy
description: On the face of it, the collapse of the Sato Kogyo Company, one of the largest construction companies in Japan, was long overdue.

title: Corrections
description: A credit listing on Feb. 22 with an article in the ''Watching Movies With . . .'' series, in which Nicole Kidman discussed ''The Shining,'' misstated the film's producer credit. Stanley Kubrick was its sole producer; Robert Fryer was not a producer.

title: Sports of The Times; Tiger Woods Gets to Play Times Square
description: IN his travels, Tiger Woods had been to Times Square several times before, but never to play golf. Even if this round would be on a video game. His video game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, PATRICIA IRENE, MD.
description: KENNY-Patricia Irene, MD. Died peacefully with her family at her side on Saturday, March 2, 2002 in Toronto, Canada. Beloved sister of Margaret Kenny of Ossining, NY and Bob Kenny of Ontario. Cherished aunt of Maureen, Bill, Alison, Sarah, and the late Carolyn. Visitation will be held in Toronto on Sunday March 10th, from 7-9pm. Service of remembrance on Monday March 11 at 2pm. For further information call 1-800-616-3311.

title: Scholastic Buys Publisher
description: The Scholastic Corporation, the publisher of the ''Harry Potter'' books in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire another publisher, Klutz, from Corus Entertainment of Canada for an initial payment of about $43 million.

title: FLORSHEIM FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY AND SELLS MOST ASSETS
description: The Florsheim Group, the maker and seller of men's shoes, sought bankruptcy protection after four years of losses and said it had found a buyer for most of its assets. The buyer, the Weyco Group, has agreed to purchase Florsheim's domestic wholesale business, related assets and some of its 155 stores for about $44.8 million, plus the assumption of certain debts. Weyco also agreed to buy some of Florsheim's foreign units, bringing the transaction's value to more than $47 million. The company, founded by a cobbler's son, Milton Florsheim, in 1892, listed $156.7 million in assets and $159.6 million in debts in Chapter 11 papers filed today in in Chicago, where it is based. Thomas W. Florsheim, the chairman of Weyco, which is based in Milwaukee, is the grandson of Florsheim's founder.

title: A Proud Renovation (Aside From That Falling Glass)
description: Before the curtain went up at the opening of ''Samson et Dalila,'' starring Plcido Domingo, the audience members could not seem to take their eyes off the ceiling.

title: In Manhattan, A U.N. Dispute On Real Estate (What Else?)
description: It is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's first diplomatic flap.

title: When Acclaim Isn't Enough
description: On the surface, the Brooklyn Philharmonic has everything. It is known for adventurous programming, and its music director, Robert Spano, is hailed as one of the most exciting young Americans on the podium today. New York's music critics routinely toss large bouquets in the orchestra's direction for concerts ranging from the American premiere of ''Powder Her Face,'' a provocative new English opera by Thomas Ades, to more familiar fare like the Mahler Third.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Candidate's Husband Target Of Raid
description: The rightist Liberal Front Party has threatened to withdraw from the governing coalition after a police raid on the business office of the husband of its candidate for president, Roseana Sarney. The police said that they were seeking evidence of Jorge Murad's involvement in a corruption scandal and that they had found more than $600,000 in cash, but party leaders accuse the government of trying to undermine Ms. Sarney's chances in the October election. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Viennese Tribute
description: The Vienna Philharmonic will perform a free concert on March 17 at St. Patrick's Cathedral as a memorial to the victims of Sept. 11.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Withdrawal Of Admission Plan
description: Texas A&M University, the flagship campus of one of the state's public university systems, has withdrawn a proposal that would have resulted in offers of admission to the top 20 percent of graduates of 250 high schools, provided they met thresholds for SAT scores and grade point averages. The university had devised the plan in response to a federal court ruling that struck down race-conscious admissions. But critics said that the proposal was intended as an end run and that many of the high schools had been selected because they had high concentrations of minority students. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: Big Draw Blocks Out Small Treasures
description: Jim Boeheim can be a glum sort, often acting as if the college basketball world were aligned against what he has built at Syracuse and adopting the conspiratorial monotones favored by the trench-coat-wearing F.B.I. agents on ''The X-Files.'' But he uttered something yesterday that not only falls neatly into that television show's tag line -- ''the truth is out there'' -- but also describes the uneasy twilight zone that teams enter this time of year.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intel Ships New Pentium 4 Chip
description: The Intel Corporation said it had begun shipping its newest member of the Pentium 4 chip family, this one for notebook computers. Several computer makers, including Dell and Compaq, began taking orders for new top-of-the-line notebooks that are powered by the new Pentium 4 chips, which Intel called the Pentium 4-M. The Pentium 4-M chips run as fast as 1.6 or 1.7 gigahertz, or billion cycles a second, compared with their fastest predecessor, the 1.2 gigahertz Pentium 3-M. Intel also introduced a faster memory system and chip set, which lets the processor talk to other parts of the computer. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Hindu Justifies Mass Killings Of Muslims in Reprisal Riots
description: Harish Bhai Bhatt is a jolly-looking man with a round belly and a bushy mustache that turns up like a smile, but his words would chill the soul of any Muslim in India.

title: New Hope for Taming Deadly Septic Shock
description: Can an otherwise healthy 58-year-old man die from a bad cold? He can, and he did.

title: Stanley Saplin; Sports Historian, 88
description: Stanley Saplin, a sports historian and statistician in New York for more than a half-century, died Friday night at New York University Medical Center. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALVERT, SEYMOUR, PH.D
description: CALVERT-Seymour, Ph.D Chemical Engineering. Pioneer in air pollution control and education. Died February 25, 2002 in San Diego, CA. Born January 9, 1924 in Detroit, MI. Internationally recognized as the foremost expert on air pollution control scrubbers. He has lectured throughout the world. His research led to the publication of books, numerous technical papers and patents. He served in the U.S. Army from 1943-46, in the Spec. Eng. Detach. at Los Alamos, NM, working on the atomic bomb initiator, which ultimately led to his demise from Berylliosis (respiratory failure). He set up & directed an Air Pollution Interdisciplinary Research Center at Penn State which became the largest air pollution program in the US. In 1967 Dr. Calvert joined the University of California Riverside as Dean of Engineering and Director of the Air Pollution Research Center. Dr. Calvert's ability and years of service were recognized by his invitation to attend the signing of the first Clean Air Act in 1967 at the White House by President Lyndon Johnson. In 1969 Dr. Calvert set up his own engineering company, A.P.T. Inc. in San Diego, CA. A.P.T. became the major contractor for EPA-sponsored Scrubber Research and Development. Dr. Calvert is survived by his wife of 54 years, Phyllis; his daughters Barbara Kuwent and Susan Sherman; and two grandchildren, Michael and Stephen Sherman.

title: Officials Say U.S. Should Have Shared Tip
description: Several of New York's top officials said yesterday that the Bush administration should have told them about an unconfirmed intelligence report in October that said terrorists planned to smuggle a nuclear weapon into New York City.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: New Chief for Trash Agency
description: Gov. John G. Rowland named a new head for the state's embattled trash authority, which is likely to have lost $220 million in the Enron Corporation bankruptcy. The new chairman of the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority is State Representative Richard O. Belden, a Republican from Shelton, who succeeds Peter Ellef, Mr. Rowland's co-chief of staff, who chose not to seek reappointment this year. Mr. Ellef has come under intense criticism in recent weeks because the authority apparently lost millions in a failed steam energy deal with Enron. The two leading Democratic candidates for governor have demanded that Mr. Ellef also resign as chief of staff. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Selig Has Become Target Of Some Players' Anger
description: The hot rumor of the spring isn't about a possible trade or the name of the man who will replace Joe Kerrigan as manager of the Boston Red Sox.

title: Sweaty Palms: Not Just a Case of Nerves
description: People with excessively sweaty palms may have their genes, and not their nervousness, to blame, a new study suggests.

title: Mets Play Hardball With Jordan
description: Brian Jordan has made a career out of beating the Mets. Jordan was so destructive against them last season that the Mets rationalized Gary Sheffield's trade from the Dodgers to the Braves for Jordan this off-season by saying that no one could hurt them as much as Jordan did.

title: A Model and Her Traitorous Stilettos
description: A remixed Stevie Nicks song was blaring. A parade of models was stalking a fur-covered runway in the Hotel Diana wearing the Betty Page stilettos that are Tom Ford's way to clothe a woman's foot.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, Some Stalwart Labels Take a Flier and Fall
description: Age means nothing in the world of fashion as long as you are connected to your times. Ask Karl Lagerfeld, already middle-aged when he took over Chanel 20 years ago and still alive to new ideas today, at 63. And Chanel herself was no young thing when she gave women a modern uniform to wear in the youth-conscious 1960's.

title: For Devils, Colorado Is Still Where Bad Things Happen
description: The noise level was several decibels below what the Devils heard the last time they left the Pepsi Center. The stakes were nowhere near as high as they were that night last June, the disappointment much less searing.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Laundry Manager Is Killed
description: The manager of a coin laundry in the Bronx was fatally shot after three men burst into the establishment early yesterday morning, the police said. Investigators said they did not believe the early-morning shooting was a robbery attempt because no one tried to steal anything after the manager, Michael Guzman, 34, was overcome. Mr. Guzman, who was hit once in the chest, was pronounced dead at St. Barnabas Hospital at 5 a.m., about 30 minutes after the shooting at the N.Y. Laundromat on Southern Boulevard in Crotona Park. A witness told the police that before the shot, one man said something in Spanish that he did not understand. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

description: BAKER-Richard Brown. A gathering in remembrance of art collector and philanthropist Richard Brown Baker will be held at The Grolier Club at 47 E. 60 St, NYC, on Tuesday, March 12, at 6 PM.

description: Unable to reach agreement on a bill to overhaul the nation's election procedures, the Senate decided today to set aside the legislation while a few Democrats and Republicans try to thrash out a compromise.

description: Siena began the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament as an embarrassed underdog. The Saints had lost three straight games, relegating them to the play-in round as the host team.

description: Things were getting hot last year for John M. Rusnak, a currency trader at a Baltimore bank, which now says that he hid $691 million in losses over five years.

title: Dreams of 'Metamorphoses' Echo in a Larger Space
description: The images snag on the edges of thought, stirring up fragments of half-remembered dreams. A door opens to reveal a dead lover, alive again and yet not quite the same. A man looks over his shoulder and fails to see the familiar face he was sure was behind him. A warm body dissolves in mid-embrace into water.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Pharmaceutical Executive Steps Down
description: Jrgen Dormann, the chief executive of the French-German drug company Aventis, announced plans to step down from active management and become chairman of the supervisory board. Mr. Dormann transformed the German chemical company Hoechst into a drug company and then merged it with the French company Rhne-Poulenc to form Aventis. Aventis recently reported huge jumps in sales and profits. Igor Landau, above, chairman of Aventis's pharmaceutical business, will succeed Mr. Dormann. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

description: C. Farris Bryant, who straddled two eras in a four-year term as governor of Florida, died on Friday in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 87.

title: The Flavor Is in the Spelt, A Somewhat Secret Ingredient
description: Spelt, an ancestor of modern wheat, is still cultivated for its nutty flavor and high fiber content. It is not found in every baker's pantry, but it has started having a cult following. Spelt figures prominently in a temptingly moist cake at Sugarpie Bakery, a shop that also bears the name Mousse Cafe, at 389 Broome Street (Mulberry Street) in Little Italy that is owned by Joe Evangelista, above, and his wife, Rosa. The grain enhances the floral intensity of almonds in the cake, which is $4 a slice, $30 for a whole cake (8 servings). The shop is open only Friday through Sunday.

description: An enormous red rose dominates the backdrop Gene Moore designed for Paul Taylor's ''Arden Court.'' The choreography is rosy, too, as the Paul Taylor Dance Company demonstrated on Thursday night at City Center.

description: Leonard Melfi, a playwright with a long career Off Broadway and a brief career on Broadway, is dead -- but his body is missing.

description: In the ideal Knicks world, last night's game against the Milwaukee Bucks will be more than a meaningless late-season victory. It will be a precursor to the remainder of the Don Chaney era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, GLORIA, DR.
description: ADAMS-Gloria, Dr., 76, educator, died suddenly at her home in Riverdale, New York, Sunday, March 3rd, 2002. She had been retired from the NYC school system for 18 years after serving for 38 years as English Teacher, Reading Specialist, Bilingual Education Coordinator, and Adjunct Professor at City University in the training of student teachers and school supervisors. Her preparation included a B.A. from Hunter College, a Master's Degree from Columbia University, and a PH.D. from Fordham University. She studied in programs at the University of New Mexico, Puerto Rico, and Madrid. She is the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Adams of Lakeland, Florida and the niece of the late Attorney and Mrs. Thomas B. Dyett of NYC. Gloria is survived by two sisters, Peggy Adams of Riverdale, NY and Helen Adams Pierce of Fishers, Indiana, a niece and nephew. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 9 at 12:00PM at the Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232nd Street, 718548-1100

title: Slightly sweet malt beverages get some heavy marketing, with young drinkers the targets.
description: AMERICA'S leading brewers and distillers will spend about $350 million this year in a marketing blitz meant to woo younger consumers into trying new types of alcoholic beverages.

title: Boycotts and a Bill Protest Mandatory State Tests
description: Nearly a year after a group of rebellious mothers in Scarsdale staged a boycott of the state's eighth-grade reading test -- only to have their children's schools threatened with punishment by the state -- the protest movement against standardized testing in New York is still simmering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, CHAYA RIFKA
description: BERGER-Chaya Rifka. The Officers and members of the New Synagogue of Fort Lee mourn the loss of our beloved rabbi's mother. Born in 1911 in Jerusalem, she will be interred there alongside her beloved husband, Rabbi Baruch Berger. She was from two of the oldest and most prestigious families in Jerusalem, the Eisenbachs and the Hamburgers. Survived by her children, Miriam and Louis Fruchter, Rabbi Meir and Miriam, Samuel and Ronnee, Isaac, Cantor Leon and Francine, Rabbi Moshe and Karen, eight grandchldren and six great grandchildren. Donations may be made to the New Synagogue of Fort Lee, 1585 Center Ave., Fort Lee, NJ 07024, or JOY, Jewish Outreach and Intervention.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREGORI, LEON
description: GREGORI-Leon. On March 6, 2001. Dearest Dad, this has been the longest year in our lives. Even though you are in our thoughts and hearts 24/7 and every second each day, our sadness is overwhelming. We are so proud of the lessons you have taught us, the knowledge we soaked up from you in many subjects, your adoption of my friends as their ''surrogate father''. Everyone in this town of NYC misses you, respected you, admired you, was thankful for your kindness, gentleness and ability to make us all laugh, a gentleman's gentleman. Dad, your life's work, art and illustrations are all masterpieces and are recognized as such. You truly had ''golden hands''. Mom sends her love, Eva sends her love, you know how much they miss you. As for me, your son Michael, I also send my love and ask for forgiveness that I was not with you hand-in-hand as you started your journey one year ago. I shall never forgive myself. Dad, I love you so very much. Thanks for everything. Your Michael.

title: Open Assembly Seat Attracts a Dozen West Siders
description: Just two days after Assemblyman Edward C. Sullivan announced that he would not seek re-election this year, a dozen potential candidates have emerged to run in this year's Democratic primary to succeed him.

title: Truly Spanish Chorizo, In America At Last
description: IF you've ever experimented with chorizo, the pork sausage cured with paprika and garlic, you know how persuasive its full aroma and deep clinging heat can be. You might have sliced it up and stirred it into paella, chopped it into little cubes that were swept up into an omelet or infused it in stew to give it a smoky edge. Its robust flavor and warm, tingly spice were distinctive, giving everything it touched the feel of Spanish cooking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PYNER, DR. RUBIN
description: PYNER-Dr. Rubin. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Dr. Rubin Pyner. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved family. Richard J. Bornstein, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: Bristol and ImClone Revise Cancer Drug Venture
description: ImClone Systems and Bristol-Myers Squibb have agreed to new terms for their drug development partnership that will give Bristol-Myers greater control and reduce its payments to ImClone, the companies said yesterday.

title: A Proxy Battle Exaggerates the Form
description: All proxy battles are bitter. But an unusual blend of family pride and money, a prominent chief executive, copious advertising and a fusillade of personal criticism have converged in Hewlett-Packard's attempted purchase of Compaq Computer to create what some experts regard as one of the most unusual and ugly of proxy fights.

title: Hewlett-Packard Gains Key Backing For Compaq Merger
description: Hewlett-Packard's plan to buy Compaq Computer, a plan fiercely and publicly opposed by heirs of Hewlett-Packard's founders, received sorely needed support yesterday when an influential investor advisory firm recommended that shareholders vote in favor of the deal.

title: Public Lives; The Runyonesque Voice Atop the Savile Row Suits
description: SOMEDAY, maybe, somebody will get Eddie Hayes to slow down, but that day is not now, so hold on, because up here in his Madison Avenue law office, where the floor is high and the fee starts at $500 an hour and every piece of clothing on Eddie Hayes's body is custom-made, it's raining stories.

In mid-February, before the case went to the jury, a judge agreed to dismiss the complaint against Dr. Legatt for lack of evidence. The order was put in writing later, on Feb. 26, after the jury had found the hospital liable on Feb. 14.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Loss At Telekom
description: The telephone company Deutsche Telekom posted its first full-year loss since it became a publicly held company. Deutsche Telekom said it lost 3.5 billion euros, in contrast to a profit of 5.9 billion euros the previous year.

description: House Republicans drafting legislation to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare said today that they would encourage the use of low-cost generic drugs as an alternative to brand-name medicines and would try to persuade drug makers to curtail advertising, which has been blamed for rising costs.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Interest Rate Steady
description: Citing a stronger-than- expected economic recovery, the Bank of Canada kept its target for overnight interest rates unchanged at 2 percent. The rate stood at 5.75 percent at the start of 2001 when the Canadian central bank began cutting interest rates, roughly in tandem with the United States Federal Reserve. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Chips Off the Barolo Block

Other wines reveal themselves more slowly, teasing you along with a little more depth, adding a dimension of flavor, a new aroma. Without quite realizing it, you are hooked.

title: At Bazzini's, an Extravaganza for the Palate
description: A. L. Bazzini, the company that specializes in nuts and dried fruit, recently moved its wholesale operation out of its TriBeCa headquarters to the Bronx, making room for a big new store at 339 Greenwich Street (Jay Street). The store, Bazzini's, features nuts, of course, but it also carries much more: fresh produce, oils and vinegars, spices, fancy canned goods, coffees and teas, prepared foods, breads, cheeses, charcuterie, fresh meat and some fresh fish. A small selection of tableware, a soda fountain and a few cafe tables complete the picture in the airy space. Worth noting are small jewel-bright fruit tartlets ($1 each) made by the Roc restaurant down the block, and cashew nuts coated in dark chocolate ($5.95 a pound), which are new to the Bazzini line.

title: Bulletin Board; New Dean at N.Y.U. Law School
description: New York University Law School named RICHARD REVESZ, a 43-year-old Argentinian-born law professor, as its next dean, effective June 1. He succeeds JOHN SEXTON, who will become N.Y.U.'s president. Professor Revesz studied civil engineering at Princeton and M.I.T. before earning his law degree from Yale, where he was editor of The Yale Law Journal. In 1985, after clerking for Judge WILFRED FEINBERG of the United States Court of Appeals and Justice THURGOOD MARSHALL of the Supreme Court, he joined the law school, where he teaches environmental and administrative law. Professor Revesz's wife, VICKI BEEN, is also an N.Y.U. law professor. They met when they were Supreme Court clerks. The law school is one of the largest in the country, with 1,800 students, 80 tenure-track faculty members and 25,000 alumni. Karen W. Arenson

title: President Rewards 43 Members of Fund-Raising Club With Prominent Posts
description: President Bush has rewarded 43 members of his Pioneers fund-raising club with appointments to ambassadorships and other prestigious government positions, according to a study by a Texas public policy group.

title: An Uptown Weekend for a Downtown Songwriter
description: It would be only a mild exaggeration to say that the music of Stephin Merritt refracts the entire American songbook, from Stephen Foster to punk rock by way of Cole Porter, into an intimate downscale chamber music. An East Village musical legend unknown to most, Mr. Merritt is a craftsman of exquisite miniatures, many of which examine romantic love and its discontents with a true believer's passion and an absurdist's cynicism. As one of his finest songs, ''Love Is Like a Bottle of Gin,'' puts it:

title: New Rules Proposed To Help High-Rises Withstand Attacks
description: The leader of the investigation into the World Trade Center's collapse and the director of the federal agency that evaluates major fires and building failures are calling for the adoption of new national standards for the construction of public and governmental buildings to make them more resistant to catastrophic failures in the event of terrorist attacks.

title: DOW CORNING TO SELL LOW-COST SILICONE OVER INTERNET
description: The Dow Corning Corporation, the former maker of silicone breast implants, plans to sell low-cost products over the Internet as it prepares to emerge from bankruptcy protection next year. Stephanie Burns, an executive vice president of the company, said products sold over the Internet would cost 25 percent less. Dow Corning, which makes silicone-based products including lubricants and sealants, has operated under bankruptcy court protection since 1995 after facing billions of dollars in claims from women who used its breast implants. The company, is based in Midland, Mich., and is owned by the Dow Chemical Company and Corning Inc.

description: SUMNER ROTHENBERGPamela. April 14, 1956 to March 6, 1999. In loving memory. Rich & Family

title: Metro Briefing: NEW YORK; ALBANY: CORRUPTION CHARGE AT STATE AGENCY
description: A former project manager for the New York State Dormitory Authority has been charged with taking more than $456,000 to help subcontractors receive payment for work they never performed at four colleges in Queens and Brooklyn. Prosecutors said the former manager, Michael O'Connor, who had worked for the authority for 17 years before being asked to resign last year, received cash and services from the subcontractors, including renovations on his home in New Jersey and visits from prostitutes at an apartment that he maintained in Queens. Another man, Robert Marsac, an architect who was a consultant to the Dormitory Authority, was also charged with participating in the kickbacks. Each man faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted. Lawyers for Mr. O'Connor and Mr. Marsac said they would plea not guilty. Robert Worth (NYT)

title: Mubarak Urges U.S. Role in Stopping Mideast Bloodshed
description: The visiting President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt implored the Bush administration today to intervene to stop the mounting bloodshed between Israelis and Palestinians, but President Bush gave no indication tonight that the United States would step up its role in trying to halt the conflict.

title: Chinese Hear From Premier On Threats To Economy
description: Prime Minister Zhu Rongji called today for a renewed assault on official corruption and for bolstering the dwindling incomes of farmers in a stern speech that highlighted gnawing threats to China's prosperity and social stability.

title: 3-Way Playoff in Ivy League As Penn Rolls Over Princeton
description: The scene and the scenario were nothing new as Penn students stormed the court the second the buzzer sounded, embraced their heroes and rejoiced in the sound defeat of their archrival, Princeton. The Ivy League regular season always seems to end like this, with Penn beating Princeton or Princeton beating Penn with everything on the line. But there was an enticing twist this time. This was the game that resolved nothing, other than guaranteeing that this most interesting Ivy League race will have a second and third course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARNES, JERRY

title: Deadly Days in the Mideast
description: The news from Israel and the Palestinian territories grows grimmer and deadlier by the day. Terror attacks and reprisal raids have now merged into continuous carnage that looks increasingly indistinguishable from all-out war. Ordinary Israelis and Palestinians are being drawn into the cycle of bloodthirsty revenge, with some Israelis taking the law into their own hands. Each nation's leaders persist in vowing ever more pain for the other side.

title: National Briefing: New England; MASSACHUSETTS: DORM ADVISERS UNIONIZE
description: Resident advisers at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst voted to join the United Auto Workers, becoming the first such group to unionize in the nation. The vote was 138 to 88, with 12 contested ballots. Many resident advisers, who counsel students and maintain order in the dormitories, said they wanted higher pay and a voice in their work. University officials were reviewing their options. The university had insisted that the resident advisers were students, not employees, but a state labor board ruled that they were employees and had the right to unionize. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

description: ROTHSCHILD-Judith F. (1921-1993) Nine years.

title: The Core Of Muslim Rage
description: The latest death toll in the Indian violence between Hindus and Muslims is 544 people, many of them Muslims. Why is it that when Hindus kill hundreds of Muslims it elicits an emotionally muted headline in the Arab media, but when Israel kills a dozen Muslims, in a war in which Muslims are also killing Jews, it inflames the entire Muslim world?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Mortgage Lender Penalized
description: The mortgage lender Halifax said it would pay 7 million to borrowers in response to a ruling by Britain's financial ombudsman that the bank improperly offered dual rates to new and existing customers. In a bid to win customers, Halifax offered cut-price loans to new borrowers last year. Halifax, part of the HBOS banking group, said it would pay 10,000 borrowers an average of 350 ($498) plus 150 for any inconvenience caused.

title: Woeful Start and Lack of Offense Thwart the Devils Again
description: In two nights, an eye blink in the marathon regular season, the Devils watched their hopeful rebound toward the playoffs turn into a baffling, frustrating slump.

title: Bulletin Board; Help for Ex-Welfare Recipients
description: Three New York City colleges have banded together to help former welfare recipients trying to earn bachelor's degrees. In January, 50 students began the Welfare to Careers program, run by Audrey Cohen College, Pace University and Medgar Evers College. Federal and New York State funds pay for tuition, perks like MetroCards and a full-time staff of eight that offers career counseling and mentoring. CARLOS PERMELL, the program's director, said that most students were working mothers over 30 years old. Each year, the program will admit about 180 students, who must fulfill the same admissions and graduation requirements as traditional students at the institutions, Mr. Permell said. Kathleen Carroll

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTHEIMER, GLORIA
description: HARTHEIMER-Gloria. Of Hackensack, formerly of Dumont, N.J. on March 4, 2002. Beloved wife of Louis. Devoted mother of Richard, Fred, Walter, David, Peter and Debra Ellison Gass. Loving grandmother of Julia and Joline. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park St, Hackensack, on Wednesday at 12 noon. Should friends desire, contributions to Englewood Hospital Hospice Program would be greatly appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey; SOUTH BRUNSWICK: MAN CHARGED IN KILLING OF WIFE
description: A man has been accused of violating a restraining order, killing his wife and then calling the police to report that she had committed suicide, the Middlesex County prosecutor's office said. The man, Boris Boretsy, 52, a native of Russia who lives in South Brunswick, was arrested on Sunday night and charged on Monday with first-degree murder and contempt in the stabbing death of his wife, Saoule Moukhametova, 41. Mr. Boretsky was arrested on Jan. 19 and charged with aggravated assault after he beat Ms. Saoule, the authorities said. Ms. Moukhametova filed for divorce last Thursday. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Danger for the Flowers That Bloom in the Winter
description: The warmest winter on record in the Northeast has fooled plants and flowers into early budding, though many may be damaged or killed because of a destructive little cold snap like yesterday's.

description: MILLER-Lindley G. Of Upper Brookville, LI, on March 16, 2002, age 81. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Cromwell). Father of Barbara, Alexandra Cooper, Robin, Carley Sullivan (Gary) and L. Garrison Jr. (Carrie). Brother of J. Norris, Edward M. and Anne Mason. Grandfather of five. Memorial Mass St. Dominic's R.C. Church, Oyster Bay, Friday, March 22, at 10:30 AM. Donations to North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove, c/o Emergency Department Campaign.

description: A group of Germanbased artists placed a container in the city center of Berlin asking for donations for Leo Kirch, the founder and chief executive of the indebted Kirch Holding. The Munich-based company, which Mr. Kirch founded 43 years ago and turned into Germany's second-biggest media company, is trying to sell assets to avoid defaulting on $5.7 billion in debt.

Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck; 914-698-5968. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, at Holy Family Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

description: BALINSKY-Benjamin. Professor Emeritus Baruch College CUNY. The Psychology Deparment deeply mourns the death of its founding chair and inspirational leader. We extend our condolences and love to Ruth and the family.

title: Knoblauch Is Adjusting to Life After the Yankees
description: Chuck Knoblauch stood by his locker in the sterile, concrete visitors clubhouse here today, a royal blue Kansas City jersey on his back with his surname above the No. 11. For the first time in five years, Knoblauch's uniform identified him by name. He appeared at peace as he answered questions from two waves of New York reporters, ready to hear how life was after going from a dynasty to a small-market team.

title: Boldface Names; The Squeezable Captain Kirk
description: On doctor's orders, the director HENRY JAGLOM was in Los Angeles during the New York premiere of his film ''Festival in Cannes.'' Mr. Jaglom came down with sciatica, and his doctor told him not to fly. So he was heard but not seen. CANDICE BERGEN introduced him. Using a long-distance connection and a loudspeaker, he greeted the audience, which included MAXIMILIAN SCHELL, RON SILVER, TAMMY GRIMES, NATASHA RICHARDSON and HARRIS YULIN.

title: Metro Briefing: New York; BROOKLYN: FAMILY ARRESTED IN DRUG RAID
description: Narcotics detectives, acting on information that a shipment of the drug Ecstasy was about to arrive, raided a Borough Park home early yesterday and arrested seven people, all related. All were charged with felony drug possession. The police said they seized more than $120,000 in cash and a .25-caliber pistol in the raid at the home of Dror Hershowitz, 25, and recovered 35 Ecstasy tablets. Also arrested were Mr. Hershowitz's wife, Moran Hershowitz, 23; his brother and sister, Ravin Hershowitz, 23, and Bella Hershowitz, 20; his mother and father, Miriam Hershowitz, 45, and Joseph Hershowitz, 61; and his uncle, Israel Drami, 76. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Bloomingdale's Considers Opening a SoHo Branch
description: Bloomingdale's is seeking city and state tax relief and other incentives to open a store in a historic building in SoHo, state and city officials said yesterday. It would be the first branch in Manhattan for the retailer, whose flagship store is on the Upper East Side, and the only major department store to have a presence below 14th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, GRACE STURTEVANT
description: HOPKINS-Grace Sturtevant. Of 200 Leeder Hill Dr., Hamden, CT, formerly of New Brunswick, NJ, died on March 12, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Francis W. Hopkins, sister of Julian M. Sturtevant of North Branford, CT, aunt of Ann Sturtevant Ormsby of Seattle, WA, Jane Sturtevant of New York, NY, and Dixon R. Sturtevant of Schaumburg, IL; she was predeceased by a brother, Cortland A. Sturtevant. Grace was born July 14, 1904, daughter of the late Edgar H. and Bessie Skinner Sturtevant. She graduated from Vassar College in 1924 and had a doctorate in classical linguistics from Yale. While living in New Jersey from 1931 until 1962, she was active in the League of Women Voters of which she served on the New Jersey State Board in different capacities including as State President for four years. She was also a member of the National Board. Before retirement, she and her husband spent summers in Branford, CT, and later lived in Branford and Naples, FL, before moving to Hamden. She loved political activism, travel, swimming, playing bridge, and her family. Grace will be missed by all who knew and loved her. As she wished, no memorial service is planned. In her memory, gifts can be made to Vassar College, Box 725, 124 Raymond Ave., Poughkeepsie, NY 12604.

description: IT is sad but true. Every meal, no matter how dazzlingly creative, no matter how much care you put into it, will end up the same way: you will be left with a mess. The dirty dishes in the kitchen seem to outnumber the clean ones you started with. The kitchen looks like a crime scene.

description: IF it was a crime, it was the perfect crime: a multiple murder mystery without a single body left behind. There are suspects, and motives, and a perfectly named crime scene -- the Dismal Swamp -- but no evidence. Only the abandoned home of the victims, if that is what they were.

title: Restaurants; Appearances Can Be Pleasantly Deceiving
description: BLUE FIN is the sort of restaurant that encourages diners like me to set their sights low. It's in Times Square, for one thing. It greets the street with a glass-enclosed bar that looks like an advertisement for the latest youth-oriented liqueur. The restaurant itself can feed multitudes -- 400 diners on two floors -- and the waiters and waitresses look like cast members for next year's slate of young-adult sitcoms. A quick tabulation generated the following memo addressed to the culinary department of my frontal lobe: too big, too good-looking (both the interior and the personnel). Inform pleasure centers of brain that they can take the night off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, IRVING J.
description: LEVINE-Irving J. Died March 4, 2002, at the age of 89 in Princeton, New Jersey. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Thome Levine for 61 years, he is survived by his son Richard J. Levine, daughter Nancy L. Castro, sister Pauline L. Rosenblum; four grandchildren, Jonathan D. Levine, Stephanie L. Castro, Russell N. Levine and Wendy E. Castro; three greatgrandchildren, twins Emma S. Levine and Caroline B. Levine and Trevor S. Levine; and daughter-inlaw Neil Ann S. Levine and son-inlaw Peter E. Castro. Born in Harlem in 1912 and educated in New York City public schools, he graduated from Brooklyn College in 1933 and earned a Master's degree in history from Columbia University in 1935. A dedicated, life-long educator, he spent 38 years in the New York City school system. He taught history at Manual Training and Midwood High Schools as well as at the Ramaz School in Manhattan and Brooklyn College, served as chairman of the social studies department at Benjamin Franklin High School and was principal of John D. Wells Junior High School 50 in Williamsburg and later Isaac Bildersee Junior High School 68 in Canarsie. He retired in 1975 and lived in Southbury, CT and Deerfield Beach, FL. Graveside service at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI, Thursday, March 7, at 12:30PM.

title: Zanzibar Journal; Tourists and Islam Mingle, Not Always Cozily
description: Zanzibar has long wrestled with its dual role as both an Islamic society and a tourist spot, but lately a combination of bikinis, bombs and beer has made that balancing act tougher than ever.

title: Tips From the Chef: The Cork Is Out of the Bottle
description: A wine cork is much more functional than it may seem. In restaurant kitchens, cooks often use corks to stack plates with space in between. They cut the corks in half diagonally so that there is a long flat side. They lay three or four corks flat-side down around the rim of a plate, then stack another plate on top. That way, they can place garnishes on the plates in advance, then finish the dishes as orders come in. At home, this could be handy for dinner parties prepared in small kitchens. You could, for example, place a thin galette on each plate in advance, stack the plates and then add a scoop of ice cream just before serving.

title: MEDTRONIC RECEIVES BACKING FOR HEART DEVICE
description: Medtronic Inc. has received the narrow backing of a government panel for a medical device that treats heart failure and works as a defibrillator. The advisory panel voted 6 to 5 to recommend that the Food and Drug Administration approve the device, called the InSync ICD. The F.D.A. usually follows the advice of its expert panels. Medtronic is competing with the Guidant Corporation to be the first on the market with a heart failure device that can treat fast rhythms with a defibrillator.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey; TRENTON: KIDNAPPER SENTENCED TO LIFE
description: A man has been sentenced to life in prison after pleading guilty in November to the kidnapping and murder of a British computer consultant who was dating the man's former girlfriend, the United States attorney's office in Newark announced. The defendant, Gregory Marcinski, 24, of Brick, N.J., who was sentenced Monday in United States District Court in Trenton, had driven to Kentucky in April 2000. There, posing as an F.B.I. agent, he abducted Paul J. Gale, 28, and strangled him. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Mideast Turmoil: The Bloodshed; SYRIA CHIEF BACKS SAUDI PEACE PLAN AS MIDEAST BOILS
description: Syria expressed its support today for a Saudi peace effort for the Middle East, while a bomb planted in an Arab schoolyard and crude rockets fired at an Israeli town fed the rapidly expanding blood feud between Israelis and Palestinians.

description: Advocates for low-income people rallied here today against President Bush's proposals to overhaul the 1996 welfare law. Emotions ran so high at an afternoon demonstration on the Mall that some advocates tried to shout down Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem, who is usually considered an ally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORRESTER, DONAL F., CSP.
description: FORRESTER-Donal F., CSP. On March 4, 2002 at age 95. He was born and raised in New York City. Fr. Donal made first promises to the Paulist Fathers on June 16, 1930 and was ordained in St. Patrick's Cathedral by then Cardinal Hayes on May 25, 1934. A proud veteran, his assignments included two tours of duty as Army chaplain, one during W.W. II and then in Korea. He served at both Good Shepherd Parish in Inwood Park and St. Paul the Apostle Church in Midtown. His Paulist priesthood took him to the Paulist Chinese Mission in San Francisco, Old St. Mary's in Chicago's Loop and Santa Susanna the American Parish in Rome, Italy. Two brothers were also priests, one for the Archdiocese of New York, Msgr. Henry Forrester & Fr. Berthold Forrester a Carmelite. Fr. Don Forrester was a member of Division Three of AOH. Viewing will be at the Paulist Rectory, 405 W. 59 St on Wednesday, March 6 from 7:00 to 9:00 PM and on Thursday, March 7 from 4:00 to 7:00 PM followed by a Mass of Christian burial at 7:30 PM in the Church of St. Paul the Apostle (60th & Columbus Ave). title: World Briefing: Africa; SOMALIA: U.N. WORKER FREED
description: Ahmed Moallim Mohamed, the senior Unicef official in Mogadishu, who was abducted Thursday, was released. United Nations officials said they did not pay a ransom and were unsure which faction had kidnapped him. The abduction prompted the United Nations to impose a temporary ban on travel to Mogadishu. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swissair Challenge Fails
description: A Zurich court threw out a legal challenge by the collapsed Swissair to prevent its former regional subsidiary Crossair from using the new name, Swiss. The decision clears the way for the new national carrier, a merger of Swissair and Crossair operations, to start operating as ''Swiss'' airlines on March 31.
