description: The government-owned Korea Electric Power Corporation broke off talks with leaders of the company union, on strike since the beginning of last week. A spokesman for the power company said talks were futile since the union refused to back down from its opposition to plans to sell the company to private investors. The union said it would try to negotiate directly with the government.

title: World Briefing: Asia; SOUTH KOREA: FOOD DISCARDS VS. NEED
description: South Koreans threw away more than four million tons of food last year, more than North Korea's total output of staple foods, the Seoul government reports. South Korea's population is twice that of the North, but its economy is 30 times bigger. Last year it gave the North $135 million in aid. James Brooke (NYT)

title: FARMLAND PLANS TO SELL GRAIN TRADING BUSINESS
description: Farmland Industries, the cooperative based in Kansas City, Mo., said yesterday that it planned to sell or shut down Tradigrain, its unprofitable international grain- and sugar-trading business. The operation, which is based in Geneva, has offices in 11 countries. The firm faltered after Farmland sold control of its United States grain depots to the Archer Daniels Midland Company in April. The sale cut off access to grain from Farmland's 600,000 farmer members, forcing Tradigrain to buy from other traders at higher prices, said Mark Hinkel, a vice president at Tradigrain's office in Memphis.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey; ELIZABETH: SKETCH OF MURDER SUSPECT
description: Prosecutors yesterday released an artist's depiction of a man witnesses described as the killer of a doctor in a hotel parking lot last week. Witnesses said the killer of Dr. Jeffrey S. Perchick, shot in the head after parking his car at the Wyndham Newark Airport Hotel on Friday, was a black man, around 5 feet 10 inches tall and 225 pounds, in his 30's and wearing a tan jacket. Prosecutors said robbery might have been the motive. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: SABRE MAKES HOSTILE BID FOR REST OF TRAVELOCITY.COM
description: The Sabre Holdings Corporation, the travel reservation company, yesterday began a $345 million hostile offer for the 30 percent of Travelocity.com Inc. that it does not own after Travelocity rejected the bid. Travelocity.com said that Sabre's tender offer of $23 a share for 15 million shares was inadequate. Sabre created Travelocity.com about two years ago and merged it with Preview Travel Inc., whose shareholders got 30 percent of the combined company. Sabre, which needs to increase its stake to 90 percent to force the remaining investors to tender shares, waited two years to make the bid to keep the merger tax free. Sabre's offer for the 30 percent stake was 20 percent higher than the share price at the time of last month's bid announcement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, HON. MARVIN E.
description: FRANKEL-Hon. Marvin E. Yeshiva University and its Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law mourn the passing of the Hon. Marvin E. Frankel, who served as chairman of the Board of Directors of Cardozo from 1979 to 1981 and played a significant role in the strengthening of the law school. A former member of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, he was a strong advocate for human rights, including before the Supreme Court. A distinguished attorney and partner at Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel, a Manhattan law firm where he was litigation director for many years, he taught law at Columbia University from 1962-1965 and was the author of five books and more than 40 major articles. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Alice, children Eleanor Perlman, Mara Wallace, Ellen Schorr and David Schorr, sister Marjorie Frankel, and his six grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Earle I. Mack, Chairman CSL Board of Directors David Rudenstine, CSL Dean

title: County Chiefs Agree to Share Some Services And Clout
description: Long Island's two counties, Nassau and Suffolk, have historically shared little but the boundary line that divides them. But now a political odd couple is teaming up to tackle regional issues in an uncharacteristic spirit of bicounty cooperation.

title: Egypt Hopes for Free Trade Pact With U.S.

title: Madeleines for Madeline? Pint-Sized Bites for Happy Hour

The bar, named for Ludwig Bemelmans, the creator of Madeline, the winsome French schoolgirl, serves warm cheese madeleines made by Jean-Louis Dumonet, the Carlyle's chef. A dish of them is $6; this month they are free with drinks from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m.

title: National Briefing: Northwest; WASHINGTON: PROPOSAL TO RENAME ROAD DIES
description: A proposal to rename Jefferson Davis Highway expired without fanfare in the State Senate Transportation Committee on Monday. A bill sponsored by Representative Hans Dunshee, a Democrat, that would have replaced the Confederate president's name with that of William P. Stewart, an early black settler in the state, passed unanimously in the House. But Senate leaders said they did not think the matter urgent and did not meet a deadline for voting on moving the bill out of committee. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: A Nation Challenged: Journalists; No Immediate Turnover Of Suspect in Pearl Killing
description: After an internal debate, the government of Pakistan has decided against any immediate handover of the main suspect in the killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, government and law enforcement officials said today.

Overstock.com, based in Salt Lake City, matches suppliers with excess inventory and customers seeking to buy brand-name merchandise at a discount.

title: MOODY'S CUTS CREDIT RATING OF QWEST FOR A SECOND TIME
description: Moody's Investors Service has cut the credit rating of Qwest Communications International Inc., which is facing a default on $4 billion in debt by June, to one level above junk. It was the second reduction in three weeks, and Moody's said another downgrade was possible. Qwest had $24.9 billion in debt at year-end. Its long-term rating was reduced to Baa3 from Baa2. Moody's cited concern about Qwest's ability to repay $850 million of debt maturing in July and to revise terms of its loans. Qwest said on Friday that it would violate loan terms if it did not change them or reduce debt. Qwest borrowed $4 billion last month to repay short-term loans.

title: A Nation Challenged: The Scene; Americans Battling Closer to Qaeda Bunkers
description: American-led ground troops fought their way under withering fire today toward Taliban and Al Qaeda strongholds in these snow-covered mountains, and were reported in some places to have pushed to within a few hundred feet of bunkers and caves where enemy fighters appeared to have dug in for a final stand.

title: STAPLES REPORTS QUARTERLY PROFIT AND RAISES ESTIMATE
description: Staples Inc., which has been cutting costs and remodeling stores, reported a fourth-quarter profit yesterday, reversing a year-earlier loss, and raised its estimate for the year. The company said it had earned $93.8 million, or 20 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $111.7 million, or 23 cents, a year earlier. Profit will be 76 cents to 80 cents this year, almost double last year. Staples stopped selling less-profitable items, like $399 personal computers, and increased higher-margin products, including printer cartridges, in the fourth quarter. Sales fell 6 percent, to $2.93 billion.

title: Best Defense In the Face Of War

John Dexter's 1981 production, with enchanting sets and costumes by David Hockney, last seen in 1986, returned on Monday night with James Levine conducting. Dexter made an integrated triple bill out of three French works: Satie's ballet ''Parade''; Poulenc's bizarrely comic opera ''Les Mamelles de Tirsias''; and Ravel's sublime ''L'Enfant et les Sortilges,'' about a naughty boy who comes to know compassion.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Broadband Surpasses Dial-Up
description: Time spent online by people whose Internet access is through broadband connections like cable modems surpassed that of users connecting through dial-up modems for the first time in January, according to the Internet research company Nielsen/Net Ratings. Broadband users spent 1.19 billion hours actively connected to the Internet in January, accounting for 51 percent of the 2.3 billion hours spent online. Broadband users spent 727 million hours online in January 2001, or 38 percent of the total time spent online.

The teacher, Jennifer Sanchez, 23, was arrested at Middle School 143. ''I believe the mom notified the police,'' Detective Kevin Czartoryski said. title: Bulletin Board; Bloomberg Against Bonus Plan

During a City Hall news conference, Mr. Bloomberg said that such a system was ''probably inherently unfair'' and that he would rather reward every teacher in a school whose performance improved, a distinction the teachers' union also favors. But Mayor Bloomberg, whose aides are expected to hold a second bargaining session with the United Federation of Teachers today, said he did not know whether such a system could be worked out through contract talks. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNER, EDWARD H.
description: KERNER-Edward H. Died at home in Newark, Delaware, on Feb. 11, 2002, of myelofibrosis. Dr. Kerner was Emeritus Professor of Physics at the University of Delaware, having retired in 1999 after 37 years of service as a Professor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. Dr. Kerner was born in New York City on April 22, 1924. He earned a Bachelor's Degree from Columbia College in 1943, and a Ph.D in Physics from Cornell University in 1950. Dr. Kerner was interested in theoretical physics very broadly. He studied and contributed significant research results in biophysics, relativity, gravity, and the foundations of quantum mechanics. Recently, he had published an article and was working on others in the area of uniform field theory, i.e., how particles and waves interact at a subatomic level. He was preceded in death by son Jeffrey C. Kerner. He is survived by his wife Barbara B. Kerner; brother George H. Kerner; son Benjamin Kerner; and daughter Winifred Kerner. Contributions may be made to the Scholarship Fund, Dept. of Physics, The University of Delaware, Newark, DE. 19716.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cray Chief Resigns
description: Cray, maker of some of the world's fastest supercomputers, said yesterday that its new president and chief executive, Michael P. Haydock, had resigned after a dispute with the board over Cray's strategy. Mr. Haydock, hired only four months ago from I.B.M.'s global services division, had vowed to revamp Cray's aging line of supercomputers and earn more money from professional services. James Rottsolk, the Cray chairman, was named president and chief executive, reassuming the positions he held before Mr. Haydock was hired in October. Cray said Mr. Haydock resigned because of differences with the board over how to restore ''long-term industry leadership.'' Cray shares fell 33 cents, to $2.04, after the announcement. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: WILLIAMS, THE ENERGY COMPANY, TRIES TO REWORK DEBT
description: The Williams Companies, which owns natural gas pipelines, said yesterday that it expected to get more time from creditors to make payments on $1.4 billion in notes used to finance a telecommunications subsidiary. Williams guaranteed part of the debt from the Williams Communications Group, which last week said it might file for bankruptcy. Under the proposal, Williams Companies could make payments over a longer period of time instead of paying in 60 days, if Williams Communications defaults. Williams Companies has said it may be responsible for as much as $2.6 billion if there is a default by the communications company, which Williams spun off in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMEO, ANDREW A.
description: ROMEO-Andrew A. Passed on Mar. 2 in his 70th year. A man of great gusto, lover of life, successful in business, loyal friend, avid handball player and golfer. Loving husband and best friend of Lynne Romeo. Devoted father of Andrew Romeo, his wife Sandra, & Marco Romeo. Cherished grandfather of Adriana. Beloved brother of Barbara Polito. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Graduated from Fordham in 1955 which he attended on a football scholarship. Remained active in the university's Gridiron Club. Longtime member of the New York Athletic Club where he served as restaurant chairman and on its Board of Governors for 14 years. Soon after graudating from Fordham he joined the Horn & Hardart Company where he rose to EVP of Operations in a 14 year tenure. In 1970 he became divisional president of ARA, known as Aramark. In 1979 he became Chairman and CEO of B/G Foods, which doubled in size under his leadership and which he subsequently took private. Made numerous acquisitions and operated such restaurants as the Broadway Diner and the Landmark Oscar's Salt of the Sea. Co-founder and Chairman of the Board of ADF Companies, a franchisee of 200 restaurants and the second largest Pizza Hut franchise. Andy's larger than life personality and unforgettable sense of humor will be greatly missed by the many who loved him. Family will receive friends on Thursday 2-4 and 6-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral services Friday, 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to be made to the Fordham University Football Recruiting Fund, C/O Michael Fazio, Office of Development, 113 W. 60 St., NY NY 10023 and the New York Athletic Club, The Athlete Fund, C/ O The New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South, New York, NY 10019.

title: Experiencing the Cataclysm, From the Inside
description: It feels like you're being buried alive. You're on the ground, gray ash falling everywhere, as if it were being shoveled over you, and you can hear debris rattling on a car overhead, dropping like hail. From the perspective of Jules Naudet's camera, you have run on the street after escaping from the lobby of Tower 1 of the World Trade Center just six or eight minutes before it would collapse. When it does, you are pushed to the ground, and soon everything gets dark. Then a piece of paper flutters in front of the camera lens. A voice yells, ''Let's go before the car blows up.''

description: As he had promised for weeks, Boris A. Berezovsky, the Russian tycoon-in-exile, released part of a film today claiming to document the role of the Kremlin's intelligence service in the 1999 string of apartment-house bombings in which more than 300 Russians perished.

title: Bulletin Board; New Program at St. John's
description: The School of Law at St. John's University has announced a program to help law students prepare for work as federal judicial clerks. The Federal Scholars Program was established after a $500,000 gift from KEVIN and PATRICIA CASTEL, alumni, and will finance up to five $5,000 stipends annually. The Castels were federal law clerks after graduating from St. John's. JOSEPH W. BELLACOSA, dean of the law school and a professor of law, said that the stipends would help support students working in unpaid internships with the federal judiciary. Peter Valdina

title: Raiders of the Restaurant Table; Make an Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox Suspends Mexico's Tax On Fructose From U.S.
description: President Vicente Fox issued an executive decree today suspending a 20 percent tax on American high-fructose corn syrup used by the soft drink industry. Mexico's Congress created the tax in January to help the sugar industry battle a growing surplus amid repeated refusals by the United States to increase its quota on sugar from Mexico.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about three graduates of Hostos Community College who are attending Columbia University under a new scholarship program misspelled the middle name of one. She is Kazi Fateha Ahmed, not Fatecha.

title: Market Place; Disney Woes Force Leader To Confront Hard Questions
description: In Hollywood, there are few media figures as respected, feared and envied as Michael D. Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company. But the imbroglio over Disney's move to woo David Letterman to ABC has put a spotlight on what a tough spot he is in these days.

title: Dispute Over Cloning Experiments Intensifies
description: The public relations battle over cloning experiments intensified today in the Senate as opponents warned of ''embryo farms'' and proponents pulled out a Hollywood trump card, the actor Christopher Reeve. Mr. Reeve told lawmakers that the United States would ''lose its pre-eminence in science and medicine'' if the research was banned.

title: Hyundai Narrows Review to 5 Finalists
description: Hyundai Motor America in Fountain Valley, Calif., a division of the Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea, has narrowed a review for its creative account, with billings estimated at $160 million, to five finalists.

title: Going Beyond Mere Facts In the Study of History
description: STUDENTS are woefully ignorant of history. A 1999 survey asked college seniors questions like who led our troops at Yorktown; the most common answer was Ulysses S. Grant. In 1986, the government tested 17-year-olds in history; most said the Civil War occurred before 1850.

title: $25 and Under; Soups, Sandwiches and the Essence of Elegance
description: FROM the soft leather banquette, the thick linens, the flattering lighting and the vaultlike designer bathrooms, it is clear that Craftbar, the new, casual adjunct to Craft, is something more than a knockoff of the humble Italian wine-and-sandwich shops that are its inspiration.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Executive Leaving
description: Amazon.com, the Internet retailer, said its chief financial officer, Warren Jenson, plans to resign later this year. Mr. Jenson has been Amazon.com's top financial officer since September 1999, when he left the same job at Delta Air Lines. He will stay on for several months to recruit a successor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASKIEWICZ, LEON J.
description: WASKIEWICZ-Leon J. Of Eastchester, NY on March 4, 2002, age 46. Beloved husband of Peggy Grubert Waskiewicz. Dear father of Meg and Michael. Beloved son of Betty. Brother of Ann Marie Grimaldi and the late Robert. Devoted nephew of The Uncle Joe and Aunt Millie. Also surviving are many loved nieces and nephews. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, 2-4 and 7-9 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe, on Thursday, March 7 at 9:45 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Tuckahoe Scholarship Fund.

title: State Charges Of Obstruction May Be Possible In Louima Case
description: The Brooklyn district attorney said yesterday that he would consider filing obstruction-of-justice charges against the three police officers in the Abner Louima case who were acquitted on similar federal charges by an appeals court last week.

title: Novice Wins G.O.P. Primary for Governor of California
description: In a stunning upset that jolted this state's political establishment as well as the White House, Bill Simon Jr., in his first try for public office, won the Republican primary for California governor today, overwhelming Richard Riordan, the former mayor of Los Angeles.

title: Save a Beacon Of Intelligent TV
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH PUTS TARIFFS OF AS MUCH AS 30% ON STEEL IMPORTS
description: President Bush took some of the broadest federal action in two decades to protect a major American industry today, imposing tariffs of up to 30 percent on most types of steel imported into the United States from Europe, Asia and South America. The tariffs will last three years, he said, to give American steel producers time to consolidate operations and stem layoffs.

title: Iraqis Will Face Blunt Terms In Weapons Talks at the U.N.
description: After three years of refusing to deal with United Nations arms inspectors, a high-level Iraqi delegation is about to come face to face for the first time with the leader of the inspection commission, Hans Blix.

title: Worst Job Loss For New York In a Decade
description: Most of the loss reflects the economic aftershocks of the attack on the World Trade Center. But the new data also show that the national recession hit New York's services sector slightly earlier, and a lot harder, than economists realized.

title: A Nation Challenged: The Terrorist; Al Qaeda May Be Rebuilding In Pakistan, E-Mails Indicate
description: Newly detected Internet traffic among Al Qaeda followers, including intercepted e-mail messages, indicates that elements of the terror network may be trying to regroup in remote sanctuaries in Pakistan near the Afghan border, government officials say.

title: National Briefing: Northwest; WASHINGTON: FIGHTING POTENT BEVERAGES
description: Mayor Greg Nickels, left, of Seattle is asking the State Liquor Control Board to ban the takeout sale of cheap and potent beers and wine in the historic Pioneer Square neighborhood. The board has asked the area's merchants to eliminate malt liquor and fortified wine sales voluntarily, but the mayor says a mandatory ban is necessary to combat alcoholism. ''This is one additional tool to help the businesses and residents of Pioneer Square deal with the problem of chronic public inebriation,'' Mr. Nickels said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Fresh Interest in a Global Crossing Bid
description: Platinum Equity, a buyout firm, said today that it was considering bidding for the assets of Global Crossing, a fiber optic cable company that has filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Sports of The Times; Powerhouse Drones On, Unappreciated
description: CONNECTICUT, the state that gave us the dictionary, the sewing machine, the pay phone, the hamburger and the can opener, has now given us the most versatile women's college basketball team ever assembled, and perhaps the best. Haven't heard? You're not alone. Aside from intense statewide coverage, its season has existed in a virtual news blackout that would make the Pentagon jealous.

title: No Headline
Official Says S.E.C. Is Strained, With Duties Exceeding Budget
description: The head of the General Accounting Office warned today that the Securities and Exchange Commission was ''increasingly strained'' because it did not have the financing to do its job while its workload has been rising.

title: National Briefing: Southwest; ARIZONA: FIRE BURNS 800 ACRES
description: More than 100 firefighters, some flown from Tennessee and North Carolina, battled a blaze that has spread to more than 800 acres in the southeastern Huachuca Mountains. The nearest houses were more than a mile away and not considered to be in immediate danger, the Forest Service said. Erratic winds and steep, unstable terrain made the fire, which was discovered on Friday, hard to fight. Its cause was not known. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Prayerfully and Powerfully, New York City Before and After
description: There is a prayer circle at the Museum of Modern Art, and it's not for Gerhard Richter, the German painter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGAN, MARY M. (NEE HYNES)
description: HAGAN-Mary M. (nee Hynes). On March 4, 2002. Beloved wife of Joseph C. Devoted mother of Charles T., Patricia A. Travers, William H., Joseph C. Jr. & Laura M. Feketie. Also survived by 11 loving grandchildren. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC, Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10:45 AM, at the Immaculate Conception Church. Interment Rhode Island Veterans Cemetery, Exeter, R.I.

title: Bulletin Board; Brown President Seeks Gifts
description: RUTH J. SIMMONS, the president of Brown University, met around 600 members of the Brown Club in New York last Wednesday in her campaign to raise $100 million so that Brown can start a needs-blind admission policy, beginning with the class entering in 2003. Did she expect $2,300 from each of the 70,000 alumni, as a letter that some alumni received last year suggested? ''Some will contribute more, some will contribute less, but that would be the average,'' Dr. Simmons said. Elaine Louie

title: Save a Beacon Of Intelligent TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Angry Europeans to Challenge U.S. Steel Tariffs at W.T.O.
description: Steel producers from around the world angrily denounced President Bush's decision today to impose protective tariffs on imported steel and vowed to fight the plan at the World Trade Organization.

title: Raiders of the Restaurant Table; Three Stooges Cutout Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Menu
description: Art Over the Bar

title: Metro Briefing: New York; QUEENS: GUILTY PLEA IN DELIVERY MURDER
description: A 16-year-old has pleaded guilty to second-degree murder for his role in the killing of a Chinese food restaurant owner, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, announced. The teenager, Robert Savage, admitted to striking the man, Jin Sheng Liu, 44, with a brick on Sept. 1, 2000, after Mr. Liu delivered food to him and four friends. Two of those friends, James Stone, 17, and Darryl Tyson, 18, previously pleaded guilty to first-degree robbery and were sentenced to 16 and 17 years in prison, respectively. Another, Jamel Murphy, 18, has pleaded guilty to first-degree robbery and is awaiting sentencing while the fifth defendant, Stacy Royster, 19, is awaiting a pretrial hearing. Mr. Savage will be sentenced on March 25 to seven years to life in prison, Mr. Brown said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Trash Heap? Not in My Backyard
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Turmoil: The Outlook; A Test of Wills: Deep Divide With Both Sides Seeming Only to Dig In
description: No amount of diplomacy can long conceal that the conflict here has become a standoff between one people, the Palestinians, who feel they have nothing to lose, and another, the Israelis, who feel they have everything to lose.

title: Dolan and Layden Buying Some Time
description: Scott Layden, the Penn Plaza piata, was back from a scouting trip to China and well within striking distance. James L. Dolan, the once-reclusive chairman of Madison Square Garden who now wants to be part of the scene, sat a few feet away from the team president, making it clear that this was Layden's show.

title: Agencies Realign Merger Oversight
description: Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission oversight of corporate mergers and other antitrust matters will be reconfigured under an agreement reached today, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLI, PIZZI, LOUIS J.
description: DELLI-PIZZI-Louis J. We and our families grieve the loss of Dr. Louis Delli-Pizzi, our uncle, friend and mentor. Our love and prayers are with Aunt Joan, our cousins Louis and Denise and their families. Emilia Mia Sordillo, M.D., Ph.D. Peter Sordillo, M.D., Ph.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, IRWIN G.
description: NELSON-Irwin G. On March 3, 2002. Army Air Force Veteran of WWII and Korea. Beloved brother of Miriam Chan and Gloria and Alan Seff. Dear cousin of Roslyn and Alex Levine. Also survived by nieces and nephews Liane Onish, Amy and Robert Chan, Janet and Tyler Donaldson. Services Thursday 11:30AM at the Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, P. FRED
description: WEINGARTEN - P. Fred. On March 15, 2002. Beloved husband of Naomi. Dear father of David and Renee, Roni and Mark Greenberg, and Jill. Adored grandfather of Adam, Leah, Matthew, Lisa and Michelle. Brother of Mildred Abrams. A friend of many who will be sorely missed. Services Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, MILDRED FALENDER
description: HURWITZ-Mildred Falender. On March 17, 2002, at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Jacob S. Hurwitz. Mother of the late Susan H. Sorkin. Grandmother of Anne E. Sorkin and Samuel L. Sorkin. A graduate of Wellesley College, she served during World War II as a lieutenant in the WAVES.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Write-Offs At Bank
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia, based in Toronto, has taken write-offs totaling 540 million Canadian dollars ($340 million) on its business in Argentina, trimming net income for the quarter ended Jan. 31 to 52 million Canadian dollars, compared with 510 million Canadian dollars a year earlier.

title: Bond Insurers Win Round In Enron Case
description: A federal judge in New York yesterday rejected an effort by J. P. Morgan Chase to compel insurers to honor almost $1 billion in bonds issued to guarantee certain transactions by Enron, saying that there was sufficient evidence that the bonds may have been obtained through fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, PAUL E. SR.
description: CARR-Paul E. Sr. Trustees and staff of Brooklyn Public Library and Brooklyn Public Library Foundation mourn the death of Paul E. Carr, Sr. father of library and foundation Trustee, Paul E. Carr Jr. Our prayers and love are with the Carr family. Albert C. Wiltshire, President, BPL Howard Smith, Chairman, BPLF Siobhan A. Reardon, Acting Exec Director, BPL

title: Reality Video, All Too Stark; Preacher Hopes Taping Can Save a Drug-Riddled Area
description: The rapper Tupac Shakur had a song ''Death Around the Corner'' that described the hell of living in a world of drugs and guns, a world that the Rev. Cornell Lewis and other North End residents here know all too well.

title: A Bump in Connecticut's Night Causes Widespread Puzzlement
description: Many of the 35 men at the Monday night meeting of the Long Ridge Fire Department jumped out of their seats. ''Then we ran outside to see what it was,'' said Chief Bob Bennett. ''But we didn't see anything.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: We don't leave Americans behind. BRIG. GEN. JOHN W. ROSA, Jr., describing a raid in Afghanistan in which seven died. [A13]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUZZALLINO, JOSEPHINE MC CANN
description: BUZZALLINO - Josephine Mc Cann. Of Pompano Beach, FL. and Roslyn, NY on February 26, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Angelo Buzzallino, cherished mother and best friend of Joan Buzzallino, Susan and Robert Dougherty, Paul and Anne Buzzallino and Anne and Thomas Matarazzo. Adored grandmother of Paul, Elizabeth and Alan Buzzallino, Kristin and Joseph Dougherty and Suzanne, Thomas, Karen and Kathryn Matarazzo. Also survived by her sister Marion D. Short of Minneapolis, MN and brother, John J. McCann of Belle Harbor, NY. A memorial mass will be held at St. Mary's Church, 1300 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY, on Friday, March 8, 2002 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave, New York, NY 10021.

title: NBC Announces Arena League Deal
description: NBC Sports will carry the Arena Football League for two years, beginning in 2003, filling a void on Sunday afternoons because of the expiration of the network's N.B.A. rights this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECH, GERTRUDE
description: BLECH-Gertrude. Young Israel of Oceanside mourns the passing of the mother of its Rabbi Emeritus, Rabbi Benjamin Blech. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi Joel Felderman, President

title: Record of Defeat Doesn't Matter to Knicks
description: Scott Layden smiled and spoke as if he had just secured a genius for the Knicks' bench next season. Without a hint of doubt or regret, he talked of his decision to extend Don Chaney's contract as if no defense was necessary.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: GUILFORD MILLS INC., -- Greensboro, N.C., a maker of fabrics, said it would file for bankruptcy protection and seek court approval for a restructuring plan that would eliminate $125 million in senior debt and give senior lenders 90 percent of the company's new stock. Shareholders would receive the remaining 10 percent.

title: Boldface Names; Chef Dishes Up Big Helping
description: When someone gives to the Twin Towers Fund -- even a contribution with lots of zeroes -- ''I usually buy the coffee at the donation ceremony,'' said LAURENCE A. LEVY, the fund's president. But on Monday, the someone making the donation was ALAIN DUCASSE. So the event was at his restaurant in the Essex House in Manhattan, with truffled herbed ravioli and loin of veal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, ADOLPH, M.D.
description: POSNER-Adolph, M.D. The members of the Manhattan Ophthalmological Society mourn the death of their honored member and founder Adolph Posner, M.D. A true giant in the field, his teaching and learning for over 50 years inspired us all.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey; NEWARK: KILLER'S REQUEST IS REJECTED
description: A state appellate panel has rejected a request by a man to withdraw his guilty plea in the April 1999 shooting death of an Orange police officer, officials said. Condell Woodson, 28, who is serving a life sentence without possibility of parole, pleaded guilty in May 1999 to the murder of Officer Joyce Anne Carnegie, after prosecutors agreed not to seek the death penalty. Mr. Woodson later asked a state judge to overturn his plea, however, asserting that he had been coerced by the police. A Superior Court judge rejected the request, and on Monday a two-judge panel in the Appellate Division upheld the judge's decision, said a spokeswoman for the Essex County prosecutor's office. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Injury Risk Seen for Children in Small Pickups
description: Children riding in the back seats of compact ''extended cab'' pickup trucks like the Dodge Dakota, Chevrolet S-10 and Ford Ranger are nearly three times as likely to be hurt in a crash than children in the back seats of other vehicles, according to a review of 71,000 accidents by researchers at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Seeks Delay
description: Microsoft sought a two-week postponement of hearings on a proposal by nine states pursuing restrictions on its business, saying it needed time to study last-minute changes to the plan. The hearings, scheduled to begin on Monday, concern remedies that go beyond a settlement Microsoft reached with the Justice Department and nine other states. Lawyers representing Microsoft argued that the modification yesterday of an earlier proposal by states that have not settled occurred without notice and without the court's permission, entitling the company to more time to study the changes.

title: Soot Particles Strongly Tied To Lung Cancer, Study Finds
description: Prolonged exposure to air tainted with tiny particles of soot significantly raises the risk of dying of lung cancer or other lung and heart diseases, according to a new study of 500,000 people in 116 American cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, HARVEY
description: ROSS-Harvey. Passed away Mon, March 4, 2002 in Aventura, FL. Son of immigrant parents, he started early learning the watch business and grew it into an international company. Very well loved here and abroad. A supporter of synagogues & other charities, member of Town Club and City Athletic clubs. Loving brother, husband, father, uncle and son. Services at Lincoln Square Synagogue, Mar. 6, 11 AM, 70th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SYLVIA JOSEPHS
description: BERGER-Sylvia Josephs. In her 100th year. Died on March 2, 2002. A woman of extraordinary intelligence and taste; character and grace. Fiercely independent in mind and action. Her midwestern roots were evident in her sense of fairness and ethics. Born and raised in Duluth, MN she graduated from Smith College in 1924 (was the only one to return and participate in her 75th reunion). Attended the Sorbonne, received a law degree from New York University in the late 1920's. She was a pro bono lawyer for 20 years at the Juvenile Court in the Bronx. A seasoned traveller before World War II. She could read Greek, Latin and French; studied Russian language and Russian literature at Hunter College until she was 96. Attended art classes at the Metropolitan Museum and went to the Philharmonic until late last fall. Married to Arthur M. Berger for over 53 years. He predeceased her, as did a brother Irving and son-in-law Daniel Cowin. Survived by daughter Joyce Cowin, three grandchildren Kenneth (Jasmin), Andrew (Allyson), Dana (Barclay Palmer), three great-grandchildren Reagan and Alexandra Cowin, Sylvie Palmer. As well as a sister Muriel Cowan and brother Arthur Josephs (Adrianne) from Duluth, MN. Interment private. A celebration of her life will be held at her daughter's, April 3rd, 4-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Russian Department at Hunter College or the Jewish Studies Program at Smith College.

title: National Briefing: Rockies; COLORADO: COLUMBINE LAWSUIT DISMISSED
description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit against makers of video games and other entertainment companies by the family of Dave Sanders, a teacher killed in the Columbine High School shootings. The family said the two gunmen in the Columbine massacre, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, were influenced by the movie ''The Basketball Diaries'' and video games like Mortal Kombat and Doom. Judge Lewis Babcock cited rights to free expression in dismissing the lawsuit. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Bush Joined Unit of Enron In '86 Venture To Seek Oil
description: In his earliest known tie to the Enron Corporation, President Bush, then an oil man in West Texas, joined an energy drilling venture organized in 1986 by a subsidiary of Enron.

title: Mall Prefers Shoppers, Not Commuters, in Lot
description: Most days, the vast parking lot here at Willowbrook Mall seems to be awash with empty spaces. But soon, hundreds of North Jersey commuters may find themselves completely at sea.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Seeks Buyer
description: A British insurer, Britannic, said it was looking for a buyer after it swung to a pretax loss in the recently completed fiscal year. For all of 2001, Britannic lost 319.5 million ($454 million) before taxes, compared with a profit of 47.6 million the prior year. Britannic, based in Birmingham, laid off 2,000 employees last year to cut costs. Potential bidders could include AMP, Royal London Mutual Insurance, CGNU P.L.C. and Prudential. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The Essence of Tamarind, Without All the Work
description: TAMARIND is the lemon of Southeast Asia, India and much of Latin America; its tart fruitiness sharpens and rounds out flavors wherever it is used. But unlike lemon, which requires nothing more than a squeeze, tamarind does not give up its intense liquid easily. Its bulbous pods are peeled and pressed into a block of pulp that needs to be soaked, mashed and strained. Most tamarind concentrates (or extracts), like bottled lemon juice, are acrid and unpleasant.

title: A Crisis of Clergy, Not of Faith
description: More than 80 priests in the archdiocese of Boston have been accused of sexual molestation. This scandal -- and similar allegations of abuse in Philadelphia, New Hampshire and Maine -- do more than simply reveal an institution in crisis. They call into question the credibility of the Roman Catholic Church in America.

title: Lakers Hold Off The Nets' Late Rally
description: It seemed easy for both teams to affix an asterisk to tonight's game, considering that the Lakers and the Nets were missing key players because of suspensions and the Nets had no 7-footer to shadow Shaquille O'Neal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILT, HELEN F.
description: BILT-Helen F. Park East Synagogue and Sisterhood mourn the passing of our devoted member, Helen F. Bilt. Deepest sympathy to her children, Cynthia and Michael, and her brothers. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Julius H. Gewirtz, Chairman Maguy Naparstek, Sisterhood President

title: A Nation Challenged: The Victims; Families Count Cost of Afghan Battle With Memories From 7 Lives
description: One was so modest he did not tell his fellow soldiers that he had earned a black belt in tae kwon do. Another was such an outstanding parachute rescue medic that an Air Force magazine featured him on its cover.

title: Songs With Philosophy, and the Beat of a Thumb
description: The hardest-working right thumb in show business may belong to Bruce Cockburn, the Canadian songwriter, who played a sold-out solo show at the Bottom Line on Saturday night. With quiet virtuosity, on his acoustic guitar, Mr. Cockburn materializes chords and modal filigrees while his thumb provides the music's pulse and its foundation. It is at once a deep Celtic drone, a drumbeat and the throb of a vigilant conscience.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Contractor Seeks Bailout
description: The Tobishima Corporation became the latest construction company to seek a bailout from its main lender as it struggles to restructure. The midsize contractor asked Fuji Bank to swap 10 billion yen ($76 million) in loans in exchange for preferred shares. The move follows the collapse on Sunday of Japan's 10th-largest contractor, the Sato Kogyo Corporation, which had been in merger talks with Tobishima. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Bush Sets Range of Tariffs On Steel Imports Up to 30%

title: Future of 'Nightline' Remains Uncertain
description: A meeting of the Walt Disney Company president, Robert A. Iger, and the ABC News anchor Ted Koppel in Washington on Monday was frank but nonconfrontational. Still, the men came to no resolution about the future of Mr. Koppel's program, ''Nightline,'' people close to the discussion said.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fifth Avenue Jewel Robbery
description: About $200,000 worth of jewelry was stolen from the Van Cleef & Arpels store on Fifth Avenue early yesterday after someone smashed a small front window, grabbed the jewelry and fled, the police said. The 4:25 a.m. theft at the store at 744 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street, was captured on videotape, though the police said the footage was of poor quality. No arrest had been made by last evening. Among the items stolen was a $73,000 necklace and sets of earrings worth a combined $103,500, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Lee Jackson, 93, Painter of New York City
description: Lee Jackson, a New York-born painter who made the city the subject of many of his paintings, died on Feb. 19 in Southampton, N.Y., his family said. He was 93 and lived in Southampton.

title: Hugh Gloster, 90, Ex-President of Morehouse
description: Hugh Morris Gloster, who as president of the historically black Morehouse College greatly strengthened its endowment and faculty in the civil rights era, died on Feb. 16 in Decatur, Ga. He was 90.

title: Study Expands Range of Stem Cell Abilities
description: Adding an important piece to the rapidly changing picture of human stem cells, researchers have found that cells from the blood can regenerate not just the blood supply but tissues of the skin, liver and gut.

title: Fitting Bloody Sunday Into the Present
description: NORTHERN IRELAND hardly needs help remembering Bloody Sunday, when British paratroopers shot and killed 14 unarmed civil rights marchers in Londonderry on Jan. 30, 1972. Those events are etched in collective memory.

title: Researchers Call Anthrax Vaccine Safe and Likely to Work
description: The anthrax vaccine is safe and effective, and is likely to work even against strains of the bacteria that have been engineered as weapons, according to a new study that could clear the way for the Pentagon to resume its program of vaccinating all soldiers.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Skiing Fatalities Set Record
description: A woman injured while skiing last week has died, bringing to 13 the number of fatalities on Colorado slopes this season, a record. Most of the deaths resulted from collisions with trees, said officials of Colorado Ski Country U.S.A., an industry group. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Nuclear Threats, Real and Imagined
description: To the Editor:

title: F.T.C. Raises No Objections to Hewlett-Compaq Merger
description: A day after winning support from a prominent shareholder advisory firm, Hewlett-Packard's effort to acquire Compaq Computer received another boost -- unanimous approval from the Federal Trade Commission.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Date Set For Sharon Hearing
description: A court set May 15 for a hearing on whether a case can proceed against Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel over the 1982 massacre of Palestinian civilians in two Lebanese refugee camps by militiamen allied with Israel. Under Belgian law, plaintiffs can sue over human rights violations that occurred anywhere in the world, but the World Court ruled last month that government officials have diplomatic immunity. An Israeli inquiry at the time ruled that Mr. Sharon, who was Israel's defense minister, was indirectly responsible for the killings.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Expects Profit
description: Hynix Semiconductor reported an operating profit for January and February as a result of rising prices worldwide for memory chips. A Hynix spokesman said the company lost a record $3.8 billion last year while prices for memory chips fell on global markets but predicted a net profit for the first quarter of this year. Hynix's chairman, Park Chong Sup, left for the United States and another round of talks with Micron Technologies, which wants to take over the company's memory chip operations. As a result of the partial recovery of the memory chip market, Hynix officials said, the company may not need a deal with Micron to survive despite debts of more than $6 billion. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Some Drive the Expressway; Some Just Drink to It
description: In what was once a speakeasy, the BQE Lounge in Williamsburg offers (as one might guess) a glimpse of its namesake roadway from the main room. The bar is above La Brunette restaurant (once a hot-dog counter), and both are the work of Craig Shillitto, an architect and the principal at Weeve Projects. The original building was a mess, he said, and demolition took a big bite out of the budget. Simple, relatively inexpensive materials were used to create the long, comfortable bar area (left) with its expressway view. White ash is used throughout, accented by black metal and white tiles. Live music and D.J.'s are often on hand.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Statehouse Going Solar
description: If city inspectors in Salem approve, Oregon will become the first state to affix solar panels on its Capitol building. The three rows of panels are designed to generate the 7.8 kilowatts necessary to power spotlights fixed on the golden Oregon Pioneer statue at the building's apex; any excess would be diverted to the power grid. Capitol officials said the panels, which could be installed in April, would not be visible from the street. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Giants Lack Clear Path to September
description: The Giants open the 2002 season in exactly 26 weeks. Giants fans, do you have any idea what players will be in uniform welcoming the San Francisco 49ers on Sept. 5?

title: A Winning Strategy
description: In a world teeming with war and terror, you take your good news where you can get it. And some of that good news is here in New York.

title: Trash Talking Over Basketball Ad
description: The elbows-up style of play for street basketball is being used by two marketers of athletic footwear as they scrap over a commercial centered on a re-creation of a storied era in New York basketball.

title: The Senate's Leisurely Ethics Inquiry
description: Two months ago, federal prosecutors ended their investigation into Senator Robert Torricelli's seamy financial dealings with a wealthy political favor-seeker named David Chang without bringing criminal charges. The Senate Ethics Committee's review of the matter has now reached a critical juncture. The committee's staff has completed its preliminary report summing up the prosecutor's findings, and the committee must decide whether to authorize an official ethics investigation and retain an outside counsel to conduct it. This is a sound idea that has been followed in previous high-profile ethics cases in Congress.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Crown Heights Case Review
description: The solicitor general of the United States, Theodore B. Olson, will personally review the Yankel Rosenbaum case, according to a lawyer for Mr. Rosenbaum's family. Federal prosecutors are facing a deadline tomorrow on whether to ask the full United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to review a three-judge panel's recent decision in the case. The decision ordered a new trial for two black men convicted in the fatal stabbing of Mr. Rosenbaum in Crown Heights in 1991. Yesterday, Norman Rosenbaum, the victim's brother, and a lawyer for the Rosenbaum family, Nathan Lewin, urged the Justice Department to appeal. Mr. Lewin said he was told the decision would be made, probably today, after a review by Mr. Olson.

title: In G.O.P. Primary, the Giuliani Factor Comes Into Play
description: Political analysts called it the ''Giuliani factor,'' and in November they cited it as a chief reason Michael R. Bloomberg, a rich businessman with no experience in elective office, pulled off a stunning upset to become mayor of New York City.

title: Albany Pact Shields The Whistle-Blowers
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders have reached agreement on a bill to protect health care whistle-blowers from retaliation by employers, the State Assembly announced today.

title: Enron's Ex-Chief Ties the Knot
description: Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, married Rebecca Carter, another former Enron executive, over the weekend in a ''small, private ceremony'' in his home in Houston, his spokeswoman said today.

title: F.D.A. EXPEDITES REVIEW OF AMERICAN HOME'S CANCER DRUG
description: The American Home Products Corporation said the Food and Drug Administration would give an expedited review to its experimental treatment for kidney cancer as the drug maker expanded its line of cancer therapies. American Home also sells Mylotarg, a treatment for acute myloid leukemia. The F.D.A. will review the experimental drug, known as CCI-779, as a treatment for renal-cell carcinoma after initial therapy has failed, said American Home's pharmaceuticals unit, Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories.

title: U.S. Users of Steel Worry That Tariffs Will Be Costly
description: Gary Hill, the president of National Metalwares, cannot yet quantify the effect steel tariffs will have on his business. But he assumes it will not be small, and it will not be good.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Metal From Truck Kills Driver
description: A 58-year-old physician from Nassau County was killed yesterday on the Long Island Expressway in Queens when a large piece of metal came off a truck and smashed through his windshield, the police said. The victim, Dr. Denis H. Tyras, was nearly decapitated in the accident, which occurred at 6:15 a.m. on the westbound side of the expressway near the Maurice Avenue exit, the police said. He was driving from his home in Kings Point to his job at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital in Greenwich Village, the police said. Police investigators recovered the steel piece of equipment that they believed came off the truck and struck Dr. Tyras. The truck has not yet been located, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: U.S. ADDS TROOPS AND HELICOPTERS IN AFGHAN BATTLE
description: More American troops and helicopters were called in today to counter attempts by the Taliban and Al Qaeda to bolster the Islamic fighters who are struggling to hang on to their mountaintop redoubts.

title: Hear the One About the Goose on the IRT?
description: To the Editor:

title: Possible Deal Seen on Fuel Economy Measure in Senate
description: Senator John McCain and a handful of other Republicans appeared to be close tonight to signing on to a modified proposal from Senate Democrats to raise federal fuel economy standards. An agreement would increase the measure's chances of survival as part of the Senate's energy bill.

title: Second Accusation to Be Factor In Decision on Priests in Maine
description: Officials of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Maine, considering whether to remove two priests who had admitted sexually abusing boys, said late last week that one factor in their decision would be the belief that each priest had abused only one victim.

title: Bush Officials End Support Of Sharon's Tough Stance
description: Alarmed at Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's comments earlier this week that Israel would intentionally cause casualties among the Palestinians to force them to the bargaining table, the Bush administration decided to terminate its unequivocal support for Mr. Sharon's hard-line strategy and declared today that his approach would likely fail.

title: Ahmedabad Journal; In India, a Child's Life Is Cheap Indeed
description: The flatbed truck pulled up to the Muslim cemetery today bearing a terrible cargo. Volunteers with plastic bags tied to their hands lifted tiny charred bodies from the back, where they were piled without so much as a sheet for cover, and gently carried them onto the grounds as though they were just asleep.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column on Feb. 28 about talks between the Justice Department and Crdit Lyonnais, the French bank, concerning the possibility of criminal charges related to the bank's acquisition of a bond portfolio from a failed California insurer referred incorrectly to their status. No agreement has been reached for the bank to avoid prosecution and pay a fine. An article about the case appears today, on Page W1.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the explosion of a homemade bomb in the yard of an Arab boys' school in east Jerusalem misstated the number of children injured in an earlier attack, on Sunday, in an ultra-Orthodox neighborhood of the city. It was six children, not four.

title: One Thing the Red Sox Don't Lack Is Turmoil
description: The interim manager of the Boston Red Sox leaned against the railing of the third-base dugout here, discussing the position he had accepted less than 18 hours earlier. Mike Cubbage recounted how he received a scratchy call on his cellphone from the Red Sox hierarchy while he was eating at a seafood restaurant, informing him that Joe Kerrigan had been dismissed and that the club wanted him to manage the team temporarily during spring training.

title: Sale by Enron Set Back in India
description: An Indian court dealt a significant setback today to the sale of the Enron Corporation's majority interest in a $2.9 billion project of the Dabhol Power Company.

title: Rumsfeld's Burden: Stilling Echoes of the Grisly Raid in Somalia
description: At the Pentagon, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and his top aides were working hard today to exorcise the ghosts of Mogadishu.

title: Lord of the Hackers
description: ''The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'' is a brainy and beautiful film that has received more Academy Award nominations than any other film this year. It takes nothing away from its artistry to allow that its appeal, like that of the books on which it is based, owes much to the computer culture that made J. R. R. Tolkien's fantasy world its own.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about plans to dedicate two memorials to the people killed at the World Trade Center misidentified the man speaking to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in the background. He was Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society, not Philip K. Howard, its chairman.

title: French Bank Still Pursuing U.S. Settlement
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column on Feb. 28 about talks between Crdit Lyonnais, the French bank, and the Justice Department concerning possible criminal charges related to the bank's acquisition of a bond portfolio belonging to Executive Life, a failed California insurer, misstated the status of the talks. No agreement has been reached for the bank to avoid prosecution and pay a fine.

title: He Never Asked to Be the Mayor on Weekends
description: FROM the stink of things in his underdecorated but aggressively aromatic City Hall office, it is evident that Marc V. Shaw, New York City's deputy mayor for operations and, more famously, its mayoral surrogate when the boss sneaks those secret weekends out of town, has just parted company with a cigar. Maybe that's why he's being such a grouch: separation anxiety.

title: Owners Refine Their Offer
description: Negotiators for baseball's owners and players moved closer in a session tonight to what could be a pivotal point in this stage of their bargaining for a new labor agreement.

title: GLAMIS TO BUY FRANCISCO GOLD FOR $121 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Glamis Gold Ltd. said that it had agreed to buy the Francisco Gold Corporation for 192.2 million Canadian dollars ($121.5 million) in stock to expand in Latin America. Glamis, which is based in Reno, Nev., agreed to pay 1.55 shares for each Francisco share, the companies said. The purchase gives Glamis the El Sauzal gold deposit in Mexico, which it expects will become its principal mine and produce about 170,000 ounces of gold a year.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sony Says No Fee For Online Games
description: Laying down a challenge to Microsoft, Sony Computer Entertainment America is expected to announce today that it will not charge a monthly fee to connect its popular PlayStation 2 video game console to the Internet. Sony said it would begin selling a network adapter, which permits players to play online games through a dial-up modem or a broadband connection, in August for $39.99. Unlike Sega, which charges $9.95 a month for players to compete online, Sony will permit players to connect through their own Internet service providers. ''Players are interested in experimenting with online, but not paying for it,'' said Molly Smith, a spokeswoman for Sony. The service will work only for games that have online features built in. Microsoft included equipment for a broadband connection in its Xbox console, but has not yet discussed how Xbox users will connect to the Internet. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: A Cup of Memories, With Matching Saucer
description: I HAVE seen plenty of dog owners who looked like their pets, but until I unpacked Nana's teacup collection last week, I had never considered the possibility of a woman who resembled her china.

title: A Portable Printer Turns Out Instant Snapshots on the Road
description: Digital cameras and Polaroid cameras both produce images on the spot. But while you can pass around a Polaroid or give one away, digital images are temporarily locked in the camera.

title: Vincent Wagner, 57, Director Of Festival and Music Manager
description: Vincent Wagner, a classical music manager who was the music director of the summertime Maverick Concerts in West Hurley, N.Y., just outside Woodstock, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 57 and lived in Manhattan and West Hurley.

title: TYCO FINANCE UNIT RAISES $1 BILLION IN DEBT SALE
description: The CIT Group, a finance unit of Tyco International, sold $1 billion in securities backed by home equity loans, part of its pledge to raise $3 billion to pay off maturing debt. Tyco tapped $14.4 billion in bank loans on Feb. 4 to repay short-term i.o.u.'s as it prepared to split off CIT and three other companies, as well as to sell a plastics unit. The conglomerate is breaking up after being roiled by concerns that its accounting has not been transparent and that the company has used $64 billion in acquisitions since 1993 to mask slowing growth.

title: Ex-Executive at Citigroup Is Bank One Vice President
description: The Bank One Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Heidi G. Miller, one of the most prominent women on Wall Street until she left to join Priceline.com to manage its strategy and development.

title: VW Hopes Sports Car Revives Bentley
description: The lighting was low, the security was high and the artificial fog was thick as Volkswagen executives gave selected visitors a glimpse today of their secret project: the first all-new Bentley since Volkswagen took over Rolls-Royce Motor Cars three years ago.

title: A Sentence of No TV? Unusual, Yes, but Cruel?
description: Is it cruel and unusual punishment to deprive an American of his right to watch television?

title: The Urge to Converge
description: ''Mere size is no sin against the law,'' President William Howard Taft told Congress in 1911, in defense of the legislation that had enabled his G.O.P. predecessor, Teddy Roosevelt, to bust the trusts stifling competition. (Taft weighed over 300 pounds at the time.)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: F.T.C. Clears Acquisition Of Compaq by Hewlett

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Verisign Sees Return To Profitability
description: Signaling a return to profitability for VeriSign, a provider of Internet security and domain registration services, Stratton Sclavos, left, the president and chief executive, said yesterday that the company would report a first-quarter profit in line with analysts' expectations of about 20 cents a share. VeriSign, based in Mountain View, Calif., lost $401 million, or $1.91 a share, in the fourth quarter of 2001, on revenue of $284 million. In the current quarter, which ends March 31, analysts' forecasts call for revenue of $340 million; the company said it expected to meet that target. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Police Captain Acquitted of Drug-Related Theft
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday acquitted a high-ranking police commander of conspiring with a fellow officer and a drug dealer to steal $60,000 from a drug supplier in 1996.

title: Grooming a Little Montmartre, Just North of the Bronx
description: JAGON ELDRIDGE, a saxophonist, was spending $550 a month for a 6-by-6-foot cubicle with paper-thin walls on the Upper West Side, his ears assaulted by unruly children next door. Kate Wattson, a painter, was negotiating the end of her marriage from a sun-deprived garden apartment in Brooklyn Heights. John Pavlou, a sculptor, was living over his parents' grocery store, feeling utterly isolated from Manhattan artistic life.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Thursday with the continuation of an article about the Philadelphia Flower Show misidentified one plant. The lavender flower in the upper left of a grouping of four photographs was a Lavatera trimestris, not a Mystic Merlin hollyhock, a related plant with similar blooms.

title: Special Counsel Puts Lewinsky Case to Rest
description: In a final report that is supposed to end the long legal melodrama resulting from President Bill Clinton's relationship with Monica Lewinsky, the independent counsel said today that there was ample evidence to convict Mr. Clinton of perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Two Envoys Recalled
description: Foreign Minister Soledad Alvear said the ambassadors to Cuba and Switzerland had been summoned home for consultations about left-wing guerrillas who escaped from a Santiago prison in 1996 and later surfaced in those countries. Switzerland acknowledges granting asylum to one of the guerrillas but Fidel Castro has denied offering refuge to any of the escapees and his government has criticized Chile's insistence on pressing for more information about the matter. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: A Different Take on Human Origins
description: In a new genetic study of modern human origins, an American scientist has found what he says is substantial evidence that could reshape the prevailing ''out of Africa'' theory. Among his findings, he says, is the likelihood that genes from Neanderthals and other species live on in present-day humans.

title: Downloading Files and Storms
description: Every year Michael Greene, the president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, stands onstage during the show he runs, the Grammy Awards, and delivers a speech about an issue that pertains to the music world. On the broadcast last week, however, he chose a strange way to make his point.

title: NATIONAL STEEL SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The National Steel Corporation filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday because of low prices and a weak economy. The filing came a day after the Bush administration imposed tariffs on most steel imports. National Steel, majority owned by the NKK Corporation of Tokyo, said it received a $450 million loan to continue operating plants. The company, based in Mishawaka, Ind., makes about six million tons of steel a year and has 8,400 employees. National Steel, which had $2.49 billion in sales last year, listed $2.61 billion in debt and $2.3 billion in assets, according to papers filed in bankruptcy court in Chicago. National Steel has lost money in six consecutive quarters.

title: A Cup to Make Any Keats Burst Out in an Ode
description: The work of Vivienne Ross, a British potter -- including the dreamlike cup, $60, above -- is at Environment337 on Smith Street in Carroll Gardens. Her hand-painted earthenware pieces feature nude bodies swimming around in shades of pink and yellow. ''My everyday thoughts, preoccupations and sometimes anxieties dictate the direction of the images,'' she said. There are also square plates and a pitcher ($60 to $105). Loren Sosna (right) and Donald W. J. Mulligan, who own the store, also sell tabletop items, pillows, lamps and Juliska blown-glass ware from the Czech Republic (on the shelves, from $18 to $220). At 337 Smith Street; (718) 522-1767, Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.

title: Hernndez States Case To Win a Starting Job
description: Orlando Hernndez stared at the ground, shook his head and said several times in Spanish that he had no comment about the awkward position he is in. Hernndez had just pitched three dazzling innings today against the brawny Texas Rangers, and that had seemed to say plenty.

title: Houston Believes Knicks Can Avoid Bulls' Path
description: When the Knicks held a news conference on Tuesday night to announce the contract extension for Coach Don Chaney, there were two points that were spun over and over. The Knicks stressed that the extension was the first step in what they believed would be a turnaround of their fortunes. And second, perhaps more surprising and more realistic, they admitted that it was a step in transition and rebuilding.

title: Hostages Held In Robbery At a Store In Nassau
description: Several robbers were holding at least seven people hostage inside a Staples store on Long Island this morning after a robbery attempt went awry, the police said.

title: D.C. Commission Meets With Tyson
description: Mike Tyson met with boxing commissioners in Washington on Tuesday to discuss his application for a license to fight Lennox Lewis there, Gina Douglas, a spokeswoman for the commission, said yesterday.

title: Resignation and Debt Warning Add to the Troubles at Conseco
description: Prospects for Conseco Inc., the beleaguered consumer-finance and insurance company, dimmed yesterday as its chief financial officer abruptly resigned and a debt-rating agency warned that the company might not be generating enough cash to meet its obligations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Ruling Questioned
description: Only days before a scheduled vote, Columbia University has asked the National Labor Relations Board to overturn a recent ruling by the board's New York office, which held that the university's 1,900 graduate research and teaching assistants were employees and had the right to unionize. Columbia argues that the assistants are students, not workers. The labor board has scheduled voting on March 13, 14 and 19 on whether the graduate assistants want to join the United Auto Workers. The request for review will not stop the vote.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Bush Brother Pushes Education on Sales Campaign Trail
description: Neil Bush might as well have been giving a stump speech when he addressed three dozen principals at a middle school here the other day.

title: US Airways Names Ex-Official of Continental as President
description: US Airways, which like many other airlines has had financial troubles since Sept. 11, said yesterday that it had hired David N. Siegel, a former executive at Continental Airlines, as president and chief executive.

title: Malcolm X Family Fights Auction of Papers
description: A cache of personal writings attributed to Malcolm X has turned up for auction in San Francisco and on eBay, infuriating members of his family who are trying to stop the sale and alarming scholars who worry that the material could disappear into private hands.

title: So What, Exactly, Do Online Gamers Want?
description: IT was billed as a new form of online entertainment, one that would broaden the base of people who play games on the Internet. Majestic, an online suspense thriller introduced last year with great fanfare by Electronic Arts, was episodic and interactive, offering additions to the story line each month and reaching outside the computer to infiltrate players' lives with e-mail, faxes and even telephone calls that advanced the plot. The game's slogan was ''It plays you.'' But that turned out to be precisely the problem.

title: Meet the E-Mail Daemon, Always Eager to Pitch In
description: Q. What is a mailer daemon and how did it get that name?

title: Council Speaker Outlines Potential Battles With Mayor
description: Gifford Miller, the speaker of the City Council, offered a rare glimpse of the new Council's vision for the city yesterday, focusing on cuts to children's services and raising taxes as potential battle lines in budget negotiations with the Bloomberg administration.

title: As Tastes Shift Again, It's, Oh, Natural
description: AS the shiny surfaces and sleek forms of midcentury modern furniture and housewares fade from fashion, designers are turning to the rougher, earthier textures found in nature. Shells, sponges, grasses and even snakeskin were inspiration for the pieces shown here.

title: One China? Perhaps Two? Little Things Mean a Lot
description: As China convenes its Parliament this week, its leaders seem less agitated about the nettlesome issue of Taiwan than they have been for some time.

title: Villanova Knocks Out Syracuse
description: DeShaun Williams knifed down the baseline for an unescorted layup that he somehow left short on the rim. No problem. His Syracuse teammate Jeremy McNeil was alone in perfect position to tap the ball in. Instead, McNeil mis-hit it. That three-second sequence reflected the Orangemen's entire out-of-sync season.

title: Flatlands Developing New-Age Competitors
description: Travis Mayer, the 2002 Olympic silver medalist in freestyle moguls, was raised in Orchard Park, N.Y., a place more famous for its football stadium, home to the N.F.L.'s Buffalo Bills. There was plenty of snow in Mayer's neighborhood, but no mountains. He learned to ski on a hill with just 750 feet of vertical drop.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Use Of Funds Is Criticized
description: City Council members criticized the Giuliani administration yesterday for not spending all of a special state and federal fund devoted to child care and the Bloomberg administration for using part of the money to ease the budget deficit. The committees on welfare and women's issues said the city received $192 million in federal and state aid for day care over three years. The committees said that the number of slots available for children had fallen by 6,000 and that more than 30,000 families were on waiting lists. Bloomberg administration officials testified that no expansion was likely until 2006 because $80 million of the fund was being used to ease the deficit and the rest went to other programs. Nina Bernstein (NYT)

title: Court Rejects Any Liberty For Milosevic, Citing Threats
description: Judges at the war crimes tribunal today formally turned down Slobodan Milosevic's repeated requests to be temporarily released from jail to organize a proper defense, saying in effect that he could not be trusted.

title: Torre Is Praised by Wohlers
description: Minutes after the Yankees lost Game 6 of the World Series in Arizona and were staring at a deciding Game 7, Manager Joe Torre asked a clubhouse attendant to find Mark Wohlers and call him into his office. Wohlers, a reliever who been left off the Yankees' postseason roster, said today that Torre told him ''that he had wished there was room for me on the postseason roster.''

title: Subtitle Suggests the Real Story in Clinton Report
description: On the book's blue-and-white cover, the title appears in medium-size type: ''Final Report of the Independent Counsel In Re: Madison Guaranty Savings & Loan Association.''

title: Comcast Cable To Carry YES
description: Comcast Cable yesterday became the second major cable systems owner in the New York metropolitan area to agree to carry the YES Network, the new home of the Yankees.

title: Nuclear Threats, Real and Imagined
description: To the Editor:

title: A Playoff With Yale A Surprise To Some
description: As midnight approached on Tuesday in a near-empty gymnasium, the Yale men's basketball players and coaches gathered to cut down the nets in one of the odder championship celebrations in Ivy League history. Yale did not play that night, but Penn did, and Penn's 64-48 victory over Princeton allowed Yale to back into a three-way tie for the league championship.

title: Retirement at Hicks, Muse
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the fifth-biggest leveraged buyout firm, with $14 billion in assets, said a partner, Charles W. Tate, would retire June 30 after 11 years. Mr. Tate, 57, will continue to represent the firm on the boards of four companies it owns a stake in, executives told about 30 investors. His name will remain part of the firm's name.

title: Eagles and the Hoyas Overcome Their Errors
description: The Big East tournament opener was supposed to offer experience (Boston College) versus youthful energy (Rutgers), the defending tournament champion (Boston College) against a team that did not even qualify for this competition last year (Rutgers) and sharpshooters (Boston College) compared with lousy shooters (Rutgers).

title: 'Attention, Shoppers. Don't You Use That Tone With Me'
description: One of the great conveniences of the modern bank machine is that the customer never has to talk to a live person. But new kiosks being tested for grocery stores may signal how the lost art of conversation will fare in digital-age commerce.

title: China Is Increasing Its Budget For Military Spending by 17.6%
description: China is increasing military spending this year by 17.6 percent, or $3 billion, bringing the publicly reported total to $20 billion, the finance minister announced today.

title: With Dvorak Coming Alive, Rangers Are More Confident
description: The way the Rangers rallied from a 2-0 deficit in the third period for a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota Wild in overtime Tuesday night could be a turning point of their season.

title: Video Game Pioneers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about an increase in cases of pertussis, or whooping cough, misstated the age at which infants begin to receive vaccine for it. While the vaccine does not provide protection until after the third shot, generally given at 6 months, current guidelines call for the first shot to be given at 2 months.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Steelmaking nations warn of retaliation; battle likely at WTO : U.S. tariffs draw fire from Asia to Europe
description: SEOUL:  Steel-making countries edged closer to a possible global trade war Wednesday as they announced plans to appeal President George W. Bush's decision to impose tariffs to the World Trade Organization.

title: Train Fire That Killed 370 Puts Egypt's Malaise in Spotlight
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt is in Washington this week to talk about Middle East peace with President Bush and others. But back home, the violence convulsing Israel and the Palestinian territories is taking distinct second place to a national debate about mediocre governance.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Copyright Treaty Takes Effect
description: An international treaty negotiated in 1996 to reinforce protection of copyright on the Internet has come into force. The copyright treaty is the work of the World Intellectual Property Organization, as is a companion treaty protecting sound recordings, which will take effect in May. Both are intended to bring intellectual property law into the digital age. The pacts aim to prevent unauthorized copying or use of work and to ensure the payment of royalties. The organization says clear copyright protection will encourage people to put their work on the Internet. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Treatments For Fertility Are Studied For Problems
description: Babies born after couples undergo fertility treatments are more likely to have low birth weights and birth defects, researchers report today in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Diallo Officers Deskbound
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the three officers involved in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo who are still on the force would continue to be barred from carrying weapons and for the immediate future would remain assigned to desk duties that prevent them from meeting the public. Mr. Kelly's predecessor, Bernard B. Kerik, announced last April that the officers' desk duties would be reviewed in a year. The three officers are Richard Murphy, Kenneth Boss and Sean Carroll. The fourth officer involved in the Feb. 5, 1999, shooting, Edward McMellon, has joined the Fire Department. The officers were acquitted in February of 2000 of criminal charges in the death of Mr. Diallo.

title: E-Book 'Borrowers' Beware
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Awakening a Seed

title: Light, Truth and Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Pastor Sentenced For Killing Family
description: In a macabre case that has gripped Belgium, a Hungarian-born pastor was sentenced to life imprisonment and his daughter to 21 years for having murdered most of their family. Andras Pandy, 74, was found guilty of murdering two wives and four of his children, and of raping three of his daughters. His eldest daughter Agnes, 44, was found guilty of helping to kill her mother, her stepmother, two brothers and one sister. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Economic Scene; As recovery builds, the less educated go to the end of the employment line.
description: ''EVEN if the economy is on the road to recovery,'' Alan Greenspan warned last week, ''the unemployment rate, in typical cyclical fashion, may resume its increase for a time.'' Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who will appear before the Senate Banking Committee today, did not mention that the lingering effects of high unemployment early in a recovery tend to be concentrated among the unskilled and minorities.
