This is true even though recessions are becoming more egalitarian.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Wedgwood Profit Falls
description: The Irish luxury goods manufacturer Waterford Wedgwood announced a 50 percent decline in annual profit, to 41.3 million euros ($36.1 million) for 2001, because of difficult trading conditions after the Sept. 11 attacks. Revenue remained just above 1 billion euros for the second consecutive year, at 1.01 billion euros ($885 million). The company will take a 61.8 million ($51.4 million) restructuring charge as it cuts back on capacity, closes a crystal plant in England and continues to expand its international chain of retail stores. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Move to Ease Term Limits Loses at Polls In California
description: A little more than 10 years after a voters' revolt placed strict term limits on many state and local offices, politicians in seven states have started to fight back with efforts to ease those limits.

title: Where Top British Directors Are: Broadway
description: Is it simply a coincidence or could it be a cabal? Three of the foremost British directors are working on Broadway at the same time, readying major American shows to face New York audiences this month. Richard Eyre is opening a revival of ''The Crucible'' tonight, Nicholas Hytner's production of the new musical ''Sweet Smell of Success'' opens on March 14, and Trevor Nunn's remounting of his acclaimed Royal National Theater production of ''Oklahoma!'' opens on March 21.

title: Details of a Terrorist Plot Still Cloaked in Confusion
description: A murky front in the war on terrorism has opened in this tense Balkan nation, as security forces last weekend killed seven foreigners they said were planning attacks on embassies and arrested another four men for a similar plot last month.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Shot In Midtown
description: A man was shot at Eighth Avenue and West 35th Street around 4 p.m. yesterday, the police said. The man, whose name was not released, was shot in the hand and the side. The victim, who the police said was in his 30's, was taken to St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital, where he was listed in serious but stable condition last night. The police have two suspects, though no arrests had been made as of last night, an officer said. The street was blocked off to traffic through the afternoon.

title: Alomar Fits In, On or Off the Field
description: This spring training was in its infancy and Manager Bobby Valentine was asked what questions he had for his new-look Mets. Surprisingly, Valentine listed Roberto Alomar, a 10-time Gold Glove winner, 12-time All-Star and most likely future Hall of Famer. How could perhaps the most talented all-around player in camp and possibly in team history be a question?

title: Bush Makes a Public Appeal For a Federal Court Nominee
description: On the eve of a showdown vote on his nomination of Charles W. Pickering Sr. to a federal appeals court post, President Bush today accused the Democrats of maligning a good man and opposing his confirmation for political reasons.

title: Bill to Raise The Insurance On Deposits Has 2 Big Foes
description: A Congressional proposal to increase the amount of bank deposits protected by government insurance is facing opposition from the Bush administration and the Federal Reserve.

title: Conservation? Just Ask
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank To Buy Back Shares
description: Switzerland's largest bank, UBS A.G., plans to purchase up to $2.95 billion of its own shares, or about 4.7 percent of its share capital. The program, which began Tuesday and will last a year, is the fourth buyback in two years. The bank finished purchasing 28.8 million shares, for about $1.4 billion, on Tuesday. The program, UBS said, is aimed at institutional investors who need to sell shares for tax purposes. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: McLEODUSA INC., Cedar Rapids, Iowa, a provider of telephone service, said it would sell three subsidiaries, CapRock Services Corp., CapRock U.K. Ltd. and Spacelink Systems Inc., to a holding company formed by two investment firms, Genesis Park, Houston, and Riverside Co., New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: No. 2 Denver Wins Title
description: Regular-season races in three Division I conferences went down to the last weekend of play, with the champion in the Western Collegiate Hockey Association determined in overtime.

title: The Recovery That Defied The Forecasts Of Economists
description: The economy's quick recovery from recession, evinced by the latest reports from the Commerce Department and the Federal Reserve, has taken many experienced forecasters by surprise.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Staying in the Neighborhood

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Police Commander Quits Under Fire
description: A Baltimore police commander resigned amid criticism of a Feb. 22 memorandum in which he instructed officers to question all black men they saw late at night at a bus stop where a rape by a black man had occurred. The commander, Maj. Donald E. Healy, who is white, issued a statement that said: ''I'm deeply sorry if I offended any citizens. I assure you that my intention was to apprehend a violent criminal; it had nothing to do with profiling.'' Gary Gately (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you declare war against the Palestinians thinking that you can solve the problem by seeing how many Palestinians can be killed, I don't know that that leads us anywhere.''

title: Miscellany
description: * McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising is laying off employees in two offices. In San Francisco, McCann-Erickson laid off fewer than 20 employees from a staff of 230, a result of the loss late last year of the Blue Shield account. In Washington, several employees are being dismissed as the office closes on Friday after losing the US Airways account in January. McCann-Erickson is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: A Place to Buy a Vase, Or Catch Your Breath And Blow Your Own
description: On a side street in Williamsburg, John Pomp (above), a glass artist, has opened One Sixty Glass, a studio and school, with Michiko Sakano (in background). The large, garagelike space functions on several levels. A retail area is in front (right), where Mr. Pomp's own creations are for sale, along with a signature line of vases, which is exclusive at the store ($50 to $250 for vases, $350 and up for hanging lamps). The large door brings the outside into the space, flooding the store with sunlight. The glass furnace and reheating chambers give an industrial, Wagnerian feel to the glass-blowing area. Customers are encouraged to observe the process.

title: Hard Times, and Hard-Driving Music, Back in the Big Easy
description: The good-natured New Orleans jazz revue ''One Mo' Time'' was an Off Broadway hit when it opened in 1979 at the Village Gate. It ran for three and a half years and begat numerous touring companies, becoming a more or less reiterative theme on the theatrical landscape. A full-fledged revival production, which first appeared at the Williamstown Theater Festival, opened on Broadway last night at the Longacre Theater. That will certainly make it the oldest show eligible for this year's Tony Award for best new musical. But otherwise there seems little reason for it to be here.

title: Vienna Skewered as a Nazi-Era Pillager of Its Jews
description: The Austrians had a good run, for many years, as the ''first victim'' of Adolf Hitler, who occupied his native Austria in March 1938. But two historians have now documented the extent to which the Austrians were among the first war profiteers, moving quickly to expropriate the property of Vienna's Jews.

title: 'Call Me When You Get This': A Pager Turns Into a Cellphone
description: With its built-in wireless telephone, the new BlackBerry 5810 e-mail pager and organizer is the latest entry in the all-in-one communications device market.

title: The Book Deal As a Cudgel
description: When the lawyer for the former chief executive of Enron suggested on television last Friday that the whistle-blower in the scandal was only whistling because ''she has a lucrative book deal,'' it reminded that the all-but-automatic book deal for the suddenly celebrated can go well beyond mere certification and vindication of fame. It can now also be manipulated so that having a contract is an accusation.

title: Tourney Is Back in Houston, And Earlier One Is Recalled
description: Thousands of bridge enthusiasts of all grades will converge on this city in the next 48 hours for the American Contract Bridge League's 11-day Spring National Championships. The focus of attention will be the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, which begins on Sunday.

title: For Fatah, Only a War Can Bring Peace to Mideast
description: Since the beginning of the year, it has been Palestinian militants tied to Yasir Arafat's Fatah faction who have carried out most of the attacks against Israelis -- and the most lethal attacks, Israeli and Palestinian officials say.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Settles Deceptive Ad Charges
description: Palm agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission accusations of deceptive advertising over claims that Palm hand-held computers provide built-in wireless access to the Internet. Many of Palm's models do not have such access without separate wireless modems or additional software, F.T.C. officials said. In addition, the F.T.C. said, some of the company's advertisements failed to disclose that one of the models that permits wireless Internet and e-mail access requires users to pay monthly fees to subscribe to the company's Palm.Net Internet service. The trade commission ordered Palm to ''disclose, clearly and conspicuously, when consumers have to buy add-ons in order to perform advertised functions.'' The settlement provides for an $11,000 fine for any violation of the order, the officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Loss For Software Developer
description: Baltimore Technologies, the troubled Irish developer of security software, reported a preliminary loss for 2001 of 86.2 million ($125.5 million) before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, compared with 29.5 million ($41.9 million) in 2000. Excluding the sale of its e-mail scanning division and part of its Japanese subsidiaries, revenue fell 32 percent, to 39.2 million ($55.7 million). Baltimore's market value has fallen from a peak of 7 billion two years ago to less than 60 million. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Some leaders among new casualties : Allies' attacks stagger Taliban and Qaeda
description: U.S.-led forces, bolstered by hundreds of American reinforcements and newly arrived attack helicopters, have killed at least half the Qaeda and Taliban fighters involved in intense fighting in a targeted area of rugged eastern Afghanistan, the U.S. commander in the area said Wednesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Shelved but Not Forgotten; Palm Drops the M505 Organizer, But a Synching Problem Persists
description: WITH the release of a new Palm hand-held organizer, the m515, the company has announced that it is eliminating a predecessor, the m505.

title: GOING HOME WITH: Cassandra Wilson; Jazz Diva Follows Sound of Her Roots
description: ON the highway up from Jackson, Miss., the conversation in the car circled around the local women and the blues. Cassandra Wilson, the jazz singer, sat wreathed by her golden dreadlocks, a New York woman in a chic leather jacket. Really, what she was talking about was home. ''Mississippi,'' she said, ''has the freest and meanest women in the world.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Support For Tax On Wealthy
description: A poll of Nassau voters shows wide support for a new local income tax on the wealthy to help solve the county's fiscal crisis, advocates of the tax said yesterday. But the county's legislative leaders have expressed opposition to the proposal. The survey found that 69 percent of those responding favored a proposed tax of 1 percent on personal income above $150,000 and 2 percent on income above $200,000. Proponents of the tax say that the revenues would enable a reduction in property taxes for homeowners and would also avert draconian service cuts.

title: Gang That Couldn't Shoot Straight Played Defense
description: Donald Emanuel, Kyle Cuffe and Sharif Fordham missed point-blank tips one after another. Marcus Hatten, an all-Big East first team guard, banged jumpers off the front and the back of the rim. Willie Shaw arced shots too high off the backboard. It was hypnotic, like watching a slot machine reel off loser after loser. St. John's tried awfully hard, to shoot themselves out of the Big East tournament, the N.C.A.A. tournament, even out of Madison Square Garden.

title: Hubble Power Controller Replaced With Soft Touch
description: The Hubble Space Telescope is alive and in stable condition, with electricity surging through its instruments, after astronauts performed a heart-stopping replacement of its central power controller today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Loss At Airline
description: Stung by a loss of passengers after Sept. 11, Cathay Pacific Airways of Hong Kong said its net profit fell 87 percent in 2001. Cathay Pacific's traffic had already been affected by the economic slowdown, said its chairman, James Hughes-Hallett, but the sudden loss of customers after the terrorist attacks forced the carrier to cut back several routes. To woo back skittish customers, Cathay then had to discount its fares heavily. The airline reported a net profit of $84.7 million, down from $645 million the previous year. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Bush Set to Announce Plan To Improve Investor Protection
description: As Congress considers legislative responses to the collapse of Enron, President Bush will unveil proposals to protect investors better through faster and more complete disclosure of important financial information, improved auditing standards and new requirements for executives, administration officials said tonight.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: He's Out For The Season
description: A man whose security breach caused Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta to be shut down for about four hours on Nov. 16 has been ordered by a county judge not to attend University of Georgia football games next season. The man, Michael Shane Lasseter, left, a 33-year-old bank executive, ran past airport security that day so that he would not miss a flight carrying him to a Georgia game. He subsequently pleaded guilty to two counts of criminal trespassing. In addition to barring Mr. Lasseter from Georgia games, the judge, Morris Braswell, ordered him to perform 250 hours of community service and to spend five weekends in jail and two years on probation.

title: Some See Panic As Main Effect Of Dirty Bombs
description: Radioactive materials in wide use in the United States could be turned into weapons of terror that would probably kill few people but would spread panic and produce severe economic damage, scientists told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

title: Voices Across the Mideast Chasm
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR
description: New York Now and in 2050

title: Ted Koppel's Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Losers Of Auction Winners
description: IT'S hard to resist a good Internet bargain, especially when it seems too good to be true.

title: Far From the Market, Game Designers Dissect What Fizzles
description: SID MEIER is an icon among video game fans and his fellow game designers. The many titles that bear his name, including the wildly popular Sid Meier's Civilization and its two sequels, have sold millions of copies.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In trying to acquire all of Travelocity, Sabre finds itself in a struggle to regain what it once had.
description: BUBBLE-TIME decisions can be hard to reverse. At least that is what Sabre Holdings, the computer reservation system, seems to be finding out.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adviser May Bid For Imagis
description: Imagis Technologies, a producer of software for security systems that identify people by the patterns of their facial features, said the Pembroke Group, an investment firm it has retained for financial advice, might formally offer to take Imagis private in a buyout valued at more than $50 million. Imagis, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, said it would appoint an independent committee of its board to consider the plan. Pembroke said it was considering offering $4.10 a share for Imagis, which closed trading yesterday on the Nasdaq bulletin board at $3.40, up 93 cents, or 38 percent. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: From Hospital Bed, Woman Asks To Die
description: A paralyzed 43-year-old woman told a High Court hearing from her London hospital bed that she felt entitled to refuse life-prolonging treatment and wanted to be allowed to die. The woman, a former social worker who by court order cannot be identified, gave her testimony to the chief judge of the Family Division and 10 lawyers gathered around her bed. The morning's questions and answers were transmitted by video link to the courtroom where the case is being heard, and the afternoon session in the courtroom was televised back to the woman's ward. Doctors have said it would be against their ethics to switch off the ventilator she has needed to keep her alive since a ruptured blood vessel in her neck a year ago left her unable to breathe unaided.

title: A Stripping Act That's Hard on the Body
description: Ballet Florida is not exactly a name that rings a local bell. Yet this 16-year-old troupe, founded in West Palm Beach by Marie Hale, seems hardly unknown on the professional circuit. Making its New York debut on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, the company featured three works by choreographers of international repute and a committed group of dancers drawn from both abroad and different parts of the country.

title: Judge Says Ruling on Microsoft Won't Come Quickly
description: The Bush administration and nine states urged a federal judge today to approve their settlement of the Microsoft antitrust case swiftly and reject a raft of complaints by rivals and consumer groups.

title: Decision on Chancellor's Contract Is Delayed
description: At the request of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the Board of Education and Chancellor Harold O. Levy agreed yesterday to a two-month postponement of the board's decision on whether to extend Mr. Levy's contract for another year.

title: A Bit of Minimalist Cool in the Hubbub of Atlantic Avenue
description: Among Atlantic Avenue's many antiques stores, a new one called Adresse is a standout for its cool, minimal setting. Couches from the 1950's reupholstered in vintage fabric (like the one shown above, $3,000) form two living room vignettes, one of which includes a glass coffee table with a metal wheat-stalk base (also shown, $1,500). A service-pantry setting in the back of the store has vintage clothing, glass-front cabinets and perfect ironstone coffee cups ($8). Wooden bowling pins (center, $30 each) sit on a wood and iron folding chair ($125).

title: Civil Liberties Groups Sue U.S. On Closed Immigration Hearings
description: Several civil liberties groups sued the federal government today, challenging its closed immigration hearings for those detained in New Jersey in the investigation of the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: A Gadget in the Mood for Love, Whether or Not Anyone Else Is
description: A Toronto company has developed a device that may be of interest to gadget-minded couples who are trying to have children. The company, Pheromone Sciences Corporation, has developed a wristwatch that can also predict when a woman will ovulate by measuring changes in chloride ions on the surface of her skin.

title: Sports of The Times; A Changing Of Direction For Rutgers
description: WHO is Rutgers? What is Rutgers?

title: INSIDE
description: The Last Lewinsky Report

title: For Relatives of 9/11 Dead, Anguish Is in the Details
description: It may mean nothing at all, but for Terry McGovern, the recovery of her mother's wallet changed everything.

title: A Tribe Is Prey to Vengeance After Taliban's Fall in North
description: One after the other, the villages in the valley of Shor Daryab stand all but empty.

title: Mortgage Applications Rose Last Month
description: An index measuring applications for mortgages rose last week to the highest level in 1 1/2 months, led by a surge in refinancing, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said.

title: New Rules In Zimbabwe Likely to Aid Mugabe's Side
description: The violence that has flared in the campaign for the presidential election this weekend has dominated the headlines here. But lawyers and election observers are increasingly concerned about a series of changes to the electoral law that may disenfranchise thousands of voters and favor President Robert Mugabe.

title: AIRPORTS
description: The National Guard will begin a ''phased withdrawal'' this month from the hundreds of airports the troops have been patrolling for almost six months and are to be completely gone by May 31, the Transportation Department said. At first, the Guard will be replaced mostly by officers supplied by state and local police departments, said Michael P. Jackson, the deputy secretary of transportation; later, more federal police officers will be used.

title: Accounts
description: * Tiger Schulmann's Karate, Paramus, N.J., to Rotter-Kantor, New York, to handle the account of the chain of karate schools, which had been at Dcode, New York, part of Intelefilm. Spending was estimated at $4 million to $6 million.

title: Clash of Brothers Widens Battle for Global Crossing
description: A second Los Angeles investment firm confirmed yesterday that it was planning a bid for Global Crossing in a move that would pit one brother against another.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Committee Control Retained
description: Democratic Party leaders in Bridgeport appear to have retained control of an important party committee, despite resistance by some party advocates opposed to Mayor Joseph P. Ganim, left, who has been indicted on corruption and other charges. In a preliminary vote on Tuesday, Mario Testa, a supporter of Mr. Ganim, kept chairmanship of the 90-member Democratic Town Committee. But the vote will not be final until absentee ballots are tallied tomorrow. Mr. Ganim's trial on racketeering and other charges is scheduled for next January.

title: Official Forced To Step Down After Testifying On Budget Cut
description: The head of the Army Corps of Engineers was forced to resign today after he suggested to Congress that he opposed the budget cuts the administration had proposed for his agency.

title: Annan Says Terrorism's Roots Are Broader Than Poverty
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan told an audience of foreign policy experts today that terrorism was not necessarily linked to poverty but rose from a broader mix of problems caused by bad government, opportunistic politicians and militant leaders who exploit grievances.

title: Footlights
description: Art History

title: Shrinking and Rethinking the Old Vertical Antenna
description: AS cellphones start to approach the size of matchboxes, their antennas are shrinking, too. In the tiniest new phones the antenna is often hidden inside, where it may take the form of a piece of foil or a coiled wire. But a new material may allow antennas for phones and other devices to become both obvious and invisible at the same time.

title: Army Official Kept Options On Enron Stock Until January
description: Thomas E. White, a former top executive of the Enron Corporation, promised to give up any financial interest in Enron when he became secretary of the Army, but held options to buy 665,000 shares until early this year.

title: Instability in India
description: Several days of rioting in the western Indian state of Gujarat have left hundreds of Muslims and Hindus dead and stirred anxiety throughout the nation and the region. At a time when South Asia is on edge because of religious hatred and the war in Afghanistan, the violence makes clear that India has work to do to sustain the sectarian harmony that Mohandas K. Gandhi, the independence leader, championed in Gujarat more than 50 years ago.

title: U.S. Duties On Steel Anger Russia
description: A trade dispute between Russia and the United States escalated today, as punitive American duties on steel from Russia -- and elsewhere -- brought angry words from officials and fresh statements about a ban on American poultry.

title: And When She Was Bad She Was . . .
description: ATONEMENT

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Capital Spending And Profits Fall
description: Japanese companies sharply cut capital investments in the October-December quarter, the first decline in two years, to help offset falling profits, according to new government figures. Companies cut capital investments by a worse-than-expected 14.5 percent in the fourth quarter from the year-earlier period. That came as pretax profits fell 31.4 percent, about as fast as they fell in the prior quarter, while sales fell 3.8 percent. Capital spending makes up about 15 percent of Japan's economy. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Israel Strikes Hard at Gaza Strip As Powell Assails Sharon Stance
description: Israeli forces struck hard today by land, sea and air at the teeming Gaza Strip, where Palestinians breached another red line on Tuesday when they fired rockets into an Israeli town. With the mounting carnage, which added 10 Palestinian and 2 Israeli dead to the toll, the government of Ariel Sharon received an unusual rebuke from Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.

title: Medical First: A Transplant Of a Uterus
description: Doctors in Saudi Arabia are reporting that they performed the world's first uterus transplant, from a 46-year-old woman to a 26-year-old who had a hysterectomy because of a hemorrhage after childbirth, but still hoped to have another baby.

title: Voices Across the Mideast Chasm
description: To the Editor:

title: Howard Cannon, 90, Senator Who Served Four Terms, Dies
description: Former Senator Howard W. Cannon of Nevada, who served four terms as a moderate Democrat and was unseated after Teamsters union officials were accused of offering him a bribe, died today at a hospice in Las Vegas. He was 90.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: An Eager Student Orchestra Gets a Compleat Education
description: The compleat conductor came to the Manhattan School of Music on Friday night. Gunther Schuller, composer, conductor, educator, producer and author of ''The Compleat Conductor,'' an exhaustive and opinionated guide to the art of conducting, led the Manhattan School of Music Symphony in a compleat -- and very nicely rounded -- program that ranged from Lutoslawski's Piano Concerto to Beethoven's ''Pastoral'' and included a piece, ''Seven Studies on Themes of Paul Klee,'' of Mr. Schuller's own.

title: Merrill Analyst Shifts His Accounting Focus in Making Forecasts
description: As part of an effort by Merrill Lynch & Company to rely less on companies' choices in reporting their earnings, a Merrill stock analyst covering Computer Associates said yesterday that he would no longer use pro forma results from the company to derive his earnings forecasts.

title: Agriculture Nominee Faces Contentious Senate Hearing
description: Thomas Dorr, the nominee for a top position in the Agriculture Department, defended himself today against accusations of racial bias and manipulating farm subsidy programs.

title: TRACKING TERRORISTS
description: The F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said Al Qaeda followers in the United States and abroad remained committed to participating in terror attacks in the United States. Mr. Mueller, speaking at a hearing of the House Appropriations Committee on his bureau's budget, said counterterrorism officials had thwarted some attempted terrorist plots. ''But,'' he warned, ''the mere fact that there have been successes does not in any way, shape or form mean that we are confident that there will not be another attack.'' David Johnston (NYT)

title: Walter Goodman, 74, TV Critic And Reporter for The Times
description: Walter Goodman, a former reporter and critic at The New York Times and the author of a widely read history of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, died yesterday at a hospital in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 74 and lived in Greenburgh, N.Y.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Offers Bullish Forecast
description: The Sprint Corporation said that it would meet its 2002 profit forecast and that its Sprint PCS Group wireless unit would add as many as 750,000 customers this quarter. Sprint will earn $1.40 a share this year, excluding expenses related to the canceled Integrated On-Demand Network project, the company said. Analysts' forecast $1.31 a share. Cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, will be about $4.6 billion, Sprint predicted. Sprint's PCS Group, the fourth-largest United States mobile-phone company by customers, expects to add three million subscribers this year. The company's two tracking stocks surged, with the PCS unit rising 20.1 percent, to $11.47, and the Sprint FON Group, which handles long-distance and local services, up 8.7 percent, to $15.83.

title: GENCORP RESTATES FINANCIAL RESULTS FOR LAST 3 YEARS
description: GenCorp Inc. restated financial results for the last three fiscal years yesterday after the company, which makes aerospace supplies and chemicals, completed a review of accounting items and costs at two auto parts plants. Net income for the first three quarters of fiscal 2001 was reduced $3 million, decreasing earnings to 52 cents a share from 59 cents, the company said. Income from continuing operations in fiscal 2000 was reduced 5.4 percent, to $52 million, or $1.23 share, from $55 million, or $1.31 a share. For 1999, income from continuing operations was restated as $45 million, or $1.07 a share, from $46 million, or $1.09, the company said. The revisions correct errors in the accounting for customer-owned tooling, inventory and the recognition of liabilities at a GDX Automotive unit plant.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Mixing Green With Red
description: Reversing a long-held policy, the ruling Communist Party said that party members would be permitted to engage in private enterprise. The ban had meant that most party members were excluded from the country's drive toward private enterprise and entrepreneurship, which has raised urban living standards. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Amtrak President May Move to Replace Deposed Head of New Jersey Transit
description: The president of Amtrak, George Warrington, plans to resign his post to become executive director of New Jersey Transit, The Associated Press reported last night.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the composer and pianist Leo Ornstein yesterday misstated the name of the school where he studied and made his musical debut. It was the Institute of Musical Art (now the Juilliard School), not the Institute for Musical Arts.

title: Metro Briefing | Today: Public Transport At Ground Zero
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on improving subway, PATH train and ferry service as the World Trade Center site is rebuilt. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (212) 788-7722.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Retailer's Profit Rises
description: Europe's largest supermarket retailer, Carrefour S.A., reported a 15 percent increase in 2001 earnings but warned that profit growth could slow. Carrefour said that 2001 net profit rose to 1.21 billion euros ($1.06 billion) in 2001 from 1.05 billion euros in 2000 and that it aimed to increase net profit by 10 to 15 percent in 2002, which some investors viewed as too low. Last year, the company, which is based in Paris, slashed prices on toys, clothing and food to increase sales after its $17 billion takeover of the Promodes chain in January 2000. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Voices Across the Mideast Chasm
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Wants Radiologist to Lead National Institutes of Health
description: After months of searching for a new director for the National Institutes of Health, President Bush has selected Elias Zerhouni, a radiologist and executive vice dean at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a front-page picture by Agence France-Presse in some copies on Tuesday with an article about the violence in the Middle East referred incorrectly to a covered body outside a nightspot in Tel Aviv where three Israelis died on Monday in a shooting. The picture showed an unidentified Israeli, not the Palestinian gunman.

title: City Agrees State Money Can Pay for Teacher Raises
description: New York City's long-stalled contract talks with its teachers' union made some progress yesterday when the Bloomberg administration said it would agree to use a $204 million infusion of state money to pay for raises.

title: Bidders Beware; Tips for Sizing Up The Invisible Seller
description: Some ways to avoid becoming a victim of auction fraud:

title: Review/Fashion; Lessons in Glamour From Donatella Versace
description: Strong collections by Angela Missoni and Donatella Versace closed the fall 2002 shows here, as each shrewdly sidestepped gimmicks and other stylish hokum to deliver fine female punch.

title: Old Masters Get the Spa Treatment; An Art Fair's Stars Need Some Rejuvenation -- but Not Too Much
description: Tucked away in obscure buildings from Manhattan to Maastricht, in the Netherlands, art restorers have spent the last six weeks quietly racing the clock in the annual art world ritual that begins in late January with the old master sales in New York and peaks today in Maastricht with the opening of the International Fine Art Fair.

title: Lost Body Of Writer Is Tracked To Hart I.
description: City officials said yesterday that they had found the missing body of the playwright Leonard Melfi at the potter's field on Hart Island. He was buried at the cemetery, which is used for the unidentified and the indigent, nearly two months after his death on Oct. 28 at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Melfi's family only recently learned of his death and had been searching for his remains for weeks.

title: Charity Shifting Emphasis Away From Cash Payments
description: In six months, the Sept. 11 Fund has distributed $205 million, 85 percent of that in direct cash payments to victims. But in a major shift yesterday, the fund's leaders said that they now intended to sharply curtail direct grants to victims.

title: News in Tampa
description: To the Editor:

title: CANON TO CLOSE OFFICES AND SHIFT PRODUCTION TO ASIA
description: Canon Inc. will shut its 14-year-old Mexican computer printer factory and an administrative office in Costa Mesa, Calif., and shift the production to Southeast Asia, where costs are cheaper. The company, Japan's largest maker of office-equipment, will close the Tijuana-based factory, which employs 417 people, in May; 33 people will be let go in the California office. The company hopes to reduce costs by more than 20 percent by moving its production of ink jet printer cartridges to Thailand and Vietnam. Canon said sales of printers and ink cartridges increased 0.2 percent in 2001. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A new report says ad spending in major media fell 9.8 percent last year, more than first thought.
description: ADVERTISING activity in major media fell even more than had been feared last year, according to a report released yesterday by a company that tracks ad spending by marketers.

title: Seeking Satisfaction; Once Bamboozled, Now a Bloodhound: On the Trail, Online
description: CONSIDER them a band of auction-fraud vigilantes.

title: Mismanagement Muddled Collapse Inquiry, House Panel Says
description: Members of Congress today criticized the investigation into the collapse of the World Trade Center, saying it had been mismanaged, far too slow to start and hampered by a lack of cooperation by New York City and other government agencies controlling the disaster site.

title: Stopping Hackers, While Doing Detective Work on the Side
description: Worrying about hackers and viruses is becoming a way of life for Windows users, but Macintosh owners should not assume they are immune to Internet ills. For them, Symantec has announced Version 2 of its Norton Personal Firewall for Macintosh ($69.95 or $39.95 for an upgrade). The program is also available ($99.95 or $69.95 for the upgrade) in the larger Norton Internet Security suite, which includes Norton Anti-Virus and Aladdin's iClean clutter-reducing software.

title: In Milan, Fur, Any Fur, Is a Budgeting Necessity
description: ''It's woven marten,'' Andr Leon Talley said, his large frame filling a doorway to the Versace show on Tuesday night. Mr. Talley, a Vogue editor at large, was referring to a tippet he was wearing as an accessory to a $3,500 chalk-striped bespoke suit from Huntsman, the English tailor; a $400 shirt with coordinated tie from Charvet in Paris; and a Tyrolean hat from Habig, whose hatband brush alone, of badger, cost $300 in 1988. Never let it be said that the occupationally fashionable are afraid to spend.

title: A Struggling Town, A Hesitant Hope; Memories Tinge a Business's Plan
description: One day in January, a Canadian entrepreneur appeared out of the northern blue and said that of all the places in North America, he had chosen this proud but wobbling little city as the future site of a new company in the suddenly sexy business of emergency preparedness.

title: Police Department May Hire An Expert in the Use of Force
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he was close to naming James J. Fyfe, a nationally recognized expert in the use of force by the police, to direct and possibly revamp the way the Police Department trains its officers.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Land Manager Quits
description: Martha Hahn resigned as director of the federal Bureau of Land Management's Idaho office, saying she preferred to stay in the state rather than accept a transfer to a National Park Service post overseeing operations in New York Harbor. Environmental groups said Ms. Hahn, who oversaw the bureau's 11.8 million acres in the state, had been forced out by Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, because he did not like her land protection policies. The senator's office denied that.

title: On Sunday, A License To Snoop
description: BY 1:40 last Sunday afternoon, the crowd outside the prewar co-op on West 83rd Street was growing restive. Twenty-one people -- a blonde with hair down to her waist, guys in leather jackets and a father with his baby in a backpack -- were waiting for the doors to open. All but the baby were clutching folded classified ads, with this item circled: ''Best 2BR Value, Elev., hi ceils, French doors, park block.'' And then the kicker: ''$399,000.''

title: Corrections
description: A Metropolitan Opera review yesterday misspelled the name of the French writer who was the librettist for ''L'Enfant et les Sortilges,'' by Ravel. She was Colette, not Collette.

title: Surround Sound Through Headphones
description: WITH DVD players and low-cost surround-sound systems, making a TV room sound like the flight deck of an aircraft carrier is within reach of many a videophile. But there's a downside to replaying, say, the D-Day offensive at home: an irate spouse and a screaming infant awakened by the incredible noise.

title: Metro Matters; The Doctor Will See You, For Now
description: A FEW months ago, Dr. Jennifer Breznay began to notice something different about some of her patients at the Montefiore medical office in the north Bronx. Some had health problems that they had long ignored. Or arrived with ailments that they used to take to the emergency room. Or had no ailments at all but had developed a sudden interest in preventive care.

title: All That's Missing Is the Disco Ball
description: IN 1962, Warren and Marguerite Blake built a summer house here and filled it with hundreds of stylish tokens, among them elegant drinking glasses with silvery rims and big ornate letter B's emblazoned on the side in silver script.

title: City to Use State Money To Raise Teachers' Pay
description: New York City's long-stalled contract talks with its teachers union made progress when the Bloomberg administration said it would use a $204 million infusion of state money to finance raises.

title: KMART GAINS PERMISSION TO DRAW UPON $2 BILLION LOAN
description: The Kmart Corporation won the permission of a federal bankruptcy judge to draw on a $2 billion bank loan, the biggest known for a company reorganizing under Chapter 11 protection from creditors. Judge Susan Pierson Sonderby, at a bankruptcy hearing in Chicago, approved Kmart's request to use the money to help pay its more than 250,000 workers and hundreds of suppliers while reorganizing.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Governor's Descendant Is Running
description: A great-grandson of a former governor is pursuing the Democratic nomination to challenge Gov. Dirk Kempthorne this year. The new candidate, Jerry Brady, 65, said he would step down as editor and publisher of The Post Register of Idaho Falls and retire as president and chairman of the company that owns the paper and a local television station. Mr. Brady, whose great-grandfather James H. Brady, a Republican, was governor from 1909 to 1911, is the first Democrat to announce his candidacy formally. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Bush Promises Minimum Wage In Welfare Jobs
description: Tommy G. Thompson, secretary of health and human services, said today that the Bush administration was committed to guaranteeing that welfare recipients received the minimum wage for the hours they worked.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Ex-Kremlin Aide Convicted
description: A Geneva judge has found a former Kremlin aide guilty of money laundering and ordered him to pay a $177,000 fine. Pavel Borodin, a former top aide to Boris N. Yeltsin, was accused of laundering millions of dollars in kickbacks from two Swiss companies that won remodeling contracts for Kremlin buildings.

title: A Work on a Critic's Collision, Cultural and Vehicular
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 6 -- Cubism, or at least a cube, has adopted the art critic Robert Hughes as a subject.

title: Threats to Be Shared With City and State
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that the director of homeland security, Tom Ridge, had called them to say that they would be apprised of all credible threats against New York in the future.

title: Here Comes the Bride, With All Her Significant Others
description: One man and one woman? Not necessarily, says Chris Collicott, a Brooklyn artist whose molded equal-opportunity wedding cake toppers ($20 each, in butterscotch-, cream- or chocolate-colored resin, above) are sold individually. Shoppers can mix and match gender, skin color and even number, as needed. They will be available exclusively at Zipper, a branch of a Los Angeles store that is to open on Smith Street in Carroll Gardens late this month. The two-level shop will offer plants and flowers, vintage toys, personal-care and spa products and barware, as well as an exclusive line of furniture designed by Steven Saden, who owns Zipper with Elizabeth Cashour.

title: House Republicans Try Again for Bill on Tax Cut for Business
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 -- With evidence growing by the day that the recession is over, Republican leaders in the House made a last-ditch effort today to enact tax cuts for businesses this year by tying them to increased unemployment benefits.

title: Bush Zigzags After Choice Loses in California Primary
description: When President Bush called Bill Simon Jr. this morning to congratulate him on winning the California Republican primary for governor, he only indirectly acknowledged that his preferred candidate, Richard J. Riordan, was overwhelmed in an upset on Tuesday that just weeks ago was inconceivable to the White House.

title: For Austria: A Tribute And Protest
description: RAIMUND ABRAHAM, the architect of the Austrian Cultural Forum, which opens next month, has compared the building's tilting zinc facade to the slicing blades of a guillotine. The imagery may be severe, but it serves Austria's ambition to shed its quaint Old World reputation -- land of marzipan sculptures and flouncy waltzes -- and update it with something unmistakably contemporary. Kenneth Frampton, the architectural historian, called the building, on East 52nd Street, ''the most significant modern piece of architecture to be realized in Manhattan since the Seagram Building and the Guggenheim Museum of 1959.''

title: Judge Denies Giuliani's Request for Joint Custody
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has been lauded worldwide for his stalwart leadership after the Sept. 11 attacks, but the judge handling the former mayor's divorce case suggested yesterday that he had been less laudable in his private life and that his years in office had hurt his relationship with his children.

title: You Listen, You Pay: Post-Napster Music Services
description: I MISS music singles, walking into a record store and seeing racks of 45's, and later cassette singles. I am a big fan of one-hit wonders, obscure artists, novelty tunes, soundtracks and other hard-to-find items, so having an array of singles, with B-sides, at my fingertips for $3 to $4 a pop would be heaven to me.

title: With Growth in Sight, Korea Plans Privatization for Banks
description: The South Korean government unveiled today a far-reaching plan to sell back to the private sector most of the controlling stakes in banks that it acquired at the climax of the 1997-98 economic crisis, when they were threatened with bankruptcy. It includes new measures and additional details about some that had previously been announced piecemeal.

title: Bush to Unveil Plan To Protect Investors
description: Responding to the Enron debacle, President Bush will unveil proposals today to protect investors better through faster and more complete disclosure of information, improved auditing rules and new requirements for executives, officials said.

title: This Night Goes to Marbury and Suns
description: When the buzzer sounded on the Nets' futility of a wasted fourth-quarter lead and wasted free-throw attempts to tie the game in the waning split-seconds, Stephon Marbury and the Phoenix Suns knew they had a vindicating 89-87 victory over Marbury's former team.

title: ANTHRAX
description: The cost of the anthrax cleanup at the Hart Senate Office Building has reached $23 million, $2 million shy of the ceiling approved last year by Environmental Protection Agency, officials said. The figures were released by Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the ranking Republican on the Finance Committee, who had questioned whether the agency had spent the money properly.

title: Peacocks Of Palmtops, In 3 Breeds
description: THERE must be something in human DNA that makes us want things that aren't good for us. As children, we want junk food. As teenagers, we worship the boy or girl who treats us like dirt. As adults, we buy sport utility vehicles.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Medicaid Bailout
description: In an effort to allow the state to begin paying its Medicaid bills again, the Legislature approved, and Gov. Ronnie Musgrove immediately signed, an unpopular package mandating cuts in payments to health care providers; a tripling, to $3, in the price of patients' drug co-payments; and an appropriation of $108 million from the state's tobacco-suit trust fund. The Mississippi Medicaid program was running a deficit of $158 million when it ran out of cash in February.

title: You Spill Your Coffee on It, You've Bought It
description: Along the Smith Street miracle half-mile, the prize for nonchalance goes to Sherwood Cafe/Robin des Bois. Fellows in ski hats smoke and eat amid antique French country tables and vintage chandeliers. Red tags identify items for sale. (Most of them are.) Bernard Decanali, a native of Marseille, is the owner, and he returns to France to replenish the stock. ''I am happiest in my truck, going around to small flea markets to find things for the shop,'' he said. Tables run $1,000 to $2,000; the croque-monsieur is $8.50. Sherwood Cafe/Robin des Bois is in Boerum Hill at 195 Smith Street; (718) 596-1609. Open Tuesday through Sunday, noon to midnight.

title: U.S. Official Backs War-Crime Tribunal
description: A week after casting doubt on the integrity of the war crimes tribunals, a senior American official said today that the Balkans tribunal should stay open until its most wanted men, the former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and the military commander Ratko Mladic, were brought to justice before it.

title: INSIDE
description: G.O.P. Loses Filibuster Vote

title: Voices Across the Mideast Chasm
description: To the Editor:

title: Engine Defects in a Few New Cadillacs
description: Cadillac acknowledged today that it had encountered engine failures on a small number of its new CTS sedans, whose success is critical to the renaissance of the venerable brand.

title: Video Game Pioneers
description: To the Editor:

title: Fall of Condit, Still Caught in the Shadow of Scandal, Comes as No Surprise
description: It was the day after election day, but no one at the downtown Starbucks was talking about it. The Modesto Bee, with a front page headline ''Condit Loses,'' was splayed on a cafe table, but patrons ignored it, preferring to talk about the dark and stormy day.

title: Last Moments Of Navy Man Still a Puzzle
description: The mystery surrounding the combat death of a Navy Seal deepened today as Pentagon officials said the commando's search-and-rescue beacon was activated by hand after he tumbled from a helicopter in Afghanistan.

title: Ted Koppel's Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Landscapes Under Siege
description: Interior Secretary Gale Norton has been moving briskly to open up more public lands for domestic oil and gas production, just as Vice President Dick Cheney's task force instructed her to do in last year's ''national energy strategy.'' Last weekend, however, Ms. Norton was told that she, or at least her underlings, had been proceeding in an irresponsible manner. The rebuke came from an unlikely source, her own administrative review board. Responding to appeals from environmental groups, as well as complaints from other federal agencies, the board halted a controversial oil exploration project in Utah's Dome Plateau authorized by the department's Bureau of Land Management. It also suggested that the bureau had ''capriciously'' ignored environmental reviews mandated by federal law.

title: New Encyclopedia
description: The sixth edition of The Official Encyclopedia of Bridge, the most comprehensive book about the game, has been published by the American Contract Bridge League. The editor in chief is Henry Francis, and the executive editor is Alan Truscott.

title: Respect for Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the filing of a preliminary report by investigators looking into ethics charges against Senator Robert G. Torricelli misspelled the given name of his spokeswoman, who expressed confidence that he would be cleared. She is Debra Deshong, not Deborah.

title: Voices Across the Mideast Chasm
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mixture of Modernism, Familiar and Unfamiliar
description: There is a theory that performers could break down resistance to new works by walking listeners through them, effectively providing a road map with sonic landmarks clearly marked. Leonard Bernstein showed that this can be an effective approach, and both Leonard Slatkin and Michael Tilson Thomas have long followed his example.

title: Star-Struck Classmates Welcome Hughes Back
description: Gold medal or no gold medal, the principal of Great Neck North High School wanted everything to be as normal as possible when Sarah Hughes, champion figure skater and high school junior, returned to class this morning.

title: Jets Pick Up Cowart To Replace Farrior
description: The Jets that were formed during the Bill Parcells era continued their transformation to the Terry Bradway-Herman Edwards regime yesterday when linebacker James Farrior, Parcells's first draft pick for the club, in 1997, was given a symbolic goodbye.

title: Big Board Is Approached About Amex
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had been asked to look at the books of the American Stock Exchange, whose owner is looking for a buyer.

title: Mayor Gets A Bigger Say On Rebuilding
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he was ceding to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg equal control of the agency created last fall to oversee the rebuilding of downtown Manhattan. And amid concern about the pace and control of the reconstruction effort, Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Pataki declared that they would ultimately be responsible for deciding what should happen with the World Trade Center site.

title: Going, Going, Gone
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Slide Show: Whitney Biennial 2002
Paid Notice: Deaths  COPELAND, JANE RASKIN
description: COPELAND-Jane Raskin. Beloved wife of David Copeland. Loving mother of Danielle Raskin and Amanda Copeland. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1895 Flatbush Avenue (at Avenue L), Brooklyn, Sunday, 12:30 PM.

title: 9-Hour Hostage Standoff Ends in Arrests
description: Almost from the moment four people set out to rob a Staples store here on Wednesday night, the police say, nothing seemed to go right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEARD, JOSEPHUS SIMMONS II.
description: BEARD-Josephus Simmons II. Former President of IBM World Trade Corporation Asia and United States Navy Lieutenant Commander, WW II and Korea. Died March 4th, 2002 in Jacksonville, FL. Former resident of Rye, NY, Atlanta, GA, and Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. Beloved husband of 59 years to Jean Otey Beard, loving father of James Beard of Little Rock, Ark, Blaine Trump of NYC, Josephus Beard of Atlanta, GA and Jean Barden of Stamford, CT, adored grandfather of Christopher Trump Retchin, Scott and Lelia Barden, Lauren and Ansley Beard, father-in-law to Robert Trump, Lannette Beard, Judy Hefner Beard and Robert Barden. Loved dearly by his family and friends he will be greatly missed by all. Memorial services will be held 2:00 PM Friday at Christ Episcopal Church, 400 San Juan Drive, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELFI, LEONARD
description: MELFI-Leonard. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the loss of our colleague Leonard Melfi. Mr. Melfi was an Active and dedicated member of the Guild. Our deepest sympathies to his family. John Weidman, President The Dramatists Guild of America

title: Spiritual America, From Ecstatic To Transcendent
description: YESTERDAY was the opening of the 2002 Whitney Biennial, the show that's supposed to take the pulse of contemporary American art and that almost always gets the art world's knickers in a twist. Score-settlers and list fetishists have fits. Last time around, a lot of people were just dismissive. American art is out of steam, the idea was, and here's the proof.

title: A Calm at the Epicenter of Legal Upheaval
description: UNITED STATES marshals, looking combat-ready in bulletproof vests and black knit watch caps, submachine guns slung over their shoulders, slouch warily behind barricades in front of the federal courthouse in Foley Square these post-9/11 days. But 25 floors up, all is calm in the chambers of John M. Walker Jr., chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Of Matthew Shepard
description: Christina Ricci, above, is among the large cast of actors who portray residents of a Wyoming town coming to grips with homophobia in ''The Laramie Project,'' tomorrow night on HBO.

title: Miami and Pitt Become Physical and Advance
description: Miami rode its resiliency and Pittsburgh banked on its depth yesterday to streak toward a Big East tournament semifinal encounter.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Medford: Four Die In Crash
description: Four people were killed and two were injured in a car accident last night, the police said. A Hyundai with five people in it, traveling west on Woodside Avenue, apparently crossed over into the path of an eastbound Nissan around 10:18 p.m., said Sergeant Thomas Blomberg of the Suffolk County Police Department. All five people were ejected from the Hyundai, and four of them died. One appeared to have been hit by a third car, which left the scene, Sgt. Blomberg said. The fifth person and the driver of the Nissan were hospitalized, he said.

title: WILLIAMS REPORTS A LOSS OF $1.24 BILLION
description: The Williams Companies, the No. 1 natural gas pipeline owner in the United States, reported a fourth-quarter loss of $1.24 billion that included charges from a former communications unit that may file for bankruptcy. The loss was $2.39 a share, compared with a loss of $48.3 million, or 11 cents, a year earlier. Results included a $1.31 billion charge, or $2.62 a share, for costs from Williams Communications, the unit it spun off, which ran up debt building a fiber optic network. Williams, which also said it sold its Kern River pipeline for $960 million to Berkshire Hathaway, had delayed its quarterly report for five weeks to review its costs from the communications spinoff.

title: Living So Large in the Life as a Bounty Hunter
description: In the new hip-hop shoot-'em-up buddy comedy, ''All About the Benjamins,'' Ice Cube plays a freelance bounty hunter named Bucum (pronounced ''book 'em''), who gets mixed up in some very violent, very lucrative and fairly confusing business involving stolen diamonds and a lost lottery ticket. Bucum is drawn into this mess by Reggie Wright (Mike Epps), a small-time con man with a knack for being in the wrong place at the wrong time and an absolute inability to keep his mouth shut.

title: Cleaning Up the Boardroom
description: The nadir of the Enron scandal so far may be the smarmy turn by its former C.E.O. Jeffrey Skilling before a Senate panel last month. Mr. Skilling repeatedly protested that he could not possibly have known his company was headed for the biggest bankruptcy in the nation's history because ''I'm not an accountant.'' Holding fast under tough questioning, he exhibited open contempt for the senators' assumption that, as the head of Enron, he should have had a basic understanding of the company's finances.

title: Invaded by the Species With the Machines
description: To the Editor:

title: Saks Reports Lower Profit
description: Fiscal fourth-quarter profit at Saks Inc. fell 2.4 percent, as the company, the operator of the Saks Fifth Avenue and Proffitt's chains, cut prices to get rid of merchandise and closed stores.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Coat, Backpack, Sweat: Close Call in Israeli Cafe
description: The tall, heavyset young man with a backpack who walked into the cafe today was wearing a denim jacket on a warm, sunny afternoon. He had his hands in his pockets and he was sweating profusely.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the resignation of Mike Parker, head of the Army Corps of Engineers, included an official incorrectly among those present at a House subcommittee hearing last week at which Mr. Parker testified about the corps' budget. Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., director of the Office of Management and Budget, did not attend.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Ignition Locks For D.W.I. Offenders
description: Gov. Gary E. Johnson signed a bill that will require installation of ignition locks for some repeat drunken drivers. The device, at a cost of $60 to $70 per month for the offender, requires the driver to blow into a tube connected to the ignition. If the driver's blood-alcohol level is over 0.02 percent, the car will not start. The bill-signing ceremony was attended by relatives of four Nebraskans who were killed by a suspected drunken driver in January, when the man drove the wrong way on a highway. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: A Harbinger of Spring And Future French Hits
description: Year after year, the popular late-winter series Rendez-Vous With French Cinema, which showcases the best of recent French film at the Walter Reade Theater, brings to New York the first encouraging signs of spring amid the bleak post-holiday wasteland of dumped Hollywood movies. It reminds us that yes, there's still an art cinema worth caring about. And yes, the odds are good that the series's best films will eventually find distributors and open in New York theaters during the coming months.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: A Third Of Crematory Bodies Identified
description: Of the 339 bodies found at Tri-State Crematory in Noble, 109 have been identified, the state medical examiner, Dr. Kris Sperry, said. Dr. Sperry said that well over 500 sets of cremated remains given to families by Tri-State had been examined, and that about 15 percent of those were adulterated or not human. Some families received cement dust instead of ashes and, in at least one case, what appeared to be potting soil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWLEY, EDWARD G.
description: BOWLEY-Edward G. On March 5, 2002. Grand nephew of first Queens Borough President, Fred Bowley. Electrical engineer, member of numerous choral societies, W.W. II veteran and ham operator for over 55 years. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Smith), loving father of Patricia, dear brother of Ruth Passenant, Virginia Schreider and Florence Egan. Reposing at Thomas M. Quinn & Sons Inc, 35-20 Broadway, Long Island City, NY. Visiting hours Friday 2-5 & 7-9. Funeral Mass 10;30 A.M. at Most Precious blood RC Church, Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DI SCIULLO, JOHN
description: DI SCIULLO-John. The Chairman, Vice Chairman, and Board of Directors of SanPaolo IMI SpA wish to extend their deepest sympathy for the loss of Mr. John Di Sciullo, a dear friend and a former Director of SanPaolo US Holding.

title: Residential Real Estate; Printing Plant Is Transformed to a Condo Building
description: For more than five years, a hulking building at 535 Dean Street in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, that once served as the printing plant for The Daily News stood vacant and menacing, a haven for vagrants, squatters and drug addicts.

title: 'Jaws V': A Shark Alert Along the French Riviera
description: Because ''Festival in Cannes,'' Henry Jaglom's satire of Hollywood wheeler-dealers foaming at the mouth with dealmaking fever, was filmed two years ago at the actual Cannes International Film Festival, its setting initially reinforces the authenticity of its insider's view of that annual shark convention on the French Riviera. The screenplay, much of which sounds improvised on the spot, crackles with abrasively authentic dealmaking jargon hurled by fast-talking hustlers dramatically swathed in black. Real-life stars, among them William Shatner and Faye Dunaway, are shown rubbing elbows with the fictional characters.

title: If Jobs Are Gone for Good, What Good Are Benefits?
description: For 13 years, Amy Altman worked at the JPS Apparel Fabrics plant here, and wound up earning $9.50 an hour. With production grinding toward a halt early last year, she began working one week on and one off, and on the off weeks she collected a $224 unemployment check. When the plant closed on Aug. 1, letting 346 workers go, the checks continued.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Slow Growth In Sporting Goods
description: Adidas-Salomon A.G., the world's second-largest maker of sporting goods, said net income growth this year would slow from 2001 as it increased marketing spending because of the World Cup soccer tournament. Earnings this year will rise no more than 10 percent, the chief executive, Herbert Hainer, said at a news conference, less than the 15 percent long-term target the company gave in 2000. Global sales are expected to rise about 5 percent this year, the company said.

title: New Emotion Enters This Year's St. Patrick's Day Parade
description: There have been so many St. Patrick's Day parades in Manhattan -- 240 in fact -- that in the city's collective memory they tend to blur into one long march of roaring throngs, internal squabbles and bagpipe renditions of ''The Minstrel Boy.'' The 241st, though, will stand apart.

title: Notes From Fayetteville; North Carolina Under Friendly Fire
description: At a quiet rural crossroads 25 miles northwest of the Army's Fort Bragg, a local lawman shot two soldiers on a Special Forces training exercise two weeks ago Saturday, killing one. The deputy feared for his life when the soldiers -- dressed in flannel shirts and jeans and failing to identify themselves -- grabbed for an automatic rifle in their bag. The soldiers wrongly assumed that the sheriff was in Pineland with them, Pineland being the imaginary country where these exercises have taken place over the last 50 years.

title: Even Cars Need to Make a Good First Impression
description: LIKE young women presented at a debutante ball, a car needs a proper introduction. Even if a new model has an impeccable pedigree and wears the latest style, it can falter in the marketplace if its manufacturer bungles what is known in the auto industry as ''the launch'' -- the crucial period when cars start moving from factory to showroom to street.

title: President Is Leaving At DDB Worldwide
description: Jake Schroepfer, president and chief executive at the Dallas office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that he would resign to become president and chief executive at Electronic Billboard Technology in Austin, Tex., a division of SI Diamond Technology.

title: Imperial Tobacco Will Control German Company
description: The Imperial Tobacco Group agreed today to buy control of Reemtsma Cigarettenfabriken of Germany for 5.22 billion euros ($4.58 billion), a deal that will give Imperial a larger presence in the lucrative markets of Eastern Europe and Asia.

title: Caroline McCarthy
description: Parker's Box

title: Reflections From the Town of the Crime
description: The case of Matthew Shepard had become a morality play as much as a news event even as it was unfolding. The brutal murder of this gay 21-year-old college student in 1998 in Laramie, Wyo., became a flashpoint for gay activists and a highly publicized moment of sorrow and soul-searching for Laramie's citizens.

title: DEUTSCHE BANK BUYS U.S. REALTY FIRM FOR $490 MILLION
description: Deutsche Bank, Europe's largest lender, has agreed to buy the real estate investment manager Rreef for $490 million, almost doubling its property holdings. With the acquisition, Deutsche Bank will gain $16.2 billion of assets in the United States, the chief executive, Rolf Breuer, said. Deutsche Bank is buying Rreef from Rodamco North America, Haslemere, Rodamco Europe and Robeco Groep. Rreef, founded in 1975 and based in Chicago, is an acronym for the name of the company's founder, Claude Rosenberg, and the words ''real estate equity funds.''

title: 'Miss Wonton'
description: Directed by Meng Ong

title: In Futuristic New York Are Pods Rent-Controlled?
description: Each movie generation gets its own takeoffs on H. G. Wells's science-fiction classic ''The Time Machine.'' Nicholas Meyer used a screen version of Wells as the hero of his inventive 1979 film ''Time After Time,'' and 80's filmgoers got two, ''Back to the Future'' and ''The Terminator.'' Video stores stocking these films will probably have a rush of new customers looking to get the taste of the stolid new adaptation of ''The Time Machine'' out of their mouths. This uninviting and pallid version, starring Guy Pearce, is intent on grinding all the sharp edges off the original story, in effect making the movie childproof, so no one can get hurt touching it.

title: Zimbabwe President's Rival Vows to Prevail at the Polls
description: Behind the concrete walls topped with barbed wire, beyond the metal gate and the bodyguards with watchful eyes, Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition presidential candidate, was talking into his silver cellphone about trying to avoid assassination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBOW, SOL B.
description: LUBOW-Sol B., Bronx, NY, passed away on March 7, 2002. Mr. Lubow is a retired NYC educator. He taught at Stuyvesant H.S. in NYC and Columbus H.S. in the Bronx. He held the position of principal at P.S. 168 Manhattan and P.S. 105 Bronx. He is survived by his sisterin-law, Mildred Lubow; beloved niece, Susan Chorman, and her husband, Jeffrey, and his grandnieces and nephews. He was also a dear friend of Mary T. O'Malley. He was predeceased by his brothers, Irving & Benjamin, and sister, Gus, and a niece, Barbara Leinwand, and a cousin, Carl Erdberg. Services will be held graveside at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY, on Sunday, March 10, 12 Noon.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Antibiotics Found to Have Helped Limit Anthrax Infections
description: The widespread use of antibiotics in response to the October bioterrorist attacks spared at least nine people from being infected with inhalation anthrax, the deadliest form of the disease, according to a study released today.

title: Shakespeare's Game, Without a Score Card
description: Pick one. ''Cymbeline'' is a comedy in which a character is beheaded. It's a tragedy with a happy ending. It's a history that has elements of time travel. It's a romance in which the lovers are tiresome, and a story that celebrates family togetherness in which a mother and son are killed off.

title: Sparks Forward Suspended

Aronson; also the children of her late husband, Richard Lewisohn III, Aileen L. Godsick, Clifford H. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, NYC. Service Friday, March 8, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell.

description: Major League Baseball yesterday acknowledged an executive development that had been known for weeks, if not months. Paul Beeston has resigned as baseball's president and chief operating officer. Robert DuPuy, who had been executive vice president for administration, will replace him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SYLVIA JOSEPHS
description: BERGER-Sylvia Josephs. In her 100th year. Died on March 2, 2002. A woman of extraordinary intelligence and taste; character and grace. Fiercely independent in mind and action. Her midwestern roots were evident in her sense of fairness and ethics. Born and raised in Duluth, MN she graduated from Smith College in 1924 (was the only one to return and participate in her 75th reunion). Attended the Sorbonne, received a law degree from New York University in the late 1920's. She was a pro bono lawyer for 20 years at the Juvenile Court in the Bronx. A seasoned traveller before World War II. She could read Greek, Latin and French; studied Russian language and Russian literature at Hunter College until she was 96. Attended art classes at the Metropolitan Museum and went to the Philharmonic until late last fall. Married to Arthur M. Berger for over 53 years. He predeceased her, as did a brother Irving and son-in-law Daniel Cowin. Survived by daughter Joyce Cowin, three grandchildren Kenneth (Jasmin), Andrew (Allyson), Dana (Barclay Palmer), three great-grandchildren Reagan and Alexandra Cowin, Sylvie Palmer. As well as a sister Muriel Cowan and brother Arthur Josephs (Adrianne) from Duluth, MN. Interment private. A celebration of her life will be held at her daughter's, April 3rd, 4-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Russian Department at Hunter College or the Jewish Studies Program at Smith College.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Interest Rates Are Steady
description: The European Central Bank and the Bank of England left interest rates unchanged amid signs of an economic rebound. The European Central Bank, which sets rates for the dozen countries using the euro, left its benchmark rate at 3.25 percent. The Bank of England kept its main lending rate at 4 percent. The central banks of Europe and Britain along with the United States Federal Reserve have signaled that they are done lowering borrowing costs as global economies show signs of recovery. Central bankers now want to gauge the resilience of the recovery before nudging rates higher, analysts said. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The Next Takeovers May Not Be Easy
description: Advertising agencies have spent the last decade acquiring rivals in their quest to be big enough to serve their clients' every need, whether in the creative or media or public relations realms. The Publicis Groupe's acquisition of the Bcom3 Group is simply another step in that cycle, and it raises the question, who is next?

title: Scientists Discover a Dinosaur Clad in Flightless Feathers
description: Chinese and American paleontologists have found fossils of a feathered, flightless dinosaur, slightly bigger than a pheasant, that they say should settle once and for all that feathers originated before birds or flight.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I miss my sons, but there was nothing to eat.''

description: GINSTLING-Myrna. On March 5, 2002. Beloved wife of Norman, devoted & loving mother of Gary, Nancy, and Jill, and adoring grandmother of Emily and Joel. She touched the lives of everyone she met, she brought us laughter and hope, and she will be dearly missed. Her family wishes that contributions be made to the Revlon/UCLA Women's Cancer Research Program, 10833 Le Conte Avenue, 11-259 Factor, Los Angeles, CA. 90024-1678.

description: A 15-year-old girl on her way to school was raped twice yesterday morning in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Protesters Oppose Bison Plan
description: Five people have been arrested for protesting a government plan that allows for the capture of any bison that leaves the boundaries of Yellowstone National Park, and its destruction if it tests positive for the contagious disease brucellosis. On Monday, four women locked themselves together in a state livestock office and on Wednesday a man chained himself to a gate where the bison are handled just outside Yellowstone. State officials said that of ''a few thousand'' bison returned to the park in the past five years, about 130 had tested positive for brucellosis and been killed. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Sees Sales Gain
description: Sun Microsystems reiterated forecasts that its third-quarter revenue would rise slightly from last quarter's $3.11 billion. Michael E. Lehman, chief financial officer, said Sun expected to have a profit, before some costs, in the fourth quarter. Sun, which has lost money for three consecutive periods, did not comment on profit in the current quarter, which ends this month.

title: A Preference For Mingling Old and New
description: Axel Vervoordt is not like most antiques dealers. First, he sells many of his wares by appointment out of Kasteel van 's-Gravenwezel, a 14th-century castle outside of Antwerp, Belgium. Second, he sells contemporary art along with ancient artifacts and antiques. And he has a staff of nearly 100 who scour the world for antiques, do restoration work on art and antiques and make upholstered pieces for the interiors he designs.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: A Warning From China
description: With Japan debating whether to salvage a ship that it sank in a gun battle in Chinese waters, China has warned that it not ''take any action that will continue the escalation or complicate the situation.'' Japanese newspapers reported last week that American spy satellite photos showed a ship similar to the presumed North Korean ship docked at a Chinese naval site south of Shanghai days before the sinking on Dec. 22. China's foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, said on Wednesday that ''on many occasions'' China ''expressed our strong dissatisfaction over Japan's indiscreet use of force in China's exclusive economic zone, which caused the sinking of that boat.'' James Brooke (NYT)

description: Mariah Carey, the pop diva who was paid $28 million to walk away from her contract with the EMI Group's Virgin Records six weeks ago, is in advanced negotiations with other labels about a deal and could make a decision as early as next week, people close to those talks said today.

title: The Collections / Paris : Dior's magpie magnificence
description: PARIS  With skirts whirling, fur from Mohican boots flying and colors vibrating along with the 1980s dance music, John Galliano finally got Dior products out on the runway. His joyous show brought pep and energy to the opening day of the Paris autumn/winter 2002 shows Thursday and proved why Dior's latest figures are as hot as its designer's clothes.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Panel Approves 'Kids' Domain
description: A House panel on telecommunications and the Internet approved legislation to create a kids.us domain for Web sites that would be free of pornographic images and other material considered inappropriate for children. The domain would limit exposure to such material through voluntary participation. NeuStar Inc., which holds the contract to manage .us Web domain names, would set the standards and determine content for the kids.us sites, officials said. The measure has broad support among lawmakers, although the idea of regulating Internet content and enforcing the rules for such a domain led to some debate about restricting free speech. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, which governs domain names, has been reluctant to create a .kids suffix.

description: Guenter Hensler, a record business executive who worked with classical and popular music but was best known for restructuring the American classical divisions of Polygram in the 1980's and Bertelsmann in the 1990's, died on Sunday at a hospital in Friedrichshafen, Germany.
