description: All-Mozart piano programs can look better than they sound. They begin with a composer whose perfect grace can be taken for granted. Yet experienced as a group, the piano sonatas have a way of gliding: like genius on automatic pilot, chirpy and untroubled to the point of annoyance.

title: WNYC-FM to Cut Back Classical Music
description: The radio station WNYC-FM announced yesterday major changes to its programming that would eliminate five hours of classical music from its daytime schedule and replace them with news and varied cultural shows.

description: Dan Blackburn, the 18-year-old rookie, started in goal for the second consecutive time tonight, the first time he has done that in the N.H.L. He played well, but his listless teammates were outskated and outclassed by the Chicago Blackhawks, losing by 5-1.

title: HEALTHPARTNERS EXECUTIVE TO LEAD KAISER PERMANENTE
description: Kaiser Permanente, the country's largest nonprofit managed care health plan, appointed George C. Halvorson to succeed David M. Lawrence, 61, as chairman and chief executive yesterday, effective May 1. Mr. Halvorson, 55, a former journalist, has led HealthPartners, a big Minnesota-based insurer, since 1992. Both Kaiser, which has 8.3 million subscribers in nine states, and HealthPartners, with 670,000, are integrated nonprofit health maintenance organizations with their own hospitals, clinics and associated medical staffs. HealthPartners said Mary K. Brainerd, its executive vice president, would succeed Mr. Halvorson as chief executive. Milt Freudenheim (NYT)

title: EXIDE, A BATTERY MAKER, PLANS TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS
description: Exide Technologies, which makes automobile batteries, said yesterday that it would close two plastics plants and lay off more than 200 workers. The company, based in Princeton, N.J., said two plants in Mississippi, one in Jackson and one in Vicksburg, would close by May 10. Battery cover and battery case manufacturing will be moved to a plant in Lampeter, Pa., the company said. Earnings have suffered as sales to the automotive industry have declined.

title: Testing His Metal
description: Just a few days ago, some supporters of George W. Bush hoped that he would show his mettle by standing up to steel industry demands for tariff protection. Instead he capitulated, with a cravenness that surprised even his critics.

title: Brazil's Coalition Loses a Key Partner Over a Police Raid
description: After more than seven years, Brazil's four-party governing coalition collapsed in a storm of rancor and accusations today with the pullout of the country's second most powerful political force, the right-of-center Liberal Front Party.

Schwab II, Chairman

description: Gov. James E. McGreevey appointed the president of Amtrak as executive director of New Jersey Transit yesterday, saying his immediate goal would be to resolve the problem of overcrowded commuter trains in the nation's third-largest public transit agency.

description: WORLDTEX, Hickory, N.C., the largest maker of elastic yarn for apparel, said it had emerged from bankruptcy protection and eliminated $185 million in senior debt. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: DVD Service Plans Stock Offering
description: At a time when high-technology stock offerings remain a rarity, the online DVD rental service Netflix Inc. said yesterday that it had filed to sell as much as $115 million worth of stock to the public. The filing comes on the heels of last month's offering by PayPal, whose stock was greeted enthusiastically and continues to trade above its offering price of $13 a share. Based in Los Gatos, Calif., Netflix has attracted 500,000 customers for a $20-a-month service. Customers can select from a library of more than 11,500 films, selecting as many as three movies at a time and keeping them for as long as they want with no late fees, a crucial feature in the service's rising popularity. In 2001, Netflix reported a loss of $38.2 million on revenue of $76 million. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Omnicom Completes OMD Consolidation
description: The Omnicom Group in New York is completing the consolidation of media assignments formerly handled by its ad agencies at OMD, a worldwide media-only agency that is meant to compete against similar divisions of the Interpublic Group of Companies and the WPP Group.

title: More Graduates Mired in Debt, Survey Finds
description: Two out of 3 students must now borrow money to attend college, and 4 out of 10 face unmanageable debts as they finish college and enter the job market, according to a report released today.

title: White House Supports Official Who Kept Stock Options Till This Year
description: The White House declared its support today for the secretary of the Army, Thomas E. White, after the disclosure that Mr. White had retained a significant interest in Enron from his days as a senior executive there until early this year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Life-After-Death Bid Goes To Court
description: A legal battle over whether the frozen bodies of a wealthy French couple can be kept indefinitely in a special chamber built in their chateau is to go before a French court today. The case was brought by local authorities in Saumur who argue that the continued refrigeration of Raymond Martinot, who died last month, and his wife, who died in 1984, does not constitute a proper burial. But lawyers for the Martinots -- who hoped to be revived in the distant future -- will argue that it is not illegal.

description: President Jacques Chirac has had a bad week in his campaign for re-election.

title: China's Lost World Of Art
description: ''Treasures From a Lost Civilization: Ancient Chinese Art From Sichuan,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, displays objects recently excavated in this southwestern province. They include a late-Shang-period bronze figure on a pedestal, right, almost nine feet high, from around 1200 B.C. The show illustrates how archaeology revealed a 3,000-year-old lost civilization, changing how Chinese art history is understood.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Turn To The Right In Local Vote
description: A right-wing party with a strong anti-immigration platform did unexpectedly well in municipal elections, which are seen as an indicator for the general election to be held in May. The Liveable Netherlands Party led with 30 percent of the vote in Rotterdam, the country's second largest city, where almost half the population is not of Dutch origin. With the national turnout low -- little more than half the eligible voters took part -- the governing coalition of left and centrist parties lost close to 12 percent of their regional seats.

title: A Primary Idea: Wait Three Months
description: To the Editor:

title: Marlins' Young Pitchers Reach for the Stars
description: This is a confusing place. Situated on the east coast of the state, not far from where they fire astronauts into orbit on telescope-fixing assignments, this town is home to a baseball team for spring training. The team is the Florida Marlins, but not with the same owner and staff they had last year. And they won't be here much longer.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Pension Head Resigns
description: The director of the state's $7.4 billion Teacher Retirement System, William Shirron, resigned effective Thursday, one day before the pension fund's trustees were to review his job performance. The system has been involved in several controversial investments in the last several years, including more than $30 million in Enron. A prosecutor is investigating whether Mr. Shirron violated state law by amending the minutes of a meeting of the trustees without their authorization.

title: Harsh Light Is Shed on Way City Treats Abused Mothers
description: In stinging words and detailed accounts of 10 cases, a federal court opinion has concluded that the city routinely violates the constitutional rights of battered mothers and their children by separating them unnecessarily.

title: Charles Wagner, 89, Maker Of Wines on Caymus Label

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHALEN, THOMAS M. III.
description: WHALEN-Thomas M. III. Former Mayor of the City of Albany, died suddenly on March 4. Husband of Denis; father of Laura, Thomas, Mark, Matthew, Jonathan; brother of Mary Pat Devane, Carolyn Gaynor, Dr. Michael Whalen; stepson of Ruth Whalen. Funeral services Saturday at 9 A.M. at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, Albany. Visitation at the McVeigh Funeral Home, 208 N. Allen St., Albany, Friday from 28 P.M. Memorial contributions may be sent to St. Mary's Church, 10 Lodge Street, Albany, 12207, or Albany Law School, 80 New Scotland Avenue, Albany, 12208.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Falun Gong Presses Its Case
description: Seven foreigners believed to be Australians were detained on Tiananmen Square yesterday when they tried to protest the persecution of the Falun Gong spiritual movement during the annual session of the National People's Congress. The detentions came two days after supporters of the outlawed movement in the northeastern city of Changchun broadcast a pro-Falun Gong videotape on a state cable television channel, breaking into regular evening programming for 50 minutes. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Kidd Is Fined for a Gesture
description: Jason Kidd was fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association today for making an obscene gesture toward fans after Wednesday night's 89-87 loss to the Suns in Phoenix.

title: A Little Russia On the Hudson
description: For the full impact of a certain Russian experience, nothing quite beats ''War and Peace.'' The book is long, and so is the opera. It has falling snow and ballroom dancing, soul-searching and vodka bingeing, honor and dishonor, not to mention the main themes, which are, of course, war and peace. (''Some subject, eh?'' as an American tourist said upon exiting the Leo Tolstoy Museum in Moscow.)

title: What a Difference a Week Makes
description: In just over a week, in Alan Greenspan's view, the economic recovery has gone from a maybe to a certainty. ''Recent evidence increasingly suggests that an economic expansion is already well under way,'' Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee yesterday. On Feb. 27, he had been only guardedly optimistic in his testimony, saying that he expected the economy would soon emerge from the downturn that began last year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Pompey: Two Firefighters Killed
description: Two firefighters died last night after they were trapped in a burning rural house that then collapsed. Another firefighter was hospitalized with burns that were not considered life threatening, the authorities said. The fire, in a basement and attached garage, was reported at 7:20 p.m. on Sweet Road in Pompey, which is 20 miles east of Syracuse. ''We believe there may have been a floor collapse or a hole in the floor,'' said Peter Alberti, director of emergency management for Onongaga County. ''There was a further collapse later of some of the structure.'' The cause was under investigation. The names of the dead firefighters, who belonged to the Manlius Fire Department, were not released early this morning. They were found in the basement. The fire company includes both paid and volunteer members. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 8 about Turks' concerns that an Islamic political movement could undercut their long commitment to a secular government misstated the century in which the religion arrived. Islam began to spread in the 11th century in what is now Turkey -- not in 1453, when the Ottoman sultans conquered the area. A reader reported the error in January; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Pressure Increases on Cablevision to Carry YES
description: If a feud between Cablevision and the YES Network, the Yankees' new television channel, is not resolved, three million households will not be able to watch Yankees games on local cable when the season starts on April 1.

title: LIMITED RAISES OFFER FOR REMAINDER OF INTIMATE BRANDS
description: Limited Inc. raised its offer yesterday to buy the remaining 16 percent of Intimate Brands, the parent of Victoria's Secret, it does not already own. Limited increased the exchange offer to 1.10 common shares for each outstanding Class A common share of Intimate Brands, from 1.046 shares. Limited did not say why it raised the offer. Limited's $1.56 billion offer would give it full control of Intimate Brands, which last year accounted for about 90 percent of its operating income. Limited owns apparel chains like Limited, Express and Lerner New York. It retained 84 percent of Intimate Brands after it sold 16 percent to the public in 1995 for $680 million, or $17 a share.

description: Howard R. Young, a director and former partner at Goldman, Sachs, died on Feb. 21 at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 83.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Smaller Loss On Enron
description: The state trash authority lost close to $213 million, not $220 million as previously estimated, in its failed deal with the Enron Corporation, according to Attorney General Richard Blumenthal. Last year, the agency, the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority, agreed to pay Enron the $220 million in a transaction that required Enron to pay the agency $2.4 million a month for 11 years. The payments were to have started in April but appear to have started only in July, Mr. Blumenthal said. Because federal bankruptcy law required Enron's creditors to temporarily give back payments for the three months prior to its declared insolvency, the agency would have received payments from July through September, reducing its loss to roughly $213 million.

description: In tough budget times, New Jersey lawmakers can be an awfully tough audience.

title: TV Ads Spur a Rise in Prescription Drug Sales
description: Television advertising, aging baby boomers and the greater use of expensive new medications drove prescription drug sales up 17.9 percent last year, a study shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARO, DR. HERMAN
description: CARO-Dr. Herman. Beloved husband of Kate, dearest brother of Helen Dreifus and Ludwig Caro. Shiva through Tuesday at 583 Cedar Hill Rd, Far Rockaway, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, RUSSELL
description: THOMAS-Russell, 72. Of NYC, on March 3, at Lenox Hill Hospital. Brother of Joan Thomas Terrall of Altadena, CA, and Edward C.P. Thomas of Bedford, MA. Memorial service Saturday, March 16, at 2:30 PM, Church of the Ascension, 12 West 11th St., NYC. Interment in Vermont at a later date.

title: Invaded by the Species With the Machines
description: To the Editor:

title: New York's $20 Billion
description: Yesterday, in a startling love fest with some normally cantankerous New Yorkers, President Bush delivered completely on his pledge of $20 billion to help the city rebuild -- and then improved upon it. Altogether the package of financial aid and tax credits does more than provide much-needed help to reconstruct Lower Manhattan. It represents a gesture of confidence in, and solidarity with, the entire New York region.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about competing bids from two brothers who own investment firms for Global Crossing, the communications company that filed for bankruptcy protection in January, misstated one firm's strategy. The Gores Technology Group, run by Alec Gores, still controls most of the companies it has acquired. It does not ordinarily sell them soon after making them more efficient.

title: Tariffs May Temper a Glut of Steel
description: In the world of trade policy, no good deed goes unpunished. The Bush administration made the right call in imposing tariffs of up to 30 percent on selected steel imports from major exporting countries. The expression of support from industry, labor and Congress has been exceeded in volume by the howls of protest from our trading partners. Even so, this action was necessary for reasons beyond the immediate plight of the American steel industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYRAS, DENIS H., M.D.
description: TYRAS-Denis H., M.D. The Board, Administration, and staff of Saint Vincent Catholic Medical Centers-St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, mourn the tragic death of Denis H. Tyras, M.D. Chief Emeritus of Cardiothoracic Surgery at St. Vincent's Manhattan. A widely respected and renowned surgeon, Dr. Tyras served on the medical staff of St. Vincent's Manhattan for more than 11 years and as Professor of Surgery at New York Medical College. As a deeply respected colleague, mentor and friend, the St. Vincent's community extends to his wife Linda, his two children, Jonathan and Jocelyn, grandchildren and the entire Tyras family, our prayers and deepest condolences. Jane Connorton, President St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan

title: Token Booths Closing? Riders To Get Their Say
description: A state appeals court yesterday upheld a lower court's decision that New York City Transit must conduct public hearings before it can close token booths or reduce hours at 53 subway stations.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Shows Must, And Did, Go On

title: Children as Barter in a Famished Land
description: Haunted by want, depleted from hunger, Akhtar Muhammad first sold off his few farm animals and then, as the months passed, bartered away the family's threadbare rugs and its metal cooking utensils and even some of the wooden beams that held up the hard-packed roof of his overcrowded hovel.

title: Laura Letinsky -- 'Morning and Melancholia'
description: Edwynn Houk Gallery

title: Jets Add Steve White As Retooling Continues
description: The deal-a-day Jets were at it again yesterday, signing Steve White, a free agent defensive end from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, who became the fourth player the team has added this week in its relentless overhaul of its defense.

title: Sports of The Times; For Jarvis, A Number With Magic
description: TWENTY. The number makes such a powerful statement, like the grizzled face of Andrew Jackson on the $20 bill or the passage of no longer being a teenager. Pitchers who win 20 games in one season are celebrated in baseball, but pitchers who win 19 know they somehow fell short.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Spending On Homeless
description: New York City spent $956 million on homeless services and related construction last year, the city's Independent Budget Office reported. A figure for 2000 was not immediately available, Douglas Turetsky, a spokesman for the office, said yesterday because this was the first time the office had collected data from seven city agencies and more than 120 contracts under one heading. The largest parts of homeless spending were $493 million on emergency shelter and services; $127.5 million on homeless prevention programs; and $121.6 million on permanent housing for the homeless.

title: Kabul Rushes 1,000 More Men To Join G.I.'s in Battle's 6th Day
description: B-52 bombers loosed a furious air attack today on the well-fortified positions of tenacious Taliban and Qaeda fighters as the Afghan government sent 1,000 reinforcements to the American-led effort in the craggy, frigid peaks near the eastern border.

title: Like Italy, Only Not Far Away
description: The Italians invented hanging out. The design of their towns and cities draws people together. Once, outside a train station in a small Italian town, I observed this scene: There was one customer in the outdoor cafe. A second arrived, scanned the dozen or so tables, then sat at a table next to the one already occupied. That probably would not have happened in the United States, except in places like Carmine Street in Greenwich Village, where the old traditions still live, even as they morph into more modern form.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Senate Passes Bullying Measure
description: The State Senate passed an anti-bullying bill that would force school districts to develop and enforce rules to deal with harassment and intimidation by students. A similar bill passed the House last month, and Gov. Gary Locke has expressed his support. If signed into law, the bill would make Washington the eighth state to adopt protections against bullying based on race, sexual orientation and other factors. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Mideast Death Toll Spirals
description: Israeli forces killed nine Palestinians, including a major general, and wounded 35 in southern Gaza. Five Israelis settlers were killed and more than 20 wounded. Page A8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGUINALDO, DR. JOSE
description: AGUINALDO-Dr. Jose. March 5, 2002. Beloved son of Mercedes Aguinaldo. Long time partner of Edward Jones. Devoted brother of Val, Chato, Tony, Lery, Chad and Tante. He will be deeply missed by his many loving family members and friends. He graduated from Santo Tomas School of Medicine in Manila, trained as a pediatrician in New York City. He was a member of the American Academy of Pediatrics, currently on the staff of Gouverneur Hospital, New York City. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday and Friday 3-5 & 79pm. Service Saturday, March 9, 11AM, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112 St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Setbacks For Satellite Services
description: Investors in the satellite industry got bad news on two fronts yesterday. Orbital Sciences, based in Dulles, Va., said it expected its auditor to attach a note to its 2001 results questioning its ability to avoid bankruptcy. Orbital said it must refinance $100 million in debt due in October and show that it can start generating more cash than it is using to meet the concerns of its auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers. It said sales rose more than 80 percent in the fourth quarter, to $121 million, but that it lost $31.7 million, or 80 cents a share. Orbital's shares fell $1.12, or 14.1 percent, to $6.80. Separately, Lockheed Martin said in a regulatory filing that its contract to build four satellites for Astrolink International L.L.C. had been canceled. Lockheed owns 31 percent of Astrolink, which was created in 1999 to offer a satellite-based broadband service. The filing said Astrolink did not have enough money to build and launch its four-satellite network. Astrolink had aimed to begin service next year. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Two Against Mob Rule Who Can Turn Up the Heat
description: When the Devil comes to call, it sure helps if you have star power on your side. Playing a husband and wife under moral siege during the Salem witch trials, Liam Neeson and Laura Linney bring a transfixing heat to Richard Eyre's otherwise merely sweaty revival of ''The Crucible,'' which opened last night at the Virginia Theater.

title: World Briefing | World: Unions Hope To Recruit Women
description: The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced a three-year campaign aimed at doubling to 128 million the number of women belonging to unions worldwide. (There are 93 million men in unions.) The confederation, based in Brussels, said it would urge labor federations around the world to focus on the issue of women's right to decent work. Nancy Riche, chairwoman of the confederation's women's committee, said unions needed to change the perception that they were not doing enough to meet women's needs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNOR, NORMA L.
description: TANNOR-Norma L. Beloved wife of Solomon. Loving mother of Merrill, Robert and Erica, and Evan and Ilene. Cherished grandmother of Amanda, Samantha, Bradley, Jaymie and Cole. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 11:30 AM, Friday.

title: Yale Holds Off Tigers And Holds On to Dream
description: The game was 10 seconds old, and Princeton was on just the second of the weave of passes it would run, when the chant came cascading through the Palestra. The Yale fans who made the three-hour trip from New Haven and held the implausible belief that their Bulldogs could somehow find themselves in the N.C.A.A. tournament were the first to signal that this would not be a night for old-fashioned ball in the old-fashioned gymnasium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMER, ELEANOR
description: ZIMMER-Eleanor. On March 6, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Paula and Daniel Reingold, and Mindy Singer. Adored grandmother of Jessica, Lisa, Brett, Corey and Ryan. Services Friday, 10 AM at ''Gutterman's Inc'', Rockville Centre, LI. Donations may be made in her memory to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 1 Penn Plaza, Suite 1610, NY, NY.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Tax On Plastic Shopping Bags
description: A 13-cent tax on plastic shopping bags went into effect this week, to be paid by shoppers and contributed to a government fund for environmental causes and waste management. The government hopes the tax will prevent discarded bags from polluting waterways and littering the countryside, where they are a common sight fluttering in trees and hedges. Irish shoppers use more than 1.2 billion of the bags annually, enough for one bag per person per day. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: In Transition, Bloomberg Team Kept On Spending
description: Even after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's record-setting $72 million campaign ended and he was sworn into office, he continued to spend more than half a million dollars on inaugural and transition expenses, according to finance reports filed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, WALTER
description: GOODMAN-Walter. The Board of Trustees and staff of Thirteen/ WNET New York mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Walter Goodman, and wish to express our deepest condolences to his family. His illuminating presence in American journalism will be sorely missed, but his vision will continue to inspire us all. Steven R. Rattner Chairman William F. Baker President

title: A New World of Ancient Culture, Recorded in Bronze
description: Some Bronze Ages are better than others, but the one that flourished in China beginning sometime in the fourth or third millennium B.C. was arguably the greatest of the ancient world. It may actually have been two Bronze Ages: a garden-variety Bronze Age followed fairly rapidly, as ancient time goes, by what could be called a golden age of bronze. Its excellence is exemplified by the cast-bronze ritual vessels of the Shang (1600-1046 B.C.) and Zhou (1046-221 B.C.) dynasties.

title: Islanders Come Unglued To Another Soft Opponent
description: The Islanders, a team that has blown raspberries at the N.H.L.'s elite and kills penalties as if they are on the power play, had been given a terrific chance to fatten their point total in a seven-game stretch against losing teams. But they are squandering the opportunity.

title: Andersen Told It May Face Charges Soon
description: The government has warned Arthur Andersen that obstruction of justice charges in the Enron investigation could be made public against it in as little as a week, and the firm is working with prosecutors to determine whether a resolution of the criminal case can be reached, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Airline Selects Airbus
description: Airbus won an order for 41 planes worth as much as $3.5 billion from South African Airways, defeating the Boeing Company, which once supplied most of the carrier's fleet. The airline chose Airbus because its planes are cheaper to fly and better suited to African airports, Andre Viljoen, the chief executive, said. South African Airways will purchase six A340-600 and six A340-300 Enhanced long-haul jetliners, plus 11 A319 and 15 A320 narrowbodies.

title: A Market Solution to the Accounting Crisis
description: Since the collapse of Enron, there has been no shortage of proposals for reform of the accounting profession, the latest coming yesterday from President Bush. Unfortunately, most of these suggestions are neither constructive nor realistic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRENNER, LYNNE
description: BRENNER-Lynne. We miss you dearly. You'll always be in our hearts. Nancy and John Lori and Jay, and Bobi and Scott Love Always, Mort

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLAGOFF, SHIRLEY
description: PLAGOFF-Shirley. On March 7, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Edward, loving mother of Lynne and Alan, and grandmother of Jessica and Sam. We will miss you.

title: Thomas M. Whalen III, 68, Three-Term Mayor of Albany
description: Thomas M. Whalen III, mayor of Albany from 1983 to 1993, who moved it away from machine politics and helped revitalize its economy, died Monday evening when his car hit a tree near his home in Feura Bush in Albany County. He was 68.

title: Invaded by the Species With the Machines
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 Companies Agree to Fines For Sales Telephone
description: Thirteen companies have agreed to pay a total of $217,000 in the first fines imposed under New York State's ''do not call'' telemarketing law, according to Pataki administration officials.

title: Iraq Calls U.N. Meeting On Weapons 'Constructive'
description: Iraq and the United Nations ended their first talks in more than a year today with little more to show than an Iraqi pledge to give back some stolen Kuwaiti property and an agreement to meet again in mid-April, after an important Arab League summit-level meeting.

title: UConn Moves On With Escape Act
description: Before the Big East tournament, there was not a more enthusiastic booster of the conference than Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun. He was so impressed with the talent on display at Madison Square Garden that he predicted the league would send seven teams to the N.C.A.A. tournament. The fast-talking Calhoun practically choked on his ''underrated'' and ''not getting its dues.''

title: Russia's New Appetites (For Those Who Think Young)
description: HOMO ZAPIENS

title: Union Heads Among 7 Charged With Extortion on Docks
description: Seven men, including six past and present officials of a New Jersey longshoremen's local, were arrested today and accused of running an extortion ring that forced dock workers at a cargo terminal here to pay kickbacks for better jobs, the authorities said.

title: Brice Delsperger
description: Team Gallery

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Pakistan Pursues Taliban And Al Qaeda Fighters Who Fled Afghanistan
description: Pakistani officials say the government is pursuing large numbers of Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters who have crossed into the country from Afghanistan in recent months and are now believed to be hiding in tribal villages or large cities.

title: 'The Making and Meaning Of ''We Are Family'' '
description: Directed by Danny Schechter

title: Memo Shows White House Ire on Budget Criticism
description: An acerbic, confidential memorandum written to senior White House officials by Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., President Bush's budget director, has made clear the administration's anger with Mike Parker, the head of the Army Corps of Engineers who was forced to resign this week after he opposed White House budget cuts for his agency.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Elliott Leads Pace Past Queens
description: Since a knee injury prematurely ended his freshman season in 1999, seven games before his teammates lost to Adelphi in the first round of the Division II N.C.A.A. tournament, Pace guard Al Elliott had been waiting for his chance.

title: A Vast Trove of Drawings Amassed With Fervor
description: Collectors of drawings are a special species of the genus Ars acquisitoriensis. They may like paintings, but they will happily forgo the showier, fleshier appeal of pigment on canvas for the relative austerity of line and tone on paper. They are more apt to be turned on by the subtleties of a Gricault pencil study of two soldiers' heads or the lively scratchings of Czanne on a sheet of pen-and-ink figures.

title: Subcommittee Backs Bank Deposit Bill
description: A proposal to increase the amount of bank deposits protected by government insurance was unanimously approved yesterday by a Congressional subcommittee, despite opposition from the Bush administration.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Wait for Explosions, and Despair
description: The military action on Thursday was in Tulkarm, where the Israeli Army effectively sealed off the West Bank town and its refugee camps. But the fear was everywhere: in Bethlehem, where a woman described how her son vomited in panic when 500-pound Israeli bombs came down before dawn, or here in Jerusalem, where the authorities warned of more Palestinian suicide bombers poised to strike.

title: Fed Chief Sees Decline Over; House Passes Recovery Bill
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, effectively declared the recession over today, saying a spate of recent economic news suggested that the recovery ''is already well under way.''

title: McCall Campaign Won't Pay for Israel Trip
description: H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller running for governor, returned from a three-day trip to Israel yesterday, called a news conference to recount his impressions of Israel, and held out the possibility that his campaign would pick up part of the cost of the trip, a visit that could enhance his candidacy among Jewish voters in New York.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: State Delays Tax Refunds
description: For the second year in a row, residents will have to wait for income tax refunds because of a cash flow problem. The Department of Revenue is withholding thousands of refunds from early returns until state coffers are refilled, which could be this summer. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Injury Report Can Define The Yankees Thus Far
description: Steve Karsay walked freely around the Legends Field clubhouse this morning. There was no limp in his step, no tape around his foot. Karsay's right heel was bruised by a line drive on Tuesday, and he knows it could have been worse. ''If it had hit me right here,'' Karsay, a reliever, said, pointing to his ankle bone, ''I would have been in real trouble.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: U.S. Decision On Taiwan Condemned
description: The government condemned the Bush administration's decision to allow Taiwan's defense minister to attend a conference in Florida next week that is sponsored by American arms makers and will include speeches by senior American defense and foreign policy officials. In deference to the ''one China'' policy, the United States avoids official meetings with senior Taiwan officials, and a Chinese foreign ministry spokesman said that the Florida visit would amount to official contact and would damage Chinese-American relations. He repeated calls for the United States to end sales of advanced weapons to Taiwan. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Meet, one of the last restaurants to open in the meatpacking district, might be the first to get it right since Florent opened its doors back in the Pleistocene Epoch. It has style, but not too much. It's dim and moody without being sullen. The brief menu, bistro in spirit, gives proper attention to meat but does not make a caveman to-do about it.

title: Snow and wind hamper allied offensive in Afghan mountains
description: WASHINGTON:  U.S. warplanes resumed heavy bombing attacks Thursday in the eastern Afghan mountains, inflicting heavy casualties on Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters, but snow, bitter winds and plunging temperatures made air and ground operations increasingly difficult, according to reports from the area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLOTZ, RUTH
description: KLOTZ-Ruth. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Ruth Klotz, beloved mother of Martin B. Klotz, a dear friend of the Jewish community. Martin and his wife, Bobi, express their dedication to improving the lives of those less fortunate through their exceptional commitment to UJA-Federation. A compassionate leader who serves on our Board of Directors, Mrs. Klotz is extremely active on many committees at UJA-Federation and its beneficiary agencies. We extend our deepest sympathies to Martin and Bobi; and to the entire Klotz family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Joan Ginsburg, Women's Campaign Chair

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 26 about five investment bankers who were fired by Barclays Capital after they took part in an expensive dinner and wine party in a London restaurant misstated the reason for their dismissal. (An editorial on Feb. 27 repeated the error.) None of the bankers tried to pass off part of the dinner bill as client expenses. Barclays now refuses to say why they were dismissed or otherwise comment on the matter.

title: Judge Rules It Was Too Late To Charge Priest With Rapes
description: The most serious criminal charges against a priest who is accused of molesting nearly 200 children over three decades were thrown out today by a judge who said too much time had elapsed since the accuser first reported the incidents.

title: Malcolm X Letters Show His Evolution
description: In a rare trove of journals, letters and other writings attributed to Malcolm X that are to be auctioned on March 20, the fervid civil rights leader shows himself as humbled by his first pilgrimage to Mecca, in 1964, the year he broke with the Nation of Islam amid his growing conviction that not all whites were devils.

title: Kim Jones; Gary Panter
description: Pierogi

title: New Video Releases
description: Sexy Beast

title: PRESIDENT TO SEND ENVOY TO MIDEAST TO PUSH FOR TALKS
description: Under pressure from Arab allies, President Bush announced today that his special envoy, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, would return to the Middle East next week in an effort to end the mounting Israeli-Palestinian violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HOWARD
description: COHEN-Howard. The Officers, members and staff of New York Electrical Contractors Association express their sorrow at the loss of their associate and friend, Howard Cohen. For many years he served on various industry committees, including the Association Executive Committee. His loss will be felt by the entire industry. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Maxine, and his entire family.

title: Nina Levy
description: Eyewash@Holland Tunnel

title: Israel and America
description: To the Editor:

title: Telefnica To Expand In Cellphones In Mexico
description: Seeking to consolidate its position in Latin America despite setbacks in Argentina, the Spanish telecommunications giant Telefnica said today that it had agreed to acquire 65 percent of the Mexican mobile phone operator Pegaso. Telefnica is expected to reveal details of the deal on Friday.

title: Yugawaramachi Journal; Japan's New Insider Speaks Up for the Outsiders
description: The sound of the Pacific surf wafts up the hill, over the roofs of a Buddhist temple, through the terraced cemetery, and into the sunlit study of Japan's newest senator. But it is not enough to wash away memories of what he remembers as ''the shouting and shooting'' long ago in Finland.

title: Leon Mandel, 73, Former Publisher of AutoWeek, Dies
description: Leon Mandel III, an influential figure in the auto industry as editor in chief and publisher of AutoWeek magazine, died on Tuesday at his home in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATTLE, HYMAN L., JR.
description: BATTLE-Hyman L., Jr. His former partners at Battle Fowler are saddened by the death of their former senior partner, Hyman L. Battle, Jr., who died Wednesday at his home in Sagaponack, LI. Wise and courtly, Hy had a profound effect on all those who knew him. We extend our condolences to his wife, Reine, and to his family.

title: Eugene Gabritschewsky
description: Phyllis Kind

title: Is the Boy a Genius, or a Victim?
description: To the Editor:

title: Irish Voters Reject Broader Ban on Abortions
description: Irish voters narrowly rejected a proposal on Wednesday that would have tightened what is already a near total ban on abortions here by preventing pregnant mothers who are suicidal from terminating their pregnancies.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the arts pages yesterday about three British directors in New York misidentified the building where their plays were in rehearsal. It is the New 42nd Street Studios. (The Duke on 42nd Street is a ''black box'' theater in the building.)

title: Time Out for Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about surround-sound technology for headphones misstated the name of a company whose DVD drive software incorporates the technology. It is InterVideo, not InterVision.

title: A New Urgency on the Mideast
description: Responding wisely to a rapidly deteriorating situation in the Middle East, President Bush announced yesterday that he was sending his envoy Anthony Zinni back to the region next week to try to bring about a lasting cease-fire. On Sunday, Vice President Dick Cheney is also departing for the Middle East on a mission originally designed to discuss possible American actions against Iraq but now amended to include efforts to restart negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: 2 Large Advertisers Announce Choices
description: Two large advertisers made decisions on accounts yesterday.

title: World Briefing | World: Caviar Harvest Can Resume
description: The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, a United Nations agency, said four countries on the Caspian Sea can resume harvesting caviar from sturgeon because they have made progress in protecting the endangered fish. Russia, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan were allowed to proceed after surveying their stocks, setting quotas and taking steps to stop poaching. Iran, the other country on the Caspian, has not been under restrictions because it controls the sturgeon catch in its waters. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Strip-Search Suit Settled
description: The city has reached a settlement with an elderly woman who said she was arrested and forcibly strip-searched after neighbors complained that she had played her radio too loud. Under the terms of the settlement, the city, which admitted no wrongdoing, agreed to pay $50,000 to the woman, Mary Novak, 83, of Brooklyn. Ms. Novak agreed to drop charges against the city, two police officers and the Kings County District Attorney's office. Ms. Novak said she had been listening to talk radio, not ''threatening'' rap, as her neighbors alleged. The disturbance violated a December 2000 order of protection against her, a charge that was later dismissed.

title: Vessels of a City's Grief; Displays From Sept. 11 Form a Museum Exhibition
description: Last Sept. 11, at about 3 p.m., Jordan Schuster duct-taped a 15-foot-long roll of butcher paper to the pavement of Union Square. He had no expectation that it would be celebrated in a major museum exhibition. ''It was just something I needed to do -- wanted to do,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about a hearing in the Microsoft antitrust case misstated the roles of Kenneth W. Starr and Robert H. Bork. The two lawyers represent ProComp, a trade group critical of the proposed settlement. Mr. Starr does not represent the company, and Mr. Bork does not represent other groups opposing the settlement.

title: Sepracor's Stock Plunges On F.D.A. Ruling on Drug
description: Sepracor Inc. said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration would not approve its new allergy drug because the company failed to provide enough evidence that the drug would not cause heart problems. Shares of Sepracor lost more than half their value in heavy trading.

title: 3 Ad Competitors Unite to Conquer
description: Three giant advertising agency companies in Chicago, Paris and Tokyo announced yesterday that they would form what would be the world's fourth-largest such corporation, with strength in North America, Asia and Europe.

title: Beige Cosmos Produces Red Faces
description: Few gave a thought to the color of the universe until two months ago, when astronomers at Johns Hopkins University ran calculations through a spectrum of color schemes and concluded that on average the universe is pale turquoise, or just a shade greener.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, FLORENCE
description: BERLINER-Florence. Devoted wife of William. Beloved mother of Jeffrey and Leonard. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Elizabeth, Alanna and Ryan. Services Sunday 1 PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLACKS, JOSEPH H.
description: FLACKS-Joseph H. Age 91, on March 6, 2002 in Hyannis, MA. Former resident of Miami, FL., and Brooklyn, New York. Beloved husband of Rose (Wershil). Survived by sons Andy and Hank, daughter-in-law Jane, grandchildren Johanna & Gabriel. Memorial service to be held at a future date in Osterville, MA.

title: Records Indicate a Lack of Direction for Executives in Deal-Approval Procedures
description: The Enron Corporation's approval process for deals involving partnerships controlled by the chief financial officer was so haphazard that important people involved in the procedures had limited grasp of their responsibilities, records of an investigation by Enron's outside law firm show.

title: Counting His Sabbatical's Blessings
description: In the late spring of 2000, as performing artists everywhere were heading off to summer music festivals, the acclaimed young Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, surprisingly, was not among them. Instead, he went to a snow-bound wooden house way above the Hardanger fjord in southwest Norway, about a three-hour drive from Bergen, a lot of it uphill.

title: Can Not-So-Ordinary Artists Make Ordinary Snapshots? Well, Not Really
description: ''Snapshots,'' at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art here, presents an apparent democracy. All of the 1,300 or so photographs in the exhibition are roughly the same dimensions, 4 by 6 inches or smaller, protected by identical plastic covers and arranged in a grid formation in alphabetical order by the photographer's last name, beginning with Abernathy and ending with Zwiebel.

title: 'Chicks With Guns'
description: A generation ago, women here at Mount Holyoke College defied convention by burning bras and moving in with boyfriends. These days, some women here are shocking the campus by embracing something even more dangerous than men -- guns.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: S.& P. Cuts Hewlett Rating
description: Standard & Poor's lowered Hewlett-Packard's credit ratings by three notches yesterday, saying that falling profit and the planned purchase of Compaq Computer put the company at financial risk. Hewlett-Packard's corporate credit and senior debt ratings were reduced to A- from AA- and its commercial paper ratings were cut to A2 from A1+, S.& P. said. The rating agency said it would have reduced Hewlett's ratings even without the planned Compaq deal because of steep competition and mounting losses in its computer hardware businesses.

title: Japan Economy Contracts for 3rd Consecutive Quarter
description: Japan's economy contracted sharply in the fourth quarter of 2001, by 1.2 percent, the government reported today. It was the third consecutive quarter in which the economy shrank, the first such streak in nearly a decade. For all of 2001, the economy contracted 0.5 percent.

title: 'Arte Povera'
description: Barbara Gladstone

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Court Bars Elections
description: The State Supreme Court barred primary elections for the State House and Senate, scheduled for May 7, until it reviews a lower court decision that found new legislative districts to be unconstitutional. The ruling comes in response to a lawsuit by Republican lawmakers, who argue that the Democratic-controlled General Assembly split more counties than was necessary to comply with the federal Voting Rights Act, in an effort to ensure that Democrats keep control of the Assembly. Last month, Judge Knox Jenkins of Superior Court agreed.

title: Big Picture Is Important For Franco And the Mets
description: John Franco has accomplished much in 18 years in the major leagues. He has saved 422 games, won three season-saves titles, been a four-time All-Star and appeared in more games than any other Met.

title: Arthur Andersen Needs Help to Survive
description: WHEN the Enron scandal began to mushroom, and Arthur Andersen disclosed that its auditors had shredded documents, Andersen's big competitors shuddered and privately voiced fears that Andersen might not survive.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Novelist Freed After Paying Fine
description: the novelist Arundhati Roy was released from jail after serving what the Supreme Court called a symbolic one-day sentence for contempt. She paid a $42 fine rather than spend three more months in jail, saying she did not want to make herself ''a martyr for a cause that is not mine alone.'' Prominent editors and journalists said the court's action would chill free expression, particularly criticism of the court. Ms. Roy, a leading opponent of a huge dam project in central India, was convicted after saying the court had tried to silence criticism of its approval of the project.

title: Juan Cspedes
description: Andrew Kreps

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Legal Settlement Reviewed
description: An $850,000 legal settlement paid to the recently elected mayor of Atlantic City and a political ally will be investigated by the state inspector general's office, a spokesman for the office said yesterday. The money was paid by the city to settle a four-year-old lawsuit by Lorenzo Langford, above, elected mayor last November, and William Marsh. Their suit sought reinstatement after they lost their city school board jobs in 1998. The City Council approved the settlement on Feb. 27. The sole dissenting vote on the Council, Timothy Mancuso, sought the state review.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the increase in American troops and equipment in the fighting in Afghanistan misidentified the Army division commanded by Maj. Gen. Frank L. Hagenbeck. It is the 10th Mountain Division, not the 101st Airborne Division.

title: Far From Beijing, a Semblance of Democracy
description: Yao Lifa looks like a man with a mission, as he hurtles down the slick sidewalk, head bent against the rain, briefcase bulging with proposals he has brought to present to higher authorities in this provincial capital.

title: After Angry Debate, Senate Confirms State Police Head
description: Joseph J. Santiago was confirmed today as New Jersey's new State Police superintendent, winning by five votes after a fierce Senate debate in which one critic compared him to Benito Mussolini and one supporter to Ulysses S. Grant.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: St. John's Leaves Fate to the Mercy of Others
description: No amount of determined defense, no hot shooting from Marcus Hatten, not even an appearance by St. John's crowd pleaser, the jumbo 7-foot-3 center Curtis Johnson, could help the Red Storm overcome itself last night against Notre Dame. Its regular season is over, its Big East tournament appearance has been cut short, and now the players must wait.

title: 'A Return to January 1982' -- 'The Corcoran Show Revisited'
description: Luise Ross Gallery

title: Final Rules for Federal Victims' Fund Increase Aid to Families of Sept. 11 Dead
description: Saying that the complaints from families of those killed or injured on Sept. 11 had not fallen on deaf ears, the official overseeing the federal Victims Compensation Fund announced final regulations today that he said would produce substantially larger awards than his initial rules would have allowed.

title: And in This Corner . . .
description: Next Wednesday evening, Paula Jones, late of Arkansas politician fame, and Tonya Harding, the Olympic bad dream, will face off in a three-round bout on Fox Television's ''Celebrity Boxing.'' Amy Fisher, the ''Long Island Lolita,'' was originally scheduled to go against Ms. Harding, but her parole board prevented her on the grounds that her appearance ''would send an inappropriate message to victims of violent crime.'' Clearly, national television would be a better place if more celebrities had parole boards.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 26 about five investment bankers who were fired by Barclays Capital after they took part in an expensive dinner and wine party in a London restaurant misstated the reason for their dismissal. (An editorial on Feb. 27 repeated the error.) None of the bankers tried to pass off part of the dinner bill as client expenses. Barclays now refuses to say why they were dismissed or otherwise comment on the matter.

title: Bush Offers Details Of Aid to New York Topping $20 Billion
description: President Bush summoned top New York officials to the White House this afternoon and declared that he was moving to fulfill his promise to give the city at least $20 billion to help rebuild from the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: 2 Californians May Become First Sister Act in Congress
description: From the moment the first speaker of the House, Frederick Muhlenberg, stepped into office alongside his brother John, so many sets of relatives have passed through Congress that historians sometimes liken it to prep school or college, where familial ties are an indelible part of the institutional fabric.

title: Hong Kong Election
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Ex-Prosecutor Is Disbarred
description: The State Supreme Court disbarred a former Clackamas County district attorney, Teresa M. Gustafson, for disregarding a court order to destroy documents and then lying to a judge about it. Ms. Gustafson ignored an order to expunge files related to a 1992 case involving a juvenile accused of molesting two neighbors. She testified that she had complied, despite keeping the records in her home and car. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Straight to the Source
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Blithe Souls
Corner of England in Paris gets a colorful makeover
description: PARIS  With a burst of color, one of the city's oldest shopping destinations, Old England, has been recently redone, turning it into one of Paris's most modern shopping venues.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Mother Admits Neglecting Son
description: In a Broomfield County courtroom sealed off to the news media, Elizabeth Chapman admitted she had neglected her 8-year-old son, Justin, by creating an ''injurious environment'' detrimental to his welfare, according to a statement issued by Judge Harlan Bockman of District Court. Justin had received wide notice for having an I.Q. of 298, the highest on record. But in November he suffered emotional problems, was removed from his mother and placed in foster care. Last month, Ms. Chapman said the records attesting to Justin's superior intelligence had been faked. Judge Bockman set a hearing for April 12 to decide on a treatment plan by which Ms. Chapman could regain custody of Justin. Erica Goode (NYT)

title: Republican Senator Says He Won't Run
description: Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee announced today that he would not seek re-election, becoming the fourth Republican senator with a presumably safe seat to decide not to run again this year.

title: Mayor Links Teacher Pay To Control Of Schools
description: For months, three questions have dominated the education debate in New York City: whether the mayor should control the school system, who the mayor's choice as chancellor will be, and how a contract deal can be reached with the union representing the city's 80,000 teachers.

title: Huskies and Panthers Hold Their Ground
description: Connecticut's Caron Butler is the Big East's co-player of the year, Johnnie Selvie is the Huskies' coat-hanger-shouldered senior leader and Ben Gordon is their freshman phenomenon. So it is easy to overlook Tony Robertson. Even though he starts, Robertson, a soft-spoken junior, is the third guard in a three-guard rotation.

title: The Collections / Paris : Forward-looking designers go back to their roots
description: PARIS  The powerful shows that have hit the runways  Bang! Bang! Bang!  in the first two days of the autumn/winter 2002 have a collective thread. Designers are going back to their roots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELUGG, ANNE
description: DELUGG-Anne. Born April 22, 1921; died March 1, 2002. Loving wife of Milton. Mother of Michael (Vivien) and Stephen. Services were held March 4, 2002, at Mt. Sinai Cemetery, Los Angeles, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWENSTEIN, BOB
description: LOWENSTEIN-Bob. Seven years have passed and it seems like only a moment ago. We miss you terribly. Love, Dad and Han

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, FRANCIS T.
description: COLEMAN-Francis T., 80. Of Bronxville, NY and formerly of Glenville, NY died March 7, 2002. Former Labor Relations executive with Atlantic Richfield. Proud member of the 8th Air Force Historical Society and a supporter of the Friends of the Old Dutch Burying Ground in Sleepy Hollow. Visitation at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY on Saturday (today) 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-4 PM only. Funeral Mass Mon. 11:00 Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, Elmsford. Interment Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to the Friends of the Old Dutch Burying Grounds, 42 North Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSTLING, MYRNA
description: GINSTLING-Myrna. Her wit and wisdom and courage we will remember always. To Norman, Gary, Jill, Nancy & Ben we extend our love. Sandy and Steve Turk

title: Plagiarism That Doesn't Add Up
description: In the 1950's, the waggish mathematician-balladeer Tom Lehrer paid mischievous tribute to the 19th-century Russian mathematician Nicolai Ivanovich Lobachevsky, who was thought to be an inveterate plagiarist. Mr. Lehrer imagined an unscrupulous acolyte following in Lobachevsky's footsteps by writing a math book in which every chapter is stolen from somewhere else and the index is copied from an ''old Vladivostok telephone directory.''

title: New Jersey Family in Cuba Is Allowed to Return Home
description: A New Jersey family who had been prevented from leaving Cuba for a week after officials there accused them of helping relatives flee to the United States are finally being allowed to leave, officials here said today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We were fighting in their backyard. We were not used to it. They knew every crevice, every cubbyhole, every cave.''

title: Isabelle Holland, 81, Novelist for Teenagers
description: Isabelle Holland, a prolific writer of fiction for young adults and Gothic mystery novels, died on Feb. 9 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She was 81.

title: How Can the Church End Abuse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Remember The Slocum? Probably Not
description: TO call it forgotten might be going too far. Let's just say that it is little noticed, the Slocum Memorial Fountain in Tompkins Square Park.

title: Yankees' Greene Eager to Prove That He's a Cut Above
description: Todd Greene has been released on the last day of spring training two years in a row. The streak plays tricks on his psyche.

title: Alvin Eicoff, Innovator in Late-Night TV Ads, Dies at 80
description: Alvin M. Eicoff, an advertising executive in Chicago who gained his reputation making television commercials aimed at bleary-eyed late-night viewers, died last Saturday in Highland Beach, Fla.

title: Black School Abruptly Exits Chicago Catholic League
description: A black Catholic school abruptly withdrew today from a mostly white Catholic athletic conference, after months of struggle in which it was initially denied membership until national publicity and a plea from the archbishop led to its admission.

title: AAIPHARMA BUYS RIGHTS TO ELI LILLY PAINKILLERS
description: AaiPharma Inc. agreed to buy the United States rights to Eli Lilly & Company's painkillers Darvon and Darvocet for $211.4 million, a purchase the drug maker said would add to profit immediately. AaiPharma plans to finance the acquisition through debt, the chief executive, Frederick D. Sancilio, said in a statement. The price could change depending on initial sales performance, Mr. Sancilio said. The company will increase its marketing and sales force as its NeoSan Pharmaceuticals unit takes on the drugs, which are mild to moderate painkillers, David Hurley, president of the unit, said. The company, which is based in Wilmington, N.C., will also invest in marketing and research to add new uses for the treatments.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Amnesty For Rebels Approved
description: Lawmakers passed an amnesty for ethnic Albanian guerrillas, a move both sides hailed as a vital step to solidify a peace that has held tenuously since last summer. The amnesty was long considered one of the most sensitive parts of a broad peace plan that ended six months of fighting but has yet to move completely through Parliament. The law does not cover possible crimes investigated by the international tribunal in The Hague, which has said it is looking into several incidents involving both Macedonians and Albanians. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Pakistan Prepares to Expel Foreign Religious Students
description: The government is preparing to expel thousands of Arab, Afghan and other foreign students now studying at religious schools across Pakistan, out of concern that their presence might be a step toward possible militant activities, senior Pakistani officials said tonight.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on Wednesday about boycotts of New York State's eighth-grade tests reversed the percentages of parents and teachers who said in a national Public Agenda survey that testing was overemphasized. That was the view of 60 percent of parents and 84 percent of teachers.

title: Zimbabwe Vote Heralds a Shift in Southern Africa
description: President Robert Mugabe shakes his fist, his supporters roar and for a moment he is a hero again to the African diplomats who have converged on this city to observe this weekend's presidential election. He is the guerrilla who ended decades of white rule here, the fiery nationalist who nurtured and inspired a generation of black leaders.

title: Old Swing Makes Alfonzo a New Man
description: If the swing had not been preserved on videotape, fans might have trouble believing it existed. Dave Engle saw the swing when he began studying the Mets' batters after becoming the hitting coach a year ago. Then, two weeks into the 2001 season, Edgardo Alfonzo's swing was snuffed out.

title: Are the Bulls Starting a Run As the Economy Gathers Steam?
description: A new economic expansion seems to be beginning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANZER, SIDNEY
description: PANZER-Sidney. The officers and staff of Walter & Samuels, Inc. mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague of more than 30 years. His compassion and professionalism will be greatly missed. Our sincerest sympathies to his beloved wife, Mickey, and family.

title: Mayor Bloomberg's Public Schools
description: New York's political leaders are finally ready to begin streamlining the city's unmanageable school system. The question now is whether an inability to agree on details will turn into a deal-breaker. Mayor Michael Bloomberg has made compelling arguments that it is time to give the mayor full control over New York City's 1,100 schools. He wants to be able to hire and fire a chancellor. He wants to get rid of the Board of Education, its delays, its patronage, its costs. And he wants parents and communities to get involved more intensely at the local school and borough level.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SOPHOMORES SOAR TO RECORDS
description: Two sophomores set collegiate indoor records last night at the N.C.A.A. indoor championships in Fayetteville, Ark. Amy Linnen of Arizona raised the pole vault record to 14 feet 10i inches. Perdita Felicien of Illinois lowered the 60-meter hurdles record to 7.90.

title: Campaigning for 2 Bushes: One in 2002, One in 2004
description: Floridians got another first-hand look at President Bush today, their eighth since he took the oath of office, suggesting that if any of them have forgotten the 36-day election recount crisis of 2000, the White House has not.

title: United States Team Wins Nations' Cup
description: Paced by faultless rides by McLain Ward of Brewster, N.Y., and Margie Engle of Wellington, Fla., in the first round, and by Lauren Hough of Ocala, Fla., in the final round, the United States Equestrian Team yesterday won the first outdoor Nations' Cup for horse show jumpers held in the United States.

title: Schering-Plough to Offer Nonprescription Claritin
description: With low-priced competition looming for Claritin, the heavily advertised allergy drug, the Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it would offer a nonprescription version later this year. Analysts predicted a drugstore free-for-all that could drive down prices for consumers and severely erode Schering-Plough's profits in 2003.

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about ''The Time Machine,'' an adaptation of the H. G. Wells novel, misstated the nationality of a cast member, the pop star Samantha Mumba. She is Irish, not Scottish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYRAS, DENIS, M.D.
description: TYRAS-Denis, M.D. The Officers and Members of The Staff Society of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center mourn the tragic passing of our friend and colleague, Denis Tyras, M.D. Dr. Tyras was the Chief of the Division of CardioThoracic Surgery at LIJ from 1984 to 1991. He devoted his life to helping others. We extend our heartfelt condolences and best wishes to his family. Ira N. Kalfus, M.D., President Eugene Friedman, M.D., V.P. Keith Cardell, M.D., Secretary Randall Feingold, M.D., Treasurer

title: Shimon Peres's Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Agreement On Electricity Rates
description: Rates charged by the Entergy Corporation, the state's largest provider of electricity, will remain stable through fall 2003 under a deal between the company, the Public Service Commission and the state attorney general. The agreement allows Entergy to use accumulated cash balances above its authorized rate of return to offset almost $200 million in damages to its facilities from ice storms in 2000. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: COURT APPROVES CHIQUITA'S REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: Chiquita Brands International, the world's biggest banana producer, won court approval of its Chapter 11 recovery plan, clearing the way for the company to emerge from bankruptcy. Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. of United States Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati approved the plan yesterday. Chiquita plans to emerge from bankruptcy court protection on March 19, Matt Kleiman of Kirkland & Ellis, Chiquita's bankruptcy lawyer, said. Chiquita's plan will enable it to swap about $700 million in debt for 40 million new shares in the company. Chiquita is based in Cincinnati.

title: New Task Force Is to Deal With Questions on Air Quality
description: Responding to the continuing fear and confusion over air safety near ground zero, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday announced a new task force to coordinate the response of city agencies and to establish a complaint and information phone line about environmental issues in and around the World Trade Center site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, H. REUBEN
description: MANDEL-H. Reuben. Passed away on March 8, 2002 in Miami Beach. Devoted husband of the late Bertha. Cherished father of Rita and William Lurie. Beloved grandfather of Ellen and Erick Cortes, Lynn and Andrew Koven, Jay and Elizabeth Lurie. Adoring great-grandfather of Barnett, Franny, Erica, Eve, Dana and Aaron.

title: Cantor Is Arrested In Molesting Case
description: The cantor of Temple Emanu-El, one of Reform Judaism's most prominent synagogues, turned himself in to the authorities in a Philadelphia suburb yesterday to face charges that he sexually molested his young nephew.

title: For a New Lease on Life, Unplug the TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Kill at Least 40 After Arab Kills 5 Teenagers
description: On the deadliest day in 17 months of fighting, Israeli forces killed at least 40 Palestinians today with fire from land, sea and air after five Israeli teenagers died in a Palestinian's suicidal rampage through a settlement south of here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNOR, NORMA L.
description: TANNOR-Norma L. Beloved wife of Solomon. Loving mother of Merrill, Robert and Erica, and Evan and Ilene. Cherished grandmother of Amanda, Samantha, Bradley, Jaymie and Cole.

title: A Better Taxi System
description: To the Editor:

title: An Emotional First Day Of Liberty for Schwarz
description: The second thing Charles Schwarz did on his first full day out of prison was shower. His hands were not shackled on the way to the tub. The third thing he did was eat a stack of pancakes. His sister had prepared the meal, not a slapdash federal cook.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Denial On Handing Over Of Suspects
description: The government denied a report from one of its officials that four terrorism suspects had been handed over to the United States, a report that was also rejected by the State Department. Earlier this week, a senior government official told foreign reporters that the four men -- two Bosnians and two Jordanians arrested last month on charges of plotting against Western embassies -- had been taken out of the country by American authorities. Meanwhile, the Bosnian government says it has no report of its citizens' whereabouts and has demanded an explanation from Macedonia. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Catholic Bishop in Florida Quits, Admitting Sex Abuse in the 70's
description: The Roman Catholic bishop of Palm Beach, Fla., resigned yesterday after admitting that he sexually abused a teenage seminary student in the 1970's.

title: Police Families Demand a Say In Handling of Benefit Fund
description: Before Sept. 11, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association had $330,000 in its Widows' and Children's Benefit Fund, just enough for Christmas parties, ski trips and other outings for 102 families of the New York Police Department who, over the years, have lost relatives in the line of duty.

title: Sports of The Times; Dave Odom Feeling Cozy In New Home
description: THE Southeastern Conference fascinates me. Always has. Every time I go into SEC territory, I think of the Kingfish. Not the Kingfish on ''Amos 'n' Andy'' but Huey Long, the legendary governor of Louisiana, a fascinating figure in Southern politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SASLOW, CLAIRE F.
description: SASLOW-Claire F. With great courage, dignity and love, Claire F. Saslow, 84, died peacefully, surrounded by her family on March 8, 2002 after a short illness. Her children, Doris and Peter Tilles and Martha and David Maisel, and her grandchildren, Brenda, Diana, Lilly and Ben, recently shared a vacation with her in which Claire experienced one of her joys - her dream of seeing her children and grandchildren love and appreciate each other. As the young widow of Benjamin Maisel, Claire ensured that her children received fine educations and that they successfully launched their careers before marrying Seymour G. Saslow with whom she had many happy years. Claire and Seymour traveled extensively, and upon retirement as a legal secretary in 1981, she began her second career as a docent extraordinaire at both the New York Public Library and Gracie Mansion. Claire was an incredible role model and a tough act to follow. She showed us what life is all about and how to do it. She will be deeply missed by her children, grandchildren, sister, Selma Sulken, and her many friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to ''The Claire F. Saslow Docent Fund'' at the New York Public Library.

title: In Tug of War, Pittsburgh Is Able to Pull Out Victory
description: For all the substance Pittsburgh offers when it takes the court, there are times when the Panthers are flashy, energetic and high flying.

title: Sharon Gets in Step After U.S. Steps In
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon put the best face on the Bush administration's decision to send its envoy back to the Middle East after a two-month absence, declaring that he would drop his demand for a week of peace before joining in negotiations. Yet after several months of operating against the Palestinians with a virtual green light from the Americans, there was little question that the American re-entry was a setback for Mr. Sharon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, HILDA
description: STARK-Hilda. Beloved wife for 61 years of Henry J. Stark. Loving mother of Linda Glantz. Cherished grandmother of Robert and Shari. Dearest sister of Miriam Reisberg and Lillian Heflich. Services on Sunday at 10 A.M., I.J. Morris, Hempstead, NY. 516-486-2500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMBER, MURIEL ''MIMI'' (NEE ELLENBOGEN)
description: DEMBER-Muriel ''Mimi'' (nee Ellenbogen). Of Massapequa and Amityville. Devoted wife of Jules; loving mother of Stuart, Ann Ryan, John and Allyne, Peggy and Gary Zucker, and Larry; cherished grandmother of Robert, Philip, Ian, Jasmine, Rebecca, Ryan and Liam. She proudly spent 20 years as Health Educator at Amityville High School and also Nassau Community College. Services will be held Sunday 11AM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ at The Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah.

title: New Drug for Multiple Sclerosis Gains Approval From F.D.A.
description: Serono A.G., Europe's biggest biotechnology company, said today that the Food and Drug Administration had approved its multiple sclerosis drug, Rebif, to be marketed in the United States. The drug will go on sale in America in a few days.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a picture by the Votava agency on Thursday with an article about Austrians who were among the first war profiteers to seize the property of Vienna's Jews misstated the month in 1938 when the scene occurred. The picture, showing swastika banners on the Bristol Hotel, was taken after the German annexation of Austria in March 1938, not in January.

title: An Elite Track Cyclist Has Taken to the Road
description: Marty Nothstein has nothing left to accomplish in the world of track cycling. He is America's most decorated track cyclist, having won a gold medal in the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney, Australia, a silver medal in 1996 in Atlanta, 3 world championships and 30 national titles.

title: Pain in Pettitte's Elbow Is the Latest Concern
description: Andy Pettitte had a twinge and a vision before today's 3-2 exhibition loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates. A twinge in his left elbow during his bullpen session made him imagine the Yankees leaving Florida without him in three weeks.

title: Let Us Prey
description: One thing I learned in the course of my Catholic education is that the church is not a democracy. So the fact that a plurality of Boston Catholics believe the leader of their archdiocese should resign for his shameful cover-up of pedophile priests is just an interesting bit of polling data, not something likely to influence the cardinal, whose word (and name) is Law.

title: 4 Are Dead And 2 Injured In a Car Crash In Suffolk
description: Four young adults were killed and a fifth was critically injured when their car struck another vehicle head-on Thursday night, the Suffolk County police said yesterday.

title: Richter and Lindros Facing Questions on Performance
description: Mike Richter, who is scheduled to start in goal for the first time in three games when the Rangers play Pittsburgh on Saturday, is not in danger of losing his job, according to Rangers General Manager Glen Sather.

title: Details Disputed in Death of Man Lodged in Windshield
description: Sobbing and seemingly dazed as television cameras circled around her, a young nurse's aide charged with murder in the gruesome death of a homeless man appeared in court today as her lawyer disputed some of the most graphic accusations against her.

title: Flying Car Plunges to Tracks, Snarling Rush Hour for 17,000
description: The morning rush hour was thrown into chaos for about 17,000 New Jersey rail commuters today after a speeding car, a 2000 gold Jaguar, plunged 30 feet onto railroad tracks here, closing them down for three hours and disrupting the schedules of 37 trains, officials said.

title: Zimmer and Umpires Say an Old Debt Has Been Paid
description: John Dowd, who led the gambling investigation of Pete Rose, and Fay Vincent, the former baseball commissioner, acknowledged yesterday that Don Zimmer and two umpires were punished 13 years ago for placing bets with a drug-dealing bookmaker in Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, JAMES RONALD, PH.D.
description: THOMAS-James Ronald, Ph.D. On March 7, 2002. Retired Professor of Biology at Bronx Community College and NYU. A graduate of St. Francis College, NYU and LIU. Member of The Duns Scotus Society. Beloved husband of Kathleen. Devoted father of Elizabeth Janocha and Matthew. Dear brother of George, Mark and Marianne Mattaliano. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, March 11, at 10 AM.

title: Police to Get A New Chief In Nassau
description: Nassau County's 2,800-member police force, which is the focus of a bitter power struggle between union leaders and the new county executive, is getting a new leader.

title: World Briefing | World: Criminal Court Nears Reality
description: With Mauritius, Macedonia and Cyprus acting this week, 55 of the required 60 nations have ratified the treaty creating the International Criminal Court, which would be the first permanent tribunal set up to try individuals charged with genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity. Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations said he expected the court to be established by July. The Bush administration opposes it. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Corrections
