description: An article on Thursday about strikes by Israel against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip misspelled the surname of a commentator for the newspaper Yediot Ahronot who criticized the government for its handling of the conflict. He is Sever Plotzker, not Plotzer.

title: Redistricting, and Lunch, Draw a Crowd
description: One after another, the school buses pulled up to the curb outside Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday morning and disgorged their charges. But it was not student-appreciation day at the government center. Nearly all of the passengers were elderly, and several hundred of them wore bright yellow baseball caps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, JOSEPH, M.D.
description: SILBERSTEIN-Joseph, M.D. Cherished husband of Thelma for more than 50 years. Model father of Debbie, Linda and Eric. Trusting father-in-law of Fred, Larry and Nancy. Inspirational grandfather of Jonathan, Zachery and Jacob. Friend to all. Doctor to many. Died suddenly on March 8, 2002. An octogenarian, he served as a captain in the U.S. Army in W.W. II, a doctor in the communities of Port Chester and Rye Brook for over 35 years and a respected counselor to family, friends and the ''Hammerschlag'' clan for even longer. Dr. Joe was born and raised in the Bronx, graduated from City College, received a Master's in Public Health from Columbia University and a medical degree from the University of Zurich. He ministered to all in need, chaired the Department of Family Practice at United Hospital of Port Chester, served his community as police doctor, school physician and family practitioner par excellence, painted beautifully, golfed with a need to swing and, above all, loved, nurtured and aided endlessly. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel, 575 King St., Port Chester, NY at 1 PM Sunday, March 10, 2002. Contributions may be made in his memory to United Hospital of Port Chester, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, New York 10573.

title: Yale Looking to Make History Against Penn
description: When James Jones took over as the Yale men's basketball coach in April 1999, he set out on a recruiting mission with a bit of history to overcome. The team was coming off a 4-22 season and had not captured even a share of an Ivy League title since 1963. Yale's last winning season was 1991-92 and the last 20-victory season was in 1948-49.

title: A Singer Who Puts Herself Before Dates
description: Nelly Furtado doesn't pretend to be anything but self-centered. Songs from her album, ''Whoa, Nelly!'' (DreamWorks), including the Grammy-winning ''I'm Like a Bird,'' are catchy warnings to any would-be suitor that her needs and impulses will always come first.

title: Landlord Is Found Guilty in Tenant's Murder
description: The landlord of an East Side apartment building who had feuded for decades with a tenant was convicted of second-degree murder yesterday for fatally shooting the woman and leaving her body sprawled on a staircase while he took out the building's trash.

title: Jets Solidify Defense by Signing Beasley
description: The Jets signed their fifth free agent of the week yesterday, and in doing so virtually plugged the last of the seven holes on defense that were created when the free-agency carousel began a week ago.

title: Insensitive in the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: How Can the Church End Abuse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEATHERS, ELIOT B.
description: WEATHERS-Eliot B. The Partners of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett are deeply saddened by the passing of their retired partner, Bay Weathers. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ann and to his entire family.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPRINT CORP., Kansas City, Mo., the third-largest long-distance phone carrier, raised $5 billion from a bond sale to help it pay down short-term debt. The sale was the second largest corporate bond sale in the United States this year and drew more than $12 billion in investor bids.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Federal Rule For Biggest State
description: President K. R. Narayanan approved the imposition of federal rule in the country's most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, after an election last month failed to produce a clear winner. No coalition has emerged that could command a majority in the State Assembly. The Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, which had held the most seats, fell to third place in the election, while the Samajwadi Party, with its base in the peasant castes, won the largest number of seats. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: 12 Iranians Turned Over to Americans
description: Twelve Iranians apparently seeking to secure the allegiance of commanders in western Afghanistan have been seized by Afghans and handed over to American military officials here, an Afghan familiar with the details of their capture said.

title: The War in Colombia Intensifies
description: Things may get a lot worse before they get any better in Colombia, the site of the bloodiest and longest-running conflict in the Americas. Last month President Andrs Pastrana abandoned a failed three-year-old peace process with the country's largest leftist guerrilla movement, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, and ordered the army to reoccupy an enormous and desolate southern area that he had ceded to the insurgents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, SOLOMON D.
description: SIEGEL-Solomon D. On March 6, 2002. Formerly of Westbury, L.I. Beloved husband of Pearl, devoted father of Susan Kolpen and Larry Siegel, loving father-in-law of Jeff and Merryl, cherished grandfather of Lisa, Jared, Eric, Bryan and Carly. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Does a Shoe Fit? A Stepsister's Story
description: If the title character of ''Lolita'' can now tell the story from her side, if a slave can rewrite ''Gone With the Wind'' from her perspective, then why shouldn't one of Cinderella's famously unpleasant siblings tell her story?

title: Hanover Compressor Inquiry Widens
description: The Hanover Compressor Company, a provider of natural gas pipeline equipment, said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission wanted more information on the transactions that forced it to restate its earnings last month.

title: Senate Approves Economic Stimulus Bill
description: The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a package of tax cuts for business and extended benefits for unemployed workers, bringing to a close a partisan battle over how to help the economy.

title: A Patch of Greenwich Beach Is Available to All, at $10 a Day
description: Caught between a court order to open its beaches to outsiders and fears about crowds and high costs, this well-heeled suburb deliberated for seven months and came up with a plan: charge each out-of-town adult $308 for a season pass.

title: INTELSAT SATELLITE NETWORK TO OFFER STOCK
description: Intelsat Ltd., a satellite network owned by 200 of the world's biggest telephone companies, said it planned to raise $500 million in an initial public offering of stock. Intelsat's shareholders also plan to sell stock in the offering, the company said. Intelsat was founded in 1964.

title: Excerpts From 'Etz Hayim' Essays
description: From the essay ''Biblical Archaeology,'' by Lee I. Levine, referring to the reigns of Kings David and Solomon.

title: Tread Carefully In Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulators Seek to Block Enron's Hiring of a Chief
description: Federal regulators moved yesterday to block the Enron Corporation from hiring Stephen F. Cooper as its new chief executive, saying that the deal with Mr. Cooper ''cast doubt on the fairness of Enron's handling of its bankruptcy case,'' according to papers filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Staples Suspects Face Old Charges
description: Three of the four people arrested on Thursday after a nine-hour hostage incident in a Staples store in Valley Stream, Long Island, will be charged with a robbery at a college bookstore in Queens in 2001 and a burglary there the year before, the New York City police said yesterday.

title: Arrest in Baby's Death
description: A Brooklyn woman was arrested yesterday and charged with second-degree murder in the death on Wednesday of her newborn daughter, the police said.

title: EXPANDING IN U.S., FALCK BUYS WACKENHUT SECURITY
description: Group 4 Falck, a leading global provider of security services, agreed to buy a rival, the Wackenhut Corporation, for $573 million so Falck can expand in the United States, where demand for security guards is rising after the Sept. 11 attacks. Falck, which is based in Copenhagen, will pay $33 for each share of Wackenhut, the chief executive, Lars Noerby Johansen, said. The price was below Thursday's closing price of $34.40. Falck and a bigger rival, Securitas, are buying competitors in the $14 billion market in the United States, which they expect to grow faster than other markets. Wackenhut, which is based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., provides more than 40,000 security guards to companies.

title: Family-Style Burlesque, Abstract And Comic
description: Donald Byrd looked back on a decade of choreography in ''Byrd-lesque,'' the program Donald Byrd/ The Group danced on Sunday afternoon at the New Victory Theater. Appropriately subtitled ''A Kinda-Sorta Mini Retrospective,'' the 75-minute event featured a premiere and bits and pieces from dances created since 1992. All revealed Mr. Byrd's ability to borrow elements from disparate styles and fuse them into coherent new wholes.

title: Devils' Scoring Struggles Lead to 3rd Straight Loss
description: The opposition was supposed to be easier this time, and certainly not as strong as the previous two road opponents -- the defending Stanley Cup champion Colorado Avalanche or the competitive Phoenix Coyotes.

title: Fire Destroys a Sikh Temple In Queens, Injuring 6 Priests
description: The city's oldest Sikh temple, a nexus for the Sikh community along the East Coast, was destroyed early yesterday morning when fire engulfed the building and injured six visiting priests, the authorities said.

title: Trend-spotting:new spins on old techniques
description: PARIS  Not that long ago, one of the thrills of traveling abroad was to shop for something distinctly different from what one could find at home. But no longer. Today the only difference between a pair of jeans bought in New York, Sydney or London is the price.

title: LVMH Avoided Loss for '01 With Gains on Gucci Shares
description: The world's biggest luxury goods group, LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, reported sharply reduced net income for 2001 today, and it said it was able to avoid a full-year net loss only because of capital gains from the sale in September of shares in the Gucci Group, in settlement of a long-running dispute for control of Gucci.

title: AMF BOWLING WORLDWIDE EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: AMF Bowling Worldwide, the world's largest owner and operator of bowling centers, said it had emerged from bankruptcy protection. The company, which is no longer affiliated with AMF Bowling, said it also received $350 million in financing from the Bankers Trust Company unit of Deutsche Bank. Under the plan, secured lenders, who are owed about $622 million, will receive $150 million in notes as well as 92.5 percent of the restructured company's new shares and cash. Unsecured creditors, including bondholders owed more than $550 million, received a 7.5 percent stake in the new AMF and options to buy up to a 26 percent stake, depending upon the company's value. AMF Bowling Worldwide, which is based in Richmond, Va., has more than 500 bowling alleys worldwide. It reported $1.68 billion in assets and $1.26 billion in debts in the bankruptcy filing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MOSES
description: SHAPIRO-Moses. Beloved husband of Ethel. Devoted father of Naomi and Richard Resnick, Louise and Robert Cohen. Dear brother of Jessica Gribetz. Loving uncle and brother-in-law. Adored grandfather of Deborah, Ilana, Sarah and David. Highly respected member of the community. Retired Deputy Treasurer of Revlon. Former Chairman of the Board of Cejwin Camps. Member of the Board of Bay Terrace Jewish Center; Treasurer of Bay Terrace Cooperative Section VIII. Services Sunday 10:00 AM at Schwartz Bros., Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVECE, IRENE
description: LOVECE-Irene. Of Mt. Kisco, passed away Thursday, March 7, 2002 in the Calvary Hospital, Bronx, New York. Mrs. Lovece is survived by her son Joseph Jr., nine grandchildren and 15 greatgrandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband Joseph Sr. and her daughter Marilyn. Visiting is scheduled for today and Sunday, from 2-4 and 7-9PM at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle, NY. Family will gather at the Funeral Home on Monday, 10 A.M. for an interment at the Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx.

title: Officials Say Figures Show That Profiling Is Decreasing
description: New Jersey state troopers made more than 36,000 traffic stops on the New Jersey Turnpike in the six-month period that ended Oct. 31, but asked to conduct searches only 11 times, according to statistics released today by the state attorney general's office.

title: Wounded Soldiers Recall Tenacious Enemy Attack
description: The first shots were so erratic that they seemed a form of harassment rather than an attack. But then came a rain of unnervingly accurate mortar fire, from opposite directions.

title: CALPERS OPPOSES HEWLETT-COMPAQ DEAL
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System said yesterday that it would vote against the Hewlett-Packard Company's proposed $22.3 billion purchase of the Compaq Computer Corporation. The pension fund, which is based in Sacramento and is known as Calpers, cited what it saw as the high premium being paid for Compaq, the negative financial consequences of the purchase, ''significant integration risks'' and the cost of losing focus on Hewlett-Packard's main businesses. While Calpers owns fewer than 1 percent of Hewlett-Packard's shares, its actions are influential because it is the largest public pension fund in the nation and has a reputation for pressing companies to raise shareholder value.

title: Spacewalkers Tend to Inactive Hubble Camera
description: A supercold refrigeration unit that scientists hope will revive a dormant camera aboard the Hubble Space Telescope was installed there today by a pair of astronauts.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Is Steady
description: Canada's unemployment rate was unchanged at 7.9 percent in February from January, as factory hiring led to an unexpected increase in jobs for the second consecutive month. The economy created a net 5,900 jobs. Manufacturers added 61,600 positions, outweighing declines in education and construction employment, Statistics Canada said. Full-time positions increased by 15,500, while part-time jobs declined by 9,700. Factories, which added workers for the second consecutive month, accounted for most of the gain, the agency said. Retailers, Canada's largest employers, added 500 positions, while transportation and warehousing companies hired 7,100.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Tread Carefully In Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs; After 100 years, William James's 'Varieties,' maybe not flawless, resonates nonetheless.
description: ''Dear Professor James,'' a recent magazine article began. ''A century has passed since you delivered the 20 Gifford Lectures on natural religion at Edinburgh, and published them as 'The Varieties of Religious Experience.' We are celebrating this occasion, my students and I, and your friends around the world, as the 100th birthday of the greatest modern book on personal religion.''

title: Taking Our Liberties
description: The war against terrorism will go on indefinitely, President Bush has warned, seeking the enemy around the world. Already American forces are committed to the Philippines, Georgia and Yemen. Iraq may be next. Heavy fighting continues in Afghanistan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Government Has Prepared Indictment of Andersen

title: Too Many Tests?
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Worst of Seasons, an Unlikely Victory
description: They may be going to the draft lottery, and may be the worst team the franchise has had in at least 15 years, but these Atlantic Division basement-dwelling Knicks did something tonight that Jeff Van Gundy's teams never did: they beat the Utah Jazz in the raucous Delta Center.

title: White House Memo; Bush Is Still Winning War There, But He Begins to Lose Battles Here
description: Ever since Sept. 11, President Bush has used his steady command of the war and his soaring approval ratings to his enormous political advantage. As one aide said not long ago, ''With these kinds of approval ratings, why compromise?''

title: UAL CHANGES PLANS FOR ITS BUSINESS AVIATION UNIT
description: The UAL Corporation will no longer seek outside investors for Avolar, its business aviation subsidiary, reversing a strategy announced late last year. Also, Stuart Oran resigned as president of Avolar, UAL said yesterday. The business jet unit was created to sell the equivalent of ''time share'' interests in the planes. Last May, the board of UAL, which also owns United Airlines, allocated $250 million in seed money for the business. After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, UAL began shopping a majority stake in Avolar to potential private equity investors. No one has stepped forward so far for Avolar, which has placed orders for some $2.5 billion in jets.

title: Buyout Firm May Join Lineup Of Suitors for Global Crossing
description: The Texas Pacific Group, a private investment partnership, is considering a bid for Global Crossing Ltd., the fiber optic cable company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January, a person close to Texas Pacific said yesterday.

title: In Post-Enron World, G.E. Increases the Financial Information in Its Annual Report
description: General Electric, worried that it might be tarred with the Enron brush, released its annual report yesterday with fanfare, saying the financial section ''contains approximately 30 percent more content,'' including more information on results of operating segments.

title: New Torah For Modern Minds
description: Abraham, the Jewish patriarch, probably never existed. Nor did Moses. The entire Exodus story as recounted in the Bible probably never occurred. The same is true of the tumbling of the walls of Jericho. And David, far from being the fearless king who built Jerusalem into a mighty capital, was more likely a provincial leader whose reputation was later magnified to provide a rallying point for a fledgling nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, ELISABETH SLOAN PRATT
description: LIVINGSTON-Elisabeth Sloan Pratt. The Packer Collegiate Institute Board of Trustees, Alumni Board, members of the Alumni Association, faculty and staff deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend and esteemed alumna Elisabeth Sloan Pratt Livingston '25. Through her generosity and years of service and commitment to Packer, Mrs. Livingston has improved the lives of countless Packer students. An Honorary Director of the Alumni Board, she provided counsel and unflagging support to five Heads of School. Betty Livingston will long be remembered for her personal integrity, insistence upon high academic & moral standards, and long range vision for our school. We shall miss our devoted and caring friend.

title: Shelley Mydans, 86, Author and Former P.O.W.
description: Shelley Mydans, a journalist who with her husband, the photographer Carl Mydans, covered the war in Asia in World War II and later wrote a novel based on their 21 months in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp, died on Thursday in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 86.

title: An Editor's Relationship With G.E.'s Former Chief Results in a Resignation
description: The editor of the Harvard Business Review resigned yesterday after members of her staff complained that the preparation of an interview she conducted with John F. Welch Jr. was compromised by her relationship with Mr. Welch, the former chairman and chief executive of General Electric.

title: CUNY and Its Staff Members Agree on New Labor Contract
description: The City University of New York reached a tentative labor contract yesterday with its faculty and staff union, the Professional Staff Congress, in an agreement that both sides said would help CUNY regain its stature.

title: Rebel Tactics Intimidate Colombia Candidates
description: Senator Jaime Lozada's campaign for re-election ended after heavily armed leftist rebels smashed into his apartment in southern Colombia last year and kidnapped his wife and two teenage sons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, KATHLEEN M. (NEE REED)
description: MEYER-Kathleen M. (nee Reed). Of Merrick, NY, on March 8, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Margaret M. and Christopher F. Reed. Devoted wife for 55 years of William J. Loving mother of The Reverend William J. Meyer S.M. of San Antonio, TX, and Christopher F. and his wife, Ann H. of Merrick, Mary Ann C. of Bridgewater, NJ, and Daniel G. and his wife, Catherine M. of North Brunswick, NJ. Loving sister of Thomas C. Reed and his wife, Marion T. of Merrick, NY; sister-in-law, Ruth Meyer of Jackson Heights, NY, and her husband, the late John H. Meyer. Loving cousin of Margaret Jarazzo of Tamarac, FL, and the late James P. Kiernan. Devoted grandmother of Elizabeth A. and Emily J. Meyer of Merrick, NY, and John P. and Christopher H. Meyer of North Brunswick, NJ. Beloved aunt of many nieces and nephews. Formerly employed by the Society of Electrical Engineers, Chase Manhattan Bank and the National Bank of NA. Reposing at N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Avenue, Merrick, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 11 AM, at Cure of Ars Church, Merrick, NY. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Family will receive friends Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Our Lady of Consolation and Good Shepherd Hospice.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Possible Bank Bid
description: The government's program to privatize a number of banks that it acquired during the 1997-98 economic crisis may get a head start with the help of Lehman Brothers. The Wall Street firm may acquire 10 percent of Woori Finance Holding, a government company that owns Hanvit Bank and several smaller banks, according to Woori officials. A Woori spokesman said negotiations with Lehman Brothers could go until June with Lehman Brothers offering nearly $400 million and possibly as much as $1 billion. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Water Utility Sold
description: Scottish Power said it would sell its Southern Water utility for 2.05 billion ($2.9 billion) to First Aqua, a consortium formed for the transaction led by the Royal Bank of Scotland Group. First Aqua will itself try to sell Southern Water to a trade buyer like Vivendi Environment. By shedding Southern Water, Scottish Power will have exited the water business to focus solely on its electricity and natural gas business. The sale will also allow Scottish Power to reduce debt. Proceeds from the deal will be about 300 million more than an alternative plan considered by the company to refinance Southern Water through the sale of bonds. The divestiture will result in lower earnings, a 450 million reduction in net assets and a 40 million good will charge, the company said.

title: After a Filing, Retrial Likely On Killing In Crown Hts.
description: A legal filing yesterday disclosed that the United States solicitor general has ruled out an unusual appeal of the recent decision overturning the convictions of two black men in the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic Jew during racial violence in Crown Heights in 1991.

title: Accurate Defense Helps Couple Win Open Pairs Title
description: Several thousand bridge players arriving here Thursday for the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals were looking forward to 10 days of play that will include the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams and many other events.

title: Saying No to Israel's Occupation
description: In this past week of madness and carnage, hope for peace between Israel and the Palestinians appears impossible. After 35 years of Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza, the two sides seem only to have grown accustomed to assassinations, bombings, terrorist attacks and house demolitions. Each side characterizes its own soldiers as either ''defense forces'' or ''freedom fighters'' when in truth these soldiers take part in war crimes on a daily basis. Daily funerals and thoughts of revenge among Israelis tend to blur the fact that we, the Israelis, are the occupiers. And as much as we live in fear of terrorism and war, it is the Palestinians who suffer more deaths hourly and live with greater fear because they are the occupied.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the challenges of interstellar travel referred imprecisely to the stars nearest Earth's. While Alpha Centauri is the nearest star system, it has three stars; the nearest is Proxima Centauri, 4.2 light-years away. The next nearest is Barnard's star, at 6 light-years -- not the double star Sirius, 8.7 light-years away.

title: Samuel W. Hawley, 92, Ex-Bank Executive
description: Samuel W. Hawley, a former president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, died on Feb. 28 at his home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 92.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Charles W. Pickering, a federal appeals court nominee under fire for his early stands on civil rights, referred imprecisely to the stage of life in which Senator Robert C. Byrd had a Ku Klux Klan connection, apparently the topic of a veiled warning by the White House against using old personal history. Senator Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, joined the Klan in 1942, when he was 24 years old, no longer in his youth, and resigned the next year. He praised the Klan in a letter at age 28, a fact used against him in a 1952 campaign. Mr. Byrd has called his support of the Klan a mistake.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Air Traffic Increases
description: Passenger traffic at BAA's seven British airports rose 0.3 percent in February, to 8.2 million passengers, the first monthly increase since the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Traffic increased on most short-haul routes from one European city to another, mainly because of increased competition from budget airlines like EasyJet and Ryanair. North Atlantic traffic continued to decline compared with last year, dropping 7.7 percent in February, although that slowdown was less than the 31.3 percent falloff recorded in October. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SYLVIA JOSEPHS
description: BERGER-Sylvia Josephs. In her 100th year. Died on March 2, 2002. A woman of extraordinary intelligence and taste; character and grace. Fiercely independent in mind and action. Her midwestern roots were evident in her sense of fairness and ethics. Born and raised in Duluth, MN she graduated from Smith College in 1924 (was the only one to return and participate in her 75th reunion). Attended the Sorbonne, received a law degree from New York University in the late 1920's. She was a pro bono lawyer for 20 years at the Juvenile Court in the Bronx. A seasoned traveller before World War II. She could read Greek, Latin and French; studied Russian language and Russian literature at Hunter College until she was 96. Attended art classes at the Metropolitan Museum and went to the Philharmonic until late last fall. Married to Arthur M. Berger for over 53 years. He predeceased her, as did a brother Irving and son-in-law Daniel Cowin. Survived by daughter Joyce Cowin, three grandchildren Kenneth (Jasmin), Andrew (Allyson), Dana (Barclay Palmer), three great-grandchildren Reagan and Alexandra Cowin, Sylvie Palmer. As well as a sister Muriel Cowan and brother Arthur Josephs (Adrianne) from Duluth, MN. Interment private. A celebration of her life will be held at her daughter's, April 3rd, 4-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Russian Department at Hunter College or the Jewish Studies Program at Smith College.

title: Kmart to Close 284 Stores; 22,000 Jobs Will Be Cut
description: In what may be just the first stage of a long effort to reinvent Kmart, the company said yesterday that it would close 284 stores across the country and eliminate 22,000 jobs. To cover expenses associated with the cuts, the company plans to take a charge of more than $1 billion.

title: U.S. Shifts Gears in Mideast Policy
description: For months, the Bush administration's calculus on the Middle East boiled down to this: rising Israeli-Palestinian violence was brutal but did not threaten strategic American interests, and it was bound to ease in time, paving the way for resumption of peace efforts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNHA, VIVIANE C.B.
description: CUNHA-Viviane C.B., 44. On March 7, 2002 after a long battle against ovarian cancer. Cherished wife of Mark, devoted and loving mother of Nicholas and Celine. Adored daughter of Mario and Paulette Meningaud Sirotto. Treasured sister of Roxane Sirotto. Viviane was vice president of the Parents Assoc of Lycee Francaise de N.Y. (A.P.E.L.), an active member of the Board of French-American Aid for Children, Co-chair of the Debutante Committee at Bal des Berceaux, and a pillar in the Aumonerie Catholique de N.Y. through which she founded a children's choir and initiated fundraising events for the children in favor of the forgotten children of Haiti. Viviane was a kind and gentle woman who touched us all. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, 9:30AM St. Vincent de Paul Church, 123 W. 23 St. Friends may call Sat 2-4 & 7-9 and Sunday 7-9 at Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to French-American Aid for Children, Inc., 575 Madison Ave, Suite 2409, New York, NY 10022.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Council Supports More Iraq Talks
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan briefed the Security Council on his meeting with an Iraqi delegation on Thursday, and the Council encouraged him to continue with the talks. Mr. Annan said he had told the council that the Iraqis had asked for more information on the timetable for lifting sanctions if they agreed to allow arms inspectors to return. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Company Payrolls Show Rise For First Time in Nine Months
description: Companies added workers to their payrolls in February for the first time in nine months, the government said yesterday, the strongest evidence yet that the economy is emerging from the recession.

title: A Town's Public Memory, Its Residents' Private Grief
description: A middle-aged widow rarely gets out of bed when the sun is up. Another staves off the pain with mounds of paperwork and nonstop errands. One young mother, inconsolable and financially overwhelmed, has scared friends with dark suggestions that she and her children might join her husband in heaven. For a mother coping with a lost son, spirituality has become a comfort and a crusade.

title: Microsoft Hearings Are Postponed for a Week
description: The presiding judge in the final stages of the Microsoft antitrust trial today postponed by a week hearings to determine whether the company should face tougher sanctions. She also expressed irritation with the states proposing those sanctions.

title: Ringing In Words Along With Fierce Spirit
description: ''Bright is the ring of words when the right man rings them.'' Singing these words by Robert Louis Stevenson at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, in Vaughan Williams's ''Songs of Travel,'' Bryn Terfel was beyond any question the right man.

title: Blair's Support of Bush on Iraq Is Criticized in His Own Party
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, America's most vocal ally in the war on terrorism, is running into resistance from his party, the British public and some members of his own cabinet for backing President Bush's call for action against Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, FLORENCE
description: BERLINER-Florence. Devoted wife of William. Beloved mother of Jeffrey and Leonard. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Elizabeth, Alanna and Ryan. Services Sunday 1 PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, LI.

title: Philippines Terror Group Seeks Money For Couple
description: A gang of Muslim extremists that has been holding an American missionary couple hostage in the jungles here for nearly 10 months has offered to release them for about $1 million, Philippine officials said today.

title: Adelphi To Face Assumption In Final
description: Adelphi now knows not to take any team for granted.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Files For Bankruptcy
description: Chubu Bank, a midsize lender in Shizuoka Prefecture south of Tokyo, declared itself insolvent because of worries it would run short of cash. Financial regulators found late last year that the bank's capital-to-asset ratio had fallen below 4 percent, the established minimum for domestic banks. The bank said on Thursday it would increase its capital but gave up that effort yesterday, fearing that depositors would pull their money out. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: CHAIRMAN OF ZALE HEADS FOR SECOND RETIREMENT
description: The Zale Corporation said its chairman and chief executive, Robert J. DiNicola, would resign when the company's fiscal year ends July 31. Zale's stock fell $4.35, or 10 percent, to $39.15 a share. The stock had risen 36 percent in the last year. Mr. DiNicola was chairman and chief executive from 1994 to 2000, when he first retired, then rejoined the company in February 2001 at the request of the board. He will become a consultant to Zale, which is based in Irving, Tex., and is the biggest jewelry retailer in the nation.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Plea to Clinton Long Weighed For Fugitive, E-Mail Shows
description: Marc Rich's advisers debated whether to seek a presidential pardon as early as February 2000 but deliberately held off lobbying the White House until ''the closing days'' of the Clinton administration, their private e-mail messages show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPPARD, PAMELA
description: SHEPPARD-Pamela. On March 7th, 2002. Beloved mother of Julian and sister of Ruth. Born in London, she persevered and created a life for herself in New York. Pamela dedicated her life to the arts and her synagogue. She will be greatly missed by friends and family. Services on Monday at 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Thursday about a potential buyout of Imagis Technologies, which makes software for systems that identify people by facial features, misstated the name of an investment firm that has proposed talks about taking Imagis private. It is the Pembridge Group, not Pembroke.

title: Whitewater Prosecutor Considers G.O.P. Senate Bid
description: To an already long list of relatively unknown Republican candidates who want to challenge Senator Robert G. Torricelli this fall, New Jersey voters may have to add one more: Robert W. Ray, the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: Jeter Is Feeling Fine
description: Derek Jeter tested his neck during a batting practice session today and declared himself ready to play shortstop for the Yankees in Saturday's spring training game. Jeter, a player who hates to discuss injuries, could finally admit how much the injury had unnerved him.

title: Tread Carefully In Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: BP May Make Dabhol Bid
description: The British oil company BP said it would bid for the Enron Corporation's stake in Dabhol Power. It is unclear whether a BP bid will be considered by the Industrial Development Bank of India, which leads the Indian creditors in supervising the sale, because it is four weeks past the deadline for bidders to send in expressions of interest. BP would be bidding on Enron's 65 percent stake in the 2,184-megawatt, $2.9 billion power station. BP said Dabhol was a crucial piece of infrastructure that could play an important role in the development of the gas business in India if restructured properly. The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, British Gas and Gaz de France have filed expressions of interest. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Irvington Mayor Says She Will Not Run Again
description: The mayor of Irvington, Sara B. Bost, announced Thursday that she would not seek re-election this spring even as federal investigators continue to look into possible misconduct in City Hall.

title: Boys and Girls High Endures Rough Day
description: Boys and Girls High School of Brooklyn was having an outstanding indoor season until yesterday, the opening day of the three-day national scholastic championships.

title: Group Sues Over Frozen Assets, Saying U.S. Violated Rights
description: The Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development, the largest Muslim charity in the United States, sued the federal government yesterday for labeling it a financier of terrorism and freezing its assets.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Arrest In 1973 Murder
description: Sheriff's deputies in Thurston County arrested a man in a 29-year-old murder case using new DNA evidence from the state crime laboratory, officials said. William E. Cosden Jr., 55, who has been serving an unrelated prison sentence for rape since 1976, was charged in the murder of a 14-year-old Seattle girl, Katherine M. Devine, in 1973; the authorities said this was the oldest murder case using DNA evidence in the state. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Unhappy With Settlement, Sun Sues Microsoft
description: Dissatisfied with the federal government's antitrust settlement with Microsoft, Sun Microsystems filed a private lawsuit today accusing Microsoft of ''choking off'' Sun's Java programming language through illegal behavior.

title: A Movie on Two Channels, One With Cussing
description: Who says television isn't innovative? Tomorrow night ESPN is interrupting its format of sports events and sports talk to offer -- ta-daaa -- a sports movie. The network has been knocking itself out to promote its first dramatic film, ''A Season on the Brink,'' starring Brian Dennehy as Bobby Knight, the notoriously volatile and profane college basketball coach.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Judicial Investigator To Go To Italy
description: The United Nations investigator for the independence of judges and lawyers said he would visit Italy next week to examine judges' complaints that Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's government has tried to undermine their independence. Param Cumaraswamy wrote to the government in January expressing concern over ''nationwide protests by hundreds of magistrates'' who feared Mr. Berlusconi's plan to overhaul the judiciary would undercut them. He will report his findings to the United Nations Human Rights Commission next month. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paul Carbone, 70, Researcher Of Cancer and Its Prevention
description: Dr. Paul Carbone, a cancer researcher who was honored for his work involving Hodgkin's disease, chemotherapy and other aspects of the treatment and prevention of cancer, died on Feb. 22 in Singapore, where he had gone to encourage cancer research. He was 70 and lived in Middleton, Wis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an effort by the United States to close a Canadian drug route for illegal stimulants referred imprecisely to the availability of the decongestant pseudoephedrine. Although it is tightly controlled in the United States when bought and sold in large quantities, it is widely available in retail sales as a component of over-the-counter medicines like Sudafed. The article also classified the drug methamphetamine incorrectly. It is a stimulant, not a narcotic.

title: Manhattanville In Title Game
description: A goal by Melanie Grover 3 minutes 20 seconds into sudden-death overtime last night carried the Manhattanville College women's hockey team to a 2-1 victory over Bowdoin and into the Division III title game.

description: The other day, Mary Zimmerman decided to give Ceres, the goddess of agriculture, a pair of opera glasses.

title: Conversation Mixing Notes And Words
description: Monday night's concert at the Miller Theater by the Da Capo Chamber Players was a lot like one of those sticky dinner parties where the guests have absolutely nothing to say to one another. All the pieces came from the last 20 years or so, but that only heightened their mutual distrust. Michael Gordon's resolutely repetitive and uningratiatingly scored ''ACDC'' made no connection with Nicholas Maw's genial, ruminative Flute Quartet. And both, from their different perspectives, looked askance at the newcomer: ''My 20th Century,'' by Martin Bresnick, which was receiving its world premiere.

title: For Cambodian, a Life Transformed by Dance
description: THERE is a magic door at the back of the big practice hall at the Royal University of Fine Arts where tiny birds swoop through the rafters and there always seems to be incense in the air.

title: Old Arms Now Joining The New Near Gardez
description: Ragged lines of antiquated tanks, with billows of black smoke lifting from their exhaust pipes, chugged today toward the Shah-i-Kot Mountains as the first of 1,000 Afghan reinforcements headed for what was billed as the climactic push of American-led forces against Al Qaeda and Taliban soldiers holed up in high-altitude caves.

title: Disposing of Nuclear Wastes
description: The Bush administration is moving forward with plans to bury highly radioactive waste from the nation's nuclear power plants and bomb-making facilities at Yucca Mountain, a remote desert site in Nevada. The move is being justified as a way to make the material less vulnerable to terrorists and to help domestic and military nuclear programs. But there is only one truly persuasive reason to push the process forward now. It is time to determine, once and for all, whether Yucca Mountain is a suitable disposal site, or whether the nation will need to look elsewhere.

title: The Updated Face of Electronic Composition
description: As part of its 30th-anniversary season, the Kitchen is presenting ''Electronic X-travaganza,'' a three-day electronic music festival that opened on Thursday evening and runs through tonight. The prospectus includes a few retrospective glimpses: works by David Behrman, for example, that had their first performances during the Kitchen's early years. Mostly, though, this is a festival of new work by young composers and ensembles, and even the 1970's works by Mr. Behrman are reconfigured to account for updated technology.

title: Nets Have Little Chance Against Red-Hot Blazers
description: The Nets wore grim faces in the fourth quarter tonight as they continued their somber march through the Western Conference, unable to find answers or victories.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Old Foe Of Mobutu Seeks Presidency
description: tienne Tshisekedi, the longtime opposition leader to the late Mobutu Sese Seko, has declared his candidacy for the presidency. Mr. Tshisekedi, 69, whose political importance has greatly diminished during the nearly four-year Congo war, said that he would not take part in a national unity government headed by President Joseph Kabila and that Mr. Kabila should be replaced. He made those comments in Sun City, South Africa, where peace talks finally began after a two-week delay. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Enron Sought To Raise Cash Two Years Ago
description: Less than two years ago, amid some of the earliest signs that the Enron Corporation was beginning to falter, the company failed to complete a deal to sell the bulk of its international energy holdings for about $7 billion to a group composed primarily of wealthy Middle Eastern investors, according to individuals involved with the negotiations.

description: STERN-Arieh I. Beloved husband of Tobi, passed away March 7, after a long and courageous battle with lung cancer. He is survived by his wonderful family and friends. Service Sunday, 11:30 AM, Plaza Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Will Fingerprinting Stand Up in Court?
description: In 1993, when the Supreme Court demanded real scientific standards for expert evidence in federal courts, some critics correctly anticipated that several criminal identification techniques would be attacked in the courts with some success: microscopic hair comparison, bite mark analysis, handwriting comparison. Few, if any, predicted what is happening now: The bedrock forensic identifier of the 20th century, fingerprinting, has started to wobble.

title: U.S. Is Called Ready To Indict Audit Firm Over Enron Papers
description: Federal prosecutors have prepared a multicount criminal indictment charging Arthur Andersen & Company with obstruction of justice in the Enron case, people involved in the matter said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Nebraska: Gay Adoption Effort Denied
description: The state Supreme Court refused to let a Lincoln woman adopt her gay partner's 3-year-old son, but left undecided the larger issue of gay adoption. The mother became pregnant in 1997 by artificial insemination. The child has lived with his mother and her companion since birth. The court, which did not identify the women, said the child was not eligible for adoption because his mother had not given up her parental rights. The court did not address whether a gay couple could adopt a child whose parents had ceded their rights. Daniel I. Dorfman (NYT)

title: Needed to Cover Arizona District: A Jet
description: Anyone who wants to run for the House of Representatives in Arizona's First Congressional District will need more than money. A dependable car would be a major asset. So would spare tires.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the decision by President Bush to send Gen. Anthony C. Zinni to the Middle East to try to quell the Israeli-Palestinian violence misstated the timing of the general's most recent trip to the region. It was in early January, not late last year.

title: Pataki Sets April 16 Date For Election In Queens
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has set April 16 as the date of a special election to be held for an Assembly seat in Queens that was left vacant by the death this year of Pauline Rhodd-Commings, a Democrat.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Secret Files On Kohl To Stay Secret
description: A Berlin court ruled that files compiled by the East German secret police on Helmut Kohl must not be released to journalists and historians. The ruling came after the government custodian of the files appealed a court ruling Mr. Kohl won last year blocking their release; he said publication would violate his privacy. The new ruling will be a precedent for other cases involving the files of public figures. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: The Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, called today ''Black Friday'' because of the high Palestinian death toll, and Arab foreign ministers demanded that the United States and the United Nations intervene immediately to restrain Israel's actions in the West Bank and Gaza.

description: SHEF-Angela (nee Drapczyk). On March 7, 2002 at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Loving sister of the late Casimira Cyzewski & Jeanette Ostrowski. description: Sometimes, in the rarefied world of opera, you have to resort to jargon to describe a performance. Here, then, is an assessment of ''Adriana Lecouvreur'' by Francesco Cilea, as presented by the Opera Orchestra of New York at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night: it was over-the-top verismo; the singers chewed up the scenery; Aprile Millo had a triumph; and Marcello Giordani sang like a god.

description: In a stance that is likely to keep the United States on a collision course with Saddam Hussein's government, a senior Bush administration official warned today that United Nations weapons inspections would be a trap unless the monitors had immediate and unrestricted access to any site in Iraq.

description: GLOVER-Ernest. March 6, 2002. Age 96. Loving father of Barbara and Hilary, grandfather to Paul, Jo, Louise and Sally; son-in-laws Ron and Peter. Memorial service at St. Lukes, Easthampton, Sunday, March 10, at 3:00 PM. He was loved by all who ever met him.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Nuclear Disaster Tips
description: In case of a nuclear disaster near Irish shores, people should stay indoors and take government-distributed iodine tablets to avoid absorbing radiation, according to a brochure mailed to every home in Ireland. The mailing follows a dispute between Britain and Ireland over the Sellafield nuclear processing plant in western England, 60 miles from Dublin, which has failed to pass several security and maintenance tests. Last year, Ireland's case at a European court governing maritime law failed to prevent England from processing additional types of nuclear materials at the plant. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: A new wave in Tokyo pursues the next Cool Look
description: TOKYO  The economy is in shambles. The nation is going down the tubes. Amid the moans and groans, it seems like the only bastion of mental security, the examples of real creativity, are in fashion.

description: Molly Huddle is a high school runner without a team, but that has not stopped her from becoming this season's Alan Webb in the girls' mile.

title: After Filing Taxes, Keep Those Records
description: The desks in many homes are brimming with tax-related papers this time of year. In some households, the 1099's, W-2's and other documents may be piled up on the dining-room table. Wherever the paperwork, most people probably can't wait for the day when they can toss it all away. Not so fast, the experts say.

title: Canal Crossing
description: To the Editor: Your fine article on the Panama Canal, ''Lock by Lock, Across the Isthmus,'' (Feb. 3), did not explain one major step in the intricate movement of ships in the locks. How does the cable connecting the ships to the locomotives (mules) become attached?

title: Oscar Films/View From Abroad; Feeding National Pride In a World Gone Ga-Ga
description: THE broadcast rights to the Academy Awards are sold to dozens of countries around the world every year, and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences likes to boast that the show reaches some one billion viewers. Skeptics, in turn, like to point out that there are not enough Nielsen ratings boxes scattered across the globe to substantiate that claim.

title: Blocking a Building's Side Windows
description: Q I rent a one-bedroom apartment in a five-story building in Manhattan. The building was built right up to the property line and the side windows used a light well of an adjacent apartment building. Recently, the building next door was demolished and the new building being built has a wall that will close off all the windows on the side of my building. This means that my three-room apartment now has only one room with natural light and ventilation. Is this a violation of the Building Code? Can the new building be forced to duplicate the previous light well? . . . C. Bjone, Manhattan.

title: CREATURES OF A FEATHER
description: Paleontologists in China have unearthed fossils of a dinosaur the size of a pheasant. But that was not the 125-million-year-old creature's only avian resemblance. Though not a bird and incapable of flight, it was covered with feathers remarkably like those of modern birds. The discoverers said the specimen should settle once and for all two issues in evolutionary history. Feathers evolved before birds and for some purpose other than flight. And birds are somehow descended from dinosaurs. John Noble Wilford

description: CROSSING OVER

title: Ideas & Trends: Game Plan; Where Does Phase 2 Start? In Afghanistan
description: AFTER the Taliban were driven out of power in Afghanistan, the Bush administration put out the word that it was time to go global with ''Phase 2.'' In the next phase of the campaign against terror, American forces and their allies would pursue the remnants of Al Qaeda around the world. The United States might even continue the crusade by marching on Baghdad to take on Saddam Hussein.

title: ONE MORE CLINTON REPORT
description: The independent counsel released his final report on President Clinton's dalliance with Monica Lewinsky, an event that seemed to many a relic of an earlier time -- despite her virtually simultaneous appearance on an HBO special. The report said that Mr. Clinton could have been convicted of two felony charges but Robert W. Ray, the prosecutor, declined to indict because he concluded that Mr. Clinton had paid enough penalties in public criticism, surrender of his law license and his admission that he lied when he denied an intimate relationship with Ms. Lewinsky. Neil A. Lewis

title: Music; Adding a Dimension to His Work, Literally
description: THE name Rafal Olbinski may ring no bell for you. Odds are you know his paintings, however. A contemporary surrealist, he has graced the covers of magazines like Time, Business Week and Der Spiegel, illustrating reports on globalization, new frontiers in psychotherapy, the rise of the yen: huge, abstract themes, crystallized in images as startling as they are nail-on-the-head.

title: Investing; A Winter of Turmoil Could Make Irish Stock Exchange a Target
description: IRISH winters don't come much harsher than this. The sleepy Irish stock exchange, accustomed to steady and predictable returns, has been rocked by problems at two of the country's biggest companies, dragging down the benchmark ISEQ index by nearly 12 percent since January.

description: Readers responded to Margaret Talbot's article about attitude makeovers for ''Mean Girls'' with hundreds of letters. Many recalled their own encounters with cliques -- and, surprisingly, some stuck up for them. Others had fun comparing Alpha Girls to the pundits in Frank Rich's essay.

In 1971, Mick and Keith and the boys communed in France to record ''Exile on Main Street.'' Other rockers made the pilgrimage. Anita Pallenberg and Bianca came along for the ride. And men have been dreaming of their relaxed way of being, dressing and loving ever since.

title: Yanks Take Another Chance On the Potential of Rivera
description: Like so many others, Chris Gomez was in awe of Ruben Rivera. Gomez, Rivera's teammate with the San Diego Padres, would watch Rivera hit off a tee or take underhanded soft-toss during batting practice. With only himself to supply the power, Rivera launched balls into the upper reaches of Qualcomm Stadium.

title: The Bold Geometry Of Swiss Poster Art
description: A SHOW at the Hofstra Museum here offers Long Islanders a rare look at Swiss poster design, which is notable for its bold geometric structure and dynamic interplay of form and content.

description: Mexican authorities arrested Benjamn Arellano Flix, the chief of the nation's most powerful and violent drug gang, early this morning, Mexican and American officials said.

title: The Rev. Robert V. Lott, 62; Helped the Poor of East Harlem
description: The Rev. Robert V. Lott, a Roman Catholic priest who played a leading role in the building of low-rent housing and an assisted-care residence in East Harlem, died on Feb. 27 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 62.

title: Oenophile's Hike (With Stops) in France
description: The wine-producing village of Rasteau, 25 miles north of Avignon, will hold its third annual ''Escapade des Gourmets'' hike on May 12. All the training anyone needs for this relaxing ramble can be done in the nearest French bistro. Participants on the three-and-a-half-mile trek through the idyllic Ctes du Rhne vineyards will make frequent stops to sample the area's wines, local cheeses and regional specialties like Provenal meat pies. Accompanied by musicians, groups of 100 hikers leave Rasteau's village square every 10 minutes between 11:20 a.m. and 1:40 p.m. with wineglasses (supplied by the event planners) in hand.

title: Private Sector; A Soft-Drink Substitution, But No Hard Feelings
description: A funny thing happened at the United Negro College Fund awards dinner honoring those who have supported minority education. One of the two award recipients, Douglas N. Daft, chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company, didn't show up.

title: Two U.S. High School Indoor Records Are Set at Armory
description: Samantha Shepard cleared 13 feet 4 1/4 inches in the pole vault and Sanya Richards won a heat of the girls' 200 meters in 23.41 seconds to set United States indoor records yesterday in the national scholastic indoor championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEVETT, ROBERT
description: SHEVETT-Robert. Died on March 7, 2002, at 75 years of age. Bob was an extraordinary man who lived his life heartily. He was a profound influence in all of our lives-his wife Barbara Rosenthal, his children Sarah and David Shevett, his grandchildren Josh Barry and Zachary Shevett, and Sasha, Zachary and Jacob Rosenthal, his siblings Janice Shevett, Gershen Shevett, Irene Spoelstra, his nephews Matt, Leon and Morgan, and his niece Holli, and great-nephews Dylan and Sam, and great-niece Paula Rachel, and his many good friends and business associates and acquaintances. Bob will be remembered for his remarkable connection to everyone who was fortunate enough to have known him. An afternoon of memories, music, humor, food and wine will celebrate his life and mourn his death on Sunday, March 10, at 3 PM, at his home.

description: LONG ISLAND'S building industry is increasingly accepting the idea of tapping the earth's energy for inexpensive, nonpolluting means of heating and cooling facilities.

title: Better Behaved Cowboys
description: Clint Eastwood will not star in the movie version of Russell Freedman's IN THE DAYS OF THE VAQUEROS: America's First True Cowboys (Clarion, $18; ages 8 and up). There is no role for the loner, the sheriff or the storied outlaw. Freedman could have written this account as a wild narrative of one man's life on the range; instead, he paints a sober, fascinating landscape with striking and evocative details of the life's work of a group of men. His aim is to redress the absence of Mexican cowboys from the legends of the West. ''The North American cowboy learned his trade from the Mexican vaquero,'' he writes, but the underpaid vaqueros worked without respect even before the arrival of the lighter-skinned Anglos.

title: Sports of The Times; Bob Knight Delivers His Rebuttal to Indiana in His Autobiography
description: BOB KNIGHT is center stage again, in three different theaters. His Texas Tech basketball team is expected to be included in the national tournament tonight. He's being played by Brian Dennehy in tonight's ESPN movie, ''A Season on the Brink,'' with and without what is advertised as ''intense adult language.'' His autobiography, ''Knight: My Story'' (St. Martin's Press, $25.95), written with Bob Hammel, is on the way to the bookstores. And it's not in the Indiana University bookstore yet.

title: Private Sector; The Director Who Stood Alone
description: Morris Offit, a former Wachovia board member, is gloating a bit over the obsession with corporate governance since the Enron scandal. Mr. Offit joined the board of Wachovia, the North Carolina bank, in 1999, after selling his money management company, Offitbank, to Wachovia. Last spring, after a hostile bid by SunTrust, he was the lone board member to oppose the bank's friendly merger with a rival, First Union. Mr. Offit said he lacked enough information to evaluate the bid. ''It was a due diligence issue,'' he said.

description: The influx of strong Russian players in America in the last two decades has prompted hard feelings on the part of the local grandmasters. The newcomers were almost universally regarded as trespassers in a place where chess remuneration has always been considered anemic.

title: An Awakening From the Nightmare of the Taliban
description: THE reopening of the National Gallery in Kabul in February took place in the dark. The electricity was out again, a casualty of war, and no one could get the gallery's generator to work. A certain grimness lingered in the air. More striking than much of the art was a special display of the ripped-up drawings and broken frames left by the Taliban, lest anyone forget.

title: Your Home; Getting Pure Water At Home
description: AS water levels in area reservoirs decrease, sediment-clouded water is appearing in some homes and apartments, and many homeowners and renters are turning to water filtration devices to ensure the delivery of clean, safe water to their taps, spigots and shower heads.

In the Region/Westchester; Yonkers Waterfront Projects Move Ahead

After more than four decades of promises and plans that went no further than the drawing board, new construction is occurring on the once-decaying industrial site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEN, SHIH, CHANG
description: SHEN-Shih-Chang. Of San Francisco, CA, formerly of Hamden, CT, died on March 5, 2002 at the age of 90. Born in Shanghai, China, he received his BS from Yenching University, his MD from Peking Union Medical College, and his PhD from Cambridge University, England. Dr. Shen was named director of the National Institute of Physiology in Shanghai, but the outbreak of World War II prevented him from returning to his homeland to assume that post. From 1948 to 1958 he was a professor of zoology at Yale University and from 1958 to 1975 he taught in the field of anatomy and neurophysiology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. He is survived by his wife Clara; his son Theodore, his daughters Linda Shen, Joan Woo and Corinne Wong; six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean
description: Talbot's article hit home. When I was in middle school, I was taught to ignore the exclusionary huddles, whispers, backs turned. I continue to be motivated by this period in my life; it has taught me how not to treat others and that self-respect and respecting others are paramount.

title: Personal Business; Keys to a Rental Villa May Be Cheaper Than You Think
description: AMONG cost-conscious travelers, the thought of renting a villa is unlikely to spring to mind. But some of these rentals are surprisingly affordable, especially if you're traveling with a group or a large family.

title: Aldrich's Music Series Has Contemporary Edge
description: A MONTHLY music series at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, a town that has no bars or music clubs, is drawing a growing audience of people interested in contemporary music who might otherwise travel to Manhattan to hear the top-name performers showcased.

title: A Soldier, as Remembered by People Whose Lives He Touched
description: An Army chaplain knocked at the door of Dave and Judith Anderson's Florida bungalow Monday night with the news about their 30-year-old son, Marc, an Army Ranger. An hour and a lifetime later, Mr. Anderson was stoically dialing the phone, spreading the word through the grapevine of Marc Anderson's friends in this Ohio steel town, where he grew up, and across Florida, where he was a college track star and a teacher.

title: Sudan's War Bars Cure For Disease Eradicated In Other Parts of Africa
description: The Khartoum Hilton was fully booked this week.

title: COMING UP
description: Vice President Dick Cheney leaves today to discuss possible moves against Iraq in London, Israel, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Yemen and Turkey. On Tuesday, President Bush speaks on volunteerism and meets with officials from Russia and Uzbekistan. Later in the week, he meets with leaders from Northern Ireland and Canada. The Senate debates energy policy; the House continues Enron hearings.

title: Rare Cancer Found in Workers
description: IN June 1999, an otherwise healthy John Shea had a seizure at his home in Meriden. He was rushed to the hospital. The diagnosis: a rare form of cancer known as a glioblastoma multiforme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MOSES
description: SHAPIRO-Moses. Beloved husband of Ethel. Devoted father of Naomi and Richard Resnick, Louise and Robert Cohen. Dear brother of Jessica Gribetz. Loving uncle and brother-in-law. Adored grandfather of Deborah, Ilana, Sarah and David. Highly respected member of the community. Retired Deputy Treasurer of Revlon. Former Chairman of the Board of Cejwin Camps. Member of the Board of Bay Terrace Jewish Center; Treasurer of Bay Terrace Cooperative Section VIII. Services Sunday 10:00 AM at Schwartz Bros., Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Sprawl-Weary Los Angeles Builds Up and In
description: Look up the word sprawl in the dictionary, the joke goes, and there is the City of Angels and the dirty halo of dispiriting words it contributed to the urban lexicon: smog, suburban wasteland, Blade Runner.

title: Can America Quench Its Thirst?
description: To the Editor:

title: Staten Island Journal; Nice Lot. Just Get Rid of the Ornate Old House.
description: Mud Lane, a neighborhood in Staten Island, has the feel of another century. Dozens of rambling century-old houses line the narrow streets -- each unique and ornate. ''They're gorgeous,'' said one neighborhood resident. ''A beauty to behold.''

title: Pilgrims From the Great Satan
description: SEARCHING FOR HASSAN

title: Remembered Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes/The Wyoming Apartments, at 55th Street and Seventh Avenue; Elegant 1906 Building in French Renaissance Style
description: THE elegant, sprawling Wyoming, a giant 1906 French Renaissance-style apartment building at 55th Street and Seventh Avenue, could be called a distant descendant of the Dakota, at 72nd Street and Central Park West. The 1906 building replaced an earlier Wyoming, which had been built by same the developer-architect team that put up its northern ancestor.

title: Pink Elephants
description: ''Hello, hello.'' There was crackling on the cell phone. ''Can you come to Bhapji's birthday?'' The call was from an Indian friend, someone who knew me well enough to make the offhand suggestion that I hop a plane and travel 8,000 miles for a party.

title: TRY CUTTING BACK
description: Long-term exposure to the smallest particles of air pollution, far tinier than those that smear urban windowpanes, increases the chance of dying from lung cancer, researchers reported, after an analysis of 16 years of data on 500,000 city dwellers' confirmed a long-suspected link. Such particles come mainly from power plants and diesel engines. Over all, the scientists said, living in a moderately polluted American city raises risks of heart and lung ailments as much as living with a smoker. But that was good news, they said: a generation ago, it was more like smoking a pack a day. Andrew C. Revkin

title: The Nation; Beyond Tariffs: Why Steel Isn't Dead
description: A CENTURY ago, United States Steel was the Microsoft of its time, and Andrew Carnegie was his era's Bill Gates. Steel was the essential building block for the rest of the economy: automobiles, locomotives, refrigerators, building girders, oil derricks, factory machinery.

title: Skipping Through Life In Rose-Colored Glasses
description: ''YOU'RE not going to be dreary on the inside if you're not dreary on the outside,'' said Alexandra Stoddard, vibrating slightly in a hot pink silk Shantung suit from Shanghai Tang. ''I get all dressed up in fuchsia, looking like a clown, and show pretty pictures to people.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about a group of artists who meet at a Starbucks in Englewood each week misidentified the one who is planning to marry her college sweetheart. She is Marietta Burrowes, not Louise Schwartz.

title: London Taxis Cost More at Night
description: Evening fares for London's black taxis were recently increased by the city government in a move to encourage more drivers to work between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m.

title: Will It Play in Novosibirsk?
description: HOMO ZAPIENS

title: 14 Israelis Killed in Two Terror Attacks
description: At least 14 Israelis were killed Saturday evening, one a baby, in two Palestinian terror attacks -- one at a popular cafe in Jerusalem, and another on a seaside promenade in Netanya. The attacks underscored the enormous challenges facing America's renewed peacemaking efforts.

title: Builders Flourished In Bad Times. Now What?
description: THE nation's home builders have flourished despite the economic downturn, and investors who have stuck with them have benefited handsomely.

title: Round Isn't Everything in World of Melons
description: ''I'M a melon maniac with a mission,'' Amy Goldman said last week. The former psychologist-turned gardener grows about 100 varieties of the ancient gourd on a one-acre sunny plot on her mostly wooded 200 acres in Rhinebeck, N.Y. That same plot accommodates, incredibly, about 50 varieties of squashes, 50 kinds of hardshell gourds, 250 varieties of tomatoes and 150 different hot peppers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNELLER, ARTHUR J.
description: SCHNELLER-Arthur J. On March 8, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Virginia. Loving father of Jon and Arthur. Cherished grandfather of Bradley and Morgan. Third generation owner of A. Schneller Sons Upholstery Company in New York City. Reposing at Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy). Religious service Monday 12:30 P.M. at the funeral home. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, L.I. Visiting on Sunday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Nassau Ends Contract With Arts Group
description: IN a move that the Suozzi administration says will save money and expand the scope of cultural programming the county supports, Nassau County will not renew its contract with the Long Island Partnership for Cultural Development, a nonprofit private group that runs arts programs with county money. The county's Recreation and Parks Department, led by its new commissioner, Doreen Banks, will take over those functions now.

title: Still Awake? Count Sleep Centers, Not Sheep
description: WHAT Adam Axinn really needed was a good night's sleep. Mr. Axinn, 28, was exhausted, plagued by constant fatigue. A loud snorer, he woke up frequently night after night gasping for breath. Heading off in the morning to his job running a mental health residence, he rarely felt refreshed.

title: DROUGHT EMERGENCY
description: New Jersey has experienced the driest February -- and the driest fall and winter -- since record-keeping began in 1895, which prompted Governor McGreevey to declare a water emergency last week. The declaration enables the Department of Environmental Protection to impose mandatory water restrictions, expected to be announced this week. Rainfall last month averaged 0.76 inches; the average February rainfall is 2.96 inches. Rainfall since September has totaled 10.08 inches, well below the previously driest fall and winter, 1939-40, with 13.96 inches. Karen DeMasters

title: Theater; When Your Characters Are Speechless, Let 'Em Sing!
description: IT is a much quoted maxim that there are only seven stories. They are, apparently, Orpheus, Achilles, Cinderella, Tristan and Isolde, Circe, Romeo and Juliet, and Faust. All other stories are adaptations of these.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SYLVIA JOSEPHS
description: BERGER-Sylvia Josephs. In her 100th year. Died on March 2, 2002. A woman of extraordinary intelligence and taste; character and grace. Fiercely independent in mind and action. Her midwestern roots were evident in her sense of fairness and ethics. Born and raised in Duluth, MN she graduated from Smith College in 1924 (was the only one to return and participate in her 75th reunion). Attended the Sorbonne, received a law degree from New York University in the late 1920's. She was a pro bono lawyer for 20 years at the Juvenile Court in the Bronx. A seasoned traveller before World War II. She could read Greek, Latin and French; studied Russian language and Russian literature at Hunter College until she was 96. Attended art classes at the Metropolitan Museum and went to the Philharmonic until late last fall. Married to Arthur M. Berger for over 53 years. He predeceased her, as did a brother Irving and son-in-law Daniel Cowin. Survived by daughter Joyce Cowin, three grandchildren Kenneth (Jasmin), Andrew (Allyson), Dana (Barclay Palmer), three great-grandchildren Reagan and Alexandra Cowin, Sylvie Palmer. As well as a sister Muriel Cowan and brother Arthur Josephs (Adrianne) from Duluth, MN. Interment private. A celebration of her life will be held at her daughter's, April 3rd, 4-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Russian Department at Hunter College or the Jewish Studies Program at Smith College.

title: Business; Anthrax and Anxiety
description: The anthrax scare in October sent tens of thousands of people rushing to their doctors for Cipro, causing a nationwide shortage and fear that there were not enough powerful antibiotics. Many people began to criticize Bayer, the maker of Cipro, and other drug companies, saying they tried to profit in a crisis. But the frenzy did not last.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Sphinx Competition for young black and Latino string players misidentified the lone black player in the New York Philharmonic. He is Jerome Ashby, a horn player; Sanford Allen, a violinist, who is also black, is a former member of the Philharmonic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about new financial aid for middle-class families with children in private schools misstated the name of a research group that conducted a study about private-school enrollment. It is Public Agenda, not Public Agency.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: At a Street Market, Bruised Fruit, Summonses and Rats
description: The vegetables are cheap, even by Chinatown standards. A dollar buys a pound of mustard greens, or two pounds of bok choy, or four pounds of yellow onions. But the ramshackle market, operating daily in front of Confucius Plaza along Division Street, is facing strong opposition from tenants and might be closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZER, SARAH (SALLY)
description: SCHNITZER-Sarah (Sally). On March 8. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Dear sister of Harry Sussman. Loving aunt and great-aunt. Services today, 1:00 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI.

title: Relax. It's Spring.
description: After the year we've had, thank God it's spring. Designers obviously factored in all that stress, because what paraded down the runway this season seemed better suited to weekend getaways than corporate power plays. So, if you must wear a suit, take it down a notch, like the guy on our cover: Hayden Christensen. Appearing in the latest ''Star Wars'' spectacle, ''Episode II: Attack of the Clones,'' and on the London stage in Kenneth Lonergan's ''This Is Our Youth,'' Christensen is making a name for himself as Hollywood's latest It Boy and as the model every designer wants to dress. He certainly epitomizes the nonchalance of the season -- lots of lived-in denim, T-shirts and sexy leather jackets, basically the same look that the Rolling Stones bequeathed the world, circa 1971, when they were hanging out in the South of France. (Photographs of that raucous summer, from the book ''Exile,'' decorate our opening pages.)

title: Touched by a Scandal, Bishop Stays Silent
description: THE country watched in sadness and outrage as the case unfolded in Boston: a Roman Catholic priest, John J. Geoghan Jr., had sexually molested more than 130 children over 30 years as church officials transferred the troubled priest from parish to parish despite knowing him to be a pedophile.

title: Noosa: Surf With a Side Of Latte
description: I REMEMBER my first day in Noosa; it was in the late 1960's, and I was 12. I can still smell the earthy scent of eucalyptus and hoop pine, and feel the warm sandy paths of the Noosa National Park on my bare feet as I walked out to the wide wild beach of Alexandria Bay.

title: Enron vs. the 70's
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Crossing's Woes Echo in a Distant Warehouse
description: Global Crossing's financial struggles have not only put the company's future in doubt, but, on a smaller scale, they have also affected the future of one of Clinton's massive old warehouses.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Watch column last Sunday, about a bullish report by Lehman Brothers on the stock of Alloy Inc., a direct marketer and media company, misstated the report's description of the relationship between Lehman and Alloy. The report said that Lehman underwrote Alloy shares recently; it did not say that any analyst who contributed to the report, or any member of such an analyst's household, owned Alloy stock.

title: Is Anybody Regulating Cellphone Antennas?
description: Long before pieces of the ceiling fell on his neighbor, Alex Medwedew had misgivings about the cellphone antenna being installed atop his five-story building at 200 West 106th Street, at Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Center That Keeps Its Eyes On the Road
description: SHORTLY after 8:30 on a recent Monday morning, there was trouble on Interstate 95 -- again. That came as no surprise to workers in the mission control-like Operations Center of the State Department of Transportation in Bridgeport, where one of more than 30 television monitors showed a downed light pole that had narrowly missed a red GMC pick-up truck and blocking all three westbound lanes on the interstate near exit 24 in Fairfield.

description: It looks as if Robeson and Lincoln will now be able to finish what they started.
