description: As if waiting for the results of the SAT test did not provoke enough anxiety among high school students, those who register online to take the test now face a new source of tension.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALPERN, WILLIAM
description: ALPERN-William Dear Daddy. Not a day goes by that I don't think about you. Your loving daughter.

title: Hubble Returning to Mission Able to Peer Deeper Into Space
description: The space shuttle Columbia released a reinvigorated Hubble Space Telescope today 365 miles above Earth, sending the orbiting observatory away with new eyes to continue its probings of the universe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBELMAN, JEANETTE
description: SOBELMAN-Jeanette. 95, died peaceably in Ithaca, NY March 5, 2002. She leaves her daughter Rosalind Feinstein of Ithaca and son Rabbi George Sobelman of Rehovot, Israel -grandchildren-Jonathan, Eric and Roger Feinstein, Batsheva Shimon, Gabriella Himmel, Ariel and Daniel Sobelman -greatgrandchildren-Isabel, Aviv, Yoav and Yahel. She now rests at Cedar Park in Paramus with parents Jacob and Sadie Silberman surronded by her devoted husband Julius J. Sobelman and dear brothers Oscar, Max and Abner Silver.

title: Island Shows Weakness In Jobs Picture
description: Long Island added about 6,700 jobs last year, less than a quarter of the growth registered the previous year, while unemployment rose to 4.4 percent in January, up from 3.1 percent in January 2001, according to an employment report released on Tuesday by the state Labor Department.

title: CALIFORNIA DREAMING
description: The morning after the Republican primary for governor in California, Bill Simon Jr. said, ''I had to pinch myself.'' He was not the only one. Mr. Simon shut out Richard J. Riordan, the former Los Angeles mayor, who only weeks ago was riding high with a double-digit lead in the polls. Mr. Simon, a political unknown and wealthy investor, benefited from a $10 million ad campaign that Gov. Gray Davis ran against Mr. Riordan. Richard L. Berke

title: Music for Extrovert Yogis and Others
description: Soundtracks are migrating from the cineplex into real life to accompany the activities of the unfilmed everyday. At the Sonic Yoga studio on Ninth Avenue and 51st Street, classes in Soundtrack Yoga swap traditional soothing chants for club lighting and pounding dance music tracked to fit the class's choreography. During a 75-minute session ($16 a class, 212-397-5865), students do vigorous sun salutations to songs by No Doubt and the D. J.'s Sasha and Digweed, and wind down to mellower tunes by Sigur Ros and Sarah McLachlan. ''The rhythm of the yoga matches the soundtrack, one breath per beat,'' said Jonathan Fields, the instructor, who was a college D. J. before his incarnation as a yoga teacher. For those who prefer less exertion, Motel Records has released ''Cinemaphonics 2: Soul Punch'' ($14.99), a CD of 1970's British ''library music'' (music originally recorded for films but never used), which contains funky tracks like ''Mile High Swinger'' and ''Flute Salad.'' And in time for the Academy Awards on March 24, the British Film Institute has published ''Pop Music in British Cinema,'' by K. J. Donnelly (BFI Publishing, $22.50), a smart little volume that chronicles the impact on the movies of artists from the Sex Pistols to the Spice Girls. JENNIFER TUNG

title: A Foul Wind
description: There is something about this new, intensely violent, stage of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict that is starting to feel like the fuse for a much larger war of civilizations. You can smell it in the incredibly foul wind blowing through the Arab-Muslim world these days. It is a wind that is fed by many sources: the (one-sided) Arab TV images of Israelis brutalizing Palestinians, the Arab resentment of America's support for Israel and its threat against Iraq, the frustrations of young Arabs with their own lack of freedom and jobs. But once these forces are all bundled together, they express themselves in the most heated anti-Israeli and anti-American sentiments that I've ever felt.

title: Theater; As Targets Evolve, So Must the Satire
description: WHEN ''Forbidden Broadway,'' the revue that extols and lambastes the Fabulous Invalid called Broadway, approached its 20th anniversary this year, I thought, ''How wonderful.'' Not entirely because, as the show's writer and co-director, I had a job in theater that had entered its third decade, but because I also thought: ''Oh, good! I can do a retrospective and I won't have to write anything new. I'll pick a few favorites from my catalog of 450 parodies and then go off to Hawaii and listen to the new CD of 'Subways Are for Sleeping.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKINSON, CLINTON J.
description: ATKINSON-Clinton J. 74, died suddenly on March 4, in his summer home in Craryville, NY. He was in high spirits-and then he left us, a good death for him, difficult for family and friends. Clint was a professional theater director, at Long Island Stage and many other theaters, the latest, New York State Theater in Albany. He taught drama at Vassar, Wesleyan, SUNY Albany. He was born and raised in the Canal Zone, Panama, educated at William and Mary, and Yale, and was a lieutenant in the Korean War. His beloved family-wife Lois, sons Matthew and Seth, daughters-in-law Wendy and Oak, grandsons Blake and Kirk-feel blessed by having had this unique man and mind in their lives, a bibliophile, host, jam maker, mensch. A memorial service in NYC will be announced later. Donations would be appreciated to Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave, PO Box 56322, Montgomery, AL 36177-7459.

title: Music; Elton John and Billy Joel, Talking About Songs
description: AT a time when the music industry is jittery about its very future, two veteran artists are touring together and selling out shows as if the boom times of the 90's had never ended. Billy Joel and Elton John's Face to Face tour, which stops in the New York area for nine arena shows beginning at Madison Square Garden on Friday, serves up a staggering array of hits that fans regard as well worth the money even at a top ticket price of $175. The shows, in which the two men perform each other's songs both together and separately, are noteworthy at a time when attention-addled listeners are increasingly focused on specific songs, rather than albums, and find few artists worthy of their continued support.

title: Mullet Mania
description: ''I worship the mullet,'' declares Matt Smith, an avid mullet hunter from Hiawassee, Ga., and cast member on MTV's ''Real World New Orleans.'' ''I think it gets in tune with our primitive roots. When I think of mullets, I think of early-80's Firebirds, fistfights and spit. I think of mustaches -- they always go well with mullets. And netted baseball caps. He adds, ''I think of the WWF when it was real.''

title: Reclining Dudes
description: Slim silhouettes. Sleek tailoring. Slender ankle boots with nary a welt. Now that your new and improved 21st-century wardrobe is coming into focus, what furniture should you wear with it? Think Poul Kjaerholm.

title: The All-Stars' Skipper
description: ONE of Johanna Wright's promising freshmen girls with the uncommon grace of a gazelle but the all too common inconsistency of a balky teenager presented her coach at Columbia High School with her report card, as all team members must. She had two A's, three B's and a C-minus in English.

title: Graduate Work in Desire
description: THE VARIETIES OF ROMANTIC EXPERIENCE

title: 'Master Harold,' 20 Years Later
description: AFTER last Saturday night's performance of Athol Fugard's '' 'Master Harold' . . . and the Boys,'' at Fleetwood Stage here, one theatergoer was overheard saying: ''I thought it would be political. But it was so poetic.''

title: A Local Festival With Worldwide Draw
description: THERE are more than 700 film festivals worldwide each year, according to Variety, the show business trade publication. So why have one in Westchester?

title: Looking for the Humanity Beneath Those Outbursts
description: BOBBY KNIGHT is one of the greatest college basketball coaches ever, the winner of three national championships before he was dismissed in 2000 by Indiana University. Yet that success competes with another side of the man called the General: the bullying, out-of-control and profane man who was arrested for assaulting a policeman in Puerto Rico when he was coaching in an inter-national tournament, who threw a chair across the court during a game against Purdue and who was videotaped briefly choking a player during practice.

title: 'Piney' Tunes: It's the Music Of Old Jersey
description: THE white sandy roads of the Pine Barrens glow in the moonlight and meander through woods where some say the Jersey Devil lurks. Outlanders may lose their way, but people who live in the area love the byways, far from the main roads, that they call sugar sand roads. The Sugar Sand Ramblers, a group of local musicians, have borrowed that image for their name, and it fits because their songs are about those roads and other fabled places and people of old New Jersey.

title: Oscar Films/And The Category is ...; A Maiden Voyage to Where the Live Action Isn't
description: WHEN the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced the creation of a new awards category, for best animated feature, one obvious response was to wonder why it had taken so long and to reflect on all the wonderful pictures that might have won, going back to ''Snow White'' and ''Fantasia'' more than 60 years ago. But this pleasant exercise in speculative film history would quickly have run into two major problems. The first is that a single studio -- Walt Disney Pictures -- would hold a near-monopoly not only on past winners but on the whole field of nominees. The second, and more serious, is what to do about the long span of time, roughly from the mid-50's to the mid-80's, during which in most years it would have been difficult to scare up enough worthy candidates to give the award at all.

title: When Good Winters Go Bad; Enjoy the Sunshine, but There May Be a Price to Pay
description: Mike Sterling, an accountant from Staten Island, very much enjoyed his lunchtime stroll through Midtown Manhattan on a late winter's day last week when the temperature was drifting languidly past 60 degrees. Lovely, he said. Beautiful.

title: Word for Word/The Geneva Conventions; Who Is a Prisoner of War? You Could Look It Up. Maybe.
description: THE administration's detention in Cuba of 300 men it believes to be fighters from Al Qaeda and the Taliban has frustrated allies and outraged a number of international legal scholars. Having originally balked at applying the Geneva Conventions to any of the prisoners, President Bush seemed to heed the criticism last month when he decided that the conventions would indeed apply to the conflict and to Taliban detainees. But he also took the position that neither Taliban nor Al Qaeda would be granted prisoner-of-war status under the treaties, leaving it unclear in what sense any of them would be protected by the conventions.

title: Attention, Shoppers
description: IT is Saturday afternoon in Bergen County, and the traffic on Route 17 in Paramus is backed up for miles as people head to one of the borough's four sprawling shopping malls. The parking lot at Garden State Plaza, the granddaddy of them all, is already filling up, and a line of cars is snaking through the aisles, searching for that rare empty space.

title: The Diplomat's Dilemma
description: DISCRETION

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an essay last Sunday about being on an island in Fiji during a hurricane misspelled the island's name. It is Ovalau, not Ovalua.

title: Single Lament
description: To the Editor: The travel industry does not seem to recognize that there are many people who, by necessity or by preference, travel alone. The extra charge, usually 50 percent or more, for single accommodations is more than many singles, often on limited incomes, can afford. The economics for the industry are understandable; two people in a room are worth more than one. But it might be worthwhile for hotels and cruise ships to consider providing truly ''single'' rooms, smaller and with a single bed, at a reasonable price for the single traveler.

description: Q: ''Mirroring Evil'' doesn't open at the Jewish Museum until next Sunday, but it has already turned out to be the most controversial show of the year.

description: ABBOTT-Grace. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Grace Abbott, associated with The Times from 1937 until 1970.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, DR. PETER H.
description: STEVENS-Dr. Peter H. Distinguished psychologist, adjunct professor at New York University and CUNY, career consultant at Stevens Institute of Technology, and author of the book ''Crisis Prevention,'' passed away peacefully on January 15, 2002 at 88 years. Greatly beloved for his skillful warmth, he will be sorely missed, particularly by his devoted niece, Sybil Taylor. Memorial, April 13 call 212-242-7410 for details.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWIN, LILI
description: LOWIN-Lili. A celebration of Lili's life will be held Sat., March 16th at 2PM. The Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th St, NY, NY.

description: It was, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi figured when he saw it, one of those pictures worth a thousand words. More or less.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENDEBIEN, ALBERT W.
description: GENDEBIEN-Albert W. Lafayette College mourns the passing of Albert W. Gendebien, Class of 1934, history professor emeritus and archivist emeritus, on March 8, 2002, at age 88. We wish to express our deepest condolences to his wife, Martha, and family. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, Saturday, March 16, in Colton Chapel on campus.

title: Mets' Burnitz Just Wants to Have Fun for a Change
description: Jeromy Burnitz remembers the game well, because it provided the perfect symbol that he is in a better place now that he is with the Mets. Four days ago against Kansas City, he struck out with two runners on, but Edgardo Alfonzo followed him with a three-run home run.

title: From Bush's Lips, a Vow He Could Not Renege On
description: Only a few weeks ago, the White House made it clear that it would be a long time before New York would see the entire $20 billion that President Bush had promised the city days after the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Miss America's Runway Seems More Like a Plank
description: Whether Robert M. Renneisen Jr. jumped or was pushed from his $250,000-a-year perch as chief executive of the Miss America Organization is a moot point, those close to the pageant insist.

title: SWISS YES
description: Switzerland took a giant step away from its isolationist history when voters approved joining the United Nations. Switzerland will soon apply to become the 190th member and East Timor the 191st, leaving the Vatican the only nonmember state. Elizabeth Olson

title: Some Who Needed Holding After 9/11 Are Now Holding Off
description: CLAIRE SMITHERS spent the night of Sept. 11 on the couch of her friend Olga Valdes. The women, colleagues in an Upper East Side medical office, were too unsettled to be alone. In the following weeks, both women, who are in their late 30's, found themselves re-evaluating their cherished single lives, saying they wanted commitments of substance, even if it meant compromising their ideals for a mate and putting up with the quotidian frustrations of married life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETZ, RUTH (NEE MEHLMAN)
description: GETZ-Ruth (nee Mehlman). Of White Plains, NY, died peacefully at home on March 7, 2002, at the age of 89. Beloved wife and best friend of the late George Getz. Adoring and adored mother of Nancy and Mitchell Wollman and Marcia and Donald Gerber. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey, Richard, Daniel, Susan & Andrew. Loving great grandmother of Kaidy, Erika, Ross, Joanna, Caroline & Tayler. Devoted sister of Gladys Aronson and Bernice Zerwitz. She will live in our hearts forever. Services private.

description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Abortion Centers Get Spitzer Reprieve
description: The state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, has dropped investigations into several anti-abortion counseling centers in New York, including the Life Center of Long Island in Deer Park. Mr. Spitzer has agreed to meet the centers' representatives to iron out what the attorney general said were problems with misleading advertising and inappropriate medical counseling.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LORD OF THE NUTCRACKER MEN

title: Just Three Flights a Day, but an Eye on the Big Picture
description: The 3:50 p.m. US Airways Express flight to Pittsburgh was ready for boarding at Lancaster County Airport. It was the second flight of the day. Twelve passengers -- the entire planeload -- got in the security line.

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean
description: This kind of middle-into-high-school caste system has been making us crazy for years. How quickly we forget Columbine and the way in which the subtle torture that adolescents inflict can play out. Tolerance 101 ought to be a mandatory course.

title: ATLANTIC CITY AIR SERVICE

The carrier, based in Portsmouth, flies 19-passenger twin-turboprop planes and will be the first new carrier out of Atlantic City since the Sept. 11 attacks severely cut back air service around the country. Continental has since stopped all flights out of Atlantic City, and Spirit Airways has cut its flights by half. Boston-Maine hopes to add flights out of Atlantic City to several smaller Florida and New England airports and Gary, Indiana.

title: Advice and Dissent

Senator Orrin Hatch denounced opposition to Judge Pickering as a ''lynching'' last week, and he forced the postponement of a Judiciary Committee decision when the nomination appeared doomed to go down on a party-line vote. Perhaps Mr. Hatch and other conservative Republicans worry that if Judge Pickering is rejected, President Bush will be forced to reconsider his strategy of using seats on federal courts as a sop to the right wing. We can only hope that would be so.

title: The Literary Club
description: There have been two occasions in my life I have been motivated into the kitchen by literature. The first time it happened I was reading ''Anna Karenina'' in tandem with someone I loved very much, so when we got to Part 4, I decided to replicate Oblonsky's massive hors d'oeuvres buffet that facilitated the successful reunion of Levin and Kitty. There were six kinds of vodka and as many kinds of cheese with silver spreaders caviars, various tinned delicacies, pickled mushrooms, sliced French bread. The vodka got the best of us, of course, along with the tragic nature of Anna's, and our own, romance. Plied with booze and lust and fish eggs, we got into a heap of trouble that afternoon, with far-reaching ramifications, the least of which was my missing two planes to somewhere I really needed to be.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: HE'S a baby-faced, good-for-nothing drifter who just got out of jail. She's his ladylike big sister, who works at a bank, wears tasteful blouses and skirts, and lives with her 8-year-old son in a house where everything is in its place. But the nice thing about Samantha (Laura Linney) in YOU CAN COUNT ON ME (2000) is that she turns out to be just orderly, not saintly. In the course of the film, she uses four-letter words, smokes marijuana and commits adultery with her creepy new boss (Matthew Broderick). The brother, Terry (Mark Ruffalo), borrows money he'll never repay, takes his nephew (Rory Culkin) to a pool hall and almost destroys Samantha's house while trying to fix the plumbing. And there's no happy ending in sight. Kenneth Lonergan, who wrote and directed, is known to theater goers as the brilliant, youngish playwright of ''This Is Our Youth'' and to Robert De Niro fans as the screenwriter of ''Analyze This'' -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Showtime.

A Memorial Service will be held on April 20, 2002, 11 A.M., at St. Andrews Episcopal Church, Catlin Street, Meriden, CT.

title: MAN OF STEEL

He placed tariffs of up to 30 percent for the next three years on most types of steel from Europe, Asia and South America, saying the industry needed time to reorganize from a ''surge'' in imports. The surge ended in 1998, but with many U.S. makers bankrupt, the companies clearly need help. They will get it from consumers, who will now pay more for cars, washing machines and other consumer goods. David E. Sanger

title: Ode to Terror

In two videotapes broadcast after Sept. 11, the terrorist is shown reciting a poem that most viewers assumed he wrote himself. In one tape, he chants it to his dinner guests in a safe house; in the other, his most recent public address, he weaves the poem into a tearful homage to the 19 hijackers. The lines, however, were not bin Laden's. A few weeks after the second videotape was shown in December, a Jordanian who said he was the cousin of the actual poet published a small article in the London-based newspaper Al Hayat accusing bin Laden of plagiarism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURKIE, DR. PAUL D.
description: STURKIE-Dr. Paul D. Died Friday, March 8, at the St. Peters Medical Center, New Brunswick. Dr. Sturkie was born in Proctor, Texas, and was ninety-two years of age. He resided in East Brunswick for fifty years and was formerly from Texas. He attended elementary and high schools in Texas, he received his B.S. and M.S. degrees at Texas A&M in 1933 and 1936 respectively and the Ph.D. at Cornell in 1939. He became Associate Professor at Auburn University, 1939-1944, Associate Professor at Rutgers University in 1944, Professor in 1950, and later Distinguished Professor of Physiology until 1977, when he retired as Emeritus Professor of Physiology. During his tenure at Rutgers he served as Chairman of the Department of Poultry Science, Department of Animal Science and as Chairman of the Department of Environmental Physiology, which he established in 1971. He organized a course in basic animal and human physiology, which he taught to undergraduates in animal sciences and biology. He organized and taught the first complete course in avian physiology, and published the first one volume book on avian physiology in 1954. The second, third and fourth editions were published in 1965, 1976 and 1986. In 1981 he edited a book on basic physiology, mainly on humans for beginners in physiology and health related fields and biological sciences, which has been translated into Russian and used as a Russian text in colleges. Dr. Sturkie was an active research worker and senior or junior author of over 170 technical papers and reports. He has won four research awards for distinguished research, including the Poultry Science Award in 1947; the Borden Award in 1956; the Rutgers Lineback Award for Distinguished Research in 1974; and the Golden Egg Award for service to the New Jersey poultry industry. Dr. Sturkie has been invited (guest) lecturer at national and international meetings and seminars in England, Scotland, Ireland, Germany, Netherlands, Japan, Australia, Russia, Kenya and South Africa. He belongs to a number of professional and honorary societies, including the Royal Society of Edinburgh and the Fellow of American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS). He is listed in American Men of Science and World's Who's Who in Science and others. He is survived by his wife Betty Failmezger Welch, two sons, Robin Failmezger of Ottumwa, Iowa, and Victor Failmezger of Alexandria, VA, a daughter, Stephanie Partilla of Huntington, LI, a brother, Lloyd Sturkie of Houston, five grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Calling hours will be Tuesday, 2-4, 7-9 PM, at the Rezem Funeral Home, 457 Cranbury Road, East Brunswick. Cremation will be at the convenience of the family.

title: Other Places, in Other Times

And it helps if he has a flair for the mot juste. In 1849, seven years before ''Madame Bovary'' appeared, Gustave Flaubert set off on a trip to the Middle East. He slept on a boat on the Nile, sat cross-legged to discuss religion with a Coptic bishop, and spent a night with a famous courtesan named Kuchuk Hanem. She sent a messenger ''escorted by a tame sheep all spotted with yellow henna'' that ''followed her like a dog.'' He kept track of all this in a travel diary and many droll, preening letters home, now filled with exquisitely useless information.

title: The Brick Stood Up Before. But Now?

The second chose the unseasoned lumber of Enron bonds, pleased with the generous interest they paid. The third, preferring safety to high returns, took shelter behind double-walled brick: short-term Enron notes backed by collateral and guaranteed by both a bank credit line and an insurance policy.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday showing comparative statistics for Israel and the West Bank and Gaza Strip misstated birth rates and child mortality rates. In Israel, there are 19.12 births annually per 1,000 people, not 19.12 per 100. In the West Bank and Gaza Strip, there are 35.48 births per 1,000 people, not per 100. In Israel, 6 children in 1,000 die before they are 5 -- not 6 children in 100. In the West Bank and Gaza Strip, 25 children in 1,000 die under 5 -- not 25 in 100.

title: His Student's Voice
description: Children struggling with learning it may think that reading is for the dogs, but for some children, reading to the dogs is the cats' pajamas. Youngsters at the Parsippany Public Library have a regular opportunity to read to dogs, which may be the most noncritical listeners that children who are self-conscious about their reading skills can face. Cynthia Stichman, children's librarian, started the program after hearing of a similar effort in Salt Lake City. Three dogs and their trainers from Therapy Dogs International, based in Mount Olive, come to the library once a month, and a child in need of confidence-building sits on the floor and reads to one of the animals. About 180 children have taken part in the program so far and Ms. Stichman would like to expand it to accommodate more of the waiting list. Children who have participated range in age from 8 to 13 and most, but not all, have some sort of reading problem. ''It makes reading fun for the children,'' Ms. Stichman said.

Survived by daughter Ellen Phillips (Philip), son David (Ilene), son Gabe (Beth), son Michael (Tova), daughter Judy Stolovitz (Gary); 17 grandchildren, Adam, Alice, Caroline, Elizabeth, Linda, Emma, Daniel, Jake, Sarah, Chaim, Leah, Yisroel, Devorah, Shmuel, Ben, Adele, Ruthie. His zest for life, unique wit and artistic talent will be sorely missed. Funeral Monday, March 11, 9:30 AM, at Plaza Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his name to the Ramaz School, the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester, Yeshiva Katana of Passiac, NJ, or Greenfield Hebrew Academy, Atlanta, GA.

title: Tracking the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRITCH, MILTON
description: FRITCH-Milton. Of Ft. Lauderdale FL, died March 6, 2002. Your friendship, warmth, wisdom, guidance and your loving ways can't be replaced by anyone. I was blessed with the gift of knowing you, and you will be missed very much. My deepest sympathies to Ruth & Nancy. Love Andrew Troy

title: Waiting for Mammograms
description: LAST month I called the Mount Kisco Medical Group to schedule my annual mammogram. The first available date for a routine screening was June 24. I called my mother to complain, but she could only commiserate. She had just scheduled hers at White Plains Hospital -- for mid-July.

title: Good School District With a Bad Deficit
description: SCHOOL DISTRICT 15's accomplishments are routinely trumpeted. It is home to many National Merit scholars and to seven Intel semifinalists this year alone. It has an outstanding record of acceptances to top colleges, and it has endowed Atlantic Beach, Inwood, Lawrence, Cedarhurst and the parts of Woodmere and North Woodmere it covers with the reputation of being good places to educate children.

title: Century-Hopping In Two Home-Oriented Stores
description: Westchester lovers of antique furniture and accessories have two new shopping options -- the Keeping Room and Carol E. Charny Vintage.

title: In Classic, UConn Outlasts Pitt for the Title
description: The Big East's two best teams, Connecticut and Pittsburgh; its two best players, UConn's Caron Butler and Pitt's Brandin Knight; and two overtimes. Where do you begin to describe a classic conference tournament championship game with all those elements?

title: Two Men Are Sought In East Side Holdups
description: Two men have been arranging meetings with female escorts living on the East Side of Manhattan and then robbing them, often at knife point, the police said yesterday.

title: The Winger Wore Armani
description: When the soccer sensation Luis Figo married his sweetheart, Helen Svedin, last year, the couple walked down the aisle in made-to-measure outfits created by his friend, the designer Giorgio Armani. Figo -- the mercurial Real Madrid winger, who was voted the world's best player of 2001 by the sport's governing body -- had met Armani the previous January, when he attended the designer's runway presentation in Milan.

title: Oscar Films/Behind The Camera; In a Weird Way, David Lynch Makes Sense
description: WHEN you think about it,'' David Lynch says, ''nothing makes sense in awards.'' True enough. For the second time, the Motion Picture Academy has nominated Mr. Lynch for best director for a movie that it did not see fit to nominate as best picture. It happened in 1986 with ''Blue Velvet,'' and it's happened again this year with ''Mulholland Drive.'' In each case, it was the film's lone nomination.

title: BackTalk; The Business of America's National Pastime Is Unpatriotic Obfuscation
description: Many have scoffed at baseball's claim that 28 of its 30 teams lost money over the last seven years, including $500 million in 2001 alone. But I have no basis for doubting their figures or their sincerity.

title: An Eye on Derivatives
description: To the Editor:

title: Beautiful Minds Can Be Reclaimed
description: The film ''A Beautiful Mind,'' about the Nobel Prize-winning mathematician John F. Nash Jr., portrays his recovery from schizophrenia as hard-won, awe-inspiring and unusual. What most Americans and even many psychiatrists do not realize is that many people with schizophrenia -- perhaps more than half -- do significantly improve or recover. That is, they can function socially, work, relate well to others and live in the larger community. Many can be symptom-free without medication.

title: Before There Was Dumbo, There Was Pedro's
description: PEDRO PEREZ has a wife whose name is Carmen and a son whose name is Pedrito (Little Pedro). He keeps them above his restaurant, which is called Pedro's Spanish American Restaurant, in Brooklyn under the Manhattan Bridge.

title: Survivor
description: SELKIRK'S ISLAND

title: Sports of The Times; Kentucky Loses Game But Takes a Stand
description: GERALD FITCH'S eyes were opened Friday night, possibly for the first time in his college career. Kentucky was upset by South Carolina, 70-57, and Fitch, a talented sophomore guard, was the goat.

title: Oscar Films/Glamour; Win or Lose, It's How You Look That Counts
description: IN 1986, Geraldine Page won the best-actress Oscar for her performance in ''A Trip to Bountiful.'' You probably don't remember. But that same year, Cher, peeved at not receiving a nomination for ''Mask,'' showed up at the ceremony looking like a giant porcupine in a scanty, beads-and-feathers production number by Bob Mackie. Who could forget that?

title: Postings: Landmarks Conservancy's Awards; Honoring Preservation Projects
description: Awards that celebrate preservation of historic or significant architecture are to be presented to 10 structures on Wednesday at one of the institutions to be honored: Central Synagogue, at Lexington Avenue and 55th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, ELISABETH SLOAN PRATT
description: LIVINGSTON - Elisabeth Sloan Pratt, age 96, died at her home on March 8, 2002. Born and raised in Brooklyn, she had resided in Oyster Bay Cove, NY since 1939. John Holyoke Livingston, her husband of 64 years, died in 1995. An avid golfer in earlier days and an active watercolorist until age 95 when failing eyesight forced her to quit, Mrs. Livingston was well known in Brooklyn and on the North Shore of Long Island for her philanthropy. A memorial gathering will be held on a date to be announced. Contributions to the Art League of Long Island or Packer Collegiate Institute of Brooklyn would be appreciated.

title: A Subject No One Wants to Talk About
description: ALTHOUGH the quantity of new plays surpasses quality at the New Jersey Repertory Company here, the theater has generally chosen scripts that reflect a sense of purpose, not just risk. If the subject is delicate or unspoken, you can bet that New Jersey Repertory will bet on the play that nervily confronts it.

title: Looking for a Few Good Board Members
description: FIRST, there's the danger of being accosted in the elevator by neighbors who think all board members double as superintendents. Then there's the temptation to wear a mask when an increase in monthly charges is announced. And don't forget the legal risks of being accused of discrimination, or of being held criminally liable in case of a major accident.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of spring theater events on Feb. 24 misstated the telephone number for ''Ricky Jay on the Stem,'' which begins previews at the Second Stage Theater on April 9. The number is (212) 246-4422.

title: Fleet Bank Employees Are Local Residents
description: To the Editor:

title: In Camps, Arabs Cling To Dream of Long Ago
description: Israel has for the first time stormed the fortresses of the Palestinian uprising, sending soldiers backed by tanks and helicopter gunships to raid camps like this one in a hunt, Israel says, for terrorists and their weapons.

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean
description: Your article focuses on girls' interpersonal aggression in middle school. Yet, I see the same aggression, contrary to the feminist myth of sisterhood, in the complex world of corporate politics. The question emerges, then: Is this behavior bad (to be addressed with seminars on apology-making) or is it more complex (to be understood as preparation for the competitive reality)?

title: The World; Gandhi's Dream and India's Latest Nightmare
description: OVER the past few years, Hindu nationalism, once a pariah movement associated with Gandhi's assassination, has become politically mainstream in this nation and in the West.

title: Halle Berry, Bruised and Beautiful, Is on a Mission
description: SITTING in a cozy Kensington apartment that is home while she films a new James Bond movie, Halle Berry is so poised and stunning, it's hard to imagine that she ever suffered so much as a scratch in her life.

title: The Bad Games
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Princeton's Deer Program Is Humane and Effective
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Months After Sept. 11, Bush to Give Strategy for Intensified War on Terror
description: President Bush will describe his broad strategy for the next stages of the war on terrorism on Monday, six months after the attacks on New York and Washington, suggesting that he may pursue the terrorist network of Al Qaeda even inside countries that do not ask for an American presence.

title: Big on Beauty
description: Perhaps in keeping with the stocking-up sensibility of tighter times, beauty counters have been doing a big business in oversize products -- bricks of soap and jumbo bottles of shampoo, lotion and fragrance. Aesop's 11-ounce Body Cleansing Slab ($15 at Barneys New York) and Bliss's Big Blue Bar ($15 in the Bliss catalog) require two-fisted bathing, while Molton Brown makes ''super luxury size'' two-packs, consisting of 17-ounce bottles of bath gel and moisturizer ($45 at Barneys New York). Aveda ($25) and Origins ($27.50) carry 32-ounce shampoos, and Charles Worthington's Big Big Hair spray lives up to its name in a foot-tall metal canister ($12). Kiehl's has 32-ounce jugs of Blue Astringent ($39.50) and herbal shampoos ($43.50). Devotees of Annick Goutal's Eau d'Hadrien perfume are buying it in a 15-ounce glass flask ($195 at www

title: Long-Forgotten Delicacies of the Melon Patch
description: ''I'M a melon maniac with a mission,'' Amy Goldman said last week. The former psychologist-turned gardener grows about 100 varieties of the ancient gourd on a one-acre sunny plot on her mostly wooded 200 acres in Rhinebeck, N.Y., some 80 miles north of mid-Manhattan. That same plot accommodates, incredibly, about 50 varieties of squashes, 50 kinds of hardshell gourds, 250 varieties of tomatoes and 150 different hot peppers.

title: Dance; Minor League Stars Dream of the Majors
description: SINCE John Meehan, a former principal dancer with the Australian Ballet and American Ballet Theater, took over Ballet Theater's Studio Company in 1997, the 12-member troupe has become the most successful and prominent second, or junior, company in the country. Several companies (Alvin Ailey, Boston Ballet, Pennsylvania Ballet and Colorado Ballet among them) have such ensembles, but the Studio Company is exceptional in a number of ways.

title: Andrea Rosario, Jos De Jesus
description: Andrea Hope Rosario, the daughter of Pamela and Jaime Rosario of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Jos Manuel De Jesus, a son of Dr. Socorro Foxworthy and the stepson of Dr. T. David Foxworthy of Manhattan. The Rev. Amy Mendez is to perform the ceremony at the West End Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean
description: Talbot is right to point out that many on the lower rungs of the middle-school caste system are sustained by ''the premonition that adults did not usually play by the same rigid and peculiar rules'' of the Queen Bees. But Rosalind Wiseman's earnest efforts at ironing out the uncomfortable wrinkles of childhood social existence, with its gossip, snubs and petty hierarchies, would have left me unprepared to compete in my current profession, the entertainment industry, which, as many have pointed out, is merely ''high school with money.''

title: Slumping Nets Lose Their Way Out West
description: This Western Conference trip may have not have been the graveyard for the Nets, but it proved rather to be a junkyard, littered with the rusted pieces of their earlier success.

title: Business; Handle With Extreme Care
description: The anthrax scare has dissipated, but magazine publishers are no longer using cornstarch to keep freshly printed pages from sticking to each other. It looks too much like the kind of powder associated with anthrax. Now the publishers use a clear, odorless, silicon-based substitute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESCIGNO, JAMES
description: RESCIGNO-James. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James Rescigno, associated with The Times from 1977 until 1997.

title: When Hounded, Hound Back
description: THEY started calling us at home. We countered by getting answering machines and screening their pitches.

title: In Bold English Shirts, Enter the New Peacocks
description: FOR a couple of happy years, Curt Schiner was able to hide his secret from his wife.

title: In Three Shows, Museum Looks Beyond the Region
description: THE Noyes Museum of Art here is pursuing an ambitious exhibition schedule that goes beyond its frequent showing of art associated with southern New Jersey. The museum, which opened in 1983, has a growing permanent collection of about 1,200 items that range from vintage bird decoys to contemporary art by mostly New Jersey artists. But only a small selection of these works are displayed to make room for three special shows.

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean
description: Your article provoked the curmudgeon in me. Acknowledging that the early teenage years are emotionally taxing no matter who or where you are, I would suggest that the young women described in the article could assuage their pain, exercise their cunning and elevate their self-esteem by raising money to provide food, clothing, shelter, medicine and education for the many young women of the world who lack running water, electricity, designer clothes, schools, shopping malls, cellphones and e-mail. The problems of this privileged group seem frivolous by comparison.

title: Two Priests Who Abused Boys in Maine Are Removed
description: Two Roman Catholic priests in small towns in northern Maine who had acknowledged molesting boys in their parishes decades ago were removed from their posts today by the bishop of Portland.

title: Back Home, Bonds of Anxiety
description: As G.I.'s wage war in Afghanistan, their wives, once strangers linked only by geography and bureaucracy, are forging new bonds. Page 27.

title: March 3-9; FRONT LINES
description: MIDEAST: The escalation of violence that Palestinians date to Jan. 14, when Israel killed Raed al-Karmi, a leader of the Tanzim militia, reached a bloody crescendo in daily exchanges of attacks that left dozens of men, women and children dead on both sides and culminated in the single deadliest day in the 17-month intifada.

title: BackTalk; There Are Some Potholes On the Road to Equity
description: Into the madness of March strides Kermit L. Hall, looking to hire a basketball coach. Once he has one, he will hire a women's basketball team. A man of foresight, he already has a college.

title: A Rowdy Club Closes, and the Sleepless Rest Easy
description: Stuart Levine considers himself a neighborly man. He is in the business of public relations, and he is vice president of the West 75th Street Residents Coalition.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Heather Juergensen and Jennifer Westfeldt; Triumph of a Lark
description: THE ''girls,'' as everyone calls them, are not about to tell their ages. ''What? With Hollywood the way it is?'' said Heather Juergensen, who graduated from Stuyvesant High School in 1987.

title: A World Apart, in the Outback
description: TWO years ago at the beginning of the wet season in late October, a young Australian woman arrived at the gates of El Questro Homestead to find a monstrously swollen river where a road had been the day before. When it rains, it pours in this famously isolated stretch of northwest Australia, and on this particular day, seven inches of water had spilled from the skies in just five hours.

title: Music; Finding Time to Remember Sept. 11
description: In addition to being one of the finest orchestras in the world, the Vienna Philharmonic is one of the busiest. This elite detachment of the Vienna State Opera Orchestra labors through a crowded concert and opera season, then plays at festivals in Vienna and Salzburg, where things may become even more hectic.

title: Lindsay Harrison, Terrence O'Brien
description: Lindsay Bartlett Harrison, a daughter of Adrienne and Stett Harrison of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Terrence Michael O'Brien, the son of Patricia and G. Peter O'Brien of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARLES, RICHARD Z.
description: CHARLES-Richard Z. On March 8, 2002. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Barry and Beth, Andy and Faith and Lee and Pamela. Cherished grandfather of Randy, Scott, Zachary, Alex, Lindsay, Benjamin, Stephanie and Bonnie. Services are on Sunday 11:30AM at the South Baldwin Jewish Center, 2959 Grand Avenue in Baldwin, New York.

title: If Truancy Is the 'Gateway to Crime,' An Attempt to Nip Problems in the Bud
description: Anna Lazaro was hauled off by the police, searched and forced to sit in silence. Yet she had unexpected things to say about the truancy center in which she had spent the morning.

title: Fleet Bank Employees Are Local Residents
description: To the Editor:

title: Forever Young
description: Treva Throneberry sits across from me, smiling bashfully as if she is embarrassed to be seen here. We are in a dank, spooky visiting room in the Clark County Jail in Vancouver, Wash., looking at each other through a thick Plexiglas window on which someone has scrawled ''I Love You.'' We speak to each other through telephone receivers. We are talking about high school. She remembers first-period history, when she would sometimes fall asleep with her head down. ''The teacher would bang on the desk to wake me up,'' Throneberry says. She raps on the surface of the prison table, mimicking him.

title: Chocolate Works Its Charm on the Brooklyn Waterfront
description: IT roughly at the midway point between two of the biggest holidays of the chocolate season, Valentine's Day and Easter, Jacques Torres realized that after more than a year spent running Jacques Torres Chocolates, he had not ordered enough ingredients.

title: Joseph B. Hartranft, 86, Leader In Military and Civilian Aviation
description: Joseph B. Hartranft, the founder of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association and a pioneer of general aviation, died on Feb. 22 in Annapolis, Md. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ANNE B. (NEE BRASSINGTON).
description: YOUNG-Anne B. (nee Brassington). Died March 8, 2002, in Sugar Land, Texas, with her family present at age 68. She was born February 22, 1934, in New York City. Survivors include Anne's children Francis X. Young, Michelle Camilli, Elizabeth Young, Daniel Young and Jacqueline Granucci, six grandchildren, her sisters Mary Cronin, Gail Kernan, Kathy Hurley and Beth Wentzel and her brother William Brassington Jr. Anne's husband Frank J. died in 1998 and her daughter Suzanne died in 1980. Her parents William and Cecelia Brassington also predeceased her. Visitation will be Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home. A funeral Mass will be held Thursday 10 AM at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Elmsford, NY. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Arenal Mission, c/o Father Joseph Currie, Fordham University, Bronx, NY.

title: A Land the Apaches Loved
description: OVER several visits, I have to come to love the area where Arizona, Mexico and New Mexico converge. Especially the Chiricahua Mountains, the most spectacular of southern Arizona's sky islands, so called because their lush peaks soar to almost 10,000 feet from a sea of encircling desert scrub. Sky islands: the phrase still has for me a fairyland ring, promising a timeout from reality. And indeed, even to the returning visitor, the Chiricahuas are rich in improbability.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Yin and Yang of Late-Night TV
description: IN the Age of Enron, the Letterman versus Koppel affair has been cast as a corporate morality tale, with the Walt Disney Company placing profits above quality or loyalty.

title: Narcissus Shrugged
description: Like a beautiful young thing without an ounce of body fat or trace of self-doubt, the new Equinox gym on the corner of West 12th Street and Greenwich Avenue presides over the block.

title: QUICK BITE/Tappan. N.Y.; A Cooking Couple and the Baker's Wife
description: First, let's get the name out of the way. The owner is not the baker's wife. His name is Daniel Foti, and he is the baker's husband. His wife, Paula Oland, is head baker at the renowned Balthazar Bakery, of SoHo and Englewood. The two put down roots in this Colonial hamlet just north of Bergen County, and late last year, after a long career as a chef at such restaurants as the Sign of the Dove and Yellowfingers in Manhattan, Mr. Foti opted for a kitchen much closer to home. In the back of a sweetly countrified storefront just big enough for the streams of couples (in BMW's) and small families (in Volvo wagons) who stop in for takeout, he turns out an impressive line of savory dishes. Theres a gorgeous pissaladire, the French pizza ($20 a pie, $5 a quarter); an earthy black bean soup brightened by cherry tomatoes ($4 a pint); a Mediterranean hero with grilled eggplant, fennel and hummus ($6); and a variety of pressed hot sandwiches that are like exalted grilled cheese ($7). Soon, he says, he'll start offering takeout dinners: baked pastas, seafood stews, poultry and vegetarian dishes. Ms. Oland supplies the breads and pastries, which is like having Mike Piazza bat cleanup on your church softball team. Her other clients include an Olympian cast of Manhattan restaurants, among them Jean Georges and Alain Ducasse. A rosemary-sourdough ring big enough for a picnic is just $3. A magnificent 14-inch amber-stout rye is $7.50 and would feed every peasant in a Brueghel painting. Desserts include a terrific, mouth-puckering lemon-souffl tart and a dense, moist chocolate-almond torte ($4.50 each). Oh, the name. It is the title of a 1938 movie by Marcel Pagnol in which the baker stops working because his wife has run off with a shepherd, and the villagers, missing their bread, organize to bring her back. Tappan hasn't had shepherds for generations, but breads like these could inspire a revolution.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Your Home'' column last Sunday, about security in apartment buildings, misspelled the surname of a lawyer who commented on the importance of having an emergency plan. He is Daniel J. Sitomer, not Satoma.

title: Can It Be Dj Vu All Over Again?
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Music; ANTHONY TOMMASINI Orchestras Loosening The CD Bind
description: COLIN DAVIS'S recording of Berlioz's epic opera ''Les Troyens,'' with the London Symphony Orchestra and a splendid cast headed by the tenor Ben Heppner, is going to shake up the classical-music industry as nothing else has in some time. Not just because the performance is superb, nor because it recently scooped up a pair of Grammy Awards for best classical and best opera recording of 2001.

title: Two Shows at Yale Find the Roots of Modern Art in the 1940's
description: TWO exhibitions at the Yale University Art Gallery deal vividly with how modern art took hold in the United States. They cover roughly the same time period, the late 1940's. In both shows, viewers will feel more than a trace of nostalgia.

title: Keep the Malcolm X Papers Public
description: Malcolm Little (a.k.a. Detroit Red) entered prison as an illiterate drug hustler in 1946, but he emerged several years later as Malcolm X, a charismatic speaker and social critic who was soon to become one of the civil rights movement's most electrifying voices. He entered the public eye as spokesman for Elijah Muhammad's Nation of Islam, a religious organization that advocated racial separatism. But the former Detroit Red left racism behind after he visited the Muslim holy city of Mecca, where he learned that race-based hatred conflicted with the teachings of the Koran. During the trip, he scribbled excitedly in a journal that with ''all colors bowing in unison,'' he had forgotten about skin color for the first time in his life.

title: Heaven From the South
description: More restaurants in New York offer specialties of the South than any other American regional cuisine. Here are seven choices.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe on Feb. 24 for marinated sardines misspelled the name of the New York restaurant from which it is adapted. It is Craft, not Kraft.

title: Ding, Dong, the Cultural Witch Hunt Is Dead
description: I often agree with Frank Rich, but I think he's wrong when he says the era of character assassination by the Washington right is finally over. If there is a temporary conservative cease-fire, it's because George W. Bush is president, basking in the glow of huge post-Sept. 11 approval ratings.

title: You Want How Much, Doc?
description: The astute consumer won't think twice about bargaining for the best deal on many products and services, like a new house, a car, a vacation package or even furniture at a flea market. But what about haggling with a health care professional?

title: After 27 'SNL' Seasons, A Permanent Ticket to Grin
description: Louis C. Klein is like everyone else waiting on line for standby tickets to ''Saturday Night Live'' on this shivery first Friday of March. He loves the show. He agrees that the show is worth losing sleep over. He is even willing to wait as long as 22 hours.

title: Home Hardships End Private's Army Career
description: Three months after he left for Fort Knox, a self-described slacker looking to escape his hometown and make something of himself in the Army, Kirk Evans, 19, is back where he started.

title: Rutgers's Next Leader? That's an Essay Question
description: NO sooner had Francis L. Lawrence announced that he was stepping down as president of Rutgers University after 12 years than the maneuvering began to ascend to the $287,000-a-year post.

title: On the Runways of Paris, Mind Over Matter
description: In the 1950's and 60's, when magazines like Mademoiselle and Harper's Bazaar published the poetry of writers like Marianne Moore, it was not necessarily a bad thing to be thought of as someone whose tastes ran toward the intellectual.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, MORTON
description: RAYMOND-Morton. 76 of Closter, NJ on Wednesday, March 6, 2002. Married 54 years to his beloved Mary Greene Raymond. Survived by son Jerry and daughter-in-law Marisabel, daughter Ronnie Ellen, grandchildren Abigail and Harry, sister Natalie Ferentz and sister-inlaw Lillian Wilbur. He was an MBA graduate of CCNY and a proud member of the Pershing Rifles. After military service he worked for Diebold and founded Garden State Business Systems (later Datamation Systems). He was active in many professional associations and was a founder of the Mail Systems Management Association. Service were held Friday, at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Museum of Natural History, Planned Giving Dept., Central Park West and W. 79th Street. NYC, 10024 would be appreciated.

title: Despite What He Insists, Thomas Excels as a Center
description: For nearly 10 seconds there was silence, followed by a goofy look and a smile. When asked about the prospect of facing Shaquille O'Neal on Sunday, Kurt Thomas did not know what to say.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Another Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about a street musician named Thoth, who is the subject of a documentary film that has just been nominated for an Oscar, gave an incomplete credit for a 1972 work by the same filmmaker, Sarah Kernochan. The earlier film -- the Oscar-winning ''Marjoe'' -- was produced and directed by Howard Smith and Ms. Kernochan.

title: The Long Process Behind Bar Mitzvahs
description: On Feb. 24, I read your article titled, ''Putting Together a Big Bar Mitzvah.'' As a child who was a bat mitzvah myself almost three years ago, I found your article on bar/bat mitzvahs as an exercise in conspicuous consumption to be insulting. Your examples were extreme rather than typical, and fed a derogatory stereotype of the Jewish population on Long Island.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Peasant shirts, skintight pants, shaggy haircuts -- the Rolling Stones embodied the androgynous rock star look, and Keith Richards was the most raffishly stylish one of the lot. At Villa Nellcte he padded about barefoot, wearing little else besides handmade trousers. For your next performance, try these striped canvas pants from Marc Jacobs's spring collection ($250, at Marc Jacobs, 403 Bleecker Street). Guitar optional.

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean
description: It's always a happy Sunday (Feb. 24) when Margaret Talbot's name is on your cover, and her article on Queen Bees and Wannabes was no exception. I was particularly struck by the personal reflection that, for her, ''the best antidote to the caste system . . . was the premonition that . . . someday, somewhere, I would find a whole different mattering map.''

title: Jets Negotiating With Martin
description: The Jets have been in serious negotiations with tackle Steve Martin to repair the last hole in their once-depleted defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHBINDER, DR. EDWARD H.
description: BUCHBINDER-Dr. Edward H. March 7, in Boca Raton, FL. Born in Bayonne, NJ, 1911. Last surviving and youngest of 11 children born to the late Meyer and Emma Esther Buchbinder from whom he and his siblings learned devotion to family, charity and religion. A distinguished graduate of Ohio College of Podiatric medicine. Survived by his caring wife Faye, two sons and their spouses and five grandchildren. Especially loved and respected by his 23 nieces and nephews and their spouses.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Monks Make Music

title: ZIMBABWE VOTES
description: The people of Zimbabwe went to the polls in the country's most important election in a generation, and now the question is whether the troubled country will be able to live with the outcome. President Robert G. Mugabe, the only leader in the country's 22-year post-colonial history, wants to stay on. A spirited, surging opposition party, led by Morgan Tsvangirai, a longtime labor leader, wants him out. Months of political turmoil and violence have polarized the parties, and most indications are that the loser is unlikely to fade away quietly. The ballot counting will begin on Monday. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Gaffney Lays Out State of Suffolk County
description: Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County executive, said last week that a $24 million budget shortfall in sales tax revenues combined with a $36 million rise in state-mandated county spending for social services was jeopardizing the county's bond rating.

title: Head of Teachers' Union Criticizes Mayor
description: The president of the New York City teachers' union, delivering the second sharp rebuke in as many days, yesterday accused Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of breaking the law by attempting to hold the much-overdue teachers' contract hostage in his campaign in Albany to eliminate the Board of Education.

title: Blithe Souls
description: In a time of fashion conformity, a few uncorralled free spirits remain who dress for self-expression and fun. They wear clear plastic shoes with patterned socks, a plastic apron over a plaid skirt, a plaid wrap skirt with plastic gussets doing duty as a cape, a scarf trailing yardlong ribbon streamers, a doll hat (below), a hat camouflaging the head in peacock feathers or a doughnut-shape shoulder bag. These are a sampling of sights that brightened New York this winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, SYLVIA KUSTIN
description: MORRIS-Sylvia Kustin. On March 4, 2002. Sylvia departed her devoted husband Norman, to whom she was married for 65 years. She is survived by her loving children, Fredric and Barbara Kuperman, brother Emil, and grandchildren Andrew and Amanda Morris, and Jonathan and Jennifer Kuperman. Language, literature, travel and theater were among Sylvia's joys. Her family remembers her wonderful cooking and tireless caretaking, her sharp mind and sturdy values, her delightful wit. Those close to her feel deeply grateful for her long life.

title: A New Era at Getty Marketing

This is the best time of year, when the Judas trees are in bloom, when myriad songbirds greet the dawn, when the barren hills of the Judean wilderness turn a light green and the Jordan Valley glows with red anemones and yellow mustard. It brings back memories of hikes under the brilliant sky, of lunches in the German Colony, of buying oranges in Jericho or bantering with friends on a hot night in Tel Aviv.

title: The Fish-Eye View: In a Word, Invaluable
description: Gary McLeod started scalloping on the big boats out of Lunenburg, Nova Scotia, when he was 13. Thirty-seven years later, on Browns Bank, 100 miles off the coast, he steered the 110-foot scallop boat Ernest E. Pierce through a cold winter night. The crew prepared to set the gear, two ice-sheathed, 15-foot-wide, two-ton steel scallop dredges that hung from each side of the boat. McLeod rang a bell, two crewmen's hammers slammed down on steel knockout blocks and the dredges rumbled over the side, cable rolling off big winches as they sank to the bottom.

''Every security restriction we put into place on Sept. 11 remains in place,'' said Susan Bishop, a spokeswoman for Textron.

title: The Fighting Next Time

He emerged from a 37-year Navy career with the rank of vice admiral despite a reputation as a maverick. He has run a university. So, you show up expecting a paragon of sangfroid and self-confidence. But half an hour into our first interview, the former fighter pilot seems to be on the verge of a meltdown. He has been pacing his pristine suite in the new Pentagon Office of Force Transformation like a man in the grip of a fever, trying to explain his mission as Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld's agent of revolutionary change in the United States military.

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean

Trying to co-opt the popular kids into being nice to the unpopular ones defeats the whole power dynamic that these kids have so craftily established. The best approach is the one your writer suggests, which is to emphasize that being popular exacts a price in terms of conformity, peer pressures and distraction from schoolwork. Of course, a class on ''why it's not in your best interest to be popular'' would not be as salable as Wiseman's. For sheer entertainment value, Wiseman is onto something.

title: Love Among the Photographers
description: The work of the photographer Margrethe Mather might have been lost in photographic history had it not been for a visit to Edward Weston's Los Angeles studio in 1913. Weston, then 27, ''fell in love with art and with Margrethe Mather at the same time, and for some eight years could not separate them,'' as a friend once wrote. Although Weston ultimately burned diary entries pertaining to Mather, photographs and accounts from their decade-long affair are now unveiled in Beth Gates Warren's MARGRETHE MATHER AND EDWARD WESTON: A Passionate Collaboration (Norton, $39.95). Warren dispels notions that theirs was a traditional artist/muse relationship, suggesting that it was in fact Mather who was Weston's mentor. While posing as his model and making her own pictures, Mather exposed Weston to a bohemian circle of anarchists, poets and actors (including a pre-Tramp Charlie Chaplin). The couple eventually photographed in tandem, co-signing portraits of figures like Max Eastman and Carl Sandburg. In her solo work, Mather edited an image to its essence, a skill that undoubtedly inspired her partner. In ''Semi-Nude'' (1923), she made a close-up of hands parting a patterned kimono to reveal a bare torso, an idea for which Weston is remembered -- in nudes of another lover, Tina Modotti, wearing a kimono, and of his son in ''Neil's Torso'' (1925). Shortly before her death in 1952, Mather implored Weston to ''pretend that I didn't exist.'' We can be thankful that she's finally gotten some overdue -- if unwanted -- attention. Sarah Shatz

description: Airlines, so imperiled that Congress passed a $15 billion bailout package soon after the attacks, started adding back flights and recalling some laid-off workers as early as December. But these are mere glints of light in a dark outlook.

''Speed has nothing to do with it,'' observes Dan Stoner, the editor of Garage (a), a style-oriented custom-car quarterly. ''It's all about style and how high you can get the car to hop.'' For some, it's also about the girls. ''It's like a rock band,'' says Anthony Johnson (b), an aficionado from Riverside, Calif., who calls himself Tee. ''There's a lot of groupies involved in lowriding. If your car looks good enough, the more girls you get.''

This year, men's clothing designers are freshening up somber charcoal gray, navy or brown jackets and trousers by replacing the usual white or chalk stripes with gently hued versions. At Hugo Boss, a navy suit, left, sports a pastel pink stripe ($995), while Dolce & Gabbana carries a charcoal suit with lavender stripes ($1,025 at Bergdorf Goodman). Corneliani makes a light brown suit with pink stripes ($1,095), and Isaia puts light blue stripes on tan ($2,995), both at Saks Fifth Avenue. For men who enjoy lines of latitude with their longitude, Versace has a navy wool suit with a pink windowpane pattern ($1,995), and Paul Smith (108 Fifth Avenue, at 16th Street) makes a navy suit with a light-blue windowpane ($1,200). Among the academics and politicos he greeted was a 40-year-old Muslim cleric named Jaffar Umar Thalib. A photograph in a local newspaper the next day showed him and the vice president locked in a warm embrace. Outside Indonesia, however, this visit by Jaffar -- who was, even then, arguably the most feared Islamic militant in the most populous Muslim nation on earth and who would soon be mentioned in the same breath as Osama bin Laden -- went largely unreported.

title: Tickets in London
description: To the Editor: On a recent London trip, I took a chance on half-price tickets being available at the Leicester Square tkts booth for one of several current productions. Tkts had a good variety of matinee and evening shows available. Our party of five obtained third-row seats for that day's matinee of ''Noises Off.'' Rick Steves, in his London guidebook, ''Rick Steves' London,'' advises readers not to patronize the other half-off storefronts near Leicester and Piccadilly, and we found out why when we reached our seats. Two were occupied, and the house manager told the couple that they had bought counterfeit tickets from a bargain agency (not tkts). Because the house wasn't sold out, they were given other unsold seats as a courtesy. This scene was repeated often before curtain time.

description: As you prepare your taxes, watch out for any mistakes on the 1099 statements you receive from banks, brokerage houses or other businesses. Remember that the forms are also filed with the Internal Revenue Service, and the agency's computers are programmed to compare your tax returns with all the forms it receives.

title: Running Cyclones Up a Flagpole to See Who Salutes
description: Since Brooklyn's new borough president, Marty Markowitz, took office in January, some changes have taken place around Borough Hall, the most headline-grabbing of which was his decision to move some portraits of dead white males, including George Washington.

title: Big Obstacle to Dredging Posed by Little Larvae
description: As the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey moves into the new world of massive container ships that require much deeper, wider harbor channels, they have run into an unanticipated problem that could be every bit as hard to navigate as the rocky shoals that they are seeking to blast and dredge.

title: Method to His Madness
description: A hybrid of Caesar and Falstaff, Marlon Brando is a conundrum, a case study for the 21st century, playing the iconic thespian and the unruly buffoon, the king and the fool -- and getting away with it. And somehow he manages to hold his throne as the greatest living actor, to movie critics, the cinema-going public and his acting colleagues, no matter what he does, or doesn't, do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, DR. JOE.
description: SILBERSTEIN-Dr. Joe. We shall miss our remarkable friend and treasure wonderful memories. David ''Bill'' and Barbara Kahn

title: Princeton's Deer Program Is Humane and Effective
description: To the Editor:

title: Quintessence Of Beaujolais
description: Beaujolais is a hedonist's quintessential red. Julinas is the quintessential Beaujolais. And the virtually syrupy 2000 Domaine le Cotoyon is the quintessential Julinas: redolent of macerated raspberries and strawberries. It's from vines owned by Jean-Jacques Vincent of Chteau Fuiss, Pouilly-Fuiss's greatest estate. Windsor, 474 Third Avenue (33rd Street), Manhattan, charges $12. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: In Oaxaca, Tourists, Weavers and Cooks
description: On the eight-hour bus ride from Veracruz to Oaxaca I met a retired fellow from Arkansas who wore his long white hair in a ponytail and used the e-mail moniker El Viejo Gringo. He was in a mood to chat; I was not. But as we glided up steep mountain ridges covered with giant cactus, I found his colorful stories far more entertaining than the Spanish-dubbed reruns of ''Hawaii Five-O'' on the bus's TV screen.

title: Regime Changes
description: Secretary of State Colin Powell laid it on the rhetorical line: the Bush administration ''is committed to regime change'' in Iraq. He repeated to the Senate that ''a regime change would be in the best interests of the region.'' That's a euphemism for ''overthrow of government'' or ''toppling Saddam.''

title: Ding, Dong, the Cultural Witch Hunt Is Dead
description: We can only be grateful that David Brock, Newt Gingrich and Rush Limbaugh weren't shrewd enough to figure out ''three-way calling.''

title: He Loves to Win. At I.B.M., He Did.
description: THE revival of I.B.M. over the last nine years is most tellingly measured not in numbers but by its return to pre-eminence as the industry leader. Once again, I.B.M. is the model others follow.

title: Political Briefing; He Left His Heart In Sacramento
description: California voters slammed the door last week on efforts to gut the state's term limits law. But a closer look reveals that they left it ajar just enough for Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco to slip through, should he choose. It is a pretty good bet that he will try.

title: Art/Architecture; A Swimming Pool? A Yacht? No, It's Art
description: THE kidney-shaped plywood sculpture on view here at the Wexner Center for the Arts looks like a swimming pool from above and the unfinished hull of a yacht from below. But ''Free Basin,'' produced by Simparch, an artists' collaborative in Chicago, is a different sort of artifact: a modular rink with two birch-lined bowls for skateboarding indoors.

title: Business; On the Road, Again?
description: With busy travel seasons approaching, Americans seem more willing to travel, though not necessarily on airplanes. According to a survey of travel confidence last month by the Travel Industry Association of America, 65 percent of Americans, by far the highest level since Sept. 11, plan at least one leisure trip in the next six months.

title: The World; Finding Answers In Secret Plots
description: CONSPIRACY theories are seductive and, by nature, impossible to refute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFINKEL, EVE
description: GARFINKEL-Eve. On March 7. Beloved mother of Howard and Merrill. Wife of Stanley. Services Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Ave, Monday, 1 PM.

title: Marjorie Jaffe, Bruce Goldner
description: Marjorie Ellen Jaffe, the daughter of Maxine and Efrem Jaffe of Manchester, Conn., was married last evening to Bruce Joseph Goldner, a son of Vicki and Leo Goldner of Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Richard J. Plavin performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor, Conn., from which the bride graduated.

title: Patsy's Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Black-Power Activist Convicted in Deputy's Slaying
description: Two days after his lawyers finished presenting a quick, lackluster defense, Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, the fiery black radical known in the 1960's as H. Rap Brown, was found guilty today of murdering a sheriff's deputy two years ago.

title: The Dresser
description: Once upon a time, Dapper Dudes roamed the earth -- carelessly drinking martinis, smoking cigarettes and dressing to the nines. And when it came time to suit up, the man to see was Jack the Tailor. But today, Jack Taylor is more than a relic of days gone by. He is a living treasure, and the Beverly Hills custom-clothing shop bearing his name is a shrine for hipsters seeking a souvenir of the good life.

title: SOUTH JERSEY PRICES
description: Median home prices in three southern New Jersey counties rose sharply during the fourth quarter of 2001 over the same period in 2000, according to data released by the New Jersey Association of Realtors. Burlington County's median price was $147,300, a 16 percent increase over the fourth quarter of 2000; Camden County, prices were up 14 percent to $110,600; and Gloucester County's were $121,200, up 10 percent. The state median was up 7 percent to $200,000 over the last quarter of 2000. The fourth-quarter median price in South Jersey was $126,500; in Central Jersey, it was $201,800; and in the north, it was $272,400. The national median is $147,500. John Holl

title: Julia Golier, William Bornmann
description: Dr. Julia Ann Golier and William Carl Bornmann were married yesterday by the Rev. Walter F. Modrys at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELSEY, STEPHEN TOMLINSON, JR.
description: KELSEY-Stephen Tomlinson, Jr., 85. Of Berwyn, PA, died March 7, 2002. He was predeceased by his wife of forty years, Nancy Bryce Kelsey. He is survived by his wife Margaret Kipp Kelsey; his daughters Melie, Jenny and Margot, and five grandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 16th at 2:00 PM, St. Elizabeth's Church, Ridgewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Island People's Project, Fishers Island, NY 06390.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Identity Crisis; Is Anyone Driving A Ford Lately?
description: THE Taliban drove Toyotas. They even drove some G.M. trucks. But they didn't drive Fords.

title: Trading Places
description: To the Editor:

title: Rattling New Sabers
description: In setting forth major changes in the kinds of nuclear weapons the United States builds, and in their kinds of targets, a secret report to Congress describes in detail the military gains the Pentagon is seeking. But it says much less about the diplomatic price the Pentagon is willing to pay.

title: Bocelli's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: This Is Not News. A Son Of Hudson County Rises.
description: For some people, exiting the political scene feels like a well-deserved retirement. They leave office and begin booking golf dates or plan overdue vacations. Not so with former Assemblyman Rudy Garcia, who was unceremoniously ousted from the Democratic ticket in Hudson County last fall and who resigned as mayor of Union City two years ago after his own party began a recall.

title: The Nation; Alamo Redux: A Mission Impossible
description: THE biggest news in San Antonio last week wasn't a conference of scholars ruminating on the anniversary of the battle of the Alamo, which took place on March 6, 1836. San Antonio plays host to Alamo conferences the way Hollywood opens its arms to award shows. The real news is that there is going to be another movie about the Alamo (actually, there may be three). Michael D. Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, recently proclaimed that his studio's film intended to ''capture the post-Sept. 11 surge in patriotism.''

title: STATE BONDS DOWNGRADED
description: Moody's Investor Service last week downgraded its rating of New Jersey's bonds, making it more expensive for the state to borrow money. The service dropped $3.5 billion in bonds from Aa1 to Aa2. Though citing the state's revenue losses and high spending, Moody's commended Governor McGreevey for cutting $1 billion from the current budget. Moody's predicted that because of his pledge not to raise taxes, the state will take several years to return to fiscal health.

title: Baseball Museum Show To Visit New York
description: Devoted fans and the merely curious who have yet to visit the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., may soon find the hall visiting them. A major exhibition, ''Baseball as America,'' featuring treasures from the game that have never before been shown outside the hall, will be at the American Museum of Natural History in New York from Saturday to Aug. 18 before moving on to nine other museums.

title: Television/Radio; When AM Ruled Music, and WABC Was King
description: BEFORE anyone heard of MTV or MP3's, the most important source of popular music in the country was a New York radio station: Musicradio 77 WABC.

title: Bringing 'Hamlet' Home
description: CAMPBELL SCOTT went to college hoping to become a history teacher. With his affable manner and intellectual intensity, you can almost picture him as one.

title: The Bottom of the Cup
description: THERE'S a tempest in a coffee pot brewing here these days.

title: Business; Soothed at the Movies
description: For a brief moment after the attacks, Hollywood was a kinder, gentler place. Premieres of action films like ''Collateral Damage,'' starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, were delayed. And highly competitive and backbiting studio executives exchanged niceties between bites of lobster salad at Spago in Beverly Hills. ''There was such a fear no one was going to the movies that people were rooting for one another,'' said Sherry Lansing, the chairwoman of Paramount Pictures.

title: Will This Race Include Time Off for Good Behavior?
description: James Treffinger, the Essex County executive and a leading Republican Senate candidate who has made campaign finance reform a major issue of his race, admitted recently that he violated the federal election law by accepting more money than limits allow from some donors during a 2000 campaign and using cash intended for a general election during a primary fight that same year.

title: After Battle, Injured Foes Are Treated With Allies
description: Perhaps the most striking thing about the field hospital run by the United States Army at this old Soviet airfield is that wounded Americans lie side by side with Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR PLAN SEES NEW TARGETS AND NEW WEAPONS
description: Outlining a broad overhaul of American nuclear policy, a secret Pentagon report calls for developing new nuclear weapons that would be better suited for striking targets in Iraq, Iran, North Korea, Syria and Libya.

description: To the Editor:
