description: To the Editor:

title: Two Heads For Music, Five Hits A Week
description: PHARRELL WILLIAMS, half of the songwriting and production team the Neptunes, was worried about his bag. An assistant had stashed it somewhere after sessions at Right Track Studios, a warren of recording rooms tucked into an office building near Times Square. Through Studio A, Studio B, a lounge, a reception area and an equipment storeroom, there was no sign of it. Mr. Williams searched while answering calls on his cell phone with a silvery earpiece that never left his ear; it looked like an accessory to the three-carat diamond stud next to it.

title: DataBank; Greenspan Speaks: Recession's Over
description: The National Bureau of Economic Research, the official dater of recessions, has not spoken yet. But the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, has, declaring on Thursday that the recession is over.

title: Unrest in Latin America
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill Manager Is Leaving
description: Merrill Lynch will lose another of its best-known fund managers when Stephen I. Silverman retires at the end of the month. Since 1983, Mr. Silverman, 51, has managed Merrill's $720 million Pacific Fund, the best performer in its category over the last 10 years.

title: Executive Life; When Is a Partner Not Really a Partner?
description: IF you are a partner in a firm, you have no recourse to federal laws against workplace discrimination because you are a part-owner of the firm, not an employee.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE OTHER SIDE OF TRUTH

title: Changing Hearts
description: During a screening of the movie ''John Q.'' recently, I saw many in the audience spontaneously cheer for the working-class hero played by Denzel Washington. There were jeers, too, for the villains: the callous hospital administrator, the rich but indifferent cardiac surgeon and, of course, the sleazy H.M.O. The plot line is thin: John Q.'s little boy suddenly takes ill and needs a heart transplant, but John Q.'s H.M.O. won't cover the costs. His family earns too much to qualify for Medicaid or other assistance, and he has to shell out cash just to keep his son in the intensive-care unit. The hospital threatens to discharge the dying boy. A frustrated John Q. snaps and pulls a gun on the surgeon (to the loudest cheers in the audience) and takes over the E.R. In the end, John Q. prevails.

title: UnHamptons Prices and Open Year Round
description: RICCARDO TRASLAVINA and his wife didn't enjoy paying $140 to $160 for their dinners at Hamptons restaurants. Unlike other East Enders with similar complaints, Mr. Traslavina, a Chilean-born chef, has done something about it. Last December he opened American Bistro in Bridgehampton. It has been busy ever since.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NACK, SAUL H.
description: NACK-Saul H. On the occasion of the monument unveiling today, we take tribute and remember him for his deep devotion, support and friendship. American Friends of Yeshivot Bnei Akiva

title: Arizona Regains Poise In Tale of Two Halves
description: Lute Olson, the longtime coach of the Arizona Wildcats, was not too crazy about the decision by the Pacific-10 Conference to bring back its postseason tournament for the first time in 12 years.

title: Dance; Bodies,Imperfect But Still Moving
description: THE specter that has dared not speak its name has become almost voluble in recent years in dance. Bodies that would once have been considered imperfect -- fat, disabled or old -- are now in unselfconscious evidence in work that makes a virtue of their imperfection. That was the case with performances last month by Lawrence Goldhuber and Homer Avila.

title: Finding Pockets of Resistance to Economic Optimism
description: ROBERT J. BARBERA, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, says he will leave it to ''economic theologians'' to decide how to describe the recent economic downturn.

title: TRANSIT POLICE AND TERRORISM
description: A study by the former New York City police commissioner William J. Bratton has concluded that New Jersey Transit's police force is not prepared to handle a terrorist attack. The report said the agency's 120-member police force lacks the training to protect the 400,000 daily bus and rail commuters. The report, which was completed in the fall and reported on last week in The Star-Ledger of Newark, recommends that the agency should create divisions to monitor troubled train stations and to crack down on fare-beating. John Holl

title: Can America Quench Its Thirst?
description: To the Editor:

title: Amtrak: More Riders, And More Losses
description: IN the dramatic endings to silent movies, the heroine was tied to the railroad tracks by the villain, with the audience wondering if the hero would arrive in time to save her. In real life these days, it is the oncoming train that is on the brink, waiting for a miraculous rescue.

title: 2 Helicopters Crash at Sea Hours Apart; 2 Are Killed
description: Two civilians working for the Marine Corps were killed, a marine rescuer was lost at sea and four other marines were pulled to safety after two helicopters crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off Georgia about 5 miles and 13 hours apart on Friday night and early yesterday, military officials reported.

title: Trunk Show
description: Tall and lean, his body the color of California redwood, Mark Spitz stands in the evolutionary scale of our imagination as the living embodiment of 70's Man. His seven gold medals, freshly minted from the 1972 Munich Olympic Games, hang from his neck like so many medallions at a disco. The neatened mustache speaks of an electric trimmer. His helmet of hair could take a bullet meant for either Starsky or Hutch. But his trunks -- the cheesy, skimpy uniform of the United States men's Olympic swim team -- look as if they were plucked from this season's catwalks.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Pound Ridge; A Haven for the Rural Way of Life
description: IN many parts of Pound Ridge, the rugged landscape seems to have been only gently altered by humans since the glaciers receded. In contrast to some of its neighbors, the town, Westchester's smallest in area, has marked its topography over the years not with highways and malls but rather with stone walls and narrow country roads that wind past meandering brooks, stone outcroppings and densely wooded hills.

title: California Governor Looks to a Predecessor's Playbook for Fall Campaign
description: Republicans who wonder how Gov. Gray Davis of California, a Democrat, will wage his re-election campaign against Bill Simon Jr. in the next eight months need not look further than the playbook of Mr. Davis's Republican predecessor, Pete Wilson.

title: Fake Fifty Passed At Library In Bedford
description: ONE afternoon last month, a librarian at the Bedford Free Library gathered up the cash from a day of collected fines and fees and walked it across the street to the bank.

title: Voters Brave Long Lines And Threats In Zimbabwe
description: Voters in Zimbabwe turned out today in what appeared to be record numbers for the first day of the country's long-awaited presidential election, hopeful that it would bring an end to years of political turmoil but fearful that it could touch off even more trouble.

title: For Gap Shoppers, A Question of Age
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: ISLAND: The Complete Stories, by Alistair MacLeod. (Vintage International, $14.) The author's short fiction -- just 16 stories published over 33 years -- deals intimately with life on his native Cape Breton Island in Nova Scotia. His work centers on the pathos of social change in a generation of miners, fishermen, loggers and other proud souls that is slowly yielding to prosperity, education and wayward offspring who live a less authentic existence. ''Rarely does a great writer offer himself to us with an oeuvre so complete yet so small,'' John Sutherland wrote in the Book Review last year.

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean
description: 'Apologies Day'' is not the answer. We're killing girls' spirit trying to make them conform to impossible ideals of goodness. When girls are allowed the kind of aggression that boys have been allowed, when we acknowledge their very human capacities to want to have power over another and to want to hurt, their anger won't be expressed as often in secret and backhanded ways.

title: 13 Stripes, 50 Stars, 800 Tired Workers
description: SIX months ago tomorrow afternoon, Joe LaPaglia, the president of Annin & Company, the oldest and largest flag manufacturer in the United States, called a meeting of managers at its headquarters in Roseland, N.J. He knew that there would be a jump in demand for American flags, but not that it would be the largest surge for any product in his 35-year career.

title: Next: How to Sell a Publishing House
description: You'll probably still be able to find a copy of ''New York's 50 Best Places to Find Peace and Quiet'' to give to a stressed-out friend, peruse bridal dress hot spots in ''City Wedding'' and seek unexpected romantic advice in ''How to Meet a Mensch in New York.''

title: Oscar Films/View From Abroad; The Actor Next Door Quietly Savors His New Fame
description: SOME actors enjoy name recognition, others are remembered for the parts they play. Tom Wilkinson's destiny was to become an actor who enhances his roles rather than his star power. So even after his Academy Award nomination for best actor, he may still need to be identified as the good-natured Maine doctor in Todd Field's ''In the Bedroom.''

title: I'd Like To Buy The World a Shelf-Stable Children's Lactic Drink
description: Kazuki Yamane, Makoto Sato and I hop out of our chauffeured car at the corner of a busy Tokyo intersection. The two men are wearing suits, and I follow them into the bustle, distracted by teeming madness all around me. Some sort of shrieking dance squad is handing out free cosmetics samples. Multiple massive TV screens beam loops of commercials down to the street. The pedestrian flow is a blocks-thick surge of teenagers tapping at their cellphones.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about attitudes toward helping the poor in the aftermath of welfare cutbacks misstated the location of a mother of six working as a janitor. She was in Milwaukee, not New York.

title: Suffolk Legislator Wants Grucci's Seat
description: Vivian Viloria-Fisher, a Suffolk County legislator from Setauket, formally announced last week that she is a Democratic candidate for Congress in the First Congressional District on eastern Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEPRIN, JACK
description: WEPRIN-Jack. 1930-1996. A dear friend is alway remembered with love. Marti

title: Oil Industry Hesitates Over Moving Into Arctic Refuge
description: More than three decades ago, the world's largest energy companies led the charge to drill for oil on the North Slope of Alaska. But now, as the debate rages over opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration, those same companies remain surprisingly silent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIRI, MARGARET GLADSTONE MCKINNEY
description: WEIRI-Margaret Gladstone McKinney at 90 years, native of Winnetka, IL. Crusader-activist for human rights, years committed to Gray Panthers. Received UUA Distinguished Service Award for NGO-UN committee work. Graduate studies: music, anthropology. Vibrant, inspiration for young people. Survived by: sister Elizabeth McKinney Chmiel; children: Robyn Weiri Ray, Franklin Owen Weiri; grandchildren Franklin Dean Weiri, Melissa Robyn Ray, Alysa Beth Ray; grandchildren: Tyler Weiri, Sebastian Weiri, Connor Angus Quinn-Ray. Memorial service on April 1st 2PM chapel All Soul's Church, Lexington at 80th. Donations: Search for Common Ground (www.sfcg.org).

title: The Bittersweet Smell of the Broadway of Yore
description: BRUCE GOLDSTEIN, the irrepressible revivalist at Film Forum in SoHo, asserts that there are three great New York movies and that ''Sweet Smell of Success,'' the 1957 film noir classic about the ambient cruelty of an Olympian gossip columnist, is surely one of them.

title: Women Deserve Better
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Afghans, the Bank Is Often a Bag of Cash
description: LAST October at Da Afghanistan Bank, Mullah Muhammad Omar, the one-eyed warrior cleric who is the Taliban's proclaimed emir, wrote a check for 93,418,734 Pakistan rupees, or about $1.5 million. He wanted to write another one on the Taliban's American-dollar account with the bank, but he couldn't find the checkbook.

title: Art/Architecture; The Other Klee, the One Who's Not on Postcards
description: ARTISTS who earn a permanent place in the public imagination usually do so through the instant recognizability of their work. Familiarity is reassuring. Originality becomes mundane. In that sense, Paul Klee is no different from a dozen other leading 20th-century artists. Early in his career, he produced the semiabstract patchwork paintings -- colored squares with hints at figuration -- for which he is best remembered. Today, they are sold as postcards and posters.

title: Their Loves: Travel, Coaching, Cats, Foosball, Cokes and Saving Lives
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on The World Trade Center.

title: Lanza's Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: LIPA's Overreliance On Fossil Fuels
description: It is hard to believe that Matthew Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, will have his group focus on seven issues [''The Island's Economic Issues,'' Jan. 27] but fails to include energy on the list.

title: Television/Radio; Turning a Television Into a Music Box
description: SO, how do you like all those new music channels on your TV?'' a jazz singer I know asked me last fall. I made puzzled noises, to which she happily replied that she had just subscribed to Time Warner Cable's digital service and was now receiving 40 music-only channels, each of which offered round-the-clock, commercial-free programming. I followed her lead a couple of weeks later and subsequently discovered that many New Yorkers -- including more than a few digital cable subscribers who had access to channels 601 through 640 but had never taken the time to find out what was on them -- were as unaware as I had been that they could use their television sets as cutting-edge radios.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: GLICKSTEIN-Joseph. On March 8, 2002. Retired Professor of Chemistry at Brooklyn College, CUNY. Beloved husband of Virginia. Grandfather of Ben and Gabrielle. Memorial service Sunday, March 10, 3PM, Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (20th St. NYC).

title: Top-Secret Basketball Jury Decides Who's In, Who's Out
description: Since Wednesday, Judy Rose has been sequestered on the 15th floor of the Westin Hotel in Indianapolis with nine other people. A security guard stands sentinel at the elevators, keeping away visitors. The only meals are from room service. They talk to no one but each other, and if their families need to reach them at the hotel, they must use a secret code.

title: Toy Heaven In Tinseltown
description: It seems odd that F.A.O. Schwarz took so long to set up a store in youth-obsessed Los Angeles -- after all, Barbie is from Malibu. Still, the eagerly awaited 25,000-square-foot outpost opens Friday in a new open-air shopping mall in Hollywood called the Grove. Outside the store, a 22-foot four-ton herald-soldier will greet the toddling clientele with waving arms and music. Inside, the company's trademark clock tower has a Tinseltown tweak, with animated bears that resemble cinematic icons like Charlie Chaplin, a reference that seems intended to register more with parents than with children. Although the inventory closely mirrors that of the Fifth Avenue store, which is about three times the size of the Los Angeles store, it offers more trampolines, skateboard ramps and other backyard contraptions ill suited to an urban co-op. On opening day, Reggie Jackson, the former Yankee, and Steve Garvey, the former Los Angeles Dodger, will unveil the rerelease of Mattel's 1978 classic electronic hand-held baseball game -- with luck, to an audience of glamorous celebrity moms, who will lend a new meaning to the phrase ''babes in toyland.'' MONICA CORCORAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, SOL
description: SHAPIRO-Sol. On March 6, 2002 we lost a great man who succeeded in every possible way. He is survived by his beloved wife Helen, adoring children Linda and husband Milton, Robert and wife Sharon, cherished grandchildren Douglas and wife Lisa, Daniel, Jacqueline, Michael, and great grandchild Andrew. Also survived by devoted sister Sylvia. A retired Executive of the William Morris Agency, whose career span over four decades. He was a trusted confidant and agent to some of the world's greatest entertainers. A man of tremendous generosity, selflessness and honesty who will be deeply missed by his family and friends.

title: A Divide-and-Conquer Strategy Comes Back to Haunt
description: THE first American recession in a decade has been deemed history almost before it began. None other than Alan Greenspan, in testimony before Congress last week, opined that the recent data indicate that the economic recovery is now well under way.

title: Squeezed Out
description: REGENA HARRIS has a place in the Hamptons. It's right by the water and a stone's throw from some of the most expensive property on the planet, and she can't wait to get out.

title: Habitats/Astoria, Queens; A Time for Reconnecting With a Childhood Home
description: CYNTHIA DE MONTE has a big house in New Jersey with five bedrooms and a swimming pool on more than an acre. It is a dream house. Unfortunately, it is not her dream.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SASH, JERRY
description: SASH-Jerry. March 12, 2000. We miss you every minute of every day. Love, Barbara, Stacey, Alec, Terri and Family

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean
description: There is much to admire about Wiseman's energy and dedication. But she seems caught up with appearing hip, generating cute labels for different cliques and behavior models. When asked what they remembered most about her program, several girls spoke of learning about being popular.

title: Oops! Paying My Neighbor's Taxes
description: MY famously prosperous-yet-broke county has mystical ways of determining assessments on property, so it didn't overly surprise me a while back when my mortgage company sent a letter saying there was a shortfall in my escrow account for taxes.

title: Ding, Dong, the Cultural Witch Hunt Is Dead
description: The tactics of the Washington right, described in David Brock's expos, resemble the behavior of the immature girls. Both use the same types of verbal assaults, innuendo, anonymous lies and unflattering tales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARO, DR. HERMAN.
description: CARO-Dr. Herman. Heartfelt condolences to Kate Caro. A Silver Founder of the Medical Center together with Kate, Herman was a kind and generous man whose open hand epitomized the highest standards of Jewish tradition. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Med. Cntr. in Jerusalem

title: Saluting Five of the Island's High-Tech Pioneers
description: PETER GOLDSMITH acknowledged that he didn't know all that much about the life of Elmer Ambrose Sperry, but he had come to the Garden City Hotel to celebrate Sperry's life anyway. And he and 500 others did so in high style.

title: It's All in Arizona
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''To Find America, Get Lost,'' by Lesley Hazleton, and ''A Soothing Jaunt in Rugged Arizona,'' by Judith Anderson (Dec. 16), I wish to thank both authors for writing about Arizona and Cochise County with such understanding and feeling.

title: In Aftermath of Temple Fire, Sikhs Pray, and Share Sorrow
description: If today were a normal Sunday at the Sikh gurdwara in the Richmond Hill section of Queens, as many as 4,000 worshipers would sing prayers, meditate and share a meal at the temple, the oldest and largest Sikh gathering place in the region.

title: OVER ALREADY?
description: The nation's 10th post-war recession is almost assuredly over. The official word will probably not come for months, but Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, above, said the recovery seems to be well under way. If he is right -- and there is a raft of data to back him up, including a decline in the February unemployment rate -- it will have been one of the briefest, mildest downturns on record. Some economists now say it did not qualify as a recession at all. The rebound could have broad effects on politics and policy. The Fed is likely to push up interest rates later this year, and the budget surplus could reappear. Richard W. Stevenson

title: A Pro Tennis Player Who Began in Yonkers
description: WHEN James Blake, who grew up in Yonkers, went to Harvard, he was nationally ranked as the No. 1 player in the United States Tennis Associaton's 18 and under division. His goal in college, he said, was to be in the top four on his varsity team. By the time he left school to turn pro after his sophomore season, he was the No. 1 ranked college player in the nation.

title: The Long Goodbye

You don't have hearses and lines and lines of cars in cemeteries.

title: CAR SEARCHES
description: In a decision expected to discourage racial profiling by the police, the State Supreme Court ruled last week that officers cannot search a car without ''reasonable and articulable'' suspicion of criminal activity. Most states, and federal law, allow searches during traffic stops so long as the driver consents. But the New Jersey court, reasoning that consent may not be truly voluntary when a driver is pulled over and confronted by an officer, held that the state constitution requires more. Laura Mansnerus

title: Six Months Later
description: Any realistic estimate of where we are, six months after Sept. 11, begins with the families, the businesses, the downtown neighbors most immediately affected by that increasingly distant day. For them, and to a lesser extent for all of us, the rate of recovery at the World Trade Center site is the best metaphor. The wreckage has nearly all been removed, but in its place there remains an empty pit, as symbolic in its own way as the fallen shards of the towers themselves. Most of the victims' families have faced the worst of what they have to face, and what remains is the day-to-day recognition of an emptiness that should never have been.

title: The Sleeping Bag Strategy
description: Campaign finance legislation reached an important milestone last week when Senator Tom Daschle sent word to senators to get out their cots and sleeping bags. Diehard opponents of the Shays-Meehan bill, which passed the House last month, are preparing for an old-fashioned filibuster -- talking the bill to death -- because they don't have the votes to kill it outright. Obstructionist tactics have become the last refuge of such reform foes as Senators Phil Gramm of Texas and Mitch McConnell of Kentucky. Mr. Daschle should confront them this week by moving to the Shays-Meehan bill and filing an immediate motion to cut off debate and get a quick vote on the bill.

description: There was a rule, back when I was an education lawyer in Alabama, about visiting public schools: always go on a rainy day, so you can see how badly the roofs leak. It was just like old times last week when I dropped in on Russell Elementary, outside Hayneville, in the middle of a heavy downpour. As I talked with a county official about how little money he had to work with, we both dodged the puddle that was rapidly forming in the hall outside the principal's office.

I wrote a poem in my head and then I wrote it down, and after that writing was the only thing I wanted to do.

title: 'It's Reliving a Nightmare'
description: It all came flooding back for Eric Redwine and Lesley Esters last night as they sat in the living room of their brownstone in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, struggling to watch ''9/11.'' From the moment it began, with its much-talked-about unseen images of the trade center attack, it was difficult television for a couple whose only connection to the tragedy was the grief and anguish they felt for the thousands of lives lost.

title: Prescription Card to Link Discount Programs Is Planned
description: An association representing chain drug stores plans to announce today that it is creating a new card to link the prescription discount plans for low-income elderly people. The plans have recently been offered by four major drug companies and could be offered by more.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Corpse Found At Waste Plant
description: A man who was convicted of murder in 1973 and paroled more than a year ago was found shot to death at a plant that processes construction debris, the police said last week. The body of the man, Patrick Flynn, 48, was found March 2 at a garbage transfer station in the Williamsburg section. Mr. Flynn was last seen on Feb. 28 at the Manhattan construction site where he had been working, the police said. The medical examiner ruled the death a homicide, noting that Mr. Flynn had been shot in the face and chest. Debris is brought in Dumpsters to the transfer station, so the police said Mr. Flynn was probably killed elsewhere. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Mixture of styles reigns as retailers seek to break down barriers : Manhattan's design shops embrace fashion
description: NEW YORK  Manhattan design shops, long indifferent to matters sartorial, are revealing a new affinity for fashion, finding relevance in mini Italian coats serving as water bottle carriers, haute couture gowns inspired by Harley Davidson motorcycles, and lingerie flecked with images of Studebakers, produced by high-tech Russian cameras. Fashion and design, often separated, are learning to coexist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGEN, BEATRICE

She is survived by sisters Henrietta Honeyman, Marjorie Lubell, Clarisse Ruchames, brother Elliot Blaustein, and numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral arrangements are private.

title: Arrests in Korean Strike

Several hundred demonstrators shouted, ''No sellout, no layoffs,'' as the police stormed the Chogye Temple, where union leaders had retreated to avoid arrest. The union called the strike two weeks ago to protest the government's plan to sell the power corporation to private companies.

Cherished uncle and brother-in-law. His humanity was a touchstone to all who knew him. Services 12 noon, Monday, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Contributions may be made in his memory to Good Shepherd Hospice, 1220 Front St, Uniondale, NY 11553.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, WYATT CLAIBORNE
description: JONES-Wyatt Claiborne. Born May 4, 1919 in Cullman, AL died in Houston, TX, March 3, 2002 of Alzheimers. He was the son of William Claiborne and Rebecca Jones. He attended Cullman Public Schools and was a graduate of St. Bernard College, Cullman; Birmingham Southern College, Birmingham, AL and Vanderbilt Univeristy, Nashville, TN, Graduate School of Divinity. Early in his professional career, he was employed by the Methodist Publishing House in Nashville in the editorial division as Associate Editor of Youth Publications. He decided to further pursue his higher education and entered New York University, where he completed his studies and earned a Ph.D. in Sociology. Wyatt spent the remainder of his career as a professor in the Sociology Department of Brandeis University, Waltham, MA. Following his retirement from Brandeis University, he founded the Wyatt Jones Dissertation Endowment Fund at Brandeis. Burial will be in Cullman Cemetery, Cullman, AL. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMPSON, ELEANOR
description: SIMPSON-Eleanor A. Beloved wife and best friend of Harvey, beloved mother of William, proud and devoted grandmother of William, Jr., and cherished friend of his mother, Lisa, and loving sister of Trudy Lucke Rose, died on March 9. A woman of extraordinary ability and character and devoted to community service, she served 10 years as Mayor of the Village of Old Westbury and over a period of 30 years also served the community in the positions of Deputy Mayor, Police Commissioner, Village Trustee, and a member of the Planning Board. She also served as President of the Nassau County Village Officials Association, as a member of the Long Island Area Development Agency, as a Trustee of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts, on the Executive Committee of the New York State Conference of Mayors, and as a Trustee of the Old Westbury Gardens where she launched and chaired the Picnic Pops, the Garden's summer concert series. Always a pioneer, she was the first woman mayor and first woman to head a police department in Nassau County. As Director of the Long Island Tourism and Convention Commission, she was instrumental in bringing the International Games for the Disabled to Long Island. She was also a Trustee and member of the Academic Affairs and University Relations Committees of Long Island University - C.W. Post Campus and a member of the Council of Overseers - Tilles Center. An ardent skier and gifted gardener, she loved cooking, opera, deep sea fishing, music, and playing the organ and accordion. Ellie, you gave so much to your family, friends, and community. You are loved and will be missed by all who knew you. Funeral services will be held at Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Avenue, Westbury, NY, Wednesday, March 13 at 11 AM. Visitation from 2-4 and 7-9 PM on Tuesday, March 12, at the Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Old Westbury Gardens or the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, ROBERT KELLOGG
description: HESS-Robert Kellogg. Retired VP of Brakeley, John Price Jones, NY fundraising consultants, died in Hendersonville, NC, on March 3, 2002, after an extended illness. He was 82 years old. Graduate Bronxville HS 1937 and Dartmouth College 1941. Member Theta Chi. WWII, served more than 4 years in the Army. Final Rank, First Lieutenant, Infantry. During 30 years in fundraising worked on major campaigns for Williams College, U. of Michigan, MIT, Stanford U., U. of Pennsylvania and others. He is survived by his beloved wife, Shirley Abel Hess of Hendersonville, NC, a son, William Wayne Hess of Fairfield, OH, a daughter, Nancy Kellogg Gray of NYC, two grandsons, Bryan Wayne Hess & Robert Lewis Hess of Indianapolis, and a granddaughter, Dora Grace Kellogg Gray of NYC. Mr. Hess was a member of the Reformed Church & Siwanoy Country Club of Bronxville, NY, and of the Polish American Social Club of Vero Beach, FL. No public services will be held. Gifts may be sent to Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH 03755.

title: In Lights at Ground Zero, Steps Toward Illumination
description: ''Tribute in Light'' is a moving piece of urban spectacle. The project's impact surpasses even the dramatic digital renderings that have been circulated widely since last fall. In the renderings, the twin light towers appear to be saying something. As realized, they seem to be looking for something. More a question than a statement, the project sets a rhetorical tone worthy of emulation by those who will be shaping the future of Lower Manhattan in days to come.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Toys 'R' Us Unit Accused Of Bias
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has filed a federal discrimination lawsuit against Babies ''R'' Us, accusing it of failing to protect a cashier at a store in Paterson from a sexually hostile work environment. The lawsuit filed on Thursday asserted that co-workers mocked the cashier, Andres Vasquez, because he dressed in an effeminate manner. In one incident, the lawsuit said, co-workers removed his pants and hung them on a cash register light post. The lawsuit said the harassment forced Mr. Vasquez to quit. Rebecca Caruso, a company spokeswoman for Babies ''R'' Us, a unit of Toys ''R'' Us, said the company had not yet seen the lawsuit but does not tolerate harassment by employees. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Ready to Quit, but Deep in Debt
description: SAVING for retirement is hard enough without being in debt. But more Americans than ever before are finding themselves on the cusp of retirement and in the red.

title: A Coach and His Team Are Forged in Adversity
description: The rough road is not so bumpy now. Sidney Green playfully chides his friends from 10 years in the National Basketball Association that none of them spoiled by the N.B.A.'s riches would have even been tempted to take his low-budget, patience-challenging route to success as a college coach.

title: The Body May Creak, but the Brain Hums Along
description: OLDER but wiser is a phrase not heard much anymore, as attention has focused on time's less-kind effect on the brain. But are there advantages to having lived a lot, seen a lot and -- maybe -- thought a lot?

title: In London, putting touch of whimsy into jewelry
description: LONDON  I wanted to created something that was pure, yet totally luxurious," says the young British designer Russell Sage of the transparent twists of glass jewelry he created for his recent autumn 2002 London show. Known for using delicate fabrics such as antique French and Gainsborough silks, this season Sage is concerned with the more exclusive aspects of fashion. "Now it's time to concentrate on luxury and quality," he says.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Serial Killer's Appeal Rejected
description: Joel Rifkin's bid for new trials in the murders of several women on Long Island and in New York City was rejected yesterday by New York's highest court. The Court of Appeals refused, without comment, to hear the case of Mr. Rifkin, who had sought a ruling that his confession to killing 17 women was inadmissible. He was arrested in Nassau County in 1993 after police officers found a woman's body in his truck during a routine traffic stop. Mr. Rifkin pleaded guilty to several of the killings and received multiple sentences of 25 years to life, to be served consecutively. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

description: TIM HOWARD will take it. After all, a shutout is a shutout. In soccer jargon, a clean sheet.

title: Jet Like One in Queens Crash Shows Sign of Damage to Tail
description: Investigators looking into the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 in Queens last Nov. 12 said today that they had discovered ''indications of damage'' in the tail of another plane of the same model -- an Airbus A300 -- that was involved in an in-flight accident near West Palm Beach, Fla., five years ago.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Infineon Signs Pact With Two Companies
description: Infineon Technologies, one of Europe's largest semiconductor makers, said yesterday that it had signed agreements with the Winbond Electronics Corporation and Mosel Vitelic, both of Taiwan, to bolster production of computer memory chips. Infineon will increase its monthly production capacity by 20,000 wafers, or discs from which chips are cut, under the Windbond pact. The company will also increase its share of the capacity at ProMOS Technologies, a company it holds jointly with Mosel, to 48 percent from 38 percent. Chip makers suffered their worst slump last year as demand from computer makers declined. Earlier this month, Infineon said it was selling chips for a higher price because of increased demand.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Rises At BMW
description: BMW said its profit rose 54 percent last year as sales rose 3.3 percent. Net income rose to 1.87 billion euros ($1.64 billion), from 1.2 billion, while sales rose to 38.46 billion euros, BMW said. The company, which is based in Munich, was reporting full-year results for the first time since it sold its money-losing Rover unit in Britain.

title: One Man's One-Man Library
description: David Vise, a Washington Post reporter and author of the possibly best-selling book ''The Bureau and the Mole,'' recently bought 20,000 copies of his own book online and returned 17,000 of them, a move some regarded as an attempt to manipulate the best-seller lists. Others wondered if Mr. Vise was using online discounts to parlay his tome into a hardcover version of pork bellies. The most literary explanation is that Mr. Vise is picking up where Henry David Thoreau left off. After taking 706 copies of ''A Week on the Concord and Merrimack Rivers'' off his publisher's hands, Thoreau wrote, ''I have now a library of nearly nine hundred volumes, over seven hundred of which I wrote myself.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Avaya To Cut 1,900 Jobs
description: Avaya Inc., a communications company that was spun off from Lucent Technologies, said it would sell $100 million in stock and reduce its work force by more than 8 percent, or about 1,900 employees, in an effort to strengthen its finances. As part of the plan, Warburg Pincus Equity Partners would get a stake of about 16 percent in the company through stock transactions, officials said. The company, which cut 5,000 jobs last year, said the moves, which are a result of a lowered sales outlook and the slowdown in technology and communications spending, would save it about $180 million to $200 million a year. Company officials said second-quarter figures would probably fall short of previous forecasts. Avaya, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., said it had filed for antitrust clearance for the Warburg Pincus agreement from the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission. The company, a leading maker of voice and data networks for businesses, said it would take charges of more than $200 million for the reorganization.

title: TENET HEALTHCARE TOPS PROFIT ESTIMATES FOR QUARTER
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, a leading hospital chain, said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter earnings topped estimates as older patients made more visits for treatment. Tenet said profit for the quarter ended Feb. 28 exceeded the average estimate of 81 cents a share of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. The company earned 60 cents a share a year earlier. The company has been concentrating on more profitable services like cardiology and oncology and has cut costs and reduced interest expense by repaying some debt. Tenet said it expected earnings per share from operations to grow at least 35 percent in fiscal 2002.

A visionary committed to making medical and health research a higher national priority, he leaves a legacy of strong leadership for research to improve health care quality, health care disparities, and a dedication to ensuring that health care is based on a strong foundation of research. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Tough Times For College Endowments
description: A weak stock market has hurt the endowments of New Jersey colleges and universities, causing some to lose tens of millions of dollars, a recent report shows. The report, released by the National Association of College and University Business Offices, indicates that Drew University's endowment fell in value by 7.9 percent, or $18 million, Rutgers University's by 6.8 percent, or $30 million, and Princeton's by 0.5 percent, or $39 million. The average loss among the 610 schools surveyed was 3.6 percent. The 2001 fiscal year was the first year since 1984 in which there was a drop in the average endowment, an association spokesman said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Guilty Of Smuggling
description: Four men arrested in Charlotte almost two years ago entered guilty pleas to charges that they conspired to smuggle millions of dollars in cigarettes and funnel the money to the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah, which the United States regards as a terrorist organization. They face a maximum sentence of 20 years on each charge. The authorities said three other men also planned to plead guilty to racketeering charges. In addition, three more defendants are set to stand trial on April 15. One, Said Mohamad Harb, 31, is charged with planning to provide guns and explosives to Hezbollah. He could get up to 60 years in prison if convicted. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Keep College Open to the Poor
description: The New York State Tuition Assistance Program has propelled millions of poor and middle-income New Yorkers through college since the Legislature created the program a quarter of a century ago. The value of the TAP is obvious, given that people with college degrees earn substantially more over their lifetimes -- and pay significantly more in taxes -- than those who do not. This gospel of economic uplift has generally been lost on Gov. George Pataki, who has tried since his earliest days in office to cut the TAP or reshape it in harmful ways. The governor's most recent idea, to replace part of the TAP grant with loans, is another in a long succession of bad proposals.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Child Rights Lawyer Sentenced
description: A Long Island lawyer who specialized in representing abused children was sentenced yesterday to 22 months in federal prison for sending computer files containing child pornography, the Bergen County prosecutor's office said. The man, Bradley Kurtzberg, 35, of Melville, N.Y., pleaded guilty in October. He received a lighter sentence than the 27 to 33 months recommended by sentencing guidelines because he expressed remorse, prosecutors said. A federal judge recommended that Mr. Kurtzberg serve in the sex offender program at the Federal Correctional Institution in Butner, N.C. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Russians Arrive Bearing Shostakovich
description: The debate about what Shostakovich ''meant'' in his music is probably incapable of resolution. Did he yield to pressure from the Soviet authorities and obediently write Socialist Realist paeans to the system, or did he maintain an inner resistance, reflected in the ironic, bitter twist evident in much of his music?

title: Ohio Board Hears Debate on an Alternative to Darwinism
description: Proponents of the intelligent-design movement, which challenges Darwin's primacy in the science classroom, argued for equal footing in the state's new teaching curriculum today, while critics warned that speculative theories of some ultimate agent underpinning evolution were the antithesis of true science.

title: Troubles at Arthur Andersen Threaten Times Square Deal
description: Two years ago, the accounting firm Arthur Andersen was the latest corporation to announce it would move its headquarters to a Times Square made safe for families, tourists and even accountants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAGARIN, ANDREW
description: GAGARIN-Andrew, March 8, 2002 in Big Sur, California. Survived by his wife, Jamie Gagarin, his daughter, Genia Pujol, his sons, Michael Gagarin and Peter Gagarin, & two grandchildren. Contributions may be sent to St. Paul's School, Concord, NH.

title: Knicks Improve, but Keep Eye on Future
description: The standards have dropped significantly and the goals have changed. That is what happens when you are 23-38, when your destination is the lottery, when losing has become almost as commonplace as lacing up your sneakers.

title: In the 80's: Lights! Camera! Cigarettes!
description: Tobacco companies, hoping that smoking scenes in Hollywood movies would increase sales, worked diligently through the 1980's and early 90's to get as much screen time for their brands as possible, a British medical report says, and at least one company went so far as to provide free cigarettes to actors and directors who might therefore be more inclined to light up when the cameras rolled.

title: Astronomical Journeys
description: To the Editor:

title: The Uneasy Fit Of the Precocious And the Average
description: Elizabeth Chapman wanted to give her son, Justin, more opportunities and a better life, she said.

title: Bank Inquiry Not Expected To Pinpoint Trader's Help
description: An Irish bank's internal investigation of a Baltimore currency trader who lost $691 million will not provide definitive answers about whether he had help inside or outside the bank in hiding the losses, a person close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: A Guide to Savvy Bracket Pool Play
description: The N.C.A.A. selection committee made it easy for casual bracket players: Maryland is seeded No. 1 in the East, Kansas in the Midwest, Duke in the South and Cincinnati in the West. You pencil those teams into the Final Four, pick a winner and sweat the tie breakers. Or you can try to beat the odds with the following two scenarios.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATEREK, STEPHANIE (NEE DAZZO)
description: PATEREK-Stephanie (nee Dazzo). On March 10th, 2002 of Plandome. Beloved wife of James. Devoted mother of Juliet and Jimmy. Cherished daughter of John and Angela Dazzo. Loving sister of Mark. Dear granddaughter of Sylvia Dazzo and Joseph Buffalano. Also survived by many loving family members and close friends. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Tuesday and Wednesday 3-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 10:30 AM St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset.

title: Big Corporations Combine To Negotiate Airline Fares
description: Large corporations, frustrated by the cost of travel from airports dominated by a single carrier, are teaming up in several cities to investigate ways to spur competition and negotiate lower fares.

title: Astronomical Journeys
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning to Cope When Hospital Patients Turn Violent
description: One night last spring when I was on call at my hospital, I was paged at midnight. An alcoholic was spinning out of control in a ward. Could I admit him to the intensive care unit for observation?

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Iraq Pressed On Missing Kuwaitis
description: Yuli M. Vorontsov, the United Nations official responsible for tracking Kuwaitis who disappeared in the months after Iraq's 1990 invasion, said Iraq would sooner or later have to reveal the fate of more than 600 missing Kuwaitis and others who disappeared. Mr. Voronstsov, who spoke in Cairo, is touring the region for talks on how to increase Iraqi cooperation on the issue. Iraq says that it lost all track of any prisoners during the uprising by Shiite Muslims in southern Iraq immediately after its withdrawal from Kuwait. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Livingston Strides Into Record Book
description: She is no longer the shy, awkward teenager who ran with such reckless abandon that she often collapsed from exhaustion at the end of races.

title: One Week Till Hewlett Vote, Battle Picks Up
description: Hewlett-Packard board members, both for and against the company's planned acquisition of Compaq Computer, unleashed fresh criticism today, trying to sway investors in the final week before a fiercely contested shareholder vote decides the deal.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: China Approves Banks
description: Two Taiwanese banks have won approval to open representative offices in China, opening another channel in commercial ties across the Taiwan Strait. United World Chinese Commercial Bank will open an office in Shanghai, while Chang Hwa will open one in Kunshan, a city west of Shanghai that is a base for many Taiwan companies. Six other banks are awaiting approval to open offices, a first step toward obtaining a license. Taiwan newspapers reported that China might allow the banks to open branches immediately, but Chinese officials denied those reports. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Washington Revives Plan to Send Monitors to Ease Mideast Strife
description: As part of its renewed peace efforts, the Bush administration has revived a proposal to send American monitors to help Israelis and Palestinians judge whether each side keeps its commitments as they try to negotiate a cease-fire, and Israel is receptive to the idea, diplomats said today.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: A House Challenger
description: A radio commentator from Ashland is seeking the Democratic nomination to challenge Representative Greg Walden, a two-term Republican. The commentator, Peter Buckley, 44, is the only candidate from either party opposing Mr. Walden; the filing deadline is today. A Democrat has not won the district, which includes southern and eastern Oregon, since 1978. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Albany Leaders Agree to Expand Role of Sex Offender Registry
description: Lawmakers agreed today to significantly expand New York State's registry of sex offenders, adding categories to the list and extending the length of time offenders must remain on it.

title: Editors' Note; SPECIAL TODAY: RETIREMENT
description: The residents of a Florida life-care facility may be old, but as a writer living among them has discovered, they have lost none of their wit or zest. Plus: Planning for retirement, and saving for it. SECTION G

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the purchase of Elantec Semiconductor by the Intersil Corporation, a microchip developer, referred incorrectly to Agere Systems, which trails Intersil in the market for chips for wireless networks. Agere is part of Lucent Technologies, which plans to spin it off. It is not a spinoff of Hewlett-Packard.

title: National Book Critics Circle Honors 'Austerlitz'
description: The National Book Critics Circle last night gave its prize for fiction to ''Austerlitz,'' by W. G. Sebald, a dreamlike meditation on memory and the Holocaust, published by Random House. Mr. Sebald died in December at 57, in a car accident near his home in Norwich, England.

title: Estimating the Time of the First Impact
description: It all began at 8:46:26 a.m. on Sept. 11, when a Boeing 767 rammed into the north tower at the World Trade Center. The second plane hit the south tower at 9:02:54 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHETRIT, BENJAMIN
description: CHETRIT-Benjamin. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of the father of Esther Chetrit, and extends condolences to the bereved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about Democrats' election prospects in the West misspelled the surname of a former Colorado Senate minority leader who is seeking the Democratic nomination to Colorado's Seventh Congressional District. He is Mike Feeley, not Feeney.

title: Just Tourists on Broadway, but Barefoot and Craving Roast Monkey
description: In most ways it was a typical courtroom hearing, but sitting among the lawyers in their pinstripe suits and wingtips at the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan yesterday were two barefoot men in palm skirts with blow-dart guns around their necks, and a third wearing a blue-and-yellow crown and a necklace made of feathers.

title: Editorial Observer; In Texas, the Republican Party's Sure Thing Faces Un Gran Problema
description: A Hispanic business tycoon willing to spend tens of millions of his own fortune on a maiden political venture is hard to come by. Still, Republicans witnessing Tony Sanchez's Texas gubernatorial campaign must be asking themselves: Why didn't we think of that?

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Rewriting the Law Books
description: The government convened an international panel of political experts to help the country revise its legal system, part of a continuing process of rebuilding the nation. President Paul Kagame called a number of Rwandan laws ''obsolete'' and said they had contributed to the mass killing that swept the country in 1994 because they ''favored impunity.'' The new system is expected to be voted on in a referendum later in the year. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Better Eating Habits, and Other Healthy Proposals
description: ''Sugar Busters! for Kids,'' by Dr. Sam S. Andrews, Dr. Luis A. Balart, Dr. Morrison C. Bethea and Dr. H. Leighton Steward, Ballantine Books, $23.95.

title: Setting the Time on the Benefits Clock
description: PREPARING for retirement is a full-time and often frustrating job. That's because the central question affecting all planning cannot be answered. Namely, how long are you going to live?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NECHAMKIN, LEON
description: NECHAMKIN-Leon. The Solomon Schechter School of Westchester notes with sorrow the death of Leon Nechamkin, father of our esteemed Trustee, Gabe Nechamkin. We extend our sincere condolences to Gabe, Beth, Daniel, Jacob and Sarah. May the memory of Leon Nechamkin be a blessing. M. Mac Schwebel, Chairman, Board of Trustees James M. Dubin, Vice Chairman Dr. Elliot Spiegel, Headmaster

title: Marion Countess Dnhoff, 92, a Leading Journalist Who Opposed Hitler
description: Marion Countess Dnhoff, an architect of German postwar journalism, over which she still towered as joint publisher of the liberal weekly Die Zeit, died yesterday. She was 92 and lived in Hamburg, where the highly influential intellectual newspaper is published.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONN, WILLIAM LOUIS
description: SONN-William Louis. On March 9, 2002. Beloved husband of Carolyn Blitz Sonn, father of Maretta, son of Alice C. Sonn and the late Howard M. Sonn, brother of Elizabeth Rose, Edward Sonn and Barbara Thanhauser. Friends and family will join to honor his memory at a service on Tuesday, March 12, at 4PM at the Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy, 26 West 84th St. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Churchill School & Center, 301 East 29th St., NY, NY 10016.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Valueclick To Buy Be Free For $128.5 Million
description: ValueClick, an online advertising company, agreed to buy Be Free Inc. for about $128.5 million in stock. ValueClick will exchange 0.65share for each Be Free share, or a total of 43.4 million shares, ValueClick said in a statement. The offer values Be Free at $1.95 a share, 26 percent more than its closing price of $1.55 on Friday. ValueClick closed at $2.96 on Friday. The purchase would allow ValueClick to offer its ad-aiming products to Be Free customers like Sprint, Verizon, Travelocity.com and I.B.M., a ValueClick spokeswoman, Elizabeth Lloyd, said. Be Free, which had about 166 employees at the end of last year, provides Internet marketing services that help businesses link and analyze the performance of Web sites, the chief financial officer, Stephen Joseph, said in an interview. Be Free has about 65.8 million shares outstanding, he said. Shareholders of Be Free will own about 45 percent of the combined company's shares outstanding; the deal is expected to be completed by the end of the second quarter. Shares of ValueClick fell 16 cents, to $2.80. Be Free shares rose 23 cents, to $1.78.

title: Flying Safer (if Not Friendlier) Skies
description: To the Editor:

title: Berlin, Banking on Its Museums; Seeking a New Identity, the City Shakes Up Its Art Legacy
description: When Berlin was united in 1990, many Germans were equally united in not wanting this city to become too powerful. Their fears were understandable but have proved unfounded. Berlin is again the German capital, but of a federal republic inoculated against centralism. It has undergone extensive reconstruction, yet it remains poor, with no industry and an insolvent city government. Its problem now is, How can it demonstrate that it really is the new Berlin?

title: A Piano-Playing Vocalist Who Simmers Her Flavors
description: Norah Jones

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Fine Over Bear's Death
description: The Department of Agriculture has fined the Denver Zoo $700 over the death of a bear last fall. The female Asiatic black bear was killed by a male bear after years of fights between the two animals. The federal agency determined that the zoo had violated ''animal compatibility'' regulations by continuing to house the bears together despite the history of fights. An animal rights activist with the Rocky Mountain Animal Defense called the fine ''a joke.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, ELISABETH SLOAN PRATT
description: LIVINGSTON - Elisabeth Sloan Pratt. The Board of Directors and Trustees of St. Johnland Nursing Center, Kings Park, New York, are deeply saddened by the loss of Elisabeth Sloan Pratt Livingston, a longtime friend and generous benefactor. She will be greatly missed. Her devotion to St. Johnland and ongoing support was inspiring to us all.

CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. 212-288-3500.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Hugh Morris Gloster, former president of Morehouse College, omitted the names of his previous wives and misstated the length of his marriage to Yvonne Arnold King, who survives. Dr. Gloster's first marriage, to Louise Elisabeth Torrence, ended in divorce. In 1957 he married Beulah Victoria Harold, who died in 1985. Dr. Gloster and Ms. King were married in 1989, not 45 years ago.

title: Night Problems May Spill Over Into Day
description: Some children who exhibit attention and hyperactivity problems may really be suffering from a sleep disorder, researchers suggest.

title: In Mourning For Husband Lost as Camp Was Invaded
description: As Israeli tanks and armored troop carriers churned down the deserted road running by this camp today, Ahlam Faraj grieved behind closed doors for her husband.

title: Secrecy Over Abusive Priests Comes Back to Haunt Church
description: In 1993, lawyers for Sharon See and Brian Freibott, then both 28, served papers on the Rev. Raymond Pcolka that accused him of abusing them as children in Stratford, Conn.

title: Hospital Faces Fine in Death of Liver Donor
description: Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan will be fined and subjected to other enforcement action by the state for its treatment of a patient who died on Jan. 13, three days after donating part of his liver to his brother, the State Health Department said yesterday.

title: Story Behind 'Brink' May Be the Real Story
description: ESPN must have felt a need to atone for the sin of overpromoting its first original film, ''A Season on the Brink,'' to the point of seasickness. I love the actor Brian Dennehy, who plays Coach Bob Knight in the movie, but I need counseling for the horrific nightmares I've been suffering about a large man in a red sweater who needs his filthy mouth washed out with lye soap.

title: Ruben Rivera, Accused of Taking Jeter's Glove, Is Cut
description: Outfielder Ruben Rivera's immaturity has held him back from stardom. Tonight, the allegation of a shockingly immature act has resulted in his unconditional release from the Yankees.

title: Taking Care of Baby, Before the Pregnancy
description: Pregnancy and childbirth are rife with hazards. Those factors under personal control -- like weight issues and poor nutrition, overwork or lack of fitness -- should not become additional burdens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, JULIUS
description: FEDER-Julius. Beloved husband, loving father, and cherished grandfather, died peacefully in his sleep on March 11, 2002. Private funeral services are planned.

title: CBS and Nextel Weighing Benefits in Success of '9/11' Documentary
description: The CBS broadcast of the documentary ''9/11'' on Sunday evening drew the largest audience of any nonsports telecast this television season, benefiting not only the network but also Nextel Communications, the sponsor of the program, which ran without commercial interruption.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMPSON, ELEANOR A.
description: SIMPSON-Eleanor A. The Incorporated Village of Old Westbury, its Mayor, Board of Trustees, Village Board Members and employees mourn the passing of its esteemed Trustee and former Mayor. The Village and its constituents have lost a woman who will always be remembered for her integrity and grace. She will be missed. Harvey R. Blau, Mayor Fred Carillo, Deputy Mayor Henry Alpert, Trustee Michael Wolf, Trustee

title: Kindly Forward Their Social Security Checks to Tuscany
description: DEE AND WARREN SWEET are trying very, very hard to think of something they don't like about being retired Americans living in Tuscany.

title: Beautiful Minds Absent From Talks
description: Labor representatives of the owners and the players agreed on something today: 22 1/2 percent equals 37 percent. But that is about the only thing they agree on regarding revenue sharing, and that is not going to lead to a new labor agreement ensuring an uninterrupted season.

title: Dramaturges Take a While to Define Themselves
description: At a symposium on the role of the dramaturge in the modern theater at Mount Holyoke College here from March 1 to 3, there was considerable disagreement on exactly what a dramaturge does. In exasperation, a moderator, Anne Cattaneo, herself a dramaturge who works for the Lincoln Center Theater, asked all six members of one panel to state the mission of a dramaturge.

title: An Unconventional Jazz Singer Looks Back
description: Within jazz, Abbey Lincoln is a rare creature. Since the early 1960's jazz vocalists have been refining and refining, paying homage after homage. But about 40 years ago Ms. Lincoln -- who was shaping up as a more conventional and classical jazz singer, with the crossbred influences of Billie Holiday and Sarah Vaughan -- did a very bold thing. She broke away, creating her own songs, and they didn't sound much like anyone else's.

title: A Cholesterol Drug's Added Benefits
description: The cholesterol-lowering drugs known as statins have been shown to provide significant help for people at high risk for heart attack and stroke. But a new study offers a note of caution. Patients who are taking the drugs should continue doing so if they are hospitalized for chest pain.

title: Comfort vs. Longevity: Who Decides?
description: More than a third of seriously ill patients who requested that doctors ease their discomfort instead of prolonging their lives appear to have had their wishes overlooked, a new study reports.

title: For Theaters and Museums, a Rapid Rebound
description: New York City's major theaters and museums, which suffered a devastating drop in attendance after Sept. 11, have rebounded so strongly that several of them are reaching or exceeding pre-attack attendance predictions and even doing better than they were a year ago.

title: 4-Degree Rise in Pacific Waters Is Evidence of El Nio Revival
description: A four-degree rise in water temperature near South America last month provides strong evidence that El Nio, the disruptive influence on global weather, is developing, government weather experts report, but how severe the cycle will become remains uncertain.

title: City Agencies Are Warned Of More Cuts
description: The Bloomberg administration is bracing city agencies for another round of spending cutbacks -- possibly totaling $500 million more -- as city officials prepare for the possibility that federal and state aid, as well as labor savings, will fail to materialize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, IDA
description: ROTHSCHILD-Ida. On March 11, 2002 in her 102nd year. Beloved wife of the late Max. Adored mother of Carolyn and Norman Oshin, and William and Carol Rothschild. Cherished grandmother of Cynthia Rothschild, Lawrence Oshin and Diane Oshin. Adored great grandmother of David, Jared, Matthew and Alexa. Private graveside service on March 12th. Receiving at the Rothschild residence in Great Neck Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evenings.

title: Dad's 50. Junior's 8. What's the Plan?
description: LIKE the goalie on the town traveling team, Gary Popowcer is often the last line of defense for soccer moms and harried corporate functionaries who are hoping to catch at least part of the game -- the retirement game, that is.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Corrections Chief Nominated
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey has made his last cabinet selection, nominating a corrections official from the District of Columbia as commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Corrections. The nominee, Devon Brown, 52, began his career in New Jersey, as a prison psychologist. He worked in Maryland later, becoming the head of the Montgomery County correction department before he was named deputy trustee of corrections, a federal post, in Washington. He also has a law degree. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: After Sections of Basement Collapse, Work at a Part of the Trade Center Site Is Halted
description: A predawn collapse on Sunday of two sections of the basement of the World Trade Center complex forced a temporary stop to the demolition in that area, as engineers and contractors moved swiftly yesterday to work out an alternative plan that would ensure the safety of workers and permit the work to proceed.

title: Is Anybody Out There?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wallflowers Welcome N.I.T. Bids
description: At Wagner, the men's basketball team was so eager to hear from the National Invitation Tournament on Sunday night that Coach Dereck Whittenburg stopped practice.

title: In Hollywood, No One Gets A Casting Call for This Role
description: AT 62, in good health and the roles still coming, Cary Grant stepped into the wings of retirement. Loretta Young made the move at 50. Jessica Tandy seemed not to know the meaning of the word.

title: Drugs: More Important, More Costly
description: TOM HOGAN Doc to a few old-timers -- stares down from his perch under a 20-foot-wide sign that says ''Prescriptions.'' For 47 years, Mr. Hogan, a pharmacist, has watched his customers approach the elevated work area in the back of his drugstore and knows most of their names and all their ailments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTER, ANNE STORRS
description: SCHUSTER-Anne Storrs. The Governing Body & Staff of Family Dynamics mourn the passing of Anne Storrs Schuster. Beloved mother of Derek Schuster. Founder of Family Dynamics. Deepest condolences to her family.

title: Socking It Away Amid Red Tape
description: THIS year, under the Bush tax cuts, Americans can save much more for retirement in tax-deferred accounts, like the popular 401(k) plans, than in the past. Luckily, these new increases continue through 2008, with automatic adjustments for inflation after that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITING, BEATRICE M. (WALKER)
description: WHITING-Beatrice M. (Walker). Of Chathamport, MA, age 98, in Hyannis, MA, March 10, 2002, wife of the late Rennold W. Whiting. Services will be held in St. Christopher's Church, Chatham, MA., Friday, Mar. 15, 11 AM. Donations may be made to St. Christopher's Food Pantry, Main St., Chatham MA. 02633. Information: Nickerson Funeral Home, Chatham.

title: Showbiz Veteran Goes For His Showstopper
description: If Hal Linden isn't the hardest-working man in show business, he just might be the hardest-working cabaret performer. ''Back to Broadway,'' his act at Feinstein's at the Regency (540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street) through Saturday, is a strenuous one-man Catskills-style variety turn in which Mr. Linden, best known for starring in the television series '' Barney Miller,'' does everything short of taming lions.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Rebuff To British On Execution
description: State authorities rejected an appeal from the British government to stop the planned execution of Tracy Housel, who was convicted of murdering a hitchhiker in 1985. Mr. Housel, who was born in Bermuda but reared in the United States, has dual citizenship. High-ranking lawyers and diplomats asked the Board of Pardons and Paroles to spare Mr. Housel in part because he is mentally ill. The board rejected the request. Mr. Housel, 43, is sentenced to die by lethal injection tonight at 7 p.m. at a state prison in Jackson after being offered a sedative and a last meal. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Resting Sooner Than Planned
description: ''IVO THOMAS has retired,'' says the voice-mail message on his former extension at the Boeing Company. ''You can reach him in Bora-Bora.''

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Troops Enter Sudan Again
description: The government has sent troops across the border into Sudan for the second time in recent weeks to pursue rebels in the Lord's Resistance Army who have operated for years from the rugged terrain in southern Sudan. The group, which is seeking to impose a system based on the Ten Commandments in Uganda, has abducted young children to increase its ranks. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Via South America, A Beachfront Boom For South Florida
description: When Juan Mendez-Bages looked down the South Florida coastline five years ago, he saw more than the blond sand beaches and rows of palm trees. An international real estate broker from Colombia, he saw a refuge for himself and his money.

title: Footlights
description: Legacy

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We can't do enough. We can't say the right things. But let us never forget those that we have lost. Let us not lose sight of what we have to do again.''

title: Review/Fashion; Two Who Decline to Run With the Pack
description: About a year ago, Roger Sandall, an Australian anthropologist, coined a phrase that will perhaps now officially have its moment. Mr. Sandall offered the term ''designer tribalism'' to characterize the way in which Western liberals often fall in love with cultures at some remove from modernity. In ''The Culture Cult,'' his book, Mr. Sandall reserved particular contempt for those who fail to acknowledge as grisly the habits of primitive societies. Among his targets was Lauren Hutton, who in a 1996 television documentary appeared to be excited by the experience of watching Masai warriors slaughter a cow and drink its blood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUSK, ETHEL (NEE GUTERWILL)
description: SOUSK-Ethel (nee Guterwill). Beloved wife of the late Philip. Long time resident of Astoria, Queens. Passed away on March 10, 2002. Loving mother of Stephen. Dear grandmother of Jenny. Services Wednesday, 1 PM at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about a study that showed an increase in prescription drug sales misstated the rise in promotional spending in 1999. It was 24 percent, not 234 percent.

title: Film Festival Shows Tone Of the U.S.; It's Somber
description: South by Southwest is an annual event that attracts people who love movies. Aside from the music, film and interactive media programming, a major part of its allure is the panel discussions, which are packed with serious audiences interested in conversation about the meaning of the pictures, offering access to filmmakers in such a winningly low-key setting that you can see the panelists slowly, surely falling in love with this city. (That is, the panelists who don't already live here; the thriving Austin film industry is well represented here, too.)

title: BAUSCH & LOMB CREDIT RATING CUT TO JUNK LEVEL
description: The credit rating of Bausch & Lomb Inc., the nation's biggest maker of contact lens care products, was cut by one level to junk, possibly requiring the company to pay a $200 million loan immediately. Moody's Investors Service lowered the company to Ba1, the highest junk rating, from Baa3, the lowest investment grade. That raised the company's borrowing costs and limits the number of investors who may buy its debt. The downgrade affects $800 million of debt, in addition to the $200 million loan, Moody's said. Bausch & Lomb, based in Rochester, said it was able to meet its maturing obligations.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Workers Stage Protest
description: About 5,000 workers from six recently bankrupted state factories demonstrated and blocked traffic in the northeastern city of Liaoyang yesterday, complaining that they were owed a year or more's wages and accusing officials of corruption, a human rights monitor and local officials said. The protest in Liaoning Province, reported by the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy in Hong Kong, coincided with the annual meeting in Beijing of the National People's Congress, where President Jiang Zemin told Liaoning delegates that the province ''must rely on the working class and the broad masses of the people'' as it overhauls state enterprises. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: From Top Teenage Scientists, Topics You've Never Heard Of
description: High school seniors from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut last night captured 4 of the top 10 prizes in the Intel Science Talent Search, the nation's most prestigious high school science competition.

title: World Bank, in Report, Defends Its Use of Aid
description: The World Bank said today that its aid programs had helped ease poverty and allowed poor people to ''live longer, healthier and more productive lives,'' defending its track record against Bush administration charges that it has been ineffective.

title: 21st-Century Plumbing For a Leaky Old Aqueduct
description: All along the East Coast, drought has shriveled streams as never before. But tucked in the woods 70 miles north of New York City, a deep pool of clear water spills into a sparkling brook that runs downhill to the Hudson River.

title: Cheney, in London, Receives Strong Support From Blair on Tough Stance Against Iraq
description: On the first step of a tour to drum up support for tough action against Iraq, Vice President Dick Cheney received strong backing today from Prime Minister Tony Blair.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: A Familiar Hat In the Ring
description: As expected, Lamar Alexander, whose red flannel shirt became a symbol of his two failed bids for the Republican presidential nomination, announced that he would seek the Senate seat of Fred Thompson, a Republican who is not running for re-election. Mr. Alexander, 61, was secretary of education under President George Bush and governor of Tennessee from 1979 to 1987. He has spent the last year teaching a seminar on character in politics at Harvard University. Senator Thompson is one of four senior Republican senators who have decided not to run again, complicating the party's efforts to regain control of the chamber, where Democrats hold a 50 to 49 advantage.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Postings column of the Real Estate section on Sunday about the New York Landmarks Conservancy's annual preservation awards misstated the day of the presentation ceremony. It is today, not Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBERSTADTER, SANFORD
description: HALBERSTADTER-Sanford. Of Linden, NJ. Husband of Barbara, father, grandfather and brother. Services at Elmora Hebrew Center, 420 West End Ave., Elizabeth, New Jersey. Wednesday 10 A.M. For information please call ''Kreitzman's'' 1-888-351-4414.

title: Judge Rejects Harassment Lawsuits for Women on Workfare
description: In a legal victory for City Hall, a federal judge has thrown out a suit brought by the federal Justice Department that sought to give women in the city's workfare program more rigorous protection against sexual and racial harassment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, THOMAS F.
description: LEAHY-Thomas F. The Board of Trustees and staff of Theatre Development Fund mourn the passing of our admired colleague. While serving as TDF's President from 1992 through 1997, Tom's dedication and ability helped TDF grow and flourish in many important areas. We are deeply grateful, not only for the vast experiencee he brought to TDF, but for his generosity, kindness, sense of humor and style. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Patty, and their children. He will be sorely missed by us all. John F. Breglio, Chairman David D. Holbrook, Chairman Emeritus

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: The Lighter Side Of Redistricting
description: A government watchdog group, poking fun at redistricting, issued prizes yesterday for the tortuous boundaries of the voting districts proposed by the State Legislature. The group, the New York Public Interest Research Group, presented its ''Pablo Picasso/Salvador Dali Awards.'' The runners-up included Assembly District 17 on Long Island, titled ''Bug Squashed on Windshield,'' and Senate District 51, in Otsego and Herkimer Counties, called ''Abe Lincoln Riding a Vacuum Cleaner.'' But the top award went to Senate District 34, represented by the Republican lawmaker Guy J. Velella of the Bronx, titled, ''Oops, I Spilled My Coffee on the Map.'' Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Grit and Healing: A Sept. 11 Miracle

title: A New Look at the Long-Lost Dodo and Its Family Tree
description: Lewis Carroll's Dodo of Wonderland was such a swell old bird. When Alice and an assortment of small animals had finished running an incoherent ''caucus'' race to dry themselves off, they surrounded the Dodo and demanded to know, ''But who has won?'' The Dodo pressed a finger to his forehead, gave it a ''great deal of thought'' and replied, in the stirring spirit of a self-esteem coach, ''EVERYBODY has won, and all must have prizes.''

title: The Canterbury Tales, Set in Florida
description: FOR the last two years, I have lived about half the time in a geriatric high-rise building here called Canterbury Tower, with a crowd of pithy, brave, funny people who are, um -- not young -- and who have chosen to live in a place where they have to flip the levers on their mailboxes in the lobby each day to let the front desk know they are still alive. Living in places like this is what people in their late 70's and 80's and 90's who can afford it tend to do now. They sell their retirement homes and move into life-care towers and assisted-living complexes along the waterways and suburban highways of Florida and other states. Normally, they do it unaccompanied by children, writers or otherwise younger folks like me. I am 57. The average age in Canterbury is 86. That's a difference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBNEY, JACK
description: GIBNEY-Jack. Age 75, March 4, 2002. He worked for Protection Mutual Insurance Company in Wayne, NJ (now known as FM Global). He is survived by his sons: Craig J. and Keith J.

title: Jets Weighing Three Options For Starting Defensive Tackle
description: After a busy week of free-agent signings, the Jets have only one unfilled position left on defense: tackle. The team has made offers to three defensive tackles in bids ranging from hundreds of thousands to millions of dollars.
