title: State of Anxiety Dims as the Circus Whirls On
description: Six months to the day after the World Trade Center attack, a throng that included a great many of the people who constitute the world of fashion crowded a pavilion at the Muse Rodin to see Tom Ford secure his position as the creative inheritor of Yves Saint Laurent. It was a curious moment.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Government Defends Conduct
description: Government lawyers prosecuting a Jordanian student charged with lying in the Sept. 11 terror investigation defended their case yesterday in an 86-page filing in United States District Court. Prosecutors said that the student, Osama Awadallah, was properly arrested and detained initially as a material witness, that he consented to searches, and that he was not tricked into false statements, as Mr. Awadallah's lawyers contend. In defending their use of the material witness law, the prosecutors said that ''the duty to disclose knowledge of crime rests upon all citizens,'' and was so vital that even the innocent may be detained. Mr. Awadallah's arrest in San Diego ''was entirely consistent with this principle,'' they said. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Former N.B.A. Star Accused of Cover-Up in Addition to Manslaughter
description: Prosecutors filed additional charges today against the former New Jersey Nets star Jayson Williams, maintaining that after the fatal shooting of a limousine driver at his estate last month, Mr. Williams tried to remove his own fingerprints from the weapon, told two friends to dispose of his clothing and encouraged others to lie to investigators.

title: Domingo To Open Met Season
description: The New York debut of a recent American opera, some ambitious new productions and a Bellini rarity highlight the 2002-3 season of the Metropolitan Opera, which was announced yesterday. The 32-week season, which will present 26 different operas, opens with a gala performance on Sept. 23 that reaffirms Plcido Domingo's place as the company's dominant vocalist. Mr. Domingo will be heard in Act II of Giordano's ''Fedora,'' Act II of Saint-Sans's ''Samson et Dalila'' and Act IV of Verdi's ''Otello.''

title: Blood-Test Labs Bypass Doctors, Spurring Debate
description: In a suburban strip mall midway between downtown Denver and health-conscious Boulder, there is a place where people can go and order blood tests to detect any number of medical problems, like high cholesterol, diabetes, H.I.V. and prostate and ovarian cancer.

title: Russia Assails U.S. Stance on Arms Reduction
description: Defense Minister Sergei B. Ivanov of Russia warned today that the American proposal in arms reduction talks to ''warehouse'' excess warheads instead of destroying them would not only encourage nuclear proliferation, but could even set off a new kind of arms race.

title: Back Home, Nets Try to Reverse Slide
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott was the last one on the court at practice today, throwing up shots after most of his players had already showered. When he finally walked off the floor, he said, ''I was just thinking about putting a jersey on and going out there and helping them out a little bit.''

title: BUSH VOWS TO AID OTHER COUNTRIES IN WAR ON TERROR
description: President Bush declared today that the United States was willing to train and provide military aid to ''governments everywhere'' for the fight against terrorism and for what he made clear would be battles beyond Afghanistan.

title: Two Stubborn Men, and Many Dead
description: On Saturday night a 9-month old baby girl, an Israeli, was murdered in Netanya by a group of Palestinian gunmen. A few days earlier another baby girl, a Palestinian, was blown up by an Israeli bomb. Innocent civilians are dying, killed on both sides nearly every day. They are dying not because there is no way of resolving the crisis, but, on the contrary, they are dying precisely because a way exists and is known very well by all.

description: ARE Americans more worried about the economy than they were a year ago? Yes. Has that made them more worried about retirement? For the most part, no, according to a national poll conducted recently by The New York Times.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: School Board Takeover
description: For the first time, the State Board of Education took control of two rural school districts, citing poor academic progress by many of their pupils. State officials will assume administrative and educational supervision of the Altheimer district, outside Pine Bluff, stripping its elected school board of all authority, and install instructional supervisors in the schools in Elaine, near the Mississippi border. Most students in both districts routinely score in the lowest quadrant on the Stanford Achievement Test.

title: U.S. Auditors Find Things Are Different in Russia
description: The big American accounting firms were among the first foreign companies to arrive in Russia after the fall of Communism. They opened offices here and in other former Soviet republics, and rapidly landed many of the largest companies as clients.

title: McCarthy the Sniper Saves the Rangers
description: Sandy McCarthy is not so different from Eric Lindros. McCarthy is also a big man who speaks in a whisper and can generate excitement by throwing his body around like a sumo wrestler, but that was never a secret. It turns out that McCarthy can also shove a puck into the goal in the heat of a tight game.

title: Custom-made chic is edging out brands
description: LONDON  It used to be the rule that to be fashionable all you needed was the right label. If the inside of your jacket bore the name Giorgio Armani and your polo shirt featured a small polo player, you could consider yourself stylish and that was the end of that. But brands and labels are losing their power to denote class instantly. Instead, if you want prestige it better be custom-made.

title: Market Place; After Sept. 11, diverging attitudes about the market.
description: THE passing of a crisis can have one of two effects on people's confidence. It can make them more attuned to the dangers they face, or it can leave them more confident.

title: Hitchcock Is Concerned He May Be Tipping His Pitches
description: Andy Pettitte may not be the only Yankees left-hander trying to stop tipping his pitches. Sterling Hitchcock is having a rough spring training, and the reason may be that hitters know what is coming.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ratings For Insurers Cut
description: Moody's Investors Service cut the ratings of eight major Japanese life insurers, citing a poor outlook for recovery and uncertain prospects for support from related banks. Moody's said life insurers were facing a long-term decline because the deteriorating economy had depressed interest rates and made it hard for them to generate high enough returns to pay policyholders. The credit agency lowered the financial strength ratings for Daido Life Insurance, Dai-ichi Mutual Life, Fukoku Life, Meiji Life, Mitsui Life, Nippon Life, Sumitomo Life and Yasuda Life, and said the outlook for those companies remained negative. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Jernimo Gmez is not the average aspiring priest.

description: As tensions rise in the often fractious trade relations of the United States and the European Union, the European Commission is about to propose allowing its members to suspend landing rights and charge punitive fees to airlines based outside the union.

title: So Who Has the Best Shot? (Hint: It's Not Duke.)
description: The N.C.A.A. selection committee will not come out and say it, but it believes the defending national champion is the team to beat. The tip-off was that it awarded Duke the No. 1 seeding in the South and lined that region opposite the West, which has the weakest No. 1 in Cincinnati.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK BUYS ASSET MANAGEMENT FIRM
description: The Bank of New York Company has agreed to acquire Gannett Welsh & Kotler Inc., an asset manager based in Boston, to add more midsize institutions and clients with high net worths. Terms were not disclosed. Gannett Welsh & Kotler, which is closely held, manages about $5 billion in assets and offers fixed-income and equity-portfolio management services. Its clients will have access to the products and services of the Bank of New York. The purchase will increase the bank's assets under management to about $72 billion, the company said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Officials Seize Copies Of Terror Film
description: Customs officials in St. Petersburg seized 100 videocassette copies of a film that purports to show that Russian intelligence agents engineered terrorist bombings of apartment buildings in Moscow and elsewhere in Russia in 1999. The tapes were seized from a member of Parliament, Yuli Rybakov, who attended a screening of the film in London last week sponsored by Boris Berezovsky, the expatriate financier and vocal enemy of President Vladimir V. Putin. Another member of Parliament, Sergei Yushenko, brought 800 copies of the film through Moscow customs without incident. Russian television networks have spurned Mr. Berezovsky's demand to broadcast the film but the Liberal Russia political movement, which has Mr. Berezovsky's backing, plans a public showing. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Filing by Cisco Has New Data On Its Finances
description: Cisco Systems filed a statement with regulators today that includes new disclosures about its financial positions, a development Cisco officials attributed to heightened calls for openness by public companies.

title: Tight Texas Senate Race Loses Fight for Attention

title: Federal Lawsuit May Seek Stricter Limits on Cigarette Marketing

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer May Sell Unit
description: Old Mutual, South Africa's biggest insurer, said it was discussing the sale of a finance unit to the investment bank Beeson Gregory to cut costs after a fall in stock-trading profits at businesses in Britain. Under the deal, which may be completed in April, Old Mutual would receive up to 27.5 percent of new shares in Beeson Gregory, whose market value is about $87 million, the companies said. The unit being sold, Old Mutual Securities, had revenue of 13.8 million ($19.6 million) in 2001, down from 19.5 million in 2000. Old Mutual is based in London. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFFCOAT, ALBERT E. (JEFF)

We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Jan, children Thomas, Peter, John, Ross, Lindsay and Catherine and to their four grandchildren. title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Chile: Bank Stake To Be Sold

The central bank plans to sell 33.75 million American depository shares, valued at $770 million, at a price to be set after March 15, Banco Santiago said.

title: Nueil-sur-Layon Journal; A Wistful Future on Ice. Can France Tolerate It?

title: New School's Graduate Faculty Dean Resigns, Jolting University Community
description: When Bob Kerrey, the former senator from Nebraska, became president of New School University last year, he won plaudits for appointing Kenneth Prewitt, then the director of the United States Census Bureau and a noted political scientist, as dean of the graduate faculty of political and social science.

title: Reaching the Next Muslim Generation
description: Since Sept. 11, the world has come to know more about the educational systems prevalent today in Muslim countries and their role in promoting hostility toward the West. The educational system of Osama bin Laden's native Saudi Arabia is being criticized in the West, particularly in the United States. The Indian government last December announced an effort to reform the Muslim religious schools known as madrasas, though this is perhaps a mixed blessing given that the same government is using the schools to promote Hinduism as part of its nationalist program. Across the border in Pakistan, President Pervez Musharraf is pursuing reform of his country's educational system -- a project that will be watched by other Muslim nations. Education was a major subject of discussion in Mr. Musharraf's meeting with President Bush last month. This was itself something rather new.

He was a great economist and a remarkably good man; his passing seems to me to symbolize the passing of an era, one in which economic debate was both nicer and a lot more honest than it is today.

Banc One will buy an additional 50 percent from two other shareholders. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Air Traffic Is Off Almost Everywhere, but the Dip Is Uneven

But the drop was much sharper at Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports in New York, Ronald Reagan National here in Washington and Los Angeles International, among others.

title: Soldiers at Bagram Air Base
Second Thoughts on Mercury in Fish
description: WAS the Food and Drug Administration overly sensitive to the commercial interests of the tuna industry when it established guidelines on fish consumption and mercury contamination? Documents released this month by a watchdog group are raising that question as well as others about the decision-making that went into the agency's warning to pregnant women about which fish to avoid to reduce the risk of harming their fetuses.

title: James Tobin, Nobel Laureate in Economics and an Adviser to Kennedy, Is Dead at 84
description: Dr. James Tobin, a professor emeritus of economics at Yale who was a top adviser in the Kennedy administration and received the Nobel Prize in economics in 1981, died on Monday in New Haven. He was 84 and lived in New Haven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINDLAY, CHARLES W. JR.
description: FINDLAY-Charles W. Jr. Of Westport Harbor, Massachusetts, on February 11, 2002. The Directors of The Grenfell Association of America are saddened by the death of Dr. Findlay, who had served on the Grenfell Board of Directors since 1995. His dedication and expertise will be greatly missed. The Grenfell Association is dedicated to furthering the work of Sir Wilfred Grenfell, who brought the first medical services to Newfoundland and Northern Labrador in the early 1940s. Dr. Findlay practiced general and thoracic surgery at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for 30 years. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Peggy, two sons, Charles W. Findlay III and Frederick Findlay, a daughter, Laurie B. Findlay, and four grandchildren.

No new furniture, no pitchers of water for conference speakers, no after-hours meetings. Office cleaning has been curtailed and thermostats lowered.

description: IS there a wine with a worse reputation than Madeira? Since World War II, winemakers have flooded stores the world over with jug-quality plonk, reducing an ancient, noble wine to little more than a kitchen accessory, a flavoring that added a whiff of butterscotch to countless creamy sauces, soups and casseroles.

description: PLAYING down notions that gardening is a pursuit for old fogies, the Miracle-Gro brand of gardening products is freshening its campaign for the first time in two decades by taking steps that include replacing its longtime spokesman and using music that is more contemporary.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: New Chips From Advanced Micro
description: Advanced Micro Devices, the No. 2 maker of desktop microprocessors, plans to begin selling new versions of its Athlon chips today for desktop, notebook and data-serving computers. Advanced Micro, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said Compaq, NEC and Fujitsu-Siemens would begin selling top-of-the-line PC's featuring the Athlon XP 2100 processor, and Compaq would sell notebook computers featuring the Athlon 4 1600. The new Athlon MP will power servers from lesser-known computer makers like RackSaver and Angstrom Microsystems. The fastest version of each chip costs $380 to $415. Advanced Micro's larger rival, Intel, yesterday introduced a new chip of its own, the Xeon MP, for servers that are used in data centers. Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said the chips were based on the Pentium 4 design and offered a rise in speed of up to 30 percent over the previous generation of Pentium III-based Xeons. Chris Gaither (NYT)

description: After widespread reports of judicial wrongdoing centered mostly in Brooklyn, the state's chief administrative judge reorganized the court system's investigative agencies yesterday by consolidating three separate offices into one. The judge, Jonathan Lippman, said he was reorganizing the investigative offices and promoting a former prosecutor, Sherrill R. Spatz, to be the new inspector general for the court system. Officials said there were 13 employees in the 3 offices that investigate the state judiciary. William Glaberson (NYT)

description: ''SIMPLICITY works,'' John Sineno said, browning sausages in an enormous pot. ''In my cookbook there are no ingredients you have to go and look for. What's in the kitchen is what you need. When my grandson was 11 he was making the pistachio mousse; it's that simple.'' He put down his fork. ''To me a mousse is just a pudding,'' he went on. title: Mitch McConnell's Deceptive 'Fixes'
description: In one of the oldest tricks in the Senate playbook, Mitch McConnell surfaced yesterday with what he said was one minor ''fix'' he wanted to make in the Shays-Meehan campaign reform bill. Just a bit of clarifying language was all he wanted, he said, to make sure that politicians running for office could ''coordinate'' with independent groups in their election campaigns. But Mr. McConnell's measure is far from minor. It would blow a huge hole in the bill, allowing politicians to raise the newly banned soft money for their campaigns by other means. The Senate must reject the McConnell ''fix'' and pass Shays-Meehan right away.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Brightening Outlook For PC'S And Chips
description: Sales of personal computers and the chips that power them will increase this year after a steep drop in 2001, according to two reports scheduled for release today by the International Data Corporation, a market research concern. Citing better-than-expected demand in Western Europe and in American stores, International Data raised its projections for growth in unit shipments of desktop and notebook computers to 3 percent from 1.8 percent. Shipments should rise to 125.5 million, from 121.8 million, the company said. All regions of the world except Asia-Pacific surpassed expectations in the fourth quarter of 2001, setting the stage for a mild rebound this year, especially in the second half. In a separate report, International Data predicted that revenue from sales of personal computer chips this year would increase by 3.4 percent, to $37.6 billion, from $36.3 billion. But the report warned that weak demand among corporations, excess chip inventory and fluctuating prices would cause sales to fall through the first half of the year before swinging up in the last six months of 2002. Chris Gaither (NYT)

Feehan, who held the job. Michael Regan held the post from Sept. 18 to Jan. 31, when he took a job in private business. The first deputy position, though now unfilled, has not been continuously vacant.

title: AMERISHAM TO BUY REST OF BIOSCIENCES UNIT
description: Amersham, the biggest maker of imaging products used to diagnose diseases, plans to pay about $1 billion in cash for the Pharmacia Corporation's share of a joint venture after abandoning plans to sell stock in the unit. Amersham, which is based in Britain, is exercising an option to buy the 45 percent of Amersham Biosciences it does not already own, a spokesman, Graeme Holland, said. It is selling as many as 57.5 million shares to pay for the acquisition. Amersham gave up on an initial public offering for 10 percent of the drug-discovery tool maker after announcing plans for the share sale 18 months ago. Pharmacia agreed to Amersham's request to exercise its option ahead of schedule, according to Amersham.

title: Cheney, in Jordan, Meets Opposition to Military Move in Iraq
description: Vice President Dick Cheney today began the most difficult phase of his 12-day mission to elicit allied support for a possible military campaign against Iraq, and he immediately encountered open opposition from King Abdullah II of Jordan.

title: GE CAPITAL PLANS TO RAISE $6 BILLION IN DEBT SALE
description: The General Electric Company's financing unit plans to raise $6 billion in the biggest corporate debt sale this year, tapping the bond market before an economic recovery drives up borrowing costs. The GE Capital Corporation, which generates half its parent's revenue, will sell the bonds as soon as today. GE Capital will sell $2 billion of three-year floating-rate notes, $1 billion of five-year fixed-rated notes and $3 billion of 30-year bonds, a GE Capital spokeswoman, Marissa Moretti, said. The sale would top the Weyerhaeuser Company's $5.5 billion offering last week.

title: THE CHEF
description: I PREFER dry pasta, macaroni, to fresh noodles. One of my favorites is a short twisted kind called strozzapreti. And I like to cook it the way I learned from the farm families who have mills for pressing olives for oil in rural Liguria on the Italian Riviera. They cook pasta like a risotto. I've been doing it for years now, and I would not cook macaroni any other way.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Lufthansa's Income Is Down
description: Germany's biggest airline, Lufthansa, hit hard by the steep drop in trans-Atlantic air travel after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, said it lost about $517 million last year. The results are worse than many analysts had expected, and investors pushed the company's shares down more than 6 percent. The airline said it would not pay a dividend for 2001. Lufthansa is more dependent than many other European airlines on trans-Atlantic traffic, which was down by about one-third in the months after the terrorist attacks and is still about 12 percent below levels from a year ago. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: A Dying (and Still Difficult) Mother
description: Misguided optimism is in no short supply in the theater, which may be the only explanation short of sheer lunacy for the resurrection of a Broadway calamity like ''The Apple Doesn't Fall . . .'' by Trish Vradenburg, which closed after its opening night performance at the Lyceum Theater in 1996. Reviewing it for The New York Times, Vincent Canby called it ''ghastly.''

title: Democrats Try to Surpass Bush In Tough Post-Enron Fraud Laws
description: Senate Democrats tried to draw a sharp contrast today with President Bush's response to the collapse of Enron, proposing laws that would increase criminal penalties for certain corporate wrongdoing and give state attorneys general new powers to sue companies.

title: Osgood Helps Peca Return to Buffalo in Style
description: When the public address announcer at HSBC Arena in Buffalo introduced the Islanders' lineup last night, he paused a beat before deliberately enunciating the name of the former Sabre Michael Peca. The crowd did not hold back. Boos filled the rink, raining down each time Peca, the Islanders' center and captain, laid stick to puck. The fans who cheered Peca in a Sabres jersey for five seasons remain bitter.

title: Editorial Observer; Through Allende's Broken Glasses, a View of Chile Today
description: For a foreigner visiting Chile's National Museum of History, the most arresting exhibit comes at the very end of a winding tour. It is half of a pair of black-framed glasses -- just the left lens and temple piece -- the lens shattered and darkened from gunfire. The glasses belonged to Salvador Allende, Chile's socialist president from 1970 to 1973. He was wearing them when, it is now widely accepted, he committed suicide as Gen. Augusto Pinochet's forces bombed the presidential palace in the coup that brought about 17 years of right-wing military rule.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Newspaper Acquisition
description: Johnston Press agreed to buy Regional Independent Media Holdings for 560 million ($793 million), bringing together the fourth- and fifth-largest regional newspaper publishers in Britain respectively. Johnston Press will finance the acquisition with a combination of bank debt and new shares. Existing investors will have the option of buying two new Johnston Press shares at 280 pence each for every five they own. The company expects to raise a total of 220 million from the rights issue. Candover Investments, a venture capital group, bought Regional Independent Media in February 1998 from United Business Media for 360 million, including the assumption of debt. Separately, Johnston Press said it earned an operating profit of 90.7 million in 2001, excluding exceptional items, compared with 83.9 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 2.9 percent, to 300.6 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSER, REMEDIOS GARCIA
description: MESSER-Remedios Garcia. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation mourn the loss of Remedios Garcia Messer, who succumbed to illness on March 10, 2002. Born in Manila, Philippines in 1919, she was known to her friends as Remi. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Thomas M. Messer, Director Emeritus, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, and to her sister, nephew, and nieces. Peter O. Lawson-Johnston Honorary Chairman Peter B. Lewis Chairman Thomas Krens Director Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation

title: Real Estate In Manhattan Is Rebounding

title: A Little Dust, a Lot of Zing
description: Classic spice blends like garam masala, quatre-pices and crab boil should be part of every pantry. As for the others, I can live without most of them but could not resist the hummingbirds and lizards on Allen-Cowley's bright little packages of Salsa Dust and Guac Dust. I was not disappointed. Add a package to fresh ingredients -- tomatoes and onion for hot or mild salsa, avocado and lime juice for guacamole -- and you're home free, with results that sing with flavor. Any of the dusts could make a seasoning with fresh citrus juice for ceviche or for fish on the grill. There are also Cajun and fajita flavors. The dusts are $1.69 a package at Whole Foods markets in Manhattan, at Seventh Avenue and 24th Street, and in New Jersey.

title: Mutombo Out, Up 20, The Knicks Still Lose

The Knicks' two best players, Latrell Sprewell and Allan Houston, were scoring at an incredible rate, nearly matching their averages in the first 25 minutes of play. And the Knicks were ahead by 20 points in the third quarter.

title: Boston Archdiocese's Insurance Won't Cover Abuse Settlements
description: The Boston archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church acknowledged today that its insurance policies would not cover an estimated $100 million in settlements of lawsuits against priests accused of sexually abusing children. It also said it would have to sell church property, take out loans and ask for special donations from wealthy benefactors to cover those costs.

title: Taipei Journal; In Taiwan, a Scandal a Day Keeps the Blues Away
description: By the time the legislator Yu Yueh-hsia posed for last month's issue of Chinese-language Playboy magazine, people here had grown blas about seeing their politicians in compromising positions. After all, Ms. Yu was clothed -- in a low-cut, strapless gown -- and her college-age children featured in some shots.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hurdle For Farrakhan
description: The government began an effort to bar the entry of Louis Farrakhan, head of the Chicago-based Nation of Islam, arguing that he was a threat to community relations and public order because of his ''anti-Semitic and racially divisive views.'' The government was appealing a High Court decision last July throwing out government bans against Mr. Farrakhan that had been in effect since 1986. Lawyers for Mr. Farrakhan argued last year that he no longer identified with comments praising Hitler and calling Judaism a ''gutter religion'' and was now ''an extremely prominent spiritual, religious and social leader.'' His lawyer in the new action, Sadiq Khan, said the government should let Britons think for themselves. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline Venture
description: The Patrick Corporation, Australia's No. 1 port cargo handler, agreed to buy half of Richard Branson's discount carrier Virgin Blue for at least 260 million Australian dollars ($136 million), stepping up rivalry in the aviation market. Virgin Blue, which took 18 months to gain 15 percent of local air traffic, plans to use Patrick's partnership to help its initial share sale, planned for as early as the final quarter of 2002, said Brett Godfrey, Virgin's chief executive. Virgin Blue may bid for assets of the failed Australian carrier Ansett Holdings Ltd., he said. Virgin Blue now offers the only competition at home for Qantas Airways Ltd. after the demise last week of Ansett, the country's former No. 2 carrier.

title: Strawberry Is Jailed on a Parole Violation
description: Darryl Strawberry, the former Mets and Yankees star who has battled drug and alcohol problems for years, was jailed today for violating his probation after breaking a rule at the drug treatment center where he had been serving an 18-month sentence. In the process, he may have let down George Steinbrenner for the last time.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HONDA MOTOR CO., Tokyo, the automaker, said it bought an 18 percent stake in the closely held Mobility Inc., a car-sharing service for commuters. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 6 Months Late, I.N.S. Notifies Flight School of Hijackers' Visas
description: Six months after Mohamed Atta and Marwan al-Shehhi crashed hijacked airliners into the World Trade Center, the Immigration and Naturalization Service sent out a routine notice this week telling a flight school that the two men had been approved for student visas to study there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, ELISABETH

description: Is the world ready for a bouncy singalong ballad about Sept. 11? David Heitler-Klevans thinks so, and he appeared to have most of the people in a small, packed Greenwich Village folk audience on Monday night singing in agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONN, WILLIAM LOUIS
description: SONN-William Louis. The Board of Directors and staff of The Rent Stabilization Association mourn the loss of William Sonn, an Executive Committee member of the Board of the RSA. Mr. Sonn was forever attentive to industry concerns as well as to public needs. Mr. Sonn died very much as he lived, caring for the safety and well being of others even in his last heroic moments. He will be missed as a respected leader in the housing community. Our deepest condolences to the entire Sonn family. Joseph Strasburg, President Arnold Goldstein, Chairman

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Needing 'Clean' Money
description: The state's highest court refused to order the Legislature to appropriate money from the treasury to candidates who agree to limit spending and fund-raising under a 4-year-old ''clean election'' law. Justice Martha Sosman of the Supreme Judicial Court ruled that eligible candidates should be paid from an account that covers lawsuits against the state. The account was recently emptied by Warren Tolman, a Democrat running for governor under clean-elections rules. If the account is not refilled, the court could order the state to sell off public property. The court previously ruled that lawmakers must repeal the law or find a way to pay for it. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNLEAVY, THOMAS P.
description: DUNLEAVY-Thomas P. Former owner of Dunleavy's Tavern in Manhattan, on March 8, 2002 at age 69. Beloved husband of Denise McDermott Dunleavy, loving father of Megan Dermot Dunleavy and Cristin Margaret Dunleavy, dear brother of Sister Margaret Mary of Marymount Convent. A memorial service and funeral mass will be held on Thursday, March 14, at Holy Cross Church, 329 W. 42 St, NYC at 11 AM.

title: 'Yellow Asphalt'
description: Directed by Danny Veret

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about efforts to free Ingrid Betancourt, an author and senator in Colombia who was kidnapped by guerrillas, misidentified the party of President Andrs Pastrana, whom she is opposing as a candidate. It is the Conservative Party, not the Liberal Party. Because of an editing error, the article also misspelled the name of an artist who was a guest in her home when she was growing up. He is Fernando Botero, not Botera.

title: Pace Receives $850,000
description: The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation has given $850,000 to Pace University in downtown Manhattan for programs related to Sept. 11. A $500,000 grant will help Pace create fall online courses for students whose education was disrupted. A $350,000 grant will be for internships with small businesses and nonprofit groups downtown that need help to recover. Karen W. Arenson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPSALIS, MARY
description: KAPSALIS-Mary. Suddenly on Mar. 11, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Louis & Calliope Kapsalis. Retired proprietor of ''The Barber Is A Lady'', & was a distinguished writer. Survived by her brother Gregory, and Chyrsoula Kapsalis, and her sister Helen and Wayne Grievo. Loving aunt of James, Leonard and Susan; and grandnephew Daniel. Reposing Thursday 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St., NYC. Funeral services at St. Eleftherios GO Church, 359 W. 24 St., NYC, on Friday 11:30 AM.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Senate Hopeful Cites Jobs
description: Alan Blinken, the United States ambassador to Belgium in the first Clinton administration, says he will challenge Idaho's senior senator, Larry E. Craig, a Republican. Mr. Blinken will face a local businessman, Dave Sneddon, in May in the Democratic primary. Patty Nance, a campaign spokeswoman, said Mr. Blinken hoped to succeed in the heavily Republican state by focusing on ''jobs, jobs and jobs.'' Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFFER, LESTER
description: TAFFER-Lester. Dear father of Alice Friedgood, Betty Schoenfeld, Lewis Taffer and Jonathan Taffer. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Graveside services Thursday, 11AM at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Skyscraper Record
description: A London borough council has approved plans to build a 66-story office tower on the south bank of the Thames River that will become Europe's tallest building. Known as the Shard of Glass project, the 1,004-foot London Bridge Tower, designed by the Italian architect Renzo Piano, will be 23 feet higher than the current title holder, the Commerzbank AG Tower in Frankfurt. It is expected to take five years to build. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: A Financial Squeeze at ABB
description: The chief executive of ABB, Jrgen Centerman, said today that the company was facing a financial squeeze because investors were unwilling to lend it money by buying its unsecured short-term notes, known as commercial paper.

title: Chard Puts on a Party Dress
description: FOR as long as anyone can remember, chard, often called Swiss chard, had red stems or white stems.

title: Pataki Pushes Amendment To Allow Referendums
description: Gov. George E. Pataki cast himself today as a political outsider combating an ossified Legislature as he proposed a constitutional amendment that would let citizens bypass their elected leaders and put initiatives directly on the ballot.

title: An Overdue Ode to Madeira
description: MADEIRA offers a huge range of flavors and styles. Of the four classic Madeira grapes, sercial makes the driest wine. A good five-year-old sercial, like one from Leacock's, combines the almost salty quality of a manzanilla sherry with the complexity of an amontillado. With five more years of age, a sercial mellows, its sweet edge broadening.

title: Free-Market Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERTIG, IRVING
description: FERTIG-Irving. On March 11, 2002, of Lake Worth, FL at 87. Survived by his beloved wife, Norma Fertig, loving son Gerald Fertig, daughter-in-law Dale Fertig and grandsons Alex Fertig, Evan Fertig and his wife, Theresa Liao.

title: Downtown Rebuilding Rules Due Next Month, Official Says
description: The group overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan expects to issue guidelines for the redevelopment project next month and offer detailed plans about many of its proposed projects by June, the group's chairman said yesterday.

title: Bush's Proposal on Welfare Draws Fire From Democrats
description: The Bush administration's welfare proposal came under sharp criticism today from Democrats in the House and the Senate, who argued that any increase in work requirements for welfare recipients must come with more help for child care.

title: HOSPITAL IS FINED FOR 'WOEFUL' CARE
description: The state health commissioner, Antonia C. Novello, said yesterday that poorly supervised medical residents had provided ''woefully inadequate postsurgical care'' to a patient who died at Mount Sinai Hospital on Jan. 13, three days after he donated part of his liver to his brother.

title: Say That Again?
description: When Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, visited Washington last week he used his White House press conference to stress what was new about the peace overture by Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Abdullah. ''This is the first time in the history of the Saudis that they say we are ready to normalize relations with Israel, in case a peace prevails,'' said Mr. Mubarak. ''We should underline this.''

title: BIG TEST FOR DEVILS' TOP LINE
description: Looking for an edge in more ways than one, Petr Sykora tried on a second pair of skates yesterday. Other than pinging pucks off the posts, Sykora and the two other members of the Devils' A-Line have become strangely silent in the past week, and now center Jason Arnott has a bad back.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBS, LEE
description: JACOBS-Lee. March 13, 1993. ''Remembering will have to do, our memories alone will see us through.'' Love, Aime

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMPSON, ELEANOR A.
description: SIMPSON-Eleanor A. Long Island University mourns the loss of university trustee and friend, Eleanor A. Simpson. With extraordinary insight, judgement and grace, she served on the Academic Affairs and University Relations committees, the C.W. Post Campus Council of Overseers, and Tilles Center Council of Overseers. Her devotion to our students and service to the university community will not be forgotten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTKER, DOROTHY
description: SUTKER-Dorothy. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our dedicated benefactor Paula Stoler. To Paula, Michael and the entire family, our heartfelt sympathy. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: Defiant, the Wounded Pass On Weapons as They Fall
description: Lying in a hospital bed, Adham Daoud, wounded in battle with Israeli forces that invaded the Jabaliya refugee camp overnight, recalled today how he had faced the advancing tanks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, ROBERT NATHAN
description: LEVIN-Robert Nathan, librettist and pianist, died in Perugia, Italy, on March 4 of cancer at the age of 56. He had lived in Italy for several years while collaborating on an opera and cantata scheduled for performance shortly. Born in New York City, Mr. Levin was a graduate of Columbia University in 1967 and in 1969 received his M.A. in French and English philology. Through a PhD candidate in comparative literature, he pursued a career as a pianist and teacher of music and foreign languages. With his wife, Zaida, a violinist, he performed widely on the East Coast. He taught for many years at Manhattan School of Music and had a large following of devoted private students. In recent years, he also spent much of his time writing, translating, and doing scholarly research in literature. He is survived by his wife, Zaida, mother Pam Levin of New York City, sister Nina Jalladeau of Paris and halfsister Joan Kirsch of Portland, Oregon. A memorial service was held in Perugia.

title: Three Stars, No Upstaging
description: YOU might call this combination of leeks, ginger and shrimp a stir-fry because the technique is similar to that used in making many Chinese classics. But the proportions are unusual, there is almost none of the traditional sauce, and it is actually better served with bread than with rice. In fact, this is a less-is-more dish, with little guile.

title: Analysts Reading Between Authors' Lines
description: In Plato's ''Symposium,'' Aristophanes imagines the search for love as one half of a self looking for its other half. Imagine now that in some other Platonic universe, each person has a perfect psychoanalyst waiting out there, one who listens and comprehends the patient completely. Likewise, every analyst has a perfect patient out there, one who gives the analyst fantastic material to work with.

title: Texas Jury Convicts Mother Who Drowned Her Children
description: Taking less than four hours to reach a verdict, a Texas jury today found Andrea Pia Yates guilty of capital murder in the bathtub drowning deaths of three of her five young children. Jurors must now decide whether the mother, in whom severe mental illness had been diagnosed, should be sentenced to death.

title: Business Travel; Corporate fliers are increasingly willing to stay over Saturday night to get less expensive fares.
description: AIRLINES put the so-called Saturday night stay requirement on their discount advance-purchase fares for one reason only: They want business travelers to always pay top dollar.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Looking Ahead Before Stepping Down
description: Addressing Parliament for what may be the final time before he is scheduled to leave office after an election later this year, President Daniel arap Moi spoke of the need for his successor to turn around the country's dismal economy and for the nation to avoid tribalism, which he called ''a cancer that has destroyed many nations in Africa.'' The address came 47 years after Mr. Moi was sworn in as a member of an almost all-white legislative council in what was then a British colony. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Predatory-Loan Legislation
description: The City Council is moving to break the city's business relations with financial institutions that practice what is known as predatory lending, or attempting to take over a borrower's assets rather than providing a good-faith loan. Along with James Sanders Jr. of Queens and Philip Reed of Manhattan, Speaker Gifford Miller plans to introduce a bill today prohibiting the city from doing business with or investing in companies linked to such practices. Mr. Miller said, ''These fraudulent and unfair credit patterns are stripping our families and neighborhoods of their equity.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: 'Ulysses' and the Slocum
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Killing of Reporter Is Brash and Threatening in a Pakistani Court
description: The chief suspect in the kidnapping and killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl displayed bravado and brashness in court today, interrupting a hearing with a threat that if he was extradited to the United States, another kidnapping or hijacking would follow and he would be released.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FOX, PAUL
description: FOX-Paul. Missing you today and every day. Love, Lynn

title: Our Towns; Only a Sure-Fire Divining Rod Will Do
description: DEBATE global warming all you like, but man's effects on the environment are so obvious here you can almost taste them. Too bad there isn't enough water to wash them down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, MURRAY AND BELLA
description: ADLER-Murray and Bella. Died tragically in an auto accident March 11. Beloved parents of Ira and Joanie, Sheldon and Marcel, Alan and Lisa. Dear brother of Shirley, Sylvia and Charles. Cherished grandparents of Jonathan, Jennifer, Marissa, Dena, Jonah, Sol, Robert, and Ava. Services are today 12 noon ''Sinai Chapels'', 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: A Helping Hand From China
description: Worried about worsening tensions on the Korean Peninsula, China, a friend to both Koreas, has sent a high-ranking diplomat to the South, played host to a North Korean vice foreign minister and offered to help restart talks between the North and the United States. As a Chinese official for international affairs visited Seoul, Sun Yuxi, the Foreign Ministry spokesman in Beijing, said China wanted to promote closer ties. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Arabs Say Israel Is Undermining Peace Moves
description: Top Arab officials warned today that Israel's action in the West Bank would cause efforts to renew peace negotiations to collapse and would undermine the visits of two senior American officials.

title: Rash Act Opens Door For Loyal Journeyman
description: F. P. Santangelo, a Yankee nobody, did not want to whisper a word about Ruben Rivera's sad, sorry situation. He has been around the Yankees for only about a month, so he was smart enough to avoid discussing this camp's sensitive glove story. Santangelo even peered over his shoulder yesterday to see if anyone was listening while he said nothing about Rivera.

title: Footlights
description: Poets' Corner

title: Ending Chronic Homelessness
description: The Bush administration declared in its 2003 budget proposal that it considers ''ending chronic homelessness in the next decade a top objective.'' This may seem a surprising goal for a Republican administration in a time of economic downturn. The good news is that it is not rhetoric. Ending chronic homelessness is actually achievable, and it can be done in ways that will actually save money.

title: STATE STREET'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER IS LEAVING
description: The State Street Corporation said that its chief financial officer, Ronald O'Kelley, is leaving after seven years at the company, a leading custodian of assets for investors. Stefan Gavell, 48, an executive vice president, will be the interim chief financial officer, effective immediately, the company said. State Street, declining to elaborate on Mr. O'Kelley's departure other than to say he was leaving for personal reasons, said his last day would be March 31. The chief executive, David Spina, said the company hired an executive search firm and would have several candidates to consider for the job in the coming months. Mr. O'Kelley, 57, joined State Street in 1995 as chief financial officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLTON, HELEN STOREY
description: CARLTON-Helen Storey. 76 years old, died on March 9, 2002, of Somers, NY, former longtime resident of South Salem, NY. Former Assistant Fashion Editor for Life Magazine in New York City. Wife of Richard K. Carlton, mother of Douglass K., & Alexander Carlton, grandmother of Scott Alexander Carlton. Memorial Service will be held at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, N.Y., Thursday at 9 A.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to: The Visiting Nurses Association, 100 South Bedford Road, 3rd Floor, Mount Kisco, New York 10549.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, THOMAS V. SR.
description: BARRETT-Thomas V. Sr. Of Tenafly, NJ and Delray Beach, FL on March 12, 2002. Well respected Funeral Director of John J. Barrett Funeral Home, NYC and Bar rett Funeral Home, Tenafly, NJ. Beloved husband of Elizabeth R. (nee Davock). Devoted father of John J., Thomas V. Jr., and Elizabeth Ann. Father-in-law of Christine. Loving grandfather of Daniel John & Julia Rose. Loving step-grandfather of Kim Garland of NYC. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ on Thursday 24 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday, at 10 AM, Mt. Carmel Church, Tenafly, NJ. Interment Brookside Cemetery, Englewood, N.J. Memorials to Sacred Heart R.C. Church, 457 West 51st St, NYC, NY 10019, would be appreciated.

title: Picking a Passer Is Not an Exact Science
description: The first two quarterbacks selected in the National Football League draft do not always match their draft order in performance or stature.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Cardinal Lobbies in Albany Against Bill for Contraception Coverage
description: Last year, when Cardinal Edward M. Egan visited Albany, he had almost the same legislative agenda he did today, from meeting the needs of rural New Yorkers to softening the Rockefeller-era drug laws to restricting Medicaid funds so they could not be used to pay for abortions. But then he could count on the Senate's backing for his top concern: a women's health care bill that would require insurance companies to pay for contraception.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Discovering Another Side of Queens
description: When Mark Graue and his partner at Integrity Real Estate and Development bought two adjacent buildings on Myrtle Avenue in Queens three years ago, they had two factors working against them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFFER, SARAH GORE
description: SCHAFFER-Sarah Gore. On March 12 in Haverford, PA, age eighty-three. Widow of Dr. Julius Schaffer, beloved mother of Ellen Schaffer (Sidney Bludman) and Amy Michal Schaffer (Elijah Morton), grandmother of Adam Morton, sister of Miriam Raff. Memorial gathering at the Marriott Hotel in Teaneck, NJ, on March 17 from 12 until 4:00 PM. The family suggests contributions to the Library for the Blind and Physically Handicapped, 919 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19107.

title: Mistaken Notice On 2 Terrorists
description: Six months after Mohamed Atta and Marwan al-Shehhi crashed jetliners into the World Trade Center, the Immigration and Naturalization Service mistakenly sent a routine notice to a flight school that the two had been approved for visas to study there.

title: Sports of The Times; George Karl's Alternate Reality
description: THE scornful smile curling at the corner of Byron Scott's mouth gave him away even as he said he had ''no comment whatsoever'' regarding George Karl's commentary on head coaching hiring practices, soon to be published in a national magazine but already burning up the pro basketball grapevine.

title: Sotheby's Posts Smaller Losses
description: Sotheby's Holdings, the auction house, said yesterday that losses in the fourth quarter and 2001 had narrowed and that it expected to return to profitability this year.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Forest Fire Contained
description: A 12-day-old fire in the Miller Peak Wilderness Area of the Coronado National Forest is 95 percent contained, officials said. The fire, believed to have been started by an unattended campfire on March 1, burned at least 2,100 acres. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: McCall Criticizes City Budget
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall warned yesterday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's budget plan relied on more than twice as much borrowing as the mayor has said. Mr. Bloomberg has said that the budget calls for borrowing $1.5 billion to help close a $4.76 billion deficit. But Mr. McCall issued a report saying that the budget calls for a series of de facto borrowing items, including delaying payments to the city pension system, borrowing money to pay for short-term World Trade Center costs, and using the reserves of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. With those items, Mr. McCall said, the budget can be said to rely on $3.4 billion in borrowing. Mr. Bloomberg stuck to his $1.5 billion figure yesterday, calling it undesirable but necessary. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: St. John's Hatten Finds His Inspiration
description: Sometime today in Washington, Mike Jarvis hopes to hold his first grandchild. Tomorrow, Marcus Hatten will attend his grandmother's funeral, and on Friday, St. John's will play Wisconsin.

title: Congress Again Tries to Tighten Derivatives Rules a Bit
description: Congress is making another modest attempt to tighten regulation of the derivatives markets after the bankruptcy of the Enron Corporation, which used derivatives in part to keep debt off its balance sheet.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in the Week in Review on Sunday satirized the plagiarism problems of the historian Doris Kearns Goodwin, who has recently acknowledged that she borrowed scores of passages from other authors without credit in her 1987 book ''The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys.'' The article depicted another of her books, ''Wait Till Next Year'' (1997), a memoir about growing up a Brooklyn Dodgers fan, as a pastiche of borrowings from well-known scenes by other baseball authors and from baseball movies.

title: Beams of Blue, Soaring to the Sky
description: To the Editor:

title: Three New Regents Are Named
description: The New York State Legislature has selected three new members of the Board of Regents: JUDITH O. RUBIN of Manhattan, a former Dinkins official; JAMES R. TALLON JR. of Binghamton, president of the United Hospital Fund of New York; and MILTON L. COFIELD of Rochester, a professor at the Rochester Institute of Technology. They replace CHARLOTTE K. FRANK, CARL T. HAYDEN and ENA FARLEY, whose terms expire this month. Mr. Hayden was the board's chancellor; the Regents will choose a replacement on Monday.

title: B.U. Prepares for a Test Against a Familiar Foe
description: Men's conference tournaments in Division I reach the single-elimination stage this week. But it is not the end of the road for the losing teams. The National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament invites seven at-large teams in addition to the tournament winners from the five leagues with automatic bids.

title: Delinquencies Off in Commercial Mortgages
description: Delinquent commercial real estate loans held by life insurers fell to a low in the fourth quarter, a sign that the recession has yet to hurt property lenders, the American Council of Life Insurers says.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Is Tame
description: Consumer prices in Brazil posted a 0.36 percent gain in February, increasing the likelihood that the central bank will cut interest rates in a policy meeting next week. A slowdown in inflation, now in the fourth consecutive month thanks to falling gasoline prices, prompted the central bank to reduce rates by 0.25 percentage points last month, to 18.75 percent. The bank estimates inflation of 4 percent this year, within targets that have been agreed upon with the International Monetary Fund. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Nokia Lowers Its First-Quarter Sales Forecast
description: As mobile phone makers vie for buyers with ever fancier handsets, Nokia, the market leader, introduced six models today. But the company said neither its new color displays nor faster mobile Internet access from sidewalks and cafes would do much to increase sales immediately.

title: Candidate for Prosecutor Post Withdraws Name in New Jersey
description: The leading candidate for the job of first assistant in the office of the United States attorney from New Jersey withdrew from consideration yesterday after Justice Department officials in Washington stalled his nomination. The officials had concerns about a meeting he held with Senator Robert G. Torricelli last year when the senator was the subject of a criminal investigation.

title: A Posh Art Fair, Visited by Police
description: Every year, despite continued grumbling about the dwindling supply of great paintings, furniture and decorative objects available today, thousands of collectors, curators, scholars and auction house experts flock to this Dutch city and the European Fine Art Fair, where some 200 dealers from 13 countries offer their best.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterday about a report defending the effectiveness of World Bank aid to poor countries misstated a figure used by by James D. Wolfensohn, the bank president, for foreign aid increases. Mr. Wolfensohn called on wealthy nations to spend $40 billion to $60 billion more each year -- an amount that would double total aid spending. He did not say nations should increase their aid spending to $40 billion to $60 billion a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, JAMES M.
description: CASEY-James M., 61. Died March 8, at Jacobi Hospital. He was an Arbitrator for the American Arbitration Association and a selfemployed CPA. Memorial services are March 23, 11 AM at the Church of the Messiah, Rhinebeck, NY. Memorials may be made to Center for Hope (Hospice), 176 Hussa Street, Linden, NJ 07036.

title: Texas Mother Guilty
description: A Texas jury took less than four hours to find Andrea Pia Yates guilty of capital murder in the bathtub drownings of her five young children, despite her plea of insanity. The jurors must now decide on a sentence for Mrs. Yates, who was suffering from post-partum depression at the time of the killings.

title: Corrections
description: An events listing on Monday for memorials to the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorism misstated the time and date of an evening of prayer and healing at St. Peter's Church, 16 Barclay Street. It is 5:30 p.m. on March 21, not 5:45 p.m. tomorrow.
