description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARHART, AMORY S.
description: CARHART-Amory S. The Board of Directors and membership of the Bathing Corporation express great sadness at the recent passing of our most worthy and esteemed President and Director of twenty-nine years, and extend our deepest sympathy to Wendy, Amory and his family.

title: Former Interior Secretary to Develop Water Projects in the Middle East
description: Bruce Babbitt, the secretary of the interior under President Bill Clinton, has announced that he will become chairman of a company that will develop huge water projects in the Middle East, including Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia.

title: Smucker Turns To Buzz Grey
description: The J. M. Smucker Company in Orrville, Ohio, will consolidate consumer advertising assignments for its brands and those it is acquiring and assign them to Buzz Grey in New York, part of the Grey Worldwide unit of the Grey Global Group. Combined billings were estimated at $40 million for 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMBERMAN, JACOB
description: IMBERMAN-Jacob, on March 11, 2002. Devoted husband of Arlyn, adored father of Joseph and Diane, and cherished grandfather of Samuel, David, Daniel and Elizabeth. Funeral services will take place at Temple Israel, 112 E. 75 St., Manhattan, on March 13, at 12:30 PM. He is survived by his wife, Arlyn, two children, Joseph Imberman of Maplewood, NJ and Diane Albert of Chappaqua, NY, a sister, Ruth Taxel of Brooklyn, a brother, Milton Imberman of Manhattan, and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made either to: The Center for the Study of the Presidency, 1020 19 St, NW-Suite 250, Washington, D.C., 20036 or The Jacob Imberman Fund, U.J.A./Federation of NY, 130 E. 59 St., NY, NY 10022

title: Redistricting 2002 Produces No Great Shake-Ups
description: With Congressional redistricting almost complete, the once-a-decade redrawing of the nation's political map is turning out to favor incumbents to an unusual degree, making many of the House's swing seats into safer territory for one party or the other.

title: Mugabe Holds Large Lead In Election In Zimbabwe
description: President Robert Mugabe held a commanding lead in the presidential election early today and appeared headed to a victory certain to be contested after a campaign and balloting marred by political violence, intimidation and other irregularities.

title: Where Pain of Arthur Andersen Is Personal
description: The possible collapse of Arthur Andersen, one of the nation's oldest accounting firms, would be the end of a brand that long stood for integrity in accounting and would be a devastating blow to the firm's thousands of partners around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, ELISABETH LUCE
description: MOORE-Elisabeth Luce. On February 9, 2002, age 98, in New York City. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, Wednesday, April 10, at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and E. 91st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions will be welcomed at Brick Church Parish House, 62 East 92nd Street.

title: Profit at Credit Suisse Group Plunged 73% Last Year
description: The Credit Suisse Group today reported a steep 73 percent drop in its 2001 net profit today, and made no promises that earnings would improve this year. The company is concentrating on paring its work force further to revive its fortunes, which have been plagued by missteps at home and at its New York-based investment arm.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Hearing On Health Emergencies
description: The New York State Assembly has scheduled a public hearing on ways to respond more effectively to public health emergencies like bioterrorism. Assembly Hearing Room, Room 1923, 19th floor, 250 Broadway, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (518) 455-4941.

title: Pentagon Says U.S. Airstrike Killed Women And Children
description: Women and children were among 14 people killed six days ago when American fighter aircraft attacked a vehicle traveling from a suspected Qaeda sanctuary in eastern Afghanistan, the military said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCCI, ANTHONY T.
description: RAUCCI-Anthony T. On March 9, 2002. Beloved husband of Dr. Irene McEachen Raucci and a loving father and grandfather. Funeral service was held privately.

title: Andersen Widens Effort To Find Buyer
description: Amid signs that a possible merger deal with Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu was faltering, Arthur Andersen intensified discussions yesterday with two other accounting competitors in hopes of striking a deal by the end of the week, people involved in the discussions said yesterday.

title: Beams of Blue, Soaring to the Sky
description: To the Editor:

title: For Cheese Lovers, A Visual Feast
description: The old saying about books and their covers holds true for ''The Cheese Plate'' by Max McCalman and David Gibbons (Clarkson Potter, $32.50). It looks like a cookbook. But there are no recipes. Mr. McCalman, the cheese expert at Picholine and Artisanal restaurants, and Mr. Gibbons, a hotelier-turned-writer, have collaborated on a handsome color volume that explores cheese inside and out. The text could not be clearer. It describes how cheeses are made, the stages of ripening and ways to serve cheeses. It pairs cheeses with wine, and gives the histories of some of the best-known cheeses. The book is not an encyclopedia of cheese, though Mr. McCalman takes 50 pages of it to profile his favorite cheeses worldwide.

title: No Rich Route For Partners In a Merger By Andersen
description: A partnership in a Big Five accounting firm over the years has been as cozy a professional home as anyone could wish for. Those who made partner were paid hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, could retire relatively young, and even amid the industry's many mergers could count on job security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDERMAN, NORMA
description: SCHNEIDERMAN-Norma. Died on March 9, 2002 at age 90. Formerly of the Bronx. Beloved wife of William. The Board of Directors extends its sympathy to Loan Officer Paul Schneiderman on the death of his mother. She was a courageous woman who jumped off a Nazi death train. Condolences to children, Roberta and Larry, Paul and Hanita, grandchildren, Michelle, Joe, Jesse, and David and great grandchildren, Justin, Emma, and Zoe. Progressive Credit Union Robert Familant, Treasurer

title: Tokyo Stock Rally Is Attracting Some Suspicion
description: In Japan's well-orchestrated economy, few things happen entirely on their own, including stock market rallies.

title: Critic's Notebook; And Now The 16th Minute Of Fame
description: Without seeing even one punch from tonight's ''Celebrity Boxing'' show (Fox did not send out review tapes), it's enough to hear ''Paula Jones vs. Tonya Harding'' to know that we've fallen down some strange celebrity rabbit hole and landed in a place where new rules apply.

title: Mets Cautious With Leiter
description: Al Leiter reported to the Mets' complex today in Port St. Lucie, Fla., feeling more soreness in his right hip flexor than he did on Monday, when he injured it running sprints. Leiter did not throw, but the Mets are hopeful that he will be able to pitch in some form Wednesday to keep him on schedule in the rotation.

title: 'Kissing Jessica Stein'
description: Directed by Charles Herman-Wurmfeld

title: American Mission Takes to the Air, and the Airwaves
description: It was dusk along Pakistan's southwestern border with Afghanistan, meaning showtime had arrived. Inside a lumbering military plane, its belly packed with enough equipment to run a small-town radio and television station, four technicians punched buttons and twirled dials.

title: High School for Abused Children
description: Girls and Boys Town of New York, part of the organization for abused and neglected children founded in 1917 by the Rev. Edward J. Flanagan, has renovated a high school building in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, to serve about 40 students at its residential centers in Brooklyn and the Bronx. The school is run by counselors from the organization and teachers from Public School 371. Kathleen Carroll

title: In Philadelphia, a New Taste of Freedom
description: TWO restaurants could not be more different than Morimoto and Django. One is a temple of design, with sushi and sake in supporting roles, and the other is a personal statement that the reinvention of crme brle as a napoleon is a goal more worthy than fine linens and the ultimate wine cellar. But together they represent a new excitement at the table here.

title: INSIDE
description: Malcolm X Auction Halted

title: FEDEX TO SHIP 200,000 PACKAGES A YEAR FOR HYUNDAI
description: The FedEx Corporation, the largest overnight delivery service, won a contract to be the exclusive carrier for the Hyundai Motor Company's United States sales network, shipping about 200,000 packages a year. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKAY, EMILY
description: MACKAY-Emily. On March 10, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Richard Mackay. Devoted and loving mother of Bonnie Mackay-Eisenhardt. Respected and admired retired teacher in Patchogue, N.Y. of emotionally disturbed and memtally challenged children. She is survived by her brother Warner Lowe, sister Virginia Graham and their children. Emily was loved by all. Visitation Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Krtil Funeral Home; Yorkville Funeral Service, Inc., 1297 1st Ave, NYC. Funeral service Thursday, 11AM at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave, NYC. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y. Contributions can be made in her memory to Mary Manning Walsh Home and the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Suozzi Weighs 1,200 Job Cuts To Help Offset Nassau Deficit
description: The Nassau County executive said today that he planned to eliminate 1,200 jobs by September 2003, a 12.5 percent reduction that would save the financially troubled county about $100 million a year and reduce its work force to its smallest size in recent memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANCLIFFE, JEAN
description: STANCLIFFE-Jean. On March 11, 2002. Alumni of Manhattanville College. Beloved daughter of the late William and Agnes Stancliffe. Loving sister of the late Helen Marcato and Virginia Thoesen. Cherished aunt of Robert & David Marcato and Susan Nielsen. Also survived by several grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Funeral Mass Thursday 10AM at St. Thomas More R.C. Church. Interment to follow, St. Raymond's Cemetery. Family has requested no visitation. For further information please call Frank E. Campbell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, JOSEPH H.
description: AARON-Joseph H. In loving memory of Joseph H. Aaron, an extraordinary scholar and lifelong educator. You will be remembered always as our beloved uncle, our teacher, and our friend. Helen and Jules Kornblau, Amy & David, Lisa & Kenneth, Stacy & Eric, and Katherine

title: State Attacks Defendant's Testimony on Dog Mauling
description: The prosecution in the dog mauling trial of a San Francisco couple today attacked a defendant's version of the events, suggesting that the defendant lied in testifying that she threw herself on top of her neighbor to shield her from a rampaging 120-pound Presa Canario.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,054 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, not including 19 hijackers.

title: Unjust Rules for Insanity
description: Andrea Yates attempted suicide twice in 1999 and reported suicidal impulses again not long before the day last June when she drowned her children in a bathtub. She was hospitalized several times for mental illness; the last time her psychiatrist had threatened to force her commitment in court. Both the prosecution and the defense in her murder trial in Texas agree that she is severely mentally ill. Yet under Texas law all this was insufficient to produce a verdict of not guilty by reason of insanity, and yesterday Andrea Yates was found guilty of capital murder.

title: Priest and Worshiper Shot Dead At Morning Mass on Long Island
description: A Long Island priest standing near the altar during morning Mass was fatally shot yesterday by a man who strode through the main door, pulled a rifle out from under his raincoat and fired at least six shots, also killing a woman in the congregation, the police said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen Expects Profit Decline
description: Volkswagen expects first-quarter earnings to fall as car markets shrink and it reorganizes in Argentina. First-quarter sales will probably fall 6.5 percent, to 1.18 million vehicles, the chief executive-designate, Bernd Pischetsrieder, left, said at a news conference. Volkswagen-brand sales in the quarter may fall 9 percent from a year ago after two-month sales of the Golf, the company's best-selling car, fell 7.5 percent.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Businesses Seek Aid
description: Members of the World Trade Center Tenants Association called yesterday for more government grant money and urged that eligibility requirements for business-relief funds be eased. They urged the Empire State Development Corporation to quadruple the money it gives to trade center tenants, to 16 percent of each business's annual gross revenue, and to lower companies' eligibility to 4 employees or more from 10 or more. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Falsified Movie Reviews
description: Sony Pictures Entertainment has agreed to pay the state $326,000 for faking laudatory movie reviews and attributing them to a real person and a real newspaper, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal announced yesterday. Sony also agreed to stop producing television commercials in which Sony employees posed as moviegoers praising Sony films. Last June, Newsweek disclosed that Sony advertisements carried fake reviews by a David Manning for ''A Knight's Tale,'' starring Heath Ledger, left, and for other films. Mr. Manning is not a film critic with The Ridgefield Press, as the ad claimed. He is the son of a former first selectman from Ridgefield, Sue Manning, who admitted giving permission to Sony to use her son's name. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: One City Job Lost in Yonkers, But a Politician Finds Another
description: Just two weeks after being voted out of a job by the City Council here, the embattled politician Jay B. Hashmall was appointed today as the city's second deputy mayor.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Indian Payment Stopped For Now
description: A federal judge has granted the state a temporary stay for the nearly $250 million he determined it owed the Cayuga Indian Nation as repayment for illegally confiscated land. Judge Neal McCurn of United States District Court ruled on Monday that it was in the public's best interest that all appeals be exhausted before the award was granted. If the award was overturned, he reasoned, it could be very difficult to recover the money. The tribe is entitled to interest during the period of stay. A lawyer for the nation, Raymond J. Heslin, said yesterday that the Cayugas were still willing to join settlement talks. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Popular Parishioner Was Known for Her Deep Faith
description: Every day, Eileen Tosner would pull out of her driveway on Jefferson Avenue in her blue Ford Escort, Tweety Bird dangling from her rearview mirror, and set out for the 9 a.m. Mass at Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, REVEREND CANON FREDERICK ALEXANDER
description: McDONALD - Reverend Canon Frederick Alexander, 93, died in San Francisco March 10. Rev. McDonald, an Episcopalian minister, attended the General Theological Seminary in New York and was ordained in 1934. His parish assignments included St. Stephen's in Providence, RI; St. John's in Centralia, WA; St. David's in Portland, OR and St. Clement's in Honolulu, HI. He was also the headmaster of the Iolani School in Hawaii. During World War II, Reverend McDonald served the 12th army group under General Omar Bradley as an army chaplain. He is survived by his sister, Elizabeth Parsons.

title: Disney Chief Calls Koppel But Fails to Say Magic Words
description: Michael D. Eisner, in France for the opening of a festive Walt Disney theme park, made a phone call back home on a decidedly unfestive issue facing his company: Ted Koppel's future at ABC News.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWIN, LILI
description: LOWIN-Lili. A celebration of Lili's life will be held on Sat., Mar 16th at 2 PM. The Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th St, NY, NY.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A white-collar criminal adds conviction No. 7 to his record.
description: AS securities fraud cases go, the crime that Lionel Reifler admitted to yesterday was not particularly extraordinary. He pleaded guilty to conspiring to rig the price of a stock traded on the over-the-counter bulletin board.

title: No Counter Too Small, No Dish Too Bright
description: For the space-starved cook there is the Compact Dishrack, which can be folded in half and stored. Made of molded translucent white plastic, it is 20 by 16 inches when open and has a built-in cup for cutlery. Made by Umbra, it costs $14.99 at Home Front Hardware, 202 East 29th Street. Hungry for spring colors? How about opaque acrylic dishes in aqua, blue, green, orange, yellow and white. Eleven-inch dinner plates and nine-inch salad plates are $3.95 each. Small bowls are $1.50 each. Crate & Barrel, 650 Madison Avenue (59th Street) sells them. MARIANNE RORHLICH

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lucent Says Its Revenue Will Fall Short of Forecast

title: House Panel's Investigation Of Global Crossing Is Started
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee began an investigation today into accounting practices and executives' sales of company stock at Global Crossing, the telecommunications company that has filed for bankruptcy protection. Global Crossing faces accusations that it used sham transactions to increase revenue and that it misled investors about its financial health.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Radio Factor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOWAN, PATRICIA A., R.N.
description: McGOWAN-Patricia A., R.N. On March 12, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late William (Ret. Battalion Chief FDNY) and Virginia (nee Masson). Devoted companion of Edward Ryan. Loving mother of William Donnelly and mother-inlaw of Irene Donnelly. Cherished grandmother of Declan Donnelly. Loving sister of Joan Washington and Virginia Gilbert. Dear sister-inlaw of Dennis Washington and Bryon Gilbert. Fond aunt of Danny Washington, Andrew and Diana Gilbert. Received her Master's degree in nursing from Pace University & also graduated from Hunter College and St. Saviour High School. Funeral Friday 9 AM from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Mass of the Resurrection 10 AM St. Thomas More R.C. Church. Service to follow at Greenwood Crematory. Visiting Wednesday 7-10 PM and Thursday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10021, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTH, IRENE
description: WORTH-Irene. The Board and staff of BAM mourn the passing of Irene Worth, a great woman of theater and longtime supporter. We extend our sympathies to her family. Karen Brooks Hopkins, President Joseph V. Melillo, Executive Producer

title: TYCO WILL SPIN OFF ITS CIT FINANCE DIVISION
description: Tyco International Ltd. will spin off its entire CIT Group finance unit, accelerating a plan to split into four companies to quell investor concerns about accounting complexity. The company, which had considered retaining a stake in the finance unit, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to spin off the division by July. Tyco is still pursuing a sale of all or part of CIT, the chief financial officer, Mark Swartz, said on a conference call with investors. Tyco also received bids in what Mr. Swartz called the first phase of the auction for its plastics unit. It expects proceeds of as much as $3 billion.

title: Beams of Blue, Soaring to the Sky
description: To the Editor:

title: Color-Coded System Created To Rate Threat of Terrorism
description: The White House unveiled a system of color-coded rankings today to warn the nation of terrorist threats and said that the current alert level was yellow, meaning the threat of new terrorist attacks was ''significant'' but not ''severe.''

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Including Fetus In Murder Law
description: The House passed a bill that would place fetuses under the protection of the state's murder, manslaughter and assault laws, a step Democrats say is intended to undercut abortion rights. The Senate easily approved the bill last month. Gov. Dirk Kempthorne, a Republican, has not indicated whether he will sign the bill. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Why Did the Chickens Cross the Bridge? For Cupcakes, Of Course
description: Two Little Red Hens, a popular bakery in Brooklyn, has opened a branch at 1652 Second Avenue (85th Street) in Manhattan. The owners, Mary Louise Clemens, left, and Christina Winkler, right, took over Faith's Bakery in Park Slope in 1994 and turned it into a spot decorated with homey chicken-theme accessories. The new shop sells their sumptuously frosted cupcakes ($2.50 to $4) and layer cakes ($10 to $42), rich tartlets and tarts ($7 to $22), among other goodies. The prices for baked-goods are a tad lower in Brooklyn. Like the original store, the new bakery has a few cafe tables. The partners now have plans for a wholesale bakery, too.

title: Calls to Limit Powers of Next Schools Investigator
description: As city officials mourned the death yesterday of Edward F. Stancik, the special schools investigator, there were calls from both law enforcement and school officials to curb the powers of his office before a successor is appointed.

title: Nuclear Planning: A Threat to Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: Man of the Left Who Put Wines to Right
description: WHEN Edmund L. Penning-Rowsell died on March 3 at his home in Oxfordshire, England, a generation of wine writers died with him.

title: Mets Delay New Lease, Citing Poor Attendance
description: Fred Wilpon has one request to keep the Mets in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: Bass & Howes Is Acquired
description: The Seattle office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that it had acquired Bass & Howes, an agency with offices in New York and Washington that specializes in public policy advertising. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Shifting Tone, Annan Takes Tough Line On Violence
description: Speaking to the United Nations Security Council yesterday, Secretary General Kofi Annan took off the diplomatic gloves, criticizing Israel and the Palestinians for what he called ''horrifying carnage'' in the Middle East and accusing both sides of violence that is ''disproportionate in scale and indiscriminate in effect.''

title: Yankees Act To Restore Trust on Team
description: Derek Jeter stuffed two black Rawlings gloves in his equipment bag before boarding the team bus this morning. ''Looks like you have all your gloves,'' a reporter said, but Jeter did not bite. He did not want to talk about the incident that led to the release of Ruben Rivera late Monday night.

title: Nuclear Planning: A Threat to Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Auto Insurance Scheme Alleged
description: Thirty people have been charged with operating or participating in a car insurance fraud ring involving 68 cars worth $1.6 million, Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, announced yesterday. The individuals include 24 car owners who the authorities said gave their cars to one of six middlemen, who are accused of selling the cars to undercover police officers posing as junkyard dealers. An additional 13 car owners and two middlemen are being sought. The cars were sold for up to $1,500, and the defendants are accused of receiving insurance settlements of up to $32,000. Those charged include a public school teacher, a Postal Service worker and a Long Island Rail Road engineer. They could face up to seven years in prison. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HENNESSY, RAYMOND J.
description: HENNESSY-Raymond J., March 13, 2001. Beloved Husband, Father, Grandfather, Friend. It's been a year since you went away. Sadly missed and forever loved each day. The Hennessy Family

title: NYFIX TO BUY JAVELIN TECHNOLOGIES FOR $55 MILLION
description: Nyfix Inc., the operator of electronic trading systems for securities and derivatives, agreed to buy a rival, Javelin Technologies Inc., for about $55 million in stock and cash to add institutional clients. Nyfix will pay about $44 million in stock and the rest in cash for the closely held Javelin. Clients of Javelin, which is based in New York, include the American Stock Exchange, Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. Nyfix, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said the transaction was expected to close this month.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the preparation of a federal indictment against Arthur Andersen gave an outdated name for one of Andersen's law firms. It is Mayer, Brown, Rowe & Maw, no longer Mayer, Brown & Platt.

title: 'Back Against the Wall'
description: Directed by James Fotopoulos

title: Remains of 11 Firefighters Are Found at Trade Center
description: The remains of at least 11 firefighters and an unknown number of civilians were uncovered at the World Trade Center site yesterday in what was the biggest find of victims in weeks. The discoveries came as crews finally dug into the former lobby of the south tower, one of the few sections at the site yet to be fully cleared.

title: Bank Boards Discuss a Report on Losses by Currency Trader
description: Board members of Allied Irish Banks and its United States subsidiary, Allfirst Financial, received a report yesterday on an internal investigation into how an Allfirst currency trader, John M. Rusnak, managed to hide losses of $691 million over five years. The two boards began meeting at 9 a.m. in Dublin and finished for the day at 11 p.m.

title: A Pastor Who Changed the Face of His Parish
description: When the word spread today, from one neighbor to another around the town's close-knit Roman Catholic parish, it took only two words to convey the loss and the horror of the morning Mass. What happened? people asked. ''Father Larry,'' came the reply. ''Father Larry.''

title: Democrats Pick Novice In Texas Race For Governor
description: Tony Sanchez, the political novice who spent nearly $20 million of his own money to introduce himself to voters, won the Democratic primary for governor tonight after a contentious campaign that underscored the rise of Hispanic political power in Texas.

title: Commissioner Is Set to Enforce An Old Rule on Liabilities
description: Commissioner Bud Selig, fearful that mounting debt could force one or more teams into bankruptcy and with an eye on team payrolls, has informed major league clubs that he will enforce a liabilities rule he wrote, as an owner, 27 years ago.

title: CALPINE GETS $1.6 BILLION CREDIT TO FORTIFY ITS FINANCES
description: The Calpine Corporation, a builder and operator of power plants, delayed or canceled $3 billion of turbine purchases and obtained $1.6 billion in bank credit to shore up its finances. Cancellation penalties and unrefunded deposits on 35 General Electric Company turbines will reduce profit by $98 million this quarter, the chief executive, Peter Cartwright, said. Calpine also deferred delivery and payment on 81 more turbines from General Electric, Siemens and the Toshiba Corporation. Calpine reduced the amount it is spending on turbines by $1.2 billion this year and $1.8 billion in 2003.

title: Parents Play Crucial Role In Expanding Universities
description: PRESIDENT BUSH has signed an education bill designed to ''leave no child behind.'' But even if elementary and secondary schools improve for disadvantaged students, the goal of offering every child a good education won't be met unless lower-income high school graduates can afford college, and unless there is growth in state university systems that are now barely large enough to serve the middle class.

title: Juicy Kebabs Tucked Away in a Queens Cabby Haunt
description: THE kebab rarely receives its due respect. Dismissed as simple, sneered at as primitive, the kebab sizzles through life unappreciated, just as cars and buses rumble into the unconscious sonic background of city life.

title: Puzzling Timing: An Onslaught Before Zinni's Arrival
description: These are not normal times, an Israeli commentator mused as he pondered the large-scale Israeli invasion of Ramallah today. These are the ''days of Zinni,'' he said.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Halt Of Primaries
description: The State Board of Elections postponed indefinitely all primary elections scheduled for May 7 to await a decision from the State Supreme Court on whether the legislative districts are legal. The court is scheduled to hear arguments April 4 on a lawsuit brought by Republican lawmakers who object to the redistricting map drawn by the Democratic-controlled General Assembly. Last week, the Supreme Court halted the legislative primaries pending a decision on a lower court ruling that the districts split counties in violation of the state Constitution. The elections board said it did not want to hold separate primaries for state and federal offices.

title: Tax Bills to Rise for Scheme's Beneficiaries
description: The city's Finance Department plans to hand out new tax bills with whopping increases to the owners of 18 buildings. The department says those buildings benefited this year from a long-running scheme to pay millions in bribes for secretly reduced tax assessments on office towers, hotels and apartment buildings.

title: For Female Coaches, Gains and Concerns
description: Although colleges have more women's sports teams than ever, a smaller proportion of teams have female head coaches, a recent study on women in college sports found.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink To Serve AT&T Customers
description: At a time when Internet service providers are struggling to reach out and touch new customers, EarthLink said yesterday that it would offer its high-speed cable Internet service via the AT&T Broadband network, starting with Boston and Seattle this year and followed by additional cities in 2003. EarthLink, based in Atlanta, already offers high-speed Internet service over Time Warner Cable in 24 markets, and plans to begin service in 15 remaining Time Warner markets by midyear. The latest deal comes amid jockeying by big Internet service providers to make deals with cable and other broadband companies as growth in demand for dial-up Internet service flattens. AT&T Broadbandhas about 1.5 million Internet service customers. EarthLink shares rose 89 cents, or 9.2 percent, to $10.58. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Lucent Lowers Outlook and Sets $1.5 Billion Note Sale
description: Continued weakness in the telecommunications market is not helping the comeback efforts of Lucent Technologies, which warned Wall Street yesterday morning that its revenue in the current quarter would fall short of projections the company made as recently as three weeks ago.

title: Longtime Head of City Hospital Union Loses Re-Election Bid
description: A vote count completed yesterday showed that James Butler, the president of the largest union local at New York City's public hospitals, was narrowly defeated after nearly three decades in office.

title: New Jersey Yeshiva Teacher Accused of Sex Crimes Against Youths
description: Since joining the Kushner Yeshiva High School in Livingston, N.J., as a biology teacher in September 2000, Paul Slifer had been popular among students. They liked talking to him, in person and on the Internet, police investigators said. Some of them believed he was a doctor, the police said, and went to him for advice with problems. He offered physical exams.

title: Team of World Champions Knocked Out at Nationals
description: A team of reigning world bridge champions was upset here on Monday night in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NECHAMKIN, LEON
description: NECHAMKIN-Leon. Palm Beach Orthodox Synagogue mourns the passing of our esteemed member and founder of our Ruth & Leon Nechamkin Hebrew School. We express our deepest condolences to the family on the loss of their beloved father and grandfather. Moshe E. Scheiner, Rabbi Michael C. Gelfand, M.D., President

title: Painting a Family Portrait And Finding a Father's Soul
description: The autobiographical one-man show has become quite the crowded genre. Generally it is a young person's showcase, and often it is about an upbringing that is supposed to resonate as representative, a personal story in a generic framework. You know, ''My Story: Growing Up _____,'' where the blank is filled by a label: Gay, Iroquois, Dyslexic, Abused, Deaf, etc., or some hyphenated combination thereof.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Hard-Liners Block Budget
description: The hard-line Guardian Council has blocked President Mohammad Khatami's budget plan, which was approved by Parliament last month. The council found 18 points that it said were contrary to Islamic law, chiefly relating to money allocated to conservative bodies controlled by the country's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Parliament modified 14 articles but declared that if the Guardian Concil rejected the budget again it would go to the Expediency Council, an arbitration panel. The budget sets a standard exchange rate for the first time since the Islamic revolution in 1979. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Man Shot Dead in Argument That Hospitalizes a Neighbor
description: A 25-year-old former Army medic was shot to death in Brooklyn yesterday after he and his father argued with a neighbor, the police said. The neighbor was also wounded in the incident.

title: It's Very British, It's Very Sticky, And It's Over Here
description: High-end London restaurants serve sticky toffee pudding, a dark, dense, cakelike confection, which is a specialty of the Lake District of northwest England. One brand, from the English Pudding Company, is also sold in the food halls at Fortnum & Mason and Harvey Nichols. Three years ago, Simon Johns, whose family started the company, moved to Los Angeles and opened a branch there. His Sticky Toffee Pudding has now made it to New York, where it is sold, frozen, for $10.50 (to serve six) at Dean & DeLuca. The pudding is served warm, and the 18-ounce container can be heated in a conventional or microwave oven. It can be ordered online for $13 plus shipping from www.stickytoffeepudding.com.

title: Tyson Wins License to Fight Lewis in Washington
description: The boxing commission here decided unanimously tonight to grant Mike Tyson a license to fight Lennox Lewis in June in what could be the most lucrative bout in history.

title: Beams of Blue, Soaring to the Sky
description: To the Editor:

title: Africans Fill Churches That Celebrate Wealth
description: It was just another Sunday morning in the new home of one of Africa's fastest-growing churches, the Winners' Church, which is only a dozen years old but already has branches in 32 countries on the continent.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Foreign Ministry Official Sentenced
description: A former Foreign Ministry official was sentenced to seven years for embezzling millions in public funds in a scandal that drew broad attention to corruption in the ministry. The official, Katsutoshi Matsuo, pleaded guilty to taking the money from a secret cabinet fund for overseas travel and entertainment. He used some to buy racehorses and houses for mistresses. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Abuse Suit Reinstated
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that two brothers who said they were sexually abused by a former priest three decades ago had the right to sue him. Judge Carol A. Ferentz of Superior Court ruled that the brothers, Michael and Thomas Corsie, could sue the priest, Michael G. Campanalonga, but not his former Bergen County parish or the archdiocese of Newark. A lower court had dismissed the case, saying that too much time had elapsed since the incidents, which the brothers said took place between 1966 and 1974. The brothers said the memories of the abuse resurfaced in 1992 while Thomas, 39, was in a drug rehabilitation program, and Michael, 48, was in therapy. After the accusations were made, Father Campanalonga was unfrocked when he refused to agree to psychological testing. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: John Ashcroft's Palmer Raids
description: The federal government is still holding hundreds of Middle Eastern and Asian men rounded up after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Most are jailed on minor immigration violations, but they are being held indefinitely, presumably as the government looks for some connection to terrorists. Americans who object to this tactic of indiscriminate roundups, Attorney General John Ashcroft told a Senate committee in December, ''only aid terrorists.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEFE, HARRY V. JR.
description: KEEFE-Harry V. Jr. Known as the dean of banking, on March 8, 2002, at the age of 79. His remarkable investment banking career started in 1946 with R.L. Day followed by Tucker Anthony. He opened Keefe, Bruyette and Woods in 1962 with only eight employees and $50,000 in capital, growing it to 180 employees and $83 million in 1989 when he left to start Keefe Managers, Inc., a bank equities investment firm. He was a consultant to bank managements, an investment banker (holding the record number of bank mergers) and a commentator to the press, regulators and legislators. He received the Bancroft Prize of outstanding orator of the senior class and sixty years later, the 1999 Distinguished Graduate Award from the Boston Latin School. He received honorary doctorates from Amherst, Lafayette and Wheaton Colleges. For his key role in establishing the Greater Hartford Open, he was elected to the Connecticut Sports Hall of Fame. A former horseman, he served many years as Senior Master of the Fairfield County Hounds. He was a generous philanthropist giving freely to colleges, secondary schools and Catholic charities. He graduated from Boston Latin School in 1939, Amherst in 1943. He was the commanding officer of US LCT 555 when it was sunk by enemy fire on Omaha Beach on D-day. After the War, he attended Boston University Graduate School of Business. In addition to his wife, Anita Keefe, he is survived by a daughter, Kathleen Raffel, a son Harry V. Keefe III, stepsons Geoffrey de Lesseps and Thomas Verderber and nine grandchildren. In Greenwich, CT, calling hours will be Thursday, March 14 from 4-6 and 7-9 at Gallagher's Funeral Home. Services will be held on March 15 at 11 AM at St. Michael's Church. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City at 10:30 on March 25th. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Keefe Library Book Fund, Boston Latin School Association, 41 West Street, Boston, MA. 02111.

title: City Official Considers Ending Several Investment Programs
description: The president of the city's Economic Development Corporation yesterday said he was considering ending several programs started during the Giuliani administration that invested city tax dollars in small companies or emerging industries.

title: Though France Booms, Voters Find Politics Blah
description: France has undergone a remarkable economic and social transformation in the last few years, and Franois Prioux, 26, exhibits this country's newfound confidence.

title: Israeli Dissenter: Courageous or Dangerous?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Developer's Profit Falls
description: The big Hong Kong property developer Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd. said first-half profit fell 40 percent after it wrote off losses at its information-technology unit and sold fewer apartments. Profit for the six months ended Dec. 31 fell to 3.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($410 million), from 5.3 billion, a year earlier. Sales fell about 9 percent, to 9.52 billion Hong Kong dollars. The company's Sunevision Holdings unit, which operates data centers in Beijing, Shanghai and Hong Kong that warehouse electronic information for corporate clients, said it made a provision of 355.9 million Hong Kong dollars for the lower value of its Internet investments and wrote off 117.4 million Hong Kong dollars for closing a data center in Singapore and for scaling back its online auction unit, Red Dots.

title: AFGHANS DECLARE MOUNTAIN VICTORY; FOES' TOLL UNCLEAR
description: Afghan and American troops swooped into the Shah-i-Kot Valley from three directions shortly after dawn today and quickly won control of the high-altitude stronghold after encountering only tepid resistance from cave-dwelling holdouts of the Taliban and Al Qaeda, exultant Afghan commanders said.

title: A Matter of Opinion

The company's shares fell as much as 1.4 percent. The chief executive, Tony Trahar, saying that 2002 would be a challenging year, hinted that the company was looking to grow through acquisitions. Shoppers, she noted, will find drapes made from fabrics by Scalamandr, Schumacher, Brunschwig & Fils and others. title: Greenery to Import If Drought Strikes
description: Five months ago, Material ConneXion added FieldTurf, a synthetic lawn with ''dirt'' made of recycled tires and sneakers, to its collection. Billed as the ''closest to nature'' grass substitute, it was invented for tennis courts and picked up for other sports fields by teams like the Seattle Seahawks and the University of Nebraska Cornhuskers, whose Memorial Stadium in Lincoln is below. FieldTurf is soft, holds up in bad weather and drains faster than real grass, reducing skids, said John Ingram, the university's director of athletic facilities. The residential version is perfect for shady backyards; Alan Lemay, a customer service representative for FieldTurf, installed it at his home near Montreal. ''There are too many trees and no sun,'' he said. ''Last year, we had a drought for 50 days, and the watering police showed up and said, 'Why is your grass so green?' '' It is $5.50 a square foot for athletic installations; $10 to $12 to homeowners: (800) 724-2969 or www.fieldturf .com. ELAINE LOUIE

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Migrants Stifle Channel Traffic
description: The intrusion of hundreds of immigrants into a railyard a few miles inland from the Channel Tunnel has forced officials to suspend virtually all freight service to Britain through the tunnel. The immigrants, frustrated by increased security near the mouth of the tunnel, are now massing inland at the Frethun freight depot, hoping to get on trains headed to Britain. Normally, about 25 freight trains go through the tunnel each day but officials expected no more than three to go through yesterday. The tunnel operator, Eurotunnel, says the nearby Sangatte refugee center has become a launching pad for people trying to sneak aboard trains and should be closed. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: 'Trojan' Linked To Microsoft Hoax
description: Computer security experts said a new virus travels the Internet attached to an e-mail message that purports to be from the ''Microsoft Corporation Security Center.'' The program ''eliminates all known security vulnerabilities'' affecting the company's programs, the message states. Clue: Microsoft does not send software via e-mail messages. Those gullible enough to start the program, technically known as a Trojan horse, end up sending copies to those in their PC's address book. The program also opens a back door that could allow the program's creator unauthorized access. ''You never want to give anyone a key to your house,'' said Sharon Ruckman, senior director of Symantec Security Response. Update software that helps to block the program can be downloaded from most computer security companies; experts say it does not pose a major threat, but they grudgingly give the creator points for creativity.

title: In Toledo, Everything Was Up to Date
description: If ''Made in Toledo'' doesn't sound exciting, that's because most people don't know the design history of Toledo, Ohio. Harold Van Doren opened a design office there in the 1930's. He and John Gordon Rideout did the 1935 Streamline Velocipede, above; the 1935 Pioneer Tot Bike, right; and the 1933 Air King Midget Radio in Plaskon cabinet, left. The last may be the first plastic radio in this country, said Davira S. Taragin, the curator for ''The Alliance of Art and Industry: Toledo Designs for Modern America'' at the Toledo Museum of Art. Designs by Norman Bel Geddes and Donald Deskey, who worked in Toledo, are also in the show, which runs from March 24 to June 16. Hardcover catalog, $50; paperback, $24.95. Admission is $5; those under 5, free. (419) 255-8000. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Bush Orders Inquiry Into Visas Issued to Terrorists After Attack
description: President Bush ordered an investigation today into the student visas that were recently granted to two Sept. 11 hijackers while Senator Tom Daschle used the issue to demand that Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, testify before Congress, branding his refusal to appear ''untenable and inexcusable.''

title: Every Patient's Nightmare
description: You would think that Mike Hurewitz could have expected the best possible medical care in January when he donated more than half of his liver to save his brother's life. The operation was performed at one of New York City's best hospitals, Mount Sinai, which is a world leader in using live donors for liver transplants. There was risk, of course. Some experts say the odds of death for a liver donor can be as high as 1 in 100. But Mr. Hurewitz was healthy, and he was in the hands of a renowned liver transplant program that had never experienced a donor fatality.

title: San Francisco Art Museum Appoints Successor to Ross
description: After a seven-month search, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has named Neal Benezra as its director. Mr. Benezra, who has been the deputy director and curator of modern and contemporary art at the Art Institute of Chicago, succeeds David A. Ross, who left the museum abruptly after a whirlwind three years in which he spent $140 million building the museum's collection of contemporary art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKAS, RICHARD P.
description: FARKAS-Richard P. 77, of New York City, died March 10, 2002. Husband of Elizabeth P. Kilroy. Survived by four sons, seven grandchildren, one great grandchild. He was well respected for his expertise in aiding international and domestic companies.

title: Big Hopes for Gas From Gasoline
description: Like a salesman at a party supply store, a technician at the Ztek lab here gently unfolded a Mylar balloon and inserted a little plastic hose to fill it with a gas that made it float stiffly at the end of a string. But the gas was not helium, it was hydrogen.

title: Bronx Assemblywoman Said to Be Under Investigation in Bribery Case
description: A senior Democrat in the State Assembly, Gloria Davis of the Bronx, is under investigation by the Manhattan district attorney's office, which has subpoenaed records and seized cash in a bribery inquiry involving a construction contract, according to people familiar with the case.

title: Compassion for Andrea Yates
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, ADOLPH, M.D.
description: POSNER-Adolph, M.D. On March 12th, 2002. Emigrated from Poland. Attended CCNY and NYU/ Bellevue Medical School. After establishing his medical practice, he founded and supervised the Glaucoma Clinic at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital, was on the faculty of Albert Einstein Medical School and on the staff at Montefiore & Mt. Sinai Hospitals. Noted for identifying and developing treatment for the Posner/Schlossman Syndrome. Throughout his career he wrote many articles and books, most notably ''Slit-Lamp Gonioscopy'' co-authored with Dr. George Gorin. Survived by his wife Florence, his son George and daughter Ellen Romano, grandchildren Rebecca, Prema, David and Karen. Services Thursday, 9:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory can be made to The Lighthouse Foundation for the Blind.

title: Hewlett Gets A Big Backer In Its Quest For Compaq
description: In one of the largest endorsements yet of its $24 billion planned acquisition of Compaq Computer, the Hewlett-Packard Company today received a vow that Putnam Investments, one of its biggest institutional shareholders, would vote for the merger.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Mayor Suspends Campaign
description: Mayor Jeremy Harris of Honolulu has suspended his campaign for governor pending an appeal to the State Supreme Court on whether he must resign. Judge Sabrina McKenna of Circuit Court ruled this week that a 1978 amendment to the state Constitution requires a candidate who already holds an office to step down in order to campaign for another office. Mr. Harris notified the State Campaign Spending Commission in May 2001 that he would begin campaign operations. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: Part Lantern, Part Chameleon
description: The Aduki indoor-outdoor lamp by Mathmos may not provide much illumination, but it does produce an outsize effect. It comes in three versions and changes color gradually: one starts as blue and goes through pinks, violets and reds before returning to blue. Another goes from blue to green and back, and the last is green to red. An on-off switch stops the plastic lamps at any color. They run on a rechargeable battery and can be used on a table or hanging from a tree or hook. In late spring, they will be available at the Terence Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street ($59). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Girding the Walls, Just for Effect
description: From the department of swords-into-plowshares comes Latitude 70 Degrees, above and right. A vinyl-coated nylon fabric with curvy slits designed for Arctic camouflage, it is available from DesignTex, along with a version made with Tyvek, the soft, indestructible stuff of FedEx envelopes. The fabrics, $25 a yard, can be hung as curtains. For a more industrial look, DesignTex has another wartime material: chain mail, below, which is $1,400 a square yard. To the trade: (800) 221-1540. ELAINE LOUIE

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Reminder On Cash For Karadzic
description: NATO helicopters dropped thousands of fake banknotes showing the face of Radovan Karadzic over a remote area in southern Bosnia, offering a $5 million reward for information leading to the capture of the former Bosnian Serb leader indicted on charges of war crimes. The action followed two recent failed attempts to arrest Mr. Karadzic. Posters advertising the reward -- offered by the United States -- were ripped down by Serbs in the area who support Mr. Karadzic and oppose sending him to face trial in The Hague. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Metro Matters; The Politics Of Garbage, Forever Ripe
description: ONCE again, New York City is fretting about its garbage: the cost, the mess, the future.

title: White House Withdraws Nominee for NASA
description: The White House today abruptly withdrew the nomination of a Marine general to be deputy administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROST, CARL
description: TROST-Carl, 86 years young. On March 13, 2002. Beloved father of Bonnie, Lynn and Ed. Adored and adoring grandfather of six and great grandfather of seven, soon to be 11. An indomitable fighter for social justice and peace. A master wood carver, a great guy. Funeral service 12 Noon, Friday, March 15, Garlick's, Yonkers, New York.

title: Staid Old Toronto Museum Will Put on a Crystalline Jacket
description: Daniel Libeskind, at right, had minerology on his mind when he designed an extension for the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto. His proposal, selected last month from 12 entries, is for a 40,000-square-foot glass addition that looks like an immense heap of quartz. (One Toronto journalist compared it to a collision with an iceberg.) ''I think it was Palladio who said that all architecture aspires to be as beautiful as a crystal,'' said the architect, who was born in Poland, is a United States citizen and bases his practice in Berlin. Glass also dominated the designs of the other two finalists, Andrea Bruno of Turin, Italy, and Bing Thom of Vancouver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLINSKY, HYMAN
description: DOLINSKY-Hyman. On Wednesday, March 13, 2002. Beloved husband of Beverly, loving father of Ann, Rebecca, Joshua (deceased) and father-in-law of Frank Merle. Loving brother of Shirley Kalb Kleppel. Beloved uncle of Amy, Rebecca, Binyamin, Yael, Joseph, Dan and Zev. After a courageous battle with cancer. Services, Thursday, March 14th at 1:15PM at The Riverside, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. The family will sit Shiva at home. Contributions to The Joshua Dolinsky Memorial Fund, MD Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe Blvd, Houston, TX 77030

description: A bright panorama of flamenco dance styles flashed by on Tuesday night when Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana opened an engagement at the Joyce Theater.

title: Drug Companies Agree on Fees
description: Pharmaceutical companies agreed to finance policing of their products once they are on the market as part of a continuation of industry fees paid to the Food and Drug Administration for product reviews.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Teacher Arrested On Sex Charge
description: A Bronx high school teacher was arrested yesterday and charged with third-degree rape after a 16-year-old former student told her mother she had been having a sexual relationship with him, the police said. Investigators said the teacher, Mark Levy, 31, had dated the student's mother after they met last year through the P.T.A. at Columbus High School, where he taught. After they stopped dating several months ago, Mr. Levy continued to baby-sit for the family, the police said, and began a sexual relationship with the daughter. Mr. Levy, now a teacher at Kennedy High School, has been reassigned to a district office pending the case's outcome, a Board of Education spokeswoman said.

title: Harry Keefe Jr., 79, Innovator In Investments in Bank Stocks
description: Harry V. Keefe Jr., a founder of the Keefe, Bruyette & Woods brokerage firm and later a manager of an investment fund, died Friday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.

description: MALKIN-Carol (nee Fine). On Tuesday, March 12th, 2002 of Cranford, NJ formerly of New Rochelle, NY. Beloved wife of Martin F. Malkin; devoted mother of Andrea Malkin Brenner; adored mother-in-law of Richard Brenner; loving grandmother of Talia Brenner. Funeral services conducted from Temple Emanuel, 756 East Broad St, Westfield, NJ, Thursday March 14, 2002 at 11:00 AM. Interment will take place Judean Memorial Gardens, Olney, Maryland.

description: PARIS  In these days of task sharing, women may be out of the habit of spring cleaning: Three 30-something designers who were brought in to dust off Paris couture houses made a poor job of it Wednesday.

description: Franklin K. Lane High School in Woodside, Queens, has been known more for its students' high dropout rates and and gang activity than for their academic prowess.

description: Democrats won their second important judicial victory over racial redistricting when a state judge held this week that Virginia's legislative map was unconstitutional because it packed black voters into a few districts to diminish their political influence.

Survived by children, Kenneth and Andrew of Yardley, PA, John of Half Moon Bay, CA, Raymond of Darien, CT and Nancy Jensen of West Hartford, CT; 10 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. title: National Briefing | Religion: Jewish Groups Support Some Cloning
description: The Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations and the Rabbinical Council of America say they support the cloning of embryos for research and medical treatments but not for reproduction. The groups' policy, formulated by a panel of rabbis, ethicists and scientists, said, ''If cloning technology research advances our ability to heal humans with greater success, it ought to be pursued since it does not require or encourage the destruction of life in the process.'' Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Point, Shoot and Translate Into English
description: DR. ISMAIL HARITAOGLU, a computer scientist at I.B.M.'s Almaden Research Center in San Jose, Calif., travels overseas a lot on business. When he is not familiar with the local language -- which is most of the time -- he can have trouble finding his way around.

title: Striving for a Happy Ending To a Black Store's Struggles
description: There can be a fierceness about maintaining an independent bookstore in an African-American community that perhaps cannot be imagined elsewhere, where independent stores fail amid some fuss and publicity and are quickly forgotten because there are stimulating alternatives.

description: Net profit at Interbrew, the world's second-largest brewer after Anheuser Busch, nearly doubled, to 537 million euros ($470.2 million) last year from 271 million euros in 2000. Interbrew said the inclusion of Bass, the British brewer it recently acquired, had helped its profit. Bass brought in a windfall when it sold its Carling lager brand to Coors of the United States in December for 1.2 billion ($1.7 billion at current exchange rates).

description: President Bush said today that he ''wouldn't put it past'' President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to have secretly held an American pilot hostage for more than a decade.

title: F.D.A. Considers New Tests For Environmental Effects
description: The Food and Drug Administration, long focused on judging the effectiveness and safety of drugs in the body, is considering requiring more tests for their possible effects on the environment, agency officials said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Montclair: Rail Link Delayed
description: The opening of New Jersey Transit's Montclair Connection, scheduled for this spring, has been delayed until September or October, transit officials said yesterday. The connection, which is estimated to cost $63 million, had previously been scheduled to be completed in 2000. The project will connect New Jersey Transit's Boonton Line and its Midtown Direct Line, allowing riders to travel directly from Upper Montclair to Pennsylvania Station in New York City.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Isabelle Holland, an author of young adult and gothic mystery novels, misidentified the publishing house where she managed publicity for ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' by Harper Lee. It was the J. B. Lippincott Company, not Delacorte Press.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Sentences After Genocide
description: Rwandan courts had sentenced 660 people to death for crimes related to the 1994 genocide as of the end of last year, the Rwandan League for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights said. Another 1,795 had been sentenced to life in prison, and 2,566 people were acquitted. The group said 115,000 people were in jail awaiting trial on charges of involvement in killing hundreds of thousands of members of the Tutsi ethnic group as well as some Hutus. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Lottery Drawing Is a Cliffhanger After Mishap
description: For players, it is a nightly moment of truth. But when the New York State Lottery ended its televised numbers drawing last night, it was more like a moment of red-faced confusion.

title: For Els, The Road To Victory Is Not Long
description: Less than three months into 2002, Ernie Els has already won on three continents.

description: In several meetings here today, Michael R. Bloomberg tried to assuage the concerns of leading members of Congress who have sharply questioned New York City's efforts to secure billions of dollars in federal aid.

description: In the long day's journey from innocence to guilt that is ''The Bomb,'' here are some of the creatures, places, events and history that will be encountered:

title: I.N.S. Is Sued for Legal Aid for Minors It Holds
description: Legal groups are suing to require the Immigration and Naturalization Service to provide free legal representation for hundreds of minors being detained in deportation cases.

title: AETNA SAYS IT WILL RETURN TO PROFITABILITY THIS YEAR
description: Aetna Inc., the managed health care company, will be profitable in 2002 as its restructuring progresses, its chief executive, Dr. John W. Rowe, said. ''We haven't given any specific guidance'' because the company's new operating model makes it difficult to predict performance, Dr. Rowe said. ''We want at least one quarter under our belt,'' to work out any unseen problems before predicting results, he said. After that, though, management will give an earnings forecast for the rest of the year, Dr. Rowe said at a health care industry conference in Boston on Tuesday. The company, which is based in Hartford, posted a loss of $2.01 a share in 2001, but had a profit of $1.35 a share in 2000.

title: A Retreat in the Sky To Be More Earthbound
description: The new Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts in Philadelphia, with its 150-foot glass barrel-vaulted roof designed by the New York architect Rafael Violy, opened in December to rave reviews. But one part of the complex won't be open until the end of this month -- the soaring 83-foot-high public garden, right. The garden, a peaceful setting of 16 ficus trees atop the smaller theater, is enclosed by a clear glass railing. It is at such a vertiginous height, however, that some visitors have found themselves reminded more of Hitchcock than of Bach. ''Rafael did such a great job of making the barrier feel invisible with his use of glass,'' George Shaeffer, the facilities manager, said, ''that people feel a little, well, insecure.''

Survived by his loving wife, Rachel Glazer Fein; his devoted children, Barbara and Richard Kraft, Edward and Ronnie Fein; his dear stepchildren, Stanley and Richard Glazer; his adoring grandchildren, Courtney and David Levi, Matthew Kraft, Meredith and Gregory Lichtenberg, Gillian Fein and Russell and Sandra Glazer; and proud greatgrandfather of Parker and Chloe Levi, Zev Lichtenberg and Jacob, Samantha and Talia Glazer. Service Thursday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NYC 10021.

title: Me and My Shadow
description: ''Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men?'' asked the brooding voice of ''Lamont Cranston'' on a radio series that transfixed Americans about three generations ago. Goosebumpy listeners joined in the answer: ''The Shadow knows.''

title: Archaeologists Find Mayan 'Masterpiece' in Guatemala
description: Archaeologists exploring deep in the rain forest of Guatemala have uncovered what they think is the earliest intact wall painting of the Maya civilization. A depiction of scenes from mythology and ritual, the 1,900-year-old mural is being hailed by experts as a masterpiece.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Pentagon's plans for new kinds of nuclear weapons that penetrate the earth misspelled the surname of a physicist who advised the Clinton White House and now teaches science policy at Princeton. He is Frank von Hippel, not Hipple.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, BELLE
description: GRUBER-Belle. The Brotherhood Synagogue extends condolences to our Trustee, Ruth Raskin and family on the passing of her dear mother.

title: Spyros Kyprianou, 69, Former President of Cyprus, Dies
description: Spyros Kyprianou, a former president of Cyprus who refused to compromise with the island's breakaway Turkish minority, died on Tuesday in Nicosia, the capital. He was 69. The cause was pelvic cancer, The Associated Press reported.

title: Stripes, Every Which Way, and Up
description: AS if on cue, stripes have arrived with spring. But unlike the traditional stripes found on patio awnings and beach umbrellas, many of the patterns on this season's home fashions have undulating irregular lines or colors that have been kicked up a notch.

title: Mayor Seeks Strong Hand In Schools, But for What?
description: Nearly every day this week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made louder and more emotionally charged calls for mayoral control of the city's schools. But even as he has sharpened his attacks on the current system -- on Tuesday, he likened the Board of Education to ''a rinky-dink candy store'' -- Mr. Bloomberg has yet to articulate any concrete vision for improving it.

title: The Guru of Goo (And Gels, Mesh and Resin)
description: THE material world can be fragile and fleeting, and few people appreciate this as profoundly as a New York man named George Beylerian. Last week, in his airy offices on West 25th Street, Mr. Beylerian faced a fresh reminder of this transient state of affairs.

title: Thurman's Gamble May Benefit Yanks
description: The Yankees lost twice today, allowing 32 hits in the process. They have won one of their last 14 games, and their 4-12-1 spring training record is the worst in baseball. They must be thankful that the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, has the first-place Nets to distract him.

title: Mocking Due Process
description: I called Shorn Green about 8:15 yesterday morning. He complained that I had awakened him.

title: Judge Who Ruled Out Matching Fingerprints Changes His Mind
description: Two months after issuing the first ruling that fingerprint identification did not meet federal standards for scientific evidence, a judge reversed himself yesterday and said he would let an F.B.I. expert testify that a suspect's prints match those found at a crime scene.

title: Trenton Report Calls Auto Tests A 'Boondoggle'
description: The auto-emissions testing system that infuriated New Jersey drivers was described as a ''mammoth boondoggle'' in a report issued today that portrayed the contract as a study in patronage and incompetence.

title: Details of Victory Are Unclear but It Is Celebrated Nonetheless
description: ''Do you want to see some dead Chechens?'' a soldier named Abdul Nawab shouted as journalists approached the first stop. He was trying to attract a crowd to a grisly sight upon a ridge behind some mud houses that had been largely pulverized by American bombs.

title: Bush Appears Eager Now to Sign a Nuclear Pact With Russia
description: President Bush expressed optimism today that a deal on nuclear arms reduction would be ready for his meeting in May with President Vladimir V. Putin, and clearly moved from reluctance to enthusiasm about signing a formal agreement.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Resignation Offered At Utility
description: The president of the government-owned Korea Electric Power Corporation offered to resign in an effort to persuade the company's striking workers to return to work. The executive, Choi Soo Byung, wanted ''to take responsibility over the ongoing strike,'' a corporation spokesman said. A spokesman for the union said Mr. Choi's resignation might indicate that the corporation would negotiate the union's demand for the government to abandon its plan to privatize the company. Nearly 5,000 of the corporations 5,600 workers, fearful that a private owner will remove many of them from the payroll in an efficiency drive, have been on strike two and a half weeks. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALVET, PAUL E.
description: CALVET-Paul E. The Bolivarian Society of the United States expresses its deep regrets and sorrow at the passing of Paul E. Calvet, Former Director and longtime member of the Society, New York, March 9, 2002.

title: FOREST LABS ENDS DEAL WITH MERCKLE TO DEVELOP DRUG
description: The drug maker Forest Laboratories said yesterday that it had ended an agreement with Merckle G.m.b.H. to develop an osteoarthritis drug known as ML3000. Forest said last month that the drug did not work well enough in a European study to meet American standards. Forest's chief executive, Howard Solomon, said the ''likelihood of successfully completing the three pivotal studies required for U.S. approval does not justify our continued investment.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Comverse Warns Of A Loss
description: The shares of Comverse Technology Inc. fell $2.71, or 17.1 percent, to $13.14 yesterday after the company, the biggest maker of telephone-messaging software, said it expected to report lower sales and a loss for its fiscal first quarter. On Tuesday, Comverse reported a $54 million loss for its fourth quarter, which ended Jan. 31. Sales fell 24 percent, the first sales decline from a year-earlier quarter since at least 1990, according to Bloomberg News data. Expenses rose from the cost of job cuts. Comverse said it expected fiscal first-quarter sales of about $220 million and a loss of 6 cents a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORIN, WILL
description: LORIN-Will. Composer and writer, died at home March 12. Beloved husband of Adriane. Loving father of Katherine (Fred) Myers. Devoted stepfather of George (Kate) Schweitzer and Peter (Guthrie) Schweitzer. Caring grandfather. Dear brother of Sally (Maurice) Fox. Services e private. Contributions in his name may be sent to The Friends of The Beverly Hills Public Library, 444 N. Rexford Drive, Beverly Hills, CA. 90210.

title: The Spirit of Excess Lives On at Valentino
description: Last week, the luxury-goods conglomerate LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton announced losses to its profit margin of a sum roughly equal to the defense budget of a small island republic. In the year 2000, LVMH netted close to $640 million; last year, the figure dwindled to $9 million. This news was disclosed as the fall 2002 shows got underway here, fueled as they were by the conviction that women look good when they are covered in so many pelts and laden with so much plumage that they could be eligible for alternative housing in a zoo.

title: Countdown to a Party: Diary of a Mad Hostess
description: ONE morning last week, my friend Sherri and I went shopping in one of those unfamiliar neighborhoods where low-slung anonymous warehouses have loading docks and blank windows. We were looking for a wholesale restaurant supply store, but all the winding streets looked interchangeable, except for a few discreet signs like ''Allied Fastener Corp.'' and ''Cubbies Unlimited.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHALIK, BENJAMIN A., PHD
description: MICHALIK-Benjamin A., PhD, 84. Of Hillside. Husband of Helen R, father of Geraldine, Cecilia, Andrew and Joseph Michalik. For more information, contact the Growney Funeral Home, Hillside, New Jersey at 908-289-0400.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged In Killing
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested and charged yesterday with second-degree murder in the shooting death on Tuesday of his neighbor Israel Taylor Jr., the police said. The man, Allen Robert, 29, who was injured during an argument with Mr. Taylor, was also charged with criminal possession of a weapon. ''There was some kind of struggle,'' Officer George Jensen said. He said Mr. Robert was shot in the leg during the struggle. A pistol was found under Mr. Taylor's body, but the police are still searching for a second gun. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Orchestra vs. Ensemble, Amplification Included
description: American composers of 50 and under grew up during decades when rock thrived. So a lot of their works, even those that sound not remotely rockish, have driving rhythms and raw sonorities that might just appeal to today's rock fans, if only these young people could be enticed into the concert hall.

title: After the Raid, a Slum's Assessment
description: The tanks came in the middle of the night last Thursday, entering the refugee camp from three directions, rumbling through the streets and silencing gunfire with heavy machine guns.

title: At Airport Gate, a Cyborg Unplugged
description: STEVE MANN, an engineering professor at the University of Toronto, has lived as a cyborg for more than 20 years, wearing a web of wires, computers and electronic sensors that are designed to augment his memory, enhance his vision and keep tabs on his vital signs. Although his wearable computer system sometimes elicited stares, he never encountered any problems going through the security gates at airports.

title: North Koreans Storm Embassy Seeking Refuge
description: A group of 25 North Koreans stormed through the gates of the Spanish Embassy here today, demanding safe passage to South Korea and threatening suicide if moves were made to repatriate them.

title: Rice Wins Title Over All Hallows
description: Shagari Alleyne, a 7-foot-2 junior center, hit all 12 of his shots from the field to lead Rice past All Hallows, 62-57, in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association boys' tournament final at Fordham.

title: 11 Enter the Florida Derby
description: Though second behind Booklet in his last two starts, Harlan's Holiday has been installed as the 5-2 favorite for the $1 million Florida Derby on Saturday at Gulfstream Park. Booklet, the winner of the Holy Bull and the Fountain of Youth Stakes, is next at 4-1.
