title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, JOSEPH H.
description: AARON-Joseph H. On March 12, 2002 at age 92. Husband of the late Claire B. Aaron, father of Judith Aaron Auerbach, and grandfather of Jeffrey Aaron Auerbach and Pamela Jane Auerbach. He is also survived by three cherished greatgrandchildren, Cole, Samuel Aron son, Jonah Morse Aronson, and Dalia Neiman Auerbach. Teacher and friend to many, he enriched the lives of all around him. Services at Jeffer Chapels, 4620 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn at 2:30 PM, March 14, 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAURAIN, BEATRICE MATTER
description: LAURAIN-Beatrice Matter. Died on March 9, 2002 in Mexico. Very much loved by her daughter, Sabina; her son, Jonathan; her granddaughter, Ashley and her many pupils who include Eve Queler. She was a unique individual of the highest integrity and musical standards who made a difference in the lives of those who touched her. She will be missed.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Board Revives School Project
description: The Los Angeles Board of Education has voted to resurrect the costly, half-finished Belmont Learning Center to relieve crowding. The board abandoned the high school complex two years ago after dangerous levels of toxic gas were found at the site. But in a 6-to-1 vote, the board moved on Tuesday to begin negotiations with a coalition of education activists who want to solve the environmental problems and complete the campus. The cost of finishing the school, on which $154 million has been spent, is estimated at $87 million. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: In a Seamless Image, The Great and Small
description: IN the daily business of print journalism, losing sight of the big picture is not just a metaphorical expression. It is a very real experience for thousands of graphic artists and page designers working on computer screens, zooming in to look at the details of an image and zooming out to look at the overview.

title: Et Tu, America? The Politics of Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Class-Action Bill Favorable To Business Passes House
description: A partisan battle over the nation's civil justice system reached the floor of the House of Representatives today as Republicans pushed through a bill explicitly intended to protect corporations against the high cost of class-action lawsuits in state courts.

title: Armstrong waxes youthful in energetic effort to sell floors to a new generation.
description: JUST as kitchens have been transformed over the years from dowdy work spaces into elegant showplaces, Armstrong, the nation's leading maker of hard flooring, is doing a little renovating of its own.

title: Hotel Workers' Union Expels Leader of North Jersey Local
description: The hotel employees' union ousted the president of its North Jersey local yesterday after finding that he had made large, unjustified payments to his predecessor, who had been kicked out for associating with mobsters.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Xbox Hits Europe
description: With a marketing blitz that includes bathing a Spanish soccer arena in alien-green lights, Microsoft today will begin selling its inaugural video game console, the Xbox, in 16 European countries and Australia. With 20 games available to start with, Microsoft is trying to regain momentum lost with its tepid introduction last month in Japan, the home turf of its competitors, Sony and Nintendo. Some Xbox consoles scratched game disks, causing a public relations headache for Microsoft and forcing it to offer to replace faulty machines. At $423 in Britain and $419 in Continental Europe, the Xbox costs almost $100 more than Sony's PlayStation2. Schelley Olhava, a senior analyst with the International Data Corporation, said Microsoft stood a better chance in Europe than in Japan because game players there have similar tastes to players in North America. ''If Japan hasn't done well, as we all believe, Europe is going to be really crucial for them,'' Ms. Olhava said. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: WILLIAMS HEADS GARDEN CARD
description: Ricardo Williams Jr.'s boxing career began at age 8 and has resulted in two United States junior championships, a Goodwill Games title and an Olympic silver medal by age 18.

title: Photo-Binoculars Have a Grasp Equal to Their Reach
description: Any birder who claims to have spotted, say, a passenger pigeon will probably meet strong skepticism. But two new binoculars with built-in digital cameras might help silence doubters.

title: Valparaiso Eats, Sleeps, Dreams Upset
description: Valparaiso does not tiptoe into the N.C.A.A. tournament anymore. Bryce Drew's miraculous shot in 1998 -- since elevated to a highlight-reel staple -- coupled with the Crusaders' shocking trip to the Round of 16 took care of that. Valparaiso carries those credentials around, years later, despite an entirely new set of players.

title: Denver Police Files Raise Rights Concerns
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of Colorado has accused the Denver Police Department of maintaining secret and illegal files on hundreds of groups and people, and the mayor has asked for a review of the department's policies.

title: A Dream Cellphone Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: So Much for End of Nets' Skid
description: The Nets had hoped to leave Boston with a little bit of distance. Instead, they left Boston with the Celtics' footprints on their back and lingering doubt in the wake of yet another fourth-quarter disappearance.

title: France Orders Removal of Couple's Frozen Bodies From Chateau
description: A French court ruled today that the bodies of a couple frozen after their deaths, in the hope that they could be revived one day, had to be removed from a refrigerated crypt in the basement of their family chateau and buried or cremated.

title: Punch-Card Nostalgia
description: To the Editor:

title: Mugabe's Aides Declare Him Winner of Zimbabwe Vote
description: President Robert Mugabe, the aging African leader who was hailed as a hero until he turned to authoritarianism and violence to strengthen his weakening grip on power, was declared the winner today of a presidential election marred by political violence and other irregularities.

title: 'Coach Rizz' Still Wills Her Team to Victory
description: Jennifer Rizzotti, her face flushed and her voice possessed by the familiar passion, implored her team to believe. She nearly made them cry Saturday with her speech before the game in the locker room.

title: Palestine, One of '2 States'
description: Following is the text of Resolution 1397, the United States-sponsored measure approved Tuesday night on the Middle East, as provided by the United Nations Department of Public Information:

title: Dioceses, Facing Great Scrutiny, Look Anew at Sex Abuse Cases
description: Five major Roman Catholic dioceses in the New York metropolitan area, responding to growing attention nationwide to cases of pedophilia involving clergy members, have begun reassessing their approaches to sexual abuse charges.

title: Accidental Investment Banker Shakes Up Credit Suisse Unit
description: Adebayo O. Ogunlesi was not supposed to be an investment banker. He was definitely not supposed to be heading one of Wall Street's biggest investment banks.

title: The Mideast Knot And the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Music for Tranquillity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMBERMAN, JACOB
description: IMBERMAN-Jacob. On March 11, 2002. Devoted husband of Arlyn, adored father of Joseph and Diane, and cherished grandfather of Samuel, David, Daniel and Elizabeth. He is survived by his wife, Arlyn, his two children, Joseph Imberman and Diane Albert, a sister, Ruth Taxel and a brother, Milton Imberman. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made either to: The Center for the Study of the Presidency, 1020 19 St, NW-Suite 250, Washington, D.C., 20036 or The Jacob Imberman Fund, U.J.A./Federation of NY, 130 E. 59 St., NY, NY 10022

title: Defective Palms
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tests We Know We Need
description: A vocal group of parents and public school students in New York protested last week against new and much tougher state examinations by boycotting a statewide reading test. Every indication is that these students, mostly from two alternative middle schools, are being well prepared for college, and no one should question their convictions or those of parents who think they know what's best for their kids. They should be heard. That's the nature of our system.

title: Daschle Sets Stage for Key Vote On Campaign Finance Overhaul
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, set the stage today for a pivotal vote on Friday that will demonstrate whether proponents of limiting money in politics have the strength to push the campaign finance measure to final passage.

title: Uzbekistan's Leader Doubts Chances for Afghan Peace
description: President Islam A. Karimov of Uzbekistan, a pariah-turned-ally in the Bush administration's war on terrorism, wrapped up two days of meetings with top government officials today, praising the American campaign against the Taliban but expressing sharp doubts about the future stability of Afghanistan.

title: Sir Raymond Firth, 100, Expert on Polynesia Life
description: Sir Raymond Firth, an anthropologist who wrote extensively on the cultures of remote Polynesian islands and was noted for his close attention to scientific evidence, died on Feb. 22 in London. He was 100.

title: Some Japanese Are Hoarding Gold
description: While Japan has had the world's fastest-growing major stock market this year and the yen has jumped nearly 3 percent against the dollar in the last month, a small but growing number of Japanese investors are preparing for the worst and hoarding gold.

title: Israel's Unwise Offensive
description: With 20,000 troops in action, Israel is currently engaged in the biggest military offensive in the Palestinian territories since the 1967 war. In less than two weeks it has killed more than 160 Palestinians. Soldiers in full battle dress, riding in tanks and backed by fire from Apache attack helicopters, have ripped their way through large refugee camps. Tanks have torn up roads, missiles have gutted homes and Palestinian Authority offices, and troops have rounded up and questioned all male camp residents between the ages of 15 and 45.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about the physicist John Archibald Wheeler misstated the date of a symposium on his research. It is this coming weekend, not last weekend.

title: 'Do No Harm' Budgeting
description: Yesterday the House Budget Committee began the process of approving a $2.1 trillion federal budget for next year. The surpluses are nearly gone. Gone too are funds needed to shore up Social Security and Medicare in the next decade. Lawmakers are in a tizzy. Some Republicans want more domestic spending cuts to narrow the deficit. Others want to push for still more tax cuts while they have the chance, no matter what that does to the deficit. Democrats are torn between spending more now or saving money for the retirement systems. With control of both the House and Senate up for grabs in November, this is not likely to be a time for much political courage. The best thing we can hope for is a budget that does not make the situation worse.

title: Judge Charged In Sex Cases Is Leaving Race
description: An Orange County Superior Court judge charged with child molestation and possessing child pornography has notified his write-in opponents that he intends to withdraw from the November election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANCIK, EDWARD F.
description: STANCIK-Edward F. The Staff at The Office of The Special Commissioner are deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and colleague. Ed was committed to improving the school system and worked tirelessly toward that effort on behalf of The City's school children and their parents. He will be missed.

title: Court Bars Hindus' Rite Where They Razed Mosque
description: At a moment when religious passions are running high, the Supreme Court ruled today that Hindu fundamentalists would not be allowed to perform a ceremony on Friday in their campaign to build a temple on the site of a mosque they helped tear down nine years ago.

title: Comprehensible Mozart With an Economy of Means
description: When the New York City Opera offers the standard repertory, it is in the form of a service: clear, coherent productions sung by fresh, healthy voices. No epiphanies are promised, and few are delivered. What remains are products like the company's new ''Don Giovanni,'' which opened on Sunday afternoon.

title: 5 Are Expected to Leave Bank After Inquiry on Currency Losses
description: The chairman and four other employees of the Baltimore bank where a currency trader lost $690 million over five years will leave their jobs, a person close to the bank said last night.

title: Ex-Black Militant Gets Life for Murdering Deputy
description: A state jury today rejected the request of prosecutors to execute Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, known in the 1960's as the radical organizer H. Rap Brown, sentencing him instead to life in prison without parole for the murder of a sheriff's deputy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSH, MARTIN JULES
description: LUSH-Martin Jules. Sutton Place Synagogue extends sympathies to Harriet and David Krieger and family on the loss of Harriet's beloved father. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Robbers Strike Four Banks
description: In less than two hours, criminals robbed or tried to rob four banks yesterday morning in Brooklyn and Queens. Last year, roughly one bank in New York City was robbed each business day, according to the F.B.I. So far, the police do not see any links between any of yesterday's robberies. More than $6,000 in all was taken, said Jerry Varson, a Police Department spokesman. At 10 a.m., there was an unsuccessful robbery at a GreenPoint Bank branch in East Flatbush. Forty-five minutes later, a man claiming to be armed took $2,000 from a Ridgewood Savings Bank branch in Ridgewood, Queens. Half an hour later, a man jumped over the counter at a GreenPoint branch on 86th Street in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and made off with an undetermined amount of money. Finally, at 11:35, a man passed a note to a teller at a Bank of New York branch on 186th Street in Jamaica and stole $4,000. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: A Museum Gives Comic-Strip Works a New Cachet
description: Inside and out, the Sheldon Memorial Art Gallery at the University of Nebraska here is a temple of high modernism.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Mortal Countdown

title: Bleached and Stone-Washed, Sure. But Fused?
description: Ever wonder where denim goes when it's not making a fashion statement? Between walls, where it turns out to make surprisingly good insulation. Bonded Logic, seeing pay dirt on the cutting room floor, separates the fibers in jeans makers' trimmings and fuses them to create sheets of soft batting, called UltraTouch, that are six inches thick and as heat-conserving as fiberglass. UltraTouch is easier to install than conventional insulation and, at 50 cents a square foot, about twice as expensive, said Scott Tonkinson, the marketing manager for Bonded Logic. Fans include Bob Vila, the home repair TV host, who plans to put UltraTouch in an energy-efficient house he is building in Palm Springs, Calif., because it is biodegradable and can be installed without blowers. Michael McDonough, a Manhattan architect using denim fill in his Stone Ridge, N.Y., house, said it has ''good thermal and acoustical values, and it's insect- and fire-resistant.''

title: Pursuer of the Paper Trail on Malcolm X Boulevard
description: THE auction on eBay of journals, letters and other papers attributed to Malcolm X has been stopped, and there are indications that the collection could end up at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem.

title: Remote Towns Sell Safety in Shadow of Sept. 11
description: For most of its recent life, this small town in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains has had a hard time luring new business. The textile and furniture factories closed or migrated overseas, and Martinsville was simply too isolated to attract others.

title: Economic Scene; The real value of Enron may be as a worst-case example of the need for clearer accounting rules.
description: THE Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, was roundly criticized in January for saying the collapse of Enron was part of the ''genius of capitalism.'' But he had a point. The people who made the decisions leading to the Enron fiasco have been publicly humiliated, and this has not gone unnoticed by other executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMALYN, ISABELLE LEE
description: HERMALYN-Isabelle Lee. Of Fort Lee, New Jersey, formerly of Teaneck and the Bronx. Devoted wife of Sol. Loving mother of three and adored grandmother of five. A truly grand lady who was everyone's friend, Isabelle had the unique talent to make all who met her feel happy and important. Longtime volunteer in numerous charitable causes, including Women's American ORT, Cancer Care Inc., Starfish, and 15 years in Holy Name Hospital. From singer to homemaker to bank manager, she lived her life to the fullest. She will be greatly missed. Services Thursday, 1:30 P.M., at ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Market Place; Big Investors Maintain Faith In WorldCom Despite Inquiry
description: Few people rely as heavily on the audited financial statements of public companies as do money managers who consider themselves true-blue value investors. So word this week of a federal investigation into the accounting of WorldCom sent a chill through the club of value investors who had bought up big stakes in it.

title: No Tower Can Withstand Attack As Jets Get Bigger, Expert Says
description: As commercial jets grow larger, faster and carry ever-greater amounts of fuel, no skyscraper can be built to withstand a terrorist attack of the kind that destroyed the World Trade Center towers on Sept. 11, the chief structural engineer for the trade center project said last night.

title: McGaughey Hopes Derby Streak Ends
description: As his horse, the one that wasn't supposed to lose, crossed the wire a sluggish second in the 1989 Kentucky Derby, Shug McGaughey could take some small comfort in the thought that he would surely be back for several more attempts. Easy Goer, beaten as the 4-5 favorite that year, was his fifth Derby starter over six years, and his stable seemed destined to be among the sport's dominant operations for years.

title: U.N. Says Millions of Children, Caught in Poverty, Die Needlessly
description: Almost 11 million children, most of them babies, die each year of preventable causes, according to United Nations officials meeting to hammer out a strategy to save more young lives.

title: SOFTWARE MAKER IS PURCHASING MARKETING COMPANY
description: The Internet software maker and consultant divine Inc. said yesterday that it was acquiring a marketing company, the Delano Technology Corporation, for about $31.4 million in stock. Under the agreement, divine will issue 1.187 shares for each share of Delano stock, or a total of about 51.55 million divine shares. The value is based on divine's closing share price of 61 cents. The purchase expands divine's business in the financial services, automotive and entertainment markets. Holders of about 13 percent of Delano's shares have agreed to vote in favor of the transaction, the companies said. Delano is based in the Toronto suburb of Markham and divine is based in Chicago.

title: Compassion for Andrea Yates
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI OFFENSIVE IS 'NOT HELPFUL,' PRESIDENT WARNS
description: President Bush delivered a harsh rebuke to Israel today for its deadly military operations against Palestinians in the West Bank, saying that the actions of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's government were ''not helpful'' and suggesting that they went well beyond self-defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPP, BLANCHE
description: LIPP-Blanche. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Mother of Marian Karron and Harriet Kilstein, Grandmother of Tsvi, Stuart, Daniel, Abraham, Amy & Nathaniel. Great-grandmother and aunt. Graveside service today, 3PM, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Penalty On France Sought
description: Britain urged the European Commission to fine France for its continuing refusal to import British beef products despite the lifting in August 1999 of a European ban imposed in March 1996 because of an outbreak of mad cow disease. France is the only European country not to have accepted the finding that British beef is safe, and in December, the European Court of Justice said its stance was against the law. French agriculture officials said this week that they would not comply, citing concern for French health standards. Any decision is unlikely to come during the pre-election period in France, which is electing a new president in six weeks and a new parliament in three months. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Rangers' Injury List Continues to Grow
description: Less than 24 hours after the Rangers made a trade to help re-establish the Czech line, Radek Dvorak was lost for the season with a knee injury.

title: Rare Woods and Rustic Furnishings Go East to Long Island City
description: Manhattan designers will have to cross the East River if they want to continue buying rustic furnishings from Tucker Robbins. Mr. Robbins, top, has moved his store from the meatpacking district to that new hotbed of design, Long Island City, Queens, where he is near the new Noguchi Museum, P.S. 1 and the temporary relocation quarters of the Museum of Modern Art. Mr. Robbins's wares are from East Asia and Central America. He seeks to preserve indigenous crafts and to find materials like the rosewood for the chair, above (four chairs and a table, $15,000), or the rare Philippine wood used in the tabletop, which costs $33,000. Teardrop-shape rattan and rice-paper hanging lamps (based on the design of a fish trap) are $475. Tucker Robbins store and studio: 33-02 Skillman Avenue; (718) 764-0222. TIMOTHY JACK WARD

title: World Briefing | Europe: Latvia: Radio Station Shut Down
description: The most popular radio station in the capital, Riga, went off the air after regulators said it had violated music copyright laws. But owners of the Bizness and Baltija station, whose pop-music programming is favored among Latvia's Russian minority, said they were victims of anti-Russian bias in the government and that their offer to settle copyright disputes had been ignored. The station has had frequent run-ins with regulators over a rule requiring that 75 percent of all radio programming be in the Latvian language. A third of the country's 2.4 million people speak Russian but the government has sought to promote Latvian culture to reduce the impact of decades of Soviet occupation. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Ex-Leaders Banned From Elections
description: President Pervez Musharraf, left, said two former prime ministers, Benazir Bhutto, and Nawaz Sharif, would not be allowed to run in the parliamentary and provincial elections scheduled for October. Ms. Bhutto, who was forced out of office in 1996 and later convicted of corruption, and Mr. Sharif, who was ousted by General Musharraf in 1999 coup, live in exile. Both still have wide followings in the country. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: U.S. Role in Resolution On Mideast Startles Some
description: The passage of a resolution late Tuesday night demanding an immediate cease-fire in the escalating bloodshed between Israel and the Palestinians was praised today as the most significant response by the Security Council since the conflict erupted more than 17 months ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Italian Photographer Is Killed Covering Israeli Incursion
description: An Italian news photographer was shot and killed today, apparently by Israeli troops, while covering the Israeli Army's incursion into the West Bank town of Ramallah.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Saint Laurent's Bows, Chanel's Elegance
description: Ever since Tom Ford took over the designing of Yves Saint Laurent ready-to-wear, he has had to deal with snarky journalists who think he's not faithful enough to the style he inherited or not talented enough to create an image for Saint Laurent that's distinct from Gucci, the brand he forged out of bankrupt playboy shoe leather. And probably it seems to Mr. Ford that he can't get a break.

title: Wide-Screen or Boxy, TV Is a Numbers Game
description: Q. What does it mean when a television has a 16:9 ratio?

title: Hard-Liners Put Iranian Journalist on Trial on Spying Charges
description: A 73-year-old former journalist has gone on trial behind closed doors, charged with espionage and threatening national security in what is considered part of a new current of repression against intellectuals in Iran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, ELISABETH SLOAN PRATT
description: LIVINGSTON - Elisabeth Sloan Pratt. The Board of Directors and staff of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc. mourn the loss of Elisabeth Sloan Pratt Livingston, a longtime friend and generous benefactor, as was her mother, Katherine Sloan Pratt. John H. Livingston, who predeceased his wife, was a cousin of one of the founders of Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

title: A Ruling in Auction Houses' Case Is Reversed
description: A federal appeals court reversed a trial judge's decision yesterday and ordered additional consideration of a class-action lawsuit on behalf of auction house customers who contend that Sotheby's and Christie's colluded to fix fees charged to buyers and sellers in foreign transactions.

title: Wieden & Kennedy Hired by Pizza Hut
description: Pizza Hut, part of Tricon Global Restaurants, said yesterday that it had selected Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., as a second agency, handling projects. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Independent Publisher Is Diversifying
description: The Perseus Books Group, founded as a white knight to buy underappreciated small publishers of relatively erudite nonfiction, has agreed to acquire a very different publisher in a bid to increase its size. It is acquiring Running Press, a publisher best known for novelties and impulse buys sold at stores specializing in toys, greeting cards and gardening supplies.

title: Auction Losers, Backstage
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Discharges of Gays Rise, and So Do Bias Incidents
description: The number of military discharges of gays has risen to its highest level in 14 years, and reported incidents of anti-gay harassment have climbed by 23 percent in a year, a legal aid group said today.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Budget Package Advances
description: Negotiators from the State House and Senate reached an agreement on a budget package to deal with the state's $1.6 billion deficit. The budget, which the Senate plans to vote on today, includes $600 million in cuts to state programs and $450 million in spending from the tobacco settlement. The two chambers will also try to pass transportation legislation before adjourning tonight. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: G.O.P. Blueprint for Budget Is Approved by House Panel
description: The House Budget Committee tonight adopted a Republican tax and spending plan for next year that would give President Bush the money he wants to combat terrorism but hold down the deficit by cutting or tightly limiting financing for many other programs.

title: YES Disputes Claims in Cablevision Ad
description: The chief executive of the YES Network yesterday labeled as fraudulent a new television commercial describing the 32 Yankee games that Cablevision customers will be able to watch in the absence of the 130 to be televised by YES.

title: Modules Turn Visor Hand-Helds Into All-Purpose Containers
description: While they have a common operating system, Palm-based organizers take different approaches to expandability. Palm uses memory cards, Sony uses its own Memory Stick, and Handspring uses the Springboard module. A new line of Springboard modules from Portable Innovation Technology (www.pitech.com) will allow Handspring Visor users to take advantage of all the possibilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITELEY, STARK CANNING
description: WHITELEY-Stark Canning. Suddenly on March 11, 2002 at age 55. A graduate of The Hill School, Columbia and Johns Hopkins Universities, Stark was a lifelong historian and teacher. He lived in New York City and Friendship Long Island, ME, & was a member of The University Club in NYC. He is the son of the late Charlotte Newberry Whiteley and George Whiteley Jr. He is survived by his sister Diane Woodward (John H.) of South Kent, CT, and brothers George Whiteley III (Bunny) of NYC and Will Whiteley of Halifax, MA. In addition, he is survived by nine nieces and nephews and 10 grand-nieces and nephews. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held Saturday, March 16, at 3 P.M. at The Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory can be made to The Hill School, Stark Whiteley Library Fund, Pottstown, PA. 19464.

description: Swedish Design

title: Piracy, or Innovation? It's Hollywood vs. High Tech
description: Leaders of two of the nation's most prominent industries, entertainment and technology, have begun publicly sniping at each other over how to stop consumers from illegally copying digital movies, music and television programs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BATTAGLIA, AUGUST J.
description: BATTAGLIA-August J. Died March 14, 1973. Remembered always. A devoted husband, a loving and beloved father, a provident grandfather for whom we are eternally grateful.

title: Egypt Vows to Press Iraq on U.N. Arms Inspections, Cheney Is Told
description: Seeking to avert an American military attack on Iraq, President Hosni Mubarak said today that he would press Iraq's president to readmit United Nations weapons inspectors and had received indications that Baghdad would agree.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHN, FLORENCE B.
description: KOHN-Florence B. Born January 18, 1904. Died March 12, 2002. Lived in Brooklyn, NY & Sarasota, FL. Volunteer with the Brooklyn Red Cross at The Veterans Administration in NYC for over 33 years. Survived by sons Lawrence and Ronald of Florida and eight grandchildren. Services were held in Florida on March 13th.

title: ANDERSEN IS SAID TO RULE OUT PLEA
description: Negotiations about a possible sale of Arthur Andersen all but collapsed yesterday, even as senior executives of the firm decided that it would not plead guilty to charges of obstruction of justice in the Enron case, people close to the firm said.

title: Arrest in Colombia in 1999 Bronx Killing
description: A man was arrested in Bogot, Colombia, yesterday and charged with second-degree murder in the 1999 fatal shooting of a retired New York City detective during a robbery in the Bronx, the police said.

title: A World in Transition
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, AUGUST
description: GOLD-August. On March 12, 2002 at age 91. Educator, mentor and inspiration to an extended global family. Teacher in NYC high schools and facilities planner at the NYC Board of Education for five decades. Community activist, preservationist, environmentalist, he devoted his later life to the development of affordable housing in Westchester County. Survived by Lillian, his wife of 67 years, his children Carol and Paul, and grandson Erik. Donations may be made to Interfaith Council for Action, Inc., P.O. Box 775, Ossining, New York 10562.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, the Staten Island Journal article on Sunday, about historic houses threatened by development, omitted the given names and affiliations of three residents who supported the creation of historic districts. They are Simeon Bankoff, executive director of the nonprofit Historic Districts Council, and David Goldfarb and David Jones, board members of the Preservation League of America.

title: Priest, Once Physicist, Wins $1 Million Religion Prize
description: A particle physicist who resigned his professorship at Cambridge University 23 years ago to become an Anglican priest was named the winner of the $1 million Templeton Prize, the annual award given by the John Templeton Foundation to advance spiritual matters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CODY, JOE
description: CODY-Joe. A most memorable and popular teacher, coach and ''Searchers'' leader at Horace Mann School from 1968 to 1982. His love of life, history, rugby shirts, and ski trips will never be forgotten. Heartfelt condolences to Molly and their three children. Jodi ('78) and Herb ('77) Nass Andrew Wallach ('76)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Completes Bond Sale
description: Lucent Technologies said yesterday that it had completed a private sale of $1.75 billion of 15-year bonds convertible into Lucent stock at $6.10 a share, a 24 percent premium over Wednesday's closing price. The bonds carried a 7.75 percent dividend. Demand was strong enough for Lucent to increase the offering from its previously announced goal of $1.5 billion, and the sale further eased fears that the company would face a liquidity crunch this year. But growth prospects in the telecommunications sector remain bleak and Lucent's shares fell for a third consecutive day, slipping 9 cents, to close at $4.83, a new 52-week low. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the aging of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline misstated the percentage of oil moved through the pipeline that has spilled and misstated the amount of the largest spill. Spills represent about 0.00021 percent of oil delivered, not 0.0000025 percent. The largest spill was about 700,000 gallons, not barrels.

title: More Infections Seen After Tissue Implants
description: Four months after a young Minnesota man died from routine knee surgery, federal officials said they had turned up 25 more cases of serious bacterial infections in people who received similar operations in recent years.

title: Players Offer Their View Of a Contract They'd Like
description: Commissioner Bud Selig wants to address what he sees as baseball's competitive-balance problem with money. Increase by a hefty amount the percentage of local revenue the major league clubs share, and impose a hefty tax on the teams with the highest payrolls.

title: SCHWAB SAYS QUARTERLY PROFIT MAY NOT MEET FORECASTS
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter profit might fall short of forecasts because trading slumped last month. Schwab's clients made an average of 140,800 trades a day in February, down 10 percent from January and the biggest decline since October. Even with daily client trades up 19 percent during the first eight trading days of March, Schwab will probably not meet analysts' estimates of 10 cents a share in the first quarter, the chief financial officer, Christopher V. Dodds, said. The company's fourth-quarter profit excluding a gain on the sale of a business, merger-related costs and other expenses was 8 cents a share.

title: Final Four Is Goal For UConn This Year
description: Neither Connecticut nor St. John's made the N.C.A.A. tournament last year, although the Huskies at least got a taste of the postseason in the National Invitation Tournament. Now both are back, mates in the East regional, with decidedly different missions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLA, RABBI IMRE
description: BALLA-Rabbi Imre. We mourn with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in Budapest in 1973, he served pulpits in Hungary, Vancouver, and Sudbury, Ont. At the time of his death, he was the rabbi of B'nai Israel in St. Catherines, Ont. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Iris Cohen and sons, Peter and Adam. Rabbi Reuven Hammer, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: City's Deficit Forces Police To Study Cuts in Overtime
description: The city's fiscal crisis is forcing the Police Department to reduce overtime spending in programs that the Giuliani administration once described as essential to reducing crime. But Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that even with the cuts, the force would be able to police the city effectively.

title: Zimbabwe Moderate Offers Assurances to Opposition
description: Jubilant throngs danced through the streets, clapping, whistling and singing their throats sore. They cheered for President Robert Mugabe, who was declared the winner of the presidential election this week, and praised his promises for a better life.

title: Delta to Deny Travel Agents Most Ticket Commissions
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it would stop paying commissions routinely to all domestic travel agents who sell its tickets, a move that agents and analysts said would result in higher prices for many passengers.

title: Impressionist And Modern
description: Sotheby's has scored another impressive collection for its important evening sale of Impressionist and modern art on May 8, and this time the York Avenue auction house didn't have to offer the seller any financial incentives to close the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARELLA, ANTOINETTE D. (TONI).
description: FARELLA-Antoinette D. (Toni). Loving sister of Dorothy Grillo, Marie Battaglia, Josephine, Paul and Sam Farella. Also survived by 14 nieces and nephews, and 11 great-nieces and nephews. Antoinette was a marketing consultant to Agrexco and former employee of American Airlines. Reposing at the James Romanelli-Stephen Funeral Home, 133-20 Crossbay Blvd, Ozone Park, until Saturday 9:45 AM. Mass of the resurrection at our Lady of Grace RC Church 10:30 AM. Entombment St. Johns Cemetery. Chapel hours 2-5 and 79 P.M. In lieu of flowers make donations to St. Judes Research Hospital, New York Chapter.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Signs Of Oil Restraint
description: The Russian government gave signs yesterday that it plans to extend limits on its oil exports. The deputy prime minister, Viktor Khristenko, who oversees oil exports, was quoted in the business newspaper Vedomosti as saying that the government was setting export allotments for the second quarter ''based on the reductions of the first quarter'' that were adopted at OPEC's behest, though the decision may be altered after the prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, meets next week with oil executives. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Hide of Cloth, Heart of Gold

description: It was reassuring to find myself almost arrested as I arrived in this magical country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEVERNS, THEODATE JOHNSON
description: SEVERNS - Theodate Johnson. Died March 13, 2002 of natural causes. She is survived by her husband Dr. Scott Severns of New York City and her sister Jeanette Dempsey of Cleveland, Ohio and her brother Philip Johnson an architect in New York City. She was a former owner and publisher of Musical America. She was active in the Musicians Club of New York City. She had given solo concerts in New York and London. Services are private.

title: On Both Sides in the Mideast, Fear and Stress Are Building
description: Dr. Beny Sapir, a veterinarian, kept seeing certain symptoms in dogs and cats who lived on Jerusalem's margins, where the days and nights are pierced by gunfire, explosions and sirens. They would shake or stop eating. Some stopped going outside, even hid under the furniture.

title: Appropriating the Holocaust
description: After months of defending itself against heated protests that an exhibition it was preparing would offend Holocaust survivors, New York's Jewish Museum will finally open ''Mirroring Evil: Nazi Imagery/ Recent Art'' to the public this Sunday.

title: FLORIDA UTILITY AGREES TO FOUR-YEAR PLAN TO CUT RATES
description: Florida Power and Light, the state's biggest electric utility, agreed yesterday to reduce rates by $250 million a year through 2005 after reaching an accord with state officials and large energy customers. The utility, owned by FPL Group, will cut its base rate by 7 percent and decrease fuel charges by an additional $200 million this year, FPL said. The four-year agreement is patterned after a revenue-sharing agreement that has saved customers about $1.3 billion since 1999, FPL said. The new agreement needs the approval of Florida's Public Service Commission, which began in May the first full review of FPL's rates in 16 years.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Outlook Brightens
description: The government raised its assessment of the economy for the first time in almost two years, encouraged that a recovery in markets overseas would increase demand for Japanese exports. In its monthly report, the Cabinet Office acknowledged that the condition of the economy remained ''severe,'' but it said that ''some signs of bottoming out can be seen.'' Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Leonid Ozernoy, 62, Dissident And Soviet-Era Astrophysicist
description: Leonid M. Ozernoy, a prominent Soviet-born astrophysicist whose campaign to emigrate to the United States in the 1980's drew international attention, died on Feb. 28 in a hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 62 and lived in University Park, Md.

description: LORIN-Will. Composer and writer, died at home March 12. Beloved husband of Adriane. Loving father of Katherine (Fred) Myers. Devoted stepfather of George (Kate) Schweitzer and Peter (Guthrie) Schweitzer. Caring grandfather. Dear brother of Sally (Maurice) Fox. Services e private. Contributions in his name may be sent to The Friends of The Beverly Hills Public Library, 444 N. Rexford Drive, Beverly Hills, CA. 90210.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSER, REMEDIOS GARCIA
description: MESSER-Remedios Garcia. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Isamu Noguchi Foundation extend their deepest sympathy to our Trustee, Thomas M. Messer, over the loss of his wife, Remedios Garcia Messer, who passed away on March 10th, 2002. Isaac Shapiro, President Shoji Sadao, Executive Director

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Senate Supports Abandonment Law
description: The State Senate passed and sent to Gov. Gary Locke a bill that would make it legal to leave a newborn baby at a hospital or firehouse. The bill failed last year in the House, where conservative legislators kept it from the floor, but this year it passed both chambers by large margins. It was sponsored by Senator Jeanne E. Kohl-Welles, a Democrat, after a baby was found abandoned in her Seattle district. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Kansas Avoids No. 1 Flop By Defeating Holy Cross
description: To the list of valiant No. 16-seeded teams trying to bounce a top-seeded team in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, add Holy Cross.

title: Jews at Peace in Egypt, a Tale Told on Papyrus
description: Led by Moses, the Jews fled en masse from Egypt around 1250 B.C., after centuries of bondage. So says the Bible's book of Exodus. But later books -- II Kings and Jeremiah -- report that 800 years later, during the fifth century B.C., Jews were once again living and worshiping there.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Budget Conflict Intensifies
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber set the stage for a third special session of the Legislature to deal with a budget crisis. The governor, a Democrat, vetoed parts of a budget-balancing plan passed by the Republican-controlled Legislature in a second special session, and he cut $81 million from programs to make up the difference. Republicans wanted to use $67 million from the tobacco settlement to help cut a $846 million budget gap, but the governor vetoed the move. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: European Meeting Will Focus on Freer Rein for Economy
description: As leaders of the 15 European Union nations gather here for a two-day summit meeting that begins on Friday, the main question before them is how to go about translating high-flown goals of economic liberalization into reality on the ground.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITELEY, STARK CANNING
description: WHITELEY-Stark Canning. Suddenly on March 11, 2002 at age 55. A graduate of The Hill School, Columbia and Johns Hopkins Universities, Stark was a lifelong historian and teacher. He lived in New York City and Friendship Long Island, ME, & was a member of The University Club in NYC. He is the son of the late Charlotte Newberry Whiteley and George Whiteley Jr. He is survived by his sister Diane Woodward (John H.) of South Kent, CT, and brothers George Whiteley III (Bunny) of NYC and Will Whiteley of Halifax, MA. In addition, he is survived by nine nieces and nephews and 10 grand-nieces and nephews. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held Saturday, March 16, at 3 P.M. at The Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory can be made to The Hill School, Stark Whiteley Library Fund, Pottstown, PA. 19464.

title: U.S. SAYS POWELL DEMANDED PULLOUT BY ISRAELI FORCES
description: As the Bush administration's special envoy arrived, senior officials in Washington said on Thursday that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell had delivered a blunt private demand to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to withdraw from Palestinian-controlled areas to help American efforts to broker a cease-fire.

title: British Transplant Follows His Muse to 'Oklahoma!'
description: IT'S a dangerous choice of icebreaker, this revelation to Warren Carlyle, the peppy associate choreographer of Broadway's most torrid ticket, ''The Producers,'' and its newest blockbuster, ''Oklahoma!'' His interviewer's dusty link to the show he's fine-tuning for a March 21 opening goes back to a starring role in high school. Revelation No. 2: unlike him, she had and has no discernible dance chops.

description: The dinosaurs are still there, wondering what became of their world. So are the wonderfully realistic dioramas of American Indians, patrolling forests they could have sworn belonged to them.

title: What's Behind the New Arab Momentum
description: As expected, Vice President Dick Cheney's mission to the Middle East has been drawn into the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The Bush administration appears to have seen this coming and has reacted with speed and skill. President Bush rebuked Israel on Wednesday for its invasion of Palestinian territory. The administration also authored a Security Council resolution, which passed, calling for a cease-fire and ''affirming a vision of a region where two states, Israel and Palestine, live side by side.'' The State Department called for a ''complete withdrawal'' of Israeli forces from Palestinian areas, and the president's envoy, Gen. Anthony Zinni, arrived last night to help broker a cease-fire.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Blood Victims Seek More Compensation
description: Hemophiliacs infected with the virus that causes AIDS by blood products provided by state-run health services in the 1980's have begun a legal case to overturn a 1991 compensation package and get more reparations. The government said three years ago that the package, worth about $15 million, was inadequate and promised new legislation. More than 100 people were infected through the contaminated products and 64 have died from AIDS-related illnesses. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: U.S. Is Studying DNA of Dead Combatants
description: Forensic experts have begun testing the DNA of human tissue found in the battlefield around Shah-i-Kot Valley to determine whether any senior leaders of Al Qaeda or the Taliban were killed in the 13 days of fighting there, the commander overseeing the operation said today.

description: An artist and aspiring model was shot to death early yesterday by at least two men who approached him in the hallway of his Brooklyn town house in what the police said appeared to have been an attempted robbery.

title: Tapestry in All Its Splendor
description: In ''Tapestry in the Renaissance: Art and Magnificence,'' the Metropolitan Museum shows off one of the great art forms as it was produced in the 15th and 16th centuries. Among its 41 works is a tapestry (detail at right) from the 12-piece ''Hunts of Maximilian,'' designed by the painter Bernaert van Orley.

title: They May Be High-Tech, But They're Still the Undead
description: One way of describing the clanging, gory technohorror film ''Resident Evil'' might be to call it ''Microsoft Meets the Night of the Living Dead.'' The villainous Umbrella Corporation, which secretly develops a lab-engineered virus that reanimates the body after death, suggests an unholy combination of Microsoft (it dominates the computer market), the Pentagon (of your worst nightmares) and the world's greediest biotech company. Like so many contemporary thrillers, the movie is paradoxically infatuated with technology and paranoid about its deployment.

title: New Welfare Director Defends Stance on Food Stamp Waiver
description: Verna Eggleston, the new commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, told City Council members yesterday that she was strengthening the agency's oversight of private welfare-to-work contracts and its support services for those who have moved into jobs.

title: The Horrors of the Balkan Wars as Shrewdly Staged Illusions
description: One of the many unsettling contentions of George Bogdanich's documentary film, ''Yugoslavia, the Avoidable War,'' is its assertion that many of the most horrendous events in the recent Balkan wars were stage-managed for the news media. A number of the massacres and atrocities reported on television with bodies on display, it maintains, were shrewdly planned illusions concocted by the Bosnian Muslims to inflame international opinion against the Serbs. The city of Sarajevo in particular served more than once as an accessible location for deceptive television coverage.

title: State May Aid Public TV Stations In Shift to Digital Transmission
description: Still reeling from the World Trade Center attack and a drop in charitable giving, New York's nine public television stations have won support from legislators in Albany for aid in converting to digital signals, a plan that could cost taxpayers more than $50 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Dot-Coms To Pay Back Wages
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, left, announced that two Internet companies had agreed to pay $250,000 in back wages to 52 employees. The companies, TSI Broadband and Aptegra Services, had asked the employees to forgo their salaries for a month while the companies looked for investors to keep them afloat. The companies, which went out of business in January 2001, laid off their employees without paying the promised wages. The companies, at 229 West 36th Street, had sold computer hardware and broadband networks. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Long Resistant, Police Start Embracing Immigration Duties
description: For years, most local police departments have resisted the idea of using their officers to track down illegal immigrants, reasoning that crime-fighting is better served by building relationships of trust in immigrant communities.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Search For Head Of College Narrows
description: The City University of New York has narrowed its search for Queens College president to Eugene P. Buccini, the vice president for academic affairs at Western Connecticut State University, and James L. Muyskens, chief executive and dean of faculty at the University of Georgia's Gwinnett University Center. Each will visit the campus for an interview in April. Dr. Buccini has a Ph.D. in public administration from New York University, and Dr. Muyskens has a Ph.D. in philosophy from the University of Michigan and is a former associate provost and acting provost at Hunter College. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Fox Puts Gloves On Faded Fame And Achieves Ratings Glory
description: Relying on boxing matches between fading celebrities and names from tabloid headlines like Paula Jones and Tonya Harding, the Fox network scored some of its highest ratings of the year Wednesday night with a special called ''Celebrity Boxing.''

description: There's just no other way to put it. And considering this institution's penchant for imperious size and material razzle-dazzle, that's saying something.

description: Lawyers for Enron failed to recognize serious conflicts of interests and did not act on information that clearly should have raised concerns about the company's accounting, members of Congress investigating the company's collapse said today.
