title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Triples
description: Japan's current account surplus more than tripled in January from the month a year earlier as imports sagged and fewer Japanese traveled overseas. The surplus in Japan's current account, the broadest measure of goods and services coming in and out of the country, rose to 709 billion yen ($5.5 billion), 224 percent more than in January 2001. Imports fell 11 percent, while exports dipped 2.9 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Tom Winship's Boston Newspaper
description: Thomas Winship, who died yesterday at 81, never quite looked his part in life. A son of Harvard whose seersuckers and straw boaters evoked an era of tony conservatism, Mr. Winship succeeded his father as editor of The Boston Globe in 1965. Now owned by The New York Times Company, The Globe of 37 years ago was a cautious, provincial newspaper, stiffly written, its front page corrupted by ads. Mr. Winship, as it turned out, was not a keeper of the status quo. Once in charge, he swept the advertising inside the paper, hired rule-breaking young journalists and proceeded to create one of the liveliest metropolitan dailies in the country.

title: LINK TO MALAYSIA DENIED
description: The F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said Malaysia was not a ''launching pad'' for the Sept. 11 attacks, an assertion that had been attributed to anonymous bureau officials in the past. Mr. Mueller made his comments in Malaysia during an Asia-Pacific tour that will take him to Singapore, the Philippines and Indonesia, all countries where Al Qaeda cells have been operating. Malaysian authorities are holding 49 suspected Islamic militants without trial after arrests dating to before Sept. 11, saying they belong to a regional network seeking a conservative Muslim state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTH, IRENE
description: WORTH-Irene, March 10th, 2002. Beloved sister of Carol Johnson of Santa Monica, CA and Luke Evans of Los Angeles, CA. Loving aunt of Grant Johnson, Craig Johnson, Chris Johnson and Holly Johnson. She was an internationally known actress of both stage and screen for over fifty years. She will be deeply missed by both her family and many friends throughout the world. Funeral services will be private. Memorial services are being planned for both New York and London to be announced at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Stella Adler Studio of Acting, 31 West 27th Street, New York, New York 10001.

title: People
description: * Holland Henton was named senior vice president and executive creative director at Foote, Cone & Belding Southern California, Irvine, Calif., part of the Foote, Cone & Belding unit of the FCB Group. He succeeds Scott Montgomery, who left in June. Mr. Henton had been senior vice president and group creative director at the New York office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group. FCB and the World Group are divisions of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Profits Fall 13% at Oracle, And It Blames the Economy
description: Asserting that the technology sector is not yet seeing signs of recovery, the Oracle Corporation reported today that its sales were continuing to slide, though the company did meet its own lowered projections for its quarter.

title: KRAFT FOODS TO CUT 7,500 JOBS AS IT INTEGRATES NABISCO
description: Kraft Foods said yesterday that it would eliminate 7,500 jobs, or 6.4 percent of its work force, as it integrated Nabisco Holdings. The company is spending $373 million to close or reconfigure plants, including some Nabisco plants in Guatemala City and San Jose, Costa Rica, announced in November. Most of the closings will be completed by the end of the year, Kraft said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The job cuts include more than 1,000 positions that were eliminated last year as part of Kraft's effort to save $100 million by reducing overlap between itself and Nabisco. Philip Morris, Kraft's parent company, bought Nabisco in December 2000.

title: WASHINGTON MUTUAL PLANS EXPANSION IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Washington Mutual, the savings and loan company, said yesterday that it would add as many as 40 branches in New York and New Jersey during the next year. The company entered the New York area this year with its $4.86 billion purchase of Dime Bancorp, formerly New York's largest savings and loan. Washington Mutual, based in Seattle, gained 125 Dime branches in New York and New Jersey and said it planned to build 50 more in the next two years. The company said it would open 11 branches in Manhattan that will resemble retail stores rather than traditional banks.

title: In Many Investigations, the Church Is Often the Sole Authority
description: New York State does not list clergy members among the catalog of people who are required by law to report the suspected sexual abuse of minors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, MINNA
description: MANDEL-Minna. Passed away at the age of 102. Beloved mother of Marilyn Cohen. Loving grandmother of Francine Davidson, Michael Cohen, Thomas Davidson and Elizabette Cohen. Great grandmother of Jake, Jamie, Kief & Matthew. Services at BoulevardRiverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Ave (at Ave L) Brooklyn, Sunday, March 17th at 12:15 PM.

title: Retire? No, Reinvent
description: To the Editor:

title: Elaine Crispen Sawyer, 62, Aide And Confidante to Nancy Reagan
description: Elaine Crispen Sawyer, a trusted aide to the former first lady Nancy Reagan who parried with the news media over things like Mrs. Reagan's borrowed gowns and her consultations with an astrologer, died Tuesday.

title: Thomas Winship, Ex-Editor of Boston Globe, Dies at 81
description: Thomas Winship, who as editor of The Boston Globe for two decades propelled the newspaper to regional leadership and national stature, in part through tireless coverage of the court-ordered school busing that split the city in the 1970's, died yesterday in Boston. He was 81 and lived in Lincoln, Mass.

title: Mayor Vows Action to Stem Rise in Rapes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he wanted Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly to make stemming a recent surge in the number of rapes his ''No. 1 priority.''

title: More of Strindberg's Peace Amid Misery
description: The Jean Cocteau Repertory company certainly has its mettle tested this year. Its production of Strindberg's ''Dance of Death'' recently entered its 2001-2 roster less than six weeks after the closing of a Broadway adaptation with the vastly admired British stars Ian McKellen and Helen Mirren in the leading roles. It's good to see that the Cocteau, using a translation that Strindberg signed off on, was not intimidated by the uptown competition. We can never see too many versions; each reveals something new about how much of 20th-century theater was created in those two hours, first onstage a century ago.

title: OBITUARY : Jessie Wood, 73, Paris hostess
description: Jessie Wood, 73, a Paris hostess whose Left Bank apartment was a magnet for writers, intellectuals, draft-dodgers and cabinet ministers in the 1960s and 70s, died March 11 in Water Mill, New York. She was born in France and fled to America at the onset of World War II. She was the daughter of the American financier Henry Leigh-Hunt and Louise de Vilmorin, the French writer. (IHT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAVITZ, LAWRENCE
description: KRAVITZ-Lawrence. On March 12, 2002. A rare and honorable man who has been lost to us too soon. Loving and beloved husband of Daria Zetlen Kravitz. Cherished father of Julia Wihl Kravitz. Son of Mary Kravitz & brother of Marian Kravitz. Services Fri., 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Interment to follow at Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Reviewing Harvard's Business Review
description: Perhaps it was not intentional, but the outgoing editor of the Harvard Business Review has suddenly made her publication a must-read -- particularly this year's February issue and a 1999 case study about a philandering boss. February features an interview with Jack Welch, former chairman of General Electric, and now ranks as one of the venerable publication's all-time keepers. Mr. Welch's forceful words of advice can now be understood on several new levels, some of which seem like either sly or subconscious references to the drama he helped create at the publication.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Friends and Family Ask Jury to Spare Texas Mother's Life
description: With jurors now hearing testimony on whether Andrea Pia Yates should be put to death, defense lawyers today called a range of witnesses on her behalf, including her mother, Jutta Karin Kennedy, who pleaded that her child be spared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENNON, MIRIAM (NEE WAGNER)
description: LENNON-Miriam (nee Wagner). Devoted wife of the late Nathan. Beloved mother of Lynn Hahn and Jules Lennon. Fond mother in law of Carol and the late Jerry. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Dear sister of Hannah Ickler, the late Milton and Harold. Services Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, 11:30 AM Friday.

title: Watson Will Enforce Rule On Body Armor
description: Bob Watson, baseball's new vice president for field operations, has told teams that he will be emphasizing a rule that limits the type of body armor that can be worn at bat.

title: China Files Complaint to W.T.O. on Steel Tariffs
description: China, the world's largest steel maker, filed a complaint today to the World Trade Organization against the United States' decision to impose tariffs of as much as 30 percent on steel imports to protect its producers.

title: Making Fun Of Cop Movies
description: The funniest parts of ''Showtime,'' a new (though only in the loosest sense) buddy action comedy starring Robert De Niro and Eddie Murphy, come before the credits and in the short blooper reel at the end. That leaves an hour and a half for breaking glass, exploding cars and elaborate broad-daylight car chases. Moments of humor -- and some amusing byplay from Mr. Murphy, Mr. De Niro and a good-humored (and one hopes well-compensated) supporting cast, including Rene Russo, William Shatner and Mos Def -- are buried in glass, bullets and the discarded pages of three or four dozen other buddy action comedies, a few of them starring Robert De Niro and Eddie Murphy.

title: Miscellany
description: * Creative Artists Agency, Beverly Hills, Calif., will be a strategic consultant for the Indy Racing League, Indianapolis, helping the organization with entertainment marketing and other programs meant to increase attendance at and television viewership for its auto racing events.

title: Compromised and Sad, But Good All the Same
description: Pauline (Dora van der Groen) is a mentally retarded woman who lives with her sister Martha (Julienne De Bruyn) in a small town in Belgium. Though Pauline is probably in her early 70's, her disposition is childlike: she is unable to tie her shoes or spread jam on her morning toast; she loves to water her sister's garden and to paste images of flowers in her scrapbook.

title: Cohen Is Appointed Times Foreign Editor
description: The appointment of Roger Cohen as foreign editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Howell Raines, the executive editor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERT, HEDY
description: HALPERT-Hedy. May the memory of this wonderful and unique friend endure eternally. Thank you, Hedy, for your precious friendship. To Joel and Mom, we send you our love and sincerest condolences. Valerie Salembier and Paul J. Block

title: 2 More Big Retirement Funds Oppose Hewlett-Compaq Deal
description: Pension funds for California teachers and Ohio public workers said today that they planned to vote against the Hewlett-Packard Company's proposal to buy Compaq Computer, saying it threatens profitability.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday in the special Retirement section, about life in a Florida building for the elderly, referred incorrectly to murder trials conducted by a judge who later became a resident of the building and died there. Nine defendants were tried in the 1969 killing of the United Mine Workers leader Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter. The Yablonski family were not the defendants.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Senator Cancels Fund-Raiser
description: Senator Wayne Allard, a Republican running for re-election, canceled a $250-a-person Denver fund-raiser this weekend after it was discovered that a staff member had sent invitations to 180 Housing and Urban Development employees. It is against the law to knowingly solicit political contributions from federal employees. The cocktail party was to include Housing Secretary Mel Martinez. Mr. Allard, above, serves on a Senate committee that oversees the department's budget. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about life challenges faced by highly precocious children referred incorrectly to degrees earned by Michael Kearney, who graduated from college at age 10. Now 18, Mr. Kearney has completed work on his second master's degree, in computer science, at Vanderbilt University; he is not still working on it.

title: White Is Slowed Down By an Injury Once Again
description: When the great ones retire, Rondell White knows, they can decorate their homes with trophies and bats and jerseys from their playing days. If White's career follows its pattern, he will save a more appropriate item.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 6 about Theresa Castro, who with her husband established the company that makes Castro Convertible sofas, omitted some survivors. Mrs. Castro had six grandchildren, not four, and seven great-grandchildren, not five.

title: North Carolina, When It Sizzles
description: ''It's the place where most people are going to find this movie,'' David Gordon Green said this week. On Tuesday his first feature film, the critically acclaimed and much ballyhooed ''George Washington,'' was released on videocassette but, more important, in a DVD special edition from the Criterion Collection.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Battling Bad Reviews

title: Bronze Art The Ancients Treasured
description: The talented artisans of ancient China were as valued as computer programmers are today. ''Over the millennia, especially during the Warring States period, whenever there was a conflict on China's outer or inner borders, all the captives were killed except for the artisans,'' said Robert Hatfield Ellsworth, the veteran New York dealer in Asian art. ''Skilled workmen were valued more highly than farmers, cattle or horses. After a battle, the conquerors took the time to sort it out, and the artisans knew they and their families would be saved. Weavers, jade cutters, bronze workers and woodcarvers were taken up, lock, stock and barrel, and shipped off to the state of the conqueror.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Stock Issue For Toll Concern
description: A leading European toll road operator, Autoroutes du Sud de la France, and the French government said they planned to raise as much as 2.7 billion euros ($2.4 billion) selling stock in the company. The offer values the company at as much as 5.8 billion euros, the chairman, Bernard Val, said at a news conference. The government is selling a 49 percent stake in the highway network, whose 2,794 kilometers (1,736 miles) of roads run along the country's Mediterranean coast, to help narrow its budget deficit after slowing economic growth sapped tax revenue.

title: Seeking Mercy for Their Son's Killer
description: Two scenes from ''The Matthew Shepard Story'' on NBC leave haunting imprints for very different reasons. The obvious shock comes right at the beginning, from a stylized yet graphic re-creation of Mr. Shepard's gruesome murder, in which he was beaten and left to die lashed to a fence in a frozen Wyoming prairie in 1998.

title: Evil, the Nazis and Shock Value
description: AS usual in the art wars, the show that has caused months of debate before it opened turns out to have too much trivial art and too many extravagant excuses for why that is the case. ''Mirroring Evil: Nazi Imagery/Recent Art,'' which starts Sunday at the Jewish Museum, is dominated by the sort of dry, cool, Conceptual art that a vocal part of the contemporary art world invariably congratulates itself for finding endlessly fascinating. But it is art that leaves much of the public feeling confused, excluded and finally bored, if not pained and offended, which is of course the point.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Government Pulls Out Of Peace Talks
description: The government withdrew from peace talks in Sun City, South Africa, accusing the rebel Congolese Rally for Democracy-Goma of launching an attack in a remote area of eastern Congo. Government officials said they would remain in Sun City, a Las Vegas-like gambling resort, and resume talks if the group ceased its attacks. The rebels denied the accusations, saying the government was looking for an excuse to undermine the talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TODER, EMANUEL
description: TODER-Emanuel. Of Deerfield Beach, Florida, passed away on March 12th, 2002. He is survived by his loving wife, Florence, son Richard and daughter Nancy, grandchildren Elizabeth and David and three great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to your favorite charity.

title: U.S. Indictment In Deadly Plot On Journalist
description: A 28-year-old British-born Muslim militant was indicted today on federal charges that he orchestrated the kidnapping plot that led to the murder of Daniel Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal. The charges can carry the death penalty.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Option Absurdity: Hoping for Lower Prices
description: AS investors worry about what the Securities and Exchange Commission will find in its investigations of accounting at Qwest Communications and WorldCom, perhaps the strangest part of the whole affair is that many employees at both companies have reason to hope that their share prices fall further.

title: Agency Finds Itself Under Siege, With Many Responsibilities and Many Critics
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service is one of the government's fastest-growing agencies, and, perhaps, the most fouled up.

title: Government Sues Accountant, Saying He Helped Clients Try to Dodge Millions in Taxes
description: The government sued a former accountant yesterday who it says helped more than 200 wealthy Americans try to cheat the Treasury out of more than $36 million using the argument that Americans who work for American companies are not required to pay income taxes.

title: Sports of The Times; At St. Peter's, Coach Tells It Straight
description: WHEN Felicia Harris enrolled at St. Peter's College, the man she would come to know affectionately as Granelli sat her down for a heart to heart, one on one. ''You're an attractive young lady and guys are going to hit on you,'' he said, catching her off guard, elbowing his way right into her personal life. ''That's not what you're going to college for.''

title: Bills Seek to Restore Power For Federal Salmonella Tests
description: Members of Congress today introduced legislation that would restore the Agriculture Department's authority to set and enforce standards for salmonella in meat and poultry, including the power to close a processing plant that fails to meet expectations.

title: Aristocrats and Revelers at the Ball
description: Centuries mingled last Friday night when the New York Baroque Dance Company celebrated its 25th anniversary with an ''Anniversary Baroque Costume Ball'' at St. Mark's Church.

title: Hot Fight in Wisconsin Over University's Budget
description: A political battle over a yawning state budget deficit has left thousands of students, parents and professors in limbo as the University of Wisconsin froze undergraduate admissions and halted hiring in all but essential positions.

title: Volcker Stays at Work But Fears His Efforts Might Go for Naught
description: Paul A. Volcker, who loves a metaphor, has been referring to himself lately as Don Quixote. That is quite a contrast from the confidence he exuded when he took on the task last month of improving the accounting profession by using Arthur Andersen, desperate to overcome the stain of Enron, as his platform.

title: Israel Promises a Pullback As Death Toll Keeps Rising
description: Israeli tanks and armored personnel carriers roared through the main streets of this West Bank city this afternoon. The rattle of machine-gun fire seemed to come from all directions while the dead and wounded poured into Ramallah Government Hospital.

title: Panel Rejects Bush Nominee For Judgeship
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee shut the door today on President Bush's efforts to promote Judge Charles W. Pickering Sr. to an appeals court post, as Democrats used their majority to reject his confirmation in the committee and then refused to send the nomination to the full Senate as the president had requested.

title: Drought Leaves Maine Stoic but Struggling
description: In a cluster of 40 homes near huge Sebago Lake, whose waters are spookily low and wearing a dismal late-winter collar of mud, residents have enough water in their wells to shower every other day -- and they shower fast.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Home Depot Subsidiary To Open Store
description: Home Depot will open its first New York City Expo Design Center store, a showcase for designer products and major remodeling projects. In contrast to the no-frills Home Depot warehouse concept, the new 105,000-square-foot store, to open tomorrow at 73-01 25th Avenue in Jackson Heights, will offer services for renovation projects. About 200 people are employed at the store, one of 46 Expo centers around the country. There are three Expo stores in New Jersey and two on Long Island. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: A Healthy Patient Dies in a Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, JAMES
description: TOBIN-James. The board, administration, scholars and staff of The Levy Economics Institute of Bard College mourn the passing of a dear friend and colleague, James Tobin, who shared with us his brilliant counsel and enduring wisdom as a member of our board of advisors. His generous intellectual contribution to the Levy Institute, particularly during its formative years, will long be remembered and cherished. James Tobin was an economist of rare stature whose contributions to the discipline brought it closer to the real world. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Leon Botstein, President, Bard College Dimitri B. Papadimitriou, President, The Levy Economics Institute

title: The Stolen Election in Zimbabwe
description: The election this week in Zimbabwe was an ugly travesty from which all of southern Africa will suffer. Voters lined up for hours at polling stations, many of them in vain. Supporters of the main opposition candidate were intimidated and beaten. Then the long-serving, increasingly tyrannical president, Robert Mugabe, was declared the winner. International observers called the process deeply flawed, and the Bush administration has refused to recognize the declared results.

title: Poverty's Tragic Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, JUDY
description: KAUFMAN-Judy. In the time that our families have been joined together, we have come to know and love Judy. We will always remember her bubbly laughter and the warm and friendly way she accepted us as her extended family. We will miss her dearly. Our loving thoughts and prayers are with Richard, Adam, Hollie and Marc. Elinor and Burt Liz and Andrew

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Another Bite From That Cookie Full of Arsenic
description: As the stage version of ''Sweet Smell of Success'' opens in the new Times Square -- a place where office buildings are encased in video screens, where shrieking teenagers gather outside the MTV studios as their younger siblings ride the Ferris wheel in the Toys ''R'' Us superstore -- an older Times Square of neon, cigarette smoke and newspaper trucks lumbering out of loading bays full of gossip and scandal is being resurrected downtown.

title: Comfortable In Two Styles, Sweet or Sour
description: Arthur Berger, born in New York 90 years ago, is an interesting and elegant composer who has, for whatever reasons, not received the performances he deserves. So it's good that on Tuesday night the North/ South Consonance Ensemble presented a birthday concert for Mr. Berger at Christ and St. Stephen's Church on West 69th Street. Actually, it was not much of a tribute, since only one of the four works performed was by the honoree. Still, Mr. Berger, who had come from his Cambridge, Mass., home was as avuncular as ever in a little talk he gave before the performance of ''Collage III.''

title: Bitterness in Brooklyn Diocese Over Abuse Case
description: When three nuns came forward in 1996 with reports that three priests had sexually abused adolescent boys in a Fort Greene parish 20 years before, the Diocese of Brooklyn, led by Bishop Thomas V. Daily, assured the nuns that it would act aggressively.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 1 about a Democratic television commercial that attacked Elizabeth Dole for having attended a fund-raiser given by Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron, misstated a connection between him and President Bill Clinton. While they played golf together, records reviewed by a Clinton spokesman show that Mr. Lay did not stay overnight in the Clinton White House. A reader's e-mail reported the error to The Times a few weeks ago; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: In the Bunker, Andersen Crew Is Baffled but Happy for Hugs
description: Knowing that Arthur Andersen was going to be indicted in the destruction of Enron documents did not soften the blow for Andersen employees like Debbie Schleicher, a partner who specializes in taxes for the firm's offices in the Washington area.

title: Child Welfare Agency
description: To the Editor:

title: Yale Victory Is a Postseason First
description: Coach James Jones said Yale's first postseason victory tonight was too fresh to put in perspective. But he was clear about how his Bulldogs defeated Rutgers, 67-65, in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Public Schools Lag in Test Scores
description: As a group, students in New York State's private and religious schools performed almost identically to public school students on the fourth-grade math test last year, and only modestly better in fourth-grade English, state officials said yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''One of them lost his child three weeks ago, one lost his child a month ago, and one lost his child seven months ago. And you know, the pain is the same pain. They have the same pain that I've got.''

title: ANDERSEN CHARGED WITH OBSTRUCTION IN ENRON INQUIRY
description: In the first criminal charge ever brought against a major accounting firm, Arthur Andersen has been indicted on a single count of obstruction of justice for destroying thousands of documents related to the Enron investigation, the Justice Department announced today.

title: If Firm Stands Still, It May Lose Ground
description: With its back against the wall, Arthur Andersen has no good option and not much time.

title: Florida Atlantic Tests Character of Alabama
description: Right here, right now. Believe it. Achieve it. Want it.

title: Daschle Pushes to Query Security Chief
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, today renewed Congressional demands for testimony by Tom Ridge, director of homeland security, and House Republicans joined him in dismissing President Bush's argument that Mr. Ridge, as a presidential adviser, need not appear.

title: Rangers Pull Back on Possible Bure Deal
description: If Radek Dvorak had not been lost for the season with a knee injury on Wednesday night, Pavel Bure of the Florida Panthers might have joined the Rangers in a trade.

title: Bitter Feud In Contest For Party Post Goes Public
description: In an unusual public airing of an internal party struggle, Mayor Glenn D. Cunningham called Representative Robert Menendez ''a political terrorist'' today and urged him to resign as head of the Hudson County Democratic Party.

title: Accounting Standards Board To Be Smaller and More Flexible
description: The group that oversees the Financial Accounting Standards Board said yesterday that it would restructure the board to reduce its size and make it easier to act rapidly on new accounting rules.

title: Study Says Mammograms Cut Death Risk
description: A new analysis of mammography, the latest to address the question of whether screening for breast cancer saves lives, has found that the tests reduce the risk of dying from the disease by one-fifth.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Teacher Faces Sex Charges
description: A teacher was arrested last night on charges that he had arranged through the Internet to meet a 13-year-old girl for illicit purposes, the police said. The teacher, Albert Guasco, 31, of Geldner Avenue in Staten Island, was arrested at the Staten Island Ferry Terminal at 7 p.m., as part of a sting operation by the Manhattan South Vice Squad, Sgt. James Foley said. ''He was there to meet a kid,'' Sergeant Foley said. Mr. Guasco, who the authorities said was a history teacher at Richmondtown Prep School in Staten Island and a teacher at the Staten Island Academy, was charged with attempted rape, attempted sodomy, attempted sexual abuse, and attempted dissemination of indecent material to a minor. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: ANWR And Peas
description: On Wednesday the Senate voted down a proposal by John Kerry and John McCain to raise mileage standards on automobiles. The outcome came as no surprise, but what does it mean?

title: Residential Real Estate; Sugar Relics Are Reborn On Each Side of Hudson
description: Two former sugar processing facilities on opposite sides of the Hudson River, vestiges of one of the area's most profitable 19th-century industries, have recently been transformed into luxury condominium buildings.

title: Teacher's Aide Charged With Raping Student
description: A teacher's aide at a middle school here was charged today with raping a blind 11-year-old student she tutored, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWEY, DONALD J.
description: DEWEY-Donald J. On March 5, 2002 at the age of 79. Emeritus Professor of Economics at Columbia University. He's deeply mourned by his wife Ruth, his son Christopher, his daughter Rachel and her husband Stephen Thorsett and by his granddaughter Laura and by many friends.

title: Annika Larsson
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Energis Misses Debt Payment
description: The British telecommunications concern Energis, which is restructuring its debt, said it would not make a 13.7 million ($19.5 million) bond interest payment due today. Under the terms of the bonds, Energis has a 30-day grace period, the company said. It added that its main lending banks supported its decision. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Behind Sprewell, Knicks Take and Hold a Lead
description: There may not have been a soul among the 19,763 fans at Madison Square Garden who was not expecting the worst. The Knicks were missing jump shots, the Sacramento Kings were making layups, and another huge lead was shrinking like bad fabric.

title: A Failure of Energy
description: Americans should be outraged at the Senate's vote on Wednesday to compromise important national security and environmental concerns in order to please the auto industry and its unions. That is precisely what took place when 62 senators, as part of the ongoing debate on new energy legislation, rejected a long-overdue effort to increase fuel efficiency standards by 50 percent over 13 years. Doing so promised ultimately to save 2.5 million barrels of oil a day, more than is currently imported from the Middle East.

title: Looking for Her Man Amid the Balkan War
description: Not even the civil war in what was once Yugoslavia will keep a good woman from her husband's side. That is the loony message of ''Harrison's Flowers,'' a stupefying mix of action, politics and melodrama that is as vaguely condescending as the inept but well-meaning pictures about apartheid from the 1980's, like ''Cry Freedom'' and ''A Dry White Season.''

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Elk Disease In National Park
description: Wildlife biologists at Rocky Mountain National Park have confirmed cases of chronic wasting disease in elk and deer within the park boundaries and have requested a federal research grant to study the possible spread of the illness. There is no live test for the brain-wasting illness, so it cannot be detected without killing the animal. State wildlife officials recently killed about 1,500 domestic elk after the disease was found on some game farms.

title: Administration Seeks Unlimited Military Aid for Colombia
description: The Bush administration plans to ask Congress to lift restrictions on American military aid to Colombia in order to help the government in Bogot fight leftist rebels, officials said today.

title: Zimbabwe and Us
description: To the Editor:

title: This Time, Gonzaga Is Heading Home Early
description: For the first time in four years, Gonzaga, the model for small schools everywhere, will not make it to the N.C.A.A. tournament's Round of 16. The sixth-seeded Bulldogs did not even get out of the first round of the West Regional, bowing to 11th-seeded Wyoming, 73-66, tonight at the Pit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLINSKY, HYMAN
description: DOLINSKY-Hyman. The members and staff of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the MTA extend our heartfelt condolences to our Executive Director Beverly Dolinsky on the loss of her beloved husband Hy, and to Annie and Becky on the loss of their father. Jim Blair, Barbara Josepher, Rich Cataggio, Andrew Albert

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Into the Depths For a Thriller

title: Sports of The Times; A Father Passes Down Life's Lessons
description: ROBERT HATTEN walked up the steps to the small second-floor room that used to belong to his son, Marcus. It still does, more or less. When his son comes home now, he stays downstairs at the home on Jefferson Street in East Baltimore.

title: A Brew of Faces for Mixing and Aging
description: If the rest of Nancy Burson's retrospective at the Grey Art Gallery at New York University doesn't unsettle you, maybe this will: At the end of the exhibition you'll find Ms. Burson's computerized ''Age Machine,'' where you can sit back and see how you could look in 25 years. You also have the option of seeing what you might look like as an African, Asian, Caucasian, Indian or Hispanic (in the ''Human Race Machine'') or with various facial deformities (the ''Anomaly Machine'').

title: ING Direct Selects Bartle Bogle Hegarty

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Airport To Start Wireless Service
description: The Concourse Communications Group, which is developing wireless networks for the three New York area airports, expects to turn on its first such airportwide network, at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, on Wednesday. Concourse is to begin offering wireless access to travelers at Newark, Kennedy and LaGuardia Airports later this year. Richard Snyder, senior vice president for business development at Concourse, said limited service would begin at, Newark and Kennedy by midyear. Travelers will pay for access to the airport networks through iPass, a global corporate services company. IPass will offer long-term service plans as well as a walk-up price of $7.95 for a 24-hour period. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: KPN To Post Loss
description: The leading phone company in the Netherlands, Royal KPN, said yesterday that its loss for 2001 would be a record, after it writes down the value of its stake in the E-Plus wireless network of Germany by more than $10 billion. A number of other companies, including Vodafone, the BT Group, Vivendi and AOL Time Warner, have also written down investments made when valuations soared in the late 1990's at the height of the boom in technology stocks. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Companies defend use of strategic thinkers : The futurologist is in
description: LONDON  In 1998, after 17 years with the function-oriented electronics company Motorola Inc., Kenny Hirschhorn landed himself a job at the young and snappy British cell-phone company Orange PLC, where he took on the new-economy title of director of imagineering and futurology.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Nuclear Program Could Resume
description: The foreign ministry said that it was examining ''all the agreements with the United States'' and would no longer be bound by them if reports of a Pentagon proposal to develop new nuclear weapons intended to deter North Korea and other countries from attacking the United States were true. The implication was that the North might resume work on nuclear warheads, which it promised to stop trying to produce after signing an agreement with the United States in 1994.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Icann Rejects Election Proposal
description: The group that oversees the Internet's address system, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, concluded a meeting in Accra, Ghana, yesterday by approving a series of resolutions largely related to organizational changes. Although the Icann board assigned one committee to develop recommendations for overhauling its structure, it rejected a proposal by another committee to conduct global online elections for board members representing Internet users at large. Icann has been criticized for its bureaucracy and lack of openness, and this week several members of Congress sent letters to the Commerce Department, which oversees Icann, requesting more oversight of its operations and overhaul efforts. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, RICHARD T.
description: KENT-Richard T., 75. Retired Treasurer of Bristol-Myers Company died on March 4, 2002. He is survived by his wife Georgianne Ensign Kent; 3 children, Dana Kent, Lisa Kent, Amy Kent; and 4 grandchildren. Memorial contributions to Kent Land Trust, Kent, CT 06757, or Kent Memorial Library Association Endowment Fund, Kent, CT. 06757. Contact Kenny Funeral Home, 41 Main St., Sharon, CT. 06069 for information.

title: The Benevolent Bird Hunters
description: The gyrfalcon, dark and fierce, probably digesting a meal of herring gull or pigeon, was perched on a high ledge of the Boston Design Center.

title: Execution Before Trial for Andersen
description: Arthur Andersen admits to making a lot of mistakes, but it refused to plead guilty to obstruction of justice. And so yesterday it was indicted in what the firm said was ''a gross abuse of government power.''

title: Agency Links Tissue Processing to Bacterial Infections, Including Fatal Case
description: Four months after a young Minnesota man died from routine knee surgery, federal officials said yesterday that they had turned up 25 more cases of serious bacterial infections in people who received similar operations over the past several years.

title: CNN Headline News Anchor Says She'll Leave Network
description: Andrea Thompson, the former ''NYPD Blue'' actress whose hiring by CNN Headline News last year was panned by critics as an extreme example of the melding of news and entertainment, is leaving the network.

title: Almost an Upset In Bridge Tourney
description: A favored team seemed to be in jeopardy in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here on Wednesday night but surged to victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFFCOAT, ALBERT E. (JEFF)
description: JEFFCOAT-Albert E. (Jeff). Formerly of Larchmont, NY died March 10 at his home on Bainbridge Island, WA, after a valiant battle with cancer. His courage, spirit, and optimism throughout his life will be remembered through his accomplishments as foreign correspondent of the Wall Street Journal, founder of the Manhattan Theatre Club, and author of the critically acclaimed non-fiction ''Spirited Americans''. At the time of his death, he was working on a second book, ''Soul, Searching''. As a loving husband to his wife Jan, and devoted father to sons Thomas, Peter, John and Ross; daughters Lindsey and Catherine; and four grandchildren, he will never be forgotten. Memorial services will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, 11AM, Thursday April 11. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made in his name to the Manhattan Theatre Club, NY or the Grace Episcopal Church Library Fund, Bainbridge Island, WA. 98110.

title: Wal-Mart Dips $46 Million Toe Into Vast Japanese Economy
description: Wal-Mart Stores said today that it would make its first foray into the $3.9 trillion Japanese economy by buying a minority interest in a Japanese retailer, Seiyu Ltd.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; The Big 3 Sit and Honk Outside Korea's Garage
description: JAE H. JUNG doesn't look like a global warrior as he edges his black Lincoln LS sedan through the crush of midday traffic. But as the recently appointed president of the Ford Motor Company's Korean sales operation, Mr. Jung is storming the ramparts of a market in which 1.4 million cars were sold last year -- and in which Ford sold just 400.

title: For Children, Peace Seems Easy if They Get to Connect
description: ''Promises'' was broadcast in the ''P.O.V.'' series on PBS in December. Following are excerpts from Julie Salamon's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Dec. 13; the full text is available at nytimes.com. The film, which has been nominated for an Academy Award for best documentary, is in English, Arabic and Hebrew with English subtitles. It opens today at the Quad Cinema, 34 West 13th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Fogler Stays Unbeaten Behind the Microphone
description: Most times, when a coach or manager is fired and lands a TV job, it is a temporary refuge until the next job to run a team comes along. Mike Ditka returned to the field to coach the New Orleans Saints but was a shell of the coach he was with the Chicago Bears. But that is not the case for Eddie Fogler, who begins calling N.C.A.A. men's tournament games on CBS today from the East Regional in Chicago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES, Portland, Ore., a producer of paper, acquired the cardboard box unit of Fomento Econmico Mexicano, Monterrey, Mexico, a maker of beer and soft drinks, for $70 million.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Premier Visits War Zone
description: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe became the highest-ranking elected official in 20 years to visit the Jaffna peninsula, scene of the most devastating fighting between the government and separatist Tamil rebels. The city of Jaffna, the center of Tamil culture, was held by the rebels from 1990 to 1995. The two sides in the ethnic conflict have now agreed to a formal cease-fire. ''We are trying to make it work and go for talks,'' he said.

Aunt of Sheila and Philip Levy, great aunt of Tania Levy and James Levy, all of London, England. Cousin of Regina Kayne and Faye Lichtenstein of Columbus, Ohio and their families. description: The United States sled hockey team, competing in the 2002 Salt Lake Paralympics, may do what the men's and women's American Olympic hockey teams could not: bring home a gold medal.

title: Salomon Under Inquiry on WorldCom Options
description: Salomon Smith Barney is under investigation by the New York Stock Exchange for possible violations surrounding the firm's handling of a number of accounts opened by WorldCom employees to exercise stock options in 1999 and 2000.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the debate team at Franklin K. Lane High School misidentified the neighborhood in Queens where the school is located. It is Woodhaven, not Woodside.

title: Cuomo Supports Putting Mayor In Charge of City School System
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democratic candidate for governor, called yesterday for eliminating the New York City Board of Education and awarding Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg control of the school system. He asserted that nothing could be done to improve public schools without changing the governance system.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gay Group Invited To Gracie
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has invited members of a gay group to a breakfast tomorrow at Gracie Mansion before the St. Patrick's Day Parade. The group, the Irish Lesbian and Gay Organization, has long been banned from marching behind their own banner in the parade. Aine Duggan, a spokeswoman for the group, said that its members would attend the breakfast before protesting at the parade. As a candidate, Mr. Bloomberg had suggested that he would not march in parades that bar gay groups. But he has decided to march in tomorrow's Parade, which will honor the victims of Sept. 11. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN VOORHEES, CLIFFORD I.
description: van VOORHEES-Clifford I. Jr. On Tuesday, Mar. 12, 2002 at age 81 in Southampton, New York. Beloved husband of Nancy (Washburn), father of Clifford I. III, Sonia L. Reese, Roger W., Victoria P. (Grey) & Peter C. (predeceased), and grandfather of Alexander, Kathryn, Christiana, Bradford, Roger (Jr.), Amanda, Serena and Nina. Mr. van Voorhees was born in New York City on February 20, 1921 to Adelaide (nee Parker) and Clifford I. van Voorhees of New Brunswick, NJ and New York City. He graduated from The Lawrenceville School in 1940 & Cornell (B.A.) in 1944, and received his J.D. from Rutgers University in 1951. He served with the U.S. Army Air Force occupation forces in Japan at the end of W.W. II. Mr. van Voorhees was a loved and respected resident of Southampton, NY. A private service is scheduled for Saturday, March 16 and a memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions to support the work of Clearpool, Inc. (55 Washington St., Suite 558, Brooklyn, NY 11201) for inner city education would be appreciated by the family.

title: Suspect in Church Shootings Had Bullets Left, Police Say
description: The shooting rampage that killed a Roman Catholic priest and a parishioner at a Tuesday morning Mass in a Long Island church could have claimed more victims because the weapon taken from the suspect still had four unfired rounds, investigators said today.

description: Lehmann Maupin

title: U.N. Group Backs North Korean Asylum Seekers in China
description: Twenty-five North Koreans who burst through the gates of the Spanish Embassy here Thursday morning demanding safe passage to South Korea were visited Thursday by local representatives of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees in an effort to help resolve a sticky diplomatic standoff.

title: A Faustian Pact in a City of Demons
description: LISTEN, all ye sinners, to the Lorelei call of Manhattan after dark, a world of glitter and grime, of illicit, electrified promise. Harken to the whispers of the famous and the infamous as they do the dirty things they do when the lights are low. Hear the cries of the . . . zzzzzzzz.

title: Small Player Weighs Bid for Global Crossing
description: The list of potential bidders for the assets of Global Crossing continued to grow yesterday even as industry experts expressed some skepticism about the widening roster of companies showing interest in the beleaguered communications concern.

title: MERRILL LYNCH CUT PAY OF ITS TOP EXECUTIVES IN 2001
description: Merrill Lynch & Company cut the pay of its chief executive, David H. Komansky, by half last year as profit slid, but his compensation still totaled $16.3 million, according to the company's proxy filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He received $700,000 in salary, a $1 million cash bonus, restricted stock valued at $10.3 million and options the firm valued at $4.1 million. Mr. Komansky, 62, received total compensation of $32.5 million in 2000. E. Stanley O'Neal, who became president in July and will take over the company when Mr. Komansky retires, earned $13 million, compared with $21.6 million in 2000 as head of Merrill's United States brokerage division.

title: EgyptAir Crash Report Near Approval After Delay
description: American investigators are approaching final approval of a report that concludes that EgyptAir 990 crashed because of the deliberate actions of a co-pilot, people familiar with the investigation said.

title: Groups Fight Florida's Ban on Gay Adoptions
description: As Florida officials seek to remove a 10-year-old boy from the home of the same-sex foster parents who have raised him since infancy, gay and civil rights agencies and children's advocates have organized to challenge a state law prohibiting gays from adopting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UHLIG, RICHARD H.

For information, contact the Cremation Society of the Carolinas, Raleigh, NC.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Until someone comes up with a way to cater a flotation tank, Kai may be the ultimate in spiritually refreshing dining. The name refers to kaiseki, the Japanese tea ceremony, traditionally accompanied by small, exquisite dishes exquisitely presented, and tradition, in that sense, is followed at Kai, which is situated above the tea shop of the same name. Combed-clay walls, tea-green banquettes and dark-wood floors set the tone, which is profoundly Japanese, but modern.

description: The Mets do not have to let John Valentin know whether he will be on their opening day roster until March 25, the date agreed upon in his minor league contract. But Valentin's status has been made clear.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Wednesday about a settlement in which Sony Pictures Entertainment agreed to pay a fine to Connecticut for falsifying a movie review and attributing it to a local newspaper referred incorrectly to Sue Manning, a former town first selectwoman from Ridgefield. Her son David Manning had spoken to a friend at Sony, which attributed a quotation to him in the ad and falsely identified him as a critic at The Ridgefield Press. Ms. Manning did not give Sony permission to use her son's name.

description: STITCH-Shirley. National Council of Jewish Women Brooklyn Section has sorrowfully learned of the passing of Shirley Stitch, Past President and Honorary Director. Sylvia Ladner, Dolores Measer Co-Presidents

title: 'A Beautiful Mind' Meets Ugly Oscar Tactics
description: John Nash says he is not an anti-Semite. He says he is not a homosexual. Nor, he says, did he try to conceal any of his deficiencies as a father or any humiliating episodes in an attempt to glamorize his life.

title: Tarkanian Decides It's Time to Throw In the Towel
description: Jerry Tarkanian, the highly successful but scandal-scarred coach who fought over recruiting practices with the National College Athletic Association for more than a quarter-century, announced yesterday that he was retiring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBER, EVELYN HECHT
description: OBER-Evelyn Hecht. Of Kew Gardens, NY, and Coconut Creek, FL. Beloved wife of the late Aaron Alan Hecht, and the late Ralph Ober. Devoted mother of Hazel Bloch, Hunter, Harvey and Michael Hecht. Adoring grandmother of Leann Bloch, Leslie Stevens, Dina Bloch, Ross Hecht, Robyn Pearlstein and Ayrn Hecht, and great-grandmother of four. A true devoted friend to all. Box 220036, Glenwood, FL. 32722.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: U.S. May Regain Human Rights Seat
description: The United States looks likely to regain its seat on the United Nations Human Rights Commission now that Italy and Spain have reportedly agreed to step aside. That leaves Australia, Germany and Iceland as the only other candidates for four vacancies reserved this year for Western countries. The United States was voted off last year and will be an observer when the annual meeting starts next week in Geneva. Christopher S. Wren (NYT)

title: Imagery of Anger In a Troubled Mind
description: In ''The Believer,'' winner of the grand jury prize at last year's Sundance Film Festival, a young Jew helps his skinhead friends desecrate and try to destroy a synagogue. He doesn't protest when one of them urinates from the balcony, but some residual religiosity makes him urge the others to stop tossing around a Torah and put it back where they got it.

title: TREASURY'S CHIEF IS SAID TO FAULT STEEL TARIFF MOVE
description: Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill told a foreign policy group this week that he disagreed with the Bush administration's decision earlier this month to impose tariffs on imported steel and that the move would cost more jobs in the United States than it would save, people who heard him speak said today.

title: Tipper Gore Weighs Campaign for Senate
description: Tipper Gore is considering running for Senate, friends and advisers said. Her sudden interest has stunned Democratic officials and friends, who said she was never enthusiastic about her husband's designs on the White House.

title: Special Counsel For Whitewater In Senate Race
description: Robert W. Ray, the former Whitewater independent counsel, confirmed today that he would, as expected, join the race for the Republican Senate nomination to challenge Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic incumbent.

title: Safer Airports
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Wireless Ruling
description: Telephone companies that provide fixed-line services will be able to add mobile service on a limited basis under a new court ruling. The ruling was handed down by the Telecom Disputes Settlement and Appellate Tribunal, which dismissed a petition from India's mobile phone companies seeking to prevent fixed-line operators from offering mobile services. The ruling will benefit large fixed-line providers like Reliance Infocom, which plans to expand its customer base by offering wireless service. The Cellular Operators Association said it might appeal the decision. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Court Rejects an Estate Claim Filed by a Transsexual Widow
description: The Kansas Supreme Court today rejected a transsexual widow's claim to her husband's estate, ruling that state laws do not recognize marriage between two people who were born the same sex.

title: A corruption scandal looms over global tournament : Soccer chiefs play political game
description: The World Cup of soccer kicks off in South Korea and Japan less than 80 days from now. But instead of keeping their eyes on the ball, instead of harmonizing efforts to manage and secure the games, soccer's overlords are betraying the sport they should serve.

title: Investors Hold Bank Liable For Losses at Currency Firm
description: A group of international investors who say they were swindled out of more than $15 million by a currency trading firm that was based in the World Trade Center say that J. P. Morgan Chase bears some responsibility for their losses, which they discovered after the trading firm's offices were destroyed on Sept. 11 and several of its executives disappeared.

title: Cheney Says Next Goal In U.S. War on Terror Is to Block Access to Arms
description: Sending a signal that the Bush administration is determined to confront Iraq despite criticism and skepticism among Arab leaders, Vice President Dick Cheney said today that the United States' next goal after Afghanistan is to stop terrorists and rogue states from developing weapons of mass destruction.

title: Shirley Scott, 67, Performer Known as the Queen of the Organ
description: Shirley Scott, a jazz organist who recorded dozens of albums from the 1950's to the 90's, earning her the nickname ''Queen of the Organ,'' died on Sunday at a hospital in Philadelphia. She was 67 and lived in West Chester, Pa.

title: U.S. Panel Allows Doctors' Suit Against Health Care Companies
description: A panel of federal appeals judges in Atlanta has rejected an effort by a group of managed care companies to derail a proposed class-action lawsuit that was filed against them on behalf of 600,000 doctors.

title: The Next Gonzaga Is Here
description: When Wyoming rallied to eliminate Gonzaga in the opening round of the West Regional on Thursday night, it did more than pull off a big shocker. The Cowboys also put themselves in position to be this year's Gonzaga.

title: In Serbia, Politics in Turmoil As U.S. Diplomat Is Detained
description: Politics here twisted into chaos today as an American diplomat was arrested along with a senior Serbian official, both accused of espionage, and every person in power claimed outrage and ignorance about what had happened.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: No Plans For More Americans
description: Bush administration officials said they would not try to change Congressional limits on the number of Americans that can be stationed in the country -- 400 military personnel and 400 civilians -- or lift conditions that make aid contingent on the Colombian military's respect for human rights. They said they would soon ask Congress to allow the Colombian government to use American-trained counternarcotics brigades, attack helicopters and other United States aid in the fight against rebels. Christopher Marquis (NYT)

title: Bush Urges Congress to Increase Military Budget
description: President Bush called on Congress this morning to approve his request for a $48 billion increase in military spending as its ''first order of business'' so his administration can plan for the expanding war against terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, JUDY
description: KAUFMAN-Judy. A light in our lives has been extinguished by the loss of our dear Judy. We were so fortunate to have had her friendship. Our hearts and prayers are with Richard, Adam, Holly and Mark. Marilyn & Stu

title: Cellphone Helps Victim Lead Officers To Suspect
description: A Brooklyn father helped to rescue his teenage daughter from the hands of a rapist yesterday after the girl spoke to him on a cellphone and said she was in trouble and was being held in a restaurant by her assailant, the police said.

title: Andersen Partners Abroad Are Cutting Ties
description: The Arthur Andersen partnerships in Spain and Chile said today that they had decided to sever their ties with the worldwide Andersen practice, and their counterparts in other countries said they were considering doing the same.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Less Money For University
description: The Republican-controlled State Assembly narrowly approved a budget bill that would cut financing for the 26-campus state university system by 12 percent, or $108 million. The move is part of an effort to make up a $1.1 billion deficit in the two-year state budget of $47 billion. The 51-to-48 vote sends the budget to the Democratic-controlled Senate and back to the governor, who had suggested a more modest cut of $51 million. Admission to the University of Wisconsin has been frozen as administrators determine how many students they can afford to educate. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: History and the Bible: Reflections on Judaism
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Seeking Payment For Suicide
description: The widow of a small-town mayor who took his own life has filed a worker's compensation claim, saying that job-related pressures led to his suicide. The widow, Lois Heisner, is asking for $658 a week, saying that her husband, Kirwan, committed suicide in September after negative publicity about a land acquisition. He had been the mayor of Pinkneyville, a coal-mining town of 3,500 in southern Illinois, for seven years. Daniel I. Dorfman (NYT)

title: Top-Shelf Title Game In P.S.A.L. Basketball
description: If familiarity breeds contempt, then today's championship games of the Public Schools Athletic League boys' and girls' tournaments should be contentious affairs.

title: ISRAEL WITHDRAWS FROM MOST TOWNS IN THE WEST BANK
description: Israel pulled its forces out of all West Bank towns save Bethlehem today, bringing an unfamiliar calm to much of the area as Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, the American mediator, concluded an intensive first round of meetings in search of a cease-fire.

title: President of Cornell to Step Down in 2003
description: Hunter R. Rawlings III, the tall, gentlemanly president of Cornell University, who since 1995 has presided over a period of financial prosperity and growth, announced yesterday that he would step down on June 30, 2003.

title: Mother Who Drowned 5 Children In Tub Avoids a Death Sentence
description: Andrea Pia Yates, the mentally ill mother convicted of drowning her children in a bathtub, avoided the death penalty today as a Texas jury recommended a life sentence that requires that she spend at least 40 years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARENOW, HAZEL
description: SHARENOW-Hazel. Of Tamarac, FL, widow of Alfred Sharenow, passed away Mar. 14, 2002. She is the stepmother of Caroline Baron and Arthur Sharenow, aunt of Lee Neibert & the late Sheila Sherman. For information, contact the Star of David Memorial Chapel and Cemetery, (954) 722-9000.
