description: To the Editor:

title: ALAMO AND NATIONAL TO SHARE SOME AIRPORT RENTAL SITES
description: The ANC Rental Corporation, which operates the Alamo and National car-rental chains, said a judge approved the company's merger of operations at six airports over objections by two competitors, Hertz and Avis. After a series of hearings in Bankruptcy Court in Delaware, Judge Mary Walrath approved ANC's plan to move its Alamo rental sites to National at the Detroit; Pittsburgh; Jacksonville, Fla.; and Hartford airports and to add Alamo offices to National at airports in Huntsville, Ala., and Springfield, Mo., the company said. ANC, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., plans to combine Alamo and National rental sites at 74 airports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEPITA, PAULINE M.
description: STEPITA-Pauline M. On Mar. 11, 2002. Beloved mother of Barbara S. Cota and Mary & John Stepita. Devoted grandmother and greatgrandmother. Predeceased by husband C.T. Stepita, M.D.

title: An Uneasy Routine at Cuba Prison Camp
description: An elaborate social system is evolving here between American military guards and their captives from the Afghan war.

title: UConn Faces an Easy Opener
description: For the second time in four years, St. Francis of Pennsylvania has drawn Connecticut in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. women's tournament. UConn won, 97-46, in 1999. Today's matchup does not figure to be any more competitive.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. and More Companies Abandon Arthur Andersen

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Logger To End Old-Growth Cutting
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation said it planned to stop cutting old-growth timber within two years. The decision comes after years of pressure from environmental groups, but the company said that did not influence its change in policy. Company statements show that about 1 percent of wood used by the company in 2001 was old growth, and that percentage was expected to fall. One group, Rainforest Action Network of Boise, called the change in policy ''inadequate and incomplete.''

title: MARTHA STEWART LIVING CUTS JOBS AT INTERNET OPERATION
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, the media and housewares company built on its founder's homemaking tips, cut 40 jobs in its Internet and direct-marketing unit, or about 6 percent of the entire staff. The Web unit, which also includes the Martha by Mail catalog, is losing money. The unit lost $6.7 million in the fourth quarter, before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, on sales of $17.6 million. The job cuts are unrelated to Martha Stewart Living's relationship with the Kmart Corporation, the bankrupt discount retailer, a spokeswoman, Elizabeth Estroff, said. Martha Stewart is based in New York.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Closing Private Prisons
description: Gov. Gray Davis is seeking to end the state's experiment with privately operated prisons. The governor's office cited cost and a declining inmate population as the primary reasons for the move, which was tucked away in his budget proposal. Under the governor's plan, five private prisons would close on June 30 and four others would be phased out when their contracts expired in 2007. The state prison guards union, which contributed $2.3 million to Governor Davis's election campaign, has opposed the private prisons.

title: Immigrants Help Us All
description: To the Editor:

title: Time for Candor in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: North Koreans Who Sought Refuge in China Head for Seoul
description: Twenty-five North Koreans who made a desperate end run into the Spanish Embassy here on Thursday to demand political asylum left China today for Manila, taking an indirect route to their final destination of Seoul to avoid offending North Korea.

title: Ban on Refilling Pools Is Lifted
description: State water regulators bowed to the concerns of pool owners today and revised their drought rules to allow empty pools to be refilled for the summer.

title: A Family of 6 Is Found Dead
description: For two weeks, there had been no activity around the mobile home where Robert and Janet Bryant lived. Their four children had not been to class, and school officials had tried to contact the family to see if anything was wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENIG, CAROLYN
description: HENIG-Carolyn. Devoted wife of the late Philip, her husband of 61 years, loving mother of Andrea Clair, her husband Davis Iszard and the late Peter Henig, and beloved grandmother of Bradley and Elizabeth Clair, died at home on March 14, 2002, at the age of 84. Carolyn contributed to the art film industry in various capacities over the years. She devoted herself to her children and grandchildren, tirelessly supported them in difficult times, and imbuing them with her love of the arts. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, Sunday, March 17th, 2-5pm.

title: Religion Journal; Going Inside the Church For Same-Sex Unions
description: Deb Julian and Peg Stone are not exactly getting married. But that is the easiest way to describe the act of being ''joined in civil union'' that they are planning for April 6.

title: In a word : When deception is deceiving:false friends and other enemies
description: PARIS  One of the more vexing aspects of getting to know a language is the phenomenon described in French as faux amis, or false friends. They could better be described as true enemies.

title: Bribery Case Ties Bronx Lawmaker to $1 Million Contract
description: When the Bronx Citizens Committee Alcohol Crisis Center, a rat-infested, asbestos-ridden detox center, was badly in need of renovation, Assemblywoman Gloria Davis took a particularly strong interest in the project, according to one of the main people involved in the center's overhaul.

title: Insight for natives : Letters to the editor
description: Great new section. Interesting articles for us native-speaking expats, plus a lot of good information and insight for those we live among. They perhaps don't always understand what issues are involved, both good and bad, when one lives abroad for an extended period of time. I look forward to further installments.

title: Eisner Expected Letterman's Rebuff
description: Making his first public statement about ABC's failed bid to lure David Letterman from CBS, the Walt Disney Company's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, suggested that his deputies had become overoptimistic on their chances of snaring Mr. Letterman.

title: Witness Says He, Not Brother, Was at Scene of 1988 Slaying
description: Two brothers from Brooklyn were in the same room yesterday for the first time in years. One was brought in shackles from prison, where he is serving a long sentence for murder. The other came to State Supreme Court in Brooklyn in a gray suit and tie to say that he knew his brother was innocent because he himself was involved in the killing.

title: St. Paul's Chapel Is Closing For Cleanup of Debris
description: St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Church, the sanctuary for weary rescue workers at ground zero since Sept. 11, is closing temporarily for a cleaning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEVERNS, THEODATE JOHNSON
description: SEVERNS - Theodate Johnson. The Musicians' Club of New York mourns the passing of our esteemed member whose generous spirit and inspirational support of many young artists will always be remembered. We extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Bruce L. Kubert, President

title: 'Rabbit' Adds Drama To Florida Derby
description: The trainer Todd Pletcher did not exactly reveal his hand this morning -- not the first time he was asked for his Florida Derby strategy, not the 2nd or even the 200th time. In Smooth Jazz, he probably does not have the best horse among the 11 entered, but he could hold the key to the race. It depends on Pletcher's plan.

title: A Reading Binge
description: To the Editor:

title: HarperCollins To Junk Copies Of a New Book Cited as Libel
description: After threat of a libel suit, the publisher HarperCollins is taking the rare step of destroying its inventory of a new book that attacks James J. Cramer, the journalist and former hedge fund manager.

title: Another Disappointing Round for Knight
description: Bob Knight's remarkable return to college coaching this season ended in disappointing fashion tonight. His Texas Tech team, seeded sixth in the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional, lost to 11th-seeded Southern Illinois, 76-68, at the United Center.

title: Thomas F. Leahy, 64, Ex-Leader of CBS TV
description: Thomas F. Leahy, a former president of the CBS television network, died March 8 in Manhattan. He was 64 and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Creighton Stuns Florida With 0.2 Left
description: Terrell Taylor, who does not start for Creighton, said he watched a Michael Jordan DVD before his team played Florida today. He figured it might give him inspiration to play at the United Center, Jordan's former home court.

title: Former Boston ConcertmasterOffers Contrasts in Vibrato
description: Joseph Silverstein

title: A Village Running Dry Hopes It Has Struck Water
description: The new well is so crucial here that village workers have stopped by after hours to make sure that it is still flowing. The mayor worries about little else, and neighbors try to reassure one another that this time will be different.

title: State Ends Bid To Disqualify Passaic Mayor
description: Eight months after Samuel Rivera was sworn in as this city's mayor, the state attorney general's office gave up its effort today to remove him under a state law barring convicted criminals from holding public office.

title: An Islamic Scholar's Lifelong Lesson: Tolerance
description: NURCHOLISH MADJID, the most prominent Muslim scholar in Indonesia, had no qualms when his daughter announced she planned to wed a New York Jew, a union beyond the imagination of most Indonesians. In fact, this genial man, known as the conscience of his nation, insisted on conducting an Islamic marriage service in the couple's Washington apartment last fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MOSES
description: SHAPIRO-Moses. The Trustees and staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage-A Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of Moses Shapiro, beloved husband of Ethel and father of Naomi and Richard Resnick, Louise and Robert Cohen. Dear brother of Jessica Gribetz and brother-in-law of our Trustee Judah Gribetz. Devoted grandfather of Deborah, Ilana, Sarah and David. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Shapiro, Cohen, Resnick and Gribetz families. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, RUBIN, M.D.
description: SOLOMON - Rubin, M.D. On March 14, 2002. Husband of the late Muriel. Beloved father of Stephen and Richard. Dear uncle of Lurie Squire. Service Sunday, 12 Noon, Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, L.I.

title: Merck Withdraws F.D.A. Filing on Drug; Shares Drop 6%
description: Shares of Merck & Company fell almost 6 percent yesterday after it announced that it had withdrawn an application for regulatory approval of a pain reliever called Arcoxia, the successor to one of its top-selling drugs, Vioxx.

title: For a Bastion Of Tradition, A New World; Events of Sept. 11 Altered West Point, Too
description: Two hundred years of tradition cling to the stone fortresses that make up the United States Military Academy here. Cadets awake to reveille and, in their gray uniforms and garrison caps, hurry across campus under lofty monuments to war heroes that have developed a layer of verdigris with age. They speak earnestly about a lifetime of selfless service as members of the ''long gray line.''

title: USAIR TO RESTORE MOST OF ITS TRANS-ATLANTIC FLIGHTS
description: The US Airways Group said it would add back 37 trans-Atlantic flights that were suspended after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The airline will increase to 98, from 61, its weekly round trips between Charlotte, N.C.; Philadelphia and Pittsburgh and Britain, Germany, France, Italy, Spain and the Netherlands, a spokesman, David Castelveter, said. The additions, to be completed by June 16, restore all the carrier's trans-Atlantic service except for 14 weekly flights between Charlotte and Paris.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank Raises Executive Pay
description: Switzerland's biggest bank, UBS, increased compensation for its 45 top executives and directors last year by 18 percent, to $195 million, as profit fell by more than a third. The company, which is based in Zurich, paid $70 million, or 36 percent of the total, to six PaineWebber managers, including the chairman and chief executive, Joseph Grano, who joined in November 2000 after UBS bought the brokerage for $11.5 billion, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The increase in compensation was tied to guaranteed contracts signed in 2000 when UBS bought PaineWebber, a UBS spokesman, Axel Langer, said.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle on Thursday provided an erroneous clue for 6 Down, seeking the answer ''Custer.'' ''Scalper's victim'' did not work because although Gen. George Custer was killed in the battle of Little Bighorn, his body was not mutilated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi To Sell Unit
description: Vivendi Universal agreed yesterday to sell 49 percent of the Polish phone company Elektrim Telekomunikacja to investors led by Citigroup Inc. to focus on its media business. Vivendi invested $1.2 billion in the Polish company in 1999. Analysts estimate its stake is now worth about 500 million euros ($441 million). Vivendi's chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, has spent $50 billion on acquisitions in the last 18 months to turn the 149-year-old company from a sewage and water business into a rival of AOL Time Warner Inc. Vivendi is now looking to focus on media and trim its 19.1 billion euros ($16.86 billion) in debt.

title: A Wise Investment in Foreign Aid
description: President Bush's plan to add $5 billion to the foreign aid budget shows that his administration, like the rest of America, is rethinking the importance of helping underdeveloped countries in the wake of Sept. 11. Obviously, that is a good thing -- not only because, as Mr. Bush noted, the money may ease the hopelessness that breeds terrorism. Foreign aid, well spent, will also liberate entrepreneurial energies, protect human rights and help millions achieve better lives.

title: Nixon Daughters Battle Over $19 Million Library Bequest
description: A long-simmering battle within the Nixon family has burst into the open with the filing of two lawsuits over who should control a $19 million bequest to Richard M. Nixon's presidential library from one of his closest friends, Bebe Rebozo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, ALICE DUPONT
description: MILLS-Alice duPont, of Middleburg, VA and Hobe Sound, FL, died March 13, 2002 at the age of 89, after a brief illness. Born in Wilmington, Delaware on December 13, 1912, Mrs. Mills was the daughter of the late A. Felix duPont and Mary Chichester duPont. After graduating from Oldfields, Mrs. Mills pursued a wide variety of interests. An advanced instrumentrated aircraft pilot, she flew an open-cockpit plane up the Amazon River in 1932 along with her late brother, Richard C. duPont. During World War II, she served as a flight instructor for military pilots in Long Island, N.Y., and upon the war's conclusion, piloted one of the pioneer single-engine airplane flights between New York and Buenos Aires with her husband, the late James Paul Mills, whom she married in 1935. Upon moving to Middleburg, Virginia in 1949, Mrs. Mills continued her involvement in philanthropic activities, environmental affairs and Thoroughbred horse racing. She pioneered numerous family planning programs in the course of her work for Planned Parenthood in Northern Virginia, and served as a member of Planned Parenthood's national board of directors, as well as local chairperson for its Mineola, NY chapter. Mrs. Mills was an active proponent of conservation efforts in Virginia, and in serving as founding member of the Piedmont Environmental Council and the Bull Run Conservancy, and later as Trustee of Virginia Outdoors Foundation, championed the preservation of scenic open spaces through conservation easement programs. As past chairperson and trustee of the Chichester duPont Foundation, Mrs. Mills promoted the efforts of numerous not-for-profit organizations throughout the nation. Her life-long passion for Thoroughbred horse racing and breeding was evidenced by numerous stakeswinners campaigned through her Hickory Tree Farm near Middleburg, including Believe It, Devils' Bag, Gone West, Gorytus, Glad Rags II and Hagley. Mrs. Mills was a member of Virginia Thoroughbred Association, and served as Trustee of the Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association. Her philanthropic efforts on behalf of Thoroughbred racing and Breeding included service as a founding member of the Marion duPont Scott Equine Medical Center, as Advisory Trustee to the National Museum of Racing, and as past Director of the Grayson-Jockey Club Research Foundation. Mrs. Mills was honored as 1991's Outstanding Owner/Breeder by the Virginia Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Assocation, and received the Kentucky Thoroughbred Breeders Association's Ladies' Sportsmanship Award in 1970. Mrs. Mills was predeceased by her husband, James Paul Mills, Sr., in 1987. She is survived by her daughters Mimi (Mrs. J. William) Abel Smith, of Middleburg, Virginia, and Phyllis (Mrs. James B.) Wyeth, of Chadds Ford, Pennsylvania; her son, James P. Mills, Jr., of Middleburg, and her grandchildren: Richard P. Mills, of New York and Sophie E. Mills of Rehoboth Beach, Delaware. A memorial Service will be held 4 PM, Saturday March 23, at the Grace Episcopal Church, the Plains, Virginia.

title: Editorial Notebook; From the Pulpit, a Borrowed Word
description: Plagiarism is an ugly word and an all-encompassing one. We make more distinction among degrees of murder than we do among kinds of plagiarism. I wish I were sure that a quest for scholarly purity lay behind the charges that have recently been raised against some name-brand writers. Some seem more than just, others look more like an attempt at forced profit-sharing.

title: Countries differ in baby care : Giving birth, far from home
description: First-rate obstetricians, state-of-the art hospitals and excellent neonatal care  great, you say. But if it's not home, the best place in the world to have a baby will probably not be good enough. Going through a pregnancy in a foreign country can be a daunting prospect, especially if your language skills are poor.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EDENS & AVANT, Columbia, S.C., and Samuels & Associates, Boston, two closely held retail property investors, have formed a joint venture to buy 40 of the 60 shopping centers owned by Konover & Associates Inc., Farmington, Conn., a closely held developer. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Viacom Shifts an Insider to Be Chief of Infinity Radio Unit
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that John Sykes, president of VH1, would take over as chairman and chief executive of its Infinity Radio division.

title: History and the Bible: Reflections on Judaism
description: To the Editor:

title: It Ain't Over Till It's On Court TV
description: BASEBALL is on its way. If you're one of those whose eyelids are now starting to feel heavy, this may be the time to turn the page. No doubt there is something new in the Enron follies to keep you in stitches.

title: Europe's Military Gap
description: In live-fire exercises here, the German heavy infantry battalion, the 421st Panzergrenadiers, look terrific, scooting out of Marder armored personnel carriers with new G-36 rifles, while the gunner clobbers a tank on the horizon with 20-millimeter shells.

title: Pettitte Uses His Head And Saves His Elbow
description: Andy Pettitte gave up singles to the first three hitters who faced him this spring, and that triggered his impulse to compete. Pettitte started throwing his four-seam fastball, a pitch requiring maximum effort. It was too much, too soon, and Pettitte strained his elbow.

title: U.S. and North Korea Hold High-Level Discussion
description: A senior American diplomat met this week with North Korea's ambassador to the United Nations in the highest-level bilateral talks since President Bush denounced North Korea as part of an ''axis of evil,'' the State Department said today.

title: Security Breach Delays 4 Flights
description: A concourse at Newark Airport was evacuated yesterday afternoon after a vendor's cart went through security without being searched, the authorities said. Concourse B1, occupied by Delta and Northwest Airlines, was evacuated and passengers were rescreened, causing delays in four Delta flights, said Dan Lewis, a spokesman for the airline.

title: Zimbabwe's False Friends
description: Robert Mugabe's declaration of victory in the presidential elections held last weekend in Zimbabwe was, despite his unpopularity, hardly a surprise. He had already tweaked the system in so many ways that such an outcome was nearly inevitable. As Morgan Tsvangirai, who lost to Mr. Mugabe, said, the election was stolen in a ''daylight robbery.'' It is neither surprising nor inappropriate, therefore, that most Western supporters of democracy have condemned the elections. What is a surprise and a tremendous disappointment is the endorsement of the elections by the Organization of African Unity, which had sent an observer team.

title: Friendly Gestures: Israeli Modern Dance With Israeli-Arab Music
description: Ohad Naharin is the director of the Batsheva Dance Company of Tel Aviv and an Israeli modern-dance choreographer whose work has been performed worldwide. His ''Naharin's Virus,'' based on Peter Handke's absurdist play, will be performed by Batsheva at the Brooklyn Academy of Music April 30 to May 4. Created in 2000 amid Israeli-Palestinian violence, ''Naharin's Virus'' is set in part to music by an Arab-Israeli composer, Habib Alla Jamal. Mr. Naharin spoke to Jennifer Dunning in by telephone on a visit to Manhattan late last month.

title: UConn Finally Shakes Off Pesky Pirates
description: In the tunnel of the MCI Center about 10 minutes before tip-off today, the Connecticut Huskies put their arms around one another, pogo-hopped and chanted frantically, ''Are you ready?'' The answer was always ''Yes.'' It took all 40 minutes of basketball, but UConn proved that it was, indeed, ready for Hampton.

title: Malays in Singapore
description: To the Editor:

title: Allied Troops, Mopping Up, Find Pockets Of Resistance
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that while American and coalition troops were conducting mop-up operations in the Shah-i-Kot Valley and surrounding mountains, there were still pockets of resistance from Al Qaeda and the Taliban in ''a number of locations'' throughout Afghanistan and just across the border in Pakistan and Iran.

title: The First Enron Indictment
description: Arthur Andersen, one of the most venerable names in corporate America, has now become the first major accounting firm ever indicted, as a result of its role in the demise of Enron. Although the case involves only a single count of obstruction of justice, the steady flow of clients bolting to find a new auditor is likely to become a tidal wave.

title: Watch Out for Magenta Days
description: The White House is so happy with its new color-coded rankings for warnings of terrorist threats -- red for severe risk, blue for general risk and so on -- that plans are afoot to expand the system. Why stop at a few colors -- or one kind of risk? Americans need as much information about potential dangers as they can get. Here's what a more complete system looks like.

title: Promotions of 15 Police Officers Upheld After Union Sought Ban
description: The New York Police Department did not circumvent a court order barring some police reassignments when it promoted 15 members of the emergency services unit in February without consulting the police union, a State Supreme Court judge ruled yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Tarkanian, Ever a Rebel, Ever a Coach
description: JERRY TARKANIAN held the news conference yesterday that he had dreaded all his career. He announced his retirement from coaching after 31 years in Division I.

title: After Defeat of Judge, Lott Plans to Block Daschle Aide
description: The partisan battle over judicial nominations intensified today as Senator Trent Lott, the minority leader, struck out at the Senate Judiciary Committee and moved to block an aide to Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, from filling a spot on the Federal Communications Commission.

title: 6 Airbus Jets to Have Special Tail Inspections
description: Looking for damage to the tails of Airbus airplanes like the one that crashed in Queens on Nov. 12, American and French aviation experts have selected six planes around the world for detailed inspection because they experienced unusual strains in flight.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about legal tactics used by Roman Catholic dioceses in sexual abuse cases against priests referred incorrectly to steps taken by the Archdiocese of Philadelphia in response to accusations. While it has given prosecutors the names of accused priests, it has not disclosed them to the public.

title: In Religious Tinderbox, India Snuffs Spark
description: Today was the day on which the country had braced for the worst under Hindu hard-liners' threats to conduct a prayer session on land where they had already torn down a 16th-century mosque.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Deadlock In Corruption Trial
description: A federal jury reported that it was deadlocked after three days of deliberations in the trial of a former state prosecutor. The former prosecutor, T. J. Hively of Batesville, was originally charged with 64 counts of fraud, racketeering and extortion. After the prosecution rested, Judge James Moody of Federal District Court dismissed all but 15 counts. He ordered prosecutors and defense lawyers to submit briefs on whether a mistrial should be declared or the charges dismissed.

title: TWO PENSION FUNDS OPPOSE HEWLETT PURCHASE
description: The New York State Teachers Retirement Fund and the Public Employees' Retirement Association of Colorado said yesterday that they opposed the Hewlett-Packard Company's planned $24 billion acquisition of Compaq Computer. The decisions by the funds, which together control 8.2 million Hewlett-Packard shares, less than 1 percent, strengthen public opposition before Tuesday's shareholder vote on the deal. Other pension funds controlling a smaller number of combined shares declared themselves in favor of the purchase. The New York State Teachers Retirement Fund will vote its seven million shares of Hewlett-Packard and its seven million Compaq shares against the deal, a spokesman, Dave Daly, said. The Colorado pension fund owns about 1.2 million Hewlett-Packard shares.

title: As Tanks Leave City, Ramallah Is Defiant
description: The Israeli Army pulled out of here early this morning, leaving behind numerous cars flattened by tanks, homes shattered by searches and residents loudly proclaiming victory. Most of the militants the Israelis were seeking, however, had run away to hide.

title: LONGTIME CLIENTS ABANDON AUDITOR
description: Longtime clients, the federal government and even some of its own foreign affiliates abandoned Arthur Andersen yesterday, a day after the accounting firm was indicted for destroying Enron documents.

title: Con Ed Agrees to Pay for Cleaner Air Near Power Plant
description: In a settlement with neighbors and environmental groups, Consolidated Edison has agreed to set aside $3.7 million to address air pollution concerns stemming from plans to increase the power output from its plant at East 14th Street in Manhattan.

title: Time for Candor in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg Says Teacher Pact Isn't Tied to Mayoral Control
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged yesterday that he would not be able to hold up negotiating a contract for the city's 80,000 teachers until he gained control of the school system.

title: Miramax Films Cuts 75 Jobs After Some Recent Setbacks
description: Miramax Films, the movie studio run by Harvey Weinstein, who backed such hits as ''Shakespeare in Love'' and ''Good Will Hunting,'' notified 75 employees today that they were either being laid off or that their contracts would not be renewed, Miramax said today.

title: Coast Guard Encounters Big Hurdles In New Effort to Screen Arriving Ships
description: Shortly after Sept. 11, the Coast Guard began a program that requires every commercial ship destined for the United States to send the authorities a list of crew members' names 96 hours before docking, so that they can determine whether any terrorists are on board.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''Yugoslavia, the Avoidable War'' misidentified the faction that the documentary, directed by George Bogdanich, accuses of displaying bodies to inflame international opinion against the Serbs. It is the Kosovo Liberation Army, not the Bosnian Muslims.

title: Burn Victim Is Charged With Killing Wife in Fire
description: A man whose wife died in a suspicious fire in their Leonia apartment in November was arrested today on murder charges and accused of starting the fire, the authorities said.

title: Another Coaching Reunion
description: Back in the mid-1990's, John Phillips was coaching a Tulsa high school team when the University of Tulsa coach, Tubby Smith, went to watch one of his players. Smith was not recruiting the player. It was more of a courtesy visit.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Wednesday inaccurately described a Sept. 16, 1920, bombing in New York's financial district. The bomb damaged, but did not blow up, the House of Morgan, which is still standing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KARTER, LARRY
description: KARTER-LARRY. MARCH 16, 1996 LOVE NEVER DIES JA

title: Corrections
description: The Diner's Journal column in Weekend yesterday, about the Kai restaurant in Manhattan, misstated the name of the tea shop beneath the restaurant, at 822 Madison Avenue (69th Street). It is Ito En, not Kai.

title: A Plea to America, From a Friend
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Nixon's Daughters at Odds

title: Pittsburgh and Knight Stop Central Connecticut's Streak
description: Trailing by 6 points minutes into their game with Central Connecticut State, the Pittsburgh Panthers had no trouble remembering that they were playing a team that had won its last 19 games. Pittsburgh may have been a prohibitive favorite, and the only team in the this year's N.C.A.A. tournament that did not have to leave the city limits to play its first-round game, but there are sobering realities about the final stage of college basketball's season that routinely overtake expectations.

title: St. John's Is Forced to Leave Empty-Handed
description: It was all too familiar, from St. John's demonic defense sending bodies flying all over the court to ill-fated shots caroming off the backboards. Finally, a hard-working team was escorted from a tournament it may not have belonged in.

title: Gilmore T. Schjeldahl, Early Satellite Builder, Dies at 89
description: Gilmore T. Schjeldahl, an enterprising American inventor whose knowledge of plastics, adhesives and electronics enabled him to create the world's first communications satellite, died on Sunday in the Berkshire community of Lenox, Mass., his hometown since 1999. He was 89 and had earlier lived in the Minneapolis area for five decades.

title: Funeral for Slain Priest Draws an Overflow Crowd
description: They gathered, gasping, in front of their small church on Tuesday as word spread that their priest and a parishioner had been killed, and they gathered the next two days to pray and offer condolences as the body of the Rev. Lawrence M. Penzes lay in state.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: School Principal To Quit
description: The principal of a high school in a Kansas City suburb that is embroiled in a plagiarism case has announced his resignation. The principal of Piper High School, Michael Adams, will leave at the end of the school year. This winter, a teacher there gave 28 of her 118 biology students zeroes on a botany project, saying they had copied material. Mr. Adams supported the decision, but after parents complained to the school board, the district superintendent ordered the grades changed. Daniel I. Dorfman (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Accord On Transportation Spending
description: The Legislature passed an $8 million transportation package just before concluding a 60-day session, finding common ground on an issue that forced three special sessions last year. The plan, which includes a 9-cent gasoline tax increase, will be a referendum on the November ballot. Business and labor groups, backed by Gov. Gary Locke, a Democrat, had hoped legislators would resolve the issue without a referendum, but House leaders threatened to kill the plan unless it went to the voters. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Sense of Loyalty Keeps Many at Auditing Firm Focused on Their Jobs
description: ''What's next?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFAND, AUDREY REAL
description: HELFAND-Audrey Real. On March 15, 2002. Beloved wife of William H. Helfand, loving mother of Rachel Frankel and Jessica Drenttel, dear sister of Gladys Guralnik, devoted grandmother of Samuel & Sarah Frankel, and Malcolm and Fiona Drenttel. Service Sunday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to The National Jewish Hospital and Research Center, Denver, Colorado.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Fame Can't Excuse a Plagiarist
description: Since the revelations of plagiarism by the popular historians Stephen Ambrose and Doris Kearns Goodwin, commentators have been wrestling with the nature of literary theft. It's been interesting to see this from my vantage point as the so-called wronged party in the Goodwin case. Ms. Goodwin's book, ''The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys,'' contained many sections that were copied from my book, ''Kathleen Kennedy: Her Life and Times.''

title: Getting best therapy isn't easy : Special needs, tough choices
description: BERLIN  I wait anxiously in Berlin's Tempelhof airport as my son Liam wanders about the terminal, a glorified bus depot. Before I know it, he climbs onto the baggage ramp. He doesn't understand he will get the bag back at the end of his trip. Liam screams "no plane, no plane," and I smile meekly at the air hostesses as I drag him on, my hands cupped under his armpits as he performs his civil disobedience slump. In a moment of weakness, I pull the special needs card. "He has a developmental delay," I say. They look puzzled.

title: Chicago, in Black and White
description: Demographers have described Chicago as a ''hyper-segregated'' city where blacks and whites are less likely to live on the same block -- or encounter each other on the sidewalk -- than almost anywhere else in the country. Chicago's Roman Catholic archbishop, Cardinal Francis George, confronted this problem in a powerful pastoral letter last spring. He admonished priests, nuns and lay people who had refused ''to welcome even Catholic African Americans into parishes and schools.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Rightist Candidate Sees Conspiracy
description: Jean-Marie Le Pen, the far-right politician, accused President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of trying to keep him off the ballot in the presidential election next month. Mr. Le Pen, leader of the antiforeigner National Front party, said he was more than 100 names short of the 500 signatures of elected politicians needed to qualify for the race. He said Mr. Chirac and Mr. Jospin, who are the main candidates, were pressing politicians not to give him their signatures. Aides dismissed the assertions. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Bosnia Prison Warden Sentenced
description: A former mathematics teacher who became a prison warden in Bosnia was sentenced to seven and a half years for aiding and abetting war crimes in 1992 and 1993. Judges at the United Nations war crimes tribunal said Milorad Krnojelac, 61, a Bosnian Serb who was in the Yugoslav Army reserve, had failed to stop guards under his command from abusing hundreds of Muslims at the KP-Dom prison in the town of Foca. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Top Banker Resigns
description: The chairman of Russia's central bank, Viktor Geraschenko, left, resigned, apparently under pressure from the Kremlin, which has long wanted the bank to adopt a more progressive monetary policy. Mr. Geraschenko, 64, became chairman in September 1998 after a financial panic and collapse that devastated the Russian economy. He has since been widely attacked by reformers for blocking an overhaul of Russia's banking system, something he vehemently opposed in a message to Parliament yesterday. President Vladimir V. Putin proposed that Sergei Ignatyev, a deputy finance minister with a reputation for technical expertise and honesty, replace Mr. Geraschenko. Mr. Ignatyev is an architect of the administration's own banking-reform proposals.

title: Falls of Towers And the Rise Of Polish Poetry
description: Who could have foreseen the poetic ripples of Sept. 11? A week after the attack, Adam Zagajewski's poem ''Try to Praise the Mutilated World,'' written long before that day, ran on The New Yorker's back page. Czeslaw Milosz's poem ''The Multi-Storied Man'' seemed uncomfortably relevant. And Wislawa Szymborska's poem ''The Terrorist, He's Watching,'' composed a quarter of a century ago, came to look like a premonition. Innocent America became a land of experience. Postwar Polish poetry became eerily pertinent.

title: A Glow of Spring
description: On the Paris runways last week it was fall and winter, but for the audience going to the shows, spring was breaking out all over. Balmy weather encouraged women to celebrate the coming season by wearing clothes that had personality plus. There was a can't-be-ignored flower-embroidered white leather coat and matching boots, by Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, and a laced skirt, by Gucci, worn with a supple fur jacket, the rage of the fashion world. Also on parade were pants or full skirts topped with interestingly cut detailed jackets; a North African cape wrapped  la Rodin (below left); and a white jacket with fur trim. Shoes by Azzedine Alaa had lacings (far right, center) and a pair from Cesare Paciotti had dangling fur trim. No wonder the Paris shows, shown nightly on television, are as popular as sitcoms.

title: Less Than Meets the Ear
description: With the revival of newsboy caps and asymmetrical bobs, it was predictable that the one-earring look wouldn't be far behind. The fashion began resurfacing earlier this year, when the Chlo designer Phoebe Philo introduced supersized single rhinestone arrow earrings, left, ($42 at Chlo). Last month, a former model, Jo Reynolds, came out with a line of solo danglers in the shapes of dice, dragonflies, hearts and silver feathers ($40 to $60 at Kirna Zabte). And now Barneys New York has stocked up on Erickson Beamon's beaded strands of brown, tan, beige and smoky topaz ''singulars'' ($72 to $114). Bear in mind that the most popular versions are large and chunky. On a practical level, though, you always have one unencumbered ear left for your phone. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

Each weekday, Mr. Breitweiser, 39, would return from his job as a senior vice president at Fiduciary Trust International at 2 World Trade Center, sit on the living room couch in their New Jersey house, and snuggle with his wife for a few minutes.
