title: Yuk-Ping Wong: Admired for Her Brilliance
description: Yuk-Ping Wong, known as Winnie, went to college after raising her sons, Eddie, 22, and Christopher, 18. ''It was tough,'' said her sister, Ariane Yuk-Ling Leung. ''In Chinese culture, usually people go to school when they're younger. She felt somewhat out of place in the classes.''

title: Mulberry Street Residents Grow Weary Of Living in a Round-the-Clock Mall
description: Lillian Tozzi has lived on Mulberry Street all her life, but for five months out of the year, she barely recognizes her block.

title: Music; For Joi, Timing Is Everything
description: JOI is an R & B singer from Atlanta with gold-plated credentials. She is married to Big Gipp, from the hip-hop group Goodie Mob. She has worked with the producers Dallas Austin and Organized Noize -- who have known how to make a great R & B record at various points over the last 10 years. She's forthrightly freaky and, as such, right on time in the Macy Gray-obsessed pop world.

title: Postings: 372-Unit Building in Long Island City; Leasing Begins At Avalon Site
description: Five weeks ago after opening the leasing office at Avalon Riverview, a luxury rental tower in Long Island City overlooking the East River, Karen Rosado has noticed that tenants who have signed leases have arrived with different goals, depending on where they come from. ''The people from Manhattan are looking for savings in rents and the people from Queens want a luxury environment,'' said Ms. Rosado, the sales and marketing manager for New York and New Jersey for AvalonBay Communities.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE CONFESSIONS OF MYCROFT HOLMES, by Marcel Theroux. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14.) Though the title is a tease about sibling rivalry (Mycroft is Sherlock's smarter, lazier brother), this clever novel is at heart a multilayered mystery about a television journalist who makes a peculiar discovery when he moves to a small island off Cape Cod, the forces at play in the author's own literary family and, above all, the power of imagination. The result is a ''subtle and intelligent book'' that ''moves forward with a pleasant, unthrillerish pressure,'' John Lanchester wrote here last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENWICK, HUGH HAMMOND
description: FENWICK-Hugh Hammond. Of Bernardsville, on March 16, 2002. Beloved husband of Joyce K. Handy Fenwick. Son of the late Hugh McLeod and the Honorable Millicent Hammond Fenwick. Father of Angela Francesca Romana Fenwick, Mark Hammond, Hugh Wyatt, Sibyl Stevens, Leigh Hammond and Bayard Stevens Fenwick. Grandfather of Constanza Graziani, Alexandre and Sebastien Fenwick. Brother of the late Mary Stevens Fenwick Reckford (1987) and Maureen Fenwick Quinn. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 23, 2002, 11 AM, at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church, Claremont Rd., Bernardsville. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to the Somerset Hills Visiting Nurse Association, 12 Olcott Ave., Bernardsville, NJ 07924 would be appreciated. For information or directions, Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home, 908766-0250 or gcfuneralhome.com

title: Planting Harmony and Healing
description: From the 8th to the 14th centuries in Spain, Christians, Jews, and Muslims coexisted peacefully in an era that historians refer to as the ''convivencia,'' or living together. On Thursday at 3:45 p.m., the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, will open a ''Garden of Remembrance: A Memorial to September 11,'' inspired by the gardens of the convivencia. Baptist, Episcopal, Catholic, Jewish and Muslim religious leaders will participate in the dedication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISINGER, ALBERT
description: EISINGER-Albert. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Albert Eisinger. Albert was the beloved father of Andrea Leeds and father-in-law of Michael Leeds, cherished friends and supporters of our mission, who are devoted to maintaining a strong and vital Jewish community on Long Island and throughtout the world. We extend our deepest sympathies to Albert's wife, Harriet, to Andrea and Michael and their children, Caryn, Lauren, and Tracy, and to Andrea's sister and brother-in-law, Susan and Richard Arluck, and their children, David and Jessica. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Board Chair Erika Witover, LI Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO Stuart Tauber, LI Regional Dir.

title: Investing; Immediate Seating, Low Cover Charge
description: THE value of seats on the nation's options exchanges has been plunging. Traders who paid as much as $19,500 a month to do business on the American Stock Exchange in August 2000 are now signing leases for as little as $1,500 a month.

title: Suspect Thy Neighbor
description: AMERICAN JIHAD

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You've got a great number of people that you want to find and you've got a certain amount of dirt that's left. And there's a gap. That gap is going to be a sorrowful one.''

title: Dubliners
description: AT SWIM, TWO BOYS

title: Dance; A Big New Ballet That Mirrors America
description: ELIOT FELD is probably the last choreographer from whom one would expect a piece of wholehearted Americana. True, Mr. Feld has created ballets with American themes. But he is going all out in ''Lincoln Portrait,'' which will be performed by his Ballet Tech at the Joyce Theater on April 2, the opening night of the company's five-week spring season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAITTA, CONSTANCE C.
description: SAITTA-Constance C. On March 14, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Francis. Devoted aunt of many nieces and nephews. Loving friend of Eva Francis. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 14920 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, St. Michaels R.C. Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting Sunday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to you favorite charity in her name would be appreciated.

title: Music; Two Views Of a Singular Work
description: AMID the surfeit of performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' in New York every December, one has consistently stood out in recent years. The annual presentation by the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys and the period-instrument Concert Royal, conducted by Gerre Hancock, is typically considered the best of the lot. So it is a happy occasion when these performers busy themselves ''off season'' with another Baroque monument, as they do on Tuesday in Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' (very much in season, of course).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFEN, RABBI SAMUEL
description: GEFFEN-Rabbi Samuel. Blessed by God with the length of days of 95 years, a gracious, kind and gentle ''Rabbi in Israel'' for over 60 years. Loved by wife Ruth (Rosenfield), son Peter, daughterin-law Susie Kessler, grandchildren Jonah, Daniel and Nessa, brother and sister-in-law Dr. Abraham and Ethel Geffen, sisters Bessie Wilensky and Helen Ziff, scores of nephews and nieces of the Simon, Wilenski, Raskas, Ziff, Rosenfield and Marks-Vogel families. Funeral services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St and Amsterdam, in NYC, 11 AM, Monday. Memorial contributions to The Abraham Joshua Heschel High School Capital campaign.

title: The Long, Humbling Quest For a Job in Technology
description: THREE years ago, anyone with a computer science degree and a pulse could practically name his price in the job market as companies scrambled to dodge doomsday Y2K possibilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALLOWES, ALICE
description: FALLOWES-Alice. On March 11, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Dear mother of Lloyd and Russ. Adored grandmother and greatgrandmother.

title: Fading Out
description: AS soon as I arrived in New York in 1961, an 11-year-old, wide-eyed newcomer, I got to know the pleasure of nonstop classical music on the radio. We had brought an old portable from Poland, and I fell asleep each night with it playing by my ear.

title: Europe: Festivals 2002; Music Season In a Lower Key
description: THE oldest European music festivals are by no means the sleepiest. Indeed, the two most venerable, the Bayreuth Festival in Germany and the Salzburg Festival in Austria, have generated the most news in recent years, both having been embroiled in often contentious transitions in leadership.

title: March 10-16: NATIONAL; ANDERSEN CHARGED
description: It was the week when Arthur Andersen, the giant accounting firm, began to be held to account -- in a criminal court. Prosecutors announced that Andersen had been indicted for destroying records relating to Enron, the former energy trading giant. Andersen, which has lost clients in the wake of the Enron debacle, had been given the choice of pleading guilty or being indicted. Instead, it came out swinging, refusing to cut a deal and accusing prosecutors of high-handed, abusive tactics. Kurt Eichenwald

title: For Renters, Late Winter Is Beach Weather
description: MAUREEN McCORMICK looked around the office at James C. Otten Real Estate and saw no typical March weekend flurry of activity. In previous years, the place would be bustling with families and couples grabbing keys to rentals that they hoped would be the answer to their summer shore dreams.

title: MEDICAL LABORATORY
description: The state Department of Health and Senior Services closed a medical lab in Newark for altering test results. The department estimated that almost 4,000 people used the lab, Medical Laboratory of Ironbound, since January 2001 and urged them to be tested again by a physician. The laboratory has said it would bear the cost of any retesting. John Holl

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the change in the name of Enron Field as a reflection of a recurring American theme -- trying to reinvent one's past -- misstated the amount of time spent in prison by the financier Michael R. Milken. It was 1 year 10 months, not 3 years.

title: March 10-16: NATIONAL; M.P.G. OR G.P.M.?
description: Last year, S.U.V.'s, pickups and minivans outsold passenger cars. The Senate encouraged the trend by rejecting higher mileage standards for automobiles and voting to turn the matter over to the Bush team. ''This is a disappointing day for everyone who is serious about reducing America's dependence on foreign oil,'' said Senator John Kerry, a Democrat. Senator Christopher Bond, a Republican, said Mr. Kerry's plan to raise standards would have forced drivers to trade in trucks for ''glorified golf carts.'' Danny Hakim

title: Dr. King's Highway Should Say 'Dr. King,' Critics Argue
description: Debbie Rose, a community board member, fought hard in the late 1980's to rename the 1.5-mile Willowbrook Parkway the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Expressway. ''We hoped to unify the island with a visual reminder of Dr. King's legacy of unity and peace,'' she said.

title: Cling to a Dream (or Call It a Day)
description: LISTEN up, Michelle Kwan. It pains me to say this, but I think it's time to get over that Olympic gold thing. I know it's been a lifelong dream, but how many times can you triple-lutz around an ice rink and depart without that coveted medal? How long can you follow your bliss?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARHART, AMORY S.
description: CARHART-Amory S., 82. On March 8, 2002, in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. A gentleman who thoroughly enjoyed life. Attended Brooks School, 1937-1940. Enlisted in U.S. Navy December 1941 and served on USS Yorktown. Worked for American Express, 1947-1971. Predeceased by his wife, Lucile H. Carhart. Survived by his sister, Marion Carhart Marsh, daughter, Wendy H. Carhart, son, Amory S. Carhart, Jr. and his wife, Karen, and grandson, Amory S. Carhart III. Burial private. Memorial service to celebrate his life to be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Lahey Hospital Foundation, Burlington, MA, Brooks School, North Andover, MA., or Southampton Volunteer Fire Department, Windmill Lane, Southampton, New York.

title: Bridge Tolls: Silver Lining In a Budget Of Gloom?
description: The area in the shadow of the Queensboro Bridge is loud and dirty. Many of those who live in it, like Barry Schneider, have long believed that reinstating the toll on the bridge, which was abolished in 1911, would lessen the gritty cloud of rush hour.

title: Sports of The Times; Strawberry's Forfeit of Sympathy From a Seat in the County Jail
description: IT'S never easy to write about Darryl Strawberry. He's such a tragic figure, he attracts sympathy. But he's such a sordid figure, he has forfeited sympathy.

title: CUTS AT ROWAN
description: In response to state budget cuts, Rowan University's president, Donald Farish, last week announced plans to close four affiliate operations and lay off 18 full-time employees, with more reductions to be announced next month. The facilities being closed are the Glassboro Center for the Arts, which manages the school's theater and recital hall; the Pinelands Institute, a program for schoolchildren; the Curriculum Development Council, which trains teachers in South Jersey's poorer school districts; and the Urban and Public Policy Institute, which generates urban student outreach projects.

title: Ideas & Trends; America's Problem With Modern Art
description: OYEZ, oyez, oyez. Comes now the Jewish Museum in New York City with this season's high art controversy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONDLIFFE, JANE R.
description: CONDLIFFE-Jane R. There will be a Memorial Service for Jane R. Condliffe on Saturday, March 30th at 3 PM at the Riverdale Yacht Club, 254 St and the Hudson River.

title: The Breeders Are Still At It
description: The Phoenix Hotel, in downtown San Francisco, is favored by touring bands for its easygoing vibe, 50's-motor-lodge dcor and in-house nightclub. Tonight, though, Room 19 looks more like a slumber party than a den of iniquity. The interview with the Breeders, scheduled for 12:45 a.m., does not get under way until some time after 2. That's when Kim Deal, the band's singer and guitarist, wanders in, dressed in a Cleveland Browns T-shirt and black jeans. Waiting patiently on her single bed is Kim's twin sister, Kelley, wearing plaid pajamas and high ponytail -- a girlish counterpoint to the flecks of gray at her temples. Kelley has been executing the final knits and purls for a two-tone wool clutch. She sells her handbags for $40 each, plus shipping, on her personal Web site.

title: The View From/Fairfield; A Radio Show's Lineup: Women's Sports Only
description: TANDALEYA WILDER never liked being called a tomboy by the kids in her neighborhood in Western Philadelphia. In fact, she hated it.

title: Pilgrimage Completes Romance With Basketball
description: I was raised to disdain commercialized sports like basketball.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 3 about the ways in which artists respond to catastrophic events misstated the year in which the philosopher Theodor Adorno retracted his statement that ''to write poetry after Auschwitz is barbaric.'' The retraction, contained in his book ''Negative Dialectics,'' was first published in 1966, not 1973.

title: Not by the Arts Alone
description: It's one thing to pass legislation calling for development of an arts district. It is another to make the district a reality.

title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Editor
description: FOR several months in the summer and fall of 1999, Maplewood was a crucial location for the exotic film ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.''

title: Struggling to Pass
description: THE FALL OF ROME

title: When Sober Houses Become Part of the Neighborhood
description: FREQUENTLY, when a group of people in recovery from alcohol or other drug addiction move into a neighborhood, surrounding residents fear the worst.

title: Abbey Lincoln; Familiar Tunes
description: To the Editor:

title: As Scandal Keeps Growing, Church and Its Faithful Reel
description: By Tuesday, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Portland, Me., has promised to turn over to local prosecutors a file containing all accusations of sexual misconduct involving its priests. The district attorney wants to see every accusation ever made against a living priest.

title: U.N. to Open Rights Review With U.S. On Sidelines
description: The United Nations' chief human rights body, composed of 53 nations, will begin on Monday its annual review of abuses worldwide facing concerns that the international commitment to human rights is being eroded by the war against terrorism.

title: Private Sector; Quiet on the Big Question
description: Swiss banks are maintaining as much of their trademark secrecy as they can over how much they pay the people who run their Wall Street operations.

title: The World: About Face; What Does He Want? The Enigma That Is Sharon
description: THERE are times, as they bestride the carnage and chaos here, that Ariel Sharon and Yasir Arafat seem a little like Godzilla and Mothra, roused from political slumber to fight out their antediluvian rivalry over the vulnerable heads of a terrified city. Indomitable and rubbery, equipped with mysterious powers, the two have laid waste to offices, stores, airports and lives -- so far without mortally wounding each other.

title: The Shadow Pharmacopeia
description: POP into the Fresh Farm bodega in Jamaica, Queens, for an apple and, while waiting for a cashier, you may be astonished by what's lurking behind the counter. Has this store on Sutphin Boulevard been zapped in from the 19th century? How else to explain the unusual cornucopia of unguents, nerve tonics, salves, coconut cough medicines, oddly named healing oils and eerie elixirs stacked ceiling high?

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF you're thinking of a summer vacation in Maine, you may want to consider other destinations after viewing LAKE PLACID (1999), a droll creature film pitting Bill Pullman, Bridget Fonda and Oliver Platt against a very large crocodile that has inexplicably turned up in a Maine lake. (Yes, Maine lake. The locals had wanted to call it Lake Placid, but someone told them the name was already taken.) It's a horror film with humor, played with a wink beginning to end. Shown a severed toe and asked if it might belong to a missing man, the local sheriff (Brendan Gleeson) says, ''He looked taller'' -- Friday at 9 p.m. and Saturday at 7 p.m. on USA.

title: Denied Claims A Factor in Mammograms
description: To the Editor:

title: A Showman And His Showcase
description: LAVISH in scale and unashamedly theatrical.'' This, in a nutshell, is the style associated with the star designer and director Franco Zeffirelli as he himself defined it in his autobiography 16 years ago. He stages opera the way De Mille filmed ''The Ten Commandments,'' and he drenches movies in the pathos of opera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALVAREZ, JOSEPHINE
description: ALVAREZ-Josephine. On March 15, 2002, of Pelham Manor, NY. Wife of the late Joseph Alvarez. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 1 PM, Our Lady Queen of Peace Chapel, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. For information contact Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY.

title: The Wearing Out Of The Green, Alas
description: IN the second season of ''The Sopranos,'' the young mob soldier Christopher Moltisanti survives a shooting and wakes up in the hospital, claiming to have had a life-after-death experience. While he was dead, he says gravely, he went to hell. And hell was an Irish pub where it was St. Patrick's Day all the time.

title: CORRECTIONS CHIEF
description: Last week Governor McGreevey named his 17th and last cabinet choice, for the Department of Corrections: Devon Brown, a corrections official in the District of Columbia who began his career as a prison psychologist in Trenton. Mr. Brown held several posts in Maryland, serving as director of the Montgomery County corrections department, before he was appointed deputy trustee of the system in Washington, run by the federal government. The governor said Mr. Brown would conduct a reappraisal of the department, which has had an acting commissioner since Jack Terhune resigned 15 months ago after a series of blunders. Laura Mansnerus

title: Theft by Teammates Is a Troubling Issue
description: An official with the New Orleans Saints was asked last week to compare two ugly incidents, one involving a former player on his team, Albert Connell, accused by the police three months ago of stealing thousands of dollars from a teammate. The other centered on Ruben Rivera, who stole the glove of Derek Jeter and sold it to a memorabilia dealer, leading to the Yankees' cutting Rivera.

title: March 10-16: NUCLEAR ARMS; PROPOSED NUCLEAR OVERHAUL
description: A secret Pentagon planning document calls for creating limited-capacity nuclear weapons suited to targets in Iraq, Iran, North Korea, Syria and Libya. The report cites the need for burrowing weapons that can destroy fortified underground bunkers, including those that might store chemical and biological weapons. At the same time, it finds that conventional weapons are increasingly important in Pentagon planning. Critics here and abroad say the report blurs the distinction between nuclear and conventional weapons, and if its outlines are followed -- which is not certain -- could lower the threshold for use of nuclear arms.

title: Graceful Dark Ruby Wine
description: The fragment of Ionic scrollwork on the label of Pindar's 1998 Mythology suggests the grace of this dark ruby wine.

title: Where Used Books Never Die
description: SMALL bookstores on Long Island have been struggling to survive for years, overwhelmed by the big chains and the dot-coms. Most modern bookstores are supermarkets, dedicated to the quick processing of ephemeral best sellers with the shelf life of uncooked shrimp. Forty thousand new titles are published every year, which keeps the big booksellers busy. But what happens to these glossy new books when they drop off the best-seller lists and are deleted from the publishers' databases?

title: Entering the Era Of Marketing
description: THE music was salsa, and the art was Soviet. Some people were dancing, and some were content just to look at the paintings. The place? New Brunswick, at last month's edition of the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum's ''First Thursdays: Art After Hours,'' in which the museum, on Rutgers' New Brunswick campus, stays open late on the first Thursday of most months, offering music and guided tours.

title: Striking Down Gag In Asharoken
description: A Feb. 24 article in the Long Island section of The New York Times [''Down by the Sound, a Free Speech Debate''] described a dispute in the village of Asharoken, which recently adopted an ordinance that imposes a $1,000 fine on village trustees who divulge matters that occurred in executive sessions of the village board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLING, LORAN. RETIRED COLONEL
description: WILLING-Loran. Retired Colonel, age 76 of Alpharetta, GA. Died Thursday, March 14, 2002. Colonel Willing was a US Army Veteran who served in WWII and Korea. He is survived by his wife Jean Willing of Alpharetta; daughters and sons-in-law, Melissa and Steven Rice of Commack, NY; Cheryl and Richard Engelmann of Alpharetta; sons and daughters-inlaw, Matthew and Elizabeth Willing of Huntington, NY; Lindsay and Kimberly Willing of West Babylon, NY; Richard Louer of East Northport, NY; sister, Yvette Abrams of Aventura, FL; brotherin-law, Robert and Betty Rockwell of Ormond Beach, FL; grandchildren, James Kollen, Mathew Eli Willing, Nicholas Willing and Richard Tyler Engelmann; nephew, Matthew and Jordan Bell. Funeral services will be Sunday, March 17, 2002, 2:30pm in the chapel, Rabbi Shalom Lewis officiating. Burial, Arlington Memorial Park with full military honors. For information Louie E. Jones Funeral Home, 59 North Main St., Alpharetta, GA; 770-475-6554.

title: INVESTING WITH/Jeremy J. Hosking; Vanguard Global Equity Fund
description: THE biggest investment bargains in the world are found in Southeast Asia, says Jeremy J. Hosking, who runs the $145 million Vanguard Global Equity fund.

title: Is Kmart Out of Stock in Answers?
description: ATTENTION, Kmart executives: In the white-hot world of discount retailing, your services may no longer be required.

title: Heroes and Helpers Are Admired for Putting the Needs of Others First
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: MONTCLAIR CONNECTION
description: The opening of the long-awaited Montclair Connection, New Jersey Transit's rail line that will provide direct service from the Montclair area to Midtown Manhattan, has been pushed back yet again, this time from spring until September. The $63 million project, which will be used by an estimated 3,700 people a day, has been postponed because the 40 new cars needed for the line will not arrive until then. Cars that had been designated for the Montclair Connection were shifted to other lines when ridership increased dramatically after Sept. 11.

title: Sudanese Foes Give Consent For Relief Aid For Civilians
description: An international effort led by the United States to expand the area where aid workers can operate safely in Sudan's civil war, one of Africa's longest, has borne fruit with word that aid may soon be flowing to thousands of civilians isolated in a rugged mountain region.

title: 6,000 American Prints Take Over Stamford's Advocate Building
description: FOR nearly 80 years, the stone building at 258 Atlantic Street in downtown Stamford, built in 1894 and remodeled in 1928, was home to the offices of Stamford's Advocate newspaper and its printing plant. In the 1980's, it was occupied by a series of architects and designers, and briefly by a dot.com company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the DataBank page last Sunday about the performance of financial markets misstated employment figures for February from the Labor Department. Total nonfarm payroll jobs rose by 66,000; only jobs in manufacturing declined, by 55,000.

title: Catching a Second Wind
description: THERE'S an old saying that goes, ''When the last child leaves for college and the dog dies, the mother finally has a life.'' As I reared my two daughters, Christie and Beth, and chased after our dog, Alex, I looked forward to this promise like my eternal reward.

title: Post-Ripken Orioles In Transition Game
description: First there were the Robinsons, Brooks and Frank, and Boog Powell, Davey Johnson, Mark Belanger, Paul Blair, Jim Palmer and Dave McNally. Then came Don Baylor, Bobby Grich and Mike Cuellar and Al Bumbry, Doug DeCinces, Ken Singleton and Mike Flanagan, then Rick Dempsey, Scott McGregor, Tippy Martinez and Rich Dauer. Eddie Murray arrived, and soon after Cal Ripken.

title: Mega Stores Revive A Somers Shopping Center
description: After years of vacancy, the shopping center at the corner of Routes 6 and 118 in Baldwin Place is reawakening as Somers Commons. First to open was HomeGoods, some 25,000 square feet of off-price home dcor merchandise. Headquartered in Massachusetts, HomeGoods has a another store in Yonkers.

title: Rangers Fall to Devils And Into Ninth Place
description: With the end of the regular season less than a month away, the Rangers have become hockey's equivalent of the movie ''Groundhog Day.'' They keep awakening to find their playoff hopes slipping away.

title: New Take on Old Worry: Paying the Rent
description: FOR five years, Marc and Wendy Ducker have lived in a one-bedroom apartment at the Norwich Gate complex. They couldn't afford it on their own, but based on their $2,000 monthly income, the Duckers are among the 70 tenants at the unpretentious 348-unit complex who qualify for a federal subsidy, knocking their monthly rent down from $1,400 to $600.

title: Wendy Maidman, Scott Bremen
description: Wendy Lane Maidman, a daughter of Nancy and David Maidman of New York, was married last evening to Scott Phillip Bremen, a son of Eve and Ronald Bremen of Glencoe, Ill. Rabbi Peter Rubenstein performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in New York.

title: It's Christmas Again for Missouri in Victory Over Ohio State
description: The calendar points to March, but it sure seems as if it is December again for the Missouri Tigers.

title: Pakistan Seethes as the Militants Lash Out
description: On Tuesday evening, Dr. Anwarul Islam, a prominent surgeon, was leaving the hospital and about to get into his car when two men pulled up on motorcycles and cut him down.

title: Letting the Workers Roam
description: The travel industry slump caused by the Sept. 11 attacks extended to sales of travel guidebooks, which had been growing steadily. But Lonely Planet, the publisher of off-the-beaten-track guides, found a way to avoid layoffs: it slashed the pay of wanderlust-stricken employees and let them wander.

title: Professor Speaks Out About Hartford Suit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMANN, ROBERT JESSE SPENCE
description: FRIEDMANN-Robert Jesse Spence. On March 15, 2002. Beloved husband of Mary Felter Friedmann. Dear father of Beverly and Jacki Friedmann. Dear brother of Peter Friedmann and Toni Gales. Services Tuesday March 19th, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations can be made in Robert's name to the American Stroke Association, 2550 Route 1, North Brunswick, NJ 08902, 1-800634-1242 or strokeassociation.org

title: Band of Brothers
description: SOLDIERS

title: Art/Architecture; Peering Under the Skin of Monsters
description: I WAS living in Hitler's private apartment when his death was announced,'' the photographer Lee Miller wrote to her editor at Vogue in May 1945. She had just come from photographing piles of corpses at Dachau, an experience that left her with a lifelong animus toward Germany. Now, billeted with American soldiers in a seemingly ordinary Munich apartment where the china and linen were marked with swastikas and initialed A.H., she had her picture taken while sitting at the Fhrer's desk and bathing in his bathtub. Three blocks away, in a villa belonging to Eva Braun, she napped on the bed and tried the telephone marked ''Berlin.''

title: March 10-16: NUCLEAR ARMS; BOMB IDENTITY
description: Russia and the U.S. hope to sign a pact in May slashing their nuclear arsenals, as soon as the sides agree on one nit: what a nuclear weapon is. Washington would cut its 6,000-warhead force below 2,200, but ''warehouse'' some of the excess for use in an emergency. Moscow, which would cut its force to 1,500, says a warehoused bomb is still a bomb -- and that if Washington stores its excess, it may too. Michael Wines

title: A Rebound for Hedge Funds
description: Hedge funds around the world attracted record-breaking amounts of money last year, according to a new survey.

title: Pinkeye Cases Baffle 2 Ivy League Colleges
description: No one can say for certain how a nasty little infection could have traveled across several states, plaguing more than 1,000 college students.

title: The Puffing G.I., and Other Tobacco Tales
description: To the Editor:

title: Central America's Cities Grow Bigger, and Poorer
description: Armina de Jess lives on a road where signs warn ''Enter At Your Own Risk'' after an earthquake unleashed tons of rocks on it last year. But she cannot afford to move, since it took her 12 years to build the shack that barely survived the quake.

title: Shoes Redefine Moonwalk
description: For those happy to leap from high heels to high-tech footwear, manufacturers are introducing a batch of shoes and sneakers that are so elaborately engineered, they fairly addle the brain. This month, Adidas introduced ClimaCool sneakers, left, ($100 at Foot Locker), designed to keep feet cool with a ''360-degree ventilation system'' that includes an open mesh top (like a porch screen for the feet) as well as vents in the back and soles. Come summer, New Balance will update its N-ERGY engineering from last fall into a men's BB1000 basketball shoe, above left, ($200 at New Balance stores), which features a dual suspension system to absorb shock, reduce energy loss and enhance balance. Nike similarly soups up the basketball shoe with Vince Carter's signature Nike Shox BB4 model ($200 at Niketown stores), which has a cup design that wraps up the heel to provide lateral stability and a column design that absorbs shock throughout the foot and minimizes the stress of body weight. For spectators, Modellista shoes ($75 to $125 at Nordstrom) gives the clog a space-age makeover, top, with Tempur PRT insoles made from a pressure-relieving material developed by NASA (and used in Tempur-Pedic Swedish Sleep System mattresses and pillows). The shoes, oddly squishy and exceedingly comfortable, have an antibacterial lining to boot.

title: Commercial Property/Cooling Office Buildings; On Avenue of the Americas, the Iceman Cometh
description: TO cope with the high price and uncertain reliability of electric power in Manhattan, Douglas and Jody Durst, the co-presidents of the Durst Organization, a major commercial landlord, have chosen an unlikely alternative: ice.

title: Buying a Co-op: It's Buying Stock
description: WHILE contracts for the sale of real estate outside the New York City area are typically for private homes, many contracts within the city, and certainly most in Manhattan, are for co-op or condominium apartments. While condominium contracts are similar in many respects to contracts for the sale of a house -- after all, a condominium is legally considered real estate in the same way a house is -- contracts for co-op apartments have their own sets of rules.

title: More Mammograms Set In Carmel by Medical Group
description: To the Editor:

title: A Missing Perspective In the Milford Murders
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Terps in Perfect Spot, So Expect the Worst
description: BE careful what you ask for.

title: Aria of the Lesbian Dwarf Diaper Fetishist
description: The current sensation at the Battersea Arts Center in London delves into the themes of any number of beloved operas: infidelity and misdirected love, rage and untimely death. An aging diva, cheated by life, sings a heart-rending aria expressing her profound weariness with failure: ''I've had enough of dying/I just want to dance.'' But the gavotte is nowhere in this diva's thoughts -- her dream is to become a professional lap dancer, working the pole in some squalid dive. Such is the seamy lyricism of ''Jerry Springer: The Opera.''

title: Tom Ridge's Homeland Silences
description: Tom Ridge, head of the Office of Homeland Security, is in the news a lot. This month, he was in Mexico to negotiate a new border agreement. The other day he was unveiling a new color-coded warning system on threats to public safety. He holds news conferences about the administration's plans to defend the nation against terrorism. But one place Mr. Ridge has not appeared is before the Congressional committees that oversee and finance homeland security operations. At the White House's request, Mr. Ridge is refusing to answer Congressional questions in public. That is beyond puzzling, and the Bush administration should unmuzzle him immediately.

title: Dara Kaplan, Courtney Mann
description: Dara Beth Kaplan, a daughter of Dr. Cynthia Kaplan and Dr. Martin Kaplan of Stony Brook, N.Y., was married last evening to Courtney Evan Mann, a son of Sherry and Gary Mann of Highland Park, Ill. Rabbi Alan Abraham Kay performed the ceremony at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York.

title: QUICK BITE/Asbury Park; They Take the Courses and You Eat Them
description: ''Some people think if they are in black and white, they can be a waiter,'' said Michael Sirianni, who teaches Dining Room I and Dining Room II at the Culinary Education Center in Asbury Park. ''But we need to pay closer attention to taking care of guests and remembering what service is.'' The three-year-old center, a collaboration between Brookdale Community College and the Monmouth County Vocational School District, offers associate degrees in culinary arts and food service management. The students prepare breakfast, lunch and dinner for the public at Restaurant Mandolin in the center, where diners can watch through windows as students cook dishes like salmon bisque, frise and radish salad, dandelion greens with Camembert, duck pt, steak with peppercorns, trout amandine, and veal with sweet Vermont sage. Student waiters in black aprons, jackets and bow ties, mindful of their lessons, glide between kitchen and tables in the teal dining room as recorded piano music purrs. For dinner, lights are dimmed and candles and flowers decorate each table. A three course  la carte lunch costs about $10. A four-course dinner costs $12 to $18. The center also operates La Bakery, which sells student-baked croissants (60 cents), doughnuts (30 cents), Danish pastries, tortes ($6.50), Italian bread ($1), cookies (30 to 50 cents), pies ($3 to $4.50) and cakes ($4 to $10.50). Margo Nash

title: Madeline Uybico, Edward Pulling
description: Madeline Chu Uybico, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eusebio Uybico of Bacolod, the Philippines, was married on Friday to Edward Leffingwell Pulling, the son of Lisa Semple of New York and Thomas L. Pulling of Oyster Bay, N.Y. The Rev. John McGrath performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Hong Kong.

title: Midair Meals
description: To the Editor: I recently flew from Chennai to Cochin, India, and back on Jet Airways, a recent addition to India's air options, and was fed a complete, tasty meal in each direction on flights that lasted only 50 minutes! This service included real cutlery.

title: The Nation: Calculation vs. Conscience; The Church Breaks Faith With the Faithful
description: A prince of the Roman Catholic Church, sitting surrounded by his bishops and priests, was recently denounced by members of his flock.

title: Fire Badly Damages A Queens Church
description: Flames tore through a Roman Catholic church in Queens early yesterday morning, destroying many of its sacred objects and the garments worn by priests and charring part of the church's altar, the authorities said. One firefighter was treated for minor injuries.

title: FOR YOUNG VIEWERS
description: MISSING TEXT

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about designs of manhole covers misattributed a recent comission for a series that will show buildings or sites no longer in existence. The project is by Michele Brody, an artist, with support from the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council and other organizations. It was not commissioned by the Public Art Fund.

title: Many Doctors Shun Patients With Medicare
description: For the first time, significant numbers of doctors are refusing to take new Medicare patients, saying the government now pays them too little to cover the costs of caring for the elderly.

title: March 10-16: HEALTH; FINE IN TRANSPLANT DEATH
description: Blaming Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan for providing ''woefully inadequate postsurgical care'' to a patient who died on Jan. 13, three days after donating part of his liver to his brother, the State Health Department fined the hospital $48,000. Mount Sinai, a world leader in using live donors to provide liver transplants for adult recipients, is also banned from performing such transplants for at least six months. The patient, Mike Hurewitz, 57, vomited blood and died from inhaling it on an afternoon when one inexperienced resident was left in charge of 34 patients in a transplant unit. Denise Grady

title: Playing Holiday
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS: March 17, 2002
description: Weeks

title: March 10-16; FRONT LINES
description: MIDEAST: The week began with Israel lifting some travel restrictions on the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat -- a significant concession from the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, who, by pinioning Mr. Arafat in his Ramallah compound for months, had hoped to encourage war-weary Palestinians to choose another leader. What does Sharon really want? Page 1.

title: Hudson County Squabbling Is Just Shocking, Shocking
description: The political scuffle between Representative Bob Menendez and Mayor Glenn Cunningham of Jersey City, two Democrats, has erupted into a battle of brooms.

title: Travel Advisory; Hawaii Is Still Wary As Dengue Fever Eases
description: With six cases of dengue fever reported on Maui this month, visitors to the Hawaiian island are being reminded to be cautious when visiting the damp east Maui area. Of a statewide total of 117 confirmed cases of dengue since last June, 88 were from Maui (mostly from Hana, in the east); 25 were from Oahu (primarily on the windward side); and 4 were from Kauai.

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Alfred R. Kahn, 55

title: Personal Business; Networking and Social Graces Aren't Incompatible
description: WHILE attending a wedding reception last December in Great Neck, N.Y., Andrea Nierenberg, a corporate trainer from Manhattan, thought it was a little odd when the guest seated across from her began passing out business cards. At first, she went along with it, thinking that he was just outgoing.

title: Unrest Worries An Israeli At Cal
description: At least once a day, Cal forward Amit Tamir scours Internet news services, scrolling briskly past the icons for the N.C.A.A. tournament's March Madness in silent discomfort.

title: Corrections
description: The Choice Tables column on Jan. 27, about Florence, Italy, misidentified the region of Italy associated with winter squash flavored with amaretti, an antipasto served at Zibibbo. A reader's letter dated Feb. 27 points out that the region is Lombardy, not Emilia-Romagna.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRECKIR, ALBERT
description: BRECKIR-Albert. Happy Birthday, Bill Bailey! Your Family

title: Charity and Its Rewards
description: Millions of people opened their hearts and their wallets after Sept. 11, donating cash and goods to nationwide relief efforts. Now, during tax season, comes the chance to take a deduction for those gifts.

title: An Urban Ritual: The Tiles That Bind
description: THE smooth clicking of the Bakelite tiles lulled me into a contented silence. I stared at the eight hands swirling them around on the worn wooden table and realized that it did not matter who was playing. The ritual mixing, or ''washing,'' of the tiles always went on longer than necessary.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''Dot.Con: The Greatest Story Ever Sold,'' on Page 14 of the Book Review today, refers erroneously to action taken in 1998 by the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, to lower interest rates. The Fed lowered the federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks; it did not lower the prime rate, which it does not control, though that rate normally follows the target rate closely.

title: Knight Departs Gracefully And Early
description: It had been a long and in many ways gratifying season for Bob Knight, gratifying, surely, even though his Texas Tech team went out in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, losing to Southern Illinois, 76-68, on Friday night. He had returned from the ignominy of being dismissed by Indiana University for behavior often unbecoming to an adult, let alone someone with professorial rank at a state institution of higher learning.

title: March 10-16: NATIONAL; NO TO PICKERING
description: Senate Democrats sent a message to President Bush by rejecting his efforts to elevate Judge Charles W. Pickering Sr. of Mississippi to a federal appeals court post. Voting on party lines, the Judiciary Committee's 10 Democrats used their one-vote majority to defeat the nomination. Some said they hoped that Mr. Bush's first defeat on a judicial nomination might persuade him to take their views more into account and send up fewer staunch conservatives and more moderates. Neil A. Lewis

title: Required Course: Bully Prevention
description: ALTHOUGH he's now a New Rochelle High School freshman, Max Robkoff hasn't forgotten the teasing he endured in elementary and middle school. ''They called me stuttering Stanley,'' he said, because of his speech impediment and attention deficit disorder. ''They would bug me and beat me up. Then it stopped, but some kids still taunt me.''

title: What If The Big Five Turn Into A Final Four?
description: LAST week, the Justice Department indicted Arthur Andersen on a charge of obstructing justice in the destruction of documents related to the Enron investigation.

title: Jones Emerges to Establish a Blueprint for UConn
description: As Otis Forney Jr. watched his daughter dominate Connecticut's 86-37 victory over St. Francis of Pennsylvania today in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. women's tournament, he said he felt as if he were watching a flower blossom in slow motion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEMPLE, WILLIAM
description: WEMPLE-William, 89, of Charlottesville, VA, died at his home on February 25, 2002. He was a partner for 50 years at the NYC law firm, Dewey Ballantine. He is survived by his brother, F.H. Wemple of Plandome, NY; by his seven children, Littlepaige Wemple and Katherine Holland (Holly) Wemple of Charlottesville, William Barent Wemple of Hartsdale, NY, Leslie W. Jones of Mount Pleasant, SC, Wendy Wemple Johnson of New Hartford, CT, Stephanie W. Corbell of Crozet, VA, and Liane Ashley Wemple of London, England, a nephew, three nieces and six grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be made to the Waverly Genealogical & Historical Society, 359 E. Tremont, Waverly, IL 62692.

description: FOR several years Nitzy Cohen-Fitzgerald, owner of International Basics, a company in Westport, tried doing business in Africa.

description: BY THE LAKE

title: Investing; Seeking Buried Treasure, The Old-Fashioned Way
description: INVESTORS are showing renewed interest in small mining exploration companies that live in the hope of hitting the next mother lode. The sector, speculative in the best of times, has been troubled recently by slumping metal prices and scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARKAVY, ESTHER
description: HARKAVY-Esther. On March 15, 2002, at the age of 97 years. Beloved wife of the late Morris Harkavy. Mother of Justice Ira B. Harkavy, his wife Roberta, and the late Stuart Harkavy. Grandmother of Steven J. Harkavy, his wife Jodi; Daniel J. Harkavy, his wife Jody; and Elliot. Great-grandmother of Melissa A. Harkavy, Brian R. Harkavy and Stephanie R. Harkavy. Services Sunday, March 17, 2002 at noon, at Weinstein-GarlickKirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. Shiva will be observed through Friday morning.

title: Return the Letters
description: A friend placed a personal ad and received more responses than he could contact, so he offered some of those letters to me and another of our friends. This second friend took a few, but I declined, believing it wrong of friend No. 1 to pass along these letters. The people who wrote them wanted to hear from the man in the ad, not from some stranger. Was I right or just a prude? William Dwyer, Florida

title: Isle of White
description: THE HORIZONTAL EVEREST

title: Music; Tapping an Audience With an Ear to the Ground
description: TODAY the term entrepreneur is reserved for people who engage in business ventures. It's certainly not a word often associated with musicians. Which makes it interesting that according to the New Oxford English Dictionary, entrepreneur once referred to ''a director of a musical institution; a person who organizes entertainments, especially musical performances.''

title: Travel Advisory; Houses and Gardens: A Southern Collection
description: Tours of homes and gardens are a rite of spring in the South, with some of the best known in South Carolina, Georgia and Virginia.

title: The Light Is in New York, Its Creators in New Jersey
description: Chances are most people never heard of Paul Marantz or Charles Stone. But if they live in the New York area, they probably saw the men's work in the last few days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLI, PIZZI, LOUIS J.
description: DELLI-PIZZI-Louis J. The Morgagni Medical Society mourns the loss of former President Louis J. Delli-Pizzi and extends its sympathy to his wife Joan and his family. We also extend our sympathy to his sister Antonia E. DelliPizzi, M.D., his nephew Peter Sordillo, M.D. and to his niece Emilia Mia Sordillo, M.D., all three of whom are members of the society. Dr. Delli-Pizzi's wisdom, judgement and warmth will be missed by the society. Peter Sordillo, M.D., President The Morgagni Medical Society

title: Tennis Pro by Way of Fairfield
description: THE first ripples that James Blake was headed toward a nationally-recognized tennis career came when he was a youngster in Fairfield.

title: Do All These Tests Help Students?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, MILLARD
description: STEWART-Millard. Died March 14, 2002, at age 77. He is survived by his devoted wife, Carrie Stewart, children: Lisha Cole and John Stewart, son-in-law, Leroy Cole, daughter-in-law, Girsie Stewart, niece Gail Starling, favorite cousin, Ollivia Woods, nephew, Millard Thomas Starling, great-nephew, Seneca Louis Laws, grandchildren: Leory III, Jerome, Vincent, Girsondra, Kaven, and Kedren. Visitation/wake: Sunday, March 17, 2002, 2-6 PM, at the Robert F. Cranford Funeral Home, 203 DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral service: Monday, March 18, 2002, at 11 AM, at the Emmanuel Baptist Church, 279 Lafayette Avenue. Viewing begins at 10 AM.

title: Seeking a Seat at the Table
description: THE benches along the Brighton Beach boardwalk were packed. It was 40 degrees, and the sky had been scrubbed clean by a determined wind. Yet there they sat, the aging and aged, taking in the sun beneath great mounds of fur coats, homburgs, leather jackets, scarves and sunglasses. Men gathered around a chessboard, their pawns and kings marching strategically through the afternoon.

title: Overnight, a Quaint Hotel Is Home for the Homeless
description: During the last three years, neighbors of the Hotel Ellington on West 111th Street between Broadway and Riverside Drive grew used to seeing busloads of wealthy Europeans entering the marbled lobby. They were relieved that the former single-room occupancy and AIDS hospice with the turn-of-the-century stone facade had been converted into one of the city's quainter boutique hotels, catering also to parents of Columbia University students.

title: Superfund Sites and Whitman's New Quandary
description: THE Bush administration's efforts to scale back the number of polluted sites to be cleaned up under the Superfund program may hit New Jersey especially hard.

title: Girls' Hats Take Flight
description: Cheryl Cuzco's new Easter hats dress little girls in traditional, Sunday-best millinery -- with an untraditional twist. The hand-rolled straw hats, below, ($42 to $58 at Space Kiddets, sizes 6 months to 8 years, (212) 420-9878) come in pastels, jewel tones or natural blond trimmed with grosgrain ribbon. Each is topped with one of Ms. Cuzco's trademark silk birds: a bluebird peering around the crown, a cardinal nesting on a brim. Even the youngest customer can feel like the grandest lady in the Easter parade.

title: A Drug Will Cost Less. For Whom?
description: TO the dismay of some doctors and a few big drug companies, Dr. Robert C. Seidman may soon be able to say he helped save the health care system hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercedes-Benz C320 and BMW 325i; Solid German Architecture Under Those Stylish Roofs
description: SOMETIMES it all comes down to a roofline. Take two cars that are, on paper, almost identical, with scarcely any difference in height, width and wheelbase. Each has a six-cylinder engine and similar safety features.

title: Film; Everybody Loves a Clown, Except the Oscar Voters
description: WHEN Rene Zellweger's Academy Award nomination for ''Bridget Jones's Diary'' was announced last month, show-biz prognosticators were shocked. It wasn't that they disliked the performance, a winsome blend of English adroitness and American emotional transparency, or that they minimized Ms. Zellweger's physical transformation. (Or her bravery: is there a greater risk for a female Hollywood star than adding fat cells to her body?) They were surprised because ''Bridget Jones's Diary'' is a broad romantic comedy with a healthy dose of slapstick. In movies, pratfalls and comic humiliations can lead to popularity and riches -- but almost never to a golden statuette.

title: Television/Radio; In Richter's Universe, the Sidekick Is the Star
description: ANDY RICHTER wanted to shoot his new sitcom in New York. Too expensive, he was told. He argued for at least setting the show in Manhattan. Too NBC, he was told. Now, with ''Andy Richter Controls the Universe'' ready to make its debut Tuesday at 8:30 p.m. on Fox, Mr. Richter would just like to be in New York, where he lived while serving as sidekick on ''Late Night With Conan O'Brien.''

title: Rutgers's President Search Is Just Beginning
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HATCH, PETER
description: HATCH-Peter. Of NYC, died March 3, 2002 at the age of 80. A funeral service was held on March 7 at the First Presbyterian Church, New York City. Burial was at the Cedar Hill Cemetery, Hartford, CT. He is fondly remembered by his wife of forty years, Jane Maddox Hatch, a brother, Christopher of Dorset, Vermont, and a niece and nephew, Carol Cidney Hatch and James Hatch, both of NYC.

title: Dance; The Many Ways to Salvage Dances Long Undanced
description: A BALLET is performed. But how did it find its way onstage?

title: CRIME
description: ''Subtlety'' is a word you won't find in Jeffery Deaver's dictionary. The hero of his white-knuckle thriller THE STONE MONKEY (Simon & Schuster, $25), a quadriplegic forensics genius named Lincoln Rhyme who directs elaborate criminal investigations from his $3,000 customized bed, is the ''last hope'' of government agencies clamoring for his aid in capturing the master criminal who sank a ship of illegal Chinese immigrants off the coast of Long Island. Rhyme's quarry, a sinister shapeshifter known as the Ghost, is ''probably the most dangerous human smuggler in the world,'' and two desperate families will die if this fiend is not caught in the next 48 hours. Ticktock-ticktock-tick. . . .

title: Killer Songs
description: Simon Bikindi is Rwanda's most famous musician. He is also one of the country's most famous accused war criminals. He was arrested last July at a center for asylum seekers in the Netherlands, and he sits now in a Dutch jail awaiting extradition to Tanzania, where the tribunal investigating Rwandan war crimes is convened. The ''statement of facts'' in his six-count indictment runs to 46 paragraphs, but the charges against him focus on his music: in essence, Bikindi is accused of inciting genocide with his songs.

title: Nonprofit Groups Reach For Profits on the Side
description: In its last fiscal year, the Metropolitan Museum of Art's shops, restaurants, parking garages and other commercial endeavors produced $96.6 million in revenues, or almost three times as much as its next largest source of income, admissions and membership fees.

title: Editors' Note; EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article last Sunday satirized the plagiarism problems of the historian Doris Kearns Goodwin, who has recently acknowledged that she borrowed scores of passages from other authors without credit in her 1987 book ''The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys.'' The article depicted another of her books, ''Wait Till Next Year'' (1997), a memoir about growing up a Brooklyn Dodgers fan, as a pastiche of borrowings from well-known scenes by other baseball authors and from baseball movies.

title: Theater; The Briton Who Revived 'Oklahoma!'
description: A LESS tenacious, obstinate or driven director might have given up the battle, but Trevor Nunn was always determined to give New York theatergoers a chance to see the makeover of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''Oklahoma!,'' which he staged at the National Theater here in 1998. And why not? The production, praised by almost every reviewer for its freshness, moved to the West End, drew the crowds and, Mr. Nunn would like to think, still has something fundamental to say about the values and virtues of America.

title: Victory or Martyrdom. 'So How Could They Retreat So Easily?'
description: Following are excerpts from a letter found in a house used by Al Qaeda members in Kabul. Handwritten in Arabic by an unknown author, it appears to describe a battle between Arabs allied with the Taliban and Northern Alliance forces. The letter, which includes poetry that appears to have been written by the author, was translated by The New York Times.

title: Band of Outsiders
description: The history of modern popular music can be seen, to some degree, anyway, as a series of happy accidents -- from Elvis stumbling into Sun Studio to make a vanity record in 1953 to Paul and John meeting at a church festival to a certain scrawny band from Dublin changing its name from the Hype to U2. Still: who would have thought that one of the happiest musical accidents in recent memory would be the discovery, in a thrift shop, of some lo-fi recordings made in the mid-1970's by a few dozen Canadian schoolchildren?

title: For Women, the Price of Success
description: IT has been four years since Sylvia Ann Hewlett set out to write a book celebrating the achievements of what she calls ''the breakthrough generation'' -- women facing 50 at the millennium who ''broke through the barriers and became powerful figures in fields previously dominated by men.'' She started on her project by interviewing high-achieving, high-earning women like Jessye Norman, Diane Sawyer and Donna Shalala.

title: Brandon J. Buchanan: The Winner Within
description: There was talent and there was diligence, and then there was luck shining through Brandon J. Buchanan's days. Take the time he entered a contest, sponsored by Bloomingdale's, a block from his apartment, where the prize was a Ducati motorcycle. He really wanted to win. He hadn't heard anything, said his father, Ron, so he phoned the store one day to ask who had won.

title: Beck's 198-Track Mind
description: Out of the 8,000 songs Beck has downloaded onto his hard drive, he's got a rotating mix of hundreds on his iPod that he updates daily. This is what Beck was listening to on Feb. 27, 2002.

title: Leading Girl Scouts: It's His Job
description: CHLOE EFFRON concedes it's not the kind of thing one gives much thought to: ''You think about it just being there, not invented,'' she said.

title: N.F.L. Owners to Discuss A Super Bowl in the East
description: If the 2007 Super Bowl is to be played in the New York metropolitan area or in Washington, part of the groundwork for the game could be created here today at the N.F.L. owners' annual meeting.

title: MISS AMERICA STAFF
description: Less than two weeks after taking over as interim chief executive of the Miss America Organization, George Bauer dismissed two vice presidents hired by his predecessor, saying he was trying to save money. They were the vice president for marketing, John Kincade, and the vice president for operations, Libbi Taylor. Mr. Bauer's predecessor, Robert M. Renneisen Jr., resigned his $250,000-a-year job as chief on March 1 after threatening to move the pageant out of Atlantic City if the state and city did not come up with more money. Local officials set up a committee to aid the pageant, but Mr. Renneisen refused to let them look at the organization's books. Robert Strauss

title: March 10-16: NATIONAL; LATE NIGHTLINE
description: David Letterman decided to stay with CBS, despite ABC's offer to give him the 11:35 p.m. slot occupied for the last 22 years by Ted Koppel's ''Nightline.'' And ABC has not satisfied Mr. Koppel's subsequent request for a statement of unequivocal support for his show. Bill Carter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHMAN, ANN
description: HIRSCHMAN-Ann. The President, Trustees, Faculty and Student Body of Touro College and Touro University extend our kos tanchumim to our distinguished Board member & outstanding physician, Dr. Sholom Hirschman, on the passing of his beloved mother of blessed memory. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Bernard Lander, President Dr. Mark Hasten, Board Chairman

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Wild Card Of the Recovery: Inflation
description: THE amazing strength of the American economy, despite the recession, has economists scrambling for explanations. Consumer resilience is much cited. So is price cutting. Who can resist a bargain, even in hard times? Less noticed, but crucial, is the boost that came from a declining inflation rate.

title: Word for Word/Temper, Temper; From bin Laden's Native Land, A Voice to Calm the Angry American
description: KHALED AL-MAEENA, the editor in chief of the English-language Saudi newspaper Arab News, is an unabashed America-lover. He studied in the United States, sent four of his five children to American colleges and, with a tiny budget, built a newspaper staff of young Saudi men and women who are required to speak flawless English.

title: The Puffing G.I., and Other Tobacco Tales
description: To the Editor:

title: Oh, the Pipes Are Calling, and Calling Still; A Somber St. Patrick's Day Parade for a Fire Department Bagpiper
description: Perhaps no one person could have embodied the many emotions of yesterday's St. Patrick's Day Parade in Midtown, emotions that reached beyond ethnic pride to include the stab of remembered terror, the ache of fresh absence, the affirming joy of life. Still, consider Christopher Walsh: firefighter and bagpiper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENSTEIN, MIRIAM
description: SCHOENSTEIN-Miriam. On July 27, 2001. When we said ''goodbye'' to you last summer, each of us spoke your loss in our hearts and individual expressions. Today we come together to celebrate your 91st birthday in memory and in joy. Your children, Shira and Irv, Judy & Ralph, your grandchildren, Wallace, Jill and Loren, Eve-Lynn and David, and Lori, and your great-grandchildren, Mia and Max, light the candles of love and thankfulness as your spirit remains a constant in our lives. Your caring for us all continues as blessing.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Arthur Baker (left) and Felix da Housecat, London, March 3, 2002

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Eric Nederlander; All His World's a Stage
description: HE surely doesn't want to hear any more about the wife who left him, three months after their honeymoon, because she met Jerry Seinfeld at the gym and decided to become Mrs. Seinfeld. Except for that twist, Eric Nederlander, 36, is pretty much set.

title: Islanders' Playoff Push Takes Back Seat
description: Inside the visitors' dressing room at the Corel Centre tonight, the Islanders locked the door to talk about how badly they played in their 4-3 loss to the Ottawa Senators, and what they could do to improve.

title: Airport Assistance
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Airlines Help Kids Flying Solo'' (Practical Traveler, Feb. 3) and ''Catering to the Elderly Can Pay Off,'' (Money & Business section, Seniority column, Feb. 3):My mother has the time and the money to travel, but will no longer fly unaccompanied. She does not need assistance on the plane, or getting to or from the airport, but she does require assistance in the terminal. The confusion of security, check-ins, gate assignments, and especially the transfer between one airline's Gate A1 and another's Gate Z99 is more than she will attempt to tackle by herself.

title: Palestinian Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Blowing Smoke
description: TOBACCO

title: In a Drought, Hung Out to Dry
description: IS the pool half empty or half full?

title: Whitney York, John Lancaster
description: Whitney Mossy York and Neville John Lancaster Jr. were married in New Orleans last evening by Maurice J. Hartson III, a Roman Catholic deacon, at the Most Holy Name of Jesus Church.

title: An Inspiration for van Gogh Is Still Vibrant
description: THE year 1886 was a turning point in the tumultuous life of 33-year-old Vincent van Gogh. In the spring he moved to Paris, saving money by living with his brother Theo, an art dealer. The young painter met and was influenced by Degas, Monet, Pissarro, Seurat and other Impressionists. He painted steadily, and as the seasons progressed he chose to portray a host of floral subjects, including daffodils, fritillaries, hellebores, pansies, peonies, roses and chrysanthemums. During this time van Gogh created at least one painting featuring the sunflowers that he immortalized time and again later in his career.

title: Famous for Being Super
description: They're an odd, self-consciously neurotic bunch, one that includes a superhero with skin so unbearably sensitive to others' bodies that their rapid heartbeats or ''the saliva rushing around their mouths'' induces despair -- he plays Russian roulette each evening with a revolver beside his bed. Among their number is also a wolfish boy -- a student of Harold Bloom's -- who is ''able to tear through steel walls with his teeth and claws,'' and there's a peeved African-American whose skin emits flesh- and metal-melting acidic sweat. He declares, ''I'm a black mutant. In this country, that's like being black with a little black added,'' and believes the superhero business is -- well, business: ''Internal conflict. Struggles for ascendancy. Personal enmities. Isn't that the kind of thing that keeps people interested in us? I mean, we can't be fighting bad guys all the time.'' Proceeding from the assumption that given a world containing scores of superheroes, at least one bunch of them will prove to be media-manipulating cynics, we are offered X-FORCE: New Beginnings (Marvel Comics, paper, $14.95), a witty blast of media criticism disguised as a garish spin-off of ''X-Men.'' The writer Peter Milligan assembles a bickering team of mutants who negotiate the TV rights to their rescue of Boyz R Us, a teen-pop group taken hostage. The heroes, as drawn by Mike Allred and inked by Laura Allred in bright, primary colors, are stiffly posed with few facial expressions (frowning anger, teary woundedness) -- a parody of bad comic-book art whose ugliness becomes astute when combined with Milligan's merciless view of humanity. The members of X-Force are celebrities not for the occasional good they do, but merely for dominating the news. As their callously corrupt advisor, Coach, says: ''That's what's so great about today. No one remembers anything any more.'' Harold Bloom couldn't have said it better. Ken Tucker

title: March 10-16: HEALTH; VISCERAL ECOLOGY
description: Humans and their livestock are increasingly medicated and disinfected, and all those drugs and chemicals are leaving a subtle mark on the country's waterways, government scientists found. A survey of 139 streams in 30 states found that 80 percent had traces -- mostly just a part per billion or less -- of dozens of drugs, disinfectants, detergents, insect repellents and other compounds flushed down sewers and not completely captured by treatment plants. Water experts said that the two dozen antibiotics found, along with triclosan, the active ingredient in antimicrobial soaps, could lead to sturdier bacteria strains. The survey -- performed by a unit slated to be closed by the Bush administration -- also found that many streams held traces of hormones from birth control pills and other sources that could harm fish. As a result, the F.D.A. said it might have to expand environmental tests before approving new drugs. Andrew C. Revkin

description: To the Editor: In response to Maureen B. The restaurant has a spectacular view of Tuscan hills and faces one of the most beautiful Medici villas. It was built by the renowned Renaissance architect Buontalenti as a hunting lodge for Medici princes. Ristorante Da Delfina serves simple but refined Tuscan cuisine, and it is not expensive (dinner for two with wine, about $75).

title: Professor-Picking 101
description: There is an adage in business that says that employees should pick their bosses, not have the bosses pick them. The same goes for college students and their professors, say Ernie Lepore and Sarah-Jane Leslie, the authors of the new book called ''What Every College Student Should Know'' (Rutgers University Press, $12.95). Mr. Lepore, a philosophy professor at Rutgers, and Ms. Leslie, a student in the Rutgers honors program, spend 127 pithy pages guiding students in finding teachers. Among their tips: Look at the syllabus the teacher hands out. If it is sloppy and imprecise, he or she will be, too. Be sure to make professional, not necessarily personal, connections with a professor from whom you want a recommendation. Don't think you can intuit a professor's requirements; ask directly if you have to or you won't get that A. Robert Strauss

title: Homage to Oscar
description: The New York branch of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences may be having its annual Oscar party at Le Cirque 2000, and there's always the annual mixer at Elaine's. But this year, some East Coast retailers are also offering a taste of Oscar bonhomie. Eleni's Cookies in the Chelsea Market carries a Best Picture Tin ($50), right, filled with frosted sugar cookies in the shape of icons representing each nominated film (for example, a blackboard inscribed with E=mc2 for ''A Beautiful Mind''). Gourmet Garage offers Cheesy Movie Popcorn for at-home viewing of the ceremony, on March 24. Moviefone is running a less reverent version of the Oscars, the American Moviegoer Awards; winners will be announced this week, and they will be notified by mail with a light-activated sound piece on which the movie names have been recorded by Mr. Moviefone. And guests at an Oscar party at the TriBeCa Grand Hotel sponsored by Mercedes-Benz will receive a goody bag dedicated to New York designers and shops. Goodies include products from Alex & Ani, Bumble & Bumble, Cosi and Equinox gyms, as well as the popular ''I NY'' T-shirt designed by Rebecca Minkoff. Best of all? Recipients don't have to thank the Academy or their agents.

title: My Mingus
description: I first met Charles Mingus late one night in July 1964. I had gone down to the Five Spot, a jazz club in Lower Manhattan, because the producer of a film I was acting in had commissioned a jazz soundtrack from the saxophonist Ornette Coleman, and my friend Sam Edwards, who was working on the film, suggested I check out the scene. I didn't know the first thing about jazz. Sam warned me I was not with it, especially for someone in New York, but added in his usual upbeat fashion that anyone could learn. Members of the cast had given me an Ornette Coleman album called ''Something Else!'' and I had listened over and over to a Miles Davis record called ''Miles Ahead,'' because the director of the film had played it over and over in the apartment where we were shooting during the long intervals between takes. But that was, at that point, the extent of my baptism into the music.

title: Slouching Toward Downtown
description: During my teenage years, I was stuck in suburban Virginia, staring out the window at the cul-de-sac as I sprawled across the rosebud comforter of my white canopy bed. In my world women's reputations were strictly delineated: either you were good, i.e., you read books, always had clean hair and never swore; or bad, i.e., you wore tight jeans, smoked, drank, slept around and worst of all had fits of public hysteria. Among the strip malls and split-levels, there wasn't much room for idiosyncratic expression, let alone punk-rock passion. So when I first heard the music and later saw photos of Patti Smith spitting onstage in her black peg-leg pants or Deborah Harry, the Garbo of the East Village, taking the mike at CBGB, I was both confused and thrilled, recognizing for the first time that good and bad, mixed together in the right proportion, equals cool. The women in Lower Manhattan seemed different from musicians in other scenes, influenced by gritty street life as well as the city's literary and visual-art cultures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, HUBERT DUBOIS, COL., (US ARMY RETIRED)
description: LEWIS-Hubert duBois, Col., (US Army Retired) died in Marshall, TX on March 11, 2002 at the age of 95. An honors graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1930, Col. Lewis served with distinction in the United States Army until his retirement in 1958. During his long career Col. Lewis held a variety of technical and leadership positions including participation in the liberation of the Philippines in World War II and service as an Anti-aircraft Artillery Group Commander in Alaska during the Korean War. Col. Lewis also earned a Master's degree from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1937. Following his retirement, Col. Lewis settled in Marshall, TX where he worked for more than three years as a project engineer for Thiokol Chemical Corporation and later as a management analyst for Bendix Corporation in Kansas City. During his retirement Col. Lewis remained devoted to West Point and served for 27 years as the Area Admissions Coordinator for a substantial area of northeast TX. Thanks to the tireless efforts of Col. Lewis, more than two hundred young men and women received appointments to West Point and the other service academies and have served with distinction in the US armed forces. Col. Lewis' beloved wife of more than 62 years, Louise Lanke, predeceased him in 1993. He is survived by his son, Herman Lewis of Marshall, TX; his daughter Marie Lewis Matthews of Princeton, NJ; a sister, Josephine Utley of Seattle, WA; a brother, Paul A. Lewis of Santa Barbara, CA; six grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. A private service and burial will be held at West Point on March 18, 2002. The family of Col. Lewis mourns his passing and and expresses its deep appreciation for his love and guidance during his lifetime. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the West Point Fund, Association of Graduates, Herbert Hall, 698 Mills Road, West Point, New York 10006.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUESSER, MARIANN
description: SUESSER-Mariann. Mariann died peacefully in her home on March 16, 2002, of ovarian cancer at the age of 66. She lived most recently in New Suffolk and formerly in Garden City. She was very active in the Garden City Community Church, where she assisted in the nursery school and was a church officer for many years. She served as President of the Women's Auxiliary, an organization she revitalized. For serveral years she hosted the Twigs Bridge Meetings. Upon retiring to New Suffolk, she became a Cornell Master Gardener and enjoyed growing flowers in her newly established garden. She was also an accomplished quilt maker, many of her designs decorate the walls of her home. She will be remembered for her ability to see colors in everything, for her smiile, laughter, and love of people in general and children in particular. Her mother Marie Mehlhop, husband Fred, sons Eric and Mark, daughter Laura and grandchildren Thomas and Julia survive her. The family will receive friends at the William Coster Funeral Home, Main Rd, Cutchogue, on Monday, March 18, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. A memorial service will take place at 2 PM, on Tuesday, March 19, at The First Presbyterian Church, Main Rd., Southold. Interment will follow at the church cemetery. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMPSON, THE REV. JAMES B.
description: SIMPSON-The Rev. James B., 75, Episcopal priest, author, journalist and former public relations account executive, died March 11 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, D.C. of complications following a stroke. Born in Arkansas, Fr. Simpson was educated at Northwestern University, the University of Edinburg, Scotland, and Nashota House Episcopal Seminary in Wisconsin. Before entering the priesthood, he worked in the media in New York, San Francisco and Chicago, and reported from London, Lagos, Moscow, Tokyo and Beijing. A resident of Washington, D.C. for the past ten years, Fr. Simpson was a member of the Cosmos Club and was associated with two Washington parishes, the Church of Ascension St. Agnes and All Souls. Before retirement, he was Curate at Christ's Church, Rye, NY, and Rector of Christ Church, Middletown, NJ. He was the Editor of ''The Anglican Digest,'' served as an interim priest in Tokyo, Japan, and was currently a correspondent for the British publications ''The Living Church'' and ''Church Times.'' He was the author of four ''Contemporary Quotations'' books, the first published in 1957 and the last in 1997. His biography, ''The Hundreth Archbishop of Canterbury,'' was listed among the 200 best books of 1962. In the 1990's, Fr. Simpson was listed in ''Who's Who in America.'' A protege of H.V. Kaltenborn, he scripted an early television panel show, ''Who Said That?'' With the late Fr. Edward M. Story, Fr. Simpson co-wrote the first book on the decennial international meeting of Episcopal bishops, ''The Long Shadows of Lambeth X.'' They followed that book ten years later with ''Discerning God's Will: Lambeth XI.'' They also wrote the first comprehensive history of religious orders in the Episcopal church. Currently, Fr. Simpson was working on a pioneering study, ''A Treasury of Anglican Art,'' which is to be published this year. Fr. Simpson's byline has appeared in Look, Reader's Digest, Esquire, Town & Country, Christian Science Monitor and The New York Times Magazine. He is survived by two sisters, Mrs. L.J. Witherspoon, Jackson, MS, and Mrs. Ralph D. Skinner, Homosassa, FL; two nieces, Mary Skinner Murry, Richmond, Virginia, and Jane Phillips, Jackson, MS; two nephews, Matthew Skinner, Ellicott City, MD and Joe Witherspoon, Orlando, FL. A funeral mass was held at the Church of the Ascension and Saint Agnes in the District on Friday. Gifts to support color photos for Fr. Simpson's book ''A Treasury of Anglican Art'' are tax deductible and should be made payable to The Rector's Discretionary Fund, and mailed to St. Paul's Church, 2430 K St., NW, Washington, DC 20037.

title: Better Late Than . . .

So why did that America not inspire the sort of global anger that today's America does? Partly it's because the rest of the world was flat on its back then. But more important, it's because America after World War II took responsibility for making the world both a more secure place to live and a better place to live. And it expended a lot of resources, as in the Marshall Plan, to do both.

title: Music; High and Low Meet, and Mix With Drink

A small hunting party assembles at Bon Repos, the gallery of Count Spork, near the Elbe River in Bohemia; or perhaps it meets at a smaller lodge a hundred miles to the east, in the rolling hills of Moravia. There are several musicians, playing everything from fiddles, horns and lutes to bird whistles and jew's-harps. Amid much tippling, there are many songs: little gems about death and mourning alternate with giddy displays of drunken good humor. Horn players set off each song with duets, and the whole event is framed by a pair of local hunting tunes.
