title: Overdue Jewels
description: In the weeks before the Academy Awards, Hollywood becomes a frenzied Style Lending Library of sorts, as personal stylists to the stars scurry to boutiques and hotel suites, putting dibs on accessories and million-dollar jewels for their clients. ''Some stylists grab whatever they can,'' said the Beverly Hills jeweler Martin Katz. ''They hoard.'' Worse, many borrowers hold on to their baubles right up until the show, keeping other stars from having a chance to wear them. So, this year, an anti-hoarding movement has taken hold. Some designers plan to limit quantities and place time limits on borrowers; others claim they will not. Will everyone play nice? ''We'll have to see. But I am prepared to be available 24/7,'' said Marilyn Heston, the publicist for MHA Media, who is handling more than a dozen pairs of diamond-encrusted Jimmy Choo shoes this week. title: Darwinian Struggle in Ohio
description: Creationists have gotten a lot of bad publicity since the Scopes trial brought the fight over teaching evolution into sharp relief in 1925. Nearly two years ago, Kansas voters threw out conservative members of the state Board of Education who had pushed through new science standards that eliminated biological evolution as an explanation of the emergence of one species from another. The nation has, over the years, come to wide agreement that public school science classes should teach science, not religion. But creationists have not given up. Now in Ohio, another batch of conservative board members is taking a different approach -- one that would leave evolution in the curriculum but insert the teaching of alternative explanations as well, particularly a theory known as ''intelligent design.''

title: The Nation; Sinful Tax?

Both the city and the state plan to raise their taxes to $1.50 per pack -- up from 8 cents for the city and $1.11 for the state. Needless to say, the major tobacco companies -- essentially an oligopoly of four that is already bleeding cash into a lawsuit settlement that some consider a tax -- are opposed to any increases. R. J. Reynolds, for instance, complains on its Web site that cigarettes are one of the most heavily taxed consumer products in the United States.They're right. Federal, state and local governments all get a bite. But over all, taxes aren't what they used to be, and for those trying to quit, higher prices might just be the nudge they need. TOM ZELLER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEUNG, MOO KIT TSUI
description: LEUNG-Moo Kit Tsui. Of Boca Raton, FL, and New York, passed away on March 15, 2002 of natural causes. Born August 21, 1919, in Hong Kong. She was a graduate of Canton University, Canton, China, and Soo Chow Law School, Shanghai, China, and completed graduate studies at Columbia University. A highly successful life insurance agent, in 1954 she became the first female insurance agent in the history of the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America to write over $1 million in life insurance policies in a single year. In 1955 she became a member of the prestigious Million Dollar Round Table of life insurance agents and continued her membership until her retirement in 1982. She will be remembered for her energy, passion, athleticism, love of her family and helping people. Surviving relatives include her husband Kwok Choy Leung of Baton Raton, FL, and New York; her brother Shau Yan Tsui of Palo Alto, CA, her sister Shau Wan Tsui of Calgary, Canada, and her children, Dr. Donald Leung of Denver, CO, Florence Leung of NYC, and Firman Leung of Scarsdale, NY. In addition, she is survived by six grandchildren: David and Daniel Trasmonte; Allison and Alexander Leung; and Anthony and Philip Leung. A memorial service will be held Sunday, March 24, 2002, at 5 PM, at True Light Lutheran Church, 195 Worth Street, New York, NY. Entombment will be on Monday, March 25, 2002, at 11 AM, at Ferncliff Cemetery Chapel, 280 Secor Road, Hartsdale, NY. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Chinese Public School of New York, 64 Mott Street, New York, NY 10013, or Chinatown Manpower Project, 70 Mulberry Street, New York, NY 10013.

Tour members wear a light headset and belt pack receiver, the guide a belt pack transmitter and headset microphone.

title: A Chance to Reshape the Corps
description: President Bush may have done more than he knows to start a process of reform in the hitherto untouchable Army Corps of Engineers -- an agency famous for its servility to Congress and its indifference to presidents. Earlier this month, Mr. Bush forced the resignation of the agency's civilian chief, Mike Parker, a former Mississippi congressman he had appointed only months before as a favor to Trent Lott, the Senate minority leader. Mr. Parker's main sin was that he asked Congress for more money than Mr. Bush had budgeted. This did not bother Congress in the least, since most members regard the Corps as their own personal pork barrel. It infuriated Mr. Bush, not only because he is trying to trim what he regards as wasteful domestic spending, but also because he expects his appointees to toe the line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, GRACE STURTEVANT
description: HOPKINS-Grace Sturtevant. Of 200 Leeder Hill Dr., Hamden, CT, formerly of New Brunswick, NJ, died on March 12, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Francis W. Hopkins, sister of Julian M. Sturtevant of North Branford, CT, aunt of Ann Sturtevant Ormsby of Seattle, WA, Jane Sturtevant of New York, NY, and Dixon R. Sturtevant of Schaumburg, IL; she was predeceased by a brother, Cortland A. Sturtevant. Grace was born July 14, 1904, daughter of the late Edgar H. and Bessie Skinner Sturtevant. She graduated from Vassar College in 1924 and had a doctorate in classical linguistics from Yale. While living in New Jersey from 1931 until 1962, she was active in the League of Women Voters of which she served on the New Jersey State Board in different capacities including as State President for four years. She was also a member of the National Board. Before retirement, she and her husband spent summers in Branford, CT, and later lived in Branford and Naples, FL, before moving to Hamden. She loved political activism, travel, swimming, playing bridge, and her family. Grace will be missed by all who knew and loved her. As she wished, no memorial service is planned. In her memory, gifts can be made to Vassar College, Box 725, 124 Raymond Ave., Poughkeepsie, NY 12604.

But when the Rangers lost by 5-3 to the Detroit Red Wings yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, there were several moments that featured the fury of Fleury, the leading scorer on a falling team. title: Editorial Notebook; Riding the Demographic Wave Ashore
description: It used to be that a man had seven ages. Or so thought Jaques, the melancholy misanthrope in Shakespeare's ''As You Like It.'' You probably remember his speech, the one that begins ''All the world's a stage. . . . '' According to Jaques, a man's seven ages were puking infant, whining schoolboy, sighing lover, bearded soldier, round-bellied justice, slippered pantaloon and mere oblivion. Demographically speaking, those seven ages have now been whittled down to three: too young to have a credit-card, the prime of high consumption, which ends abruptly at 34, or maybe 49, and mere oblivion. Jaques is now a media buyer, and he knows just what he's looking for.

title: RWE Is Set to Buy Innogy
description: RWE, the large German utility, is near a deal to acquire Innogy, Britain's No. 2 electricity and gas company, for over 3 billion ($4.3 billion), people close to the companies said today. RWE has raised its offer to a range of 270 pence to 275 pence a share for Innogy, up from its initial bid made last month of 258 pence a share. The boards of both companies are expected to meet this week to complete the transaction, these people said. If RWE, which bought Thames Water of Britain in 2000, clinches the deal, it would have outmaneuvered Scottish Power, which had expressed early interest in Innogy, but later withdrew from the bidding.

title: A Dutiful Recruit's Notebook: Lesson by Lesson Toward Jihad
description: On July 9, 2000, a young man opened a notebook and jotted down the opening words in his life as an Islamic guerrilla. The man was a Tajik who had crossed from the former Soviet Union, where pockets of fundamentalism had been brewing, into Afghanistan, where Al Qaeda-sponsored training camps were preparing students for terrorism and war.

title: 2 Americans Killed in Attack on Pakistan Church
description: Two men walked into a Protestant church close to the American Embassy this morning, in one of the most guarded areas in one of the most secure cities in Pakistan, and threw several grenades. Five people were killed, including an embassy employee and her daughter, a high school senior.

title: Foundlings Wrapped in a Green Mystery
description: Who were the green children? Sometime between the years 1135 and 1154 A.D., the villagers of Woolpit, in East Anglia, England, discovered a boy and a girl beside a pit. Two monks, writing about the event years later, said the children cried out in an incomprehensible language. But even stranger, ''the color of their skins differed from all mortals of our habitable world,'' wrote Ralph of Coggeshall, one of the monks. ''For the whole surface of their skins was tinged with a green color.''

title: White House Letter; For Most-Favored Term, A Presidential Workout
description: President Bush said recently that the United States has a ''fabulous'' military. On other occasions, he has proclaimed himself proud of such a fabulous country, and of his fabulous cabinet. Texas and Alaska are both fabulous states. Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, is a fabulous senator.

title: Company Town Keeps Indians at Home
description: The temperature outside is a steamy 95 degrees and the noise from the construction of dome buildings is deafening. Inside the brightly lighted expanse of a completed dome, it is a pleasant 72 degrees, and the din is barely audible as software developers sit at workstations lined up along the curved walls.

title: Oscar's New, Smaller Home Has Many Feeling Rejected
description: All over Hollywood, unwelcome letters are being received by famous, powerful and accomplished people who are not used to being told no.

title: Life Goes On, Or It Goes on Hold; As Some 9/11 Volunteers Go Home, Others Find a Longtime Mission
description: Bob Cline came the day after. He felt catapulted by some ethereal force. On Sept. 12, he boarded an Amtrak train to New York City, leaving behind his pared-down life upstate in Speigletown to do whatever they wanted him to do at ground zero. Right away, he was sent to the mountainous rubble of the towers and put on a bucket brigade, hauling detritus out of the site. He saw horrors that won't leave him. The first night, he slept in a chair on the street.

title: Indonesia Bans Australian Who Wrote About Abuses

title: Gray Whales Rebound For West Coast Ritual

title: Avraham Tory, 92, Whose Diary Told the World of Nazi Crimes
description: Avraham Tory, a Lithuanian Jew whose meticulous diary chronicled three years of murderous Nazi rule and was later included as evidence in war crimes trials, died on Feb. 24 at his home in Tel Aviv. He was 92.

title: Microsoft, Back in Court Again
description: The Microsoft antitrust litigation enters a new phase today in a federal courtroom in Washington. Nine state attorneys general will make the case that a settlement reached with the Justice Department and other states last November does not go far enough.

title: Connecticut Report Revisits Egan's Role in Settling Abuse Cases
description: For more than half of his 12 years as bishop of the Roman Catholic diocese in Bridgeport, Conn., Edward M. Egan was beset by a series of very public lawsuits charging some of his priests with child sexual abuse. The suits accused him and his predecessor of covering up the abuse and allowing the priests to continue to work.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: State Investigates Deaths at Hospital
description: Mount Sinai Hospital, fined for faulty care in the January death of a man after liver surgery, is being investigated by the State Department of Health in connection with at least four other deaths. The investigation, reported yesterday by The New York Post, stems in part from the death of a 48-year-old Brooklyn ironworker who died on Thursday in the hospital's liver transplant ward. State officials are also looking into earlier deaths of two men, aged 47 and 62, and a patient whom they declined to identify. Rob Kenny, a spokesman for the Department of Health, told The Associated Press that state officials ''are investigating any and all complaints'' and will have ''a presence at Mount Sinai for the foreseeable future.'' Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: U.S. to End 24-Hour Fighter Jet Patrols Over New York

The car left the scene and the driver has not been found, they said. The dead man, identified as Michael Lombardi, 24, of Middletown in the Bronx, was hit at the intersection of East Tremont Avenue and Haskin Street around 11 p.m., the police said. So the executioners of the great state of Texas will not be plunging a poison needle into Andrea Yates.

Mr. Auriemma, 54, of Chatham Township, is credited with handling some of the state's most significant casino gambling issues since he joined the regulatory system in 1978, Mr. Samson said. The dead man, Felix Toribio, 41, of Orlando, Fla., was hit three times in the chest and arm while standing in front of 539 West 145th Street around 9 p.m. on Saturday, the police said. At least six shots were fired and several bullet casings were recovered at the scene, they said. Mr. Toribio was pronounced dead at Harlem Hospital Center a short time later. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: See, This Baby's a Baritone

Yes, ''Baby Bob,'' which has its premiere tonight on CBS, is midseason-replacement television at its most challenging.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on March 7 about the revival of the musical ''One Mo' Time'' misstated the date of the show's original production and its relationship to another revue show, ''Ain't Misbehavin'.'' title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Large Screen On New Sony Laptop
description: The Sony Corporation introduced a laptop computer yesterday that it said was the first notebook personal computer to come with a 16.1-inch display. The new Vaio GRX notebook ''offers a viewing area similar to a standard 17-inch CRT monitor in a flat, space-saving panel,'' the company said. The notebook, which is powered by Intel's new Pentium 4-M mobile processor, comes with a CD-RW/DVD drive, two PC card slots and Sony's audio and video editing software. Sony said the machine would be available later this month in three configurations. The most expensive model, the Vaio GRX590, will cost about $3,000 and comes with a 40 GB hard drive. The least expensive, the Vaio GRX550, with sell for about $2,100, but has a slightly smaller 15-inch monitor.

title: David Mann, 85, Composer and Pianist
description: David Mann, who wrote the music for the popular 1955 song ''In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning,'' which was recorded by Frank Sinatra, died on March 1 in Manhattan.

title: In Shooting, a Brother's Word vs. Another's Videotape
description: On Friday, a Brooklyn man named Lorenzo Branch attracted widespread attention by testifying that he knew his imprisoned brother was wrongly convicted of a 1988 murder because he himself was involved.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What we do is look for the enemy, we find the enemy and, I think it's been said, we either bring the enemy to justice or bring justice to the enemy. I think what you've seen in this operation is a little bit of both.''

title: Auditor Takes Steps On Overseas Mergers
description: KPMG and Arthur Andersen said they were in talks on a merger of their operations outside the United States, the latest effort to salvage parts of Andersen as it prepares to challenge a criminal charge.

title: Pakistan's Leaders as Target
description: Most of the people killed or wounded in a church attack in Pakistan on Sunday were foreigners, but a principal target was Pakistan's government. News Analysis, Page A14.

title: 90 Are Arrested in Inquiry Into Internet Child-Sex Ring
description: A nationwide Internet child-pornography ring has been smashed with the arrest of about 90 people, including two Roman Catholic priests, a school bus driver, a teacher's aide and a police officer, the federal authorities said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling On West Side Tracks
description: A plan to tear down the High Line, a defunct elevated railway line dating to the 1930's, has been struck down by a state judge. In a ruling issued on March 12, Justice Diane S. Lebedeff of State Supreme Court in Manhattan found that the plan, approved in the final days of the Giuliani administration, violated city law by circumventing public review. Opponents of the plan want to turn the viaduct, which runs above 10th Avenue from West 33rd to Gansevoort Streets, into an elevated esplanade. The plan's proponents, nearby property owners, consider the structure an unsafe eyesore. Randy Mastro, a former deputy mayor who is a lawyer for the property owners, said that he planned to appeal. Denny Lee (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Brewery Acquisition
description: Molson Inc. of Canada and Heineken, based in the Netherlands, have joined forces to form Brazil's second-biggest brewer through the merger of the Kaiser Group, in which Heineken has a 14 percent stake, and the smaller Bavaria Group, controlled by Molson. Molson has agreed to pay $765 million in stock and cash for Kaiser. Heineken will have a 20 percent stake in the new company for an investment of $220 million. Coca-Cola and its Brazilian bottler presently own 85.8 percent of Kaiser. They will be paid in stock and will have a representative on Molson's board. Molson presently distributes Heineken products in Canada. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: In Racial Split, Regents Elect A Chancellor
description: The New York State Board of Regents chose Robert M. Bennett, a seven-year member of the board from Buffalo, as chancellor yesterday in a tense vote divided largely along racial lines.

title: Russia Steps Toward Banking Overhaul
description: When the Parliament votes this week to confirm President Vladimir V. Putin's nominee to run the central bank, it will also be voting to begin the long-delayed transformation of Russia's financial system into one that can serve a modern economy, analysts and investors said.

title: Yeast Infection: The Pitfalls of Self-Diagnosis
description: Just because a medication once sold only by prescription is now available over the counter does not mean that patients know how and when to use it properly. A good example involves the antifungal products now sold without prescriptions for the treatment of vaginitis -- not just any vaginitis, but the most common form, caused by the ubiquitous yeast of the genus Candida.

title: Add Grinding Schedule To List of Knick Woes
description: The motto is to finish strong, to build confidence, to create some positive vibes heading into next season. As if reaching that goal would not be hard enough under normal circumstances, the Knicks have been handed another obstacle by the league: a brutal schedule.

title: Lawmakers Seek to Change Tax Formula
description: Conceding their own failure to change New Jersey's tax laws, some influential state legislators today urged a state constitutional convention to cure the inequities in a system that relies more and more on property taxes to pay for government.

title: Research Leads to Call for Quick Testing of Mad-Cow-Infected Animals
description: Researchers studying mice have made a discovery that is certain to upset anyone who loves the rump end of beef but worries about mad cow disease. In mice, anyway, the aberrant proteins that cause the condition seem to accumulate in muscle tissue, especially the hindquarters.

title: Qwest Narrows Account Review
description: Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its consolidated account, with billings estimated at $100 million, to two finalists. The decision came as one Qwest incumbent, J. Walter Thompson in New York, part of the WPP Group, resigned its assignments by withdrawing from the review.

title: A Good Workout With the Master of Precision
description: Busta Rhymes wears his pants higher than any other hip-hop star, and when he came to the Hammerstein Ballroom last Tuesday night, the top of his red leather trousers was much closer to his navel than to his knees. This may be a sign of his age: Busta is almost 30, a decade older than many of his contemporaries. But it's also a reminder that he treats his concerts as athletic exhibitions. Busta isn't afraid to break a sweat, and he expects his audience to do the same. He ended the concert with a simple demand: ''Bang ya head until you start to break ya neck!''

title: Court Allows Juror Excuse For Hardship In New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that financial hardship was a valid ground for excusing a juror from a criminal trial after jury deliberations had begun, provided that an alternate was available to take the excused juror's place and that the deliberations were started anew.

Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978, or the East Hampton Library, 159 Main St., East Hampton, NY 11937, would be appreciated.

title: Another Possible Aspirin Benefit for Men
description: Men over 60 who took aspirin or another anti-inflammatory drug daily were half as likely as those who didn't to be diagnosed with prostate cancer during a six-year Mayo Clinic study.

title: Knight Leads And Pitt Follows
description: Pittsburgh guard Brandin Knight is a young man of few words. Ask him a question and he will usually rub his scalp, scratch his nose or pull on an ear -- as his eyes dart and a brow furrows. It is as if Knight is manually arranging the answers in his head, waiting to sort them in the order he wants to deliver them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Zagat Resigns From Tourism Group
description: Tim Zagat will step down as New York City's tourism booster in chief on May 13, his birthday, when he resigns as chairman of the city's official tourism agency, he said yesterday. Jonathan M. Tisch, chief executive of Loews Hotels, has been nominated as chairman of the agency, NYC & Company; Cristyne L. Nicholas remains president. Mr. Zagat will remain on the agency's executive committee, but plans to devote more time to the Zagat Survey, the restaurant and hotel survey he founded with his wife, Nina. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: The Place for Public Documents: On File or Online?
description: Hospitals and insurance companies can readily obtain information about a physician's malpractice claims, but in most states the public cannot. But in at least 15 states, the Federation of State Medical Boards says, some such records are available on official Web sites. Physician groups in most states oppose the practice. Gale Scott discussed the issue with the presidents of two medical societies. These are edited excerpts of those interviews.

description: Federal prosecutors in Virginia and New York are seeking the death penalty for Zacarias Moussaoui, who has been identified by law enforcement officials as the ''20th hijacker'' in the Sept. 11 attacks, government officials said today.

title: The Not-So-Telltale Sign of Lyme Disease
description: People worried about Lyme disease have long been told to keep an eye out for a bull's-eye rash -- a red circle with a pale center. But a new study suggests that this advice may need revision.

title: Second Banana Leads His Own Bunch
description: In the shrewdly wistful movie ''Groundhog Day,'' the cranky weatherman played by Bill Murray turns a Kafkaesque nightmare on its head. Finding himself trapped in the same day over and over, he begins to use the information he gathers on each repeated experience to improve it next time around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LINDLEY G.
description: MILLER-Lindley G., President of Miller-Davison & Co. of Locust Valley and retired Village Justice of Upper Brookville, died Saturday, March 16, 2002, after a brief illness. Beloved husband of the former Patricia Cromwell and devoted father of Barbara C. Miller, Alexandra M. Cooper, Patricia R. Miller, Carley M. Sullivan and L. Garrison Miller Jr. Father-in-law of A. Gary Sullivan and Carrie Barr Miller. Proud grandfather of Grant Cooper, Kimberly Spallone, Courtney Sullivan, Pepperrell Sullivan and Charles Miller. Also, survived by brothers J. Norris Miller, Edward M. Miller and sister Anne Miller Mason. Predeceased by his sister Jane Benziger and brother William W. Miller. Judge Miller graduated from Princeton University in 1943 and the University of Virginia Law School in 1949. During W.W. II, he served as a flight engineer in the United States Air Force on a B-24 in the 451st Bomber Group. He flew 39 missions, earning a D.F.C. Air Medal, three Clusters, a Purple Heart and the Presidential Citation. Judge Miller was elected Village Justice of Upper Brookville, New York in 1958, a position he held until he retired in 2001. A memorial service is scheduled for 10:30 AM on Friday, March 22nd at the St. Dominic's RC Church in Oyster Bay, New York. In lieu of flowers, a donation in his memory would be greatly appreciated to the North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove, C/O the Emergency Department Campaign or to the Upper Brookville Village Court.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Comptroller Candidate Withdraws
description: Anthony J. Nanula, the Buffalo city comptroller, dropped out of the race for state comptroller yesterday and endorsed Alan G. Hevesi, the former New York City comptroller and former mayoral candidate. His withdrawal left two Democratic candidates, Mr. Hevesi and William J. Mulrow, an investment banker who has taken the lead in fund-raising and in getting endorsements from party leaders. Also yesterday, the only Republican in the race, John J. Faso, announced that he would resign as Assembly minority leader in a few weeks to focus on the race. Comptroller H. Carl McCall is running for governor. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: So, Who's Your Daddy? In DNA Tests, TV Finds Elixir to Raise Ratings
description: ''Tony,'' the talk show host Maury Povich intones, his voice taut with suspense, ''is not the father!'' The young man leaps up and bounds across the stage like a contestant who has just won a car. His former girlfriend Latoya flees the stage in tears, crushed that the DNA test did not prove that Tony was the father of her 4-month-old girl.

title: National Briefing | Washington: No Budget From House Democrats
description: After being challenged by Republicans to show how they would address the nation's budget problems, Democrats said they would not offer their own plan when the House takes up a $2.1 trillion Republican budget proposal on Wednesday. Instead, House Democrats said they would press for a bipartisan negotiation led by President Bush to come up with a plan to eliminate deficits while paying for the war on terrorism. Democrats said the House Republican plan was riddled with gimmicks. Republicans said Democrats should put a detailed plan on the table or stop criticizing their approach. Democrats in the Senate plan to unveil their budget this week. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: Both Fans and Foes of Police Offer Tributes on a Retirement
description: In his more than 40-year police career, Chief Allan H. Hoehl oversaw several hundred of New York City's largest and most noteworthy demonstrations, marches, parades and celebrations. And, in his capacity as chief of southern Manhattan, he watched as thousands of protesters were taken away in handcuffs.

title: Quick Debate Is Expected For Campaign Finance Bill
description: The Senate opened debate today on a comprehensive overhaul of the campaign finance law in a drive to give the bill final approval and send it to President Bush by the end of the week.

title: High in Andes, a Place That May Have Been Incas' Last Refuge
description: Every generation or so, explorers of the high Andes of Peru come upon an elaborate sacred place or city that had been unknown to archaeologists studying the Incan civilization. The most impressive still is Machu Picchu, discovered in 1911, and no important ''lost city'' has come to light since the 1960's.

description: Kenyon Martin was sent to his room by the league Sunday in Memphis to serve a one-game suspension, but when he returns Tuesday against the Cavaliers, he says he will not change his style of play.

description: The stereo systems of aging baby boomers still wail with Mick Jagger's plaint about the difficulties of obtaining satisfaction. This hard truth can also be demonstrated mathematically.

title: Tagliabue Still Supports A Super Bowl in the North
description: Super Bowls could be played in the New York metropolitan area and Washington, but there is not a timetable and the reason for the games would not simply be an economic or emotional reaction to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, said today at the league's annual owners meeting.

title: For Delphic Oracle, Fumes and Visions
description: For at least 12 centuries, the oracle at Delphi spoke on behalf of the gods, advising rulers, citizens and philosophers on everything from their sex lives to affairs of state. The oracle was always a woman, her divine utterances made in response to a petitioner's request. In a trance, at times in a frenzy, she would answer questions, give orders and make prophecies.

title: Orchids Still Herald Spring, But Not at Winter Garden
description: In a triumph over adversity, organizers of the New York International Orchid Show have toiled feverishly to relocate uptown, far from the show's ravaged longtime home at what is now ground zero. The riotous rainbow of 5,000 plants -- long a harbinger of spring in wintry Manhattan -- is to make its debut on Thursday in a new space: Rockefeller Center.

description: The Vienna Philharmonic's 14th annual visit to New York over the weekend promised to be hectic for the players as it was, with three different concerts at Carnegie Hall. Nor could they have known several months ago, when they decided to add a fourth, free program to honor the victims of Sept. 11 on Sunday evening at St. Patrick's Cathedral, just how timely the tribute would be.

description: A 26-year-old man was stabbed to death last night in Brooklyn, the police said. The man, whose name was not immediately released by police, was discovered unconscious in front of 1500 Coney Island Avenue in the Ocean Parkway section around 8:40 p.m. He had been stabbed in the left side of the back, said Lt. Elias Nikas, a police spokesman.

title: Exiles Wait for Return Of King to Kandahar
description: A grapevine of turbaned men bend and clap and swirl their arms in sync, 200 feet kicking up gravel and dust in a parking lot. Their hypnotic song rises heavenward.

title: Stratton Journal; Ohio Village Pleads Its Case for a No-Pitch Zone
description: This village's wariness of the door-to-door solicitors denounced locally as ''flim-flam men'' has drawn the scrutiny of the United States Supreme Court, a fact that turns out to be a cause of local pride rivaling the steak dinners at Abdalla's Tavern.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: MSC Will Buy Mechanical Dynamics
description: The MSC.Software Corporation, which makes simulation software for manufacturers to test designs of their products, said it would buy the rival software maker Mechanical Dynamics Inc. for $120 million. MSC.Software said the arrangement would create a client base of more than 10,000 companies, increasing efficiency and customer satisfaction. Mechanical Dynamics, of Ann Arbor, Mich., makes software for the aerospace, auto and rail industries, including technology used by engineers to design landing gear for airplanes and suspension and steering systems for automobiles. The combined companies will employ more than 1,700 people in 22 countries, officials said. MSC.Software of Santa Ana, Calif., said it had revenue of about $236 million in 2001, while Mechanical Dynamics had revenue of $57.5 million. ''The fact that our products are so complementary greatly increases the integration opportunity for our customers and our ability to expand our presence,'' said Frank Perna, chief executive of MSC.Software. Shares of MSC.Software rose $1.03, to $21.01. Mechanical Dynamics shares rose $6.67, to $18.68.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Economic Growth
description: Thailand's economy grew 1.6 percent in the fourth quarter of 2001, according to the state planning agency, beating most economists' predictions thanks to higher domestic spending and a stronger agricultural sector. The National Economic and Social Development Board said the Thai economy grew 1.8 percent for all of 2001, and, encouraged by gathering strength in the economy of the United States, raised its estimate of growth this year to as high as 3 percent from an earlier prediction of 2 percent. The agency warned that weakness in the Japanese economy and among Thai banks, as well as the possibility of a dry year for farmers, could darken the outlook.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mount Holly: Too Little Rain To End Drought
description: Rain yesterday and Sunday did little to relieve New Jersey's drought, the National Weather Service said yesterday. Rainfall for March, which is typically under 3.5 inches, is seasonable so far, but it will take unseasonable downpours to end the emergency. Rain this month has ranged from 1.75 inches to 2.5 inches in various locations. Walt Nickelsberg, a National Weather Service water researcher, said rain like that of the past two days would have to fall for as much as three days a week for the next two months to end the drought.

title: From Paris, Milan and New York, Impressions of Fall
description: No white flags were raised. Nor were there any weeping cries of ''Uncle!'' Designers showing their fall 2002 collections here and in Europe were bound to take exception to the chants six months ago that fashion was frivolous or simply for the birds. That they voiced such clear-headed statements about women is surprising, though, after all the lollipop gestures and hip relevancy of the last few seasons. Maybe what designers needed was a moment on the ropes to see what was missing in fashion: great, womanly clothes. Here's a look at some of the trends for fall.

title: Cloud Over Pakistan: Is Musharraf's Life Safe?
description: While most of the people killed or wounded in the attack on a church here on Sunday were foreigners, there is little question that a principal target was the government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who has become one of the point men in the Bush administration's war on terrorism.

description: GEFFEN-Rabbi Samuel. The entire Abraham Joshua Heschel School community mourns the passing of our beloved founder Peter Geffen's revered father, Rabbi Samuel Geffen. Rabbi Geffen was an exceptionally talented man, who was a concert violinist and lawyer before becoming a Rabbi. He was the devoted spiritual leader for over 40 years of the Jewish Center of Forest Hills West. We send our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Ruth (Rosenfield), son Peter, daughter-in-law Susie Kessler and grandchildren Jonah, David and Nessa who will greatly miss this kind, gentle, caring soul. Shira Nadich Levin President, Board of Trustees Roanna Shorofsky, Director Abraham Joshua Heschel School

title: Now on YES, It's Dynasty, For Those Not in the Dark
description: For sports fans who believe the Yankees have too many World Series titles, too many Hall of Fame players, too loud an owner and too much cash, the new YES Network is the newest symbol of the team's expanding power.

title: Presidents Rush to Zimbabwe To Plead for Political Unity
description: The presidents of South Africa and Nigeria flew to Zimbabwe today and urged President Robert Mugabe and his opposition party rival to work together to salvage this nation, which is troubled by food shortages, unemployment and simmering political tensions.

title: Partnership in Deal for Empire State Building
description: Donald J. Trump and his Japanese partner are ending their stormy, decade-long ownership of the city's tallest skyscraper, the Empire State Building.

title: State Hearings Are Begun On New York Police Pact
description: A state panel that will decide how much New York City should pay its police officers began its hearings yesterday by listening to testimony from representatives of the police union, which asserted that its members were woefully underpaid.

title: In Traffic, The Camera Just Might Be Fake
description: The city's Department of Transportation is planning to expand its program of photographing drivers who run red lights, by adding 200 fake cameras to keep the drivers from knowing which ones are operating.

title: Leaner Factories, Fewer Workers Bring More Labor Unrest to China
description: As the overhaul of China's moribund state industries enters a decisive phase, public protests by displaced workers are becoming larger and angrier than ever, with huge demonstrations breaking out this month in several places.

title: Who Will Treat Elderly Patients?
description: To the Editor:

title: Strahan Faults Giants For Weakening Roster
description: Giants General Manager Ernie Accorsi said last week that he anticipated some criticism of the team's passive-aggressive approach to salary-cap matters this off-season. But his best player is speculating that the team will have trouble competing in the coming season, and that is a little different from a talk radio rebuke.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.E.C. Suspends Trading Of Car Shipping Company

title: AVON TO LAY OFF 3,500 WORKERS, 8% OF WORK FORCE
description: Avon Products Inc., the largest direct seller of beauty products, said yesterday that it would lay off 3,500 employees, or about 8 percent of its work force, as it scales back manufacturing to cut costs. Avon said last month that it would close a jewelry plant in Puerto Rico with 320 workers. Avon employs 43,800 people, including 9,600 in the United States. The chief executive, Andrea Jung, said last month that the company would save $400 million a year by 2004 because of expense reductions, including lowered supply costs and elimination of more than a fifth of its products.

title: Deal for Enron Unit
description: Sempra Energy, the owner of the third-largest utility in California, agreed today to buy Enron's metal-concentrates trading business for $43.5 million.

title: Iranian Cleric Rejects Talks With the U.S.
description: Iran's religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ruled out talks with the United States today as a way to ease threats by Washington against Iran.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Makes Bid for Spinoff
description: Network Associates Inc. made an unsolicited $248 million bid to reabsorb its spinoff, the McAfee.com Corporation. Network Associates, which sells antivirus software in stores under the McAfee brand, spun the company off in 1999 to test the waters for selling software online. Network Associates said the business had proved itself, and offered to buy the 25 percent it did not already own for $18.64 a share, a 20 percent premium over Friday's closing price of $15.54. The offer is expected to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission next Monday. McAfee.com said it would consider the offer and issue a recommendation within 10 days of the filing, but Network Associates said it would take the deal directly to shareholders regardless of the board's response. ''This was not a negotiated deal,'' Stephen C. Richards, the chief operating officer and chief financial officer of Network Associates, said in an interview. Shares of McAfee.com soared $3.91, or 25 percent, to $19.45, while Network Associates' stock fell 26 cents, to $27.35.

title: Hewlett's Shareholders Meet Today on Compaq Merger
description: The closing of the fiercely fought proxy battle over the future of Hewlett-Packard is intended to be a comparatively low-key affair today.

title: States Seeking Stiffer Penalty For Microsoft
description: As the landmark antitrust battle against the Microsoft Corporation enters its latest phase, the company's opponents are trying to shift the focus to how Microsoft will be prevented from abusing its market power in new technologies.

title: Familiar Rhythms, Perhaps From Past Lives
description: Festival of Greek Music and Dance

title: Colin Davis and His Way Of Turning Likely Phrases
description: The New York Philharmonic's subscription concerts last week were in the hands of the orchestra's principal guest conductor, Sir Colin Davis. The program was comfortably and unchallengingly familiar: Schubert's Fifth Symphony and Mozart's Sinfonia Concertante shared the first half; Haydn's Symphony No. 92, the ''Oxford,'' was played after the intermission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKUS, RALPH
description: PICKUS-Ralph. Age 75. Husband of Patricia Belmont Pickus, son of the late Isidor and Mary Roseman Pickus, died Saturday evening at his home in Niantic. Survived by son David; daughter Karen; stepson Mark McNiven; step-daughter Anne McNiven; brother Edward; seven grandchildren; predeceased by first wife Elaine Kabak Pickus; sister Esther Pincus; brother Jules. Mr. Pickus is retired from Sperry. Shiva will be observed at his son David's home at 42 Edgemere Ave., West Hartford, CT. through Friday from 2PM to 9:30PM. Memorial donations to Hospice of S.E. Connecticut, 179 Gallivan Lane, Uncasville, CT. 06382.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Aluminum Unit For Sale
description: Confronting markets toughened by United States tariffs, the Corus Group, the second-biggest European steel maker, said it would sell a profitable aluminum business worth an estimated $1.3 billion to reduce its $2.2 billion debt. The French group Pchiney said it was interested in buying. Corus, created from the 1999 merger of British Steel and Royal Hoogovens of the Netherlands, posted a 2001 loss of 419 million ($590 million). It said it would cut 4,000 of its 52,000 jobs.

title: The Plagues of Poverty
description: Infectious diseases in poor countries kill more than 12 million people a year and play a significant role in keeping countries destitute. Hookworm creates anemia and learning disabilities. Malaria, by some estimates, has cut sub-Saharan Africa's economic strength in half.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Report By Child-Services Watchdog
description: An independent panel that has monitored the overhaul of the city's Administration for Children's Services since 1998 said in its final report yesterday that progress had been made, but warned that it ''can be all too quickly undone.'' The report urged Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to support unfinished work to improve the child welfare system, including better legal representation for parents in Family Court and more neighborhood-based services. It also announced the formation of a new advisory panel headed by Gail Nayowith, the executive director of Citizens' Committee for Children, an independent children's-advocacy organization.

description: REPORT FROM GROUND ZERO

title: A Landlord Who Says, Love Me or Not, Just Listen
description: JEFFREY GURAL, the would-be whistle-blower in New York's property tax scandal, swigs from his plastic bottle of mineral water with a shaky hand and asks the implausible: don't hate him just because he's a landlord.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about six Airbus jets selected for inspection of their tails misidentified the model number of some of the jets. They are A310's, not A319's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MICHAEL STUART
description: COHEN-Michael Stuart. Suddenly on March 18, 2002. Loving husband of the late Joan. Devoted father of Kevin. Cherished brother of Dr. Herrick and Ellyn Cohen, and devoted friend of Eleanor Brown. He was a unique and very special person who will be missed by all who loved him. Services Tuesday, March 19, at 1 PM at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

description: The station wagon is coming back.

description: KPMG and Arthur Andersen said yesterday that they were in talks on a merger of their operations outside the United States, in the latest effort to salvage parts of Andersen as it prepares to challenge a criminal charge.

title: The Pride Of Salinas: Steinbeck At 100
description: Here in the fertile California valley that was home to many of the hobos, vagrants, prostitutes and migrant farm laborers who populate the works of John Steinbeck, a yearlong celebration is under way to honor the writer's memory.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Accord On Fishing-Boat Payments
description: The United States Navy has agreed to pay $10 million to the local government of Uwajima for the sinking of the Ehime Maru, a fishing school training boat, by an American nuclear submarine, officials said. Nine students, teachers and crew members on the boat died when the submarine Greeneville surfaced beneath the trawler on Feb. 9, 2001. The $10 million will include the cost to Uwajima of a new training boat. Separate compensation talks are still going on between the Navy and families of the victims. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Mexico Leader Hopes His Talks With Bush Will Unblock Aid
description: Days before a scheduled summit meeting with President Bush, President Vicente Fox of Mexico said today that he hoped to end a months-long stalemate and make concrete advances in negotiations on immigration and American economic support for the poorest regions of his country.

title: Portrayal of the Church Causes Unease
description: In heavily Roman Catholic Fairfield County, and particularly here in the urban heart of the Bridgeport diocese where Edward M. Egan ran a tight administrative ship as bishop for 12 years, there was palpable discomfort today that had nothing to do with the driving rain or biting winds.

title: The Promotion Tour Known as Fashion Week
description: ''It's about the ignorance,'' Steven Stoute, the executive vice president of Interscope Geffen A&M, the record company, explained the other day. Mr. Stoute was referring to Claudette Ortiz, a young singer from Willingboro, N.J., whose group, City High, was nominated for a Grammy Award this year.

description: Losing something in your own living room is bad enough. Losing something in the street is so much worse, prompting the frantic retracing of the route, the desperate search of the dirty sidewalk, the hope that people are more honest than you have always assumed them to be.

title: The Tang Dynasty's Harmonious Formality
description: Dr. Liu Feng-Shueh and her Neo-Classic-Dance Company from Taiwan, which made such an excellent impression in 1993, returned for a brief run over the weekend at the Taipei Theater with a new set of exquisitely reconstructed ancient Chinese dances.

title: Indian Leader Feels Pressure From All Sides Over Violence
description: The temple that Hindu hard-liners seek to build on the site of a razed 16th-century mosque continues to create problems for the government led by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party -- even though a showdown at the mosque site in Ayodhya was averted on Friday. For even as Hindu fundamentalists persist in beating the temple drum, the party faces ever greater pressure to keep them in check.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Coronation Is Premature For UConn
description: THE opposing coach called it a great opportunity, not necessarily to win, but ''to see one of the best women's basketball teams of all time play.'' So said Lisa Bluder before her University of Iowa underdogs engaged not just Connecticut on its home court of horrors, but also all the hype of a team that had steamrolled unscathed into the second part of a supposed N.C.A.A. coronation.

title: Print the Recipes
Exploring the Intersection Of Discord and Delicacy
description: ''Hello, you guys,'' Benjamin Gibbard said. ''Welcome to Death and Dismemberment 2002.'' The fearsome name is misleading, since the tour, at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night, paired two alternative rock groups devoted to misery, not mayhem. The Dismemberment Plan, from Washington, builds on discordant guitar parts that are almost danceable, while Death Cab for Cutie, Mr. Gibbard's band, cuts open exquisite tunes to find the bare-bones pulse underneath.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: At&t Wireless Gains Network Capacity
description: AT&T Wireless Services Inc., the third-largest United States mobile phone company, will install software this year that could more than double the number of calls its upgraded telephone network can carry. The new compression technology will be integrated into parts of the company's network later this year, AT&T Wireless said yesterday in a statement. The cost was not disclosed. New phones using the technology will go on sale then. AT&T Wireless is also upgrading its network to the global standard for mobile communications, which more than 70 percent of mobile phone customers worldwide use.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Europe Votes To Finance Satellite Systems
description: European Union leaders decided to finance a disputed satellite navigation system at their Barcelona summit meeting over the weekend. The system, known as Galileo, would rival the Global Positioning System of the United States. The project is budgeted for $3 billion and is scheduled to be completed by 2008. Galileo had been stymied for several months by questions on the project's economic viability and opposition from the United States government. The Department of Defense has voiced concerns that Galileo would interfere with the functioning of Global Positioning System military signals. In a divisive vote in December, European transportation ministers refused to approve financing for Galileo, pushing the final vote to European Union leaders. The approval over the weekend is considered a victory for France, where scientific, political and business leaders have championed the project. The French president, Jacques Chirac, has said that Europe ''risked becoming vassals'' of the United States if it did not proceed with Galileo.

title: Long Shots Try to Win Spots in Yanks' Outfield
description: Juan Rivera and Gerald Williams are at opposite ends of the Yankees' spectrum, but each is hoping for the same thing. Rivera is a promising 23-year-old whose power hitting has caught Manager Joe Torre's eye. Williams, after 10 major league seasons, is looking for a sign that he is still wanted. Both are outfielders and remain long shots to make the opening-day roster.

title: A Shutter That Clicks To a Blues Rhythm; History Sits for a Memphis Photographer
description: Howlin' Wolf and his band, dressed in white shirts, snappy trousers and brightly shined shoes, laughingly pretend to pick cotton in a field in Arkansas. A very young B. B. King poses with one foot on a piano stool, holding a book of gospel songs. Elvis Presley hangs out backstage, surrounded by black teenagers in Indian costumes, at a concert presented by the rhythm-and-blues station WDIA; a sign overhead proclaims, ''Profanity or Obscene Language Will Not Be Tolerated on this Stage.'' A tearful Aretha Franklin joins Coretta Scott King at a conference after the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

description: Renhui Tian wept tears of happiness last year at Kennedy International Airport when he saw two of his sons for the first time since they were infants.

She is survived by two sons Douglas R. of Lawrenceville, N.J. and Donald R. of Irvington, N.J., one daughter, Lynne N. Potts of Pepperell, MA. and one sister, Nadine Charles of Sterling, Va. Memorial service will be held Sunday, April 7, 2002 at 2PM at the Meadow Lakes Meeting Room in Hightstown, N.J. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Lancelot Owens Scholarship Fund, 155 Morgan Street, Jersey City, New Jersey 07302.

title: Raising a Glass or Two to Better Health
description: For women, a little alcohol -- say, two or three drinks a week -- seems to lower the risk of developing high blood pressure, while more -- two drinks a day or more -- seems to raise it, according to a new study.

title: Lessons From a Poisoned Coffeepot
description: It could be called ''The Case of the Coffee-Break Poisoner.'' No one died, but 12 men who worked in an auto factory in the Midwest were hospitalized, and the incident holds lessons for emergency-room doctors in the difficulty of diagnosing poisonings, a case report says.

title: Widow Argues for Right to Sue Officials
description: Jennifer K. Harbury, the Harvard Law School-educated widow of a Guatemalan rebel leader, argued in the Supreme Court today for the right to sue government officials who did not tell her all they knew about his capture, torture and death at the hands of the Guatemalan military in the early 1990's.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Posts Loss
description: Converium, formerly known as Zurich Re, posted a larger-than-expected yearly loss, mainly from claims after the Sept. 11 attacks. The company said it lost $367 million last year, compared with an expected $323 million loss. That compared with a loss of just under $30 million the prior year. The re-insurer was, however, upbeat on prospects for 2002, in part on pledges that its exposure to asbestos-related claims is marginal. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Fresh Power in Familiar Works
description: There is little that hasn't been said in praise of the sonic opulence, virtuosity and musicality of the Vienna Philharmonic, or of the particular qualities -- some to do with the orchestra's matched instruments, frozen in a 19th-century Central European design -- that set this premium ensemble apart from virtually all others.

title: Campaign Reform's Time Has Come
description: The Senate began a momentous countdown yesterday toward consideration of the Shays-Meehan campaign finance bill. A crucial vote was scheduled for tomorrow in which 60 senators will be needed to cut off debate and approve the most important reform legislation in 25 years. This is no time for complacency. Reformers must swat away last-minute attempts to pass amendments that would weaken the bill, or to attach ''technical'' provisions that would force it to a House-Senate conference, where it would die. If they succeed, the bill can be sent right away to President Bush for his signature.

title: Tokyo Journal; One German, and His North Korean Conscience
description: After a comfortable decade as a family doctor in central Germany, Norbert Vollertsen went a bit further than most men who want to put a divorce behind him. He took a job as an aid doctor in North Korea.

title: Perez's Bat Complicates Decision on Center Field
description: Timo Perez stopped running on Todd Zeile's drive off the left-field wall in the 2000 World Series, and it seems he never took off again. Perez was nabbed at the plate and the Mets lost Game 1, and eventually the Series, to the Yankees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, PHYLLIS J.
description: COHEN-Phyllis J. Beloved wife of Jules, to whom she was married for over 61 years. Devoted mother of Ronnie Lane and Alan Cohen. Cherished mother-in-law of Bill Lane and Louise Cohen. Loving grandmother of Alison, Craig and Anna, Drew and Samantha. Adored great-grandmother of Claudia, Arden, Lily and Simon. A supremely dignified woman who will be sorely missed, but always remembered lovingly. Private graveside service on March 19.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State Gets $18.5 Million In Settlement
description: New York State will distribute its $18.5 million share of a lawsuit settlement to 106 health programs, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday. In October 2000, Hoffmann-La Roche, BASF and four other companies agreed to pay $225 million to 21 states after being accused of fixing prices. New York's share will go to programs involving prenatal care, nutrition and other health measures. The largest allotment, $600,000, will go to the New York State Coalition Against Domestic Violence; the largest allotment in New York City, $300,000, will go to Food For Survival, a food-distribution program in the Bronx. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Banks Agree To Revisions In Credit Terms For Qwest
description: Qwest Communications International Inc., which unnerved Wall Street and its banks last month by unexpectedly drawing down a $4 billion line of credit, said yesterday that the banks had agreed to relax debt restrictions in the credit agreement.

title: A Revealing Trove in Afghanistan
description: Reporters from The New York Times have discovered thousands of pages of documents in the remains of the Afghan camps and buildings of the Taliban and Al Qaeda that provide a surprising portrait of an army and how it was trained.

title: Mayor Wants Tweed Building For School Use
description: A confident Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that when he takes over control of the city's public schools he will place the central office of the Board of Education and a new school in the storied Tweed Courthouse, which was revamped at great expense and had been promised to the Museum of the City of New York.

title: California Is Tightening Rules on H.I.V. Care
description: Managed care plans in California will be required to refer H.I.V. patients to doctors certified as AIDS specialists under regulations scheduled to take effect in July, making the state the first to impose such a requirement on private health insurers.

title: S.E.C. Forces New York Stock Exchange to End Trading of a Company
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission forced the New York Stock Exchange to suspend trading in A.C.L.N. Ltd. yesterday, the first time in 27 years that federal regulators have required the exchange to stop trading in a stock.

description: LIPNACK-Ida. Loving mother of Myra & Jerry Luftman. Devoted grandmother of Douglas and Heather Luftman, and David and Kerri Luftman. Services today, 12 Noon, at Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave., Bronx NY at 167 St.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Fighting Firearms With Fire
description: The government plans to burn more than 10,000 illegal firearms to send a message to criminals and gun dealers. President Daniel arap Moi set ablaze a huge pile of elephant tusks more than a decade ago to show the government's seriousness in fighting poaching. By destroying guns in a similar manner, officials hope to curb the smuggling rings that bring weapons from neighboring countries like Somalia. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: For a Second Day, Egan Keeps Silent on an Issue Roiling the Church
description: For a second day in a row, Cardinal Edward M. Egan remained silent yesterday on the public disclosure of court records related to his handling of sexual abuse allegations against priests while he was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Cambodian Leader Rules as if From the Throne
description: The ceremonial doves know their master, and nobody around here needs to be told who that is.

title: U.N. Chief Says Israel Has Been Waging Full-Scale War
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan, employing his bluntest criticism of Israel in the latest Middle East violence, has told Prime Minister Ariel Sharon that Israeli forces have been waging what looks like an all-out conventional war on Palestinian civilians.

title: Ripples in Ohio From Ad on the Big Bang
description: A full-page advertisement in The New York Times on Sunday by a professor of radiology at Ohio State University about abstract theories of heat, the Sun and the cosmos was described by other scientists as demonstrably incorrect and, because of a debate on teaching science in Ohio, politically worrisome.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK/Leon R. Kass; Moralist of Science Ponders Its Power
description: Dr. Leon R. Kass was trained as a physician and a biochemist but throughout his professional career has been trying to heal a single patient. Now that President Bush has appointed him chairman of the President's Council on Bioethics, Dr. Kass is at last in a position to administer, if he chooses, a sharp dose of corrective medicine.

title: Citibank Fires 2 With Ties To Trader At Allfirst
description: Two foreign exchange salesmen at Citibank who dealt with the Baltimore currency trader whose employer says he hid $691 million in losses over five years have been fired, Citibank said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, ROBERT
description: EISENBERG - Robert. Devoted husband to deceased wife, Mildred (Mimi). Proud and loving father of daughters, Marsha and Lori, and sons-in-law, Ezra and Brian. description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Aerospace Loss Narrows
description: The European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Company's second-half loss narrowed 48 percent last year as it cut costs and its subsidiary Airbus SAS delivered more planes. EADS, Europe's No. 1 aerospace company, had a loss of 285 million euros ($251 million). A year earlier, the company lost 550 million euros. EADS's chief financial officer, Axel Arendt, said it would have a loss for 2002 as operating profit fell 29 percent after the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, HERBERT CARL, D.P.M.
description: GOLDMAN-Herbert Carl, D.P.M. Age 78. W.W. II Veteran, 8th Airborne Div. Loving father of Julia, Donna and Robert. Grandpa of Jordan, Dylan, Brandon, Zachery, Alexis, Gavin, Hannah & Lauryn. For service information, call ''Sinai Chapels'', 800-446-0406.

title: U.N. Takes Swing at Crooks Who Steal Aid for the Poor
description: Corruption among governments, politicians and businessmen endangers the world's efforts to ease poverty, according to leaders of a United Nations conference on aid and economic development that opened here today.

title: Mitsubishi And Hitachi Talk About Chip Merger
description: Hitachi Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said today that they were in talks to merge their system chip businesses, moving the consolidation trend in the semiconductor industry up a rung on the product-sophistication ladder.

title: Trade and Aid in a Changed World
description: In rural areas of Bangladesh, most girls marry at a very young age -- not because they wish to, but because their families cannot afford to send them to school. In some districts, however -- Narshingdi, for instance -- that is changing. Girls' enrollment in secondary schools there has more than doubled, and in three years the proportion of married women in the 13-to-15 bracket dropped to 14 percent from 29 percent. Families are getting smaller, and more women are employed, with higher incomes. The benefits will reach far beyond individual girls; they will include lower birth rates, better health practices, fewer children dying in infancy and a more productive labor force.

title: An Australian's True Self Comes Out in the Big City
description: They're calling ''Prodigal'' the first Australian musical ever produced in the United States, which creates more expectations than this small show can meet. No distinctive Australian breeze is generated at the York Theater, where the show runs through March 31; the play does not deliver a brash slap the way that, say, the first ''Crocodile Dundee'' film did.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CINTAS CORP., Cincinnati, a maker of uniforms for hotels and airlines, said it planned to acquire Omni Services, which rents uniforms to 90,000 customers in 31 states, from Filuxel, a holding company based in Luxembourg. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ALCOA TO ACQUIRE IVEX PACKAGING FOR $440 MILLION
description: Alcoa Inc. the aluminum maker, agreed to acquire the Ivex Packaging Corporation, a maker of specialty packaging, for $440 million. Alcoa said it would pay $21.50 in cash for each share of Ivex. Alcoa, which is based in Pittsburgh, acquired the Reynolds Metals Company, the maker of Reynolds Wrap aluminum foil, in 2000 and wants to broaden its presence in the food-packaging market through the acquisition of Ivex, which makes plastic packaging for food sold in grocery stores, according to Joyce Saltzman, a spokeswoman for the company. Ivex is based in Lincolnshire, Ill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUTHALER, FRANCES
description: NEUTHALER - Frances. On March 16, 2002 at the age of 93 years. Beloved wife of the late Jack Neuthaler. Cherished mother of Susan Poster and her husband Herbert, Paul Neuthaler and his wife Abbi. Adored by her six grandchildren and their spouses, Randall (Lynn), Meryl (Dan), Mindy (Steven), Howard, Jamie and Jake. Great grandmother of Zachary, Jared, Ava, Natasha, Eliza & Jed. Services Wednesday, March 20, 12 noon, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: A Better Use for the Tweed Courthouse
description: One of the most impressive things about Mayor Michael Bloomberg's first months in office has been his unwavering focus on New York City's schools. The mayor has been campaigning furiously to eliminate the Board of Education and put the system under mayoral control. Now he also wants to move its administrative headquarters from Brooklyn to the Tweed Courthouse next door to City Hall. The mayor's idea of putting the city's education bureaucracy right under his eye makes sense, both managerially and symbolically. But using the newly renovated Tweed Courthouse is more problematic.

title: BBC Pieces Played Live And Filmed
description: ''Sound on Film,'' Thursday's event at the Miller Theater with Ensemble Sospeso musicians, brought to this country four collaborative works commissioned by the BBC. Two were given with live music performed from a pit in front of the screen, silent-movie style. On the other two the composer's part was folded into the soundtrack.

title: McClatchy Profit to Rise
description: The McClatchy Company, publisher of The Sacramento Bee, said today that first-quarter profit would be higher than expected as advertising declines eased. Profit will be 48 cents to 50 cents a share, compared with the company's earlier forecast of 36 cents to 39 cents, McClatchy said. The company was expected to earn 39 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Workfare Harassment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUERSTEIN, INA KLAMBERG
description: FEUERSTEIN - Ina Klamberg, peacefully and in the presence of her family on March 18, 2002, at age 61. Beloved wife and best friend of Andrew; devoted and adored mother of Melissa, Joshua and son-in-law Ben; cherished sister of Susan Cook. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Ina was passionate, caring, and filled with a boundless love of life. She gave fully of herself to family, friends, and community, forever enriching the lives of those she touched. We will always bask in the glow of her warmth, wisdom, elegance, humor, and unconditional love. Through several bouts with cancer over the past nine years, Ina maintained a full and joyful life, inspiring all with her uncommon courage and optimism. The family is grateful to the doctors and staff of Mount Sinai Hospital for their expert and loving care. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on March 20 at 9:30 AM. Contributions in Ina's memory may be made to The Ina K. Feuerstein Memorial Fund, c/o The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, One Penn Plaza, Suite 1610, New York, NY 10119.

title: Church Scandal Resurrects Old Hurts in Louisiana Bayou
description: Nothing stays buried for long in the bayou. That is why the granite vaults and the whitewashed tombs of the cemetery behind St. James Chapel are built above ground: high water means the dead just don't stay down.

title: Deal as Politics: A Professional's View
description: The Hewlett-Packard proxy fight, it often seemed, was a case of corporate life imitating politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSHEIM, LEONARD
description: OLSHEIM-Leonard, December 4, 1934-March 14th, 2002. Devoted father of Glen and Ainslie (Scott) Kaufer. Adoring grandfather of Hayley Kaufer, brother of Jules (Lois). Loving companion of Mary Ann Canter and many, many friends. Memorial service private.

title: Derby's Crystal Ball Demands a Little Rest
description: It is hard to be patient seven weeks from the Kentucky Derby. Owners begin tasting the mint juleps and smelling the blanket of roses, trainers agonize over the right workouts for their colts and horseplayers want to have landed on their selections by now so they can say ''I told you so'' on the first Saturday in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIMBERG, JEANETTE
description: NIMBERG-Jeanette. On March 18, 2002. Devoted wife of the late Edward. Loving sister of Dr. Ruth Carol, Charles Bernstein and Edward Burns. Services 12 noon today, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, New York (Avenue M.).
