description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Colombian Rebels Included in Drug Charges by U.S.
description: A fed eral grand jury has indicted seven men including three Colombian guerrillas -- on charges of conspiring to smuggle planeloads of cocaine from Colombia to the United States. They are the first felony narcotics charges brought against members of the rebel movement.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Is Ill
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, has the flu and his trial was suspended for three days, according to the war crimes tribunal. Richard May, the presiding judge, said the trial could not continue without Mr. Milosevic because he is defending himself. The trial, which began five weeks ago, has heard 19 prosecution witnesses and Mr. Milosevic has personally cross-examined most of them. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Jolley Becoming Fixture In MetroStars' Lineup
description: When the MetroStars begin their seventh season in Major League Soccer on Saturday at home against New England, STEVE JOLLEY will be playing in his 61st straight league game (regular season and playoffs) for the team.

title: This Time, 'Forgetting' Is Healthy
description: When the first jet hit the north tower of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, my patient Alan was in his office on the 81st floor of the south tower. He remembers the blue sky turning white with a rain of paper and debris. And within minutes, the sight of people jumping to their deaths was burned into his memory.

title: Towers of Light: The View From Downtown
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: ISRAEL IS LEAVING PALESTINIAN AREAS IN THE WEST BANK
description: Israeli ground forces began withdrawing early today from Palestinian-controlled territory in Bethlehem and two other West Bank towns, the Israeli Army said, as Israel moved under American pressure toward meeting Palestinian conditions for formal cease-fire talks.

title: Taurasi's All-Around Game Leads UConn
description: During the national anthem, Diana Taurasi swayed from side to side as she always does, shifting her weight from one foot to the other like a sprinter, restless to burst from the starting blocks.

title: Islanders Seek Defensive Help
description: The Islanders, trying to earn their first Stanley Cup playoff berth in eight years, were working on a deal last night that would bring defenseman Tom Poti from the Edmonton Oilers before today's 3 p.m. trade deadline.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New Satellites to Map Gravity More Precisely
description: No one thinks that much about gravity, one of the most powerful, yet subtle, forces on the earth. It is just there, seemingly never changing, holding feet to the ground.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Boy Hospitalized with Meningitis
description: An 8-year-old Brooklyn boy has been hospitalized with bacterial meningitis, and the principal of his school, Public School 214 in East New York, met with parents and a representative of the City Health Department last night to discuss the disease. The boy was hospitalized on Thursday and was doing well yesterday morning, being treated with antibiotics, said Greg Butler, a spokesman for the Health Department. The school was notified about the case on Friday, said Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Board of Education. Parents were told to take their children to a doctor if they showed symptoms including fever, stiff neck, mental confusion, vomiting, lethargy or headache. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Sather Is Epicenter Of This Trade Temblor
description: On the N.H.L.'s Richter scale -- no relation to a goalie of the same name -- yesterday's trade of Pavel Bure from Florida to the Rangers is an earth-shaking event. Like some seismic episodes, it could be disastrous. At the very least, it rearranges the scenery and creates a great deal of excitement.

title: Bush Revives Tax-Cut Plan Providing Aid To Businesses
description: Nine days after signing the second tax cut since he took office, President Bush today proposed a new round of cuts, intended largely for small businesses, a constituency he is heavily courting for the coming Congressional elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVINGER, BLANCHE
description: DAVINGER-Blanche. On March 16, 2002, at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Bruce Brandaleone and Barry Davinger. Cherished grandmother of Tara Glicksman, Nicholas Brandaleone, Christopher Brandaleone, Steven Davinger, Jennifer Brandaleone, Bethany Davinger and great-grandmother of two. Private memorial service was held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURBOW, ROMANA
description: TURBOW-Romana. On March 17, 2002, at age 85. Widow of Irving Turbow. Beloved mother, grandmother, mother-in-law and cousin. She was a true survivor. Services Wednesday, March 20, 12:30, Weinstein-Garlick Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: John Erickson, 72, Dies; Briton Chronicled the Red Army
description: John Erickson, one of the foremost scholars on the development of the Red Army and its role in World War II, died on Feb. 10 in a hospital in Edinburgh. He was 72.

title: Bad Medicine
description: Sunday's front-page article in The Times on doctors who shun patients with Medicare may have been alarming enough; it seems that recent cuts in Medicare payments are inducing many doctors to avoid treating Medicare recipients at all. But this is just the beginning of a struggle that will soon dominate American politics.

title: Five Irishmen in London, Holding Forth About Home
description: Devotees of Irish drama may react to ''The Kings of the Kilburn High Road,'' a play by Jimmy Murphy that is now at the Irish Arts Center, as if it were a scrapbook from long ago. The works of O'Casey, Beckett, Behan and their American cousin, O'Neill are all present here.

title: Labor Strife of a Different Collar
description: Petrleos de Venezuela S.A. may be state owned, but it is known internationally as efficient and well managed, even cutting edge. The company, one of the world's largest oil producers, has also long attracted the brightest minds in Venezuela to its singular task: producing the huge amounts of oil that motor this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIECHTUNG, HERBERT
description: LIECHTUNG-Herbert. On March 18th, 2002. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Beloved father of Chaim (Sarah), Malkie Neuberg (David), Shlomo (Aliza) and Marc (Louisa). Cherished and beloved grandfather & great-grandfather. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. at 11 A.M. Tuesday. Shiva will be observed through March 25, 2002 early A.M. at 380 Kenridge Road, Lawrence, Long Island.

title: Stephen King's new collection of short stories is on the beam, literally, to would-be buyers.
description: BRACE yourselves, aficionados of the strange and supernatural. Excerpts from the newest collection of short stories by Stephen King, due out today, are being beamed through the air to would-be book buyers.

title: The Big City; Twisted, Yes, But Don't Call It Shocking
description: IN the mid-1970's, several years after we graduated from a Christian Brothers high school in Pittsburgh, one of my classmates told me the following story. It was about an awkward encounter he had just had with one of our former teachers, near a public men's room a few blocks from the high school.

title: An Easier Aid for a Lazy Eye
New Inductees Take Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Into the Punk Era
description: Teen idols, punks, a rhythm-and-blues crooner and a twangy guitar band -- it wasn't the current pop charts, but the 17th annual Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony last night. Recognizing musicians whose recording careers date back at least 25 years, the awards stepped into the punk era as the Ramones and Talking Heads, two bands nurtured at the Lower East Side dive CBGB, collected trophies in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: 'One Mo' Time' to Close
description: ''One Mo' Time,'' a revival of the 1979 musical conceived, written and directed by Vernel Bagneris, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, Manhattan. The play will have run for 21 regular performances and 16 previews.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Alloy Earnings Gain In 4th Quarter
description: Alloy Inc., a New York direct marketing and media company aimed at teenagers, announced earnings of $1.5 million, or 4 cents a share, yesterday for the fourth fiscal quarter of 2001, in contrast to a net loss of $6.8 million, or 32 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 2000. On a pro forma basis, Alloy earned $7 million, or 21 cents a share in the fourth quarter of 2001 on revenue of $64.2 million. Alloy's net loss for fiscal 2001, ended Jan. 31, was $15.6 million, or 62 cents a share. Total revenue for the 2001 fiscal year was $165.6 million compared with $91.2 million in 2000. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: When He Talks For Mexico, Washington Pays Attention
description: One afternoon in Washington two summers ago, Jorge G. Castaeda sat down in the lobby of the Willard Hotel and explained what he and his newly elected president, Vicente Fox, had in mind for Mexico.

title: State Expands Its Inquiry Into a Ward At Mt. Sinai
description: State health officials said yesterday they had expanded their investigation into the liver transplant ward at Mount Sinai Hospital to include the cases of another patient who had died and two who had complained of faulty care during liver surgery.

title: Men's Reproductive Health Care Gets New Emphasis
description: Henry Harris had a new girlfriend, and it was beginning to get serious. So last summer, Mr. Harris, 24, a high school safety officer from Brooklyn, decided it was time to be tested for H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Russia's Savage History, Florida's Relaxing Climate
description: For the next few weeks, Russian mayhem in the ice and snow is right around the corner from South Florida's freeways, where phalanxes of automobiles breathe in the sultry Southern air and practice a mayhem of their own.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Seiko May Sell Printer Stake
description: The Seiko Corporation, the Japanese watchmaker, may sell part or all of its 6 percent stake in the Seiko Epson Corporation to raise cash to avert insolvency. Sales have fallen in the last decade because of increasing competition from makers of expensive Swiss watches and low-priced Chinese timepieces. Though Seiko would raise cash by selling shares in Seiko Epson, Japan's largest maker of inkjet printers, it would lose its share of the company's profits.

title: Suspect Held in 6 Robberies of Women
description: A 31-year-old man was arrested yesterday in connection with a series of crimes in which a man arranged to meet female escorts at their homes on the East Side of Manhattan and robbed them, often while brandishing a knife, the police said.

title: Gates to Create 70 Schools for Disadvantaged
description: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is putting up more than $40 million to help start 70 high schools that will try to keep disadvantaged students in school by giving them college-level work in their junior and senior years and enabling them to earn two-year associate degrees while they earn high school diplomas.

title: INSIDE
description: Campaign Finance Debate

title: Visiting N.R.A. Heaven
description: Want to buy a submachine gun?

title: Market Place; Conseco Seeks to Delay Bond Repayments
description: Sometimes a borrower with bad credit is in a good position to negotiate with its creditors. So it may be with Conseco, the insurance and finance company that is struggling to stay afloat while it tries to sell assets and put its house in order.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Former Kremlin Aide Won't Pay Fine
description: Pavel Borodin, the former senior Kremlin aide found guilty of money laundering by a Swiss court, will not pay a $180,000 fine, his lawyer said. Mr. Borodin, who worked for Boris N. Yeltsin, was convicted of laundering $25 million in kickbacks from a Swiss construction firm that won big Russian government contracts. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Dow Slips a Bit as Investors Fear a Rise in Interest Rates
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell yesterday for the first trading day in three as some investors said rising interest rates might stunt a rebound in corporate profits.

title: Disney Is Cutting 250 Jobs at Animation Unit
description: Walt Disney Feature Animation, the creator of animated classics like ''Snow White,'' ''The Lion King'' and ''Beauty and the Beast,'' told 250 employees today that they were either being laid off or that their contracts would not be renewed over the next 12 months, Disney executives said.

title: Britain Sends 1,700 Troops to Afghan Fight
description: Britain announced today that in response to a request from the United States it was sending 1,700 troops trained in arctic and mountain warfare to Afghanistan to help the Americans flush out remaining Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROPPER, EVA (NEE FISHMAN)
description: PROPPER-Eva (nee Fishman). Mother of Stephen. Grandmother of Ruth and Vallerie. Services will be held today, 1:30PM, Cedar Park Cemetery, Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, N.J.

title: Memphis Is Courting Tyson-Lewis Fight
description: The organizers of the heavyweight title bout between Mike Tyson and Lennox Lewis met yesterday with a promoter and other businessmen in Memphis to discuss holding the fight there, a spokesman for Main Events, Lewis's American promoter, said.

title: Afghan Battle Declared  Over And Successful
description: The commander of American forces in the region said today that military operations in Afghanistan's Shah-i-Kot valley would probably cease by the end of the day. But in a sign that the United States expected continued ground operations elsewhere in the country, Britain announced that it would send 1,700 troops to help flush out remaining Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters.

title: Life and Death Decisions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Possible New Therapy For Smallpox Is Seen
description: Two years ago, long before most Americans gave much thought to bioterrorism, a small group of scientists began a series of experiments they hoped would yield a treatment for smallpox.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New City: Guards Sue Sheriff
description: Three corrections officers have filed a federal lawsuit against the Rockland County Sheriff's Department charging that supervisors conducted a campaign of racial harassment against them after they complained about staffing assignments. The supervisors, the suit said, allowed a flier to be posted that depicted one officer in the company of Hitler and did nothing when an officer made a racially offensive remark to a black officer. Joseph E. Suarez, a lawyer for the Sheriff's Department, said the fliers were removed when supervisors learned of them and that the lieutenant had been reprimanded. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTSCHUL, ARTHUR GOODHART
description: ALTSCHUL-Arthur Goodhart. On March 17, 2002, at age 81. Beloved husband of Patricia Dey Altschul. Loving father of Dr. Stephen, Charles, Arthur Jr., Emily, Serena, stepson Whitney Smith, and grandfather of William & James. Dear brother of Edith Graham and the late Margaret Lang. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, March 21st, 6-8 PM, with service Friday, 10:30 A.M. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Community Trust, 2 Park Ave., 24th Floor, New York, New York 10016.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: 97 Arrested In Drug Inquiry
description: Ninety-seven people from five New Jersey counties have been arrested on drug conspiracy charges, the largest number of people arrested in a single investigation in 20 years, the Middlesex County prosecutor's office said. The arrests, made Friday, came after a nine-month investigation and resulted in the confiscation of almost $90,000 worth of cocaine, plus cash and weapons. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Business Travel; Despite a longstanding policy of same-sex screenings, charges of airport groping continue.
description: THE great stand-up comedian Richard Pryor has a classic line, adapted from Chico Marx. This, Mr. Pryor claimed, was the way he defended his innocence to a wife who came home unexpectedly one day and found him in bed with a girlfriend: ''Hey, who you gonna believe?'' he asked indignantly. ''Me or your lyin' eyes?''

title: Sports of The Times; Rangers' New No. 9 Isn't Enough
description: WITH the Vancouver Canucks and the Florida Panthers, he wore No. 10, but as Pavel Bure scored the Rangers' only goal in a 3-1 loss to the Canucks last night, he was wearing No. 9.

title: Officials Defend Plan to End 24-Hour Patrolling of Cities
description: The Air Force secretary and the White House spokesman defended plans today to reduce combat flights over American cities and end round-the-clock fighter patrols over New York, saying the steps were justified by the increased security at airports and aboard jetliners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, IRVING
description: RUBINSTEIN-Irving. The Board of Governors of Middle Bay Country Club of Oceanside, New York, on behalf of its membership wishes to express its sympathy and condolences to the family of its esteemed member, Irving Rubinstein. He will be sorely missed.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Hand-Held Makers Choose Standards
description: Handspring, the second-largest maker of Palm OS-based hand-held computers, announced plans yesterday to develop a version of the Treo communicator, its combination personal digital assistant and telephone, that will operate on Sprint's new third-generation wireless network. Sprint's network is based on C.D.M.A., or code division multiple access -- the dominant wireless standard in the United States -- and is expected to begin nationwide service in mid-2002. So-called 3G services, long heralded as promising a new era in wireless communications, have finally started to appear in some United States markets. On Monday, Nokia introduced three 3G handsets for use in North America. Separately yesterday, Palm Inc. said it would use a different short-range wireless technology, called Bluetooth, for its hand-held devices. Palm said Bluetooth was ideal for hand-held devices because of its low power consumption and its flexibility to allow devices to talk spontaneously. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Money for New High School
description: ALAN B. SLIFKA, whose son attended the Abraham Joshua Heschel School, a progressive elementary school in Manhattan, has given the school $15 million to help in the construction of its high school. The high school, which will open in September, will be named after Mr. Slifka's parents, SYLVIA and JOSEPH SLIFKA. Mr. Slifka is founder and chairman of the Abraham Fund, which promotes peace between Jews and Arabs in Israel.

title: Two Children Are Killed in L.I. House Fire
description: Two children died and an 8-month-old girl was seriously burned last night when a fire destroyed a second-floor bedroom of their home in Bay Shore on Long Island, the authorities said.

title: Q&A / Jacques Chirac : What message for the globalization talks?'Liberty, equality, fraternity'
description: Following are excerpts from the interview Monday at the Elysee Palace with President Jacques Chirac. The excerpts were transcribed and translated by Chirac's staff. The interview was conducted by the executive editor of the International Herald Tribune, David Ignatius, and its senior correspondent, John Vinocur.

title: Do We Value History, or Cubicles?
description: To the Editor:

title: Valentine Sends Chen To Bullpen, for Now
description: When Bobby Valentine was asked earlier in spring training about the four weeks Al Leiter missed at the start of last season, he noted how Leiter's absence coincided with the bullpen's overuse. It was a curious remark from Valentine, since he believes relievers should be counted on like everyday players.

title: Bush Proposes Insurance Plan to Businesswomen
description: President Bush spent nearly an hour today with hundreds of female entrepreneurs, offering up proposals to help their businesses in a sign that the White House is actively pursuing women who tended to support Al Gore in the last election.

title: Works the Young Aren't Supposed to Like (but Do)
description: You have to wonder how the pianist Marilyn Nonken's neighbors in her Manhattan apartment building have been dealing with her intensive practicing in recent months. This season Ms. Nonken, a noted advocate of 20th-century music, has been on tour with two programs of formidably complex atonal and 12-tone music: the complete solo piano works of Arnold Schoenberg and the complete solo piano works of Pierre Boulez. Thank goodness for prewar walls.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid Urged for Small Businesses
description: Grants up to $50,000 and monthly rent subsidies of up to $5,000 for small businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack were proposed yesterday to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The roughly $200 million required for the initiative would come from federal Community Development Block Grants. Councilman Alan J. Gerson, above, one of the plan's supporters, said that too much aid had gone to businesses with revenues of more than $1 million. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Anthrax on the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Report North Korea Is Not Meeting A-Pact Terms
description: For the first time since North Korea agreed to freeze its nuclear activities in exchange for foreign aid, the United States will refuse to certify that the country is complying with its commitments under the accord, a senior administration official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCHER, MYRNA
description: ASCHER-Myrna. Beloved wife of Harris. Loving mother of Steven and Ellen, Terri and Alan Benvenisty. Adored grandmother of Alissa, Brian and Bonnie. For further information call ''Sinai Chapels'' 800-446-0406.

title: Miscellany
description: * Leo Burnett Worldwide, Chicago, part of the Bcom3 Group, is forming a nonequity affiliation with CDP Associates, Dublin, which is being renamed Leo Burnett Associates.

title: Supreme Court Seems Ready To Extend School Drug Tests
description: The Supreme Court appeared ready today to authorize a substantial expansion in drug testing of public school students beyond the category of student athletes, for whom the court has already found random drug testing to be constitutional.

title: A.G. Decker, Power Tool Developer, 94
description: Alonzo Galloway Decker Jr., who made Black & Decker into a household name by putting power tools on the do-it-yourselfer's work bench, died Monday at his home in Earleville, Md. He was 94.

title: Levy Asks Local School Districts To Shoulder $305 Million in Cuts
description: Faced with dwindling state and city aid, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has asked school districts to contribute almost half of the $686 million in cuts the school system will need for the next fiscal year, and district superintendents are warning of bigger classes and fewer programs.

title: Reading to Rover
description: At the Sands Point Preserve in Port Washington, N.Y., elementary school students read aloud to dogs. ROBERT BERENS, president and founder of the Dog Project, a nonprofit organization that encourages dog adoption and that last month began running what it calls Dog U., believes the dogs increase the students' proficiency and enjoyment of reading by creating a comfortable, no-pressure environment.

title: Pentagon's Top Cuba Expert Pleads Guilty to Espionage
description: Ana B. Montes, an intelligence analyst who was the Pentagon's top expert on Cuba, pleaded guilty to an espionage charge today, admitting that she spied for the Cuban government for 16 years because she opposed United States policy toward Havana.

title: FORTUNE BRANDS SAYS DEMAND WILL INCREASE PROFIT
description: Fortune Brands Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit would rise more than expected, helped by demand for its cabinets, tool-storage products and Moen faucets. Earnings will top forecasts of 50 cents to 53 cents a share, so long as ''strong orders'' continue through the end of March, the company said. Fortune Brands had profit of 39 cents a year earlier. Fortune Brands will report first-quarter results next month.

title: Mentally Ill Inmates
description: To the Editor:

title: In an Aircraft Safety Effort, New Technology Tests Its Wings
description: A mile above the clouds, Michael Carriker, who is what Boeing used to call a test pilot, drew a bead on the rocky summit of Mount Rainier and then began easing his new 737 down to 12,500 feet, almost 2,000 feet below the peak. ''Ought to be some nice skiing up there today,'' he mused aloud.

title: White House Wants Chief of Chemical Arms Group to Resign
description: After the failure of weeks of quiet diplomacy, the Bush administration called today for the resignation of the director of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, the international organization charged with stopping the spread of chemical weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, JEAN
description: BARNETT-Jean. The Board of Trustees and members of the Ocean Beach Club note with sadness the loss of longtime friend and member, Jean Barnett. The Beach Club card room will not be the same without her. Sandy Paskin, President Nancy Lobell, Secretary

title: Juicy Muscats From Chile (Handle Included)
description: Big greenish-pink muscat grapes flood your mouth with winy juice. The season for them is typically in the fall, but from now until early April they are available from Chile.

title: 3 on High Court Fault Peremptory Challenges
description: New York State should eliminate or reduce lawyers' right to dismiss jurors before trial without explanation, because it opens the door to racial bias, three of the seven judges on the state's highest court said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURTLE, NORMAN
description: TURTLE-Norman, 81. Of Rockville Centre, passed away March 19, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Shirley. He is survived by his dearest friend, Jean. Loving father of John and Randee, Jeri & Andrew, and Randy. Cherished grandfather of four. He was an active volunteer at Long Island Jewish Hospital, and an ardent supporter of the State of Israel. Services on Thursday, 12 noon at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Outlook Iffy Even as Goldman Posts Solid Results
description: The Goldman Sachs Group overcame a slump in corporate merger activity and the botched sale of a large block of stock to report first-quarter earnings yesterday that were better than expected. But Goldman's outlook for its business did not bode well for the rest of a steadily shrinking Wall Street.

title: Shares Edge Higher as Fed Says Economy Is Expanding
description: Stocks rose modestly yesterday as the Federal Reserve, in a widely expected move, provided an assessment of the nation's economy that gave investors further reason to believe that a rebound is under way.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Budget-Cut Battle
description: The Republican-dominated House passed a $2.2 billion budget that cuts state services, setting the stage for a battle with Democrats in a House-Senate conference. The House budget includes $100 million in cuts to counter a projected $865 million deficit that is draining state reserves. Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat, has proposed $400 million in new taxes and other revenue possibilities. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Internal Security Is Attracting a Crowd Of Arms Contractors
description: Edmund B. Woollen, a vice president for integrated information systems at Raytheon, had just started a meeting in his office in northern Virginia when he heard a thunderous explosion and looked up to see the Pentagon burning. The date was Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Canada's trade surplus climbed to its highest level in nine months in January, with exports rising at almost twice the pace of imports, Statistics Canada reported. The surplus with the United States, which makes up almost 85 percent of Canada's exports and 73 percent of imports, widened to 7.61 billion Canadian dollars ($4.8 billion) from 6.76 billion in December. The overall surplus in January was 5.1 billion Canadian dollars, up from 4.5 billion the previous month. Exports grew to 33.01 billion Canadian dollars from 32.01 billion. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: German and Dry? Of Course
description: PEOPLE tend to cling tenaciously to their perceptions, regardless of the facts. So it's no easy task for the German wine industry to promote dry rieslings to an American public convinced that all German wines are sweet. Even so, in the hope of selling dry wines, the Germans have managed to make their already complex wine terminology even more dense and incomprehensible.

title: All-Black Casts for 'Porgy'? That Ain't Necessarily So
description: The premiere production of ''Porgy and Bess'' in 1935 took place in the Alvin Theater on Broadway, not an opera house. George Gershwin and his collaborators, DuBose Heyward, who wrote the libretto, and Ira Gershwin, who wrote the lyrics with Heyward, knew that no mainstream opera house would touch the work. Not just because of its subject matter: life among the downtrodden residents of Catfish Row in Charleston, S.C., during the 1920's. Nor because of its music, which infused elements of jazz, Tin Pan Alley and African-American folk music into a melodically lush and quite complex operatic score.

title: S.E.C. Had Sought $500 Million In Failed Talks With Andersen
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission was demanding that Arthur Andersen pay $500 million to settle claims stemming from the Enron investigation, but the negotiations broke down after the firm was indicted by the Justice Department on charges of obstruction of justice, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISNER, ANTON
description: MEISNER-Anton. A survivor of The Holocaust, died March 17, 2002, at the age of seventy-four years. He was taken from his home of Sighten, Transylvania, to Auschwitz, and then to Buchenwald, where his mother, father, and brother were killed. Liberated by the Americans, aided by the OSE, an organization in France that helped the children after the War. With the help of relatives in America, he was able to come to New York, along with some of his childhood friends to start a new life. He was able to attend and graduate from Hunter College, go into partnership & create a successful business. Through opportunities and hard work, he achieved The American Dream, with a European influence. In his later years, he was able to reflect on the War and its damages in the interview for Steven Spielberg's SHOA tapes. He is survived and will be missed by his loving wife, daughter, and son-in-law.

title: Indonesia Begins Trials of Military in East Timor Abuses
description: Four army officers accused of serious human rights abuses during the violence in East Timor three years ago appeared in a steamy courtroom here today, the first military defendants to be tried over East Timor after long delays by successive Indonesian governments in bringing the military to account.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSON, WILLIAM B.
description: PARSON-William B., 72. Of Trumbull, CT. died March 18, 2002 at Shelton Lakes Nursing Home, Shelton, CT. Born in Shenandoah, Iowa on May 1, 1929, he was the son of the late Walter and Grace Parson of Centerville, Iowa. A longtime resident of Stamford, CT, he was employed at the New York Times as the Director of Management Services for 26 years. He received his Bachelor Degree in Print Management from Carnegie Mellon University in 1956 and his MBA from University of California Berkeley in 1959. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy Parson of Trumbull, CT, one son, Gary Parson of Trumbull, CT; four daughters, Margo Parson of Norwalk, Sheila Taccone and Shari Lamson both of Trumbull, CT and Michele Hope of Shelton, CT; two surviving brothers, Schubert Parson of Brookfield, MO., Victor Parson of Milwaukee, Oregon and one surviving sister, Martha McEldrry of Baton Rouge, Louisiana. Three brothers, Maurice Parson, Marion Parson and Wayne Parson, predeceased him. He is also survived by his father-in-law, Lloyd Brown of Centerville, Iowa, a brother-in-law, Jerry Brown of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, nine grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Visiting hours will be held on Thursday, March 21 at Abriola Funeral Home, between 4-8 PM. Funeral services will be on Friday, March 22 at 1:00PM at Abriola Funeral Home in Trumbull, CT. Interment will follow in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Trumbull, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 607 Main Avenue, Norwalk, CT. 06851.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Game-Playing By Subscription
description: Terra Lycos, the Internet arm of the giant Spanish telecommunications company Telefnica S.A., introduced a subscription-based games Web site yesterday that lets users play PC games without having to buy the software normally required to do so. On the Web site, Gamesville on Demand, access to a single popular PC game like Slingo and Centipede costs $4.99 a week. A package of five games is $7.99 a month and all 20 games offered on the site can be played for a monthly fee of $14.99. ''We feel our unique offering will attract a whole new audience of users who are looking to take advantage of their high-speed connections with premium services,'' Meredith Hanrahan, Terra Lycos vice president for entertainment, said in a statement. Jupiter Media Metrix, the technology research firm, expects online game revenue to grow to $2.5 billion by 2006 from $210 million in 2001. Most other portal sites offer some form of online games, but do not charge a fee. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Europe Presses U.S. on Steel Tariffs
description: With the Bush administration's new tariffs on imported steel about to take effect, trade negotiators from the United States and the 15-nation European Union made their first formal effort today to negotiate a settlement addressing European complaints that the tariffs are impermissible under World Trade Organization rules.

description: A City Council subcommittee voted down a proposal to redevelop a deteriorating city-owned residential building bordering Crown Heights and East Flatbush in Brooklyn yesterday, drawing the ire of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. It was the first time the new Council had scuttled one of the administration's redevelopment projects, a Council spokesman said.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada, Russia: Envoy Convicted
description: A former Russian diplomat who killed an Ottawa pedestrian and injured another in a drunken driving accident has received a four-year sentence in a minimum-security prison in Russia. A Moscow court found Andrei Knyazev guilty of involuntary manslaughter in the January 2001 death of Catherine MacLean, 50. Canada expelled Mr. Knyazev after Russia refused requests to lift his diplomatic immunity. The disclosure that Mr. Knyazev had been accused of drunken driving on two earlier occasions caused widespread outrage. He was released both times after claiming diplomatic immunity. Susan Catto (NYT)

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD CLAIMS A VICTORY
description: Hewlett-Packard declared victory yesterday in its bitterly fought contest to win shareholders' support for its planned purchase of Compaq Computer, the largest merger ever in the computer industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, NATALIE D., M.D.
description: GOLDBERG-Natalie D., M.D. Died on March 16, 2002. Her companion of 25 years, Matthew Barish died in 2000. Dr. Goldberg was born in New York City on May 4, 1908. Her mother Sarah Goldberg, was the first woman graduate of the Columbia School of Pharmacy; and her father Abraham Goldberg was a reporter, writer and Zionist. Dr. Goldberg attended Hunter College and received her M.D. degree from New York Medical College. Initially, a general practitioner, she followed her husband, Nathan Pensley, M.D. into dermatology and continued in practice after his death. She used her maiden name on the grounds that she became an ''M.D.'' before she became a ''Mrs.'' After her retirement at 84 she and Mr. Barish travelled extensively. She was an avid theatre and concert goer. She leaves a brother Joseph Dancis, M.D. of Great Neck, N.Y. a son Joel Pensley of Norfolk, Ct., a granddaughter Danielle Pensley and a great granddaughter Chandalar, presently living in Berlin, Germany. Gathering for friends and family will be held at 150 West End Ave today starting at 1:00PM.

title: The Fear Beneath the Burka
description: As an Afghan woman returning to post-Taliban Afghanistan after two decades, I spent my first days there, in February, trying to blend in with my countrywomen. Realizing that this still means donning the now famous cornflower-blue burka, I asked my wizened and toothless driver to take me to the marketplace to buy one. He shook his head and reproached me: ''Unless it is a religious choice, wear a veil instead of a burka. We need a few women to cast these things off to help us move beyond the dark period of the Taliban.''

title: Scented Teas With Florentine Flair
description: The pharmacy of Santa Maria Novella in Florence, Italy, which was founded by monks in 1221, has sold its herbal balms and elixirs to the public since the 16th century. Today the shop, with its elaborately decorated ceiling, left, is privately owned and also sells fragrances, teas, honeys and jamlike fruit compotes. Lafco, a shop for home and personal products at 200 Hudson Street (Canal Street), recently started selling the pharmacy's food products. There are 16 teas, mostly herbal infusions with great fragrance and intensely clear flavors, packed in boxes covered in Florentine paper ($22 to $30); small paper sachets ($10.50 to $17); and glass canisters with decorative dried flowers in their lids ($28 to $38). One tea, bergamot, is none other than Earl Grey with infinitely more finesse and less bitterness than most. The honeys, some limpid and some thick and creamy, are mostly $16.50 for 8 ounces; the fruit compotes are $18 for 12 ounces. Most of the line is also sold at La Cafetire, 160 Ninth Avenue (20th Street).

description: Franois Bogrand, who is French and who owns a food company, decided it was time to give some of his chips a French accent. His company, Good Health, in Northport, N.Y., introduced a line of olive oil potato chips a few years ago. The new selection, Culinary Chips, has such flavors as Provence, fragrant with lavender and thyme; Rose (in foreground above), pink potatoes hinting of garlic and shallots; and Bleu, made with blue potatoes and tangy with yogurt and garlic. There is also Nouvelle, sharply seasoned with pepper and salt, and Mlange, a mix of multicolored potatoes.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: $3 Million Heathrow Caper
description: Robbers hijacked a security van in a restricted zone of Heathrow Airport, taking $3 million in cash just offloaded from a South African Airways flight from Johannesburg. It was the second such incident in five weeks at Europe's busiest airport, where security was said to have been tightened after the suicide hijackings of Sept. 11 in the United States. On Feb. 11 robbers stole a British Airways van in a restricted cargo-loading area and made off with $6.7 million in cash from a flight arriving from Bahrain. The men who carried out both raids were identified as Asians, but the police said neither incident was terror-related. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Rivera Places the Blame in Brosius' Hand

Before Tony Womack slapped his game-tying double off Mariano Rivera in Game 7 of last year's World Series, Rivera thought the Yankees were assured of securing two outs on a bunt play. But Scott Brosius held the ball. For some reason, he held the ball.

title: Angola's Opportunity
description: If geology were destiny, Angola, with rich deposits of oil and diamonds and a relatively small population, would be one of Africa's most prosperous countries. Instead, more than a quarter-century of civil war and brazenly corrupt government have left it a ruin. The death in combat last month of the longtime rebel leader Jonas Savimbi opens a possibility of finally ending the fighting, introducing more accountable government and using oil revenues to build a better life for Angola's people.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Legislature Passes Spending
description: The Legislature passed a budget package yesterday to fill shortfalls in this year's $84.6 billion spending plan. Lawmakers approved about $855 million requested by Gov. George E. Pataki, including $5.7 million for prenatal care for immigrants. Most of the new spending covers shortfalls in formula-driven health programs. But the Democratic majority in the Assembly could not agree with Republicans in the Senate on other bills, including $125 million for environmental programs, $70 million for a settlement in the Yonkers school-desegregation suit and $10 million in scholarships for the children of trade center victims. The Assembly Democrats said they would reconsider the measures when budget debate began for the next fiscal year. James C. McKinley Jr.(NYT)

The semifinals will be played there tomorrow and the final on Saturday.

title: Gifts to Help Modernize Library
description: Every day, more than 6,000 people visit Bobst Library, the New York University library at Washington Square South. Now, with the help of a $10 million gift from MAMDOUHA DODO BOBST, widow of ELMER HOLMES BOBST, and a $3.5 million gift from KEVIN and MADELINE BRINE, the university is about to modernize the 29-year-old library, which was designed by PHILIP JOHNSON and RICHARD FOSTER. CAROL MANDEL, dean of libraries, said the plans included creating a gallery for special collections, a technologically advanced reading room with soundproof areas for group study, state-of-the-art computer resources and a cafe.
