title: Egan Defends His Handling of Abuse Cases
description: Cardinal Edward M. Egan issued his first public statement yesterday since disclosures of court records raised concerns about how he handled sex abuse allegations against priests when he was bishop of Bridgeport, defending his performance and saying his heart goes out to the victims of such abuse.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NOKIA, Espoo, Finland, the largest maker of mobile phones, said it had won a $300 million order from VoiceStream Wireless Corp., the United States mobile phone unit of Deutsche Telekom, Bonn, to expand its nationwide GSM network.

title: Schools Across U.S. Await Ruling on Drug Tests
description: In tiny Modoc, Calif., 150 people turned out this month to discuss the school district's proposal to begin random drug testing of all high school students.

title: U.S. Concludes Al Qaeda Lacked a Chemical or Biological Stockpile
description: After months of searching the bomb-ravaged wreckage of terrorist training camps and other sites in Afghanistan, investigators have concluded that although Al Qaeda researched chemical and biological weapons there is no indication that it acquired or produced them, government officials say.

title: Statement by Fed Panel
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to leave interest rates unchanged:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Rises
description: France's biggest bank, Crdit Agricole, said its net profit climbed 5.5 percent in 2001, to 1.47 billion euros ($1.3 billion), and that it expected profit to rise 5 to 10 percent this year. The company, which is based in Paris, had costs of 324 million euros last year related to the financial crisis in Argentina, where it owns 70 percent of Banco Bisel. The chief executive, Jean Laurent, hinted that the company might change its strategy in Argentina, because ''Latin America isn't a strategic investment area'' for the bank, Bloomberg News reported. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: F.D.A. Panel Opposes Drug Meant to Treat Cause of Colds
description: The cure for the common cold remains as elusive as ever. A federal advisory committee recommended yesterday that the first drug aimed at treating the cause of the cold rather than just its symptoms not be approved.

title: A Tragic Crisis for the Church
description: The accounts that have come out of the Roman Catholic Church's sexual abuse scandal could hardly be more horrific -- altar boys lured into bed by priests; children entrusted to the church's care forced to perform oral sex. No fewer than 55 priests nationwide have been removed from their assignments since January, and one priest, John J. Geoghan, is accused of molesting more than 130 children in Boston. The scandal has given the lie to the hierarchy's longstanding insistence that priest pedophilia amounts to just a few isolated incidents.

title: Chile Faces the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Liver Transplant Investigation
description: State health officials, widening their investigation of liver transplant surgery, have ordered six hospitals to reassess the safety of their liver transplant procedures. The hospitals -- four in New York City, one in Westchester County and one in Rochester -- have 30 days to comply. Robert Kenny, a spokesman for the State Health Department, said no wrongdoing had been uncovered at any of the hospitals besides Mount Sinai, which has been disciplined over the death of a liver donor. Mr. Kenny said investigators were studying 11 other Mount Sinai cases in which liver transplant patients died and two in which patients complained of inadequate care.

title: A Worthy Child in the Cabernet Brood
description: CABERNET franc is creeping up the charts.

title: Suicide Leap From a Train
description: Rush hour train service on Metro-North's New Haven line was disrupted last night when a man committed suicide by jumping out of a window of a northbound train near Rye, the authorities said.

title: Do We Value History, or Cubicles?
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor Tithes Tobacco Funds for Research
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey took aim today at New Jersey's stubborn record of high rates of cancer by designating $28 million from the state's share of the tobacco settlement to expand the Cancer Institute of New Jersey.

title: A 'Carmen' Directed More To the Eye Than the Ear
description: The two recurring visual themes in Jonathan Eaton's production of Bizet's ''Carmen,'' which returned to New York City Opera on Sunday afternoon, were Venetian blinds and Corinthian columns. The blinds, ratty wooden slats, hung behind the stage in the first two acts, signifying awnings, windows, anyone's guess. The columns graced all four scenes, orderly in the town square in Seville, half broken as part of a ruined church in the smugglers' camp.

title: Manhattanville Migration
description: Much of Manhattanville College's School of Education seems to have migrated east to the recently opened Long Island University graduate campus at the neighboring State University of New York at Purchase. L.I.U.'s associate provost, DR. SYLVIA BLAKE, was the former dean of the School of Education at Manhattanville. CAROL A. MESSAR, the director of admissions and marketing, was a director of recruitment at Manhattanville. And faculty members DR. JANET SIMON and DR. REBECCA RICH are now program directors.

title: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Party
description: LIKE just about everyone else who cooks (and I assure you this holds true even for some four-star chefs), I become pathetically nervous when a group of anyone but relatives or close friends comes to my house to eat. But the scariest dinner party I ever held was a turning point for me, the day I finally realized that my own standards, and not those of my guests, were making me work like a fiend and worry neurotically. It was an insight that changed the way I entertain forever.

title: Ambition and the Bird
description: I HAVE a vivid memory of the time I roasted a chicken on my first job as a full-fledged chef. It was in 1979 at L'Amandier, one of Roger Verg's restaurants in Mougins on the Riviera. I was 23.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Auto Talks Continue
description: General Motors still hopes to end the talks for taking over Daewoo Motor by next month, according to a G.M. regional spokesman, Rob Leggatt. G.M. officials have met leaders of Daewoo's union, which has demanded guarantees that workers will not lose their jobs if G.M. takes over. Mr. Leggatt said issues remain, including that of a collective bargaining agreement with the union. Lee Young Kook, president of Daewoo Motor, said G.M. and Daewoo negotiators, led by the company's lead creditor, the government-owned Korea Development Bank, face only minor differences. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: The Small-Plate Club
description: ON a recent warm evening at  Ct, a tiny new restaurant in Oakland, a stylish, electric young crowd was standing nose to nose, drinks in hand, spilling over into the aisles and cheerfully waiting to claim tiny tables. Once seated, they would cover their tables with tiny plates of food of almost every description: mussels with Pernod, saffron pappardelle with rabbit, broccoli raab flatbread, skate wing with beets. And they would sip ''flights'' of four tiny glasses of wine.

title: Palestinians Reclaim Homes In Battered Neighborhoods
description: The Israeli Army's withdrawal from this town overnight brought tentative calm here today, but the local leader of the Fatah movement, whose gunmen fought the Israelis during a 12-day incursion, warned that the quiet could not last without political gains for the Palestinians.

title: McGreevey Won't Rule Out An Increase In Cigarette Tax
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey declined today to rule out an increase in New Jersey's cigarette tax, an idea he rejected a few months ago, in the budget he is to propose next week.

title: With Prizes Near, Paper Prints Attack on Another's Entry
description: Less than a month before the announcement of the Pulitzer Prizes, an editor at The Wall Street Journal yesterday took the highly unusual step of publishing an opinion column in her newspaper denouncing a series of articles in The Seattle Times that have already won major awards and are a likely candidate for a Pulitzer.

title: Briefly Noted; 4 REBELS KILLED IN PHILIPPINES
description: Philippine troops shot dead four Muslim guerrillas in an offensive to rescue two American hostages held by a group linked to Al Qaeda, the military said. Two members of a Philippine army patrol were wounded within earshot of American troops and four Green Berets entered the combat zone to try to retrieve the wounded. Officials said American detection equipment was helping pinpoint the Abu Sayyaf rebels, aiding chances of rescuing an American missionary couple, Martin and Gracia Burnham.

title: Kemet Set to Cut 350 Jobs
description: The Kemet Corporation, a maker of electronic parts for mobile phones, plans to cut 350 manufacturing jobs in the United States and Mexico and expects to have fiscal fourth-quarter costs as it reorganizes operations.

title: High Heels, High Art
description: Italian shoes are known for their high fashion, but students at the Fashion Institute of Technology recently turned them into high art. SOOYONG AHN used an Iceberg shoe for a takeoff on Edvard Munch's ''The Scream.'' ANA REBOLLEDO created a ''double-breasted'' boot entitled ''I'm So Sexy.'' And KRISTIE NILSEN added four wheels and lace to a high-heeled number by Marc Jacobs to create a designer ''Baby Buggy.'' The shoes will be on display at World Shoe Association trade shows this year.

title: Nice Season, Poor Finish For Yale
description: Yale's best basketball season in 40 years ended ingloriously tonight when a young Bulldog team that exceeded expectations was soundly beaten by Tennessee Tech, 80-61, in the second round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: When Vengeance Is Not Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Management Shifted at Bates
description: The Cordiant Communications Group said yesterday that it had reorganized top management at its lead agency, Bates Worldwide in New York.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Working With Phyllo Dough

title: An Ivy League Team Change
description: CAROLINE BYNUM, a medieval historian and Columbia University's highest-ranking female professor, is taking a position with the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, to allow her more time for research. In 1999, she became the first woman to be named a university professor, Columbia's top faculty honor. A former MacArthur fellow who helped create the Institute for Women and Gender Studies at Columbia, Dr. Bynum, 60, will not sever her Columbia ties completely; she will hold the title of university professor emerita ''on leave,'' and continue to work with Columbia students.

title: Hanoi and New York Museums Set 2003 Show
description: An exhibition of Vietnamese culture in the early 21st century billed as the first comprehensive show on Vietnamese life to be presented in the United States will come to the American Museum of Natural History in the spring of 2003, the museum announced yesterday in Hanoi.

title: Senate Democrats, Aiming at Debt, Offer $2.1 Trillion Budget
description: Democrats in the Senate said today that they would propose a $2.1 trillion federal budget for next year that provides all of what President Bush wants for the war on terrorism but also makes more progress than the administration's plan would in paying off the national debt.

title: Bartok Keeps the Emerson Quartet on Its Toes
description: With every piece he composed, Bartok thought a lot about his target audience. So much so that he essentially developed two compositional voices, one public, one private. The well-known Concerto for Orchestra epitomized his public voice. The six string quartets, which span almost his entire composing career, from 1908 to 1939, epitomized his private voice. Challenging, ingenious and utterly original, they are his greatest works. But he assumed that only musical insiders would ever get much out of them.

title: A Stunned York Is Told His Future Is in Edmonton
description: Mike York took part in the morning skate at Madison Square Garden yesterday, relieved that he had not been sent to Florida in Monday's trade for Pavel Bure. But by the afternoon, he was packing his belongings for Edmonton after being traded with a fourth-round draft pick for defenseman Tom Poti and forward Rem Murray.

title: What Does This City Need? O.K., You Asked
description: ALEXANDER GARVIN's temporary office overlooking the World Trade Center site in Lower Manhattan is all but empty of detail and clutter -- a desk, a few chairs, a panoramic view of the city. That's about it, and, given Mr. Garvin's job, it seems about right.

title: With Rug Pulled From Under Its Feet, Museum Is Reeling
description: The Museum of the City of New York, which had staked its future on a move to the elegant, expensively renovated Tweed Courthouse downtown by City Hall, faces uncertainty now that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said he will not give the space to the museum.

title: Knicks' Strange Season Includes Late Comeback
description: Usually, the fourth quarter is wilting time for the Knicks. It is when they make ridiculous passes, dribble the ball off their feet, allow open 3-pointers, and blow seemingly insurmountable leads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATELY, MARTIN J., MD
description: GATELY-Martin J., MD. On March 18, 2002 of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of the late Mary Patricia. Loving father of Tricia & John Rowe, Martin & Mary Ellen Gately, Kevin and Terry Gately, Dr. Michael & Sherry Gately, Rosemary & Peter O'Neill, Timothy & Charleen Gately. Also survived by eighteen grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Doctor Gately was a proud New York City Fireman for 13 years.He was an Ensign in the Pacific Theatre during WW II. He was a physician in private practice in Levittown for 47 years and retired as a Police Surgeon in Nassau County. He was very involved in Fordham Prep and the MaryKnoll Missions in Guatemala. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel Tuesday and Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 10:00 AM at St. Mary's RC Church in Manhasset. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to Fordham Prep or MaryKnoll Missions would be appreciated.

title: 'Huff,' Deconstructed
description: To the Editor:

title: Petition Asks For Removal Of Diet Drug From Market
description: A consumer group petitioned the federal government yesterday to take the popular weight-loss drug Meridia off the market after 19 deaths were reported as possibly related to the prescription medication.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Seeking Re-Election
description: Representative Diana DeGette, a Demo- crat, has announced she will run for a fourth term. Ms. DeGette, a 44-year-old from Denver, represents the state's First District and sits on the Energy and Commerce Committee. She said she was seeking re-election because she wanted to focus on health care, affordable housing and Social Security. She faces a challenge from a Denver councilwoman, Ramona Martinez, in the Democratic primary in August. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: KODAK'S CREDIT RATING IS CUT AS FILM SALES FALL
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, hurt by declining film sales as more consumers shift to digital photography, had credit ratings on about $1 billion in bonds lowered by Moody's Investors Service Inc. The long-term debt rating was cut to Baa1 from A3, Moody's said. Kodak's short-term rating was left unchanged at Prime-2. Lower ratings usually increase borrowing costs. Profit has dropped for six consecutive quarters, and Kodak had its first quarterly loss in five years in the fourth quarter. Moody's assigned a ''stable'' outlook to the debt, reflecting an improved economy, overseas sales and revenue from other businesses like Kodak's commercial and components units.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIECHTUNG, HERBERT
description: LIECHTUNG - Herbert. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member, beloved husband of Charlotte, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: Arthur G. Altschul, 81, Banker, Art Collector and Philanthropist
description: Arthur G. Altschul, an art collector, investment banker and philanthropist, died on Sunday at his home in Centre Island, N.Y.. He was 81 and also lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, HENRIETTA (NEE COHEN)
description: BROOKS-Henrietta (nee Cohen). March 19, 2002. Wife of the late Abraham of Maple Shade, NJ. Mother of Carol Goldberg and Susan Tarr. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. Graveside services, Thursday, 11AM, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ (blk. 24). For information, call Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc. 856-428-9442.

title: U.S. Offers Aid to Turkey To Lead Kabul Peace Force
description: The United States has offered Turkey $228 million in aid to seal its agreement to assume command of the international peacekeeping force in Kabul, the Afghan capital, American and Turkish officials said today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR DECLINES. Sugar prices fell on expectations of a bumper crop in Brazil, the world's largest grower. In New York, raw sugar for May delivery fell 0.19 cent, or 3.1 percent, to 6.03 cents a pound.

title: Accounts
description: * HIP Health Plans, New York, the health insurance company, to the Lord Group, New York, part of Spier New York, to handle advertising and marketing, which had most recently been at the Baltimore and New York offices of Elmore Keller Marks Communications. Spending was estimated at $10 million.

title: From the Center of the Earth, the Mighty Bubble
description: IN the glare and clamor of restaurant kitchens, chefs reach for bottles of sparkling water not just to cool their throats. Those tiny bubbles that sting and dance on the tongue also give a lilting chew to noodles and dumplings, papery crispness to tempura, a lift to dips and an acerbic attitude to desserts. Sparkling water is almost as much fun to cook with as Champagne -- but much cheaper.

title: INSIDE
description: New Smallpox Therapy Seen

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Profit For Lego
description: The big Danish toy maker Lego reported pretax income rose in 2001 to 530 million Danish kroner ($63 million), after a loss of 1.07 billion kroner the year before, on a 14 percent revenue increase to 10.7 billion kroner ($1.3 billion), from 9.4 billion in 2000. Lego attributed the improvement to stronger sales, mainly in the United States, where business was lifted by new products, including Lego's licensed Harry Potter products. Lego, which is privately owned, has undertaken an aggressive overhaul of its factories and products after reporting two losses in the three previous years, its first ever. Lego said the sole blemish remained the theme park division, where high start-up costs for new parks continued to generate losses. Net income rose to 431 million kroner ($51 million), after a loss of 831 million kroner in 2000. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Global's Filings Failed to Note Business Link To Its Adviser
description: Global Crossing and the Blackstone Group, its bankruptcy adviser, did not disclose a complex communications-capacity deal that was reached with a Blackstone affiliate several months before Global Crossing filed for bankruptcy protection in late January, according to regulatory filings.

title: Senators Move Toward Votes on Election Overhaul Bills
description: Senators of both parties said tonight that they had made substantial progress on a bill to clean up the nation's election procedures. At the same time, with Republicans conceding defeat, the Senate prepared for final votes on Wednesday on a separate bill to overhaul the nation's campaign finance law.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: 2 Charged In Kabila Killing
description: Two senior officers were charged in the killing of President Laurent Kabila, who was gunned down in his office more than a year ago. The officers, Col. Eddy Kapend, left, and Gen. Yav Nawej, were among more than 100 defendants who appeared at a military tribunal in Kinshasa and were indicted on charges ranging from murder and treason to abandoning their duties. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a letter to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel in which the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, said that Israeli attacks on Palestinians resembled full-scale war misstated the site of Mr. Sharon's office. It is Jerusalem, not Tel Aviv.

title: Israel Assails U.N. Chief for Public Letter
description: The Israeli mission to the United Nations assailed Secretary General Kofi Annan today for a critical letter that he sent to the prime minister of Israel last week and released publicly on Monday.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Trades Equity For Debt
description: Qwest Communications International, continuing to whittle down its debt load, announced yesterday that it had traded 9.9 million shares of stock for just over $97 million in outstanding bonds. But the company said that the Securities and Exchange Commission had expressed qualms about Qwest's recent filing to sell new securities, forcing a delay in that part of the company's financial restructuring. In a conference call led by Joseph P. Nacchio, above, the company's chief executive, Qwest executives declined to describe the S.E.C.'s concerns or estimate how long it would take to respond to them. Qwest's shares fell 7 cents, to $8.94, yesterday. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Illnesses Halt Police Program
description: The Police Department suspended a training program yesterday after eight officers who participated were hospitalized for elevated enzymes in their blood and four more showed similar symptoms. The program is a physically rigorous course for officers before they move from the uniformed patrol force into a plainclothes unit, the police said. The illness was discovered on Friday when an officer and a sergeant reported that their urine was brown, said a doctor with the department. Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly ordered all 28 officers who took the class, as well as four trainers, to undergo further testing. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Tiny Heart Devices Reduce Death Rate, But Cost Is Concern
description: Researchers have found that they can sharply reduce the death rate in high-risk heart attack patients with small but costly devices that are tucked under the skin of the chest and can avert potentially fatal heart rhythms.

title: Regulators Raising Questions On Airline Merger in Japan
description: The proposed merger between Japan Airlines and Japan Air System, which would create one of the world's largest airlines by sales, has been repeatedly criticized by regulators on antitrust grounds. That is a highly unusual development in a country where the government is much more prone to rubber-stamp corporate mergers than to question them.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Fewer Days In School, Maybe
description: Portland's school year would be the shortest in the nation under a budget passed by the school board late Monday. If approved by the state, the plan would eliminate the equivalent of eight or nine days of instructional hours from the 171-day school year. The board, which said it was facing a $36 million budget shortfall, also voted to freeze raises for district employees and to privatize custodial jobs. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ROSETTA LENOIRE
description: BROWN-Rosetta LeNoire. On March 17, 2002. (Mother Winslow of the TV show Family Matters). The beloved mother of William and mother-in-law of Barbara. Loving sister of Mary A. Francis, Wilmote Burton, Warren Burton and the late Joyce Costello. Dear grandmother of Paula and William LeNoire and great grandmother of Adriana Collier and Jerell Collier. Visitation Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM at the ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Funeral Friday 11AM at St. Francis of Rome Church, 761E. 236 St. Bronx, NY. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to AMAS Musical Theatre, 450 W. 42 St., Ste. 2J, NY, NY 10036.

title: Large Ice Shelf In Antarctica Disintegrates At Great Speed
description: A Rhode Island-size piece of the floating ice fringe along a fast-warming region of Antarctica has disintegrated with extraordinary rapidity, scientists said yesterday.

title: Facing the Word's Absurdity, Fortified With an Ocarina
description: When three blokes walk into a bar in Bill Bailey's stand-up comedy act, they turn out to be God, Jesus and the Holy Spirit. The bartender is Werner Heisenberg.

title: Popping The Cork On Fizzy Nostalgia
description: A peaches-and-cream vision of Broadway's Ziegfeld era in glamorous bloom, KT Sullivan is as airy as a bubble in a glass of pink champagne in her new cabaret show, ''Scandals and Follies,'' at the Oak Room of the Algonquin. Airy, however, does not mean air-headed. That glittering bubble is also a nostalgic crystal ball into which Ms. Sullivan and her sidekick, the pianist and singer Larry Woodard, peer and revisit the byways of Broadway past with a refined blend of scholarship and wit.

title: Pull Up a Chair
description: We need to talk.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BMW Predicts Growth
description: The German automaker BMW expects its sales and profit to grow further this year, company executives said. They expect vehicle sales to rise 10 percent at least and top one million cars, up from 905,700 in 2001. Last week, BMW posted record results for fiscal 2001, the first year after the money-losing Rover unit was sold. The group's net profit rose 54 percent, to 1.87 billion euros ($1.65 billion), and its revenue rose 3.3 percent, to 38.46 billion euros last year. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: U.C.L.A. Seeks New End to Drama
description: For U.C.L.A., to use the local lingo, there is no such thing as a rewrite. The script is the same every year.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: XM Satellite's Future Questioned
description: For the third consecutive year, auditors attached a notice to the year-end report of XM Satellite Radio Holdings warning that the start-up digital radio service might not survive if it was unable to raise fresh capital. This time, with so many other bankruptcies in the news, investors were unnerved by the warning yesterday, and XM's shares tumbled $2, or 13.3 percent, to $13. XM, which began offering its satellite-based service last fall, said it remained confident that it would be able to raise capital as necessary to support its expansion. It is not projected to break even until 2005. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Laying a Firm Foundation for His Own Destruction
description: When Halvard Solness drops from the pinnacle of his new house at the end of the Century Center's production of ''The Master Builder,'' he leaves behind an emotional void deeper than the quarry pit he dies in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLI, PIZZI, LOUIS, M.D.
description: DELLI-PIZZI-Louis, M.D. The Medical Staff and Administration of St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center extend their deepest sympathy and condolences to the family of Dr. Louis Delli-Pizzi. David M. Burke, M.D., President, Medical Staff Len Walsh, Site Administrator, St. Clare's Hospital

title: Legacy of Egyptian Rose, In Time for Passover
description: FOR the Misrie family, the Passover seder may start with the story of the Jews' flight from Egypt, but it always ends with tales about one larger-than-life personality, a woman known as Egyptian Rose.

title: Devils Deal Arnott for Nieuwendyk
description: Devils General Manager Lou Lamoriello did not like what had happened to his team's A-Line. Too much pressure had been placed on it to produce too many goals, and if there is one thing that Lamoriello does not like, it is a team that is out of balance.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Newspaper To Make Debut In 4 Weeks
description: The New York Sun, a new daily newspaper based in Manhattan, announced yesterday that its first issue would be available on April 16. The newspaper will be sold Monday through Friday for 50 cents a copy at 4,000 newsstands and will be delivered for $2.50 per week, the newspaper said. The paper will be 12 to 18 pages, and 60,000 copies are to be distributed at newsstands each weekday. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: What $2,000 Buys
description: Congress must enact a ban on the political contributions known as soft money, but that shouldn't come at the price of relaxing controls in another part of the structure that delivers millions of dollars to candidates each year. The version of reform now apparently on its way to a presidential signature is actually a step backward. Senators John McCain and Russell D. Feingold, after years of championing more comprehensive reform, have yielded to supporting a soft-money ban that comes with a doubling of the amount that a wealthy individual can contribute directly to a candidate -- hard money. The bill raises the limit to $2,000 from the current $1,000.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Blood Test Said To Be Effective
description: A blood test developed by Biosite of San Diego can diagnose congestive heart failure more accurately than existing techniques, according to a study presented at the American College of Cardiology meeting in Atlanta yesterday. In a study of 1,586 patients who came to emergency rooms with shortness of breath, the test was correct 81 percent of the time, said Dr. Peter McCullough, chief of cardiology at the University of Missouri-Kansas City School of Medicine and a lead investigator. Doctors using traditional techniques like X-rays were correct in only 74 percent of cases when they felt certain, he said. The test, known as Triage BNP, looks for a hormone produced by the heart when it is stressed. The test won regulatory approval in 2000 but the new results should provide ''the final piece of evidence that will make this a requirement,'' said Dr. McCullough, who is a consultant to Biosite. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: FCB Agency Quits Hyundai Review
description: Foote, Cone & Belding West in Irvine, Calif., and San Francisco said yesterday that it had withdrawn from a review for the national creative account of Hyundai Motor America in Fountain Valley, Calif., a division of the Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea. Spending was estimated at $160 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MICHAEL
description: COHEN-Michael. Dearest friend, a true, one and only, special guy. We will miss you so. Helene and Jules Saunders

title: Bombardier Net Off 34%
description: Bombardier, the Canadian transport equipment manufacturer, reported a 34 percent decline in net income for the fourth quarter. Most of the drop was attributed to an after-tax charge related to the acquisition of Adtranz, a German maker of rail cars.

title: Lifting New York's Air Cover
description: In its war on terrorism, the Bush administration continues to have trouble communicating its domestic defense strategy in a reassuring manner, a failure that makes its refusal to allow former Gov. Tom Ridge, head of the Office of Homeland Security, to testify on Capitol Hill all the more baffling.

title: VIVENDI ENVIRONNEMENT WINS $1.5 BILLION CONTRACT
description: Vivendi Environnement, the world's largest water company, won a contract worth $1.5 billion over 20 years to manage the waterworks of the City of Indianapolis, the largest contract of its kind in the nation. The U.S. Filter subsidiary of Vivendi will manage all operations, maintenance and customer service to supply water to the city's 1.1 million people, Vivendi Environnement said. The Indianapolis contract is the largest since Atlanta hired Suez S.A. to supply water to its 1.5 million residents in 1998. Suez already treats the wastewater of Indianapolis and was among rivals bidding against Vivendi Environnement to supply the drinking water. Vivendi is based in Paris.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Facing Spy Charge, Serb Resigns
description: Momcilo Perisic resigned as a deputy prime minister of Serbia, he said, to allow a full investigation of charges of espionage and to prevent a larger crisis in the Serbian government. Mr. Perisic, an army general during the era of former president Slobodan Milosevic and a former chief of staff, was arrested last week in the company of an American diplomat on the outskirts of Belgrade, the capital, and charged with disclosing state secrets. He declared his innocence and waived his immunity to prosecution. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Ex-Whitewater Prosecutor Draws Fire for Senate Bid
description: The head of the Senate Judiciary Committee called today for a federal investigation into the political activities of Robert W. Ray, who recently stepped down as the Whitewater independent counsel and announced that he was running for the United States Senate in New Jersey.

title: Pizza With a Topping of History
description: IN this microchip world, pizza ovens are not exactly high technology. Yet some restaurants treat them as sacred objects, and assume that the public is endlessly fascinated with the construction techniques and materials that go into what is essentially a fireplace.

title: Final Shot Is Good But Nets Ask Why
description: The Nets left Cleveland in a fit of outrage and protest tonight, accusing the referees for mishandling the game clock as time expired -- time that they felt was on the Cavaliers' side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PURCELL, GERARD W.
description: PURCELL-Gerard W. President of Gerard W. Purcell Associates in New York. He had more than 50 years experience in the entertainment industry. Experience that encompassed an enormous variety of accomplishments. He co-produced many of the Perry Como and Red Skelton shows. Gerard Purcell was the business and personal manager for many stars and Grammy winners, such as Al Hirt and Hugo Montenegro, author Dr. Maya Angelou, songwriter Gale Garnett, poet Rod McKuen, and discovered comedian Jay Leno. He was Eddy Arnold's manager for the past 35 years. He was president of the American Conference of Personal Managers for 20 years. He produced more than 4,000 concerts. He got Perry Como to record ''Faraway Places'', ''Love Somebody'' for Doris Day, ''Java'' for Al Hirt, ''Make the World Go Away'' for Eddy Arnold, ''I Honestly Love You'' for Olivia Newton-John, etc. He is survived by his wife, actress-author Monique Van Vooren, and his son, entrepreneur Eric Purcell. Family will receive friends on Thursday 25 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral Mass Friday 11 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola RC Church, 84th Street and Park Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRIER, LOUISE
description: SCHRIER-Louise. On March 19. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Port Jefferson, NY. Survived by her beloved husband, Dr. Robert Schrier, devoted children, Paul and Lori Schrier, Helene Schrier Nankin and Ken Nankin, cherished grandchildren Matthew, Ariana, Jessica, and Amy. Services Thursday, 9AM, at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Rd. Interment to follow, Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Bonanno Family Indictment
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn unsealed a sweeping racketeering indictment yesterday of 13 people they said had ties to organized crime. The defendants included a man prosecutors identified as Anthony Graziano, the third-ranking member of the Bonanno crime family. The indictment was the culmination of the largest investigation of the Bonanno family since the infiltration of the organization more than 20 years ago by an undercover agent, Joseph D. Pistone, who wrote the book, ''Donnie Brasco: My Undercover Life in the Mafia.''

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: No Spying Without Cause
description: The Denver City Council passed a resolution asserting that no law enforcement agency should spy or collect information on an individual or group based on race, religion, sexual orientation, country of origin or social views. The resolution, which is not a law, took on more significance when last week the American Civil Liberties Union of Colorado threatened a lawsuit over Denver police files on peaceful protesters. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Malnourished To Get Help In Guatemala
description: With 126 children already dead from severe malnutrition since September and 6,000 more at risk of dying, the World Food Program today announced an emergency feeding project in dozens of rural Guatemalan villages battered by drought, unemployment and illness.

title: Footlights
description: Medalists

title: Citibank Wins Access to Chinese Consumers
description: China granted Citibank rights to offer banking services to local Chinese residents and companies, making it the first wholly foreign-owned bank to gain access to the country's $120 billion in individual and corporate foreign-exchange savings.

title: Kansas Carrying a Chip It Placed on Its Shoulder
description: In Kansas' quest to win its first national basketball championship since 1988, Coach Roy Williams has tried just about everything. He has sought good luck with various tactics, including spitting in the Mississippi River and taking his players to rub the stomach of the Saint Louis University icon, the Billiken.

title: An Orchestra That Won't Give Up; The Players Own It, And Took a Pay Cut
description: When the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra faced a budget crunch in the summer of 2001, its members made an extraordinary decision. Rather than shorten their season, find a less expensive music director or allow the firing of some musicians, they voted themselves a pay cut.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Interest Rate Raised
description: Sweden's central bank raised its benchmark repurchase rate a quarter of a point, to 4 percent, the first increase since July and the first time a Western central bank has raised rates this year. Economists said they expected policy makers in the United States, Britain and the dozen countries sharing the euro to raise rates this year, as the world economies recover from the recent economic slump. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: U.S. Acts to Shrink Endangered Species Habitats
description: The Bush administration, under pressure from lawsuits by real estate developers, is urging federal judges to roll back legal protections for nearly two dozen populations of endangered species around the country.

title: A Hot Camp Helps Sojo Toss Out Plans to Retire
description: Luis Sojo has gray hair and a lumpy body and he is continually advising younger players. Before tonight's game, he took a fungo bat and hit grounders to Derek Jeter. Sometimes, it seems, all that separates Sojo from a Yankees coach are his 13 hits last season and the location of his locker.

title: IN A SHIFT BY U.S., CHENEY IS WILLING TO TALK TO ARAFAT
description: In a shift of Bush administration strategy, Vice President Dick Cheney said on Tuesday that he was prepared to meet soon with Yasir Arafat to promote a Middle East peace settlement if the Palestinian leader takes steps to curb attacks by militants and to impose a cease-fire.

title: People
description: * Myrna Blyth, editor in chief at The Ladies' Home Journal and More magazines, New York, published by the Meredith Corporation, was named to the new post of editorial director for Meredith's New York-based magazines and new-product development. She will also continue as publishing director at More. Meredith is seeking a new editor in chief at The Journal; Susan Crandell, editor at More, was promoted to editor in chief.

title: For Arts Space, Shabby Charm Turns Sleek
description: The jackhammers are pounding, the drills are screeching. Just a little more than two weeks to go before the grand reopening on April 8 of Symphony Space, that touchstone of culture on the Upper West Side at Broadway and 95th Street. After 11 years of legal fighting over ownership of the site, after raising nearly $24 million to renovate the complex and to create an endowment, Isaiah Sheffer, who founded it all in 1978 with his friend Allan Miller, will finally get his dream, a gleaming new performance center with two theaters, a new cafe, new offices, and now, more than one shower and toilet for the actors, singers and dancers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMANN, ELSIE, NEE GUGGENHEIM
description: BERGMANN-Elsie, nee Guggenheim, March 18, 2002. Wife of the late John of Media, PA. Mother of Barbara Jacobs and Kenneth Bergmann; aunt of Norman & Debbie Sherran. Also survived by six grandchildren. Graveside services Wednesday, 1 PM, Haym Salomon Memorial Park, Frazer, PA. The family will return to the late residence. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of the donors choice. For information: Joseph Levine and Son.

title: Bloomberg Backed On School Role, To an Extent
description: The City Council leadership, in its first major foray into the school governance debate, approved a plan yesterday that would give Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg conditional control over the school system but leave the setting of educational policy in the hands of a board.

title: Owners Make Changes But Retain Fumble Rule
description: N.F.L. owners passed rules today banning artificial noise when the visiting team has the ball, restricting low blocks and eliminating out-of-bounds calls when a player touches a pylon.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Tiff About Travel Is Put in Perspective
description: The alignment of the men's Division I tournament, which begins Friday, has generated some controversy, although it is tempered by the fact that it grew out of concern over travel after Sept. 11.

title: Union Crosses Party Lines For Pataki
description: Two months after Gov. George E. Pataki engineered a deal that provided $1.8 billion in raises for health care workers, the state's largest health care union broke with the Democratic Party and announced yesterday that it would support Mr. Pataki, a Republican, over either of the two Democrats seeking to challenge him.

title: Illinois G.O.P. Taps Candidate For Governor
description: Attorney General Jim Ryan captured the Republican nomination for Illinois governor tonight, but the three-way Democratic contest was too close to call after the tightest primary campaign in this state in years..

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINSINGER, FRIEDA
description: KLEINSINGER-Frieda, 93. Loving wife of the late Harold Kleinsinger for over 70 years. Beloved mother of Jack. Aunt, cousin, friend. NYC teacher, principal, and pioneer in program for gifted children (IGC). Services Friday, March 22, 2:15PM, Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN CLARE
description: KENNEDY-John Clare. The partners, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison express profound sorrow at the death on March 15th of John Clare Kennedy, beloved father of our friend and partner, John C. Kennedy. We express our deepest sympathies to John, and to all other members of the family.

title: Mugabe's Opponent Hints At Possible Reconciliation
description: One week after a bitterly fought presidential election, the defeated leader of the opposition announced today that he was willing to consider talks with President Robert Mugabe that could lead to a coalition government.

title: Liaoyang Journal; Where Workers, Too, Rust, Bitterness Boils Over
description: This onetime showcase of Communist enterprise, the site this month of large, angry protests by displaced workers, is ringed by the rusting remains of defunct state industries.

title: New Chocolates Pop Up, Like Crocuses in Spring
description: Spring begins today, so it is time for Andrew Shotts's new line of chocolates in salted caramel, mint tea and grapefruit, among other flavors. Mr. Shotts, above, a confectioner and pastry chef, makes his chocolates, Garrison Confections, at the Chocolate Loft, 119 West 23rd Street, which he owns with Guittard, a company in Burlingame, Calif., that makes chocolate mostly for professional use. Mr. Shotts's smallish, richly flavored pieces change every season. They are $12 for 10 pieces, and can be ordered from www.thechocolateloft.com, or by appointment at the loft. Mr. Shotts holds classes, most of the time for chefs, in candy making and pastry at the loft, which is also available to rent for parties and classes. For information: (212) 929-2545.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Attack On Global 'Blood Diamond' Trade
description: Government and industry officials from 35 countries are meeting in Canada on new rules for combating the trade in diamonds mined in conflict zones. The conference, which ends today in Ottawa, aims to carry out a certification system to track the origins and movements of diamonds and prevent the sale of the ''blood diamonds'' used to finance rebellions in Sierra Leone and Angola. A similar meeting in Botswana last November ended in disagreement over monitoring policies and possible conflicts with World Trade Organization rules. Susan Catto (NYT)

title: Lower Goals For Telecom In Europe
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europe's biggest telecommunications company, has acknowledged that it will not reduce its debt as quickly as it had promised and has begun bracing for another reduction in its credit ratings.

title: Abuse Allegation Offers a View of Issues in Scandal
description: On an August afternoon in 1996, Luis Guzman, then 22 years old, made a surprise visit to the Rev. Henry Mills at the rectory of St. Joseph of the Holy Family Church on West 125th Street in Harlem.

title: AVANEX TO BUY A COMPETITOR, OPLINK COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Avanex Corporation, which makes parts for fiber optic equipment, will buy a rival, Oplink Communications Inc., for $287.2 million in stock. Under terms of the transaction, expected to close by June 30, Avanex will pay 0.405344 share of its common stock for each of the 163.7 million shares outstanding of Oplink, the companies said. Avanex, which is based in Fremont, Calif., has been reducing staff over the last year to cope with lower demand for fiber optic components. Oplink, which is based in San Jose, Calif., has been eliminating jobs in the United States to expand in China.

title: Three singers praise both the joys of milk and their mothers in a popular radio campaign.
description: THEY have worn white ''mustaches'' and sung the praises of milk, figuratively speaking, in highly recognizable broadcast and print ads that began running in the 1990's. But until now, celebrity endorsers had never actually broken into song about it.

title: Briefly Noted; PAKISTAN DEFENDS SECURITY
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf moved to counter criticism that the grenade attack on a church in the diplomatic enclave in Islamabad on Sunday reflected poor security measures by suspending four senior police officers. There was apparently no movement in the investigation of who was responsible for the attack, which killed five people, including two Americans. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: AMERICAN SKIING SEEKS WAIVERS FROM LENDERS
description: The American Skiing Company, an operator of ski resorts, said it might fall into default of its financial covenants and was seeking waivers from lenders after fewer skiers came to its Eastern and Utah resorts. The company, owner of the Killington resort in Vermont, said it had fallen into default in the second fiscal quarter and received amendments from lenders on March 18 for that quarter. Unless it again wins concessions from lenders and completes the sale of the Steamboat resort in Colorado, it will be in default for the third fiscal quarter, the company said. American Skiing, which is based in Newry, Me., said warm weather had led to a late start to the ski season in the Northeast.

title: Con Ed Asks Permission to Hold Rebates
description: Consolidated Edison has asked New York regulators to let it withhold millions of dollars in consumer rebates to pay for World Trade Center-related damages, in case promised federal aid proves to be inadequate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUERSTEIN, INA KLAMBERG
description: FEUERSTEIN - Ina Klamberg, peacefully and in the presence of her family on March 18, 2002, at age 61. Beloved wife and best friend of Andrew; devoted and adored mother of Melissa, Joshua and son-in-law Ben; cherished sister of Susan Cook. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Ina was passionate, caring, and filled with a boundless love of life. She gave fully of herself to family, friends, and community, forever enriching the lives of those she touched. We will always bask in the glow of her warmth, wisdom, elegance, humor, and unconditional love. Through several bouts with cancer over the past nine years, Ina maintained a full and joyful life, inspiring all with her uncommon courage and optimism. The family is grateful to the doctors and staff of Mount Sinai Hospital for their expert and loving care. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on March 20 at 9:30 AM. Contributions in Ina's memory may be made to The Ina K. Feuerstein Memorial Fund, c/o The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, One Penn Plaza, Suite 1610, New York, NY 10119.

title: Currents: California
Personal Shopper: A Spring Garden of Boots and Umbrellas
From the Skin Artist, Always a Free Makeover
description: FOR Steve Moss, an artist, software is a matter of substance and style. Mr. Moss is one of thousands of people online who are creating and freely distributing skins, the graphical interfaces that act as both the face and the control panel of a computer program. Rather than settling for manufacturers' often mundane built-in visuals, they make and trade their own.

title: SHELL SETTLES ROYALTIES CASE FOR $33.5 MILLION
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group paid $33.5 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the State of Alabama claiming more royalties from natural gas Shell produced in state waters, a lawyer representing Alabama said. Shell Oil, the United States unit of Royal Dutch/Shell, was sued in June 1999 for underpaying royalties as far back as 1991 for gas from Mobile Bay, said Richard Dorman of Cunningham, Bounds, Yance, Crowder & Brown. Alabama got $27.1 million in the settlement. The remaining $6.4 million went for lawyers' fees and expenses. ''Shell and the state have been working for a number of years to resolve their differences on certain mineral lease provisions,'' Shell Oil said. Shell Oil denied wrongdoing.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about John Erickson, a historian of the Red Army, misstated the period of his British military service. It was 1946 to 1949, not during World War II.

title: The Longer Ward Stays, The Greater His Value
description: They have been trying to trade him for years. In his eight seasons with the Knicks, Charlie Ward has spent nearly as much time on the trading block as he has on the court.

title: Military Tribunals Modified
description: Those of us who denounced the Bush executive order last year setting up military tribunals for non-citizens -- and who were then besmeared by Attorney General John Ashcroft for ''aiding terrorists'' -- now feel somewhat reassured by Defense Secretary Don Rumsfeld's ''refinement'' of the hasty order.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about YES, the new cable sports channel, misidentified a client served by Zenith Media, a media buying company whose vice president was quoted analyzing the price for 30-second commercials on the channel's Yankee broadcasts. The client is Toyota, not General Motors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, IRVING
description: RUBINSTEIN-Irving. We mourn the loss of a cherished friend. All our sympathy to Adele and family. Bunny Grossman and Family

title: GOODYEAR'S TIRE SHIPMENTS LAG THOSE OF RIVALS
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire maker, said shipments to retailers in North America lagged rivals for the first two months of the year as dealers sold fewer tires than expected. Shares of the company fell $2.55, or 9 percent, to $25.40, the biggest one-day drop since Sept. 17. Goodyear's shipments for January and February were unchanged from the period a year earlier, below the 8 percent increase of all shipments in North America, the company said.

title: John Robson, 71, Longtime Official Who Led U.S. Export-Import Bank
description: John E. Robson, whose leadership as president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States helped shape the Bush administration's trade and foreign policy agenda, died today. He was 71.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Unsafe PCB Levels Near Bonneville
description: The Army Corps of Engineers found unsafe levels of PCB's at a dump it used in the Columbia River near the Bonneville Dam. The corps found the elevated levels in 2000 at three sites used to dispose of electrical equipment until the early 1980's. A study, that began in May, of tissue and sediment samples from the river found that crayfish exoskeletons were laden with ''significantly higher'' PCB levels than were considered safe for human consumption. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Staying or Not, Wall St. Giants Could Reap Aid
description: The state and city have begun to send letters offering the first of dozens of multimillion-dollar federal grants to some of the most important financial companies in the world, in an effort to keep jobs in Lower Manhattan or lure them there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAKIM, RUTH
description: ZAKIM-Ruth. On Tuesday, March 19, 2002. Devoted wife of the late Samuel. Beloved mother of Dr. David Zakim and Linda Murphy. Adored grandmother, especially of Daniel. Aunt and friend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFEN, RABBI SAMUEL
description: GEFFEN-Rabbi Samuel. We mourn with deep sorrow the passing of our beloved Rabbi and spiritual leader of the past 47 years. He was an inspiring man of God who taught our children and our grandchildren in our Religious School including almost 2000 Bar Mitzvah and Bat Mitzvah students. He was devoted to every facet of our Synagogue including the Daily Minyan, and led our Sabbath and Festival and High Holy Day Services with his full strength and vigor throughout those years. After more than four decades of dedication, he retired and became our Rabbi Emeritus until his passing. He also found time for many years as President of The Queens Council for Soviet Jewry, and was an organizer of the Interfaith Council in our community, where he led religious services with members of other faiths. We offer sincere condolences to his dear wife Ruth; son Peter; brother Dr. Abraham; sisters Dessie Wilensky and Helen Ziff and three grandchildren. Nathan Gittleman, President Jewish Center Of Forest Hills West

title: 8 Die in Blast Outside U.S. Embassy in Peru
description: At least 8 people were killed and 40 injured late Wednesday night when a car bomb exploded near the American Embassy here just three days before President Bush is due to arrive for talks.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 7, but Envoy Presses On
description: A Palestinian suicide bomber tore an intercity bus into twisted metal today, killing seven Israelis. Despite the attack, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators met with the American mediator in the evening to try to hammer out a cease-fire.

title: Dept. of Dysfunction
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPAIGN FINANCE BILL WINS FINAL APPROVAL IN CONGRESS AND BUSH SAYS HE'LL SIGN IT
description: The Senate gave final approval today to an overhaul of the nation's campaign finance law, and President Bush said he would sign it, putting the political system at the cusp of the broadest change in a generation.

title: Little Hope for Accord on Canadian Lumber Exports to U.S.
description: Canadian and American officials hold out little hope that a 20-year trade dispute over softwood lumber will soon end, despite a call by leaders of both countries for a settlement by midnight Thursday.

title: South of the Border or North, Their Futures Are Linked
description: There's nothing dry about ''Mixed Feelings,'' a half-hour documentary about urban development in Tijuana, Mexico, and San Diego. The film concerns two contrasting urban landscapes that have ''an inevitable common future,'' Phillip Rodriguez, its director, said. Wry commentary from wistful Mexican and Mexican-American architects is set to Tijuana's punchy Nortec music (a mix of techno and nortea, the music of the border) and snappy digital imagery. ''Mixed Feelings'' can be seen on PBS stations in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, JEANNET
description: SIEGEL-Jeannet. March 20, 2002. Beloved mother of Margie and Alan Starensier, and Carol and Ralph Perlberger. Beloved grandmother of Amy, David, Jody and Jillian. Beloved great-grandmother of Hannah, Ali, Josie, Zoe and Zach. Beloved friend to many. Family will be at Carol's home Monday, March 25th, at 5PM.

title: In Los Angeles, a Traveler's Best Friend
description: Since Sept. 11, airport security officials have been armed with an array of new high-tech weapons in the battle against terrorism. Officer Michael Ahumada of the Los Angeles International Airport police force keeps the most important item in her arsenal tucked discreetly in a pocket just below her gun.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Trading Halt
description: The Prague Stock Exchange suspended trading in shares of a Czech telecommunications group controlled by Deutsche Bank of Germany and the Danish telecommunications operator TDC. Regulators called on the company, Ceske Radiokomunikace, to tell minority shareholders the details of its planned breakup after its shares have fallen 17 percent since Monday. The company says it wanted to cut its registered capital by 99 percent, transfer its assets to a Cayman Islands company and issue nontradable shares to current shareholders. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Render Unto Buddha

title: U.S. MIGHT PURSUE QAEDA AND TALIBAN TO PAKISTAN LAIRS
description: The commander of American forces here said today that they might cross the border into Pakistan to capture or kill Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters widely believed to have found sanctuary there.

title: Compaq Shareholders Approve Sale to Hewlett-Packard
description: Compaq Computer said yesterday that its shareholders had overwhelmingly approved its $24 billion purchase by Hewlett-Packard, a day after Hewlett's managers declared a narrow victory in the hotly contested proxy battle.

title: Mets Get a New Proposal
description: As promised, Doug Anderson, the administrator of St. Lucie County, planned to send a package of proposals to the Mets today for capital improvements that would be made if the team were to extend its lease at Thomas J. White Stadium. A 15-year agreement expires next February, and the Mets have until August to exercise a five-year option.

title: A Moving Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Batteries Promise Not to Fade Before the Light Does
description: Digital cameras have a reputation for slurping down battery power like linemen at the Gatorade table during a summer football practice. A new long-lasting battery may give photographers many more snaps per pack in a year that some industry analysts are predicting a 29 percent increase in digital camera sales. It could mean a lot less fumbling to change the batteries before the baby moves.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Tax Assessor Public Hearing
description: The New York State Assembly has scheduled a public hearing on possible legislation resulting from the recent bribery scandal involving New York City tax assessors. Association of the Bar of the City of New York, Meeting Hall, 42 West 44th Street, Manhattan, 10:30 a.m. Information: (518) 455-3888.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Immigrants Killed In Minefield
description: Two immigrants from Turkey believed to be Kurds were killed and one seriously wounded while trying to sneak into Greece through a minefield on the northeastern border with Turkey. Thousands of economic and political refugees try to enter wealthier European Union countries through Greece. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Scandal in the Church: A Time of Anguish
description: To the Editor:

title: The King Will See You Now
description: JERRY CADORETTE and I were holding hands the other day, as Mr. Cadorette, red-haired and blue-eyed as a rare tiger, explained the finer points -- wrist angle, elbow drag, shoulder alignment -- of his sport. Mr. Cadorette, a sales manager at a Nissan and Volvo dealership, is also a professional arm-wrestler.

title: Scandal in the Church: A Time of Anguish
description: To the Editor:

title: Refs' Call Is Seconded By League
description: The National Basketball Association offered no consolation to the Nets today after Stu Jackson, the league's senior vice president for basketball operations, spoke with game officials and supported their decision to allow Cleveland's game-winning 3-pointer on a play that began with five-tenths of a second remaining Tuesday night.

title: In Microsoft Case, RealNetworks Says Competition Is Unfair
description: A RealNetworks executive accused Microsoft today of withholding information that would have allowed RealNetworks' video and audio software to work as well with Microsoft's operating system as rival software made by Microsoft does.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the expected testimony of major credit rating agencies at a Congressional hearing into the collapse of Enron gave an outdated name for one agency. It is Fitch Ratings, no longer Fitch Investors Service.

title: Many Hispanics, Scant Marketing
description: Maybe the most important thing that ever happened in this country for Hispanics wanting to read relevant books was the 2000 census. It said, hey, publishers, there are 35.3 million Latinos out there. So book publishers started to awaken from the somnolence that often embraces them when it comes to the new and started to take notice. Awakened might be too strong a word, but things are slowly changing for Hispanic writers and their audience.

title: Annan's Careless Language
description: A redefinition of the Middle East conflict occurred last week when Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations called Israel's occupation of lands acquired in the 1967 Six Day War ''illegal.'' A new and provocative label of ''illegality'' is now out of the chute and running loose, ready to wreak damage. The worst prospect is that Palestinians will dig in with a new feeling of righteousness and believe that the international community will force Israel to withdraw from its ''illegal occupation.''

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: A Warm Place to Go

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNER, MIRIAM
description: KRASNER-Miriam. Passed away on March 15, 2002 in Palo Alto, CA at age 77 of complications related to Parkinson's disease. Born in NYC to Sarah and David Shostak on January 27, 1925, she was a much beloved wife, mother, grandmother, educator and friend. Married to Leonard Krasner for almost 55 years, she is also survived by her children Wendy (Richard Levine) of Bethesda, MD; David (Marsha) of Rutland, VT; Charlie (Lisa) of Stockton, CA; and Stefanie (Maureen Farran) of Los Angeles; grandchildren Robin, Michelle, Zachary, Henry and Harry; siblings Selma Rosenbaum (Lawrence, NY), Dorothy Moss (Las Vegas, NV) & Jerry Shostak (Staten Island); & scores of loving friends. Miriam graduated from NY City College and received a Master's in Education from Columbia. She taught elementary school at the Three Village School District in Stony Brook from the mid-60s to the mid-80s. She collaborated with her husband, Leonard Krasner, psychology professor emeritus, SUNY Stony Brook, on numerous articles, speeches and textbooks. She was active in Hadassah, the Sherlock Holmes Society, and several other longstanding book clubs. Gatherings to celebrate her life will be held on the West Coast and the East Coast at a future date. In lieu of flowers, her family requests donations be sent to Spiritual Care Services, Stanford University Hospital, 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford, CA 94305, Attn: Jewish Chaplaincy, or the charity of your choice.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a Bush administration proposal to consolidate some agencies that control border activity omitted a reference to the news organization that disclosed the scheduling of a meeting on the subject. It was The Washington Post.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16, 20

title: New List of Safe AIDS Drugs, Despite Industry Lobby
description: In a move that could help bring down the price of AIDS medicines for poor countries, the World Health Organization today released its first list of manufacturers of safe AIDS drugs, which included a large Indian producer of generics and three smaller European ones.

title: For Hemingways With Hand-Helds, Typing With Both Fists
description: For most people, using a stylus to scrawl information about contacts and appointments into a hand-held device may be speedy enough, but for punching in long memos, e-mail or the great American novel, only a keyboard will do.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Falls On Analyst Comment
description: Intel sales may fall in the second quarter from the first because of seasonal trends and prices on Pentium 4 chips that probably will not change, a Salomon Smith Barney semiconductor industry analyst said. Intel shares fell $1.19, or 3.8 percent, to $30.53. ''Intel could record a modest seasonal decline in second-quarter revenue,'' the analyst, Jonathan Joseph, wrote in a report. He cut his second-quarter sales estimate to $6.7 billion from $6.9 billion and trimmed his profit estimate to 14 cents a share from 16 cents.

title: Beijing Increases Detentions of Illegal North Korean Immigrants
description: China is stepping up its detention of North Koreans living illegally in China, diplomats and aid workers along the border say. The move is apparently a response to the defection of 25 North Koreans who stormed the Spanish Embassy in Beijing last week, demanding political refugee status and safe passage to South Korea, which they reached after being allowed to go to the Philippines.

title: Russians to Keep Limits on Oil Exports Through June
description: Executives from Russia's biggest oil companies met with Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov today and agreed to extend through the second quarter the cuts of 150,000 barrels a day in the country's oil exports.

title: MALAN REALTY, SHOPPING CENTER OWNER, TO LIQUIDATE
description: Malan Realty Investors Inc., citing a decline in its stock price, said its board voted to sell the company's 58 shopping center assets and liquidate the company. The plan by Malan, which leases more space to the bankrupt retailer Kmart than all but two other real estate investment trusts, is subject to shareholder approval, said Fred Nachman, a company spokesman. The company's shares have fallen 43 percent over the last 12 months. Malan, with a stock market value of about $29 million, had about $199 million of mortgage debt, convertible bonds and convertible notes at the end of the third quarter, according to Securities and Exchange Commission filings. The company leases 27 stores with three million square feet of space to Kmart. The Kimco Realty Corporation's 75 Kmart locations total 7.8 million square feet, and New Plan Excel Realty's 40 Kmart stores have 3.7 million square feet.

title: Moving Beyond Sept. 11 by Staying Closely Tied to It
description: CHRISTY FERER'S warm brown eyes start to glisten. She is recalling how she nearly grabbed black-and-white cookies when she went grocery shopping. A reflex. They were favorites of her husband, Neil D. Levin, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, who died in the World Trade Center attack.

title: Justice Dept. Wants to Query More Foreigners
description: The Justice Department announced today that it was expanding its program of interviewing young, mostly Muslim foreign men visiting the United States, saying it would try to track down and speak to an additional 3,000 of them for information about terrorism.

title: Calling In the Makeover Medics
description: I SUPPOSE you could say I felt the way any troubled person would right before picking up the phone and finally calling for professional help: desperate, resigned, deeply relieved. The help I needed, though, wasn't psychiatric, physical or spiritual (at least, not technically). It was domestic, spatial, aesthetic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEEN, JANIS
description: BEEN-Janis. Beloved wife of Hal. Loving mother of Alan, Hope and Meryl. Cherished grandmother. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 10 A.M. Thursday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Toasting a Season With Snow, Not Soap
description: Chet Huntley, the staid NBC broadcaster, developed Big Sky Resort in the early 1970's most likely never imagining its annual ski party would come to be known as dirtbag day.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEARN, WILLIAM G.
description: SHEARN-William G., 72. Of Sarasota, FL on March 19, 2002. Graduate of the Cornell School of Hotel Administration. Survived by one brother Gregory of Greentown, PA., and nieces Marcella Dietz of McLean, VA and Claudia O'Donnell of Winchester, MA. Predeceased by his sister Marcella Shearn Hanlon. Interment private Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Memorial Mass Friday, April 5, 2002, 11 AM Church of St. Matthew, R.C., Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Memorials to Cornell School of Hotel Administration or the American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: Sports of The Times; A Tough Choice for Wildcat Partisans
description: Talk about a sense of entitlement: upon arriving in town today, Mike Krzyzewski immediately attributed all those ball caps and sweatshirts with the letter K on them to a massive outpouring of respect and love for him.

title: State Again Expands Its Inquiry Into Mt. Sinai Liver Transplants
description: Once again yesterday, state health officials expanded their investigation into liver surgery procedures at Mount Sinai Hospital, focusing on 13 cases in which transplant recipients died and 3 others in which people complained of inadequate care.

title: Scandal in the Church: A Time of Anguish
description: To the Editor:

title: Party Lines Begin to Emerge As Congress Debates Enron
description: As Congress began rewriting the law today in response to the Enron debacle, Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, urged lawmakers to reject a raft of Democratic proposals restricting the accounting industry.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Warning Of Budget Risks
description: City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. warned yesterday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed budget could fall $1 billion short of closing the city's $4.76 billion deficit in the fiscal year that begins July 1. Mr. Thompson issued a report that identified $1.8 billion in potential risks in the mayor's budget, warning of a possible worst-case situation in which the state and federal governments fail to take actions that the mayor is counting on, overtime costs increase more than anticipated, and labor and pension costs grow. The comptroller also identified $870 million in additional resources, contending that the surplus at the end of 2002 will be higher than the mayor expects, tax revenues will be more robust and the city will be able to write off liabilities. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Relic in a Cave: But What War?
description: After raising the haunting prospect that a global positioning device found in Afghanistan had belonged to a serviceman killed in Somalia in 1993, the Pentagon said tonight that it had been lost by a pilot who served in Afghanistan.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Chirac Inquiry Can Proceed
description: A court has refused to halt an investigation into more than $300,000 in cash payments for luxury trips made by President Jacques Chirac, his family and entourage in the early 1990's, when he was mayor of Paris. The ruling means that Mr. Chirac, who currently has judicial immunity as president, could be called for questioning if he loses the presidential election next month. He has denied any wrongdoing. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Talks To Resume
description: Talks on the future of the country will resume today, a week after the government withdrew because of a rebel attack in eastern Congo, said Ketumile Masire, the facilitator of the inter-Congolese dialogue. The negotiations, in South Africa, are expected to go on until mid-April and produce a transition government. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMANN, ROLF DIETER
description: HARTMANN-Rolf Dieter. Of Cold Spring Harbor, New York. On Mar. 17, 2002, age 68 at Manasota Key, Florida after a courageous battle with cancer. Devoted and loving husband of Carlotta for 45 years, & adoring father of Erika Couture and her husband Joseph of Colchester, Vermont; Lisa Matricardi & her husband Robert of Dunedin, Florida; Christian Hartmann of Oyster Bay, NY; and Alexander Hartmann of Seattle, Washington, as well as the very loving and proud grandfather of Samantha, Olivia, and Ethan Couture, and Mason Matricardi. He was the son of the late F.W. Hartmann and Edith Hartmann Farley, both originally of Bremen, Germany, and brother of Peter W. Hartmann of Bronxville, NY. Mr. Hartmann graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1951, & from Harvard College in 1955. After serving in the US Coast Guard as a commissioned officer, he spent his entire career in the steamship industry, & was a founder of Containership Agency, Inc. He was vice president of the German Seaman's Mission of New York, and has served on various volunteer boards including The German Society of The City of NY and the Society of St. Johnland. He will be remembered by all for his sense of honor, integrity, kindness and generosity of spirit. He was always a true gentleman. A small service will be held in Florida as well as a memorial service to be held 11:00 AM Thursday, Mar. 28 at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in his memory to Phillips Exeter Academy, 20 Main Street, Exeter, N.H. 03833.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: More Labor Leaders Detained
description: Three more leaders of labor protests in the northeastern city of Liaoyang were detained yesterday as several thousand workers demonstrated at city offices for the fourth straight day, participants reported. The workers say they have not received back wages and pensions or adequate benefits since the bankruptcy of their state-owned factories and they have denounced local officials for corruption. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: GOVERNMENT SETS RULES FOR MILITARY ON WAR TRIBUNALS
description: The Bush administration has set the rules for conducting military tribunals for prisoners from the Afghan war, opening the door for the United States to prosecute and possibly execute foreigners by a legal process not used since the Truman presidency after World War II.

title: Second Act for Hong Kong Billionaire
description: If clothes make the man, then Richard Li is a very different person from the one he was a year ago.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: A Policy Of Kindness
description: Legislators are considering a resolution to make the idea of ''treat others as you would like to be treated'' an official state policy. The House Human Services Committee unanimously endorsed the resolution this week. The full House will debate it. Eddie Farnsworth, a Republican House member, said the policy might make people ''more courteous.'' The resolution would not be legally binding. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Pictures with the Metro Briefing column yesterday were reversed. Alan J. Gerson, a New York City councilman, should have been shown with the report about a council proposal he supports to aid downtown businesses. Richard L. Judd, the president of Central Connecticut State University, should have appeared with the report about a reprimand he received from the university's trustees for having impersonated a police officer.

title: Attack Puts Israeli Army On Edge In the North
description: A few feet over the border fence at this concrete outpost facing southern Lebanon, the yellow and green flags of Hezbollah and a billboard taunt Israeli soldiers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Setback for Bristol-Myers Spurs Rumors of a Merger

title: A 'Green' Car Built for Four (Plus Dog)
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Major Issue in Age Bias Law
description: Discrimination in the workplace can be subtle and hard to prove. For that reason, Congress and the Supreme Court have devised rules enabling workers who lack direct evidence of intentional race or sex discrimination to sue their employers by showing that a seemingly neutral policy falls more harshly on one group than another without a valid business reason for the disparity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINBERGH, GOSTA
description: WINBERGH-Gosta. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the untimely death of our friend and colleague, Gosta Winbergh, who sang six roles with our Company. He made his debut in 1983 as Don Ottavio in ''Don Giovanni'' and also appeared here in other Mozart roles as well as Don Jose in ''Carmen'', a role he was to reprise with us next season. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Elena, and his family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFENBAUER, BERDIE
description: SCHIFFENBAUER - Berdie. Be loved wife to Morris. Devoted mother to Susan and Aaron Fruchter, and Marty. Special grandmother and great grandmother. Caring sister to Leo Feuer, Sol Feuer, and Edith Weg.

title: Final Report By Prosecutor On Clintons Is Released
description: In a final report that ends the Whitewater investigation that sprawled across a range of subjects and vexed President Bill Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton for most of his two terms in the White House, the independent counsel's office said today that there was insufficient evidence to show that either committed any crimes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 Charged In Prostitution Ring
description: Three men were charged yesterday with running two prostitution services that charged up to $650 per session, generating more than $2 million a year, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said. The defendants -- Anthony J.
