Nastasi, Joseph Birro and Scott Rosenberg -- were also charged with money laundering, and were arraigned last night in Criminal Court in Manhattan. The names of the defendants' lawyers could not be determined last night. The investigation began with a tip from a state judge who noticed in a divorce proceeding that a husband had frequented the escort services. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: A Glowing Delphic Orb Says 'Buy,' 'Hold' or 'Panic'
description: If the devil is in the details, don't tell the people at Ambient Devices in Cambridge, Mass. The company is staking its future on a demand for more timely and personalized yet less specific information from gadgets and computers.

title: Scandal in the Church: A Time of Anguish
description: To the Editor:

title: Projector Makes the Pictures That Got Small Big Again
description: For those who want the home theater experience without the bulk of a home entertainment system, the InFocus ScreenPlay 110 might be the answer. The six-pound projector connects to devices like television sets and video game consoles and projects an image on a wall up to 25 feet away. The company recommends projection of a 5-by-8-foot image, larger than that of most big-screen televisions.

title: What Price Merger?
description: The ferocious six-month struggle between Hewlett-Packard's management and its founding families for the hearts and minds of 900,000 shareholders was unprecedented in many ways. So it should come as no surprise that Tuesday's shareholder vote turned out to be a cliffhanger, more befitting a political race than a corporate proxy contest.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sanyo Cuts Profit Target
description: The Sanyo Electric Company slashed its profit target 89 percent for the year ending March 31 because of slower sales of electronics. The company, which dominates the market for cellular phone batteries, expects to earn 1.5 billion yen ($11.4 million). Sanyo will also write down the value of its equity portfolio under new accounting rules that require companies to price their holdings at current market prices. Sanyo said sales would fall 3.8 percent below previous estimates. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Proper Table for Passover, Then Easter
description: I USED to worry that our household's unusual holiday traditions might confuse the children. But I didn't fully realize the toll they took on the fellow who bags our groceries until one recent day when he held aloft two boxes, one full of matzos for Passover and the other harboring pastel tablets of Easter egg dye, and asked cautiously, ''Are these both yours?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, JEAN W.
description: BARNETT-Jean W. The Boards of Trustees, physicians and staff of Monmouth Medical Center and Monmouth Health Care Foundation mourn the passing of a very special benefactor and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Dr. Lester A. Barnett, her family and friends

title: Grinding Terror or Grand Adventure? Choose Your War
description: OPERATION FLASHPOINT:

title: In Film, Three Country Houses Make One Gosford Park
description: In the movie ''Gosford Park,'' nominated for seven Oscars, the dowager played by Maggie Smith scorns Hollywood. But England's landed gentry needs Hollywood, or at least the income from renting its country houses as movie sets. It took three English estates to play Gosford Park. The facade is Luton Hoo in Bedfordshire (below); the drawing rooms were in Wrotham Park, in Middlesex; and the bedrooms were in Syon House, near London. Starting Wednesday, the bedrooms at Syon House will be open -- adults, $10; (011) 44-20-8560-0881; www.syonpark.co.uk. The Syon House gardens (by Capability Brown) can be seen on the CBS ''Early Show'' at 8:36 a.m. tomorrow, New York time.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on March 13 about Dr. James Tobin, who received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, misstated his tenure on the Council of Economic Advisers. He served for two years under President John F. Kennedy but did not remain under President Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Nets Leave Nothing To Chance Or Judgment
description: The Nets felt cheated out of one victory; they were not about to rely on a referee's judgment in the fourth quarter to decide this one. They relied instead on the indomitable grit, flash and will of Jason Kidd, who embodied the defiant attitude of each of his teammates eager to erase what happened Tuesday night.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Media Merger Scrapped
description: Kirch Holding, Germany's second-biggest media company, scrapped a merger of two units and said it would eliminate a third of the jobs at its pay television business as it struggles to pay back $5.7 billion in debt. Canceling the planned union of ProSiebenSat1 Media, the television business, with KirchMedia, the film unit, may pave the way for a sale of the TV unit to an investor like Rupert Murdoch, analysts said. Kirch, run by its founder, Leo Kirch, 75, was forced to sell assets after creditors including Dresdner Bank asked for their money back. The company, which is based in Munich, needs $1 billion in cash by next month.

title: Flying Puck That Hit Girl Caused a Rare Brain Injury
description: A 13-year-old girl who died on Monday night, two days after being hit in the forehead with a puck at an N.H.L. game in Columbus, Ohio, sustained a rare injury in which an artery leading to her brain ruptured when her head snapped back, a coroner said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Shrinks
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus shrank 11.3 percent in February as exports slowed in the midst of the Chinese New Year, when many businesses in Asia are closed. Over all, exports fell 4.2 percent while imports fell 2.4 percent. The size of the declines in the surplus are narrowing, however, as demand for Japanese products picks up overseas. Japanese steel exports to the United States rose 24.6 percent from February 2001. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: 'You'll Pure Because I Said So'
description: BE careful what you say around the house. Your appliances may be listening.

title: Study Suggests Racial Gap In Speeding In New Jersey
description: Two years ago, when the Justice Department forced New Jersey officials to adopt new policies to discourage racial profiling by state troopers, it also told the state to study the driving habits of black and white motorists on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUZIN, DANIEL M.
description: STUZIN-Daniel M. 32 years old died on March 18, 2002. Beloved son of Gerald and Marie. Loving brother of Nina and Gary Vincoff. Cherished uncle of Zoe and Sophia. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to B'nai B'rith Metro North or Fordham University Law School.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: WorldCom Sued By Employees
description: WorldCom; Bernard J. Ebbers, left, its chief executive; and Scott D. Sullivan, its chief financial officer, have been sued on behalf of current and former employees who say the company's 401(k) retirement plan, for which the two executives were trustees, wrongfully bought and held WorldCom stock for a period in 2000 when they knew the company was overvalued. The suit, filed on Monday in the Federal District Court in San Francisco, argues that WorldCom inflated its earnings, revenue and cash flow and that Mr. Ebbers and Mr. Sullivan reaped millions of dollars selling shares before the stock tumbled. WorldCom's shares fell to $18.20 from nearly $49 from Feb. 8, 2000, to Nov. 1, the period covered by the suit. WorldCom officials said the suit was baseless because employees had control over their 401(k) portfolios, including options to have no WorldCom stock. In addition, WorldCom said, Mr. Ebbers and Mr. Sullivan have not been trustees of the plan since 1995. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: SHARES OF STATION CASINOS RISE ON LAS VEGAS OUTLOOK
description: Shares of Station Casinos Inc. rose 12 percent after the owner of Las Vegas-area casinos said its first-quarter and 2002 earnings would beat analysts' estimates because the city's economy was improving. Station Casinos shares rose $1.70, to $15.95. First-quarter profit before charges will be 16 cents to 18 cents a share, the chief financial officer, Glenn Christenson, said. The company is expected to earn 10 cents a share by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Prosecutors Say Tapes Show Jailed Mob Boss Isn't Crazy
description: When Vincent Gigante, the convicted Mafia leader who says he is insane, called from prison, he said his daughter was under the weather. Laryngitis.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Fire Threatened Historic Town
description: Firefighters contained a morning fire that threatened Nevada City, one of the best-preserved of the Sierra Nevada gold rush towns, 60 miles northeast of Sacramento. More than 100 firefighters battled the fire, which gutted a historic two-story building that housed a restaurant, an herb shop, a theater and the County Probation Department. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Talks Could Return Land To Indians
description: Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton said that as part of negotiations over using water and land in the Klamath Basin the federal government could return to Indian tribes reservation land that it acquired in the 1960's. Much of the 690,000 acres is national forest, but the tribes retain hunting, fishing and water rights. The talks are part of an effort to find a compromise among farmers, anglers and environmentalists. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: The $2,000 Answer
description: Despite passage of the most ambitious campaign bill since the Watergate era, many players in financing elections will find their roles untouched -- or even enhanced.

title: Facing Outcry, NBC Ends Plan To Run Liquor Commercials
description: Bowing to criticism, NBC said yesterday that it was ending a three-month-old experiment that would have brought the first liquor advertisements onto national broadcast network television.

title: Coalition Asks for Federal Government Assistance in Saving the Highlands
description: Pointing to the current drought, a coalition of environmental and civic groups called on the federal government today to take a broader role in planning and financing land preservation in the New York-New Jersey Highlands, a swath of the Appalachians that provides drinking water for 11 million people in the metropolitan region.

title: Westchester Teacher Is Charged With Abuse
description: A grade-school computer teacher in affluent Briarcliff Manor was charged today with sexually abusing five girls, ages 9 and 10, and the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said she expected more charges to follow.

title: Welcome to the Database Lounge
description: ABOUT 10,000 people a week go to The Rack, a bar in Boston favored by sports stars, including members of the New England Patriots. One by one, they hand over their driver's licenses to a doorman, who swipes them through a sleek black machine. If a license is valid and its holder is over 21, a red light blinks and the patron is waved through.

title: World Champions Do Well in Houston Most of the Time
description: The conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Houston on Sunday saw victories by two teams well supplied with world champions.

title: In Twist, Idahoans Fight Toxic Cleanup
description: Nancy Slaight knows that the federal government wants to spend big money in the Idaho Panhandle -- as much as $1.3 billion over several decades -- to clean up toxic mining waste in the Coeur d'Alene River Basin. But no thanks, she says.

title: William Root, 78, a Contract Bridge Player, Teacher and Author
description: William Root, one of America's greatest bridge players, died on Monday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 78.

title: Economic Scene; Effective victory in the war against terror hinges on cutting off resources.
description: THE war against terrorism promises to be a long one, and the horror of Sept. 11 may suggest that pulling out all the stops is justified. But any government policy, including war, has costs and benefits. Can traditional economic analysis provide useful insights into how to fight this war? Relevant analysis has been undertaken at least since the late 1970's, with a number of economists now specializing in this. Their findings are sometimes frustrating, but, by no means conclusive, can be surprisingly useful.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WHIRLPOOL CORP., Benton Harbor, Mich., the appliance maker, said it would buy Polar S.A., Poland's largest appliance maker, from the former Moulinex-Brandt Group, France, for $43 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: A Musical Return to 1933, When Mackie Was in Town
description: Few people know that in 1933, two decades before the legendary Off-Broadway production of ''The Threepenny Opera'' opened in New York, a different English-language version of the Brecht-Weill show arrived on Broadway and lasted for only 12 performances. One of the high points of ''The Broadway Musicals of 1933,'' Monday's season-opening concert of the Town Hall series Broadway by the Year, was Mark Coffin's rendition of ''The Legend of Mackie Messer,'' the 1933 forerunner of ''Mack the Knife.'' Mr. Coffin, a little-known cabaret performer of exceptional interpretive savvy, delivered a sly, sinister performance that was a dramatic tour de force.

title: After Eight Years, Tennis Has a Fan Again in City Hall
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unraveled his predecessor's deal for new baseball stadiums. He scuttled his plans to move a museum into the Tweed Courthouse. And he has made pals with people Rudolph W. Giuliani refused to speak to.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Mayor's Settlement Opposed
description: New Jersey's inspector general has sued to overturn an $850,000 settlement awarded to Atlantic City's mayor and a city councilman. The inspector general, Edward M. Neafsey, said the settlement awarded to Mayor Lorenzo Langford and City Councilman William Marsh was rife with conflicts of interest. One conflict he cited was that the Council was advised to approve the settlement by two of Mr. Langford's appointees. Mr. Langford declined to comment. The settlement stemmed from a wrongful termination lawsuit that the two men, former school board employees who lost their jobs to budget cuts, filed in 1998 against James Whelan, the mayor at the time, and the Council. While the suit was being litigated, Mr. Langford unseated Mr. Whelan as mayor and took office on Jan. 2. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: An Isolated Zimbabwe Tightens Strictures on Opposition Leader
description: Despite international pleas for political reconciliation, the government of President Robert Mugabe summoned the opposition leader to police headquarters today and ordered him to surrender his passport and report weekly to the authorities until he is tried on charges of treason.

title: A 'Mind' Is a Hazardous Thing to Distort: When Films Juggle the Facts
description: To anyone who has read ''A Beautiful Mind,'' Sylvia Nasar's biography of the mathematician John Forbes Nash Jr., the past few weeks have been mind-boggling.

title: Raids Seek Evidence of Money-Laundering
description: Federal law enforcement officials today raided 15 organizations and individuals in Northern Virginia and a chicken farm in Georgia, all of them, the authorities said, suspected by the Treasury Department of laundering money for Al Qaeda or other terrorist groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSSMAN, FREDERICK
description: SCHLOSSMAN - Frederick. On March 19, 2002. Beloved uncle of Alan Schlossman, Gary Schlossman and Carol Comeau. He will be remembered for his caring, charitable spirit and sharp wit by many life long friends and neighbors. Services March 21, 12:15 at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Av, Bklyn.

title: Whitman Says Counsel Spoke About Senate Bid
description: Christie Whitman, the former governor of New Jersey, acknowledged today that she and Robert W. Ray had talked briefly about his plans to run for the United States Senate in New Jersey while he was serving as the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: $6 Million Tax Windfall
description: A major insurance company has given the state government, which is struggling with a large budget deficit, an unexpected $6.1 million payment, the secretary of the state said. The payment to cover taxes related to a pending stock sale was hand-delivered on Tuesday by representatives from the company, the Travelers Property Casualty Corporation in Hartford. It is the largest amount of franchise tax, a tax paid before an initial public offering, ever delivered to the state in one transaction, a spokesman said. The money, deposited in the general fund, will help cover an expected $1 billion budget gap over the next two years. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: N.F.L. Ownership Delays Decisions
description: Super Bowls in Northern cities, more involvement in the Arena Football League and greater flexibility in the late-season television schedule are issues the National Football League will continue to research and discuss, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said today as N.F.L. owners ended their annual meeting.

title: A Concrete That Percolates, Keeping Snow and Spies at Bay
description: SECURITY experts looking to prevent spies from eavesdropping on computers by intercepting the electromagnetic waves they throw off don't turn to Martha Stewart for interior-design inspiration. The solutions they employ are often unattractive and well beyond even her budget. For example, one involves building a room within a room out of welded thick steel plates.

title: Global Crossing Under Inquiry Of Panel Today
description: The House Financial Services Committee is scheduled to hold the first Congressional hearing today on fallout from the bankruptcy filing of Global Crossing, whose financial collapse has fueled concerns about accounting practices at some telecommunications companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTSCHUL, ARTHUR GOODHART
description: ALTSCHUL-Arthur Goodhart. On March 17, 2002, at age 81. Beloved husband of Patricia Dey Altschul. Loving father of Dr. Stephen, Charles, Arthur Jr., Emily, Serena, stepson Whitney Smith, and grandfather of William & James. Dear brother of Edith Graham and the late Margaret Lang. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, March 21st, 6-8 PM, with service Friday, 10:30 A.M. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Community Trust, 2 Park Ave., 24th Floor, New York, New York 10016.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Sunday about the Jazz Composers Collective misstated the address of the Jazz Standard nightclub in Manhattan, where concerts are scheduled this week in honor of the group's 10th anniversary. It is 116 East 27th Street, not West.

title: Interior Design Fair, The Other Show in Town
description: The Oscars are only one rite of spring in California. Another is WestWeek, an interior design and furniture fair, to be held at the Pacific Design Center in West Hollywood next Tuesday and Wednesday. The prototypes of five pieces by the architect R. M. Schindler, including a sofa ($14,340) and ottoman ($3,340), below, will be on display. The Schindler pieces will be available next month from the architects Marmol Radziner & Associates, www.marmolradzinerfurniture.com or (866) 869-0250. Also on display will be the work of six Swedish designers, including Ann Wahlstrom's Soapbubbles glasswork, above, for Kosta Boda. The Design Center is at 8687 Melrose Avenue (San Vicente); (310) 657-0800.

title: Walter J. Rockler, War-Crimes Agency Chief, Dies at 81
description: Walter J. Rockler, a Washington lawyer who was the first director of the Justice Department agency that identifies and deports former Nazis, died on March 8 at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 81.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: $100 Million Committed To Police
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey said yesterday that despite a nagging budget deficit, he had committed $100 million to build the state police a new headquarters and three regional training centers. The current headquarters in West Trenton, built in the 1920's, are obsolete, he said. Several days after Sept. 11, Mr. McGreevey toured the agency's training facility in Sea Girt and found it unsafe, shabby and outdated. The governor's plan would also establish training centers in Mercer, Essex and Camden Counties. David Kocienewski (NYT)

title: Monterrey's Poor Sinking in Rising Economic Tide
description: When President Bush lands here Thursday, the Monterrey he will see is a model city -- ''a living example of the entrepreneurial spirit and prosperity possible in developing nations,'' in the words of his host, President Vicente Fox.

title: Jump in Health Care Lobbying, Then in State Health Care Spending
description: In the year before state lawmakers approved a huge increase in health care spending, the powerful hospital workers' union and allied hospitals spent almost $4 million lobbying for that increase, far more than any other interest group spent to influence the state.

title: Johnson Stayed Loyal, And So Did the Mets
description: In an off-season when Mets uniforms seemed to be constantly changing hands, Mark Johnson was the ubiquitous Met. At every charity function the team organized, there was Johnson. When the mayoral candidate Michael R. Bloomberg needed another campaigner to join him and Al Leiter on the No. 7 train during evening rush hour, Johnson hopped on.

title: SCHERING TO BUY REST OF COLLATERAL THERAPEUTICS
description: Schering agreed to take over Collateral Therapeutics Inc. for $140 million in stock to expand in gene therapy products and heart treatments. Schering, which is based in Berlin, will pay about twice as much as Collateral's market value before the deal was announced. It is paying the premium because the company's experimental drugs will offer treatments for unmet medical needs to a large number of patients, Schering's chief executive, Hubertus Erlen, said. Schering and Collateral have been co-developing products that encourage the growth of more blood vessels, relieving heart ailments. Schering already owns 12 percent of Collateral, which is based in San Diego.

title: Myths of Motherhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: Up and Coming

title: Police Seek Cause for Fire That Killed 2 in Bay Shore
description: Money was always tight in the simple gray house where Gwendolyn Travis lived with her mother, half-sister and four children. Still, the scents of fresh-baked peanut butter cookies and other treats mingled with the sounds of Rugrats videos and games of tag in the hallways.

title: Toronto Journal; Green Tea Flavors the Land of the Maple Leaf
description: Keng Chit So speaks barely passable English, but he appears to get along just fine in Canada.

title: City Scenes And Videos For Global Rhythms
description: Herbin (Tamango) Van Cayseele burst onto the New York dance scene three years ago with a Bessie Award-winning show called ''Urban Tap.'' Tamango, as he is now known professionally, was already known as a tap dancer of special elegance, delicacy and virtuosity -- in ballet terms, Erik Bruhn to Savion Glover's Nureyev. ''Urban Tap'' established him as a savvy producer, putting together dancers and musicians who, like him, had honed their art performing on European streets.

title: Finally, a Way to Itemize Star Trek Memorabilia
description: Collectors of everything from Fitzgerald first editions to ceramic chicken figurines now have another software option for keeping track of their inventory, a cataloging program called MyStuff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOT, WILLIAM
description: ROOT-William. You were a special friend in the bridge world. I will miss you. Tubby Stayman

title: Cheney's Bid to Arafat Aimed to End Violence
description: The Bush administration's decision to propose a meeting with Yasir Arafat was not made until Vice President Dick Cheney marched off Air Force Two on Monday afternoon at Ben-Gurion International Airport just outside of Tel Aviv, according to accounts that emerged today.

title: Inquiry Into Crematory Fraud and Grave Desecration Is Set
description: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said today that it would investigate recent cases of grave desecration at cemeteries in two states and fraud at a crematory in another.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Interim Police Director Named
description: Mayor Sharpe James named the city's police chief, Anthony F. Ambrose, interim police director yesterday. He succeeds Joseph J. Santiago, whose appointment by Gov. James E. McGreevey as superintendent of the state police was confirmed by the State Senate on March 7. Mr. Ambrose, 43, is a Newark native whom Mayor James appointed chief in August 1999. Mr. Ambrose joined the Police Department, the state's largest, as an officer in 1986, and has worked in various units, including Internal Affairs and the director's office under Mr. Santiago. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN CLARE
description: KENNEDY-John Clare. The partners, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison express profound sorrow at the death on March 15th of John Clare Kennedy, beloved father of our friend and partner, John C. Kennedy. We express our deepest sympathies to John, and to all other members of the family.

title: Saying No to Satan
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRD, JAMES R.
description: BIRD-James R. On March 19, 2002 at the age of 81 years. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Clark), devoted father of James R. Bird, Jr. and father-in-law of Anita M. Bird of Lake Forest, IL. Graduated from the Feagin School of Drama, former Broadway actor; owner of Bird Letter Service; Vestryman and Senior Warden of All Saints' Episcopal Church, Bay Head; member and former Trustee of the Bay Head Yacht Club; member of the Log Cabin Gun Club. Served in the U.S. Army in World War II. Funeral service will be held at 11:00 A.M. on Friday, March 22, 2002 at All Saints' Episcopal Church, Lake Avenue, Bay Head, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions to All Saints' Episcopal Church would be very much appreciated. For information: Van Hise and Callagan Funeral Home, 812 Arnold Avenue, Point Pleasant Beach, New Jersey.

title: CALENDAR
description: Looking at a Fantasist

title: Downsizing Videotape, Yet Again
description: INTRODUCING a new format for anything is always a tricky business. Some innovations become standards, like Microsoft Windows, Phillips screws and queen-size beds. Others wind up in the Museum of Forgotten or Niche Technologies, like Betamax VCR's, quadraphonic sound and those old bicycles with the huge front wheels.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The reforms passed today, while flawed in some areas, still improve the current system over all, and I will sign them into law.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a medicine that has stopped the replication of the smallpox virus in laboratory experiments referred incompletely to the affiliation of Dr. Karl Y. Hostetler, the researcher who developed it. While he is a professor of medicine at the University of California at San Diego, his primary affiliation is with the VA San Diego Healthcare System.

title: Sing A Song Of Good King Arthur
description: The New York Collegium, the period-instrument band if not the chorus, has blown hot and cold during its three years. In Purcell's delightful ''King Arthur'' on Friday evening, as if to warm the Cold Genius and the Cold People of Dryden's text, it blew mostly hot under the direction of Bernard Labadie.

title: 2 Unions Compete for N.Y.U. Adjunct Professors
description: Two unions -- the United Auto Workers and the American Federation of Teachers -- are competing to represent adjunct and non-tenure-track professors at New York University.

title: Old Guitarists Don't Die; They Just Strum Away
description: Television, which reunited for a two-night stand at Irving Plaza, was the jam band of the punk era. While most of the bands that converged on CBGB in the mid-1970's set out to bring overblown 1970's rock down to earth with brevity and punch, Television, by contrast, wanted an alternative dream.

title: A Show Honors the Long Lives of Images of the Dead
description: It can be safely assumed that history's most famous people spend more time dead than alive. In that sense, there may be logic to the idea that they should be portrayed departed as well as present. The opportunity to do so is, of course, brief, but that also explains the peculiar institution of the death-bed image or, as a new show at the Muse d'Orsay prefers to call it, ''Le Dernier Portrait'' (''The Last Portrait'').

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Citigroup Selects Microsoft
description: Microsoft won an endorsement yesterday for its online identification software from Citigroup. It said it would use Microsoft's Passport identity software and .Net Web services technology to improve service to online customers. Citigroup now has 16 million online accounts among its banking, brokerage and credit card customers, up from 3 million two years ago. The automated identification software is intended to make it easier for people to shop online and have personalized instant messages sent to a computer or cellphone for account updates or fraud alerts, for example. Such features should be available to Citigroup customers by the end of the year. As part of the agreement, Citigroup's credit cards will be promoted on MSN, Microsoft's consumer Web site. No financial details of the agreement were disclosed. Citigroup will remain a member of a group, the Liberty Alliance, that is backing a rival online identification technology, an effort begun by Sun Microsystems. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: A Port Beckons: Moving to a New PC
description: UPGRADING to a new PC is a little like moving into a new home. Before you can settle into your new environment, you have to deal with transporting everything you own.

title: More Young Muslims Face U.S. Interviews
description: The Justice Department is expanding its program to interview young, mostly Muslim foreign men visiting the United States, saying it will try to track down and speak to an additional 3,000 for information about terrorism.

title: Out of Jail and Out of Food
description: After barely two minutes of debate, a floor amendment was added to the 1996 welfare law that denies food stamps and welfare (Temporary Aid to Needy Families) for life to anyone convicted of a drug felony. It is doubtful that the members of Congress realized a large part of this burden would fall on struggling women and their young children.

title: Credit Agencies Say Enron Dishonesty Misled Them
description: As the Securities and Exchange Commission announced a formal review of credit-rating agencies in the aftermath of Enron's collapse, the rating firms argued today that Enron officials had withheld crucial details about company finances. That dishonesty, the agencies said, played a crucial role in their failure to discern Enron's problems more quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAKARS, MARIS
description: CAKARS-Maris. In memory of a lover of freedom and fighter for peace, on the ten year anniversary of his death. Husband of Susan, father of Janis & Andrea. We love and miss him.

title: A Guide to an Experiment In Housing Weighs In
description: You need a California workout to lift ''Case Study Houses: The Complete CSH Program 1946-66'' (Taschen; $105), by Elizabeth Smith, but the book, an exhaustive homage to the houses, is worth the effort. The experimental homes were built after World War II as prototypes for mass housing. The book has pictures and plans by the Eamses, Richard Neutra, Eero Saarinen and others. Pierre Koenig's Case Study 22 in West Hollywood for Carlotta and Buck Stahl is still used in fashion shoots and in movies, like ''Nurse Betty.' Principal photography by (who else?) Julius Shulman.

title: Market Place; Heart-drug test delivers the latest blow to Bristol-Myers.
description: Bad news has been dogging Bristol-Myers Squibb for months, and yesterday things grew worse. A new study of Vanlev, a treatment for heart failure from Bristol-Myers, found the drug to be only marginally more effective than enalapril, an inexpensive generic version of Merck's Vasotec, a blockbuster of yesteryear.

title: Guidelines, but No Pills For Radiation in Children
description: The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, said today that confusion over federal dosage guidelines was hampering plans to distribute a cancer-blocking pill to residents in a radioactive emergency.

title: Orangemen Advance To Semifinals of N.I.T.
description: Hakim Warrick scored 15 points and helped visiting Syracuse dominate inside as the Orangemen beat Richmond, 62-46, last night to advance to the National Invitation Tournament semifinals at Madison Square Garden.

title: G.E. Faulted For Strategy On Growth
description: William Gross, a widely respected bond fund manager, sharply criticized General Electric yesterday, saying that G.E. is using acquisitions to drive its growth rate and is relying too much on short-term financing.

title: Race Gap Seen in Health Care Of Equally Insured Patients
description: Racial and ethnic minorities in the United States receive lower quality health care than whites, even when their insurance and income are the same, say a panel of scientific experts who termed their study a wake-up call to the nation's doctors.

title: Housing Starts Rise To Three-Year High, Bolstering Economy
description: Housing starts rose in February to the highest level in more than three years, government figures showed today, suggesting that the construction of new homes will underpin a rebounding economy.

title: An Extraordinary Victory
description: When the moment finally arrived yesterday for the Senate to consider the bill known alternately as Shays-Meehan and McCain-Feingold, it passed so easily you would hardly know what the fuss had been about. Yet approval of the biggest election reform in a generation, by a vote to 60 to 40, had just overcome what seemed only six months ago to be impossible odds. Congratulations were heard, and merited, all across the Capitol. But a few more steps remain. President Bush must sign the bill. The courts must uphold its constitutionality. And the Federal Election Commission, which helped gut existing campaign finance laws, must vigorously enforce the new rules.

title: More Connecticut Records About Enron Deal Emerge
description: The state attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, released documents today that he said provided additional proof that the $220 million paid to Enron by a quasi-public agency in late 2000 was an ''illegal, unsecured loan'' and not a legitimate energy transaction, as the agency has maintained.

title: From Cottage to Toolshed, On the March for Takeout
description: IN between trips to Italy to oversee the restoration of the 15th-century sculptured facade of an artists' guild hall, John H. Dobkin, the new president of Save Venice, spends his weekdays in Manhattan and his weekends here in a gardener's cottage on the grounds of Montgomery Place, one of the great Hudson River estates.

title: U.N. Agency Tells Nations to Use the Courts to Combat Tobacco
description: As negotiations resumed this week on a global anti-tobacco treaty, the World Health Organization asked nations to use their courts to awaken public outrage and redress injuries in the fight against smoking.

title: A Civil Turn for Erin Brockovich's Boss
description: In the two years since the release of the film ''Erin Brockovich,'' Edward L. Masry has undergone something of a transformation.

title: Republican Budget Passes In Partisan Vote in House
description: The House passed a $2.1 trillion Republican budget plan tonight that would grant President Bush all the money he had sought for the campaign against terrorism but result in a deficit next year despite cutting or freezing many other programs.

title: Tough Field and Nightmarish Hole to Challenge Woods
description: Like a distance runner poised for a finishing kick, Tiger Woods is gaining momentum at an opportune time.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Symantec Wins Heuristic Patent
description: Symantec said yesterday that it had been given a patent on its advanced heuristic antivirus technology. Standard antivirus software looks for specific strings of code that appear in known viruses; heuristic systems look more generally for suspicious patterns. Heuristic systems are not as accurate as standard ''fingerprint'' systems, but when used with them can help fight known viruses and prevent infection by new viruses. Rob Clyde, chief technology officer, declined to comment on whether Symantec would try to enforce the patent by seeking royalty payments or taking other steps against companies that use similar heuristic systems. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Another Writer's Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZORNOW, JACK, D.D.S.
description: ZORNOW-Jack, D.D.S. Age 86 of Coconut Creek, FL, and Heritage Village, CT. Beloved husband of Marion. Dear father of David (Martha) Zornow & Todd Zornow. Cherished grandfather of Sam, Hannah, & Ethan. Chapel services Thursday, March 21st, at 9:30 AM at Riverside Chapels, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Files Detail Debate in E.P.A. on Clean Air
description: The Natural Resources Defense Council released documents today from the Environmental Protection Agency that shed light on the heated debate in the agency over the Bush administration's proposals to change clean air rules.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Swindle Case
description: A Bay Ridge lawyer was arrested yesterday on charges that he swindled 10 of his clients, many of them elderly, out of $2 million, said Charles J. Hynes, left, the Brooklyn district attorney. In one case, the lawyer, Frank Gangemi, 38, is accused of stealing more than $600,000 from a 90-year-old man by cashing in the man's life insurance policies, selling his Miami Beach apartment and writing a $65,000 check to himself on the man's account. In another case, a client was supposed to be given $150,000 to settle a lawsuit, but Mr. Gangemi first refused to turn over the money, then wrote his client a bad check for it, Mr. Hynes said. Mr. Gangemi, who is charged with 19 counts of grand larceny, could serve 5 to 15 years in prison if convicted, Mr. Hynes said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Bomb Kills at Least 8 Near Lima Embassy
description: A bomb exploded outside the U.S. Embassy in Lima, Peru, late last night, killing at least 8 people and injuring 40, just three days before President Bush is scheduled to arrive for talks as part of his trip to Latin America. No Americans were reported killed in the blast, which severely damaged a hotel, shops and restaurants in a busy neighborhood in the Peruvian capital. It was the first time in several years that a car bomb had been set off in the city. No one claimed responsibility for the explosion.

title: Delay in Sotheby Case
description: The sentencing for A. Alfred Taubman, the former Sotheby's chairman who was found guilty in December of conspiring with Christie's, its rival auction house, to fix fees charged to sellers, has been postponed to April 22 from April 2.

title: An Avant-Garde Design For a New-Media Center
description: While the 1990's may come to be known as a decade in love with eye-popping, crowd-attracting design, the new century is in search of a fresh building type, architecture that can impress but also reinvent itself in a digital flash to accommodate the latest technologies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKER, MURRY
description: BECKER-Murry. 1895-1982. Your family remembers you daily with love and respect. We remain devoted to you and to each other, holding your character and ideals in our hearts and minds. We pray that you, Ida, and Lois are together in peace.

title: And 2 D.I.Y. Guides to Reviving Rooms
description: PIGEONS are courting on the windowsill. Crocuses are blooming. And do-it-yourself guides are sprouting, all promising to turn drab rooms into dazzlers. Whose advice can be trusted? And whose flights of fancy are worth heeding, when television's popular home-improvement show ''Trading Spaces'' is a sort of ''Survivor'' for the aesthetic set?

title: Commissioner Defends Plan For Garbage and Recycling
description: New York City's sanitation commissioner, facing sometimes heated questions at a City Council budget hearing yesterday, said that cutting the recycling program in half and transferring garbage from one borough to another for cheaper disposal were the least painful ways to keep his department's budget solvent through the city's financial crisis.

title: Scandal in the Church: A Time of Anguish
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Economic Growth
description: The South Korean economy grew 3.7 percent in the fourth quarter compared with the quarter last year, the Bank of Korea said. For all of 2001, the economy grew 3 percent. One reason for the improvement was rising domestic demand, which analysts say will keep the economy growing by 5 percent this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ruling In Hyperlink Case
description: After a hearing last month, a federal judge has issued an opinion in a patent suit by British Telecommunications, a subsidiary of the BT Group, against Prodigy, the online service now owned by SBC Communications, inching the case closer to trial in September. In the suit, British Telecommunications says a patent it was granted in 1989 covers hypertext linking on the Internet. In her initial ruling, Judge Colleen McMahon of Federal District Court in Manhattan effectively limited the arguments British Telecommunications can make on the basis of the patent, based largely on the fact that it was issued before the development of the Internet. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Dissident Legislator Sentenced
description: A member of Parliament was sentenced to five years in prison after being convicted of trying to alter the constitution through illegal means. Mamoun al-Homsi was among 10 government critics arrested last summer for disparaging the Baath Party's monopoly on power and the prominent role of the secret police in running Syria. Government opponents had hoped for more tolerance under President Bashar al-Assad, who succeeded his father in July 2000, but their strident attacks on the elder Assad's 30-year rule provoked a crackdown. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: A Spring Garden Of Boots and Umbrellas
description: SOME houses, like some divas, know how to make an entrance. If your entry lacks a first-class first impression, consider these new takes on humble hooks, coat racks, hat stands and doormats.

title: Scandal in the Church: A Time of Anguish
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Eve of his Trip to Latin America, Bush Ties U.S. Aid To Reforms
description: President Bush is to leave Thursday morning for a four-day trip to Mexico, Peru and El Salvador, where he will promote trade and counterterrorism as well as initiatives to help immigrants and a proposed $10 billion increase in American foreign aid.

title: A Different Tour For Venus Williams
description: When Venus Williams was ranked No. 1 in the world for the first time on Feb. 25, she was understandably delighted. She called it a dream come true. Yet during a family celebration, her mother, Oracene, recalled yesterday, Venus said of her new status in the tennis world, ''It's all relative.''

title: In a Quest for Youth, An Old Pepsi Theme
description: The recycling of soft drink cans and bottles is commonplace, but how about the recycling of soft drink advertising themes?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Worker Dies In Subway Accident
description: A construction foreman working at a Brooklyn subway station died yesterday morning after an accident in which one of his arms was severed, the police said. The foreman, Michael Hammel, 38, of New Jersey, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead at 4:10 a.m. The circumstances of the accident are unclear. Mr. Hammel, a superintendent for the Schiavone Construction Company, was working on a project to renovate the Atlantic Avenue subway station when a northbound Q train at Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues entered his work area at 1:40 a.m. The accident is under investigation. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Sierra Leone War Crimes Court to Begin Deliberations in Fall
description: The United Nations is pressing ahead with arrangements for a special war crimes court in Sierra Leone that officials say will be leaner and less bureaucratic than the tribunals that were created to prosecute war criminals in the Balkans and Rwanda.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Nomura To Sell Pubs
description: Nomura International, led by the British investor Guy Hands, said it would sell 4,189 pubs for $2.9 billion to Enterprise Inns and a group of private investors including Cinven, Legal and General Ventures and Morgan Stanley's Princes Gate Investors. The deal will make Enterprise Inns the biggest pub landlord in Britain, with about 15 percent of the market. Mr. Hands, who went to Nomura from Goldman, Sachs, plans to run his own company, Terra Firma Capital Partners. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Same Time, but Not the Same Place: Oscar in Hollywood
description: The Oscar ceremony returns to Hollywood on Sunday. For years, the event switched between the Shrine Auditorium and the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, in the downtown area. This year, it will be held at the new Kodak Theater, above and right, built for the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in the $600-million Hollywood and Highland shopping center. The center is the anchor of a revival of Hollywood Boulevard, which has brought restored theaters and new nightspots: the Hollywood & Vine Diner and Ultra-Lounge Bar at the intersection of Hollywood and Vine, and CineSpace, a restaurant-bar-screening room, opening soon.

title: Redecorators Next Door
description: THREE redecorators who learned the trade from Lauri Ward, author of ''Trade Secrets From Use What You Have Decorating'' (see box at left), run businesses in New Jersey. Charging $250 to $300 for a room less than 19 feet long, $100 to $185 an hour to shop, a 10 to 20 percent markup on wholesale purchases and no markup on retail purchases, they use existing furnishings and new items from places like Ikea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIECHTUNG, HERBERT
description: LIECHTUNG-Herbert. The Officers, Employees and Trustees of Atlantic Realty Trust are deeply saddened by the passing of Herbert Leichtung, a former Trustee, and Past President of RPS Realty Trust. We very much valued his wise counsel and guidance, and cherished his friendship. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Charlotte, and to his family. Joel Pashcow, Chairman

title: After Mixup, Americans Free 12 Afghans Suspected of Being Iranian Agents
description: American military officials today released 12 detainees held for two weeks in Kandahar on suspicion of being Iranians or Iranian agents, having concluded that they all are Afghan.

title: Vietnam's determined war on poverty
description: THACH TUONG, Vietnam:  Several dozen farmers crowded into a small concrete hut the other afternoon in this village at the end of a valley full of rice and sugar fields. They came by motorbike and on foot to get advice on how to apply for a bank loan to increase farm production and income.

title: Andersen Judge Seen as Restrained
description: Until the Enron case, Melinda F. Harmon was best known as the federal judge who put Vanessa Leggett, an aspiring crime writer, in jail for refusing to turn over her notes to a grand jury investigating a 1997 murder case.

title: An Unheated Market In a Hot Spot
description: LAST fall, Hamptons brokers were predicting the best rental season ever, confident that the events of Sept. 11 and the consequent fear of flying would keep New Yorkers close to home.

title: Einstein (the Demon Slayer) Lands in Court
description: YOUNGSTERS who don't know any better might assume that Albert Einstein is an invention of the computer age. His picture appeared in Apple Computer's ''Think Different'' ad campaign, and he made a cameo appearance in a 1995 video game, Command & Conquer: Red Alert, released by Electronic Arts.

title: Unplug the Cyborg
description: To the Editor:

title: HUBBELL TO BUY LIGHTING UNIT OF U.S. INDUSTRIES
description: Hubbell Inc., which makes outdoor and commercial lighting and electrical products, agreed to buy the LCA Group lighting unit of U.S. Industries for $250 million. LCA makes flood and road lights, as well as residential decorative lights. The unit had $575 million in sales last year. U.S. Industries, which is based in Iselin, N.J., also makes Jacuzzi whirlpool baths. Hubbell is based in Orange, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GHITELMAN, SIMON
description: GHITELMAN-Simon. On March 15, 2002, after a ten year battle with Alzheimer's Disease. I will continue to miss you. Gail

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Seeking Help With Rebellion
description: Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba traveled to India and will discuss Nepal's increasingly violent Maoist rebellion. The Indian government has been supportive of Nepal's effort to put down the insurgency and Mr. Deuba is expected to make further pleas for help in shutting down various supply routes to the guerrillas. Nepal has been under a state of emergency since November, when the Maoists abandoned a truce. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Board Debates Summer School With a Mind Toward Money
description: Facing deep budget cuts, members of the Board of Education were bitterly divided yesterday about whether to continue or drastically cut the summer school program for lagging students, a program on which the schools chancellor has staked his reputation. The board's decision could affect the lives of students as soon as this summer.

title: Bamboozling the TV Viewer
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; These Salukis Are Stubborn Underdogs
description: OH, great. Just what Lorraine Trenholm and her associates in the Saluki Club of America needed, a sports-crazed and cult-buying nation waking up to Southern Illinois University this week to ask: what, exactly, is a Saluki?

title: Lazio Declines To Make Race For Old Seat
description: Rick A. Lazio announced yesterday that he would not try to regain the Congressional seat on Long Island that he gave up to make his unsuccessful race against Hillary Rodham Clinton for the United States Senate in 2000.

title: Okafor Is Quick Study, On Court and in Class
description: They call him a shot blocker, a defensive specialist and, more often than not, a freshman. But the label Emeka Okafor likes best is student. Currently, Okafor, the Connecticut center, is immersed in an advanced tutorial on college hoops, though after two rounds of the N.C.A.A. tournament there are a pair of coaches and a few dozen players now watching from home who might want to call him professor.

title: A Long Ascent on Mt. Oscar
description: RANDY NEWMAN lives in a custom-built 6,500-square-foot house here -- a beige stucco job with blue trim that has the feel of a golf clubhouse in Palm Desert. Inside, the look is part preschool (tiger-print rugs on the stairs), part hotel lobby (high-ceilinged living room overlooking patio and pool) and part pro athlete's bachelor pad (black coffee table, white couch, giant brown velvet pillows).

title: Leonard Gershe, 79, Playwright Who Wrote 'Butterflies Are Free'
description: Leonard Gershe, a playwright and screenwriter who was the author of the hit play ''Butterflies Are Free,'' died on March 9 in a hospital in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 79 and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Bank of Japan left monetary policy unchanged as signs of a recovery eased pressure on the bank to act. At its two-day meeting, the bank's policy board reaffirmed its commitment to leave up to 15 trillion yen ($114 billion) in the money markets. With the government trying to calm fears of a financial crisis, the bank on Feb. 28 agreed to raise the amount of government bonds it buys to one trillion yen ($7.6 billion) a month. But stock prices and some economic indicators have since rebounded, making it less urgent for the bank to ease policy. The board did, however, expand the range of collateral it accepts in return for loans. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Losing Faith: Globalization Proves Disappointing
description: The world leaders who have gathered here to discuss how to fight poverty do not always see eye to eye on what works best. But many now agree that the force they once saw as a near panacea -- globalization -- has come up short.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bigger For Steel Concern
description: Hanbo Iron and Steel, whose collapse in 1997 preceded the full-scale Korean economic crisis later in the year, may finally have found a buyer. The Korea Asset Management Corporation, trying to sell off the bankrupt company's assets, said a Korean financial firm, AK Capital, had agreed to pay $400 million for Hanbo. AK Capital was not expected to sign a contract, however, until finishing its review of the company's books in August. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, MARILYN R.
description: KELLER-Marilyn R. The entire Keller family deeply mourns and will forever miss our beloved matriarch. Devoted wife of 55 years to Harold; treasured mother of Jane, Amy, Alice and Emily; mother-in-law of Tom, Bob, Michael and Robert; adored grandmother of Molly, Rosie, Lily and Ruby. Full of generosity, courage, wisdom and charisma, Marilyn had a wonderful ability to connect with people. She willingly shared her good fortune with others and taught her family to do the same. She was a loyal and trusted friend to many. Marilyn's strength, courageous spirit and passion for life will live forever in her four daughters and four granddaughters.

title: In Search of Magic
description: There's always a solution to the terrible problems of the New York City school system. Just over the horizon.

title: You Can Go Home Again, but You Might Not Stay
description: NO HEROES

title: Pettitte Makes Progress, But He's No Sure Thing
description: At the start of spring training, the Yankees had six starting pitchers for five spots. When they break camp in 10 days, they may have only four starters who are healthy.

title: A Disappointing U.S. Attorney Choice
description: United States attorneys are a bulwark of the justice system. The top federal prosecutors at the state level, they enforce some of the nation's most critical laws. With vast resources, including the F.B.I., at their disposal, United States attorneys take on the government's biggest, highest-impact cases, from prosecuting international terrorists to getting to the bottom of the Enron mess.

title: Kidnappings By Koreans Have Angered The Japanese
description: From a courtroom here, new details about a North Korean program to kidnap Japanese citizens in the 1970's and 1980's are stoking animosity in Japan.

title: Athletes May Next Seek Genetic Enhancement
description: The International Olympic Committee has seemingly been playing catch-up for years with athletes who use sophisticated means to mask their use of steroids, human growth hormone, erythropoietin, or EPO, and other performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MILTON
description: COHEN-Milton. The Merrick Jewish Centre mourns the passing of our dear member and extends heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Ruth, daughter Laura and son-in-law Hank Arkin and family. We pray they will be consoled with all the mourners of our people. Alan Sussman, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein,

title: Study Ranking Utility Polluters Aims to Sway Emissions Debate
description: As debate flares anew over White House plans to revise air pollution regulations, a study that ranks the biggest air polluters in the power industry is expected to be issued today.

title: Trades May Have Come Too Late for the Rangers
description: After trying simultaneously to improve the present and the future of his club, Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, railed against the timing of Tuesday's trading deadline.

title: Milton C. Rose, 97, Lawyer At Firm of Nixon and Mitchell
description: Milton C. Rose, a partner at the Wall Street law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon, died on Tuesday at his home in Alford, Mass. He was 97 and had worked as a lawyer for over 60 years.

title: Errant Shell Kills Soldier At Fort Drum
description: One soldier was killed and 14 others were injured today when two artillery shells fell far short of their target and sent shrapnel ripping through a mess tent during military exercises here. The incident deepened the tension for soldiers and their families who were already on edge about the fate of the 10th Mountain Division, which is based here and has been involved in heavy fighting in Afghanistan in recent weeks.

title: Official Sees Links to Italian Leftists in Adviser's Killing
description: Italy's interior minister, Claudio Scajola, said today that the police had every reason to link the assassination of a government labor adviser on Tuesday to a ''second generation'' of the Red Brigades -- a new group that has adopted the name of the leftist guerrillas active here in the 1970's and 1980's.

title: Study Said to Show Added Benefit of Genentech Breast Cancer Drug
description: A new study shows that Herceptin, the breast cancer drug from the pioneering biotechnology company Genentech, not only blocks a factor that promotes tumor growth but also slows the flow of blood the tumors need to grow. If so, that could make the drug a competitor to several cancer treatments under development for reducing blood flow to tumors.

title: After Riots, Some Muslims Fear for Their Future in India
description: The mobs set fire to the lobby of the Signor Hotel but left the Opel car dealership next door untouched. Just below the charred shell of the Neeltop Hotel, a sweet shop is doing a brisk business. Under bright white lights, dinner is served at Vaibhav restaurant. But the Topaz next door is incinerated and another once-popular restaurant upstairs is black with soot.

title: Unplug the Cyborg
description: To the Editor:

title: Andersen Wins An Early Trial As Date Is Set For May 6
description: Responding to Arthur Andersen's argument that its survival depends on a fast resolution of the criminal indictment filed against it, a federal judge ruled today that a trial would begin in just 47 days on a charge that the firm obstructed justice in the Enron investigation.

title: A Rush to Fix Ground Zero's Damaged Dike
description: Workers are hurrying to shore up and patch a 90-foot-wide gash in the below-ground retaining wall that encircles much of the World Trade Center site after discovering that groundwater, fed by the Hudson River, is only a precarious foot below the lower rim of the damaged area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAGHY, LUCY M. (NEE PATALANO)
description: DONAGHY-Lucy M. (nee Patalano). Peacefully on March 19, 2002. Devoted wife of the late Joseph P. Donaghy, NYPD; beloved mother of Joe (Mary Lynn), Janet (Hayib Sosseh), Rita, Jack, Mary, and Bob (Theresa). Cherished grandmother of Matthew (Stacy) and Sarah Donaghy & Saj and Musou Sosseh; loving great-grandmother of Sophie and the late Evan Donaghy. Family will receive friends at 9:00AM at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave. (at E. 72nd St.), where the Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at 9:30AM In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the National Shrine of St. Jude.

title: INSIDE
description: Last Word on Whitewater

title: EMI to Revamp and Cut Its Work Force 20%
description: The EMI Group, the music giant that dropped Mariah Carey in January, announced today a sweeping restructuring of its operations that will eliminate 20 percent of its work force.

title: Fielding an Afghan Army Is Months Off, U.S. Finds
description: While the Bush administration says the way to maintain stability in Afghanistan is to train and equip an Afghan Army, a confidential review by the United States concludes that it will take many months to train and equip even a modest force.

title: Law Revises Standards for Scientific Study
description: It does not even take effect until next Oct. 1. But a little-noticed law called the Data Quality Act, signed in the waning days of the Clinton administration, has set off a fierce debate over how best to weigh health and environmental risks.

title: Luke Walton Emerges From a Long Shadow
description: Even in an era of expressive tattoos on basketball players, the display on Luke Walton's right shoulder prompts a double take. In blue dye on tanned white skin are drawings of four skeletons twirling basketballs on their fingers. The skeletons are symbols of the Grateful Dead, a band his famous father favors. The four figures represent Walton and his three brothers. The basketballs, of course, stand for the family game.

title: Some Houstonians Whom Enron Called Friends
description: Inside the company, they were called the Friends of Enron, and they were among the energy company's secret financial weapons.

title: From Ancient Days, a Tasty New Year; Rites of a Persian Feast Recall Homelands Left Behind
description: It was 2:16 p.m. yesterday, the exact moment when the Persian New Year should have announced itself in tender spring sunshine, and a chilling rain was pelting the brave few hurrying past Mohammed Nasim's restaurant in Astoria, Queens.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about increased enforcement of immigration laws by local police departments misattributed the comment ''Islamic terrorists have penetrated every aspect of our immigration system.'' It was from a statement by Mark Krikorian, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies -- not by Dan Stein, executive director of the Federation for American Immigration Reform, which also endorsed such efforts by the police.

title: Retrieving a PC's Past With XP's Time Warp
description: Q. After making some changes to the settings on my Windows XP system, I didn't like the results, but now I can't get the computer back to the way it was before. What can I do?

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Apple Raising Prices Of iMac
description: Apple Computer said yesterday that it would raise prices on its popular flat-panel iMac by $100 because of cost increases in displays and memory chips. It said it had sold 125,000 of the new computers since it began shipping them at the end of January and that it now had a backlog of 100,000 orders. Apple Computer said at the end of January that it had orders for 150,000 computers, a rate that was faster than that for the original iMac. In recent weeks, reports of tight iMac supplies have led to speculation about Apple's quarterly results, but Apple said it was sticking by the guidance it issued at the beginning of the quarter. Phil Schiller, Apple's marketing chief, said it was now making 5,000 iMacs a day, but that it was facing a 25 percent increase in display costs and a tripling in memory cost since the introduction of the new computer. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Motion Rejected in Wendy's Case
description: A Queens judge ruled yesterday against a defense motion to throw out the confession of the man accused of staging the massacre of five workers at a Wendy's restaurant nearly two years ago. The ruling rejected a defense argument that the man was improperly denied access to his lawyer.

title: Squawking, Swooning And a Bit Of Hooting
description: Depending upon your point of view, the abundance of compositional techniques and schools over the last 50 years has been evidence of either exciting diversity or dispiriting confusion. Either way, it makes it hard for a composer to develop a distinctive style and voice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMOLLON, RICHARD J.
description: SMOLLON-Richard J. Of Manhattan, formerly of Garden City, on March 18, 2002. Beloved husband of Rita, dearest son of Mary and William, adored brother of William, John, Mary Beth, Francis, Ann, Catherine and James. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at Krauss Funeral Home Inc, 1097 Hempstead Turnpike in Franklin Square, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, on Saturday, 9:30 AM, St. Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City. Interment, Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Lawmakers In Britain Pursue Fox Hunters
description: The lights in the Gothic Parliament buildings on the banks of the Thames have been burning late this week as hot-tempered debates and hard-fought votes in the Commons and the Lords continued long into the night.

title: A Warbler Set Aloft By a Dedicated Flock; Patience Pays Off for Nelly Furtado's Team
description: Nelly Furtado, a Canadian singer-songwriter, rushed to the stage at the Grammy ceremonies last month to accept the award for best female pop singer for her song ''I'm Like a Bird.'' Ms. Furtado, the daughter of working-class Portuguese immigrants, said she felt like Cinderella.

title: Nieuwendyk's Devils Debut Turns Out to Be a Winner
description: Joe Nieuwendyk left his pregnant wife, their 10-month-old daughter, a lot of friends and a house in Dallas. He figures it could be a lot worse: he could be helping an inexperienced team chase a Stanley Cup playoff berth.

title: Data Defense
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Anti-Terror Bill Rejected
description: The upper house of Parliament rejected an anti-terrorism bill favored by the governing coalition, which is led by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party. But others feared that the measure, which allowed suspects to be detained for 30 days without appearing in court, would be used against the Muslim minority. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Do Israel and Arabs Need a G.I. Buffer?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Federal Aid For Steelworkers
description: Workers laid off from three Kaiser Aluminum plants will be eligible for federal assistance and job training, Senator Patty Murray, a Democrat, announced. The 1,900 steelworkers from the Spokane and Tacoma areas requested assistance from the Labor Department last December after Kaiser closed its plants in the face of rising aluminum imports. Under the 1974 Trade Adjustment Assistance program they will receive a year of cash payments and 104 weeks of retraining assistance. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: School Strip-Search Investigated
description: A principal and two teachers were removed from a Kansas City school after parents complained that third-grade students were strip-searched when $5 was reported missing on Monday. A school district spokesman said the principal, Jana Schwimmer, and two teachers, whose names were not released, were placed on administrative leave on Wednesday. The Kansas City School District and the Missouri Division of Family Services are investigating. The school spokesman said strip-searches violated district policy. Daniel I. Dorfman (NYT)

title: Money in Politics: The New Mood
description: To the Editor:

title: An American Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEARNS, ELEANOR M.
description: KEARNS-Eleanor M. On March 21, 2002. Longtime resident of Mount Vernon, NY. Survived by her son Richard Kearns of New York City. Calling hours on Friday from 3 to 5PM and 7 to 9PM at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St, Bronxville, New York. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday at 11 AM Our Lady of Victory Church, Mount Vernon. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Maryknoll Fathers, Maryknoll, NY 10545.

title: EXECUTIVE RESIGNS AND L90 PAYS TO END A MERGER
description: L90 Inc., an Internet marketing company, said yesterday that its chief financial officer had resigned and that it had paid eUniverse an undisclosed amount to end their merger. The chief financial officer, Thomas Sebastian, had been on administrative leave since March 10, and resigned effective Tuesday, the company said. The Securities and Exchange Commission issued subpoenas to L90 and one of its directors on Feb. 4, requesting documents related to its financial records. L90's purchase by eUniverse was postponed in February because of the S.E.C. investigation.

title: Some tough competition heats up the Arctic Winter Games : Now starring in the knuckle hop
description: So you thought the Winter Games were over. In Nuuk, Greenland, and Iqaluit, Canada, the opening ceremony took place only Sunday.

title: Mother vs. Daughter
description: Patricia Cardoso's comic melodrama ''Real Women Have Curves'' relates the generational conflict between a Mexican-American teenager (America Ferrera, right) and her traditionalist mother. ''Real Women'' and Jeong Jae-eun's ''Take Care of My Cat,'' about five young friends in South Korea, open the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art tonight.

title: Euro quandary:It's no small change
description: LONDON:  They're small, nearly valueless  and a nuisance to millions of Europeans.

title: A Pope 'Conscious of Human Weakness'
description: Following is an excerpt from a document titled ''Letter of His Holiness John Paul II to Priests for Holy Thursday 2002,'' provided by the Vatican:

title: Webber Among Players Paid by Michigan Booster
description: A former University of Michigan booster was indicted yesterday on charges of running an illegal gambling business, conspiracy and money laundering. He was accused of giving cash payments totaling more than $600,000 to former players, including Chris Webber, now a star with the Sacramento Kings.

title: 23 Accused of Taking Money Meant for Sept. 11 Victims
description: In one case, a Michigan man who falsely stated that his brother had died in the World Trade Center attack was awarded $272,800 days after making his claim, officials said. In another, a Bronx woman said that her mother had died in the attack when she had in fact died three years earlier, investigators said.

title: For Longhorns and Ducks, It's Point, Counterpoint
description: Midway through today's practice for its game with Oregon Friday night in a semifinal of the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional, Texas Coach Rick Barnes took aside his freshman point guard, T. J. Ford, for some individual attention. It wasn't the first time.

title: Painters Who Nurtured The Genius of Others
description: When it comes to new art, all it takes are a few good men or women, and maybe some personal wealth, to make a difference. Such differences were made by the intrepid collector and painter Katherine S. Drier, working with Marcel Duchamp in the 1920's and 30's, and by the painter John Stephan and his wife, Ruth, a poet, in the late 1940's. Their accomplishments are being honored with side-by-side exhibitions at the Yale University Art Gallery here. ''The 1948 Directors of the Socit Anonyme Exhibition'' and ''The Tiger's Eye: The Art of a Magazine'' are both fruitful and pertinent exercises in historical reconstruction.

title: Up Close, Too Close, to a Suicide Bombing
description: Memory becomes selective after a close call. A few sharp details remain, like those of the young woman in a bombing on Wednesday who could not shake the thought of the suicide bomber smiling and chewing gum before he disappeared in a blinding flash. One thing everyone who has been near a suicide bombing always remembers is the blast, how loud it is.

title: Oklahoma's Muscle Is Too Much for Arizona
description: The bench was a strange place for the star of the game, especially with the score so close. But there sat Hollis Price, the Oklahoma guard with the long, accurate shot. He had 26 points at the time, but there were complications. First, Price turned his ankle and found a chair while limping and wincing in pain. Next, he came back in but committed his fourth foul and went right back to the first row.

title: Revamped Mets Concerned About Pitching
description: Mo Vaughn will return from a strained hamstring on Friday, completing the Mets' lineup. A winter's worth of renovation will be on view.

title: New York Loses Jobs Despite Trend in U.S.
description: New York City lost roughly 14,000 private-sector jobs last month, even as the number of jobs rose at the national level. The city's job losses were worse than in January, and hit hard in two areas economists consider bellwethers for the local economy: Wall Street and temporary help agencies.

title: Universities Report Record In Private Contributions
description: Despite an economic downturn and a choppy stock market, contributions to American colleges and universities rose to a record in the year that ended on June 30, according to a study to be released today by the Rand Corporation Council for Aid to Education.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DirecTV In WorldCom D.S.L. Deal
description: DirecTV announced an agreement yesterday with WorldCom Inc. that is meant to allow DirecTV to offer high-speed Internet service more broadly. Though DirecTV is the nation's No. 1 satellite television provider, the company also provides high-speed data connections over normal phone wires, using the technology known as digital subscriber line, or D.S.L. Yesterday's agreement will allow DirecTV to use WorldCom's systems to offer D.S.L. to a total of about 50 million homes. DirecTV is part of General Motors' Hughes Electronics division, which G.M. has agreed to sell to the EchoStar Communications Corporation. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: How Old Fashioned: Cars Built on Frames
description: RETRO, a hot design trend for several years, may be more than skin deep. To make niche models at reasonable prices, General Motors is reviving a car-building method -- bolting bodies onto solid frames -- that had almost disappeared. What's more, the change could revive the frequent restylings that gave pizazz to cars of the 1950's and 60's.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption on Sunday for an illustration of an Urdu-language document left behind by Islamic militants in Afghanistan identified it incorrectly. The document was an oath signed by Muhammad Sajid Ali, a recruit from Pakistan. (The caption referred to another recruit's oath, previously considered for publication.)

title: Fox Hunters In England Win a Reprieve
description: Faced with division in Parliament and anger from England's influential countryside, the government shied away today from a promised ban on fox hunting but pledged final action on a revised proposal in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSONS, REVEREND HAROLD J.
description: PARSONS-Reverend Harold J. On March 21, 2002. Ordained in 1929. Oldest priest in the Archdiocese of New York. Last assignment was at St. Peter's, RC Church, Barclay St, NYC. Served many parishes in the Archdiocese and affected many people in the practice of their faith. His dedication to the Catholic Church, knew no bounds. Survived by one cousin, Irene Smith of Vermont. Reposing at Vanella's Funeral Chapel, 2860 Long Beach Rd, Oceanside, LI. Mass of Christian burial, Sacred Heart RC Church, Island Park, Saturday, 10:00 AM. Visitation 2-5, 7-9

title: A Federal Soft-Money Ban Could Benefit State Parties
description: An expected federal ban on political contributions known as soft money would not affect state and local races, and could funnel more of these large, unlimited donations to state parties, campaign finance experts say.

title: Mt. Sinai Lays Out Plans For Better Transplant Ward
description: Responding to criticism over the death of a healthy donor following a liver transplant, Mount Sinai Hospital said yesterday that it would no longer allow residents and summer interns to work in the transplant ward.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Analyst Offers Warning On AOL
description: An influential Internet analyst cut her estimates yesterday for AOL Time Warner's sales and profits, expressing concern over the outlook for online advertising revenue. ''The single biggest risk to AOL Time Warner's near-term earnings is the AOL division and advertising in particular,'' Holly Becker, new-media and e-commerce analyst for Lehman Brothers, wrote in a research report. ''Several difficult quarters lie ahead.'' Ms. Becker cut her first-quarter sales expectation for the company to $9.4 billion from $9.7 billion. Many of the lucrative marketing contracts that AOL signed during the Internet bubble have already expired or will soon. The prevailing rates for these arrangements are now much lower than they were at the time of the original deals. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about publishing in Spanish in the United States, misstated the name of Simon & Schuster's Spanish imprint. It is Libros en Espaol, not Libres in Espaol. The column also misstated the number of Spanish imprints at Random House. It is three, not two, including Random House Espaol in addition to Vintage Espaol and Random House Para Nios.

title: VERIZON SEEKS TO SELL LONG-DISTANCE SERVICE IN MAINE
description: Verizon Communications is seeking approval from regulators to sell long-distance phone service in Maine. Verizon, based in New York, filed the request with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday, the company said. The F.C.C. has 90 days to review the bid, Verizon said. The company, which had a $2 billion fourth-quarter loss, is trying to sell long-distance throughout the United States amid slowing growth in its local-calling business. Verizon needs F.C.C. approval to offer the service in its local-phone region. It sells long-distance in 41 states and is the fourth-largest carrier, behind AT&T, WorldCom and Sprint.

title: Notes From Sioux Falls; Politics on the Great Plains
description: All politics is local, but on the sparsely populated Great Plains, it may be more local than elsewhere. The national parties and the Washington political consultants are starting to focus on the Senate race in South Dakota, but there's little evidence the voters, or the candidates, want the attention.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Producers Who Measure Profit Against Beautiful Odds
