description: The stars at Universal Studio's party after the Golden Globe Awards in January could not have been brighter. Tom Hanks bounded down the steps at Trader Vic's in Beverly Hills, arms waving to a throng of photographers. Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones chatted with Emily Watson, one of many distinguished actors from ''Gosford Park.'' Steven Spielberg snaked his way through the crowded room, squeezing past Oscar nominees like Halle Berry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, HERMAN (HY)
description: WIENER-Herman (Hy). Former owner of the Pastrami King Restaurant. Beloved husband of Laura. Loving father of Joyce and Allyn Cohen, Fern and Sonny Salamy, Carol and Harry Schweitzer and Peggy and Steve Lebensfeld. Cherished grandfather of Stephen, Jason, Meredith, Matthew, Chelsey, Joey, Margo, Jared, Robert, David & Michael. Services are at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 1:30 P.M. Friday.

title: Soft Money Lives: Democrats Take In $12 Million (2 Gifts)
description: A day after the Senate voted to abolish the enormous campaign contributions known as soft money, Democratic Party officials said today that they recently received a $7 million check, the largest known donation in the history of American politics.

title: Corrections
description: The New Economy column in Business Day on March 11, about efforts by British Telecommunications to claim patent rights to the technology underlying hypertext links, which let computer users navigate the Internet by clicking on highlighted text, misstated the nationality of Ted Nelson, the computer scientist credited with coining the term hypertext in 1963. He is a citizen of the United States, not Britain.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Prosecutor Makes It Official
description: Robert W. Ray, the former Whitewater special prosecutor, formally joined New Jersey's crowded Republican primary campaign for the United States Senate yesterday. His announcement came a day after the final report on President Bill Clinton's failed Arkansas land deal was released and questions arose about Mr. Ray's nonpartisanship during the investigation. Mr. Ray, 41, of Rumson, is the sixth Republican hoping to challenge the Democratic incumbent, Robert G. Torricelli, in the fall. He said that his campaign would be ''an uphill fight'' and that he would campaign on the issues of reforming education and cutting taxes. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: India Offers Help Against Rebels
description: India has offered the government military equipment and training in the fight against Maoist rebels. An Indian foreign ministry official told reporters about the offer after Nepal's prime minister, Sher Bahadur Deuba, met with Indian leaders in New Delhi. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the News Watch column of Circuits yesterday about the Stock Orb, a wireless market indicator from Ambient Devices, misstated the surname of the company's chief engineer. He is Ben Resner, not Resman.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: A Step Toward Europe
description: The country cleared a major hurdle on the road to European Union membership, winning a relatively long 12-year transition period in which land sales to foreigners can be limited. The issue of land has been sensitive, with union opponents fearing that foreigners will buy up the fertile farmland. Poland, with 40 million people, is the largest of 10 East European countries set to join the union in late 2003. It has faced criticism from neighbors for lagging in its negotiations with Brussels. Several other issues, even more contentious, remain to be settled. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Candidate Contests Defeat
description: The former head of a city hospital workers' union, who was narrowly defeated for re-election last week, is seeking to overturn the vote on the ground that voters were intimidated and misled. James Butler, the former president of Local 420 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, lost to Carmen Charles, a surgery technician, by 54 votes. Mr. Butler filed a protest this week with the union's election committee, charging Ms. Charles with intimidation at the polls, making untrue statements and campaigning on work time. Ms. Charles called the accusations untrue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PILMAR, HOWARD
description: PILMAR-Howard. Feb. 3, 1956Mar 22, 1996. It is 6 years that you were taken from us so viciously. Justice will soon prevail. Always in my thoughts. Miss you terribly. Dad

title: Experts at Hearing Disagree Over Losers in Tax Scandal
description: When detectives try to solve crimes, they ask themselves a simple question: who benefits? In the bribery scandal that has upended the city's property tax system, federal prosecutors have alleged that the beneficiaries included the city assessors who took bribes, the tax consultants who gave bribes and the landlords whose taxes were reduced.

title: Nongovernmental Organizations Show Their Growing Power
description: Since the end of the cold war, private aid organizations have mushroomed across Africa, addressing every conceivable need in seemingly every corner of the world's poorest continent.

title: BUSH ACTS TO DROP CORE PRIVACY RULE ON MEDICAL DATA
description: The Bush administration today proposed dropping a requirement at the heart of federal rules that protect the privacy of medical records. It said doctors and hospitals should not have to obtain consent from patients before using or disclosing medical information for the purpose of treatment or reimbursement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Valhalla: No Racial Profiling Found
description: A report released this week by the Westchester Department of Public Safety found no racial profiling in traffic stops or tickets issued by county police since May, when the Board of Legislators adopted a law forbidding the practice. The law required the police to compile statistics on the race and ethnicity of drivers who were stopped. The report said that the racial breakdown of those stopped -- 58 percent white, 17 percent black, 12 percent Hispanic, 2 percent Asian, 6 percent other -- closely matched the county's population. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Campaign Finance Battle Heading to Court
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the former independent counsel whose investigation led to President Bill Clinton's impeachment, and Floyd Abrams, a First Amendment lawyer who took on the Nixon administration, will lead the legal challenge to the campaign finance law just passed by Congress.

title: High Schools That Work
description: New York City's public schools are infamous for budget problems, building delays and the political dogfights that have created a revolving door at the schools chancellor's office. It is less well known that the system has also produced some of the nation's biggest success stories. One of the most innovative programs, developed during the late 1990's, is aimed at public education's most daunting and intractable problem -- its high schools.

title: Residential Real Estate; Zoning Aid Helps Create Housing For the Poor
description: A 41-apartment rental building for low-income elderly residents rising on Lexington Avenue at 31st Street would seem to have little in common with the vastly larger and more luxurious mixed-use tower planned 28 blocks north at the old Alexander's site. But the developments are connected by New York City's inclusionary housing program.

title: Bloomberg to Keep His Private Finances Mostly Private
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would most likely release a heavily edited version of his tax returns, without specifying how much money he earns, just as he did during the mayoral campaign.

title: Killing Suspect to Be Tried Under the Laws of Pakistan
description: A 28-year old Muslim militant, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, will be formally charged on Friday with the kidnapping and murder of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, the prosecutor in the case said this evening. The move is likely to complicate and possibly thwart American attempts to have Mr. Sheikh handed over to the United States for prosecution.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Ex-Speaker Joins Lobbying Firm
description: The former speaker of the state's General Assembly, Jack Collins, left, has taken a position at a prominent lobbying firm. Mr. Collins, 58, joined the Princeton Public Affairs Group in Trenton as senior counsel. He will be responsible for developing client strategies, the group's managing partner, Dale Florio, said yesterday. Mr. Collins, a Republican, did not seek re-election last year after 16 years in office. New Jersey does not require a waiting period before a former lawmaker can lobby his former colleagues. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBSON, JOHN EDWIN
description: ROBSON-John Edwin. Passed away on March 20. Services 4:30PM, Monday, at the Navy Chapel, Nebraska Avenue Complex, 3801 Nebraska Ave. N.W., Washington, D.C. and in Chicago at 3:30PM Wednesday, at the Chicago Historical Society on Clark Street at North Ave. Donations to the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse (CASA), 633 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017-6706 or Yale University, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT. 06521-1038.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, PHYLLIS J.
description: GRANT-Phyllis J. On March 20, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Myron Studner. Services and interment private.

title: Jordan, Holding Off a Neighbor's Wildfire, Plays Down an Arms-Smuggling Case
description: This is a nervous little kingdom, picking a careful path through the ArabIsraeli conflict. Just how delicate was well illustrated recently when Jordanian intelligence thwarted a Hezbollah attempt to smuggle Katyusha rockets to the Palestinians -- and the smugglers were then quietly allowed to go back to Lebanon.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Tuberculosis 'Epidemic'
description: Nearly 700,000 of Ukraine's 49 million people have tuberculosis, a ''dangerous and worrying situation'' that is resisting government efforts to control it, Yuri Feshchenko, director of a state tuberculosis institute, said at a news conference. The rising number of new cases -- 32,000 last year alone -- means that ''we are facing an epidemic,'' Mr. Feshchenko said, adding that control is difficult because many new cases resist standard drug treatment. The situation is made more perilous by the fact that Ukraine's rate of H.I.V. infection, about 1 percent, is expected to rise to as much as 6 percent by 2010, and H.I.V. sufferers' weakened immune systems are especially susceptible to TB. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MARY BLUMENTHAL
description: SMITH-Mary Blumenthal. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved mother of Robyn Forman. To Robyn, Bruce, and the entire family, heartfelt sympathy. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: Marketing in Spanish Gets Added Attention
description: Two agencies are expanding in the realm of marketing communications aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers. Publicis Sanchez & Levitan, part of the United States operations of the Publicis division of the Publicis Groupe, is opening an office in New York to complement its operations in Dallas, Los Angeles and Miami. Jos Gonzlez, 35, will head the new office as senior principal and managing director. He joins from the Vidal Partnership in New York, where he had been account director and strategic planning director on accounts like Heineken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZOFF, LILLIAN
description: LAZOFF-Lillian. On March 21, 2002 at age 100. Beloved wife of the late Louis and mother to Rita (Lionel) Sobel and the late Robert. Grandmother to Dory (Tom) and Ted (Mary). Great-grandmother to Adam, Lucy, Julia, Rebecca and Louis. In nearly every culture and time, the heroes of bedtime stories are orphans and castaways, unloved stepchildren and disenfranchised princes, who must overcome the indifference and malignancy of the world and find their way home.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Workers Ignore Strike Call
description: The general strike called by the nation's largest federation of trade unions wheezed into its second day with most workers ignoring the call to stay away from their jobs. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Receiver For Power Project
description: In a victory for Indian creditors of Dabhol Power, the mothballed $2.9 billion electric power project principally owned by the Enron Corporation, a court in Bombay issued an order prohibiting Dabhol from filing for bankruptcy protection or liquidation in any American court. The Bombay court also ordered the appointment of a receiver to safeguard the company's assets. The creditors have been trying to auction Enron's 65 percent interest in the project, and the smaller stakes of General Electric and Bechtel, to satisfy debts. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: NBC Discloses TiVo Stake
description: General Electric can acquire as much as 8.3 percent of TiVo, G.E. said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. G.E., through its NBC unit, owns one million shares of TiVo common stock for a 2.3 percent stake, and holds securities convertible into 2.9 million common shares, the filing said. In 2001, TiVo, a subscription-based television provider, announced a private placement of $51.75 million of convertible debt and warrants. G.E. said it had invested $10 million as part of that placement. It acquired the common stock at TiVo's initial public offering in 1999.

description: Pentagon officials raised the possibility today of indefinite detention of prisoners from the Afghan war, saying that captives might not be released from United States custody even if they were acquitted in a military tribunal.

description: Taking advantage of a likely boom in profits at commercial insurance companies, Citigroup sold 21 percent of its Travelers Insurance unit yesterday in the largest initial public offering this year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: The First Photograph
description: A photograph believed to be the world's first -- of a faded pen and ink drawing of a boy and his horse -- was auctioned for nearly $400,000 in Paris. The photograph, along with letters in which Joseph Nicphore Niepce detailed the techniques he used, indicate the image was made in 1825. Experts already credited Niepce with producing the first permanent photographic images but they thought he made his first photos in 1826. The image of the drawing had been kept for 50 years in the home of a Parisian bookseller and collector of old photos. It was bought by the French National Library. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: $132 MILLION IS AWARDED TO INVESTOR IN S.& L. CASE
description: A federal judge yesterday awarded an investor in Bluebonnet Savings Bank $132 million, the second-largest award so far in 120 related lawsuits against the United States stemming from the savings and loan crisis of the 1980's. The award to James M. Fail, founder of the holding company that owns Bluebonnet, which is based in Dallas, came six months after a federal appeals court said that the government owed him damages. Mr. Fail and a partner acquired 15 insolvent institutions in 1988 that eventually became Bluebonnet. Their agreement with regulators included a provision that permitted Bluebonnet to maintain capital levels lower than those normally required for 10 years. A 1989 law made several changes that, taken together, meant Bluebonnet was below the capital requirements and had to raise additional money. The damage award is designed to compensate Mr. Fail for the money he spent to meet the new requirements.

title: Hitchcock Out, but Yanks Have a Cushion

title: BARR LABORATORIES IS BUYING ENHANCE PHARMACEUTICALS
description: Barr Laboratories, which makes generic versions of brand-name drugs, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Enhance Pharmaceuticals for $44 million to expand its offering of health products for women. Barr, based in Pomona, N.Y., gains a system to deliver medicines that treat urinary incontinence and relieve pain after gynecological procedures. The acquisition of the closely held Enhance, which is based in Princeton, N.J., will shave 1 cent to 3 cents from Barr's per share profit in 2002 and 15 cents to 20 cents from 2003 earnings, Barr said. The purchase will add to earnings after the introduction of a product under development at Enhance, Barr said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Visit By Japanese Leader
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan arrived in Seoul in an effort to promote good will before the World Cup soccer finals, which Japan and South Korea will play host to starting on May 31. He and President Kim Dae Jung are expected to discuss trade and investment as well as efforts to improve cultural and social ties. Thousands of police officers were on guard against protesters; Japan made South Korea a colony in 1910 and remained there until the end of World War II. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: RESTORATION HARDWARE RESTATES 2 YEARS OF EARNINGS
description: Restoration Hardware shares fell more than 8 percent yesterday after it said it was restating almost two years of earnings as it changed the way it accounted for some revenue. The company's stock fell 99 cents, to $11.01. The company, a home furnishings retailer, also reported a fourth-quarter loss. Restoration said Wednesday that it had decided to restate results and change the way it recorded furniture sales, after discussions with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Costs to close stores and eliminate slow-selling products resulted in a loss of $12.4 million, or 53 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, which ended Feb. 2. In the same quarter a year earlier, Restoration Hardware had restated net income of $9.51 million, or 55 cents.

title: Barnes & Noble Reports Profit
description: Barnes & Noble, the bookstore chain, posted its first quarterly profit in almost two years yesterday on increased sales of books and video-game systems during the holidays.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Walkout At Oil Company
description: Administrators, technicians and managers at Venezuela's state oil company, Petrleos de Venezuela, began a one-day strike, challenging the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chvez, left, to follow through with his threat to militarize the company. The workers are protesting last month's appointment to the board of five employees the strikers said were not qualified and were selected for their political loyalty to Mr. Chvez. Since then, workers have staged almost daily protests, becoming the focal point for forces opposed to Mr. Chvez. The strike has not affected oil production, said Ruben Silva, a work coordinator for the oil company.

title: Senators Assail Corporate Use Of Bermuda As Tax Shelter
description: Senior senators from both parties used blunt language today to denounce companies that use Bermuda as a mail drop to reduce their American income taxes by tens of millions of dollars, calling them ''greedy'' and ''unpatriotic'' tax evaders whose actions could not be tolerated ''in a time of war.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: School Financing Goes Back To Court
description: The State Supreme Court, which has ruled three times that the level of state financing for schools is unconstitutional, will take up the issue again because a mediator's effort to settle the matter has failed. About 500 schools filed a lawsuit in 1991 contending that the state's financing system favored students in affluent districts over those in poor districts. Mediation began in September after the state asked the court to reconsider a ruling that more money would have to be spent on the schools. Daniel I. Dorfman (NYT)

title: Subtle Racism in Medicine
description: It has long been known that blacks, Hispanics and other minorities receive lower-quality health care than whites do, a disparity generally attributed to lower incomes, inadequate insurance coverage and lack of doctors in minority areas. These socioeconomic causes are real, but a disturbing new study by the Institute of Medicine has concluded that even when members of minority groups have the same incomes, insurance coverage and medical conditions as whites, they receive notably poorer care. Biases, prejudices and negative racial stereotypes, the panel concludes, may be misleading doctors and other health professionals.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Keep Hands On Wheel, Not Phone
description: People who use a hand-held mobile phone while driving face a $384 fine and the possibility of a three-month jail term for repeat offenses under a law passed in response to outrage over road deaths. The legislation also bans hand-held CB radios and walkie-talkies but not hands-free devices. Nearly 80 percent of Irish people over 15 own mobile phones. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: A 'Passion' As Bach Might Have Wanted It

The orchestra was a period-instrument band, Concert Royal, but that is not so unusual. Much more rarely and impressively, here, in Bach's biggest work, was a regular (though exceptional) church choir, singing where it sings every Sunday and providing most of the soloists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RABBI ISRAEL
description: MILLER-Rabbi Israel. The entire Yeshiva University & its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) family express profound sorrow over the passing, in Jerusalem, of its revered senior vice president emeritus. Rabbi Miller was a truly inspiring leader, humanitarian, colleague and mentor to us for more than six decades. He was also a world-renowned Jewish leader and eloquent national and international spokesman for the Jewish people. His leadership skills were rooted in his keen intellect and in his profound grace and humility, which touted all who knew or dealt with him at any level. He championed a myriad of Jewish causes as chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, chairman of the American Jewish Conference on Soviet Jewry, secretary of the International Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture, a founder of the Jewish Community Relations Council, president of the Rabbinical Council of America and of the Rabbinical Alumni Association of RIETS, and he was a top officer of nearly every other major Jewish organization in New York and the nation. As president of of the Conference of Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, his tireless energies helped achieve a landmark compensation agreement for the criminal theft and plunder that was part of the barbarity of the Holocaust. The legacy that his labors and commitment to the Jewish people left for the survivors of the Holocaust is timeless and immeasurable. For more than 25 years, he provided insightful and compassionate guidance as beloved spiritual leader of the Kingsbridge Heights Jewish Center in the Bronx. As learned as he was wise, Dr. Miller was an alumnus of Yeshiva College, earned his master's degree from Columbia University, and was ordained at RIETS, where he taught practical rabbinics and influenced the careers and lives of countless students. In 1967, when he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Divinity degree, then-University president Dr. Samuel Belkin called him ''the symbol of the ideal rabbi.'' He joined the University administration in 1968, was appointed vice president in 1970, senior vice president in 1979, and senior vice president emeritus in 1994. He was a member of the Board of Governors of YU's Wurzweiler School of Social Work and of the RIETS Board of Trustees. As he was fond of saying, ''I came as a freshman in 1934 and have never really left.'' We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ruth; his children, Rabbi David (and Miriam) Miller, Rabbi Michael (and Phyllis) Miller, Deborah (and Norman) Kram, and Judith (and Jay) Kalish, his 19 grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, his brother David and sister Dorothy who reside in Netanya, Israel, and all members of the bereaved family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The loss of this remarkable man of wisdom, warmth, compassion and leadership leaves a void in the world. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University and RIETS Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustess

title: Painting Their Souls, Predicting Their Future

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Google Removes Anti-Scientology Links
description: Google Inc. said it had removed some links to an anti-Scientology Web site from its popular search engine this week after the Church of Scientology told it that the linked pages infringed on church copyrights. The pages were part of Operation Clambake (xenu.net), a site based in Norway that is a well-known hub for critics of Scientology. The church cited the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, a 1998 law that can make it illegal to link to copyright-infringing material. Andreas Heldal-Lund, the owner of Operation Clambake, said the material fell under the fair-use provision of copyright law, and that he would ask Google to restore the links. David F. title: CARNIVAL, THE CRUISE COMPANY, REPORTS HIGHER PROFIT

Net income rose to $129.6 million, or 22 cents a share, from $128 million, also 22 cents, a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended Feb. 28, fell 10 percent, to $905.8 million. Twelve of 52 Senate districts and 39 of 122 House districts, up one from a decade ago, have black majorities. Under the Voting Rights Act the federal Justice Department must review the plans.

title: The Art of Banality
description: Few exhibitions of contemporary art have come into the world more shrouded in exegesis than ''Mirroring Evil: Nazi Imagery/Recent Art,'' which opened last week at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan. The catalog is a briar patch of rhetorical questions and explanatory negotiations, and that spirit is echoed on the wall text in the gallery rooms. The exhibition reads as though its real purpose were to watch the reactions of viewers, as though this were mainly an exhibition about the act of exhibiting. This seems awfully devious in a room where Prada, Chanel, the swastika and the Fhrer's mustache intermingle in some all-too-simple equilibrium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, ELISABETH ACKER
description: HARRISON-Elisabeth Acker. Age 88, of 10016 Cederfield Court, Richmond, VA., died suddenly and quietly on February 17, 2002. She is survived by three sons, Clayton Adelbert Farrar, Jr., the Reverend C. Thomas Farrar and LTC David S. Farrar, USA (ret.), one daughter, Ann Farrar Browning, five grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. She is also survived by two stepsons, Charles & Peter Harrison and one step-daughter, Elizabeth Harrison Morgan. Mrs. Harrison was born and raised in New York City, and attended Spence School & Vassar College. She married Clayton Adelbert Farrar Sr. (deceased) in 1934, and Henry A. Harrison (deceased) in 1964. She was one of the first female aviators, flying small planes all over the country. A lifelong volunteer for the Red Cross, she drove ambulances during World War II. She was a Master Bridge Player who enjoyed sharing her knowledge. Private funeral services will be held graveside at the Acker family plot, Woodlawn Cemetery, New York City on March 23. The family suggests that memorial contributions be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Senator Offers Antipiracy Bill
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina and chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, introduced a bill yesterday intended to prevent consumers from exchanging unauthorized copies of movies, music and television shows over the Internet. The measure would give the technology and entertainment industries one year to agree on a copy-protection technology that would prevent computers and electronic devices from playing unauthorized material. If they cannot agree on a standard, the Federal Communications Commission will impose one. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Doctors Face A Big Jump In Insurance
description: Doctors in the New York area face sharp increases in their medical malpractice insurance costs, which are already among the highest in the country.

title: 3 MORE AIRLINES ELIMINATE COMMISSIONS TO TRAVEL AGENTS
description: United Airlines and the US Airways Group joined rivals yesterday in scrapping most commissions paid to travel agents in the United States and Canada. American Trans Air also matched the change, while Vanguard Airlines said it would keep paying a 5 percent commission. Last week, Delta Air Lines began the change. It was followed this week by AMR, parent of American Airlines; Continental Airlines; and Northwest Airlines. Dropping the commissions is expected to save the airlines about $1 billion a year, analysts said.

title: The Middle East's Failed Leaders
description: Vice President Dick Cheney's visit to the Middle East has made it even more obvious that forging an Israeli-Palestinian peace is a vital American strategic priority. We cannot serve any of our other interests in this region, which has nearly 70 percent of the world's proved oil reserves, unless we are seen to do everything possible to win a just peace. We cannot take action against Iraq with the regional support we need, roll back proliferation of nuclear weapons or even sustain our military presence.

title: Pope Says 'Shadow of Suspicion' Has Been Cast Across All Priests
description: Pope John Paul II, in a letter released today, weighed in for the first time on recent pedophile scandals in his church, saying ''a dark shadow of suspicion'' had been cast over all priests by ''some of our brothers who have betrayed the grace of ordination'' and succumbed to evil.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Joyful Life Of a Jazz Man

title: 'Margarita Happy Hour'
description: Directed by Ilya Chaiken

title: Big Builder In Germany Is Bankrupt
description: Germany Inc. refused to rescue one of its own today, as the country's biggest banks and its political leaders watched the Philipp Holzmann construction conglomerate declare bankruptcy.

title: Leaving It All to New York; Minnesota Handyman Made a Million-Dollar Bequest
description: A celebratory air filled the room as Joe Temeczko, an 86-year-old scavenger and handyman, signed his last will and testament. He ran around his lawyer's office, hugged everyone and said, ''We should call Mayor Giuliani and tell him.''

title: Refining Military Tribunals
description: The Bush administration's plans for military tribunals to try suspected terrorists are less troubling now than they were when the idea was first announced four months ago. But there is still no practical or legal justification for having the tribunals. The United States has a criminal justice system that is a model for the rest of the world. There is no reason to scrap it in these cases.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: ABB's Commercial Paper
description: The ailing Swiss-Swedish engineering group ABB said it would draw on a $3 billion bank loan to pay short-term debt after investors failed to buy its commercial paper. ABB, Europe's largest electrical engineering company, said most of the money was to be used to pay off commercial paper that matured in 2000. About $1 billion will be added to cash reserves, but ABB said it would renegotiate the loan as it tries to reduce its debt by $1.5 billion this year. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Couple Guilty of All Charges In Fatal Attack by Their Dog
description: Two lawyers whose huge dog mauled a neighbor to death as she was trying to enter her San Francisco apartment were convicted today on all five charges, including a count of murder against one of them.

title: Cable for Long Island Sound Is Approved, but Opponents Are Not Giving Up
description: A proposal for an underwater cable carrying electricity between Long Island and Connecticut received the last in a series of required approvals this week, meaning the cable could be in place as early as June, supporters of the project said yesterday.

title: Councilmen and Mayor's Office Ask for Apologies After Tiff
description: One of the first open spats of the new administration became a duel of demands for apologies yesterday, as a group of City Council members sought one from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for comments they deemed racist, and his spokesman requested an apology in response.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVEY, MARJORIE H.
description: KAVEY-Marjorie H. Of Scarsdale New York, age 87. On March 20, surrounded by her family. Beloved wife for 52 years of Milton K. Kavey. Adoring mother of children Madelon Kavey O'Shea (Rod) and Neil B. Kavey, M.D. (Karen). Also survived by five grandchildren and sister Lucille H. Jacobs. Graveside service will be held today at 2PM at the Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: New Video Releases
description: Focus

title: Second Soldier Dies From Injuries In Fort Drum Munitions Accident
description: A second soldier has died from injuries suffered in Wednesday's munitions accident, in which two powerful artillery shells landed well short of their target during military exercises and in the midst of a battalion eating breakfast, officials reported today.

title: Phone and Credit Files Link Student Held in New York to 3 Terrorism Figures
description: A Bradley University graduate student from Qatar who was arrested in January may have links through telephone records to three men named as conspirators in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to documents unsealed in federal court here.

title: The Big City; Wrong Labels Inflame Fears Of Catholics
description: NOW that we in the press have so energetically contemplated ''the sins of the fathers,'' as headline writers keep putting it, let us contemplate our own.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Japanese Coats Of Many Colors

title: Ex-Gateway Executive Says Microsoft Bullies PC Makers
description: The Microsoft Corporation bullies computer makers by withholding discounts if they promote products that threaten its Windows monopoly, a former Gateway Inc. executive testified today on behalf of states seeking tough antitrust remedies against Microsoft.

title: Many Blessings From Buddha
description: There is always plenty of Asian art on view in New York City's art institutions. But once a year, when Asia Week unfolds, work arrives here from all over the world. This weekend can be a total immersion experience for art lovers, with two big fairs and dozens of gallery shows displaying paintings, sculpture, carvings, jewelry and other precious objects.

title: Fire Chief's Remains Are Among 13 Found
description: The remains of one of the highest ranking Fire Department officers killed on Sept. 11 were found yesterday at ground zero, along with those of 10 other firefighters and two civilians, fire officials said.

title: Glitches for YES In Early Innings
description: The first two days of the YES Network's existence have been troubled by out-of-sync reception on Time Warner's New York City cable system.

title: Facing Reality
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Fur As Light As a Breeze
Ovitz Film Unit Loses Partner, Putting Future In Some Doubt
description: The major investor in the film unit of Michael Ovitz's Hollywood management company has decided to withdraw from their joint venture agreement, putting the future of the unit in question.

title: William Scholl, 81, Designer Of a Sandal That Set a Trend
description: William H. Scholl, the son of a founder of the Dr. Scholl's company and the developer of the wooden sandals that became as much fashion as foot care, died March 15 at a hospital in Douglas, on the Isle of Man.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Progress Reported In Talks With U.S.
description: The United States and Russia have narrowed differences in two days of talks in Geneva on a pact to reduce nuclear arms, negotiators said, but differences remain on how warheads will be counted and on whether they will be destroyed or stored when taken out of operation. The two sides will meet again in Moscow on April 23 to try to prepare a deal that President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin can sign at a summit meeting in May.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENCER, EILEEN
description: PENCER-Eileen. The members of the board of trustees of the Lower Eastside Service Center along with all staff members are profoundly saddened by the untimely death of our beloved president and CEO, Eileen Pencer. She was a visionary whose remarkably good judgement and steady leadership helped guide both the expansion of LESC and the success of Angel Street Thrift Shop. We cannot say enough about her tremendous courage, spirit and will to live. She has been an inspiration to us all. We will always love her and cherish her memory. We remember her with heartfelt gratitude and extend our condolences to her family. Contributions may be made to the Eileen Pencer Memorial Fund made payable to Friends of LESC, 157 Chambers St., New York, NY 10007 Peter Santoro, Board Chairman Elaine Katz, First Vice President

title: For Security, Tourists to Be On Other Side Of Cameras
description: With a week or so before the cherry blossoms burst, the spectrum of Americans braved cheek-scorching, near-freezing winds today to tour the Mall's hallowed grounds, where, come October, each step they take to the memorials, each gaze at the monuments, perhaps each crumb they toss the gulls in the reflecting pool will be watched and videotaped.

title: Steve Gromek, 82, a Pitcher Who Is Best Known for a Picture
description: Steve Gromek, the Cleveland Indians pitcher who provided a signature moment in the integration of Major League Baseball when he was photographed in a joyful embrace with Larry Doby at the 1948 World Series, died March 12 at a hospital in Clinton Township, Mich. He was 82.

title: Report Linking Anthrax and Hijackers Is Investigated
description: The two men identified themselves as pilots when they came to the emergency room of Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., last June. One had an ugly, dark lesion on his leg that he said he developed after bumping into a suitcase two months earlier. Dr. Christos Tsonas thought the injury was curious, but he cleaned it, prescribed an antibiotic for infection and sent the men away with hardly another thought.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Pipeline Strategy
description: Malaysia's state oil company reiterated warnings this week that it might reroute a natural gas pipeline to exclude neighboring Thailand, where political opposition has delayed construction. Malaysia and Thailand had hoped to begin building the 210-mile Thai-Malaysia pipeline from gas fields offshore through southern Thailand to Malaysia early this year. But opposition from villages along the pipeline's proposed route has forced the Thai prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, above, to delay until next month a final decision on whether to proceed. The leadership of the Malaysian company, Petroliam Nasional, said this week that the company, which has a contract to start buying gas in July, might be forced to pursue ''Plan B'' for the pipeline. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paralyzed Woman Has Right To Die, a British Judge Rules
description: A High Court judge ruled today that a paralyzed woman had the right to die and that it was her decision rather than her doctors' whether a life-support machine should be shut off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLECHTER, ARTHUR D.
description: SCHLECHTER-Arthur D. Died quietly at home after a short illness at the age of 88. Survived by his loving brother Herbert & sisterin-law Selma, beloved companion to Karola Sallan and dear friend to her son Dr. Stephen Sallan and his wife Darlene and children, devoted uncle of Bruce and Susan and Kenneth and Marcia, great-uncle of Aaron, Alan, Annie, Benjamin and Michael. Arthur was a lawyer, served in W.W. II as a Staff Sergeant in the European Theatre and for 50 years was in the real estate ownership and management business with his brother Herbert. Funeral services will be private at Beth Olom Cemetery in Queens. The family will welcome friends at the home of Herbert Schlechter Sunday from 3-6 P.M. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: 19-Year-Old Roddick Finds Life Tough Near the Top
description: After being a Davis Cup star and a United States Open quarterfinalist in his first full pro season last year, Andy Roddick is already feeling that 2002 may not end soon enough for him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MAX
description: KAUFMAN-Max of Clark, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Blanche. Loving companion to Bronia Furst. Devoted father, brother and grandfather. Services at Congregation Beth Israel, Scotch Plains, NJ. Sunday at 11 A.M. For information please call ''Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman'', 800-351-4414.

title: Beliefs; Two faiths, a sacred season, lessons for the young and the incongruity of child's play.
description: Here, in the children's section of a major Manhattan bookstore, was a display of children's books about Passover. There, a few yards away, was a display of children's books about Easter. The contrast was unmistakable. Why, one had to ask, are these books so different from those other books?

title: Police Department Takes Steps to Modernize Its Technology
description: Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has ordered an overhaul of the way the Police Department uses computers and other technology after determining that its current systems were woefully inadequate and lagged behind innovations of other police agencies.

title: A Delicate Word in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Bush Looks South
description: Most Latin American nations are feeling a bit jilted these days. President Bush came into office pledging to make them a top foreign policy priority, but has found it hard to live up to his commitment.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article on March 14 reported on a proclamation by the mayor of Inglis, Fla., population 1,400, banning Satan from the town. The mayor, Carolyn Risher, had prayers encased in posts at the entrances to the town. The article said that while the proclamation was signed by the town clerk and stamped with the official seal, other town officials had said the mayor was speaking only for herself.

title: Bush, in Monterrey, Speaks of Conditional Global Aid
description: President Bush called today for a ''new compact'' for global development by insisting that rich nations give foreign aid to poor nations only if poor nations undertake a broad range of political, legal and economic reforms.

title: Sprewell Wants to Be Consulted on Moves
description: Latrell Sprewell is tired of holding his tongue. After the Knicks gave up 118 points in a listless loss to the Atlanta Hawks Thursday night, Sprewell abandoned his policy of avoiding potentially controversial subjects.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on March 15 about the exhibition ''Baseball as America'' at the American Museum of Natural History misstated the surnames of two legendary African-American sportswriters. They are Wendell Smith, not Houston, and Sam Lacy, not Lacey.

title: In a Small Upstate City, They Love Lucy Anew; Lucy-Desi Museum in Jamestown Plans to Expand Shrine to a TV Classic
description: Lucy and Ethel, mouths stuffed with chocolate from that famous factory scene in ''I Love Lucy,'' peer down from the side wall of the Jones Bakery here. Lucy and Ricky, in another mural, stare out from the side of the post office, on Prendergast Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZ, DR. LEO
description: WEITZ-Dr. Leo. Devoted father of Barbara Pollard; loving grandfather of Laura Masurovsky and Jonathan Pollard; delighted greatgrandfather of Alex, Adam, Jason, Benjamin and Danielle. An avid proponent of public education, Dr. Weitz served as Principal of James Monroe High School in the Bronx, and Lafayette High School in Brooklyn. He created the Core Curriculum and helped to develop the plans for John Dewey High School in Brooklyn. He went on to establish the Graduate Program in Administration and Supervision at Pace Unviversity in New York City. He loved people, books and teaching, in that order.

title: Robin Anderson, 51, Creator Of Documentaries on Australia
description: Robin Anderson, an Australian filmmaker whose award-winning documentaries ranged from examinations of tribal life in Papua New Guinea to social and political controversies in Australia, died here on March 8. She was 51.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decision by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee creating a commission to investigate the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks misstated the vote. It was a unanimous voice vote of the 9 members present -- not a unanimous vote of the 17 committee members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMANN, ARTHUR E., DDS.
description: HERMANN-Arthur E., DDS. On March 21, 2002 in Roslyn, NY after a nine month struggle following heart surgery. Beloved husband of Mildred Hermann. Loving father of Laurie Schwartzer, Elizabeth Schoenfeld and Jane Simons. Father-in-law of Richard Schwartzer, Larry Schoenfeld and Paul Simons. Devoted grandfather of Matthew and Jenni Schwartzer and Todd and Jodi Stillman. Beloved brother of Lucille Kagan. Known for his kindness, intelligence, humor, vitality and strength. Practiced dentistry for more than 50 years after graduating in 1943 from NYU College of Dentistry. Served his country with a two year tour in the US Army as a dentist during the Korean Conflict. Loved dearly by family and friends, he will be greatly missed and fondly remembered by all who knew him. Services Sunday, March 24th at 12:45PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Ohio Town Tries to Cope As Girl Hit by Puck Is Buried
description: The farewell took all of two hours. A young girl sang ''Amazing Grace'' in the Preble Memory Gardens Chapel. An uncle delivered a eulogy. Hundreds of people wept and hugged each other and whispered Brittanie Nichole Cecil's name as if to sharpen the icicles of memory that had yet to melt from their minds.

title: Life Inside Tall Tin Can in Utah Is All Mars
description: In the red-rock desert west of this lonely little town, six seriously smart people are living in something that looks like a sawed-off corn silo and smells of their unwashed socks.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Marconi In Debt Talks
description: The British telephone equipment maker Marconi said it was in talks with its banks about renegotiating credit lines, after agreeing to cancel the portions of two loans it has not yet drawn. The company also said it did not expect sales to pick up for at least another year. Marconi must repay the 2.2 billion ($3.1 billion) it has drawn on one line totaling 4.5 billion by March 2003, although the banks can now demand repayment at any time, the company said. Standard & Poor's cut Marconi's credit rating by two notches to B- and said it expected a reorganization of the company's debts. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Indiana's Jeffries Faces New Set of Decisions
description: SOMETIMES, the best decisions are made in church. Jared Jeffries does not claim he was praying for guidance, but at the very least he was in church on a Sunday morning, the church his grandfather helped build 73 years ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Volcker Proposes Andersen e Controlled by New Panel

title: Pakistan Chief Said to Plan A Vote to Extend His Rule
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who seized power in a coup in 1999, plans to stay in power for at least another five years by holding a referendum on the matter, probably in May, according to politicians who have discussed the plan with him.

title: PALM SHARES RISE 22 PERCENT AFTER ROSIER FORECAST
description: Palm 's shares rose 22 percent yesterday after the company reported a fiscal third-quarter profit and forecast a rebound in sales of its hand-held computers. Sales of Palm devices, which had fallen for four consecutive quarters, will rise this quarter as demand improves, Palm said on Thursday. Palm, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it earned $2.95 million, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter ended March 1, in contrast to a loss of $1.94 million, or break-even on a per-share basis, a year earlier.

title: James J. Dunn, 81, Ex-Publisher of Forbes
description: James J. Dunn, the publisher of Forbes magazine for 20 years, died on Monday at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, CATHERINE
description: MORAN-Catherine. On March 20, 2002. Beloved wife of Joseph, loving daughter of the late William and Anna Durkin. Dear sister of the late James, Mary and Dr. Joseph Durkin. Mass of the Resurrection today at Epiphany Church, 22nd St and 2nd Ave., 10 AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: U.S. Confident of Suspect's Extradition From Pakistan
description: The Bush administration is convinced that the militant accused of killing an American reporter will eventually be handed over to the United States even if the Pakistani government follows through with its plans to try him for the crime in Pakistan, officials said today.

title: Senators Agree on Measure To Overhaul Voting System
description: Senate negotiators said today that they had reached agreement on a bill to clean up the nation's election procedures, clearing the way for Senate approval of the bill soon after Congress reconvenes in two weeks.

title: Protecting the Bench From Politics
description: In a reassuring development for New York's judicial system, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has decided to continue the city's tradition of merit selection of lower court judges begun by Mayor Edward Koch nearly 25 years ago.

title: Mets' Latest Lineup Could Start the Season
description: Charles Grodin, the actor and comedian, was visiting his friend Bobby Valentine recently in the Mets' spring training complex. When the conversation turned to the Mets' lineup, a favorite discussion of everyone but Valentine, Grodin jumped in. Apparently, he, too, has an opinion of who should bat where.

title: City Hall Memo; Mayor's Bid For Schools Tests His Ear For Politics
description: When he was running for mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg could be counted on to speak frankly, whether it was in his interest or not. More than occasionally it wasn't.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about eight American soldiers who were awarded the Purple Heart for wounds sustained during fighting in Afghanistan misidentified the officer receiving his medal from Maj. Gen. Franklin L. Hagenbeck during a ceremony at Bagram Air Base. He was Capt. James Taylor of the Third Battalion, Sixth Field Artillery, from Fort Drum, N.Y., not Pfc. Chad Ryan.

title: Commission Concludes That Swiss Policies Aided the Nazis
description: An independent historians' commission, wrapping up five years of research into Switzerland's wartime past, concluded today that the country's neutrality was twisted to justify policies that helped the Nazis, including turning away Jews fleeing the Holocaust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, JOHN T.
description: ELLIOTT-John T. On March 22, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Mary A. (nee Connaghan). Devoted father of John C., James G., Michael D., Brendan P., T.J. and Irene Elliott-Hupe. Dear brother of Mary Farmer, Betty Mescall and the late Br. James F.S.C., Thomas J. & Edward R. Loving grandfather of twelve and great grandfather of four. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing Monday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at Riverdaleon-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 11 AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church.

title: Salukis Fail to Account for UConn's Resolve
description: Southern Illinois Coach Bruce Weber could not have drawn it up any better, nor could his Salukis have executed it any more flawlessly. Swarm Caron Butler, the Connecticut star, whenever he touched the ball and hold him to 2 points for 15 minutes of the second half. Still, it was not enough.

title: Notes From Hartford; Carried Away by the Women's Team
description: Last year, before the March Madness tournament started, Shea Ralph, an All-America basketball player for the University of Connecticut, blew out her knee for the third time, in a game against Notre Dame.

description: To the Editor:

title: For Tigers, Hot Streak Wipes Out The Pain
description: In Missouri's first game of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Kareem Rush's lip became the symbol of the team's season. Rush, a 6-foot-6 junior forward, sustained a 21-stitch gash in his lower lip when hit with an elbow late in the Tigers' victory over Miami.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON TO ACQUIRE BELGIAN DRUG MAKER
description: Johnson & Johnson, seeking to expand its line of infectious- disease treatments, agreed to buy a closely held Belgian drug maker, Tibotec- Virco, for about $320 million in cash and debt. Johnson & Johnson already markets Levaquin for pneumonia and bronchitis; Floxin for urinary tract infections; and an anemia drug, Procrit, to AIDS patients. It would gain two H.I.V. drug candidates in human trials. Tibotec-Virco, based in Mechelen, Belgium, is developing ''next generation'' versions of H.I.V. drugs for patients resistant to similar drugs on the market. The company also has operations in North Carolina and Ireland. Johnson & Johnson is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Navy, to Cut Costs, Proposes Joining With Marines in Two Big Fighter-Jet Programs
description: In further acknowledgment that the Pentagon cannot afford all the high-cost programs on the books, the Navy is proposing to combine its two major fighter-jet programs with those of the Marine Corps, allowing the two services to cut planned purchases sharply, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, HARVEY DAVID
description: TURNER-Harvey David. Beloved husband of Barbara Persky Turner. Adored by his son Jeffrey Turner, his daughter Susan Daltrey Turner and her partner Cheryl Murray. Loving grandfather of Dylan and Jason Turner. Devoted brother and brother-in-law of Natalie & Jacob Lebovitz. Formerly of Roslyn Heights, Long Island, Mr. Turner taught at the Saddle Rock School in Great Neck for thirty-three years. Services Sunday, March 24, 11 AM, Temple Anshe Amunim, 26 Broad Street, Pittsfield, MA.

title: The Wrong Way to Remember Sept. 11
description: There is no easy way to memorialize an event as ineffably sad as the loss of 3,000 innocent lives in New York last Sept. 11. The New York State Assembly has, however, seized on precisely the wrong way, passing a bill sponsored by Speaker Sheldon Silver to create an official holiday and a day off for state workers.

title: Day of Pitching Progress Brings Relief to Yankees
description: Four baseball diamonds fan out from an observation tower at the Yankees' minor-league complex here. From the top of the tower today, coaches could look in two directions and see potential Hall of Famers overpowering Philadelphia Phillies farmhands. To the south, Roger Clemens. To the east, Mariano Rivera. It didn't seem quite fair.

title: Regents Board Approves Bronx Charter School
description: While many teachers dream of starting their own school, few get that chance. But this week, a group of teachers, a social worker and a business-school graduate received approval from the state's Board of Regents to do just that, becoming one of the first grass-roots groups in the city to start a charter school.

title: Europe Lists U.S. Imports It Plans to Tax
description: The European Union has drawn up a list of imports from the United States, worth about $2.1 billion annually, to penalize in retaliation for the Bush administration's recent imposition of tariffs of up to 30 percent on some imported steel.

title: Martin Gets a Call and Then Fires Up the Nets
description: When Milwaukee's Darvin Ham swung his arm into Kenyon Martin's face to deny his driving layup in the second quarter tonight, the whistle shrieked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, LILLIAN
description: FISHMAN-Lillian. On March 22, 2002, at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Noah; mother of David and the late Nancy and mother-in-law of Sandrel. Her life spanned a century of dramatic change, and throughout she remained a loving, caring and wonderful mother, aunt, and friend to all of us. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her.

title: Agency Chief For Inspections Fails in Vote Of Confidence
description: The United States won a battle today, but failed to win its war against the director of the organization that supervises the destruction of chemical weapons.

title: Rating Services' Doubts Hurt Shares of Verizon
description: The bond and share prices of Verizon Communications Inc. fell yesterday after two credit ratings services said the company needed to reduce its dependence on volatile short-term borrowing or increase its bank commitments backing that debt.

title: Tales of Mutiny and Murder Unfold After a Missing Taiwanese Ship Is Found
description: A dramatic tale of murder and mutiny on the high seas unfolded yesterday in Honolulu as the authorities accused a Chinese seaman of killing his captain and first mate and taking over a 195-foot Taiwanese fishing vessel that disappeared for three days last week in the vastness southeast of the Hawaiian Islands.

description: To the Editor:

title: Terrapins Turn Their Triumph Into Senior Night
description: Lonny Baxter threw his 260 pounds inside like a pinball. Byron Mouton stuck on Kentucky's Tayshaun Prince like a Secret Service agent. And Juan Dixon showed why he is the most heralded Maryland senior of them all. In addition, the junior Drew Nicholas moved into shooting position like a wisp of smoke.

title: Advocating Tobacco, On the Payroll Of Tobacco
description: ''Roger Scruton, High Priest Philosopher of the Libertarian Right, Defrocked and Exposed as 'Grimy Hack' for Tobacco Industry.''
