description: In percent

title: Energy That Jumps, Bounces and Screams
description: The TriBeCa Performing Arts Center at Borough of Manhattan Community College has the admirable policy of inviting composers, directors, writers and dance troupes to be artists in residence for a year. During that time, they receive rehearsal space, a stipend, administrative support and opportunities to present public programs.

title: Colorado Quietly Builds a Case for National Recognition
description: Anonymity is not hard to come by out here. This is football country. And it is skiing country. On their campus, the Colorado women's basketball players draw a flicker of recognition.

title: Government Orders Inquiry Into Trade Center Collapse
description: The Bush administration has agreed to finance an expanded investigation into the exact circumstances that led to the collapse of the World Trade Center towers, a $16 million inquiry that could lead to changes in codes that govern the design and construction of skyscrapers.

title: Murder Suspect Escapes From Station House
description: A man who was arrested Thursday, a suspect in a a double homicide in December and a double shooting this month, escaped from a Brooklyn station house last night, the police said.

title: The Right Path Toward Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUN, CHONGSUN T.
description: YUN-Chongsun T. Midhattan Dental Study Club notes with sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Chongsun Yun, D.D.S., and extends deepest sympathy to the bereaved family. Stephen Gerstman, D.D.S., President

title: Taxi Drivers Win a First Amendment Round Against the City
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that city officials violated the First Amendment nearly four years ago when they blocked a demonstration in which taxi drivers planned to flood the Queensboro Bridge and Broadway with their cars during the morning rush hour.

title: A Bias Toward Waste
description: Detroit's latest automotive brainchild appears to be an updated version of the old family station wagon. The automakers say the new cars are designed to attract drivers who want the space of an S.U.V. plus the handling and looks of a luxury car. As a report in The Times by Danny Hakim makes clear, however, these vehicles will also allow manufacturers to exploit a loophole in the government's outdated fuel economy standards to sell inefficient -- if highly profitable -- cars.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCNEELY, JAMES JOSEPH
description: McNEELY-James Joseph. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, April 13, 2002 at 10:30AM, The Church of Saint Agnes, 143 East 43 Street, NY, NY

title: FORMER FED CHIEF OUTLINES PROPOSAL TO SAVE ANDERSEN
description: Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve who was brought in last month by Arthur Andersen to restore its credibility, proposed yesterday that the government drop its criminal case against Andersen and that he put a new board in charge of the accounting firm.

title: G.O.P. Says Checks Show Democrats' Hypocrisy
description: Republican Party officials said today that it was hypocritical for the Democratic Party to accept $12 million in soft money from two donors to build a new headquarters building even as the party was supporting legislation to ban such gifts.

title: Sharp Rise in Federal Spending May Have Helped Ease Recession
description: When a bitterly divided Congress failed to pass an economic stimulus bill last fall, many predicted the recession would only worsen. But while few were paying attention, government spending surpassed the amounts envisioned in the stimulus measure, exceeding what even the most vociferous advocates wanted.

title: BANKS GIVE CONSECO MORE TIME TO MAKE DEBT PAYMENT
description: A group of banks gave Conseco, the insurance and finance company, more time to repay $1.5 billion of debt in exchange for a higher interest rate. The banks, led by J. P. Morgan Chase and the Bank of America, also approved a plan by Conseco to swap up to $2.54 billion of new bonds for existing securities. The new debt will mature in one to two and a half years. The agreement may help Conseco avert a credit-rating downgrade, which would raise borrowing costs as the company repays about $6.1 billion in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAPLIN, ARTIE
description: CHAPLIN-Artie 3 years-March 23, 1999 Thanks for the circus, but we sorely miss the clown. Mimi, Kids and ALL those Friends

title: U.S.-Mexico Relations: Alliance Meets Boundaries
description: In the courtship between President Bush and President Vicente Fox of Mexico, images seem so convincing.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Inspection Concern Posts Loss
description: The world's largest cargo inspector, Socit Gnrale de Surveillance Holding, posted a $45 million loss last year, its second in recent years. The group, based in Geneva, took an extraordinary charge of $108 million to cover outstanding bills at a unit that inspects goods for governments. Socit Gnrale, which performs customs inspections in two dozen countries worldwide, said it might sell one unit to return to profitability. It is negotiating with governments in the Philippines and Ivory Coast to recover about $240 million in unpaid fees. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Sleight of Hand Makes 2 Enemy Tricks One
description: William Root, always known as Bill, died Monday in Boca Raton, Fla., at 78. He was in every sense one of the giants of the game. At 6 feet 8 inches, he towered over the thousands of students he instructed in a 42-year teaching career. He wrote five significant books, won 13 major national team titles and was made a member of the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame.

title: Broad Increase in Postal Rates Is Approved by Federal Panel
description: The cost of sending a first-class letter will increase this summer by 3 cents, to 37 cents, as part of a broad postal rate increase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RABBI ISRAEL
description: MILLER - Rabbi Israel. The Trustees and staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage-A Living Memorial to the Holocaust deeply mourn the passing of Rabbi Israel Miller. A revered leader of the Jewish people as President of the Claims Conference since 1982, he was dedicated to its mission to obtain restitution for Holocaust victimes, helping over 400,000 survivors in more than sixty countries to receive compensation payments. Rabbi Miller's vision included Claims Conference support of research and documentation of Jewish suffering, which will facilitate the education of future generations. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Miller family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chairman

title: As Options Shrink, New York Revisits Idea of Incineration
description: In recent years, the idea of using incineration to dispose of some or all of New York City's daily tide of garbage seemed about as dead as Marley's ghost.

title: Senate Issues 29 Subpoenas In Inquiry on Enron Collapse
description: A Senate committee looking into the collapse of the Enron Corporation issued 29 subpoenas today seeking information from the company, its accountant and board members about communications they had with the government about energy policies and related matters.

title: Selling Furniture and Style by the Roomful
description: Some people watch their local television news for the weather report, while others tune in for the hidden-camera exposs. Jeffrey Seaman, chief executive of Rooms to Go, likes to look at living rooms.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the first sports page in some late editions yesterday about the Kent State-Pittsburgh basketball game misidentified the Kent State player shown. He was Demetric Shaw; Eric Thomas appeared on Page 3 of the section.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, PHYLLIS J.
description: GRANT-Phyllis J. On March 20, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Myron Studner. Services and interment private.

title: Survivor and Humanist, Celebrating con Brio
description: WAVES of laughter rolled out from the Barbican Hall, but it wasn't a stand-up comic working the room. It was Mstislav Rostropovich taking the London Symphony Orchestra through a rehearsal of Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: Andersen's Partners
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Damages From Cigarette Maker
description: A Multnomah County jury ordered Philip Morris to pay more than $150 million in damages for falsely representing low-tar cigarettes as safer than regular ones. The jury found that by advertising low-tar cigarettes as less dangerous and failing to disclose research about the health effects of smoking, Philip Morris was in large part responsible for the death of Michelle Schwarz, 53, in 1999 from lung cancer. The suit was filed in state court by the estate of Mrs. Schwarz; estate lawyers said she switched to Merit cigarettes for her health. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Labor Monitor To Go To Myanmar
description: The International Labor Organization has reached agreement with Myanmar, the former Burma, to place a liaison officer in the capital in an effort to end forced labor in the country. The military rulers rejected a permanent representative. A 1998 inquiry by the agency found ''widespread and systematic'' use of forced labor.

title: On First Day, Travelers Shares Are Up 6% in Heavy Trading
description: Shares of the Travelers insurance business rose just less than 6 percent yesterday in their first day of trading, disappointing some investors.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: New Leader For Rightist Party
description: Stockwell Day, the conservative politician who helped form the Canadian Alliance party two years ago, has lost an election to regain the party's leadership. Initial hopes that Mr. Day would unite Canada's right-wing voters dissolved after the party's poor showing in the November 2000 general election, and public gaffes and defections led Mr. Day to resign as the party's head in December. In the vote for a new leader, Stephen Harper, a former member of Parliament from the Reform Party, got 55 percent and Mr. Day 37.5 percent. Mr. Harper will now seek a seat in Parliament.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Acquisition
description: The German utility RWE has agreed to buy Innogy of Britain for 3.1 billion ($4.4 billion). RWE said it would offer 2.75 for each Innogy share, and 27.50 for each Innogy American depository share, each representing 10 shares of the underlying stock. RWE will also assume about 2.1 billion of Innogy debt. Innogy will add 4.7 million electricity customers and some 1.9 million gas customers to RWE's business in Europe, the companies said. The offer represents a 31 percent premium to the share price of Innogy on Feb. 15, the day before the company confirmed it had received approaches from several bidders. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Turmoil Starts Early For Giants This Year
description: The Giants begin workouts Monday and won't play their first game for another five months, but already they've provided their signature moments of 2002. If the Giants make the playoffs, the players will take credit for regrouping after a rancorous off-season, fondly speaking of Michael Strahan's ability to set aside his contentious negotiations and focus on football.

title: Another Anthrax Trail
description: A Florida doctor treated a Sept. 11 hijacker last June for a curious, dark sore on his leg, and now says he believes it may have been a case of cutaneous anthrax. The hijacker, Ahmed Alhaznawi, lived near a tabloid office attacked with anthrax, and a panel of experts has concluded that anthrax was ''the most probable'' explanation for his lesion.

title: Mickelson, Down by One, Plays It His Way
description: Hardly anything about Phil Mickelson's golf game is boring, not the way he plays or the way he responds to critics.

title: Rice Beats Lincoln In State Tournament
description: Jason Wingate's running jumper with three seconds remaining in the game gave Rice of Manhattan a 50-48 Class A semifinal victory over Lincoln of Brooklyn yesterday in the New York State Federation basketball championships in Glens Falls.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUPERT, RUDOLPH
description: RUPERT-Rudolph. In loving memory of my son, Rudolph Emanuel Rupert: You always said I cannot spend one day without mentioning your name. Since March 23, 2001, the day you parted from us, every part of my heart still cries out for you and your name rings in my soul. To all of you who loved him, think of him today, because he loved you too

title: Security-Prone Oscar Ceremony a Blight on Business
description: The long-awaited return of the Oscars to Hollywood, after an absence of 42 years, was intended to incite development and symbolize the neighborhood's economic revitalization. Instead, its first act is to shut the place down.

title: Paris briefed Beijing on deal, report says : Taiwan cites betrayal by France over frigates
description: HONG KONG:  An explosive report by the Taiwan government alleges that France betrayed Taiwan's confidence by passing top-secret information to China about the controversial sale of $2.5 billion worth of French frigates to Taiwan in the early 1990s, according to people who have seen the report.

title: A Sept. 6 Call To the Congress
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki asked national leaders yesterday to convene a joint meeting of Congress in New York City on Sept. 6 to commemorate the coming anniversary of the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Lawyer Balks At Discussing Enron Case
description: A lawyer on the staff of Arthur Andersen who played an important role in the events surrounding the firm's destruction of documents related to the Enron investigation refused to answer questions in a deposition yesterday and invoked her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

title: Japan and South Korea Agree to Simplify Business Dealings
description: The leaders of Japan and South Korea signed an investment agreement at a summit meeting here today that both see as the prelude to talks on establishing a free trade zone in Northeast Asia.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Why It Was Called The Gunpowder Plot
description: The British Library has discovered explosives believed to have been used by Guy Fawkes and his fellow Roman Catholic conspirators to try to blow up Parliament in 1605. Catalogers found a solid bar of gunpowder and paper twists of granular material in a box with notes linking it to the incident, which led to the execution of the plotters and is celebrated yearly across Britain with fireworks and bonfires. The box was part of a 1995 gift to the library from the collection of John Evelyn, a 17th-century diarist whose family made its fortune in gunpowder manufacture. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Maybe we'll get that free drink when we get back on the plane -- if we get back on the plane.''

title: Injury, Insult and Defeat For Struggling Rangers
description: The Rangers may still make the playoffs. But there was no clearer demonstration of why they do not deserve to qualify for the postseason than their performance in a 5-2 loss last night at Madison Square Garden to the worst team in the N.H.L.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, STEPHEN G.
description: KATZ-Stephen G. On March 21, 2002. We, the Katz family, are very saddened by the tragic loss of our father. Dear friend of Arlene; loving and cherished father of Lauren and Brandy; adoring grandfather of Olivia; kind fatherin-law of John. We will forever miss him and hold him close to our hearts. Funeral services will be held 11:30 AM on Sunday, March 24, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Government and Oregon Vie Over Doctor-Aided Suicide
description: In a courtroom where at least two terminally ill patients watched, both of them strong supporters of Oregon's assisted-suicide law, lawyers for the federal government told a federal judge today that Oregon doctors could and should be barred from helping such people hasten their deaths with lethal medicines.

title: Sports of The Times; Calhoun In a Game He Can't Win
description: GETTING a monkey off your back is one thing, shaking free of ghosts is something else. In fact, it can be impossible.

title: A Falstaff You Want To Have a Beer With
description: When you think about it, Verdi's ''Falstaff,'' his last opera and only comedy (not counting an early failure) is not that funny. Shakespeare's merry wives of Windsor, as reconceived by Verdi and his insightful librettist, Arrigo Boito, play some downright mean tricks on tubby old Sir John, whose bloated ego is so easy to prick. Yes, he's a mooch and a loudmouth. But he has done nothing worse than send the same preposterous love letter to two married woman. Why not just laugh him off?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Fire Forces Partial Closing of Holland Tunnel
description: A fire in a vacant warehouse at the entrance to the Holland Tunnel prompted officials to close the tunnel's Manhattan-bound lanes today, snarling traffic for miles and adding as much as an hour to the usual Friday night delays at the other Hudson River crossings.

title: This Year, It's Kansas Sending Illinois Home
description: The Kansas Jayhawks sought and found revenge tonight.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Automaker Settles Dispute
description: The DaimlerChrysler Corporation agreed to pay the Department of Motor Vehicles $325,000 to settle eight-year-old charges that the company violated the state's lemon laws. The state accused the automaker of repurchasing and reselling 119 defective vehicles without informing buyers. DaimlerChrysler, which denied any wrongdoing, had faced a 45-day temporary suspension of its license to conduct business in California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSSON, OLIVIA A.
description: OLSSON-Olivia A. March 22, 2002. Beloved sister of Agnes and Carl Olsson, devoted sister-in-law of Catherine Olsson, cherished aunt of Karl, Kathleen, Eric, Kristine and Mark, and several greatnieces and nephews. She served in the United States Navy during WWII. Later she became the president of A.E. Johnson Employment Agency of New York City. An active member of the Salmagundi Club, American Scandinavian Foundation and the American Scandinavian Society. Her work as a sculptor has been shown in New York City. A very proud and dedicated member of Park Avenue Methodist Church for almost 50 years. The family will receive friends Saturday, March 23, 3-8 PM, with a service at 6:45 pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, NYC. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice. A memorial service will be held at a later date at the Park Avenue Methodist Church.

title: When Private Words Go Public
description: The latest 400 hours of Nixon tapes, released by the National Archives on Feb. 28, include nasty comments by Richard Nixon about Jews. People yawned; we had heard such stuff on previous White House recordings. But the tapes contained a much bigger surprise: raw anti-Semitism from the Rev. Billy Graham, widely known for preaching harmony between Christians and Jews.

title: Coming Next, Landmark Ruling in Campaign Money Fight
description: The intense fight in Congress over campaign financing will soon turn into an equally hard-fought constitutional battle in the federal courts that many legal scholars expect will produce a new generation's landmark ruling in the field of free speech.

title: PRODDED BY U.S., ISRAEL AGAIN TRIES TO FORGE A TRUCE
description: Urged on by the Bush administration, Israel's security chiefs reluctantly resumed negotiating toward a truce today with their Palestinian counterparts, a day after a suicide bombing in Jerusalem prompted Israel to cancel talks.

title: U.S. Will Impose 29% Tariff On Canada Building Lumber
description: The Bush administration said today that it would impose duties totaling 29 percent on softwood lumber -- the kind used to build houses -- that is imported from Canada, infuriating Canadian industry and government officials.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INSTRUMENTARIUM OYJ, Helsinki, Finland, a maker of medical equipment, said it would buy Spacelabs Medical, Redmond, Wash., a medical technology company, for $140 million as it expands into the American market.

title: The Soul of George W. Bush
description: About a year ago, The Economist published an article under the smirky headline ''George Bush, homme srieux.'' The British newsweekly argued that despite the new president's apparent intellectual weightlessness, the administration had in fact come to town with some serious thinkers in its entourage and some interesting ideas on its program. There might be more to the C-student president than we expected.

title: College Board to Revise SAT After Criticism by University
description: The College Board is planning to revamp the main SAT test taken by generations of college-bound students, acknowledging that it is doing so partly in response to criticism from the University of California and others that the test does not reflect enough of what is actually learned in the classroom.

title: 4 Immigrant Killings Linked to Russian Kidnapping Gang
description: After scouring a reservoir for their bodies, federal authorities have identified the remains of four well-to-do Russian immigrants they believe were the targets of a gang of Russian kidnappers and extortionists.

title: A Father-Daughter Homage To the Way Things Were
description: The songs of Henry Mancini that dominate ''Mancini at the Movies,'' the show his daughter Monica has brought to Feinstein's at the Regency, distill a particular kind of homegrown nostalgia rooted in 1950's and 60's dreams of small-town America.

title: INSIDE
description: Conditions on World Aid

title: There's Singing and Talking And, Sure, Some Moving
description: A good deal of thought and quiet passion seems to have gone into the making of Julia Ritter's ''Love After Death,'' presented last Saturday at the University Settlement. This new hourlong dance, inspired by roadside shrines to the dead, is an intelligent but surprisingly unemotional piece of work.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Verdict Reversed In Reporter's Death
description: A court overturned the conviction of a man in the 1996 murder of a journalist who reported on Dublin's crime gangs and drug dealers, finding that a police informant's testimony against him was unreliable. In 1998, a no-jury antiterrorist court sentenced Paul Ward to life imprisonment for helping to dispose of the gun and motorcycle that were used in the killing of Veronica Guerin, left, in 1996. One other man has been convicted of shooting her while her car was stopped at a traffic light. Mr. Ward remains in jail on other charges. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Rejection Of Redistricting Plan
description: The State Supreme Court threw out the state's redistricting plan and sent it back to the panel that drew it, saying it violated constitutional and statutory provisions. The 4-to-1 ruling struck down 19 House districts and ordered 3 others reviewed. The ruling also affects Senate districts, which are composed of two adjacent House districts. The panel has until June to complete a revised plan for legislative districts.

title: Trafficking in Humans
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 School Buses In 2 Accidents; 20 Are Injured
description: Two school buses were involved in collisions at intersections this morning in New Jersey, the first in East Windsor, a suburb of Trenton, and the second a few minutes later in Newark.

title: In the Circle Of the Tango
description: Donna Uchizono got the Dance Theater Workshop's DTW Around Town series off to an intriguing start on Thursday night at the Duke on 42nd Street. Full appreciation of Ms. Uchizono's new ''Low,'' a dance of glinting obsidian facets, may depend on the knowledge, available only to reviewers, that the dance is based on the counterclockwise circle of the tango. But the piece and its score by Guy Yarden are certainly a fascinating deconstruction of that popular dance form and music, in a series of small, hot eruptions and shifting liaisons that are coolly and subtly abstracted.

title: Russia Imposes Flat Tax on Income, and Its Coffers Swell
description: The American publishing billionaire Steve Forbes once trumpeted a flat-rate income tax so simple you could fill it out on a postcard. The Russian government recently took his advice about the flat tax to heart.

title: The demand drains market : Going, going, gone:art's disappearing act
description: LONDON:  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Wednesday, March 27, 2002 :

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RUTH
description: MILLER-Ruth Small on March 22, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Archie. Loving mother of the late Alice Bregman. Dear aunt of Jonathan Small and great aunt of Anne and Katherine Small. Services graveside, Monday, 10:15 am at Washington Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Clothes Maker Profits
description: Europe's largest clothing retailer, Hennes & Mauritz, said first-quarter profit more than doubled as it avoided slashing prices and added stores across Europe. Net income rose to 767.2 million kronor ($74.6 million) from 371 million kronor in the period a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended Feb. 28, gained 17 percent, to 11.25 billion kronor. The company said the weakness of the kronor helped its results.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article on March 14 reported on a proclamation by the mayor of Inglis, Fla., population 1,400, banning Satan from the town. The mayor, Carolyn Risher, had prayers encased in posts at the entrances to the town. The article said that while the proclamation was signed by the town clerk and stamped with the official seal, other town officials had said the mayor was speaking only for herself.

title: Danang Round Trip, Sad All the Way
description: ''This may sound so selfish, but I can't wait to get out of here,'' says Heidi Bub, back in Vietnam 22 years after she was taken to the United States America for adoption. Heidi is the protagonist of ''Daughter From Danang,'' a documentary having its premiere tonight as part of the New Films/New Directors series at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: In Men's Clothing, More and More of the Labels Say 'Made in Canada'
description: It's a familiar story line. A flood of imports drives long-established American manufacturers out of business, leaving factories idle and hundreds of workers out of a job.

title: No-Tax Pledge By McGreevey Faces Test
description: In the final weeks of last year's governor's race, and the heady days immediately following his landslide victory at the polls, James E. McGreevey made a sweeping promise to New Jersey residents that he would not raise taxes.

title: Value of Ecosystems
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Military Exercise Disrupted
description: A joint United States-South Korean military exercise in Pohang was briefly suspended when a small group of student protesters stood in the way of amphibious vehicles. About 10 students blocked the vehicles, which carried several hundred American marines, until they were removed by the police. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Making Big Plans to Build Stadiums, and Interest
description: Major League Soccer begins its seventh season tonight confident that soccer's history as a second-rate sport in the United States will end, eventually. Perception, meet reality.

title: German Immigration Bill Wins Disputed Vote
description: After two years of emotional debate that cut to the heart of questions about German identity, the upper house of Parliament passed a groundbreaking immigration law today that would open the gates to greater numbers of skilled foreign workers.

title: Palestinian Group Says It Will Increase Bombings
description: A day after the United States said it would add their group to its list of terrorist organizations, leaders of a Palestinian militant movement defiantly said today that the listing would prompt them to carry out more suicide bombings in Israel.

title: Oregon Dodges a Late Texas Scare
description: In a game that showcased several of the nation's top underclassmen, it was a senior who took charge tonight when the game was on the line.

title: Promotions at Federated
description: Federated Department Stores, owner of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, promoted its president, Terry J. Lundgren, to chief operating officer and extended the contract of its chief executive, James M. Zimmerman, by at least a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDEMAN, CLIFFORD G. JR.
description: LUDEMAN-Clifford G. Jr. Of Chester, CT. Beloved husband of Theresa Zwart-Ludeman. Father of Cloude Ludeman. Stepfather of Justin Zwart. Brother of Lyda Ludeman. Self-employed petroleum landman, Vietnam veteran, poet and artist. Memorial services Saturday, April 6, 10 AM, Saugatuck Congregational Church, Westport, CT.

title: Afghans Have a Palace, but Not a Role, Ready for the Former King
description: For weeks a large two-story white mansion beside a stretch of open parkland in the Afghan capital has been a hive of construction, and of rumor.

title: Lapse in La Guardia Security Grounds Passengers
description: Planes taxiing for takeoff were called back to the gates. Passengers already strapped in for their flights were forced back to the lobby of a major terminal. Babies, and adults, wailed and giggled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNKIS, KAY
description: KUNKIS-Kay. On March 21, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving mother of Roger and the late Michael. Devoted mother-in-law of Martha. Dear sister of Kermit and the late Ruth. ''Miss Kay'' of Schacters will be profoundly missed. Visiting Sunday 7-9 PM. Service Monday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam.

title: NEWS CORPORATION AGREES TO TRADE TELEVISION STATION
description: The News Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to give a television station that it owns in Portland, Ore., KPTV, to the Meredith Corporation in exchange for two Meredith television stations, WOFL in Orlando, Fla., and WOGX in Ocala, Fla. The Portland station is affiliated with the UPN network while the two stations in Florida are affiliates of the Fox network, which is owned by the News Corporation. A person close to the deal said that the News Corporation would also give Meredith about $8 million in cash. If approved by the Federal Communications Commission, the deal would give the News Corporation two stations, known as a ''duopoly,'' in the Orlando market. The company also has duopolies in seven other markets. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer's Profit Falls
description: The world's biggest reinsurance company, Munich Re, said its 2001 profit fell 85 percent, to 250 million euros ($220 million), about half of what analysts had expected. The company said damage claims of 2.2 billion euros from the Sept. 11 attacks offset a 16.1 percent increase in revenue from insurance premiums and one-time investment gains of 830 million euros. The insurer said it would leave the per-share dividend at last year's 1.25 euros. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Ping-Pong As Metaphor For an Affair
description: Midway through ''The Mars Canon,'' Kinuko, the 29-year-old heroine, plays Ping-Pong with her older, married lover, Kohei. As they glumly lob the ball across the table, neither of them making any effort to win a point, Kinuko remarks that the match is a lot like their relationship: tentative and passive. Rather than risking passion or commitment, they are, in Kinuko's words, ''just maintaining,'' meeting only on Tuesdays so as not to disrupt Kohei's domestic life.

title: M.L.S. at Seven: Contraction and Distraction (World Cup)
description: (Teams listed in alphabetical order)

title: A Dated Musical Whose Music Is Never Out of Date
description: Precious things lose their luster fast in ''Golden Boy,'' the 1964 musical inspired by Clifford Odets's hit drama of 1937. The working-class hero's golden aura tarnishes as he punches his way to fame in the boxing ring. As for those diamonds he sings about plucking from a glamorous, forbidden world, you can be sure they'll dissolve into dust once he finds them.

title: National Briefing | South: Miami: Drug Charges At Airport
description: Federal prosecutors in Miami have indicted eight present or former employees of companies at Miami International Airport on federal narcotics charges, including conspiracy to import and distribute cocaine and heroin. A separate indictment filed on Thursday charged two others with importation of narcotics offenses. The defendants are accused of using their secured access to remove cocaine and heroin from the interior panels of aircraft cargo areas. If convicted, they face 40 years to life in prison.

title: The Courthouse That Graft Built
description: Tweed Courthouse: only in New York would a municipal building be named after the city's greatest scoundrel. When I worked there back in the 1980's as a low-level city employee, answering Mayor Ed Koch's mail, I liked to call it the building they never stopped building, because it always seemed to be under construction. Since 1860, this weighty classical edifice of iron and gray marble has squatted behind the elegant City Hall like an unwanted stepchild. No one quite knew what to do with it until a couple of years ago, when the city decided to renovate it and move the Museum of the City of New York there.

title: Kent State Is Surprising Even Itself This Season
description: After Pittsburgh had become the latest team dazed and battered by the Kent State Golden Flashes on Thursday night, Kent State Coach Stan Heath strolled down a long hallway in Rupp Arena with guard Trevor Huffman matching his stride. Their arms soon were locked over each other's shoulders and their eyes engaged in a knowing glance.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the legal challenge to new campaign finance rules misspelled the given name of a former legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union who will help defend them. He is Burt Neuborne, not Bert.

title: In Hindsight, Regret For Some Decisions
description: Thomas V. Daily, the Roman Catholic bishop of Brooklyn, issued a mea culpa yesterday for his actions while serving in Boston when a pedophile priest was shuffled from parish to parish and acknowledged the pain caused by such sexual abuse.

title: Rabbi Israel Miller, 83; Aided Holocaust Survivors
description: Rabbi Israel Miller, a leading advocate for Holocaust survivors as president of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, died on Thursday at his home in Jerusalem. He was 83 and had moved to Israel from Manhattan about two years ago.

title: When Janie Came Marching Home
description: Lauren M. Cook had been participating in re-enactments of famous Civil War battles for two years, and she took the hobby seriously. She spent thousands of dollars buying Civil War-period clothing. She taught herself how to play the fife, then memorized hundreds of Civil War tunes to play at battles. She bound her breasts under her uniform so no one would guess she was a woman. She even tried to adopt male mannerisms to aid her disguise. ''I would always squint,'' she said. ''Women's eyes are larger than men's, so they really give you away.''

title: Defense Department Agency Severs Its Ties to an Elite Panel of Scientists
description: The Pentagon has abruptly severed its ties with a secretive advisory panel of elite scientists, leading to accusations that the country is blunting its ability to deal with increasingly sophisticated terrorists and other foes after Sept. 11.

title: In Court Files, How Bishop Handled a Problem Priest
description: It was an emotional and extraordinary meeting, a loyal Catholic family from a hardscrabble Boston neighborhood who had come in desperation to the door of the second-highest official in Boston's Roman Catholic archdiocese, Bishop Thomas Vose Daily.

title: Some Tests Are Useful
description: To the Editor:

title: Debate? Dissent? Discussion? Oh, Don't Go There!
description: That familiar interjection ''whatever'' says a lot about the state of mind of college students today. So do the catch phrases ''no problem,'' ''not even'' and ''don't go there.''

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Letting Voters Decide
description: Gov. Gary Locke signed a transportation bill to give Puget Sound voters the option to tax themselves to pay for regional improvements in highways and transit. The governor also vetoed a portion of the bill that tied it to a state transportation plan, which hinged on a statewide ballot measure. Officials in Pierce, Snohomish and King Counties, the state's most densely populated, can ask voters to raise taxes and licensing fees to collect up to $8.7 billion over the next decade for transportation improvements. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: U.S. Says It Found Qaeda Lab Being Built to Produce Anthrax
description: The United States has discovered a laboratory under construction near Kandahar, Afghanistan, where American officials believe Al Qaeda planned to develop biological agents, officials said today.

title: A 'Roi David' That Evokes Other Battles
description: Honegger's ''Roi David,'' which the Brooklyn Philharmonic presented on March 15 and 16 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, tells a story that has gained much more meaning since the work was new, in 1921. Then its themes were all long in the past, 3,000 years old. Now the warfare between Israel and its neighbors, the frail humanity of leaders and the political value of claiming God as your own are all very much of the present.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Admissions To Resume
description: The University of Wisconsin's Board of Regents lifted its suspension on enrollments, allowing the admission of freshmen for the fall semester. The regents voted two weeks ago to freeze freshman admissions because of steep spending cuts proposed by state lawmakers to ease a $1.1 billion state budget deficit. The regents said they had since received assurances about financing from Gov. Scott McCallum and lawmakers.

description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Enron Cases Await. Let the Swaggering Begin.
description: For theatrics of potentially profound significance to corporate America, no place will be as intriguing to watch over the next few months as the courtroom of Judge Melinda F. Harmon.

description: DOWNING-Elizabeth M. On March 20, 2002. Of Brooklyn. Born Muckera Kenmare, Co Kerry, Ireland. Former payroll supervisor for the Charles H. Greenthal Group, Inc. description: Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is retiring from public life immediately for health reasons, her office announced today.

description: For those who pay attention to such things, there is change afoot at the Indian Point nuclear plants. Correction: Make that the Indian Point Energy Center.

title: U.S. Embassy In Sarajevo Closes Doors After Threat
description: The American Embassy in the Bosnian capital of Sarajevo has closed ''until further notice,'' a spokeswoman said, citing an unspecified threat that officials there treated with increasing caution throughout the week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on March 15 with an article about the decision of a Scottish court to uphold the conviction of the suspect in the bombing of an American airliner in 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland, misstated the location of a memorial honoring the 270 people who died. It is in Lockerbie; Syracuse University, which lost 35 students in the crash, was the home of visitors shown at the site.

title: A Brief Respite Between Battles
description: American soldiers returned to their camp at the old Soviet air base near Kabul, Afghanistan, last week to do as soldiers do after a battle.

title: Slide Show: Eye-Catching Cars
The Importance Of Being Silly
description: DON'T mention the BBC. Not, in any event, to John Cleese, who was, it turns out, slightly miffed to learn by letter that the cable channel BBC America had scheduled a mini-retrospective called ''John Cleese Forever'' for next Saturday and Sunday. ''You'd think they'd have discussed it with me,'' he says, ''or even -- I don't want to sound too democratic -- asked me if I had any ideas.''

title: The Classic Lure of Southern Italian
description: YOU'VE tasted the food at Pencenzo before, especially if you're Italian, grew up in the New York area or have a mother who is a talented cook. The rest of us may also feel nostalgic about the hearty Southern Italian, red-sauce-dominated dishes at this New Hyde Park newcomer. There is nothing innovative or cutting edge on the menu, but all the golden oldies that appear have soul. They are the classics we grew up with done well.

title: Riots Shake Friendships And Faiths In India
description: On the day that a scooter-riding mob set fire to Akbar Divecha's apartment building in an affluent, largely Hindu neighborhood here, it was his friend, Sanjay Shah, who drove across town and ferried him to safety.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: BARRY BONDS may have hit 73 home runs last season, but a few years earlier he couldn't hit any off Henry Rowengartner, a 12-year-old who lives out a major league dream in ROOKIE OF THE YEAR (1993). Mr. Bonds is one of several real-life ballplayers to put in cameos in the film, stopping by just long enough to swing and miss against young Henry, appealingly played by Thomas Ian Nicholas. Some benign medical malpractice gets it all started: when Henry breaks his arm, whoever puts it back together doesn't quite do the job properly, and suddenly the boy can throw a 100-mile-per-hour fastball. The Chicago Cubs find out, sign him, and the rest is a pleasantly predictable baseball romp, perfect for this time of year - Thursday at 8 p.m. on the Family Channel.

title: No More Fortissimo? Europe Wants a Little Quiet
description: THE European Union is coming down hard on Beethoven, Berlioz, Strauss and all those other symphonic loudmouths. Politicians think it's high time. The trumpets in Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, the big bass drum in Verdi's Requiem, even Tchaikovsky's squalling little piccolo in ''The Nutcracker'' have poisoned our environment long enough. A little peace and quiet, please.

title: Enjoy the Nest Before It Fills Again
description: Regarding ''Catching a Second Wind,'' (Soapbox, March 17) by Kathleen O. Maria. The nest will not be empty for long. Why not take this time to enjoy life and stop missing the next natural cycle of life?

title: Jodi Segal, Aaron Sherber
description: Dr. Jodi Beth Segal and Aaron Andrew Sherber were married last evening by Rabbi Steven Schwartz at the Belvedere Hotel in Baltimore.

title: Cheers, Dears
description: How to give a toast without burning it?

title: A Legacy, and a Lot of Advice
description: ONE of the fears held by most people coming into money is that they will suddenly become very popular. Well, it's true.

title: Two For The Road
description: What could be more romantic than a car, a picnic, the open road, a man and a woman -- or some combination thereof? Suddenly this season, road trips are, well, all the rage (pun intended). Considering the state of the economy and concerns about travel abroad, there has never been a better time to see the U.S.A. in your Chevrolet, or any car of your choice. ''The whole object of travel,'' as G.K. Chesterton explained, ''is not to set foot on foreign land; it is at last to set foot on one's own country as a foreign land.''

title: Second Time Around
description: VERY little seizes the public imagination more than a clergyman embroiled in an adulterous affair. Except maybe murder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, JOHN T.
description: ELLIOTT-John T. On March 22, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Mary A. (nee Connaghan). Devoted father of John C., James G., Michael D., Brendan P., T.J. and Irene Elliott-Hupe. Dear brother of Mary Farmer, Betty Mescall and the late Br. James F.S.C., Thomas J. & Edward R. Loving grandfather of twelve and great grandfather of four. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing Monday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at Riverdaleon-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 11 AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church.

title: Looking for a Few Good Eggs
description: Eastertime is the season for eggs -- a time to hunt for them, dye them and eat them. The egg industry took in about $3.5 billion in revenue last year, and consumption in the United States has gone up steadily in the last few years, according to the American Egg Board. The rate is now 260 eggs per person a year, up from 234 in 1991, but still down from the high of 402 in 1945.

title: When Oscar Is Bad, He's Very, Very
description: MAKING sport of the Oscars is a sport in itself. After all, if we couldn't, in current academic parlance, ironize the whole affair -- the glitter, the gushing thanks, the issue-of-the-day pieties and ultimately the choices -- how could we salvage our self-respect as we attend to the proceedings with more passion than we want to admit?

title: Public Spirit, Private Money and a New New Deal
description: ''TRIBUTE in Light,'' the temporary memorial to the victims of the World Trade Center attack, appeals to the powerful desire to undo wrongs. As conceived back in September by John Bennett and Gustavo Bonevardi, two of the designers responsible for the project, the work was initially called ''Proposal for the Immediate Reconstruction of the Manhattan Skyline,'' as if by filling in the twin voids with brightness we could blot out the galling sensation of being overtaken by events outside our control.

title: Mr. Ray's Neighborhood
description: Man Ray, born Emmanuel Radnitsky and raised by Russian Jewish parents in Brooklyn, arrived in Paris in 1921 to see originals of paintings he admired as an art student. ''Unfortunately when I got over here I got tied up with the avant-garde movement, which despised museums, which wanted to destroy them,'' he recalled. Before long, he found a mentor and collaborator in Marcel Duchamp and established himself as a fashion and portrait photographer. In MAN RAY'S MONTPARNASSE (Abrams, $29.95), Herbert R. Lottman provides a glimpse of the bohemian Parisian neighborhood as seen through the photographer's lens: Picasso in his studio, Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas in their salon, Marcel Proust on his deathbed, Peggy Guggenheim in couture. The book is also a homage to a place where an influx of artists exchanged ideas on art and revolution at the Coupole and La Dme. ''Montparnasse was really the first international colony of artists . . . superior to Montmartre, Greenwich Village or Chelsea,'' Duchamp wrote in his memoirs. Lottman, whose books include ''The Left Bank: Writers, Artists, and Politics From the Popular Front to the Cold War,'' clearly knows and adores his subject. Even though his premise that Man Ray's portraits link the creative circles in Montparnasse is contrived, ''Man Ray's Montparnasse'' is an enchanting introduction to these artists' lives. Sarah Shatz

title: POSTINGS: 280 More Rooms for the Marriott; Hotel to Grow In Brooklyn
description: The New York Marriott Brooklyn hotel, which has been highly successful since it opened in 1998, will add 280 guest rooms, retail space and meeting rooms as a result of an agreement with the city's Economic Development Corporation.

title: Ex-Leader of Belarus Challenges a Punishment by Pension
description: Political enemies of Belarus's autocratic ruler, Aleksandr Lukashenko, have been hectored and arrested, and sometimes have even vanished. But his predecessor as president, Stanislav Shushkevich, is suffering in especially cruel and unusual fashion: the government refuses to index his monthly pension for inflation.

title: Dissecting Enron in School
description: There are plenty of lessons to be gleaned from the rise and fall of Enron, and business students will be reading about them for years. But students at Oregon State University are not waiting for a textbook. They are now enrolling in a class titled ''The Enron Implosion.'' The seven-week course, which begins on April 8, is so popular that the university has moved it to a 700-seat auditorium.

title: U.N. Reviews Plans to Protect Its Offices Around the World
description: Reinforced fences. Bulletproof partitions. Electronic monitors and alarms. Sensors to detect gas and chemical attacks. Stockpiles of biohazard gear. Blastproof trash cans.

title: A Show With Touches Of Humor and Anger
description: PROVOCATIVE content goes along with much of the art associated with the feminist movement. This is certainly true in the case of Mary Beth Edelson, a New York artist whose 30-year career survey is making its final stop here at the state university after an extensive national tour. Reaching in many directions and often probing cultural history, the two- and three-dimensional pieces in various media in this show blend touches of anger, aggression and the kind of humor intended to tweak.

title: Filing Tips for Avoiding Audits
description: Taxpayers in high income brackets should be especially careful this tax season to double-check their returns, because an error increases the chance of an audit, warns Doug Stives, a partner at the accounting firm Wiss & Company in Red Bank, N.J.

title: Piazza Hit by Another Pitch
description: For the third time this spring, Mike Piazza was hit by a pitch, and this one knocked him out of the game. Piazza grimaced when he was struck on the left hip by an 0-2 pitch by the Montreal Expos starter Britt Reames in the first inning today.

title: Primedia's Improbable Digital Dreams
description: PUSHING the elevator button to get to Primedia's offices on the 23rd floor at 745 Fifth Avenue, a block and a half south of Central Park, is like hitting a reset button to spring of 2000, back when digital enterprises were selling for unthinkable multiples. In these corridors, the old buzzwords linger, the traditional metrics do not apply, the PowerPoint diagrams always envelop the consumer, and the monetization of traffic -- remember traffic? -- lies just around the corner.

title: MAYOR'S SETTLEMENT
description: The state's inspector general, Edward Neafsey, has filed a complaint that an $850,000 settlement of a lawsuit by the Atlantic City mayor, Lorenzo Langford, and a political associate should be nullified or at least renegotiated. The settlement stems from a suit brought by Mr. Langford and William Marsh, who said they were fired from their jobs in 1999 at the city board of education as political retribution by former Mayor James Whelan. The Atlantic City Council negotiated a $1 million settlement last year, but Mr. Whelan refused to sign off on it. After Mr. Langford defeated Mr. Whelan in an election in November and took office in January the city agreed on the $850,000. But Mr. Neafsey's complaint says the city's business administrator, Benjamin Fitzgerald, and the City Council should not have had the authority to settle, especially since Mr. Fitzgerald recommended the settlement after Mr. Langford appointed him to the job. In addition, the complaint says, Charles Ercole, who served as the city's counsel for the lawsuit, raised money for Mr. Langford's election and has been awarded a city contract for $200,000 by the Langford administration.

title: Terribly Smart
description: It's not hard to understand why Elizabeth Chapman did what she did -- even her 8-year-old son, Justin, forgives her. From the time he was 2, Justin's mother touted his phenomenal maturity: chess at 3, high school at 5, college classes at 6, the same age he scored 298-plus on the Stanford-Binet Intelligence exam, the highest score on record. He spoke at conferences about a children's voting rights act. He met with Governor Pataki. Then, in November, Justin was hospitalized for an apparent overdose of Motrin and told medics, ''I don't want to be me anymore.'' Doctors placed him on 72-hour hold for suicidal ideation and separated him from his mother, placing him with a foster family. Earlier this month, as she prepared for her custody fight, the 29-year-old Chapman confessed to falsifying her son's spectacular scores and to enabling him to cheat on his I.Q. test. ''I didn't plan on it,'' his mother told the press. ''I let things get out of control.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTINGER, VIVIAN
description: PATTINGER-Vivian. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Vivian Pattinger, beloved sister of our devoted Chairman of the Board and benefactors Julius H. and Hermine Gewirtz. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President

title: Support Is Building For Instant Replay
description: In his old job, Rod Thorn watched reels of controversial videotape. He knew when the timekeeper suffered brain lock in the final seconds, forgetting to start the game clock. Or when a referee flat-out missed a call that cost a team a game.

title: Sports of The Times; Fosbury Bemoans Decline of College Track and Field
description: AT first glance, it was remarkable to see Dick Fosbury enter the Manhattan hotel restaurant Friday perpendicular to the ground, rather than horizontal. If you've never seen Dick Fosbury before, all you have to go on are the old photos of him soaring over the high-jump bar headfirst, like a falcon in flight except upside down, with that inspired, innovative technique that would be laughed about but widely imitated to this day and that would come to be known as the Fosbury Flop.

title: Tempest in a Seaport
description: A hefty rainstorm may be welcome in these days of drought, but 40 years ago this month, there was a storm that New Jersey residents could have done without. A huge northeaster hit March 6 through 9, drenching the coast. The storm kicked up five destructive high tides coinciding with a new moon, and the onrush of ocean swallowed dunes, wrecked homes and businesses, flooded streets and demolished boardwalks. Photographs of the storm and its vicissitudes can be seen in a gallery now being exhibited on the Web site of The Sentinel newspaper, at www.gallowaynews. com. The 150 photos were taken by W. Earle Hawkins, an engineer with Atlantic Electric and have been kept by Dr. Stewart Farrell, director of the Richard Stockton College of New Jersey Coastal Research Center in Port Republic. Karen DeMasters

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: End of an Era; The Legal, Political and Personal Legacies of Whitewater
description: EXACTLY 10 years ago this month, The New York Times reported that Bill and Hillary Clinton were business partners with the owner of a failing savings and loan association in an Arkansas real estate venture called Whitewater. Last week, with a 2,090-page, five-volume report, the $64 million independent counsel investigation into the collective matters known as Whitewater ended with a heavy thud.

description: FILIPPONE-Joseph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph Filippone, associated with The Times from 1951 until 1992.

description: The marble is expected any day now. It's imported. From Italy, no less. The new door will be oak and huge and inlaid with a looping, ornate wrought-iron design.

description: IN the opera house and the concert hall, in the United States and Europe (and Asia), on CD and DVD, in reviews and feature articles, the conductor Valery Gergiev is everywhere.

title: The View From/Bridgeport; Saving Thumb's House. Do Little Details Matter?
description: IN Bridgeport, anything associated with P. T. Barnum and one of his most famous acts, the 33-inch-tall Tom Thumb, is big. The city is home to the Barnum Museum, the Tom Thumb Florist and Tom Thumb Street.

description: Stephanie Ready, Asheville, N.C., Dec. 18, 2001

description: In the annals of style, a great wrong has been committed. And my purpose here is to set the record straight.

title: An Outsider Who Isn't Out Far Enough
description: ''NOW, Pete must direct his movie.'' This was the tag line intoned, over an annoyingly perky score, during the opening credits of each episode of ''Project Greenlight,'' the HBO documentary series that wrapped up last month. Pete is Pete Jones, the winner of an Internet screenwriting contest dreamed up by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck with the noble intention of giving a worthy outsider a chance to direct his own movie, which Miramax would distribute. With the release on Friday in New York, Los Angeles, Boston and Chicago (the director's hometown) of ''Stolen Summer,'' Pete's movie, this curious pop culture saga came full circle, and the audience that vicariously lived through Mr. Jones's million-dollar hazing must judge the fruit of his labors.

title: Clemens Still a Pitcher With a Purpose
description: At the World Series in Phoenix last fall, an old friend paid Roger Clemens a compliment. He was flattered by it. Bruce Hurst, his former teammate with the Boston Red Sox, was simply telling the truth.

title: Illustrating North Korea's Abuses
description: On March 14, 25 North Korean asylum-seekers stormed past a Chinese policeman into Spain's embassy threatening to kill themselves. Beijing quickly granted them passage to Seoul. A rare glimpse of what they were running from can be seen in these primitive drawings primarily by Jang Gil Su, a teenage refugee, and his family; they were also given safe haven in South Korea last summer after escaping from the north and taking refuge in U.N. offices in Beijing. The pictures were published in a book that created a furor in South Korea and became their ticket to safety.

title: Private Sector; Funny Lady, Serious Woman
description: IN January 1996, a phalanx of William Morris agents poured into a room in a Long Island mansion during a break in the filming of ''The Associate'' to explain to a new client, Whoopi Goldberg, the actress and comedian, how they could expand her career. Ms. Goldberg, between scenes portraying a Wall Street financial analyst stymied by sexual and racial discrimination, pointed to the lone female agent in the group, Cara Stein, and said, ''Let her go first.'' Then, she relentlessly peppered Ms. Stein with questions and ideas.

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on Page 24 of The Times Magazine today misspells the given name of the French foreign minister, who has disparaged the notion of an ''axis of evil.'' He is Hubert Vdrine, not Herbert.

title: Jayhawks And Ducks Fulfill Seedings
description: When all was said and done Friday night, the cream had risen to the top in the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional. On Sunday, the top-seeded Kansas Jayhawks, the Big 12 regular-season champions, will face the second-seeded Oregon Ducks, the Pac-10 regular-season champions, for the right to move on to the Final Four.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHMER, MILDRED
description: ROHMER-Mildred. Active member with her recently deceased husband Leo of 3 Arrows Cooperative Society. We extend our heartfelt condolence to daughter Judy Wine and son Daniel. Halona Balgley, President

title: Saving the Blue Zone For Its Intended Use
description: YOU could be on a dash-in, dash-out errand, or running late for an important meeting, or umbrellaless in the rain. But beware of those super-convenient parking spaces reserved for physically handicapped drivers. Law enforcement officials say they are spending more time writing tickets to those who have no valid permit but succumb to the allure of a blue-lined space.

title: A Game Beyond The Real Games Is Being Played In a Courtroom
description: Even in big-time college basketball there is an upstairs and a downstairs. There are dukes and there are butlers. There are places, however, where the classes can mingle. They are tournaments with fanciful names, the Great Alaska Shootout, the Maui Invitational, the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic in New York, that dangle the promise of a fun trip, some competitive games and even a worthy cause.

title: Central America Waiting To Reap Beneifts of Peace
description: The United States lavished money and concern on El Salvador during its 12-year civil war, and in the decade since the fighting ended, Jos Jacobo Jimnez has held fast to the idea that this nation's hard-fought democracy must still matter to Washington.

title: Will Florida Be Able to Pay?
description: To the Editor:

title: Word for Word / Sports Mascots; Choking, Groping and Emoting: You Think It's Easy Being a Jester?
description: MARCH is madness for college basketball fans, and it's also a pivotal month for sports mascots, those giant furry embodiments of anthropomorphism. Game after game, viewers of the N.C.A.A. tournament are treated to the sight of costumed scamps pumping up the crowd and mugging wildly for the cameras. But while gawking at the antics of the Kansas Jayhawk or the Duke Blue Devil (and with opening day for Major League Baseball next week), have you ever wondered what goes on under all that Technicolor fake fur?

title: Petal Pusher
description: ''Here are my babies,'' wails Jeff Leatham, the florist for the Four Seasons Hotel George V in Paris. He's standing in the heart of the world's largest flower market, on the outskirts of Amsterdam, surveying his latest order: four giant fern trees, five squat ferns and several trolleys of cut flowers. He peels off his black leather jacket and grabs a couple of bouquets of Kelly green viburnum and fuchsia roses -- ''to give it a little bit of life'' -- and leans them against the trees. ''Voila!'' he declares, then stands back and surveys the setup. ''Wait till we get that bamboo,'' he says, grinning proudly. ''Ooh la la!''

title: History That's Signed or Delivered
description: MALCOLM FORBES began his extraordinary collection of American autographs and manuscripts at 15, snipping signatures from the correspondence of his father, Bertie Charles Forbes, the founder of Forbes magazine, where Malcolm worked summers in the mailroom.

title: Small Star Rising
description: IN politics, cocktails and canaps can mark deep changes in a relationship. Ask members of New York's 59 community boards, and many will say that their Age of Lowered Expectations began in 1995, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declined to invite them to Gracie Mansion for a customary mayoral get-together.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column on March 10 about mayors who were aviators misstated the type and location of a memorial to John Purroy Mitchel, who served from 1914 to 1917 and later joined the Army Air Corps. It is a bust, not a plaque, and is at the entrance to Central Park at East 90th Street, not East 95th Street.

title: Springtime Blossoms for Impressionists
description: Impressionism may be Americans' favorite style of art, if the number of museums in the Northeast with Impressionist exhibitions this spring is any indication. Here are four major shows:

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: March 17-23: NATIONAL; ENDANGERED HABITATS
description: The Bush administration, under pressure from lawsuits by developers, is urging federal judges to rescind millions of acres of protected habitat for nearly two dozen populations of endangered species around the country. The administration is also questioning whether to preserve ''critical habitat'' designations that safeguard millions of acres for about 10 other endangered species. Administration officials say they are abiding by a federal appeals court decision last May that invalidated protected areas in New Mexico because the government did not fully consider how businesses and landowners would be affected, as the law required. Bush officials also say the animals are adequately protected by the Endangered Species Act. Greg Winter

title: That's Entertaining!
description: The other night, I was cooking dinner for an old friend. Once the chicken was safely in the oven, I began to set the table -- a task I usually approach with a mixture of pride and mild chagrin. My approach to what we in the design world call ''tabletop'' is a tad random. There's the plain: no-nonsense, off-white plates from a Crate & Barrel outlet; elegantly thin but remarkably inexpensive glasses from the Martha by Mail catalog; flea-market linen napkins. Then there's the fancy: Tiffany's Audubon flatware, which I've collected since I was in high school, and a blue-and-white Staffordshire platter. Add a couple of classic midcentury ceramic serving bowls, and that's my table. No one would mistake it for a state dinner at the White House, but it's my idea of fine dining.

title: Slow Recovery for Black-Car Drivers
description: TO understand the long-lasting economic aftershocks of Sept. 11, you can pore through reams of data and stacks of reports. Or, you can talk to Tony Limo.

title: A Bunny Who Hops to a Different Drummer
description: I DIDN'T have a chance to talk to Greg the Bunny in person. Scheduling and travel conflicts, I think. But I did spend some time with him by telephone from his new Los Angeles quarters, where he seemed elated about his move into the big time. His namesake series has its premiere on Fox on Wednesday night.

title: March 17-23: INTERNATIONAL; CHURCH SCANDAL
description: The case of John J. Geoghan, a former Boston priest convicted last month of fondling one child and accused of molesting more than 130, has opened a floodgate of accusations of priestly sex abuse and church cover-ups and prompted believers to debate the all-male priesthood, the vow of celibacy and the ordination of gay men. Pope John Paul II has broken his silence on the topic with a one-paragraph apology to victims of sex abuse by the clergy in a recent document, and in three sentences in his annual pre-Easter message, in which he referred to a ''grave scandal'' caused by priests who succumbed to ''the mystery of evil'' that has thrown a ''dark shadow of suspicion'' on good priests.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRAYER, DORIS
description: DRAYER-Doris. On March 26, we celebrate 52 years of marriage. You are always, always in our thoughts and love, Sonny, Michelle, Joe, Emily, Billy, Caroline.

title: Forever Young
description: I am a psychiatrist who has seen many cases of multiple personality/dissociative-identity disorder (Emily White, March 10). The sad story of Treva Throneberry is almost a textbook case of this very severe mental illness. Her imprisonment appears to be a miscarriage of justice. This woman needs an attorney to reopen the case and a good psychiatric evaluation to confirm the diagnosis. She should be sent to a residential program to serve out her term, if need be, while starting what will inevitably be long-term psychiatric treatment.

Inspired by the palette of unfashionable institutions like the Snappy Turtle in Kennebunkport, Me. (whose Web site, www.Snappy-turtle.com, boasts a category called Pink and Green Forever), these covetable wares take the old school colors from country club to city streets, with fresh shadings, witty materials and chic graphics. They thus set the stage for looks that are one part preppy and one part party princess -- with a healthy measure of irony thrown in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALOSH, ANNE M., MD
description: KALOSH-Anne M., MD on March 16, 2002. Born in Milwaukee, WI; graduated Marquette University Nursing 1941. Served as a U.S. Army nurse from 1942 thru 1946 in the European Theatre; first wave of nurses landing at Normandy, Battle of the Bulge, etc. Awarded numerous decorations and citations. After War, attended Medical College of Wisconsin, graduating in 1955. Completed her residency in OB-GYN at St. Vincent's Hospital, NYC, and was an attending physician there for almost 40 years. Also enjoyed working at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in NYC. Beloved sister of the late Dr. Frances Kalosh DiTolla, Peter, and Michael Kalosh. Loving aunt of Dr. and Mrs. William DiTolla, Dr. and Mrs. James DiTolla, Mr. John and Robyn DiTolla, Dr. Mary DiTolla and her husband William Zeh, Brenda, Michael, Mary Anne, Anne Frances, and Mark Kalosh.

She was greatly loved and loving, leaving an unfillable void. Funeral service will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY, at 11:30 AM, Monday, March 25. Interment private.

title: The Lessons of Whitewater
description: The Clinton era ended for real last week, with neither a bang nor a whimper, but only a 2,090-page report. Robert Ray, the last of three independent counsels on the Whitewater investigation, released his findings, closing an inquiry that came to dominate much of Bill Clinton's eight years in office. Mr. Clinton's defenders will argue that the entire investigation was a waste of more than $64 million in taxpayers' money. But we hope that Whitewater will be a permanent reminder to people who seek elective office that the best defense against any inquiry is to volunteer the truth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVE, DAVID A.
description: LOVE-David A. On February 11, 2002, in New York City, at the age of 61. Associate Vice President for Research and Development, Oberlin College, since 1994. A native of Norwich, England, and a graduate of the University of Bristol, Mr. Love was Instructor in Philosophy at Duke University (196970) and Oberlin College (1970-). At Oberlin, Mr. Love also served as Assistant Provost (1978-84), Associate Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences (1980-86), Associate Provost (1984-94), and Director of Sponsored Programs (1984-). He is deeply mourned by his wife Yolanda Cruz, daughters Imogen Love and Maria Rosasco, stepdaughter Elsa Cruz Pearson, mother Nena Roberts Love and brother John Love. A fund in Mr. Love's memory has been set up to continue his commitment to ensuring that every Oberlin College student partake fully of the transformative value of a liberal arts education. Donations may be made to the Community Foundation of Greater Lorain County, 1865 North Ridge Road, Lorain, OH 44055. A memorial service will be held at 11am on 6 April in Warner Concert Hall, Oberlin College.

description: After Friday's semifinal victory over Central Catholic High School of Troy, Murry Bergtraum guard Shameena Felix made only one statement regarding her team's matchup with Christ the King in the New York State Federation Class A girls' basketball title game.

title: Loved the Play, Hated the Posters
description: ''The Vagina Monologues,'' the play by Eve Ensler, has left a wake of controversy after a benefit performance at the Irvington Town Hall Theater on March 8. Problems began when posters advertising the play were hung along Irvington's Main Street, with neon-pink cutouts concealing all but the V in the word ''vagina.''

title: The Nation; The Future of Superfund: More Taxing, Less Simple
description: IT seems an idea completely free of nuance: ''the polluter pays.'' Its logic seems unassailable, its down-home clean-up-after-yourself sentiment familiar and right. Which is probably why it became the battle cry for legislation that in 1980, after a decade of nightmarish environmental episodes from leaky landfills to Love Canal, created the ways and means to start cleaning up: the Superfund.

title: A Jazz Diva Who's Losing Interest in Jazz
description: THE golden age of jazz singing ended many years ago, but its passing has been felt with particular force since the early 1990's. Sarah Vaughan died in 1990, Ella Fitzgerald in 1996 and Betty Carter two years later. Abbey Lincoln (born 1930) and Shirley Horn (1934) are still singing, and singing beautifully, but they're practitioners of an art that has moved, like jazz itself, from the center of the culture to a glorified periphery. The best young singers (Lauryn Hill, Erykah Badu, Jill Scott) have gone into hip-hop and neo-soul, depriving jazz of talent it would have snapped up a half century ago.

title: Private Sector; Reinventing the Wheel
description: Robert L. Crandall, the former chairman of American Airlines, helped to pioneer the hub-and-spoke system that many travelers hate because of all the connecting flights. Mr. Crandall now says the system's days could be numbered.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 10 about a cuckoo clock, with an article on Switzerland's neutrality before and after its vote to enter the United Nations, misattributed an ironic reference to the tradition's value. The comment -- that in Italy the Borgias presided over bloodshed and the Renaissance, but in Switzerland ''they had 500 years of democracy and peace, and what did they produce?'' -- was indeed from Graham Greene's screenplay for ''The Third Man,'' but Greene said the speech was written by Orson Welles.

title: Teacher's Choice: More Kids in a Class
description: A POSTER in the classroom reads ''Childhood should be a journey, not a race.'' Still, the prospect of nearly 40 third graders stampeding back from an art class on small but energetic feet could make a visitor hug the wall of the sun-filled classroom here at the Brookside Elementary School.

title: Ardsley Road in Greenburgh Closed for an Upgrade
description: Commuting and making deliveries in Greenburgh may take longer over the next few weeks. Ardsley Road, a major east-west artery, will be closed between Sprain Valley Road and Sprain Road from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Mondays through Fridays.

title: The Tweed Courthouse: You Be the Judge
description: It cost $13 million to build, and that was in 1878 when a dollar was a decent day's pay. So the Tweed Courthouse, which has just enjoyed an $89 million face lift, obviously has potential. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani promised it to the Museum of the City of New York. But last week Mayor Bloomberg rejected that idea in favor of using the space for the Board of Education and a school. Do New Yorkers have a better idea? Send suggestions to thecity@nytimes.com. Please include a daytime telephone number.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUPERT, RUDOLPH
description: RUPERT-Rudolph. In loving memory of my son, Rudolph Emanuel Rupert: You always said I cannot spend one day without mentioning your name. Since March 23, 2001, the day you parted from us, every part of my heart still cries out for you and your name rings in my soul. To all of you who loved him, think of him today, because he loved you too!

title: Latest Way to Cut Grade School Stress: Yoga

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE GARDENS OF KYOTO, by Kate Walbert. (Scribner, $13.) The middle-aged narrator of this elusive first novel recalls her coming of age in the 1950's, moving back and forth between America, Japan and Paris as she reconstructs her past in a way that is emotionally honest even as she withholds certain darker facts and violent episodes. Last year in the Book Review, Alida Becker admired the tale's ''understated power,'' which ''is expressed not only in quietly wrenching scenes . . . but in its narrator's wistful asides.''

title: Galluccio Vineyards Plans Downsizing

title: Ideas & Trends; Diagnosis: Supersize
description: AT this late date, few Americans need to be warned that ours is a nation of expanding waistlines. But two studies released last week point to a particularly insidious dimension of what experts call the ''epidemic'' of obesity: the health risks faced by overweight children. Today, more than 20 percent of all preschool children are overweight -- more than double the number in 1970 -- and 1 in 10 are considered clinically obese.

title: For Europeans, Love, Yes; Marriage, Maybe
description: Bjorn Lindahl and Nina Kjolaas do not feel inclined to declare their love in front of some anonymous official in a municipal building, or in a church. So they have never married -- not when they moved in together, not when they bought their first house, not when they had their son, now 16.

title: McLaughlin? Is That a Jewish Name?
description: It is a mild december evening in Georgia, and in the community room of their synagogue in the town of Marietta, Felton and Deborah McLaughlin talk with typical parental pride about their elder daughter's bat mitzvah, which took place earlier in the year. Felton, wearing a purple skullcap, smiles at the memory. ''It was literally the most wonderful experience of my life,'' says Deborah, who works as a librarian at a private school in Atlanta. ''It was very spiritual. Everyone loved it -- everyone in both of our families was so proud of her.''

title: Other People's Religions
description: Americans don't like religious intolerance, and who can blame them? When backed by state power, it can lead to murder and mayhem, which is why our founding fathers insisted on the separation of church and state. People who disparage other faiths no longer come off as commendably pious, as they did centuries ago; now they just seem boorish. So naturally, when Los Angeles school officials discovered anti-Semitic commentary in an edition of the Koran donated to school libraries last fall by a local Islamic foundation, they pulled the books off the shelf. Then, to emphasize that they weren't discriminating against Islam or protecting the feelings of Jews only, they announced the formation of a committee to review the commentaries accompanying all religious texts in their collection. The idea is to get rid of ''any matter reflecting adversely on persons because of their race, color, creed, national origin, ancestry, sex or occupation.''

title: An Escape Artist Trained During the Soviet Circus
description: IN the Soviet Union of the late 1970's, Boris Eifman was an exception -- a young, ambitious choreographer who had his own dance company, then known as the Leningrad Ballet Ensemble. That alone made him practically unique in a world of state-controlled institutions. But what made him even more exceptional was his popular success, which stood out like a beacon at a time when most Soviet artistic culture was mired in stagnation.

title: The Colombia I Left Behind
description: From the air, the lush forest of northern Colombia looks endless and serene. It is broken only by a wide strip of prairie, slashed from the jungle by my grandfather more than 50 years ago, stretching out to a blue backbone of hills. The only other signs of civilization are a reservoir, a few head of grazing cattle and some glinting rooftops made of zinc. For the most part, the forest stretches like a great, green shroud, concealing a civil war that has raged beneath the canopy for years and years.
