title: SEPTIC-SYTEM REGULATIONS
description: A state appellate court last week struck down a regulation on septic systems that was designed to combat suburban sprawl. The Department of Environmental Protection rule required builders to go through a strict permission process for any housing development with more than six units that would need a septic system. The court said that the public was not given an opportunity to comment on the regulation, which differed from the state's original proposal. The state Builders Association, which brought the suit, said the rule has stifled home construction.

title: Fur as Light as a Breeze
description: Knitting with fur was pioneered in the 1960's by artisans making one-of-a-kind designs and by avant-garde fur designers like Jacques Kaplan and Emeric Partos at Bergdorf Goodman. Technical drawbacks in cutting the pelts made the garments stiff and warm. This month, designers in Milan and Paris showed chiffon-light coats and jackets of knitted fur so supple that they conform to the body like a fitted sweater. The technique involves the laser cutting of pelts into quarter-inch strips and sanding down the skin. Far left, a Russian sable coat from Fendi's Italian workroom, where the grade of knitting is far superior to that in commercially produced garments from Turkey, China and Korea. Below, two dyed fox jackets from Sonia Rykiel and below them a close-up of the looser, more open knitting used in less expensive coats. Bottom right, a Dior couture coat of knitted mink in the pattern of a kilim rug: back seen in New York and front in Paris. Now, with these new lightweight knits, fur knows no season.

Similar offerings are in development from Ford, Mercedes, Audi and Nissan. The new wagons will be aimed at drivers looking for S.U.V.-like roominess but somewhat better mileage and handling. They will also have an advantage for automakers. Features like all-wheel drive and eight inches of ground clearance will allow them to be classified as light trucks rather than passenger cars, meaning looser federal mileage standards apply. Danny Hakim

title: To Be Young and Homeless
description: Like most people who find themselves seeking shelter at the Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx, the sole portal into New York City's shelter system for homeless families, Jackie Fuller and two of her children were at the tail end of a run of extremely bad luck. Fuller, 44, had been living most recently in Brooklyn, but like many people who eventually wind up homeless, she had not resided at her last address very long or securely. She and her husband were New Yorkers who moved to Memphis in 1994, where just two years ago they had good jobs and were rearing the youngest three of Fuller's five children from her first marriage in a rented house. But Fuller missed her two adult daughters and granddaughter, so the family decided to return north. Fuller's husband came back ahead of time to set things up, but by the time Fuller arrived, he had lost a lucrative bridge-painting job and had had an affair with another woman. The marriage collapsed.

As President of the Conference of Jewish Material Claims Against Germany for the past 20 years, he has exhibited extraordinary responsiveness to the physical and material needs of survivors worldwide. We extend our deep and heartfelt sympathies to his wife Ruth and his entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Eli Zborowski, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CHARLES H.
description: MURPHY -Charles H., 82. Died at his home in El Dorado, Arkansas March 20, 2002. His wife, Johnie Walker Murphy, preceded him in death; surviving him are: four children; Michael Walker Murphy, Martha Wilson Murphy, Charles Haywood Murphy, III, and Robert Madison Murphy; three sisters, Theodosia Murphy Nolan, Caroline Murphy Winter, and Bertie Murphy Smith; and eight grandchildren. He was born in El Dorado March 6, 1920, the son of Charles Haywood Murphy, Sr. and Bertie Wilson Murphy. Charles Murphy is best remembered as an oilman. His father had him manumitted by court order at the age of sixteen so he could legally transact business for himself, and he entered the petroleum industry on his own as an independent while still in his teens. At the age of twenty-one he assumed full managerial responsibility for his family's business, consisting primarily of oil production, farming and timber lands scattered across Arkansas, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama. For the next fifty-three years (except for three years' service in the U.S. Army infantry during World War II) he devoted his considerable energy to building this business into an international oil company that has been active on every continent except Antarctica. It is now a public company, of which the family still owns some 25%, and it still bears the family name, Murphy Oil Corporation. It is ranked by Fortune and Forbes magazines on some of their various measures as from the 312th to the 370th largest industrial concerns in the United States. Charles Murphy served this organization, under various titles, as its Chief Executive Officer until 1986 and continued as Chairman of the Board until 1994. While building Murphy Oil, Charles Murphy did not forsake his heritage as a banker. He succeeded his father as a major shareholder and dominant force in the First National Bank of El Dorado, which later became part of a group of banks owned by First United Bancshares, which Charles Murphy served as Chairman of the Board. This group of banks has now been succeeded by BancorpSouth Banc. Additionally, Murphy was a major investor in First Commercial Corporation, a significant regional bank holding company, where he served as Chairman of the Executive Committee. First Commercial has now become part of Regions Bank. Less public attention has been focused on Charles Murphy's career as an educator and philanthropist. This is the way he wanted it. He served seventeen years on the Arkansas Board of Higher Education, where he was instrumental in beginning the drive to improve the quality of public education in Arkansas. At the same time, he was dedicated to the improvement of private education as well, and gave generously of his time and money in this cause. He served ten years as a trustee of Hendrix College, where he and his family established the Hendrix Murphy Foundation, providing financial support to the institution. He also served on the Board of Administrators of Tulane University, where he and his family established the Tulane Murphy Foundation and the Murphy Institute of Political Economy. The Murphy Foundation, established by Charles Murphy, his wife, and his mother, provides financial support to both public and private institutions of learning, as well as scholarships to enable students to pursue higher education. For his service in the field of education, Murphy was recognized with an honorary Doctor of Laws degree by the University of Arkansas in 1966. (continued next column)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESCON, HOWARD
description: MESCON-Howard. Of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Scarsdale, on March 22. Adored husband for 56 years of the late Florence Mescon, beloved father of Richard and Michael, proud ''Honey'' to grandchildren Andrew, Jennie, David, Daniel and Hannah, cherished father-in-law of Miriam and caring surrogate father of Jane Ryffel, loving brother-in-law of Shirley Leitstein and uncle of Robert, Bruce and Alex Leitstein, dearest cousin of Evelyn Steinberg and Michael and Enid Mescon. We hold Grace Rosen in our hearts for her love and support to all of our family. Howard Mescon graduated from the City College of New York and the Harvard Business School, which he attended on full scholarship, served as President of the Coblentz Bag Company of New York City and was a founder of Adler Associates, a south Florida real estate developer of many projects including the Galahad apartments and the Miami International Commerce Center. He was active in both public and private philanthropic causes throughout his life-a life filled with hard work and the light of intelligence, devoted to caring for others with modesty, wisdom and kindness. Services at The Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY, Monday, March 25, at 12 o'clock.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Audrey Hepburn had serious doubts about doing ''Two for the Road.'' Her career was built on guileless characters and sweet romances, so a very adult, somewhat cynical take on marriage seemed risky. The director, Stanley Donen, eventually talked her into taking the role and then promptly talked her out of being dressed by Givenchy, the French couturier she had always entrusted with concealing what she considered her figure flaws. Donen accompanied her on a shopping spree in London and Paris, where they bought most of her character's wardrobe off the peg from Mary Quant, Paco Rabanne and Michele Rosier, among other swinging 1960's emporiums. Although Hepburn allowed jeans and miniskirts on screen, she did hold to certain rules. Primary colors and busy patterns were to be avoided. Outfits were padded to fill out her upper body and altered to minimize her hips. Stockings and boots had to emphasize her slender calves. ''I want to stay in fashion, but being young in spirit counts more toward looking young than dressing in a hippie style,'' Hepburn told an interviewer.

But then there were the foreigners who never really connected to the culture or the language. They might have been present in the Middle Kingdom, but they didn't even try to get the Chinese reality.

title: Valaria Murray: A Working Mother
description: Valaria Murray, a legal secretary, was a mother, a professional and a woman who knew how to enjoy herself. She gave hours and hours to the PTA at the school her five children attended in Flushing, Queens. She clicked off to work in Manhattan each morning, resplendent in high heels. She kept a book of crossword puzzles in her purse for those empty moments on the subway, where she sat busily filling in the answers with a pen. She was always up for a game of bingo, and loved Clint Eastwood movies like "In the Line of Fire."

Then a kind of clinical distance takes over. What happened? Why? Could it have been avoided or was it inevitable? And, finally, there is that sense of futility, even anger at all the missed chances and misused talents.

About four miles northwest of Pike Place Market, for decades Ballard remained a low-rise, hard-working area where folks drove slowly and fattened their savings accounts. A district whose distinguishing cue from the bridge was a winking neon sign for Bardahl automotive oil and whose biggest annual celebration was dedicated to the Norwegian constitution was not exactly a this-minute place.

description: Governor James E. McGreevey signed a tax amnesty bill last week. Under the law, penalties will be waived for late payments on taxes that were due Jan. 1, 1996, through Jan. 1, 2001, if they are made by June 10. Those who do not take advantage of the amnesty will be assessed a 5 percent fine in addition to the 18 percent penalties they already owed. The program is expected to bring in $150 million in extra tax revenue. Jo Piazza

title: A Virtuoso Who Favors the Fringe
description: THE French-Canadian pianist Marc-Andr Hamelin is not easily frightened. At 40, he has made a career of playing the seemingly unplayable. So his account of first laying eyes on the tude No. 1 by Nikolai Roslavets sticks in the ear: ''It was one of the few times that I have ever looked at printed music and been genuinely scared.''

And the specialties you may never have tried, like bacalatos, mofongos and alcapurias, are unforgettable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, R. MOWRY
description: MANN-R. Mowry, of Hamburg Road, Lyme, CT, died Thursday, at Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, CT, at age 57. Mowry was born and grew up in Montclair, NJ. He was a graduate of the University of Wisconsin at Madison, and a member of Kappa Sigma fraternity. He worked in advertising with Marstellar Inc., where he created the award-winning crying Indian campaign for Keep America Beautiful. He later started his own advertising firm, Hoffman-Mann and shared his creativity with many clients. Mowry married Gretchen Pratt in Armonk, NY, in 1983. They lived in Essex, CT, before settling at Jollywood Farm in Lyme. Mowry founded Greenwich Publishing Group, Inc., in 1988. He was an active member of The Leash in New York City and a trustee and former President of the Connecticut River Museum in Essex, CT. In addition to his wife of nineteen years, Mowry is survived by a daughter Molly Bellemore Mann; a son and daughter-in-law, William Mowry Mann and Jennifer Mann; two sisters, Cynthia Treene of Montclair, NJ, and Marcia Butler of Palos Verdes, CA, and two young granddaughters Campbell and Hollis Mann. Mowry has been and remains a tremendous presence in the lives of many. A memorial service will be held on April 6, at the Connecticut River Museum in Essex, CT. For information contact Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home, Old Lyme CT

title: The Country Music Country Radio Ignores
description: WHEN a dark horse, the roots-music soundtrack to the film ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?,'' won the top honor at the Grammy Awards last month, there was a clamor in the press room. Country music might never be the same again, the critics and journalists said. After all, besides albums by Glen Campbell and Bonnie Raitt, no recording that had anything to do with country had ever won the top Grammy -- Album of the Year. And the competition, especially U2 and Bob Dylan, had been fierce. So as the performers who appear on the soundtrack -- a rag-tag winner's circle if ever there was one -- streamed backstage into the press area, they were all asked the same question: Will country radio start playing traditional country music now?

''I'm starving,'' she bellows, in a way that suggests she might take a knife and fork to you if you strayed too close to a bottle of A1. title: The Nation; Braking for Dummies
description: SURVEILLANCE programs reduce crime, the experts say, and there are plenty of statistics to back them up. But there is a new trend in surveillance, and it seems to be working, too: fake surveillance.

title: PULSE: Pink and Green Are an Item Again; A Striped Splashback
description: Spring 2002 is a feast of pink and green, as clothes, accessories, beauty products and furnishings bloom in the season's favorite color combination. Inspired by the palette of unfashionable institutions like the Snappy Turtle in Kennebunkport, Me. (whose Web site, www.Snappy-turtle.com, boasts a category called Pink and Green Forever), these covetable wares take the old school colors from country club to city streets, with fresh shadings, witty materials and chic graphics. They thus set the stage for looks that are one part preppy and one part party princess -- with a healthy measure of irony thrown in.

title: On the Loose in a Work-Free Environment
description: VINCENT, the central character in Laurent Cantet's atmospheric new film ''Time Out'' (''L'Emploi du Temps''), is a businessman who at first glance seems average in every way. Tall and balding, with a jovial demeanor, Vincent (Aurlien Recoing) spends his days speeding along the French highways, checking in by cell phone with his devoted wife, Muriel (Karin Viard), to recount his demanding schedule of meetings and appointments.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 24, 2002
description: Weeks

title: To Some Homeowners, a Septic Tank Trumps a Sewer
description: New York may be a thoroughly modern city, but it still has neighborhoods with no sewers. Private homes in places like Douglas Manor, Queens, and Rossville, Staten Island, still send waste water into underground septic systems. But contrary to what you might assume, as city sewers are extended to those areas, some homeowners say they would rather not hook up to them.

title: Executive Life; To Foster Your Star Quality, Get an Agent
description: MOVIE stars, rock performers and sports celebrities have agents to keep their careers on track and to negotiate deals. Now, a handful of corporate senior executives are hiring agents, too.

title: Business; The New Accountability: Tracking the Social Costs
description: THE Enron-Andersen debacle has cast an unforgiving light on corporate bookkeeping, but the growing demand for accountability could extend far beyond financial statements. Pressure from investors, customers, consumer activists and even some governments is pushing more companies, particularly multinational ones, to report their nonfinancial performance, detailing the impact of their businesses on the environment and human rights.

title: Once Again, the State Is Going to the Birds
description: Is New Jersey in danger of being overrun by cute but annoying wildlife? Some members of the State Legislature think so.

title: Lacking Turpitude, Passaic's Mayor Stays
description: State officials who tried to unseat Mayor Sammy Rivera of Passaic have lost their case in court.

title: In Montrose, Houston First Went Boom
description: WHEN I told a friend I was going away for a break at a quiet inn, she assumed I was heading for the country. In fact, my destination was Houston, perhaps better known for refineries, NASA, urban sprawl and, lately, the bankruptcy of Enron than for a relaxing getaway.

title: Smugglers' Route
description: Throughout the winter, Kurds make the treacherous journey over the mountains that separate Iranian and Iraqi Kurdistan, smuggling goods. Some merchandise is banned (like imported foreign tea); some is cheaper on the black market (like TV's and cosmetics that come via Turkey and circumvent legal border posts). Each smuggler is paid 1,000 tomans (about $1.25) to make the round-trip run, while the mules they lead bring in double that amount because the animals can carry that much more.

title: Retired Police Commander Sues, Charging Harassment
description: A retired New York City police commander who once critiqued the department's handling of discrimination complaints is now suing the department, charging that she was passed over for promotions because of her pregnancies.

title: Tokyo's Still No Bargain, But It's a Lot Cheaper
description: SUMMER kimonos are going for $22 at Oriental Bazaar, a souvenir store on one of this city's most elegant shopping streets. Near the central fish market, Tsukiji Tamazushi restaurant offers all-you-can-eat sushi for $26 for men, $24.50 for women. On an expressway north of town, the Hatagoya Motel offers lodging and breakfast for a family of four for $92.

title: Rockville Centre 'Color Wars' Never End
description: IN an atmosphere more reminiscent of the rah-rah 1950's than this been-there-done-that era, nearly 800 mothers, fathers and siblings filled the South Side High School gym in Rockville Centre last weekend to cheer, stomp, whistle and wave flags as their daughters and sisters -- 300 strong, 150 on each team -- competed in the 86th annual Red and Blue contest.

description: With his ''Prada Deathcamp,'' Tom Sachs uses the Holocaust to make an antifashion statement (The Way We Live Now, Deborah Solomon, March 10). The ironic detachment that permits invoking a great horror to make a trivial point may in time come to be known as the T. Sachs Syndrome.

title: March 17-23: NATIONAL; DOG MAULING VERDICT
description: Marjorie Knoller, a San Francisco lawyer, was convicted of second-degree murder in the death of a neighbor, Diane Whipple, 33, who was attacked by Ms. Knoller's 120-pound dog, Bane, last year. Ms. Knoller and her husband, Robert Noel, were also convicted of involuntary manslaughter. She faces 15 years to life; he faces up to four years.

description: Curative Health Services Settles Shareholders' Suit

title: Through Old Music, a New Look at Iran
description: BAHMAN KIAI, 56, gave his first performance on the dulcimer in Iran, when he was 6 years old. Since then, Mr. Kiai, who immigrated to the United States in 1986, and has lived in Great Neck since 1988, has given many other performances. But his most recent, at the Great Neck library on March 16, had particular resonance for him because it was an opportunity to cast light on a rarely visible side of Persian culture.

title: Straps and Buckles Demystified
description: AT Police Officer Jason Caravaglia's station for child-safety seat inspection and installation in White Plains, the numbers are numbing: Only 1 percent of the 3,500 seats he has seen in the last three years have been placed in the car correctly. And, almost a third of the seats brought in have been outdated, broken or recalled.

description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: March 17-23: NATIONAL; RACE GAP IN HEALTH CARE
description: Experts have long attributed the race gap in medicine to lack of insurance for minorities. But a study by the Institute of Medicine found that even insured minorities get lower-quality health care than whites. Nonwhite patients were less likely to have heart bypass surgery or kidney transplants, for instance, while nonwhite diabetics are more likely to have limbs amputated. The reasons include differences in the quality of health plans and the fact that white patients tend to have longer relationships with primary care physicians, as well as subtle racial bias, said the authors, who termed their findings a wake-up call to doctors.

title: Elizabeth Worley, Teymour Farman-Farmaian

title: March 17-23: INTERNATIONAL; WHY SHE SPIED
description: As a former Defense Department intelligence analyst pleaded guilty to spying for Cuba, perhaps the most striking part of her tale was not how she had worked secretly for Fidel Castro's government but why. Ana B. Montes, 45, a bright, hard-working woman from the Baltimore suburbs, was driven by the belief that United States policy toward Cuba was deeply unfair, her lawyer, Plato Cacheris, said. Over the 16 years she worked in the Pentagon, officials said, she passed the Cubans top secret defense information and disclosed the identities of American intelligence officers -- but took no payment other than the reimbursement of some expenses.

description: THE enclave of College Point, whose modern roots go back to the 1830's, is separated from the rest of Queens by a phalanx of megastores, industrial plants, office buildings and the swampy remnant of the former Flushing Airport, which together form the 550-acre College Point Corporate Park north of the Whitestone Expressway.

description: ALTHOUGH Westchester is a land of plenty, it suffers a severe shortage of baby sitters. Finding a regular sitter for weekend nights is so difficult that, for many, the concept of dinner and a movie is nothing more than an abstraction.

title: A Brief Respite Between Battles
description: With the campaign against Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters in the Shah-i-Kot Valley completed, American soldiers returned to their camp at the old Soviet air base near Kabul last week to do as soldiers do after a battle: put up their boots, read mail, eat, trade battle stories, shave, call home, play cards, relax. But for the men of the Special Forces, 10th Mountain Division and the 101st Airborne Division, the rest was not likely to last. American commanders said at midweek that pockets of resistance remained and that it might be months before the war was won.

title: QUICK BITE/Union; As the Bird Turns
description: Burnet Barbecue is the kind of place you could drive by a hundred times and never notice. With a gas station next door and a traffic light down the street, there are more pressing things to look at than a small restaurant with a simple green sign. But beyond the nondescript facade lies a taste of the Portuguese cooking made famous in Newark's Ironbound section. Churrasco, a k a barbecue, is the restaurant's raison d'tre. Even if you somehow forget the restaurant's name, you'll know this is a barbecue joint the second you walk in the door. The smoke tips you off, as do the whole chickens rotating on spits over the brick charcoal pit behind the counter. One smell and it's guaranteed that whatever else you order, you'll be trying some of that perfectly crisped chicken ($10 for a whole bird). Rotisserie-style pork ribs ($10) are the other house specialty. Like the chicken, the ribs are served plain, with no sauce or seasoning. ''We let the charcoal give them flavor,'' said the owner,the Portuguese-born Feliseerto Santos. For $7, the half-combo is a steal, with half a chicken, several ribs, and a choice of French fries and rice or boiled potatoes, cabbage and carrots. (The fries come in a mound so tall you'll wonder if there are any spuds left in Idaho.) More manageable for lunch is the steak sandwich ($5), smothered with cheese and fried onions and served with those great fries. There are a handful of tables, but given the smoky atmosphere it's best to order take-out. You'll probably want to anyway: this is messy eating and some things are better done in private. Gretchen Kurtz

title: RADIATION-TREATMENT PILLS
description: The state last week announced a plan to stockpile 867,000 potassium iodide pills, a drug that prevents thyroid cancer if people are exposed to radiation. Residents who live within 10 miles of the state's four nuclear plants would each be given two doses in the case of an accident or terrorism. The state will be given the pills by the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: March 17-23: INTERNATIONAL; FIGHTING GLOBAL POVERTY
description: President Bush and more than 50 other heads of state reached an agreement that they said redefined the relationship between rich and poor countries. The so-called Monterrey consensus, named for the Mexican industrial city where they met, binds poor nations to combat corruption, to open markets and to respect the rule of law, while obliging the rich to increase aid and reduce barriers to the exports of poor countries. Mr. Bush made a down payment, a 50 percent rise in U.S. foreign aid budget, and Europeans also pledged increases. The test will be whether the benefits reach the 1.2 billion people who still live on less than $1 a day.

title: Kasparov Dominates Field At Linares for the 8th Time
description: Garry Kasparov did it again in Linares, Spain, Feb. 23 to March 10. He triumphed over a powerful field to win for the eighth time. His score in the 12-round tournament, known as the Wimbledon of chess, was 8-4.

title: Scandals Drive a Crackdown On Illegal Gambling in Greece

title: E-ZPASS
description: The state's troubled E-ZPass electronic toll collection system came under more criticism last week as the Assembly Transportation Committee was told that 4.8 million violations were recorded during November, December and January, but only about 240,000 of those were really non-pass holders driving through E-ZPass lanes. The committee also learned that WorldCom Inc., the company that installed the system and processes violations, was paid $3.2 million to weed out the real violators. Still, 660,000 violation notices were erroneously mailed. Karen DeMasters

Survived by four children, Richard, Stephen, Helen and Martha; eight grandchildren; and husband Philip C. Niles. Served as Director of Community Relations and the Director of the Corporate Arts Program at PepsiCo, Inc. for more than 20 years. Also president of the Westchester Council for the Arts, executive committee member of the United Way of Northern Westchester, founder and president of the Northern Westchester Junior League, and national vice president of the Association of Junior Leagues of America. Memorial contributions in Katherine's name may be directed to the New York State Council of the Arts, or your local arts program.

title: Girls Just Want To Be Mean
description: Wiseman's program reminds me of the school meetings that were held several times a year when I attended National Cathedral School (class of 1989) to discuss the issue du jour: eating disorders. An endless parade of ''recovered'' food addicts detailed the minutia of their disorders, which only served one purpose -- to give us even more ideas on how to attain an unreasonably thin body. And it didn't help that the women who had recovered from anorexia or bulimia were typically beautiful, successful and . . . skinny. Everyone in the audience could connect the dots.

It is always interesting, therefore, to see a big, bravura pianist scale back for Schubert sonatas, as the Russian firebrand Arcadi Volodos does in a new CD from Sony Classical (SK 89647).

For big rice and cotton farmers, the issue is a provision that would limit each farmer's annual subsidy to $275,000. For advocates of the poor, the goal is to add legal immigrants to the food stamp program without undercutting hungry school children or their mothers.

title: A Different Kind of Shock Treatment
description: IT takes a clever filmmaker to show a 21st-century audience of seasoned voyeurs things they think they should not see. In acclaimed movies like ''Funny Games'' and ''Code Unknown'' with Juliette Binoche, the director Michael Haneke dispenses with the routine blood and sex that Hollywood has trained moviegoers to stomach and instead shocks them by catching his characters in awkward, sometimes perverse situations -- leaving the most disturbing pictures to the viewers' imaginations. A kiss might be shot from the back, a rape scene from the neck up, a stream of blood trickling down a leg all we see of a woman's self-mutilation.

Our democracy is sinking fast from the onslaughts of the bloated military and the ''superpatriots'' who stifle dissent.

''I might even end up owing something,'' said Mr. Findley, 72, an account executive at a software company, explaining that he had accumulated little equity since buying the house two years ago.

title: Ideas & Trends; Buying Friends or Building Nations?
description: IT was a circumspect group of leaders that got together in Mexico last week to talk about world poverty. President Bush and his European counterparts pledged to spend more on aid, but they talked mostly about the strings they were attaching. International welfare often fails because recipients follow bad policies, they said. The poor should really look more to private investors than government aid. The rich, once and for all, have learned to deny money to corrupt or incompetent governments.

title: Our Towns; 'A Beautiful Mind'? She Hasn't Seen It, but She's Heard the Voices
description: JOHN FORBES NASH JR. can have his Nobel. Lenora Brown wants only this out of life: a good man, a home of her own, and a driver's license. A replacement for her missing front tooth can wait.

title: Israeli Foreign Minister Says Arafat Should Go To Arab Talks in Beirut
description: Palestinian officials warned today that an Arab summit meeting scheduled to open Wednesday in Beirut could make no progress in resolving the conflict here if Israel blocked Yasir Arafat from attending.

title: Forever Young
description: Clearly, Brianna/Treva is a troubled young woman, but I have to applaud her efforts to take care of herself. By finding acceptance among people who truly cared about her well-being and getting an education, she cost the state far less than if she had been a patient at a mental-health facility (and, in all likelihood, got better results). She also certainly fared better, contributed more and cost the state less than she now will in prison.

title: Sports of The Times; Double the Height of Hockey's Plexiglass Panels
description: IN hockey, a player's facial scars are part of the job description. If he's cut, he's quickly stitched and he's back on the ice by the next period. That's the hockey credo. Always has been. Always will be. It has also been the hockey credo for anybody in the stands who got hit by a flying puck. Get a few stitches, then return to your seat.

title: Political Briefing; G.O.P. to Court Blacks In South Carolina
description: At first glance, South Carolina would seem to be a state where Republicans could all but rule out signing up many black members. Republicans -- white Republicans -- pretty well run the state these days, and the state they run is still in a state of war over where, and even whether, to fly the Confederate battle flag.

title: A Self-Taught Artist's Blue-Collar City and What's Left of It
description: RALPH FASANELLA, labor organizer, gas station attendant and late-flowering, self-taught painter of blue-collar New York, wrote his own epitaph: ''Remember who you are. Remember where you come from. Change the world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILFOND, HENRY
description: GILFOND-Henry. Age 94, died of a heart attack on January 31, 2002, in Southampton, N.Y. Born in Ekaterinoslav, Ukraine, on May 29, 1907, he emigrated with his family to England and then to the United States in 1917. He graduated from The College of the City of NY in 1927. Poet, playwright, scholar, and educator, he was a frequent contributor of poetry and short stories to literary magazines in the 1930s-including the ''Yale Harkness Hoot,'' ''Bonacker,'' and the little magazines. He edited ''The Dance Observer'' and ''New World Monthly,'' and did public relations for the African Council. His play ''Region of the Cross,'' was produced at Circle in the Square in NY, & ''The Wick and the Tallow'' was recorded by Folkways. He was a writer for radio and television-including Cavalcade of America, New World A'Coming, American Inventory, Shakespeare's Women, and Ellery Queen. He contributed to ''The NY Times Sunday Book Review,'' ''Diplomat'' magazine, Readers Digest books, and the ''Southampton Press.'' He was the author of more than 100 Plays for Reading and more than 50 nonfiction and educational books. His poetry was published in ''The Yale Literary Magazine,'' ''Commentary,'' ''The Centennial Review,'' ''The NY Times,'' ''The Sewanee Review,'' & ''Tiananmen Square Anthology'' (Australia), among others. A collection of his poetry, ''Journey Without End,'' was published in 1958. Active into his 95th year, his most recently published poem appears in the current issue of ''The Sewanee Review.'' His wife Edythe, costume designer for Martha Graham, Broadway, and television, died in 1989. He is survived by his son Michael and his daughter Pamela, three grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Following a private service, he was laid to rest in Good Ground Cemetery, Hampton Bays, NY on February 3, 2002.

title: Stay Tuned: Yankees Coverage Still Up in Air
description: FOR New York Yankees fans, watching cable television, and more specifically, Cablevision's Madison Square Garden Network, was how they followed their team to four World Series championships and five American League championships over the past six years.

title: Corrections
description: An art review on March 3 about a show at the East End Arts Council in Riverhead misstated the surname of an artist whose work was on display. She is Pamela Topham, not Topping.

title: Foodies And The Feast
description: There were no strangers at the cozy, sentimental party Alice Waters gave at Chez Panisse for her friend Marion Cunningham. On a warm summer's day in February, the matriarch of home cooks was celebrating her 80th birthday the way she loves best: sitting around the dinner table talking and laughing with more than 80 of her best friends and family at an old-fashioned Sunday supper served family style.

title: Editorial Observer; Why Republicans Are Shamelessly in Love With the Voting Rights Act
description: John Lewis, Georgia's legendary black congressman, has been called many things. He had every known racial epithet hurled at him -- and had his skull fractured -- when he marched for voting rights in Alabama in 1965. But one thing no one had thought to call him is an enemy of black voting rights. Yet he stands accused of just that now, by a most unlikely source: Georgia's Republican Party.

title: SNOW REMOVAL
description: The state spent only $6.9 million on snow removal during a winter of low snowfall, compared with the $29 million spent last winter, according to the Department of Transportation. The state used roughly 49,000 tons of rock salt compared with the 200,000 tons used last winter. The mild weather allowed the 600 maintenance workers who normally plow the roads to repair potholes, clear debris and perform other general roadwork. John Holl

description: Mike Richter felt better yesterday while resting at home after taking a slap shot off the side of his head during Friday night's embarrassing 5-2 loss to the Atlanta Thrashers, the worst team in the N.H.L.

Klieg lights pierced the sky around the Fabian Theater on Church Street, and fans turned out to see Lou Costello, the star from Paterson who never forgot where he came from.

title: New York Cardinal Responds to Critics

In a letter delivered to parishioners for Palm Sunday masses, he wrote, ''I pledge to you that I am totally and unconditionally committed to protecting our children from abuse of any kind.'' The cardinal condemned all sexual abuse of children and called on victims to step forward. He said the archdiocese would report incidents to the police if given the victim's permission.

The other half of the family wanted to continue running it. Each side owned 41 percent of the company, which is based in Sunbury, Pa., and went public in 1965.

Thai restaurants are old hat in the city, but have been relatively slow to come to the Island. Only recently have they begun to multiply.

The money will be awarded to the Cancer Institute of New Jersey associated with the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. Institute officials said that 20 percent and 30 percent of the $28 million will be used to research cancer clusters, particularly in the Toms River area. Jo Piazza

For good reason: Mr. Toro, who oversees community affairs for the nonprofit organization, considers himself homeless and regularly sleeps on a couch in the group's Mott Haven office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENCER, EILEEN
description: PENCER-Eileen. The members of the Board of Trustees of the Lower Eastside Service Center along with all staff members are profoundly saddened by the untimely death of our beloved President and CEO, Eileen Pencer. She was a visionary whose remarkably good judgement and steady leadership helped guide both the expansion of LESC and the success of Angel Street Thrift Shop. We cannot say enough about her tremendous courage, spirit and will to live. She has been an inspiration to us all. We will always love her and cherish her memory. We remember her with heartfelt gratitude and extend our condolences to her family. Contributions may be made to the Eileen Pencer Memorial Fund made payable to Friends of LESC, attn: Lee Pavis, 157 Chambers St., New York, NY 10007. Peter Santoro, Board Chairman Elaine Katz, First Vice President

Here at Style & Entertaining, we do not concern ourselves with the longevity of warm-and-fuzzy, except to say that we, as both hosts and guests, like warm-and-fuzzy as much as we like sexy and hot, sporty and spicy, Mickey and Minnie, Fred and Ethel, Britney and Justin, Ben and Jerry. We have the room for it: warm-and-fuzzy can hang out for as long as it likes. Same as it ever was, the secret of the good life, like personal style, is all in the mix. Take what you want from Column A, a pinch from Column B, mix with C and D, shake it all about! Voil! You read it here first: Live as well as you work.

At college, I discussed this as a possible research subject when I applied for a grant from the women's studies department. I was told by the supervising professors that such a topic showed that I was ''buying into a male version of women's social interactions.'' I'm glad to hear that feminists, teachers and parents are finally paying closer attention.

She squeezed it and I felt in my heart that she would make it because the squeeze told me she was a fighter.

Many low-priced rentals are in dilapidated buildings in run-down areas. Many are too far away from the artists' markets in Manhattan. And when an artist finally discovers space that fits the bill, there is always the worry that others looking for reasonable rentals will also move in, resulting in increased demand and higher rents.

title: Forging the Monterrey Consensus
description: Half the world's population lives on $2 a day or less. Can prosperous nations best help them by spending significantly more on foreign aid, or by better targeting their assistance and making it more efficient? Both, is the sensible answer that came out of the United Nations' International Conference on Financing for Development, held last week in Monterrey, Mexico. But even though rich nations have pledged to reverse recent declines in assistance, it is not clear that they are prepared to invest enough.

He dreams of a Catholic Church in which priests can marry and have children, women can be ordained as priests, and homosexuals can feel welcome without question. description: The United States Chamber of Commerce, founded in 1912, describes itself as the world's largest not-for-profit business federation, with three million business members, 3,000 local chapters nationwide and 97 chapters abroad. It is also dominated by white men. Last week, the chamber announced an expanded effort to draw in minority and women entrepreneurs, offering them new ways to obtain financing and expand their businesses. The effort will be led by Reta J. Lewis, a chamber vice president and a Washington lawyer who was a special assistant to President Bill Clinton. The chamber, she said, ''is not where it needs to be as it relates to minorities and women.''

description: SCARSDALE has long prided itself on being a village in a park, the sort of place where green space -- both public and privately owned -- is considered a precious community commodity.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TOVELL, HAROLD M.M., MD,
description: TOVELL-Harold M.M., MD, peacefully slept away in his Florida home last May. Born in Toronto, Canada, he received his medical degree at the University of Toronto. Later he completed a tour of duty in the Canadian Army Medical Corps. After moving to NYC in 1949 he spent five years in residency at Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology and Gynecologic Oncology. He remained on the teaching staff of the Department for seven years before being appointed chief of the Obs/ Gyn service at Columbia University's affiliated Woman's Hospital in 1963 where he was Director for over a decade. There he created the Divisions of Reproductive Medicine, and Oncology, and reorganized the residency program. Among his numerous accomplishments, he opened a clinic with his good friend and colleague, Dr. Alexander Young, which became a referral center for the NY area. Harold also served as a board member of Planned Parenthood of NYC and chaired the medical committee for many years. He was also a member of the NY Obstetrical Society and played tennis on a weekly basis with several of its members for many years. He thoroughly enjoyed golf in his later years. He retired as Director of Woman's Hospital in 1974 and closed his practice in 1987. He moved to Sanibel, FL with his wife, Elizabeth (Betty), where he quickly became strongly supportive of the Bailey-Matthews Shell Museum from its inception with the late Dr. Tucker Abbott, a malacologist. Dr. Tovell served multiple terms as President of theBoard of Trustees of the world class, non-profit museum where he ''imparted a professional, scientific momentum to the museum'', according to the director, Dr. Jose Leal. Harold was predeceased by his loving wife of two months shy of 50 years, in 1995, and by their first 2 sons, Harold & Craig, during their early manhood. He is survived by their 2 other sons, Christopher, of Arizona, and Daniel, of Atlanta. A memorial service is to be held at the Shell Museum this Spring. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The BaileyMatthews Shell Museum, P.O. Box 1580, Sanibel, FL. 33957.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIL, DAVID
description: GIL-David, 79. A resident of North Pownal, VT., died unexpectedly early Monday morning, March 18, 2002 at the Southwestern Vermont Medical Center in Bennington, VT. Born May 29, 1922 in New York City, NY, he was the son of Louis and Rose Goldfarb. He grew up in the city and later served as a merchant seaman in World War II. Upon his return, he attended the School of Ceramic Design at Alfred University, receiving a Bachelor of Fine Arts Degree. Moving to Bennington, David founded Bennington Potters, Inc. in 1948. His 54 year career began with a one-man operation and grew to include multiple stores, a restaurant, a mail-order business, a contract art production facility, and a ceramic factory. He spent his last five years building his successor operation. His loves were art, design and production. His satisfaction was problem solving, his greatest pleasure was seeing his own designs out in the world, both in the marketplace and in people's hands being used everyday. David's legacy is the Bennington Pottery Brand and his memory is an icon to craft producers; he was a man who made a business from his art. David's arrival at his studio inside the Pottery everyday from 1948 until last Saturday, was his daily adventure in practicing his craft. David was also devoted to his family and friends. A man who called his children every Sunday. He leaves his wife, Sheela Harden, and his children & grandchildren: Martin Gil and his wife Eva Holden, and their sons, Solomon and Merlin of Colchester, VT; Jane Gil and her husband Tom DiCillo of New York, NY; Sally Gil and her husband Ken Johnston and their daughter Lilabeth of Brooklyn, NY; & Michael Gil of Los Angeles, CA. David's brother Saul Gilford of Oberlin, OH, and a nephew, Todd Gilford of San Francisco, CA. predeceased him. David is also survived by Saul's children: Mark Gilford of Loveland, CO; Beth Gilford and her daughters Ruth and Elain Alden of Ann Arbor, MI; Peter Gilford of Northampton, MA; and Hilary Gilford of New York, NY. Funeral services will be private. A memorial celebration at Bennington Potters is being planned for late May. Contributions may be made in David's memory to the Bennington Fire Department in care of the HansonWalbridge Funeral Home, PO 957, Bennington, VT. 05201. For directions or to send condolences, contact us at www.nsm.org/covey.

title: The Capitalist Communitarian
description: A couple of months ago, I was talking to Howard Schultz in the lobby of the Seattle SuperSonics' practice facility. Schultz, the chairman and chief global strategist of Starbucks and the new principal owner of the Seattle N.B.A. team, continually emphasizes that ''the Sonics are a public trust'' and that his primary motivation in purchasing the team is not to feed his own ego or to make money but to ''return the team to where it once was'' (the Sonics won the N.B.A. championship 23 years ago) by restoring a communal spirit within and around it. While we were talking, one of us dropped a dime on the floor. Schultz bent down to pick it up and offered it to me, since it wasn't clear which one of us had dropped it. ''You think I can be bribed so easily?'' I asked. Schultz blanched, and he took a full step back. In Schultz's world, money is obviously such a deep subtext that it can never be mentioned explicitly in public, even if it's only a joke, only a dime. A minute or two later, as if to recover, he stage-whispered to the Sonics' public-relations director to tell me about how Desmond Mason, a second-year player, was going to visit a terminally ill teenager that afternoon.

description: THE truth, feared but at the same time sadly comforting, came in the night. Two police officers from the local precinct drove through the quiet streets of Bayside last Wednesday to deliver the news, to tell the mother and father of Muhammad Salman Hamdani that yes, he had died on Sept. 11. His remains had been found near the north tower, and identified.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBROW, MARGERY B.
description: DUBROW-Margery B. Beloved wife of Daniel Mansolino, cherished daughter of Gus and Ann Dubrow, loved sister of Phyllis Klein, adored niece of Beatrice Friedman, Morris and Rose Schlecter, died peacefully at home on March 19, 2002, at the age of 59. She was a loving wife, deeply devoted to family and friends, especially her five grandnieces and nephews who brought her great joy. She was a wise, sensitive, compassionate and effective psychotherapist and teacher, engaged in private practice in NYC, and was a valued volunteer for GMHC. Despite being stricken with polio at the age of two, her ability to overcome her lifelong disability with tremendous courage and optimism, while battling cancer, was an inspiration for us all. May remembrance of her profound love and compassion bring comfort to all who mourn her passing. A remembrance service will be announced at a later date.

description: Two public relations agencies are being acquired for undisclosed terms.

description: Tribal leaders from the treacherous mountainous areas along the border with Afghanistan have an unambiguous message for American commanders who have suggested that they might enter the region in pursuit of Al Qaeda fighters: Don't.

description: The fire that had been gradually consuming a vacant warehouse next to the Holland Tunnel for two days spread to an adjoining building yesterday, all but guaranteeing that the tunnel would remain closed to Manhattan-bound drivers through tonight.

description: Vice President Dick Cheney said today that it was important that Yasir Arafat go to the Arab summit meeting in Beirut this week, a development that would require Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel to lift his travel ban on Mr. Arafat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIGGS, JAMES G.
description: BRIGGS-James G. Of 10th Street, died Friday, March 22, 2002, at the Brooklyn VA Hospital in Bay Ridge. He was 79. Born on January 12, 1923, in Saratoga Springs, he was the son of the late James T. and Margaret Briggs. Mr. Briggs was a Sergeant First Class in the United States Army serving from 1941 to 1961 in the Philippines, Korea, Germany and Austria. He worked for 17 years in the security department at the New York Times newspaper in Manhattan. He was a very religious person, an avid sports fan and loved horse racing. Mr. Briggs was a member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars Gurtler Brothers Post 420, the American Legion Adirondack Post 70 and the 26th Infantry Division Association. He is survived by two nephews, Robert R. Briggs and Bruce M. Briggs, both of Saratoga Springs; and several great nieces and great nephews. Funeral services will be held at 6:15 PM on Tuesday, March 26, at the William J. Burke & Sons/Bussing & Cunniff Funeral Homes at 628 North Broadway in Saratoga Springs (888-584-5373 or www.burkefuneralhome.com). Rev. Francis J. Sullivan, C.Ss.R., associate pastor of St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church, will officiate. Burial will be at a later date in Greenridge Cemetery. Friends may call from 4 to 6 PM on Tuesday prior to the service. Memorial donations may be made to the Saratoga Emergency Corps Inc., PO Box 4456, Saratoga Springs, NY 12866.

title: An Analyst Raises Ad Spending Estimates
description: In another indication that the American advertising market may be moving out of its serious slump, a Wall Street analyst has upgraded his estimate for ad spending this year.

title: Maryland Squeezes, and Kansas Eases, Into Final Four
description: Juan Dixon was keeping pace with Caron Butler in an elegant scoring duel, but that was not enough. Lonny Baxter, Dixon's fellow senior, needed more help if Maryland was going to turn back Connecticut. So with 3 minutes 53 seconds left and the Terrapins trailing by 3 points, Dixon called for the ball.

title: In East Coast Drought, Even Trout Want Rain
description: On the opening day of trout season in New York State next Monday, anglers will find many streams running at typical late-spring or early-summer levels, conditions ideal for fly-fishing.

title: The Wrong Fight
description: I'm no fan of the Board of Education. It's been wasteful, at times irresponsible, frequently too political and -- in the case of some individual members -- flat-out incompetent. So there'll be no gnashing of teeth here if the curtain is brought down on its long and unhappy run.

title: For Sharon, a Painful Choice
description: Vice President Dick Cheney has presented the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, with a dilemma: let Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, escape his siege and attend a summit meeting of Arab leaders this week in Beirut, or risk having Israel look as if it sabotaged an Arab bid for peace in the Middle East.

Possessed of a winning personality, keen intellect and a true commitment to public service, John will be remembered by us with affection and respect for his lively, generous spirit and unfailing kindness, and for his many contributions to American life. title: Choosing Celibacy
description: By almost any measure, the wave of pedophilia scandals sweeping through the country represents the greatest crisis ever to face the Catholic Church in the United States. Not surprisingly, the scandals have prompted widespread anguish among American Catholics. The discussions taking place around the country -- in homes, in schools, in parishes -- are necessary if the church is to emerge from this crisis healthier and more open.

description: Broadview International, an investment bank that specializes in technology company mergers, is in serious discussions to sell itself to UBS Warburg, several Wall Street executives said over the weekend.

title: General Musharraf's Travails
description: Few leaders have a tougher balancing act these days than Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan. Since January, he has built an impressive record of going after groups linked to terrorism. But because of the continuing ability of terrorists to strike back with such actions as the recent attack on a Protestant church in Islamabad and the murder of Daniel Pearl, General Musharraf sometimes appears not to be doing enough. President Bush continues to support the general and credit his efforts. For now, that backing seems justified. But the United States must be alert to possible backsliding and keep pressure on the general to return democracy to Pakistan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Bus Injures 2
description: An 87-year-old woman was critically injured yesterday when she and another person were hit by a city bus while crossing Sheepshead Bay Road, near East 15th Street, the authorities said. The second person in the 3:40 p.m. incident suffered minor injuries and went to Lutheran Medical Center. No summonses were immediately issued. The elderly woman, Loretta Murray, was taken to Lutheran in critical condition, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

A design centerpiece is a simulcast parlor resembling a sports bar, with a center stage for magicians or scantily clad dancers -- male as well as female, he promises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENCER, EILEEN
description: PENCER-Eileen. The members of the Board of Trustees of the Lower Eastside Service Center along with all staff members are profoundly saddened by the untimely death of our beloved President and CEO, Eileen Pencer. She was a visionary whose remarkably good judgement and steady leadership helped guide both the expansion of LESC and the success of Angel Street Thrift Shop. We cannot say enough about her tremendous courage, spirit and will to live. She has been an inspiration to us all. We will always love her and cherish her memory. We remember her with heartfelt gratitude and extend our condolences to her family. Contributions may be made to the Eileen Pencer Memorial Fund made payable to Friends of LESC, attn: Lee Pavis, 157 Chambers St., New York, NY 10007. Peter Santoro, Board Chairman Executive Staff

title: Security at U.S. Reactors Criticized by Congressman

Markey in response to his questions about security after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Surprising Run of Victories For Foursome at Vanderbilt
description: Teams can have four, five or six players, with four playing at any one time. In major tournaments, six is normal. Stamina is part of the reason, but more significant is sponsorship. Most of the top-ranked teams consist of some top professionals plus one wealthy sponsor, slightly below the highest class, who plays for the first half of the match and leaves his hired guns to shoot it out in the second half.

title: Library and Legacy Adrift As the Nixon Sisters Feud
description: To stroll into the lobby of the Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace Foundation here in this quiet Orange County suburb is to confront one of the quirkiest and most bitterly fought-over institutions in the presidential library system.

title: John M. Eisenberg, 55; Led Health Agency
description: Dr. John M. Eisenberg, a former medical educator who led the federal agency that monitors quality and safety in health care and research, died on March 10 at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 55.

title: At Seminary, New Ways for a New Generation
description: In the next three months, 43 men who have trained here at the nation's largest Roman Catholic seminary are to be ordained as priests. They include a former soybean farmer, an astronomer, a former minor league baseball player and a Vietnamese-American who feels a debt to the church that saved his refugee family.

Duncan's former employer, Arthur Andersen, may rest on what this accountant was really thinking last fall when he oversaw a wholesale destruction of documents related to the company's audits of Enron.

title: White House Letter; Diplomatic Two-Steps In Latin America Trip
description: Was President Bush's four-day trip to Mexico, Peru and El Salvador one he never wanted to make? The White House says no, Mr. Bush had a fine time meeting with more than a dozen Latin American heads of state, speaking his own brand of Spanglish (''Mexico es a grand amigo de los Estados Unidos and we're equal partners'') and promoting trade in Lima's baroque Presidential Palace after a 21-gun salute.

title: John Patton, 66, Organ Player With a Jazzy, Laid-Back Style

description: The journey for Craig Perks was grueling, but the ending was glorious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, ANDREW JAMES
description: JOSEPH-Andrew James. Much beloved husband of Suhasini (Sue). Devoted and loving father of Ravindra and Nilufer, adored father-in-law of Anne and Peter and cherished grandfather of Anjali, Lauren, Madeleine, Cassidy, James and India. He also leaves behind his dearly loved sisters Amybelle, Isabelle and Rukmani and his great friend Jane. Andrew's career spanned five decades of public service from the Ceylon Civil Service to the World Health Organization to the United Nations Development Program, where he retired as Under Secretary General and Associate Administrator. The family will receive friends at Frank E.Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Tuesday, March 26, from 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 3:30 PM, at St. Stephen's Hungary Church, 414 East 82nd St. A reception will follow in the Church Hall. In lieu of flowers, Andrew has requested that friends and family give donations to his old school, St. Joseph's College in Colombo, Sri Lanka, where the monies will be used to fund needy students. Checks should be made payable to Rector, St. Joseph's College with the memo marked ''Andrew Joseph Memorial Fund.'' Checks may be sent to Sue Joseph at 75 East End Avenue, Apt. 15J, New York, NY 10028.

title: In El Salvador, Bush Talks of Trade and Criticizes Democrats
description: President Bush said today that he would push hard for a trade accord between the United States and Central America, but he also took time to criticize the Democrats back home for calling his four-day trip to Latin America an excuse to pander for Latino votes.

title: Coming soon: advance selling of blocks of movie theater screens for pre-show advertising.
description: THEY run the gamut from snack promotions on slides to full-blown filmed extravaganzas. Now appearing on roughly two-thirds of America's 34,000 odd screens, they are movie theater ads and, like television commercials before them, they are well on their way to becoming a staple of American life.

title: Wishing for a Velvet Rope To Keep Nightclubs Out
description: It was a recent Friday night on the Lower East Side, and at the nightclub Mint, on the corner of East Houston and Essex Streets, business was being conducted much as usual. Groups of people in their 20's sipped $7 bottles of beer or $11 mixed drinks. As colored lights flashed and dance music blared, partyers bobbed and shimmied. A woman wearing maroon velvet pants cuddled up on a couch next to a man dressed head to toe in black.

description: Spring is sweeping as bountifully as ever across the bluegrass pastures of the thoroughbred horse farms. The season's early foals are tottering upright in the barns and prancing forward from the starting gate of life.

description: Federal investigators are examining whether terrorist operations by Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda and other Islamic groups were indirectly financed by at least two wealthy, well-connected Saudis through a maze of foundations, companies and financial institutions.

An old man had mailed two dollar bills.

description: Edison S.p.A., Italy's second-largest electric utility, said today that net income fell 14 percent last year as it made investments in telecommunications and upgraded power plants.

description: After more than two years of civil war in Chechnya, Russian lawmakers have opened a new dialogue with Chechen political figures in hopes of setting terms for direct talks between President Vladimir V. Putin and the rebel leaders he has branded terrorists.

title: Broadcasters' Woes Spill Into the World of Soccer
description: When the World Cup soccer championships begin in May, the primary television broadcaster will be Premiere, the pay-television company owned by the Kirch Group.

title: Railtrack Bailout Expected This Week
description: Shareholders of the Railtrack Group will be offered a 1.3 billion ($1.8 billion) bailout this week as part of a government-backed bid for the company, the insolvent owner of Britain's train tracks and stations.

title: The New York Times to Add a Section on Leisure Pursuits
description: The New York Times is announcing plans today to introduce a Friday section devoted to weekend travel, weekend homes, cars and diversions while making its arts, dining and home sections newly available to readers across the country.

title: No Iverson, No Problem, As 76ers Slap Knicks
description: In the latest indictment of how miserable the Knicks have become, the Philadelphia 76ers soundly defeated them today without Allen Iverson, their slashing scoring machine who broke his left hand on Friday.

title: Shell Plans to Triple Its Stake in China
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Europe's biggest publicly traded oil company, plans to triple its investment in China to more than $5 billion by 2005 as the company helps build a natural-gas pipeline across the country.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Members Criticize Mayor
description: Two more City Council members criticized Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday for remarking this month that black and Hispanic parents who oppose mayoral control of the school system ''don't understand how poor a job'' the schools are doing. Mr. Bloomberg's remarks were in answer to a reporter's question on whether the mayor needed to better present his proposal to black and Hispanic parents. Councilman G. Oliver Koppell, above, a Democrat representing the Bronx, said that the mayor's remarks were ''patronizing; they were, in fact, insensitive, they were condescending, they were denigrating.'' He was joined by Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer, who represents the Upper West Side. Yesterday morning, Mr. Bloomberg said in an interview on WABC radio that his remarks referred to ''all the parents of the 1,100,000 kids'' in the school system. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Advice on the Task of Rebuilding, From a Mayor Who Knows Terror's Toll
description: Standing in the pit and looking up at damage done by the worst terrorist attack in American history, Oklahoma City Mayor Kirk Humphreys could not help but think of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building.

title: Where Just About Everyone Has a Gun
description: ''Tirana Year Zero'' suggests that one way of responding to the bottoming out of your country's economy is to throw up your hands and chortle at the absurdity and hopelessness of it all. That's more or less the attitude taken by Fatmir Koci's manic, scattered portrait of contemporary Albania.

title: E-Commerce Report; J. Crew reaches a milestone as its sales over the Web exceed sales from its catalog.
description: WHEN J. Crew announced its results for February recently, the company highlighted its growing Internet sales as the one bright spot in an otherwise forgettable month. Surprisingly, what it did not say was that it had crossed a threshold that few apparel and general merchandise catalog businesses have crossed: for the first time, J. Crew's Web sales eclipsed its catalog sales.

title: Negotiations Begin In Andersen Claims
description: Eric D. Green, the mediator assigned to oversee negotiations between Arthur Andersen and groups that have sued the firm for its handling of the audits of Enron, brought the parties together at a hotel in the Dallas area yesterday afternoon for preliminary talks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 Accused Of Forced Servitude
description: Three men were charged yesterday with holding three immigrant women against their will and forcing them to work as prostitutes in Brooklyn and Connecticut, the authorities said. According to an indictment filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the men induced the women to come to the United States from Indonesia, promising them work in restaurants. Instead, they were taken to brothels where they were forced to work as prostitutes until one of them escaped and told the police. The men, Chai Hock Ng, Kian Chai Ong and Sadiman Tio, were charged with involuntary servitude, forced labor and other crimes. They would face sentences of up to life in prison if convicted. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Return to the Final Four Is a Relief for Indiana
description: The Indiana players, coaches and followers had an immediate and joyous basketball hangover late Saturday night in Rupp Arena. But afterward, in a quiet moment in a far corner of the locker room, Indiana Coach Mike Davis reflected on his team's 81-69 victory over Kent State. The Hoosiers (24-11) had earned the South Regional championship and a trip to the Final Four.
