title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESCON, HOWARD
description: MESCON-Howard. Of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Scarsdale, on March 22. Adored husband for 56 years of the late Florence Mescon, beloved father of Richard and Michael, proud ''Honey'' to grandchildren Andrew, Jennie, David, Daniel and Hannah, cherished father-in-law of Miriam and caring surrogate father of Jane Ryffel, loving brother-in-law of Shirley Leitstein and uncle of Robert, Bruce and Alex Leitstein, dearest cousin of Evelyn Steinberg and Michael and Enid Mescon. We hold Grace Rosen in our hearts for her love and support to all of our family. Howard Mescon graduated from the City College of New York and the Harvard Business School, which he attended on full scholarship, served as President of the Coblentz Bag Company of New York City and was a founder of Adler Associates, a south Florida real estate developer of many projects including the Galahad apartments and the Miami International Commerce Center. He was active in both public and private philanthropic causes throughout his life-a life filled with hard work and the light of intelligence, devoted to caring for others with modesty, wisdom and kindness. Services at The Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY, Monday, March 25, at 12 o'clock.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Accused Of Raping 6-Year-Old
description: A family friend was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 6-year-old girl in her family's apartment in Hunts Point, the authorities said. The man arrested, Nicholas Panton, 19, was charged with first-degree rape and sodomy, the police said. Investigators said the man lived in the same apartment building and was a friend of the girl's family. Detectives said they believed the rape occurred about 10:30 Thursday night when the man was left alone with the girl. They said the incident was reported on Friday after the girl's parents took her to a hospital for evaluation. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Drinking Still on Rise At Women's Colleges
description: Binge drinking and drinking generally have been increasing at women's colleges since 1993, even as the overall proportion of college students engaging in binge drinking has remained stable at 44 percent, according to the Harvard School of Public Health's College Alcohol Study, which will be released tomorrow.

title: Sun Aims to Extend a Lead
description: In federal court, Sun Microsystems has portrayed Microsoft's Internet services software effort -- known as .Net -- as a virtually unstoppable monopoly. On Monday, Sun will try to cast itself as a Microsoft beater.

title: I'm Wearing . . . Fill in the Blank
description: It was Sting, the British pop star, who summed up the sartorial confusion of the Academy Awards tonight when he said, apropos of the designer horse race, ''I'm wearing Jean Paul Gaultier, Prada, Yves Saint Laurent and Donna Karan. Everybody.''

title: Painterly Images Color Leotards and Poses
description: A sense of purity pervades the plotless dance pieces of Nancy Meehan, who retains her originality amid the clutter of passing trends. Movement that is clear and straightforward frees her choreography from psychological obstacles. Drama takes the form of unpredictable occurrences caused by shifts in space and rhythm.

title: Decision About Valentin Is Looming for Valentine
description: For much of spring training, John Valentin was expected to win a spot on the Mets' roster. Although he was signed to a minor league contract, Valentin provided right-handed power off the bench and proved he could play all four infield positions.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Riding Bike Is Stabbed To Death
description: A 19-year-old man riding a bicycle in Williamsburg was fatally stabbed by a man who rode off on the bike, the police said. The man, Henron Winfield, was riding at Marcy Avenue and South Fourth Street around 4:45 p.m. when the attacker stabbed him in the back, said Officer George Jensen, a police spokesman. Mr. Winfield had had a prior dispute with the killer, according to the police. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Shelter Mutts: Uncle Sam Needs You, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I went through more screening to get into the seminary than to get a security clearance in the military.''

title: Unselfish to a Fault
description: Sue Bird was named the preseason national player of the year based on her reputation. Coach Geno Auriemma asked Bird, the Connecticut point guard, how much she desired the more prestigious postseason honor, which would depend on achievement.

title: Despite Its Success, Sooners' Basketball Team Finds Nothing Beats Oklahoma Football
description: With the Oklahoma basketball team headed to the Final Four this weekend, someone asked Coach Kelvin Sampson whether its success would alter the athletic priorities in a football-centric state.

title: How Quickly a City Can Grow
description: A plan is needed for the World Trade Center site but not a big plan. There are times for building Central Park, and there are times for remedial gardening. Lower Manhattan should not be remade according to some new grand vision. A framework needs to be put in place and some principles agreed on, and city life will take its course.

title: Louis Rukeyser Is Removed Early As Host of 'Wall Street Week'
description: Louis Rukeyser was removed last night as host of ''Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser'' by the president of Maryland Public Television, Robert J. Schuman.

title: New Economy; Many start-ups have survived but will need infusions of venture capital.
description: JUST when you thought the dot-com boom and bust had been safely put behind us, new studies suggest that more carnage lies ahead.

title: 'Beautiful Mind' Wins; Best Actress Goes to Halle Berry
description: ''A Beautiful Mind'' won the Oscar for best picture of 2001 in ceremonies tonight in Hollywood that also included the first Oscar for a black actor in a lead role in almost four decades and the first for a black actress in a lead role in Academy Award history.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on March 12 about troubles faced by Vinson & Elkins, one of the law firms that represented Enron, misstated the outcome of a 1995 case -- unrelated to Enron -- that accused the firm of malpractice. Although the firm initially lost, it won an appeal and later settled for an undisclosed sum. It did not lose the case outright.

title: A U.N. Sentinel
description: To the Editor:

title: Extending Life, Defibrillators Can Prolong Misery
description: The patient, a man in his 60's, arrived at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation hospital in acute discomfort. His defibrillator, a tiny device implanted in his chest to correct abnormal heart rhythms, was going off six times a day or more, with a jolt that felt like a boxer's punch to the chest.

title: Supreme Court Drama In the 'West Wing' Mold
description: ''The hell with the robe; I need a flak jacket,'' Sally Field says as a newly appointed Supreme Court Justice in ''The Court.'' That line from a future episode reflects the political skepticism, maneuvering and no-nonsense personality that make this show so engrossing. As Kate Nolan, recently the governor of Ohio and now the lowliest member of the most exalted court, Ms. Field is independent minded, expert at manipulating the media, a little nervous, extremely confident and a likable character to root for.

title: Privacy and the American Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Law Limiting Internet in Libraries Challenged
description: This morning in a Philadelphia courtroom, a coalition of libraries, Web sites and library patrons will begin nine days of hearings in which they will ask three federal judges to help decide a seemingly simple question: What is a library for?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Is Shot On Subway
description: A man was shot in the stomach on a subway train last night, the police said. The man, 25, was on the southbound A train between the Ralph Avenue and Rockaway Avenue stops at 7:47 p.m. when another man, in his 20's, shot him once, said Officer George Jensen, a police spokesman. The victim was in stable condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. In a separate incident around the same time, a 21-year-old man was stabbed in the leg on the platform at the Lorimer Street Station on the L train, Officer Jensen said. The police said they had no suspects in either incident. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: 2 Convictions Overturned, HCA Says
description: HCA Inc., the health care chain, said today that a federal appellate court had overturned fraud convictions against two former executives.

title: Justice and Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil's Prized Exports Rely On Slaves and Scorched Land
description: The recruiters gather at the bus station here in this grimy Amazon frontier town, waiting for the weary and the desperate to disembark. When they spot a target, they promise him a steady job, good pay, free housing and plenty of food. A quick handshake seals the deal.

title: 31 Arrested in Brothel Raid
description: Thirty-one people, including three off-duty corrections officers, were arrested early yesterday in Newark when the police raided what they called a brothel. The corrections officers worked as security guards at the unlicensed club, said Sgt. Robert Koval, a police spokesman.

title: Analysis of Stimulus Package Has City Losing $300 Million
description: A new analysis of the economic stimulus package that Congress passed earlier this month -- which was conceived as strong medicine to create jobs and spur investment -- points out that it may have some unwanted side effects in New York City.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Wage Bill Would Protect Housekeepers And Nannies
description: Imelda Rosario, a nanny on the Upper East Side, is so upset about being paid just $300 a week for 72 hours' work -- far less than the minimum wage -- that she has joined other domestic workers in an unusual fight.

title: Patents; Recognition for canine breath freshener with a special, head-scratching, ingredient: garlic.
description: DOGGY breath appears to be a problem that pet suppliers take seriously, judging from the many canine halitosis remedies on the market these days: poultry-flavored toothpaste, pet breath mints, yucca-infused chlorophyll tablets and charcoal dog biscuits, to name but a few.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, SELMA
description: WEINSTEIN-Selma. On March 24, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother, grandmother, sister and aunt. She will be missed. Services private.

title: In Palm Sunday Homily, Cardinal Egan Says Evil of Sex Abuse 'Will Be Stamped Out'
description: In an extraordinary homily from the pulpit of St. Patrick's Cathedral, Cardinal Edward M. Egan yesterday confronted the issue of sexual abuse of children by priests, which has shaken the Roman Catholic Church, telling Palm Sunday worshipers, ''It is a time of great suffering for the church.''

title: Set Death Penalty Aside
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Savor Special Rivalry and Chance to Help Bury the Rangers' Playoff Hopes
description: He may be a rookie coach, but the Islanders' Peter Laviolette is certainly no rookie to hockey lore. And yet, he has an admission to make about the way he once regarded the clashes between the Islanders and the Rangers, who meet tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Big Mexican Breadwinner: The Migrant Worker
description: Three construction workers who gathered outside a Western Union office on the west side of this city seemed too tired to drag themselves home, much less help lift their homeland, Mexico, out of poverty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOETTIGHEIMER, LUDWIG
description: BOETTIGHEIMER-Ludwig. On March 23, 2002, in his 94th year. Beloved husband of Marianne, devoted friend to many. Services today March 25, 11 AM, at Congregation Habonim, 44 West 66th St. Contributions to Congregation Habonim will be appreciated.

title: Pipe Bomb Badly Injures Brooklyn Man
description: A pipe bomb in an orange bag exploded beside a minivan parked in one of Brooklyn's busiest Jewish neighborhoods yesterday morning, critically injuring a Hasidic man and briefly sending shudders of fear through a community anticipating Passover and concerned over mounting violence in the Middle East.

title: An Odd Couple and a Former Beauty Queen in a Tale of Exiles in Sweden
description: ''The New Country'' is a modern Swedish spin on an old Hollywood genre: the road picture, in which two temperamentally mismatched buddies hurtle through a picturesque landscape, meeting assorted odd characters and discovering the meaning of friendship amid comical and terrifying adventures. Geir Hansteer Jorgensen's film, trimmed down to feature length from a mini-series on Swedish television, adds an element of topicality to the formula. The buddies in question, Massoud (Michalis Koutsogiannakis) and Ali (Mike Almayehu) are illegal immigrants who, having fled violence and persecution to come to Sweden, find a cold welcome in Scandinavia.

title: Sports of The Times; UConn Can't Solve The Baxter Problem
description: AFTER his team's comfortable victory over Southern Illinois on Friday, Coach Jim Calhoun said the difference in the game, the difference at this level of Division I competition, was not that Connecticut had better players, but more of them.

title: Another Short Second Act for a 'Seinfeld' Alum?
description: Jeff Zucker does not want to hear about the curse of ''Seinfeld.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: London Journal; Thatcher Exits, but, List, Is That a Voice Offstage?
description: ''I was told beforehand that my arrival was unscheduled, but on the way here I passed a local cinema, and it turns out you were expecting me after all,'' Margaret Thatcher told a delighted audience of Conservatives during last year's election campaign.

title: Hans-Georg Gadamer, 102, Who Questioned Fixed Truths
description: Hans-Georg Gadamer, a leading figure of 20th-century philosophy who spent an extraordinarily long career contemplating the nature of meaning and understanding, died in Heidelberg, Germany, on March 13. He was 102.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIPFEL, MAE SYDNEY
description: GIPFEL-Mae Sydney. See notice under ALIMENA-Mae Sydney.

title: Oscar's Home Is Smaller, but the Night Still Thrills Fans
description: The nature of adulation demands extraordinary sacrifices. People who revere Hollywood stars will go to the ends of the earth, or across the country at least, to catch a glimpse of the objects of their obsessions.

title: Hingis Is Still Hungry For That No. 1 Ranking
description: She has been ranked No. 1 in the world on four occasions, the last for nearly a five-month span ending in October. She can win on any surface and has won every major title except the French Open.

title: Audience for Cable News Grows
description: Immediately after Sept. 11, there were predictions that the terrorist attacks would prove to be a seminal moment for the television news business.

title: This Week
description: Shedding Light

title: Andersen Ex-Partners Sue
description: A group of retired Arthur Andersen partners, including the firm's former chief executive, have sued the accounting giant in an effort to protect the retirement benefits they receive.

title: Longtime Assemblyman Announces He Will Not Seek Re-Election
description: Arthur O. Eve, a Buffalo assemblyman who has served longer than any other current member of the Assembly, announced over the weekend that he would not run for re-election this year.

title: Jayhawks Coach Hopes His 3rd Trip Brings Him a Title
description: Roy Williams, the Kansas coach, is hoping his third trip to the Final Four is better than the first two.

title: Arab Leaders Warn Israel Over Arafat
description: Officials gathering here for an Arab League meeting said today that Israel could miss an opportunity to achieve an enduring cease-fire if it insisted that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, could not attend.

title: Dog Attack Trial Is Over, but the Debate Goes On
description: The infamous dog mauling case may be over, but this city is still reeling from it.

title: When Immigrants Are Children
description: Each year, more than 4,000 children arrive in America unaccompanied by an adult. Some are teenagers looking for work, but others are toddlers used as props by smugglers or young people fleeing abuses like forced recruitment as soldiers or arranged marriages. Except for Elin Gonzlez, the Cuban boy whose mother drowned en route to America in 1999, they get little attention. But Elin's case was unusual in another way -- he was allowed to stay with family and given legal representation.

title: And a Second Baseman Shall Be First for Yanks
description: He is playing with confidence and enthusiasm, slashing hits to all fields, running the bases with passion, smiling and laughing. He has been the best player in the Yankees' spring training camp and, to at least one of his teammates, Alfonso Soriano may soon be one of the best players in baseball.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: UBS Warburg Is in Talks To Buy an Investment Bank

title: Call Against Martin Overshadows Nets' Rally
description: Once again, Kenyon Martin unleashed his frustration by swinging an elbow into his opponent. Once again, the referees hit him with a flagrant foul, to be followed by another suspension.

title: A Woman Pushed Into Heroism in the Times That Tried Men's Souls
description: Some years ago, having written several novels in succession about insanity and obsessive sexual love, I decided that the next would be a story about the American Revolution. Instead of wild delusions, ungovernable passions, bad decisions and flawed perceptions there would be horses and muskets and sailing ships and thunderstorms. There would be sacrifice, treachery and bloodshed. Tyranny would be overthrown, a nation born. It was a chancy venture, but every author will recognize the impulse to travel down strange roads, if only for one book.

title: Assembling A Big Merger: Hewlett's Man For the Details
description: Webb McKinney, a senior Hewlett-Packard executive, first learned of his company's plans to buy Compaq Computer three days before the deal was announced early in September.

title: Sales of Debt Set for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills; four-week bills on Tuesday and two-year notes on Wednesday.

title: The Politics of Judgeships
description: Since the rejection earlier this month of Judge Charles Pickering for the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, senators and White House officials have dwelled on old grievances. Trent Lott, the Senate minority leader, has threatened retaliation. Democrats are slow-walking other nominations because they do not relish another fight. Meanwhile, President Bush's top political adviser told a conservative religious group that Mr. Bush would keep selecting conservative ideologues for the bench.

title: Multiple Phone Calls Overseas Surprise Recipients of the Bills
description: The phone bills look more like ones that belong to envoys to the United Nations than to the residents of a quiet block of West 135th Street in Harlem: a 21-minute call to Pakistan, 20 minutes to India, 11 minutes to Egypt and 317 minutes to Kuwait.

title: Our Natural Habitats
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALKE, EVA
description: BALKE-Eva. March 21, Oslo, Norway. We mourn for an exceptional educator and leader. She had been president of the World Organization for Early Childhood Education. Because of her profound contributions, young children of the world will have a better education and life. She was deeply loved and will be missed internationally. Our thoughts are with her three beloved sons. Gordon Klopf, Rita Cooper Kate Kolchin

title: Taiwan Maker of Notebook PC's Thrives Quietly
description: As Barry Lam shows a visitor around the art gallery on the top floor of his corporate headquarters, his gaze keeps coming back to a blue-and-green landscape by the legendary Chinese painter, Zhang Daqian.

title: Slide Show: The Wedding of Lina and Mazen Sawan
Shedding Light on an Invisible Problem
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Arafat and the Beirut Summit
description: It doubtless seems bizarre to Ariel Sharon that 20 years after sending the Israeli Army to the edge of Beirut to force Yasir Arafat out, he is now expected to let Mr. Arafat return there to be toasted by Arab leaders. Mr. Arafat, whose strategy of talking peace while waging war is spreading death across Israel, wants to be the guest of honor at tomorrow's Arab summit meeting. Bizarre and frustrating as this may be, letting him go is the smart thing to do.

title: Crime Is Up in City Schools, Mostly in Assault Category
description: New statistics on school safety released by the New York Police Department show increases in several crimes that directly affect students' lives and can help to create an unsafe atmosphere in classrooms, hallways and schoolyards.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: McAfee.Com Rejects Buyout
description: The directors of McAfee.com have rejected as inadequate a $248 million buyout offer by Network Associates, the company that spun it off three years ago. Network Associates offered a 20 percent premium over McAfee.com's closing price on March 15 for the 25 percent of shares it did not own. But a committee of McAfee.com's directors said yesterday that the bid significantly undervalued the company. Network Associates, which spun off McAfee.com in 1999, said it would take its offer to shareholders. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Memphis Has a Point to Make in the N.I.T.
description: Memphis Coach John Calipari took a day off from directing his wrath at the N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee, spoke glowingly of the National Invitation Tournament and even made nice with his longtime foe John Chaney.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Central American Unity
description: Central American leaders have signed an agreement to guarantee investment and allow service companies to operate freely in the region, saying they have made significant advances toward regional economic integration. Meeting after seeing President Bush on Sunday, the leaders said they had also made progress toward eliminating customs barriers within Central America. ''This is a new era for Central American unity,'' said President Enrique Bolaos of Nicaragua.

title: Parks Monitors Say Federal Hall Is Imperiled by Water and Neglect
description: Pop-quiz question: What urban icon took its place yesterday on the America's 10 Most Endangered National Parks list, among such wild wonders as Yellowstone National Park, the Great Smoky Mountains and the Big Cypress National Preserve?

title: Giants Try to Reel In Dirty Laundry
description: Michael Strahan passed through a crowd of reporters in the Giants' locker room today, the gap in his front teeth showing through a grin. Then Strahan hoisted his arms into the air, bent them at the elbows and flashed peace signs with both hands, Nixon-like.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a suspect in a double homicide who the police say escaped from the 88th Precinct station house in Brooklyn on Friday misstated its location. The station is in the Clinton Hill section, not Fort Greene.

title: Hollywood Questions the Meaning of Its Historic Oscar Night
description: Hollywood, still warming itself in the glow of Sunday night's Oscar ceremonies when blacks won both of the top acting awards for the first time, was wondering this morning whether this amounted to a milestone in movie history or a mere coincidence.

title: Grand Jury Being Misused As Investigator, Andersen Says
description: Lawyers for Arthur Andersen filed a motion late yesterday seeking to block prosecutors from using a federal grand jury to continue investigating the document destruction that led to the firm's indictment on a charge of obstruction of justice.

title: People
description: Alan Cohen was named senior partner and group account director at the Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, overseeing work on the global BP account. He succeeds Jack Rooney, who left to join GMR Marketing, Milwaukee, part of the Omnicom Group, as executive vice president for client services. Mr. Cohen had most recently been chief marketing officer at uBid.com, Chicago.

title: FORD EXPECTS TO MAKE A PROFIT IN 2ND HALF OF YEAR
description: Ford Motor will probably make a profit in the year's second half, its chief financial officer said yesterday. ''I would see us getting to some form of profitability'' in the second half, while losing money in the first quarter, the executive, Martin Inglis, said at a Morgan Stanley automotive conference in New York. Ford, which is based in Dearborn, Mich., is cutting jobs and closing plants after a 2001 loss of $5.45 billion, its first annual loss since 1992.

title: Pettitte Makes Progress; Ventura Is Hurt
description: On the daily medical scoreboard that has dominated the Yankees' spring training camp, today's result was Progress 2, Setbacks 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISS, MARY M.
description: MORRISS-Mary M. On March 24, 2002 in Saint Louis, MO. Beloved mother of Jean Rasmussen, Christopher Middendorf, Alexander Middendorf & Mary Bale. Devoted grandmother of ten grandchildren. Wife of Ralph Morriss and the late W. Kennedy B. Middendorf. Services Thursday, March 28th, Saint Louis, MO.

title: Enron Selling Wessex Water for $777 Million
description: The Enron Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell Wessex Water, a British utility, to the YTL Corporation, a Malaysian energy and construction company, for $777 million in cash.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Steel Industry To Be Sold
description: Under pressure from the European Union to cut subsidies to heavy industry, Poland's left-wing government said it would consolidate the country's state-owned steel industry and pick a foreign buyer by the end of April. Poland has already received offers from the Dutch-registered Ispat International, a consortium of the Salzgitter and ThyssenKrupp steel makers in Germany, and Arcelor, a consortium comprising interests in France, Luxembourg and Spain. The four mills to be sold, Katowice, Sendzimira, Cedler and Florian, together produce 75 percent of Poland's steel, about 8.6 million metric tons last year. Production fell 16 percent from 2000, and losses last year rose nearly 40 percent, to 1.3 billion zlotys ($316.4 million). The European Union says industrial subsidies must be eliminated by the time Poland and other former Communist states enter the union in 2004. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Playing Defense to Keep the Heisman at Home
description: JAMES CORCORAN is penned in -- we hope -- by his desk at the shuttered and endangered Downtown Athletic Club but otherwise exhibits all the danger signs of road rage: glazed eyes, raised fist, bitter verbiage, seismic blood pressure.

title: High and Mighty Oracle
description: To the Editor:

title: Questioning the Moralist
description: To the Editor:

title: A Naughty Dachshund Fuels a Fable
description: Set in a rural, rice-growing province of central India, ''A Dog's Day'' opens with the vibrant colors and rhythmic chanting of a village ceremony. The region's hereditary ruler, a vain, portly lord with thick plastic-framed glasses and a lush white mustache, has decided to surrender authority to an elected official. He also, with equal pomp and fuss, bestows his beloved pet dachshund, Apu, on the elderly childless couple who have served his lordship for many years.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the dramatic soprano Eileen Farrell yesterday misidentified the university where she taught voice in the 1970's. It was Indiana University at Bloomington, not Indiana State.

title: Doctor's Specialty Is Special to Patients
description: A recent look at the cases of more than 5,000 hospital patients found that about one-fourth were treated by medical specialists working out of their area of expertise, and the patients may have paid a price for it.

title: Facing the Crisis in the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: A campaign for Meow Mix brings back a popular singing cat and a haunting, if repetitive, lyric.
description: MEOW MIX is reviving one of the best known, most readily sung commercial jingles as it brings back the commercial that introduced the product almost three decades ago.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank's Outlook Slips
description: Germany's biggest bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., said that bad loans would continue to overcast its profit outlook when it publishes its annual report today. The bank released last year's main figures in January, posting a 9 percent decline in profit as it was hurt by loans to Argentina and the Enron Corporation. This year a growing number of German companies are expected to file for insolvency, among them the construction company Philipp Holzmann and the media group Kirch Holding, which will reduce the lender's profit outlook. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Andersen's Partners Are Vital Part of Rescue Proposal
description: Paul Volcker's proposal to salvage Arthur Andersen requires the alignment of several forces, including the federal prosecutors who would have to drop criminal charges against the firm and the shareholder lawyers who would have to agree to a settlement.

title: Just One Big Family
description: Getting into the Vanity Fair Oscar party was easy. Getting out was tough. Sharon Stone, who had changed somewhere between the Kodak Theater and Morton's (maybe in the limousine) from her sweetheart dress to a black pantsuit, was creating a bottleneck at the door as she huddled with Sissy Spacek. Reese Witherspoon, being small, wedged herself into an air pocket and got out. Meanwhile, Ron Howard and Brian Grazer, the producers of ''A Beautiful Mind,'' were running the media gantlet at the entrance. ''Ron! Brian! Over here!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, EILEEN
description: FARRELL-Eileen. On March 23, 2002, at age 82. Internationally renowned opera & popular music singer. Beloved wife of the late Robert V. Reagan Sr. Loving mother of Dr. Kathleen Reagan and Robert Reagan Jr. Dear sister of John L. Farrell. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, Tuesday, March 26th, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Wednesday, 1 PM. Interment Castine, Maine. Contributions in her memory may be made to Mabel Mercer Foundation, 160 E. 48 St, #

title: Improving His Average To One in 16
description: When Randy Newman finally won an Academy Award for best original song on Sunday night, putting 16 nominations and 15 losses behind him, he couldn't resist a little mockery. ''I don't want your pity,'' he teased, and went on to thank the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for giving him so many opportunities for humiliation. Receiving the award, for ''If I Didn't Have You'' from ''Monsters, Inc.,'' was a capstone to a career that has followed, in its odd way, a classic trajectory: the brilliant bohemian iconoclast who ends up going back into the family trade.

title: Ridge Offers Compromise on Testimony Before Congress
description: Seeking to defuse a growing confrontation with Congress, Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, has softened his refusal to testify before senators about domestic security efforts, offering to take questions from lawmakers informally but in public.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC Falls On Analysts' Comments
description: Shares of the EMC Corporation, the world's largest maker of data storage systems, fell almost 5 percent yesterday after two analysts said they did not think the company would meet estimates. H. Clinton Vaughan, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in San Francisco, said EMC could miss first-quarter revenue estimates of $1.43 billion by more than 10 percent. He lowered his estimate to $1.26 billion, saying technology managers ''seemed to come into the new year reluctant to spend.'' Thomas Mancino, an analyst with Pacific Growth Equities in San Francisco, also cut his estimate. In January, EMC forecast first-quarter revenue of $1.43 billion, 5 percent lower than the fourth quarter. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Bach's Preludes and Fugues, Monolithic in Beat and Tone
description: Bach could never have imagined playing or hearing the 24 preludes and fugues he collected in his ''Well-Tempered Clavier'' as a concert program, but the pieces work very well that way, and the Russian pianist Sergey Schepkin made an imposing display of them on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The venue felt right, too. In some of the grander fugues -- the one in G sharp minor especially -- the whole of human culture could be sensed out there, slowly circling around its center, in Bach.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Taking On a Kennedy
description: Representative Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. will seek the Republican nomination for governor. Mr. Ehrlich, who represents the Second District, outside Baltimore, acknowledged that he would face an uphill battle against Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, the likely Democratic nominee. But he predicted that he could win, to become the state's first Republican governor in more than 30 years. If elected, Mr. Ehrlich said, he will impose tighter state spending controls. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORNFELD, LESLIE PARIS, M.D.
description: DORNFELD-Leslie Paris, M.D. On Friday, March 22, 2002, at the age of 64. Beloved husband of Mariagrazia. Devoted son of Morton and Dorothy. Dear brother of Paris. Interment private. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St, Tuesday, March 26th, 4 PM. For further information, call 212-288-3500. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Officer Faces New Charges In Torture Case
description: A former Brooklyn police officer whose two convictions in the Abner Louima assault case were overturned last month was indicted yesterday on two new charges of perjury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISSEY, MARIE W. (NEE WENDLING)
description: MORRISSEY-Marie W. (nee Wendling). On Thursday, March 21, 2002. Beloved wife of John T., dear sister of Madeline and aunt to many loving nieces and nephews. A Memorial Service at Immanuel Lutheran Church, 11th Ave. and 150th St., Whitestone, NY, on Wednesday, March 27 at 8:00 PM. Please remember her in your prayers.

title: Fire Dept. Has Pinpointed 700 New Human Remains
description: More bodies were removed from ground zero yesterday as the gruesome recovery efforts continued in some of the final areas of the World Trade Center ruins to be searched. The effort to find remains has proven especially productive in the last three weeks, as Fire Department searchers mapped more than 700 new discoveries.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Travelocity Adds Fee To United Tickets
description: Travelocity, an online travel agent, said yesterday that it had added a $10 service charge to reservations made for United Airlines. The move came in response to United's decision last week to stop paying commissions to travel agents in the United States and Canada. A spokeswoman for Travelocity said the company deserved to be paid for booking reservations and for marketing United flights to its 32 million members. Representatives from the companies said they were discussing the fee. Travelocity took similar action against Northwest Airlines but dropped the $10 fee last month when the companies reached a settlement. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Csar Milstein, 74, Who Won Joint Nobel Prize in Medicine
description: Dr. Csar Milstein, who shared the 1984 Nobel Prize in Medicine for a revolutionary technique to produce antibodies that latch onto specific proteins, died on Sunday in Cambridge, England. He was 74.

title: What Yemen Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Is Ready to Impose Broad Limits on Steel Imports
description: Moving to head off a feared deluge of steel diverted from the United States, the European Union is preparing to impose tight limits on imported steel products, officials of the union said today.

title: WATERS REDUCES 2001 EARNINGS AND 2002 FORECAST
description: The Waters Corporation reduced its 2001 reported earnings and its forecast for this year after a jury ordered the company, a maker of laboratory instruments for drug development, to pay $47.5 million for patent infringement. The jury found earlier this month that a British unit of Waters had wrongly used technology covered by a United States patent licensed to a joint venture of the Applera Corporation and MDS, a Canadian concern. The decision affected Waters's Quattro Ultima mass spectrometers, which are used to analyze chemicals. Waters, based in Milford, Mass., plans to appeal the ruling.

title: Broadway Returns $1 Million in Aid
description: In the wake of its surprisingly rapid recovery since Sept. 11, the Broadway theater community is returning $1 million of emergency aid to the city, which will redistribute it to nonprofit cultural groups, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday.

title: Hoosiers Paint Town, And Their Faces, Red
description: The five cherry-red banners hanging at the south end of Assembly Hall are as anonymous as the concrete from which the basketball arena was built. Each bears the words Indiana University and each lists a year: 1940, 1953, 1976, 1981, 1987. But the players and coaches who won those championships are not named.

title: Cablevision Adds Free Coverage
description: Cablevision announced yesterday that subscribers in the metropolitan area who have MSG Network or Fox Sports New York will receive the one they do not have for free this year.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Crocodiles Kill 43 People
description: Officials armed with automatic weapons have begun patrolling the waters of Lake Victoria in search of crocodiles so aggressive they have devoured an estimated 43 people in the last six months. ''The situation had become so acute that we were recording about two casualties a week,'' said Mary Francis Owuor, district commissioner in Bugiri, in the east of the country. One of the worst areas, she said, was in the waters around the Sigulu islands, where fishermen's small boats are frequently overturned by crocodiles. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: A Ballerina's Past Magic As Her Gift to the Future
description: George Balanchine went out of his way to recruit Violette Verdy into his New York City Ballet in 1958. Anyone who saw her enchanting performances there until 1976 could understand that Balanchine chose her because she was unlike, not like, his usual ballerinas.

title: On College Basketball; A Merge On the Road To Atlanta
description: Oklahoma bullied its way to the Final Four. Indiana took the long (range) route, turning the South Regional final into a game of H-O-R-S-E. Kansas ran and ran, and is probably still running to Atlanta. Maryland, a collection of old souls, mixed wisdom with elbows, deft shooting with determined defense, and is the team to beat in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Prices for Auto and Home Insurance Are Increasing Sharply
description: Prices for auto and home insurance have been rising sharply around the country in the last few months as insurers struggle to keep pace with increasing costs, insurance executives and analysts said yesterday.

title: Action Against Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Forget the Car Keys
description: Unlike his predecessor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is not much known for fiery righteousness, except when he takes on the school system. But at a news conference this month, another subject seemed to bring out the Giuliani in him.

title: Grey Global Involved In U.S. Investigation
description: The Grey Global Group in New York said yesterday that it was cooperating with a federal investigation of the print production industry that resulted in the arrest last week of a former top employee, who was charged with conspiracy to defraud Grey clients by padding invoices.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Municipal Archives Legislation
description: City Councilman Bill Perkins, a Manhattan Democrat, proposed a bill yesterday that could undo Rudolph W. Giuliani's plans for his mayoral papers. Under the bill, which would require amending the City Charter and would be made retroactive to Jan. 1, 2001, former officials could not control the indexing of their own records. Before Mr. Giuliani left office, his aides transferred custody of his mayoral papers to a private center he controls, drawing criticism from historians worried about access. The Perkins bill would restrict the City Department of Records and Information Service's ability to transfer custody of historical records to any private group. City records would first be placed in municipal archives and then possibly in other ''archival establishments,'' but only if they operate under ''public auspices,'' presumably a public university or museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASER, ROBERT S.
description: GLASER-Robert S. Of Ridgewood, N.J. Beloved husband of Martha (nee Urish). Devoted father of Thomas, Marjorie Sommer, & Laura Donkin. Cherished fatherin-law of Ruby Glaser, Robert Sommer and George Donkin. Loving grandfather of Michael and Jacob Donkin, Rachel and Natalie Glaser and Alexander and William Sommer. Services on Tuesday, 11:30AM, at ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J. Contributions to the James Parkinson Fund, c/o Dr. Jacob Sage, Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, CN19, New Brunswick, N.J. 08903-0019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, JACOB W.
description: ABRAHAM-Jacob W. On Mar. 25, 2002. Beloved husband of Regina A. Abraham. Devoted son of the late Louis & Esther (Weisner). Former Justice of The Supreme Court, New York County. Past President, Bankruptcy Lawyers Bar Association. New York State Labor Department Special Referee. For over twenty-five years, Judge Abraham led The Federal Republican Club in Manhattan. A native New Yorker, he was a proud graduate of Seward Park High School, and Brooklyn Law School. A practicing attorney for seventy years, he was a respected and revered advisor and friend. Services are at Plaza Chapels, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY, March 26, 2002 at noon.

title: Judge Dismisses Fox News Suit Over Anchor's Defection to CNN
description: Fox News lost its lawsuit yesterday against the agent for Paula Zahn, the morning news anchor who quit Fox to join the Cable News Network last September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RABBI ISRAEL
description: MILLER-Rabbi Israel. The American Jewish Committee mourns the passing of an admired leader and esteemed friend. Rabbi Miller served the Jewish people in countless ways. He was a man of exceptional dedication, compassion, kindness and modesty. We shall always be grateful for his manifold achievements on behalf of Holocaust survivors, the State of Israel, overseas Jewish communities and American Jewry. We express our heartfelt condolences to his grieving family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Harold Tanner, President David A. Harris, Exec Director Andrew Baker Director Int'l Jewish Affairs

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Support For North Koreans
description: About 100 demonstrators rallied outside the Chinese Embassy in Seoul, protesting a roundup of North Koreans who have fled across the border into China. Norbert Vollertsen, a German doctor who is waging an international effort to call attention to the harsh conditions in North Korea, was detained briefly after a scuffle with the police. Two weeks ago, Dr. Vollertsen helped 25 North Koreans in China with a plan to reach South Korea. They charged into the Spanish Embassy in Beijing seeking asylum, and China allowed them to leave for the Philippines and they went on to Seoul. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: An Operatic Duo Donates Time and Voice for a Benefit
description: Four years ago the tenor Roberto Alagna and the soprano Angela Gheorghiu got temporarily fired from the Metropolitan Opera for balking on singing contracts to appear in the new Franco Zeffirelli production of Verdi's ''Traviata.'' Since then they have made amends and done valuable work. On Sunday they further endeared themselves to the company by performing arias and duets with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and Chorus in the annual pension fund gala concert, conducted by Bertrand De Billy. They even donated their services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, DR. CHESTER SCOTT
description: KELLY-Dr. Chester Scott. Died Friday, March 22, 2002, Louisville, KY. He was 70 years old. Born in Hazard, KY, son of Chester and Rachel Kelly. Graduated Phi Beta Kappa and valedictorian of Hampden-Sydney College, class of 1953. Served as Lieutenant in US Navy, earned MA in International Relations at the University of Pennsylvania and a PhD from Teachers College of Columbia University. Fulbright Scholar in Paris 1957-59. He co-directed the first Peace Corps Training Program for Liberia. Served as education coordinator in Lagos, Nigeria. While at Columbia he organized and recruited 40 to 150 teachers per year for East African schools and universities. Employed as an Africanist and senior political risk analyst for Mobil Oil. He is survived by his sister, Kitty Galloway of Louisville, KY, her children Dayna Payton, Louisville and Britton Galloway, New Orleans. A graveside service was in Lancaster, KY on Monday, March 25, 2002. Memorial gifts to Broadway Baptist Church, 4000 Brownsboro Road, Louisville, KY 40207, or charity of choice.

title: Energy Chief Met Envoys From Industry
description: The Bush administration released the first wave of documents related to Vice President Dick Cheney's energy task force today. The papers showed that Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham, a member of the panel, met with three dozen energy industry representatives but with no consumer or conservation groups in preparing the national energy strategy last year.

description: All in the Publishing Family

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronxville: Union Vote Set For April
description: The National Labor Relations Board has scheduled a unionization election at Lawrence Hospital on April 11 after a majority of the hospital's workers signed cards saying they wanted to join 1199/S.E.I.U., the hospital workers union. The hospital and union have been locked in a battle for more than a year, with 1199 narrowly losing a unionization vote last March. Hospital officials have campaigned against the union, saying the workers do not need it, while 1199 asserts that the hospital has coerced workers to vote against the union.

title: Soy May Play Role in Pain Management
description: Diet may affect the amount of pain that patients with long-term illnesses suffer, say researchers who have been exploring the role of soy in pain management.

title: An Engine for a New Age of Ocean Research
description: Studying the ocean with ships and buoys is like reading a book by staring at single scattered letters. Buoys are stationary, so the information they collect lacks context; ships rarely take readings in the same place twice, so their data lack continuity.

title: DELTA CHIEF'S CASH COMPENSATION FELL BY 72 PERCENT
description: Total cash compensation for the chief executive of Delta Air Lines, Leo Mullin, fell 72 percent in 2001, to $596,250 from $2.145 million in fiscal 2000, as he took a voluntary post-Sept. 11 pay cut, according to a proxy statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Mullin also had common stock worth $1.57 million at the time of the award as part of the company's long-term incentive plan. As Delta struggled to recover from an economic downturn, Mr. Mullin gave up his salary for the last three months of the year. His salary was set at $795,000 in 2001, so his voluntary cut amounted to nearly $200,000. Mr. Mullin's compensation was further reduced when he and other top managers recommended to the board that they receive no cash bonuses in 2001. He got a bonus of $1.4 million in fiscal 2000.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Government Must Offer AIDS Drug
description: A judge affirmed that the government must distribute an AIDS drug at public hospitals that have adequate staff and expertise while it appeals a court ruling that it make the drug available. The decision upheld an order from two weeks ago when the government was told to hand out nevirapine while it appealed the original ruling, made in December. The government has argued that the drug, which is already being distributed in a pilot program, needs to be tested more thoroughly before it is widely distributed. Nevirapine reduces the risk of transmission of H.I.V. from pregnant mothers to their unborn babies. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBWITH, EDWARD, DR.
description: LEBWITH-Edward, Dr. On March 25, at the age of 101. Beloved husband of the late Estelle, father of Martin Lebwith and Patricia Bleetstein. Father-in-law of Patricia Lebwith and Morton Bleetstein. Adored grandfather of Stephen, Michael and Larry Bleetstein, and Kelli and David Lebwith. Funeral private.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Land Prices Fall
description: Land prices in Japan fell for the 11th year, a sign that deflation is persistent and growing. A government report said property prices fell 5.9 percent last year, the fastest decline in nine years. Commercial real estate prices, a crucial indicator of corporate health, fell 8.3 percent and are now 62 percent below the peak that they reached in 1990. The decline in prices erodes the value of land used as collateral for many loans. Banks, however, have been reluctant to sell the property they hold, preferring to wait for prices to rebound. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Nordic Telephone Companies Are Reconsidering a Merger
description: Nordic phone companies are talking mergers again, with Sonera of Finland and Telia of Sweden confirming that they are back at the bargaining table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACQZ, JANE WILDER
description: JACQZ-Jane Wilder. Died in the evening, Sunday March 24, 2002, aged 74. Most recently a senior advisor to the Division for NonGovernmental Organizations at UNDP, Jane had long served in the international not-for-profit community. Mother of Margot & Christian; mother-in-law of Susan Baldwin; grandmother of Sarah Fulton, Henry William, and Irene Baldwin Jacqz. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions may be made to The Nature Conservancy, attn: Member Services, 4245 North Fairfax Dr. Suite 100, Arlington, VA. 22203.

title: Assembly Republicans Elect Minority Leader in Close Vote
description: When the Assembly's Republican minority gathered today to elect a new leader to replace John J. Faso, who resigned last week to focus on his bid for state comptroller, two things happened that are unusual in Albany: the vote was conducted by secret ballot and it was very, very close.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Haverstraw: Power Plant Cleared For Construction
description: State regulators have approved the construction of a third power plant at Bowline Point that will burn natural gas and oil and deliver 750 megawatts of electricity. The plant was cleared by the State Board on Electric Generation Siting and the Environment. Known as Bowline 3, the plant will join two 621-megawatt plants that went into operation in the early 1970's at a 257-acre station run by Mirant. Bowline 3 is one of several plants that had been proposed for Rockland County in the past two years. One plant stalled in a corporate merger, plans for two others have since been tabled, and the Ramapo Energy Project, a 1,100-megawat natural gas plant proposed for the scenic Torne Valley, remains under review. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

description: GOULD'S BOOK OF FISH

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Academy Awards broadcast on Sunday misstated the number of Oscars won by Woody Allen, who introduced a film of New York City scenes. It is three Oscars, not two.

description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by computer-related and financial shares, on concern that rising borrowing costs would crimp corporate profit growth.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Greenvale: Firefighter Killed In Training Exercise
description: One firefighter was killed and another was injured during a training exercise last night in Greenvale in Nassau County, the authorities said. The accident occurred in a southbound lane of Glen Cove Road, just north of Northern Boulevard. The lane had been barricaded with barrels, cones and flares, but a driver went through and hit the firefighters, said Officer Thomas Brussell of the Nassau County police. They were rolling up a hose at the time, the police said. The firefighters, both with the Roslyn Rescue Fire Company, were taken to North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, where one died and the other was treated and released last night, a hospital spokeswoman said. Officer Brussell said homicide detectives were investigating. The driver was taken into custody to be tested for alcohol. A statement from the volunteer fire company said that one of those struck was an officer and one was a firefighter. Their names were not released. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Langenbrunner Celebrates, and the Devils Tag Along
description: Jamie Langenbrunner celebrates each goal with a cockeyed grin, as if he has surprised himself. His goals do not usually include pirouettes or shots that reach triple digits on a radar gun. He scuffles for everything he gets.

title: EX-CHIEF OF AREMISSOFT INDICTED ON FRAUD CHARGE
description: The AremisSoft Corporation's former chairman and co-chief executive, Roys Poyiadjis, has been indicted for fraud, authorities said. Federal prosecutors unsealed an indictment last month against Mr. Poyiadjis, a British citizen now living in Cyprus, though they did not publicly announce it. The charge came to light in a case filed Friday in which prosecutors say they are seeking to seize $175 million in illicit profits diverted to two overseas banks by Mr. Poyiadjis and his co-chief executive, Lycourgos Kyprianou. In October, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged Mr. Poyiadjis and Mr. Kyprianou with making more than $300 million in secret stock sales while AremisSoft was reporting inflated revenue.

description: To the Editor:

title: Here, Islamic Law Guides How the Food Is Killed
description: Along a gray industrial stretch of Third Avenue in the South Bronx, it is a surprise to hear a rooster crowing daybreak. But then one spots the sign at the corner of East 168th Street showing hand-painted heads of chickens, goats and sheep and the words ''You Pick Them, We Kill Them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, EDITH
description: HALPERN-Edith. Died peacefully at her home on March 23. She is survived by her husband Nathan for whom she was a loving, devoted wife for 62 years, son Michael, daughter-in-law Christine and grandsons Ian and Nathaniel. Edith gave true friendship and kindness to many. She was a skillful and passionate advocate and Life Trustee of the New York City Ballet, a benefactor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and active in early days with the Harlem School of the Arts. Born in Kiev, Ukraine, she immigated to the U.S., graduated with honors in Sociology from the University of Chicago and then taught Sociology at UCLA. She worked closely with President Franklin Roosevelt and was instrumental in the planning of several major international conferences. Her family is receiving friends at the her home Wednesday, March 27 from 4 to 7 PM.

title: Britons Testify To Spare Life Of Millionaire
description: After having his death sentence overturned, a British multimillionaire was once again before a jury today with his life at stake.

title: Letters on Students' Weight Ruffle Parents
description: Last month, Heather Jones got an unusual letter in the mail from the nurse at her son's school in Pennsylvania. The letter said her 9-year-old son was too fat. Mrs. Jones was one of about 400 parents in the school district of 6,700 students to receive the same news.

title: Fishing Ban to Be Lifted
description: New York City's ban on public use of lands and waters that are part of its water supply system will be lifted next Monday, the opening day of New York State trout season, according to the city's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Global Crossing Creditors in Deal to Open Way for More Bids
description: The creditors of Global Crossing have reached a deal with two Asian companies interested in acquiring its assets, with the accord expected to open the way for more bidders.

title: FOOTSTAR TO CONSOLIDATE TWO SHOE STORE CHAINS
description: Footstar Inc., the owner of Just for Feet and Footaction athletic-shoe stores, said yesterday that it would consolidate the two chains to trim costs. Footstar will operate separate stores as it combines marketing, finance and other departments, the company said. Footstar, which is based in West Nyack, N.Y., said it operated 480 Footaction stores and 87 Just for Feet stores as of Feb. 23. It also runs 6,663 footwear departments in stores through a joint venture called Meldisco, including 2,114 in Kmart Corporation stores. Kmart holds a 49 percent stake in the departments in its stores, Footstar said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Unilever Sees Sales Decline
description: Unilever, the world's biggest food and soap maker, said that its first-quarter sales would fall as much as 2 percent, or about 370 million euros ($324 million), because of lost income from businesses it had sold. Growth will slow to about 10 percent for the full year, Howard Green, head of investor relations, said on a conference call with analysts. Unilever, which bought Bestfoods for $24 billion in October 2000, has been reorganizing to cut costs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Toll Road Bid
description: The large toll-road operator urea Infraestructuras del Estado raised its bid to buy a rival, Ibrica de Autopistas, to 915 million euros ($803 million), topping a competing offer by 18 percent. urea said it would pay 13 euros a share in cash or give Ibrica de Autopistas shareholders urea stock with a special dividend. The cash bid tops the offer last week of 11 euros a share from Autopistas Concesionaria Espaola.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZER, NETTIE COHEN
description: SCHNITZER-Nettie Cohen. Loving mother of William, Mark and Meryl and mother-inlaw of Sara Jane, Jean and Henri. Beloved grandmother of Madeline, Gideon, Michael, Nikki, Leslie, Allison and Phillippe. She lived a long and independent life-may she rest in peace. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Fund Fighting Blindness, Baltimore, MD, Children's Diabetes Foundation, Denver, CO, Interfaith Nutrition Network, Hempstead, NY, or the Lawrence-Woodmere Academy, Woodmere, New York. Services Tuesday, 2 PM, at Riverside-Nassau No. Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pataki Hires Democratic Adviser
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has hired Greg Tarpinian, a Democratic labor consultant, to be an adviser on union issues and outreach for his re-election campaign. Mr. Tarpinian, president of the Labor Research Association, is a top adviser to James P. Hoffa, the Teamsters president, and also advises 1199/S.E.I.U., the 210,000-member hospital workers union that endorsed the governor last week. Teamster officials say they are leaning toward backing Mr. Pataki, a Republican. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Metal Workers Strike
description: The big German labor union IG Metall started warning strikes with half-hour work stoppages in eastern states after a third round of talks between employers and the union failed to settle a dispute over wages. IG Metall, with 2.7 million members among the 3.6 million workers in the engineering and automobile sector, is demanding a pay increase of 6.5 percent to compensate for low increases in the past and productivity gains. The employers offered annual increases of 2 percent for 2002 and 2003. ''We won't allow ourselves to be separated from wage developments in western Germany,'' said Hasso Dvel, above, the union's leader for eastern Germany. Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: Like many steel towns in Pennsylvania or Ohio, this one is still home to a hulking old mill in the grand tradition: iron ore in at one end, giant smelters in the middle and finished products at the other side.

description: Divorce often hurts children, everyone agrees. It can cause great pain, anger, anxiety, confusion and behavior problems in the first couple of years of the breakup. And for some it leads to lasting anxiety, insecurity and fear of having close relationships with other people.

description: Whether or not we invade Iraq to topple Saddam Hussein, let's go about this the American way. Let's sue him.

description: Place-kicker Morten Andersen, the second-leading scorer in N.F.L. history, agreed to a one-year contract with the Kansas City Chiefs yesterday.

description: For a man occupying a post that has led almost inevitably in recent years to exile or execution, Hamid Karzai exudes a surprising confidence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILCHRIST, DAVID I.
description: GILCHRIST-David I. Of Southampton Village died of respiratory failure at Southampton Hospital on Wednesday evening March 20 at the age of 78. He was a lieutenant in the US Navy from 1943 to 1946 on a yard minesweeper. He attended Swarthmore College and Columbia University Law School where he earned his LLB. in 1950. He also held a Master's degree in International Law from New York University. In the 50's Dave spent a year as full-time lobbyist for the United World Federalists, an organization which believes in strengthening the United Nations for the support of world peace through world law. He returned to the law at Hill, Betts and Nash where he enjoyed a satisfying practice in the fields of maritime and international law for 31 years until his retirement in 1985. For five of those years he served as his firm's managing partner. Since his retirement Dave fulfilled his desire to be of public service to his community of Southampton. He served on many Town and Village committees, was tirelessly active in the Town Democratic Party and gave generously of his time and energy to social and environmental causes. Dave was a concerned and active citizen and a good man loved by many. He will be sorely missed by his community as well as his friends and family. He is survived by his wife Marilyn, his son Josh and his daughter Mary. There will be a memorial service at the Unitarian Universalist Church located in the Watermill Community Association on Montauk Highway in Watermill. The service will be held on Sunday, April 14 at 12:30 PM.

title: Shackleton Marches On
description: Some hero. He failed in his mission, lusted after fame, cheated on his wife and more or less abandoned his children. But Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton, the Antarctic explorer, continues to grip the public imagination precisely because he was so flawed and yet behaved so nobly. In 1914 he led his men into a disastrous situation, but then he managed to get them out, against unbelievable odds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, GEORGE H.
description: SCOTT-George H., 94. On March 24, peacefully at home in Florida. Adored and cherished husband of Hazel (Leichter) and the late Thelma (Lippman). Loving father of Jane Lande and Nancy and husband Arthur Stampleman. Stepfather of Beth Sommer and Anthony Leichter. Proud and loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Loved and admired by his brothers Nathan and Dr. Benjamin Scott and his many in-laws, nieces and nephews. Funeral services at Paperman and Sons, Montreal, Quebec, 1-800-515-7101. In lieu of flowers, a donation would be appreciated to Mt. Sinai-CVI in honor of, Dr. Valentin Fuster, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 1 Gustave Levy Place, New York, New York 10029, or Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A little civility is what Afghanistan needs. If I had guns, people would hate me. Who wants guns?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORENSTEIN, SAMUEL
description: BORENSTEIN-Samuel. The Jewish Center of Atlantic Beach records with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved and esteemed member, Samuel Borenstein. He is fondly remembered for over 50 years of support and leadership, including service as President from 1975 to 1985. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know no further sorrow.

title: Market Place; AOL Suggests Move by Malone and Other Risks
description: AOL Time Warner may soon face a move by John C. Malone to expand his ownership and obtain a seat on the board.

title: TALKS ARE INTENSE AS ARAB LEADERS PREPARE TO MEET
description: As Israelis and Palestinians tussled over whether Yasir Arafat would be allowed to attend an Arab League summit meeting here, Arab diplomats and foreign ministers tried today to overcome lingering tensions on how to treat Israel and Iraq and give life to a new Saudi peace initiative.

title: The Big City; The Gentry, Misjudged As Neighbors
description: WE all think we know how gentrification works. Developers and yuppies discover charm in an old neighborhood, and soon the very people who created the neighborhood can't afford it anymore. Janitors and artists are forced out of their homes to make room for lawyers and bankers.

title: Senator Helms as an AIDS Savior
description: Babies do not have to be born with the AIDS virus. If mothers bottle-feed their children and health workers administer a simple regimen of inexpensive drugs to pregnant and delivering mothers and to their newborns, the rate of AIDS transmission from mother to child drops drastically. Yet last year more than 600,000 babies were infected with H.I.V., the AIDS virus, at birth.

title: Bush Is Likely to Approve Carter Trip to Cuba
description: The Bush administration is considering a request by former President Jimmy Carter to visit Cuba this year, the White House spokesman said today.

title: Stockpiling Water For a River of Grass
description: Long ago, water in this subtropical state flowed this way: summer downpours coursed from the central flatlands into Lake Okeechobee, which spilled south through the vine-tangled forests beyond its indefinable marshy shore.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Telephone Concern Cuts Jobs
description: The debt-laden Hong Kong telephone company Pacific Century CyberWorks took a knife to its costs, announcing that it would lay off 858 workers, or 6 percent of its labor force. The company's chairman, Richard Li, said that the ''extremely difficult situation in Hong Kong and globally'' had made the cuts necessary. CyberWorks cut more than 800 employees last year as it struggled to reduce costs in the aftermath of its $28 billion acquisition of Cable and Wireless HKT. Mr. Li said the cuts would save $33 million a year; he refused to rule out further reductions. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Venezuela's President vs. Military: Is Breach Widening?
description: Rear Adm. Carlos Molina had ruled out conspiring to overthrow President Hugo Chvez, but he still wanted to be heard. He wanted the country to know that he and other military men were steadfastly opposed to the left-leaning, mercurial Venezuelan president.

description: What do traffic violations have to do with a presidential election?

title: Tree Rings Show a Period of Widespread Warming in Medieval Age
description: A new study of old tree rings shows that 1,000 years ago, long before power plants and sport utility vehicles, temperatures across North America, Europe and Asia rose in a period of unusual warmth.

title: 'Tosca' With a Sense Of Menace
description: Mark Lamos's 1998 updating of Puccini's ''Tosca,'' a staple of the New York City Opera repertory since 1998, returned to the New York State Theater on Saturday evening.

title: Peso Down Steeply, Argentines Strengthen Currency Curbs
description: With pressure on the already wobbly Argentine peso growing and an agreement with the International Monetary Fund still elusive, the government here today imposed strict new controls on the foreign exchange market. But it was unable to halt a panicky flight to the dollar by savers and investors.

title: Close to Departure Time, Maneuvers Continue Over Whether Arafat Can Travel
description: With a deadline looming, Israel, the Palestinians and the White House all were maneuvering tonight over the question of whether Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, would attend an Arab summit meeting in Beirut, Lebanon -- and how that might play into the effort to achieve a cease-fire.

title: Educators Offer Dire Warnings of School Budget Cuts' Effects
description: The school district covering Washington Heights, facing an $8.4 million cut, may have to drastically scale back remedial programs for newly arrived immigrant children and their parents and a Saturday program for students who want to earn high school credit.

title: Suozzi Proposes 20% Increase In Taxes For Nassau
description: Nassau homeowners and businesses face a record rise of at least 20 percent in the county portion of their property taxes next year, County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIN, NICHOLAS A.
description: MULLIN-Nicholas A. On March 25th, 2002. Former proprietor of Mullin's Lumber Co., Coney Island, NY. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Aiello). Loving father of Margaret Doerr, Rev. John A. Mullin, S.J., Susan Mikochik, Marianne Kavanaugh and Barbara Mullin. Cherished grandfather of Barbara Jean, Jennifer and Michael. Dear brother of William, Anna, Louise and the late Lucille, George and Theresa. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St., NY NY, Tuesday, 7-9 PM, and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Rite of Christian Burial Thursday, 11 AM, St. Francis Xavier R.C. Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Jesuit Seminary and Mission Bureau, 39 East 83rd Street, NY, NY 10028 or the charity of your choice.

title: Weapons Labs Close to Settling A Bias Boycott
description: The nation's three premier weapons laboratories have offered to change their hiring and promotion practices in exchange for the ending of a boycott by two Asian-American academic organizations, federal officials and the leader of the boycott said yesterday.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 9, Dies in Fall Under School Bus
description: A 9-year-old yeshiva student was run over and killed yesterday by a school bus he was running to catch in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Psychologists Get Prescription Pads And Furor Erupts
description: Psychologists are adept at diagnosing and treating mental illness. But unlike psychiatrists, who are medically trained, they have never been able to prescribe drugs for their suffering patients.

title: When a Buyer for Hospitals Has a Stake in Drugs It Buys
description: Dr. Tom Ferguson was puzzled when a patient on an IV drip of the antibiotic gentamicin suddenly experienced a sharp fall in blood pressure and a racing pulse. Then it happened to a second patient.

title: Diverticulosis, an Ill of the Affluent Life
description: Let me start with some good news for the many millions of people who have been told that they have diverticulosis and should avoid eating foods containing small seeds and that they should never eat nuts.

title: Philips and Nike In Joint Venture
description: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's largest maker of consumer electronics, and Nike, the world's leading maker of athletic shoes, said today that they had signed an agreement to develop audio sports products.

title: Director Defends C.D.C.'s Handling of Anthrax Attacks
description: Dr. Jeffrey P. Koplan, the departing director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, defended again yesterday his agency's handling of the anthrax attack and the way the investigation was communicated to the public.

title: Huskies Raise Their Game, Again
description: Sometimes the runs come early, sometimes they come late, but they always come. Each game this season, Connecticut has entered a luminous stretch when every rebound is seemingly plucked by friendly hands, when every pass appears to find soft reception, when every shot seems to sail into the basket.

title: Nets Want Martin To Control His Game
description: When Kenyon Martin hammered Orlando's Tracy McGrady in the head with a hard foul on Jan. 4 -- just two weeks after he fouled Karl Malone in the back of the head -- he carved his reputation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Utility Fires Strikers
description: The government-owned Korea Electric Power Corporation said it was dismissing nearly 4,000 workers after several thousand police officers broke up a protest rally on a university campus and arrested 381 of them. The corporation and the police decided to crack down as a strike by power company employees entered its fourth week. The workers are protesting plans to sell the company's regional power plants to private companies, which they fear will then lay off hundreds of employees. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Sampras's Dry Stretch Is Becoming a Drought
description: His body language told it all. Pete Sampras, the leader in Grand Slam titles, grabbed his equipment and, looking down, quickly headed for the exit on the Stadium Court at the Tennis Center at Crandon Park. The crowd at the Nasdaq-100 Open applauded politely as he left.

title: Rare Tumor Is Deceptive And Deadly
description: ''Do you have flushing?'' the gastroenterologist repeatedly asked my wife early last year. Days before, she had had a routine colonoscopy, and now the doctor was asking her if her face was turning bright red, and if she was sweating uncontrollably. Except for a few gastrointestinal problems over the years, Carol felt fine. But she wasn't. She had cancer.

Services today, 11AM, Temple Beth El, Stamford. Interment Temple Beth El Cemetery, Stamford, CT. The family will greet friends from 10:30AM until the service. Inquiries Leo P.
