title: World Court For War Crimes Inches Closer To Reality
description: The world's first permanent international court to try individuals charged with genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity may become a reality within the next few weeks, much sooner than expected, legal experts said today.

title: New Jersey Needs More Choices
description: New Jersey Republicans have now fielded six candidates for their party's senatorial nomination, the latest being Robert W. Ray, the former Whitewater independent counsel. None of them, including Mr. Ray, are particularly well known, but Republican voters will at least have a choice in New Jersey's June 4 primary. The same cannot be said of the Democrats, who have yet to produce anyone willing to challenge Senator Robert Torricelli, a two-term Democrat who is up for re-election.

title: Big Contracts Didn't Stop Bankruptcy
description: Dale Carter signed a four-year, $22.8 million contract with the Denver Broncos in 1999. He signed a five-year, $28 million contract with the New Orleans Saints two weeks ago.

title: Grizzlies Shock The Blazers
description: Rodney Buford scored 14 of his 20 points in the fourth quarter as the Memphis Grizzlies rallied from 19 points down in that period to stun the Portland Trail Blazers, 103-100, last night.

title: Talking About Dying
description: To the Editor:

title: Wild Things: Painted Faces on the Runway
description: ''One day we'll live by instinct alone.'' The words, offered like an incantation, appear in the March issue of i-D, the avant-garde British art and fashion monthly. They introduce a style portfolio photographed by Paolo Roversi, in which a succession of models wear the shredded, cat-spotted fashions of the day, their feral look accentuated by face paint with a fiercely primitive cast. The cover of the issue shows the model Devon Aoki, her delicate features crudely bisected by black and blue markings, a pattern of dots, stripes and wedges that recall a fearsome tribal mask.

title: I.R.S. Says Offshore Tax Evasion Is Widespread
description: The I.R.S. said yesterday that Americans in far greater numbers than it had once thought were evading taxes by secretly depositing money in tax havens like the Cayman Islands and withdrawing it using American Express, MasterCard and Visa cards.

title: Bishop Caught Up in Scandal Is Recalled as an Ideal Cleric
description: To many of the students at the Roman Catholic seminary he headed in Missouri, the Rev. Anthony J. O'Connell was a role model and a tireless salesman for religion, the priesthood and life itself. So successful was he at running St. Thomas Seminary that he was chosen bishop of Knoxville, Tenn., in 1988 and, a decade later, bishop of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday with a front-page article about the Bush administration's endorsement of nuclear technology promoted by the Exelon Corporation referred incorrectly in some copies to the lawmaker who has received the most in campaign contributions from Exelon since 1999. He is Representative Timothy V. Johnson, Republican of Illinois, not Senator Tim Johnson, who is a South Dakota Democrat.

title: U.S. to Send Special Forces To Train Army For Kabul
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld assigned the American military a complex new mission in Afghanistan today as he announced that Special Forces troops would begin training the new Afghan national army within the next six weeks.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Good News For Criminals
description: The country's highest court has ruled that a law allowing the state to take all of a criminal's assets as part of his punishment was unconstitutional. The law, passed in 1992, did not set an upper limit for punishment and thus was so vague that it did not meet the constitutional requirement to be clear, the court said. The ruling came in the case of a convicted drug trafficker who in 1994 was sentenced to three and a half years in prison and an additional $271,000 fine that came close to the value of all his assets.

title: Ex-Executive Sues Baker Hughes; Kickbacks Cited
description: A former executive of Baker Hughes, the oil field services company, contends in a lawsuit that the company paid kickbacks to win a major contract with a unit of Royal Dutch/Shell and that he was dismissed for refusing to go along with the arrangement.

title: Chapel Delays Its Closing At Towers Site
description: The leaders of St. Paul's Chapel in Lower Manhattan, which has served as a haven for rescue workers at ground zero since September, said yesterday that they had decided to keep it open until the excavation of the World Trade Center site was completed.

title: Migraine Sufferers Limit Their Options
description: Fewer than half the estimated 28 million migraine sufferers in the United States seek medical attention for the ailment, a new study has found.

title: Discussing the Nature of Reality, Between Buffets
description: The secret of the universe was not discovered here the other weekend, but it was fun trying.

title: 2 Acquitted of Killing Georgia Sheriff
description: Two men accused of killing a newly elected Georgia sheriff 15 months ago were acquitted today, raising questions about whether anyone -- including the chief suspect, former Sheriff Sidney Dorsey -- would be convicted in the case.

title: Serna Is the MetroStars' No. 71, With a Bullet
description: It is a pretty safe bet that the MetroStars' DIEGO SERNA is the only player in the history of soccer to set foot on a field wearing jersey No. 71.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Games By the Bay?
description: Gov. Gray Davis signed a bill pledging $250 million in state money for a bid by San Francisco for the 2012 Olympic Games. The money will be unnecessary if the effort is privately financed, as expected. But the pledge strengthens the city in competing with New York, Washington and Houston, which have similar pledges. California last held the Games in 1984, in Los Angeles. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: Bad Hair Night
description: From the vantage of style, the 74th annual Academy Awards served as a rebuke to mothers everywhere who told their daughters that life would prove more rewarding if they always remembered to comb their hair before they left the house.

title: New Standards Mean Korean Air Is Coming Off Many 'Shun' Lists
description: When Korean Air brought in David Greenberg, a retired Delta Air Lines vice president, to run its operations two years ago, he was given a tall order: rescuing the airline from international disgrace.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about the University of St. Mary of the Lake omitted the names of three seminarians at a dining table and misidentified a fourth man in some copies. The three at the table, from the left, were Steve Roberts, John Fain and Jerry Arano-Ponce. The fourth man was Deacon Burke Masters, not the Rev. Robert Barron.

title: Tunnel Vision; A $60 Subway Ride? Maybe, but He's Fighting It
description: Saturday, March 9, was not such a bad day at the Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens. It was almost balmy, and during the 47th running of the Stymie Handicap, a horse named Ground Storm -- ''elusive of a win,'' as they say in racing -- outran the favorite, paying $3.80 for a $2 bet.

title: Four Ways To Get Fans To Dance
description: There are lots of different ways to make an audience dance: you can coax, you can demand or you can lead by example. On Thursday night, Blackalicious, Spearhead, Nikka Costa and Karl Denson came to the Hammerstein Ballroom -- four groove-oriented acts, with four different approaches to making people dance.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ebay Says Inquiry Is Closed
description: EBay, the online auction house, said in its annual report that the Justice Department had ended its antitrust investigation of the company without taking any action. In 1999, eBay sued a Massachusetts company, Bidder's Edge, asserting that the company had trespassed on eBay's computer servers when it listed eBay's search results on BiddersEdge.com. Bidder's Edge denied the claim and accused eBay of violating antitrust laws by monopolizing or trying to monopolize a market. In March 2001, the companies settled the dispute for an undisclosed sum. The inquiry examined eBay's licensing program and the lawsuit against Bidder's Edge. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Governor Wants Prosecutor Out
description: A lawyer for Gov. Don Siegelman, a Democrat, said he would ask the Justice Department to remove the United States attorney, Leura Garrett Canary, from an investigation of the governor because her husband is a Republican political aide. The lawyer, David Cromwell Johnson, said Mrs. Canary's office was in effect controlled by her husband, William J. Canary, who has worked for the Republican candidate for governor, Lt. Gov. Steve Windom. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Japanese Political Watchdog Now Finds Herself Accused
description: When Kiyomi Tsujimoto stood on the floor of Parliament in Japan last May and repeatedly shouted ''Mr. Prime Minister!'' a dozen times, she earned herself far more than the standard 15 minutes of fame.

title: Police Search Home and Business of Brooklyn Man Hurt in Pipe Bomb Blast
description: Detectives searched the home, business and car of a Brooklyn man whose lower right leg was blown off by a pipe bomb explosion on Sunday, seizing wire, metal connectors and business records yesterday, law enforcement officials said.

title: Dorothy DeLay, Teacher of Many of the World's Leading Violinists, Dies at 84
description: Dorothy DeLay, one of the world's most famous teachers of the violin and a mentor to two generations of players ranging from Itzhak Perlman to Midori and Sarah Chang, died on Sunday. She was 84 and lived in Upper Nyack, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the announcement by North and South Korea that they would resume a long-stalled dialogue misspelled the surname of a spokeswoman for the State Department who said the United States welcomed and supported the move. She is Jo-Anne Prokopowicz, not Prokopowitz.

title: Pakistani Plotted to Bomb Florida Power Plants, Officials Say
description: Federal immigration officials have arrested and are seeking to deport a young Pakistani immigrant who they say plotted last spring to blow up power plants and other sites in South Florida, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Hockey Safety Debate Lands at the Garden
description: This was her first hockey game. He was a Rangers fan who had sat several times in the cheaper seats near the ceiling at Madison Square Garden. But when somebody gave Laszlo Tokolyi two free tickets in the seventh row near one of the nets, he persuaded his wife, Gyongyi, to go see the Rangers play the Detroit Red Wings on March 17. A handyman at an apartment building, Tokolyi does not often have $120 seats to see the Rangers play the best team in the National Hockey League.

title: Romania and Bulgaria Edge Nearer to NATO Membership
description: A year ago, the idea that Romania and Bulgaria might join NATO this autumn in the next round of enlargement seemed laughable, and many thought that the aspirations of the Baltic nations for NATO membership might be held hostage again to relations with Moscow.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Crackdown On Scofflaw Diplomats
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would support towing the cars of scofflaw diplomats, if it were found to be legal. But his administration is also looking into enforcement of a federal plan that would withhold foreign aid to countries whose diplomatic missions have cars with unpaid tickets. Officials say the city provides enough diplomatic parking places that diplomats should not have to park illegally and disrupt traffic patterns.

title: Verizon Shifts Debt To Longer Terms
description: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it sold $1.5 billion of bonds with maturities as long as 30 years. Credit-rating companies have recently said the company relied too much on short-term debt.

title: Unions Win Dues Ruling On Appeal
description: In a decision that will bolster union organizing, a federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled yesterday that employees at unionized workplaces cannot withhold the part of their union payments that finance organizing drives.

title: Food Aid for Afghans Way Short of Need, U.N. Agency Says
description: Despite pledges from many nations to help the people of Afghanistan, governments have given the World Food Program barely 5 percent of the $285 million in emergency aid it needs to feed people there for the rest of the year, says the agency's director, Catherine Bertini.

title: Inbound Holland Tunnel Remains Closed as Fire Lingers
description: City and state officials said today that the Holland Tunnel, closed to Manhattan-bound traffic for three days because of a stubborn fire at a vacant warehouse here, would remain closed to eastbound traffic at least through the Tuesday morning rush and possibly longer.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about women who were soldiers in the Civil War misstated the number of dead in the battle of Antietam. It was at least 3,650; the casualty figure of more than 22,000 included wounded, missing and captured.

title: AMERICA WEST REDUCES SOME FARES BY AS MUCH AS 70%
description: America West Airlines cut fares as much as 70 percent on tickets purchased shortly before travel and ended a required Saturday night stay to make business flying cheaper and attract more last-minute leisure passengers. The airline, a unit of America West Holdings, cut the number of days tickets must be bought in advance to get lower fares. A rival, the U.S. Airways Group, matched the moves in some markets. America West expects the changes, effective yesterday, to bring in more passengers at a higher average price.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Europe Adopts Internet Suffix
description: The European Union's Council of Telecommunications Ministers adopted a regulation yesterday to create a new .eu suffix for Internet addresses. The .eu extension has been approved by the European Parliament and the organization responsible for the Internet's address system, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, but several procedural hurdles remain. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: A Los Angeles Suburb Climbs Out of the Doldrums
description: In this once rundown and gang-ridden outpost south of Los Angeles, the new white picket fences bordering frontyards on street after street are just one sign of a citywide makeover that is as pervasive as the plummeting crime rate. The flower beds are another.

title: Bombs and Quakes
description: Q. Could the bombing of Afghanistan have resulted in recent earthquakes there?

title: The Most Seductive Equation in Science: Beauty Equals Truth
description: In the fall of 1915, Albert Einstein, living amid bachelor clutter on coffee, tobacco and loneliness in Berlin, was close to scrawling the final touches to a new theory of gravity that he had pursued through mathematical and logical labyrinths for nearly a decade. But first he had to see what his theory had to say about the planet Mercury, whose puzzling orbit around the Sun defied the Newtonian correctness that had long ruled the cosmos and science. The result was a kind of cosmic ''boing'' that changed his life.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Court Upholds Napster Ruling
description: A federal court, upholding a lower court decision, ruled yesterday that Napster could not resume its free online music sharing service until it could be certain that the service would not be used to swap copyrighted songs owned by the major record labels. The ruling, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, has little effect because Napster has not tried to resume the service, which it took offline in July, after it was found guilty of aiding in copyright infringement. Since then, Napster has focused on a pay service, which would sell music licensed from record companies. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Mount Sinai Hospital's response to criticism over the death of a healthy liver donor misstated an action the hospital had taken. The hospital will no longer allow first-year residents to work in the transplant ward. It will not prohibit other residents from working there.

title: Islanders Put the Rangers in Playoff Peril
description: If the Rangers were in the Islanders' position right now, with a playoff spot nearly secured, tonight's 4-2 defeat would not have hurt so much. But because the Rangers have squandered so many points this season, because the regular season is winding down and because they were less than seven minutes from a victory they sorely needed, this loss verged on being unbearable.

title: When a Polar Bear Needs a Pedicure
description: ''It's not necessarily gross,'' said Bruce Schwendeman as he snipped the tendons of a freeze-dried red-tailed hawk. He paused to wipe his bloody hands on his denim apron and looked up at his 77-year-old father, David, who was preparing a Cooper's hawk as flaccid as a rubber chicken.

title: Walker Hoping to Be Part Of the Mets' Bullpen Mix
description: As Manager Bobby Valentine was recapping a day late in spring training five years ago, he reported that an obscure pitcher who spent most of that camp filling out crossword puzzles in front of his locker had pitched like a surgeon.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: XEROX CORP., Stamford, Conn., the copier maker, said it had won a $250 million contract to provide printers, scanning devices, software and services to Broadlane Inc., Santa Barbara, Calif., a group purchasing organization for hospitals and health care providers.

title: A Fractious Family's Decline, With Vintage Mustiness
description: A heady aroma, as specific and elusive as childhood memories, seems to rise from the monologues that make up ''The Carpetbagger's Children,'' the new play by Horton Foote. It brings to mind a mixed perfume of lavender, hard candy, mothballs, talcum powder and maybe vanilla extract.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Police Seize Kashmiri Separatist
description: The Indian police arrested the leader of a Kashmiri separatist group during his press briefing in Srinagar, capital of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. Yasin Malik, head of the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front, was arrested a day after the police arrested a woman who said she was ferrying $100,000 for Mr. Malik from a Pakistan-based leader of his group. Mr. Malik denied the charge. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONRAD, FRANCES
description: CONRAD-Frances. A memorial for Frances Conrad will be held at the Shelter Rock Public Library, 165 Searingtown Road, Albertson 11507, on Sunday, April 7, at 11 AM, 516-248-7363.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERMAIN, LAWRENCE
description: GERMAIN-Lawrence. 11th Anniversary I wished upon a star last night I dreamt that it came true What I wished for was an hour just to sit and talk to you You have crossed the golden river to a shore forever green Each day I long to see you But God's river runs between As long as hearts keep beating As long as our eyes shed tears I will always love and miss you No matter how many years No one knows the heartache of what your parting cost but God in all His glory has gained what I have lost By your ever loving wife Sheila

title: Albany Bills Would Require Clergy to Report Any Abuse
description: The Republican-led State Senate announced plans today to pass a bill on Tuesday that would add members of the clergy to the list of people who would be required to report suspected child abuse. The Assembly introduced a similar measure today, but will not vote on it immediately, Assembly officials said.

title: Army Secretary Discloses More Phone Calls on Enron
description: Secretary of the Army Thomas E. White has told Congressional investigators that he had six additional contacts -- beyond the seven he had already acknowledged -- with former colleagues at Enron last October. During that month, he sold about $3 million of Enron stock just after the company began to dribble out negative disclosures that ultimately led it to seek bankruptcy protection in December.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Catholic Bishop Arrested
description: A 67-year-old Roman Catholic Bishop of the ''underground'' church has been arrested, according to a religious rights monitor. Bishop Julius Jia Zhiguo of Hebei Province in central China previously spent some 20 years in jail or labor camps for insisting on loyalty to the Vatican. In recent years he was often under house arrest but last week unidentified authorities picked him up and his whereabouts are unknown, said the Cardinal Kung Foundation, based in Stamford, Conn. The police frequently harass priests and worshipers who refuse to accept the authority of the Government-affiliated Catholic church, and Bishop Jia, who was ordained by the pope in 1980, is one of dozens of Catholic leaders who are jailed or under virtual house arrest. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Those Daring, Dueling and Darling Arts
description: Panoply, pageantry and patriotism are only a few of the ingredients. Add humor and hype, daring and dancing, and still the list is incomplete. Yes, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus is back in town, and more than a few potent nouns and adjectives must be marshaled to sum up the 132nd edition of the spectacle that lays not entirely immodest claim to the description Greatest Show on Earth.

title: 6 Are Accused of Forcing Girls From Mexico Into Prostitution
description: Four people, including two sisters, were charged today with a scheme in which, prosecutors said, teenage girls were smuggled into the United States from poor Mexican villages after whirlwind courtships and promises of marriage, only to be forced into prostitution in two New Jersey towns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAY, DOROTHY
description: DeLAY-Dorothy. The Juilliard community deeply mourns the death of Dorothy DeLay, distinguished member of the violin faculty from 1948 to the time of her death. From a lifetime dedicated to nurturing generations of young violinists, her legacy lives on in the presence of great violinists as soloists, chamber musicians, orchestral members and teachers throughout the world. The excellence of The Juilliard School exists, in part, through her presence and dedication. Our condolences go to her beloved husband, Edward Newhouse, her children, Jeffrey and Alison, and her grandchildren. A memorial service at Juilliard is planned for the late spring. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President Stephen Clapp, Dean

title: Knicks Can't Hold Lead, Even Against Nuggets
description: For a few fleeting moments last night, the fans at Madison Square Garden forgot that the Knicks' season had become meaningless. They forgot that this will be the franchise's first team to miss the playoffs in 15 seasons or that a large Knicks lead is as secure as priceless jewelry in an open vault.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suspect Holds Son Hostage, Then Gives Up
description: A man wanted in a New Jersey murder investigation held his 3-year-old son hostage for four hours yesterday in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, before surrendering to the police, the authorities said. No one was injured. The man, Vincent Nguyen, is a suspect in the killing of Tuan N. Thieu, 20, of Bloomfield, N.J., who was shot to death on Sunday, the police said. Around 1 p.m. yesterday, officers from the Somerset County prosecutor's office went to the apartment of the man's girlfriend on Lafayette Avenue, and Mr. Nguyen refused to come out, the police said. City police officers, including hostage negotiators, were called to the scene. After several hours, Mr. Nguyen and another man walked out with the toddler. Emergency Service Unit officers took the child, and the two men were taken into custody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLOFF, SARAH
description: SOKOLOFF-Sarah. Widow of Herman, passed away in Boca Raton, FL March 23, 2002. Formerly of Stuyvesantown, NY. A loving wife & aunt. Survived by nephews, nieces, great and great-great nephews & nieces. Graveside services Tuesday, March 26, at Beth-David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWEN, LOUIS W.
description: BOWEN-Louis W., March 22, 2002. Businessman, interior designer, long associated with the Winter Antiques Show. Born in Los Angeles in 1914, he attended UCLA until 1936 when he was hired by Dorothy Hammerstein as her interior design assistant. When Mrs. Hammerstein reopened her business in NYC in 1939, he came to New York as her partner. A World War II Navy veteran, trained as a medical assistant, he was always pleased that his ward was chosen to be shown to Eleanor Roosevelt when she visited wounded servicemen in the South Pacific. He returned from active duty to open his own business, Louis W. Bowen, Inc., to manufacture specialty wall coverings. He operated this business for 40 years while continuing to create interior designs for many clients. He served as Chair of The Winter Antiques Show in 1970-71 and 1976; as co-chair, in 1995; and as a Board member of East Side House Settlement, the Show's beneficiary, since 1968. Active and acutely witty until his death at home, he was beloved by his many friends. There are no surviving family members. Funeral arrangements are private. A memorial service will be held at The Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Ave., Wednesday, April 17, 2002 at 4 P.M.

title: U.S., Alarmed by Corrosion, Orders Checking of Reactors
description: Nuclear reactor operators have been ordered to check their reactor vessels after the discovery that acid in cooling water had eaten a hole nearly all the way through the six-inch-thick lid of a reactor at a plant in Ohio. The corrosion left only a stainless-steel liner less than a half-inch thick to hold in cooling water under more than 2,200 pounds of pressure per square inch.

title: Bill Would Make It Easier To Sue Over Lead Poisoning
description: More than half the members of the City Council introduced a bill yesterday that would rewrite a 1999 lead-poisoning prevention law to make it easier for the parents of children with lead poisoning to sue their landlords.

title: Hollywood History and Fantasy
description: It took only a little imagination to see the weight of what he called ''the difficult years'' in the ferocity of Sidney Poitier's gaze on Sunday night at the Academy Awards. Mr. Poitier stood at the microphone, almost as erect a figure as the honorary Oscar he was holding, and looked out over the audience directly into the viewer's eye. He paid homage to directors and producers who had helped him make his way in an industry that has been racially divided and racially impenitent for most of its history. And last night he was able to watch two African-American actors, Denzel Washington and Halle Berry, win Oscars for their leading performances.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Pilot Priest Found Dead In Plane Wreck
description: A Roman Catholic priest who served one of the largest parishes in the world was found dead in the wreckage of his plane on a mountainside near Dillingham. The Rev. James Kelley, 73, a pilot, had been missing since Saturday, when he left Dillingham for Togiak and King Salmon, where he was planning to hold Palm Sunday services. Father Kelley served a 160,000-square-mile parish in western Alaska. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Top Prosecutor Names His Aide
description: United States Attorney Christopher J. Christie yesterday named Ralph J. Marra Jr., a 17-year veteran criminal prosecutor in the office, as his first assistant. Mr. Christie's previous choice, Walter F. Timpone, a former top prosecutor now in private practice, withdrew from consideration two weeks ago after other federal officials questioned his candor about a meeting with Senator Robert G. Torricelli. The senator was the subject of a criminal investigation at the time, which ended without any charges being brought. The choice of Mr. Marra appears to address concerns that Mr. Christie lacked criminal prosecutorial experience while avoiding the controversy of the Timpone appointment.

title: Accounts
description: i3Mobile, Stamford, Conn., a wireless media company, to Draft Worldwide, New York, to handle the account of Pronto, a new voice-activated information subscription service. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Draft is part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: In Awful Year for Industry, 2 Airlines Make Strides
description: In a year when the aviation industry suffered $15 billion in losses worldwide and two venerable European flag carriers went bankrupt, Turkish Airlines defied the odds by earning a slim profit, the company reported today.

title: An Upgraded Role for Stress Tests
description: As a rule, doctors give stress tests only to patients who have symptoms of heart disease like chest pain. But two new studies suggest that use of the tests, in which heart function is measured as a patient uses a treadmill, should be expanded.

title: Justices Ponder Next Step in Reshaping Sentencing System
description: The Supreme Court unleashed a potential revolution in criminal sentencing two years ago when it ruled that only the jury, and not a judge, could find a defendant eligible for a sentence above the range the legislature had specified for a crime.

title: A Strangely Cool and Eloquent Use of Arms
description: The dances presented by Lydia Johnson and her company on Saturday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church stood out for their simplicity and quiet depth of abstracted feeling. Ms. Johnson trained with major New York teachers but has worked in New Jersey, where her troupe is based. That distance from the hectic, cliquish New York dance scene may have been a good thing for her. She is on to something, and that something is entirely her own.

title: Medical Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, HENRY J.
description: KRAMER-Henry J. On March 23, 2002. Beloved husband of Louise, loving father of Benjamin. Services Tuesday, 2:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Notes From St. Louis; Loving the Cardinals as They Are
description: This is the ultimate baseball town. When the Cardinals open their 127th season next week, the beloved Busch Stadium will be awash in a standing-room-only sea of red and white, a Norman Rockwell portrait of a sport now noted more for slicing the revenue pie than for apple pie. The athletes on the field may be multimillionaires, but the stands in St. Louis will be filled with extras from ''Field of Dreams.''

title: Students Won't Debate? Turn Off the TV!
description: To the Editor:

title: Spreading the Blame at Andersen
description: Arthur Andersen, Enron's accounting firm, went public last week with a campaign to free itself of accountability for whatever its Houston-based partners may have done to abet the cooking of Enron's books. At rallies in Houston, Washington and elsewhere, and in full-page advertisements in national newspapers, Andersen's 28,000 United States employees offer the defense that in effect, they are innocent bystanders. It is unfair, they say, to punish the entire firm for the acts of a few miscreants.

title: Questioning the Moralist
description: To the Editor:

title: Victims' Kin May Be Able To Hear Tape From Plane
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was strongly leaning toward allowing families of the victims of United Flight 93, the hijacked plane that crashed in western Pennsylvania on Sept. 11, to listen to the tape from the jet's cockpit voice recorder at a private briefing next month in New Jersey.

title: Lewis-Tyson Goes to Memphis
description: After two months of negotiation, a deal has finally been reached to put Mike Tyson in a ring with Lennox Lewis in Memphis on June 8. It could be the most lucrative bout in boxing history, the fight's organizers said yesterday.

title: Nature, Red in Tooth and Claw
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: Andersen's Chief Quits In Bid to Rescue the Firm

title: The Man Who Paid the Price For Sizing Up Enron
description: Enron executives pressed UBS PaineWebber to take action against a broker who advised some Enron employees to sell their shares in August and was fired by the brokerage firm within hours of the complaint, according to e-mail messages released today by Congressional investigators.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Restates Results
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to restate nearly $1 billion in revenue related to products and licensing agreements lasting longer than one year. The company attributed the mistakes for the quarters ended Sept. 30 and Dec. 31, 2001, to a clerical error. Microsoft waits to report part of its revenue from software sales until it ''earns'' the money by shipping interim upgrades and repairs of flaws and supplying customer support services. In the case of Windows, the company typically defers 15 percent to 25 percent of revenue and then books that amount over three years. Microsoft now says it recognized $1.879 billion in deferred revenue in the September quarter and booked $2.069 billion of ''unearned revenue.'' It originally recognized $914 million and added $1.104 billion during the period. The company said, however, that its net cash from operations and net change in cash and equivalents were unaffected. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Financial Acquisition
description: The Brascan Corporation has offered to buy the 30 percent of the Trilon Financial Corporation that it does not already own for 776 million Canadian dollars ($490 million) in cash and stock. Trilon, which specializes in merchant banking and asset management, will change its name to the Brascan Financial Corporation. Brascan owns 50 percent of the Brookfield Properties Corporation, one of North America's most powerful developers of commercial real estate. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Wagner Leads Memphis Into the N.I.T. Title Game
description: Dajuan Wagner, the Memphis freshman sensation, didn't play like a young man in a hurry to end his collegiate career or accept the inevitable millions from the N.B.A. The ''will he stay or will he go'' debate will surely resume later, but for now Wagner will have to focus on his team's appearance in a National Invitation Tournament championship game, something he made possible.

title: In a Debut, a Broadway Singer Makes an Art of Insight
description: It is the rare singer who can negotiate the tricky, stream-of-consciousness folk-pop lyrics of Joni Mitchell, the art songs of Adam Guettel and traditional popular standards like ''Come Rain or Come Shine'' with equal insight and authority. But Judy Kuhn, the Broadway singer who has appeared in ''Chess,'' ''Les Misrables'' and ''She Loves Me,'' did exactly that in her revelatory cabaret debut at the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center on Saturday evening.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPMAN, SAMUEL
description: LIPMAN-Samuel. We miss you and love you very much. Larry, Beth, Reed, Samara and Donna

title: World Briefing | World: No Progress On Tobacco Curbs
description: Negotiators meeting in Geneva to draft a global treaty curbing tobacco use wrapped up their fourth round of talks without making progress on any issues, including a ban on advertising, compensation for people with tobacco-related illnesses and incentives for tobacco farmers to shift to other crops. The treaty, which the World Health Organization wants to complete by May 2003, will be taken up again in October. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Federal Interference in Assisted Suicide
description: The state of Oregon and the Bush administration collided in court last week on the sensitive issue of physician-assisted suicide. The hearing provided sad evidence of the administration's willingness to misuse a law designed to control illicit drugs to prevent doctors from carrying out the wishes of Oregon voters that lethal drugs be provided to terminally ill patients under tightly regulated circumstances.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on March 18 about a coming series of articles in The Atlantic Monthly on the cleanup of the World Trade Center site gave an erroneous figure from the magazine for the length of an earlier article and thus misstated the comparative rank of the new one. Robert Caro's excerpt from the first volume of his biography of Lyndon B. Johnson, which appeared in 1981 and 1982, was a five-part series with 93,000 words, not 55,000. That makes it the longest nonfiction series in the magazine's history. The World Trade Center article -- three parts by William Langewiesche, totaling 60,000 words -- will not be the longest, although it is the longest piece of journalism commissioned directly by the magazine.

title: BOISE CASCADE EXPECTS LARGER FIRST-QUARTER LOSS
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, the paper and lumber maker, said an expected loss in the first quarter would be wider than analysts' forecasts because of falling paper prices and expenses from production cuts. The loss will be 15 cents to 20 cents a share, the company said. Boise Cascade, which is based in Boise, Idaho, was expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call, to lose 3 cents a share. Boise's average price for products like newsprint and copier paper fell about $15 a ton from the fourth quarter, the company said. Paper makers slowed production and closed plants as demand slowed with the economy. Boise cut paper output by 60,000 tons, or 2 percent, in the quarter.

title: Our Towns; Taking On Speeders, Personally
description: YOU'VE got to admire the way this state goes after speeders. Everyone gets into the act.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8, 13

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a warehouse fire that closed part of the Holland Tunnel misstated the name of the Jersey City official who said that there would be no investigation because of the nature of the damage. He was Jose Cruz, the deputy fire director, not Capt. Jim Whalen.

title: Some Inbound Holland Tunnel Lanes Reopen
description: Transportation officials partly reopened the Holland Tunnel to Manhattan-bound traffic this evening, five days after a still-smoldering fire at a nearby warehouse forced its closing.

title: From Brazil's Backlands, a Master of a Folk Tradition
description: For an artist whose work has been exhibited in the Louvre and the Smithsonian Institution, Jos Francisco Borges labors in humble surroundings. His studio occupies a corner of a drafty adobe warehouse that has crumbling walls, smells of printer's ink and lies just off a dusty highway here in the arid interior of northeast Brazil.

title: Writing to Sell
description: It is not unusual for an author to try to give sales of his book a little nudge. Disguising himself as an ordinary customer, the anxious author will regularly visit bookstores to make sure his book is in stock and properly displayed, buying a couple of copies here and there in the hopes that others will follow his lead. But recently David A. Vise, author of ''The Bureau and the Mole,'' has taken this kind of furtive self-promotion to a new level.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Guerrillas Fight Each Other
description: Rival groups of ethnic Albanian guerrillas waged a fierce nighttime battle, killing two fighters and wounding five bystanders. Many experts had predicted a wave of violence between Albanians who support a peace plan signed with the government last summer and those who advocate continued armed struggle. The leader of the National Liberation Army, which signed the deal, called the other group, the Albanian National Armada, criminals who will be ''denounced, isolated and driven away.'' The Armada reportedly attacked in an effort to free six prisoners held by its rival. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: President Chooses 2 for Leading Posts in Health
description: Moving to fill two important health positions, President Bush today announced his nomination of an Arizona trauma surgeon to be surgeon general and an administrator at Johns Hopkins University to lead the National Institutes of Health.

title: A Historical Chateau, Again Fit for Kings
description: CHTEAU LAFITE is an old country home; Chteau Palmer is a fortress. Mouton-Rothschild could be an estate in the hills above Santa Barbara. But Chteau d'Issan? Issan is the original gingerbread castle. It could well be the most beautiful chateau in the Mdoc, the storied wine country north of Bordeaux.

description: Jody Sperling

Belfer, Chairperson Albert Einstein College of Medicine Board of Overseers

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Holy Thursday, Good Friday and the first and second days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: NETS TO SELL TICKETS
description: Nets playoff tickets will go on sale Saturday at 10 a.m. Tickets can be purchased in a block of seven games, the maximum number of possible home games in Rounds 1 and 2, or as individual tickets for Round 1, which will be available only for upper-level seats.

title: Business Travel; Offering goldfish to treadmills, many hotels are striving to appeal to corporate guests.
description: NOTE to Willy Loman: The business travel routine has changed a bit since those grim road trips and lonesome hotel room trysts that push a sad undercurrent through Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman.''

title: Unlikely Allies Against Cloning
description: New genetic technologies may someday reshape human life, but they're already reconfiguring decades-old boundaries of partisan politics. This was made clear last week when a broad coalition of environmentalists, feminists and other progressives released an open letter urging the Senate to ban reproductive cloning and to place a moratorium on therapeutic cloning. That position differs radically from legislation sponsored by Senators Ted Kennedy and Dianne Feinstein that would allow medical researchers to proceed with creating cloned embryonic cells. It is arguably closer to the stance of most conservative Republicans, who want a permanent ban on all forms of cloning.

title: Nassau Copies City Program For Computer Crime-Fighting
description: Nassau County's crime rate is already much lower than New York City's, but officials here are borrowing the city's latest crime-fighting techniques to drive it even lower.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Military Concern Names Executive
description: The military contractor BAE Systems said John Weston would resign as chief executive immediately. Michael Turner, BAE's chief operating officer, will succeed him. Mr. Weston became chief executive of BAE in May 1998 and led the company's transformation from British Aerospace, which mainly focused on its home market, to an international military contractor. Mr. Weston said that after more than 30 years with the company, he wanted ''fresh challenges.'' Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNING, URSULA
description: CORNING-Ursula. On March 20, 2002, in her 99th year, died peacefully in her sleep. Interment private. Memorial services at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. at 90th St., Monday, April 8, 11 AM.

title: Quinnipiac Receives $2 Million
description: Quinnipiac University in Hamden, Conn., has received a $2 million pledge from HELEN D. BLAKE, a 1951 graduate, and her husband, S. PRESTLEY BLAKE, a founder of Friendly Ice Cream. The pledge will be used to establish an endowed scholarship fund for liberal arts students. As a result of the donation, the university will also name its recently constructed Liberal Arts Center after the late ROBERT W. EVANS, a longtime dean at Quinnipiac whom Mrs. Blake had as a professor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, LUCILLE F.
description: COHEN-Lucille F. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Gilbert with his wife Andrea, Michael and the late Carol. Adored grandmother of Wendi and Alanna. Cherished sister of Sid Frank, Elaine Kranis and the late Herb Frank and Frankie Marx. Services Wednesday, March 27th, 9:30AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opp LIRR), Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANSING, ELIZABETH HUBBARD
description: LANSING-Elizabeth Hubbard, 90. Died March 21 at home in Cornwall, CT after a short illness. She had returned to her childhood home with her late husband Tod Lansing in 1979. Born in Providence in 1911 Mrs. Lansing was the daughter of William Brewster Hubbard and Martha Hale Hubbard. She attended St. Margaret's School in Waterbury, CT and the Agnes Irwin School in Philadelphia. She earned a B.S. degree from Simmons College in library science in 1933. She formed an association with Thomas Y. Crowell Publishers and with her editor the late Elizabeth M. Riley which lasted her whole career and inspired the publication of over 45 children's books of fiction and biography. In the 1960's she was a featured instructor for the famous Writers School in Westport. During the past 26 years she had been an instructor for the Institute for Children's Literature in Redding Ridge. She was working on her students' lessons the week she died. Tod Lansing died in 1997. Mrs. Lansing's three brothers and a sister survive her: William B. Hubbard of Newark, DE; Lydia H. Wolf of Cornwall; Gordon H. Hubbard of Tucson, AZ; and Thomas J. Hubbard of Bronxville, NY and Cornwall. Also surviving are her children Lisa Lansing Simont of Cornwall; Lydia B. Lansing of Bartlett, NH; Robert T. E. Lansing of Lake Forest, IL; and Mary H. Lansing of Mill Valley, CA. She had six grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service is planned for the summer. Gifts in memory of Mrs. Lansing may be sent to: The Cornwall Library Association, Box 126, Cornwall, CT. 06753.

title: Funny Round Ball Hits Oklahoma
description: Oklahoma fans have a decision to make: which Final Four to attend? The women's basketball team is headed to San Antonio for its first Final Four appearance, and the men's team is going to Atlanta for its first since 1988.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, SAM
description: WEINBERG-Sam. Died Sunday at the age of 93 in FL. Predeceased by his beloved wife, Sylvia and mourned by his daughter Arlene, son Stanley, his grandchildren Sharon, Mark, Scott, and Elisa, and great-grandson, Seth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMLO, PETER L.
description: RAMLO-Peter L. Of Bloomfield, New Jersey, suddenly on March 20, 2002. Loving brother and uncle. Cherished friend of many. He will be greatly missed. Services are in Decorah, Iowa. Contributions to In God's Name We Deliver and City Meals on Wheels.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 1 about Bernard Green, a founder of the Eastern Newsstand Corporation, omitted the names of his partners. He was not the sole founder; Stanley M. Jordan, who died in 1979, was a partner in various enterprises, including Eastern Newsstand, from 1947 until 1976. They had another partner, Harry Diamond, from 1950 to 1953.

title: 40,000 Kennedy Photo Negatives Missing After Attack
description: For five months, Thomasina Lowe waited and hoped that an indelible part of her father's legacy had managed to survive the inferno that raged for four days inside 5 World Trade Center after Sept. 11.

title: Killings of Journalists Rose In 2001 From the Year Before
description: The world was a far more dangerous place for journalists in 2001 than it had been the year before, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists.

title: Court Says Agency Can Tighten Smog Rules
description: An appeals court ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency could strengthen smog rules for the first time since 1979, and enforce the first-ever regulation of the smallest soot particles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, IRWIN L.
description: TURNER-Irwin L. Died on March 19, 2002 at the Hospice of Palm Beach, after a long illness, of heart disease. Irwin was born in Pittsburgh, PA, January 27, 1922. Beloved husband of Dolly, cherished father of Nancy and Charles, daughter-in-law Alexandra and adoring grandfather of Natasha, Piers and William. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 28, 2002 at 11 A.M., at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Main Street, Woodbury, CT.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Package From Linux Distributor
description: Red Hat, the distributor of the Linux operating system, introduced a package for computer servers yesterday and said that more than 20 software developers had agreed to support it. The package, Red Hat Linux Advanced Server, will be marketed to large companies that now use Microsoft's Windows or versions of the Unix platform like Sun Microsystems' Solaris. Companies use such computer servers to store data and send information to Web pages. Red Hat is based in Raleigh, N.C. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: ARAFAT SAYS FEAR OF EXILE WILL KEEP HIM FROM MEETING
description: Yasir Arafat declared today that he would not attend an Arab summit meeting in Beirut after Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel said he wanted the right to prevent Mr. Arafat from returning to the West Bank.

description: Get ready for Round 2 of Ranger Governance versus Computer Associates International.

description: The Bush administration devised a successful strategy for winning the war in Afghanistan. An equally effective plan for securing the peace is now urgently needed. Unfortunately, no coherent policy is yet in sight.

description: Laurels

title: READER'S DIGEST INVESTOR RAISES BID FOR A STAKE
description: Highfields Capital Management, one of the largest investors in the Reader's Digest Association Inc., raised its offer to buy the controlling stake owned by Wallace-Reader's Digest Funds to $165.5 million. Highfields is offering to exchange each of its Class A nonvoting shares and $5 in cash for each of the 6.2 million Class B voting shares owned by the funds, Highfields said. An official at Wallace-Reader's Digest Funds had said an earlier offer to exchange the shares and $3 in cash was ''not attractive.'' Highfields wants control of Reader's Digest to change the company's strategy from making acquisitions to growing or selling existing businesses.

title: Towns With Odd Jobs Galore Turn to Inmates
description: For generations, convicts have made license plates or gone out, sometimes in chains, to clean roads and clear ditches. But in recent years struggling rural communities like this one have relied more and more on inmates to do jobs that public employees once did: tending cemeteries, cleaning courthouse restrooms, moving furniture, renovating municipal buildings and even running errands for the police.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metropolitan Diary on March 18 about a poem titled ''A 13-Year-Old's Wish List'' omitted credit for the poem that inspired it. That poem was ''If I Were in Charge of the World,'' written by Judith Viorst in 1981.

title: Coast Guard Says Extra Tasks Stretch Harbor Safety Thin
description: The Port of New York is vulnerable to a terrorist attack in the aftermath of Sept. 11 and its existing security safeguards are stretched thin, speakers at a Congressional hearing said yesterday.

title: Egan Condemns Sexual Abuse in a Speech to Priests
description: Cardinal Edward M. Egan repeated his message yesterday condemning the sexual abuse of children by priests, this time to a special audience: more than 300 men in flowing white robes who had come to St. Patrick's Cathedral to recommit themselves to the priesthood.

title: TOLL IN THOUSANDS POSSIBLE AS QUAKE HITS AFGHAN TOWN
description: An earthquake and its aftershocks have razed a city and several villages in remote northeast Afghanistan, with initial reports saying it killed as many as 2,000 people and left legions without homes.

description: GUTTER-William. On March 25 at the age of eighty, died peacefully after a long illness. Beloved husband of Ruth (Rubenstein) for fifty-seven years, devoted father of Lawrence and Lynn, loving father-in-law of Ellen, and grandfather of Amy. description: BERGER-Magda. On March 25, 2002, in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Loving mother of George Berger and Nancy Siegel. Cherished grandmother of David, Jonathan and Jessica Siegel. Services are on Wednesday, 11:45 AM, at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street), New York, New York.

title: Bush Aide Denies Berenson Report
description: The White House said today that President Bush had not asked for clemency for Lori Berenson, the American serving a 20-year jail sentence in Peru after being convicted of helping rebels plan a 1995 attempt to capture the country's Congress.

title: Condit Subpoenaed In Disappearance
description: Representative Gary A. Condit has been subpoenaed to testify next month before a grand jury here investigating the disappearance of an intern with whom he was reported to have had an intimate relationship.

title: Morgan Stanley Reports A 16% Drop in Earnings
description: Hurt by a continuing slide in its investment banking business, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter reported a 16 percent drop in its fiscal first-quarter earnings yesterday and forecast no quick rebound on Wall Street.

title: U.S. Grant to Gazprom Partner Is Questioned
description: Why was the United States government subsidizing Itera Holding, a mysterious company in Jacksonville, Fla., at the center of accusations of corruption swirling around Gazprom, the Russian gas giant?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Exports Jump
description: Leading automakers increased their exports to North America last month. Exports were helped by a weak yen, the introduction of several new models and the economic recovery in the United States. Toyota Motor shipped 21.8 percent more cars to the United States, while exports by Nissan Motor rose 23.9 percent. Exports by Mitsubishi Motors and Mazda rose even faster. But domestic auto sales slipped for most companies. Ken Belson (NYT)
