description: Ailey II

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SWISSAIR GROUP, Zurich, said it would sell Gate Gourmet, its airline catering business, to Texas Pacific Group, San Francisco. Terms were not disclosed.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''While my nature is to keep fighting and protect our clients, the fact is that the improper shredding of documents took place on my watch -- and I believe it is now in the best interests of the firm for me to step down.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telecom Stake Dispute Resolved
description: France Tlcom and MobilCom, a mobile telephone company in Germany, ended a dispute over ownership of MobilCom. Gerhard Schmid, MobilCom's chief executive, and his wife, Sybille Schmid-Sindran, are negotiating to sell their 43 percent stake in the company to a group of banks for more than 700 million euros ($615 million), a person close to the companies said. Upon completion of that transaction, Mr. Schmid will step down as chief executive, according to Estelle Rozine, a France Tlcom spokeswoman. Mr. Schmid had previously tried to exercise an option that would have forced France Tlcom to buy his stake and consolidate MobilCom's six billion euros of debt on France Tlcom's books. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: More Resignations Sought
description: In another effort to distance himself from the Connecticut trash authority's failed deal with Enron Corporation, Gov. John G. Rowland asked nine of the authority's board members yesterday to resign. The Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority lost about $213 million in a murky deal with Enron last year and then, in February, raised municipal dumping fees to make up the loss, outraging taxpayers. Last week, Mr. Rowland, up for re-election in November, dismissed Peter Ellef, his co-chief of staff, who was also the most prominent of the governor's 12 appointees to the trash board. Yesterday, the governor sent out letters demanding that his nine remaining appointees resign by June 30. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: A Suit Says WorldCom Deals Obscured Millions in Bad Debt
description: A lawsuit quietly moving forward against the telecommunications giant WorldCom accuses the company of using concealed transactions and sham contracts to avoid reporting an uncollectible debt of $165 million.

title: This Blessed Plot, This Realm of Tea, This Marmalade
description: IT is made from exotic fruits that grow far away bitter oranges that hang like golden baubles amid the shiny leaves of trees near Seville in southern Spain. Its name comes from marmelo, the Portuguese word for quince. It has been eaten in one form or another since the days of the ancient Greeks and Romans.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Opposition Politician Missing
description: The police said that they had turned up no sign of an opposition politician missing since Thursday and that they had asked Interpol for help. Vlad Cubreacov is a leader of the Christian Democratic People's Party, which rallied students against the governing Communist Party's decision to make schoolchildren in the former Soviet republic study Russian and a Soviet-style version of Moldovan history. The government scrapped the plan in February but protests against Communist rule continued. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Commercial Real Estate; Deloitte Picks Light, Flexibility and Link to History
description: After twice being forced out of offices in the World Trade Center area by terrorism, Deloitte Consulting is preparing to move its regional office back downtown from temporary quarters elsewhere, this time into 130,000 square feet of space in a landmark building.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Lawmaker Quits In Corruption Scandal
description: A prominent opposition member of Parliament resigned after accusations that she misused government funds intended for an aide's salary. The lawmaker, Kiyomi Tsujimoto of the Social Democratic Party, has been leading a chorus of corruption accusations against prominent members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party but was snared in a scandal of her own. ''I feel so vexed and chagrined, but I've decided to quit because I thought it would cause public distrust in politics if I didn't admit my mistakes and clearly take responsibility,'' she said. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: A Dancer Made Still; Portraits of Nureyev, Created by James Wyeth
description: Over a period of several years, beginning in 1977, James Wyeth filled his sketchbooks and canvases with portraits of Rudolf Nureyev. There were hundreds of them, more of Nureyev than of any other subject.

title: Opinionated Postell Has High Opinion of Himself
description: He said it as if his career high in minutes played was not a mere 18, as if his highest-scoring game in the N.B.A. was not only 10 points, as if he owned a glistening rsum featuring multiple all-American honors.

title: Robin Williams Is Making a Run for It, on a Rare One-Man Tour
description: If Robin Williams were a runner, he'd do the marathon as one long sprint. He performed a manic, indefatigable set on Monday night at the Beacon Theater in the second of four nights of solo shows in New York City, part of his first one-man tour since 1986.

title: Tennessee's Snow Poses Big Problem for UConn
description: When Connecticut and Tennessee meet for the fourth time in the women's Final Four on Friday, the Huskies will have an advantage in experience, shooting and cohesiveness. The one advantage the Lady Vols may have is size.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Indictment In Car Rampage
description: A New Jersey man was charged yesterday with killing a man and trying to kill 24 others, including a taxi driver, during a hit-and-run rampage in Midtown Manhattan in February. The defendant, Ronald Popadich, 41, of Garfield, N.J., is accused of using his car to run down 25 people on Feb. 12 and 14, including Neal Spicehandler, who died, said the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. Mr. Popadich also shot a cabdriver on Feb. 13 in the East Village, Mr. Morgenthau said. He was charged with second-degree murder, 26 counts of attempted murder and other crimes. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: General Injures Himself
description: Gen. Henry H. Shelton, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, hurt his spinal cord on Saturday when he fell at his home, the Army said. He was in serious condition at Walter Reed Medical Center in Washington. After experiencing partial paralysis after the fall, the general improved gradually, but continues to experience weakness in his arms and right leg, the center said. General Shelton, 60, became chairman of the Joint Chiefs, the chief military adviser to the president, in 1997. He retired last year.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Police Sought In Sex-Club Link
description: Newark police are contacting other police departments in New York and New Jersey to determine if any of their officers frequented a strip club where 31 people were arrested on prostitution-related charges Sunday morning. Officials found more than 200 Polaroid photographs of men who also paid a $25 membership fee to the club, Sights. The police said nude dancers sold 10 minutes worth of sex in private cubicles for $100. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: An Apprentice Offers Glimpses of a Literary Sorcerer
description: MY MENTOR

title: Justices Rule Drug-Eviction Law Is Fair
description: The Supreme Court today interpreted a federal drug law to permit the eviction of public housing tenants for drug use by any household member or guest, even drug use that takes place outside the apartment without the tenant's knowledge.

title: Waste Management Executives Are Named in S.E.C. Accusation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil complaint yesterday against six former officers of Waste Management Inc., providing new details of the accounting fraud case that has become a driving force behind the government's criminal action against Arthur Andersen.

title: Summer School Draws More Critics
description: Two years ago, the New York City school system was enthusiastically preparing for a major expansion of its summer program, which it promised would end the longstanding ritual of promoting students to the next grade despite dismal academic performance.

title: Playwright With a Problem: The World Is Falling Apart
description: S. N. Behrman was in his mid-40's when he wrote ''No Time for Comedy,'' and the play, bittersweet and obviously self-examining, shows every sign of a playwright's midlife crisis, both as a writer and man. Known for his sophisticated comedies, largely about the upper class, Behrman was prolific and popular. But when ''No Time for Comedy'' opened on Broadway in 1939 (starring Laurence Olivier and Katherine Cornell), Spain was convulsed in civil war and all of Europe threatened by the harrowing shadow of the Nazis, and the play is about a playwright who is agonized by his success in the genre of sophisticated comedies when the world is such a serious place.

title: Answering '800' Calls, Extra Income but No Security
description: For all her skill in designing Web sites, Alicia Suarez made only $5,000 last year from 10 clients. So she did what many women here do to make ends meet -- she took a job in a call center, on the answering end of the ''800'' numbers that Americans dial so often to deal with the companies that sell to them.

title: A Mass Transit Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF THE MENU
description: New Places, Lots of Red

title: Judge Approves Settlement In Yonkers Desegregation Suit
description: A federal judge approved a $300 million settlement yesterday in a desegregation lawsuit against the Yonkers public schools, a widely expected decision that will end more than two decades of litigation and federal intervention in the state's fourth-largest school district.

title: Polish Priests Press Vatican on Case Against Bishop
description: Here in western Poland, in what residents boast is the oldest diocese of a fervently Roman Catholic country, it was the priests who reported the many whispers of homosexual advances by the local archbishop -- and the priests who got the Vatican to take some action.

title: Someday, Your S.U.V. Won't Be Cool
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefly Noted; ATTACK ON MOSQUE
description: A man who said he hated Muslims drove a truck into a Florida mosque just 30 minutes before evening prayers, the police said. No one was injured on Monday in the Islamic Center of Tallahassee at Florida State University. The driver, Charles Franklin, 41, was arrested later at a campus bar. Investigators said Mr. Franklin told the police that he tried to join the military to kill Muslims but was turned down.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times yesterday about a symposium in honor of the physicist Dr. John A. Wheeler misstated the given name of a friend and colleague and omitted her title. She is Prof. Cecile DeWitt-Morette, not Celine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLISH, RICHARD
description: PERLISH-Richard. March 16, 2002 in Boca Raton. Loving wife, Annabelle, daughter, Betty Helen, sister, Roz Muller and her family, niece, Sandra Fox, nephew, Mark, and his extended family in Atlanta. He loved life and spread joy.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Trial For Accused Genocide Plotter
description: The United Nations tribunal for Rwanda has set next week for the opening of the trial of a former Rwandan Army colonel who is accused of being one of the masterminds of the 1994 frenzy of killing in which bands of Hutus massacred hundreds of thousands of Tutsis and moderate Hutus. Col. Theoneste Bagosora is charged with genocide and will be tried with three accused accomplices. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Report on Social Security Adds 3 Years to Fund's Life
description: The financial outlook for Social Security and Medicare improved in the last year, despite the recession, the Bush administration said today.

title: A Town Calls a Timeout for Overextended Families
description: The people in this suburban town of overachievers decided they weren't spending enough quality time as families because they were overscheduling their children.

title: A Shepherd's Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: If We Care About City Schools . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Airlines and hotel chains are spending plenty to revive travel, especially business travel.
description: BUSINESS travel has shown definite signs of life since the double shock of Sept. 11 and a slumping economy, but it is still limping. So airlines, hotel companies and others involved in travel have introduced campaigns in recent weeks to try to get things going at a brisk pace again.

title: U.S. Consumers Are Positive. So Are Orders For Durables.
description: Consumer confidence soared in March, the Conference Board reported yesterday, offering more evidence that the optimistic resilience of the American shopper is pulling the nation back from recession.

title: Fists and Elbows Fly More Frequently
description: The elbow came up high and caught Shareef Abdur-Rahim in the upper body. Whistles blew, play stopped and the offending player began a stare-down with Abdur-Rahim, the Atlanta Hawks star.

title: Mystery Death From Anthrax Is Analyzed
description: Ottilie Lundgren, the 94-year-old Connecticut woman who died of inhalation anthrax in November, had the habit of tearing her junk mail in half before she threw it away and may have been infected by anthrax spores as she ripped up her bulk mail, a Connecticut health official reported at a medical conference here today.

title: Drawing Inspiration From Palladio to Neruda
description: Ballet Builders 2002

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACQZ, JANE WILDER
description: JACQZ-Jane Wilder. Died in the evening, Sunday March 24, 2002, aged 74. Most recently a senior advisor to the Division for NonGovernmental Organizations at UNDP, Jane had long served in the international not-for-profit community. Mother of Margot & Christian; mother-in-law of Susan Baldwin; grandmother of Sarah Fulton, Henry William, and Irene Baldwin Jacqz. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions may be made to The Nature Conservancy, attn: Member Services, 4245 North Fairfax Dr. Suite 100, Arlington, VA. 22203.

title: Not the Usual Chef on the Shelf
description: IF only cookbooks by chefs really were a dime a dozen.

title: Our Safety Requires a Shift in Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Will Preserve Its Streak: For the 18th Year, a Late Budget
description: For the 18th year in a row, New York State will not have a budget enacted by the start of the fiscal year, a fact the Legislature acknowledged today by passing an emergency spending bill to keep the government running past April 1.

title: From Alcott, a Parable for a Spirited Niece
description: In 1880 Louisa May Alcott inherited her 10-month-old niece and namesake, Louisa May Nieriker, who was called Lulu. The mother, Alcott's youngest sister, May Alcott Nieriker, was the model for the character Amy in ''Little Women.'' She had died in Paris just after Lulu's birth, and before her death she had begged her husband, Ernest, to send Lulu to Alcott in Concord, Mass., to be reared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, BETTY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Betty. On March 25, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Isaac. Devoted mother of William and Michael, and mother-in-law of Diana and Jinny. Loving sister of Pearl Rochelson. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Marc and Eric. Caring and dear friend to many. Services Wed., 9:30AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her memory can be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind, the Lighthouse, or Guiding Eyes for the Blind.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Soldiers Executed For Killing Priest
description: A firing squad executed two soldiers after a military tribunal found them guilty of murdering an Irish priest last week. The corporal and private, who were not identified, were shot in public in the northeastern town of Kotido for killing the Rev. Declan O'Toole, who was doing missionary work in the countryside when his vehicle was ambushed. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Lakshmi, 58, a Star of Indian Classical Dance
description: Lakshmi Knight, a dancer and teacher of Indian classical dance who performed widely in the United States in the style specifically associated with her mother, the great dancer Balasaraswati, died in Chennai, India, on Dec. 23. She was 58 and lived in Chennai and Hunterdon, N.J.

title: A Fresh Start For a Pioneer Of Park Slope
description: THE Brooklyn dining scene has changed drastically in a decade. In a trickle that has swelled to a flood, Manhattan exiles have colonized every available block in formerly fringe areas off Park Slope and Cobble Hill, taking their money and appetites with them. Not surprisingly, a new generation of restaurants has arisen, seemingly overnight, to conform to the new demographics. Smith Street, in particular, has established itself as Restaurant Row, but the signs of dining excitement can be seen from Fort Greene to Prospect Heights.

title: JONES APPAREL WILL CLOSE STORES AND CUT 240 JOBS
description: The Jones Apparel Group, a maker and retailer of women's shoes and clothing, will close 30 to 40 of its less-profitable stores this year, eliminating about 240 jobs. Jones Apparel will open 15 to 20 stores in 2002, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company had 944 stores last year, including Nine West, Easy Spirit and Enzo Angiolini. Revenue from Jones Apparel stores fell 24 percent in the fourth quarter, hurt by the recession's effect on consumer spending.

title: At Rutgers, Help to Repay Loans
description: The Newark campus of the Rutgers School of Law has received $1 million to supplement a program that helps repay loans for graduates who work for five years in public interest employment, like nonprofit organizations or government agencies. Started by law students and financed by a fee they pay each semester, the program is evaluated every three years. The endowment was given by an impressed but anonymous alumna. Peter Valdina

title: Easter Baskets That Shine
description: ANYONE can use commercial dye to color eggs, but going back to vegetables and spices can make your Easter basket one of a kind.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUSKIN, MIRIAM ROSE
description: LUSKIN-Miriam Rose. Gone, but not forgotten. Love, always and forever, Joan and Ir

title: Brotherly Love, and Disdain: Acting as His Keeper, Years After His Execution
description: ''Shot in the Heart'' was shown on HBO on Oct. 13. Following are excerpts from Julie Salamon's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12; the full text is available at nytimes.com. The film opens today, through April 9, at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Somali foreign minister, in U.S., pledges support on terror
description: WASHINGTON:  With his country under intense U.S. scrutiny for possible terrorist connections, the foreign minister of the transitional government of Somalia has pledged full cooperation in the fight against terror even while denying any Al Qaeda link to his shattered country.

title: NEW SWISS CARRIER TEAMS UP WITH AMERICAN AIRLINES
description: Switzerland's new airline, Swiss, which is taking the place of the failed Swissair, said yesterday that it would team up with American Airlines as its trans-Atlantic partner. Tapping the American market is vital to the new airline's financial survival, its officials said. The new Swiss carrier also said it hoped to overcome the regulatory obstacles to joining the Oneworld airline alliance led by American and British Airways. Some of its rivals, like the budget carrier EasyJet, have threatened to ask the European Commission to force British Airways and Swiss to give up landing slots at Heathrow Airport in London if Swiss joins Oneworld. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Someday, Your S.U.V. Won't Be Cool
description: To the Editor:

title: After Losing Its New Home, Museum Loses Its Director
description: The longtime director of the Museum of the City of New York resigned yesterday, citing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's withdrawal last week of the use of the sumptuous, expensively renovated Tweed Courthouse as his institution's new downtown home near City Hall.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Rule Limiting Judicial Candidates' Speech
description: With the coming Supreme Court battle over federal campaign regulation still months away, the court turned today to another election issue that also raises substantial First Amendment questions: restrictions on the views that candidates can express while running for judgeships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARVELL, DR. PHILEMON ''P.T.'' TRUESDALE MARVELL II
description: MARVELL-Dr. Philemon ''P.T.'' Truesdale Marvell II, age 33 of Newport and Little Compton, RI. A gentleman with a beautiful mind. Amazing son and brother of Dr. Philemon ''Captain'' Truesdale Marvell and Rhonda (Moore) Marvell & Edward Brayton ''Ted'' Marvell and his fiance, Lauren Lankau, grandson of Mary Tugwell, & the late Dr. Frank Tugwell & the late Avery D. Moore and Elinor T. Marvell, and the late Thomas Brayton Marvell, nephew of Mr. & Mrs. Vernon Wiggins Mr. & Mrs. Chandler Kirwin, Mr. Tom Moore, and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Marvell. He was also great grandson of the late Minna (Dickinson) & Dr. Philemon E. Truesdale founder of the former Truesdale Hospital and Truesdale Clinic in Fall River, MA, and great great nephew of Miss Alice Brayton of ''Green Animals'' in Portsmouth, RI a part of Newport Preservation Society. A celebration of his life will be held Sat., March 30, 2002 at 11:00 AM in the United Congregational Church, The Commons, Little Compton, RI. Visiting hours Thurs. 4-7PM & Fri. 4-7PM in the 'Cherry Place Home Of WaringSullivan, 178 Winter St., Fall Riner, MA. Memorial contributions: PO Box 534, Little Compton, RI 02837 to be distributed among: International Yacht Restoration School, Sakonnet Yacht Club, Sail Newport, the hospitals he serviced, Wilbur House in Little Compton & Green Animals of Newport Preservation Society. Burial private. www.waring-sullivan.com

title: Man Charged With Perjury
description: Federal authorities charged a Virginia man yesterday with lying to a grand jury after he and another man flew from New York to Israel carrying a letter that an F.B.I. agent described as a terrorist's farewell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, DONALD
description: SILVERSTEIN-Donald. Condolences to the Silverstein Family from his friends at National Bank of New York City. Richard Gelman, President

title: In Abandoned Subway Tunnels, Building a Particle Accelerator
description: Science has taken to the stage again, this time in an experimental piece called ''Calabi-Yau,'' at Here in the South Village through April 7. Susanna Speier, who wrote the play, has a promisingly nutty premise: Metropolitan Transportation Authority workers are building a particle accelerator in abandoned subway tunnels under New York to try to prove string theory, a dense piece of physics that seeks to explain the inadequacies of other dense pieces of physics. But Ms. Speier has forgotten to include people in her scientific foray.

title: Area Is Prone to Quakes
description: The Hindu Kush region of Afghanistan, at the intersection of the Indian and Asian tectonic plates, is one of the most earthquake-prone in the world. In an average year, five earthquakes with a magnitude of 5.0 or stronger strike within 100 miles of the location of Monday's earthquake.

title: AOL Officials Got No Bonuses in 2001, but Lots of Options
description: After receiving regular bonuses in recent years, AOL Time Warner's top executives received no bonuses in 2001 but reaped more than $250 million from the exercise of stock options, according to a company filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Tax Repealed
description: The Tokyo District Court has repealed a two-year-old tax on banks operating in Tokyo, a major victory for the cash-short lenders. To help balance its budget, the Tokyo metropolitan government charged banks a 3 percent tax based on the number of workers they employed and other costs. The court ruled that local governments could not single out one industry for taxation and ordered the city to refund 72.4 billion yen ($543 million) to the banks. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Hong Kong Journal; For Raising Skyscrapers, Bamboo Does Nicely
description: Perched on a bamboo construction scaffold 18 floors above a swarming expressway, his legs wrapped around a pole, his lips around a cigarette, Ho Siu Leung looks, against all odds, like a man at ease. Mr. Ho has been clambering up and down these creaky contraptions since he was 14. He is now a weather-beaten 54.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Identical Quadruplets Born
description: A Sacramento woman gave birth of identical quadruplets, each weighing less than three pounds, a month and half early. The four girls, conceived by Ornsee Khamsa and Verek Muy without fertility drugs, were reported doing well in a local hospital. Occurring in only 1 in 11 million cases, identical quadruplets are created when a second round of splitting occurs after a fertilized egg has already split into two embryos. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: Bush Energy Paper Followed Industry Push
description: As he helped the Bush administration write its national energy report last year, Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham heard from more than 100 energy industry executives, trade association leaders and lobbyists, according to documents released by the Energy Department.

title: Baseball Negotiators Shift Their Sights to Next Off-Season
description: Baseball's club owners and players don't have to sit across the bargaining table from each other to initiate a verbal skirmish, their representatives demonstrated again yesterday.

title: Online System Aids Police Recruiting
description: After years of struggling, New York City police officials said yesterday that recruitment efforts were well ahead of pace, primarily because of a new online application system.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lead-Paint Law Upheld
description: An appeals court unanimously upheld a disputed lead-paint control law yesterday, dismissing a lower court ruling that the City Council had not made a proper review of the law's environmental impact. The ruling came a day after a majority of City Council members introduced a bill that would make it easier for the parents of children with lead poisoning to sue their landlords. Critics of the upheld law have long said it unduly favors landlords, while its supporters say it has been effective because the number of lead-poisoning cases among children has declined since it was passed in 1999. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Man in the News; A Man of Many Professions -- Richard Henry Carmona
description: Dr. Richard H. Carmona, the man chosen by President Bush to be surgeon general of the United States, has an M.D. and a master's degree in public health, but he also has experience in law enforcement and on the battlefield, which may help him cope with the threat of biological terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, MARGIE A.
description: WARREN-Margie A. On March 20, 2002, former nursing instructor for many years at The New YorkCornell Medical Center. Memorial Service to be held at a later date.

title: Injury Sends Richter Home for the Season
description: Rangers goalie Mike Richter will most likely miss the rest of the season after a CT scan on Monday revealed a fracture of the temporal bone above his right ear.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Hotels Withdraw Request
description: The Adam's Mark hotel chain is withdrawing a request to the Justice Department for early relief from an antidiscrimination settlement, a spokesman said. The order, imposed in 2000 after black guests complained, is supposed to run through 2004, but a department official had said he would consider lifting it at the end of the year. The chain is operated by the HBE Corporation, which is owned by Fred S. Kummer Jr., a longtime friend and political supporter of Attorney General John Ashcroft. The company said it was withdrawing its request to have the order lifted because the issue ''had become unduly politicized.'' Neil A. Lewis (NYT)

title: Lewis and Mayorga Trade Insults
description: The challenger spouted threat after threat. The champion pushed his inner mute button.

title: Cool, Hot and Exotic
description: AT the end of an elaborate dinner you need something fresh. And light. And somewhat exotic, too. In my restaurant, we serve chilled mango and a sorbet of fromage blanc or sour cream spiked with pepper after the dessert. It's meant to wake up the palate before the finale of caramels, little cakes and chocolates.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Meadow: Critically Burned Infant Dies
description: The 8-month-old baby who was critically burned in a house fire in Bay Shore last week that killed two of her brothers died Saturday at Nassau University Medical Center, the authorities said. The baby, Starkeya Steeple, died as a result of severe burns and smoke inhalation from the fire, which also injured her mother and another brother. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, said Sgt. Bruce Tilden of the Suffolk County arson squad. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Elias Returning to Form On Nieuwendyk's Line
description: A generation gap apparently must still be bridged on the Devils' exciting new line. Left wing Patrik Elias referred to center Joe Nieuwendyk recently as ''Mr. Nieuwendyk,'' as if he were playing next to Gordie Howe.

title: Le Pen Makes His Lack of Support a Cause Clbre
description: Will he make it or not?

title: Vaughn Plays Down Criticism by Percival
description: Mo Vaughn has played with broken bones, returned from knee surgery in three weeks and played half a season with what turned out to be a torn biceps tendon in his left arm. That is why he is insulted when his ability to lead is questioned. After hearing more complaints from his previous team, the Angels, about his alleged bad attitude in Anaheim, Vaughn was livid.

title: Agassi Is Training Smarter to Make Sure Youth Isn't Served Against Him
description: A day after Pete Sampras's unceremonious elimination in the Nasdaq-100 Open, Andre Agassi said he felt no particular need to strike a blow for the 30-plus set. Yet Agassi did just that today, showing an ability to defy time among the ever-pressing twentysomethings on the ATP Tour that Sampras has been unable to match.

title: New Attacks Feared With Afghan Thaw
description: The spring thaw in Afghanistan may bring a sharp rise in guerrilla attacks on American and allied troops, American officials say. They say melting snow in mountain passes will make small bands of fighters harder to spot and attack. Article, Page A10.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Indicted Judge Loses Pay
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday rejected a plea by a Brooklyn judge to continue to receive his $137,000 annual salary, despite his indictment on bribery charges. The judge, Victor I. Barron of State Supreme Court, is accused of asking a lawyer for $115,000 in exchange for approving a civil settlement. The appeals court continued the Jan. 22 suspension of the judge. All seven judges rejected Mr. Barron's arguments for continuing to receive his pay. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Pricing the Poor Out of College
description: Tens of millions of Americans have used college to propel themselves out of poverty. This road to upward mobility has been, unfortunately, narrowed in recent years by changes in aid programs that focus more on middle- and upper-income students. Poor and working-class students have considerably more access to college today than 30 years ago, thanks in particular to federal Pell grants, which provide up to $4,000 a year in tuition aid. Even so, enrollment data show startling differences in college attendance rates for high-income and low-income students with roughly comparable academic abilities.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Profit At Jet Maker
description: Despite a slump in aircraft deliveries, the Brazilian jet maker Empresa Brasileira de Aeronutica, or Embraer, used currency gains to increase profit by 18 percent in the fourth quarter. Net revenue fell to $632 million from $637 million in the fourth quarter of last year, though, as the company delivered 10 fewer jets. After delivering 161 planes in 2001, the company said it would deliver 135 planes in 2002 and 145 in 2003. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Trying to Dribble Past a Trapdoor
description: NOW the real game, or shell game, begins. For Lenny Cooke, it could mean millions of dollars for keeping his eye on the ball or an empty cup for losing his focus.

title: The Free-Speech Bind
description: So here's an interesting moral dilemma: I got e-mails last week from Saudi and Egyptian friends encouraging me to write a column about the Saudi poet who had been thrown in jail for writing a fiery poem attacking Saudi judges as corrupt.

title: India Passes Antiterror Bill Over Protests About Rights
description: After caustic debates during a rare session of both its houses, the Indian Parliament passed a broad antiterrorism measure tonight.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Hunger Spreads In The South
description: The World Food Program warned that hunger is on the rise in southern Africa, particularly in Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe, where drought has devastated corn crops. The agency, an arm of the United Nations, is appealing for contributions from donor nations to help an estimated 2.6 million people in the region suffering from food shortages. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Tainted Mahogany
description: To the Editor:

title: Companies Are Sued for Slave Reparations
description: Citing the persisting legacy of slavery, a Manhattan woman yesterday filed what appears to be the first class-action lawsuit that seeks compensation from United States companies for allegedly profiting from the slave trade.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Economic Outlook Improves
description: An index of business confidence in Germany rose by 3.3 points, to 91.8, in March, the strongest increase in five months, the Ifo economic institute said. The increase was driven mainly by the expectation component, which jumped to 106.3 points from 101 in February, reaching its highest level since April. The assessment of current conditions was virtually unchanged. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Our Safety Requires a Shift in Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebuild Downtown, And Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Suit Against Insurers
description: A lawsuit accuses two of the state's largest insurers of withholding full reimbursement to health care providers. The suit, filed by about 80 doctors, therapists and nurses in the Franciscan Medical Group and Tacoma Orthopedic Surgeons Inc., says Premera Blue Cross and Regence Blue Shield systematically deny claims and delay payment of them. The plaintiffs are seek class-action status for the suit. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Wallowing Deep in Angst And Attitude
description: Before Puddle of Mudd took the stage at the Roseland Ballroom, there was the sound of a radio being tuned, with bits of songs interspersed with static and snippets of news. It was a misleading beginning to a concert that was notable for its simplicity. There were few guitar solos and there was hardly any interaction with the audience -- Puddle of Mudd raced through a dozen songs and then split.

title: Three Dissatisfied Wives Consider a Chilly Calculus
description: ''Take my husband . . . please!''

title: Briefly Noted; RULING ON DETAINEES
description: A New Jersey judge ruled yesterday that the Hudson and Passaic County jails should turn over the names and incarceration dates of immigration detainees held there under contract with the federal government in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The ruling, which the government plans to appeal, stems from a lawsuit filed in January by the American Civil Liberties of New Jersey in State Superior Court, after the government began detaining immigrants anonymously. A similar suit against the government is pending in federal court, but the New Jersey group sued the jails directly under state laws. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: FAILING MORTGAGES SOAR IN NEW YORK
description: The number of low- and moderate-income families in the New York metropolitan region who are seriously behind on their mortgage payments is soaring, according to new federal and city data and housing experts, who say they have seen a surge in mortgage troubles since Sept. 11.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial yesterday mistakenly described Robert Torricelli of New Jersey as a two-term senator. He was elected to the Senate in 1996.

title: Spike Lee Gets Post at N.Y.U.
description: SPIKE LEE made ''Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop: We Cut Heads,'' the film that brought him widespread attention, for $12,000 as his thesis project when he was a graduate student at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. Now he is becoming artistic director of the school's Kanbar Institute of Film and Television. He will advise graduate students about their thesis projects and help them make contacts in the entertainment industry. ''N.Y.U. meant a lot to me,'' Mr. Lee said in an interview this week. ''I became a filmmaker at N.Y.U.'' Mr. Lee, who has taught for several years at N.Y.U. and also for a couple of years at Harvard, said that he finds a great deal of talent among students today. ''But a lot of people are lazy,'' he added. ''I am constantly challenging them. I tell them they got to do the work.'' He said he will give some of his students internships on his next film, ''The 25th Hour,'' starring EDWARD NORTON, which is in preproduction now, but he will not simply hand them the jobs. ''They had to read the book and give me a synopsis,'' he said. ''There is a whole rigorous process, for them to be considered.''

title: Among New Sitcoms, A Funny Latino Father
description: Passing through the revolving door of new sitcoms are a Latino father, a living puppet and the staff of a fictional television network; that scent in the air is one of slapdash desperation.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Voting Rights For 17-Year-Olds
description: Swayed by the campaign of some politically active high school students, the Cambridge City Council voted to lower the local voting age to 17. The measure, if approved by the Legislature, would apply only to city elections. More significantly, students reasoned, it would give them a say in who sits on the school committee. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPMAN, SANDY
description: LIPMAN-Sandy. No matter where I go, no matter where I am, you will always be a part of me. Miss Penny

title: A Dirty Town, Still Gritty And Strong
description: SOMEWHERE between Whoopi Goldberg doing her ''Moulin Rouge'' shtick and Denzel Washington saying ''Allahu Akbar'' in English -- ''God is great'' -- an unsettling question wormed its way into the brain: is New York in even worse shape than we have been led to believe?

title: Briefly Noted; ANTITERRORISM BILL
description: Maryland's House of Delegates has approved antiterrorism legislation that would broaden powers to wiretap telephones and monitor e-mail messages and other computer communications. The bill would allow law enforcement officials with court orders to plant a wiretap indefinitely, not only 30 days, the current limit, and would permit taps of multiple phones with one warrant. Investigators could get court orders to seize records of e-mail messages and other electronic communications. The measure now goes to the State Senate. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: National Test Is Out of Tune With Times
description: TEST scores are rising nationwide. But with so much focus on testing, scores are bound to go up even if there is no real improvement. Pupils spend more time practicing for tests and as tests become familiar, teachers more often emphasize the types of problems tests include.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, DR. DAVID
description: KAUFMAN-Dr. David of Summit, NJ. Beloved husband of Honey (nee Cowen). Devoted father of Larry Kaufman & Rabbi Melissa Crespy, Bob Kaufman and Esther and Peter Harper. Loving brother of Alison and Sandy Wellen, adored grandfather of Avi Kaufman. Services at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, NJ Wednesday March 27 at 11 AM. For info. call 1-800-938-6372

title: The Aisle Less Traveled: A Stranger in a Junk Food World
description: I STRONGLY suspect that I was the last human on the planet to taste Pirate's Booty. As everyone but me has known for many months, this is the cheese-coated puffed rice and corn snack that Vanity Fair put on its ''in'' list a year ago, and that Good Housekeeping recently treated to a nice cold shower. Delia Hammock, the director of nutrition at the Good Housekeeping Institute, grew suspicious after hearing her co-workers raving about Pirate's Booty. How could a snack that tasted so good really be as low in fat and calories as its manufacturer claimed?

title: Chinese Protests Ebb as Officials Talk Tough, but Give Ground
description: The giant protests by displaced workers from state-owned factories in northeastern China have dwindled in recent days as officials responded with a dual strategy, meeting some of the workers' monetary demands while detaining several organizers and threatening still more demonstrators with arrest.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Leaders Hope To Attract Aid
description: The heads of 16 African countries met in Nigeria's capital, Abuja, to draft a plan to attract Western aid and investment. The plan, called the New Partnership for Africa's Development, will commit the nations to democracy and good government in return for aid. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAY, DOROTHY
description: DeLAY-Dorothy. The Juilliard community deeply mourns the death of Dorothy DeLay, distinguished member of the violin faculty from 1948 to the time of her death. From a lifetime dedicated to nurturing generations of young violinists, her legacy lives on in the presence of great violinists as soloists, chamber musicians, orchestral members and teachers throughout the world. The excellence of The Juilliard School exists, in part, through her presence and dedication. Our condolences go to her beloved husband, Edward Newhouse, her children, Jeffrey and Alison, and her grandchildren. A memorial service at Juilliard is planned for the late spring. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President Stephen Clapp, Dean

title: T. J. Kelly, 72, Dies; Father of Lunar Module
description: Thomas J. Kelly, the engineer who led the team that designed and built the spacecraft that landed Apollo astronauts on the Moon, died on Saturday at his home in Cutchogue, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 72.

title: Strawberry Hires A New Lawyer
description: Darryl Strawberry, who is facing time in prison after being charged recently with numerous probation violations at a Florida substance-abuse rehabilitation facility, has hired a new lawyer. Darryl Rouson will replace his longtime representative, Joseph Ficarrotta of Tampa, Fla., who withdrew recently.

title: In Year of Attacks, Passover Preparations Are Somber
description: Tamar Warburg wanted to be reunited with family members who did not feel safe making their annual Passover trip to Israel. So, at the last minute, she decided to leave her yearlong studies in Jerusalem for a quick return home to Englewood, N.J.

title: Maine Is Banking On Leading Scorer's Return
description: When Maine meets New Hampshire in the first game of the N.C.A.A. semifinals on April 4 in St. Paul, Colin Shields hopes his tooth troubles will be over.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Medal for Brattiness

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; U.S. inquiry into Network Associates' accounting hurts share prices and delays McAfee.com offer.
description: SHARES in Network Associates, the computer security company, tumbled 11 percent yesterday after it disclosed that federal regulators had begun a formal investigation into its accounting practices during 2000.

title: U.S. Forces May Keep Order In Afghanistan Countryside
description: President Bush's envoy to Afghanistan suggested today that American military forces might intervene in local conflicts in the absence of international troops stationed around the country.

title: Cockpit Tape Offers Few Answers but Points to Heroic Efforts
description: Families of passengers and crew members aboard United Flight 93, the hijacked plane that crashed outside Shanksville, Pa., on Sept. 11, will hear nothing to resolve crucial questions about their loved ones' last minutes when they listen to the cockpit voice recorder next month, say officials who have heard the tape or read transcripts of it.

title: DUPONT CANADA WILL BUY LIQUI-BOX
description: The chemicals company DuPont Canada Inc. said that it would buy the Liqui-Box Corporation, a packaging company that specializes in packing liquids, for $333 million. DuPont Canada said that it agreed to pay $67 a share in cash for Liqui-Box, a 34 percent premium over its closing stock price of $50.10 on Monday on the Nasdaq. Samuel Davis, the chairman of Liqui-Box, which is based in Worthington, Ohio, said the offer was fair and the transaction was expected to close in May or June. Liqui-Box's packaging is used for foods for restaurants and fast-food chains.

title: Citi Man Is Thinking Big but Thriftily in the Midwest
description: Not long ago, Jay S. Fishman was considered a leading candidate to replace Sanford I. Weill some day as the chief executive of Citigroup, the world's largest financial services company.

title: Whether It's State or Local, Somebody Has to Raise Taxes
description: The biggest applause line in Gov. James E. McGreevey's budget address today was a kind of New Jersey cheer: ''I will not raise our income taxes. I will not raise our sales taxes.''

title: Once Again, an Aspiring Catcher Is Cut, This Time by the Yankees
description: Todd Greene was trying not to be paranoid about it. He had been released on the last day of spring training in 2000 and 2001, and he was certain that if the Yankees held a fair competition, he would not be cut this spring. Greene believed he should hold on to his job as the backup catcher, but tonight he lost it.

title: Injuries Dogging Germany and the U.S.
description: Soccer has never been a game of statistics, except when it comes to counting the number of players missing a game. That figure keeps increasing for the United States and Germany.

title: Raids, Detentions and Lists Lead Muslims to Cry Persecution
description: As the Bush administration investigates what it says may be domestic ties to Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups, some Muslim leaders say the government is persecuting them as it once did suspected supporters of Japan or the Soviet Union more than 50 years ago.

title: Timber Company Reduces Cutting of Old-Growth Trees
description: Boise, the giant timber company, has begun telling its employees and customers that it will no longer cut centuries-old trees in some undisturbed forests on public and private lands.

title: City Where Visitors Never Sleep; Trenton's New Hotel May Wake Up Its Downtown
description: The Quaker Oats Company in Chicago asked about having a shareholders meeting here a few years ago, and Sally Lane was the one who had to answer with the truth: that would not be possible. Trenton had no hotel.

title: Talk of a Strike, but No Action Yet
description: Are New York City teachers seriously contemplating the possibility of a strike? Probably not, but the United Federation of Teachers, which has gone 16 months without a contract, seems to want the public to think so. RANDI WEINGARTEN, the union president, has publicly been hinting that more than a few teachers are now pushing for a strike. Although Ms. Weingarten has fought off motions for a strike authorization vote in recent delegate assemblies, she has left open the possibility for such a vote next month. The union is encouraging the city's 80,000 teachers to picket outside their schools on the morning of April 15, before classes begin. One of the signs it is printing for teachers to wave reads, ''I don't want to, but I will!'' Abby Goodnough

title: Man in the News; From Algeria to a Dream -- Elias Adam Zerhouni
description: There was a time when medical experts thought it would be impossible to use magnetic resonance imaging to take moving pictures of the heart. Dr. Elias A. Zerhouni cured them of that notion.

title: Years of Work Underground Before Steel Reaches Skyward
description: Nothing will be built above ground for several years at the site of the World Trade Center because of the extensive underground construction that must be completed first, the chairman of the group overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan said yesterday.

title: YES Says No to Cablevision Proposal
description: Cablevision, which has resisted carrying the Yankees' new cable channel as part of its basic package, proposed a compromise of sorts yesterday. Cablevision said it would carry the Yankees' channel, the YES Network, on its systems but would allow YES to set the price and keep all the revenues.

title: Foreigners May Get Control of German Media Group
description: Leo Kirch, who controls Germany's biggest commercial television networks and the rights to a huge library of programming and sports events, is in danger of being toppled by Rupert Murdoch.

title: The Women's Movement, By One of Its Heirs
description: Jill Sigman

title: Money for After-School Programs
description: The After-School Corporation, a nonprofit organization that fosters after-school activities in New York, received $250,000 from the AOL Time Warner Foundation recently for new programs for 2,500 students who attend the schools near the World Trade Center site. ''We are thrilled,'' said LUCY N. FRIEDMAN, president of the corporation. ''This gift ensured that we would have the resources to provide high-quality after-school care. And after 9/11, parents are particularly concerned about whom their kids are with.'' Yilu Zhao

title: In the New Dinner Theater, The Kitchen Comes to the Table
description: WE were well into the sweetbreads and braised endive when our waiter began setting the stage for our main course. He pulled over a dark narrow wood table and placed it beside us. He set down a folded linen napkin, along with a few utensils.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EFROS, ALLEN
description: EFROS-Allen. Of Brooklyn, NY, died early Tuesday, March 26, 2002 at the age of 87. Beloved husband of the late Belle Efros, to whom he was married for more than 50 years before she died in December 1997. Survived by nieces and nephews, Mr. Efros was a well respected accountant, practicing in New York City for more than 50 years, highly esteemed by his colleagues and clients. He was a supporter of many charitable organizations, and beloved by friends and family. Graveside services will be held on March 27, 2002 at Wellwood Cemetary, Farmingdale, NY at 10 AM. For more information call Weinstein, Garlick, Kirshenbaum Chapel at 718-377-4848.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Cross-Border Telecom Merger
description: Sonera of Finland and Telia of Sweden said they would merge to form the Nordic region's largest telecommunications company. The deal completes the first major cross-border merger between two formerly state-run phone monopolies. The Finnish government still owns 53 percent of Sonera, and the Swedish government owns 71 percent of Telia. Sonera shareholders will receive 1.5144 Telia shares for each Sonera share they hold, a 15.8 percent premium over the price of Sonera shares on March 22, the last trading day before news of the pending merger began to circulate. The deal values Sonera at about $6.5 billion; Telia will also assume $2.2 billion in Sonera's debt. Telia shareholders will own 64 percent of the combined company. If the companies had been combined for all of 2001, they would have had revenue of nine billion euros ($7.9 billion). Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Racial Study of Speeders Is Released in New Jersey
description: New Jersey released a long-withheld and hotly disputed study of turnpike speeders today that suggests blacks may be more likely than others to break the speed limit, along with correspondence from the federal Department of Justice challenging the report's conclusions.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Travelocity Adds Last-Minute Capacity
description: The online travel agency Travelocity.com said yesterday that it would acquire Site59.com, a two-year-old online seller of last-minute air and hotel inventory. Under terms of the deal, Travelocity.com will pay $43 million for Site59 and will maintain it as a separate operation. Travelocity.com officials said the acquisition would help it offer more last-minute discounted travel packages and develop a higher-margin hotel inventory business. Travelocity.com, based in Fort Worth, now gets hotel rooms through an agreement with Hotel Reservations Network and through its own contracts. Site59, based in New York, was founded by the iFormation Group, a venture of the Boston Consulting Group, Goldman Sachs and General Atlantic Partners. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Meet With Mediators
description: A month after they signed a cease-fire agreement with the government, leaders of the island's Tamil separatist movement opened talks with Norwegian mediators in rebel-held territory to prepare for direct negotiations to try to end the nearly 20-year-old civil war. The head of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, Vellupillai Prabhakaran, took part in the talks along with the the group's chief negotiator, Anton Balansingham, who returned to the country this week from exile. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Andersen Chief Quits in Effort To Rescue Firm
description: Joseph F. Berardino announced yesterday that he would step down as chief executive of Arthur Andersen in an effort to save the firm, which has been indicted for shredding documents related to its audit of Enron.

title: Europe's Trade Chief Trains Cross Hairs on U.S. Tariffs
description: The Bush administration has a new bogeyman in Brussels to contend with.

title: E. van den Haag, 87, Educator And Backer of Death Penalty
description: Ernest van den Haag, a conservative commentator on social issues, especially crime, and a leading advocate of the death penalty, died on Thursday in Mendham, N.J. He was 87 and a longtime resident of the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Diocese Reels After Losing 2 Tainted Bishops
description: The Bishop's Cup annual charity golf tournament, with its local celebrities and big-money buzz, is one of the brightest events on the Palm Beach social calendar.

title: Lighthearted And Buoyed By Ether
description: Inflation Returns. Man Blows Self Up Onstage.

title: Meeting on Ties Between Town and Gown
description: University presidents will meet with mayors on April 8 and 9 to discuss how to strengthen what are known as town/gown relationships. ROGER HULL, the president of Union College, which has helped in the effort to reinvigorate Schenectady, its hometown, will act as host at his campus. The mayors of Albany, Rochester, Canton and Schenectady will represent the civic side. The presidents of Syracuse University, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the Rochester Institute of Technology, Hartwick College, the State University of New York at Binghamton, SUNY's University at Buffalo, SUNY Geneseo and SUNY's Onondaga Community College are also scheduled to attend. Gov. GEORGE E. PATAKI and ROBERT L. KING, the chancellor of SUNY, will be among the speakers at the meeting, which will cover topics like technology parks and entrepreneurship centers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPINS, NATHAN
description: SHAPINS-Nathan. On March 26, 2002. Beloved husband of Dorothy for 61 years. Dear father of Michael, Jerry and Ann, and Holly. Adored grandfather of Lisa and Jonathan Lawrence, and Jesse Shapins, and great-grandfather of Bennett James Lawrence. Brother-in-law of Judith Dicker. Uncle of Marcia and Kenneth, Meryl, Marc, Daniel, Mark and Fran, Jeffrey, Taryn, and Adam. Services today 10AM at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, L.I.

title: Greenspan Says Enron Cure Is in Market, Not Regulation
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the solutions to weaknesses in corporate governance exposed by Enron's collapse rested more with market forces than with new legislation or regulation.

title: Cambodia 32 years later / 'Life is better' : Revisiting a jungle district where war and terror reigned
description: KIRIVONG DISTRICT, Cambodia  Motor scooters piled high with black market goods careered along the narrow dirt road from the border. Beyond, the flag of Vietnam, a yellow star on a red field, hung limply in the afternoon sun.

title: Whipped, Sculptured and Bespeckled
description: THE yolks in Fritz Knipschildt's handmade white chocolate Easter eggs, far left, look amazingly realistic, but the filling is actually a sweet lemon curd. The outsides of the eggs are marbleized: several sizes come packed nine to a box in an excelsior-filled egg tray. A box of eggs, made in Mr. Knipschildt's workshop in Norwalk, Conn., is $32 at Dean & DeLuca, 560 Broadway (Prince Street). A single egg in a tiny basket is $7.

title: Sports of The Times; Some True Heroism Outside of the Lines
description: TOM PACIOREK was what is known in our society as a sports hero, a baseball star, a golden boy. He played the outfield and first base for six major league teams over 18 sun-burnished seasons -- including a brief period with the Mets in 1985. Tom Paciorek played in a World Series with the Dodgers and had a highly respectable lifetime batting average of .282. He hit home runs and batted in clutch runs and made game-saving catches and was cheered lustily in packed ballparks.

title: CBS and Fox Meet With the N.F.L.
description: National Football League officials met yesterday and on Monday with executives from CBS and Fox Sports, hoping to persuade them to agree to a scheduling change that would chiefly benefit the slipping ratings of ABC's ''Monday Night Football.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, GEORGE H.
description: SCOTT-George H., 94. On March 24, peacefully at home in Florida. Adored and cherished husband of Hazel (Leichter) and the late Thelma (Lippman). Loving father of Jane Lande and Nancy and husband Arthur Stampleman. Stepfather of Beth Sommer and Anthony Leichter. Proud and loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Loved and admired by his brothers Nathan and Dr. Benjamin Scott and his many in-laws, nieces and nephews. Funeral services at Paperman and Sons, Montreal, Quebec, 1-800-515-7101. In lieu of flowers, a donation would be appreciated to Mt. Sinai-CVI in honor of, Dr. Valentin Fuster, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 1 Gustave Levy Place, New York, New York 10029, or Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Driver Charged In Death
description: A Queens woman was charged yesterday with driving while impaired by prescription drugs and alcohol after her car hit two firefighters in Greenvale on Monday night, killing a fire captain, the Nassau County police said. The woman, Elizabeth Bartfield, 41, of Forest Hills, was arrested Monday night with a blood alcohol content of 0.05 percent, the police said. Capt. Alan Frye, 31, of Roslyn Rescue was killed during a training exercise on Glen Cove Road, where a lane had been barricaded with barrels, cones and flares. Ms. Bartfield's car went through the barricades and hit the firefighters, the police said. The other, Chris Baffa, was released from North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Evictions Are Upheld

title: Weakened Nets Let the Hawks Run Over Them
description: Atlanta's Shareef Abdur-Rahim spun inside the lane and muscled his way to the basket. The Nets could not stop him.

title: History Is in His Bones and Brain and on His Back
description: IF C. Stevens Laise of the National Park Service had grown up in New York and not Virginia, we might get a more robust expression of his distaste for the exhibitions at the Federal Hall National Memorial in Lower Manhattan.

description: To the Editor:

title: Guerrilla Attacks May Rise In Warmer Days, U.S. Says
description: The Bush administration is concerned that the approach of warmer weather in Afghanistan may signal a sharp rise in guerrilla attacks on American and allied troops, senior officials say.

title: U.S. Fears Absence of Arafat and Mubarak Will Dilute the Impact of Arab Talks
description: Officials of the Bush administration struggled today to prevent the once-promising Arab League meeting in Beirut from turning into an embarrassing setback for American peacemaking efforts in the Middle East.

title: Where the Smoke Rises (and Rises)
description: IN Tennessee towns and at Texas crossroads, and even in urban climes like Memphis and Kansas City, everybody knows how to find the local barbecue joint. Follow your nose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATKINS, TED J.
description: WATKINS-Ted J. Died peacefully at home on March 24, 2002 at age 82. He is survived by his beloved daughter Pamela K. and devoted son-in-law Robert J. Seligman of Manalapan, N.J., and cherished granddaughter Tiffany Dawn Seligman of Manalapan. He is a veteran of W.W. II, serving in the Army from 1942-1946. He was a longtime employee of the Communications Workers of America. He last served in the national office as Executive Assistant to the President prior to his retirement.

title: VAIL RESORTS TO BUY HEAVENLY SKI FOR $96 MILLION
description: Vail Resorts Inc. agreed to buy the Heavenly Ski Resort near Lake Tahoe on the border of Nevada and California from the American Skiing Company for $96 million to $99 million in cash, expanding its West Coast assets. Vail, which is based in Vail, Colo., will pay $102 million to American Skiing, minus a ''cash adjustment'' of as much as $6 million based on the closing date of the purchase, Vail said. Vail said it would spend $25 million over the next five years to replace lifts, add restaurants and improve the snow-making system at Heavenly. American Skiing, based in Newry, Me., has been selling properties to pay off debt added during a 1990's expansion. The Heavenly sale will complete the company's effort to cut debt, it said.

title: Microsoft Judge Seeks Justice Dept.'s View
description: The federal judge hearing a challenge by nine states to the Justice Department's proposed antitrust settlement with Microsoft invited the Bush administration today to say whether the challengers have the authority to do so.

title: Fettig and Kamholz Waived By Power
description: In a surprise move yesterday, the New York Power of the Women's United Soccer Association dropped defender Nel Fettig. Fettig had started all 21 games for the club in 2001, its inaugural season. The Power also waived defender Kalli Kamholz, whom the team acquired recently in a trade with the Philadelphia Charge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, ANNETTE (SHAPIRO)
description: MORSE-Annette (Shapiro). On Tuesday, March 26, 2002. Loving wife of the late Alfred L. Morse. Loving mother of Harriet M. Zimmerman and the late Ellen M. Tishman. Grandmother of Anita Tishman Winkler, Steven M. Tishman, Linda Tishman, Claire Marx, Nancy O'Leary and Robert Altschuler, and great grandmother of 13 great-grandchildren. Graveside services at Temple Israel Cemetery, North Avenue, Wakefield, MA, on Sunday, March 31 at 1:00PM. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the American Israel Education Foundation, 440 First Street NW, Suite 600, Washington, D.C. 20001. For information Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA. (1-617-277-8300).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ISRAEL
description: MILLER-Israel. Consulate General of Israel in New York and the Mission to the U.N. deeply mourn the passing of Rabbi Israel Miller, a prominent Jewish leader and a true advocate for Israel. Rabbi Miller devoted his life to promote Israel's well being, inspiring many with his wisdom and eloquence. His leadership will be sorely missed. Our condolences to his wife, Ruth, and his children, Michael, David, Debbie and Judy.

title: If We Care About City Schools . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cutbacks At American Superconductor
description: Moving to conserve cash in the face of weak demand for its pioneering power-saving products, American Superconductor said yesterday that it would cut 100 jobs, or 25 percent of its work force, and take a charge of up to $11 million, or 54 cents a share, against earnings for the quarter that will end this Sunday. American Superconductor, based in Westborough, Mass., said it would spend less on research and concentrate more on cutting the cost of its current products. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

description: In percent

title: Takeover Plan For Schools In Roosevelt Wins Approval
description: The state would take over the troubled Roosevelt school district on Long Island under an agreement reached by state lawmakers today, but the plan hinges on Gov. George E. Pataki's approval.

title: New Jersey Budget Plan Cuts Aid To Avert Worst Shortfall in U.S.
description: After warning for months that New Jersey faces the worst budget crisis in the nation, Gov. James E. McGreevey unveiled a $23.6 billion spending plan today that sought to avert a $5 billion budget shortfall by cutting aid to parks and universities, increasing cigarette taxes and using some one-time measures to increase revenues.

title: Executives' Windfalls
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTLER, E. NEWTON JR.
description: CUTLER-E. Newton Jr. Of Bryn Mawr, PA. and Edgartown, MA. On March 24th, 2002. Age 86. He graduated from St. Paul's SchoolConcord, N.H. in 1933 and from Princeton University in 1937. He served in W.W. II as a Lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps. He spent over 35 years with Citibank in New York and left as Sr. Vice President to become Chairman of Horizon Bancorp, Morristown, N.J. until his retirement in 1979. In addition to his wife of 64 years, Beverly, he is survived by his two sons Earle N. Cutler III & Michael W. Cutler, 2 daughters, Carolyn C. Goodman and Allison C. Fox, 11 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM on April 2 at St. David's Episcopal Church-Chapel, 763 Valley Forge Road, Wayne, PA. and a similar service will be held this summer in Edgartown, MA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in his memory to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant St, Concord, N.H. 03301 or the Vineyard Sailing Foundation, PO Box 319, Vineyard Haven, MA. 02568. Stuard Funeral Home, Ardmore, PA.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA WILL ACQUIRE EAGLE BANCSHARES
description: The Royal Bank of Canada said it had agreed to acquire Eagle Bancshares Inc. of Atlanta for $153 million to expand its retail banking business in the United States. Eagle Bancshares stockholders will be able to convert each common share into the right to receive $26, said a Royal Bank spokesman, Beja Rodeck. The offer is 49 percent higher than Eagle Bancshares' closing price Monday of $17.50. Royal Bank, based in Toronto, will gain about 90,000 accounts and 14 branches in metropolitan Atlanta, the company said.

title: CREDITORS FORCE POLYMER GROUP INTO BANKRUPTCY COURT
description: The Polymer Group, which makes fabrics used in diapers and surgical products, was forced into bankruptcy court by creditors owed more than $30 million in bond debt. The company, which reported $862 million in fiscal 2000 sales and a $4.32 million loss, said in January that it was considering financial revamping to avoid Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings after obtaining a loan extension. The company, which is based in North Charleston, S.C., said it was discussing a resolution with its creditors.

title: Edison Gets a Share of Philadelphia Contracts
description: Over the objection of dozens of parents, teachers and students chanting, ''Stop corporate greed!'' and ''I am not for sale!'' the state panel overseeing the troubled Philadelphia public schools voted today to engage Edison Schools Inc. and several other for-profit companies to offer the district broad advice on how to better manage its central operations.

title: Save the Last Slurp for Me
description: THE young hard-shell clam, most commonly called the littleneck, has as many charms cooked as it does raw. Either way, its deliciously briny liquid complements the meat's chewy texture, and there is enough of it to create a brothy stew (or chowder if you prefer) with a distinctive flavor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWEN, LOUIS W.
description: BOWEN-Louis W. The Board of Managers and staff of East Side House Settlement are profoundly saddened by the passing of Louis W. Bowen. A dear friend and devoted benefactor, he joined the Board of Managers in 1968 and provided dynamic and tireless leadership of the Winter Show Committee for over 30 years. He also held leadership positions on the Executive, Finance and Nominating Committees. Mr. Bowen was an integral part of the heart and soul of East Side House-his professionalism, dedication, unfailing courtesy and especially his friendship will long be remembered. Joan P. Young, President David L. Duffy, Chairman East Side House Board of Managers John A. Sanchez, Executive Director East Side House Settlement

title: Mayor Limits Use of Water During Crisis
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg declared a drought emergency in New York City yesterday and ordered mandatory restrictions on water use by businesses and residents.

title: In Beirut, Arab Officials Vow To Move on Saudi Peace Plan
description: Senior Arab officials said today that they were determined to push ahead with a Saudi-proposed peace initiative, even though the absence of two crucial participants, Yasir Arafat and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, diminished what had been promoted as a sweeping Arab commitment to transforming relations with Israel.

title: If We Care About City Schools . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebuild Downtown, And Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Finds Room in Its Heart for a French Bistro
description: LIKE a flower poking through the gritty concrete near the mouth of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, Tournesol, a new French bistro in Long Island City, is a spray of brightness on a field of gray. Outside of a couple, winning restaurants don't easily come to mind when you think of Long Island City, and as far as French restaurants in Queens go, well, the 2002 Zagat guide lists exactly one, La Baraka, in Little Neck.

title: Afghan Says U.S. Posture Led to Delay By Zahir Shah
description: A senior Afghan official said today that American reluctance to provide security for the former Afghan king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, set off the events that led him to postpone his return to his homeland after 29 years in exile in Italy.

title: At the Site of the Quake
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Personal Shopper: A Luxury of Choice, Alfresco
