National Briefing | West: California: Injury In A Reality Show
description: A contestant in the first episode of a planned NBC reality-television series called ''Dog Eat Dog'' was hospitalized in Los Angeles after being pulled from a pool where a stunt went wrong. The contestant, a 26-year-old physical trainer whose name was not released, was unconscious and spitting up blood, a witness said. NBC said that the contestant had not lost consciousness and that there were adequate safety precautions for the contest, in which two submerged people tried to see who could hold his breath longer. A network executive said it planned to broadcast the show. Bill Carter (NYT)

title: Virtual Game Weapons Bought With Real Money
description: KEN SELDEN is having a red-letter month selling goods on the Internet. He has unloaded about 400 million pieces of silver, a sanctified claymore and a lot of women's clothing, among other things. His total take is about $9,000. But the merchandise is strictly digital, nothing more than words written on a computer screen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERBST, JOSEPH
description: HERBST-Joseph. It is with deep sorrow that we announce the untimely passing of Joseph Herbst and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Lois. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Frank D'Ambrosio, President Charles Baraf, Secretary

title: Emotions Swirl at Passover Gatherings
description: For Jews across the New York region, Passover arrived at sunset yesterday with a forbidding chill of anger and frustration over the latest suicide bombing in Israel.

title: It's Williams vs. Williams After Serena Routs Hingis
description: Serena Williams, who now hungers to match the ranking achievement of her sister Venus, overwhelmed Martina Hingis, 6-4, 6-0, today at the Nasdaq 100 and will get a crack at her older sibling in the semifinals.

title: Foes of New Campaign Law Bring Two Suits Against It
description: Shortly after President Bush signed the campaign finance bill, Senator Mitch McConnell, Congress's most outspoken opponent of it, filed suit in federal court here today challenging its constitutionality.

title: Drugs and Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: A Virtual Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COREN, ROSE L.
description: COREN-Rose L. Died Sunday March 24, 2002. Wife of Arthur, mother of Jonathan and Charlotte, mother-in-law of Pam and Hal. Grandmother of Justin, Perry, Benjamin and Lauren, sister of Esther Abramson. A graduate of Hunter College, former chairperson of the Department of Biological Sciences at NYC Technical College, Docent at the Museum of Jewish Heritage, active community member. A dynamic and intellectual participant in life, she was a sensitive and caring human being who will be missed by all who knew her. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage, 212968-1800 x174, Lanie.

title: A Summer That Melted Conventions
description: Boundaries warp and melt in the dense urban heat that pervades ''Franny's Way,'' Richard Nelson's sensitively drawn portrait of love in the age of J. D. Salinger. The lines between childhood and adulthood blur disorientingly for the three generations of characters gathered in a cramped apartment in Greenwich Village at the height of summer in the 1950's.

title: Player Brings Convergence To the Family Room
description: Just as the all-in-one computer helped alleviate the frustrations of home users trying to get their technology up and running with a minimum of Advil, home theater systems are becoming simpler to set up.

title: Nonstate TV In Russia Wins License To Broadcast
description: A team of Russian journalists, shut off the airwaves in January in bankruptcy proceedings they say were rigged, scored a victory today when they won the right to continue broadcasting on national television.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: N.A.A.C.P. Head Criticizes Study of Turnpike Arrests
description: The president of the New Jersey conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People criticized the state's racial analysis of speeding motorists on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday, calling the data flawed and contending that state troopers will use it to justify racial profiling.

title: Now All You Need Is an Ottoman for the Monitor
description: Furniture has never been as functional as Soldam's Prism Plus, the new desk that turns into a desktop. The Prism has a campy vision-of-the-future look, with its visible circuitry and blinking lights, but the desk itself is simply a computer case. Users must buy and install components like motherboards and drives.

title: Drink-Size Tables And Conceptual Bowls: A Young Designer Rethinks the Everyday
description: ''I was a bit stuck in Israel,'' said Ron Gilad, an Israeli industrial designer who had studied at the Bezalel Academy of Art and Design in Jerusalem. He arrived in New York last year searching for adventure. Paola Antonelli, a design curator at the Museum of Modern Art who has recommended his work to the MoMA store, said: ''There really was no design tradition in Israel except Judaica. Most design there was for practical things like gas masks. Who cared about sofas and chairs?'' Now Mr. Gilad, 29, far right with his vases, is providing adventure for followers of his fresh designs, which include the Personal Mobile Coffee Table, bottom right, actually a table leg with four diminutive legs of its own. The handmade 18-inch-high beech table holds one drink; sets of three are $1,200. ''I am trying to deconstruct the form of useful objects,'' Mr. Gilad said last week in his SoHo studio. Vases inspired by curving, wilting and splitting flower stems, left, and fruit bowls without sides, top right, are playfully conceptual.

title: U.N. Official Calls for a Much Larger International Force in Afghanistan
description: A United Nations investigator urged a significant expansion of the international security force in Afghanistan, warning that failing to do this could torpedo efforts to create democratic institutions in the war-devastated country.

title: Andersen Chief Says He Quit As a Sacrifice To Aid the Staff
description: In the end, it was the demonstrations of Andersen employees that clinched the decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BERNARD
description: SCHWARTZ-Bernard. A dear sweet man left us in an instant Sunday, March 24. Loving husband of Sally, adoring father of Steffi Hausfater (Jere) and Nancy Sperber, devoted grandfather of Matthew, Jonathan, Suzanne and Noah, and dear friend of his first wife, Bunnie Schwartz Moses. His humor, insight, kind heart and gentle ways will be sorely missed and remembered always by all who knew him. Graveside service Friday, March 29 11am, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Betrayed by the Bar
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Uphold Verdict Against Killer Represented By Victim's Ex-Lawyer
description: A sharply divided Supreme Court today upheld the conviction and death sentence of a Virginia inmate whose court-appointed lawyer had represented the murder victim in an unrelated case until the victim's death.

title: Neighborhoods That Gentrify
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx School Defies Norm, With Whites Lagging on Tests
description: At first glance, Public School 8 in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx seems a fairly typical New York City school. It has about 1,200 students, 84 percent of them poor enough to qualify for the federal free lunch program. It is overcrowded, with a waiting list for kindergarten and up to 32 students per class. Nearly a third of its students are children of immigrants and are learning English as a second language.

title: Jim Brown Is a Prisoner on His Own Terms
description: Jim Brown is on the telephone from Ventura County Jail in California, and the sense of irony does not escape him. Normally when Brown, a Hall of Fame running back, steps into a prison, he is counseling inmates, preparing them for the day their sentences end and they attempt to become functioning members of society. Now, Brown is not an adviser who will stay for a few hours, then depart. He is locked up in a cell the size of a walk-in closet. The teacher has become a prisoner.

title: Betrayed by the Bar
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: War Prisoners Lose Compensation Bid
description: The Tokyo High Court rejected an appeal for government compensation for 150,000 civilians and military personnel held prisoner in Asia during World War II. The ruling was the latest in a string of legal setbacks for people seeking compensation from Japan for war-related atrocities and human rights abuses. The seven plaintiffs who represent larger organizations of former prisoners, said they would make a final appeal in the seven-year-old case. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column last Thursday about the film ''Gosford Park'' referred incorrectly to the filming of the fictional house where most of it was set. Two English estates, not three, were used to represent the house. As the report noted, the bedrooms were from Syon House, near London, and the drawing rooms from Wrotham Park, in Middlesex. But the exterior shots were also filmed at Wrotham Park; Luton Hoo, in Bedfordshire, was used to represent the exterior of the house of the character played by Maggie Smith.

title: Footlights
description: Twin Bill

title: Auditing Firm Goes in Search Of Direction
description: A day after their worldwide chief executive announced that he would resign, partners at Arthur Andersen engaged in a fierce debate yesterday over what strategy the accounting firm should take.

title: Taking the Plunge, Gown and All; 'Incubator' Adds Business Know-How to Fashion Sense
description: The boutique sits on a relatively quiet stretch of Orchard Street on the Lower East Side.

title: PepsiCo wants to link its new lemon-lime soft drink with 'Ahhh.'
description: THE commercial opens on a caveman trekking across a desert searching for water when he is clunked in the head by a falling rock. Five thousand years later, he is found encased in a block of ice. As explorers chip away at him, he suddenly comes alive, saying ''Ahhh.''

title: A Hell on Earth, Lived by Children and Parents
description: ''God's Children,'' an unblinking documentary portrait of hell on earth (or at least one version of it), focuses on the desperate lives of three families eking out a living in the enormous Payatas garbage dump on the outskirts of Quezon City, in the Philippines. Facing malnutrition, disease and a high infant mortality rate, the families display remarkable dignity in the face of disaster.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I would further say to the Israeli people that if their government abandons the policy of force and oppression and embraces true peace, we will not hesitate to accept the right of the Israeli people to live in security with the people of the region.''

title: Who's to Blame at Andersen?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLOWAY, GAIL FISKE
description: HOLLOWAY-Gail Fiske, 66. Of Buck Hill Falls, PA and formerly of Manhattan, died March 26. Predeceased by her husband, Edward Holloway, Jr. and son ''Quint''. She was a graduate of the Chapin School and Columbia University, & a member of DAR. Survived by her mother, Ruth (Winckelmann) Fiske, daughter Hope Holloway, and sister Jane Fiske McHugh. Funeral on Saturday, March 30, at noon from Canadensis United Methodist Church, Canadensis, PA. Viewing from 11AM-Noon at the church. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to the Chapin School, 100 East End Ave., NY NY.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Tuesday with an obituary of Csar Milstein, who shared a Nobel Prize in medicine in 1984, was published in error. It showed Dr. Paul C. Lauterbur, a professor of chemistry and research professor of radiology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook; the scientists appeared in a group photograph after receiving Albert Lasker awards for medical research in 1984.

title: An Elegant Gilded Stylus For the Fin-de-Sicle Palm
description: Some products that are useful also make a statement. Montblanc, the maker of luxury writing instruments, has introduced the Touch Pen line of styluses for the Palm V hand-held computer. Making that Montblanc statement of elegance will cost you $45 for the gold-plated or platinum-plated version, or $3,910 for the diamond-studded solid platinum model. (There are also diamond-studded versions in stainless steel for $1,465 and solid gold for $2,930. Be sure not to lose yours, because the description would look awfully strange on an insurance claim form.)

title: Corrections
description: The ''Most Wanted'' chart in Business Day on Monday omitted a magazine from a list of the top 10 ranked by advertising revenue for February. Sports Illustrated was first, with revenue of $74.8 million.

title: Accounts
description: * Maryland Department of Human Resources Child Support Enforcement Administration, Baltimore, to Eisner Communications, Baltimore, to handle its advertising, marketing and public relations account. Spending for a three-year contract was estimated to total $6 million. The contract, which is subject to approval by the state, also has an additional two one-year renewal options. The administration has not worked with an agency since September 2000.

title: Changing Identities as Often as Socks
description: THE IMPRESSIONIST

title: President Signs Bill On Campaign Gifts; Begins Money Tour
description: President Bush signed a major overhaul of the nation's campaign finance system into law without ceremony today, then almost immediately left Washington on Air Force One for a two-day, three-state trip to raise nearly $4 million for Republican candidates and his party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, JANET WILLIAMS (FORMERLY JANET WILLIAMS MEDINA)
description: TOBIN-Janet Williams (formerly Janet Williams Medina), 85. Of Delray Beach passed away peacefully on Monday, March 25, 2002. She was born in NYC, daughter of the late Herbert D. and Nina Williams. Mrs. Tobin had been President of the Board of Trustees of The Spence School, the first woman on the Board of the Legal Aid Society of NY, and served on the Boards of the YWCA of the City of NY, the Grosvenor Neighborhood House & many others. She & her late husband, Harold R. Medina, Jr. moved to the Country Club of FL. in 1967. They were married for 53 years. She is survived by her devoted husband of nine years, Joshua B. Tobin, sons Harold III and Robert, and daughter Ann Medina, and grandchildren Scott Medina, Elizabeth Whitney and Rachel Medina, in addition to her first great-grandchild, George Whitney. A small private family service will be held. Donations can be made to The Critical Care Fund of the Bethesda Hospital Foundation at P.O. Box 2200, Delray Beach, Florida 33447, or to The First Presbyterian Church of Delray Beach at 33 Gleason St, Delray Beach, Florida 33483.

title: Blackburn Stands Out Amid Ranger Wreckage
description: Dan Blackburn earned the standing ovation he received at Madison Square Garden late in the second period last night. The rest of the Rangers could not evade the boos that came with another loss, this one by 4-2 to the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: INSTINET ISSUES WARNING OF A POSSIBLE LOSS
description: The Instinet Group, the electronic stock-trading network, said yesterday that it would probably post a first-quarter loss and would take a bigger-than-forecast charge as it increased efforts to cut costs. It said it wanted to reduce annual operating costs by $120 million, up from its previous estimate of $60 million and expected restructuring charges of $55 million in the first half, up from $25 million. Competition has prompted a price war with a rival, Island ECN, and Instinet has cut prices twice to try to recapture the top position in Nasdaq trading, which it ceded to Island in November. Instinet, based in New York, is majority owned by Reuters.

title: Valentino sale reveals sour market for high-end firms : Luxury has gone out of fashion
description: PARIS:  The Valentino fashion house was sold Wednesday, after six months on the block, at a discount that signals the bursting of a seven-year bubble of rising prices for luxury companies  and the end of a feeding frenzy of acquisitions in the luxury market.

title: Tracking Missiles Launched From the Mound
description: BASEBALL fans who watched major league games on Fox's cable stations last season may remember seeing a kind of instant replay, generated entirely by a computer, showing the path of selected pitches.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Beauty In The Eye Of The Government
description: Vietnamese women are now officially beautiful. For the first time, the Communist government will recognize and certify the winner of a Miss Vietnam contest that has been held by a newspaper every other year since 1988. Unmarried women between the ages of 16 and 27 will be eligible to compete in September and the winner will receive $2,650 in a country where the average annual income is just over $300. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: F.B.I. Document Search Ordered
description: Advancing a privacy group's effort to obtain more information about an Internet monitoring system used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a Federal District Court judge has ordered the F.B.I. to conduct a new search for documents regarding the surveillance system. After the existence of the system, which is known as Carnivore, was disclosed in July 2000, the Washington-based Electronic Privacy Information Center filed a Freedom of Information request seeking the release of records related to it and later filed a lawsuit to expedite the process. Although more than 1,000 pages of documents were released last year, the court this week ordered the F.B.I. to search more offices for records by May 24, including the bureau's offices of general counsel and Congressional and public affairs. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Patients Surge And Hospitals Hunt for Beds
description: Paul Hochenberg, the executive director of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, was desperate to find more beds. So last year, as occupancy for his hospital climbed to more than 95 percent, he gave up his own office and his staff's so the hospital could convert the area to a 15-bed unit for patients who were being observed for a day or two.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a listing last Thursday with an article about Dotty Volpe and Dolly Sturman, redecorators who work with the furniture and accessories their clients already own, omitted part of the name of a redecorating business in Upper Montclair, N.J., that takes a similar approach. It is By Design Interiors, not Design Interiors.

title: Seducing Paris, a Cafe at a Time
description: TWO weeks ago, the new Costes brothers restaurant, tienne Marcel, threw open its doors. There was no opening night party, but word of mouth was enough to pack the house with what the French call ''pipole,'' the hip, the beautiful and the famous.

title: CALENDAR
description: Landscape Preservation

title: With Mathis Playing for U.S., MetroStars' Offense Stagnates
description: One thing became evident in the MetroStars' 1-0 loss to the Columbus Crew tonight in their second game of the season: they are not the same without Clint Mathis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 16 about a settlement by Consolidated Edison, environmentalists and community groups to reduce air pollution from a power plant on East 14th Street in Manhattan gave an incorrect figure from a Con Ed spokeswoman for the number of stacks the company agreed to equip with a filtration device. It was one, not all four.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Currents column last Thursday about the book ''Case Study Houses: The Complete CSH Program 1946-66'' (Taschen), by Elizabeth Smith, referred imprecisely to its price. The list price is $150; $105 is the price on Amazon.com.

title: EMERSON CUTS SALES FORECAST, SAYING DEMAND IS WEAK
description: The Emerson Electric Company, which makes power systems for telecommunications networks, has reduced its sales forecast for the 2002 fiscal year. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Emerson said customer orders for the three months that ended Sunday dropped 15 percent to 20 percent from the year-earlier period. The company foresees sales improving more slowly than expected in the fiscal year ending in September. Emerson, based in St. Louis, is trying to reduce costs after spending about $2.5 billion on acquisitions just before demand collapsed.

title: Economic Scene; One theory on why it seems easier to buy a house in the nation's 'red' zone.
description: ARE there really two Americas, the ''red'' conservative heartland and the ''blue'' liberal coasts? Extrapolating from the 2000 election results, political commentators like to think so. The electoral map has morphed into a mental map, a shorthand for different regional cultures.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Challenge To Budget Cuts
description: The Legislature is joining several advocacy groups in a court challenge to Gov. John Kitzhaber's decision to veto parts of the state budget and fill the gap with cuts in services. The governor, a Democrat, said his allocation authority allowed him to rebalance the budget after he vetoed more than $85 million in new revenues, mostly from tobacco settlement proceeds. Republicans, who control both chambers in the Legislature, say the governor exceeded his authority by eliminating specific programs instead of ordering general cuts. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Death Sentence Now a Life Term For Millionaire in Florida Case
description: In what the defense called ''a bittersweet victory,'' a judge followed a jury's recommendation today and sentenced a onetime British millionaire to life in prison for double murder, taking him off Florida's death row after 16 years.

title: Dangers in the Night
description: Q. I use my New York terrace garden mostly in the evenings, so I prefer night-blooming flowers with scents strong enough to stand up to wafting car fumes. Daturas are favorites, but one time I got some sap in my eye, and the pupil was dilated for days. Just how poisonous are these plants, anyway?

title: Returning After 28 Years, Leading an Army of Brass
description: Bigger means better to Roy Wood, the English rocker whose four shows at the Village Underground were his first New York City performances since 1974. His music has always equated blare with rock 'n' roll bliss.

title: Not the Best of Times, but Manhattan Hotels See Encouraging Signs
description: At the W Hotel in Times Square one recent evening, Oksana Baiul, the Olympic figure-skating champion from Ukraine, went slinking through the lobby in a short black dress and a pearl necklace. Nearby, John Corbett of HBO's ''Sex and the City'' was standing close to a real estate developer who was hobknobbing with Elizabeth Jagger, Bridget Hall and other supermodels.

title: L.P.G.A. Asks Players' Help In Attracting More Fans
description: In his state-of-the-Tour address, Commissioner Ty Votaw of the L.P.G.A. said today that he was optimistic about the future but realistic about the organization's need to promote its product aggressively.

title: Budget Plan By McGreevey Raises Doubts
description: Before presenting his first budget proposal on Tuesday, Gov. James E. McGreevey promised to end the state's bad fiscal habits of excessive borrowing, profligate spending and reliance on one-time measures to increase state revenues.

title: Computer Associates Names 2 to Board Seats
description: Computer Associates International Inc., a leading software maker, named two outside directors to its board. The announcement came as a shareholder, Sam Wyly, reemerged as a dissident seeking to oust the chairman.

title: One-Way Discussion on Energy
description: Energy Department documents now confirm what everyone has long suspected -- that in seeking guidance on its energy strategy last year, the Bush administration welcomed industry executives and lobbyists with open arms, while treating environmental groups like skunks at a picnic. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham, for example, held meetings last year with dozens of industry representatives directly involving the energy plan between late January and May 17, when the White House released its energy report. But he did not meet with conservationists or consumer advocates. The documents also suggest that while staff members of Vice President Dick Cheney's energy task force eventually consulted environmentalists, they did not do so until late in the game, and then in a perfunctory manner.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Retrial Denied For Ex-Officers
description: Two former police officers found guilty of running a brothel have been denied a new trial, even after a witness recanted his testimony. The former New Brunswick officers, James Marshall and Marco Chinchilla, were convicted in October of promoting prostitution. A witness, Robert Rogers, said recently that he had received help with unrelated charges in other courts in return for testimony favorable to the prosecution. In an opinion issued on Tuesday, Judge Barnett Hoffman of State Superior Court said he did not believe Mr. Rogers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 7 about the singer Cassandra Wilson misspelled part of the name of the town in Alabama where she rented a mobile sound truck for a recording session. It is Muscle Shoals, not Mussel.

title: Afghans Grapple With Earthquake's Toll, and Face More Misery
description: On the road in, the wreckage pointed the way.

title: A Daughter Who Dies, and a Son Who Never Was
description: Apparently, there can't be a New Directors/New Film series without a Dogma 95 film, and this year's contribution from that Danish collective, which is being shown tonight, is ''Truly Human,'' a no-tech ghost story crossed with ''Being There.'' When Lisa (Clara Nepper Winther), a girl with a halo of blond curls and a sullen face, says to the wall, ''We're moving,'' the reverse angle suggests that the wall has eyes -- the girl in greenish-tinted black-and-white, as if someone were peering at her through a swimming pool.

title: Testaverde Has Benign Tumor Removed
description: Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde had a small, benign bone tumor removed from a toe on his right foot Tuesday, team officials said yesterday. The Jets expect him to be ready when training camp begins on July 27.

title: France Warns It Opposes Death Penalty In Terror Trial
description: The French government has warned the United States that it might end its cooperation in the investigation of Zacarias Moussaoui, a French citizen who is the only person charged so far in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, if the United States seeks the death penalty in the case, American officials said today.

title: Goldman Names 3 Executives To Share Vice Chairman Post
description: The Goldman Sachs Group, one of the biggest and most profitable investment banks on Wall Street, appointed three senior executives to be vice chairmen yesterday and promoted other executives to assume their roles.

title: Thousands in Manhattan Needed Therapy After Attack, Study Finds
description: In the aftermath of the World Trade Center collapse, tens of thousands of Manhattan residents suffered emotional difficulties severe enough to warrant psychiatric treatment, according to a report in the new issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, out today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HERN, PHILIP E., CSP.
description: O'HERN-Philip E., CSP. On March 26, 2002 at age 95. He was born into a military family on August 6, 1902 in West Point, New York. Fr. O'Hern was ordained by his uncle Bishop John Francis O'Hern in Rochester, New York, on June 11, 1932. His assignments included Old Saint Mary's Cathedral in San Francisco, military chaplain during World War II when at the end of the War his hospital unit entered the Nazi death camp at Ebensee where he stayed for two months. He returned to the states to serve at St. Philip Neri Church, Portland Oregon, Saint Paul the Apostle in Manhattan and Old Saint Mary's in the Chicago Loop. Since 1970 Fr. O'Hern served Southern parishes, Clemson, SC, Mobile, AL, Houston, Texas, and finally at Saint Austin's Parish in Austin, TX. He died as the oldest living Paulist with links to the founders of the order. Viewing will be 2:15 PM until 7:00 PM, Monday, April 1 at St. Austin's Parish, 2026 Guadalupe Street, Austin, Texas 78705-5609. This will be followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at 7:30 PM. Burial will take place on Tuesday, April 2 at Assumption Cemetery in Austin, TX.

title: And the Winner Is . . . Oscar History
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Weighs the Fate of Child Immigrants
description: In January 2001, Malik Jarno, described by his lawyers as a mentally retarded Guinean who is now 17, arrived at Dulles International Airport in Virginia. He said he was seeking sanctuary from political persecution that had left his family dead.

title: So New, and So Veteran, 1,359 Police Graduates Are Praised
description: Many of them were police officers before they ever finished their training. All of them are the first to join the Police Department since the attack on the World Trade Center. And yesterday, the 1,359 newly minted officers made up the first graduating class of police officers presided over by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, with his police commissioner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOREK, SUSAN
description: BOREK-Susan. The Officers Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of Susan, daughter of our Master Club Professional Gene Borek and extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Corey B. Rabin, President Joyce Baumgarten, Secretary

title: Drug Ruling Worries Some in Public Housing
description: Herman Walker is getting too old for all this worry. His feet ache from 79 years of wear and tear; lingering complications from a stroke five years ago have him in and out of his doctor's office; and he is bone-tired. The last thing he needs to fret about is getting kicked out of his apartment and ending up on the street.

title: A Virtual Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Poles and Jews Refashion Old World Ties
description: Stefanya, a doleful, aging Pole, sat on a milk crate early yesterday morning in Brooklyn, vowing that she would work for no less than $10 an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONETTI, THOMAS
description: MONETTI-Thomas. In Danbury, CT., March 27, 2002, age 55, of Greenwich Ave., New York, NY. Brother of Joseph & Gary Monetti. Mass of Christian Burial Holy Family Church, 315 East 47th St., NY, N.Y., Monday, April 1, 2002 at 1:00PM. Calling hrs Honan Funeral Home, 58 Main St., Newtown, CT, Friday, March 29, 2002 6-9 PM.

title: A Russian Rhapsody With the Power to Jolt
description: The adventurous Canadian pianist Marc-Andr Hamelin brought a fascinating ''Russian Avant-Garde'' program to the Miller Theater on Tuesday and played it with his customary brilliance and insight.

title: Doctor Called Likely Source Of Hepatitis In Patients
description: State health officials said yesterday that they planned to track down and urge testing of up to 3,000 patients who may have been exposed to potentially fatal hepatitis while undergoing operations by an infected cardiac surgeon on Long Island.

title: Another Bloomberg Toll Idea: Charge Out-of-Towners More
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has never come right out and said that he would like to place tolls on the East River bridges into Manhattan, but his administration accounted for them in the proposed budget plan for 2006, and has conceded that they are under consideration.

title: Once Again, Japan's Fix Is Short Term
description: It is an old ritual here by now. As the fiscal year nears its close on March 31, fears of a financial meltdown reach fever pitch. Alarmed investors head for the exits, raising even more worries that the nation's banks will collapse after losing billions of dollars on their stock and bond holdings.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Justice Will Retire
description: Major B. Harding, the second-longest serving member of the Florida Supreme Court, said he would resign on Aug. 31. The resignation will give Gov. Jeb Bush, a Republican, the opportunity to name a new justice to the seven-member court. Justice Harding, 66, appointed in 1991 by Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, opposed the manual recount of all Florida presidential ballots that was ordered by the court in December 2000. That recount was halted the next day by the United States Supreme Court. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, EDITH
description: HALPERN-Edith. The Board of Trustees of the Central Park Conservancy is deeply saddened by the passing of Edith Halpern. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Nathan, a Life Trustee of the Central Park Conservancy, and the entire Halpern family. Since the founding days of the Conservancy more than two decades ago, the Halperns have been generous with their support and counsel. Their contributions to Central Park will benefit visitors for generations to come. A.J.C. Smith, Chairman Regina S. Peruggi, President The Board of Trustees, Central Park Conservancy

title: The Driving Force for Maryland
description: He stomps on the sideline, and sometimes his feet leave the floor and land with a startling thud. His arms flail as if he were a cop at an intersection trying to orchestrate traffic to heavy metal music. He glares, bellows, screams and sweats so much that each season he buys 10 new suits. Win or lose, Maryland Coach Gary Williams always looks the same after a game, like a patient rolled out of surgery: exhausted, hurting and not ready for anything beyond sucking ice chips.

title: Postell Lives Up to His Words
description: By calling himself a future All-Star, saying he was as good as Latrell Sprewell and Allan Houston, and all but begging for the opportunity to someday guard Kobe Bryant, the Knicks' Lavor Postell created a bit of an uproar before tonight's game.

title: Army Secretary Defends His Dealings With Enron
description: Thomas E. White, a former Enron executive who is now Army secretary, defended today the timing of his sale of millions of dollars in Enron stock late last year, saying that numerous conversations he had with Enron executives at that time did not guide his decisions.

title: Mace Brown, 92, Pitcher Who Gave Up Hartnett's 'Homer in the Gloamin''
description: Mace Brown, an outstanding relief pitcher who yielded one of baseball's most memorable home runs, Gabby Hartnett's ''homer in the gloamin' '' that propelled the Chicago Cubs to the 1938 National League pennant, died Sunday at his home in Greensboro, N.C. He was 92.

title: Father and Son Are Shot and Killed in Queens Home
description: A 66-year-old retired restaurant supply salesman and his son were shot to death in their Queens home yesterday morning, the authorities said.

title: A Cellphone That Opens With a Swing, Not a Flip
description: For those who miss the rotary phone dial, Motorola has a partial solution. The company's new V70 cellphone has a circular face and a rotating action, not in the dial, but in the chassis. Instead of flipping up, the silver front cover spins. At 180 degrees, it snaps into the fully open position with a satisfying click. Now if they could only make it feel like Bakelite.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: XBOX Sales Estimate Cut
description: Analysts with the SoundView Technology Group, an investment bank, lowered their estimates for sales of Microsoft's inaugural video game console, the Xbox, citing performances in Japan and Europe that were weaker than expected. The analysts, Mark Specker and Shawn Milne, said that they expected Microsoft to miss its sales predictions of 4.5 million to 6 million consoles for its fiscal year, which ends June 30. SoundView lowered its estimates to 4.35 million from 4.6 million, with 62 percent of those sales coming from the United States. In spite of ''subdued launches'' in Europe and Japan, SoundView said, Microsoft had won 22 percent of the market for next-generation game systems in the United States market, demonstrating commercial viability of the Xbox. Officials of Xbox were not available to comment.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA WINS CONTRACTS WORTH $1 BILLION
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said it had received contracts in the United States and Europe valued at $1 billion. The agreements, with governments and businesses, were signed this year, an Electronic Data spokesman, John Clendening, said. The deals included an eight-year contract with the British post office to process benefit payments; a multiyear deal with ABN Amro Bank to process data and support its business in India; and a one-year deal with the United States government to process Medicare claims.

title: Pennington Watches, Waits and Wonders
description: The two quarterbacks spoke briefly on a game day last December, one of them already entrenched as the season's Cinderella, the other preparing for yet another Sunday cradling a clipboard.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NIIT LTD., New Delhi, a software maker and computer training company, said it had bought Osprey Systems, Charlotte, N.C., a provider of management software services, for $3 million in a bid to increase sales.

title: Islanders' Hot Streak Ends With A Fizzle
description: Eleven days ago, the Islanders closed the door to their dressing room after a one-goal loss in Ottawa and searched for answers about where their season was headed after they had dropped five of seven games. The Islanders regrouped and earned points in each of their next four contests, winning three and losing in overtime to Toronto. They crept within 4 points of the Ottawa Senators for fifth place in the Eastern Conference.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Presumption Of Intelligence
description: A High Court judge turned down lawsuits by 36 people suing McDonald's for scalding burns they said were caused by hot drinks. Justice Richard Field said people who buy coffee or tea know it is hot and can burn if spilled. ''I am quite satisfied that McDonald's were entitled to assume the consumer would know that the drink was hot, and there are numerous commonplace ways of speeding up cooling, such as stirring and blowing,'' he reasoned. The outcome was in marked contrast to a similar case in the United States, where a woman from Albuquerque, N.M., who was scalded by hot coffee in 1992 was awarded $160,000 and McDonald's was assessed punitive damages of $480,000 before the case was settled for an undisclosed amount. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Durst's Lawyer Says Killing In Texas Was in Self-Defense
description: Robert A. Durst's lawyer told a Texas judge yesterday that Mr. Durst, a member of the Manhattan real estate family who is accused of murdering an elderly neighbor in Galveston, had acted in self-defense during an encounter with the neighbor.

title: INSIDE
description: Death Sentence Is Upheld

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hoboken: Utility To Improve Electric Grid
description: Public Service Electric and Gas is taking steps to strengthen its power grid in Hoboken, which experienced scattered power failures last summer. Additional electric lines are being installed in the northern section of the city, where residents intermittently lost power after several circuits failed during a hot spell in August. The utility is installing the lines as part of a $1.1 million project, scheduled for completion by June 1. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Challenge To Inmate Rules To Advance
description: A lawyer for a terrorist convicted in the embassy bombings trial has successfully argued that he should be paid by the government for his planned legal challenge to Justice Department rules allowing prison officials to eavesdrop on inmates' conversations with their lawyers. The lawyer, Frederick H. Cohn, argued that if he were not paid, his client, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, might be denied effective representation in the challenge. The government did not oppose Mr. Cohn's request. But Mr. Cohn was asked to present his case to a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which granted the request on Tuesday. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Lighten Up on S.U.V.'s!
description: To the Editor:

title: Expired Domains; New Path to Web For Pornography
description: PORNOGRAPHY has been a persistent presence on the Web. Now, with the number of expiring domain names on the rise, it has found new ways to infiltrate the desktop.

title: Chicago Takes Over 4th Place
description: Steve Passmore, starting consecutive games for only the second time this season, made 16 saves as Chicago beat visiting Nashville, 4-1, last night.

title: Pharmacists Attack Union Over Prescriptions by Mail
description: The hospital workers' union, 1199/S.E.I.U., was founded as a union for pharmacists, but now New York's pharmacists are attacking the union over a cost-saving program in which workers obtain mail-order prescriptions from a nonunion company in Texas.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Premier Sees Taxi Conspiracy
description: Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra is worried that taxi drivers are gossiping about him. Not just idle gossip, he says, but ''a devilish practice'' organized in an effort to discredit him. Mr. Thaksin, whose government has been accused of trying to stifle criticism by the press, said an unnamed opposition group had hired people to ride around in taxis criticizing him so that the taxi drivers would spread the bad word. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: All-Spam Station

title: Broadcasting Awards Cite Sept. 11 Work
description: Coverage of the events of Sept. 11 by ABC News and National Public Radio, two documentaries on the lives of Afghan women broadcast by CNN, and ABC's ''Nightline'' were among the winners yesterday when the 61st annual Peabody Awards were announced.

title: At Columbia, Police Recruiters Draw Little Interest, Good or Bad
description: On the first day of the Police Department's Ivy League recruitment campaign yesterday, turnout was so poor that a forum at Columbia on 21st-century policing had to be canceled. But recruiters still managed to sign up more than 35 students willing to take the next police examination.

title: Poverty and Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, JACOB W.
description: ABRAHAM-Jacob W. We mourn the passing of the Honourable Jacob W. Abraham, whose distinguished career was marked by wisdom, compassion, deep spirituality and love of the law. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to his loving wife Regina. We shall all miss him. Rest in peace, dear cousin. Ruth Rosenberg and family

title: Milton Berle, TV's First Star As 'Uncle Miltie,' Dies at 93
description: Milton Berle, the brash comedian who emerged from vaudeville, nightclubs, radio and films to become the first star of television, igniting a national craze for the new medium in the late 1940's, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93.

title: Mortgage Applications Up
description: An index that measures applications for mortgages rose last week, reflecting gains in refinancing and home purchases, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Holy Thursday, Good Friday and the first and second days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Celine Dion Nails It Down

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an increase in defaults on federally insured mortgages in the New York City region misstated the title of Paul Muolo of The National Mortgage News, who discussed the trend, and misstated the paper's home city. He is executive editor, not executive director. The newspaper is published in New York, not Washington.

title: A Seminary Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Presidential Health Picks
description: President Bush has finally chosen his nominees for two of the nation's top health positions, the director of the National Institutes of Health and the surgeon general. Both have compelling personal biographies -- rising from obscurity and hardship to great prominence -- but are relatively unknown outside their fields. Their views on social and ethical issues are a mystery, but the White House seems certain that neither is likely to challenge Mr. Bush's policies on hot-button issues like embryonic stem cells, cloning and sex education.

title: World Briefing | World: Demand For AIDS Funds Exceeds Supply
description: Developing countries have asked the Global Fund to Fight AIDS for some $1.15 billion this year -- twice as much as the fund has available, officials said. When the fund was set up last year, the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, asked for governments to contribute $7 billion to $10 billion a year to battle AIDS as well as tuberculosis and malaria, but so far only $1.9 billion has been pledged. Of that, no more than $800 million will be available for use this year, the Geneva-based fund said. Among the requests from developing countries, some 36 nations in Africa have asked for $641 million. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Who's to Blame at Andersen?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixed Holiday Traditions
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Job Cuts At BT
description: The BT Group said it would eliminate about 1,200 jobs at its BT Retail division by March 2004, as it closes 53 call centers. BT also said it would spend 100 million to upgrade the technology used at 30 other call sites. The job cuts are in addition to 13,000 staff reductions over three years announced in December, Gerard Bithell, a spokesman, said. They are part of 5,000 to 6,000 reductions that BT plans to make in 2002. BT Retail sells fixed-line phone and Internet services to consumers and small businesses. Its call centers handle about 2.2 million calls a day. The job cuts will be made either through attrition or by relocating employees to other BT divisions. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: D'Arcy Will Close Its St. Louis Office
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, part of the Bcom3 Group, said yesterday that it would close its office in St. Louis, where a predecessor of the agency began almost a century ago.

title: Review Shows Energy Industry's Recommendations to Bush Ended Up Being National Policy
description: A review of documents released this week by the Department of Energy showed that several recommendations from energy industry representatives were written into the White House's national energy report and into an executive order signed by President Bush.

title: Owners Lost Leverage, Lawyer Says
description: Contrary to the union's view, a baseball management lawyer said yesterday that the owners gave up significant bargaining leverage with Commissioner Bud Selig's pledge not to lock out the players or unilaterally impose new work rules during this season or the postseason.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SHEA, BERNADETTE (NEE DOWNES)
description: O'SHEA - Bernadette (nee Downes). On March 27, 2002. Beloved wife of Nelligan, devoted mother of Mary Ann O'Callahan, John, Michael, Bernadette O'Shea Weir, Elizabeth and Thomas O'Shea. Loving sister of Stephen, John, Thomas and William Downes, Margaret Ardino and the late Robert and Nicholas Downes, Ann Maguire and Joseph Downes. Cherished grandmother to ten grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch & Son Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Blvd, Sunnyside, NY, Friday and Saturday 2-5 and 79:30PM. Funeral Mass Queen of Angels R.C. Church, Monday 10:30am. Interment Calvary Cemetery. No visitation Easter Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAY, DOROTHY
description: DeLAY-Dorothy. The School for Strings mourns the passing of longtime Advisory Board member, Dorothy DeLay. Adele Hogan, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Louise Behrend Founder and Director Alexander Yudkovsky Executive Director

title: Soreness In Elbow Still Nags El Duque
description: Orlando Hernndez was suspicious today when asked about the tightness in his right elbow. He objected to the questions but finally offered one answer through a translator: ''I felt a little tired, some tightness and asked for two more days.'' He refused to take follow-up questions.

title: CONTINENTAL ENDS TICKET ALLIANCE WITH AMERICA WEST
description: Continental Airlines Inc. ended a ticket-selling alliance with America West Airlines after America West cut fares to draw last-minute travelers. Continental decided to end the seven-year agreement, which allows the partners to book tickets on each other's flights, on May 1 because revenue from it ''was approaching zero,'' a Continental spokesman, Jeff Awalt, said. An agreement on frequent-flier benefits will end Sept. 24. America West has cut fares as much as 70 percent on tickets bought shortly before travel and has dropped a required Saturday night stay.

title: And the Winner Is . . . Oscar History
description: To the Editor:

title: Flurry of German Goals Sinks the United States
description: The United States national team was firmly reminded by a scrappy German team last night that size and muscle can make all the difference in a soccer match.

title: Wish List: 9 Innovations in Search of Inventors
description: YOU can say what you want about the bursting of the technology bubble (just not in front of the children). True, the Super Bowl lost some advertisers, 20-year-olds lost their beachfront condos, and investors lost their shirts. But for technology writers, it was a great time to be alive.

title: Eyeing the Forgotten Fifth Wall
description: WALK into Grand Central Terminal, the Pantheon or the Sistine Chapel and the first thing you do is look up. The most celebrated spaces in the world have the best ceilings, but they tend to be the last things we think of when decorating our homes. The clients in my interior design practice fixate on the width of their floorboards yet they seem oblivious to the untapped power overhead. The largest uncluttered expanse in your home provides an extraordinary opportunity.

title: Enlisting the Cellphone To Send Laptop E-Mail
description: Q. Can I connect my laptop to the Internet with my cellphone to send and receive e-mail?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about classic equations of physics referred incorrectly to antimatter particles, whose existence was predicted by an equation of Paul Dirac. The first one observed in nature was the antielectron, not the antiproton.

title: Judge Moves to Speed Along Lawsuit Over Managed Care
description: A federal judge in Miami has allowed a group of managed care companies that have been accused of fraud to ask an appeals court for an immediate ruling on whether they are open to racketeering claims, a move that lawyers for both sides said could speed a final decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, LEO, JR.
description: WINTER-Leo, Jr. Born July 26, 1926. He was a medical officer for New York City Fire Department, rank of Deputy Chief Hon. and CEO of Leo Winter Associates. He published 65 scientific articles in an oral surgery textbook. He is survived by his devoted and loving wife, Josephine, and his loving brother, Richard E. Winter, and their families.

title: Lacing His Fiction With History; Vargas Llosa Keeps a Latin American Literary Boom Booming
description: For Mario Vargas Llosa, a novelist has the obligation to question real life. ''I don't think there is a great fiction that is not an essential contradiction of the world as it is,'' he said during a recent visit to New York. The writer creates an alternative world in response. ''This is,'' he said, ''the great contribution of the novel to human progress. You know, the Inquisition forbade the novel for 300 years in Latin America. I think they understood very well the seditious consequence that fiction can have on the human spirit.''

title: Ex-Global Crossing Worker Arrested by F.B.I.
description: The F.B.I. arrested a disgruntled former employee of Global Crossing yesterday and charged him with using the Internet to post threats to injure or kill company executives and to display personal information, including the Social Security numbers, of nearly 2,000 of the company's employees.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Loss Widens At Sirius
description: Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. reported a wider loss yesterday, but also said that it would roll out its subscription service on July 1, a month ahead of schedule and that it had set a deal with Nissan. Shares in the company rose 63 cents, or 14.2 percent, to $5.06. The company said its fourth-quarter loss was $83.6 million, or $1.52 a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of $54.1 million, or $1.28. Nissan North America said yesterday that the Sirius satellite radio systems would be available in some 2003 Nissan and Infiniti vehicles starting later this year. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: On Piano, Many Personalities
description: Markus Groh, a German pianist who has won several important contests, including the Queen Elisabeth Competition in 1995, gave a superb recital on Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection. His program touched on several styles -- early Beethoven and Brahms before the intermission; Schoenberg, Thomas Ads and Liszt in the second half -- and among the more remarkable qualities of his playing was the degree to which he gave each composer a distinctive voice.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Call For Modernization
description: At a meeting of the rubber-stamp legislature attended by the country's leader, Kim Jong Il, Prime Minister Hong Song Nam called for ''technical improvements and modernization of the national economy,'' which is in shambles, and for more joint ventures with other countries. Mr. Kim is to meet today with President Megawati Sukarnoputri of Indonesia, who will then go to South Korea, possibly carrying indications of what the North expects in talks with the South next week. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Small Slam That Works When Just a Game Does Not
description: During her adventures in ''Through the Looking-Glass,'' Alice met a sheep who was a shopkeeper with a strange pricing structure for eggs:

title: Military Suppliers and Financial Companies Lead Climb
description: Military contractors and financial companies led shares higher yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Resignation At Deutsche Bank
description: In a continuation of the shake-up at Deutsche Bank as Josef Ackermann, left, prepares to take over as chief executive in May, Michael Philipp resigned as the bank's head of global asset management. The bank said Mr. Philipp, an American, would remain as an adviser but had decided to pursue other interests. He will be replaced by Pierre de Weck, a former executive at UBS, who will join Deutsche Bank on Monday. The change is the second big shift in Deutsche Bank's management board, which Mr. Ackermann overhauled in January to centralize decision-making. That overhaul led to the resignation of one board member, Thomas Fischer. Below the top level, Mr. Ackermann has moved rapidly to install his own team in crucial posts. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Bush Diplomacy Yields Few Promising Signs
description: After months of caution, the Bush administration suffered a string of setbacks to its newly active Middle East peace efforts this week, raising unsettling questions about its influence in the region and what steps it can -- and will -- take next.

title: XEROX RECEIVES $557 MILLION IN FINANCING
description: The Xerox Corporation received $557 million from General Electric as part of a plan for its GE Capital finance arm to take over most of the equipment financing for Xerox's customers. The deal is secured, Xerox said, by $266 million in lease receivables from the United States and $291 million from Canada. The company also set up customer-financing agreements for Mexico and Brazil. Terms were not disclosed. Xerox now has about $4.8 billion in cash. The chief executive, Anne M. Mulcahy, has turned to third-party financing because Xerox's credit rating, which is below investment grade, prevents it from borrowing at competitive rates.

title: Two Quick Goals Make Winners of Devils
description: Stphane Richer finally scored a goal for the Devils tonight, and he added an assist, of sorts, while he was sitting on the bench.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Philips In Parts Deal With Dell
description: Royal Philips Electronics said that it had struck a deal to supply Dell Computer with as much as $5 billion in computer parts over five years. As part of the agreement, Philips, the Dutch electronics manufacturer, will supply Dell with standard and flat-panel monitors, wireless connectivity equipment, storage devices and other components and Dell will become a preferred supplier of Philips. Earlier this week, Philips announced a deal with Nike to sell electronics equipment like CD players and digital music players bearing the names of both companies. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ex-Global Crossing Worker Accused of Making Threats

title: Despite Economic Dip, State Needs More Power Plants, Group Says
description: Despite the destruction of the World Trade Center and the economic downturn, New York's appetite for electricity has not slowed significantly, and there is still a dire need for new power plants, the managers of the state's power grid said today.

title: Andersen Regroups; White Defends Sales
description: Joseph F. Berardino said it was the demonstrations of Arthur Andersen employees that clinched his decision to resign as chief executive. It was the only sacrifice he could make to join in their effort, he said, and to prove to the government how much Andersen was willing to change. A day after his decision, partners engaged in a fierce debate over the firm's strategy.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Steel Import Tariffs
description: The European Commission, the administrative arm of the European Union, adopted a tariff of up to 26 percent on imports of steel to discourage a sharp rise in imports. The tariff is a response to the imposition of tariffs of up to 30 percent by the United States this month, a move that officials expect will cause the diversion of 15 million tons of steel to the European Union. The tariffs will take effect on April 3 and last six months. In Washington, the Bush administration said it would ask for consultations with the European Union over the higher tariffs, the first step in bringing a case against the union at the World Trade Organization. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Dream Car, Dream Colors? A Dream Indeed
description: ONCE I owned the cutest car in America: a sporty red 1989 Honda Civic, fun to drive with a peppy four-speed manual transmission.

title: A Luxury of Choice, Alfresco
description: THIS spring, think beyond teak. The new crop of garden chairs includes options in plastic, canvas and even banana leaves. For limited space and limited budgets, many designs fold or stack. To furnish more elaborate outdoor settings, there are new takes on traditional styles in durable synthetics. For a close-up view of some midcentury modern classics, R 20th Century in TriBeCa (82 Franklin Street at Broadway) will hold an exhibition and sale of vintage outdoor furniture (April 25 to Aug. 15) in a 1950's Hamptons patio setting designed by Steven Learner Studio.

title: City Agrees to End the Giuliani Policy of Jailing Most Protesters for the Night
description: City officials have agreed not to reinstate a Giuliani-era policy that forced most people arrested at demonstrations to spend a night or more in jail instead of being released and given a summons to appear in court.

title: Map of the Fallen
description: For most of us, the prevailing image of the site where the World Trade Center stood is still the one formed in those first few days after Sept. 11. The fires still burned with most of their original heat, and the rescue teams were hard at work on a scene that looked literally like some chaotic inferno. But now, slowly, that ruinous site is yielding up new information of a kind that will allow us to understand the character of the event more completely.

title: A Golden Reign of Tolerance
description: The lessons of history, like the lessons of religion, sometimes neglect examples of tolerance. A thousand years ago on the Iberian Peninsula, an enlightened vision of Islam had created the most advanced culture in Europe. A nun in Saxony learned of this kingdom from a bishop, the caliph's ambassador to Germany and one of several prominent members of his diplomatic corps who were not Muslims; the bishop most likely reported to the man who ran the foreign ministry, who was a Jew.

title: As the Web Matures, Fun Is Hard to Find
description: GLENN DAVIS, the founder of the once-popular online destination Cool Site of the Day, used to be so addicted to the Web that he called it his ''recreational drug.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Telecom Profit Rises
description: The big Chinese mobile phone company China Unicom said 2001 profit jumped 38 percent, as it doubled subscribers. Profit rose to 4.46 billion yuan ($538 million), or 0.36 yuan a share, from 3.23 billion yuan, or 0.29 yuan, in 2000. Unicom said GSM subscribers doubled to 27 million, slowing from a threefold increase in 2000. Monthly average revenue per user, an industry benchmark, fell 31 percent to 86.3 yuan ($10.43).

title: Now End the Racial Bias in Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A News Cocktail Mixed by a Software Genie
description: REPORTERS whose work appears on news Web sites are finding that yet another editor is going through their articles after they are published. This one is unseen and unheard and cannot be reasoned with. It can do an impressive job, or a disturbing one, of changing their words. And it never issues a correction.

title: Let Judicial Candidates Speak
description: Free speech for judges'' may never be a bumper sticker, but it aptly describes an appeal the Supreme Court heard this week. The appeal asks whether Minnesota's restriction on the campaign statements of judicial candidates violates the First Amendment guarantee of free speech.

title: Relatives of Sept. 11 Victims Aid the Prosecution
description: Eileen Morello walked into a nondescript hotel room in Midtown Manhattan this week, sat on a couch facing her youngest daughter and for 45 minutes reminisced about her husband -- ''hysterically laughing and hysterically crying,'' she said -- in front of two federal officials who took notes.

title: From Brazil, An Armchair Named Flor
description: The Flor chair, left, has a single stem that supports a gently rocking seat, which opens like a flower to enfold the sitter. (Call it a one-point suspension system.) On April 3, Flor and other designs by the Brazilian designer Maurcio Klabin will go on view at Latincollector Art Center. It is the first time designs by Mr. Klabin, who died in 2000, will be available in this country. Flor ($2,000) comes with a matching Kanto footstool ($700) in 56 colors of leather. The center is at 153 Hudson Street (Laight Street); (212) 334-7813 or www.latincollector.com. DONNA PAUL

title: Now End the Racial Bias in Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Sees Lower Towers That Can Empty Faster
description: Whatever is rebuilt on the World Trade Center site must be secure against much more sophisticated bioterrorism attacks than the nation has yet seen and, because of both safety and economics, should be no more than 50 or 60 stories tall, according to a new study by the nation's leading engineering organization.

title: Editors' Note
description: An obituary of the golfer Paul Runyan on March 19 reported on his upset victory over Sam Snead in the 1938 P.G.A. Championship and recalled that Runyan, a slightly built man generally outdriven by opponents, achieved 29 tour victories by relying on a superb short game.

title: A Beautiful Body

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Racial Harassment Settlement
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced that Apollo Colors, a pigment manufacturer in Rockford, had agreed to pay $1.8 million to settle a racial harassment lawsuit on behalf of 32 current and former black employees. The commission sued Apollo two years ago after employees complained about graffiti and offensive remarks by co-workers. One black employee said a noose had been drawn around a photograph of his son on his locker. Several black workers said management had done little to respond to their complaints, but the company maintained that it had taken adequate steps. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Prison Guards Suspended After Brothel Raid
description: Two correction officers from Northern State Prison here were suspended today without pay in administrative hearings that stemmed from their arrests during a raid at a strip club that the Newark police said was used for prostitution. The raid has also become an issue in the contentious race for mayor.

title: Don't Point, Just Think: The Brain Wave as Joystick
description: THIS is a case of monkey think, monkey do.

title: National Briefing | West: California: 4 Accused Of Immigration Fraud
description: Four people were arrested in Los Angeles on charges of using fake naturalization ceremonies and a phony judge to defraud Koreans and Filipinos seeking to become United States citizens. The arrests come after a yearlong investigation headed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in which each of 25 immigrants paid up to $25,000 for speeded processing of their applications. The four were charged with mail fraud; two also face charges of impersonating a federal judge. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: A Good Deed Is Punished
description: It was a hugely popular discount program to ease the introduction of the euro, but it was illegal. A German court ruled that C&A, a chain of clothing stores, violated Germany's pricing laws when it offered 20 percent discounts to customers who paid with credit or debit cards in the first days of January, when euro notes and coins were starting to replace German marks. The idea was to avoid running short of change and to reduce the confusion of handling two currencies at once. But rival stores and a German consumer protection agency said it violated laws requiring that discounts be offered to all customers equally. The court fined C&A one million euros ($877,300).

title: Terror's Confounding Online Trail
description: FOR all the sophisticated electronic tools the United States government has at its investigative disposal, tracking the activities of suspected terrorist groups online has proved to be not unlike the search for Osama bin Laden and his operatives on the ground.

title: River Views Everywhere, Including Underfoot
description: Forget Superman. When it came to expanding the Carnegie Science Center in Pittsburgh, the powers that be made the French architect Jean Nouvel their new man of steel (no small compliment in this town). Mr. Nouvel's rendering, far right, shows an open glass-and-steel design perched on the Ohio River that echoes three nearby bridges. Anchoring it is a large cubelike space cantilevered over the water, affording visitors an extraordinary vista. But what may be the center's greatest attraction when it opens in 2008 is a glass floor 80 feet above the river. ''It's so daring,'' said Seddon Bennington, the director of the Carnegie, ''that once you overcome your fears, you'd find it absolutely fascinating.'' Mr. Nouvel, who recently won the commission for a concert hall in Copenhagen, has embraced the cube-over-water look before, with his steel pavilion for Swiss Expo.02, above left, opening in May. But the pavilion has small perforations instead of windows, so the best view it offers is of itself, from the shore. ROB TURNER

description: This town stinks. For that, Giya Khiazaneishvili gives thanks.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Modified Seeds Approved
description: The Indian government said it would allow commercial planting of genetically modified seeds under certain limits. Three varieties of disease-resistant cotton developed by Mahyco, an Indian affiliate of Monsanto, won approval for three years. Modified mustard seeds are also being considered. Farmers and environmentalists have resisted genetically modified crops in India, in part because they are usually engineered to be unreplantable, forcing farmers to buy new seed. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Dire Day: Trying to See Beyond Sure Revenge
description: Few doubted, after a Hamas suicide bomber transformed a solemn Seder into a horrible blood bath in Netanya, that Israel would seek to avenge so many victims on so sacred a night.

title: The Population Slowdown
description: Demographers from around the world met this month at the United Nations to discuss and celebrate the surprising finding that the world's population has not grown as fast as had been feared. Just a few years ago, the expectation was that the planet would have 10 billion people by the end of the 21st century. Now it looks as if the true figure will be nine billion, up from six billion today.

title: For the Faithful, Trying to Reconcile Morality and Scandal
description: As awful as the news of priests forcing sex on altar boys is, to many of the faithful who sit in a pew each Sunday, the reaction of Roman Catholic Church leaders is even more shocking. After all, individual instances of sexual depravity are not unfamiliar to the church. ''All around me resounded the cauldron of dissolute loves,'' said St. Augustine, who fathered a child with his mistress before converting.

title: For Priests, Days of Hope in Time of Trouble
description: They hurried into St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan through a side door, their white robes flapping in the cold, misting wind, to gather for a Mass in their honor.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Teacher Faces Pornography Charge
description: An elementary school teacher in Wichita has resigned after being charged with possession of child pornography. The teacher, Jeffrey D. Klazura, 29, a fifth-grade teacher at St. Thomas Aquinas School, is free on $20,000 bail. Daniel I. Dorfman (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Heroin Seized At Airport
description: Customs officials seized 262 pounds of clothing and other textiles saturated with dissolved heroin and brought to Kennedy International Airport on a flight from Colombia, the officials announced yesterday. An additional 23 pounds of powdered heroin were also discovered. Luz Valdes Acevedo, 36, a Colombian woman now living in Ozone Park, Queens, was arrested when she went to pick up the cargo, the Customs Service said. She faces 10 years to life in prison if convicted of smuggling. Inspectors discovered the heroin on Saturday after noticing that furniture crates on an Avianca Airlines flight from Bogot contained wet clothing and had an unusual smell. Heroin seizures at Kennedy totaled 1,350 pounds between Oct. 1 and March 25, more than triple the 379 pounds seized during the same period a year earlier.

title: A Brownstone Is Typecast as a 'Townstone'
description: ''The Panic Room'' with Jodie Foster, opening tomorrow, is about burglars trying to break into a brownstone's safe room. But New Yorkers may focus instead on the description of the brownstone. For starters, no one uses the term ''townstone,'' as the film does, for the house on West 94th Street employed in the movie. And how about claiming it is from 1879? ''Extraordinarily early for that section of town,'' said Christopher Gray, an architectural historian. More important, what's a mint 4,200-square-foot ''townstone'' on a park block, with an elevator, worth? About $3.5 million, said Elaine Flug, a sales agent at Coldwell Banker/Hunt Kennedy. Adding a safe room doesn't add value. ''New Yorkers don't need safe rooms,'' she said, ''unless it's to store your jewelry and paintings when you're on vacation.'' LINDA LEE

title: Gunman Kills 8 in France, and an Election's Focus Shifts
description: A shooting early this morning that killed 8 people and wounded 19 others left this working-class Paris suburb numb today and immediately swung the focus of the French presidential campaign back to crime, drawing a half dozen candidates to the scene hours after the shooting.

title: NEWS CORPORATION TO TAKE CHARGE RELATED TO GEMSTAR
description: The News Corporation intends to take a charge of about $2 billion against its earnings for the current quarter as a result of a write-down at Gemstar-TV Guide International, a News Corporation spokesman said yesterday. The charge will require no cash outlay and will have no effect on the company's operating performance or results, the spokesman said. The News Corporation owns 42.6 percent of Gemstar-TV Guide, which produces electronic television program guides and owns TV Guide magazine. Last week, Gemstar-TV Guide said that it expected to take a $5 billion charge in the current quarter because of a change in national accounting standards that went into effect at the beginning of the year. The new standards affect the way that companies account for acquisitions. The News Corporation's $2 billion charge roughly reflects 42.6 percent of Gemstar-TV Guide's $5 billion write-down.

title: In Pristine Grandeur, a Sublime Presence
description: When Abstract Expressionism emerged in the mid-20th century, it was soon heralded as the first truly American school of art. Yet landscape painting a century earlier was arguably the first American art movement to connect with a larger public, certainly the first to flaunt the natural grandeur of the United States to city dwellers in the East and to Europeans across the water.

title: JUDGE DELAYS DECISION ON CAR RENTAL CONSOLIDATION
description: A judge declined to rule yesterday on a motion by the ANC Rental Corporation to consolidate rental car operations at four airports and instead asked objectors to file briefs in support of their argument by April 5. The judge, Mary F. Walrath of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., said she needed the briefs to summarize relevant state statutes and specific provisions of the contracts that the Hertz Corporation and Avis Rent a Car contend prohibit ANC's proposal. ANC Rental estimates that consolidating its Alamo and National rental car chains at four airports will save about $4.3 million a year.

description: The Boeing Company emerged today as the likely winner of a fiercely contested $4 billion contract to supply the South Korean military with 40 new fighter jets.

description: A high-quality, independent, medium-size publishing house may very well lose its signature author, whom the company discovered and nurtured and whose novel it blasted off into an astonishing best seller. The melancholy reason, and the only one, is that the publisher might not have enough cash for the advance on the writer's second novel.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Lowers Dividend
description: Fiat lowered its dividend for 2001 to 0.31 euro (27 cents) a share from 0.62 euro in 2000. The dividend applies to holders of ordinary and preferred shares. The company, which is based Turin, also announced that it would forgive $1.3 billion in debt owed by CNH Global , a maker of farm tractors that is based in Lake Forest, Ill., in exchange for shares of CNH. Fiat owns 85 percent of CNH and earned 17 percent of its sales last year from it. Fiat had a net profit of 379 million euros for 2001. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Racial Gap in Test Scores Found Across New York
description: New York State has broken down elementary and middle school standardized test scores by race and ethnicity for the first time and found that white and Asian students do much better than black and Hispanic students in English and mathematics.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Judge Backs Yosemite River Plan
description: A federal judge has almost entirely upheld Yosemite National Park's plan to protect the Merced River, which runs through the heart of the Yosemite Valley and is one of 160 nationwide protected under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Two environmental groups filed suit in August 2000, contending that the plan relied on faulty data and would allow a rash of commercial development in the valley. The only change the judge ordered was a revision in the park's 1980 management plan to emphasize the importance of protecting the river. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Study Finds Less Data Collection
description: Web sites seem to be collecting less personal data on consumers and are giving slightly more information about how that data is used, according to a survey conducted for the Federal Trade Commission by the Progress and Freedom Foundation, which opposes greater government regulation of privacy. At least some of the reduction in data collection can be linked to the dot-com downturn, the report concluded, and a growing sense that data collection is not as lucrative a business as many companies had hoped. The report is similar to a series of surveys since 1998 that have helped to shape federal privacy policy. Marc Rotenberg, who heads the Electronic Privacy Information Center in Washington, said the report is likely to be used by the Bush administration in support of its opposition to regulation, even though privacy fears among consumers have not abated and the issues are growing increasingly complex. ''The F.T.C. is spending too much time looking in the rearview mirror and not looking at the road ahead,'' he said. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Killer Declines To Appeal Judgment
description: The convicted killer of a young girl has declined to challenge a $750,000 civil judgment against him by allowing the deadline for appeal to pass. Joseph McGowan, who was convicted of murdering Joan D'Allessandro, 7, in 1973, was successfully sued last year by her mother, Rosemarie D'Allessandro. The mother had won repeal of the state's two-year statute of limitations in wrongful-death suits. She had also successfully lobbied for a law banning parole for those who rape and kill children under 14. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
