description: To the Editor:

title: Making a New Home Where Darkness Fell
description: ANTHONY RICCI was drawn by the ruin and the recovery. In March, he let the lease expire on his apartment on East 54th Street and moved to Battery Park City, where he looks out on the empty sky where the World Trade Center towers used to be. ''I wanted to be part of the resurrection,'' said Mr. Ricci, 36.

title: PHILIP MORRIS PROMOTES SEVERAL EXECUTIVES
description: The Philip Morris Companies has named Michael Szymanczyk, 53, chairman of its Philip Morris USA tobacco unit. Mr. Szymanczyk's promotion is effective April 25. He was president and chief executive of the unit and will be succeeded by John Nelson, 50, president of the company's international business. Dinyar Devitre, 54, is returning to Philip Morris as chief financial officer after holding a management position with Citigroup Inc. He succeeds Louis C. Camilleri, who takes over as chief executive on April 25 from Geoffrey Bible, who is retiring. Mr. Bible will remain chairman until August, when Mr. Camilleri assumes the job.

title: Editors' Note
description: An obituary of the golfer Paul Runyan on March 19 omitted attribution for several quotations about his career, obtained from other publications. A detailed editors' note appears today on Page A28.

title: Market Place; Loans Backed By Company Helped Family To Buy Shares
description: The Rigas family, which founded and still runs Adelphia Communications, appears to have borrowed $1 billion or more in loans guaranteed by the company and used the money to buy Adelphia stock and bonds.

title: An Old Store Moves House And Finds a Treasure Trove
description: After 75 years in one spot, Empire Restaurant Supply moved from 114 Bowery to larger quarters a few blocks away. In the process, thousands of forgotten dishes, glasses and serving pieces were unearthed in the basement. ''Many of the pieces are 60 years old,'' said Sheldon Lewis, a son-in-law of the store's founder. Vintage pieces -- the blue willowware favored by Chinese restaurants, the bean pots used by Horn & Hardart, jadeite cups and saucers, and heavy white Buffalo china -- are now displayed in the new store's basement. Some items are still packed in newspapers from the 1930's. You might think you're in a Fishs Eddy shop until you see the low prices. Dinnerware and serving pieces range from 80 cents to $20. Empire Restaurant Supply, 180 Bowery (Spring Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Corrections

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Peace Talks Set For May
description: The government announced that it would hold peace talks in May with the island's Tamil separatists in a bid to end a 17-year civil war that has claimed more than 60,000 lives. A site for the talks has not been announced. The government and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam signed a cease-fire late last month. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: F.C.C. to Refund Wireless Auction Money
description: Verizon Wireless and other mobile phone carriers will receive $2.8 billion from the Federal Communications Commission, a portion of what they paid a year ago for disputed airwaves held by NextWave Telecom.

title: Mastering an Ancient (and Dusty) Art
description: STEPHEN MORRIS learned how to plaster the hard way: on his own time. Unable to afford an expert to fix the walls and ceilings in his 200-year-old landmark house in Haverstraw, N.Y., he spent months teaching himself. Along the way, he discarded countless pounds of failure.

In a molasses-smooth baritone, he's crooning a few bars from a hit song in the chandeliered lobby of the Apollo Theater in Harlem. The tour group, mostly elderly women from Long Island, is tickled to the bone.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Phone Law Could Snare Police
description: A week-old law under which people can be fined $384 for driving while using hand-held mobile phones or other communication devices will not be enforced by the police, according to the commissioner, Pat Byrne, because it seems to apply to emergency workers like police officers and ambulance drivers using walkie-talkies and CB radios. Mr. Byrne referred the law to the attorney general's office for evaluation. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Meningitis Death
description: A fifth-grade student at Public School 140 in South Jamaica died of bacterial meningitis on Tuesday, a Board of Education spokesman said last night. The boy, whose name was not released, went home sick from school on Monday and on Tuesday was taken to a hospital, where he died, said the spokesman, Kevin Ortiz. School board officials notified the City Health Department, and a letter was sent to parents warning them to take their children to the hospital if they exhibited symptoms like fever, vomiting, stiff neck, mental confusion, lethargy or headache. ''We believe that none of the kids came in close contact with the boy,'' Mr. Ortiz said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

They cannot seem to stop talking about each new blow and counterblow in an all-out marketing war between Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola, fought out on television with ads, counterads and counter-counterads as the weather starts to soar into summer heat.

It's obvious that Mr. Attal, who also stars in the film, loves the movies, too; he's made a terrifically deft picture about the thick line that separates movie glamour from the real world, and the thin line between common sense and paranoia.

description: A federal magistrate judge in New Hampshire dismissed a charge of identity fraud yesterday against a former employee of Global Crossing accused of posting the Social Security numbers of thousands of employees on the Internet but the magistrate let stand a separate charge of threatening executives.

title: SPANISH HOTEL CHAIN AGREES TO BUY CRESTLINE CAPITAL
description: Barcelo Hotels and Resorts, a Spanish hotel chain, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Crestline Capital Corporation for $601.8 million to expand its operations in the United States. Barcelo will pay $34 for each share of Crestline, a 7.3 percent premium to the closing price of $31.70 on Wednesday. Crestline, based in Bethesda, Md., manages 29 hotels and conference centers in 12 states and the District of Columbia. Its hotels include Marriotts, Hiltons, Sheratons and Crowne Plazas. Barcelo Hotels owns or manages 108 hotels in 16 countries, including 18 in the United States.

title: Emerging From the Broadway Cocoon
description: Show business careers often begin with youthful epiphanies. For Melissa Errico, who has starred on Broadway in ''Anna Karenina, ''My Fair Lady'' and ''High Society,'' the moment of truth was the 1983 Broadway revival of ''On Your Toes.'' As she recalls that inspirational flash in her cabaret act, ''New Standards,'' the singer radiates the blushing charm of a quintessential Broadway ingnue.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Strike At Philips
description: Six thousand workers went on a one-day strike at Royal Philips Electronics N.V. in the Netherlands yesterday and threatened to stop work again next week if the company does not agree to larger wage increases. Philips, which suffered heavy losses last year, has been restructuring. The unions want a 3.5 percent increase in pay to keep pace with inflation, which is running at about 4 percent, but Philips management is offering only 2 percent. Separately, Philips became the latest large European company to announce that it will adopt the generally accepted accounting standards that are used in the United States.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Rollerblades Slow Benetton
description: The Benetton Group, Italy's largest clothing chain, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 2.3 percent because it had overestimated demand for Rollerblade in-line skates and sold them at a discount to clear inventories. Profit dropped to 64.4 million euros ($56 million) in the quarter from 65.9 million euros a year earlier, after excluding one-time gains and costs. Net income rose to 62.6 million euros in the period from 48.43 million euros the year before. Benetton's share price rose, however, as sales of its clothing increased 9.5 percent, and it has already started restructuring its sporting goods business.

description: Down on legendary Beale Street, in the heart of this southern metropolis, there is music in the streets.

title: Study Finds Garment Jobs More in Line With the Law
description: The United States Department of Labor reported yesterday that there has been a significant drop in the number of minimum-wage and overtime violations in New York City's apparel industry. The department surveyed 67 New York garment factories last year and found that 93 percent of the workers were paid in compliance with minimum-wage laws, up from 83 percent in 1999.

description: It was the sort of situation that would find most rookies sitting at the end of the bench with their warm-ups still snapped up.

description: Federal officials said yesterday that they might now have access to much more smallpox vaccine than had been thought, a finding that many said changed their options in responding to a terrorist attack with smallpox.

title: The Return of the Wankel Engine
description: WHEN it goes on sale early next year, the Mazda RX-8 will bring the Wankel rotary engine back to America. The last rotary-powered model sold here was also a Mazda, the RX-7, which was last imported in 1995. Rotary engines remain a mechanical oddity in an industry that worships standardization and volume.

title: Democrats Join in Attack On McGreevey Budget Plan
description: The sniping at Gov. James E. McGreevey's painfully constructed budget began, predictably, even before he unveiled it, but two days later the governor is taking fire from some fellow Democrats.

Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Billy Wilder, Master of Caustic Films, Dies at 95
description: Billy Wilder, the caustic writer and director who won six Academy Awards and international acclaim as one of the world's great filmmakers and then spent the last 21 years of his vivid life imploring Hollywood to let him make another movie, died on Wednesday night at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 95.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Owego: Redistricting Challenged In Suit
description: Upstate voters have filed a lawsuit charging that they would be constitutionally underrepresented under a redistricting plan being debated by the State Legislature. David M. Gouldin, a lawyer representing voters in eight counties, said the lawsuit, filed this month in Tioga County, contended that the redistricting plan did not reflect the current census. Under the plan, upstate counties would lose 3 of their 67 Assembly seats, while New York City would get 65 seats, a gain of 4.

title: A Nation Challenged: The Vaccine; Officials See No Grounds For a Mass Smallpox Effort
description: Even with more abundant supplies of smallpox vaccine expected by the end of the year, health officials said yesterday that they still would not recommend mass vaccination to prepare for a possible terrorist attack. But they left themselves plenty of room to change course, saying repeatedly that the issue was still open for public discussion.

title: Taking Notes on Democracy; Tibetan Exiles Explore Government, the American Way
description: Running into Tibetan monks and teachers is no longer much of a surprise in this part of the United States, where monasteries and meditation centers have flourished. But what are Tenzin Norbu and Tsering Dorjee doing wandering the halls of the Connecticut State Legislature?

title: Vindication on Clean Air
description: In 1999 a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit issued a hugely controversial decision that not only paralyzed the Clinton administration's clean-air strategy but challenged the government's basic regulatory architecture as well. On Tuesday the same panel ruled that the Environmental Protection Agency could proceed with regulations it had blocked in 1999. The decision brought full circle a tortured legal struggle that wound through the Supreme Court and the full D.C. Circuit. It delighted clean-air advocates, who have not had much to cheer about lately. And it imposes an obligation on Christie Whitman, the E.P.A. administrator, to move aggressively to enforce regulations that have been in legal limbo for too long.

description: BAD BLOOD

title: A Study Finds More Links Between TV and Violence
description: Teenagers and young adults who watched more than one hour of television daily were more likely to commit violent crimes and engage in other forms of aggressive behavior later, according to a new report.

title: Bishop Says His Inquiry Into Abuse Should Have Been More Thorough
description: Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Brooklyn, who was a top official in the Boston archdiocese when one of the nation's worst pedophile priests was allowed to keep ministering, acknowledged yesterday that he should have investigated more thoroughly when parishioners complained.

title: Pakistani Group Offers Bleak View of Pakistan's Rights Record
description: A report by a Pakistani human rights organization paints a bleak picture of respect for human dignity here, particularly for women and children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, AGNES P.
description: BERGER-Agnes P. The beloved mother of John Joseph Berger and wife of the late Laszlo Berger died peacefully at age 85 in Lenox Hill Hospital on March 27. Funeral services will be held today, March 29 at 10am at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Avenue (70th St.) in Manhattan. She was a professor of biostatistics at Columbia University's School of Public Health and a consultant in statistics at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. Throughout her life, she remained vitally interested in mathematics & statistical research, literature, current events, classical music concerts, and fine arts. Her compassion and concern for others and her love for teaching and nature deeply touched many lives. She is survived by her son John, grandsons Daniel and Michael Berger, and daughter-in-law Nancy Gordon, all of El Cerrito, CA. Contributions in Agnes' memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Business Tax Cuts
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said the government would reduce taxes on small businesses. Proposals that would eliminate several large taxes, reduce others and simplify the payment system, will be submitted to Parliament by April 10. The tax cuts are critical to improve growth in Russia's virtually stagnant small-business sector, and to ensure long-term growth. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Model of globalization at risk of losing international clout : At Andersen, success backfires
description: LONDON:  With armies of accountants in offices from Tokyo to Toronto, Arthur Andersen created the model for the globalization of a fragmented industry. Now it is suffering in part because of its success.

title: A Political Neophyte in Newark Challenges a Shrewd Incumbent
description: The incumbent is a feisty, street-smart veteran of the civil rights era who shepherded this city through its darkest days. The challenger, a political neophyte half his age, boasts an Ivy League pedigree, Wall Street backing and the kind of polished good looks that make voters and talk show hosts swoon. Both men have raised more money than anyone has ever seen in Newark, a place still mired in stunning poverty.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Toll Road Concern Sells Shares
description: Europe's moribund market for new stock offerings showed signs of life yesterday as France's largest toll road operator, Autoroutes du Sud de la France, sold shares for the first time. The French government floated 49 percent of the company, about 107 million shares, to pay off pensions and reduce debt. The offering, the biggest in Europe this year, raised 2.6 billion euros ($2.3 billion) as money managers raced to try to buy 19 times the amount of stock that was available. Shares in Autoroutes rose 9.2 percent, to 27.3 euros ($23.80), bringing the value of the company to 6 billion euros ($5.24 billion). The French government still owns 51 percent. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Bush Vows to Seek Conservative Judges
description: In his first substantive response to the Democratic rejection of Judge Charles W. Pickering Sr. of Mississippi for a federal appeals court post, President Bush hit back today at the leadership of the Senate and said that he would continue to push for ''good, conservative judges'' on the nation's highest courts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLE, MILTON
description: BERLE-Milton. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved Abbot Emeritus, Milton Berle. To the world he was Mr. Television, but to the Friars, he was a friend who touched our lives, not only with his comedy, but also through his personal guidance. He singlehandedly assured the revival of the Club in the 1950s and was fierce in his dedication and continued support of humanitarian causes. He helped us preserve the rich theatrical roots of the Friars Club and his name belongs among the legendary and immortal Friars like Jack Benny, George Burns, Enrico Caruso, George M. Cohan, Cary Grant, George Jessel, Joe E. Lewis, Dean Martin, Ed Sullivan, Mike Todd and Frank Sinatra. And like them he shared a legacy of commitment to the very best. We are honored and proud to have been touched by the legend that will always be Milton Berle. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Sally Jessy Raphael, Prior Stewie Stone, Scribe Fred C. Klein, Treasurer Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

description: Roman Hamrlik and Mark Parrish needed only a power play and 39 seconds tonight to turn what looked like certain defeat for the Islanders back into a game.

title: F.D.A. REJECTS DRUG FROM WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals, the maker of generic drugs, said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration had rejected a skin patch for urinary incontinence, a treatment that analysts called the company's most important new product. The F.D.A. asked for more clinical data on the patch, called Oxytrol. The company has comparative research the F.D.A. has not seen that may resolve the agency's concerns, Watson's chief executive, Allen Chao, said. The F.D.A.'s rejection, the second in 24 hours involving a Watson product, is a blow to the company's strategy of shifting to higher-profit brand-name products. Watson's stock price fell $3.65, or 12 percent, to $27.09.

title: Capturing Humanity, Rough and Unrefined
description: Marlene Dumas, a white South African artist now living in Amsterdam, touches visually on many issues important to the Modern Psyche: gender, identity, power, politics, love, sex, babies, machismo and racial inequality, although not necessarily in that order. She translates her ideas -- sometimes half-baked -- into raw drawings with such ease and fluency that her art seems to say conversationally, ''Hey, let me show you this.'' But ingratiating it isn't.

title: From Disco Floors to Skylines, Illuminating Life
description: THE night the ''Tribute in Light'' was unveiled at ground zero, Paul Marantz, the illumination wizard behind the 88 mega-bulbs that form its intentionally evanescent twin towers, and ersatz referee between the dual, occasionally dueling teams -- two artists, two architects -- who first concocted it, paced uneasily behind the scenes. He was haunted by, of all things, dark thoughts. What if the flipped switch revealed a dim dud instead of funneling two commemorative fingers of light seven miles into the sky above Manhattan?

title: ALLTRISTA, MAKER OF CANNING JARS, AGREES TO BUY TILIA
description: Alltrista, the largest seller of Ball-brand home-canning jars, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Tilia International, which makes vacuum-packaging products for home use, for $145 million. The acquisition is expected to add to earnings immediately and double Alltrista's revenue at its consumer products unit, its chief executive, Martin E. Franklin, said. That unit also sells home-canning items under the Kerr and Bernadin brands. Alltrista will also assume $15 million in debt for Tilia, a closely held company based in San Francisco. Shares of Alltrista rose $4.25, or 18 percent, to $27.55.

title: AKSYS SHARES RISE ON APPROVAL OF DIALYSIS DEVICE
description: Aksys Ltd., a maker of medical devices, said the Food and Drug Administration had approved its home dialysis machine, setting off a 92 percent increase in its share price. Aksys expects to begin shipping the dialysis device, called the PHD System, in the third quarter. The device is intended to automate dialysis, the process by which kidney patients regularly have their blood cleaned. Most kidney patients must go to hospitals or clinics to have the procedure done. The company made the announcement after the close of markets on Wednesday. Its stock rose $4.22, to $8.78 a share.

title: Firm That Advises Firefighter Widows Has Tarnished Past
description: About a month after the attacks of Sept. 11, firefighters' widows began showing up at an obscure investment firm on Long Island called Goldis Financial Group. Some arrived in small groups, escorted by members of the Uniformed Firefighters Association. Some went on their own, assured by union officials that Goldis was a trustworthy source of financial advice.

description: Over the last three decades many of art's hierarchal divisions have softened -- between high and low art, for example, and between art and craft. But at least one has remained relatively resilient: the distinction between outsider and insider art. It's a wall that despite considerable erosion is maintained by parties on both sides.

title: Legal Representation and a 10 Percent Fee
description: Many of the firefighters' widows who have turned to Goldis Financial Group have gotten more than financial advice. Some of them have also been referred to Kreindler & Kreindler, a private law firm that will help them secure awards from the federal Victims Compensation Fund.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loss For Telecom Concern
description: Japan's leading mobile phone operator, NTT DoCoMo Inc., will probably post a loss for the fiscal year ending today, because of larger-than-expected losses on overseas investments. DoCoMo, the largest stock by capitalization on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, will lose 100 billion yen ($758 million), the company's first full-year loss, according to a report in Nihon Keizai Shimbun. DoCoMo is expected to take a one trillion yen ($7.6 billion) one-time loss, including a write-down of its $9.8 billion investment in AT&T Wireless Services. A decision on a write-down may be made today, the company's president, Keiji Tachikawa, said. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sale Of A Unit Of Homestore Is Approved
description: Homestore.com, the online real estate company, has received antitrust clearance for the sale of ConsumerInfo.com, its consumer credit-reporting unit, to Experian for $130 million. The agreement, announced last week by Homestore, would strengthen finances at the company as it tries to shift its business focus from real estate consumers to professionals, officials said. Experian, a unit of GUS of Britain, sells personal credit reports and provides advice on managing credit and debt. Homestore, of Westlake Village, Calif., is one of the nation's leading online home-listing companies. The Federal Trade Commission said the federal review had been completed, but the F.T.C. did not disclose whether it or the Justice Department had considered the matter. The trade commission and the Justice Department agreed earlier this month to change the way the agencies share responsibilities for antitrust reviews.

title: Interactive TV Deal Unites Moxi Digital With Digeo
description: Ending more than a month of speculation about its fate, Moxi Digital, a prominent Silicon Valley start-up, announced today that it was being acquired by Digeo, the interactive television company founded by Paul Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft.

title: Undermining the New Campaign Law
description: While everyone has been focused on the campaign finance legislation that President Bush reluctantly signed into law, he is working to make sure that the Federal Election Commission -- the agency that will be responsible for enforcing the new law -- remains ineffective. The president has nominated Michael Toner to be a commissioner of the F.E.C. and may put him on the commission through a recess appointment. This nomination has barely registered on Washington's radar screen, but it should cause an uproar.

title: KLM PLANS TO BUY PLANES FROM BOTH BOEING AND AIRBUS
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that it would buy 11 Boeing jetliners worth as much as $2.09 billion and an undetermined number from Airbus, the first time it has chosen Airbus planes in 25 years. Boeing, based in Chicago, and Airbus, the European plane maker, plan to build 20 percent fewer airliners this year as carriers cancel or delay purchases after the Sept. 11 attacks. KLM will initially buy eight Boeing 777-200ER, or extended-range, models and three Boeing 747-400ER freighters to replace 12 Boeing 747-300's. The planes are to be delivered starting in late 2003.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Dutch Ruling In Kazaa Case
description: In a setback for the entertainment industry, a Dutch appeals court has overturned a lower court order that prohibited distribution of a popular program used to trade music and movies over the Internet. The appeals court ruled that the distributor of the program, Kazaa Media Desktop, is not liable for unauthorized copies of material made by people who use the software. The decision underscores the difficulty copyright holders face in trying to fight piracy by attacking the technology that makes it possible, particularly given the global reach of the Internet and the inconsistency of national copyright laws. The Dutch court decision contrasts with a United States appeals court ruling earlier this week that upheld an order against Napster, another file-trading service, which was found liable for contributing to copyright infringement. Music and film industry trade groups have accused the Australian company that distributes Kazaa, Sharman Networks, of violating United States copyright laws. The groups have sued Sharman and two other file-sharing software companies in Federal District Court in Los Angeles. That trial is expected to start in October. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Kinky and Cruel Goings-On in the Conservatory
description: Stiff-backed and unsmiling, her dark eyes as opaque as cough drops, the French actress Isabelle Huppert gives one of her greatest screen performances as Erika Kohut, a haughty, sexually repressed priestess of high culture in Michael Haneke's powerfully disquieting film, ''The Piano Teacher.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNING, URSULA
description: CORNING-Ursula. The Board, staff and participants of The Student Conservation Association, Inc. (SCA) sadly note the death of Ursula Corning. For nearly two decades, Miss Corning was a staunch and generous supporter of SCA's conservation and youth development programs. She particularly loved to receive letters from the young people she supported in the field. Miss Corning's devotion to youth and the environment will be greatly missed. The Board, staff and participants of SCA

title: Alfred H. Lane, 85, a Librarian Who Wasn't in It for the Money
description: Alfred H. Lane, a librarian who worked without pay for years just for the love of research and picked up enough pennies on the street to give hundreds of dollars a year to the needy, died on March 20 at St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: They Had Fun, Fun, Fun Till the Stock Fell
description: WHO says business should be all work and no play? Not the AES Corporation, a global electricity producer. Right there in its annual report released this week, AES declares it has four ''shared principles'' that guide its operations: integrity, fairness, social responsibility and fun.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Bit Part And a Beast

title: Bribery, Revenge, Obsession: At Heart It's a Comedy
description: Almost every other episode of ''The Simpsons'' wrings more laughs out of the fertile material of a venal, corrupt children's-show host who goes through money faster than a gambler on a cold streak than the new satire ''Death to Smoochy.'' There are a few laughs, but I'm not sure that a comedy is supposed to make you recoil, which is what ''Smoochy'' does.

title: At a Crossroads in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: At a Crossroads in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINGERHOOD, STANFORD A.
description: FINGERHOOD-Stanford A. On March 28, 2002. Beloved husband of Nina. Devoted father of Steven and Michael, and father-in-law of Sheba. Proud grandfather of Olivia, Minna and Sarah. Loving brother of Marjorie Pfeffer and Shirley Fingerhood. Mentor and friend to many. He was dearly loved and we will miss him terribly. Funeral services Monday, April 1, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions are requested to MIT or NYU Medical Center.

title: The Firefighter Who Made It to the Party
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMPSON, RICHARD
description: SAMPSON-Richard. Passed away unexpectedly on March 23. He leaves his loving aunt, Ruth Vitow Messias, Aunt Jeanette, Uncle Stan, nieces Alysa, Rana and Michelle, and great nephew Jonah. Services will take place Sunday, March 31 at 11am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, LORI
description: SCHMIDT-Lori. On March 26th, 2002. Beloved daughter of Bernard and Dorothy Schmidt. Dear sister of Dr. Michael and Stacie Schmidt. Cherished aunt of Emma and Russell. Services Friday, March 29th, 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Mideast Turmoil: THE OUTLOOK; Two-Edged Diplomacy
description: In offering Israel terms for eventual peace with Arab states today, Arab leaders encouraged Palestinians, in the meantime, to keep fighting.

title: Change the World and Tweak the Bourgeoisie
description: AS a final offering before going dark on West 53rd Street for a three-year expansion, the Museum of Modern Art has come up with a very MOMA show. Titled ''The Russian Avant-Garde Book, 1910-1934,'' it's a classic combination of visual lan and radical ideas, of art graced with a patina of age but firmly linked to the present.

title: Giving Tax Evaders A Big Start
description: To the Editor:

title: The True Madness Concerns the Money
description: The talk from CBS at the N.C.A.A. men's tournament is, predictably, about games and players. So much time is spent on Juan Dixon, Tom Coverdale, Drew Gooden and the Final Four matchups that no one utters a word on the air about what the network pays for the 10-day event, which ends Monday night.

title: A Survey Reveals Sentiment For Keeping Shafts of Light
description: Having gingerly and gratefully grown reaccustomed to the nightly sight of two brilliant columns over Lower Manhattan -- a compass point on which so many lives have turned -- some New Yorkers seem reluctant to lose them again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIKE, TIMOTHY C.
description: PIKE-Timothy C. Died Wednesday, March 27, 2002 at Cabrini Hospice. He was a graduate of Manhattan College and New York University. He was a participating associate of Jaros, Baum & Bolles. He is survived by his parents Leroy and Nancy Pike, brothers William and David, and sister Dr. Anne Pike-Tay, niece Hannah Tay and nephew Brendan Tay. Memorial mass will be April 26, 2002, 11 AM at St. Francis Xavier Church, 46 West 16th St. Memorial contributions to Cabrini Hospice, 227 E. 19th St., NYC 10003.

title: Man Who Fatally Shot 8 French Officials Jumps to His Death
description: A 33-year-old loner arrested in a shooting rampage that killed eight local officials in the Paris suburb of Nanterre killed himself today, the police said, when he jumped from a fourth-floor window of an interrogation room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MARTIN D.
description: BERNSTEIN-Martin D. Loving husband of Caryl. Father of David and Jonathan. Brother of Robert. Grandfather of Jenna and Beth. Father-in-law of Susan and Avital. Service Friday 12 noon at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Freehold: Officer Accused In Pornography Sting
description: A 42-year-old police officer has been accused of having child pornography on his home computer and trying to solicit sex from a minor. The officer, Cpl. James R. Davis, a 16-year veteran of the Holmdel Township Police Department, was suspended without pay when he was charged on Tuesday with attempted sexual assault, luring and endangering the welfare of a child after communicating online with an undercover officer posing as a 13-year-old, according to the Monmouth County prosecutor's office. The Associated Press, quoting the county prosecutor, John Kaye, said Corporal Davis had been sent a photograph of the undercover officer made up to look like a 13-year-old, but the online exchange ended when Corporal Davis recognized her at a training conference on hostage negotiations.

title: National Briefing | West: California: 'Morning-After' Pill Coverage
description: Gov. Gray Davis has ordered the state's health maintenance organizations to cover ''morning- after'' contraception and to ensure speedy access to the pills, which must be taken within 72 hours. H.M.O.'s will have to cover the costs through their network pharmacists or, in emergency situations, through pharmacists who do not have an H.M.O. contract. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: Hewlett Heir Files Lawsuit To Overturn Merger Vote
description: Walter B. Hewlett, who has fought to keep the company his father helped create from merging with Compaq Computer, today took his fight to court in an effort to block the $24 billion deal that Hewlett-Packardsays it has won.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Atlas no longer has its fire-breathing young chef, Paul Liebrandt, but the restaurant has not gone cold, or timid. The eel with candied violets went out the door with Mr. Liebrandt, but the spirit of adventure lingers. David Coleman, Atlas's sous-chef, has taken charge of the kitchen, and he is not the macaroni-and-cheese type. Conservative diners can pick their way carefully through the menu and fashion a meal of butter lettuce with red onion and capers; diver scallops with cpes, artichokes and chickpeas; and a caramelized banana tart for dessert. The diner who orders this meal will feel very isolated.

title: A Storm Gathers Over a Resort Town's Airport
description: On Friday afternoons from November to April, tens of thousands of Southern California skiers and snowboarders jump into their cars and drive north. They make excellent time speeding through the Mojave Desert, up the vast Owens Valley and along the eastern edge of the Sierra Nevada, and arrive in this town 300 miles from Los Angeles.

title: Baseball Rituals And Rhythms If Not Reality
description: ''The Rookie,'' a G-rated macho weepie about dads and sons, fading boyhood dreams and baseball, is so well made that even the absurdly sanitized language of its locker-room scenes feels reasonably authentic, at least while you're watching it. Unabashedly lyrical and beautifully photographed, the movie, based on a true story, preaches the optimistic can-do philosophy that it's never too late to be what you might have been.

title: Councilman Resigns Committee Positions but Retains Seat
description: City Councilman Angel Rodriguez of Brooklyn resigned from all his positions on Council committees yesterday, within hours of being indicted on federal extortion charges.

title: The Show Comes to an End for the Yanks' Sojo
description: One of the toughest things about the baseball life, Manager Joe Torre said today, is thinking you are close to your players but knowing you will have to part ways. ''Sooner or later, you're going to have to tell somebody -- or somebody's going to have to tell you -- it's over with,'' Torre said.

title: Mideast Turmoil: Arab League; Arabs Approve an Offer to Israel With Conditions It Has Rejected
description: The Arab nations committed themselves Thursday to accepting Israel as a neighbor if it would meet a set of conditions, many of which Israel has long rejected, leading to the creation of an independent Palestinian state.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Holland Tunnel Access Expands
description: Another E-ZPass lane at the Holland Tunnel will reopen to Manhattan-bound traffic today, even as a nearby fire continues to smolder. Three eastbound lanes were opened on Tuesday to E-ZPass users. Cash-paying customers are still prohibited from using the tunnel, which was closed last Friday morning after a fire broke out at the adjacent Mecca & Sons Trucking Company warehouse. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUR, ALVIN L.
description: SCHUR-Alvin L. Born July 27, 1925, of St. Lucie West died, March 26, 2002 at Port St. Lucie Nursing Center. A native of Woodmere, New York, he lived in St. Lucie West for seven years. He moved here from Oceanside, New York. He loved the outdoors. He particularly enjoyed downhill skiing, deep sea fishing, fast pitch softball and gardening. Before retirement, his 30 year career in finance included being Vice President at Merrill Lynch and Dean Witter Reynolds. Survivors include daughter Leslie Pearson Gottlieb of Little Ferry, New Jersey, sister Marilyn Howard of Ft. Pierce and longtime companion Beatrice Byers of St. Lucie West. He was predeceased by his wife, Enid Kaiser Schur in 1993. Those who wish may donate to the American Lung Association of Southeast Florida, 2701 N. Australian Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407. For information call At Peace Cremation, Sarasota, FL.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Bulletin Board column of the Education page on Wednesday about a $2 million pledge to Quinnipiac University referred incorrectly to Robert W. Evans, a former dean for whom a liberal arts center is to be named. He is not ''late''; he is retired, in Arkansas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRER, TERRY
description: FERRER-Terry, 82. Pioneering woman journalist, former education editor of Newsweek and the New York Herald Tribune. Witty, warm, wise-she was loved and admired by friends and family. Died on February 12 in Charlottesville, VA. An 11am memorial mass will be celebrated on Monday, April 1, at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Jet Controversy
description: The French aircraft manufacturer Dassault Aviation and other companies involved in building the Rafale jet fighter have responded angrily to indications that the Boeing Company would win the $4 billion contract to produce 40 fighters for the Korean air force. Dassault and two allied companies demanded ''detailed information'' on the evaluation and said they would ''protect their legitimate interests.'' A spokesman for Boeing, which is offering an advanced version of its F-15, complimented the Korean government for ''a fair and transparent process'' so far and promised full cooperation in the final selection. The defense ministry said the government would make a decision in April. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RELIANCE STEEL AND ALUMINUM, Los Angeles, the fourth-biggest metals distributor in the United States, agreed to buy two other distributors, Olympic Metals, Denver, and Central Plains Steel, Kansas City, Kan. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Mideast Turmoil: Diplomacy; Saudi Peace Plan Is Finding Resistance in U.N.
description: The Saudi plan for putting an end to conflict in the Middle East, based on Israeli withdrawal from occupied territories in return for normal relations with Arab nations, is not likely to be endorsed quickly by the Security Council, diplomats said here today.

title: Layden Dons Scout's Hat As Draft Day Approaches
description: The Knicks' president, Scott Layden, was at Madison Square Garden last night, watching University of Memphis guard Dajuan Wagner play in the National Invitation Tournament final. But Layden was not envisioning Wagner in the backcourt beside Allan Houston next season.

title: Mideast Peace, Mideast Carnage
description: The Arab League took an admirable, if long overdue, step Wednesday when it offered to establish normal relations with Israel in exchange for a Palestinian state's being built on the land captured in the 1967 war. The assertion that Israelis have a right to peace and security -- a first acknowledgment by the Arab world, in effect, of their collective humanity -- rings hollow, however, when juxtaposed with the league's indifference toward one of the most horrific Palestinian suicide bombings to date. Arab leaders must take up the challenge hurled at them by Hamas with its carefully timed attack on a Passover seder at a hotel in Netanya. Unless the leaders find a way to end the intoxication with suicide bombings taking over Palestinian society and force the Palestinian Authority to end these acts, the historic peace offer will mean nothing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONDIK, LEON
description: SONDIK-Leon of FL and CT died March 28, 2002. Husband of Ethel (Zinman); father of Rick and Jeannie Sondik, NY, NY, Barbara and Louis Perlmutter, NY, NY, Cindy and Mark Aron, Washington, D.C.; brother of Selma Squires of FL and CT; and grandfather of Kermit and Eric Perlmutter, Samantha Aron Foti and John Foti, and Lily Sondik. Funeral services Sunday, March 31, 2002. Memorial contributions may be made to the Helen and Harry Gray Cancer Center at Hartford Hospital, c/o Dr. Andrew Salner, 85 Retreat Ave., Hartford 06106-2627

title: The True Arab Leaders
description: India's national tumult produced Gandhi and Nehru. America's nurtured Jefferson and Madison.

title: Sports of The Times; Huge Arena Is Bad Fit For Women's Game
description: GROWTH is good. Bigger is better. That is what most people in sports tend to believe, the approach they typically take, but Duke has come all the way to the women's Final Four with an eight-player team that is about to be swallowed up along with everyone else by a charmless and canyonesque dome.

description: To the Editor:
