description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISNER, FRANCES A.
description: REISNER-Frances A. Passed away Thursday, March 28, 2002. Beloved wife of George. Loving mother of Judith & Michael Levy, Susie & Gil Wang. Adored grandmother of Michael, Matthew, Anna and Delila. Sister of Nino Luciano. Services at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, FL, Monday, April 1st at 1 P.M.

title: Rod Rodgers, Choreographer of Modern Dance, Dies at 64
description: Rod Rodgers, a modern-dance choreographer known for dances with an unforced, thoughtful physicality often motivated by social themes expressed with quiet passion, died on Sunday at a Manhattan hospital. He was 64 and lived in Manhattan.

title: An Old Revolutionary's Home Turf
description: Benjamin Franklin wasn't born in Philadelphia, but it is hard to go very far in the heart of this city without encountering his ubiquitous spirit in mortar, monument and, most important, in a legacy of scientific invention and civic innovation that amounts to a one-man Freedom Trail of democratic possibility. Franklin's grave site, mere blocks from the Liberty Bell, is strewn with pennies, tossed by passers-by for good luck. His sly-eyed image peers down from marble busts above historic doorways, as well as from building-high, graffiti-type Pop Art wall murals. His name routinely slips from the mouths of tour guides as you pass the Franklin Institute Science Museum, the Benjamin Franklin Parkway, the Benjamin Franklin Bridge.

title: Japan's Premier Muses on a Recovery-Proof Economy
description: Nearly a year after taking office as a popular reformer, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said in an interview today that he does not know why the nation's economy shows no sign of revival and that real growth may be so far away that he may not be in office to see it.

title: When Things Aren't What They Seem (Are They?)
description: ''What I believe is there are words and then there are the feelings and thoughts behind the words,'' the woman, whose name is Setsuko Hearn, says carefully, trying to parse a profession of ardent feeling from Darius Wheeler, a man she hardly knows.

title: The Smoke Machine
description: In a way, it's a shame that so much of David Brock's ''Blinded by the Right: The conscience of an ex-conservative'' is about the private lives of our self-appointed moral guardians. Those tales will sell books, but they may obscure the important message: that the ''vast right-wing conspiracy'' is not an overheated metaphor but a straightforward reality, and that it works a lot like a special-interest lobby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SHEA, BERNADETTE (NEE DOWNES)
description: O'SHEA - Bernadette (nee Downes). On March 27, 2002. Beloved wife of Nelligan, devoted mother of Mary Ann O'Callahan, John, Michael, Bernadette O'Shea Weir, Elizabeth and Thomas O'Shea. Loving sister of Stephen, John, Thomas and William Downes, Margaret Ardino and the late Robert and Nicholas Downes, Ann Maguire and Joseph Downes. Cherished grandmother to ten grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch & Son Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Blvd, Sunnyside, NY, Friday and Saturday 2-5 and 79:30PM. Funeral Mass Queen of Angels R.C. Church, Monday 10:30am. Interment Calvary Cemetery. No visitation Easter Sunday.

title: World Briefing: Africa; ZIMBABWE: JOURNALIST'S ARREST CONDEMNED
description: The Media Institute of Southern Africa condemned the arrest and detention of a Zimbabwean journalist, Peta Thornycroft, who was accused of publishing false information that was prejudicial to the state. If convicted, Ms. Thornycroft, who writes for The Daily Telegraph of London and has been investigating reports of violence against the opposition by supporters of the governing party, could face up to five years in prison. Her lawyers described the arrest as a continuation of the government crackdown on its critics in the press and opposition parties. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: How Japan Took Tea and Refined the Idea for 800 Years
description: No other people, not even the English at their most proper, can do tea with the ritualistic panache of the Japanese. Aficionados for more than 800 years, ever since tea was introduced in powdered form by Zen monks who had studied in China, the Japanese have constantly been fine-tuning the complex culture known as the way of tea (called the tea ceremony in the West).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUTTERMAN, WILLIAM OTTO (BILLY)
description: FUTTERMAN-William Otto (Billy). Succumbed on March 27, 2002 at the age of two to Niemann-Pick Disease Type A. Loving son of Wendy and Roy, dear brother of Eddie and Katie, adored grandson of Eve and Ted Friedman. Service 10:30 AM today at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th Street, NYC. Memorial donations may be made to the National Tay-Sachs and Allied Diseases Association, 2001 Beacon Street, Suite 204, Boston, MA. 02135.

title: Dumais Again Wins One-Meter Title
description: The Texas diver Troy Dumais won his third straight one-meter springboard title and the defending champion Longhorns topped the team standings yesterday after the opening day of the N.C.A.A. men's swimming and diving championships in Athens, Ga.

title: Andersen Plans a Split, As Government Signals Continued Prosecution
description: Proclaiming its intention to break with the one-time model for the modern accounting firm, Arthur Andersen announced yesterday that it would proceed with a plan proposed by Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, to split its audit and consulting work into separate businesses.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: YUGOSLAVIA: MILOSEVIC TRIAL 'SICKENS' LEADER
description: President Vojislav Kostunica, who helped oust Slobodan Milosevic in 2000, said he feels ''sick to my stomach'' whenever he thinks about the international tribunal trying Mr. Milosevic for war crimes. Though he added that cooperation with the tribunal is inevitable, Mr. Kostunica has frequently cast it as anti-Serb and has contended that Yugoslav courts should have tried Mr. Milosevic. He made his comments in anticipation of an expected new round of extraditions to The Hague after the Serbian government issued a decree on cooperating with the tribunal. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column on Tuesday about a memoir by Thomas Von Essen, the former fire commissioner, referred imprecisely to the role of Rebecca Kurson. She is still his agent; her representation was not limited to the initial stages of finding a publisher.

title: College Hoops and Academics
description: As college basketball fans prepare to settle in for the season's final weekend of competition, it's worth considering the gap between the men's and women's game. We're not talking about the fact that the men play a faster, rougher and more spectacular brand of basketball. We're thinking of the gap in graduation rates. The contest isn't even close; the women win by a mile. The reason is that their game has not yet been corrupted by the win-at-any-cost philosophy that has deformed men's collegiate basketball and most of the schools that field the perennial powerhouse teams. The women must be wary of the same fate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAIL, DONALD
description: VAIL-Donald of Bedford, NY, died on March 27, 2002 at the age of 80. Mr. Vail was born in Yonkers, NY, to John I.B. Vail and Margaret Gray Vail of Hyannis, MA., and Blairstown, NJ. A 1938 graduate of the Holderness School & the Class of 1942 at Princeton University, he entered the Navy in World War II. As a Marine pilot, he served in the South Pacific, leaving the service as a Captain. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1948 and practiced law at the firms of: Sullivan & Cromwell, McCanliss & Early, Alexander & Green, and Walter, Conston, Alexander & Green. Mr. Vail was a founding member of the Bedford Association; Chairman of the Building Committee of St. Francis A.M.E. Zion Church; and a Vestryman and Clerk of the Vestry of St. Matthew's Church. At Northern Westchester Hospital Center, he was a member of the Board of Trustees for 20 years, and a president of the Board from 1977-1982. He had also been a member of the Triangle Club at Princeton and of the Blue Hill Troupe in New York. Mr. Vail is survived by his wife of 50 years, Priscilla L. Vail, author & educator in learning disabilities & dyslexia. He leaves four children: Melissa Vail Selby of Mt. Kisco; Polly Vail Walsh of Chevy Chase, MD; Lucia Vail of New York City; Donald Angus Vail of Portland, OR; and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford on Monday, April 1st at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Northern Westchester Hospital Center Foundation, Mount Kisco, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIGELSON, CHARLES I., M.D.
description: FEIGELSON-Charles I., M.D. The members of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute and Society mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague, Dr. Charles I. Feigelson. Dr. Feigelson was a remarkable educator and a profound influence on his colleagues. As a Training and Supervising Analyst, he contributed immeasurably to the education of generations of students of psychoanalysis. We all feel a sense of infinite loss of this valued teacher and loyal and courageous person. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Carolyn, brother Eugene Feigelson, M.D., children Jeremy, Daniel, Tom, Paul and Suzanne. Philip Herschenfeld, M.D., Pres., N.Y. Psychoanalytic Institute Leon Kupferstein, M.D., Pres., N.Y. Psychoanalytic Society Edward Nersessian, M.D., Chairman, Educational Committee N.Y. Psychoanalytic Institute

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Alters Privacy Policy
description: Yahoo changed its privacy policy yesterday to give it far more latitude to send e-mail or postal mail and make phone calls to sell its services and those of the companies it works with. Yahoo's policy had strictly prohibited the sale or rental of personally identifiable information. Customers could choose, by selecting an option, to receive marketing messages from other companies. Yesterday, Yahoo started sending an e-mail message to customers telling them that unless they changed options on its site, they would be agreeing to receive e-mail, phone calls and postal mail on behalf of Yahoo's services, including partners like stores that rent space in Yahoo's shopping channel. Yahoo's new policy gives it more latitude to disclose personal information, for example, in ''situations involving potential threats to the physical safety of any person,'' it said. Yahoo also permits itself to transfer personal information if the company is bought. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Killer Of Levin Fails In Appeal
description: New York State's highest court has refused to consider an appeal by the man who was convicted in 1998 of torturing and killing Jonathan Levin, son of Gerald M. Levin, the former chief executive of AOL Time Warner. Judge Victoria A. Graffeo of the Court of Appeals declined without comment yesterday to let the man, Corey Arthur, appeal his conviction in the 1997 murder of Mr. Levin, his former teacher. Mr. Arthur, 23, was convicted of torturing Mr. Levin to obtain his automated teller machine code before shooting him. He is serving a term of 25 years to life. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: After a Push and a Pull, Stocks End the First Quarter Mostly Flat
description: During the stock market's first quarter, which ended yesterday, interest rates and corporate earnings fought each other to a draw on Wall Street.

title: Yes, Someone for Everyone, Even Someone With Fangs
description: Hal Hartley's ''No Such Thing'' at first appears to be part of a new genre, slapstick magic realism, before it winds down into slapdash realism. The picture is more abrasively quirky than a lesser Bjork B-side, though the hideous monster who co-stars hails from Iceland, too.

title: Residential Real Estate; 3 Rental Buildings Reflect Shift in Flower District
description: Three high-end rental buildings, two of them being leased to tenants as they near completion and the third under construction, reflect the continuing evolution of the area around Manhattan's flower district.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Growth
description: The economy grew by a higher-than-expected 6.3 percent in the third quarter, powered by growth in the farm sector. Overall growth topped the 5 percent increase that was forecast and the 5.3 percent growth in the second quarter, according to the country's Central Statistical Organization. The farm sector, which accounts for a quarter of the economy, grew 7.1 percent. Manufacturing increased 2.8 percent in the quarter, which ended Dec. 30.

title: Luxury Home, Built-In Trouble
description: ''Panic Room'' belongs, with movies like ''Rosemary's Baby'' and ''Single White Female,'' to a small, appropriately exclusive subgenre: the Manhattan luxury real estate thriller. In spite of their apparent parochialism, these movies appeal to the universal, complementary emotions of smugness and envy. New Yorkers (or anybody else) who must do without several thousand light-flooded, architecturally distinguished square feet -- most of us, that is -- can marvel at the good luck of those who do live like this, and then, once the bad stuff starts to happen, thank our lucky stars that we are not in their shoes.

title: For the Terrapins' Mouton, It's All About Family
description: Shirley Mouton is here. So are her sons Ed and Brian and her daughter, Darlene. They have come to see Byron Mouton, Maryland's defensive stopper and the sparkplug of a coolly efficient team, play at least one, hopefully two, more college basketball games. Of course, they want the Terrapins to win the national championship.

title: Viacom Wins Delay In TV Station Sales
description: Viacom won approval today for a further delay in complying with a government order to sell television stations while the Federal Communications Commission rewrites an ownership limit, as ordered by an appeals court.

title: Late-Season Nose Dive Reveals Rangers' Errors
description: There is never a good time for a skull fracture, but Mike Richter's timing could not have been worse. His team, the Rangers, still hopes for a playoff berth. His contract is about to expire, sending him into free agency at age 35. Guarding the goal last Friday against Atlanta, Richter stopped a speeding puck with the colorful headgear that is decorated with the face of the Statue of Liberty. He fell like a toppled monument. There was blood, a punctured eardrum and a concussion. A few days later, a CT scan revealed a fracture above his right ear.

title: Against Her Sister, Serena Williams Makes a Statement
description: The Williams sisters came out on the court to the strains of ''We Are Family'' before their semifinal match today at the Nasdaq-100 Open. But the setting provided a backdrop for Serena Williams to make her boldest statement yet in seven career matches against Venus.

title: Brooklyn Councilman Is Charged in an Extortion Scheme
description: A Brooklyn councilman who was recently a contender for City Council speaker was charged yesterday with demanding a $1.5 million break on a real estate deal from a developer in exchange for supporting the multimillion-dollar renovation of a waterfront warehouse in his district.

title: Ukraine's Leader Struggles to Go Quietly
description: Nearing the end of his political career, President Leonid D. Kuchma is fighting for a safe exit from public life in parliamentary elections this coming Sunday.

title: Mazdaspeed Comes to America
description: MAZDA is bringing its Mazdaspeed nameplate to North America, the company said yesterday at the New York auto show. Under the Mazdaspeed umbrella, Mazda will develop a series of special performance models and coordinate the company's motorsports activities.

title: 'Art That Heals'
description: Apex

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Pope Accepts Polish Archbishop's Resignation
description: Pope John Paul II today accepted the resignation of a high-ranking Polish prelate accused of molesting young seminarians, bowing to pressure to resolve a sex scandal that had torn the church in intensely Catholic Poland.

title: The Pentagon Opens Inquiry On Travels In Military Jet
description: The Pentagon's inspector general is looking into the recent travels of Army Secretary Thomas E. White amid concerns that he may have used a military jet for personal travel, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WETZLER, MONTE E.
description: WETZLER-Monte E. Of Essex, CT. and Manhattan, died March 27. He was the husband of Sally Elsas, father of Andrew, brother of Garrett and his wife Cynthia. His legacy shines through; his deeply held sense of integrity, his gentleness, the clarity of his mind and his natural grace in adversity. A graveside service will be Friday March 29 at 1:00 PM in Riverview Cemetery, N. Main St. Essex, CT. A reception will be Monday April 1 from 3-5 PM at the Essex Yacht Club, 13 Novelty La. Essex. Contributions in his memory to Vanderbilt Shy-Drager Research Fund, Vanderbilt University Medical Center., AA-3228 Medical Center North Nashville, TN. 37232-2195.

title: 'Colors on the Edge' -- 'Hard and Soft: The Paintings of Richard Anuszkiewicz and Leon Berkowitz'
description: ACA Galleries

title: Moody's Raises Debt Rating Of South Korea by 2 Notches
description: Moody's Investors Service surprised and delighted South Korean officials today by upgrading the country's sovereign debt rating two notches to A3 from Baa2. The change puts the rating just one notch below where it was before the 1997 economic crisis, when the government needed a $58 billion rescue package from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Hunting a Rhino
description: In Danny DeVito's new film, ''Death to Smoochy,'' Robin Williams, left, plays Rainbow Randolph Smiley, a corrupt children's show host, who is fired. He is replaced by a rhino named Smoochy, the felt-covered alter ego of Sheldon (Edward Norton).

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 11.

title: Relative Is Charged In 2 Queens Deaths
description: A Queens man was arrested yesterday in connection with the shooting deaths early Wednesday of his father and brother.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Debt Accord For Cordiant
description: A British advertising agency, the Cordiant Communications Group, said it had reached an accord with its banks to amend certain agreements, known as covenants, governing its loan facilities. The new agreements take effect for periods ending on and after Dec. 31, and reflect the sharp slide in advertising revenue, the company said. Cordiant said it would provide more details of the agreements when it reports its annual results next month. The company has suffered several setbacks. Earlier this year the North American arm of Hyundai Motor, one of its largest clients, said that it was taking its media buying business elsewhere and would put its creative business up for review.

title: 'H. W. Janson and the Legacy of Modern Art'
description: Salander-O'Reilly Galleries

title: Citing Recent Crime Statistics, Jersey City Sues Gun Makers
description: Jersey City today became the 33rd governmental entity in the country since 1998 to sue the gun industry, charging that negligent sales practices have helped create a black market in weapons for criminals.

title: Death Penalty Sought
description: The Justice Department said that it would seek the death penalty for Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person arrested in the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. Moussaoui is charged with conspiring with Osama bin Laden and the Qaeda terrorist network.

title: Calipari's Consolation Is the N.I.T. Title
description: The beauty of winning the National Invitation Tournament is that it gives the winners a chance to say, ''I told you so.'' It's a rare coach who goes to the N.I.T. final and is not still stinging from a perceived snub from the N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee. Few participants were angrier or more vocal about being left out this year than Memphis Coach John Calipari.

title: Ellen Gallagher -- 'Preserve'
description: Drawing Center

title: Ad Age Group Buys AdCritic.com
description: The Ad Age Group in New York, the division of Crain Communications that publishes Advertising Age, has acquired AdCritic.com, a company that provided online access to television commercials. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Mexico Arrests A Key Figure In Drug Cartel
description: Adding to an extraordinary string of antidrug successes, Mexican authorities announced the arrest of a top lieutenant today in the cocaine trafficking organization known as the Gulf cartel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, RONALD I., M.D., F.A.C.C., F.A.C.P., F.S.C.A.&I., F.C.C.P., F.A.H.A.
description: RUBINSTEIN-Ronald I., M.D., F.A.C.C., F.A.C.P., F.S.C.A.&I., F.C.C.P., F.A.H.A. 46 years old, of Ocean Township, died Wednesday, March 27th at Jersey Shore Medical Center. Dr. Rubinstein received his education at Texas Tech University School of Medicine in Lubbock, Texas. He did his Internal Medicine Internship and Residency at Mount Sinai Hospital in NYC and, his Cardiology Fellowship & Invasive and Interventional Fellowships at the Philadelphia Heart Institute, Presbyterian-University of PA Medical Center in Philadelphia. Dr. Rubinstein had a private practice in both Neptune and Marlboro Townships. He was an Interventional Cardiologist and the Director of Interventional Cardiology at Jersey Shore Medical Center, the Director of Cardiology at Bayshore Hospital and a staff Cardiologist at Community Medical Center. Dr. Rubinstein was a member of the Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon and a benefactor for the Jewish Community Center in Ocean Township. Dr. Rubinstein devoted much of his time and energy to the American Heart Association. He was the President of the American Heart Association, Southern Board and a leader in the Heart Walks and Dinner Dances for the Monmouth and Ocean Chapters. Dr. Rubinstein worked tirelessly to promote better education of Heart Disease and the need for AED's as the first chain of survival in sudden cardiac arrest. Dr. Rubinstein was also a leader in the field of Research, always striving to find safer and healthier methods to treat his Cardiac Patients. Surviving are his wife Judith Bashover Rubinstein, his three sons, Benjamin, Max and Jacob, his mother Rochelle, of New York City and 2 brothers, Todd, of the Bronx, NY and Steve, of Mamaroneck, NY. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, March 29th at 2:00 P.M. at the Temple Beth Miriam Elberon. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the American Heart Association at 2550 Highway 1, North Brunswick, NJ 08902-4301 and/or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the obituary of Milton Berle yesterday referred incorrectly to his son, Bill. Bill Berle did not die in 1989; he resides in Sherman Oaks, Calif., where he writes grants and raises money for a charity that helps the homeless.

title: Mr. Television
description: A quirky reminder of television's dominant role in American life was delivered a few weeks ago. A federal judge in Manhattan, striving for an appropriate alternative to prison, sentenced a recidivist petty criminal to 10 months of home detention with no TV. The man's lawyer immediately filed an appeal, contending that the television ban violated his client's constitutional rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAY, DOROTHY
description: DeLAY-Dorothy. I mourn the loss of my beloved teacher, mentor and good friend Dorothy DeLay. My memories working with her for over twenty years will never be forgotten. My sincere condolences to Ed Newhouse and family. Rohan De Silva

title: On or Off the Field, Rough, Raw and Twangy
description: The high plains of Montana, the setting for ''The Slaughter Rule,'' remain one of the last American outposts of a genuine frontier spirit. The landscape's surreal beauty and the climate's punishing extremes ensure that only a certain kind of person -- seriously outdoorsy, proudly self-reliant and not dependent on urban comforts -- would want to live there. But to do so, the movie suggests, is to experience a purer, rawer state of being than is available elsewhere.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Solectron Wins Big Lucent Contract
description: The Solectron Corporation, a manufacturer best known for its printed circuit board assembly business, said yesterday that it had signed a three-year agreement with Lucent Technologies to produce optical networking equipment worth up to $2 billion. Solectron, based in Milpitas, Calif., will also pay Lucent $125 million for equipment and inventory and lease space in Lucent's Merrimack Valley plant in North Andover, Mass., as part of the deal. Shares in Solectron ended the day up 80 cents, or 11.4 percent, closing at $7.80. Lucent shares rose 39 cents, or 9 percent, to close at $4.73. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Morgan Cut Chief's Pay to $21.9 Million in '01
description: J. P. Morgan Chase paid its chief executive, William B. Harrison Jr., $21.9 million in 2001, 61 percent less than a year earlier, after the bank posted its first quarterly loss in five years, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Incinerate? No!
description: To the Editor:

title: Flight Attendant Ordered Held For Threats Made Aboard Plane
description: A French flight attendant was ordered held in $250,000 bail in federal court here today, after being charged with writing phony bomb threats in the lavatory of a jet in flight from London to Orlando, Fla., in January.

title: World Briefing: Africa; SIERRA LEONE: REBEL LEADER BARRED FROM ELECTION
description: Foday Sankoh, the rebel leader who has been imprisoned for the last two years and is now being tried on murder charges, is not eligible to run in a presidential election scheduled for May 14. The electoral commission said that Mr. Sankoh could not run as a presidential candidate because he is not a registered voter. The Revolutionary United Front, which was led by Mr. Sankoh and in January formally declared an end to its 10-year civil war with the government, had said it wanted to nominate Mr. Sankoh as its presidential candidate. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Jets and Giants Face Early Tests This Fall
description: The Jets cannot ease into the 2002 season like teenagers wading into a cold pool. No, they are taking the plunge early, and may quickly ascertain whether they are going to sink or swim with a roster that has been retooled.

title: Former Republican Leader Is Cleared of Bribery Charges
description: The former chairman of the Queens Republican Party was cleared yesterday of charges that he attempted to bribe a building inspector in 1998.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Good Friday and the second day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Limousine Drivers Get Back Pay
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer has announced that he has settled a lawsuit against a Queens limousine company that said it could not pay its workers because of the attack on the World Trade Center. Mr. Spitzer said the company, Corporate USA, shut down on Sept. 24 and told its workers it could not pay them because of the business downturn. But the 32 drivers were not paid for work in the previous two months, even though after it closed, the company continued to collect accounts receivable, Mr. Spitzer said. The attorney general has obtained $40,000 for the drivers. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Neumann Has One-Stroke Lead Over Sorenstam
description: Asked to assess her feelings heading into the Kraft Nabisco Championship, Annika Sorenstam was understandably optimistic.

title: Jack Tworkov -- 'Red, White and Blue'
description: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

title: Consumer Group Urges U.S. Ban on Arthritis Drug by Aventis
description: Public Citizen, a consumer group, said today in a petition to the federal drug agency that Arava, a rheumatoid arthritis drug from Aventis, should be withdrawn from the market because it has been linked to severe liver problems and deaths.

title: World Briefing: Europe; CZECH REPUBLIC: FILM BAN AT NAZI CAMP
description: Officials at the former Nazi concentration camp called Theresienstadt, near Prague, have banned visitors from making videotapes or movies at the site after a Czech newspaper reported that part of a pornographic movie had been filmed there. The director of the camp memorial, Jan Munk, said he would try to block the distribution of the movie. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Crown Heights Appeal Weighed
description: Federal prosecutors have requested two additional weeks to decide whether to ask an appeals court to reconsider its reversal of the convictions of two black men in the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic Jew in Crown Heights in 1991. Prosecutors also have the option of retrying the two men, Lemrick Nelson Jr., above, and Charles Price, in the killing of Yankel Rosenbaum during the four days of violence in Crown Heights in 1991. Earlier this month, the United States solicitor general ruled out an unusual review of the January decision by all 13 members of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Suffolk County Officer Is Charged in Abuse of Female Drivers
description: A Suffolk County highway patrolman accused of forcing female drivers to strip or face arrest was charged in federal court yesterday with violating the civil rights of five women.

title: Offering Beauty To the People
description: Can quality of design improve the quality of life? Can it change society? The Swedes take the radical proposition that good modern design can help cure society's ills. This aesthetic philosophy was probably first promoted in Sweden by the socialist reformer Ellen Key (1849-1926), who was profoundly influenced by the English reformers John Ruskin and William Morris. Like them, she felt mass production was hurting aesthetic quality.

title: Rafael A. Lafferty, 87, Science Fiction Writer
description: Rafael A. Lafferty, a prolific science fiction writer best known for his short stories and his fresh, eccentric style, died on March 18 in Broken Arrow, Okla. He was 87.

title: A Nation Challenged: Military; Addressing Worries, Pentagon Says It Can Fight Wider War
description: The Defense Department's top civilian and military leaders said today that the armed forces were capable of expanding the war on terror despite the tempo of operations in Afghanistan and concerns from some commanders that their troops were being stretched thin.

title: With a focus on small everyday triumphs, Verizon seeks an image of progress.
description: YEARS ago, General Electric used to boast that ''progress is our most important product.'' Now, Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telecommunications company, is beginning a big brand image campaign that asserts it helps its customers ''make progress every day.''

title: Novell Official Says He Sought Microsoft's Aid
description: Novell, once the biggest maker of software for corporate networks, offered two years ago to tell antitrust enforcers that Microsoft had altered its behavior in return for help promoting its products, a Novell executive testified today.

title: ADELPHIA MAY BE LIABLE FOR MILLIONS IN LOANS
description: Adelphia Communications, the cable television company that disclosed on Wednesday that it had kept $2.3 billion in debt off its books, may be liable for $500 million in bank loans to a former telephone unit. The company disclosed the loan information for the unit, Adelphia Business Solutions, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Adelphia may have to repay $500 million in unsecured bank debt of Adelphia Business, a spinoff that filed for bankruptcy protection. Adelphia, controlled by the Rigas family through a private trust called Highland Holdings, gave $36.8 million to Adelphia Business on an unsecured basis and may be unable to recover the debt, the filing said.

title: State Report Accuses SUNY Of Favoritism
description: State University of New York officials repeatedly violated university rules and twisted the process of selecting consultants so that they could award contracts to an architect who is Gov. George E. Pataki's next-door neighbor and a relative by marriage, the state inspector general reported today.

title: L.I. Bishop Gives Prosecutors Files
description: Bishop William Murphy, leader of Long Island's 1.5 million Roman Catholics, said yesterday that he had given prosecutors the names of priests in his diocese's personnel files who had been accused of sexually molesting minors.

title: Trying to Fake It in a World Where Work Is Unfulfilling
description: ''Time Out'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 3, 2001; the full text is available at nytimes .com/movies. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan and Los Angeles.

title: Waiting For Winners
description: The Oscars are announced, but what about the videos? ''Training Day'' with Denzel Washington (best actor) was released last week. ''Monster's Ball'' with Halle Berry (best actress) is scheduled for June 11. No dates have been announced for ''A Beautiful Mind,'' ''Gosford Park'' or ''Iris.''

title: Troops for Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Enron's Swap With Qwest Is Questioned
description: Enron and the telecommunications giant Qwest Communications struck a deal last fall to swap fiber optic network capacity and services at exaggerated prices in an effort to improve each company's financial picture, executives close to the deal said this week.

title: The Big City; The Perils Of Reform At Church
description: AFTER what must be a record amount of clerical atonement during Holy Week, preachers in Roman Catholic churches will be seizing on the theme of rebirth this Easter Sunday. They've already gotten plenty of suggestions for ways to resurrect the American church.

title: Energy Chief's Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Spending Rises Sharply At Pharmacies and by Mail
description: Spurred by heavy advertising for a handful of blockbuster products and a jump in prices, consumer spending on prescription drugs at pharmacies rose more than 17 percent last year, to $154.5 billion, according to a new study. Mail-order drug sales rose 27 percent, to $20.7 billion.

title: Children and Obesity
description: To the Editor:

title: Taurasi Ready to Shine Against Tennessee
description: She faced the questions the way she faces the basket. Straight up. In last year's national semifinals, Diana Taurasi shot 1 for 15 from the field, and 0 for 11 from 3-point range, as Connecticut lost to Notre Dame. She ''stunk it up'' in the Final Four as a freshman, she said. She cost her team a chance to play for a second straight national championship.

title: A Nation Challenged: The Casualty; Serviceman Is Killed in Afghan Exercise
description: A Navy petty officer from Florida was killed this morning in a training mission in a remote area near Kandahar, Afghanistan, the Department of Defense announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERBST, JOSEPH
description: HERBST-Joseph. Beloved husband of Lois and the late Zelda, father of Diane Ruth and the late Daniel, grandfather of Colin and Larry Antinozzi, father-in-law of Sandy, stepfather of Jill CohenKolb and Sherry Cohen, brother of Betty, Ellen and the late Dave, Jack, Rose, Belle and Lillian. Funeral services today, 12 noon, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset. Contributions can be made to the Bone Marrow Foundation or Cancer Society.

title: FEDERATED STORES WARNS OF LAYOFFS IF UNIT ISN'T SOLD
description: Federated Department Stores, the owner of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, will lay off 3,300 workers at its unprofitable Fingerhut catalog and Internet unit by the end of next week if a buyer is not found. Efforts to sell the unit to a turnaround firm, Business Development Group Acquisitions, are continuing, and Federated is considering selling individual Fingerhut assets, a spokeswoman said. It is selling Fingerhut to focus on its department stores, which attract higher-income shoppers, investors said.

title: Piazza Isn't Going To Take It Anymore
description: Mike Piazza can hit a baseball as solidly and as far as just about anyone else in baseball, but he shows unusual restraint when it comes to retaliation. Piazza does not charge the mound or confront a pitcher after being hit by a pitch. This spring, though, he may finally be tired of taking shots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, DOROTHY (LIPKIND)
description: SINGER-Dorothy (Lipkind). On Wednesday, Mar. 27, 2002. Loving wife of the late Murray Singer. Devoted mother of Arthur & Ellen Singer, and Barry and Ruth Singer. Grandmother of Michael Singer, Howard and Suellen Singer, Andrew and Michele Singer and Richard and Lisa Singer. Greatgrandmother of eight. Cherished sister of Max and the late Louis, Nettie, Irving, Betty and Sidney. Private graveside services.

description: A WONDERFUL sound came gurgling out of my radio the other day. It was the bizarre signature call of John Sterling, the Yankees' play-by-play announcer:

title: The Old Downtown Economy Won't Return
description: The public debate over the World Trade Center site has focused on what may happen above ground -- an appropriate memorial, a visionary streetscape. But there has been far too little discussion of what it will take to restore Lower Manhattan as an economic engine.

title: Airman's Rape Conviction Fans Okinawa's Ire Over U.S. Bases
description: Lawyers for a United States airman convicted of rape today in a Japanese court in Okinawa said that they would recommend an appeal of the verdict. The case has generated strong tensions between Japan and the United States and has fanned resentment against the heavy American military presence on Okinawa, Japan's southernmost prefecture.

title: Thomas Flanagan, 78, Author Of Trilogy About Ireland
description: Thomas Flanagan, a professor who turned a flash of inspiration into a prize-winning historical novel of Ireland, then followed it with two more acclaimed books in the same vein, died on March 21 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 78.

title: Growth Revised Upward, to 1.7% Last Quarter
description: The United States economy grew at a faster pace in the fourth quarter than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A Nation Challenged: Disaster; Afghan Resilience Aids Recovery After Quake
description: From soon after sunrise today, Muhammad Siddiq was at work in the ruins of his home, using his weak left arm to wield a pick, and then a shovel, amid the pile of mud bricks that had been his living room. His right arm was in a sling. His left leg was bloodied and heavily bandaged. His beard was caked in dust, and his jacket torn from his exertions.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Canadian artist Jean-Paul Riopelle on Sunday misidentified a project known as Refus Global and his involvement with it. It was a manifesto against Canadian social conservatism that he and other artists signed, not a group of which he was a co-founder.

title: Trying Hard to Make Sense Of Her Life Before It Ends
description: For every small film like ''In the Bedroom'' or ''Monster's Ball'' that breaks out to popular acclaim -- movies without car chases or hobbits or multimillion-dollar budgets -- there are hundreds of quiet films that never find their way into theaters. For whatever reasons, those two were lucky (the violent deaths in each may have pushed them into the just-loud-enough-for-release category), while Christopher Munch's eloquent, moving ''Sleepy Time Gal'' was not.

title: People
description: * Randy Browning, co-president and chief marketing officer at Publicis in the West, Seattle, part of the American operations of the Publicis Groupe, was promoted to chairman and chief executive. He succeeds Dennis Miller, who resigned in June.

title: World Briefing: Asia; BANGLADESH: FORMER PREMIER CHARGED
description: The government filed corruption charges against the former prime minister and the main opposition party leader, Sheik Hasina, setting off rowdy protests on the streets of the capital, Dhaka. Sheik Hasina and six of her former cabinet ministers, all members of the Awami League, are accused of financial irregularities in connection with the building of a planetarium. League officials called the move an act of political vengeance. They have boycotted Parliament since being routed from power by the Bangladesh National Party last year. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Milk Spinoff Planned
description: The Snow Brand Milk Products Company said that it would probably spin off its milk business and combine it with two national agricultural cooperatives. The company's president, Kohei Nishi, will also resign, accepting responsibility for several recent problems, including illegally labeling beef to obtain government subsidies. Snow Brand has already said that it hopes to set up ventures with other companies to salvage its frozen foods, pharmaceutical and child care divisions. The company expects to lose 71.4 billion yen ($541 million) in the fiscal year ending Sunday, three times what was expected. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Shirley Goldfarb -- 'Pink, Rose, Love: Paintings From the Early 60's'
description: Zabriskie Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, WILLIAM
description: STEWART-William. We deeply mourn the loss of our dear colleague, Bill Stewart, a noted linguist who was passionately interested in all aspects of language and a dedicated teacher devoted to his students. Frances Degen Horowitz President CUNY Graduate Center

title: Vintage Plane Crash-Lands In Seattle Bay; Crew Is Saved
description: As some lunchtime patrons watched in transfixed horror and others dashed for the street, a 1940's-era Boeing passenger plane owned by the Smithsonian Institution crash-landed in Elliott Bay here this afternoon, coming to a stop just short of Salty's, a popular waterfront restaurant.

title: A Nation Challenged: The Prisoners; Rumsfeld Backs Plan to Hold Captives Even if Acquitted
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld today defended the Pentagon's plan to keep some prisoners from the Afghan war in captivity in Cuba indefinitely even if they are acquitted in military tribunals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, DANIEL ROBERT
description: KLEIN-Daniel Robert. On March 25, 2002. Survived by Nancy Klein, dear father of Vanessa & Wendy. Loving son of Florence and the late William Klein. Devoted twin brother of Elliot. Also survived by many loving cousins and friends. Services on Friday 11:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Briefing: Africa; NIGERIA: ELECTION LAW NULLIFIED
description: The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional a recently enacted law that set local elections for next year, when the presidential and other elections are to be held. The court ruled that under the 1999 constitution the local councils' term of office ends May 29 of this year and could not be extended by Parliament. With no local elections scheduled and no voter registration lists prepared, it was unclear what would happen when the terms expire in two months. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Italy's Unions Seem Ready For Battle
description: The Italian government's resolve to create a more flexible labor market is coming under increasing resistance from the nation's traditionally powerful labor unions, threatening to unleash the worst labor trouble in decades and challenging the government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, JOSEPH J.
description: THOMPSON-Joseph J. Of Rockville Centre, New York on March 23, 2002, in his 85th year. Beloved husband of Geraldine M. (Gerry) for sixty years. Loving father of Justin, Kevin, Dennis, Rory and Joanne. Beloved fatherin-law of Bonnie, Kathy, Ronnie, Pattie & Roger. Dear grandfather of fourteen grandchildren and two great grandchildren. He was employed at The New York Times from June 1, 1947 to April 1, 1985. Past Captain of the Fire Police Squad, and a 48 year member of the Eureka Hook, Ladder and Bucket Co. #

title: Pension Director Is Retiring; Florida Fund Had Enron Loss
description: The head of Florida's state pension fund, which has come under scrutiny because of losses from investments in Enron, announced today that he would retire in June after six years on the job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, HANS
description: SCHINDLER-Hans. On March 27, 2002, in his 90th year. Beloved husband of the late Marianne. Loving brother of William Schindler and cherished uncle of Erica Neumann. He will be missed by all his family and friends. Funeral services Monday, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to follow at Old Mount Carmel Cemetery.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Punishment For Strip Searches
description: Three Kansas City school district employees face dismissal over a strip search of a group of third graders held after $5 disappeared, school officials said. The money was found, but not as a result of the search. Schools Superintendent Bernard Taylor Jr. promised that the ''district will pursue the most severe disciplinary action against those responsible.'' The principal of Pitcher Academy and two teachers have been suspended. Daniel I. Dorfman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMASH, SIDNEY A.
description: ROMASH-Sidney A. Beloved husband of Belle. Loving father of Cliff and Ellen. Devoted brother of Philip and Herman. Loving grandfather of Daniel, David, Rebecca and Rachel. Services 12:30, Friday, at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.
