title: National Briefing | West: California: Child Endangerment Conviction
description: The State Supreme Court unanimously upheld a Sacramento woman's felony conviction for child endangerment in the death of her infant daughter, whom she left with her abusive fianc. An appeals court had overturned the verdict, ruling that the woman, Eva Valdez, did not believe that her fianc, Hiram Lebron, would harm the child. But the Supreme Court ruled that no reasonable person would have left the girl in the care of Mr. Lebron, who had previously injured her. The girl died after being beaten and shaken by Mr. Lebron, who is serving 25 years to life. Friends had warned Ms. Valdez not to entrust her daughter to Mr. Lebron while she was at work. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAIL, DONALD
description: VAIL-Donald of Bedford, NY, died on March 27, 2002 at the age of 80. Mr. Vail was born in Yonkers, NY, to John I.B. Vail and Margaret Gray Vail of Hyannis, MA., and Blairstown, NJ. A 1938 graduate of the Holderness School & the Class of 1942 at Princeton University, he entered the Navy in World War II. As a Marine pilot, he served in the South Pacific, leaving the service as a Captain. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1948 and practiced law at the firms of: Sullivan & Cromwell, McCanliss & Early, Alexander & Green, and Walter, Conston, Alexander & Green. Mr. Vail was a founding member of the Bedford Association; Chairman of the Building Committee of St. Francis A.M.E. Zion Church; and a Vestryman and Clerk of the Vestry of St. Matthew's Church. At Northern Westchester Hospital Center, he was a member of the Board of Trustees for 20 years, and a president of the Board from 1977-1982. He had also been a member of the Triangle Club at Princeton and of the Blue Hill Troupe in New York. Mr. Vail is survived by his wife of 50 years, Priscilla L. Vail, author & educator in learning disabilities & dyslexia. He leaves four children: Melissa Vail Selby of Mt. Kisco; Polly Vail Walsh of Chevy Chase, MD; Lucia Vail of New York City; Donald Angus Vail of Portland, OR; and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford on Monday, April 1st at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Northern Westchester Hospital Center Foundation, Mount Kisco, NY.

title: 100 Candles For a Darling Of Society And Charity
description: Tonight, 97 of the world's wealthiest, toniest and most socially connected people will raise a birthday toast to New York's most glittering It Girl.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Ernest van den Haag, a Dutch-born conservative commentator on social issues, misidentified the regime by which he told friends he had been detained in the 1930's. It was the Fascist regime in Italy, not the Nazis in the Netherlands.

title: Gag Rules and Judicial Elections
description: Judges are elected in 38 states, but in an effort to shield the bench from politics, candidates are forbidden to tell voters in advance how they would decide contentious questions. Whether such bans violate the First Amendment was the subject of spirited arguments this week in the Supreme Court, where justices examined Minnesota's rules prohibiting judicial candidates from stating their views on ''disputed legal or political issues.''

title: Pataki Shows Little Interest In Bloomberg's Toll Proposals
description: Gov. George E. Pataki showed little enthusiasm yesterday for higher bridge tolls or more two-tier tolls in New York City, an idea that the mayor has mentioned a lot this week.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Re-Evaluating Decision On Mine
description: The United States Forest Service has temporarily withdrawn its decision to allow a silver and copper mine on the edge of a federal wilderness area in northwest Montana. The move came after the federal Fish and Wildlife Service withdrew its opinion that the Rock Creek mine could proceed without harming grizzly bears and bull trout, which are threatened species. Mark Wilson of the wildlife service said the re-evaluation would take four or five months. Environmental groups had sued to stop the opening of the mine.

title: Dause L. Bibby, 90, Electronics Executive
description: Dause L. Bibby, an executive who spent more than 40 years in the emerging fields of electronics and technology, died March 14 at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 90.

title: Oklahoma Rides Spurt To Championship Game
description: During this same week 12 years ago, the University of Oklahoma thought so little of its women's basketball team that it dropped the sport entirely. Eight days later, after gender-equity protests howled through the campus like a spring tornado, the administration reconsidered.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: U.S. To Close Bases
description: The United States will shut about half of its military bases in South Korea over the next decade, but will not reduce the number of troops from the current 37,000, said Gen. Thomas A. Schwartz, commander of American forces in South Korea. About a third of American troops will move, consolidating all American forces at 23 facilities. The $2.5 billion move is intended to return land to South Koreans and to increase the efficiency of American troops who would help Seoul's 600,000-member military defend South Korea from an invasion by North Korea. James Brooke (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Money For City And County Jails
description: Acknowledging that it was at best a short-term solution, the State Board of Correction has approved the use of $5 million intended for capital improvements to compensate city and county jails for holding state prisoners. Local officials say they are owed almost $6 million for housing inmates who cannot be transferred to state custody because of a shortage of prison beds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRONG, ELAINE GALE
description: WRONG-Elaine Gale. Economist, intellectual, devotee of the arts in life, beloved mother of Terence, grandmother of Edward, motherin-law of Naomi, she is irreplaceable. Service at 11:15AM Monday, April 1, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam & 76th

title: More War Is Not the Route to Israeli Security
description: The terrible terrorist events that have struck Israel on the Passover holiday have generated an understandable feeling that ''something must be done.'' Not surprisingly, that has meant waging war on the Palestinian Authority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSTEIN, MARGERY
description: ARONSTEIN-Margery. Beloved grandmother of Jesse Kahn, devoted wife of the late late Henry Aronstein, wonderful mother of Susan Kahn, loving aunt of Randy and Ken Rogers, and beloved daughter of Stella Hartz and Nathan Voloshen. Died suddenly but peacefully on March 28, 2002. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral services will be private.

title: In Powell's Words, a Plea to Both Sides
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference today on the Middle East by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. The full text is available at nytimes.com.

title: Price Delivers for Oklahoma in Many Ways
description: Hollis Price is a junior who looks like a freshman. He stands a little over 6 feet tall and supposedly weighs 165 pounds, but the skinny on Price is that his game at point guard for Oklahoma is much larger. He is calm and mature, factors that have helped push the Sooners (31-4) to 12 consecutive victories and into the Final Four against Indiana (24-11) on Saturday at the Georgia Dome.

title: UConn Makes March to Final Look Easy
description: By now, these stretches have become as familiar and predictable as stops on a bus route. Connecticut opens a game and within minutes, the opponent is frazzled, backpedaling, unnerved. The game is only beginning and yet it threatens already to be over.

title: With New Approach, Neumann Takes Two-Stroke Lead
description: When last year ended, Liselotte Neumann looked at some facts and did not like what she saw. She had not won on the L.P.G.A. Tour since 1998, she had her worst finish on the money list (61st), and she had fallen out of the top 125 in both driving accuracy and driving distance.

title: Strike by a U.S. Plane, Rather Than Enemy Fire, May Have Killed a G.I.
description: The first American soldier killed in the assault on Al Qaeda and Taliban forces in eastern Afghanistan this month might have died from fire from an American warplane and not enemy mortar blasts, as initially thought, a senior commander said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPARELLO, LOUISE
description: PAPARELLO-Louise, 94. On March 26. Beloved mother of Frank and Isabelle Arace. Motherin-law to Elizabeth and Michael. Grandmother of Stephanie (Hays), Scott and Kim Paparello, and Kristin and Jennifer Arace. Also survived by five great grandchildren. Services private.

title: Some Boys, Too, Just Wanna Have Fun
description: Andrew W. K.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, LEE N.
description: STEINER-Lee N. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Lee N. Steiner. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Rosalind, his daughters, Terry, Nancy and Catherine, and to the entire family. James M. Dubin, President Richard J. Bronstein, Secretary

title: February Computer Chip Sales Off 35%
description: Worldwide sales of computer chips fell 35 percent in February, declining at the slowest pace since June as chip makers outside Japan got more orders from makers of mobile phones and digital cameras, an industry group said.

title: In 1948, Fan Was Killed By a Puck at the Garden
description: The recent death of a 13-year-old girl in Ohio after she was hit in the forehead with a puck has raised concerns about safety at rinks. It was the first time a fan had been killed by a puck at an N.H.L. game. In recent years, fans have been killed by pucks at smaller arenas. But in 1948, in a game few people remember, a 47-year-old woman was killed after being hit by a puck at the old Madison Square Garden.

title: Brooke Astor's Century
description: ''When Mrs. Astor turns 100'' might be a line from a Cole Porter song, the kind of song that catches in a chorus or two the way Brooke Astor has glimmered upon New York City in her time. No one expects to turn 100, and one is not even sure, in one's own life, whether to hope to turn 100. But there can be no hesitation when it comes to Mrs. Astor -- the more of this one life of hers, the better for all of us and the better for New York. She turns 100 tomorrow and will be roundly cheered and feted tonight for doing so. She will probably say she had nothing to do with it.

title: In the Arabs' Struggle Against Israel, There Are Many Players
description: To most Israelis, and to much of the world, the unremitting series of suicide attacks that have pushed Israel to proclaim Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, an ''enemy'' and assault his headquarters in Ramallah are the work of Palestinian terrorists, acting sometimes with the tacit approval of Mr. Arafat.

title: A Far-Off Inuit World, in a Dozen Shades of White
description: In standard histories of world cinema, the Inuit people of northern Canada figure mostly in connection with Robert J. Flaherty's ''Nanook of the North,'' an epochal silent documentary made in 1922. Eighty years later, the voices of the Inuit can at last be heard on screen. ''The Fast Runner (Atanarjuat)'' directed by Zacharias Kunuk and based on an ancient folk epic, is the first feature film made in the Inuktitut language by an almost entirely Inuit cast and crew. It was made, with financial assistance from the National Film Board of Canada, by Igloolik Isuma Productions. Mr. Kunuk founded this company in 1990 with Norman Cohn, the film's director of photography; Paul Apak Angilirq, who wrote the screenplay; and Pauloosie Qulitalik, a cast member, with the intention of expanding film and video productions in the aboriginal areas that now form the Canadian province of Nunavut.

title: Firefighters Retiring at Triple the Usual Rate
description: New York City firefighters are retiring at more than triple the usual rate this year, according to fire officials who say the surge in departures is another lingering impact from the collapse of the World Trade Center.

title: Deadly Days In the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Icahn Competes With Forstmann for XO
description: XO Communications Inc. said it was considering a bid by the financier Carl C. Icahn, whose $500 million offer for 50 percent of the unprofitable phone and Internet company rivals a proposal from the buyout firm Forstmann Little, which is led by the investor Theodore J. Forstmann.

title: Pope Is Forced To Curtail Usual Role In Holy Week
description: Troubled by symptoms of Parkinson's disease and a painful arthritic knee, Pope John Paul II has been forced this week to severely curtail his participation in Holy Week ceremonies that move the church from a period of mourning for Christ's death to the Easter season of celebration.

title: Gap in Test Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: Special U.N. Session On Mideast Violence
description: The United Nations Security Council was called into an emergency session today in the wake of Israeli attacks on Yasir Arafat's headquarters and another Palestinian suicide bombing in Israel.

title: 5 Killed in Separate Army and Navy Training Exercises
description: Five military personnel were killed and five others were injured in two training accidents on Thursday and early today, Navy and Army officials said.

title: Sharon's Two Struggles
description: There were two contradictory images of Ariel Sharon to choose from today in trying to figure out where the latest twist in the Middle East conflict is headed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rate Action Unlikely
description: The future governor of the Bank of Korea, Park Seung, said the economy had shown signs of overheating but he saw no reason for acting against slowly rising prices. After he takes over on Monday, Mr. Park is expected to favor the current 4 percent interest rate rather than yield to suggestions for increasing rates to curb inflation. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A credit on Wednesday for a picture of a student who headed to classes in La Porte, Ind., as snow obliterated signs of early spring in the Midwest, misstated the surname of the photographer. He is Bob Wellinski, not Wellington.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOTT, NANCY PAULA
description: CLOTT-Nancy Paula. On March 28, 2002. Beloved daughter, sister, aunt and truest friend. Service Monday 11 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. With great sorrow and love. Janet, Stephen and Zoe Rotter

title: Europeans Voice Alarm As Violence Intensifies
description: European nations expressed alarm today at the intensifying warfare in the Middle East, urged a return to negotiations and warned pointedly against any harm coming to Yasir Arafat.

title: Angolan Rebels, Their Leader Dead, Take Part in Truce Talks
description: In the small Angolan town of Luena, where the rebel leader Jonas Savimbi is said to have been buried, the surviving military commanders of his Unita movement have been locked for days in secretive cease-fire talks with government military chiefs.

title: Heart of a Romantic, Head of a Skeptic
description: William Holden said he had a ''mind full of razor blades.'' And Billy Wilder, himself, acknowledged he liked ''to mix a little vinegar in the cocktail.''

title: Ruling May Put Marijuana Measure on Ballot
description: A federal judge here has overturned a law prohibiting residents of the city from circulating or voting on a ballot initiative to legalize marijuana for medical purposes.

title: U.S. Puts Onus On Palestinians To Stop Terror
description: Expressing sympathy with Israel's decision to respond militarily after a series of terrorist attacks, the Bush administration today blamed the bombings by the Palestinian militants for the escalating violence in the Middle East and demanded that Yasir Arafat take steps to stop the attacks.

title: Ready or Not in Atlanta, Four Will Make Two
description: Indiana's title chances may turn on a turned ankle. Oklahoma will see whether it can intimidate two more teams. Kansas and Maryland look alike, play alike and will face each other in the second semifinal game Saturday at the Georgia Dome.

title: I.R.S. to Seek Visa Card Data
description: Visa International will receive a summons from the Internal Revenue Service to turn over records of offshore accounts held by Americans suspected of evading taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, LOUIS
description: RESNICK-Louis, 89. Of Ellenville, New York, died March 26 in Miami, FL. Louis founded Channel Master Corporation with his brothers Harry and Joe. The company started with the first pre-assembled antennas in the country, which grew into a giant industrial complex in his hometown of Ellenville, employing over 1000 people. Lou's benevolence knew no boundaries, endowing his resources on a myriad of humanitarian causes in the area. He lived a life of personal fulfillment. He is survived by his wife Mildred, his daughters, Myrna Jargowsky, and Sherry Ronan, and Michele Cohen. His brother Harry and his sister, Paula Rosenblum his three sons-in-law, and his 11 precious grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, as well as nieces, nephews, and countless friends. He was predeceased by his brother Former Congressman Joseph Y. Resnick and his sister Arlene Rosenblatt. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, March 31, 2002 at 1 PM in Cong. Ezrath Israel Synagogue, Ellenville, NY and burial will be at the Cong. Cemetery in Wawarsing, NY. Donations can be made to the Ellenville Regional Hosp., Route 209, Ellenville, NY 12428, or Cong. Ezrath Israel Syn. Rabbi Eisner Square, Ellenville, NY 12428.

title: Less Traffic, a More Livable City
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, ANN E.
description: O'CONNOR-Ann E. Age 83, died on March 25, 2002. Of Naples, FL and Manchester, VT. Beloved daughter of the late Randal and Florence Burns Borough. Granddaughter of William J. Burns, founder of the William J. Burns International Detective Agency Inc, which became Burns International Security Services, Inc. Beloved wife of the late John D. ''Pete'' O'Connor. Dearest sister of the late Joan Goldsborough and Randal Borough. Survived and mourned by nieces Patricia and Mary Anne, nephews Jack, Randy, and Randal, nine great nieces and nephews and three greatgreat nieces and nephews, sisterin-laws Eileen and Sarah, and nieces-in-law Maureen and Shelby. Funeral Mass at St. Theresa's RC Church, Briarcliff, New York, on Wednesday, April 3, 9:45 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the International Myeloma Foundation, 2129 Stanley Hills Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90046. For additional information contact Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor, New York at 914941-0838.

title: Bristol Issues Warning on H.I.V. Drug
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company has warned doctors that some patients who took its H.I.V, drug Zerit developed a rare nerve inflammation that caused some deaths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINGERHOOD, STANFORD A.
description: FINGERHOOD-Stanford A. On March 28, 2002. Beloved husband of Nina. Devoted father of Steven and Michael, and father-in-law of Sheba. Proud grandfather of Olivia, Minna and Sarah. Loving brother of Marjorie Pfeffer and Shirley Fingerhood. Mentor and friend to many. He was dearly loved and we will miss him terribly. Funeral services Monday, April 1, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions are requested to MIT or NYU Medical Center.

title: Sports of The Times; And Now, the Protge Gets a Shot at Her Mentor
description: Sherri Coale recalls an old airplane hangar substituting for a gym, a tile floor, a leaky roof. She remembers Geno Auriemma without socks and thinking, ''It's sleeting out, freezing rain, why does he have no socks?''

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday, about a new campaign for PepsiCo's lemon-lime soft drink, misstated the role of Janusz Kaminski in one commercial. He was director of photography; the director was David Kellogg of Anonymous Productions. The column also misstated the name of the category in which Mr. Kaminski has won two Oscars. It is cinematography, not photography.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENCHER, IRVING
description: MENCHER-Irving. Loving husband of the late Sylvia Mencher. Loving father of Jesse (Kathleen) and Eleanor. He was a supermarket proprietor, World War II veteran and a longtime member of the Riverdale Democratic Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, HANS
description: SCHINDLER-Hans. On March 27, 2002, in his 90th year. Beloved husband of the late Marianne. Loving brother of William Schindler and cherished uncle of Erica Neumann. He will be missed by all his family and friends. Funeral services Monday, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to follow at Old Mount Carmel Cemetery.

title: County Tells Panhandlers to Pitch Woes Elsewhere
description: The rolling hills here south of Denver are saturated with pricey new subdivisions and huge shopping malls, shining testimony to the soaring growth of Douglas County. Between 1990 and 2000, its population nearly doubled, to 175,766, for a 191 percent increase, the highest change of any county in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALOI, ENRICO L.
description: ALOI-Enrico L. Born May 24, 1922 in NYC. Died March 24, 2002 in NYC of a brain tumor. His livelihood was as a commercial artist, but his passion was art and music, especially opera. His love for the great opera diva Rosa Ponselle inspired him to publish 3 books on her life, her performances, and his personal remembrances of knowing her for the last 24 years of her life. He is survived by his sister Anna Di Maria, his niece Catherine, her husband Joseph Wargo, and his longtime friend and companion Joseph K. Puglisi.

title: Russian Passion Channeled Into a New Heroic Style
description: Now that the Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg, Russia, is back for its fifth consecutive season at City Center, it is time to pay greater attention to the extraordinary power of Boris Eifman's dancers.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Hoffa Disappearance
description: The F.B.I.'s Detroit office said it would provide information it has gathered on the 1975 disappearance of the Teamster leader James R. Hoffa to Oakland County prosecutors for possible state charges. The F.B.I. pursued leads in the case as recently as January and will continue its investigation, but it said no federal charges were expected at this time, although a spokeswoman for the bureau refused to rule out federal charges at a later date. Mr. Hoffa was last seen at a Bloomfield Township restaurant on July 30, 1975.

title: A Family Dinner Makes the Headlines
description: As Richard and Jenny Breining and their children were lighting candles Tuesday night at their home here, flashbulbs went off, a newspaper reporter furiously scribbled notes and the blazing lights of a television camera upstaged the tiny flames.

title: Astin Jacobo, 73, Unofficial Mayor of a Bronx Neighborhood
description: Astin Jacobo, a community advocate who played an important role in the renewal of his problem-ridden Bronx neighborhood, Crotona, died on March 20 in Manhattan. He was 73 and had lived in Crotona, in the central Bronx, since 1970.

title: A City Jewel In the Hands Of Mr. Cubicle
description: NEW YORK mayors have a penchant for inflicting their passions and their peeves on the citizenry.

title: Petitgout Waits for a Line on His Position
description: The adjustments will be subtle if Luke Petitgout switches from right tackle to left tackle. He is right-handed and would have to relearn the left-handed stance he used at Notre Dame, for example.

title: Andersen Dealt Another Setback As Talks Over Civil Case Stall
description: Settlement talks between Enron shareholders and the company's auditors, Arthur Andersen, broke down yesterday as the firm struggled to find new leadership and signs emerged that it was facing a growing cash squeeze.

title: In Jersey City, 2 Trains Derail Within 5 Days
description: A freight train derailed in Jersey City this morning the second derailment in five days at the same spot -- and Conrail police said that vandalism might have caused both incidents.

title: Plastic Recycling Is a Work in Progress
description: At first glance, plastics recycling looks like an economic and environmental success story.

title: Final Tally: Bloomberg Spent $75.5 Million to Become Mayor
description: When the books were finally closed yesterday on the costliest campaign in the history of the United States for any office other than the presidency, the total that Michael R. Bloomberg spent to become mayor of New York City came to $75.5 million.

title: Israelis Besiege a Defiant Arafat in His Office
description: Israeli ground forces stormed Yasir Arafat's compound in the West Bank city of Ramallah today, smashing through walls and battling from room to room as the Bush administration's campaign for a truce staggered beneath a wave of anger and violence.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Top Bid For Enron Assets
description: Spain's second-largest electricity company, Iberdrola, topped five bidders with an offer of $315 million for the Enron Corporation's turbines, generators and an unfinished power-plant project. In a document filed late Thursday with the Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, Enron said Iberdrola's bid for the assets represents the highest and best offer received after months of negotiations with interested parties beginning last summer.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 10 Die In Kashmir Violence
description: In the first attack on security officials in several weeks, renewed violence in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir left at least 10 dead, including 5 soldiers, the police said. Militants blew up an army truck north of Jammu, the winter capital of the state, killing two soldiers, and opened fire on a paramilitary camp, killing two officers. In a separate attack north of Srinagar, the state's summer capital, militants stormed the home of a village headman, killing him and a visitor. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Pentagon Seeks Exemption From Environmental Laws
description: Concerned that several environmental laws are interfering with the military's ability to train soldiers and develop weapons, the Pentagon is seeking a Congressional exemption from an array of measures that have protected endangered species and their habitats for years.

title: Richard Bradford, Novelist of the Southwest, Dies at 69
description: Richard Bradford, a novelist of the Southwest who wrote ''Red Sky at Morning,'' died last Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 69.

title: Worst Drivers In New York Will Pay More
description: New York state insurance regulators yesterday approved a 19.5 percent rise in auto insurance premiums for people with the worst driving records, but insurance executives said the increase was far less than what was needed.

title: S.E.C. Warns Goldman Sachs Of Possible Charges Against It
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has notified the Goldman Sachs Group that the agency may pursue a complaint against the firm stemming from the early disclosure of the Treasury Department's plans to retire the 30-year bond, according to a person close to the firm.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a study of television viewing and aggressive behavior stated the findings imprecisely. The increase in the likelihood of aggression by teenagers and young adults who watched television for more than seven hours a week was between 16 percent and 116 percent; the numbers represented a range, not a fall.

title: When Black Alone Is Evidence Enough
description: Any pop novelist or screenwriter would be proud to claim credit for creating the hero of ''Murder on a Sunday Morning.'' This film centers on Patrick McGuinness, a cocky, hard-driving public defender in Jacksonville, Fla. Dressed in fancy suits and chain-smoking unfiltered Lucky Strikes, he uses his wits and his guts to seek the truth, and he relishes the chance to outwit -- and make fools of -- police officers who are more intent on closing cases than on serving justice.

title: In Belgrade, Too, Students Flex Their Political Muscle
description: Americans might be forgiven if a few years ago they ceased to be able to follow the bouncing Milosevic ball. Slobodan Milosevic equals Bad; that much registered. But between his various wars and the NATO bombing and the questionable elections -- well, finally it was 2000 and Americans had their own election to think about; many no doubt lost track of what was going on over in the Balkans. So when Mr. Milosevic was finally driven from power that October, it may not have registered who got rid of him and how.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Argentines Feel Misled By Foreign Banks in Crisis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNELL, FRIDA, NEE ADLER
description: CORNELL-Frida, nee Adler. Of Cliffside Park, NJ, on March 27, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Ernest. Devoted mother of Alan. Loving grandmother of Michael and his wife, Kimberly, & Lauren. Cherished great-grandmother of Chloe. Service Sunday, 9:30 AM, ''Wien & Wien,'' Hackensack, NJ.

title: The Wimps Of War
description: Here's how bad things are for the Democrats. During the last town meeting of liberals that still convenes on network television -- Hollywood's Oscar ceremony -- no one, not even the tag team of Barbra Streisand and Robert Redford, had so much as a mildly critical word to say about George W. Bush. But Nathan Lane scored one of the night's few laughs when he saluted movie animators for ''creating the illusion of life -- something that was never achieved with Al Gore.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Let's be clear about what brought it all to a halt: terrorism.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New York State inspector general's report on favoritism in the awarding of State University contracts misstated the relationship of an architect, James Copeland, to Gov. George E. Pataki. Mr. Copeland's brother, not Mr. Copeland himself, is married to a sister of Mr. Pataki's wife, Libby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WETZLER, MONTE E.
description: WETZLER-Monte E. The members, attorneys and staff of Brown Raysman Millstein Felder & Steiner LLP sadly record the loss of our esteemed former partner, Monte Wetzler. Monte's superb intellect, leadership, dedication, graciousness, warmth and dignity contributed immeasurably to the growth of our firm and its corporate department. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Sally, and his son, Andrew. Brown Raysman Millstein Felder & Steiner LLP

title: Miami's Punter Visits the Jets
description: The free-agent punter Matt Turk, who has been with the Miami Dolphins the past two seasons, visited the Jets yesterday. Turk was coached during the 2000 season in Miami by Mike Westhoff, who is now the Jets' special teams coach.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Economic Growth Expected
description: Russia expects its economy to expand by an average of 3.5 percent from 2002 to 2005, assuming the export price for its crude oil is $18.50 a barrel, the economy minister, German Gref, said. The gross domestic product probably expanded 3.1 percent to 3.2 percent in the first quarter of this year, Mr. Gref said.

title: 3 Months in Office, Bloomberg Has Set New Political Tone
description: Three months is not long enough to judge a marriage, a new home or a mayoralty. But within that period, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who unexpectedly took the helm of New York City during one of its most difficult periods in modern history, has in many ways profoundly altered the tenor, if not the substance, of city government.

title: Corrections
description: The Residential Real Estate column in The Metro Section yesterday, about new rental apartment buildings in the Flower District, misstated the name of the one at Seventh Avenue and 20th Street. It is the Westminster, not the Metropolitan.

title: Richard Sylbert, 73, Designer Of Oscar-Winning Film Sets
description: Richard Sylbert, a prolific and influential production designer who created the visual setting for dozens of films and won two Academy Awards for his work, died last Saturday at a hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 73 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Frozen Smallpox Vaccine Is Still Potent, Officials Say
description: A huge supply of smallpox vaccine frozen for the last 44 years appears to be as potent and effective as newer vaccine produced for the nation's pharmaceutical stockpile, federal officials and drug company executives said today.

title: Audit Group's Chief to Donate Disputed Stock To a Charity
description: The head of the premier trade group for accountants, facing growing condemnation over a transaction critics liken to the lucrative partnership deals at Enron, has decided to give away stock in the group's commercial subsidiary that cost him about $100,000 but is now worth more than $5 million.

title: When It's Moving Day In Sarajevo
description: The School of Hard Knocks

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, credits were illegible in some copies yesterday for a diagram showing structural causes of the collapse of the World Trade Center. It was made by Baden Copeland, Mika Grondahl, William McNulty, Sarah Slobin and Archie Tse of The New York Times. The source was a draft report by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the American Society of Civil Engineers.

title: Less Traffic, a More Livable City
description: To the Editor:

title: Baker Hughes Is Target of U.S. Investigation
description: Baker Hughes, the oil field services company, said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department were investigating accusations of a kickback scheme involving a contract in Nigeria.

title: Modernization Vs. Tradition As Egan Halts A Renovation
description: The renovation at St. Ignatius Loyola, a treasured Roman Catholic church on the Upper East Side, was to cost $3 million. As part of the project, the sanctuary would be enlarged, the altar moved closer to the people and the communion rail removed, all in keeping with the reforming spirit of the Second Vatican Council. Archdiocesan officials approved the plans every step of the way.

title: Detained Labor Leader in China Is Hospitalized, the Police Say
description: An arrested leader of worker protests in northeastern China has been hospitalized with a heart problem and high blood pressure, the police told his family, raising fears about the man's true condition and its causes.

title: U.S. Promotion of Legal Crops Fails to Stem Colombia's Coca
description: The State Department has concluded that its strategy to persuade peasant farmers in Colombia to replace their coca fields with legal crops is failing, administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the existence of more than 85 million doses of smallpox vaccine and a related article about Aventis Pasteur, which plans to deliver the vaccine to the government, misstated the title of Richard J. Markham, an executive who commented for the company. He is the chief executive of Aventis Pharma, the parent of Aventis Pasteur -- not chief executive for Aventis Pharma's American operations.

title: Love and Loss, Jacket and Tie
description: Some bands use simple melodies to make their noisy music more palatable. With Phantom Planet, a young band from Los Angeles, it works the other way around. On Tuesday night at the Village Underground, the group played its bright, tuneful songs fast and loose. In this case, a spoonful of medicine helped the sugar go down.

title: Deadly Days In the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AGENTS SEIZE TERROR SUSPECTS IN PAKISTAN RAID
description: A team of American law enforcement and intelligence officials stormed several houses in Pakistan early Thursday and captured five Taliban fighters and 25 Arabs suspected of having links to Al Qaeda, senior Pakistani law enforcement officials said today.

title: Talk of Ground Zero Tribute, as West Street Reopens
description: The twin beams of light forming a nocturnal memorial to World Trade Center victims will go dark in mid-April as planned, but may be incorporated into a permanent memorial, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: Economy's Rock: Homes, Homes, Homes
description: Amid the shaky economy of the last couple of years, housing has emerged as the central pillar of support. The market for housing has become less volatile and less prone to oversupply than before; it has also become the Federal Reserve's main lever for reviving the economy.

title: Sports of The Times; A No-Brainer All the Way Around
description: WHILE the Final Four coaches faced the news media yesterday at the Georgia Dome, the coaches' hotel was a wasps' nest of activity. This is their headquarters, a gathering of high-profile, low-profile and no-profile coaches. Thirty coaching vacancies had shrunk to 20, and the topic of individual conversation was lines of succession. The biggest buzz was about Stan Heath.

title: An Afghan Boy Cheated of Childhood
description: One of the hallmarks of Iranian cinema in the last 15 years or so has been child protagonists. More recently, and well before Sept. 11 and its aftermath alerted the rest of the world to conditions in Afghanistan, Iranian filmmakers began to explore the lives of the refugees from that country who live, often perilously and illegally, in Iran. ''Delbaran,'' Abolfazl Jalili's new movie about a 14-year-old Afghan boy living in a desert outpost near the border between the two countries, combines these two concerns. It also, like many other recent films from Iran, mixes documentary immediacy with an oblique, poetic approach to narrative.

title: Leaderless When Direction Is Needed Most
description: If the boss calls, get a name.

title: Less Traffic, a More Livable City
description: To the Editor:

title: With Vaccine Available, Smallpox Debate Shifts
description: The medical experts were faced with a tough choice. They had reason to believe that an infectious disease might strike Americans, killing many thousands. An epidemic could be prevented with a vaccine, but almost no one was immunized. Should the nation stockpile vaccine, wait for the illness to strike and then start immunizing? Or should there be a crash campaign to vaccinate everyone in America?

description: FREIMARK-Ruth (Speier). Beloved wife of Walter. Mom (Nanny) died in peace after a long goodbye on March 26th. She set an example as a Righteous Woman for all of us. She is survived by the families of her daughter, son, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Love you always. Barbara and Allen Mait Norman and Susan Freimark

title: Tie to Aetna Is Being Cut
description: American Healthways, which provides diabetes and heart disease services to hospitals, doctors and health plans, has said it plans to withdraw from a cardiac disease management contract with Aetna. The contract, to monitor Aetna customers with congestive heart failure, will end on July 1, American Healthways said.

title: A Mayoral Matter: Fishnets or Lapels?
description: It is not where Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be next weekend that is the question, but whether he will follow in the pump-steps of his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who loved to cross-dress in performing his rebuttal to the annual political roast by the press corps.

title: SUNY Fires 2 Officials, Citing Roles In Contracts
description: The State University of New York has fired two officials involved in improper contracts with an architect who is a neighbor and relative by marriage of Gov. George E. Pataki's, and a local prosecutor is looking into the matter, officials said today.

title: Deadly Days In the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, AGNES P.
description: BERGER-Agnes P. She is survived by her son John, grandsons Daniel and Michael Berger, and daughter-in-law Nancy Gordon, all of El Cerrito, CA, and by her brother in Israel, Bela Herzl, and his family.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Finalists For Poet Laureate
description: Two New York natives were among three finalists selected this week from more than 50 applicants by the California Arts Council's poet laureate review panel. The New York natives are Diane diPrima of San Francisco, a veteran of the Beat era, and Quincy Troupe, who teaches at the University of California at San Diego. The third finalist is Francisco X. Alarcn, a Mexican-American poet who heads a Spanish program at the University of California at Davis. Gov. Gray Davis will choose the poet laureate by July. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: The Snack Police Are Out in Force; But Messy Food Is Allowed if You Buy It at the Movies
description: Nothing about Maria Paredes would arouse suspicion. A pleasant-looking woman with a friendly smile, she hardly seems a rule breaker. Still, alarm bells rang in the security guard's head when she approached him on a recent Sunday, a shopping bag slung over one arm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLE, MILTON
description: BERLE-Milton. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved Abbot Emeritus, Milton Berle. To the world he was Mr. Television, but to the Friars, he was a friend who touched our lives, not only with his comedy, but also through his personal guidance. He singlehandedly assured the revival of the Club in the 1950s and was fierce in his dedication and continued support of humanitarian causes. He helped us preserve the rich theatrical roots of the Friars Club and his name belongs among the legendary and immortal Friars like Jack Benny, George Burns, Enrico Caruso, George M. Cohan, Cary Grant, George Jessel, Joe E. Lewis, Dean Martin, Ed Sullivan, Mike Todd and Frank Sinatra. And like them he shared a legacy of commitment to the very best. We are honored and proud to have been touched by the legend that will always be Milton Berle. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Sally Jessy Raphael, Prior Stewie Stone, Scribe Fred C. Klein, Treasurer Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Telecom Sale Closer
description: The Czech Republic's finance minister, Jiri Rusnok, said the government might complete the long-awaited sale of Cesky Telecom before June parliamentary elections, to raise as much as 80 billion koruna ($2.3 billion) for the state budget. The National Property Fund said three binding offers were submitted to the sale adviser, J. P. Morgan in London, by the deadline yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIGELSON, CHARLES, M.D.
description: FEIGELSON-Charles, M.D. On March 24th. Age 71. A psychoanalyst known for his sensitivity to the emotional problems of children. He had been regarded as one of the most gifted psychoanalysts of his generation. Famous among his friends for his sunny ironic wit, his personal sweetness, and superb intellect. Survived by his wife Carolyn, his sons Daniel, Thomas, Jeremy, Paul, his daughter Suzanne, his brothers Harvey and Eugene and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in June. Donations in Charlie's memory made be made to: The Bridge, 712 Park Street, Charlottesville, VA. 22901.

title: Explosive Encounters With Perry Como
description: Andrea Kleine and Yasmeen Godder

title: As Arabs Seethe, Saudi Says Uprising Will Go On
description: With his peace initiative looking forlorn, Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia warned today that no strike against Yasir Arafat would stop Palestinian violence while several Arab governments braced to contain popular outrage over the Israeli incursion into Ramallah.

title: Good Friday Ritual Is Cast With the Backdrop of 9/11
description: The last time so many people crossed the Brooklyn Bridge on foot, a little more than six months ago, it was on a panicked exodus.

title: Buying Up Baseball's Possibilities
description: Opening day of the Major League Baseball season has always been a giddy occasion, a kind of unofficial American holiday. By the time the president tosses out the first ball of the spring, everyone (even a Cleveland Indians fan) is optimistic about his team's chances for at least an interesting summer. In a national pastime laden with symbolism, the rituals of the new baseball season have long served as an annual re-enactment of the most basic American premise -- that at the beginning, anything is possible for everyone. Yet when this year's season begins tomorrow, that democratic sense of possibility will be diminished. In recent years, winning has come too predictably to the teams with the biggest payrolls.

title: Listening for the Voices of Women
description: When her marriage to Ted Turner was unraveling two years ago, Jane Fonda pulled out her copy of ''In a Different Voice,'' the famous 1982 study of gender and moral reasoning by the feminist psychologist Carol Gilligan.

title: Agassi Notches 699th Match Victory After Rios Defaults
description: Andre Agassi had failed on 15 of 17 break points through two sets today in the Nasdaq-100 Open semifinals. But as he waited for the start of the third set, he was optimistic.

title: Mastery of Timing, Concern for Details
description: Pilar Rioja

title: Drilling Could Hurt Wildife, Federal Study of Arctic Says
description: Undercutting the Bush administration's case for oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, a federal study released today said that such drilling could harm caribou, snow geese, musk oxen and other wildlife.

title: Knicks' Ineptitude Provokes Angry Boos From Fed-Up Fans
description: On many nights this season, especially once the Knicks' futility became apparent, the Madison Square Garden crowd has been an apathetic lot, often passing up prime opportunities to boo the home team. The indifference seemed to be a sign that the fans had become desensitized to the Knicks' failure. So why waste their breath jeering?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNY, EILEEN
description: KENNY-Eileen. On March 27, 2002. Former resident of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Beloved wife of Thomas F. Kenny, loving sister of Eleanor, Elizabeth and William. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends, Saturday, 7-9PM and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81st St. Funeral mass Monday, 10 AM at St. Joseph's R.C. Church. Interment, St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Grammys May Be New York-Bound
description: City officials would not comment yesterday on a news conference scheduled for Wednesday at which Grammy officials and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg are to be present.

title: In Israel, Press Kits Roll Out With Tanks
description: Israel's army and its government and its vast public relations apparatus -- appeared to be mobilizing today for a long, drawn-out battle against the Palestinians.

title: Pity the Owner: Too Busy Running a Club to Play in It
description: There are two groups of people in the bridge community who hardly ever reach the rarefied levels of international competition. One consists of professional tournament directors, who spend their time watching others play. An exception to this generalization was the late Harold Franklin of England, who was the chief director of the World Bridge Federation and still managed to represent his country on several occasions.

title: Beverly Sills And the Future Of City Opera
description: It is one of those New York City fairy tales that are all the better for being true: the story of a girl called Bubbles who rose from her middle-class Brooklyn neighborhood, lisp and all, to become an internationally acclaimed coloratura and the reigning queen of the New York City Opera.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Two Japanese Banks Lower An Interest Rate to 0.001%
description: With the basic logic of their business twisted into knots by years of recession and falling prices, two of Japan's largest banks said today that they would slash the interest rate they pay on ordinary savings accounts to 0.001 percent, just one-twentieth of the already tiny 0.02 percent they pay now.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economy Struggles
description: Japanese factory production rose less than expected in February and unemployment stayed high, signaling that Japan may not pull out of a 17-month recession quickly. Stocks fell after the government said production rose 1.3 percent last month from January, about half the 2.5 percent gain economists expected and less than a third of the gain manufacturers forecast a month ago. The jobless rate held at 5.3 percent.

title: Patching New Jersey's Budget
description: Much like New York's governor, George Pataki, whose proposed budget this year was for a ''monsoon,'' not a mere rainy day, Gov. James McGreevey of New Jersey has used every trick in the book to make his first statewide budget balance. In particular, both governors are using one-time windfalls to fill their financial gaps. In general, it is very bad budgeting to use one-time revenues to pay for expenses that occur every year. But both governors are arguing that because last year was no ordinary year, it required extraordinary remedies.

title: YES Seeks Meeting With Cablevision
description: The head of the YES Network yesterday asked for a meeting with James L. Dolan, the president of Cablevision, to resolve the dispute that might keep three million Cablevision subscribers in the New York metropolitan area from seeing 130 Yankees games this season.

title: Commissioner's Ban on Inmates' Art Sales Ends Annual Show
description: The New York State corrections commissioner announced yesterday that he had banned the sale of artwork created by prison inmates, saying the benefits of such sales are not worth the anguish they cause to crime victims and their families.

description: Kenyon Martin sat surrounded by a larger than usual contingent of cameras and reporters today, and as the questions came, he sat quietly, smiling and shaking his head, refusing to talk about the controversy involving him.

description: Adam Shapiro, an American volunteer living in Ramallah, was able to enter Yasir Arafat's besieged office building late tonight accompanying a doctor in an ambulance.

title: Prisoners In Peru Seek A Way Out
description: Condemned to life in prison for treason, Wagner Aponte was once resigned to spending the rest of his days behind bars, like hundreds of others imprisoned for joining rebel groups that waged war against the government during a 20-year conflict.

title: Enron Is Seeking Approval For Bonuses and Severance
description: The Enron Corporation asked a bankruptcy court in New York today for permission to spend as much as $130 million to keep crucial employees working for the company as it reorganizes its business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARF, ELIZABETH MELLEN
description: SCHARF-Elizabeth Mellen. On March 28, 2002. Beloved wife of Meyer. Devoted mother of Stephanie Scharf and Jane Schiff. Loving sister of Tillie Edinoff. Cherished grandmother of Julie and Lauren Schiff and Meredith and Jonathan Mandell. Private funeral service. Family is sitting shiva at home of Jane Schiff.

title: Rocky Road for Enron Shareholders and Andersen
description: The efforts to reach a settlement between Enron shareholders and the company's auditors, Arthur Andersen, have shown glimmers of promise over the last two months, but they have never gone smoothly.

title: Kmart Runs Up Big Loss Since Bankruptcy
description: The Kmart Corporation, the biggest retailer to file for bankruptcy, lost $753 million in the five weeks after it sought protection from creditors as consumers abandoned the discount chain.

title: Phillies Waste No Time Paying Back Spencer
description: A spring training camp marked by injuries is ending appropriately for the Yankees. One starting outfielder is on his way back to the team, but another will be bruised when the season begins.

title: A Hard Life That's Easy To Sing About
description: Life is cruel, and then you die. Maybe someone will love you for a while; maybe you'll mourn someone. That's the gist of the songs that E (formerly Mark Oliver Everett) writes for his band, Eels, and the music doesn't soften the bad news.

title: INSIDE
description: Oklahoma Next for UConn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDBAUM, BEATRICE NATALIE
description: WALDBAUM-Beatrice Natalie, 89. March 29, 2002 on Long Island. Beloved daughter of Frances Baron & Henry Lowell Miller, cherished sister of Zyra Lourie, proud and adoring mother of Myra Stark and Dr. Robert S. Waldbaum and of Dr. Ruth Waldbaum and Leslie J. Stark, loving grandmother of Nicole Moser, Victoria Stark, Ali Waldbaum, Hillary Waldbaum and Brian Baron Stark. She is survived by her children, her grandchildren and two precious great-grandchildren, Cameron and Charlotte Moser. Services will be private on Sunday, March 31, at Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale.

title: Religion Journal; An Era When the Art of the Sermon Has Declined
description: ''Preachers are like comedians,'' said Dr. Richard A. Lischer, the Cleland professor of preaching at Duke Divinity School. ''They're always looking for new material.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Unemployment Rate Falls
description: French unemployment declined last month for the first time since June as signs of recovery encouraged companies there to increase hiring. The number of people out of work fell by 4,000 last month, based on the International Labor Organization's measure, the Labor Ministry said. The decline left the jobless rate unchanged from January at 9 percent. Economists had predicted a rise of 15,000 job seekers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYMAN, ELEANOR (NEE LICHTER)
description: HEYMAN-Eleanor (nee Lichter). Doctor of Social Work, died peacefully and with great grace in her home, surrounded by her loving family, March 24, 2002. Adored by her surviving children, Ida, Alison, and Philip, and grandchild Elliot, beloved by her siblings, Shirley, Morton, and Marilyn, loved and admired by her colleagues, and cherished by a multitude of friends, neighbors and relatives who were touched by her generosity, insight and good humor. Dr. Heyman received her B.A. from William Smith College, and her Master's in Social Work from Hunter College. She completed her Doctorate at Columbia University while working and raising 3 children. Her joyful commitment to learning was lifelong and an inspiration to all who knew her. As an analytic social worker she strove to help her patients find their own voices and fulfill their own life goals. Her guidance and wisdom helped so many improve the quality of their lives. She felt honored to be of service, and we are all blessed to have known her.

title: Argentines Feel Misled By U.S. Banks in Crisis
description: As the Argentine economy lurched toward collapse late last year, Mara Carmen de los Santos was worried for her country but felt secure about her own prospects. After all, she had $225,000 in the bank -- not in some fly-by-night local bank, but in dollar accounts in a rock-solid symbol of American capitalism, Citibank.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the existence of more than 85 million doses of smallpox vaccine and a related article about Aventis Pasteur, which plans to deliver the vaccine to the government, misstated the title of Richard J. Markham, an executive who commented for the company. He is the chief executive of Aventis Pharma, the parent of Aventis Pasteur -- not chief executive for Aventis Pharma's American operations.

title: The Nixon Tapes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Limits of Force
description: Who can blame the Israelis for wanting to lash out? With funerals filling their land from scores of Palestinian terror attacks, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon sent tanks to Ramallah yesterday and called up thousands of soldiers. We share Israel's rage. Our reservations are not over the impulse to respond militarily but over the long-range effectiveness of policies that rely heavily on the use of force. It is a lot to ask, but Israel must look beyond its current fury to find a political solution to this conflict. It must realize that no matter how many tanks it sends to the West Bank, only a commitment to withdraw from occupied lands and permit the building of a Palestinian state, in return for normal relations with its Arab neighbors, offers a way out .

title: Bush Names Affirmative Action Critic to Civil Rights Post
description: President Bush used his power to make appointments during Congressional recesses today to name a young black lawyer who is a vocal critic of preferences for minorities to be head of the Office of Civil Rights in the Department of Education.

title: A Loss to Medical Privacy
description: In December 2000, as the Clinton administration was leaving office, we released the first-ever national standards for protecting the privacy of Americans' medical records. Those rules were designed to protect the privacy of information about patients and consumers that doctors, hospitals, health plans and health insurers keep.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Peace Talks In Bangkok
description: Raising hopes for an end to Sri Lanka's 17-year civil war, peace talks between the government and the island's Tamil rebels will take place in Thailand in early May, the Thai foreign minister, Dr. Surakiart Sathirathai, announced in Bangkok. Norwegian officials will mediate the talks, the first in seven years. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Returning Tundra's Rhythm to the Inuit, in Film
description: ZACHARIAS KUNUK'S film, ''Atanarjuat (The Fast Runner),'' based on an age-old Arctic folk tale, has made him a celebrity of sorts. But frankly, he would rather pass on the parties.

title: Urgency, and Bondra, on Capitals' Side
description: The Stanley Cup playoffs do not start for more than two weeks, but the Devils locked up with the Washington Capitals tonight in a tight game that could have been played in May or June. That is because both teams want to still be playing then.

title: Piazza Explains His Loss Of Control
description: Mike Piazza broke his silence today, explaining why he went after Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Guillermo Mota on Thursday, an inning after Mota hit him with a pitch. Other Mets, meanwhile, were glad to see their usually restrained teammate let loose.

description: The big Rottweiler was an awesome sight: glistening black fur, 135 pounds of muscle and nearly 6 feet tall when it rose up on its hind legs. Strangers scattered when they saw it coming.

description: As army engineers prepared for the arrival of 1,700 British troops here, a spokesman for the unit said today that they had already been assigned a mission and that they would be ready for action by mid-April.

title: Parade of Dreamcoats
Brother, Can You Spare a Billion?; In Hard Times, Budget Makers Will Cut, Tax and Borrow
description: Money troubles, everybody's got money troubles. From Albany to Trenton, to the halls of power in New York City and Nassau County, state and local governments around the region are trying to figure out how to plug big deficits. Really big deficits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, LOUISE
description: THOMPSON-Louise. 81 years old on March 23rd, 2002 in New York City. Playwright, skilled legal secretary, wrote for feminist newspapers, Majority Report in NYC and New Directions in NJ. Former NOW Task Force Chair, wrote plays for & with the feminist movement, life-long advocate of human rights, dedicated supporter of animal rights, survived by family and friends.

title: Building an Audience for Live Jazz and Blues
description: THERE is no blues music scene in Westchester County -- not precisely.

title: March 24-30: NATIONAL; A HALF INCH OF STEEL
description: At Davis-Besse, a 25-year-old nuclear power plant near Toledo, a chemical used to control the chain reaction was found to have eaten away 40 pounds of steel in the five-inch-thick lid. If the lid had ruptured it would have created a leak far larger than any yet experienced, although probably still theoretically manageable by the plant's emergency system. The lid did not burst, but was on its way; the only remaining steel was half an inch thick, and it was bent. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission ordered the nation's 68 other pressurized-water reactor plants to check for corrosion. Matthew L. Wald

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: $53 Million Deal Proposed For Morton's Restaurants

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, HANS J.
description: FRANK-Hans J. The Boards of Directors and staff of Selfhelp Community Services and United Help are deeply saddened by the loss of our esteemed Board member, Hans J. Frank, Esq. As a dedicated advocate for the Nazi victim community, Mr. Frank generously brought his legal expertise and commitment to the Boards' work during his 28 years of service. We will miss his inspired leadership and unwavering support. Our sympathy is with his family.

description: To the Editor:

title: Amateur Performances, But the Highest Standards
description: FOUR mighty choral works will be on display in April as amateur groups take on the challenges of Monteverdi's ''Vespers of 1610,'' Bach's Mass in B Minor, Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' and the Dvorak ''Stabat Mater.'' Also ahead is a fascinating array of smaller-scale pieces by two professional choirs, the Pro Arte Singers and Concora.

title: A Top Qaeda Aide May Be Held Captive
description: American and Pakistani officials say they believe that Abu Zubaydah, a top commander under Osama bin Laden, may be among the 30 Qaeda and Taliban fighters captured in Pakistan on Thursday. If confirmed, it would be the most significant apprehension of a Qaeda commander since the United States began its military campaign. Mr. Zubaydah, a 30-year-old Palestinian, has been trying to reorganize the terrorist network for new attacks against the United States, American officials say.

title: U.S. Antiterror Forces May Extend Stay on Philippines Island
description: The American troops sent here with fanfare last month to train the Philippine military in counterterrorism and to help rescue two American hostages will most likely stay longer than the originally announced six months, American and Philippine officials said this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENCHER, IRVING
description: MENCHER-Irving. Loving husband of the late Sylvia Mencher. Loving father of Jesse (Kathleen) and Eleanor. He was a supermarket proprietor, World War II veteran and a longtime member of the Riverdale Democratic Club.

description: IIGO MANGLANO-OVALLE says his best architectural experience occurred when he was 10, when his mother and grandmother took him to visit a cathedral built into a salt mine outside Bogot, Colombia. As the women proceeded through the stations of the cross, the boy licked every church wall he could.

description: FATHER knows best, and this one was claiming that his girl named Sue, his rare Bird, is no Larry.

title: Music 2002
description: As an older reader whose favorite musician is Michael Tilson Thomas, I found nothing to relate to in your music issue. Even the Letters column was missing. Yes, Safire was there, but talking about music. The Food column was there, exploring as usual the outer reaches of cuisine (lamb cooked with exotic herbs, probably to the accompaniment of a rock beat).

title: Stock Option Excesses
description: In his Congressional testimony last month, Jeffrey Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, offered a primer on the misuses of stock options. Options, he said, are the most egregious way for companies to pump up their profits artificially. They also netted him a tidy $62.5 million in 2000 and helped Enron pay no income taxes in four of the last five years.

title: Two Wrongs Don't Make A Right in World Trade
description: DOES it make sense for countries to punish one another for erecting barriers to trade by -- get this -- erecting more barriers to trade?

description: The Carolina Panthers have Chris Weinke at quarterback and his 62.0 rating, which was the worst in the National Football Conference last season. One scout said Weinke does not throw passes so much as he throws ground balls.

description: Some call it Potomac Fever; others are less gracious. How else to explain why Jon Corzine and his wife of 33 years, Joanne, are splitting up?

title: A Long Night, and Breakfast With Arafat
description: Adam Shapiro, a volunteer relief worker from Brooklyn who spent a harrowing night trapped inside Yasir Arafat's compound in the West Bank while Israeli troops pounded it with heavy gunfire, was released unharmed yesterday after having breakfast with Mr. Arafat, he said during a telephone interview.

title: Sorenstam And Webb Put Rivalry In Spotlight
description: For the first time in a major championship, Annika Sorenstam and Karrie Webb will be together in the final group on Sunday.
