description: The volunteers and staff at St. Bernard's Catholic Church sat around the living room in the rectory after dinner on Thursday night, giggling. Should they short-sheet Father Mike's bed?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHMAN, JULIUS
description: FISHMAN-Julius. 3/26/80. With each day that passes, we realize how lucky we were to have had you in our lives. Children, Grandchildren and Great Grandchildren

title: Parade of Dreamcoats
description: Colorful as Ukrainian Easter eggs, coats richly embroidered with a rainbow of needlework and braid are being worn in Paris and New York by women seeking an alternative to commercial plainness. The hippies and flower children of the 1960's rediscovered folkloric clothes from Romania, Hungary and Ukraine. Today the prize coats being worn often come from Turkey, Pakistan, Afghanistan and the Far East.

title: March 24-30: NATIONAL; NEW TAX CHEATS
description: One million to two million Americans deposit funds into secret accounts in tax havens like the Bahamas to evade income taxes, and then spend it using American Express, Mastercard and Visa cards billed to the accounts, the Internal Revenue Service said, pointing to widespread tax cheating among the affluent. Examining charge records is so costly, tax experts say, that only a handful of people are likely to be prosecuted. Many may not even have to pay up because Congress has shriveled the capacity of the I.R.S. to enforce the tax laws. David Cay Johnston

title: A Diver Who Acts, Too
description: DYLAN KORN of Westlake High School in Thornwood is a diver. Although only a sophomore, he recently won a third straight Section 1 high school diving championship.

title: The Girls of Summer
description: TO followers of the national pastime, much is right with the world when the words ''play ball'' waft through the crisp spring air -- as they will once again this week. Then there are the wives of those pampered, prosperous and highly desirable young athletes.

title: And Top o' the Mornin' To You, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Dengue Fever Brings Cancellations in Rio
description: An outbreak of dengue fever in the state of Rio de Janeiro has caused cancellations at several luxury hotels in the city, according to their managers.

title: A Spitball-Shooting Executive, a Frank Zappa Fan and the Lawn King
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: In Pataki's Courtship, Minority Groups See Chance for Veto of Redistricting Plan
description: In this election season, Gov. George E. Pataki has elaborately courted the state's minority voters. The self-proclaimed ''governor of all the people'' has protested the Navy bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques, mourned the dead in the Dominican Republic, kissed the governor of Puerto Rico and attended the Black and Puerto Rican Caucus annual dinner for the first time in his seven years in office.

title: Working Her Way Through Handel
description: ''I LIKE to think of Agrippina as a real Joan Crawford character,'' the English conductor Jane Glover said of the lead role in Handel's youthful opera ''Agrippina.'' ''She is an absolutely appalling woman, and yet you never dislike her. And I think this is what we see in Handel at age 25, this great understanding of human behavior, and sympathy for it. He's a regular, human guy, and I love him for that.''

title: THE BLOWN SAVE
description: The last game of the World Series ended with one. Afterward, a dazed Mariano Rivera glanced over his shoulder, lowered his head and trudged off the mound at Bank One Ballpark, a stunned loser. It is something any team, any reliever, detests. It is the blown save, two of the ugliest words in baseball.

title: Music School Expansion Opposed
description: SCARSDALE neighbors are fighting a locally renowned music school's plan to expand, even as school leaders contend that the proposal could actually ease the area's traffic woes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 17 about a proposal for the Academy Awards to use a form of balloting known as approval voting misidentified a co-author of a 1983 book by that name. Steven J. Brams's co-author was Peter C. Fishburn, not Paul Hager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECHER, RAY
description: BLECHER-Ray. Loving mother, grandmother and wife of the late Max Blecher, Jr. Passed away peacefully on March 28th, 2002 in Los Angeles. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, Monday, April 1st, at 1:30 PM.

title: Street Fight
description: AT 3 a.m. on an unusually warm Friday recently, most of Christopher Street slept, repairing for another workday. But Darnell, a slight 19-year-old in a hooded sweatshirt and baggy jeans, sat on a shadowy stoop with a few friends, smoking a joint. A red Nissan Sentra pulled up, fuzzy dice dangling from the rearview mirror, Jennifer Lopez booming from the back.

title: Soccer, a Cast of Nations And a Kind of Belonging
description: SO far, it's SalesMan United, 3, Real Nerdy, 0. But it's only the beginning of the soccer season, and there are a few more months before the Alacra Cup. Anything can happen.

title: Legacies, Left Unsaid
description: Most Americans want to leave an inheritance; the trouble is, they usually never bother to discuss their legacy plans with their heirs, according to the results of a survey released last week.

title: Suicidal Lies
description: The outcome of the war now under way between the Israelis and Palestinians is vital to the security of every American, and indeed, I believe, to all of civilization. Why? Quite simply because Palestinians are testing out a whole new form of warfare, using suicide bombers -- strapped with dynamite and dressed as Israelis -- to achieve their political aims. And it is working.

title: Out of the Black Box of Phobia
description: I USED to be a lawyer. Most of my adult life I suffered from phobias; I spent 10 years in and out of therapy. Nothing helped until I discovered supported exposure therapy, in which the therapist accompanies you into whatever situation you're afraid of. You repeat the experience until you become desensitized to it. It worked so well for me that I decided to start my own therapy practice.

title: RACIAL STUDY OF SPEEDERS
description: After declining since January to make public a disputed study concluding that black drivers on the New Jersey Turnpike were twice as likely to speed as white drivers, the state attorney general, David Samson, released the report to the public last week. He said he reversed his decision because the findings do not undermine past evidence that racial profiling is real. The report, financed by the state, was prepared by the Public Services Research Institute and cost $426,000. Jo Piazza

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAY, DOROTHY
description: DeLAY-Dorothy. We will miss a warm and legendary mentor. On behalf of many of the violin teachers in Kansas, we extend our deepest condolences to the family. Beth Titterington Heart of America Suzuki Teachers Association

title: March 24-30: NATIONAL; FIRST SLAVE REPARATIONS SUIT
description: A Manhattan woman filed the first class action lawsuit demanding damages from U.S. companies for allegedly profiting from the slave trade. Citing recent suits by Holocaust survivors as precedent, the suit was filed in Brooklyn federal court against Aetna, the FleetBoston Financial Corporation and the CSX Corporation on behalf of all descendants of American slaves. Plaintiffs' lawyers said similar suits will be filed against other companies in coming weeks. Officials at Aetna and CSX said the suit had no merit. Robert F. Worth

title: BEST SELLERS: March 31, 2002
description: Weeks

title: What Fools Fat Cats Can Be
description: CALL it research, if you must call it something: there was Harry Shearer, of ''Spinal Tap'' and ''The Simpsons,'' singing his satirical songs for the all-male membership of San Francisco's Bohemian Club at their sacrosanct retreat north of the city, Bohemian Grove.

title: A Last Bow, To Polite Applause
description: AT a time when so many American orchestras hew to the status quo -- afraid to alienate subscribers, wary of adventurous repertory and younger conductors -- it is easy to forget how risky it was in 1973 for the Boston Symphony Orchestra to appoint Seiji Ozawa as music director. Mr. Ozawa was a rising Japanese conductor, just 37, and this in America's most culturally hidebound city.

title: Private Sector; No, Enron Wasn't Funny, But He'll Get a Few Laughs
description: The employees and investors who were hurt by the collapse of Enron may wish that the last six months were just a practical joke. At least they can take symbolic comfort from Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who chose Enron as a discussion topic in his April Fool's Day schedule.

title: Minding the Law
description: WITH the appointment of his new top assistant prosecutors last week, United States Attorney Christopher J. Christie addressed a couple of concerns -- one public and one not-so-public -- about the 123-person law office here.

title: Ocean Race Promises Adventure
description: The round-the-world Volvo Ocean Race made its first stateside port of call last week, and it did so in dramatic fashion. Early Wednesday, the Swedish entry Assa Abloy crossed the finish line off Miami to win Leg 5 of the offshore marathon, just over an hour in front of the second-place yacht Illbruck, from Germany, after some 4,450 nautical miles of racing. The leg had started from Rio de Janeiro on Feb. 9.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRAYER, DORIS
description: DRAYER-Doris. On March 26, we celebrate 52 years of marriage. You are ''always'', in our thoughts and love, Sonny, Michelle, Joe, Emily, Billy, Caroline.

title: UConn Leaves Trail of Vanquished Admirers
description: A surprise visitor might attend spring graduation at the University of Connecticut. Pat Summitt, the Tennessee coach, said she wanted to make sure that Sue Bird, Swin Cash, Asjha Jones and Tamika Williams would finally trade in their sneakers and UConn jerseys for caps and gowns.

title: Ideas & Trends; Full Disclosure
description: AS they waded through three large cardboard boxes jammed with 11,000 pages of Energy Department documents, lawyers and reporters expected to find a trove of fresh details last week about the secret deliberations of Vice President Dick Cheney's national energy task force.

title: Will They Be Biting or Dying?
description: AS thousands of anglers get ready for the opening of trout season in two weeks, some are pondering a new meaning for the dry in dry fly.

title: Executive Life: The Boss; Life Is a 3-D Puzzle
description: MY father was the financial person in a chain called Lay's 5 & 10 that had 35 stores in four Southern states. As a teenager in Cleveland, Tenn., I worked for $1.60 an hour loading trucks. I was pretty good at it. It was like filling in a three-dimensional puzzle.

title: In the Region/Westchester; 16 Years Later, a Journey's End Nears
description: A 110-ACRE hilltop site overlooking the Hudson here seemed a natural for development 16 years ago. The property, a former girls' boarding school with its extensive grounds, convent and a chapel with 55 stained-glass windows, even lent itself to an evocative name: Chapel Hill.

title: From Old Files, a New Story Of U.S. Role in Angolan War
description: In the summer of 1975, with the cold war raging and the memory of Saigon's fall terribly fresh, the United States sponsored a covert operation to prevent another Communist takeover, this time across the world, in Angola.

title: Tourism Venture Ends On Midway Atoll Refuge
description: THE Bush administration is hoping to create business partnerships with private companies to invest in wildlife refuges and preserves, sometimes with development in mind and sometimes for conservation. The proposal is the highlight of the administration's budget request for the Fish and Wildlife Service, an agency in the Interior Department that runs the sanctuaries. But while the approach meshes nicely with Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton's ''new environmentalism,'' a similar venture by the previous administration has failed.

title: Smiles And Frowns In Higher Oil Prices
description: NO one is ringing alarms yet, but in the last month or so oil prices have started to bubble.

title: Pound Sand
description: When Tony Blair called George W. Bush on the day after Sept. 11 to pledge his support, the British prime minister said he assumed the U.S. was considering an immediate response. According to a report in The Sunday Age of Melbourne, Australia, giving an anonymous Blair adviser as a source, Bush replied, ''We're thinking about that,'' but he did not want to ''pound sand with millions of dollars in weapons'' to make himself feel good.

title: U.S. Joins Council Vote Telling Israel To Withdraw
description: The United States joined other United Nations Security Council members early yesterday in demanding that Israel withdraw its troops from Ramallah, the West Bank city where Yasir Arafat's headquarters now lie in ruins, and from other Palestinian cities.

title: Acclaim Entertainment: Back in the Groove
description: TUROK, a dinosaur-hunting marksman who came to life in comic books of the 1950's, made the evolution to the digital era six years ago when programmers at Acclaim Entertainment in Glen Cove animated him and turned his exploits into in games sold to eager Nintendo players around the world.

title: Girls Just Want to Be Mean
description: At the age of 35, I am still having the same experiences as those 11- and 12-year-olds in your article: making friends with one girl as revenge against another, gossiping, secrets shared only to be used against you at a later time.

title: A Busy Crossroads of History
description: THE sun is homing in on the mountaintop, an alien spaceship docking, red as a huge San Marzano tomato. It hovers there above us as we coast down the Apennine foothills onto the tavoliere, the great agricultural plain of Apulia. It's a gorgeous late December sunset as such sunsets go -- but also a bone of contention. I prod the accelerator and squint sideways at my husband, Vittorio, who sits in the passenger seat, a sphinx. Whose fault is it that we'll be arriving in the dark? Well, let's just say we disagree on that point.

title: On the Road With the Inner Candidate
description: AMBLING INTO HISTORY

title: Merton Bernfield, 63; Researched Cell Structure
description: Dr. Merton Bernfield, a pediatrician and microbiologist whose research advanced knowledge of the human cell structure, died on March 18 in Boston, where he was previously chief of newborn medicine at Children's Hospital. He was 63.

title: The Tram Is Back, With New Parts and the Old (Grateful) Commuters
description: Last Monday at 6 a.m., the Roosevelt Island tram returned to service after being grounded for four months for want of eight feet of cable. Daniel James, who has been a tram operator since 1994, guided the red cable car and its cargo up into the gray dawn. The trip was mercifully uneventful.

title: Adding a B To the Four C's
description: FORGET for a moment the four C's: carat, clarity, color and cut. To the untrained eye, a diamond's beauty is most often judged by its brilliance.

title: Anza-Borrego
description: To the Editor: The gentrification of Anza-Borrego, as detailed in the articles under the headline ''When Spring Comes to Anza-Borrego,'' (Feb. 10), elicited a smile and fond memories.

title: For Rodgers Fans, More Enchanted Evenings
description: The lifelong New Yorker Richard Rodgers would have turned 100 this year. Tomorrow at 7 p.m., a monthlong program called ''Some Enchanted Evenings: The Songs of Richard Rodgers'' begins at the New-York Historical Society. On Friday, ''A Tribute to Richard Rodgers: The Sound of His Music'' begins at the Museum of Television and Radio, featuring radio versions of his musicals (like ''South Pacific,'' below) and television appearances.

title: Secaucus Journal; Humbled Mountain Offers a Mine of History, and Prehistory
description: The greatest indignity might have occurred when the mountain was sold for scrap, dynamited, quarried and gutted until it was little more than a rocky shoulder for the New Jersey Turnpike to lean on. Or maybe the biggest insult came later, when what was left of the mountain -- a geological marvel, a pristine example of igneous diabase nearly a quarter billion years old and as tall as a 20-story building -- became a canvas for college students spray-painting their fraternity letters.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Chairman Arafat is the leader of the Palestinian people. His leadership is now, and will be, central to any meaningful effort to restore calm.''

title: Empty Warnings
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A New Kind Of Water Restrictions?
description: To Dr. Marva Mitchell, a dentist and mother of two who has lived for a decade at the Boulevard, a co-op on Broadway north of 86th Street, the building's extra-long swimming pool is a major attraction.

title: Gone to Seed And Back, Again
description: GARDENING metaphors are popular in business: Start-ups seek seed money. Mature businesses fertilize to branch out.

title: The World; The Anxiety of Postwar Afghans
description: RECENTLY, an American soldier approached an American reporter at Bagram Air Base, the former Soviet air field now taken over by American troops.

title: In Chicago, an Exhibit Enlivens Genetics
description: Cloned mice, genetically altered frogs and the mutation of fruit flies are all helping make advances in genetics tangible in a new permanent exhibit at the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE BUFFALO SOLDIER

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GHERARDI, DR. LINDA BUCH
description: GHERARDI-Dr. Linda Buch. March 31, 1996. Six years since you left us. We love you. So you are deeply remembered and sorely missed by all. Your Loving Family

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Evening Hours column last Sunday about a preview of the New York International Orchid Show misidentified the man shown with the designer Geoffrey Beene. He was Carlos Fighetti, chairman of the show, not David Horak.

title: March 24-30; COMING UP
description: In Philadelphia on Tuesday, President Bush will talk about education and help raise money for Mike Fisher's campaign for governor. On Friday, he returns to his ranch in Crawford, Tex., to meet with the British prime minister, Tony Blair. Congress remains in recess.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: AS we well know these days, any diaster generates its twist-of-fate stories -- people whose lives were spared or lost because of a seemingly harmless delay or decision. In BOUNCE (2000), two big stars apply nicely understated performances to that premise to create an appealing if somewhat airy romance. Ben Affleck is Buddy, a carefree fellow who gives his airplane ticket to a young father eager to get home to his family. After the plane crashes, Buddy, tormented by guilt and alcohol, looks up the widow of the man who used his ticket. It's Gwyneth Paltrow, and a rocky healing process takes place -- Friday at 8 p.m. and Saturday at 10:35 a.m. on Starz.

title: U.N. Opens Rebuilding Effort, With Limits, in Afghanistan
description: Rejecting the kind of administrative dominance that the United Nations has exercised in East Timor and Kosovo, the Security Council authorized a new mission in Afghanistan this week that will leave most of the responsibility for rebuilding the country with its own government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARF, ELIZABETH MELLEN
description: SCHARF-Elizabeth Mellen. On March 28, 2002. Beloved wife of Meyer. Devoted mother of Stephanie Scharf and Jane Schiff. Loving sister of Tillie Edinoff. Cherished grandmother of Julie and Lauren Schiff and Meredith and Jonathan Mandell. Private funeral service. Family is sitting shiva at home of Jane Schiff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNE, MARY ETHEL (BROWNIE)
description: BROWNE-Mary Ethel (Brownie). March 4, 2002 Scottsdale, AZ. Born Montreal, Canada June 22, 1916. Employed by Elizabeth Arden & Maine Chance. A brilliant light in our lives has been extinguished.

title: Wendy Lamont, Poul Flagstad
description: Wendy Elizabeth Lamont, a daughter of Elizabeth G. Lamont and Judge Dan Lamont of Cobleskill, N.Y., was married yesterday to Poul Flagstad, a son of Ulla Flagstad of Sonderborg, Denmark, and the late Carl Flagstad. Kermit Spaulding, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Stowe Mountain Resort in Stowe, Vt.

title: Tax Dollars for Stadiums? Foul Ball!
description: To the Editor:

title: March 24-30: BUSINESS; ANDERSEN LOSES CHIEF
description: Joseph Berardino tried many tactics to save Arthur Andersen from criminal indictment, but failed. So he announced his resignation as chief executive of Andersen Worldwide, hoping prosecutors would see it as a sign of change at the firm.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: James Lanning and Rain Lanning, Brooklyn, Jan. 13, 2002

title: ANTITERRORISM BILL
description: The state Senate approved legislation last week that would make terrorism a death penalty crime if an act of terrorism results in death. The measure now goes to the Assembly for concurrence with Senate amendments to its bill. The legislation also carefully defines the term terrorism and removes the statue of limitations for crimes associated with terrorism. Jo Piazza

title: Everyone on the Same Page
description: IF it takes a book to raise a village, then New London and Hartford are being brought up well. Residents in both of these Connecticut cities, as well as their surrounding areas, will soon be collectively reading, and discussing, the same book, as part of a growing national program called ''One Book.''

title: Concerts Feature a French Accent
description: VIVE la France could be the motto at a number of April concerts, starting Friday at 8 p.m., when the Lyon Opera Ballet pays a visit to Purchase College.

title: Bye, Bye 'American Pie'; Mrs. Robinson Is Calling
description: AT the age of 23, the actor Jason Biggs can claim to have portrayed two of the most memorable characters in the history of young American angst.

title: A Look at the Old West Through Smaller Works
description: 'Window on the West'

title: Warning on Hedge Fund Fraud
description: Investors should be vigilant about possible fraud in hedge funds, the Securities and Exchange Commission warned last week.

title: Need a Goat's Head? How About a Free Blow-Dry?
description: MANGIA!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACQUENEY, MONA G.
description: JACQUENEY-Mona G. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Devoted mother of Stephanie Jacqueney. Sister of Frank Grabart. Cherished grandmother of Danielle, Adam and Jordan. Funeral services Monday, April 1st, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Deadline Looms for Submitting Trash Haul Settlement Claims
description: Tomorrow is the deadline for Westchester businesses to submit claims to part of the $11.5 million settlement that several trash hauling companies signed last year. The settlement resolved two federal lawsuits claiming that the companies had artificially inflated their charges over almost a decade. Claims forms were mailed to 30,000 businesses in December.

title: Close and Personal In a Media Maelstrom
description: FOR most authors, the hard part comes in the writing -- those long lonely days and nights spent alone at a desk, staring at the existential whiteout that is the blank page. For Nicholas W. Maier, the 33-year-old author of the Wall Street memoir ''Trading With the Enemy,'' the toughest days have come since publication.

title: Record Colorado Ski Deaths Prompt Calls for Helmets
description: As another ski season winds down, industry officials in Colorado are puzzling over why more people have died in skiing accidents this winter than ever before, a record that has brought new attention to the use of helmets for protection against serious head injuries.

title: On Second Thought
description: It is often edifying, if not always pleasant, when readers criticize the column (although I prefer it when they amend my reasoning rather than attack my character). They do sometimes spot a flaw in my argument or detect an aspect of the question I'd not even considered. It is only fair that every now and then I acknowledge some of those cases when readers lead me to re-examine my responses.

title: Where Postmodern Art and Schizophrenia Intersect
description: THE human mind, so fragile and so susceptible to trauma, pain and despair, also has wonderful recuperative powers and can find a kind of release through the processes of art.

title: The Master Puppeteer
description: WAVEMAKER II

title: Music 2002
description: Some musicians have taken the tribute band concept (''The Pretenders,'' Chuck Klosterman) to even further extremes. I say this speaking as the John Lennon in a faux Beatles band, the John Paul Jones in a phony Led Zeppelin band, the guitarist in a Nick Drake band, the Elvis Costello in another and the Carl Perkins in yet another -- this in addition to leading my own original New York band.

title: Serena Williams Overcomes Capriati
description: Serena Williams said today that she simply did what her sister Venus, a three-time champion of this tournament, would have done had Serena not eliminated her in the semifinals of the Nasdaq-100 Open on Thursday.

title: 3 Are Killed And 2 Hurt In Attacks Around City
description: Three men were killed and two critically injured during a spate of violence across the city Friday night and early yesterday morning, the authorities said. Two of the victims were apparently robbed, and one of those who died was a taxi driver, they added.

title: Despite Brave Effort, Los Angeles Fails to Remove Politics From Selecting a Police Chief
description: If there was one thing most here agreed on in the long struggle to open up and change the Los Angeles Police Department it was that politics had to be removed from the process of selecting a chief. So the civilian police commission was granted greater autonomy in the hope that its choice would then be based purely on the merits rather than political arm-twisting.

title: Telling the Story Of Riverhead's Golf Course
description: First the developers of the proposed Traditional Links Golf Course in Riverhead attack the appeals court that determined that their project was illegally approved, then they attack The Times [letter, March 24] for its report on the subject.

title: Rutgers Sweeps Against Columbia
description: The Rutgers men's heavyweight crew swept a dual regatta against Columbia yesterday, winning the Collins Cup on a calm Harlem River course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURCHNER, DOROTHY KATZ SHAPIRO
description: KURCHNER-Dorothy Katz Shapiro. Died on March 27, 2002 in Tamarac, Florida. Formerly of Jersey City, NJ and Union, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLPOT, MAUREEN T.
description: HILLPOT-Maureen T., March 24, 2002, after a long illness. Loving wife of the late William A. Hillpot. Funeral Mass, Monday, April 1, 10:00 AM, Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Ave. at 84th St., New York City. Contributions in her memory may be made to Sisters of the Divine Compassion, 52 N Broadway, White Plains, NY 10603.

title: I'd Like to Buy The World a Shelf-Stable Children's Lactic Drink
description: In his article about Coca-Cola and marketing (March 10), Seth Stevenson says the world's consumers ''want endless choices, in dozens of categories.'' But recently in my town one grocery store was replaced by a chain store that offers a pared-down approach: fewer brands, less choice, lower prices. Competition among a multitude of hyped-up brands with ever-changing logos, splashy new designs and licensed cartoon sponsors actually increases cost, according to the chain store's management.

title: Alyssa Pei and Neal Sondheimer
description: WITH her master's degree in earth and planetary sciences, Alyssa Pei knows a little something about the principles of orbital interaction: how, for example, a body in motion continues in a straight line unless acted upon by some force; and how the resulting change of motion is in the direction of that force.

title: Waste Cleanups Halted By Superfund Bankruptcy
description: Your March 17 article [''Parents' Fear: A Monster in the Playground''] illustrates the dangers that toxic waste sites can pose to local families and communities. Unfortunately, the toxic waste site near a Mineola day care center is not an isolated case. There are hundreds of these contaminated sites throughout New York State. In fact, Nassau County leads all counties in the state with 80 Superfund sites, while Suffolk County comes in third with 58 sites.

title: U.S. Soldiers Wearing Many Hats As Afghans Look to Them for Help
description: Several months ago, a women's health clinic was unceremoniously evicted from its rented premises here by the property's owner, a newly returned exile. The clinic's director, Nafisa Khousal, went to the police station, distraught, saying the local intelligence chief had helped the owner throw her out.

title: Destroying the Dunes
description: To The Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNING, URSULA
description: CORNING-Ursula. On March 20, 2002, in her 99th year, died peacefully in her sleep. Interment private. Memorial services at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. at 90th St., Monday, April 8, 11 AM.

title: In Tarrytown, A Buzz Builds As Venues Grow
description: WHEN Marty Kounitz of Irvington surveys the crowd at Sunset Cove, the Hudson River waterfront restaurant here where he plays bass in a jazz band most Friday evenings, he senses more than a growing appreciation for jazz.

title: An AIDS Skeptic in South Africa Feeds Simmering Doubts
description: Peter Mokaba is a member of Parliament, a senior official in the governing party and a fiery orator who rallied a generation of young blacks to the fight against apartheid.

title: Dj Vu All Over Again
description: BASEBALL

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: End of a Run

title: Outrage Is Rising as Options Turn to Dust
description: IT was February 1999, and after 10 years of work in the communications industry, Kimberly Smith was about to realize her dream. A single mother with an infant son, Ms. Smith had amassed $1.1 million in savings and in stock options on WorldCom shares that she had received as an engineering director. Finally, she had enough to cash in her chips and stay home with her child. ''I had this dream of having $1 million in the bank and living off the interest,'' she said. ''That seemed really safe.''

title: At Linares, Ukrainian, 19, Shows His Title Is No Fluke
description: The biggest surprise at Linares was Ruslan Ponomariov, the 19-year-old FIDE titleholder from Ukraine, taking second place. Most grandmasters consider Garry Kasparov or Vladimir Kramnik the best.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOHN C. WILCOX; Democracy's Corporate Attire
description: THE March 19 shareholder vote on whether Hewlett-Packard should buy Compaq Computer for $24 billion is still being counted. But the proxy fight between Hewlett-Packard and Walter B. Hewlett, the co-founder's son who opposes the deal, is already part of business folklore. Enormous sums of money, and time, were spent by Mr. Hewlett and Carleton S. Fiorina, the company's chief executive, to woo votes. Last week, Mr. Hewlett showed that he would not quit even if he lost; he filed a lawsuit accusing Hewlett-Packard of improperly obtaining votes. John C. Wilcox, vice chairman of Georgeson Shareholder Communications, which helped Hewlett-Packard enlist shareholder support, spoke last week about the nature of proxy contests. JULIE FLAHERTY

title: A Rigid List
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; All Roads Lead To D.C.
description: STRUGGLING to get a handle on American foreign policy? For starters, try dusting off your Livy and boning up on the Second Punic War. Or dip into a good history of 19th-century Britain, paying close attention to those dazzling military campaigns in the Middle East -- the Battle of Omdurman, say, or the Second Afghan War.

title: Yankees End Camp With Familiar Result
description: Although he did not get the victory, Mike Mussina finally received the run support he needed since donning the pinstripes as the Yankees rallied from a five-run deficit to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 8-5, in their spring finale.

title: When Cool Is Not Enough
description: BOUTIQUE hotels were among the glittering successes of the 1990's. They flouted the hotel-world rules, dressing up small, often oddly shaped rooms with high-tech gadgets and high-concept design, and wooed guests with the downstairs as much or more than the upstairs -- the hip bar, the spare but glamorous lobby and, it was hoped, the cool crowd. The approach worked. In general, boutique hotels charge steeper rates and have enjoyed higher occupancy levels than traditional hotels, particularly on weekends, according to Bjorn Hanson, a managing partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting company.

title: Investing; Wall Street's Latin Spotlight Dims
description: ON his recent sojourn through Latin America, President Bush extolled the economic potential of Mexico, Peru and other nations that are opening their markets and pursuing free trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIOLANTE, ANTONIO
description: VIOLANTE-Antonio. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Antonio Violante, associated with The Times from 1974 until 1982.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURAVCKI, JOHN
description: MURAVCKI-John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Muravcki, associated with The Times from 1944 until 1991.

title: Barcelona Crime
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''What's Doing in Barcelona'' (March 10) by Emma Daly: Less than a year ago I visited Barcelona for the first time. Readers should know that the Barrio Gtico and all of La Rambla are bustling not only with purse snatchers and pickpockets but also with violent muggers.

title: Executive Life; Overcoming His Torment From Within
description: THE night after the first birthday of his younger son, J. B. Fuqua called his wife, Dottie, from his office.

title: Harboring a Grand Obsession With Orchids
description: IT doesn't take 5,000 orchids at the New York International Orchid Show at Rockefeller Center, which ran through March 24, to turn normal human beings into obsessed orchid lovers.

title: Time to Play A Little Traveling Music
description: AS a first-time columnist, I discovered that a column is to journalism what a marriage is to a relationship. It's there week after week after week, for better or for worse.

title: Local Voters In India Stun Leader Of Top Party
description: Four years ago, the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party scored its biggest victories ever in a national election, securing enough seats in Parliament to lead a coalition government.

title: Afghanistan's Former King Sets Mid-April for Return, Ignoring Warnings of Threats
description: Despite warnings from Western intelligence officials of a possible attempt to assassinate him, Afghanistan's former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, has rescheduled his return home and will now arrive in the Afghan capital in mid-April, Western diplomats said today.

title: The Little Engine That Can
description: ON a recent Monday morning, a few dozen commuters scurried along the train platform to get out of a cold rain. Among them were the novelist Peter Benchley; Gregory J. Osberg, executive vice president of Newsweek magazine; and Nicholas Katzenbach, a former attorney general of the United States. They settled into their seats with pleasant nods to the other regular riders whom they recognized, then snapped open their morning papers.

title: Circled Dates
For Ewing and the Knicks, a Bittersweet Meeting
description: These games, pitting the Knicks against their former franchise player, Patrick Ewing, used to hold an allure that overshadowed the average game. But with the Knicks finishing out a miserable season and Ewing possibly doing the same on a 17-year career, Sunday afternoon's game against the Magic in Orlando instead gives Ewing and his former mates a chance to commiserate.

title: Smallpox Grows Less Terrifying
description: Americans feeling vulnerable to a potential smallpox attack by terrorists can breathe a little easier, thanks to two encouraging developments last week. New experimental results showed that the federal government's small stockpile of smallpox vaccine could be enlarged fivefold through dilution without losing much effectiveness, providing enough medicine to protect some 77 million Americans. At the same time, officials revealed that a drug company had a large additional supply of vaccine -- some 85 million doses -- left over from decades ago that might also be expandable through dilution. The combined result may mean that the government could quickly marshal enough smallpox vaccine now to protect most of the country should the need arise.

title: March 24-30: POLITICS; SOUTH OF THE BORDER
description: Latin America was a focus of President Bush's foreign policy -- until Sept. 11. Eager to show it still mattered, he spent four days in Mexico, Peru and El Salvador promoting trade, counterterrorism and U.S. foreign aid. But he did not have an immigration bill to deliver to the Mexican president, Vicente Fox, nor an Andean trade agreement to present to Peru's, Alejandro Toledo. Both are stalled in the Democratic-controlled Senate. Elisabeth Bumiller

title: 'There's Room 'Ere for You'
description: MANCHESTER, long England's northern city of the industrial, soot-stained image, has undergone a metamorphosis. Grime has been sandblasted off Victorian buildings; old warehouses in the city center now house chic apartments. The renovation, begun in the 1980's, led to such developments as the opening of DKNY and Herms boutiques on King Street, now a pedestrian mall. Downtown Manchester bustles with cafes, bars and restaurants that offer a remarkable range of cuisine. The city is fashionable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, THOMAS FRANCIS, M.D.
description: DILLON-Thomas Francis, M.D. Died March 29, 2002, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center of pneumonia and related complications of prostate cancer. He was 77. Born 1925, in Raquette Lake, NY. Graduated from Georgetown University, School of Medicine, in 1947. Served in the US Navy 1943-1951. Spent his professional career as a Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Cornell Medical Center and Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons. He also was the past president of the New York Obstetrical Society and the American Fertility Society. He retired in 1987 to East Hampton, NY. He was an avid golfer and fisherman. His beloved wife Jane and three children, Dr. Peter Dillon of Hershey, PA, Pamela Shea of Jackson, WY, Ann P. Dillon of St. Louis, MO, and four grandchildren survive him. A private service will be held in Raquette Lake, NY, this summer. Family and friends are making contributions to the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: Kroon Gravin Wins After Long Layoff
description: Molly Ashe and Kroon Gravin came off an eight-month layoff and cleared all eight barriers on the jump-off course in 45.37 seconds to win the $200,000 American Invitational grand prix yesterday in Tampa, Fla. They became the second horse and rider combination to win back-to-back renewals of the event in its 29-year history.

title: WEST NILE VIRUS

New Jersey and New York are tied as the states with the highest incidence of the disease, according to the state Department of Health and Senior Services. There were six cases in in New Jersey in 2001. One person in New Jersey died in each year. Test results have not been completed on one additional suspected case from last year. Karen DeMasters

title: When a Rapper Acts Out
description: Rapping, like acting, exists in a gray area between charisma and craft. You put on some nice clothes, you deliver your lines and people respond, because they like you, or the character you're playing. Will Smith may be the most respected rapper-actor, but other rappers from Ice Cube to Queen Latifah have crossed over, with Eminem set to make his screen debut this fall. And in recent years, there has been a string of straight-to-video hip-hop action flicks indistinguishable from long-form music videos. Rappers have come to see acting as part of their job description, as another way to promote their music and, more important, themselves.

title: How Susie Bayer's T-Shirt Ended Up on Yusuf Mama's Back
description: If you've ever left a bag of clothes outside the Salvation Army or given to a local church drive, chances are that you've dressed an African. All over Africa, people are wearing what Americans once wore and no longer want. Visit the continent and you'll find faded remnants of secondhand clothing in the strangest of places. The ''Let's Help Make Philadelphia the Fashion Capital of the World'' T-shirt on a Malawian laborer. The white bathrobe on a Liberian rebel boy with his wig and automatic rifle. And the muddy orange sweatshirt on the skeleton of a small child, lying on its side in a Rwandan classroom that has become a genocide memorial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAIL, DONALD
description: VAIL-Donald of Bedford, NY, died on March 27, 2002 at the age of 80. Mr. Vail was born in Yonkers, NY, to John I.B. Vail and Margaret Gray Vail of Hyannis, MA., and Blairstown, NJ. A 1938 graduate of the Holderness School & the Class of 1942 at Princeton University, he entered the Navy in World War II. As a Marine pilot, he served in the South Pacific, leaving the service as a Captain. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1948 and practiced law at the firms of: Sullivan & Cromwell, McCanliss & Early, Alexander & Green, and Walter, Conston, Alexander & Green. Mr. Vail was a founding member of the Bedford Association; Chairman of the Building Committee of St. Francis A.M.E. Zion Church; and a Vestryman and Clerk of the Vestry of St. Matthew's Church. At Northern Westchester Hospital Center, he was a member of the Board of Trustees for 20 years, and a president of the Board from 1977-1982. He had also been a member of the Triangle Club at Princeton and of the Blue Hill Troupe in New York. Mr. Vail is survived by his wife of 50 years, Priscilla L. Vail, author & educator in learning disabilities & dyslexia. He leaves four children: Melissa Vail Selby of Mt. Kisco; Polly Vail Walsh of Chevy Chase, MD; Lucia Vail of New York City; Donald Angus Vail of Portland, OR; and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford on Monday, April 1st at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Northern Westchester Hospital Center Foundation, Mount Kisco, NY.

title: QUICK BITE/Northvale; A No-Star Show Business Brunch
description: Where can you dine with the movers and shakers of the television and film world? The obvious choices are Spago in Hollywood, Nobu in Tribeca and Hennessy Tavern in Northvale. No, really. The Bergen County bar and restaurant is named after Jill Hennessy, star of the television show ''Crossing Jordan.'' Her husband, Paolo Mastropietro, opened the establishment in 1999, and even enlisted Benjamin Bratt to help hang drywall. More recently, the NBC comedy ''Ed'' has used the bowling alley two doors down as its primary set, and that program's cast and crew have become Hennessy regulars. This was not my motivation to visit. I am a man of the people, not easily entranced by the glitz and glamour of the Tinseltown elite. So I dropped by during a quieter time: Sunday brunch (served from 11 till 2). For $8.95, you can select two eggs with bacon or sausage, a three-egg omelet with three fillings, steak and eggs ($2 extra), eggs Benedict, buttermilk pancakes, French toast, grilled chicken or a burger and fries. Also included are coffee or tea, and a bloody Mary, mimosa or orange juice. The large dining room has a sort of ski lodge feel, with a fireplace, exposed-beam high ceiling and real wood paneling. I savored every bite of my ham, bacon and mozzarella omelet with home fries and toast. Okay, I admit it, I was lingering, hoping for a celebrity sighting. Somebody. Anybody. Abe Vigoda, even. But it was not to be. Still, brunch was a pleasant experience. I took a few snapshots of the ''Stuckey Bowl,'' and returned home to my normal life. Oh, Benjamin Bratt, if you're reading this, I could use a hand caulking the tub. Jack Silbert

title: The Court Of Public Opinion
description: A new home for the Musuem of the City of New York isn't in the cards at the Tweed Courthouse. If Mayor Bloomberg has his way, it will house the Board of Education and a school. But when the City section invited readers to suggest uses for the Tweed Courthouse, people offered a few other ideas. City officials, take note.

title: Ideas & Trends; Britain's Imperial Lessons
description: AS the United States settles the mantle of empire, however uneasily, on its shoulders, it must constantly deal with the legacy of the West's last major empire, Britain.

title: A Real Feel-Good Barbecue Experience
description: THERE are hickory wood chips in the smokers and warm corn chips on the tables at the new Eldorado Southern BBQ in the Waldbaum's Centereach Plaza on the corner of Middle Country Road and Holbrook Road (631-588-7227). Although it is a Long Islandized version of a barbecue joint with a menu that offers burgers, sandwiches, salads, fajitas, pastas and quesadillas, in addition to the mandatory smoked ribs, chicken, pulled pork and brisket, Eldorado manages to capture the generous barbecue spirit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLESHETTE, MARJORIE
description: PLESHETTE - Marjorie. The Mount Sinai Medical Center Community Advisory Board mourns the loss of our beloved mentor and friend Marjorie Pleshette. Her compassion, humor and insights will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her extraordinary family. Gary Rosenberg, PhD, Chair Mount Sinai Medical Center Community Advisory Board

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 10 about El Questro Homestead in northwestern Australia misstated its rates. They begin at $362 a night per person, based on double occupancy, and include meals; the room itself does not begin at $362.

title: Elementary and Middle School Report Cards
description: New York State moved to confront one of the thorniest issues in public education last week when it released school test score results that, for the first time, had been broken down by sex, race and income, documenting large gaps in performance between white students and their black and Hispanic classmates.

title: March 24-30: INTERNATIONAL; $500,000
description: Anthony S. Fauci, a top AIDS researcher and pioneering immunologist, received the nation's richest medical award, the $500,000 Albany Medical Center Prize. Dr. Fauci, who directs the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, won the two-year-old prize for developing effective therapies for once-fatal immune and rheumatic diseases like Wegener's granulomatosis and polyarteritis nodosa, contributions to science and distinguished public service. Lawrence K. Altman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, MORTON D., C.P.A.
description: GOLDBERG-Morton D., C.P.A. Passed away at home on March 26, 2002. He was a graduate of Pace University and was a Certified Public Accountant who practiced in New Jersey and New York. He will be remembered lovingly by his devoted wife Rose, son Allan and his wife Enid, granddaughter Elizabeth, and grandson Daniel and his wife Melissa. He will be missed deeply by family, friends and professional associates. He was President and Chairman of the Madden Open Hearts Camp in Great Barrington, MA., and was a Lifetime Trustee of the Teaneck Jewish Center. Memorial donations may be made to the Rose and Morton Goldberg Scholarship Fund, Teaneck Jewish Center, 70 Sterling Place, Teaneck NJ 07666.

title: Role Models
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: An Unsentimental Education
description: We're housesitting a shabby Craftsman in Hollywood the summer of '77, my soulful friend Chris and I, all 20-something arrogance and alligator boots, our only responsibilities to feed the dog and water the plants. I've only just arrived from England, bent on using these three vital months to finish my witty magnum opus. Breakfast is the orange tree in the garden and dinner whichever gallery opening or studio gala we can locate by calling around. Rare is the night we come home hungry, rarer still, alone. We've got it made.

title: My Old Buddies, Mike and the Mad Dog
description: GOING back to the FAN (that's WFAN, 24-hour sports radio, to you nonsports fans) is like hanging out again at a neighborhood pub where you were once a regular. I've started listening in again, and it's been comforting to spend time in an electronic sports bar where the on-air personalities mix the drinks while the guys line up, sometimes three and four deep, to weigh in on everything related to sports.

title: Ragout and Riffs
description: LARRIE COLLURA may be the hardest working chef in show business. After spending hours over a hot stove at Fiddleheads, he is likely to appear in the dining room with a sax around his neck and a plaintive request for indulgence. Then, before his captive audience, he tries a little of ''Somewhere Over the Rainbow.''

title: Culture by the Sea
description: To the Editor: As one of thousands of transplanted New Yorkers who have discovered the joys of living on the West Side of Los Angeles, I really enjoyed Daisann McLane's Frugal Traveler on Santa Monica and Venice, ''Los Angeles in a Nutshell (Except for the Traffic)'' (Feb. 10).

title: Baltimore Celebrates the Railroad's Roots
description: The 175th anniversary of American railroading is being celebrated in Baltimore through July 2003. The B&O Railroad Museum will present exhibitions, lectures, train trips and other events during the 16 months, focusing on the time between the government's first charter of the railroad, in February 1827, and the laying of the ceremonial first stone signifying the start of the line, on July 4, 1828.

title: Private Sector; Kindness Repaid, 80 Years Later
description: This is a story of how a simple act of generosity can pay big dividends in the long run.

title: Aiming for the Union Square Cafe of Jazz
description: IF you've spent any time in St. Louis or Kansas City, you're familiar with the tradition of barbecue and jazz. Stockyards and speak-easies made a perfect match.

description: 'Bach to Beatles'

title: Medicare Is Now Covering Treatment for Alzheimer's
description: The Bush administration, in a major change, has authorized Medicare coverage for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease, which afflicts nearly four million Americans and is expected to grow to epidemic proportions with the aging of the population.

title: Political Briefing; Bush Rescue Mission For Ally of Old Foe
description: Two years ago, Representative Lindsey Graham of South Carolina did all he could to help John McCain win his state's Republican primary. But in the end, George W. Bush carried the state, effectively ending Mr. McCain's presidential hopes.

title: Private Sector; Marketing the Power of Plaid
description: When Ian M. Russell takes to the streets of New York this Saturday, spectators may be forgiven for not knowing that he is the chief executive of ScottishPower, a large utility and parent of PacifiCorp, a Northwestern power company. Mr. Russell will lead 10,000 bagpipers who are expected to march in the St. Andrews Day Parade to celebrate National Tartan Day, marking the signing, in 1320, of the Scottish Declaration of Independence. No less than 45 miles of plaid will make its way through 36 city blocks, up Sixth Avenue to Central Park, as bagpipers from all 50 states and from 28 countries -- including Malaysia and Ghana -- raise money for cancer organizations in the United States and Scotland. Gilda's Club Worldwide and the Scottish branch of Marie Curie Cancer Care are the main beneficiaries, although some proceeds will also go to the Piping Center in Glasgow.

title: Fire Singes but Does Not Engulf a Black Cultural Outpost
description: John Watusi Branch was in Senegal in February when he heard about the fire. Some wires had ignited and burned most of the second floor of the building that has served for 23 years as home to the Afrikan Poetry Theater, a cultural center he helped found.

title: Volterra's Past Speaks In Its Stones
description: ANY visitor to Volterra will be struck by the starkness of the contrast between the town itself and the countryside surrounding it. You pass from the smiling upland country of central Tuscany, with its red earth, the warm colors of its stones, its great sweeps of undulating land, to this bleak and isolated-looking complex of cobbled streets and small squares, huddled close on its high plateau of thin clay soil, ringed round by volcanic hills, the dark stone of its buildings rising high overhead, closing off the sky.

It was Jack Lemmon, not their co-star Tony Curtis. The obituary also misspelled the surname of an earlier Hollywood director who was denied a third Oscar in a single night, a distinction Wilder then attained. That director, who died in 1969, was Leo McCarey, not McCary.

description: LAST fall, when Boeing's bid to build the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter flamed out and the $200 billion winner-take-all contract to supply up to 3,000 planes went to its rival, Lockheed Martin, a good part of Boeing's plans went up in smoke. Designed for the Air Force, the Navy and the Marines, the F-35 will be the last new manned American fighter for decades to come.

description: Chevron/Texaco of San Francisco has closed on the sale of the former Texaco headquarters in Harrison to Morgan Stanley, the largest securities company in Manhattan. Morgan Stanley paid $42 million for the four-story, 750,000-square-foot building at 2000 Westchester Avenue, and the surrounding 107 acres.

They talked about their roles recently with Barry Singer; here are excerpts.

description: IN this time of uncertainty it is reassuring to know that the tall sign in the Madison Plaza shopping center in Oceanside will not topple. This must be so because the word ''Stationary'' appears on the sign. However, it's more than likely that the proprietor of the stationery store in Madison Plaza would question my interpretation of the sign. What a difference one letter makes!

title: That 70's Jazz (for the Discriminating Rapper)
description: IN their quest for rare grooves and ear-catching hooks, hip-hop D.J.'s do a lot of digging through old LP's. Anything is fair game, from classic R & B hits to corny movie soundtracks. But for many D.J.'s, nothing confers sophistication better than jazz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANFER, HERBERT, CPA.
description: KANFER-Herbert, CPA. On Tuesday, March 26, 2002. Adored husband and cherished best friend of Lillian. Beloved father of Ronni (Ted), doting & proud grandfather of David Isaac. description: THE REV. PETE COLAPIETRO is known as the saloon priest, and can sometimes be found sipping bourbon in the city's dignified establishments.

description: KAHN-Marion. On March 29, 2002, at age 96. Beloved wife of the late Efrem A. Kahn. Loving mother of Franklyn C. Frawley. Dear mother-in-law of Frances J. Frawley. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY 10605.

description: PEOPLE who fled home as soon as they could hitchhike may have trouble understanding a generation that thinks it's fine to move back for a while after college.

title: Beyond The Clash, And the Din
description: IN the summer of 1981, the Clash came to Times Square for a series of concerts at a cramped haberdashery-turned-club called Bonds International Casino. The band was preaching revolution, and got it: after a show was canceled by the Fire Department because of overcrowding, some 800 angry fans took to the streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOSKOW, ALEXANDER M.
description: DOSKOW-Alexander M. Loving husband of Martha, father of Arthur and Jonathan, grandfather of Sara Brooke and Mariko Genevieve. Inspiring teacher, inspired photographer, ceramicist, humanitarian. We will miss you.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 17 about art exhibitions in Europe misstated the opening date of the van Gogh-Gauguin show at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam. It opened on Feb. 9; it does not open in September.

title: March 24-30: POLITICS; HELMS ON AIDS
description: Senator Jesse Helms, below, North Carolina's conservative icon, called for $500 million to fight the global AIDS pandemic. He wrote in The Washington Post, ''I know of no more heart-breaking tragedy in the world today.'' Mr. Helms, 80 and retiring soon, said he was shifting his view with the view that his conscience was ''answerable to God.'' But as for the U.S., he still believes AIDS is caused by ''the homosexual lifestyle.'' Adam Clymer

title: For 9/11 Families, Shoulders to Cry On
description: STACEY STONE was sitting in her car, waiting her turn at a drive-in bank a few blocks from her home in Bellmore when she heard the news of the first Sept. 11 attack on the radio. Her husband, Lonny, an operations manager at Carr Futures, was at work on the 92nd floor of 1 World Trade Center.

title: INSIDE
description: Indiana Will Face Maryland

title: Brookhaven Districts Might Be Scuttled
description: TIPPED off that some Brookhaven Republicans planned a sneak attack on the district election system that town voters narrowly approved in a referendum on Jan. 22, backers of the new system stayed glued to their seats through a long Town Board meeting earlier this month.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 17 about the pedophilia scandals within the Roman Catholic Church misstated the number of Catholics in the New York Archdiocese. It is 2.3 million, not 1.2 million.

title: Room With a Review
description: NOT too long ago, but long enough that employees could smoke at their desks, annual employee reviews involved a literal pat on the back and a modest raise. This process took approximately one and a half minutes, following which the boss and the subordinate were both relieved to have survived the uncomfortable exchange, and thus might light up a celebratory cigarette. Sure, the process lacked style. It must have, without all our current slick dialogue. After all, back then we all thought inside the box.

title: Where V.I.P.'s Flaunt It
description: Private V.I.P. rooms in bars and restaurants used to be about . . . well, privacy. These days, however, even privacy has gone public, with the newest rooms taking the form of exclusive, but open, alcoves that look out on the scene -- and, more important, offer the opportunity to be seen. At Opia on East 57th Street, the elite can meet in a Moroccan-style hideaway just two steps above the main lounge. From the inside, it resembles a plush opium den; from the outside, it looks like a stage. At Discothque on West 19th Street in Chelsea, left, a room furnished with a large leather banquette has an opening shaped like an eye. And at Happy Ending, the massage-parlor-turned-lounge on Broome Street on the Lower East Side, two former saunas serve as V.I.P. nooks with sliding glass doors. ''People feel comfortable and protected in V.I.P. rooms,'' said Peter Sibilia, who designed Discothque. ''And the people on the outside have something to look up to. They can ask themselves, 'What do I have to do to get there?' '' Calling for a reservation is a start; being famous is a clincher. JENNIFER TUNG

title: BackTalk; As Gambling Is Sweeter, The N.C.A.A. Goes Soft
description: Hungry for dish and dirt before heading off last week to the Final Four, that joyous celebration of highest education, I hit an online gambling site. These guys never disappoint. Indiana just didn't belong there with Oklahoma, Kansas and Maryland, the bookies confided, but there was an upside: Duke long gone means we are spared the embarrassment of Coach K stalking the sidelines and spouting obscenities that TV has to bleep.

title: On the Island, a Kinder, Gentler Pro Wrestling
description: THE crowd booed and jeered. Saturno Mercado, 52, a retired New York City police officer and former marine known on the pro wrestling circuit as Sheik Saturno, strutted into the arena, accompanied by his manager, Shabebe, and his doppelganger, a retired World Wrestling Federation character called the The Iron Sheik. Sporting a kaffiyeh, a Salvador Dal moustache, Aladdin shoes with curlicue tips and carrying an Iraqi flag, Sheik Saturno cast menacing glances at the 900 spectators gathered for ''The Assassin's Ball,'' a wrestling match at Sports Plus on a recent evening. A woman in a black burka trailed behind.

title: TALKING AUTOS WITH: J Mays; Honk if You Love Spiffy Designs in Cars
description: JUST as there are people who can't tell a camshaft from a distributor cap, there are probably plenty who think that the Rust Belt is something one wears with a nice pair of jeans. The relationship between car culture and fashion has rarely been one that either party wanted to ventilate in public. Yet it is perfectly obvious that fashion evolution has tracked automobile design from the days when dusters and goggles were considered de rigueur while motoring in open-roof roadsters.

title: Ideas & Trends; Song of Myself: DNA Ditties
description: SEQUENCING DNA, whether of hamster or human, is a big project. Biotechnology companies spend enormous sums and tap the creativity of countless scientists to determine the exact order of DNA nucleotides in genes, in the hope that the knowledge will lead to new drugs to fight disease.

title: Amsterdam
description: Expect more than tulips when the premier garden exhibition in the Netherlands, Floriade 2002, opens on Saturday on the Haarlemmermeer polder three miles west of Amsterdam's airport. This lavish horticultural extravaganza, held once every 10 years, incorporates flowers, fruit trees, prize vegetables, ornamental shrubbery and national gardens from more than 30 countries, including France, Bulgaria, Egypt, Thailand, Chile, Kenya, China and the United States.

title: Fairfield University's B.W.O.C.
description: MOST of the signs of change on Fairfield University's suburban campus are obvious, such as the bulldozers working on new athletic facilities and the bright lobby of the newly renovated Barone Campus Center.

title: More Overseas Choices For Cellphone Users
description: Americans have a growing number of options for using cellphones in the rest of the world, most of which uses a different technical standard for mobile phones from the one the United States does.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARUCH, GERTRUDE (''TRUDEE'')
description: BARUCH-Gertrude (''Trudee''). Gertrude Goldring Baruch, 93, of Greenwich CT and Palm Beach FL died peacefully on March 22. She was married to Martin S. Goldring from 1939 until his death in 1958 and to Joseph M. Baruch from 1967 until his death in 1994. She is predeceased by her son David Goldring. Steven Goldring, her surviving son, resides in Chicago. For more information, contact Riverside Gordon 561-683-8676.

title: By the Drop and by the Gallon
description: THE water restrictions announced last week by New York City and Westchester County have hardly turned the region into a Sahara. But already, there has been a flood of concern from water users, including landscapers, car wash owners and golf course operators.

title: Fairy-Tale Run Continues as Hoosiers Grind Out a Triumph
description: Indiana flexed its muscles inside and displayed its will all over the court in forcing Oklahoma to play a patient, tedious, methodical game, the kind of bump-and-bruise-and-grind stuff that has long been an Indiana staple.

title: The Talented Mr. Lerner
description: Last January, New York publishing houses received a pitch for an unusual ''fictionalized'' memoir. It was a prison book, written by an inmate serving a 2-to-12-year sentence for voluntary manslaughter in a Nevada jail. But what made this prison book different was its author, Jimmy A. Lerner: a middle-class, middle-aged former marketing executive at Pacific Bell. Lerner was a ''sharp, regular guy,'' his agent, Brian DeFiore, asserted in the pitch letter -- one ''with a wife, two kids and a mortgage payment'' who had ''never before gotten into any sort of trouble with the law.''

title: Cutting Too Close to the Bone?
description: Companies have been trimming work forces for months now, to control costs and stay competitive in a weak economy. But have they made themselves too lean in the talent department? A recent survey of senior executives at Fortune 1,000 companies suggests that this may be the case.

title: Devils Are Surging, And Gomez Joins In
description: Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur was simply excellent tonight against the Toronto Maple Leafs in his first appearance in Canada since winning an Olympic gold medal in hockey for this country, which has made the sport its national obsession.

title: Footlights
description: Where Music Is Therapy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, LEE N.
description: STEINER-Lee N. Died at his home in Scarsdale, NY, on March 28, in his 80th year. He leaves his wife Rosalind and three daughters, Terry and her husband Roger Smith, Catherine and her husband Fred Adair and Nancy and her husband Robert Fraiman Jr. He also leaves four grandchildren, Daniel and Lily Adair and Kate and Anne Fraiman. During WWII, he served in the Navy as the skipper of an LST in the Pacific theater and was cited by Admiral Halsey for valor in action. A partner in the law firm of Loeb and Loeb, he was one of the early and preeminent practitioners in the field of entertainment law. A past trustee of Carnegie Hall, he was also secretary and trustee of the Cousteau Society, secretary of the Counterpart Foundation and a former trustee of Lafayette College. He was a past president of Sunningdale Country Club. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st St, on Wednesday, April 3, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 640 West 168th Street, NYC 10032.

title: The Millennium Bridge: Steady for One and All
description: The Millennium Bridge in London has reopened to the public. The first major crossing over the Thames in 100 years, and the first dedicated to pedestrians, opened in June 10, but was closed after three days because of excessive movement under certain conditions, causing it to be described as the ''wobbly'' bridge.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Luckies and Liberty

title: AS ISRAELI TROOPS TIGHTEN GRIP, BUSH SAYS ARAFAT MUST DO MORE TO AVERT NEW TERROR ATTACKS
description: Violence continued today to outrace diplomacy and faltering hopes for a cease fire here, as a suicide bomber struck in Tel Aviv and Israeli troops sealed Yasir Arafat into what Palestinian officials described as three rooms in his ruined compound in Ramallah, in the West Bank.

title: Sports of The Times; Exorcising a Ghost at Indiana
description: I'M stunned.

title: Waiting for Mammograms
description: THERE has been a huge amount of attention focused on mammograms recently. The breast cancer screening has been an annual routine for millions of American women, but a recent Danish study cited flaws from studies that doctors thought proved mammography saved lives. Advocates for mammography countered that mammography remains the best tool to lower breast cancer death rates.

title: Exotic Pursuits

It doesn't matter that croissants have taken over the cafe and bakery scene in New York; they just don't measure up to fresh, flaky Paris croissants. I regularly cross the ocean for the real thing.

description: A 130-year-old cast-iron building on Greene Street in SoHo will soon be home to a Swiss company that has manufactured modular furniture since 1963.

title: AROUND THE DIAMOND
description: On the Horizon

title: Amy Greenwald, Justin Boyan

Stephen Boyan Jr., who is the bridegroom's father and a leader of the Baltimore Ethical Society, led a ceremony that incorporated elements of Judaism and humanistic philosophy.

title: Indian Point and the Big If

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Address to a Hot, Wet Place
description: Cynthia Zarin knows that sometimes all that's needed to raise ordinary speech to poetic richness is a single, right word -- for instance, she describes winter branches as being ''furred with ice,'' or notices in a painting ''a green smear of fields.'' In THE WATERCOURSE (Knopf, $23), her third poetry collection, Zarin deploys a rigorously simple vocabulary in the service of varied forms -- an eclogue here; a round there; even a psalm. The poet's tightly packed lines contain rhymes and descriptions of animals -- a hen, moths, a haughty parrot (''Stutterer, loiterer, his cage a Taj Mahal'') -- that may occasionally remind a reader of Elizabeth Bishop or W. H. Auden. (The latter's ''crepe-paper face'' is wittily invoked in ''Auden in the Aquarium.'') But Zarin, who has also written three airy, rhyme-inflected children's books, claims her own territory in numerous poems about her children -- about taking them to a neighborhood swimming pool, or watching one of their sleep-voyages (''Not longer than the crib is wide, / you berth at every latitude, / brown bear at your foot, birds / by your head, and along your length / beasts congregate: dolphin, / seal, man-manatee; kin / in the blood-heat sea / that buoys you up''). In ''The Swimming Pool,'' a pregnant Zarin pats her round tummy while thinking about the amniotic fluid that turns motherhood into its own watercourse for a baby: the poet becomes a body of water. Ken Tucker

title: Taco Belle
description: Jemima dashed through the house carrying groceries. She was coming to cook dinner for my family for the week we were staying in Mexico. I was looking forward to spending time with her while she worked, in hopes of learning something about Mexican cooking. As she unpacked our groceries, I leaned on a counter out of her way, wanting to catch her eye and express my interest. A small young woman with athletic legs and straight dark hair pulled back in a ponytail, Jemima (pronounced heh-MEE-muh) bent over her bags and shuffled to the refrigerator, never looking up. I gave it a few minutes, then left her alone.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TOVELL, HAROLD M.M., MD
description: TOVELL-Harold M.M., MD, peacefully slept away in his Florida home last May. Born in Toronto, Canada, he received his medical degree at the University of Toronto. Later he completed a tour of duty in the Canadian Army Medical Corps. After moving to NYC in 1949 he spent five years in residency at Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology and Gynecologic Oncology. He remained on the teaching staff of the Department for seven years before being appointed chief of the Obs/ Gyn service at Columbia University's affiliated Woman's Hospital in 1963 where he was Director for over a decade. There he created the Divisions of Reproductive Medicine, and Oncology, and reorganized the residency program. Among his numerous accomplishments, he opened a clinic with his good friend and colleague, Dr. Alexander Young, which became a referral center for the NY area. Harold also served as a board member of Planned Parenthood of NYC and chaired the medical committee for many years. He was also a member of the NY Obstetrical Society and played tennis on a weekly basis with several of its members for many years. He thoroughly enjoyed golf in his later years. He retired as Director of Woman's Hospital in 1974 and closed his practice in 1987. He moved to Sanibel, FL with his wife, Elizabeth (Betty), where he quickly became strongly supportive of the Bailey-Matthews Shell Museum from its inception with the late Dr. Tucker Abbott, a malacologist. Dr. Tovell served multiple terms as President of theBoard of Trustees of the world class, non-profit museum where he ''imparted a professional, scientific momentum to the museum'', according to the director, Dr. Jose Leal. Harold was predeceased by his loving wife of two months shy of 50 years, in 1995, and by their first 2 sons, Harold & Craig, during their early manhood. He is survived by their 2 other sons, Christopher, of Arizona, and Daniel, of Atlanta. A memorial service is to be held at the Shell Museum this Spring. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The BaileyMatthews Shell Museum, P.O. Box 1580, Sanibel, FL. 33957

title: Diamonds Are for Everyone

The county parks department is building a ballfield to be used by the Little League Challenger Division as part of a $5 million reconstruction of fields in Overpeck Park. The synthetic field will be completely level. The lines will be larger than normal, as will the bases, which will be painted on the surface so there are no raised obstacles. title: So, Rub Rice on Your Face
description: If on the Chinese calendar this is the Year of the Black Horse, on the beauty calendar it just might be the Year of the White Rice. Valued for their supposed purifying properties, rice and its derivatives are showing up in a bumper crop of products for face and body. This month, Awake introduced Skin Renovation Serum 14, intended to reduce signs of aging ($180 at Bergdorf Goodman). Fresh has Rice Face Cream ($75 at Sephora). Parched bodies might turn to Perfect World hydrating body cream from Origins ($30 at its stores). Prada puts rice bran hulls to work in an Exfoliating Face Mask ($60 for 15 applications at Saks Fifth Avenue), and Shiseido offers Advanced Essential Energy body exfoliating gel ($28 at Saks, Nordstrom and Bloomingdale's). Dr. Brandt Balanced Body Moisturizer contains rice bran ($45 at Bloomingdale's), while Kiehl's Baby Lip Balm ($5.50 at Kiehl's stores and www.kiehls.com) soothes with rice bran oil. To carry it all, Supply Curve sells makeup bags and totes by Carry Me Bags ($50 and $70 at www.supplycurve.com), made from burlap basmati rice sacks spiced up with bright vintage fabrics.

description: Spent radioactive fuel rods will be moved sometime next month from a cooling pool to concrete storage vaults at the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant in Lacey Township. For security reasons, the exact date of the move is not being announced, said David Simon, communications manager for Exelon, the operator of the generating plant. The 20 vaults, which cost $15 million to build, are to be used until the federal government makes a final decision on what to do with used radioactive fuel rods. Karen DeMasters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAWSON, ADA SCHUPPER
description: SLAWSON-Ada Schupper. We mourn the passing of Ada Slawson, mother, grandmother, mother-in-law and grandmother-in-law, who died in Rhinebeck, New York, on March 30, 2002, at the age of 91, after a short illness. Her first ninety years were lived in her beloved New York City. She married John Slawson, then Director of the Jewish Board of Guardians, in 1937 and the following year graduated from the Columbia School of Social Work and joined the staff of the Jewish Child Care Association (JCCA) as a Case Worker in the Foster Home Department. By the time her husband became Executive Vice-President of the American Jewish Committee (AJC) in 1943, a position he held until 1967, she had stopped working full-time to raise a family, but never ceased her commitment to community welfare. In the 1950's, she was a national chairwoman of the Council of Jewish Women and also served on the JCCA Board of Directors. In 1961, she rejoined the staff of that organization in a parttime capacity, administering its psychiatric clinic from 1961 until 1974, when her husband's health began to deteriorate. Until his death in 1989, she balanced caring for her spouse with volunteering at the Museum of Natural History and participating in projects at the Women's City Club. In the last full decade of her life, she studied in seminars at the Lotos Club and helped out wherever she saw a need, whether in feeding boarder babies at New York Hospital or tutoring a blind social work student. We will miss her deeply but are sustained by the memory of a grand lady whose energetic commitment to social service was accompanied by the charm of a personal style expressed through a daily fashion statement of elegance and panache, and oh, those hats! We will not see her like again. Interment is private. Donations to Hospice, Inc., Dutchess Division, 374 Violet Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601, would be appreciated. Ruth Slawson and Arvin Kaufman Rhinebeck, New York Judith Slawson King Glenwood Springs, Colorado Rachel Schwartz and Arturo Pardavlla Hoboken, New Jersey Jennifer Schwartz Garberville, California

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MYERS, WILLIS F. ''JIM''
description: MYERS-Willis F. ''Jim'', 85. Died on January 17, 2002. Interment was private. He leaves his sister, Grace Myers Sachtleben, his niece Nancy Sachtleben Mitchell, both of Denver, CO and his nephew Alan Sachtleben of North Chatham, MA. Mr. Myers was a lifelong resident of the north New Jersey area and for many years maintained a summer home in Kennebunkport, ME. He was a graduate of Rutgers University and was a captain in the U S Army during World War II. In 1947 he joined the music rights organization, SESAC Inc., and remained with that organization until his retirement in 1991. He was one of the founding fathers of the Gospel Music Association (GMA) in Nashville, TN and in 1993 was inducted into that organization's Gospel Music Hall of Fame. Memorial donations may be made to the South Congregational Church, P. O. Box 414, Kennebunkport, ME. 04046.

title: Editorial Observer; How Learning to Read a Book Is Like Learning to Play the Piano
description: A mother and father I know were told that their 6-year-old was reading poorly and would be forced to repeat the first grade. Fortunately, the couple did not take the school at its word. Testing by a learning specialist revealed that the child was brighter than most. He suffered from a common neurological quirk that makes it difficult for him to process written language. Nine in 10 children with this problem can succeed if given teachers who are properly trained. The problem is that fewer than a quarter of America's teachers know how to teach reading to children who do not get it automatically. Children forced to repeat classes with ineffective instruction tend to fall behind and act out, then drop out.

title: Genetic Engineering Comes to the Rescue

Lawrence, left, who announced his resignation in February. Out of 2,699 surveys mailed, only 563 or 21 percent of the recipients responded. The faculty members were asked to rate 19 issuess on a 10-point scale, with 1 being the lowest and 10 the highest. The average response was 3.96. Dr. Thomas J. Figueira, president of the association said the results ''portray the shipwreck that has been the administration of Francis Lawrence.
