title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, KENNETH RIDGEWAY
description: BROWN-Kenneth Ridgeway, 77. On March 19, 2002 in Toronto, Canada. Born in Newcastle, England, graduated from the Durham School and University of London (engineering). Served in the Royal Navy during World War II on aircraft carrier HMS Battler in the North Atlantic. Immigrated to Canada in 1954 during 36 year career with The General Electric Company PLC. CEO of English Electric Corp. in New York for 9 years until his retirement in 1983. Member of several boards of directors. Survived by his wife Diane of 47 years, sister Ann (Bridges), sons Christopher, Graeme and David, daughter-in-law, Anne, grandsons Trevor and Derek. A memorial service to celebrate Kenneth Brown's life will be held in Bracebridge, Ontario in June.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SEABISCUIT: An American Legend, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Ballantine, $15.) A racing journalist recounts the life and times of the great thoroughbred whose stunning career, capped by his sensational 1938 victory over the Triple Crown winner War Admiral, made him a Depression-era celebrity. ''Seabiscuit was an extraordinary athlete who embodied the heart and spirit of a nation,'' Jim Squires wrote here in 2001, and his ''captivating story'' is told ''with the detail of good history, the blistering pace of Biscuit himself and the charm of grand legend.''

description: To the Editor: I read ''Around Oslo, Indoors and Out'' by Perri Klass (Feb. 3) with great interest. My family is of Norwegian background and we have spent much time in Norway, including last Christmas.

title: Girls Just Want to Be Mean
description: Having watched some Queen Bees from cradle to puberty and beyond, I don't believe these girls are on the pathway to successful careers. Most haven't cultivated serious goals beyond the next party. Being mired in relationships to manipulate for power, favors and special status does not contribute to developing excellence in a talent or special interest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDOFF, RICHARD
description: DAVIDOFF-Richard. Born December 30, 1929, in Baltimore, MD. Died March 26, 2002, of complications following a heart transplant. Richard was a management consultant and wine aficianado. title: Troubled Bridge Over 400 Feet of Water
description: THE Belleville Turnpike snakes through some of most desolate swampland in the state of New Jersey. Although there is the requisite stunning view of the Manhattan skyline, it is a forbidding road nonetheless, especially at night -- the kind of place where Tony Soprano might take care of family business. The main landmarks are an overgrown Jewish cemetery and a couple of ancient radio towers. But if you have faith, the road will take you through a final labyrinth of ugly steel overpasses to the Holland Tunnel, and into Gotham itself.

But a spurt of redevelopment along Vernon Boulevard between 47th and 51st Avenues has given these pioneers soy-milk smoothies, yoga classes and, perhaps most important, the sense that their bet on this neighborhood is paying off.

Can the club owners be trusted to keep their pledge of no lockout until after the World Series? Can the players union be trusted not to strike, or not to boycott the All-Star Game in Milwaukee as a hometown slap in the face to Commissioner Bud Selig?

Crew puts a clever twist on the patchwork plaids, suedes and leathers of last year with its patchwork chinos for men: plain-front classic-cut pants made of small fabric squares from the khaki spectrum. New for spring, the trousers ($68) have been a sellout for the company -- a sly sartorial statement for really casual Fridays (or better yet, just Saturdays). Those who miss out on the current shipment can look for shorts in the same material in June.

Great Performers at Lincoln Center began its festival ''George Frideric Handel: Beyond the 'Messiah' '' with a concert and a symposium yesterday and presents the composer's last oratorio, ''Jephtha,'' this afternoon at Alice Tully Hall. Ren Jacobs, one of the hotter properties on the early-music scene, conducts the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, from London, and the Choir of Clare College, Cambridge. The vocal soloists are Rosemary Joshua, Patricia Bardon, Michael Chance, Richard Croft and Nathan Berg.

title: Through a Bronze, Darkly
description: THE ancient Chinese were probably right to insist that their mirrors were magical. The lustrous, reflective bronze surfaces delivered wondrous illusions that could easily be seen as supernatural. The backs were fascinating, too, awash with circular patterns and reliefs of mythological images that told powerful stories of deities. And the calligraphic maxims on them carried messages of good fortune and happiness for their owners.

Designers of the new Mini Cooper have produced a wall clock; BMW designed cellphones for Nokia, a mountain bike and a skateboard. Now the Italian concern Pininfarina -- the primary designer of Ferrari automobiles for the last 50 years -- has created a product that is for walking, not driving. With the shoe company Fila, Pininfarina designed its first running shoe, introduced in Europe last fall and now available in the United States. The Pininfarina shoe has a woven carbon fiber sole and side panels reminiscent of Adidas basketball shoes ($120 at www.fila.com).

It is one of Pakistan's finest and oldest public schools and boasts a rich history, said Mr. Qurashi, the school's principal, pointing to a plaque commemorating a student who attended in 1915. Nearby, students had gathered under a huge banyan tree, more than a century old.

Bobby Valentine marked that occasion by protesting the game when Cubs Manager Don Baylor made an omission on his lineup card. The opening day location this year, Shea Stadium, may not be so exotic, but Valentine may again ring in the season with a protest. Upset that baseball officials have determined that Satoru Komiyama's windup violates a rule, Valentine said he might protest games when opposing pitchers make a similar violation.

description: IN many ways, ''24'' is one of the most interesting new shows to appear on television in a long time. Formally, it's miles ahead of the competition: the people who created it understand television, and its limits and possibilities, in profound and unusual ways. And as a thriller, this weekly show is consistently gripping. It gets your pulse racing and makes you want to tune in again. But it does so for reasons that have nothing to do with our usual notions of ''interest.''

title: The Tyranny Of Skinny, Fashion's Insider Secret
description: I OWE Rene Zellweger an apology. Over a year ago, as the editor of a fashion magazine, I pulled her picture off the cover of an issue at the last minute, swapping it for a photo of a lanky swan in a whiff of Dior chiffon. The problem wasn't the usual one that kills covers. The lighting was impeccable. Her dress was a glamorous Galliano, and there was a lot of talk about her new movie, ''Bridget Jones's Diary'' and a starring performance that would be hailed with an Oscar nomination. No, the problem was much more primal, born of one of the not-so-secret obsessions of the fashion world: she was too fat.
